title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1986
description: The Shuttle Tragedy The Challenger explosion theories focus on the space shuttle's right-hand booster rocket, according to a source close to the inquiry into the accident. The solid-fuel rocket suddenly lost power 10 seconds before the shuttle exploded, the source said, and officials are inclined to believe that this indicates flame burned through the rocket's side and then through the skin of the external fuel tank. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] President Reagan mourned the loss of ''our seven Challenger heroes'' at a memorial ceremony at Houston's Johnson Space Center. Paying tribute to their ''brave sacrifice,'' Mr. Reagan pledged to honor them with a renewed national commitment to the conquest of space. Thousands of people attended the ceremony, including relatives and friends of the space shuttle's crew. [ 1:3. ] Cameras on the ocean floor were photographing and videotaping a sunken object to determine whether it came from the space shuttle Challenger. The search was made 40 miles east of Daytona Beach, in the same area where the Coast Guard Thursday found five large floating pieces of the shuttle. One fragment was a clearly identifiable section of the right side of the fuselage, adjacent to the crew compartment. [ 10:1. ] International A state of siege in Haiti was declared by President Jean-Claude Duvalier, who went on national radio to refute widespread rumors - and an erroneous White House report - that his 15-year-old Government had fallen and that he had fled the country. The erroneous information that the 34-year-old President had fled followed a week of tumultuous anti-Government demonstrations.

title: Calling All Conservatives
description: Radio America, the fledgling Washington-based radio network that supplies 170 local stations around the country with rock-ribbed cassette messages from such conservative spokesmen as Jack F. title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 51. 1. This unexpected side effect of a corruption scandal is piling up. Identify it and explain. 2. Two pieces of evidence were deliberately destroyed that might have helped solve the puzzle of why the space shuttle Challenger exploded. What were they and what was the reason for the action? 3. ''I am sailing out along parallel 32.5,'' said a national leader. Who is he and what were the circumstances? 4. Two point records were set in the Chicago Bears' Super Bowl victory over the New England Patriots. What were they? 5. Forty years after its introduction as a stopgap in World War II, a material that was once equated with flimsy products is winning a reputation for durability and quality. What material is it? 6. Two rebel leaders were in the news: Jonas Savimbi, who met in the United States with top officials of the Reagan Administration, and Yoweri Museveni, who was sworn in as President of his nation. What countries are they from? 7. At a time when Republicans are challenging Democrats nationally as the majority party for the first time since the Depression, a state that has for many years been one of the most heavily Republican states in the country has been moving leftward. What state is it and what is the reason for the political shift? 8. Mayor Koch asserted that the Bronx Democratic leader, Stanley M. Friedman, had exercised a virtual veto power in the City Council over legislation affecting an industry he represents as a lawyer and registered lobbyist.

title: A CAT'S GOT TONGUES WAGGING IN SMALL-TOWN LIBRARY DISPUTE
description: Fred was snoozing atop a library desk - exhausted, perhaps, from prowling about the stacks.

title: Preview of a Tower
description: Construction workers in hard hats directed visitors. Uniformed employees frantically dusted tables. Elevator workers struggled with sticky doors.

title: U.N. Aide Denies Charge On Ethiopia Deaths
description: A United Nations official has denied allegations that tens of thousands of famine victims have died because of Ethiopian efforts to resettle them.

title:
PATENTS;
Simpler Computer Keyboard
description: A COMPUTER keyboard that can reduce the number of keys from many to a dozen was patented this week by the founder of a New Orleans company. One version now on the market cuts 35 keys to 16, and is useful for hand-held computers.

title: REDMEN'S ROWAN GETS HIS SHOTS AT LAST
description: When St. John's began playing its Big East Conference schedule last month, about the only thing most observers agreed on was that the Redmen would only go as far as Walter Berry, the 6-foot-8-inch junior center, could pull them.

title: HOME GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $4 million for the quarter and $20 million for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $17 million. Results for the latest year reflect nonrecurring pretax charges to income of an extraordinary addition to insurance loss reserves of $170 million, establishment of a reserve, aggregating $40 million, against reinsurance recoverable, a provision of $22 million for restructuring and cost reduction programs and a $23 million writedown of certain unconsolidated operations, principally a wholly- owned claims service subsidiary.

title: Mud Stalls Ship's Overhaul
description: A World War II battleship was to get a new lease on life today, but instead remained literally stuck in the mud.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. More than 315,000 unprocessed parking tickets have piled up in the New York City Parking Violations Bureau because when the city canceled its contract with Citisource Inc., the company that was reportedly developing a hand-held device to issue summonses, it also lost the services of the subcontractor key-punching the daily flow of summonses for the bureau's computers. 2. Officers at Cape Canaveral destroyed the shuttle's two solid-fuel booster rockets by remote control after the explosion because they were flying wildly, threatening to strike populated areas. 3. Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya sailed into the Gulf of Sidra in a symbolic confrontation with United States air and naval forces that were holding maneuvers inside the limit of 32.5 degrees north latitude that Libya says defines her waters. 4. title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $21,867,000 for the quarter and $21,464,000 for the year. Year-ago results include a net insurance gain of $26,815,000, or 73 cents a share, for the quarter and the year on a drilling barge and a charge of $5,180,000 for the quarter and the year related to retirement of three drilling barges.

title: RIGHTS UNIT INVESTIGATES SEARCH AT A SOCIAL CLUB
description: The State Division of Human Rights is investigating a complaint by an Italian-American group in Greenwich Village that a task force on organized crime, in search of a murder suspect, raided the club with a sledgehammer last week and intimidated an elderly member at gunpoint.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about New York State's tax amnesty program misstated its expiration date. Amnesty expired last midnight.

title: NAVY ATTEMPS TO SHOW OFFICER'S KILLER SHOULD BE EXECUTED
description: An officer of the Navy frigate Miller testified today that a lieutenant murdered at sea was crucial to the ship's operations, a factor vital to the Navy's attempt to impose a death sentence on his killer.

title: Suit Against Red Sox
description: Tommy Harper, a former player and coach, has charged that the Boston Red Sox dismissed him as a minor league coach last Dec. 18 for speaking out last spring against the team's practice of awarding passes to white players, coaches and reporters to an Elks Club in Winter Haven, Fla., during spring training. ''After practices and games they go to a segregated place where I can't go and they call me 'teammate,' '' Harper said after filing the charges with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunities Commission.

title: WARNACO INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 38
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1.2 million of expenses relating to a proposed merger announced by the company Oct. 31, 1985. c-Including the results of Olga Co. from the time of its acquisition on June 4, 1984.

title: BRIDGE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $176,000 for the quarter and $239,000 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,047,000.

title: Italian Experts Report Bullet In the Head Killed Klinghoffer
description: Italian medical and ballistic experts confirmed today that Leon Klinghoffer, the American slain in the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, was shot twice before his body was thrown into the Mediterranean.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE PRESIDENT'S EULOGY FOR THE SEVEN CHALLENGER ASTRONAUTS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's eulogy at a memorial service for the seven Challenger astronauts at the Johnson Space Center in Houston yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $6.2 million for the quarter and the year on the sale of stock. c-Including a gain of $11.3 million from the sale of television stations.

title: Lecture at Y by Villella Opens Series on Dance
description: ''Great Dancers, Great Choreographers'' is the name of a series of four Sunday evening lectures starting this weekend at the 92d Street Y. The opening talk is by Edward Villella, who is currently serving as director of the Oklahoma Ballet and as artistic adviser of the New Jersey Ballet. He is also a former principal dancer for the New York City Ballet.

title: THEATER: WILSON'S 'MOUND BUILDERS'
description: The characters in Lanford Wilson's ''Mound Builders'' are on an archeological dig in Illinois, unearthing an Indian burial ground. Audiences who visit the Circle Repertory Company's new and revised revival of Mr. Wilson's 1975 play had better plan on doing some hard digging themselves. There are some fragments of interest in ''The Mound Builders,'' but they are buried beneath mounds, if not mountains, of talk.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Tuesday of Rose Sobell, who fought to reverse the 1951 conviction of her son, Morton, for conspiracy to commit espionage, described her incorrectly. She was a housewife; Mr. Sobell's former wife was a physicist.

title: Honduran Military Chief Decides Not to Resign
description: The Honduran armed forces commander, Gen. Walter Lopez Reyes, decided today to retain his post.

title: BURNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1.4 million, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of surplus real estate for the quarter and year. The year result is after a loss of $4 million, or 33 cents per share, resulting from provision for employee terminations and restructuring of operations principalli in France. c-Net income.

title: BI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BAN ON ALCOHOL WEIGHED
description: Concerned about reports of fan rowdiness and drunkenness, Giants Stadium officials are looking at the possibility of banning alcohol during professional football games, the executive director of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said today.

title: Commodore Given Extension on Loans
description: Commodore International Ltd., the struggling home-computer maker, said today that its major lenders had given it additional time to renegotiate loan agreements for which it was already in technical default.

title: SALEM NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Power Plant Blast Hurts 15
description: A steam line ruptured and exploded Thursday, injuring 15 people, at the Detroit Edison Company's Monroe Power Plant on Lake Erie about 40 miles south of Detroit. Six people remained hospitalized today and were reported to be in good condition.

title: DETAILS ARE GIVEN ON SPYING CHARGE
description: The Air Force has acknowledged for the first time that an airman arrested last week is accused of trying to provide the Soviet Union with classified information on a highly secret spy plane.

title: ELECTROSPACE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 25 percent stock split paid Sept. 24, 1985.

title: R J FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Gas Reserves Off China
description: Preliminary estimates indicate that a natural gas field in the South China Sea being developed by China and the Atlantic Richfield Company has reserves of about 3.15 billion cubic feet, a news report said today. The official Communist Party newspaper People's Daily said $312 million would be invested in developing the field, which is 60 miles south of Sanya City on Hainan Island.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1986
description: International

title: ART: 'MEMPHIS/MILANO'
description: Acid colors, oblique angles, bizarre cartoon shapes, busy and dense graphic surface patterns typify the furniture, ceramics and design drawings in ''Memphis/Milano,'' an exhibition that opened Tuesday at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum (through April 13). The Memphis movement exploded on the international design scene at the 1981 Milan Furniture Fair. The strategy of Memphis designers was to challenge Modernist conventions of good taste - coherent lines, sensible shapes, clear function.

title: GERMAN ACCENT IN MEN'S WEAR
description: For years, Germany's fashion industry seemed content to supply the kraut and sausage of European men's wear. Just basic fare, never mind the haute cuisine.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,355,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $13,805,000. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,645,000 and an extraordinary gain of $7,278,000. Results for the latest period reflect the company's acquisition of Permian Corp.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AS THEY WERE There is an unusual anniversary exhibition, rich in Americana, that opens today at the ACA Galleries, 21 East 67th Street (628-2440). ''Commemorative Exhibition of the 50th Anniversary of the American Artists' Congress (1936-1942)'' consists of work by 70 of the artists who were among the 400 signers of the call to organize the group that announced its aims as a fight against poverty, oppression and fascism.

title: U.S., CANADA PAPER MAKERS AT ODDS OVER TRADE
description: Canada's pulp and paper industry generates 150,000 jobs and more than $7 billion (Canadian) in exports to the United States. Small wonder that it looms as a major issue in impending free-trade negotiations between the two nations.

title: PRESIDENT REPORTED READY TO PROPOSE OVERHAUL OF SOCIAL WELFARE SYSTEM
description: President Reagan plans to call for a comprehensive revision of the nation's social welfare system, White House officials said today.

title: Kentucky Official and 6 Not Guilty of Theft
description: A jury today found the Kentucky State Treasurer and six co-defendants not guilty of all theft charges relating to her 1983 campaign.

title: 'German Requiem'
description: Brahms's own arrangement of his ''German Requiem'' for two pianos, soprano, baritone and chorus will be performed tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street. The pianists will be Myron McPherson and Bruce Brubaker; Wendy Hill and Kurt Ollmann will be the vocal soloists, and Dennis Keene will conduct the Ascension Choir. Admission is by contribution; information: 254-8620.

description: The prospectus for a magazine starts out with engaging immodesty: ''This may be the most exciting, provocative, entertaining and important magazine to ever hit the newsstands.''

description: The company went public on September 16.

title: 470 BETTING PLACES RAIDED IN MOVE AGAINST SYNDICATE
description: More than 2,200 city police officers and Federal agents swept down on hundreds of illegal betting parlors across the city yesterday in a raid the police said was aimed at crippling an organized-crime syndicate run by Cubans.

title: SAVINGS ON GENERIC DRUGS REPORTED
description: Consumers who bought prescription drugs in 1984 saved $130 million to $236 million under recent laws that permit pharmacists to substitute unbranded, or generic, drugs under their common names in place of brands, according to a Federal Trade Commission study.

title: Travels With Kennedy
description: It is not unusual for members of Congress to visit the Soviet Union, but seldom do they have much opportunity to establish a cult of personality.

title: Korean Car Priced
description: Hyundai, The South Korean car maker, joined the battle for the bargain basement end of the American car market today by announcing that it will sell a car for $4,995.

title: JOHN NUVEEN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAMERAS USED BY SEARCHERS TO LOOK AT SUNKEN OBJECT
description: Search teams sent remote-controlled cameras to the ocean floor today to determine whether an unidentified sunken object discovered by the Coast Guard is a large piece of wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger.

title: The Marcos File
description: Within hours after disclosures that the Army had years ago rejected as ''absurd'' claims by Ferdinand E. Marcos that he had led a resistance unit against the Japanese occupation forces in the Philippines, representatives of the Philippine Embassy swept into the National Archives building to get copies of the documents detailing the Army's findings. Mr. Marcos, now President of the Philippines, says the disclosures are an effort to discredit him in his current re-election campaign. The Philippine Embassy representatives picked up copies of all 339 pages of the files on Mr. Marcos, presumably for transmission to him. The archives documents, which had lain out of public sight for 35 years, are available to anyone upon request at 35 cents a page.

The year ago results have been restated to reflect year-end audit adjustments.

title: McDonnell Douglas Edges Up 3.4%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation yesterday reported a 3.4 percent rise in earnings in the fourth quarter of 1985 on a 17.9 percent increase in sales.

IOWA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: KENTUCKY DEFEATS AUBURN BY 81-71
description: Kenny Walker scored 24 points tonight to lead Kentucky to a 81-71 Southeastern Conference victory over Auburn at Rupp Arena.

title: REAGAN PAYS TRIBUTE TO 'OUR CHALLENGER HEROES'
description: President Reagan mourned the loss of ''our seven Challenger heroes'' today, paying tribute to their ''brave sacrifice'' and pledging to honor them with a renewed national commitment to the conquest of space.

title: FOR A UNIFIED SERVICE ACADEMY
description: The United States needs a joint military service academy to complement West Point, Annapolis and the Air Force Academy. Its purpose would be to provide an alternative source of officers.

title: BMW Has Gain; Revamping Is Set
description: BMW, the West German luxury car maker, announced healthy results for 1985 and disclosed plans to start giving each of its model series a new look starting later this year. Eberhard von Kuenheim, managing board chairman, said worldwide revenues provisionally rose just under 10 percent last year to a record $7.6 billion on a small 1.5 percent rise in car sales, to 440,732.

title: Army Colonel Commits Suicide
description: The former director of a weapons development laboratory at the Army's Picatinny Arsenal committed suicide here Wednesday, two weeks after resigning his command amid an inquiry into purported improprieties involving travel, officials said today.

title: NAUGLES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 9
description: b-Net income.

title: FINGER-POINTING OVER HAITI ERROR
description: An erroneous announcement today by the chief White House spokesman that the Government of Haiti had collapsed led to a day of confusion and conflict between the White House and the State Department.

title: Cornell Trustees Reject Divestiture
description: The trustees of Cornell University voted yesterday, 33 to 7, against immediate, total divestiture of the institution's holdings in companies doing business in South Africa.

title:
PATENTS;

description: Compounds for use in blocking a form of shock that is characterized by an inadequate supply of blood have been patented by K. C. Nicolaou, a chemistry professor at the University of Pennsylvania, and two former graduate students, Nicos A. Petasis and Steven P. Seitz.

title: Oil Prices Off Sharply
description: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products fell rather sharply yesterday in advance of an OPEC meeting on Monday.

title: A South Korean Envoy Is Kidnapped in Beirut
description: A South Korean diplomat was kidnapped at gunpoint today as he drove to his country's embassy in predominantly Moslem West Beirut, a Lebanese Army official said.

title: CITY'S INVESTIGATION UNIT FACES INHERENT CONFLICT
description: From perhaps its first roots more than a century ago, the city's Department of Investigation has had to grapple with an inherent conflict at the crossroads of government and politics.

description: Billy Olson suffered his first major defeat of the indoor season tonight when he failed on all three pole-vault attempts at 18 feet 8 inches at The Toronto Star Indoor Games. Waldyslaw Kozakiewicz of Poland won the event at 18-8 1/2.

description: After a break for the memorial service today, the space agency's interim board of inquiry resumed its quest here for clues to the cause of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: MEXICO TRIMS PRICE OF ITS CRUDE
description: Mexico, as expected, lowered its price of crude oil an average of $4 a barrel today, a move that will cost it an estimated $2 billion in revenues this year.

title: PLASTIC IS A BUBBLE KILLER
description: Glass soft-drink bottles may become as scarce as bottle openers and as obsolete as bottle stoppers if the present trend continues. So scarce in fact, that in our family we have started a small collection of the quart (or thereabouts) size.

title: CONTRIBUTORS FOR NEEDIEST CITE TRADITION
description: Among the many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are those who began contributing decades ago as children and have continued the tradition of giving in hopes of helping the homeless, the ill and the despairing.

description: Harrison A. Williams Jr., the former United States Senator who was the highest-ranking official to be convicted in the F.B.I.'s Abscam bribery-conspiracy investigation, was released from a halfway house today after serving two-thirds of his three-year prison term.

description: The birth of a child confronts a parent with a range of unexpected experiences, but I never imagined they would include overhearing a conversation between the obstetrician and the standby anesthesiologist about investment strategy.

title: PENNY ANTE LIVES
description: TIME SHARING. By Richard Krawiec. 184 pages. Viking. $14.95. They sound, at first, like characters in a country-western song, or maybe a late-night, grade-B movie: Artie, a shifty-eyed, two-bit hustler, who hangs out at cheap beer joints and strip parlors, desultorily hoping something will come along to change his luck - someone used to having to scramble and lie and cheat in order to get by. And Jolene, a big, strapping woman, who's determined to do anything to give her baby a second chance at life - a tough, lonely woman, who's had her share of men, but who's never been in love.

title: PONTIFF BEGINS HIS 10-DAY VISIT TO INDIA
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here this morning for a 10-day visit to India that has aroused protests from Hindu fundamentalists, despite the Pope's insistence that he is intent on preaching tolerance and harmony.

title: CELTICS WIN 10TH IN ROW, 97-88
description: Scott Wedman, starting for the injured Kevin McHale, scored 24 points as the Boston Celtics defeated the Washington Bullets, 97-88, tonight and extended their winning streak to 10 in a row, the longest in the National Basketball Association this season.

title: Pennsylvania's Nurses End 9-Day Walkout
description: Nurses returned to work today after reaching a tentative agreement to end a nine-day strike against 140 state-run hospitals, health clinics and prisons.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income of $962,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $168,000 in the quarter and $516,000 in the year, as well as a charge of $2,185,000 for the writeoff of the company's investment in New England Tube & Machine Co. and a provision for other costs. c-Including a tax credit of $261,000 in the quarter and $628,000 in the year.

title: ERIE LACKAWANNA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sniper, 16, Gets 8-Year Term
description: A teen-ager who fired a rifle at cars on Interstate 95 last summer because, according to Assistant State Attorney Laura Starrett, he had ''bored of shooting at birds and squirrels'' has been sentenced to eight years in a prison program for young offenders, the authorities said today. The teen-ager, 16-year-old Julius Davis, was also ordered to pay $1,200 in restitution to 13 people whose cars were fired at last June. Six people were hurt, none seriously.

title: CLINI-THERM CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CONVERGENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring credit of $1.7 million from a reduction in facilities obligations by reason of certain sub-leases and early lease terminations. c-Net loss including a gain from discontinued opeartations of $154,000 for the quarter, after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,390,000 for the year, and after losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,659,000 for the quarter, $11,124,000 for the year.

title: CARRYING ON
description: What does the loss of an all-American mean to a basketball program? Nothing much this year, judging by the records of the six schools that placed players on last season's consensus team, as compiled by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: BLACK HILLS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a previously declared 100 PC stock dividend payable March 1.

title: No Tours in Battle Creek
description: The Kellogg Company said Thursday it would halt plant tours on April 11 to protect new high-technology cereal-making processes. ''This is an extremely competitive marketplace in which we do business,'' said Dick Lovell, a Kellogg spokesman. More than six million people have toured the plant since the company was founded in 1906.

title: LTV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $7 million for the quarter and $47.6 million for the year on the exchange of debt and the early extinguishment of debt. Results for the latest year reflect a charge of $380 million for the year for the indefinite idling of steel operations at the Aliquippa Works in May 1985.

title: Welfare Official Stabbed by Client
description: A welfare office administrator was stabbed and five others were injured this morning during an attack at the city's welfare office by a knife-wielding 30-year-old welfare recipient, the police said.

title: FOR HAITIANS, DREAM IS TAKEN AWAY
description: First thing yesterday morning, Gerard Joseph heard the giddy news on the radio of his taxicab, lighted the off-duty sign and headed for a Creole restaurant on Tenth Avenue to celebrate the fall of President Jean-Claude Duvalier.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,760,000 from the sale of a bakery.

title: FRENCH ARREST EX-SERVICEMAN ON SPY CHARGE
description: A retired member of the French Air Force has been arrested and charged with spying for the Soviet Union, the Interior Ministry announced today.

title: RANGERS LOSE TO SABRES, 5-3
description: Pierre Larouche, a castoff a little more than a week ago, tonight became the Rangers' first-string center. Mark Pavelich, the Rangers' best player for the last two seasons, was demoted to second-line status. And Ron Greschner, a defenseman-turned center, was moved to left wing. As the Rangers continue to have their difficulties, their world becomes more confusing.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PATTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $142,400,000 for the quarter and $163,500,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $132,700,000 for the quarter and $150,600,000 for the year. The latest quarter and year results reflect a charge of $120 million to writedown two non-utility businesses.

title: HELPED END BERLIN BLOCKADE
description: Philip C. Jessup, an American authority on international law who was credited with a key role in ending the Soviet blockade of West Berlin, died yesterday at his winter home in Newtown, Pa. He was 89 years old.

title: Red Liberty Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: Golden Meanness of the Greedy Unmasked
description: To the Editor:

title: IGNORED BY TELEVISION, AQUINO REINVENTS PRE-VIDEO POLITICS
description: On official television, Corazon C. Aquino's presidential campaign goes virtually unnoticed, which only made it all the more remarkable this morning when she was mobbed by tens of thousands of people in this verdant outpost of rice and coconut farms.

title: CENTRUST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $18,506,000. c-Including a gain of $1,389,000 from Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation preferred stock dividend.

title: MPSI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CABARET: CULTURAL EXERCISES
description: Wednesday was pastiche night at the Kitchen, with a double bill of cheerfully cross-cultural performers.

title: CCX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $222,000 for the quarter and $365,000 for the year. c-Net income, after an extraordinary charge of $14,000 for the quarter and including an extraordinary gain of $228,000 for the year.

title: HON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DENIES HIS OUSTER
description: President Jean-Claude Duvalier declared a state of siege today and went on national radio to refute widespread rumors, and an erroneous White House report, that his 15-year-old Government had fallen and that he had fled the country.

title: PRESIDENT'S LETTER TO CONCORD HIGH SCHOOL
description: Following is the text of a letter from President Reagan to the faculty and students of Concord High School, where Christa McAuliffe taught:

title: MIDLAND-ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $50,055,000 for the quarter and $56,095,000 for the year.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST WYOMING BANCORPORATIONN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE 55 M.P.H. SPEED LIMIT NO LONGER MAKES SENSE
description: It's about 8 A.M. on a crisp winter Sunday and we're heading north on the New York Thruway, about 70 miles from New York City. We're almost alone. The few cars in sight are strung out at intervals of about a quarter mile, and we're all moving at 80 to 85 miles an hour.

title: U.S. Needs a New Commitment to World Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Augustus Thorndike, 89, Sports Medicine Specialist
description: Dr. Augustus Thorndike, chief of surgery at Harvard University Health Services from 1931 to 1962 and a specialist in sports medicine, died Wednesday. He was 89 years old.

title: MARCOS SAYS PROTEST OF VOTE RESULTS IS LIKELY
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said in an interview Friday that he expected that whoever loses the presidential election next week would challenge the results.

title: Calling All Hot Dogs
description: Galvanized by the disclosure that Washington's Omni Shoreham Hotel had neglected to include hot dogs on its opening menu for a monthlong salute to the Empire State called ''I Love New York,'' the Big Apple's best-known purveyor of the quintessential New York knosh promptly shipped down to the capital a supply of franks, along with a cookbook with 150 (!) recipes for preparing them.

title: THE OPPOSITION IN HAITI: BROAD BUT NOT ORGANIZED
description: Opposition to the Duvalier Government, which has long been stifled and has been diluted by years of heavy migration, has become widespread in Haitian society in recent months, in the view of authorities on that Caribbean nation.

title: ELISABETH WELCH EARNS NEW SUCCESS AT HOME
description: In the early 1930's, Elisabeth Welch, who as a child sang in the choir at an Episcopal church in the San Juan Hill neighborhood a couple of octaves away from what is now Lincoln Center, emigrated to Paris and went on to England, where radio brought her voice to millions.

title: U.S. AGENT SEIZES DOCUMENTS AT QUEENS DEMOCRATIC OFFICE
description: A Federal agent yesterday seized financial records from the Democratic Party headquarters in Queens, searching for information relating to Federal investigations involving Borough President Donald R. Manes.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: Results for the latest year include a net gain of $527,000 on the sale of assets. Results are for 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and for 14 and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WEIRTON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANYBODY'S BETTER THAN DUVALIER
description: Not only Haitian exiles had reason for joy yesterday when the White House erroneously announced the flight of Haiti's dictator. Let us hope that an unspoken wish inspired its spokesman's confusion. After 29 years of brutal repression, Haitians have taken to the streets to vent their protest against the Duvalier dynasty's misrule.

title: POREX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WOMAN WHO LIVED WITH AN ARTIFICIAL HEART FOR 45 DAYS RECEIVES A HOMAN ORGAN
description: Mary Lund, the first woman to receive an artificial heart, was given the heart of a 14-year-old girl today to replace the mechanical pump that has kept her alive for 45 days, the hospital authorities said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday, with an article about fourth-quarter earnings in the banking industry, carried an incorrect figure provided by the Continental Illinois Corporation for the company's leverage. The leverage was 8.12 percent.

title: Cable TV
description: Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review of the film ''Heimat'' when it was screened in April 1985, during the New Directors/New Films Festival at the Museum of Modern Art. It will be broadcast for the first time on cable on Bravo in eight parts beginning Sunday at 8 P.M. and at 1:30 A.M., with an additional rebroadcast of Part I on Feb. 11. Part II will be shown Feb. 9 and 18; Part III on Feb. 16 and 25; Part IV on Feb. 23 and March 4. The remaining four parts are scheduled in March.

title: Robin Jennifer Roy Engaged to Dr. Michael Katz
description: Robin Jennifer Roy, coordinator of editorial and marketing communications services at the Presbyterian Hospital, and Dr. Michael Katz, the Reuben S. Carpentier Professor and chairman of the department of pediatrics and professor of tropical medicine at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, plan to be married in July.

title: HOBOKEN ORCHESTRA OFFERING DOUBLE BILL
description: THE Hoboken Chamber Orchestra, under Gary M. Schneider, will perform a double bill of 20th-century dance classics Thursday night at the Demarest School, Fourth and Bloomfield Streets.

title: Searle Settles It: No More IUD's in U.S.
description: In the 1960's, millions of American women started using intrauterine devices, which were heralded as a better method of contraception than birth control pills. That era effectively ended last week when G. D. Searle & Company, citing ''unwarranted product litigation'' and the difficulty of obtaining insurance, said it would stop selling IUD's in the United States.

title: A CASE FOR MAKING FEBRUARY THE MONTH OF MONTHS
description: WHAT is your favorite month? Most people I know opt for either October or April, and who doesn't rejoice in their heady colors and scents? And the dubious distinction of everyone's least-favorite month would surely be won by that calendar stepchild, February.

title: WASHINGTON SENDS A WIGH LIST TO THE PHILIPPINES
description: PRESIDENT Reagan has made clear Washington's worries about the future of the Philippines. Admonishing this ''major friend and ally'' to insure that Friday's elections are ''credible'' to Filipinos, he stamped the Presidential imprimatur on the United States observer delegation to be headed by Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: REMEMBERING A MAINSTAY OF BRONX HOUSE
description: BEN HOWIE is dead. He had worked at Bronx House for more than 25 years. He died on his office floor of a cerebral hemorrhage. Not his body. That died three days later attached to a respirator at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx.

title: ZOELLER LEADS BY 3 AMID RULES DISPUTE
description: A dispute over golf rules of play caused something of a distraction today from what was shaping up as a possible confrontation between two recent and popular United States Open champions - Fuzzy Zoeller and Tom Watson - at the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

title: HOTEL AT KENNEDY
description: Construction has begun on the first new hotel to be built at John F. Kennedy International Airport in 15 years. It will be a Holiday Inn, and when it is completed the number of hotels clustered in and around the airport on Jamaica Bay in the southeastern corner of Queens will rise to seven, according to officials of the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau.

title: A Prep School in Connecticut Expels 10 Students for Drugs
description: Ten students at the Westminster School in Simsbury have been expelled for what the headmaster called ''an association with drugs.''

title: MUSICAL TO HOLD AUDITIONS AT EMELIN
description: TWELVE-YEAR-OLD Kelly lives in New Rochelle with her divorced father. Her dream is to be a star of stage, screen and television. By the time she turns 14, she has fulfilled that dream - although not without paying some emotional dues.

title: THE PHILIPPINE MIDDLE CLASS: TURNING AGAINST MARCOS
description: BY PHILIPPINE STANDARDS, BING ROXAS and her family have done well for themselves. With her husband Sixto, an investment banker from whom she is now separated, Bing has raised six children, and the family has enjoyed relative financial success, together with the satisfaction of being involved in the mainstream of Philippine society. Bing, who is 58 years old, has been chairman of several cultural and civic organizations, and she and her husband were at one time frequent guests of President and Mrs. Ferdinand Marcos at Malacanang Palace. Like so many members of the Philippine establishment, Bing also has strong ties to the United States: she was educated at Barnard College in New York, and her ideas and manner of speech seem almost those of a native American.

title: EDITOR ENLISTS LAWYERS FOR RELIEF OF FAMINE
description: Last summer, as he was watching the Live Aid benefit concert for African famine relief on television, Steven Brill had an idea.

title: WHY LONG MARRIAGES FAIL: YOUTH WORSHIP A FACTOR
description: ''When Long Marriages Fall Apart'' [ Jan. 5 ] was terrific as far as it went, and I challenge Sylvia Millenky to take it even further. She asked if there is a Solomon among us with answers.

title: POLL FINDS CHILDREN REMAIN ENTHUSIASTIC ON SPACE FLIGHT
description: American children, although pained by the space shuttle explosion that killed a teacher who reminded them of one of their own, seem resiliently enthusiastic about the space program, according to a New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: Q AND A
description: RENTING A VACANT UNIT Question: I bought an apartment house with a vacant unit that had been occupied by the previous owner since 1965. How do I establish rent for this unit? . . . M.J., Manhattan Answer: You can set a market rent and the new tenant will have no right to appeal the rent, according to Thomas Viola, assistant commissioner in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

title: MYTH OF SOCIAL SECURITY AND THE DEFICIT REVISITED
description: To the Editor:

title: LAUTENBERG STUDYING G.E.-- RCA MERGER
description: WHILE Senator Frank R. Lautenberg was in Sweden last month studying remedies to problems of radon gas emanation, his staff in Washington was scheduling his next project: a fight against possible economic repercussions in the wake of the pending RCA Corporation-General Electric Company merger.

title: LIBYA SANCTIONS GO INTO EFFECT AMID UNCERTAINTY
description: The economic sanctions ordered by President Reagan against Libya formally went into full effect today, with American oil companies and oil-related businesses still uncertain about how the United States plans to carry them out.

title: DANCE: MANUEL ALUM AND COMPANY
description: RELIGIOUS institutions and personalities have provided the subject matter for a number of interesting modern dances. And there were faint allusions to Martha Graham's ''Appalachian Spring'' and Doris Humphrey's ''Shakers'' in ''Secret Services,'' a piece performed by Manuel Alum and Dancers on Friday at St. Mark's Church.

title: TURKEY'S RESTING PLACE OF STONE GODS
description: The immense mountaintop burial mound of King Antiochus, with its array of gigantic marble heads severed from their stone bodies, is one of the great sights of eastern Turkey. From the remembrances of the Hittites in central Anatolia to Mount Ararat in the distant east - whose heights American fundamentalists continue to scale in search of Noah's Ark, persuaded that there it ended its voyage - eastern Turkey is one of the world's most historically and culturally fascinating regions.

title: BOSS AS DOCTOR: REPLIES
description: The article ''When the Boss Becomes Your Doctor'' (Jan. 5) -which described the increasing participation of companies in health care decisions through tighter management of health insurance programs -elicited an unusual number of responses. What follows is a sampling.

title: Pennsylvania Town Awaits Groundhog Day
description: Punxsutawney Phil, napping inside his burrow on Gobbler's Knob, is oblivious to it all, but this town of 7,800 people is about to go groundhog-wild.

title: FOLK ART -- REAL AND ARTIFICIAL
description: THE outputs of William Edmondson and David Butler have nothing in common other than that both belong to the folk genre.

title: THESE LOUDSPEAKERS SET THEIR SIGHTS ON MUSICALITY
description: The chitchat of audiophiles is obscure enough when they indulge in technical talk, but it gets worse when they appropriate the common language. A case in point is the frequent prattle about ''musical'' components.

title: BOSS AS DOCTOR: REPLIES
description: The article ''When the Boss Becomes Your Doctor'' (Jan. 5) -which described the increasing participation of companies in health care decisions through tighter management of health insurance programs -elicited an unusual number of responses. What follows is a sampling.

title: HOUSING DEMAND SOARS IN RTE. 1 CORRIDOR
description: THE demand for new housing is great throughout much of New Jersey, but in few places is it as pressing as along the Route 1 corridor extending both north and south from the Princeton area.

title: POP: HARRY DE WIT, ONE-MAN BAND
description: HARRY de WIT, a composer and performance artist from Amsterdam, made an eerie racket Friday at the Kitchen. Mr. de Wit presented himself as an instrument builder, one-man band and mad scientist. He builds devices that make tiny sounds gigantic and, as a sideline, exploit acoustical phenomena; they also make quite a show.

title: SCOTTISH HIKE, TEX-MEX EXPRESS
description: Baronial Base For Birders in The Highlands In the remote northern Highlands of Scotland, where wilderness abounds, stands a wood-paneled Edwardian sporting lodge.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''While we may not have turned the corner on the trade deficit, we have at least reached the corner.''

title:
NATURE WATCH;
LAPLAND LONGSPUR
description: Calcarius lapponicus Size: Six to seven inches.

title: FLYERS AND NORDIQUES TIE, 2-2
description: Brent Ashton and John Anderson scored 2 minutes 9 seconds apart midway in the third period tonight to give the Quebec Nordiques a 2-2 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: PRESSURE RISES ON COLLEGES TO WITHDRAW SOUTH AFRICA INTERESTS
description: Buoyed by the success of protests last spring against South Africa's policy of racial separation, students at colleges and universities around the nation have increased pressure on their schools to divest themselves of holdings in companies that do business in that country.

title: MUST AMTRAK BE SCRAP FOR THE PENTAGON'S MILL?
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST END WORKS TRAVEL WELL
description: DRAWING on the vast pool of notable artistic talent in residence on the Island's South Fork, the Arbitrage Gallery in Manhattan's SoHo section last fall assembled a group show featuring 14 of the region's painters and sculptors. The exhibition has now moved to the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island, where ''Hampton Artists Visit Hempstead'' will be on view through March 16.

title: Summer Wedding For Maggie Joyce
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Flint Joyce of Pacific Palisades, Calif., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Joyce's daughter, Marie-Louise Maguire Joyce, to Richard Jeffrey Bailly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Louis Bailly of Boxford, Mass.

title: ANOTHER TRY AT CLARITY
description: The House of Representatives is still grappling with making the Congressional Record reflect more accurately in its typography what has really happened in the chamber. Speeches by members that were never delivered but simply handed to a clerk were formerly printed in the Record in a way that left many readers believing the words had actually been spoken in Congress.

title: INDIAN RULER'S LEGACY ON VIEW IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Akbar the Great, the most illustrious of India's 16th-century Mogul rulers, may well rank with Emperor Augustus of Rome as an empire builder. Like Augustus, he reigned for half a century, more or less; and when he died he left behind a vast, stable realm at its zenith of might and stability, perhaps the greatest world power of its day.

title: FROM GASCONY, CAVIAR AND COD
description: Alain Dutournier, one of Paris's most talented and ambitious chefs, has realized his dream. For years, the 36-year-old owner of the Michelin two-star Au Trou Gascon has searched for a larger, more centrally located site in which to practice his inventive cuisine.

title: A Big-Ticket Fine For Cartier
description: The scheme may not have been top-drawer, but it did prove expensive. When Cartier Inc. pleaded guilty last week to falsifying records so that customers could use out-of-state addresses to evade city and state sales taxes, the internationally known jewelry store was ordered to pay $2.2 million in taxes, interest, fines and penalties.

title: 'SAMSON' - AN ORATORIO WITH OPERATIC LEANINGS
description: The Metropolitan Opera will raise its curtain tomorrow night on the English oratorio ''Samson.'' It is the second Handel work ever presented there, and the greatest possible contrast with the first is to be expected.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EXECUTIVE SECURITY
description: CRIME, from kidnappings in South America to terrorist attacks in Europe to muggings in the United States, has sparked a new demand among executives for the products and skills that they hope will protect them from assault.

title: Social Events; Out of the Ordinary
description: Party in Harlem Feb. 5 - A landmark Harlem restaurant, Sylvia's at 328 Lenox Avenue, near 126th Street, will be the setting for an evening that includes entertainment and a menu of ribs, chicken wings, sweet potatoes, black-eyed peas and collard greens. The black-tie event, starting at 7:30 P.M., is for the Citymeals-on-Wheels program, which provides food for thousands of shut-ins. Tickets, $150 or $300 if guests want to sit at a table with the food writer Gael Greene, from 212-577-7324. For New York's Police Feb. 6 - Police Headquarters at the Manhattan approach to the Brooklyn Bridge will undergo a transformation for a black-tie dinner-dance to benefit the New York City Police Foundation. The foundation is celebrating its 15th year of aiding the police by buying bulletproof vests, providing fitness centers for officers and supporting the mounted unit and bomb squad. Tickets for the event, which starts with cocktails at 7 P.M., $250, from 212-751-8170. Pan Asian Evening Feb. 7 - There will be cocktails at 6 P.M., followed by a 10-course Chinese banquet and then a showing of ''The Return of the Phoenix,'' a one-hour movie adaptation of an ancient Chinese drama and one of the most acclaimed presentations of the Pan Asian Repertory Theater. The evening at the Silver Palace Restaurant, 52 Bowery, near Canal Street, marks the ninth year of the theater group, which promotes Asian and Asian-American works and artists. Tickets, $45, from 212-505-5655. In Philadelphia Feb. 8 - The Bal Masque-Mardi Gras Celebration is a benefit for the Philadelphia chapter of Alliance Francaise, which promotes French-American ties.

title: TAX AMNESTY PLAN IS TERMED A SUCCESS BY ALBANY OFFICIALS
description: With the final tally still a week away, New York State tax officials yesterday called the tax amnesty program that ended at midnight Friday an overwhelming success.

title: ANOTHER DEBUT
description: The setting was familiar and so was the game, but for Bob McAdoo, a 14-year National Basketball Association veteran making his first appearance of the season, something seemed a bit amiss Friday night as the Lakers beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 134-100, at the Forum. He was in the wrong uniform.

title: R. D. Finstein to Wed Jessica Ivy Elfenbein
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Iris M. Elfenbein of Washington and Richard Elfenbein of Pomona, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Ivy Elfenbein, to Robert Daniel Feinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Feinstein of Albany.

title: PUNTER TURNS PITCHER
description: Peter Murphy, the Columbia punter who quit the football team last fall after he was publicly and extravagantly denounced by his coach, Jim Garrett, says he would just as soon forget the whole thing. ''Now I'm just concentrating on playing baseball,'' said Murphy, a right-handed pitcher who was one of 23 Columbia players who reported for the season's first workout.

title: TAX OPTION AIDS WILDLIFE GROUPS
description: THROUGH license purchases, hunters and fisherman provide most of the operating revenues of state fish and game departments, but in recent years significant support of those agencies has also come from so-called nonconsumptive outdoor enthusiasts such as hikers, backpackers, canoeists, campers and bird watchers among them.

title: BOSS AS DOCTOR: REPLIES
description: The article ''When the Boss Becomes Your Doctor'' (Jan. 5) -which described the increasing participation of companies in health care decisions through tighter management of health insurance programs -elicited an unusual number of responses. What follows is a sampling. To the Editor: To a certain extent, the managed care programs you describe do represent an ''intrusion by corporate management into employee medical care.'' But the relationship into which they intrude has too often been a one-sided affair, in which patients play a rather passive role, and ''a doctor they trust'' has strong incentives to provide services he or she finds convenient and lucrative.

title: MONUMENT TO CREATORS OF A BRIDGE
description: If city officials approve, a bronze monument to the Roebling family, creators of the Brooklyn Bridge, will overlook the Brooklyn Heights Esplanade from its northern end.

title: Bank Aide Accused of Hiring Hell's Angels to Burn House
description: The police have arrested a bank vice president and accused him of hiring the Hell's Angels motorcycle club to burn down a vacant house last spring.

title: D.E.P.'S NEW CHIEF SEES A 'SALES' ROLE
description: RICHARD T. DEWLING, who takes the helm tomorrow as Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, is an engineer and career civil servant, but he recognizes that one of his most important jobs now is sales.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Named Duane Kuiper as infield instructor for minor-league spring training.

title: NEW TECHNOLOGY TELLS OLD STORY
description: ONE screen shows action videos of gibbons swinging from tree to tree. Another challenges the viewer to a video game of skulls. A third console unleashes the sounds of screeching apes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: KABUL. By M. E. Hirsh. (Atheneum, $19.95.) This interesting but ultimately unsatisfying novel gives readers a better understanding of recent events in Afghanistran.

title: WHY SUPER BOWL IS IMPORTANT: BASEBALL FOLLOWS
description: LAST Sunday, like 90 odd million other people, I settled into my easiest chair and watched as the great NBC television network went dark and quiet for one full minute, thereby proving something I have long suspected: From the final out of the World Series to the first pitch of spring training, sports fans across America will happily watch nothing.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: COPING WITH AMERICA. By Peter Trudgill. (Basil Blackwell, $14.95.) Our weather is ghastly, our fauna (and even our flora) inclined to be hostile and we go about armed to the teeth.

title: N.F.L. Response To Senator Gore
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lasts Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title: Posthumous Payment: It's Just Too Much
description: It used to be that the only time a doctor or hospital didn't charge a patient was after he died. Now there's a move on by the medical profession to bill for ''care and treatment'' after death.

title: The Next Generation
description: A simple oath swearing allegiance to the King and Constitution officially made Prince Felipe heir to the Spanish throne last week. The ceremony marked both the Prince's 18th birthday and the continuity of Spain's constitutional monarchy.

title: NEGLECTED WORKS FOR PIANO HAVE A CHANCE TO SHINE
description: Even with an instrument as familiar as the piano, and even considering the plethora of pianists currently roaming the concert stages, there remain neglected areas of the keyboard repertory. A recent crop of recordings of 19th- and 20th-century piano music allows us to savor a number of rarely played works, few deserving of their obscurity.

title: Fearing AIDS, Army Rejects 400 Recruits
description: The Army has rejected about 400 recruits because tests indicated they had been exposed to the virus that sometimes causes AIDS, an Army officer says.

title: BUSHMAN PAINTINGS AS TAPESTRIES
description: IT WAS 20 years ago that this writer read ''The Lost World of the Kalahari,'' by Laurens van der Post. Yet that story of the author's first encounter with the paintings of the African Bushmen is still imprinted on the mind.

title: RADICAL JOURNAL LIVES ON IN ILLUSTRATION
description: THE magazine called The Masses lasted only from 1911 to 1917, but if started today would probably not survive its first issue, by reason of its name alone. Whereas People magazine sounds wholesome, The Masses has an ominous, Stalinist ring to it, while trailing associations of disdain for ''the great unwashed.'' And if readers were not deterred by this, they would surely balk at the journal's contents.

title: PROFESSOR TAKES A NEW COURSE, AGAIN
description: WITH a speaking style that is the oral equivalent of quiche Lorraine - smooth and light, yet chock full of juicy morsels - Arthur B. Laffer thrills his audience of about 75. In an age when the economics profession has gained a reputation for being wrong as well as boring, this audience has actually paid $200 per head to hear Mr. Laffer, and to help send him to Washington as California's next Senator.

title: 4th in Family Beaten at Home In Seattle Christmas Eve Dies
description: Derek Goldmark, the last member of a family attacked in their home Christmas Eve, died Thursday in a hospital, officials said.

title: Royals to Play Rangers In Cooperstown Game
description: Induction ceremonies at the Baseball Hall of Fame will be held Sunday, Aug. 3, with the Kansas City Royals meeting the Texas Rangers in the annual game at Doubleday Field the next afternoon.

title: IN CREDIT CARDS, ALL THAT GLITTERS...
description: WHEN Robert J. Shalhoub set up his New York City accounting practice, he decided to pay a $250 premium for an American Express platinum card, thinking it would give his fledgling business instant prestige. Instead, he found the reaction was mixed. ''Some clients were in awe,'' he recalls, ''but others would say, 'You sucker, you're paying $250 for what?' ''

title: THE ADDITION OF EGG TO SOUP ENHANCES TEXTURE AND FLAVOR
description: ONE of the simplest ways to embellish a bowl of chicken broth or consomme is to stir in a beaten egg. The egg cooks as it comes into contact with the simmering soup and the result, egg threads or egg drops, add a touch of texture and flavor to the soup, creating an attractive marbelized pattern on the surface at the same time. It's quicker than making noodles.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN HARRISION RECREATION SURVEY It's not that Harrison is without recreational facilities - it has three neighborhood pools, a dozen tennis courts, two large picnic areas and two buildings with gymnasiums. Nevertheless, said Supervisor Pat V. Angorano , ''some homeowners have been pressing for at least two years for the development of a recreational complex.''   ''But the question is,'' he said, ''how many people would be interested in using it, and would user fees make it self-sustaining?''   He said a survey was planned ''to see how many residents would pay $100 to $300 a year or more'' to support what might be an expensive indoor complex, adding that the town could raise the construction costs of up to $3 million through the sale of bonds.   ''But I would have to see where the income would come from to pay the debt service for those bonds,'' he said. ''I don't feel the income should be coming from the general tax, but from those who would be enjoying the facility.''   There would be an outcry, he said, ''if we decided to spend a substantial amount of money for a relatively few people.'' Mr. Angorano said the proposal, which originated with a petition by 40 or 50 homeowners, might be feasible if 500 to 600 families indicated a willingness to participate.
description: THERE are several versions of Harrison's origin, all including John Harrison, a Quaker from Long Island. One of those told frequently in this central Westchester County suburb had the provincial Governor offering him all the land he could traverse in one day, from sunup to sundown.

title: ABOUT MEN A Legacy
description: NOW THAT HE WILL NOT read this, or even have it read to him, I may invade my uncle's privacy by recording what he gave when it seemed impossible to give. In his 70's, blind, divorced, childless, ill and living in London utterly alone, he remained the center of a family scattered in five countries.

title: UNEARTHINNG OUR LANGUAGE'S ROOTS
description: ''I AM a Roman citizen'' was the proudest boast of the ancient world. Today, two millenniums after Caesar and his vaunted legions Romanized transalpine Gaul, every New Jerseyan, every American, can, in a symbolic way, lodge the same claim, for the ways of the Roman world are still very much with us.

title: BOSS AS DOCTOR: REPLIES

title: I.R.A.'S AND OPTION SELLING
description: There are some ''investments'' that the Government will not allow people to put into their Individual Retirement Accounts: personal property, collectibles, precious metals. That is not to say that such sectors are completely cut off; an investor could, for example, invest in shares of gold companies, or a ''gold fund.''

title: WHEN GARBAGE ISN'T
description: Although America remains the land of the full wastebasket and the overflowing dump, the citizenry has grown more cautious about its castoffs. That's because collectibles like glass orange-juice squeezers, circa 1948, and nutmeg graters, circa yesterday if they're rusty enough, can bring big bucks.

title: Pension Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Money, Love And Debt
description: Increasing numbers of people are finding themselves in financial trouble today, in addition to compulsive debtors.

title: HOW SCIENCE RECOVERS FROM DISASTER
description: Gentry Lee, of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., is chief engineer for the Galileo project, an unmanned exploration of Jupiter and its moons, which was scheduled to be launched this May from the space shuttle. Previously, he was a partner in Carl Sagan Productions, which developed the ''Cosmos'' series for public television; director of science analysis and mission planning for the Viking project that landed a spacecraft on Mars in 1976 and, in 1981, was chairman of a committee appointed by NASA to review the software on board the shuttle. Earlier this week, Mr. Lee spoke with Kyle Crichton, Business Forum editor about the shuttle tragedy.

title: COULD SUPERTITLES SOLVE THE 'CAPRICCIO' PROBLEM?
description: Even those who love and cherish Richard Strauss's ''Capriccio'' - perhaps especially those devotees - generally believe that his 15th and final opera can never be staged in such a way as to be taken to heart by the wide public. The recent concert performance at Carnegie Hall dramatized that belief, pointing up the audience's need to keep its collective head buried in the German-English libretto in order to follow the score's dialectical subtleties in any detail.

description: Yevgeny Yevtushenko describes his work as a kind of borscht, the Russian beet soup in which any ingredient goes - as long as it tastes right in the end.

title: MR. BOTHA MOVES AN INCH
description: He surely didn't intend it, but South Africa's President P. W. Botha now grants at least some resemblance between his and the Soviet Union's taking of political prisoners. So much for his stunt of offering to free Nelson Mandela on ''humanitarian grounds'' if Moscow would free Andrei Sakharov and Anatoly Shcharansky. This curious affirmation of the moral equivalence of prisoners of conscience is consistent with Mr. Botha's other declarations. He admits that significant change is overdue - indeed that apartheid is passe - but more to mollify foreign critics than to move his society away from racism.

title: MEDIEVAL SUCCESS STORY
description: WILLIAM MARSHAL The Flower of Chivalry. By Georges Duby. Translated by Richard Howard. 155 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $15.95.

title: LAKE SUCCESS PROJECT FOUGHT
description: MAYOR Reuben Kershaw of Lake Success is in the midst of a development dispute that may strongly affect the municipal elections in March.

title: CONCERT: A BIRTHDAY TRIBUTE TO FRANZ SCHUBERT
description: A RENOVATED movie house on New York's Upper West Side seems a painfully inappropriate place to celebrate Schubert's birthday. Indeed, much spoke against Friday's long, ardent and arduous tribute to the composer at Symphony Space before it had begun - first, the plastic setting so far removed from Schubert's Vienna and then the marathon atmosphere of the program, with its long recitation of 13 chamber pieces, choruses and lieder.

description: ''IF I COULDN'T make a medical decision because of an incapacity of any kind, I'd want others to know how I felt to relieve them of the burden of decision-making without knowing my wishes.''

title: Fighting Famine With Removal
description: It seems hard to believe, but famine may not be Ethiopia's worst problem. After studying the Marxist Government's efforts to resettle more than a million starving victims, a Paris-based relief group, Doctors Without Borders, has concluded that the program is ''a more important cause of mortality than the famine itself.''

title: The Light Touch
description: SEVERAL OF US WERE sitting around recently, idly musing about moments in cooking history at which we would have felt most privileged to be present. For one of our group, it would have been the first extraction of chocolate from the cocoa bean; for another, the final perfection of a dish made with spun sugar. But for me, it would have been three things: the invention of mayonnaise, the discovery of puff pastry and the rising of the very first souffle.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A ''privileged reflection of thirteenth-century Gothic art'' is the felicitous phrase this authoritative and fascinating book uses to describe the stained-glass windows produced in the century that was intellectually and artistically the most glorious of the Middle Ages. Louis Grodecki, the pre-eminent scholar of stained glass, mapped out GOTHIC STAINED GLASS: 1200-1300 (Cornell University Press, $75) with his assistant, Catherine Brisac, and the two wrote large sections of it before he died in 1982. She finished the project in the same quiet style that marked their work on Romanesque glass, ''Le Vitrail Roman'' (1977), to which this book is a sequel. That is a weak word for ''Gothic Stained Glass,'' translated by Barbara Drake Boehm. Stained glass of the 13th century is one of the greatest artistic achievements of Western culture and so much of it survives that many volumes many times the size of the one on Romanesque glass could be written about it. That the authors were able to give so much information and appraisal of more than 1,000 windows -mainly in France where the art flourished most, but also in Germany, Italy, Spain and England - in so brief and engaging a book is the best evidence of their mastery of the field. The systematic correlation of the windows with the architecture, painting and technology of the century, and with the dominant religious ideas as those are expressed in contemporary iconography gives order, directness and clarity to this history of an art that grew from hesitant beginnings to overwhelming grandeur in a few decades and came to be the dominant influence on all visual art by the end of the century.

description: IT began on April 9, 1959, the day the Mercury astronauts were introduced to the public - seven men who were willing, in Tom Wolfe's memorable phrase, ''to sit up on top of an enormous Roman candle, such as a Redstone, Atlas, Titan or Saturn rocket, and wait for someone to light the fuse.'' Overnight, before they had climbed onto a rocket, before they had started their training, before they had even got to know each other, the seven became national heroes.

title: GENDERLESS PROFESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: REWARDING WHAT MAY BE RATHER THAN WHAT IS
description: It is always difficult to know what to make of most architectural awards. The Honor Awards handed out each year by the American Institute of Architects, in some ways the nation's most prestigious architectural citations, tend to be a ''beauty contest'' as much as anything else: Any architect can nominate his own completed building, and the awards go to the ones that strike a jury of other architects as attractive. Since the makeup of the jury changes from year to year, if a building fails to win one year, it is often resubmitted to a jury of somewhat different tastes the following year, the upshot being that almost every major design by a celebrated architect makes it one year or another. It does not add up to very much except a long list of generally worthwhile buildings, a list almost any observer of the architectural scene could easily assemble by himself.

title: WEALTHY CALIFORNIA COUNTY FIGHTS FOR LEGACY
description: The San Francisco Foundation, which is supposed to distribute all income from a $400 million charitable trust within affluent Marin County, will ask a court Monday to be allowed to spend some of the money in poorer Bay area communities.

title: RHYTHM AND BLUES
description: Trivia Question: What musical group is recognized as the first purveyor of the quintessentially American musical form known as Rhythm and Blues, the lineal antecedent of Rock 'n' Roll? The an-swer, according to no lesser authority than the Smithsonian Instituton, is the Orioles, a group that played a key role in shaping the new American popular music that emerged after World War II, rooted in blues, jazz and gospel forerunners.

title: DAY CARE: CAPACITY AND COST CITED AS FACTORS IN 'CRISIS'
description: INCREASES in the number of women in the workforce and the number of single-parent households have created a burgeoning need for day care, but the county's capacity to meet that need has not kept pace, according to a number of county day-care administrators and providers. The result, they said, is a crisis that affects families across the economic spectrum.

title: 14 DEAD IN 2 DAYS
description: Anti-Government demonstrations were reported continuing in several towns today, and medical workers said 14 people had been killed and more than 70 wounded in the last two days.

title: NEW CASSETTES: KUROSAWA, DUMAS AND PROKOFIEV
description: Verdi's 'Ballo in Maschera' A Metropolitan Opera production featuring Luciano Pavarotti, Katia Ricciarelli, Louis Quilico, Judith Blegen, Bianca Berini; Giuseppe Patane conducting, 1980 Paramount Home Video 150 minutes. $59.95 The transfer of selected ''Live From the Met'' telecasts to commercial video cassette begins with Verdi's ''Ballo in Maschera.''

title: Researchers Discover Gates Believed to Be From Alamo
description: Archaeologists have discovered a pair of wooden gates they believe may have been part of the Alamo's original exterior.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT WHALERS BY 3-1
description: By now it is commonly known: The Rangers are not the flashiest of teams. They do not score much. They do not possess the sure-fire shooter, the dazzling scorer, and they are not even physically intimidating. In quick order, that is what's wrong with the Rangers.

title: SHUTTLE EXPERTS DOUBT COMPUTERS COULD DETECT FIRE
description: The computers and sensors that guided the flight of the space shuttle Challenger appear not to have been programmed to detect flames burning through the side of a solid-fuel booster rocket, experts familiar with the shuttle's systems said yesterday.

title: THE COUNT'S ACCOUNT
description: GOOD MORNING BLUES By Count Basie with Albert Murray. Illustrated. 399 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: SETON HALL UPSETS PITTSBURGH BY 85-73
description: Seton Hall, previously without a victory this season in the Big East Conference and with only three in its last 29 conference games, built a first-half lead of 20 points on the way to upsetting Pitt, 85-73, tonight.

title: Lisa Klein to Wed Dr. Steven Wager
description: The engagement of Lisa Klein and Dr. Steven Gary Wager has been announced by Prof. and Mrs. Morton Klein of Haworth, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Ruth Wager of Cleveland and the late William Wager.

title: Constance Laibe Plans a Wedding
description: The engagement of Constance Laibe, a reporter for The News and Observer in Raleigh, N.C., and John A. Hays, a specialist in American decorative arts at Christie's in New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Laibe of Greenwich, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: PARKWAY SLAYING INSPIRES BOOK
description: IN THE spectator section at the murder trial here of Robert O. Marshall and Larry N. Thompson is Joe McGinniss, whose book on the Jeffrey MacDonald case - ''Fatal Vision'' - sold two million copies. (Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald, a Green Beret physician, was convicted of killing his wife and children. An adapation of the McGinniss book was the highest-rated TV miniseries of 1984.) ''This is a fascinating story,'' Mr. McGinniss said of the Marshall case, ''far more interesting than the MacDonald case. As my editor says, it's the 'Peyton Place' of the 80's, except that this time it's true. Greed, sex, violence - the all-American values.''

title: TAKING PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE UNDERWATER WORLD
description: THE warm sun and crystal blue waters of the tropics beckon winter-weary photographers. And a growing number are spending more time discovering the beauties of the deep in such regions as the Gulf of Mexico, the Caribbean, the Florida Keys, the tropical Atlantic or the incredible barrier reef of Belize, second only to the one in Australia.

title: Five Spark Plug Plants Idled in Contract Dispute
description: Some 2,250 members of the United Automobile Workers went on strike today in a contract dispute at five Champion Spark Plug Company plants in the United States and Canada.

title: Questions For a Scientist
description: Perhaps what Ronald Kahn needs to share with his nonscience peers is the genuine joy he derives from his work.

title: EAST GERMANS DENY THEY KILLED A TOP WEST GERMAN AGENT
description: East Germany has taken the unusual step of denying that it eliminated a top West German agent reportedly betrayed by a West German official who defected last year.

title: ARTIST GIVES LITHOGRAPH TO HELP CARNEGIE HALL
description: A cocktail party at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, on Feb. 12 will open a series of 57th-Street art events that will help celebrate and raise funds for Carnegie Hall's 1991 centennial. A signed and numbered five-color lithograph by Jim Dine, some of whose work is on display at the gallery, will be given to the first 150 people who spend $1,000 for a ticket - good for two - to the party and a series of buffet dinners.

title: MEMPHIS ST. FALLS AFTER 20-0 STREAK
description: Dell Curry scored 28 points today as Virginia Tech dashed No. 2 Memphis State's hopes for the No. 1 ranking with a 76-72 upset of the nation's last unbeaten major-college team.

title: Warming Up To a Sauna
description: IN SCANDINAVIA, where the sauna was invented more than 2,000 years ago, its users jump in snow after a good sweat, and even sprinkle brandy on the coals to enliven the vapors. Americans may not use saunas with quite such gusto, but they are enjoying them in greater numbers, either in health clubs or in their homes.

title: Rumanian Official Is Said To Seek U.S. Asylum
description: A Rumanian Foreign Trade Ministry official, who slipped away from colleagues while they were visiting the Acropolis, has asked the United States Embassy for asylum, Greek sources said today.

title: HARTFORD TELESCOPE MARKS 2d HALLEY'S
description: HALLEY'S COMET is being credited with reawakening interest in a century-old telescope owned by Hartford High School.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Recent Sales
description: Boonton $122,000 142 Lake Street *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 110-year-old Victorian; *2*wraparound porch, garage, laundry room; taxes $2,029. Elizabeth $97,000 123 Applegate Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old colonial; *2*2 porches, full carpeting; taxes $1,500. Millburn $135,000 20 Sunset Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*living room with fireplace, open porch, shared driveway; taxes $2,006. Mountainside $197,000 310 Rolling Rock Road *2*3 bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; *2*family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $2,355. North Plainfield $109,900 53 Grandview Avenue *2*4 bedroom, 2 bath, 1876 Victorian; *2*beveled glass doors, wraparound porch, new gas furnace; taxes $1,601. West Milford $120,000 49 Spring Avenue *2*4 bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old bilevel; *2*free-standing fireplace, 1-car garage, near Greenwood Lake; taxes $2,459. OTHER AREAS East Northport, L.I. $118,000 542 Third Street *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 54-year-old Cape Cod; *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $1,200. Greenwich, Conn. $393,000 18 Mansion Place *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old raised ranch; *2*on cul de sac, music room with fireplace, 1.1 acres; taxes $3,323. Scarsdale, N.Y. $250,000 10 Elba Place *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old frame split-level; *2*eat-in kitchen, sun deck, family room; taxes $5,176.

title: TIMES SQUARE
description: To the Editor:

title: A.B.A. JOINS CASE ON BENEFITS DENIED TO MENTALLY ILL IN STATE
description: The American Bar Association is urging the Supreme Court to order the Federal Government to reopen the cases of thousands of mentally ill people throughout New York who were denied disability benefits from 1980 to 1983.

title: DETECTIVE TESTIFIES ABOUT PARKWAY SLAYING SCENE
description: A state police detective testified today that a Toms River insurance broker on trial in his wife's murder could have have stopped his car in much safer places than the secluded parkway rest stop where she was slain.

title: THE TURNSTILES STILL RATTLE
description: DESPITE the several drug scandals and revelations over the last several years in the three major professional team sports in America - baseball, basketball and football - attendance and television ratings for them remain high and healthy.

title: WHITHER OSRIC?
description: Stand by for the Osric Dining Society, a new Washington group created to bestow a highly specialized journalism award. Named for the foppish courtier in ''Hamlet,'' the organization has announced that it will present an annual prize for ''the most fawning, toadying piece of writing'' to appear in magazines or newspapers in the preceding year.

title: Afghans Lose Tariff Benefit
description: President Reagan suspended most-favored-nation trading status for Afghanistan today, thereby raising duties on imports. The President can revoke the status any time.

title: THE STAGE: ICE SHOW AT GARDEN
description: WHAT, just another ice show? Not so. In weather that saw considerable slippage outside of Madison Square Garden, the new Ice Capades that opened inside the big hall Wednesday night generated a warmth and sparkle that melted all fears that one was in for what might be shrugged off as merely another ice show.

title: DIAL CLEARS 19-4 3/4, INDOOR BEST
description: Joe Dial cleared 19 feet 4 3/4 inches in the pole vault today to achieve a world indoor best, bettering the mark of 19-3 3/4 established one week ago by Billy Olson in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: STROLLING, SIGHTSEEING, CAFE-SITTING
description: To take the vigorous pulse of Padua, walk past the ancient Roman arena and the churches with the Giotto and Mantegna frescoes to the nearby railroad station just before 9 o'clock on a weekday morning.
