The trains from Venice, which is just 40 minutes away, and from Ferrara and Rovigo, Vicenza and Treviso roll in one after another, disgorging thousands of young people.

title: SHOWCSE FOR AMERICAN CRAFTS MOUNTED IN LITCHFIELD
description: THE most exciting crafts in the world are created by Americans, some Litchfield County artisans and residents believe, and they are putting on a show to prove it.

title: Marianne Fuller, Magazine Official, To Become Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alan Clarke Fuller of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Mansfield Fuller, to William Barclay Buchanan Jr., a son of Mr. Buchanan of Arlington, Va., and Geraldine L. Buchanan of Fairfax, Va. A June wedding is planned.

title: SALUTING JASCHA HEIFETZ ON HIS 85TH BIRTHDAY
description: Jascha Heifetz is 85 today, and the approach of his birthday reminded me of the violinist as I knew him.

title: The Enchantment Of Vintage Disney
description: Aljean Harmetz writes that Michael Eisner had to be dissuaded from ideas that ''are sometimes grandiose and bizarre,'' such as ''driving across America in a Winnebago.''

title: IN UTAH, THE BABY BOOM IS TURNING INTO A CLASSROOM CRUNCH
description: In some ways, this is a city where time seems to have stood still since the 1950's. In shopping centers, a steady procession of mothers push baby strollers. Suburban housing developments are crowded with children playing after school. Pregnant women are a common sight on downtown streets.

title: 7 SEIZED IN A SCHEME TO INFLUENCE LOTTERY GAMES YIELDING $40,000
description: The director of the New York State Lottery said yesterday that seven people, including four employees of the lottery, had been arrested in a conspiracy to influence the outcome of lottery games that netted more than $40,000 in prizes.

title: A NEW GENERATION OF QUEENS AFFORDABLES
description: RESTRICTIVE zoning in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which often limits new construction to costly one-family houses, is creating a strong demand in Queens for new two- and three-family houses and a surge of building to meet the interest of families in these more affordable forms of housing.

title: 'GOT ANY LOOSE CHANGE?' AN ENCOUNTER I WON'T FORGET
description: IT WAS a while ago. I wasn't used to making daily runs down into the Bowery. Although this area is one of the more depressing neighborhoods in Manhattan, there is no better place around to find used restaurant equipment.

title: War Continues Over Hiring Goals
description: Among the Justice Department's civil rights proposals, few set off as much furor as a draft executive order rescinding requirements that thousands of Federal contractors set numerical goals for hiring and promoting blacks, women and Hispanic people. The debate, which began last summer, is unusual in that so much of it has been within the Reagan Administration and it has been so impassioned that, a White House official said last week, Donald T. Regan, the President's chief of staff, was ''still not putting this issue on the President's schedule.''

title: A LEGACY OF DISHONESTY FUELS ELECTION FEARS IN MANILA
description: IN these last days before the presidential election scheduled for Friday, campaign talk in Manila is concerned less with issues than with such things as flying voters, ghost precincts, advance voting, quick switches and other exotic entries in the dictionary of election fraud.

title: The Defense Gets An Insider's View
description: A Connecticut lawyer has expanded the notion of expert counsel by hiring a former juror as a consultant during the retrial of an assault case.

title: NEW CASSETTES: KUROSAWA, DUMAS AND PROKOFIEV
description: Romeo and Juliet A Royal Ballet production featuring Wayne Eagling and Alessandra Ferri; directed by Colin Nears and Sir Kenneth MacMillan Thorn EMI/HBO Video 128 minutes. $39.95 Kenneth MacMillan's choreographic version of Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet'' has always looked splendid, both in its original production by the Royal Ballet and in its recent restaging by American Ballet Theater.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: GROUNDHOG DAY While most holidays are just celebratory, Groundhog Day has a more practical side to it. After all, how else would we know how much longer winter will last? So today, members of the Long Island Greenbelt Trail Conference will be on the lookout for the ''fuzzy beasties'' and their shadows during two Groundhog Day events. The first will be a hike beginning at 9:30 A.M. at Heckscher State Park, meeting at the northeast corner of the marina parking lot in East Islip. At 10 A.M., there will begin a romp through the hiking paths of Caleb Smith State Park in Smithtown. Call Kim at 586-2406 for the Smithtown particulars; no advance registration is required for the short hike through Heckscher State Park.

title: LOOK AT THE PROGRAMS
description: There has been an important shift in the focus of official thinking about strategic missile defense, away from space-based exotic weapons toward somewhat less ambitious land-based systems. But in any case, ''Star Wars'' depends on satellites, so space launch remains vital.

title: TURNPIKE OFFICIALS CONFIDENT ON EXPANSION
description: ALTHOUGH a plan to widen the New Jersey Turnpike has begun to encounter organized resistance from citizen groups and faces at least one threat of a suit by a municipality, highway officials are confident the ambitious project will be carried out as planned.

title: WARY OF LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CASSETTES: KUROSAWA, DUMAS AND PROKOFIEV
description: One Night With Blue Note Preserved In two volumes. Sony Vol. 1: 60 minutes; Vol. 2: 55 minutes. $34.98 each From the five-hour 1985 concert that announced the reappearance of Blue Note Records, two hours of music are available on two pristinely recorded, handsomely shot video cassettes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ARROWS OF DESIRE. By Geoffrey Household. (Atlantic Monthly, $12.95.) Geoffrey Household's 22d novel is a genial futuristic satire set in the days of ''the last few British,'' 700 years after the Age of Destruction.

title: GIFTED SAXOPHONISTS REVEAL BEBOP AS AN EVOLVING IDIOM
description: Bebop is known to jazz fans as the modern jazz style that Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk, Kenny Clarke, Lester Young and other forward-looking players developed collectively in the 1940's. But because the history of jazz has been broken up, often rather arbitrarily, into a succession of innovation, consolidation and fresh innovation, many listeners have assumed that each of the historical styles has remained as it was, frozen in time. The preponderance in today's record stores of original recordings reissued from the 1940's, 50's and 60's encourages this assumption.

title: NEW CASSETTES: KUROSAWA, DUMAS AND PROKOFIEV
description: The Man in the Iron Mask Starring Richard Chamberlain, Patrick McGoohan, Louis Jourdan, Ralph Richardson, Vivien Merchant; directed by Mike Newell, 1976 Playhouse Video 105 minutes. $59.98 This production represents one of those rather rare instances when television actually improves on an old movie favorite.

title: COMPUTER CONSULTANT KEEPS USER IN MIND
description: ''NOT every company needs a computer - for some firms they're just an expensive mistake,'' Harry Stern said last week. Strange words coming from Mr. Stern, who is not a Dickensian character adding up figures with a quilt pen, but a computer consultant in Hartsdale.

title: BIOFEEDBACK: GAINS AND DOUBTS
description: NOT long ago, Marie Sciallo of Huntington Station could only drive with one hand on the steering wheel of her car. She needed her other hand to hold her head straight.

title: BOOSTER BUILDER IS JOINING INQUIRY
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., the manufacturer of the main segments of the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets, said yesterday that it had no indication from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration that the investigation of Tuesday's explosion had focused on parts of the shuttle for which it is responsible.

title: MUSIC: TWO COMPOSERS JUXTAPOSED IN 'ISLANDS'
description: STEVEN ANTONELLI and Perkin Barnes, two rock-oriented composers whose styles differ markedly, have both performed musical tasks in the productions of the avant-garde playwright and director John Jesurun. ''Islands,'' which plays at La Mama, E.T.C. (74A East Fourth Street), through today is a 75-minute program that stitches together nine pieces by Mr. Antonelli and seven by Mr. Barnes. The show is designed to suggest how musicians of dissimilar sensibility have interacted and influenced one another. Its title refers to the fact that the pieces are played by varying sized ensembles, numbering between three and nine - placed in different areas about the stage.

title: Survivors of 5 in Crew Due for U.S. Benefits
description: Government benefits for the survivors of the five Federal employees killed in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger will be computed in the coming weeks.

title: MEXICO TRYING TO HALT POLICE TORTURE
description: The discovery of the bodies of eight prisoners in the wreckage of a building destroyed in the earthquakes here in September, and widespread allegations that they had been tortured by the police, has set off a campaign to end the official use of torture in Mexico.

title: BUTLER: UNSUNG BUT TALENTED
description: PEOPLE who play for the Cleveland Indians don't often have outstanding seasons. And even if someone should happen to have an outstanding season, not many people outside Cleveland would know about it. Brett Butler is a case in point. Last year he had one of the best seasons that possibly the fewest people knew about. Offensively, Butler was in the American League's top 10 with a .311 batting average, a .377 on-base percentage, 47 stolen bases, 184 hits, 106 runs scored and 14 triples. His 42 strikeouts in 591 times at bat also was the fifth-best ratio for players with 500 or more at-bats. Defensively, the Indians' center fielder committed only one error for a league-leading .998 fielding average and he was second in the outfield in total chances (457), tied for second in assists (19) and third in putouts (437). He was, in short, as dazzling in Cleveland as Rickey Henderson was in New York.

title: Questions For a Scientist
description: I read Ronald Kahn's article with great interest and amusement. I am a doctoral candidate in chemical oceanography and thus am often in the company of nonscientists.

title: OF BLOOD DONORS AND AIDS FEARS
description: Re the article ''AIDS Fears Cut Donations'' [ Dec. 29 ] , I must take exception to Dr. Robertson's statement concerning requests for designated-donor blood donations:

title: Art View; IS IMPRESSIONISM TOO POPULAR FOR ITS OWN GOOD?
description: The longest-running love affair known to me is the one that links people the world over to French Impressionism. It began in this country just 100 years ago, when the Parisian dealer Durand-Ruel introduced the Impressionists to the American public and Mary Cassatt was a substantial contributor to the eighth and last Impressionist group exhibition in Paris. A New York collector called Erwin Davis had bought two important paintings by Manet even earlier - in 1881, to be precise - and when he gave them to the Metropolitan in 1889 he inaugurated one of the world's most majestic holdings of Impressionism.

title: VIOLIN: FREDELL LACK PLAYS YSAYE AND CORELLI
description: FREDELL LACK has been playing the violin before the public for many decades, which is a tribute both to her career longevity and to her beginning as a child prodigy. Long based in New York, she and her accompanist of more than 30 years, the pianist Albert Hirsh, now teach at the University of Houston, and had been scheduled to give their first recital here in some time on Nov. 9.

title: Wendy A. Moyer Becomes Bride of Ben Kronish
description: Wendy A. Moyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Moyer Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ben Kronish, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kronish of New York. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan.

title: NEW SUMMARY SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1986
description: The Shuttle Inquiry The computers and sensors guiding the space shuttle Challenger's flight appear not to have been programmed to detect flames burning through the side of a solid-fuel booster rocket, experts said. There were further indications that the booster was beginning to fail as long as 10 seconds before the shuttle exploded. Even if sensors had picked up the first signs of fire, safety measures built into the system to protect the astronauts would have prevented an automatic shedding of the giant fuel tanks that exploded. That command, the only step that investigators say might have saved the crew, could have come only from the pilot. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Many children want to travel in space and seem resiliently enthusiastic about the space program, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. Though they were pained by the space shuttle explosion that killed a teacher who reminded them of one of their own, two-thirds of the children said they would like to travel in space, as against only half their parents. Adult enthusiasm was also clear; four-fifths said the shuttle program should continue. [ 1:5. ] International Demonstrations in Haiti were reported continuing and medical workers declared that 14 people had been killed and more than 70 wounded in the last two days of anti-Government protests. Seven of the deaths and most of the injuries occurred in Port-au-Prince, the capital, in demonstrations after unfounded reports that President Jean-Claude Duvalier had fled the country.

title: FRESH FARE PUTS A NEW FACE ON INDEPENDENT STATIONS
description: A glance through the program schedules of New York City's three major independent television stations these days can turn up some surprises. For instance, any Saturday evening at 7 on WNEW/ Channel 5, viewers can catch fresh episodes of ''Too Close for Comfort,'' a situation comedy starring Ted Knight. Last summer, viewers of WOR/Channel 9 may have tuned in ''Years of Danger, Years of Hope: The Postwar World,'' a two-hour chronicle of the four decades since World War II, broadcast in prime-time. In April, WPIX/Channel 11 will present ''Strong Medicine,'' a three-part dramatization of the Arthur Hailey novel about a scandal-ridden pharmaceutical company, starring Patrick Duffy, Pamela Sue Martin, Dick Van Dyke, Sam Neill, Ben Cross, Annette O'Toole and Douglas Fairbanks.

title: HOME FIREPLACES: WHERE THERE'S SMOKE, THERE'S TROUBLE
description: A WOOD-BURNING fireplace can give a great deal of pleasure on a cold winter night - and can be mighty useful when the central heating system fails - but if it is continually smoking, or if you can't keep the fire going without constant attention, then it is hard to enjoy.

title: THE SENATE SEEMS TO BE GOING ALONG TO GET ALONG
description: One after another, economists told the Senate Finance Committee last week that an income tax revision bill like the ones proposed by President Reagan and passed by the House of Representatives last year would be so damaging to business that it would cripple the nation's economy.

title: A U.S. Threat Is Still Alive
description: The Reagan Administration kept alive the threat of reprisal against Libya last week, but its plans remained unclear. Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead said President Reagan had ''reserved the right to come back to the military option'' if Libya did not end its support of terrorism. Mr. Whitehead was just back from Europe, where the allies had rejected his pleas that they join in economic sanctions against Tripoli.

title: CONTRACT TALKS QUEITLY STARTING IN STEEL INDUSTRY
description: American steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America are quietly beginning contract negotiations of major importance to the future of the domestic steel industry and to the jobs of tens of thousands of its workers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CHRONICLES OF DOODAH. By George Lee Walker. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) George Lee Walker is a former speechwriter for such corporate magnates as Lee Iacocca of Chrysler and this parody of corporate life reflects a close observation of American business.

title: DANCEMACHINE CELEBRATES THE STYLE OF BROADWAY
description: City Center will be presenting dance this week and next, but it won't be by the usual ballet and modern dance choreographers whose works are performed there the rest of the year. Instead, Lee Theodore's American Dancemachine, which opens on Tuesday at City Center, will be celebrating the likes of Joe Layton and Patricia Birch, and of Ron Field and Tommy Tune, in an evening of dances from Broadway musicals.

title: Alsace's Queen
description: ''GEWURZTRAMINER,'' ITS friends might say, ''is like an old-time burlesque queen.''

title: Money, Love And Debt
description: As a Chapter 13 trustee for the United States Bankruptcy Court, I was surprised to find almost no mention of the relief afforded debtors by a Chapter 13 proceeding.

title: THE FIVE WOMEN OF 'HANNAH AND HER SISTERS'
description: They are neurotic and sexy and smart, Woody's women.

title: DECADES OF FRUSTRATION BOIL TO THE SURFACE IN HAITI
description: As Air Force One headed for Houston Friday morning, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, announced that the Government of Haiti had fallen and President Jean-Claude Duvalier had fled the country. But within hours, the 34-year-old President-for-Life went on Haitian radio to insist that he was still in power, and he drove through Port-au-Prince, the capital, to prove it. The embarrassed White House later said Mr. Speakes had been misled by an early report from the State Department.

title: Times Recovers Shuttle Film And Gives NASA Negatives
description: The New York Times, under an agreement with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, yesterday recovered its remote-controlled cameras and film from the launching site of the space shuttle Challenger at Cape Canaveral in Florida.

title: A SCHOOL SHAKEN BY TEST SCORES
description: AT 1:50 P.M. the other day, Ernest J. Kight, the principal of Westbury Junior High School, grabbed his coat and rushed out to meet the school buses.

title: Gunmen Kill Belfast Catholic
description: Two gunmen burst into a home in North Belfast on Friday and shot a Roman Catholic man to death, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on Jan. 6 accompanying a photograph in the Travel Advisory column misidentified a courtyard as part of the Ringling Art Museum in Sarasota, Fla. The photograph was of the Henry Morrison Flagler Museum in Palm Beach.

title: Miss Givotovsky Engaged to Wed Norman Birkett
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sergei Givotovsky of Sharon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Givotovsky, to Norman Myles Birkett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Myles Birkett of St. Petersburg, Fla., formerly of Toronto. A May wedding is planned.

title: 10 EXPERIMENTS SET TO HELP HARVESTERS OF SHELLFISH ON L.I.
description: The State Urban Development Corporation has approved 10 experimental projects designed to help Long Island's lagging shellfish industry by using aquaculture techniques such as the controlled planting of oysters, bay scallops and kelp.

title: CAPTIALS SURGE PAST DEVILS
description: A meeting held by Coach Bryan Murray motivated the Capitals in their game against the Devils, the third-worst team in the National Hockey League.

title: THE SHUTTLE AND THE ACCIDENT NEXT TIME
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO ASKS STIFFER 'ECONOMIC CRIME' TERMS
description: Governor Cuomo proposed legislation today to increase substantially the penalties for white-collar crimes and bring the sentences closer to those for street crimes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SATURDAY NIGHT AT SAN MARCOS. By William Packard. (Thunder's Mouth Press/Persea, $14.95.) At first glance, this quirky satire on the hermetic, incestuous world of writers' conferences could be mistaken for a familiar kind of sophomoric male humor.

title: MARCOS DENIES CHARGES OF CORRUPTION
description: The campaign for the presidency of the Philippines sharpened in its final week as Ferdinand E. Marcos denied opposition charges that his two decades of rule had been rife with corruption and deceit.

title: The Enchantment Of Vintage Disney
description: In her article ''The Man Re-animating Disney'' (Dec. 29), Aljean Harmetz points out that ''to the teen-agers who paid to see 'Star Wars' half a dozen times, Disney was for babies.''

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ''MY CHILDHOOD was surrounded with animals,'' recalled Dr. Marc A. Rosenberg, a veterinarian from Cherry Hill.

title: AMERICAN TV ISN'T TRAVELING SO WELL
description: Four years ago, Jack Lang, France's Minister of Culture, called for ''a crusade against financial and intellectual imperialism that no longer or rarely grabs territory, but grabs consciousness, ways of thinking, ways of living.''

title: TOWNS GET THEIR SHARE OF ROADS TRUST OF $20 MILLION
description: TOWN and city officials last week found out exactly how much money they will get as their share of a new $20 million state infrastructure program.

title:
INVESTING;
SORTING GOOD JUNK BONDS FROM BAD
description: AT any one time, there are some securities that even junk bond managers - the investors who buy the market dogs - will not buy. Today, the market's real pariahs are the debt securities of oil companies.

title: JOHN REED'S CALMING OF CITICORP
description: LAST month, John S. Reed passed up an opportunity to make history when Citicorp reported its 1985 earnings. It was the sort of opportunity that his famous predecessor, Walter B. Wriston, would not have missed.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A FRIEND IN DEED
description: HE was born in New York City, where he spent much of his life, but because of the help of some Westchester residents, Judge Egbert Benson will remain a county resident.

title: RHODE ISLAND G.O.P. GAINS STRENGTH
description: Four years ago, even its leaders agree, the Republican Party here was a joke.

title: A SLOPE FOR SALE
description: Five acres of undeveloped residentially zoned land in Union City offering a view of the Manhattan skyline across the Hudson River will be auctioned Wednesday in Secaucus, N.J.

title: BROWN-WALKER RIFT CONTINUES TO STRAIN THE KNICKS
description: ''When Walker wants to be a disturbance, he disturbs the entire group. Any time a person wants to do that, whether it's on the high school, collegiate or professional level, that person should go out for wrestling, tennis or golf. That way he injures himself and not the people around him.'' - Hubie Brown.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE KOREAN WAR: Pusan to Chosin. An Oral History. By Donald Knox. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $24.95.) People talk about the Korean War as our forgotten war.

title: BOOK TRANSLATOR'S 'LABOR OF LOVE'
description: THE rave reviews are continuing to pour in - most recently from John Updike in The New Yorker - for ''The Assault,'' a dark fable about war in which guilt and innocence overlap and intermingle.

title: TEA PARTY II
description: There's more to this tale than 30 women at a tea party, as these pages partly revealed last week in beginning the tale of Revolutionary Westchester's own ''tea party.''

title: MAINE TREAT: TINY SHRIMP
description: Temperatures dive way below freezing, occasionally below zero. Ice slicks the boulders, slate seas glitter in the sharp wind under blue skies.

title: LEONIE RYSANEK GLOWS IN STRAUSS
description: Leonie Rysanek has reached that stage in her career when she is backing off from the radiant, high-lying soprano parts that won her her greatest fame and settling into lower, more womanly roles that allow her to exploit her sometimes lurid theatrical skills - parts like Ortrud in Wagner's ''Lohengrin'' and Kundry in ''Parsifal.''

title: 'SEX IS THE ROOT OF IT ALL'
description: MY SOUL AND I The Inner Life of Walt Whitman. By David Cavitch. 193 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE UNWANTED: European Refugees in the Twentieth Century. By Michael R. Marrus. (Oxford University Press, $24.95.) Beacon of promise and sanctuary for immigrants set adrift, the Statue of Liberty prepares to celebrate her centenary.

title: MEMORIAL WREATH DROPPED INTO THE SEA
description: A helicopter dropped a floral wreath into the sea off the Kennedy Space Center today, not far from where search ships continued to sweep for wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN EXECUTIVE SECURITY;
CLASSES IN KICKING AND GOUGING
description: ROBERT FISHER has lived in cities with high crime rates his entire life. And he's been lucky so far - never the victim of a crime. But when the Executive Self-Defense Center opened on New York's Madison Avenue last September, Mr. Fisher was one of the first in line to join.

title: A CHAMELEON OF AN ACTRESS TRANSFORMS HERSELF ONCE AGAIN
description: New York theatergoers first saw her as a 98-year-old Vietnamese man named Uncle Remus. On stage, she went on to play a scatterbrained Richmond belle during the Civil War, a Hollywood waitress whose only ambition is to attend high school, a Southern sexpot with a failed singing career and a Moliere coquette with a musical laugh and a malicious tongue. On screen she has surprised audiences with portrayals of Diane Keaton's whining younger sister, Garp's intellectual and adulterous wife and Raul Julia's No. 1 suspect in the murder of a lecherous Long Island periodontist.

title: Cabs, Koch And New York's City Council
description: City Council approval to increase the number of taxis on New York's streets has proved as elusive as an empty cab in a rush-hour downpour. Last year alone, Mayor Koch supported three plans to change the rules governing New York's 11,787 medallion, or licensed, taxis. Each of the proposals failed to make it out of committee.

title: TELLING A TALE OF TRAGEDY MAY HELP US SAVE OUR CHILDREN
description: AT regular intervals - usually, it seems, after some minor accident involving young people, drink and a car - some parent will shyly opine to another that, as terrible as it would be, a really bad accident is what's needed, so the kids can see for themselves.

title: A TASTE OF JAIL
description: No scandal explains the incarceration last Friday of nine Connecticut legislators.

title: MENTALLY HANDICAPPED: WHAT IS THE TRUE COST?
description: ''Home for the Disturbed Approved Despite Village Opposition'' [ Dec. 29 ] was an interesting article. However, it failed to focus on what is becoming a critical problem, and that is the care of the mentally handicapped after the age of 21.

title: Jazz
description: Way down yonder in the Citicorp Center, jazz groups and singers will be turning the building's ground floor Market into a New Orleans Mardi Gras festival from Wednesday through Saturday. Five of the restaurants that are clustered around the Atrium and down along the hallway toward Third Avenue will present jazz performances twice each night by Doc Cheatham, Carrie Smith and other jazz artists, while Vince Giordano's Nighthawks, a big band that specializes in jazz of the 1920's and 30's, will give free concerts in the Atrium on Thursday from 5 to 7 P.M. and on Saturday from 3 to 5 P.M. Both concerts will be broadcast live and in full by WBGO-FM, the jazz radio station at 88.3, which is co-sponsoring the four-day festival along with the Market at Citicorp Center.

title: YANKS REJECT JACKSON TRADE
description: When Reggie Jackson and Don Baylor were free agents for the first time, Jackson signed with the Yankees and Baylor joined the California Angels. In their second time around as free agents, Jackson went to California and Baylor came to New York. Now the Yankees have apparently passed up a chance to bring Jackson back and send Baylor to the Angels.

title: Error Helps Cibao Win Dominican League Title
description: The Cibao Eagles, taking advantage of a ground ball that went through the legs of the shortstop, Mariano Duncan of the Los Angeles Dodgers, scored two runs in the eighth inning to beat Licey, 7-6, Friday night and win the championship of the Dominican Republic Winter League.

title: 'PETER THE GREAT' IS VERY, VERY CLEAN
description: ''Peter the Great'' is a huge Faberge Easter egg, exploded into hundreds of pieces. If you tried to glue it back together, however, you'd find it couldn't be done. Some pieces got lost; others were replaced. What can you say about an eight-hour, four-part, $26 million (or thereabouts) mini-series in which a Russian czar visits Europe, and the first people he meets are Mel Ferrer and Elke Sommer? The mini-series looks lovely; visually, it's like popping in and out of the rooms in the Uffizi in Florence. Here a Rembrandt, there a Titian, everywhere something to see, but by the time you've gotten to the end of the corridor, you're not sure where you've been. Besides, your feet hurt. That's the way it is with ''Peter the Great.'' Goodness knows a lot of people went to a lot of trouble to put it together, but when it's over it's over, and you don't know what it said.

title: Money, Love And Debt
description: ''The last American taboo'' - that of talking about indebtedness - may be out of the closet at last, thanks to Jerrold Mundis's article on Debtors Anonymous (''A Way Back From Deep Debt,'' Jan. 5).

title: DANCE HISTORY IS MOSTLY A EUROPEAN AFFAIR
description: Dance history is in poor shape in this country. One has yet to see an American equivalent of the rich and detailed four-volume history of Russian ballet - from its beginnings through the early 20th century - that has been written by the contemporary Soviet ballet historian, Vera Krassovska. Another admirable example is the thorough dissertation on court ballet in France (1581-1643), published in French by the British dance historian Margaret McGowan in 1963.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ACTS OF GOD. By Adrienne V. Parks. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $15.95.) This first novel describes the short dazzling life of Camila Lorca, the Evita of Mayapan - a fictional country that is a cross between Nicaragua and El Salvador.

title: Wedding Planned By Laurie Netter
description: The engagement of Laurie Netter to Philip R. Sprayregen has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Netter of New York and East Hampton, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Lee V. Eastman of New York and East Hampton and the late Richard H. Sprayregen.

title: PENTAGON PANEL SAID TO SUPPORT BUILDING OF SMALL MOBILE MISSILE
description: A special Pentagon advisory panel has concluded that the United States should begin full-scale development of a small, mobile intercontinental missile, according to sources familiar with the group's deliberations.

title: 'SHUFFLE' HITS A SNAG
description: When the Chicago Bears' record, ''The Super Bowl Shuffle,'' hit the market, the record jacket and other advertising proclaimed that ''a substantial portion'' of the profits would go to help the needy in Chicago. Company officials said that half the profits would go to charity, but according to the Illinois Attorney General's office that is not enough.

title: The Bow's Art
description: THE BOW TIE IS SIMPLY A MATTER of loose ends coming together. When they do, when the twining is mastered and the ends do meet, the result is somehow uniquely satisfying, a meld of male vanity, decorative art and precise handicraft. The bow tie is a mirror to the male psyche.

title: THE UNITED STATES' OBLIGATION TO SEND ELECTION OBSERVERS TO THE PHILLIPINES
description: Does the United States have any business sending observers to a Philippine election? The answer is yes. American objectives in the Philippines have not changed since the turn the century, when the United States took possession of the islands: We wanted above all to establish and preserve a stable, pro-American society. We also sought to enhance our geopolitical position and military power through access to strategically valuable bases, while we encouraged the Filipinos themselves to develop and preserve their own democracy.

title: PRIVATE EFFORT TO REFURBISH CIVIL WAR MEMORIAL
description: HELP from private sources is on the way for a very public monument here, the Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Arch in Bushnell Park. If all goes according to plan, the arch will be spruced up enough for a proper celebration of its centennial this year.

title: PLAYING THE GAME WITH THE END IN MIND
description: The fate of many an opening depends now a days on what kind of end game it leads to.

title: Verbatim; Love and Hate
description: 'Mahatma Gandhi reveals to us his own heart as he repeats today to those who listen: ''The law of love governs the world . . . . Truth triumphs over untruth. Love conquers hate.'' ' Pope John Paul II arriving in India yesterday on a visit that has prompted protests from Hindu fundamentalists.

title: FREEDOM LIES BEYOND THE WASHROOM DOOR
description: THE SISTERS By Robert Littell. 312 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $16.95.

title: Israel and the Trading States
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Brentwood $80,000 64 Walton Lane *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old ranch; *2*finished basement, new roof, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000. Commack $135,000 11 Astor Court *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, gas *2*barbecue, finished basement with bar, cedar siding, 1-car *2*garage; taxes $2,200. East Northport $118,000 542 Third Street *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 54-year-old Cape Cod; *2*eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $1,200. Massapequa $200,000 26 Andor Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2*eat-in kitchen, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700. Nissequogue $500,000 11 Pheasant Drive *2*5-bedroom, 4-bath, year-old contemporary; *2*vaulted ceilings, balcony, deck, water view, skylights, *2*2 acres; taxes $5,400. Sayville $135,000 51 Bartley Lane *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old split level; *2*pool, 2-car garage; taxes $2,900. OTHER AREAS Mountainside, N.J. $197,000 310 Rolling Rock Road *2*3 bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; *2*family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $2,355. Greenwich, Conn. $393,000 18 Mansion Place *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old raised ranch; *2*on cul de sac, music room with fireplace, 1.1 acres; taxes $3,323. Scarsdale, N.Y. $250,000 10 Elba Place *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old frame split-level; *2*eat-in kitchen, sun deck, family room; taxes $5,176.

title: LISBON
description: Lisbon's magnificent setting on the northern bank of the Tagus River has dazzled visitors for more than a thousand years; even the Romans described the precursor of today's city as felicitas.

title: Oral History of Jazz
description: To the Editor:

title: REVOLT OF THE POSTMODERN PATIENT
description: BEDSIDE MANNERS The Troubled History of Doctors and Patients. By Edward Shorter. Illustrated. 316 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: PANEL TO TRACE BLACK INFLUENCE ON POPULAR MUSIC
description: THOSE oldies but goodies now have a new audience - historians and musicologists who are retracing the history of American music. ''We know that rhythm and blues gave rise to a new kind of American popular music,'' Dr. Portia K. Maultsby said. ''But blacks have never gotten credit for what they created. Ask most Americans, and they can tell you about Elvis Presley as the king of rock-and-roll, but not about the people who created his style.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Feb. 2, 1986 Fiction

title: SIKH TEMPLE SIT-IN IS A CHALLENGE FOR PUNJAB
description: Hundreds of radical Sikhs, brandishing swords and spears, have been carrying out a sit-in for the last week at the Golden Temple at Amritsar, posing a problem for Punjab's moderate state leaders.

title: Ann Heagerty to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leo Heagerty of San Mateo, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Ann Marie Heagerty to Thomas J. Van Ess, the son of Blanche Van Ess of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Dr. Jerome R. Van Ess. A June wedding is planned.

title: IS IT TOO CUTE?
description: If early reaction is indicative, the United States Postal Service appears to have missed the mark with its new Love stamp. The 22-cent special issue was released Thursday in first day ceremonies in New York City and went on sale Friday across the country.

title: TOBIN SUCCEEDS RYAN
description: In another kind of shuffle involving the Bears, Buddy Ryan's job as defensive coordinator has been taken by Vince Tobin, who had just been named defensive coordinator for the New Orleans Saints.

title: DOCTORS AWAIT STATE AID
description: ALTHOUGH Long Island physicians continue to pay the highest malpractice insurance rates in the state, the State Legislature seems unlikely to provide any immediate relief.

title: MUSIC: HORSZOWSKI AND ORCHESTRA OF ST. LUKE'S
description: THE pianist Mieczyslaw Horszowski, now well into his 90's, must be counted as one of the world's wonders. The last surviving pupil of the pedagogue Theodor Leschetizky (who also taught Paderewski, by point of reference), Mr. Horszowski has already enjoyed a longer professional career than any other artist of the first rank - 85 years and counting. In youth a friend of Arturo Toscanini and Pablo Casals, later a teacher of Murray Perahia and Peter Serkin and countless young artists at the Marlboro Festival in Vermont, he is musical history personified. Yet the audience that filled the Metropolitan Museum of Art Friday night for Mr. Horszowski's concert with the Orchestra of St. Luke's, under the direction of Leon Fleisher, did not come merely to gape at a legend.

title: METHOD OF TREATING CAUSE OF HEART ATTACKS TESTED
description: A multistage technique that extracts from the blood substances that are implicated in causing heart attacks is being tested at clinics in New York, Moscow, Cologne, West Germany, and Osaka, Japan.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ONE FAMILY'S BLACK HISTORY
description: ANNIE Loftis used to pick cotton. Her father, she said, was a slave, and when he was freed after the Civil War, he ''set out to have his own place,'' a farm in Liberty, Miss. ''I would lead the field scraping cotton,'' Mrs. Loftis said recently. ''I was a farmer. I would lead the field scraping cotton in the broiling sun. And I would say, I'm going to get as far north as I can, away from cotton. Well, look where I am now.'' Mrs. Loftis is 97 years old. She lives with her granddaughter, Pauline Morgan Harrison and her husband Ronald, in a Tudor-style house in the Orchard Hill section of White Plains. Her room looks like something in a fine summer inn, with white walls, white ruffled bedspread and plenty of sunshine. She is surrounded by all the material comforts of modern life.

title: SENATOR TO SEEK DEDUCTION CAP FOR LOCAL TAXES
description: Russell B. Long of Louisiana, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee and an influential legislator on tax policy, plans to propose a reduction in the amount of state and local taxes that taxpayers can deduct on Federal tax returns.

title: WHERE ARE WE GOING?
description: President Reagan was so sensitive and so moving in his tribute to the fallen astronauts that you could almost hear Walt Whitman singing on the Illinois prairie:

title: VERMONT SENATE VOTES TO RAISE DRINKING AGE
description: The State Senate has approved a compromise measure designed to end Vermont's status as the only state in the Northeast that allows 18-year-olds the right to drink alcoholic beverages.

title: AN ASPARAGUS PLANTING IS ALMOST FOREVER - IF STARTED RIGHT
description: My asparagus bed is 17 years old.

title: U.S. Lists Observers For Philippine Vote
description: The White House announced today that Representative John P. Murtha, Democrat of Pennsylvania, would be co-chairman of the official United States delegation that would observe the presidential election in the Philippines next Friday.

title: MUSICA SACRA AND IVES
description: The ensemble Musica Sacra will play songs, psalms and other works by Charles Ives in a concert Feb. 8, at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 64th Street. Richard Westenburg will conduct the group of 22 singers, the organist William Whitehead and the pianist Seann Alderking. Tickets, $15, will be available at the door, or may be reserved by calling 874-3104.

title: FUTURE ROLE CLOUDY FOR OLD RAIL LINE
description: PEOPLE who live in the rolling countryside of Sussex County are concerned about the recent purchase of an abandoned railroad right of way by a developer who has refused to disclose his plans for the parcel.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TWIG FURNITURE -- COUNTRY IN CITY
description: TWIG furniture representing the epitome of eccentric grace and ''rus in urbe'' (''country in city'') refinement of this reappreciated genre will make up a loan exhibition at the Bucks County Conservancy's annual mid-winter antiques show.

title:
GARDENING;
SHRUBS CAN ADD COLOR TO WINTER SCENES
description: WHILE shrubs are smaller than trees, and therefore play a less dominant role in the landscape, many of them have special characteristics that create interest in the winter garden.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BETWEEN WOMEN:

title: THE ADDITION OF EGG TO SOUPS ENHANCES FLAVOR AND TEXTURE
description: ONE of the simplest ways to embellish a bowl of chicken broth or consomme is to stir in a beaten egg. The egg cooks as it comes into contact with the simmering soup and the result, egg threads or egg drops, add a touch of texture and flavor to the soup, creating an attractive marbelized pattern on the surface at the same time. It's quicker than making noodles.

title: DALLAS NEGOTIATES ITS WAY OUT OF THE COMMUTER BUSINESS
description: Since express service started 17 months ago with 3,500 passengers a day, the pin-striped horde that boards a fleet of modern buses in the this booming city's suburbs has grown to 10,000. The inauguration of the special service is one of several steps taken lately by the two-year-old Dallas Area Rapid Transit Authority to deal with mounting traffic problems.

title: TRENTON AND S.I. FIRES KILL 2 ADULTS AND 9 CHILDREN
description: A woman and five children ranging in age from 1 to 7 years old were killed in a fire in Trenton early yesterday that authorities believe was caused by a faulty, illegal kerosene heater.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: BIRD IN HAND IN GREENWICH A bird sits in someone's hands. The hands close, then reopen, and the bird is gone. This bit of magic will occur, or appear to, at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., during ''Futuresight,'' a holography exhibition making its first and perhaps its only appearance in the Northeast, Feb. 16 through April 20.

title: VENGEANCE IS EVERYONE'S
description: SLOW EXPOSURES By John Wheatcroft. 178 pp. New York: Cornwall Books. $15.95.

title: DANCE: MASK ENSEMBLE AT RIVERSIDE CHURCH
description: WHEN the curtain rose on Friday night, the stage of the Theater of the Riverside Church was filled with frogs. When the final curtain fell, monkeys had taken over.

title: REAGAN PLANNING CAMPAIGN TO PROTECT MILITARY BUILDUP
description: President Reagan, concerned that Congress might ''gut'' his military spending program, is planning a campaign on the theme that any such ''retreat'' would threaten the United States position in arms control talks and in resolving regional disputes, White House officials said today.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ON THE STATUS OF BLACKS A comprehensive view of the status of blacks in politics, education, corporate life and the arts will be presented in eight free programs celebrating Black History Month at the Greenburgh Public Library. Michelle Parkerson opens the series at 3 P.M. today with her comments on a screening of ''. . . But Then She's Betty Carter,'' a film she wrote and produced about the jazz singer.

title: Elise K. Harrison Engaged to Marry George B. Lemmon Jr. in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Harrison of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elise Kenyon Harrison, to George Blackmore Lemmon Jr., the son of Ann Peterkin Lemmon of Villanova, Pa., and Mr. Lemmon of Haverford, Pa.

title: AMERICAN CHIPPENDALE TAKES THE PRIZE
description: Last weekend, two auctions of 18th-century Chippendale furniture - English in one case, American in the other - were held at the same time at New York's two top auction houses, with dramatically different results.

title: Mary Sutherland Weds J. H. Silverman
description: Mary Sutherland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Sutherland of Gates Mills, Ohio, was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Jeremy H. Silverman, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Otto Silverman of London. The Rev. Gerald J. Osterman, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard University.

title: THE LABYRINTHIAN PATH TO CHANGE
description: LAST May, Mayor Koch announced a citywide zoning proposal designed to make it easier to build housing in middle-density districts. Planners have named it Quality Housing - a term that recalls its antecedent, discretionary rules known as Housing Quality - and they believe it has the potential to pave the way for several thousand units of multifamily housing on vacant or underutilized land, especially in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: 1944: THE YEAR I LEARNED TO LOVE A GERMAN
description: READING was not one of my boyhood passions. Girls, or rather the absence of girls, drove me to it. When I was 13 years old, short for my age, more than somewhat pimply, I was terrified of girls. They made me feel sadly inadequate. As far as I could make out, they were at-tracted only to boys who were tall or played for the school basketball team or at least shaved. Unable to qualify on all three counts, I resorted to subterfuge. I set out to call attention to myself by becoming a character. Retreating into high seriousness, I acquired a pipe, which I chewed on ostentatiously, and made it my business to be seen everywhere, even at school basketball games, absorbed by books of daunting significance. Say, H. G. Wells's ''Short History of the World'' or Paul de Kruif's ''Microbe Hunters'' or John Gunther inside one continent or another. I rented these thought-provoking books for three cents a day from a neighborhood lending library that was across the street from a bowling alley where I used to spot pins four nights a week.

title: Suzanne M. Nora To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul F. Nora of Winnetka, Ill., and La Jolla, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Michael Nora, to David Gordon Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon E. Johnson of Fort Wayne, Ind. The wedding is planned for May 3.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Speeding Toward Insanity It's an odd expression of human pride that each age thinks itself crazier than the last. In the middle of the 19th century, Dr. John Hawkes of the Wiltshire County Asylum in England laid claim for his particular moment. He is quoted in ''The Female Malady: Women, Madness, and English Culture, 1830-1980,'' by Elaine Showalter (Pantheon).

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ARE TOLD VOTERS ARE DRIFTING BACK TO PARTY
description: House Democrats got some bad news and some good news this weekend as they held a three-day retreat at a plush resort in the hills of West Virginia.

title: Woman Drives Van off a Pier; Friend Drowns in Rescue Bid
description: A 27-year-old woman apparently drowned in the East River when she backed a van off a pier in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn late Friday night. Her boyfriend drowned when he dived in to try to rescue her.

title: Peter Funt, Producer, Weds Amy S. Meltzer
description: Amy Suzanne Meltzer, a marketing manager for Home Box Office, and Peter Funt, an independent television producer, were married yesterday at the Georgian Suite in New York by Rabbi Jonas Goldberg.

title: FINISHING A PLAZA
description: Since 1967, the small, 100-year-old brick and limestone Key Bank building has stood alone overlooking the Hudson River on the once-crowded 6 1/2-acre plaza that bears its name in Newburgh, N.Y. But not for much longer.

title: Police Seize Man in Slaying Of Two Ohio Security Guards
description: The police surrounded a Veterans Administration hospital in this Cleveland suburb Friday and seized a gunman they said killed two hospital security guards and held a patient hostage.

title: Shipyard in Indiana to Close
description: Jeffboat Inc. has announced it will close the country's largest inland shipyard by mid-May, eliminating 225 jobs and closing the last major yard on the Ohio River. The shipyard is unlikely to reopen for three to five years, Robert Greene, president of the company, a subsidiary of the CSX Corporation, said Friday.

title: TOP KOSHER POULTRY PROCESSOR RALLIES FROM FIRE
description: Less than a week after a fire destroyed the main processing plant at the world's largest supplier of kosher chicken and turkey products, the owners say they hope to be back in business in a month.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
ILLEGAL RENTALS TROUBLE ONE-FAMILY AREAS
description: RISING prices and a continuing strong rental demand are creating a fertile market on the Island for investors anxious to own houses that are appreciating in value and bringing in good income.

title: THE ADDITION OF EGG TO SOUPS ENHANCES TEXTURE AND FLAVOR
description: ONE of the simplest ways to embellish a bowl of chicken broth or consomme is to stir in a beaten egg. The egg cooks as it comes into contact with the simmering soup and the result, egg threads or egg drops, add a touch of texture and flavor to the soup, creating an attractive marbelized pattern on the surface at the same time. It's quicker than making noodles.

title: Newport Debates Statue's Status
description: OFFICIALS in Newport, R.I., are trying to decide whether a nine-foot Fiberglass statue of a smiling sailor that has stood in a waterfront plaza for the last two and a half years is a tourist attraction or a traffic hazard.

title: A KENNEDY'S RIVALS FACE BIG PROBLEM
description: With eight months to go before the Democratic primary, most of the candidates for the Congressional seat to be vacated by Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. face a common problem: how to overcome the celebrity status of a rival, Joseph P. Kennedy 2d.

title: Uganda's New Leader Swears In 34 Officials
description: Yoweri Museveni, the new Ugandan President, swore in a political council and Cabinet today to run ''a Government of freedom fighters.''

title: KICKBACK CASE BACK IN COURT OVER WHO PAID 1% to G.O.P.
description: DURING last summer's 1 percent kickback trial in Federal District Court, Judge Jacob Mishler would occasionally warn the lawyer representing government workers who said they had been coerced into contributing part of their salaries to the Republican Party that he might win the battle but lose the war.

title: JAZZ: PIANIST, DAVID LOPATO
description: DAVID LOPATO, a pianist with impressive technique and a long stylistic reach, gave an ambitious concert Thursday night at Greenwich House. For the first half, he was an eclectic jazz pianist; for the second, a composer looking east at the music he studied in Java.

title: Nicaragua Devalues Currency to Ease Debt
description: Nicaragua has devalued its currency and eliminated a two-tier exchange rate in an attempt to bolster its debt-ridden economy.

title: THE PAST AS PROLOGUE
description: 1949 The First Israelis. By Tom Segev. Illustrated. 379 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A film listing today in The Guide, section 2A, misidentifies the theater where ''Lady Jane'' will play. It opens Friday at the Loews New York Twin.

title: THE EX-IM BANK'S TRICKY TACTIC
description: ARMANDO PAZ, treasurer of Calmaquip Engineering Corporation, was in Brazil last November, trying to win a contract to supply airport equipment to the Brazilian Ministry of Aeronautics, when he got some good news from his brother-in-law, the company president Raul Gutierrez, back at Calmaquip headquarters in Miami.

title: THE WRITER AS GOD AND SABOTEUR
description: THE REAL LIFE OF ALEJANDRO MAYTA By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Alfred Mac Adam. 310 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: RIGHTS RESERVED FOR THE RESEVATION
description: Although the weapons have changed, American Indians are fighting today much the same battles over tribal sovereignty and the ownership of land and natural resources that they waged in the 19th century. The difference is that this time - from tribal courthouses to the United States Supreme Court -they are winning.

title: SPENDING UP IN 'REAGAN REVOLUTION'
description: When President Reagan took office five years ago, he vowed to shrink the size and scope of government as part of an agenda that conservatives called the Reagan revolution. But despite some notable victories in limiting domestic programs, total Federal spending has continued to climb.

title: A COURTSHIP WITH FAME
description: AT 16, DEBBIE SPENCE, the No. 1-ranked junior-girls tennis player in the country, dropped out of high school and started working on her game a minimum of five hours a day, five days a week, with weekends reserved for tournaments. She served one shopping basket's worth of tennis balls after another, attempting to punch up a weak serve. She drilled endlessly on her best asset, her sizzlingly accurate passing shots, and took aerobics classes to protect her reputation as a player who often won simply by outlasting her opponent. In deference to her parents, she enrolled in an independent study program, and slipped her assignments in when she had a free moment.

title: More Promises From Botha
description: ''We have outgrown the . . . outdated concept of apartheid,'' President P. W. Botha of South Africa said last week, but it was not lost on his opponents that he was speaking to the opening session of a Parliament that has separate chambers for whites, people of mixed race and those classified as Asians, but not for blacks, a situation Mr. Botha gave no hint of changing.

title: INSURERS SEEKING NEW EXCLUSIONS
description: THE state's Department of Insurance has begun hearings on a new round of requests by the insurance industry for permission to exclude a number of coverages in its liability policies.

title: Molly Mulhern Is Engaged To Wed Kenneth S. Gross
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Arthur Mulhern of Cooperstown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Molly Mulhern, to Kenneth Stephen Gross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Gross of Camden, Me.

title: CZECH SYSTEM MANUFACTURES TENNIS STARS
description: ''FACTS on Czechoslovak Foreign Trade,'' a seemingly comprehensive but far from lyrical book that Czechoslovak officials press on visiting reporters, appears to have some key omissions. Nowhere among the lists of thousands of exported items - the tons of animal skins, the organic and inorganic chemicals, the porcelain and cut crystal - does it list tennis players.

title: BEDROOM FARCE AT THE PAPER MILL
description: WHICH is a worse dilemma for a wife: a husband who commits homosexual adultery or one who commits heterosexual bigamy?

title: SENSITIVE STAGING OF PLAY ON AIDS
description: OF the two prominent plays about AIDS, ''The Normal Heart'' has been conveniently categorized as the political one, whereas ''As Is'' has been called the personal one.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: JUST when it looked like the litter tax had triumphed, advocates of the bottle bill have opened up a new front in the long-running legislative battle: Initiative and Referendum.

title: SPENDING LESS FOR LODGINGS
description: In Macon, Ga., to pick a city at random, you can stay at the Hilton. It is right downtown and has 306 rooms, all with free color television. It has a swimming pool, two restaurants, a cafe and a lobby lounge. For a double room, at this writing, the normal rate is $73 a night, plus tax. If your budget is tight, however, you can stay at Motel 6. It is seven miles west of downtown, on U.S. Route 80. Its lobby is relatively Spartan, its 103 guest rooms are not spacious (but all have air-conditioning), you will have to pay $1.25 a night to use the color television set and the closest food service is at the Ramada Inn, across the highway. But Motel 6 does have a pool and its rate for two people is only $22.95.

title: 'GRANDE DAME' LOOKS AHEAD
description: IN 1977, shortly after the death of her husband, Ward Melville, the Thom McAn shoe magnate, Dorothy Melville was asked to replace him as president of the Stony Brook Community Fund. The fund, presided over by 15 trustees, owns and manages various properties in the Three Village area.

title: COSTA RICANS VOTE TODAY IN A TIGHT PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: In a race too close to call, Costa Rican presidential candidates face the voters Sunday after a yearlong campaign that has concentrated on the failing economy and bitter criticism of Nicaragua as a Marxist dictatorship.

title: Police Scandal Shakes Pittsfield
description: WHEN John Gunther toured the United States in 1945 and wrote the best seller, ''Inside U.S.A.,'' he labeled Pittsfield, Mass., America's ''best for least'' community.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN EXECUTIVE SECURITY;
THE BRIDFCASE THAT EMITS 4,000 VOLTS
description: THOUGH the items look run-of-the-mill in the catalogs and showrooms, they are anything but. The trenchcoat repels bullets as well as rain. The briefcase has an alarm that emits a shriek and 4,000 volts of electricity. And the elegant watch not only keeps track of the time but sports a built-in transmitter that allows someone else to keep track of the wearer.

title: AWAY, HUDDLED MASSES
description: To the Editor:

title: Marcia Pinover To Wed in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Stanley Pinover Jr. of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Lynne Pinover, to Capt. Thomas Nathaniel Beatty, U.S.M.C., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Loring Beatty, also of Darien. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Johanna Murray Married To William Mitchell Camp
description: Johanna Murray, a freelance stage manager, and William Mitchell Camp, project supervisor at Bruce Porter/Bruce Rayvid Stage Scenery Inc., were married yesterday in the St. James Chapel at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York.

title: STATE AGENCY ISSUES A FAST-SELLING BOOK
description: THE first 5,000 copies of a new guide to the state's geology have been selling so quickly that its publisher, the state's Department of Environmental Protection, is considering a second printing.

title: LESOTHO SEIZES 50 MORE SOUTH AFRICAN EXILES
description: Lesotho's new military Government was reported today to have seized 50 more South African political fugitives and told them they would be deported.

title: UCONN SET TO BUILD NEW GYM
description: AS a $4.5 million fund-raising campaign draws to a close, sports officials at the University of Connecticut are preparing to break ground next fall on a new field house, a project that was first proposed 17 years ago.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THEATERS OF THE MIND: Illusion and Truth on the Psychoanalytic Stage. By Joyce McDougall. (Basic Books, $22.95.) All of us harbor a secret theater of the mind with a favorite scenario that we repeat in fantasy as well as in life, according to Joyce McDougall, a psychoanalyst in Paris.

title: 11 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 11 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title:
ART;
SUFFOLK ARTISTS JOIN NASSAU'S IN A SHOW MARKED BY VIGOR
description: IN recent years, the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts has been recognizing the county's artists with an annual exhibition that is actually a cluster of simultaneous one-person showings.

title: MAYOTTE, LENDL IN FINAL
description: Seventh-seeded Tim Mayotte defeated fourth-seeded Yannick Noah of France, 6-1, 2-6, 6-3, tonight to advance to the final of the United States Pro Indoor tennis championships.

title: Yaffi Shapiro Engaged To Joseph Shmidman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Z. Shapiro of Monsey, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Yaffi Lisa Shapiro to Joseph J. Shmidman, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Michael Shmidman of Kew Gardens, Queens. The wedding is planned for June.

title: THE VIEW UP CLOSE
description: ''YOU ought to watch this game from the field.''

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Feb. 2, 1986 Fiction

title: IT TAKES MORE THAN A FEW SONGS TO MAKE A MUSICAL
description: Musicalette: noun, from the Italian, musicaletto, songs sung in a piazza, free and al fresco.

title: Susan Weissfeld To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerold C. Weissfeld of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Frances Weissfeld, to Jan Lawrence Hammerman, a son of Cantor and Mrs. Saul Z. Hammerman of Baltimore. The wedding is planned for June 1.

title:
GARDENING;
SHRUBS CAN ADD COLOR TO WINTER SCENES
description: WHILE shrubs are smaller than trees, and therefore play a less dominant role in the landscape, many of them have special characteristics that create interest in the winter garden.

title: BAILEY GETS 46 POINTS AS WAGNER WINS
description: Terrance Bailey, the nation's leading scorer, scored a game-high 46 points to lead Wagner to an 85-81 victory over Marist today in an E.C.A.C. Metro conference basketball game. Bailey, a 6-foot-2-inch junior, scored 30 points in the second half to spark the Seahawks, who led by 34-30 at the half. He shot 14 of 23 from the floor and 18 of 26 from the foul line in establishing a McCann Center scoring record.

title: THE RIGHT TO DIE: LEGAL GUIDELINES SLOWLY EMERGING
description: IN CONTRAST to the controversy surrounding the Nancy Ellen Jobes ''right to die'' suit, the first case using procedures outlined by the State Supreme Court is progressing without a ripple.

title: Bikes
description: To the Editor: Having been a neighborhood bicycle retailer for 18 years, I find very true the comment ''you'll quickly win friends among cyclists and shop owners'' in the article ''Italy's Bikes Compete with the Best'' (Travel, Jan. 5). But when you buy a bike overseas, beware of the following: 1. Specifications in foreign countries are likely to vary from American standards, especially those required by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, such as for brake shoes. Threading standards are different, too, and replacement parts may be very rare. For instance, a relatively inexpensive part, the freewheel cluster, which is designed to be replaced when it wears out, may have an Italian thread, rare in the United States, instead of the ubiquitous British thread. They are nearly the same, hard to distinguish, and on an expensive bike a mistake to mix. 2. American marketing corporations may not honor the warranty for products bought from the parent company in Italy. And certainly it is unfair to ask your local bicycle shop to be your advocate in this event. 3. Even the average rider requires unique measurements and judgments in the preparation of a specialty bicycle, and the guidance of sellers in Europe will reflect their temperaments and options. This may differ from the American attitude. Some changes can be made when you get back to the United States at extra cost, such as to change handlebar stem length, but many decisions made in the excitement of the frame builder's showroom will be uncorrectable.

title: Soviet Allows Bonner To Extend Stay in U.S.
description: Yelena G. Bonner has received Soviet permission to extend her stay in the United States for medical treatment, her family said today.

title: TWO MINDS OPERATING IN CONCERT
description: EDWARD ZAWACKI, dancer, choreographer and teacher, and Mark Wood, electric violinist and composer, believe they are on the ''same wavelength,'' as Mr. Zawacki put it.

title: Caroline Smith Is Planning To Wed Michael Berliner
description: Caroline Jackson Smith and Michael Alan Berliner, both graduates of Sarah Lawrence College, class of '76, plan to be married in April.

title: 88 YEARS AFTER MOST FAMOUS VICTORY, DEWEY'S WARSHIP FACES NEW BATTLE
description: The jut-jawed old bulldog of a ship rides majestically at a Delaware River pier, her nearly white steel hull gleaming in the sun, her buff superstructure as proud as on the morning of May 1, 1898, when Commodore George Dewey stood on her bridge in Manila Bay and gave his famous order: ''You may fire when you are ready, Gridley.''

title: AN ISLAND OF GULLAH CULTURE
description: A local fish dish that residents of the Carolina Sea Islands have been enjoying for more years than anybody can trace has become a current favorite at some fancy restaurants in Charleston and some of the resorts along the Carolina coast. Called Frogmore stew, it is what the natives of the coast, many of whom are shrimp fishermen, eat on the sort of ritual occasion that their inland neighbors might celebrate with a barbecue. This folk dish is a highly seasoned stew of such improbably combined ingredients as sausage and shrimp and crabs plus some other things like corn on the cob. The people who make the stew often boil the ingredients in beer.

title: Airlines
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. CEMETERIES UP FOR ADOPTION
description: CONCERNED because historic cemeteries in Huntington, L.I., were deteriorating through neglect, the town historian put out a call for volunteers to ''adopt'' them and care for them.

title: WALKING IS HEALTHY BUT LONELY
description: WALKING the streets isn't what it's cracked up to be. Maybe I should rephrase that. Walking for exercise these days can be as lonely as walking a one-way street.

title: EX-COHALAN AIDE OFFERS INSIDE LOOK
description: JOHN C. GALLAGHER spent 17 years as an educator before he became Suffolk County's Chief Deputy County Executive. And if he ever returns to education, he said, ''the first thing I'd do is throw out the standard textbooks on government.''

title: OFFICIALS AT ODDS ON AIRPORT PLANS FOR ATLANTIC CITY
description: POMONA A DESIRE after World War I to establish permanent ownership of a sprawling pinelands watershed from which Atlantic City draws its drinking water was directly responsible for the city's ownership of what is now Atlantic City International Airport here.

title: AIRLINES
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HE WILL NOT WALK WITH ME By Alice Bach. 182 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up) THIS is a surprising book - a moral tale for young people in which the heroine sets out to do a good deed for all the wrong reasons. Sixteen-year-old Hallie Clement gets a big crush on her charismatic minister and, thinking she will rub Samaritan elbows with her handsome pastor, travels downtown to volunteer on weekends at Communion House, a center for homeless people on Manhattan's Bowery probably modeled on the Catholic Worker center where Alice Bach, the author, has worked.

title: Police Forces May be Merged
description: Above and below ground, New York City's men and women in blue are likely to be united soon in a single agency, municipal officials said last week. An agreement in principle has been reached on a plan to merge the Police Department with the transit police force, the officials said.

title:
ART;
ATTENTION IS ON 19th CENTURY IN SHOW OF BLACK AMERICANS
description: ''HIDDEN HERITAGE:

title: ST. JOHN'S LOSES TO SYRACUSE, 68-64
description: In a long-awaited showdown for first place between the Big East Conference powers, Syracuse, combining bruising inside offense with superb team defense, defeated St. John's today, 68-64, before a Carrier Dome crowd of 32,165.

title: DEVELOPERS THINKING BIG - AND BIGGER
description: AFTER years of cautious construction of moderate-size developments, Westchester is facing half a dozen proposals for relatively large complexes that could add 5,000 new condominiums and rental apartments to its housing stock within the next decade.

title: BOMB THREATS AT HIGH SCHOOL
description: BOMB threats became almost commonplace at Fairview (Tenn.) High School after a black man had been appointed principal of the predominantly white school.

title: COPS AGAINST GUNS
description: ''For every Tom, Dick and Dirty Harry,'' smirks the Connecticut gun shop's newspaper ad. What it's offering on sale are .44 magnums, heavy-duty handguns that have nothing to do with target shooting.

title: WHY WAS THE BOLSHEVIK TERROR WRONG?
description: MARXISM AND MORALITY By Steven Lukes. 163 pp. New York: Clarendon Press/ Oxford University Press. $15.95.

title: THE AGED PUSH ALBANY ON PRESCRIPTION SUBSIDY
description: In what has become an annual phenomenon, older New Yorkers are resuming their campaign for a state program to subsidize prescription drugs for the elderly.

title: TWO EFFORTS TO DRAW PUPILS TO TEACHING
description: ALTHOUGH the threat of teacher shortages is not as acute in Westchester as it is in other regions of the country, two county programs are addressing the issue of how to attract top students to explore teaching as a career. If the programs are successful, their coordinators say, they may serve as models for recruiting talented people nationwide.

title: BREAKING NEW GROUND IN THE ROCKIES
description: ''Siberia's going to offer some mighty fine skiing,'' my companion said as we slid to a soft stop in untracked snow not far from the Great Wall of China.

title: ITALY HALTS TALKS ON LIBYAN DEALS
description: Italy is moving toward invoking economic sanctions against Libya, and President Reagan has sent Prime Minister Bettino Craxi a message praising Italy's anti-terrorism efforts, senior Italian officials said today.

title: WHITE ON WHITE FOR WINTER
description: ADVOCATES of a white winter may be getting only intermittent cooperation from the weatherman, but they're receiving a lot of help from designers. White, especially in the form of full-length overcoats, is turning up in welcome profusion, adding a discernible measure of cheer to sidewalks.

title: MORE WOMEN HOLD TOP ELECTED POSTS
description: ''BEING a woman is no longer an obstacle to overcome,'' said Ann S. Mandel, the first woman to be elected First Selectman of Darien. ''It's a plus.'' If Mrs. Mandel had been elected to that position just a decade ago, rather than last November, she would have been one of a handful of women in top government positions in Connecticut's towns. A record number of women, 39, now hold such offices. Twelve are mayors and 27 are first selectmen. They account for nearly a quarter of the state's top municipal officials.

title:
ANTIQUES;
STONINGTON OFFERS ITEMS FROM 7 STATES
description: GENERATIONS ago, those with goods to sell set up stalls periodically in the local marketplace - an area better known later as the town green. Along the coast, trading ships weighed in regularly at town wharves from New England to the Carolinas, to the islands of the West Indies and back again, buying in one place what they believed would be salable at the next.

title: Questions For a Scientist
description: The title and thrust of Ronald Kahn's article concerns a life of isolation, not only from the public, but from other scientists as well. In our training as scientists, we learn that the most important tasks of scientists are not technical manipulations but writing and presenting papers to our peers and, eventually, the press (if we are fortunate).

title: THE ROAD FROM CAMP DAVID SEEMS TO LEAD IN A CIRCLE
description: ''You can't dance at two weddings at the same time,'' says an old Hebrew adage - you have to finish one before moving to the next. The saying seemed equally true last week of Middle East peacemaking. The peace between Egypt and Israel is still unfinished. Israel has not implemented the clauses for Palestinian autonomy, and Egypt has not fulfilled many of the normalization provisions or returned its ambassador to Tel Aviv. Moreover, the nettlesome Taba Sinai border dispute lingers.

title: A CONCERT TRIBUTE TO HARTFORD
description: A MUSICAL celebration of Hartford's cultural heritage will be presented by Trinity College at 2 P.M. today. The program in the Watkinson Library will be of early church and concert-hall music, cotillion dances and patriotic pieces from the extensive Watkinson collection.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title:
WINE;
PENETRATING THE MYSTIQUE OF TASTINGS
description: WHILE the majority of the adults in the area drink wine at least once a month, few attend organized tastings. In fact, because of misconceptions about the character and purpose of such events, a number of otherwise self-assured individuals cringe at the thought of attending a wine tasting.

title: State Freezes Boston Aid Funds
description: THE Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination, the state agency that monitors civil rights, has frozen at least $20 million for housing and waterfront development in Boston until the city files an acceptable plan to prevent housing and employment discrimination aganst women, minorities and the handicapped.

title: EXXON MUST PAY FOR OVERCHARGINE
description: Exxon will have to pay $2.1 billion in refunds and interest for overcharging buyers of its crude in the 1970's. The Supreme Court refused to hear the oil company's appeal of the award. Exxon was accused, along with dozens of other oil companies, of selling ''old'' oil at the higher prices allowed for ''new'' oil. Exxon said it had been unfairly singled out. The refunds will be distibuted to the states involved, which are to use the money for energy-related expenses, such as subsidizing utility bills for the poor.

title: WING LEARNS FROM PLAYING WITH PROS
description: Boston University's star sophomore left wing, Clark Donatelli, loves to return home and be the enemy. That is when he is at his best. Donatelli's family lives in North Providence, R.I., just a few miles from Providence College's Schneider Arena. His father's construction company built the arena, and young Clark was one of the first to skate on its ice surface, in the wee hours of the morning some 11 years ago.

title: Aid for Fertilization
description: Two decades ago, when many women were trying not to become pregnant, researchers competed to develop the best birth control method. In the 1980's, the effort seems to be moving in the opposite direction: toward helping women have babies.

title: IN THE INTEREST OF AMERICAN MUSIC
description: ''Composers and conductors need each other,''

title: THE BLOOD IN ANDY'S SANDBOX
description: PERU By Gordon Lish. 222 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: TAKING TO THE TRAILS ON STENDHAL'S TURF
description: The great French writer Stendhal called the Franche-Comte the most beautiful region of France, but that comes as something of a surprise.

title: Deadly Results
description: In another courtroom, this one in New York City, a police sergeant was convicted of manslaughter last week.

title: PADUA: PILGRIMS AND PAINTERS
description: Milan, as everybody knows, is the site of Leonardo's ''Last Supper'' fresco; mention Rome, and immediately the Sistine Chapel comes to mind, but go on to cite Padua and, more often than not, a blank gaze will follow. Yet this is where modern painting was born almost 700 years ago. Vasari, the great Renaissance author and painter, knew it well: with Giotto, art forsook the gold grounds and flat, stylized patterns inherited from the early Middle Ages and took the real world as its subject.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: DR. MYRON SOLBERG of Highland Park and Dr. Jack L. Rossen of New York City have been named director and associate director, respectively, of Rutgers University's new Center for Advanced Food Technology.

title: Dr. Susan Mendley to Wed
description: Dr. Susan Ruth Mendley and Dr. Jason G. Umans, both residents in internal medicine at the University of Chicago Hospitals and Clinics, plan to be married in April. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mark H. Mendley of Bronxville, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross Umans of Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: GROUDHOG DAY: AN ANEMIC REMNANT OF WHAT IT ONCE WAS
description: SOME people say there is nothing sadder than a jilted lover or a movie starlet past her time. But I say there is nothing sadder than to see a noble holiday cast aside, or treated as a petty amusement rather than a great feast.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing IMSA 24 Hours of Daytona, finale of the race that began yesterday.(Television - WTBS, 3:05 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs.

title:
GARDENING;
SHRUBS CAN ADD COLOR TO WINTER SCENES
description: WHILE shrubs are smaller than trees, and therefore play a less dominant role in the landscape, many of them have special characteristics that create interest in the winter garden.

title: TWO BLACK SCULPTORS ARE SUBJECT OF LECTURE
description: Among the many celebrations of Black achievement planned for Black History Month is a lecture Feb. 26 on William Edmondson and David Butler, two black sculptors who made a significant cultural contribution despite their lack of formal training. The free lecture and slide show will be presented by William P. Miller, exeutive director of the Jamaica Arts Center.

title: QUEENS COURT POST IS SUBJECT OF KICKBACK INQUIRY
description: A Federal inquiry into guardianship appointments in Queens courts is focusing on nine assignments given to a Manhattan lawyer who said she had paid kickbacks to a Queens Democratic Party official, according to investigators.

title: SPREADSHEET WITH A LOFTY AIM
description: PERSONAL computer spreadsheets have been with us for six years now, and in that time they have undergone two distinct evolutionary phases. Their history began with the one and only VisiCalc, designed for the Apple II, and although the program looks antediluvian by today's standards, in its time it was revolutionary.

title: Heart Transplant Patient Recovering Very Well'
description: Mary Lund, who lived for 45 days with an artificial heart beating in her chest, was alert and smiling today after receiving a human heart transplant and had a chance for ''a near-normal life,'' her doctors said.

title: THE WORLDS OF A COSMIC CASTAWAY
description: COLLECTED POEMS 1948-1984 By Derek Walcott. 516 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: ANALYSIS SHOWS CONSUMERS UNION IS 50
description: FIFTY years ago, a pair of women's stockings sold for 50 cents, and in those frugal Depression years a woman could buy just one, at 25 cents - and Consumers Union magazine, in its first issue, told its customers which brand was best.

title: THE CHALLENGER'S FATE, THE SHUTTLES' FUTEURE
description: THE fireball that brought death to the seven crew members of the shuttle Challenger high in the blue sky near Cape Canaveral has left the future of the American space endeavor in doubt. The shuttles would fly again, but when? Space would be explored, but how fast and by what means?

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
SPANISH ARTISTS TAKE THEIR PLACE ON THE WORLD SCENE
description: One of the several achievements of the two exhibitions of Spanish photography now in New York is to convince us that such a thing as Spanish photography actually exists.
