The larger exhibition, at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, through Feb. 16, is entitled ''Idas y Caos: Trends in Spanish Photography, 1920-1945,'' and covers all types of Spanish photography from avant-garde art to advertising. The smaller exhibition, at the Spanish Institute, 684 Park Avenue between 68th and 69th Streets, through Feb. 28, is entitled ''Arcadian Images: The Spanish Landscape Through Pictorialist Photography,'' and concentrates on poetic art photography in the turn-of-the-century style.

title: DIAGNOSING A PERFECT FIT FOR SLAM
description: Bridge-players as a group are interested in probabilities, even if they are not directly related to bidding and play.

title: CALIFORNIA PHILOSOPHIZING
description: THE LIFE AND THOUGHT OF JOSIAH ROYCE By John Clendenning. Illustrated. 447 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $27.50. BRILLIANT, argumentative and prolific, Josiah Royce was a leading member of Harvard University's philosophy department during its legendary golden age. In the early years of the 20th century, Royce and his colleagues, who included such men as George Herbert Palmer, William James and George Santayana, first brought American philosophy to international notice. When Royce died in 1916, he was eulogized as one of the major philosophers of his time.

title: SCHOOL'S TENANTS OPPOSE SALE
description: PLANS for the Harborfields School District to sell the Little Plains Elementary School, closed in 1983, to a developer have run into opposition from a local taxpayers' association and groups that rent the building.

title: THEATER: 'RESTORATION,' REVISED, AT ARENA STAGE 12>
description: Edward Bond, an English claimant to the mantle of Bertolt Brecht, is distinguished by his historical perspective and his social awareness. In his plays, a scrutiny of the past enables us to comprehend injustices of the present - and vice versa. In pursuit of cross-cultural parallels, his work intentionally strikes anachronistic notes, as in ''Restoration,'' a musical that he wrote in collaboration with the composer Nick Bicat.

title: INFORMER IN PERSICO TRIAL TESTIFIES ON RESTAURANT EXTORTION
description: The trial of eight reputed members of the Colombo crime organization entered a new phase last week as prosecutors presented evidence of purported extortion from restaurants and union kickback schemes. The evidence was gathered by an informer whom Federal authorities set up in a bogus pasta-importing business.

title: AGENCY RELEASES PHOTOS OF 'PLUME'
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration tonight released videotape and still photographs showing what it described as an ''unusual plume'' forming on the right-side booster rocket of the space shuttle Challenger about 14 seconds before the craft exploded.

title: WEIGHT WATCHING BY FLORIDA POLICE
description: KEVIN KILLORAN was 5 feet 9 inches and weighed 180 pounds when he joined the Florida Highway Patrol 12 years ago, but his weight climbed. Supervisors warned him that unless it dropped to patrol standards, he faced dismissal.

title: MYSTERY ON THE OST-WEST EXPRESS
description: It seemed the simplest of requests. All we wanted to do was take the train from one European city to another. On a continent where rail travel is not merely a convenience but also a way of life, what could be easier than getting from Berlin to Moscow?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 3 IMMIGRANTS FROM THE CITY AFTER spending most of their lives in New York City, three new residents of Long Island - Missy, Rasputin and Skinny - are adjusting quite well to suburban life.

title: VICTIMS OF NERVE DISEASE ORGANIZE
description: WHEN Carol A. Barker of Lisbon wrote to newspapers around New England asking to hear from people who have, as she does, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, a dentist telephoned to say he had never heard of any such dental disease.

title: SOME SEARCH STREETS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have included money found on the streets of New York City and saved to help the homeless, the ill and the despairing.

title: VIDEOGENIC WINNER IN ORCHID HANDICAP
description: Videogenic, plucked from a claiming race at Belmont Park last summer, won her eighth and richest stakes race since then with an impressive 1 1/4-length score in the $247,400 Orchid Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: NETS DEFEAT HAWKS WITH RALLY, 108-100
description: For the first quarter and for part of the second quarter tonight, the Nets stood and watched Dominique Wilkins overpower them with jump shots, slam dunks and one-handed pump shots.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIA HUNGARICA ENSEMBLE
description: IT sometimes seems as though every established musical performer feels that he must now turn to conducting. The temptations of such a move are obvious, but so are the risks.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: THE CHANGING MAZE. By Zilpha Keatley Snyder. Illustrated by Charles Mikolaycak. Macmillan. $12.95. (Ages 7 to 10) In a valley west of the Ragged Hills there is a maze, and Hugh, a shepherd boy, has been warned away from it by his granny.

title: EUROPEANS MIND MANNERS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Carolyn Koke Married To Mark David Allen
description: Carolyn Denise Koke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Koke of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Mark David Allen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart T. Allen, also of Wilmington. The Rev. Dr. Adam Lewis performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, in Greenville, Del.

title: SALVADORANS NAME WOMEN INC ASE ON ALIEN SMUGGLING
description: Three Salvadorans, witnesses at the trial of 11 religious leaders here on charges of smuggling aliens into the United States, have testified that one of the defendants helped them enter the country through a hole in the fence on the Mexican border.

title: Allen Saunders Dies; 'Mary Worth' Creator
description: Allen Saunders, a cartoonist who created the ''Mary Worth'' and ''Steve Roper'' comic strips, has died at the age of 86.

title: CONTINENTAL, HOLD THE SURPRISES
description: FOR the City Lites Cafe in Plainview to evoke the atmosphere of a contemporary, stylish, big-city cafe, some redecorating would be necessary.

title: TURNING MCGRAW-HILL UPSIDE DOWN
description: WHENEVER Joe Dionne wanders through the myriad offices of McGraw-Hill Inc., he sees lots of paper. There are, after all, the thousands of books, somewhere near 6,000 new titles a year. There are the magazines (Business Week, Byte, Coal Age) and newsletters - 64 of them. He sees the Standard & Poor's stock reports. Shepard's legal citations. The F.W. Dodge construction reports. All that paper. That's what bothers Joe Dionne.

title: Lyng Nominated For Farm Post
description: Since John R. Block declared that he was resigning as Secretary of Agriculture, the name of Richard L. Lyng, who was California's agriculture director when Ronald Reagan was Governor, had been bandied about as a prospective replacement. But the nomination was apparently held up by Republicans who argued that it made better political sense to have a Midwesterner running things in an election year, when Democrats are certain to blame Republicans for the farmers' many woes.

title: A 'RAINBOW WARD' WITH CLOUDS
description: Mount Pleasant's commercial district is not large, but it is worldly. Main Street of this northwest Washington neighborhood, about two miles from the White House, includes an African restaurant, the Militant Bookstore and a Southern-style barbecue establishment owned by a man from Korea.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Dec. 15 On Language column (''Dishing the Full Plate,'' by William Safire), Michael Fuchs was misidentified. He is chairman and chief executive officer of Home Box Office.

title: IS CARE IN OUR HOSPITALS BETTER NOW OR WORSE?
description: MANY hours of my life have been spent observing hospitals as a visitor. I am amazed at how things change as the years go by. As the scientific prowess advances, so does the confusion.

title: Tide Floods Venice On Eve of Carnival
description: The third-worst flood tide of the century swamped Venice today on the eve of the opening of its carnival.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press article and the accompanying headline in Sports Pages yesterday about the European figure skating championships incorrectly identified the nationality of Jozef Sabovcik, the men's winner. He is from Czechoslovakia.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CHOCOLATE RENDEZVOUS
description: Chocolates Plus, in the Rye Ridge Plaza, has donated fruits dipped in chocolate. Broker's Confectioners in Mohegan Lake will send along chocolate roses. Paron Chocolates of Scarsdale will prepare some of their special chocolate popcorn, and Victor's Cookies, in The Galleria in White Plains, will have plenty of its chocolate chunk cookies on hand.

title: A BIT OF ITALY
description: A 22-story mixed-use building - with a name that is Italian and an interior decor to match - is going up at 157 East 32d Street in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan.

title: ELIOT WAS WRONG: JANUARY IS THE CRUELEST MONTH
description: As January moview go in any year - and they go pretty far in all directions at once - it would be difficult to top Rene Feret's ''Mystery of Alexina'' for unexpected, completely unintentional comedy portrayed with such sobersided solemnity.

title: Emily Hopkins Is Married
description: Emily Jane Hopkins and Clayton Clee Elliott Jr., who received M.B.A. degrees from Harvard University, were married yesterday in Van Buren, Ark., at the home of Mrs. Glen Eugene Hopkins, mother of the bride.

title: LONG ISLAND'S LANDFILLS NEED TO BE MORE DISCRIMINATING
description: Last fall, Attorney General Robert Abrams sent undercover agents in a battered van to check security at sanitary landfills around New York State. They took with them cans and drums of what actually was water but might have been one of the toxic substances ordinary dumps are not allowed to accept. The investigators said they found the gates protected by little more than an honor system as leaky as the landfills themselves.

title: ILL LOUISVILLE COACH PHONES IN A VICTORY
description: Louisville, playing as Coach Denny Crum watched from home with the flu, routed U.C.L.A. today, 91-72. Crum followed the game on television and kept in contact with his bench via a telephone hookup. His calls were received by Jerry May, the trainer, who relayed Crum's orders to the assistant coaches, Bobby Dotson and Wade Houston.

title: HOMOSEXUAL COUPLE FILE SUIT
description: A homosexual couple from whose home a foster child was removed by the state last year have filed suit against state officials in an effort to overturn a policy that virtually bars such couples from serving as foster parents.

title: BOSS AS DOCTOR: REPLIES
description: The article ''When the Boss Becomes Your Doctor'' (Jan. 5) -which described the increasing participation of companies in health care decisions through tighter management of health insurance programs -elicited an unusual number of responses. What follows is a sampling.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: New Togs for Toddlers And the Older Young Cottontails, a Larchmont source since 1983 for natural fiber clothing for infants and children, moved one block north on Palmer Avenue in October and added a full range of domestic and European children's shoes and girls' and boys' clothing in sizes 7 to 14. The current nearly storewide winter sale drops prices 25 to 50 percent until Feb. 22, including some gift items and selected parenting and children's books.

title: THE ESSENTIAL ROLE OF MANUFACTURERS
description: ON Jan. 7, Jobs for Connecticut's Future, a private study group, made its report on where the jobs will be over the next 10 years. It forecasts a shift to a greater reliance on service industries and further away from manufacturing, and it recommends job training and retraining so that the labor force can keep up with changes in the economy.

title: TEACHERS LOOK PAST THE TRAGEDY OF THE SHUTTLE
description: WHEN Robert Mellette, a New Haven teacher, arrived at his school last Wednesday, students held out their hands to touch him. ''If things had gone differently,'' he said, ''I would have gone.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is entirely fitting that this pilgrimage should begin here. Today we hear him still pleading with the world, 'Conquer hate by love, untruth by truth, violence by suffering.' '' -Pope John Paul II, at Mohandas K. Gandhi memorial near New Delhi.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDALLIC ART MOVES TO THE FORE
description: Emerging from years in the shadows, the Society of Medalists seems ready to reassert itself as a major force for furthering the cause of medallic art. It has served notice with its latest issue: a stunning new medal by sculptor Donald DeLue.

title: LINDENAUER ENDORSED A COMPANY PROSECUTORS SAY PAID HIM BRIBES
description: The deputy director of New York City's Parking Violations Bureau wrote a letter in 1983 enthusiastically recommending a collection agency that Federal investigators charge had been paying him bribes.

title: Bad Intentions
description: The question was not whether Petty Officer 3d Class Mitchell T. Garraway Jr. fatally stabbed Lieut. James K. Sterner aboard a Navy frigate last June.

title: REBOUNDING AT 37 TO REFIND YOUTH
description: DEEP in the nights of his wilderness years, Gary Franks would dream of the game he loves and wake with the knowledge that he had thrown it all away.

title: HOW MUCH LONGER CAN WE MAKE THE PAYMENTS
description: MOUNTAINOUSrr Federal budget deficits, a burst of highly leveraged corporate takeovers, a vast expansion in second mortgages and consumer debt and fears about the possibility of default by third world debtors have prompted widespread concern that the economy has become dangerously dependent on borrowed money. In the last five years total debt has risen markedly faster than the gross national product. If the trend continues, by 1995 there will be about $2.25 of debt for each dollar of G.N.P., up from about $1.60 today.

title: BUSBY DAYTONA LEADER
description: The Porsche 962 driven by Jim Busby of Newport Beach, Calif., Darin Brassfield of Los Gatos, Calif., Jochen Mass of Monaco and the Englishman Derek Warwick led after four hours of the Daytona 24-hour endurance race today.

title: Women as Targets
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCKTON STUDENTS END TRIP
description: SIX Stockton State College students - five men and a woman - returned from Nicaragua last month unscathed and moved after helping peasants there harvest a coffee crop. The experience, they say, will stay with them a lifetime.

title: CITY REPORT SHOWS IMPROVEMENTS IN SERVICES BUT INCREASE IN CRIME
description: Subway crime declined, ambulance response times improved and congested city traffic traveled at a faster clip in the first four months of the new fiscal year, according to the Mayor's preliminary management report.

title: WHY NOT RETIRE AT COLLEGE?
description: DO you remember college as the best years of your life? The fact is, many of us do, and we feel as if we rushed too quickly into what seemed to be the adult world - marriage and/or a job. If we had it to do over again, a lot us would spend a little more time in school inquiring into the nature of things. Things like the world and ourselves.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CHILDHOOD AND SOCIETY, by Erik H. Erikson. (Norton, $7.95; cloth, $19.95.) Erik H. Erikson's first book ''emphasizes the importance of early frustrations and leniencies in the development of adult attitudes, anxieties and actions,'' our reviewer, Marian Rayburn Brown, wrote in 1950. ''Childhood and Society,'' which eventually was to gain a worldwide audience, ''reflects a healthy trend in psychiatry, psychoanalysis and child development,'' Mrs. Brown said. Basic Books has reissued Jerome Kagan's 1984 study of child development, THE NATURE OF THE CHILD ($10.95). Daniel Goleman said in these pages that Mr. Kagan ''elegantly blends intellectual history, anthropology and philosophy with his consideration of psychological issues.'' WHITE NOISE, by Don DeLillo. (Elisabeth Sifton/ Penguin, $5.95.) Don DeLillo's eighth novel is the story of Jack Gladney, a professor of Hitler studies at a small Middle Western college, who is evacuated along with his family when their community is threatened by toxic fumes after an industrial accident.

title: MITTERRAND MAY BE FACING SOME CHECKS AND BALANCES
description: France's republics have always had an unsettled quality, and the campaign for the legislative elections March 16 has made it apparent that the latest, the Fifth Republic, is not much different. French Presidents have dominated domestic and foreign policy for 25 years. But if the polls are to be believed, President Francois Mitterrand may end up much less in command. The strong role established by Charles de Gaulle in 1958 may change so radically as to suggest a return to practices and instability associated with the Third Republic (1871 to 1946) and the Fourth.

title: DRILL FIGHT: WILL U.S. OR SUFFOLK PREVAIL?
description: THE opening act in a constitutional confrontation pitting the Federal Government and the Long Island Lighting Company against New York State and Suffolk County is set to be played out this week in Federal court on Long Island.

title: A LITTLE LIFE IN THAT DEAD BUDGET
description: The President's week, though delayed by space tragedy, has finally arrived and it will start with cheers. On Tuesday night, Mr. Reagan will troop the line of applauding Congressmen, climb to the podium and describe the State of his Union. The applause will resound into the night.

title: THE CHINA TRADE
description: China has hired Elliot L. Richardson, the former Secretary of Defense, Attorney General and United Nations representative, and Edward W. Furia, a Seattle-based government relations and trade consultant, to conduct a comprehensive study of its commercial relations with the United States aimed at dramatically increasing trade.

title: Uganda Swears In A Leader and Buries Its Dead
description: Youweri Museveni seized control of Uganda's main cities last week and promised what new Ugandan leaders usually promise: law and order now, democracy later, rewards for those who cooperate, defeat for those who do not. But the 42-year-old guerrilla leader, his hand on a Bible while he was sworn in as President, insisted that he would provide ''a fundamental change'' and ''not a mere change of guards.''

title: Denis Kemball-Cook, Former Shell Oil Chief
description: Denis B. Kemball-Cook, a retired president and chief executive officer of the Shell Oil Company, died Thursday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: SEATTLE REDEVELOPMENT PLAN AIMS AT DOWNTOWN
description: For decades ''the city couldn't decide what to do'' about the downtown, as one proponent of redevelopment put it. Now, Seattle has made up its mind.

title: DOCTORS WHO GET AWAY WITH KILLING AND MAIMING MUST BE STOPPED
description: American doctors are killing and maiming thousands of patients every year - and, for the most part, they are getting away with it. It is time that we in government, and the medical profession, came up with some remedies for this national tragedy.

title: AT PORT-AU-PRINCE MARKET, 'EMOTIONS ARE HIGH'
description: The market woman leaned over the counter of her dry-goods store and confided in a low voice, ''He's got to straighten up - or it's the army.''

title: OUT OF AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
SHRUBS CAN ADD COLOR TO WINTER SCENES
description: WHILE shrubs are smaller than trees, and therefore play a less dominant role in the landscape, many of them have special characteristics that create interest in the winter garden.

title: F.H.A. CASE RECALLS BUSHWICK IN 70'S
description: In a five-year period in the late 1960's and early 70's, the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn was transformed from a neatly maintained community of wood houses into what often approached a no man's land of abandoned buildings, empty lots, drugs and arson.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE PAPER CRANE Written and illustrated by Molly Bang. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $13. (Ages 5 to 8) MOLLY BANG'S newest book derives its charm from illustrations composed of intricate paper constructions, yarn and fabric.

title: SCHOLASTIC DEFICIENCIES
description: Three of its basketball players are facing rape charges, and now the University of Minnesota athletic department has some more bad news to contend with - a report that male Gopher athletes have the lowest graduation rate in the Big Ten. According to figures compiled by the Big Ten last fall and disclosed by The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, only 28 percent of the scholarship athletes who entered Minnesota between 1973 and 1978 had graduated within five years.

title: THE CORRUPTION SCANDAL: MANES MYSTERY IS HUB OF 8 INQUIRIES
description: To investigators, it began as a $5,000 payoff in the men's room of a restaurant. To the public, it started with the mysterious slashing of a well-known public official, Donald R. Manes, the Borough President and Democratic party leader of Queens.

title: EAST vs. WEST IN LITHUANIA: RISING TEMPERS AT A WRITERS' MEETING
description: DURING the three weeks I was in the Soviet Union, three different Americans told me the following joke, although each of them altered details in order to individualize it. In the unlikely event a Russian had related it, I doubt he would have taken the trouble. According to the common kernel of the story, a Russian is showing an American visitor the Moscow subway, of which the city is quite justifiably proud. ''Look at the spacious main corridors,'' he says, ''experience the swiftness of the escalators, note the many differences in decoration when you change stations, the painted glass inserts in the columns, the mosaics in the small domes that vary and enliven the concourse ceilings, the cleanliness of every floor and stairway, the quality of workmanship and materials, the statues of Lenin and other notables that enrich the way - for nothing is too good for the workers.''

title: THE PERILS OF A SWITCH IN FED POLICY
description: THIS is shaping up as an excellent year for bashing the Federal Reserve Board.

title: TESTS THAT SPARE ANIMALS REPORTED
description: New procedures are emerging that can reduce the number of animals required to test the safety of products, but the sharp reductions in the use of such animals sought by advocates of animal rights would have ''dangerous'' consequences for the nation's health, a Congressional report said today.

title: Data Bank February 2, 1986

DINING OUT;
COUNTY GETS A NEW JAPANESE SPOT
description: JAPANESE food has evoked such felicitous response in the county that there seem never to be enough Japanese restaurants to satisfy the demand for this cuisine. Sushi and sashimi have become so popular that, except for steak houses, there isn't a Japanese restaurant in the area without a sushi bar. Sushi Kin is the most recent entrant - equiped with kitchen as well as sushi counter - and it is a spot worth knowing about. A couple of Korean dishes liven up the usual Japanese restaurant menu, and although there are few offerings to criticize, in general, the products from the sushi bar impressed us more than did the kitchen's efforts.

title: Ami Trauber Engaged To Susan Beth Kaplan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Kaplan of New York and Lords Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Beth Kaplan to Ami Trauber, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Trauber of Tel Aviv. An April wedding is planned.

title: HIS PERFORMANCES ARE PRESERVED ON DISKS
description: Jascha Heifetz has not played in public since 1972. Yet he remains a vital presence in the music world, and the standard by which all violinists are measured. Fortunately, the Heifetz career is superbly documented on disk, and most of his important recordings remain available.

title: OUT OF AFRICA
description: To the Editor: It is astonishing to read an article entitled ''Kenya Seen Through Writers' Eyes'' (Travel, Jan. 12) that does not mention a single indigenous Kenyan writer. Among the leading Kenyan writers are Ngugi wa Thiong'o, Grace Ogot and Meja Mwangi.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Four of us would like to charter a sailboat, with skipper, in the Hawaiian Islands or in the South Pacific, possibly Samoa or Tahiti. Could you tell me what the best time of year is to do this and the names of places from which to charter? -S. E. M., New York Answer:According to experienced sailors, the strong currents, lack of safe anchorages and limited availability of boats in Hawaii make those islands unattractive for sailboat chartering. Much of the activity there is day sailing close to shore. In the South Pacific, sailing is popular the year round, but more rain is likely from December through March.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
FEBRUARY IS THE CRUELEST MONTH
description: FEBRUARY, not April, is the cruelest month. It is the longest. By the calendar, of course, it's the shortest: Thirty days hath September, April, June and November, February has twenty-eight alone, All the rest have thirty-one; Excepting leap year - that's the time When February's days are twenty-nine.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Pine Lane Winter, Clarence Center, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (716) 741-3688.

title: POPE PAYS TRIBUTE TO INDIA'S APOSTLE OF NONVIOLENCE
description: Pope John Paul II, opening a 10-day visit to India, proclaimed his respect today for all the country's religions and offered a stirring tribute to the memory of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

title: SPORTS' INTEGRAL ROLE WITH A COMMUNITY
description: LAST week Chicago celebrated. Its team won the Super Bowl.

title: DANCE: RICHARD MULCAHY PERFORMS HIS 'ASPHODEL'
description: INTERESTING things happened in the four works that the Richard Mulcahy Dance Company presented Wednesday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. But Mr. Mulcahy was not always able to tie events together in a choreographically effective manner.

title: PAINTING ON THE EDGE OF MADNESS
description: TO A VIOLENT GRAVE An Oral Biography of Jackson Pollock. By Jeffrey Potter. Illustrated. 303 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: On Language; Buzz Off, Interceptor
description: ''I AM OUTRAGED!'' said the caller.

title: NEW CASSETTES: KUROSAWA, DUMAS AND PROKOFIEV
description: Rashomon Starring Toshiro Mifune, Machiko Kyo, Masayuki Mori, Takashi Shimura; directed by Akira Kurosawa, 1950 Embassy Home Entertainment 87 minutes. $29.95 With ''Rashomon,'' Akira Kurosawa drew international attention both to himself and to the postwar Japanese cinema.

title: PLAN UNFOLDS TO INTEGRATE SCHOOLS IN YONKERS
description: DR. JOAN M. RAYMOND, the Yonkers School Superintendent, decided last week that it was time to quit researching and to start writing.

title: Robin Gordon Is Wed To Stephen J. Apple
description: Robin L. Gordon, a daughter of Dr. Ellen Gordon Adams of Fort Lee, N.J., and Edward S. Gordon of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen J. Apple, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Apple of Harrisburg, Pa. Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald, the bride's cousin, and Cantor Sherwood Goffin performed the ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Miss Mason Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Kristen Ann Mason to Richard T. Buchanan has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Alton Mason of Williamsville, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Buchanan of Madison, N.J., and Westport, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: Questions For a Scientist
description: As a scientist, I felt that Ronald N. Kahn made some important points about our cultural isolation (''The Isolated Scientist,'' About Men, Jan. 5). But as a biologist, I have noted additional tensions, in my interactions with lay persons, which are not a burden to astrophysicists such as Dr. Kahn.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. URGED TO AVOID BUDGET SNARE
description: Congressional Republicans were warned today that they would be hurt in the 1986 election if they got bogged down in debates over cutting the budgets of individual programs like Amtrak, Medicare or student loans.

title: Classical Music
description: Music is an art that exists as sound; so, for performers to realize a composer's intentions - at least if the composer isn't present in person or on records to convey his intentions orally or aurally - they must read printed notation. But the farther back we venture into music's past, the less sure we become about how music should actually sound.

title: Welfare Added to State of the Union
description: For some time now, President Reagan and his aides have been planning a broad, thematic State of the Union Message rather than one that dwells on specific legislative proposals. Last week White House officials said the address, postponed to this Tuesday instead of last because of the space shuttle disaster, will also include a discussion of two major policy initiatives. One is revision of the social welfare system, the other the expansion of Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, to cover the costs of catastrophic health care.

title: HOW DOES MY GARDEN GROW?
description: THE sky is sullen gray, seamed at the edges with bare branches. The lawn looks like a drowned rat with the mange. The flower beds show only a few green sparks, where the swordblade leaves of irises shiver. I see all that, and yet I don't. Above that mangy lawn, beneath the bare oak trees, I see a shimmer of blossom: azaleas here, the new Chinese dogwoods there. Maybe a rhododendron over here; there's a gorgeous new variety in a catalogue that has white blossoms, faintly pink at the throat. Does that leave room for an evergreen? Is there an evergreen that will thrive in the oak trees' shade?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Westchester Weekly on Jan. 19 about Pace University opening a center in Mount Kisco incorrectly quoted Herbert Falk, acting public information director. Mr. Falk said that ''there was no institution of higher learning in Mount Kisco, which is the hub of northern Westchester,'' before Pace opened its center there.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PROGRAMS ON AIDS The Long Wharf Theater in New Haven is the setting today for a forum on acquired immune deficiency syndrome from 2 to 4 P.M. The program was organized in conjunction with the theater's current production, ''The Normal Heart'' by Larry Kramer, a play dealing with the disease known as AIDS.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Long Island Weekly on Jan. 26 incorrectly implied that Dr. Elizabeth Bourque, a toxicologist, appeared at a Middle Island school district meeting as an employee of the State Board of Health. She said she spoke as a private citizen and not as a representative of state government.

title: General's Resignation Accepted by Honduras
description: The Honduras Armed Forces Superior Council today accepted the resignation of the armed forces commander, Gen. Walter Lopez Reyes, even though he said he had changed his mind and wanted to stay.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Steve Yzerman, a 20-year-old, third-year center who had appeared in 211 consecutive games for the Detroit Red Wings, can start thinking about starting his second string. He broke a collarbone in a game against the St. Louis Blues Friday night and will be out six weeks. . . . Bill Campbell, a 37-year-old free-agent relief pitcher who played for the St. Louis Cardinals last season, signed a one-year contract with the Detroit Tigers. . . Digger Phelps, the Notre Dame basketball coach, has been named to coach one of the four men's teams at the United States Olympic Festival this summer. Other coaches are Bill Foster of South Carolina, Gary Williams of Boston College and Ladell Anderson of Brigham Young. . . Rod Hundley, the former player who is a broadcaster for the Utah Jazz, was given a five-year contract by the club.

title: LIFE IN THE SLOW LANE: BORING IS BEAUTIFUL
description: I EXTOL the ordinary, delight in the dull, applaud the uneventful. By me, boring is beautiful. Life styles of the rich and famous leave me cold. Show me someone with curtains on the garage windows and a pad with a working pen next to the telephone and I'm impressed.

title: '85 TORNADO DEATH TOLL DOWN
description: The most devastating outbreak of tornadoes in more than a decade struck the United States last May, but the overall 1985 death toll in such storms remained slightly below normal, the Government has reported.

title: High Court Upholds a Record Fine for Exxon
description: The Supreme Court declined last week to take up an appeal by Exxon Corporation of a lower court's ruling that Exxon had overcharged its customers for oil pumped from a Texas field in the 1970's, when an array of now-expired oil-price controls were on the books. The judgment means that Exxon is required to refund more than $2 billion.

title: Alice Darlington Becomes the Bride Of Timothy G. Cutler, a Stockbroker
description: Alice Bontecou Darlington, a daughter of Mrs. Fred E. Brown of Harding Township, N.J., and Lake Placid, N.Y., and Peter Darlington of New York and Lake Placid, was married in New York yesterday to Timothy Griswold Cutler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hinchman Cutler Jr. of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, of which the bride's grandfather the late Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington was rector.

title: LEADER SAYS NO CANDIDATE 'OWNS' THE RIGHT
description: After three days of being courted by most of the 1988 Republican Presidential hopefuls, the Conservative Political Action Conference concluded its annual meeting today without rallying around a single contender.

title: CREW DID NOT TRY TO SEPARATE ORBITER
description: Space agency officials said today that the Challenger's pilots made no attempt to separate their orbiter from the flaming rockets that exploded after liftoff Tuesday, killing all seven people aboard.

title: A MAN FOR COLD SEASONS
description: SHACKLETON By Roland Huntford. Illustrated. 774 pp. New York: Atheneum. $29.95.

title: STRANGE SEASON PUZZLES OLSON
description: AS Billy Olson put it, it has been ''a pretty unusual year.''

title: Advertising; Angotti Agency Lands Wild Turkey Account
description: Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, which may have been the first New York ad agency formed in 1985, has started its second year with probably its biggest account so far: Wild Turkey whisky from Austin Nichols & Company. Billings could be as much as $9 million a year.

title: GONZALEZ GAINS FLYWEIGHT TITLE
description: Paul Gonzalez, the 1984 Olympic light flyweight champion, won a unanimous 12-round decision from Alonso Strongbow today to win the North American Boxing Federation flyweight title in his third professional fight.

title: Caracas Weighs Citgo Deal
description: Venezuela's national oil company and the Southland Corporation are ''seriously'' discussing ways for Venezuela to acquire a share in a major refinery in Louisiana owned by the Citgo Petroleum Corporation, a Southland subsidiary, but no agreement has been reached, Southland officials said yesterday.

title: TRIAL ON POPE'S SHOOTING REACHES DECISIVE PHASE
description: The eight-month-old trial of seven men accused of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981 has moved into its decisive stage, presenting the court with an array of difficult decisions.

title: STAGE: STEVEN WRIGHT AT THE BEACON
description: STEVEN WRIGHT brings to stand-up comedy a masterly synthesis of ideas that in the past have been more closely associated with other areas of culture. Specifically, he is a yuppie, a minimalist and a science fiction-minded absurdist rolled into one. Unleashing his carefully measured barrage of pithy reflections, most of which are just one or two lines long, his insinuating, articulate drawl epitomizes coolness. Eschewing the lowbrow, he is man who values words and exerts a powerful creative control over the shadows his imagination throws up.

title: Advertising; Arby's Moving Lobster Task
description: The management of the AFA Services Corporation in Atlanta has done some rethinking about lobster.

title: Aqueduct Pick Six Returns $189,558
description: Favorites lost in the third through the eighth races at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: C.I.A. Is Too Modest About Sponsoring Books
description: To the Editor:

title: HAITI TOWN TURNS OUT FOR PROTEST
description: In quieter days, President Jean-Claude Duvalier used Route Nationale No. 1 as a test track for his sports cars.

title: ZOELLER LEADING BY FIVE STROKES
description: The A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am may have concluded for all practical purposes this afternoon. At least it appeared to be over, as Fuzzy Zoeller gained a five-shot lead over Payne Stewart with one round left in the rain-delayed tournament on the windy Pacific Coast.

title: An Unorthodox Host or a Columbia Party
description: The party is billed as the ''largest gathering ever held for Columbia and Barnard graduates sponsored by the Columbia and Barnard Clubs.'' Both of its hosts have ties to the campus.

title: Catholic Bishops to Restudy Position on Nuclear Weapons
description: Developments in the nuclear arms race have prompted the nation's Roman Catholic bishops to restudy a pastoral letter that conditionally accepted the concept of deterrence.

title: OUTDOORS: DECEPTIVE INSTRUMENTS
description: PREPARATION for pursuit of the trout gathers impetus at this time of year, as winter-weary anglers begin creating the artificial flies with which they will attempt - when buds have burst and the soft winds of the fifth month caress the awakening meadows - to deceive the fish they hold in such high esteem.

title: COMEDY: BILL COSBY REFLECTS ON AMERICAN LIFE
description: LAST Thursday evening on television, Bill Cosby as Dr. Heathcliff Huxtable was watching bemusedly as his son prepared for a high-school examination on ''Macbeth'' by not reading the play. Every week, with love and exasperation, Mr. Cosby's character confronts - and resolves - family quandaries. For a very good reason, ''The Cosby Show'' is the most popular television series in America.

title: Soviet Official Visiting Iran
description: Georgi M. Korniyenko, the Soviet Union's First Deputy Foreign Minister, arrived in Teheran today for a three-day official visit. Iran's official press agency, in a radio report monitored here, said Mr. Korniyenko urged increased political contacts between Iran and the Soviet Union.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANNIVERSARY The city's Department of Cultural Affairs is celebrating the 10th anniversary of its designation as New York's official arts arm, with a new exhibition in its redesigned one-flight-up City Gallery in the agency's headquarters, the former Huntington Hartford Museum at 2 Columbus Circle (974-1150).

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 3, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Advisory Committee on Science and Technology - 11 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Channel-Charter Suit
description: A lawsuit filed by New York-based Channel Refinery Inc. over an agreement by the Charter International Corporation to sell its Houston oil refinery to Hill Petroleum, a subsidiary of Phibro-Salomon Inc. of New York, for $30 million has been voluntarily discontinued, a lawyer for Channel said on Friday.

title: MANILA VOTE PANEL ORDERS CLERGY NOT TO GIVE ADVICE ON THE ELECTION
description: In an apparent heightening of the confrontation between President Ferdinand E. Marcos and the Roman Catholic Church, the Government election commission has ordered the country's clergy not to offer political guidance to parishioners for the presidential election on Friday.

title: 2 BLACKS REACH MAYORAL RUNOFF IN NEW ORLEANS
description: With a majority of white voters showing that race is not an overriding factor, two black candidates advanced in elections Saturday to a runoff to succeed Ernest N. Dutch Morial as Mayor.

title: Constitution Rejects Strict Construction
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrow Air to Transport Personnel for the Navy
description: Arrow Air of Miami, the airline whose chartered jet crashed in December with 248 soldiers aboard, has received a new contract from the Air Force ''for long-range international air transportation service.''

title: CHICAGO SEES GAINS AGAINST GANGS
description: When 17-year-old Ben Wilson, a top-ranked high school basketball player, was robbed and shot near his high school in November 1984, his death focused public attention on the extent of street gang violence in Chicago.

title: OH, FOR THE GLORY OF SPENDING PAST
description: Three Democratic women in the House got a standing ovation from other House Democrats meeting here this weekend with their song to the tune of ''The Way We Were.'' The first verse went this way:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Laurie L. Horn Becomes Bride of Werner Boehm
description: Laurie Lea Horn, a vice president for mental health of the East Orange (N.J.) General Hospital, was married yesterday to Prof. Werner W. Boehm, distinguished visiting professor of social work at Seton Hall University. Rabbi Herman Cohen performed the ceremony at Woodlawn, a historic property on the campus of Douglass College of Rutgers University in New Brunswick. N.J.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO ORDER NEW NAVAL MOVES OFF LIBYA
description: The Reagan Administration has ordered two aircraft carrier battle groups to resume military maneuvers in the area of the Gulf of Sidra off the Libyan coast, a senior Government official said today.

title: AS PLAYERS GATHER, TIME IS FROZEN
description: GORDIE HOWE was near the end in 1980. It was just before the start of his twenty-third National Hockey League All-Star Game, spread over five decades. He had been around long enough to experience all the format changes the league sought to give its game more meaning.

title: NASA CONSIDERED SHUTTLE BOOSTERS IMMUNE TO FAILURE
description: The space shuttle Challenger's solid-fuel booster rockets were not equipped with sensors that could have warned of trouble because designers thought the boosters were ''not susceptible to failure,'' the head of the space agency said today.

title: No, You Can't Have It All
description: The beer commercial ''you can have it all'' sounds a kind of anthem for America's young, prosperous, upwardly mobile professionals who are supposed to typify their generation.

title: Change In South Africa
description: On Feb. 20, representatives of 30 Western banks will meet in London to discuss proposals for repayment of $13 billion owed them by South Africa. Last summer, with the country in turmoil, the banks refused to roll over the loans. Pretoria in turn suspended repayment. Now it wants the debt rescheduled. The American banks have said they first want to see a prospect of change in South Africa.

title: EFFORTS EXPANDED TO FIND WRECKAGE
description: The effort to find sunken wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger was expanded today after soundings from searchers located what were termed at least three large unidentified objects on the ocean floor near here.

title: 2 SENATE BILLS FOCUS ON STOLEN ART
description: A recent outbreak of art thefts has lent urgency to a legislative effort to fortify American museums and art collectors against what some of them say could become a flood of stolen-art claims by foreign countries.

title: PRINCE, WAGON TRAIN AND AN OUTHOUSE RACE CELEBRATE 150 YEARS OF TEXAS
description: As a tribute to his adopted state on the occasion of its 150th birthday and as an expression of his freedom, Vasile Bolos, a naturalized American citizen from Rumania, is walking the perimeter of Texas.

title: Advertising; D.D.B. Aide To Set Up Small Shop
description: IT seems that J. Roy Grace, vice chairman and executive creative director of the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group, is leaving the agency to set up his own shop, which will be dedicated to serving 10 - but not more than 10 - clients, the first of which has yet to appear.

title: ISRAELI CONCERN IS INCREASING OVER RELATIONS WITH EGYPT
description: The Israeli Government is becoming seriously concerned about its increasingly cold state of relations with Egypt, senior officials said today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When was the first National Hockey League All-Star Game played, who scored the goals and which team won?

title: IN CURRENT CITY HALL CRISIS, KOCH ADAPTS AGAIN TO HIS CRITIC'S VIEWPOINTS
description: The crisis now confronting City Hall has yielded a revealing byproduct: it has forced Mayor Koch to consider reforms he has either opposed, or declined to pursue, since he became the city's chief executive.

title: THIOKOL: CONTRACTOR AT BIGGEST RISK
description: Of all the space shuttle contractors, the company now facing the closest scrutiny, and the one with possibly the most to lose in terms of profits, is Morton Thiokol Inc.

title: MUSIC: TOWER CONCERTO
description: Joan Tower's successes as a composer have been far-flung of late, but she brought back a new piece over the weekend to what is nominally her home. Miss Tower teaches at Bard College, in Annandale-on-Hudson, and her Piano Concerto, subtitled ''Homage to Beethoven,'' had its first hearings Friday evening at Bard and Saturday night on the campus of Vassar College here.

title: 'VALENTINE'S REVENGE,' ADAPTATION FROM O. HENRY
description: WHEN public television's ''American Playhouse'' decides to be modest, it does so to a fault. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, the series is offering ''Valentine's Revenge,'' still another adapatation of the O. Henry short story about the professional safecracker named Jimmy Valentine. There is nothing dreadfully wrong with the production. In fact, if it were being presented as part of ''Wonderworks,'' a ''family viewing'' series, the hourlong drama would no doubt prove appealing to younger audiences. But fans of ''American Playhouse,'' accustomed to fare ranging from ''Go Tell It on the Mountain'' to ''Concealed Enemies,'' have every reason to demand something more challenging, something less safe.

title: U.S. Expected to Raise $13.2 Billion
description: This week's market for fixed-income securities will be dominated by the Treasury's $24 billion mid-quarter refunding operation, which will raise a record $13.2 billion in new cash for the Government.

title: KNICKS WIN DESPITE EWING'S 9
description: Something strange yet intriguing is happening to the Knicks. In their last two games, they have proved that they are indeed a team, a collection of talent that can overcome a sub-par performance by their dominating rookie center, Patrick Ewing. But what is more staggering is that tonight, before a hostile sellout crowd here at the Forum, they proved it against pro basketball's defending world champions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There have been ups and downs of Communism, but this is not that - it is an irreversible regression.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: E.E.C. Seeks Comecon Tie
description: The European Economic Community agreed Friday to resume negotiations with Comecon on establishing official relations between the two trade groups.

title: A Delay for McFarlane
description: Robert C. McFarlane's debut as a private citizen-public speaker is going to be delayed a little.

title: MUSIC: 'PARSIFAL' ACT II
description: RICHARD WAGNER conceived his operas as integral music dramas - loud, lengthy parables that would unfold gradually over the course of an evening. He avoided, for the most part, dividing his scores into pat arias and ensemble pieces, each complete with its own formal beginning, middle and end, preferring instead to shape a kinetic totality that would ebb and flow in unity with the psychology of the drama.

title: ALLY DEEP IN SHADOW OF MARCOS
description: The forgotten man in the current election campaign is the man who could well become the next president of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos's vice presidential running mate, Arturo M. Tolentino.

title: An Issue for Goldwater
description: In the sometimes bewildering, ever-changing Capital, it's comforting to find a few issues and people that are enduring there when you need something dependable to lean on. Senator Barry Goldwater, 77 years old and in the last year of his fifth and last term, is still resolutely bearing the burden of the Chinese Nationalists; just back from a world tour, he is hopping mad about what the United States is doing and not doing for Taiwan.

title: HUNGARY'S WESTERN-STYLE RETAIL GROUP
description: It is 7:30 P.M. one recent Thursday, late shopping night in Budapest. Downtown in the state-owned Corvin and Centrum department stores, customers pick quietly at racks of dowdy clothes, mostly from Hungary and other Eastern bloc countries.

title: PURCHASERS CITE UPTURN IN ACTIVITY LAST MONTH
description: The economy began the new year on a strong note, helped by expanded production and a surge in new orders, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.

title: RULING PARTY SAYS IT WON COSTA RICAN VOTE
description: With more than half the vote officially counted, the governing National Liberation Party took a commanding lead in the presidential election here today, and its candidate claimed victory tonight before a crowd of cheering supporters.

title: A CELEBRATION OF ABILITY, PLUS PIZAZZ
description: THEY are events that celebrate athletic achievement, a mid-winter gathering of the academy award winners of the ice rinks and hardwood floors. The theme of the National Hockey League and National Basketball Association all-star games is not defined so much in terms of victory and defeat as by their entertainment value. Was it boffo? Did the fans enjoy seeing all those shooting stars? Did they leave wanting more?

title: Go For It, Henry
description: This is the year in which famous people have been saying ''not me.''

title: Home for Greyhounds
description: Animal lovers who want to save an injured or retired race-track runner don't necessarily need a backyard big enough for a stable and a paddock. All it takes is a dollar a day and a leash.

title: C.I.A. DEFENDS CONTRAS' BEHAVIOR
description: A recently declassified Central Intelligence Agency report aimed at discrediting reports of Nicaraguan rebel atrocities denies that the rebels often slit the throats of captives.

title: Four Chaplains, a Symbol of Brotherhood
description: To the Editor:

title: The Military Doesn't Get Everything It Wants
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO QUESTIONS IF ESTIMATE BOARD IS REALLY NEEDED
description: Governor Cuomo, citing the widening investigations into allegations of corruption in New York City's government, called yesterday for a re-examination of the role of the City Board of Estimate.

title: U.S. Checks Atom Plant In Ohio After Quake
description: The building housing the reactor at the Perry nuclear power plant was not damaged by an earthquake Friday, but it was not yet known whether hairline cracks in walls and floors of some buildings at the site were caused by the earthquake or already existed, Murray R. Edelman, nuclear vice president of Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, said today.

title: Frates Stake in Kaiser
description: An investment group led by J. A. Frates, the Oklahoma investor, said on Friday that it had raised its stake in the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to almost 20 percent from 18.6 percent of the company's shares outstanding.

title: WORDEN DAY
description: Worden Day, an artist who specialized in woodcuts, died of cancer last Monday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. She was 71 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: Chief's Reputation Aids Guinness's Distillers Bid
description: Ernest W. Saunders, the chief executive of Guinness P.L.C., who is currently involved in the largest takeover bid in British history, has a reputation for his ability to turn around undermanaged business situations.

title: Cuomo, Koch Vow to Fight Tax Plan
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch vowed yesterday to oppose a United States Senator's proposal to reduce the amount of state and local taxes that taxpayers could deduct on their Federal income tax return.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1986
description: The Shuttle Inquiry

title: ARE MEN MORE OPEN WITH MEN?
description: FISHING trips. The golf course (and locker room). The men's club. Drinks at a neighborhood bar. These are some of the traditional settings for relationships among men. But how deep are those friendships, and how much of their feelings do men reveal to each other?

title: HARBOR SEALS ON AN ANNUAL VISIT BASK IN A CHILL LONG ISLAND WIND
description: By noon, the water temperature had crept close to 40 degrees, a chilly wind was gusting off the harbor and now and again the sun broke through gray clouds.

title: Florida Officials Seize Circus Animal for X-rays
description: Sheriff's deputies seized an animal with a single horn in the middle of its forehead from the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus Saturday and took it away for X-rays to determine if the circus violated a state law that prohibits the display of malformed or disfigured animals, or the advertisement of such shows.

title: Catching Up
description: Buddy Diliberto, the worst of his penance nearly complete, should be back on the air in a few days. Diliberto is the television broadcaster who created a stir in New Orleans during Super Bowl week with the unverified and erroneous report that Jim McMahon had referred to the city's women as ''sluts'' and to the population in general as ''ignorant.''

title: Miller of U.S.C. Injured in Game
description: Cheryl Miller of the University of Southern California, a three-time all-American, suffered a concussion and a neck strain Saturday during U.S.C.'s 89-67 victory over U.C.L.A.

title: Resorts' Casino Sale Reported
description: Officials of the U.S. Capital Corporation, a builder and marketer of condominiums, declined to comment yesterday on published reports that the company has reached a preliminary agreement to purchase an Atlantic City casino from Resorts International Inc. for about $300 million.

title: Transamerica Head Spurs Divestitures
description: If some analysts were surprised by the Transamerica Corporation's announcement last week that it plans to sell its car rental, airline and manufacturing businesses, they should not have been. Transamerica's president, chairman and chief executive officer, James R. Harvey, has made the company's transformation from a conglomerate to an insurance and financial services business his goal since taking over from John R. Beckett in 1981.

title: BENEFITS AND CUTBACKS AWAIT TAXPAYERS FILING '85 RETURNS
description: Continuing the trend of recent years, Americans will find a mixture of new tax benefits and cutbacks in some long-cherished tax breaks when they fill out their 1985 income tax returns.

title: SMALL COLLEGE GIVES TOP SCORER HIS BIG CHANCE
description: ZAM FREDRICK, Tony Murphy, Lawrence Butler and Larry Fogle all played basketball for small colleges in recent years. They all led the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I in scoring. Not too many people think about Zam and Tony and Lawrence and Larry anymore. They faded from the basketball scene after their college careers ended.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Basketball Tale
description: For more than 20 years now, a story has been drifting around Holyoke, Mass., to the effect that a local physician named George Gabler once introduced the game of basketball to a friend of his. What makes the story occasionally unsettling to the keepers of sports history is that it is set in the year 1885, and that the friend was none other than James Naismith, who by his own written account - indeed, by what has become a virtual-U.S.D.A. certified account - invented the game himself in neighboring Springfield six years later.

title: IS IT EAST OR WEST?
description: THIS is a confusing time for all of us.

title: Washington Watch; Machine Tools Divide Cabinet
description: IN one of its toughest trade cases, President Reagan's Cabinet is expected shortly to consider asking Japan to negotiate ''voluntary'' restraints on exports of machine tools to the United States.

title: Liechtenstein Women Vote for First Time
description: Women voted today for the first time in this tiny Alpine principality and helped return a conservative coalition to power in the 15-member Parliament, election officials said.

title: Icy Slalom Event Won by Yugoslav
description: Rok Petrovic of Yugoslavia, checking his speed on an icy course that knocked out more than half of the field today, won his third World Cup slalom victory of the season.

title: Capitals Win With 5 Goals in 3d Period
description: The defenseman Larry Murphy scored the winning goal with 1 minute 15 seconds left tonight as the Washington Capitals came back from a 4-0 deficit in the third period to score a 5-4 victory over the Whalers.

title: MAGIC ON COURT: PASS MASTER
description: FANTASIZE for a moment. You are an above-average guard in the National Basketball Association - about 6 feet 4 inches tall, with decent quickness and good defensive instincts. You are near midcourt, backpedaling as the opposition grabs a defensive rebound and quickly gets the ball to its point guard, who ignites a fast break. Here's the catch: leading the fast break is the most commanding playmaker in the game, Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: MERGER LAG IS LINKED TO DOUBTS ON TAX LAW
description: Uncertainly about proposed tax law changes has dramatically slowed merger and acquisition activity in recent months, according to investment bankers and tax experts.

title: Arrau Birthday Recital
description: The pianist Claudio Arrau will play four Beethoven sonatas - in D (Op. 10), in C (Op. 53, the ''Waldstein''), in E flat (Op. 81, ''Les Adieux'') and in F minor (Op. 57, the ''Appassionata'') - at Carnegie Hall on Saturday to celebrate his 83d birthday. Tickets, at $25, $22.50, $20 and $14 are available at the box office or by calling CarnegieCharge, 247-7800.

title: SKYLINES SHINE ACROSS THE MIDWEST
description: The first time Rhoda Mayerson saw the illuminated Central Trust Tower, she turned to her husband, who owned the building, and said that it looked like a giant music box.

title: Dr. Leslie Sanders, a Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Leslie A. Sanders and Dr. Barry Dashefsky were married yesterday at Temple Beth-El in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Bernhard Rosenberg performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbis Gerald Zelermyer and Juda Mintz.

title: Freedom and Feminism at the PEN Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Late Free Throws Help Georgetown
description: Michael Jackson, who usually plays in the shadow of Georgetown's outstanding front line, took advantage of Louisiana State's sagging defense to score 20 points and hand out 11 assists today in leading the Hoyas to a 74-72 victory over the Tigers.

title: NORTH SEA OIL KEEPS FLOWING
description: From this fishing-village-turned-oil-town on Scotland's misty east coast, the roughnecks and the rigs set out to pump the riches from Britain's North Sea oil fields.

title: What Happens When Mothers Get Food
description: The WIC (Women-Infants-Children) program, which provides diet supplements and checkups for poor pregnant and nursing women and their children, has long had its champions, but Dr. David Rush of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York was not among them. Previous studies of WIC, he says, were of limited use in judging the program's overall value.

title: Advertising; Peugeot to Be Seeking A Successor to O.&M.
description: Ogilvy & Mather announced Friday that it was resigning the account of Peugeot Motors of America.

title: Deposed Army Chief Leaves Honduras
description: Gen. Walter Lopez Reyes left Honduras today for the United States after his ouster as commander of the armed forces.

title: COMMUNISTS IN WESTERN EUROPE: ONCE-POWERFUL PARTIES STAGNATE
description: Across Western Europe, Communist parties that were born seven decades ago in the early enthusiasm of the Russian Revolution are in varying conditions of stagnation and decline, according to Western European politicians and political commentators.

title: Minnesota May Send Guard Back to Hormel
description: Striking Hormel meatpackers rejected pleas that they vote a third time on a proposed settlement with the company, and Gov. Rudy Perpich today considered whether to return National Guard troops to the plant to protect people crossing picket lines.

title: A Uranium Mystery Enlivens a City Bureau
description: Dangerous substances? All in a day's work for the city's Hazardous Materials Bureau. Except when the substance is brought right to the bureau's doorstep in the Municipal Building in lower Manhattan.

title: OPEC SEEN AS UNLIKELY TO EASE TUMULT
description: Oil analysts in the United States do not expect that the meeting of OPEC's marketing strategy committee this week will produce any substantive results to calm the shaken oil markets or reverse the slide in prices.

title: BEATRICE DIRECTORS ACCEPT BID
description: The board of the Beatrice Companies agreed today to accept an offer valued at more than $6 billion from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company that was slightly sweetened from the revised bid Kohlberg made in January.

title: BOURQUE: A STAR WITHOUT THE SPARKLE
description: HE has all the attributes of a star athlete: great statistics, a six-figure salary and a six-year contract that prove his best years are still ahead, the captaincy of his team, and even the spiky, gravity-defying haircut lately in favor among the youthful members of the National Hockey League.

title: CONCERNED COMMUTERS GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Commuters who find the needy seeking warmth and shelter in the city's railroad stations and bus terminals are among those contributing to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: G.M. to Keep Dealer System
description: The General Motors Corporation has decided against any radical changes in its dealership system when it starts selling its Saturn cars near the end of the decade, according to dealers and company officials.

title: THE GAME OF WINTER
description: CONTRARY to the opinion of even some keen-eyed observers, the sports world does not sink into its dark stages during the month of February. That is, it does not go into eclipse between the Super Bowl and the time when the batteries of the baseball teams, followed by their sparkplugs, show up for spring training.

title: Linda Charlton Dies; Ex-Reporter for Times
description: Linda Charlton Murray, a former reporter for The New York Times, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home in Canaan, N.Y. She was 49 years old.

title: Ending Medicaid for Abortion Punishes the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Spending on Police Levels Off
description: Spending for law enforcement and the size of police departments in many major cities have leveled off in recent years, the Bureau of Justice Statistics said today.

title: ROCKETS' OLAJUWON FINDS SHORTEST PATH TO STARDOM
description: THE DREAM looks splendid, as if he has emerged from some fashion spread in a men's magazine. But this is the hallway that leads to the Houston Rockets' dressing room at the Summit, not a photographer's studio. On this night, his olive suit is neatly pressed and businesslike, and his loafers look like buttersoft Italian leather. He is smiling; the Dream always smiles.

title: Market Place; Building Issues: Cautious View
description: AS prime beneficiaries of lower interest rates, building-related issues have performed handsomely in the current bull market. But a leading Wall Street analyst voiced a warning on Friday.

title: RISE IN COCAINE ABUSE POSES THREAT TO INFANTS
description: In the special care nursery at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, a 3-week-old girl squalled and twitched, her cries fitful and her limbs stiff. Lifted from the crib by Dr. Jing Yoon, the child failed to settle into the warm folds of an adult embrace - a sure sign, the doctor said, of cocaine withdrawal.

title: Washington Watch; Fed Split on Rate Cut
description: While money markets were speculating a few weeks ago about a cut in the Federal Reserve discount rate, the Fed's board of governors sidetracked proposals for that very action from several of the 12 Federal Reserve Banks, according to a central bank official.

title: Washington Watch; Oil Lifts Growth Outlook
description: World Bank economists are scaling up projections for economic growth this year, following the slide of $5 a barrel in oil prices over the last month. Jean Baneth, director of the economic analysis and projection department, said that, according to preliminary estimates, growth in both developing and industrial countries would be a third of a percentage point higher than it would otherwise have been.

title: LLOYD TOPS GRAF, 6-3, 6-1, TO WIN FINAL
description: Chris Evert Lloyd used her recently developed strength to take the sting out of Steffi Graf's power strokes and claim a 6-3, 6-1 victory today in the final of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1986
description: International

title: DEBATE OVER PREGNANCY LEAVE
description: When Lillian Garland lost her job as a bank receptionist four years ago after taking time off to give birth to a daughter, she started a legal battle that has become the centerpiece of a nationwide policy debate over the issue of parental leave.

title: LIBYA'S WOMEN: ERA OF CHANGE
description: Fawzia Abdullah is a 21-year-old first lieutenant at the Women's Military Academy, an extraordinary institution in the Arab world.

title: SIMMS PACES N.F.C. VICTORY
description: Phil Simms of the Giants threw for three second-half touchdowns, the last with 2 minutes 47 seconds remaining, to rally the National Conference from a 17-point deficit to a 28-24 Pro Bowl victory today over the American Conference.

title: Good Mergers, Bad Mergers
description: The latest proposals for giant business mergers - Pepsi and Seven-Up, Northwest and Republic Airlines, Goodrich and Uniroyal - have evoked little reaction from public officials. That's hardly surprising. Big, according to the Reagan Administration's economists, is not necessarily bad. With liberal populism out of fashion, many politicians are ready to give friendly mergers the benefit of a doubt.

title: Closing Is Delayed For Philadelphia Hotel
description: A lawyer for the Bellevue Stratford Hotel have announced that the landmark building, which had been scheduled to close today, would stay open at least until April 2.

title: Coach at Holy Cross Is Suicide by Hanging
description: Rick Carter, the Holy Cross football coach, committed suicide today by hanging, authorities said. Carter was 42 years old.

title: HEALTH IS KEY TO NEW DRIVE AGAINST ALCOHOL ABUSE
description: A campaign to help nonproblem drinkers avoid difficulties with alcohol is being planned by the Alcoholism Council of Greater New York.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Blacks Joining Hands for Self-Help
description: Grim evidence about the condition of the poorest blacks has wrought what reason could not: a cease-fire in the war of words between liberal and conservative blacks. In its place there is now a healthy debate.

title: A Post for Rumsfeld
description: The Institute for Contemporary Studies in San Francisco is expected to elect Donald M. Rumsfeld this month as chairman of the board. What Mr. Rumsfeld, a former Congressman, White House official and Secretary of Defense, really wants, his associates say, is to be elected President of the United States, but every candidate has to start somewhere.

title: CONISTON ACQUIRES 8.2% STAKE IN NL INDUSTRIES
description: Coniston Partners, a New Jersey investment partnership, has acquired an 8.2 percent stake in NL Industries, a leading manufacturer and supplier of petroleum equipment and services, chemicals and metals.

title: GREEN, SEEKING TO BE SENATOR, STEPS UP EFFORT
description: Mark Green, the public-interest lawyer and author, has stepped up his unofficial campaign to win the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, calling the Republican incumbent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, ''absolutely vulnerable.''

title: Investor Linkup Speeds Computer Maker's Rise
description: Pauline Lo Alker is a woman in a hurry. Rather than slowly building up her 20-month-old Silicon Valley company, Counterpoint Computer, Mrs. Alker has made her way in the computer-making market with the help of $19 million in venture capital and participation by other investors with deep pockets.

title: A Bequest for Packwood
description: Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon was startled the other day when he received a formal notice from the District Court of Logan County, Oklahoma, that he was a beneficiary in a will under probate there. Inquiry revealed that Daisy Eden O'Dell, who died Jan. 17, had left a bequest of $100 to each of the 53 Republican members of the Senate, a move her family is contesting. Senator Packwood, for one, does not plan to appear in Guthrie for the scheduled Feb. 4 hearing to argue for his challenged inheritance.

title: THE WHALERS' CHIEF LANDS ANOTHER BIG CATCH
description: HOWARD BALDWIN is the reason the National Hockey League All-Star Game belongs to Hartford this year. Four seasons back, with his club in 18th place in the league, Baldwin decided the all-star game, a credibility builder, would fit nicely into his schedule for 1986.

title: SMALLER BANKS WIN CHICAGO CUSTOMERS
description: Chicago's second-tier banks are scrambling to profit from the problems at the city's two banking giants - the First National Bank of Chicago and the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company. And, for the most part, they are succeeding.

title: A GALAXIE FULL OF MEMORIES
description: EVERY time Adrian Smith opens his garage door in suburban Anderson Township outside of Cincinnati, a 20-year-old, pale blue Ford Galaxie convertible reawakens memories of his only National Basketball Association All-Star Game appearance. The car was the prize for his selection as the most valuable player in the 1966 game.

title: Okamoto Wins by Shot
description: Ayako Okamoto, fighting off nervousness and an aching back, shot a 1-under-par 71 in today's final round to win the $200,000 Elizabeth Arden Classic, holding off Muffin Spencer-Devlin by one stroke.

title: HAITI PUTS CITY UNDER A 6-HOUR CURFEW
description: The Government imposed a six-hour curfew on Haiti's second-largest city today as tension remained high throughout the Caribbean country.

title: Defeat the Homosexual Rights Bill
description: The homosexual rights bill under consideration in the New York City Council would be, if passed - and the chances are said to be good - a dangerous assault on our families and our values.

title: Ransom Is Demanded In Beirut Kidnapping
description: An anonymous telephone caller who said he represented the kidnappers of a South Korean diplomat asked today for a $10 million ransom for the diplomat's return, raising the possibility that the frequent abduction of foreigners in Lebanon is acquiring a new dimension.

title: N.B.A. ALL-STAR GAME
description: EASTERN CONFERENCE STARTERS Larry Bird#33 Boston, forward 6-9, 220, seventh season, seventh all-star game. Considered by many to be the greatest non-center ever. League's most valuable player in '83-84 and '84-85. Julius Erving#6 Philadelphia, forward 6-7, 205, 15th season pro season (10th in N.B.A.), 10th all-star game. Nearly 36 years old, Dr. J is still a very effective player. Moses Malone#2 Philadelphia, center 6-10, 255, 12th pro season, ninth all-star game. Has led the league in rebounding six seasons, including the last five. Isiah Thomas#11 Detroit, guard 6-1, 185, fifth season, fifth all-star game. The pure point guard. Holds league record for most assists in one season (1,123). Sidney Moncrief#4 Milwaukee, guard 6-4, 190, seventh season, fifth all-star game. Can score with his jumper, by driving to the basket and by posting up opposing guards.

title: INVESTORS FACE UNCERTAINTIES
description: The credit markets, fraught with uncertainty for much of the new year, will start getting answers to some of its questions this week.

title: Security Remedies Promised
description: The chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation today pledged to discipline employees responsible for violating security procedures at the company's Convair Division in San Diego.

title: ALVA MYRDAL, NOBEL WOMEN, DIES IN SWEDEN AT 84
description: Alva Myrdal, the Swedish diplomat who was a co-winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1982 for her efforts to promote world disarmament, died Saturday night in Stockholm after a long illness. She was 84 years old and had a history of heart trouble.

title: TOY-BASED TV: EFFECTS ON CHILDREN DEBATED
description: Television programs that feature heroes and villains drawn from the toy-store shelf or developed in conjunction with the marketing of toys, once banned by Federal regulations, are booming in the free-market era of the current Federal Communications Commission.

title: Runner's Perspective
description: Fred Dwyer wants you to understand that while Bruce Phillip is ''an extremely fine athlete,'' he is not a ''super athlete.'' Not yet, anyway.

title: MAINE DAM DISPUTE LINGERS AS COMPANY AVOIDS COMMITMENT
description: The Great Northern Paper Company won a state permit to build a dam that would eliminate a popular stretch of wild river by arguing that the electricity it would produce was needed to modernize the mills and save nearly 1,700 jobs.

title: N.H.L. ALL-STAR GAME
description: WALES CONFERENCE Mike Keenan Wales coach Philadelphia He guided the Flyers to the best record (53-20-7) in the league and a berth in the Stanley Cup finals in his first season as coach last year. The 36-year-old Keenan never played in the N.H.L. Ray Bourque#7 Boston, defense 5-11, 205, seventh season, sixth all-star game. Regarded by many coaches, players and fans as the best all-round defenseman in hockey. Has averaged about 20 goals and 50 assists during his career. Rod Langway#5 Washington, defense 6-3, 215, eighth season, sixth all-star game. He is the first American to capture the Norris Trophy (twice), awarded to the best defenseman in the league. Michel Goulet#16 Quebec, left wing 6-1, 195, seventh pro season, fourth all-star game. He is simply known as the best left wing in the league. Quebec's player of the year last season, he may surpass the 50-goal plateau again for the fourth consecutive year. Mario Lemieux#66 Pittsburgh, center 6-4, 200, second season, second all-star game. Was voted the league's rookie of the year last season, the first member of the Penguins to be so honored. Most valuable player in all-star game last year. Tim Kerr#12 Philadelphia, right wing 6-3, 215, sixth season, third all-star game. Deservedly amassed the most votes among right wings in the conference to become a starter for the first time. He leads the league in goals and power-play goals. Mario Gosselin#33 Quebec, goaltender 5-8, 160, third season, second all-star game.

title: FEDERAL FINANCING OF ANIMAL RESEARCH HALTED AT COLUMBIA
description: Federal research funds for many animal studies at Columbia University's health sciences division, including its medical school, have been suspended because the programs failed to meet new requirements for animal welfare and safety.

title: ISLANDERS EXTEND STREAK TO 7
description: A moment of high emotion by Glenn (Chico) Resch, the demonstrative and loquacious goaltender, cost the Devils a double penalty and, as it turned out, the game tonight before a rare sellout crowd at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: MAN IS CHARGED IN BRYANT PARK SLAYING
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested by detectives staked out near his home Saturday night and charged with killing a woman and shooting three other bystanders in a fight over drugs on the edge of Bryant Park last October.

title: Shelley L. Lefkowitch Wed to David White
description: Shelley Lee Lefkowitch, a daughter of Stanley L. Lefkowitch of the Bronx and the late Selma Licht Gold, was married yesterday to David Lawrence White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley White of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi David Kahane performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club in Manhattan.

title: 'CELEBRATION OF JAN WALLMAN' AT CARNEGIE TONIGHT
description: During almost 30 years as den mother to aspiring cabaret performers, Jan Wallman has provided an important step up the ladder to such now familiar names as Joan Rivers, Dick Cavett, Woody Allen, Rodney Dangerfield, Barbra Streisand, Robert Klein, George Segal, Marcia Lewis and Linda Lavin. Now it's their turn to help her.

title: POPE MEETS DALAI LAMA AND CITES SPIRITUALITY OF EAST
description: Pope John Paul II, unruffled when a young man tossed a firecracker in his direction at the end of a mass here, met today with the Dalai Lama, the Tibetan spiritual leader, and urged the world to look to the spirituality of the East in its search for genuine liberation.

title: HINDU SECT'S PLANS FOR 162-ACRE COMPOUND JAR TOWN IN JERSEY
description: Over the last 200 years, ethnic groups have blended without much commotion into this little farming community in the hilly country of northwestern New Jersey.

title: Required Reading; The Foreign Service
description: Excerpts from ''Ethnocentrism Distorts Foreign Policy,'' an essay by Bernard Johns, a senior fellow at the Joint Center for Political Studies, published in the latest issue of the center's magazine, Focus:

title: THE STAGE: CAMUS'S 'CALIGULA' IN MODERN DRESS
description: TEDIOUS as it is, the Circle Repertory Company's new modern-dress revival of Albert Camus's ''Caligula'' is a perfectly respectable mediocrity for much of its first act. Then comes the fatal mistake - the grand pratfall that sends a forgettable failure skidding into the pantheon of the memorably ridiculous. The scene is one in which Camus's antihero, not the most personable of the Caesars, taunts the conspiring Roman patricians by raping another man's wife. Now, what do the august Romans do while Caligula has his noisy way with the woman in the next room? In the director Marshall W. Mason's rendition, they sit around and wolf down takeout Chinese food - right out of the white cardboard cartons, and with chopsticks.

title: Bridge: Sometimes, Two Half Stops Serve as Well as a Full One
description: A full stop is required on reaching an American intersection or on completing an English sentence. It is also desirable in the opponent's suit when planning a no-trump contract, but one can often get by with two half stops.

title: AUTO DEALERS IN UPBEAT MOOD
description: Many automobile dealers are becoming disenchanted with the recurring rounds of cut-rate financing incentives that the auto companies have been offering, saying they only produce boom-and-bust cycles in sales.

title: Advertising; 2 Publishers Appointed By American Express
