description: William J. Ahern, a retired vice president formerly in charge of the Brooklyn division of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Friday at his home in Bethpage, L.I. He was 96 years old.

title: 5 Networks to Carry Reagan Talk Tonight
description: President Reagan's State of the Union address to a joint session of Congress will be carried live at 8 P.M. Eastern standard time on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on C-SPAN, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network.

title: Narciso Ramos Dies at 86; Served in Philippine Cabinet
description: Narciso Ramos, a former Foreign Secretary, died today after a prolonged illness, the Philippines News Agency reported.

title: Castro Opens Gathering With a Harsh Attack
description: Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, opened the third congress of the Cuban CommunisttParty today with a harsh attack on inefficiency and bureaucracy in his country. He warned that he would not tolerate ''negligence, laziness, inability or irresponsibility.''

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WINE TALK
description: WILLIAM HILL is a former investment counselor turned wine maker who produces some of California's most highly respected cabernet sauvignons. His 1980 was, in some ways, a letter-perfect cabernet, a red wine any vintner in the world would be proud to have made.

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special net provision of $28.2 million from the curtailment and consolidation of certain chemical and fertilizer business and for specific environment remediation projects, equity in earnings of associated companies of $3.4 million and a tax credit of $15.5 million. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $4.2 million for the quarter and $17.6 million for the year, and equity in earnings of associated companies of $4.4 million for the quarter and a gain of $9.3 million, or 19 cents a share, for the year from the tax reform act of 1984. d-Including an approximate gain of $5.5 million, or 11 cents a share, from the disposal of the company's U.S. titanium dioxide business, a netgain of $5.9 million from discontinued operations, a net gain of $3 million on the sale of discontinued operations and after a special provision of $28.2 million for the curtailment and consolidation of certain chemical and fertilizer business and for specific environmental remediation projects.

title: SELECTING JUST THE RIGHT OUTFITS FOR ST. MORITZ
description: The need is so great; there is so little time. Diane Salzberg knows she cannot help everyone; she rushes about at this time of year doing all she can.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEES LONG-TERM DECLINE IN INTEREST PAYMENTS
description: The amount of interest paid on the Government's mountainous debt will rise 3.7 percent in 1987 but will then begin a sustained decline, according to Reagan Administration projections.

title: Margot Fonteyn Plans To Perform in Miami
description: Dame Margot Fonteyn will come out of retirement and appear Feb. 18 and 19 in Miami during the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet Company's tour of North and South America this month, a spokesman for the company said today.

title: 10-Day Auto Sales Down 2.5%
description: Sales of new American-made cars slipped 2.5 percent in late January but edged up 1.3 percent for the full month, the manufacturers reported today.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gander Crash Search Ends
description: United States Army experts, aided by mild weather, have completed a three-week search of the site of a plane crash that killed 248 American soldiers and eight crew members, officials said today. Two bodies, personal effects, medical records and debris were among the items found. The bodies of 141 soldiers and seven crew members killed in the Dec. 12 crash have been positively identified, an Army spokesman said in Washington.

title: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
18-YEAR-OLD MUST SKATE DESPITE PAIN By PETER ALFANO
description: The smile, Christopher Bowman said, is mandatory, as essential as a pair of sharpened blades in a figure skater's bag of equipment. So there was a smile firmly in place today when Bowman completed a practice routine despite the nagging discomfort of a leg injury. Judges, it is understood, do not grade on a curve, allowing for pain. And a young skater on the way up doesn't have the luxury of taking a day or two off to recuperate.

title: Letter: On the Elderly; Medicare Home Service Is Shrinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Shifts of Arms Experts
description: R. James Woolsey, a Washington lawyer whose presence on the United States delegation to the Geneva talks on nuclear and space arms was viewed in Congress as an indication that the Administration was negotiating seriously, has resigned his post.

title: WITNESS IN MURDER TRIAL TELLS OF 'INFLUENCE' CLAIM
description: A man charged with conspiring to murder his wife claimed he had enough influence in Toms River, N.J., to ''handle'' any investigation, a key prosecution witness testified today.

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economic Scene; Battle Lines In Budget Fight
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has staked out the lines for what is shaping up as a year of confrontation with Congress. He will submit a budget that hits Gramm-Rudman budget targets, with alleged balance in 1991, but in a way that reflects his priorities, not necessarily those of the Democrats or even the Republicans in Congress.

title: T.P.A. SAYS BALLESTEROS WILL COMPETE
description: Seve Ballesteros, who has been barred from all but one PGA Tour event this year, will compete in at least four United States tournaments staged by the new Tournament Players Association between Feb. 17 and March 13, according to Tom Kidd, the commissioner of the new circuit.

title: Artists and Aging
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Rebel Raid in Mozambique
description: Rightist Mozambican guerrillas killed 30 people, including a police commander, in an attack on a northern district capital on Jan. 18, the Noticias de Portugal news agency reported from Maputo, the Mozambican capital, today. Citing sources in Maputo, the agency said the town of Maua in northwestern Niassa Province, some 870 miles north of the capital, was attacked by a 300-strong rebel force. It gave no further details.

title: Bomb in Israel Wounds 3
description: A bomb exploded this morning in Ramat Gan, a suburb of Tel Aviv, wounding three women. The time bomb had been placed in a trash container at a station for buses to Tel Aviv. It went off at 7:30 A.M., during the rush hour.

title: THE COLD WAR OF LETTERS RAGING IN GUNTER GRASS
description: It was never like this before, contended Gunter Grass, gruff and mustachioed, leaning over a living-room table and peering through black-rimmed half-glasses at his American interlocutor. Americans could take criticism, continued this rumbling lion of German letters, and used to be among the sharpest critics of their own country.

title: Israelis Clear the Way For Talks With Egypt
description: The 10-member inner Cabinet cleared the way for the resumption of talks with Egypt today when it agreed on directives to the Israeli negotiators.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MAKING THEM PAY ATTENTION, AT LEAST
description: He's been known to attend high level meetings of the Greater Washington Board of Trade in shorts. He's been seen roller skating down 19th Street to the Palm for lunch. He lives in opulence in Kalorama Circle, the diplomatic community's plush residential neighborhood. He says he loves greed, power and money. And his sassy magazine with his name on the cover extols greed, power and money.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 5, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the situation in southern Africa at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HERNANDEZ IS FACING FUTURE WITH OPTIMISM AND DOUBTS
description: Three weeks before spring training, Keith Hernandez says, it's like waiting for the other shoe to drop.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESSPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOLDIN FINDS 'BIG MESS' AT ENVIRONMENTAL UNIT
description: The City Comptroller charged yesterday that his office had found ''one big mess'' in the city's Environmental Control Board, with problems ranging from lax control over private collection agencies to ''instances of fraud.''

title: VILLANOVA DEFEATS BOSTON COLLEGE, 67-57
description: Harold Pressley scored 16 points and the freshman guard Kenny Wilson added 12 second-half points to give Villanova a 67-57 Big East victory over Boston College tonight.

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: REAGAN'S MESSAGE APPEALS FOR UNITY TO CURB SPENDING
description: President Reagan appealed tonight to Republicans and Democrats to unite in an effort to control Government spending, saying, ''It's time we reduced the Federal budget and left the family budget alone.''

title: DRUG DEBATE AMID AWARDS
description: On Thursday morning at the Fontainebleu Hotel in Miami Beach, leaders of the racing industry will gather to debate the race-day use of medication, primarily the diuretic furosemide. Later that afternoon at a news conference in the same hotel, Spend a Buck is widely expected to be named as Horse of the Year.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Fiscal Calendar
description: The new budget law, which requires a balanced budget by the fiscal year 1991, also accelerates deadlines in the House and the Senate for the budget process. In addition, if Congress fails to reach the law's deficit ceiling of $144 billion in the 1987 budget, the law sets a specific new procedure for putting automatic spending cuts into effect. Deadlines in the Congressional budget process First Monday after Jan. 3 President submits his budget to Congress. (The date for this year only is Feb. 5.) Feb. 15 Congressional Budget Office submits its annual budget and economic analysis reports to House and Senate Budget Committees. Feb. 25 Other House and Senate committees submit budget proposals to the Budget Committees. April 1 Deadline for Senate Budget Committee to write the annual budget resolution, which sets nonbinding targets for spending and revenue. No such deadline for the House. April 15 Deadline for House and Senate action on the budget resolution. May 15 Appropriations may be considered in the House even if the budget resolution for the next fiscal year has not been adopted. In the Senate a waiver is necessary. June 10 Deadline for House Appropriations Committee to send bills to the floor. No such deadline for the Senate. June 15 Deadline in the the House and the Senate for passage of any legislation to meet the deficit ceiling in the budget resolution. June 30 Deadline in the House for passage of all 13 appropriations.

title: CLASSIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRESIDENT REAGAN'S SPEECH BEFORE JOINT SESSION OF CONGRESS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's State of the Union Message to Congress last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: MARGERY WILSON
description: Margery Wilson, the silent-screen actress best known for her portrayal of the doomed Huguenot girl, Brown Eyes, in D. W. Griffith's film ''Intolerance,'' died Jan. 21 in Arcadia, Calif. She was believed to be in her early 90's and lived in Arcadia.

title: Traces of Drugs Found In Rick Nelson's Blood
description: Tests showed traces of cocaine, marijuana and a powerful painkiller in Rick Nelson's blood after the New Year's Eve airplane fire that killed the singer, his fiance and five band members, officials said today.

title: RICHARD L. TURNER
description: Richard L. Turner, chairman and president of the Schlegel Corporation of Rochester, a diversified manufacturing company, died of an aneurysm Sunday while traveling in Hickory, N.C. He was 60 years old and lived in Pittsford, N.Y.

title: FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GAS UTILITIES PLAN NEW YORK PIPELINE
description: Transcanada Pipelines Ltd. and four American utilities in the Northeast, including the Brooklyn Union Gas Company of New York, said yesterday that they would build a $400 million natural gas pipeline. It would be the first new major pipeline connection to the New York metropolitan area in more than 30 years.

title: Ford, BL in Talks
description: The Ford Motor Company is discussing a possible purchase of the Austin Rover division of BL P.L.C., a move that could raise Ford's market share in Britain to more than 40 percent, industry sources said. Spokesmen for Austin Rover and the Department of Trade and Industry said talks between Ford and Austin Rover were at a preliminary stage. The Government confirmed yesterday that BL and General Motors Corporation had been talking about the sale of BL's truck and Land Rover divisions.

title: U.N. COUNCIL TAKES UP INTERCEPTION OF PLANE
description: The Security Council met for two hours today to consider a Syrian request that Israel be condemned for forcing down a Libyan civilian plane. Dia-Allah el-Fattal, of Syria said: ''It is a case of air piracy, a case of international terrorism directed against international civil aviation.

title: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss.

title: Jacob Shankman Dies at 81; Retired New Rochelle Rabbi
description: Jacob K. Shankman, former rabbi of Temple Israel of New Rochelle, N.Y., and a leader in Reform Judaism, died Tuesday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1986
description: International

title: New Wave
description: Facing eighth-ranked Kentucky on Sunday was more than a midseason challenge for Coach Jim Valvano of North Carolina State. It was part of ''a midlife crisis,'' according to the frenetic chief of the Wolfpack, who will reach 40 March 10.

title: REAGAN SEEKS WELFARE PLAN TO FREE POOR FROM GOVERNMENT DEPENDENCY
description: President Reagan said tonight that his Administration would search for new ways to help poor people ''escape the spider's web of dependency'' on Government welfare programs.

title: Punishments Reinstated At Special Care Institute
description: Massachusetts officials have not decided whether to appeal a judge's ruling reinstating physical punishments for five autistic students at a special care institute.

title: Jewish Emigration and the Atmosphere of Trust for Arms Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: AS SPY TRIAL OPENS, DEFENSE SAYS BETTER TIES WERE MOTIVE
description: A retired Central Intelligence Agency analyst accused of spying for the Chinese gave Peking highly classified documents in a personal effort to speed reconciliation between China and the United States, his lawyer asserted today.

title: Diplomats Say Rebels Increase Kabul Attacks
description: Western diplomats said today that Afghan rebels had stepped up their activities in Kabul with rocket attacks in the area around the Soviet Embassy.

title: GIFTS NOTE THE PLIGHT OF NEEDIEST
description: The homeless who sometimes wander into a Queens library for shelter and warmth have motivated a librarian to contribute to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Manson Loses Sixth Bid For Parole in California
description: Charles Manson, the convicted cult murderer, today lost his sixth bid for parole after he unexpectedly attended a hearing at which he was described as a ''caged, vicious, wild animal.''

title: AQUINO CONCLUDES HER CAMPAIGN WITH ENORMOUS RALLY IN MANILA
description: As Corazon C. Aquino ended her presidential campaign with a mammoth rally here that drew hundreds of thousands of singing supporters, the Government announced that the military was prepared to deploy troops on election day.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE LOSES IN BID TO END HIS TRIAL
description: The prosecution rested its case today in the trial of a Federal district judge on charges of influence peddling and perjury, and the defense was denied a request for a directed verdict of acquittal.

title: NASA'S RISK ASSESSMENT ISN'T MOST RIGOROUS METHOD
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration did not use the most thorough method of safety analysis available to pinpoint potential failures on the space shuttle Challenger, according to top present and former agency officials and risk experts.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1985 year was based on 52 weeks compared with 53 weeks a year ago.

title: STATE APPROVES BONUSES TO RENT TO THE HOMELESS
description: New York State yesterday formally approved a plan to allow the city to pay bonuses averaging $10,000 to landlords who rent apartments to homeless families.

title: President's Son Ronald Gets An Editor's Post at Playboy
description: Ronald P. Reagan, son of President Reagan, has been named a contributing editor of Playboy magazine, its executive editor, Barry Golson, announced yesterday. The post is in addition to one of entertainment journalist for ABC-TV, a position he has held since last July.

title: BOOSTER ROCKET IS BELIEVED FOUND
description: Search teams reported today that sonar soundings in the ocean near here may have discovered one of the two solid-fuel booster rockets from the space shuttle Challenger, which exploded over the ocean a week ago today.

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest year reflect an unspecified charge related to a nonrecurring writeoff of the undepreciated cost of the company's two crude carriers.

title: DANCE: THE AMERICAN DANCEMACHINE OPENS
description: THE Nikolais Dance Theater presented one of its most light-hearted evenings on Saturday at Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College. The program got off to a buoyant start with Alwin Nikolais's pretty ''Tensile Involvement,'' a piece set to music by Mr. Nikolais and choreographed in 1953, for 10 dancers and a stageful of colored elastic ribbons. Stretched and manipulated by the dancers, the ribbons seem to have a life of their own. They also provide a frame and background, dotted with stretched bodies, for brief solos that both work against that field of colored lines and are inspired by the ribbons' physical properties.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Advertising; McCaffrey Fills Key Post
description: In a move rare in agency circles, the head of a direct marketing agency has stepped into the presidency of a general agency. Robert H. Cherins, 43 years old, has, after a career on one side of the advertising scene, been tapped to be president, chief operating officer and a member of the board of McCaffrey & McCall, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi of London, and billing $199 million.

title: IN WITHERING STEEL CITY, DREAM TURNS DESOLATE
description: For nearly 20 years, Paul Tomai worked at the Duquesne Works of the United States Steel Corporation, a huge, dark complex that spreads along the flats by the Monongahela River in this depressed steelmaking city.

title: Bulls' Dailey Absent
description: Quintin Dailey of the Bulls failed to show up for last night's game against the Detroit Pistons at Chicago, prompting Jerry Krause, the Bulls' vice president of operations, to say he has to determine whether the league will let him release the troubled player. A few hours before the game, an unidentified woman called Chicago Stadium and told the team's trainer, Mark Pfeil, that Dailey's car had had a flat tire on Interstate 290 while en route to the game.

title: TRACKING DOWN ORIENTAL INGREDIENTS
description: FOOD is an important part of the New Year festivities this week in Chinatown and throughout the city as Chinese, Vietnamese and other Asian families gather to celebrate the start of the Year of the Tiger on Sunday.

title: AUTOMATIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
O'NEILL BUDGET CALLS FOR A RISE IN AID TO CITIES
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today proposed a $4.92 billion budget for Connecticut that would increase state aid to the cities and towns instead of reducing state taxes, as the Republicans have sought.

title: TAR HEELS COME FROM 13 BEHIND TO WIN
description: Top-ranked North Carolina stormed back from a 13-point deficit with 12 minutes to play tonight to beat second-ranked Georgia Tech, 78-77, in overtime.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: JOAN ROTH had gone to the outer reaches of Brooklyn to pick up her car from a repair shop. On the drive back to Manhattan, as she stopped for a red light on Ocean Parkway, the passenger door suddenly opened and in jumped a small, gray-haired woman whose agility belied her age. ''Take me to Avenue N!'' she commanded. Mrs. Roth could only sputter: ''Lady, who are you? You've certainly got your nerve.''

title: ABORTION BATTLE SHIFTS TO AID FOR FAMILY PLANNING
description: Abortion has been a flashpoint in American politics, often dominating elections and polarizing debate over domestic programs.

title: Touching Base With Honduras
description: When Honduras inaugurated its new President last week, the United States was represented by Vice President Bush, the resident Ambassador and two special ambassadors, Gary Carter of the Mets and Nolan Ryan of the Houston Astros.

title: Real Estate; Industrial Expansion In Suffolk
description: A COMMERCIAL expansion in western Suffolk County added more than 12 million square feet to the county's space for high technology, research and development and light industry in the late 1970's and early 80's.

title: I.B.M. Waives Intel Board Seat
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had waived the right to its seat on the Intel Corporation's board of directors because of legal issues arising from its proposed offering of debentures that are convertible into Intel stock.

title: OPERA: VICKERS IN HANDEL'S 'SAMSON'
description: WHY, you may ask, would the Metropolitan Opera, which had performed only one Handel opera in its history until Monday night, choose for its second work the oratorio ''Samson''? Primarily, because it is the Handel work that Jon Vickers chose to sing, and the Canadian tenor has reached that stage in his illustrious career where he can get what he wants. The production, which the Metropolitan shared with London's Covent Garden and Chicago's Lyric Opera, is a showcase for Mr. Vickers's dramatic and vocal talents, which did much to sustain the evening with the aid of Elijah Moshinsky's striking if often incomprehensible staging.

title: Dart Drug Holding Has New Chairman
description: In a move that surprised some in the drugstore industry, Alvin F. Towle has stepped down as chairman of Dart Drug Holding Inc. only 18 months after heading a leveraged buyout of the 77-store discount chain from the Dart Group.

title: Broken Hill Opposes Bid
description: Robert Holmes a Court, an Australian investor, has set his sights again on Australia's biggest concern, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company.

title: INVESTIGATORS LOOK AT EX-PARKING OFFICIAL'S DEALINGS WITH AGENCY
description: Federal investigators are trying to determine if a former official of the City Parking Violations Bureau used inside information and influence to help his collection company gain millions of dollars in fees from the bureau.

title: DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE INDICATE BIG FOREIGN AID CUT IS LIKELY
description: Representative Dante B. Fascell, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today that the foreign aid appropriation of the 1987 budget might be cut 15 percent to 30 percent.

title: HALE HOUSE PROMISED FUNDS FOR NEW PROJECT
description: A year after President Reagan celebrated Clara Hale as an ''American heroine'' in his State of the Union Message, the 80-year-old founder of Hale House has been promised state financing for a new Harlem project that will provide temporary apartments for recovering drug addicts and their children.

title: JACOB I. GOODSTEIN
description: Jacob I. Goodstein, a New York lawyer for more than 60 years, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After a charge of $13 million for the quarter and year for the proposed sale of divisions. c-Net income. d-Including a DISC tax credit of $933,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Bonn dispatch on Jan. 28 about Prime Minister Shimon Peres's trip to the site of the Bergen-Belsen death camp referred incorrectly to the year that Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin visited West Germany. It was 1975.

title: The Run For the Cheese
description: We are running a contest to find people with the talent to write TV mini-series. The rules are simple:

title: SHULTZ ASKS ANTITERRORIST FUNDS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz asked Congress today to approve a $4.4 billion antiterrorist security improvement program at United States embassies abroad, a 45 percent spending increase that includes fortified new buildings and 1,300 security-related new jobs.

title: HERMAN E. GOODMAN
description: Herman E. Goodman, founder and chairman of the Franklin Corporation, a Manhattan business investment concern, died Friday at his home in Manhattan.

title: SECRETS TO OMELETS START WITH PANS
description: WHILE working as a restaurant chef, I often interviewed young cooks seeking employment. If they passed the interview, the next test involved cooking a simple but challenging dish that would give me some idea of their dexterity at the stove. ''Make me an omelet,'' was often the request.

title: CHEMICAL ARMS BAN SOUGHT IN GENEVA
description: United States and NATO officials say recent proposals from Moscow have improved prospects for progress on a chemical weapons ban at the Conference on Disarmament, which resumed here today.

title: COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges for discontinued operations of $934,000 for the quarter and $2,500,000 for the year and an extraordinary credit of $4.4 million for the year related to a previously reported litigation provision adjustment. c-After a charge of $14.3 million for discontinued operations. d-Net income.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All figures are restated to reflect the acquisition of Gott Corp. in 1985.

title: Artists and Aging
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: DEALER IN RARE MORMON DOCUMENTS CHARGED IN 2 UTAH KILLINGS
description: A dealer in rare Mormon Church historical documents was charged today with first-degree murder in booby-trap bombings that killed a bishop and the wife of another bishop last October.

title: 200,000 HEAR POPE IN INDIA'S NORTHEAST
description: Pope John Paul II traveled to this hill town today, nearly 360 years after the first Christian missionaries braved headhunters and disease to make the initial forays into India's distant northeast.

title: DELAY IS CHARGED IN INQUIRY INTO PARKING UNIT CONTRACT
description: A Manhattan business executive said yesterday that an armored car company was allowed to begin working for the Parking Violations Bureau even though city investigators were told that the company was unqualified.

title: CAPITAL CITIES/ABC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $7,585,000.

title: Judge Stays Jail Terms In Meatpackers' Strike
description: A judge stayed jail sentences for leaders of a meatpackers' strike today as strikers obeyed restrictions on picketing outside the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant here, allowing replacement workers to enter without trouble.

title: UAL's Income Declines
description: UAL Inc. yesterday reported sharply lower net income in the fourth quarter of 1985 and an operating loss at its United Airlines subsidiary.

title: 'Mary' to Leave Air Briefly
description: Mary Tyler Moore's new comedy, ''Mary,'' and two other series will be taken off the air temporarily while CBS tests three new shows, the network said today.

title: U.S. Capital's Chief Pins Hopes on Atlantic City
description: Two blocks from the Resorts International casino and hotel in Atlantic City, the U.S. Capital Corporation is building the Atlantic Palace, a high-rise with 293 condominiums. About two miles down the road, U.S. Capital owns the Enclave, a similar development with 232 units.

title: STAGE: 'NORTH WIND,' AN ESKIMO TALE
description: IMAGINATION is rife at La Mama E.T.C., where the Mettawee River company is using song, dance, dolls, masks and a lot of ingenuity to tell an Eskimo legend. In the artful combination of Barbara Pollitt's music and Ralph Lee's direction, a myth is captured for the stage.

title: 'THE CLIMATE PUZZLE' TONIGHT ON CHANNEL 13
description: EVERYONE talks about the weather, and while no one does much about it, a great many scientists are trying. Why does our climate change? Why are centuries of cold followed by years of warmth, and why does rain stop falling? ''The Climate Puzzle,'' the third in the fine ''Planet Earth'' series, answers some questions and raises others. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Two Executions Are Blocked
description: The executions of two convicted murderers scheduled for this morning were blocked. A Federal judge on Monday issued a stay for Larry Eugene Mann, convicted of murdering a 10-year-old girl who was abducted while riding her bicycle to school. A Broward County judge signed an indefinite stay Monday for Omar Blanco, a Cuban refugee who came to the United States in 1980 and was convicted of murdering a man.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CRUMP, E H COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $37,000 for the quarter and $102,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the quarter and including a gain from discontinued operations of $278,000 for the year. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September.

title: ANN ANDREWS
description: Ann Andrews, who played the hostess in the original production of ''Dinner at Eight'' on Broadway, died Jan. 23 at New York Hospital.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $2,857,000 from an accounting adjustment. c-Including a gain of $844,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ANIMED INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After a charge of $136,607 for amortization of good will.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Arrow Services Inc., Englewood, N.J., has appointed H.L. Williams chief executive officer of Arrow Priority Mail System, its new overnight express mail delivery system.

title: PRICES OF CRUDE OIL NEAR $15 A BARREL
description: Contract prices for major crude oils plunged to near the $15-a-barrel level and those of petroleum products finished under 50 cents a gallon after officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended their special meeting in Vienna on a largely inconclusive note.

title: 2 Kodak Ventures In Biotechnology
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had entered into joint ventures with two biotechnology companies, the Cetus Corporation and the Immunex Corporation.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Ivan DeJesus, infielder, to minor league contract.

title: IN PARIS, A SEASON OF THE HAT
description: PARIS couture designers have taken seriously the fashion axiom ''The hat completes the costume.'' Hardly a mannequin went bareheaded, even though the shows that ended Thursday were for the spring and summer season. Perhaps the designers believe that women will once again buy a new hat instead of a lipstick or a pair of shoes when they are feeling blue, as they did through the 1950's. Or perhaps they see the Easter bonnet staging a return this year.

title: IOWA ELECTRIC LIGHT & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect a nonrecurring net charges of $2.3 million for the quarter and year, principally from provisions for certain discontinued product lines and operations of the signal and tool groups and a net credit of $2,155,000, or 26 cents a share, for the year from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: IN RESTAURANTS, SMALL KITCHENS CRAMP CHEFS, NOT CREATIVITY
description: NEW YORKERS who stack dirty pots and pans in the living room when preparing a meal in their closet-size kitchens probably dream of cooking in a restaurant where, surely, there is a place for everything and everything is in its place. What else besides yards of counter space, breezy passageways and elbow room that accommodates considerably more than a few elbows could be the source of the hundreds of meals produced each day in a top city restaurant?

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia, 7:35 P.M. If it wasn't for the Celtics and the 76ers, two of the better teams in the league, the Nets would be leading the Atlantic Division. Buck Williams of the Nets is battling Bill Laimbeer of Detroit and Moses Malone of Philadelphia for rebounding supremacy. (Television -SportsChannel, midnight, tape delay. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Colleges: Notre Dame at Dayton (Television - USA 7:30 P.M.), Rider vs. Lafayette, 7 P.M., and Syracuse vs. Seton Hall, 9 P.M., at Byrne Meadowlands Arena (Television - USA, 9 P.M. Radio - WSOU-FM 89.5, 9 P.M., and WNYE-FM 91.5, 8:35 P.M.); New York Tech at Dowling, 7:30 P.M.; Fairleigh Dickinson at Loyola (Baltimore), 7:30 P.M.; Delaware at Hofstra, 7:30 P.M.; Hunter at Staten Island, 8 P.M.; L.I.U. at Delaware State, 8 P.M.; Wagner at Monmouth, 7:30 P.M.; Montclair State at William Paterson, 7:30 P.M.; New Jersey Tech at Yeshiva, 7:30 P.M.; Old Westbury at Baruch, 7:30 P.M.; Queens at Pace, 7:30 P.M.,; Rutgers-Camden at Ramapo, 7:30 P.M.; Southampton at Mercy, 7:30 P.M.; Stockton State at Rutgers-Newark, 7:30 P.M.; Philadelphia Textile at Adelphi, 7:30 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Blues, at St. Louis. Reijo Ruotsalainen, the Rangers' only all-star, had to make an overnight flight to get here from the All-Star Game last night in Hartford. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. ) Islanders vs. Black Hawks, at Chicago, 8:35 P.M. No rest for the Islander all- stars, Mike Bossy and Bryan Trottier, after last night's game in Hartford.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Uranus's Family
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW TEST FOR JAMES RIVER
description: Since its founding in 1969, the James River Corporation has made some 20 acquisitions, evolving quickly from a two-mill operation with $4.5 million in sales to a $2.4 billion leader of the paper industry.

title: Artists and Aging
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Advertising; New Home For Burson Employees
description: BY next Monday, after a frantic weekend, the 700 employees of the New York office of Burson-Marsteller, the world's largest public relations firm, should be comfortably ensconced in their new home at 230 Park Avenue South on the southwest corner of 19th Street.

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized gains on the sale of investments of $7,370,000, or 42 cents a share, for the quarter and $17,114,000, or $1.04 a share, for the year. c-Including realized gains on the sale of investments of $6,955,000, or 48 cents a share, for the quarter and $23,680,000, or $1.64 a share , for the year.

title: Kennecott Union
description: A company demand for a 33 percent cut in wages and benefits for Kennecott's union copper workers led to a strike threat by union representatives of copper workers in three Western states. Kennecott officials said they would make every effort to reach a contract with the unions, but that they would consider hiring nonunion workers during a strike.

title: NO. 1 WEAPON IN 1987 BUDGET IS MISSILE SHIELD
description: The Defense Department today sent Congress budget documents showing that for the first time the space defense research effort that President Reagan has made his highest military priority is also the largest single program in his weapon budget.

title: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $9.3 million for the quarter and $2.2 million for the year. c-After special charges of $25.7 million for the quarter and $14.9 million for the year.

title: Advertising; PHH Group Shift
description: The PHH Group in Baltimore has assigned its Homequity division to HBM/Creamer, New York.

title: Syria Condemns Action
description: Syria said today that it held the Israelis responsible for the consequences of what it called ''this grave act.''

title: Celtics Run Streak to 12
description: Larry Bird scored 24 points and Robert Parish 20 tonight to help the Boston Celitics to their 12th consecutive victory, a 112-93 triumph over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: The Vital Vote in Manila
description: The vote that matters most in the Philippines on Friday will be cast by President Marcos. These are his choices: 1) he can permit a genuinely free contest between himself and his challenger, Corazon Aquino; 2) he can rig the election to assure his victory; 3) he can rig the results to divide the opposition by making Mrs. Aquino's running mate, Salvador Laurel, vice-president; and 4) he can cancel the election at the last moment, claiming a need to uphold law and order The first choice is the only responsible course if Mr. Marcos cares about his country's future and American support. President Reagan has properly tried to hold him to the promise of a free and fair vote. Having called the election largely to placate Americans, Mr. Marcos has no grounds for rejecting as meddlesome America's scrutiny and the standards to which it will hold him.

title: DOW TOPS 1,600, THEN FALLS BACK
description: The Dow Jones industrial average moved above the 1,600 level for a brief period yesterday before profit taking and highly sophisticated arbitrage activity pulled it back and gave Wall Street its first loss in three sessions.

title: Robber's Stray Bullet Kills a Bronx Man, 25
description: A 25-year-old Bronx man waiting for a cab was shot to death at a busy intersection yesterday afternoon by a man who had just robbed a dry-cleaning establishment, the police reported.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective Jan. 31, 1986.

title: WESTERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said data for 1984 has been adjusted for a 200 percent stock dividend effective July 1, 1985.

title: Bridge: No-Trump or a Major Suit? Difficult Choice of Contract
description: Choosing between game in no-trump and game in a major suit, when both hands are balanced, is a constant source of irritation.

title: AMERICAN METALS SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
28 Die in Colombia As Rebels Fight Army
description: A joint force of leftist guerrillas from Colombia, Ecuador and Peru tried to overrun a town in southwestern Colombia on Monday but was beaten back by Government soldiers, an army spokesman said today.

title: Whose Tax Should Be Gored?
description: If Congress were, after all, to limit the deductibility of state and local taxes, Oregon's Senator Bob Packwood apparently would go for the sales tax deduction first. That's not surprising. Oregon has no sales taxes and keeps voting them down by decisive margins. Louisiana's Senator Russell Long disagrees with Senator Packwood's priority. That's not surprising, either. In Louisiana, sales taxes yield 40 percent more revenue than property and income taxes combined.

title: Preparing for War Is No Road to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL PRICES PLUNGE AS OPEC FAILS TO ACT ON OUTPUT
description: Oil prices fell on world markets today as a two-day OPEC meeting broke up here amid indications that the group would do nothing to restrain production.

title: TEXACO'S PLAN ON SECURITY REPORTED
description: Texaco Inc. plans to use stock in its Texaco Canada subsidiary to post the $1 billion in security required by a Federal judge for it to appeal a jury verdict in its legal battle with the Pennzoil Company, a source close to Texaco said yesterday.

title: Poor Mother, Poor Child
description: ''All of them go through at least this,'' Dr. Jing Yoon said recently, pointing to eight squalling, stiff-limbed infants at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center. ''How dare mothers give them this trouble!''

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $68,000 for the quarter and $372,000 for the year. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $27,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $694,000 for the year.

title: MORE WORKER BENEFITS NOW TAXABLE AS INCOME
description: Many executives and employees will discover a new truth in Federal tax policy when they take a close look at their latest W-2 income statements: Such treasured perquisites of corporate life as the personal use of company cars, subsidized meals in employee cafeterias and free rides on corporate jets have become as taxable as wages.

title: CHINATOWN AT NEW YEAR'S: A HONG-KONG CONNECTION
description: DINING in Chinatown today is more than sitting down to some of the trendiest Cantonese cooking in the United States.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Asarco Inc. said it would permanently close its zinc oxide plant in Columbus, Ohio, in the second quarter, taking a $4.5 million charge in its 1985 fourth-quarter results.

title: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring net gain of $2,881,000, or 19 cents a share, from the recognition of the unamortized portion of feferred gain on the sale of the company's Danbury, Conn. facility.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PEOPLE often ask, to my continual amusement, if I ever resort to convenience foods.

title: FOOTE MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $9,355,000 for the quarter and the year for the writeoff of remaining book value of property, plant and equipment at Keokuk, Iowa ferroalloy plant and charges of $6.6 million for the quarter and $11.6 million for the year relating to the closing of Graham, W. Va. ferroalloy plant. c-Net income. The company said that share earnings for the prior year period were negligible.

title: 12-Year-Old Boy Admits He Set Fire
description: A 12-year-old Passaic boy has admitted setting the Labor Day fire that caused $400 million in damage, left hundreds of people homeless and devastated Passaic's industrial center.

title: AT A WELFARE HOTEL, MOTHERS FIND SUPPORT IN WEEKLY TALKS
description: ''I'm getting ready to walk away and leave them all here - the baby, too,'' the mother of four said in an agitated voice. ''I can't take it. I tell you, I'm getting ready to crack some heads.''

title: Koch Won't Deliver State of City Address
description: Mayor Koch is not giving a State of the City address this year, for the first time since 1983.

title: BEACON THEATER MAY BECOME A DISCO-RESTAURANT
description: The owners of the Beacon Theater, the 2,708-seat hall that was designated a city landmark in 1979 and that is the only mid-size facility in Manhattan that regularly books rock and pop concerts, were said yesterday to be considering turning it into a discotheque-and-restaurant complex.

title: Morgan Said to Curtail Mortgage-Backed Issues
description: The four-month-long bull run in the mortgage-backed securities market is taking a toll on the back offices of major securities firms. The problems have become so severe at Morgan Stanley & Company that it has all but pulled out of the mortgage-backed securities market for two months, according to a number of traders and sources at the firm.

title: U.S. Acts to Stay Law on Shoreham
description: The Justice Department today sought a preliminary injunction against a Suffolk County law designed to block a federally supervised emergency preparedness drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Against Arms for the 'Contras'
description: Last July, Congress voted to give $27 million in humanitarian aid to the ''contra'' forces fighting the Government of Nicaragua. I was an author of the amendment that provided these funds, but I am nevertheless dismayed by reports that President Reagan has already decided to request some $100 million in new aid for weapons, ammunition and other military supplies.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LENSMAN Arthur Fellig, better known as Weegee, was a photojournalist, a title that this photographer of the naked city, of its violence and serenity, of its people, in crowds and as individuals, would have scorned. Weegee, who died in 1968, made his home opposite the old Police Headquarters in Little Italy and jumped when a story broke. His pictures appeared in PM and other publications, and his work sang of people and incident rather than architecture or dreaminess. But he captured the city's spirit as few others have done.

title: Advertising; Franznick & Cusatis Gets Sleepy's Account
description: Sleepy's, the Mattress Professionals, is taking its advertising account to Franznick & Cusatis Advertising, a real stand-up team.

title: Artists and Aging
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: B.A.T.'S PARAGONS OF RETAILING
description: When B.A.T Industries, the giant British company, announced last month that it would be restructuring its American retailing operations, analysts praised it as much for what it would keep as for what it had decided to sell.

title: AIRBORNE FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Bonner Is Due at Big Dinner In Manhattan Next Tuesday
description: Yelena G. Bonner, recuperating with relatives in Massachusetts from a coronary bypass operation last month, is to be the guest of honor next Tuesday at a dinner in New York given by Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of the board of Random House Inc., the publisher.

title: TENNECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $19 million in the quarter and $259 million in the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6 million.

title: SLAIN EMIGRE FACED TRIAL IN FRAUD CASE
description: A Russian immigrant who was killed in Brooklyn Monday by gunmen, at least one of whom used an automatic weapon, was under Federal indictment for credit card fraud, authorities said yesterday.

title: Second Thoughts
description: Ever since the Baltimore Orioles obtained Jackie Gutierrez in a postseason trade with the Boston Red Sox, Oriole officials have been getting reports that Gutierrez, an infielder, has been acting erratically. Now, after hearing of a series of run-ins with teammates and officials that led to his release from two winter league clubs, the Orioles have asked the American League to investigate to determine if the infielder was mentally and physically fit at the time of the trade.

title: Artists and Aging
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Artists and Aging
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Benedict Who?
description: Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos comes from the Upper East Side, but a number of his colleagues have sent him to Coventry.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Homework Help
description: Q. Who is buried in Grant's Tomb?

title: Up the Green Line
description: His grandfather led thousands of marchers along that emerald route 59 years ago. Next month, Al O'Hagan will have his chance.

title: SPACE AGENCY IMAGE: A SUDDEN SHATTERING
description: Suddenly the image of the space agency has changed.

title: N.Y.S.E.&G. Issue
description: The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, based in Ithaca, N.Y., is offering $125 million of 10 5/8 percent first mortgage bonds due 2016 at 99.327 to yield 10.70 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The bonds, rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's, are priced to yield about 1.2 percentage points more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

title: Theismann Sounds Off
description: Joe Theismann, the quarterback of the Washington Redskins, may still be recovering from a broken leg, but his tongue is in full working order. That Theismann demonstrated Monday night when he used a speech at a sports dinner in Canada to criticize the Chicago Bears' quarterback, Jim McMahon, for showing a ''lack of respect for the rules of life as a professional athlete.''

title: FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,649,000 for the quarter and $9,488,000 for the year.

title: Article 827386 -- No Title
description: A guard riding in the back of an armored truck was killed by a load of $50,000 in quarters that crushed him when the driver slammed on the brakes to avoid a swerving car on Monday, officials said. One-hundred boxes of quarters weighing 2,500 pounds toppled onto the guard, Hrand Arakilian, 34 years old, of Santee, the authorities in Orange County reported.

title: ONCE MORE, DUVALIER LETS LOOSE THE 'BOGEYMAN'
description: Haiti's President, moving to put down widespread popular unrest, has turned to a feared secret police unit that he previously restrained.

title: DIASONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,079,000 for the quarter and $3,339,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a loss of $11,904,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Judge Rules Against Fed
description: The Federal Reserve Board erred last year when it determined that the commercial paper placement activities of Bankers Trust Company did not constitute selling, underwriting, or distributing under the law, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: AMISTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $519,000 from a DISC tax law change.

title: No Reservations, Please
description: The National Gallery of Art has an urgent request for art-lovers at home and abroad: please stop writing for reservations for its two banner exhibits, Treasure Houses of Britain and The New Painting: Impressionism.

title: The Background; Second Handel Opera at Met
description: Handel produced ''Samson,'' which he called a ''dramatic oratorio,'' immediately after ''Messiah,'' the work that thrust him back into public favor in London after his career as a composer of Italian operas had collapsed. Although not intended as an opera, ''Samson'' has occasionally been staged as such in recent times because of its inherently operatic nature.

title: LIBYA ACCUSES U.S. OF ROLE IN SEIZURE
description: Libya tonight denounced Israel's diversion of one of its civilian aircraft as a ''low and ugly crime'' and accused the United States of having assisted the ''Zionist air pirates'' in the hijacking.

title: UAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $136.8 million gain from the recapture of pension fund assets.

title: The Forgotten Word
description: When the Constitution of the United States directed the President, in Article II Section 3, to give the Congress an account of his stewardship, it clearly expected a plain report on the state of our affairs and the unity of our people.

title: Beware of Euphoria Over Cheaper Oil
description: The euphoria over plummeting oil prices is the mirror image of the despair that seized the nation in 1974 when oil prices were quadrupled. And it is likely to be just as misleading as the earlier emotion was.

title: New Team for Zungul
description: Steve Zungul, the most prolific scorer in the history of the Major Indoor Soccer League, is changing teams in a move that was not totally unexpected. Zungul's contract was sold by the San Diego Sockers to the Tacoma Stars for an undisclosed amount of cash in an effort to alleviate part of San Diego's financial problems.

title: 'AN ANATOMICAL GUY'
description: Anyone who dares hang a whistle around his neck and call himself a coach ought to be able to spot a Chris Mullin from 20 paces, but for Mike Muzio and other coaches working the nonscholarship world of Division III basketball, the real trick is learning how to find a Terry Tarpey.

title: QUESTIONS ABOUT SOLID-FUEL BOOSTER FOCUS ON TEMPERATURE AND CHANGES IN PRESSURE
description: The manufacturer of the space shuttle Challenger's solid-fuel booster rockets disclosed yesterday that they were not designed for use when the temperature of their propellant was below 40 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1986
description: International Israeli jets intercepted a Libyan jet over the Mediterranean and forced it to land in Israel. Israeli officials said the goal had been the capture of a Palestinian terrorist. They said the plane was thoroughly searched for seven hours. When no terrorist was found, the plane and its occupants were allowed to continue on its flight. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: For NATO, a Period of Renewal
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: 'HALLOWED GROUND,' PART OF 'FIRST LOVE' SERIES
description: ''ARTHUR'S HALLOWED GROUND'' is short and sweet, the story of one man's unwavering devotion to the cricket turf he looks after. It might seem an odd selection for David Puttnam's ''First Love'' series were not the passion so pure. The elderly Arthur (Jimmy Jewel) has been tending the same field for nearly half a century, warding off every imaginable encroachment of modern technology into his little fiefdom, and he is justifiably proud. ''Eight hundred square yards, not a weed on it,'' he proudly declares. As he later says: ''When I'm out here in the middle, nothing else matters. People come to sit on the edge, just to drink it in.''

title: How Albany Can Monitor State Expenditures
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS INTERCEPT A LIBYAN CIVIL JET AND THEN LET IT GO
description: Israeli planes intercepted a Libyan executive jet over the Mediterranean today and forced it to land in Israel.

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $63,872 for the quarter and including a capital gain of $1,196,409 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $11,437,000 for the quarter and the year related to tax forgiveness and capital gains of $98,303 for the quarter, $122.023 for the year.

title: BOMB AT TOWER DEFUSED
description: A bomb ripped through a crowded bookstore in the Latin Quarter tonight, wounding four people, the police said.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS CASE IN TRIAL OF FORMER NAVY HEART SURGEON
description: The Government rested its case against Dr. Donal M. Billig today after hearing testimony from the commanding officer of Bethesda Naval Hospital that before being suspended from performing heart operations Dr. Billig had agreed to reduce his surgical activity.

title: DEMOCRATS PAKNT BLEAKER PICTURE
description: Democratic leaders tonight painted a portrait of America that was starkly different from the picture sketched out by President Reagan in his State of the Union Message. While the President saw a nation marked by prosperity and economic growth, his political opponents spotlighted problems of farm foreclosures, lost jobs and staggering budget deficits.

title: irst Boston Gains 49%; Hutton Shows a Deficit
description: The First Boston Corporation yesterday recorded a 49 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings, but another major securities firm, the E.F. Hutton Group, reported a $12.2 million loss.

title: NEW DIRECTION IS HINTED BY REAGAN ON CURRENCY
description: President Reagan's announcement tonight that ''there's more to do'' to prevent instability in currency exchange rates reflects worries within the Administration that its faith in free markets could be misplaced when it comes to the dollar, according to experts here.

title: FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net realized gains on investments of $110,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $397,000, or 4 cents a share, for the year. c-Including net realized gains on investments of $977,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $896,000, or 8 cents a share, for the year.

title: JORGENSEN, EARLE M CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains of $1,553,000 for the quarter and $2,133,000 for the year from the reduction in LIFO inventory quartities carried at lower costs prevailing in prior years.

title: STATE DEPT. ISSUES A BRIEF ON KAHANE
description: The State Department has argued in a legal brief that an American Jew's religious and political affinity for the state of Israel may form part of the basis on which he can be deprived of his American citizenship.

title: TROTTIER SCORES ALL-STAR WINNER
description: Most of the night belonged to the goaltenders, who spun on their backs and dived onto their stomachs in brilliant displays. But finally, just when it seemed they had been driven into hiding, the scorers at the National Hockey League's 38th All-Star Game came out.

title: FAR-REACHING CHANGES POSSIBLE FROM '87 BUDGET
description: President Reagan and Congress will begin work this week on a Federal budget that analysts say could lead to changes in the economy as far-reaching as any since just after World War II.

title: TROUBLE IN HOUSTON FOR N.Y. VENDOR
description: Shirley Rubenstein, a transplanted New Yorker, is battling City Hall for the right to sell hot dogs in Houston from a pushcart.

title: CONRAIL'S SALE VOTED BY SENATE
description: In a victory for the Administration after almost a year of stalemate, the Senate approved by a 54-to-39 vote today a bill to sell the Government's 85 percent interest in the Consolidated Rail Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation for $1.2 billion.

title: Allies Plan to Consult On Soviet Arms Offer
description: President Reagan will send two officials to consult with allies in an effort to form a response to the Soviet proposal to eliminate nuclear weapons by the year 2000.

title: Jewish Emigration and the Atmosphere of Trust for Arms Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: Republic Health
description: The Republic Health Corporation said its directors had received a sweetened buyout bid from an investor group that would pay $18.50 a share in cash, or a total of $305 million, for the outstanding stock of the Dallas concern.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period

title: CHURCHGOING OFFICER WINS POINT ON LUNCH BREAK
description: New Hampshire's Public Employee Labor Relations Board has directed the Nashua Police Commission to allow one of its patrolmen to attend church services on his lunch break.

title: Required Reading; Perils of Deficit Cutting
description: Excerpt from an article in the January issue of the American Enterprise Institute's newsletter, The AEI Economist, analyzing the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit-reducing act, passed by Congress and signed by President Reagan late last year:

title: THE THREADGILL SEXTET AND ITS NARRATIVE FLAIR
description: THE Henry Threadgill Sextet has turned into the world's most compact orchestra in its third album, ''Subject to Change'' (About Time Records, AT-1007). The seven-member group, which Mr. Threadgill calls a sextet because the music is written in six parts, is joined by the singer Amina Claudine Myers for one piece. The band includes woodwinds (Mr. Threadgill), percussion (John Betsch and Pheeroan ak Laff), brass (Ray Anderson on trombone and Rasul Siddik on trumpet) and strings (Deidre Murray on cello and Fred Hopkins on bass) - a lineup that's more flexible than a campaign promise.

title: OLDER WOMEN ARE POOLING THEIR MALE RESOURCES
description: LYNN TENDLER GILBERT chipped in for wine and brought a client. Another woman brought hot hors d'oeuvres and her ex-husband. Doris Bass, who says she is a ''lousy cook,'' didn't bring food but contributed her large East Side apartment and two men.

title: SLUMP GOES ON FOR NETS
description: Micheal Ray Richardson called the Nets' normally stable defense ''a joke.'' Buck Williams said it was ''nonexistent.'' In either case, it was a distasteful performance for the Nets tonight, leading to a 117-101 loss to the Indiana Pacers.

title: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $164,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,048,000, or 22 cents a share, for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,159,000, or 23 cents a share. Results reflect the sale of Meier Metal Servicenter, as of July 31, 1985.

title: MAYTAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared Dec. 27, 1985.

title: Eastern Pilots
description: Executives of the pilots association at Eastern Airlines have voted unanimously to set a Feb. 26 strike date and to send ballots on the measure to more than 4,000 members, a spokesman said. By law, Eastern's pilots may strike after midnight on Feb. 25, which is the expiration of a ''cooling off'' period set Jan. 27 when the National Mediation Board declared an impasse in talks between pilots and the heavily indebted Miami-based carrier. The decision to strike came Monday by the Air Line Pilots Association's 27-member master executive council, which had been meeting in Atlanta.

title: Military Smokers, Too, Subsidize Nonsmokers
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Wine for Charity For the second year in a row, the Sonoma County Wine Growers Association, a group of 78 California wineries, has made an odd and interesting donation to charities around the country.

title: ROMANTIC OFFERINGS FOR CUPID'S DAY
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE young woman went to the doctor complaining of unbearable fatigue. She had stayed home from work for two days and done almost nothing but sleep, only to find that she was still tired. Before conducting any tests, the physician wisely quizzed her about her diet and exercise habits, asked if she was taking any medication and whether she was happy with her job and personal life.

title: BAY BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAS VEGAS CASINO LOANS REPAID, TEAMSTERS PENSION FUND ASSERTS
description: After more than two decades of investigations and litigation, the Teamsters Central States, Southeast and Southwest Pension Fund says it has virtually severed its financial ties with Las Vegas, the town that union money was said to have built.

title: RESTORED PARTS OF SISTINE CEILING UNVEILED
description: Zacharias, David, Goliath, the Delphic sibyl and others biblical figures emerged from beneath centuries of grime today as the Vatican unveiled the first of Michelangelo's frescoes on the Sistine Chapel ceiling to undergo restoration.

title: Stockman Accuses
description: ''The problem is us,'' meaning Republicans, when it comes to cutting the Federal budget, David A. Stockman says. Mr. Reagan's former budget director, in an interview in the March issue of Penthouse previewing his forthcoming book, spotlights a number of Administration leaders and G.O.P. legislators as responsible for blocking one step after another that he proposed in more than four years in the White House.

title: JETS' HESS TO MEET WITH STATE
description: The chairman of the state's Urban Development Corporation is planning to meet today with Leon Hess, the owner of the Jets, to discuss the method of financing a new stadium for the team.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax credit of $4 million, or 18 cents a share.

The year results also reflect a net charge of $156.5 million from writedown of assets and includes a gain of $156.5 million from the sale of a limited partnership. c-Net income.

description: Four large media companies yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings that analysts said were held down by weak demand for advertising.

title: Generalizations About Vietnam Vets Err
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: JAMES TOCCO, LISZT AND BACH TRIBUTE
description: IT is 100 years since Franz Liszt died virtually without honor in Bayreuth, where the event was hushed up because his daughter, Cosima Wagner, feared that such news would detract attention from the festival of her husband's works then in progress. But Liszt has not wanted for attention since, and certainly will not want for it in this centenary season, when pianists in particular are rushing to do homage to the memory of this peculiarly gifted genius. Last night at Alice Tully Hall, James Tocco gave a piano recital that celebrated Liszt's creative links with Bach as well as with another unclassifiable composer and piano virtuoso, Ferruccio Busoni.

title: 'THIRD ANNUAL REPORT OF THE SECRETARIES OF STATE'
description: THE five distinguished-looking gentlemen are seated at a long table. To one side, at a small table, is Edwin Newman, who introduces them as ''elder statesmen'' there to share their wisdom, and proceeds to allow them a couple of minutes apiece on such subjects as summit conferences, international terrorism and United States policies in Southern Africa, the Philippines and the Middle East. No, it is not ''Saturday Night Live.'' It is ''The Third Annual Report of the Secretaries of State'' and can be seen on Channel 13 tonight at 11:30.

title: HUTTON, E F GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an estimated gain of $23.3 million from the sale of E. F. Hutton Credit Corp. and after a charge of $40.3 million for reserves to cover potential losses in connection with second and third mortgages purchased from First American Mortgage Co. in Baltimore and in connection with an outstanding note receibable. c-Net income. d-Including a nonrecurring tax credit of $14.3 million under the Tax Reform Act of 1984 relating to insurance companies.

title: U.S. DECLINES JUDGMENT ON PLANE INTERCEPTION
description: The State Department said today that ''as a matter of general principle'' the United States opposed the interception of civilian planes in peacetime, but it avoided criticizing Israel for forcing down the Libyan plane.

title: 8 Killed and One Injured In Mississippi Blast
description: At least eight people were killed and one was critically injured today in a thunderous explosion that demolished a furniture and appliance store and sent a huge mushroom cloud into the sky.

title: Tenneco Net Off 37.7%
description: Tenneco Inc., a diversified energy company, reported that its fourth-quarter net fell 37.7 percent, to $81 million, or 40 cents a share, from $130 million, or 80 cents a share, in 1984. Revenues rose to $4.17 billion, from $3.79 billion.

title: THEY'RE NASTY, THEY'RE UGLY, AND CHILDREN LOVE THEM
description: They have round faces and plump little bodies. But cuddly or cute they are not.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is nothing that stands in more contradiction to the law than terrorism.

title: Tide Swimmers
description: Seeing the University of Alabama swimming team finish among the N.C.A.A.'s top squads each year has become a satisfying habit for Coach Don Gambril, who was also the coach of the United States Olympic team in 1984. Since Gambril joined Alabama in 1973, the Crimson Tide has finished nine times among the N.C.A.A.'s top 10 teams.

title: Utility Coupon At 6-Year Low
description: The Wisconsin Power and Light Company, one of a handful of electric utilities in the country to carry the top Aaa rating from Moody's Investors Service, is offering $50 million of 30-year first mortgage bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Company as sole underwriter.

title: Grumman Profit Down
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter fell 17.8 percent, to $23.1 million, or 76 cents a share, from $28.1 million, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales climbed 11.7 percent, to $831.9 million from $744.7 million. Grumman attributed the decline to lower profit margins on aerospace sales, a $3 million loss on the sale of its Pearson Yachts unit and costs resulting from ending its solar operations.

title: BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $6,200,000 for the quarter and $16,600,000 for the year. c-Including a gain of $1.3 million from discontinued operations.

title: Street for Shuttle Proposed
description: The County Supervisors today proposed renaming a street on which the space shuttle Challenger had been tranported to Challenger Way in memory of the astronauts who died in the explosion of shuttle.

title: TROTTIER'S FINISHING TOUCH
description: Sixty minutes of relatively check-free hockey had failed to produce a winner in the 38th National Hockey League All-Star Game. Then the Islanders' connection connected in the sudden-death overtime.

title: Market Place; Analysts Favor Aircraft Stocks
description: INVESTOR uncertainties over the impact of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit-reduction program have buffeted aerospace stocks for months. But the skies are brightening for the commercial aircraft business of the nation's two big manufacturers, the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: FRENCH CUISINE WITH A BRAZILIAN BEAT
description: AT Restaurante Claude Troisgros, the Kir Royale is made with Champagne and jabuticaba, a small black fruit that tastes like cassis; the warm chicken and pate salad is artistically arranged on a bed of dark spinachlike berthalia, and a delicate, pale yellow cashew sorbet cleanses the palate between courses.

title: Treasury Issues Are Mixed
description: Interest rates on Treasury issues were mixed yesterday, with only small changes for short- and long-term issues.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SORCERER'S APPRENTICE. By Charles Johnson. 169 pages. Atheneum. $9.95. ''WAS sorcery a gift given to a few, like poetry?'' wonders Allan, the aspiring magician in the title story of Charles Johnson's new collection. ''Did the Lord come, lift you up, then drop you forever? If so, then he was finished, bottomed out, bellied up before he even began. He had not been born among the Allmuseri Tribe in Africa, like Rubin, if this was necessary for magic. He had not come to New Orleans in a slave clipper, or been sold at the Cabildo, if this was necessary. He had only, it seemed, a vast and painfully acquired yet hollow repertoire of tricks, and this meant he could be a parlor magician, which paid well enough, but he would never do good.''

title: WEB OF CITY SCANDAL TRAPS AN OLD FRIENDSHIP
description: It began 12 years ago, a world away from scandal and corruption - a casual relationship between two men who on the surface seemed to be unlikely friends: a rising Queens politician and the founder of a private psychotherapy institute.

description: b-Net income.

title: Dr. Eugen Grabscheid, Performers' Physician
description: Dr. Eugen Grabscheid, a Manhattan physician for 45 years who ministered to the ear, nose and throat ailments of New York's theatrical community, died Monday at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: Capital Standards Rise For Thrifts Weighed
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is considering ways to increase the capital standards of the thrift industry by as much as 100 percent over the next several years, a knowledgeable bank board source said today.

title: SHOPS ARE CLOSED AS PRESSURE ON DUVALIER GROWS
description: Most businesses in the capital and many factories were closed today in what merchants and foreign diplomats said was the most extensive shutdown of commerce in the three decades of the Duvalier family dictatorship.

description: The day that Bild Zeitung disclosed that Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet Jewish activist, would be included in an East-West exchange of intelligence agents, the newspaper's main article, with a big headline across the top of its tabloid format, was about rape.

title: Zap
description: Manuevering for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination is already at a level of intensity not ordinarily reached in the national political cycle for two years more. Last week, in a column widely discussed in Washington political circles, George F. Will, the conservative theoretician who is a friend of President Reagan, wrote that Vice President Bush in his most recent speeches was emitting ''a thin tinny 'arf' - the sound of a lapdog.''

title: Spain's Prime Minister Defends NATO Stance
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez defended Spanish entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today in a heated debate in Parliament.

description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy arrived in Moscow today on a three-day visit amid expectations that the Soviet Union might allow some dissidents and others to emigrate.

description: A bomb went off at a popular book and entertainment specialty store here tonight, wounding at least 9 people, 3 of them seriously.

description: The United States Department of Energy violated Federal law by failing to consult with state officials before choosing Tennessee for a proposed repackaging plant for nuclear wastes, a Federal district judge ruled today.

description: The campaign manager for Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon said yesterday that he had paid almost $200,000 to a printing company in which the son of Yonkers Mayor Angelo Martinelli was a principal, even though he believed the bills, for campaign literature, were ''too high.''

description: ''We must all realize that the deficit problem is also an opportunity - an opportunity to construct a new, leaner, better focused and better managed Federal structure.

Market Place; A Fresh Look At the Utilities
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom regarding electric utility stocks is that investors buy these issues for their high current yields and prospects for future dividend growth.

title: FASHION INDUSTRIES AND THE AIDS ISSUE
description: IT was called Fashion Affair '84, a benefit fashion show and auction for AIDS research that was held in November of that year. The big designers were almost nowhere to be seen. ''They lent clothes for the fashion show,'' recalled Pauline Trigere, a co-chairman of the event, ''but I had a great deal of trouble getting money for this terrible disease from my fellow designers.''

title: DANCE: ERICK HAWKINS COMPANY
description: AS a choreographer and dancer, Erick Hawkins has been particularly susceptible to certain concepts in Asian theater. The unhurried time sense, the distillation of gesture beyond abstraction to communicate sensation, the acknowledgment that not doing is equated with doing - all these elements frequently find their way into his dances.

title: Man Who Took Over Jet Held
description: A man wielding a knife held a steward hostage today on a Delta Air Lines jet as the plane, with 232 people aboard, landed at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. The man, identified as Ralph A. Hughes of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was arrested by the airport police nearly two hours after the Lockheed L-1011 landed at about 6:50 P.M.

FOR DEMOCRATS, SECOND FIDDLE DIDN'T SOUND BAD
description: Serving as Act 2 to a Presidential State of the Union Message is no easy task, but some Democratic activists and political specialists rated this year's Democratic response a substantial improvement over the party's rejoinder in 1985.

title: SPY TRIAL IS TOLD CHINA HAD WORD OF U.S. INTENT
description: Just four months before President Nixon initated the reconciliation between China and the United States, an analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency gave the Chinese a confidential document signaling America's eagerness for such a move, the analyst's lawyer said today.

title: C.I.A. ACCUSED OF AID TO 30'S TERRORIST
description: A Yonkers man has been named as a Nazi collaborator and war criminal who, according to a Congressional study last year, was knowingly slipped into the United States by the Central Intelligence Agency after World War II.

title: JUDGE TESTIFIES IN INFLUENCE TRIAL
description: A Federal district judge on trial here on charges of influence peddling and perjury testified today that when he bought lucrative mineral rights from a businessman he had no knowledge of a drug case in which the man's son was implicated.

title: Eternal Youth
description: Is the triathlon becoming passe, too limited in its three-event structure to maintain a hold on restless, multitalented athletes who maintain that more is better?

NEW PLANE WOULD TAKE 2-HOUR LOW ORBIT TO JAPAN
description: The Reagan Administration, despite efforts to hold down spending, proposed money today for early development of a jetliner that could take passengers from Washington to Tokyo in two hours.

title: RACKETEERING CASE ENTERS SUMMATION
description: Summing up their case against Gennaro J. Anguilo, three brothers and a co-defendant, Government prosecutors said today that for years the five men ran a lucrative gambling and loansharking operation and resorted to obstruction of justice and sometimes murder to maintain their business.

Joint Celebration
description: The CUNY Graduate Center is 25 years old, slightly younger than most of its students. And its neighbor, the New York Public Library, is giving the City University center a birthday party tonight.

title: Advertising; Agency's 3d Cadbury Account
description: AMMIRATI & PURIS announced yesterday that it had become the agency for the line of chocolates from Cadbury Schweppes U.S.A. Billings are about $12 million, according to the agency.

description: CLOCKS and watches seem to be a continuing source of inspiration for designers and architects.

title: THE BLACK MIDDLE CLASS
description: ''CURRENTS'' takes on an interesting subject tonight: the black middle class.
