HAWKS SNAP ISLANDER STREAKS
description: Bill Smith kept the Islanders competitive in the first half of the game, and a pair of power-play goals from Brent Sutter late in the second period granted them the possibility of a comeback. But they couldn't match the Chicago Black Hawks' intensity and wound up losing, 3-2, tonight at Chicago Stadium.

title: New Brunswick City Attorney Indicted in Misuse of Funds
description: The city attorney here was indicted today on charges that he used almost $250,000 of the city's money to hide shortages in an account for his private practice.

title: STAGE: 'THE BONE RING'
description: DONALD HALL'S ''String Too Short to Be Saved'' is a loving memoir of idyllic boyhood summers spent on his grandparents' farm in New Hampshire. In the company of his grandfather, a master storyteller, the poet-to-be learns the value of hard work but does not forget to daydream. ''The Bone Ring,'' the author's dramatization of his book of stories, opened this week at Theater of the Open Eye.

title: EVIDENCE OF A MURDER EXCLUDED FROM 'PIZZA' TRIAL
description: A judge ruled yesterday that evidence about the murder of a reputed Mafia boss, Carmine Galante, could not be presented by the prosecution in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial.

title: LAND OF LINCOLN SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $454,760 from a special dividend of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock distributed by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: MILITARY BUDGET IS MET WITH SKEPTICISM
description: President Reagan's proposed Pentagon budget was greeted with derision today by Congressional Democrats, who said the request was unrealistic, and with skepticism by some budget analysts who said it appeared to understate the likely amount of military spending.

title: HOW REAGAN FARED ON PREVIOUS BUDGETS
description: A President's budget is, in many ways, a wish list. Congress accepts some of the proposals, rejects others and modifies many more.

title: Nancy Reagan Lends Name To Astronaut Children's Fund
description: Nancy Reagan has agreed to serve as the honorary head of a trust fund for the children of the astronauts killed in the space shuttle explosion last week, officials of the fund have announced.

description: Bond prices declined modestly yesterday as securities dealers sought to attract more investors at yesterday's auction of 10-year Treasury notes and today's auction of 30-year Treasury bonds.

title: Trade, Cont.
description: Foreign trade is becoming more and more a highly visible issue.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Profits Scoreboard in Business Day yesterday misstated the fourth-quarter results of Asarco Inc. The company reported a loss of $24.9 million for the period.

description: President Reagan announced today that he had asked the Surgeon General of the United States to prepare a ''major report'' on AIDS and that the Administration was committed to finding a cure for the disease.

title: MADE LOW-COST DRESSES CHIC
description: Henry Jonas Rosenfeld, the dress manufacturer who made it chic for rich women to wear inexpensive clothes in the 1940's, died of a heart attack early yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sears Net Is Off 1.9% In Period
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, said today that its fourth-quarter net income declined 1.9 percent from the comparable 1984 quarter, principally because of lower earnings of its merchandising group.

title: 'METROLINE' LOOKS AT PUBLIC TRANSIT
description: THE most appealing segment of tonight's ''Metroline'' discussion program about New York's public transportation (at 10 o'clock on Channel 13) only lasts a few minutes. It shows the underground in London, the Metro in Paris, and other spanking-clean railway systems in Moscow, Tokyo, Washington and San Francisco. Then suddenly the picture changes and we're watching a familiar IRT subway train on its roller-coaster ride back to reality in Manhattan, where the colorful cars seem to be run by Taki-183, Ric-7 and other famous spray-can names.

title: VOWS MORE 'UNCONVENTIONAL' ACTS
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, defending the Israeli interception Tuesday of a Libyan executive jet, said today that Israel was determined to continue to use what he called ''unconventional'' measures against terrorism.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1986
description: International

title: In Father's Footsteps
description: He was less than impressive for most of his years as a college golfer, and his short game has been especially weak, but after picking up some pointers from a touring pro, Jack Nicklaus 2d, the 24-year-old son of the golf superstar, says his chipping has improved so much that he is truly ready to become a chip off the old block. He said he planned to turn pro after the United States Amateur tournament in August.

title: KOCH SHIFTS STAND ON BRIBE DISCLOSERS
description: In a policy reversal, Mayor Koch said yesterday that from now on people who come forward to say they bribed a city official in exchange for a municipal contract would not necessarily lose the contract. The new approach, he said, is intended to encourage people to speak out.

title: Ryland Mortgage Sets 2 Collateralized Issues
description: Ryland Mortgage Acceptance Corporation IV, a financing subsidiary of the mortgage banking firm of the same name, announced two new offerings of collateralized mortgage obligations, through underwriters led by First Boston Corporation. Earlier this week, the company sold $119.5 million of C.M.O.'s backed by conventional whole loans.

description: Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, has elected to its board Paul H. O'Neill, president of the International Paper Co.

title: Gramm-Rudman: Toothless Dragon
description: If the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget reduction law is a dragon, it will be slain before anyone is devoured. Its timetable permits it to snarl at Congress but never bite.

description: To the Editor:

description: With 11 nominations apiece, ''The Color Purple'' and ''Out of Africa'' led the 58th Academy Award nominations announced today. Unexpectedly, they were joined in the race for best picture by a Brazilian movie, ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' which was nominated in four major categories.

description: b-Net loss.

title: The Yields On C.D.'s Decline

The average yield for bank money market accounts rose again for the second consecutive week, while yields of six-month certificate of deposits declined, and money market mutual funds remained virtually unchanged.

description: In Minnesota, craftsmen and cranes strain to shape blocks of ice and chains of lights into a wondrous palace rising high against the St. Paul skyline. Spring, however, will be here soon and, alas, the ice palace won't.

title: George Sherman Jr., Leading Polo Official
description: George Carter Sherman Jr., the polo player and longtime official of the sport who was credited with helping spur its resurgence in recent years, died of leukemia Monday at his home in New York. He was 74 years old and operated an insurance brokerage here.

description: In addition to its mass-circulation magazine, Family Circle Inc. has been publishing since 1974 one-shot how-to publications, of which there will be 11 this year.

Last year the teams split their two games, each winning at home. (Television - MSG, 9:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 9:20 P.M.). Colleges: Northwestern at Ohio State (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M.); Florida at Auburn (Television - USA, 8 P.M.); Washington at U.C.L.A. (Television - ESPN, 11 P.M.); Fairfield at Fordham, (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 8 P.M.); Army at Iona, (Radio - WFAS, 103.9; 7:30 P.M.); Jersey City State at Howard, 7:30 P.M.; Kings (Pa.) at United States Merchant Marine Academy, 7:30 P.M.; Clark at N.Y.U. (Radio - WNYU-FM, 89.1; 6:50 P.M.); Concordia at Dominican, 7:30 P.M.; Old Westbury at Purchase, 7:30 P.M.; New Paltz at Vassar, 7:30 P.M. Figure Skating United States National Championships, at Uniondale, L.I., Nassau Coliseum, 11 A.M. Junior dance optional set pattern, ladies short program and junior men's freestyle, and 7 P.M. championship dance and championship pairs freestyle. There will also be a free session at the Newbridge Arena, in Bellmore, L.I., at 7:30 A.M. with competition in men's championship figures. Golf Shearson Lehman Brothers Andy Williams Open, at La Jolla Calif., opening round. Woody Blackburn won a playoff from Ron Streak in the event last year. P.G.A. Senior Treasure Coast Classic, at Fort Pierce, Fla., through Feb. 9. Ladies P.G.A. Sarasota Classic, at Sarasota, Fla., opening round.

THE SOMBER JOB AHEAD

The bank is a Government entity that assists American companies in selling their goods abroad through loans, guarantees and insurance.

title: WHITTAKER MAPS NEW COURSE

title: Monsanto Suit
description: A shareholder suit has been filed in Illinois Circuit Court charging that directors of the Monsanto Company failed to adequately protect the company from the potential liabilities associated with the Copper-7 intrauterine device, marketed by its subsidiary, G.D. Searle & Company. The suit, filed on behalf of the Gitta Gradova Cottle Trust, said Monsanto's board knew of Searle's legal problems and their potential financial burden before its August takeover of Searle, but did not take any action to protect itself. Monsanto officials said they had not seen the suit and would not comment yet.

description: To the Editor:

title: OIL PRICES IN MODERATE RALLY
description: Reversing a sharp three-day slide, prices for crude oil and petroleum products rose moderately in light trading yesterday on world markets. Prices for refined products moved close to or above the 50-cents-a-gallon level, and crude oil prices moved above the $16-a-barrel mark.

title: 1987 BUDGET PROPOSAL WOULD TRIM ARTS 12.5%
description: President Reagan's budget proposal, submitted to Congress today, would reduce the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts by 12.5 percent next year, from $165.7 million to $144.9 million.

title: Use Gramm-Rudman To Cut Arms Costs
description: The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit-reduction law should give the arms control community in Washington an incentive to press for meaningful cuts in new weapons systems and - assuming reciprocal action by the Soviet Union - for a meaningful slowdown in the arms race.

description: President Reagan sent to Congress today a 1987 budget that would shrink the size of the Government and seemed certain to set off a battle of wills between the White House and Capitol Hill.

title: Britain to Sell Water Plants
description: The British Government said today that it planned to sell off the water companies of England and Wales in the biggest step so far in its campaign to place state-owned industries in private ownership.

title: President of Dartmouth Orders Shacks Removed
description: The president of Dartmouth College today ordered students opposed to the school's South Africa-linked investments to remove their shantytown from the college green.

title: Shops Remain Closed
description: Commerce in this troubled capital remained curtailed today as many businesses remained closed despite Government warnings that merchants faced imprisonment, fines or seizure of their businesses.

title: POPE EMPHASIZES RELIGIOUS LIBERTY
description: Pope John Paul II, paying homage to St. Thomas the Apostle at a hilltop shrine and greeting a multitude at a seaside mass, called on the Indian Government today to live up to its Constitution's guarantees of religious freedom.

title: CHIEF OF STUDY ON VICTIMS' FAMILIES DOUBTS AIDS IS TRANSMITTED CASUALLY
description: The largest and most thorough study of members of the families of AIDS victims completed to date provides ''conclusive'' evidence that the fatal disease does not spread through close, day-to-day personal contact, according to the leader of the research team.

description: In the last heated minutes, one St. Louis Blues player after another had his opening only to miss the net. It seemed that the Ranger goalie Vanbiesbrouck knew that he could not support his fragile defense because he shifted noticeably left and right in his tracks.

description: Eight months after being elevated to the rank of Cardinal, Miguel Obando y Bravo has suddenly become the object of strong political attacks by Sandinista authorities.

description: Research and development, long a favored activity under the Reagan Administration, would continue to grow significantly under the President's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1987.

title: A Cunningham Ballet Wins Approval in Paris
description: Merce Cunningham's ballet ''One Day or Two,'' created in 1973 for the Paris Opera Ballet, formally entered the company's repertory last week to the apparent approval of Paris critics.

title: Topics; Accommodations Luxury for Charity
description: Hospital accountants call it ''cost shifting'' - covering the unpaid bills of the poor by quietly padding the bills of everyone else. But now private insurers, seeking to control costs, are cracking down on cost shifting, and that creates a bind for big urban hospitals with a disproportionate share of charity cases.

title: USF&G TO RESTATE NET INCOME RESULTS
description: The USF&G Corporation, parent of the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company, said yesterday that it intends to restate its previously reported net income for the first nine months of 1985 and for the two previous years. The amount of the restatement was not disclosed.

title: Shuffle in Harmony
description: Bowing to pressure from the Illinois Attorney General's office, Dick Meyer, the producer of the Chicago Bears' record, ''Super Bowl Shuffle,'' has agreed to give 75 percent of the record's profits to charity. At the time the record was made, Meyer said that half the profits would go to help the needy in Chicago. He agreed to the 75 percent donation to comply with a state law requiring that at least three-quarters of the profits of a charitable endeavor go to charity.

description: Four tornadoes spawned by thunderstorms struck eastern Texas today, killing one person and injuring dozens of others, the authorities said.

title: NETS SUFFER THEIR WORST LOSS OF 1980'S
description: The mood was hardly somber, but it was obvious from their words and their actions that the Nets consider themselves at a crossroads. Their performances over the last four weeks have ranged from dull to disastrous, and now they will have the next five days to consider their latest failure: a 142-107 loss tonight to the Philadelphia 76ers at the Spectrum.

title: ALCOTT MIXES BIRDIES, BAGELS

title: HERS
description: THE Chinese restaurant is in a section of Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington where the table linen is changed after each meal, the Boston ferns are real, and the stir-fried string beans and ginger will cost you the down payment on a plot of land to grow your own. The young woman who comes in and sits alone could have just stepped out of any Ebony Christmas ad for Courvoisier: her shoulder-length braids are impeccable, the honey-brown skin has red highlights around the cheekbones from either the chill wind or conservatively applied blush. She moves her manicured hands with the grace of someone who is accustomed to having them pampered each week. As she places her leather portfolio on the seat beside her and picks up the menu, her body language is indisputable: she is treating herself in celebration of some personal victory - a successful business meeting? a new promotion at work? bank approval of a condominium loan? Any of those could be plugged into this picture realistically, and what is all too real is the fact that she's celebrating alone.

title: J.P. Stevens Unit
description: J. P. Stevens & Company said it had sold its woolen and worsted fabrics division to Forstmann & Company, as part of its previously announced plan to end its activities in the apparel fabrics industry and concentrate on the production of home and industrial fabrics.

title: Girl's Natural Mother Agrees To Give Marrow in Transplant
description: A 16-year-old girl suffering from Hodgkin's disease received word Tuesday that her mother, who gave her up for adoption soon after she was born, had agreed to donate bone marrow needed to keep the girl alive.

title: EMBASSY MONEY UNLIKELY, SHULTZ IS TOLD

title: RECITAL: NEIL RUTMAN, PIANIST
description: THE pianist Neil Rutman, who presented a fine, engrossing concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night, originally studied with Aiko Onishi, and then interrupted his musical education to work as a missionary in Scotland. After two years, he returned to his piano studies, graduated from both the Eastman School of Music and the Peabody Conservatory, and recently won the Seventh Annual Joanna Hodges Piano Conference and Competition.

description: The 600 members of a feared security police unit were taken into custody for investigation today, a police source said, and there were reports that the unit would be abolished by the new civilian President, Vinicio Cerezo.

title: CUATION ON EARLY PLANTING

Seedlings surge into growing once they germinate. If they are started too early indoors without the benefit of the strong outdoor sun, they become tall and spindly and when set outdoors go into a decline.

title: Loser in Arbitration
description: In the first arbitration case to be settled this off-season, Alvin Davis, the Seattle first baseman who was the American League rookie of the year in 1984, lost in his effort to get a $550,000 salary. Instead, he was awarded the Mariners' offer of $400,000, which comes after Davis's second season in the majors and after he batted .287 with 18 home runs and 78 runs batted in. . . . The Yankees, who have a left-handed first baseman from Indiana of considerable ability, have signed another one, Mark Manering, their first selection in the secondary phase of the free-agent draft last month. Manering, a 22-year-old native of LaPorte, Ind., spent the last four years setting school records for hits (208), home runs (24) and runs batted in (135) while batting .347 at Miami of Ohio.

title: BALLET: SADLER'S WELLS

title: DELICATE REPAIRS OF TOILET MIRRORS
description: The dressing glass or toilet mirror as a distinct article of furniture was introduced in England during the 18th century. Its popularity soon spread to America. Designed to be placed on a dressing table or chest or over a basin, it was shaped like a cheval mirror in miniature. The rectangular, oval or square mirror was swivel-mounted between two upright posts that rose from the base. Although there were other arrangements, the base usually housed three drawers.

title: BROADWAY VS. WEST END
description: I DON'T know a single American who saw Michael Frayn's ''Benefactors'' in London, myself included, who imagined that the play would last a month in New York. Even those who liked ''Benefactors'' couldn't picture a large Broadway audience for a muted Chekhovian piece in which the metaphorical cherry orchard is a slum London neighborhood to be cleared for mass housing. The play was too parochially English - possibly ''too intellectual'' and, worse, ''too brittle.'' Yet ''Benefactors'' has proved the most highly attended play of the Broadway season.

title: PROVIDENT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MERITOR FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $8,754,000 for the quarter and $43,637,000 for the year.

title: KEY PROGRAMS TO BE ELIMINATED AND THE REASONS FOR DOING SO
description: In the budget submitted to Congress today, President Reagan proposed to abolish more than two dozen Government programs. The Administration's rationale for eliminating these programs, as well as the justification for some other budget proposals, is contained in a document distributed by the Office of Management and Budget. What follows is a description, drawn from that document, of some of the prominent programs the President would terminate and the Administration's rationale for doing so. The dates are fiscal years. UU Health Professions Training Program: Training grants to increase the number of doctors, dentists, nurses and other health professionals. Proposal: Eliminate all grants but continue students' access to private loans guaranteed by the Government. Rationale: A shortage in these professions no longer exists, and ''future supply will outstrip demand.'' The grants are ''an inappropriate upper-income subsidy.'' Saving: $147 million in 1987; $249 million in 1991. UU Work Incentive Program Program: Employment counseling, job-search assistance and other social services to welfare recipients. Proposal: Stop financing at the end of the current fiscal year. Rationale: ''Separate Federal programs provide identical services to the same population.'' Saving: $189 million in 1987; $249 million in 1991. UU Conservation Assistance Program: Financial assistance to farmers, ranchers and land owners who initiate soil and water conservation measures. Proposal: Stop immediately direct financial assistance but continue technical assistance. Rationale: The programs are ''outdated and ineffective components of our agricultural conservation program'' that are so ''fragmented and untargeted'' that they miss ''the most serious problems on a year to year basis.''

title: Technology; Detecting Food Contaminants
description: FOR the nation's farmers, the use of pesticides, animal drugs and other toxic substances is a way to increase production and limit damage from pests and disease.

title: 2 New Fed Members
description: The Senate, by voice vote, today confirmed Manuel H. Johnson and Wayne D. Angell to seats on the Federal Reserve Board. Their confirmation means that appointees of President Reagan will have four seats, a majority of the seven-member board.

title: REAGAN'S SPEECH ASSAILED BY SOVIET
description: The official Soviet press agency condemned President Reagan's State of the Union address today and warned that proposed increases in American defense spending would intensify the arms race.

title: DATAMARINE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: SOTHEBY'S PLANS $70 MILLION ADDITION
description: Sotheby's said yesterday that it was planning to add a 27-story apartment tower to its four-story New York headquarters at York Avenue at 72d Street. The $70 million expansion, designed by Michael Graves, the Princeton, N.J., architect, would begin construction in a year if approved by the city's Planning Commission and Board of Estimate.

title: Education Board Sued Over Its Bus Contracts
description: A major operator of public school buses in New York City said yesterday that it had filed suit against the city's Board of Education seeking to invalidate the board's contracts with nearly 150 other bus companies.

title: ASBESTOS DECLINE IN CANADA
description: This mining town in Canada's Appalachian Mountains was once so proud of being at the hub of the country's asbestos industry that it billed itself as the ''City of White Gold.'' As recently as 15 years ago, children played on giant piles of asbestos tailings from the busy mills here and jobs seemed as free as the bracing winter air.

title: When They Took the Wraps Off 'Civic Virtue'
description: To the Editor:

title: VIPONT LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of 440,130. c-Net loss.

title: USERS OF COMPANY CARS FACE TAX SURPRISES
description: For years the tax laws have helped put many doctors behind the wheel of a Mercedes and countless other taxpayers at the keyboard of a home computer by allowing them to write off their purchases as a business expense. But Congress, which has long suspected that many of these cars and computers were being used mainly for personal purposes, has made such deductions less generous and more irksome to claim.

title: Serious Driving
description: Members of the diplomatic corps are known to drive big cars, but none of those limos have been drawing more stares than the big black Cadillac used by Jean-Luc Lebeau, who is with the communications section of the French Embassy. It is a 25-year-old hearse.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DETROIT AIRPORT FEELS GROWING PAINS
description: For years frequent airline travelers in the Middle West extolled Detroit Metropolitan Airport and its uncrowded terminals, roomy parking lots and quick getaways as a welcome contrast to busier airports.

title: UNITED STATES HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a provision of $3.9 million relating to the restructuring of the company's manufactured housing operations and $4.5 million relating to certain receivables. c-Including a provision of $4.6 million in the quarter and $34.1 million in the year, relating to the reduction of the stated value of land and housing inventories.

title: THERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Joining Youth
description: Having added ''streetwise'' to the familiar list that includes ''cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean and reverent,'' the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America has noted its 75th straight month of membership gains as its 75th anniversary year draws to an end.

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets figure represents total net assets. After distributions of $3.25 a share during the 12-month period ended Dec. 31, 1985, and federal income tax liability of 63-9/10 cents a share for undistributed long-term capital gains at Dec. 31, 1985.

title: LACK OF PUBLICITY IS QUESTIONED AFTER COMPANY WITHDREW A DRUG
description: A Senate committee has asked the Food and Drug Administration to explain why it failed to announce to the public that a drug that was for 15 deaths overseas had been taken off the market in the United States by its manufacturer.

title: FIELDCREST MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $5.4 million for the restructuring of operations.

title: L.I. School Giving Girl In Accident 3.5 Million
description: A young gymnast left partially paralyzed by an accident on school property has won a $3.5 million settlement from the East Meadow school district.

title: The Serenity Vote
description: With five weeks to go before crucial French legislative elections on March 16, there has been an unforeseen and revealing change of tone in the campaign.

title: RED APPLE BUYING GRISTEDES
description: The Red Apple Company, a supermarket operator based in New York, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the 36 Gristedes Brothers supermarkets in the metropolitan area from the Southland Corporation.

title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically offers a selection of such questions.

title: JOINT HELP FOR MEXICO SUGGESTED
description: Bankers said yesterday that Mexico's debt burden, aggravated by the slump in oil prices, would probably require a joint rescue by lenders, with most of the assistance coming from public entities such as the International Monetary Fund, the Inter-American Development Bank and governments around the world.

title: NEW PROCESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books: Beyond X-rays
description: A MACHINE CALLED INDOMITABLE.By Sonny Kleinfield. 250 pages. Times

title: Hess and Officials Meet
description: Leon Hess, the owner of the Jets, met for 90 minutes yesterday in his office with representatives from the city and the state to discuss whether he would bring the Jets back to New York by 1989.

title: A DAY AT THE RINK
description: It was cold in the Newbridge Road Park ice skating rink, the site of the ladies' compulsory figure-skating competition yesterday. Young women drew figure 8's on the ice as spectators seemed at times to exhale them with their steamy breath.

title: HOME INTENSIVE CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago results are not meaningful because it is the surviving entity of a merger and reorganization with a public company.

title: Von Stade to Sing At City Ballet Premiere
description: Frederica von Stade will sing tonight in the world premiere of Peter Martins's ''Chants d'Auvergne,'' performed by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater. The mezzo-soprano will appear only in the first performance of the ballet, which is set to Joseph Canteloube's arrangement of 13 folk songs from the Auvergne region of France.

title: GENERAL AMERICAN INVESTORS CO reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets figures represent net assets. Year-ago per share does not reflect a long-term capital gain distribution of $1.35 per share and an income dividend of 28 cents per share, both paid in March 1985.

title: DUPONT AWARDS ANNOUNCED
description: ABC's news program ''Nightline'' won an Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Award last night for a series of reports on South Africa that the awards jury called ''the most extraordinary television of the year.''

title: Advertising; Furniture Discounter Moves to Bloom & Gelb
description: The Edgar B Furniture Plantation, a discount catalogue operation based in Clemmons, N.C., has switched its account to Bloom & Gelb, a direct marketing subsidiary of Jordan, Case, Taylor & McGrath, from Morphis & Friends in Winston-Salem.

title: Advertising; Media Research Giants Offer Computer Aids
description: The Simmons Market Research Bureau, one of the country's major forces in syndicated media audience research, yesterday revealed the future. It is a new microcomputer system called Choices, which, although as complete as Simmons's current offerings, will be much more portable and far more user friendly.

title: BREEDING AND TRAINING OF HORSES IS HELPING TO SAVE JERSEY FARMS
description: After struggling for years to make a living in the cattle business, Taylor Palmer Jr. faced a tough decision in 1979. ''It was either try something new or sell out,'' he said.

title: '84 STUDT CITED ROCKET'S PRESSURE SHIFT
description: The booster rockets suspected as a possible cause of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28 have showed a tendency to undergo abnormally large changes in internal pressure about 60 seconds into a flight, according to a 1984 analysis done for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: GENRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After a charge of $19 million for the quarter and the year related to severance payments, early retirement benefits, facility closings, discontinued product lines and inventory writeoffs. c-Net income.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $25,900,000 for the quarter and $26,900,000 for the year. c-After a charge of $207 million for establishing a reserve for unrecovered gas costs. d-Net income. The latest quarter and year results include a net gain of $11 million as a result of discontinued application of financial accounting standards number 71.

title: FINALLY, GASOLINE PRICES START TO FALL AT PUMPT
description: Local service stations have begun to lower gasoline prices in the last week, in many cases by 3 to 4 cents a gallon.

title: N.H.L. APPROVES SOVIET INVOLVEMENT
description: To generate more interest for its All-Star Game, the National Hockey League has decided to involve a team from the Soviet Union.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: General Development Corporation to McColloch, Bryan, Cipriano in Miami.

title: PARKING TICKET CONTRACT SOUGHT
description: With more than 590,000 parking tickets unprocessed because of a contract cancellation, officials of the City Parking Violations Bureau said yesterday that they hoped to be able to sign an emergency contract today with a company to keypunch information from summonses into the bureau's computers.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $3,780,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Line by Line For 75th Birthday
description: Jack Rosen, a retired artist who lives at 8701 Shore Road in Brooklyn, drew a caricature of President Reagan the other day and decided to send it to him as a birthday gift. The President will be 75 years old on Thursday. According to a White House spokesman, the President received the drawing, which consists of 75 different lines, and ''appreciates it very much.''

title: Pump Leaks Plutonium Mist At a Nuclear Plant in Britain
description: Plutonium mist leaked from Britain's only nuclear reprocessing plant today, prompting a major alert and tests on 70 workers, the plant owners said.

title: ARCHITECTS' DRAWINGS LURE COLLECTORS
description: ''THE painter sketches to paint, the sculptor draws to carve, and the architect draws to build,'' the late Louis Kahn once wrote. And it is true. Architects tend to put pencil to paper mainly for practical reasons, not for the sake of art. After serving the utilitarian purpose, ''to build,'' the architect's drawings tend to stay, more or less, in his or the client's files.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 6, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the situation in Southern Africa at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CHAIRS and tables that are loose and rickety or have burn marks or other minor blemishes in the finish can often be rejuvenated without costly repairs.

title: Quantum Is Suing NEC on Patents
description: The Quantum Corporation of Milpitas, Calif., a leading manufacturer of Winchester disk drives, said it had filed a patent infringement suit against the NEC Corporation, NEC Information Systems Inc. and Mountain Computer Inc.

Figures include the results of Mohawk Rubber Company and Mastershield Incorporation since their acquisition in September 1984.

title: ELECTION OBSERVERS FACE HUGE TASK
description: Along with Philippine citizens groups and official poll-watchers, the 20 American political professionals and academics who arrived here today to monitor the presidential election face a prodigious task.

title: RESDEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $186,000 in the quarter and $366,000 in the year. c-Net losses.

title: WOODSIDE PLANT TURNED INTO CONDOMINIUMS UNITS
description: Alex Blau does not own property in Manhattan but the higher that prices rise for co-ops and condominiums in Manhattan, the happier he is. Mr. Blau builds for people priced out of the Manhattan market.

title: Mickey Bass Quartet
description: The bassist Mickey Bass is leading a quartet - with James Williams on piano, Bobby Watson on alto saxophone and Mark Johnson on drums -tonight and tomorrow at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue, near 23d Street (242-9066). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: GANNETT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OIL IMPORT TAX: THE DOOR OPENS
description: President Reagan's assertion this week that he might accept a tax on imported oil in certain circumstances has somewhat changed the script for tax legislation in the Senate.

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $167.5 million for the quarter and the year for a restructuring program to dispose of some assets, reduce the carrying value of others and sell or liquidate some businesses. c-Net income.

title: FOR SKATERS, IT'S TANGO ON ICE
description: The role of Rudolph Valentino was not totally unfamiliar to Donald Adair. Any figure skater who has sought the perfect partner may have felt at times like a cad, discarding those who do Adair went through that stage of his career five years ago when he found Renee Roca. It was at the point, he said, where he could not afford to make the wrong choice.

title: Texans Cancel Staging Of Uncut 'Civil Wars'
description: The proposed production of the complete ''Civil Wars'' theatrical epic by Robert Wilson, planned for Austin, Tex., in September as part of the Texas Sesquicentennial celebration, has been canceled, the Texas production team formed to present the work said yesterday.

title: THEATER: 'DEEP SLEEP' BY JESURUN AT LA MAMA
description: IN Woody Allen's ''Purple Rose of Cairo,'' the leading man in a movie steps off the screen and into life and, conversely, the leading lady in life is magnetically attracted to the glamorous world on screen. John Jesurun's new play, ''Deep Sleep'' (at La Mama Annex), takes an alternative look at the crosscurrents of truth and cinematic illusion. His devious - and exceedingly clever - play considers the nature of the reel thing.

title: City Awards Contract To Process Summonses
description: An emergency contract to prepare New York City's backlog of parking tickets for computer processing was awarded yesterday to Commercial Computer Service Inc. of Belleville, N.J., the City Department of Transportation announced last night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Man Goetz Wounded Is Let Out of Hospital
description: A young man who was shot on a subway car by Bernhard H. Goetz in 1984 was released from St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center yesterday.

title: PICASSO SKETCHBOOKS TO GO ON VIEW
description: Forty-five of the 175 sketchbooks left by Pablo Picasso at the time of his death are to be exhibited for the first time anywhere at the Pace Gallery from May through July. They will also be the subject of a book called ''I Am the Sketchbook: The Sketchbooks of Pablo Picasso,'' to be published by the Atlantic Monthly Press in September in conjunction with the Pace Gallery, which gained the right to exhibit the sketchbooks after five years of negotiation. It will mark the 25th anniversary of the gallery's founding.

title: BRITISH CHOREOGRAPHER GETS U.S. INTRODUCTION
description: David Bintley suspects he was fated to be a choreographer. As he puts it, ''I had all these random interests and they somehow came together in choreography.'' The son of two piano teachers, he cannot remember a time when he did not like music. Over the years, he developed a love of painting. And by the time he was 5, he was stagestruck.

title: Advertising; Bache, C.I.T. Agencies Set
description: There was advertising activity in the monied halls of the financial community yesterday as Ted Bates Advertising/New York picked up the Prudential-Bache Securities investment banking and brokerage account and Edwin Bird Wilson was tapped to be agency for the C.I.T. Financial Corporation.

title: 1987 PEN Congress Is Set for Switzerland
description: The lakeside town of Lugano will play host to next year's International PEN Congress of the world's leading poets, authors and playwrights, a spokesman for the local author's federation said today.

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2.5 million from the sale of an installment not received from the sale of Royster Co. c-Including net from discontinued operations of $457,000.

title: BALLET: SADLER'S WELLS IN 'BEAUTY'
description: AT the end of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' occurs a stately melody that many dancegoers imagine could be the national anthem of the fairy-tale realm in which the ballet is set. When the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet danced ''The Sleeping Beauty'' on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, audiences heard, in addition to Tchaikovsky's imaginary anthem at the conclusion, two real anthems at the outset: ''God Save the Queen'' and ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' The performance was a gala in the presence of Princess Margaret, who is president of the Sadler's Wells company.

title: REAGAN PLEDGING MORE DECONTROL
description: President Reagan said today that he would seek further deregulation of the nation's banks and the dismantling of the Government's elaborate farm support bureaucracy.

title: Officer Pleads Guilty In Hit-and-Run Case
description: A suspended New York City police officer will be sentenced to one year's probation after pleading guilty to charges stemming from an off-duty hit-and-run accident in which his car struck a young woman riding a bicycle. The woman was not seriously injured.

title: Jan Kalnberzin Is Dead at 92; Former Soviet Latvian Leader
description: Jan Kalnberzin, Communist Party leader of Latvia for 19 years after the Baltic nation was absorbed into the Soviet Union in 1940, has died after a long illness, the Soviet press agency Tass said today. He was 92 years old. Mr. Kalnberzin was born Sept. 17, 1893, near Riga, the capital of Latvia, and joined the Communist Party in April 1917.

title: ART: BLADEN SCULPTURES AT WASHBURN GALLERIES
description: RONALD BLADEN came to New York from San Francisco in the mid-1950's as an abstract painter. After gaining a reputation for expressive yet austere works in which squat, daubs of color could be scattered over vast, thickly impastoed surfaces, Bladen turned to sculpture. First he made reliefs. Then, in the mid-60's, he began creating the large, abstract sculptures for which he is best known. Most of them are angular. Although they appear straightforward, they can be discreetly diabolical. They never allow us to feel in control.

title: I.M.F. MAY BAR PERU FROM FURTHER CREDITS
description: Peru, which has fallen behind in loan repayments to the International Monetary Fund, may be declared ineligible for further credits, monetary officials said today.

title: Curbs on Tax-Free Bonds Are Unconstitutional
description: To the Editor:

title: Statue of Liberty Through Children's Eyes
description: In some paintings, she is crying. In others, she wears shocking pink lipstick and scarlet fingernail polish.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 7, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on situation in southern Africa.

title: MODIFIED PLAN FOR OFFSHORE OIL LEASES OFFERED
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel today proposed a five-year offshore oil and gas exploration program that would slow sales of drilling rights and exclude 15 areas from the leasing program.

title: Collegiate Chorale
description: The Collegiate Chorale will sing Mozart's Mass in C minor and Schubert's Mass in G at St. Bartholemew's Church, 50th Street and Park Avenue, on Sunday afternoon at 4 o'clock.

title: Faust Is Prepared
description: When Lou Holtz, then the Minnesota coach, was asked to replace Gerry Faust at Notre Dame last season, Holtz did not have to ask Minnesota's permission to accept the offer. Although he had a long-term contract, Holtz had insisted on a provision allowing him to leave any time Notre Dame called.

title: An Oil-Import Tax Would be a Mistake
description: The sudden drop in oil prices has set off a clamor for the United States to slap a stiff tax on imported petroleum. The proponents of an import fee as high as $12 a barrel argue that it would reduce dependence on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, prop up domestic production and raise revenue that could be used to trim the budget deficit. They contend that only Arab producers would be hurt.

title: SPEND A BUCK CITED AS HORSE OF YEAR
description: Spend a Buck, the $12,500 colt who won the Kentucky Derby and a record $2 million bonus last May, today won the Eclipse Award as the Horse of the Year for 1985.

title: EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Oil Prices Up Modestly; Trading Reported Light
description: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products rose slightly in light trading yesterday, as the market continued the cautious upturn begun Wednesday. But traders cast a nervous glance toward a meeting of Norwegian oil officials this weekend.

title: LED SOVIET ICE-FLOE RESEARCH
description: Ivan D. Papanin, the Soviet polar explorer who commanded the Russians' first ice-floe station in 1937-38 in one of the more daring exploits in polar history, died Jan. 30 in Moscow. He was 91 years old.

title: JETS WILL REMAIN IN NEW JERSEY
description: The Jets have rejected state and city attempts to bring the club back to New York and will continue to play in Giants Stadium.

title: THE DOWNTOWN PRESS: 4 IRREVERENT JOURNALS
description: Tish Gervais, a downtown nightclub performer, arrived at Area one night not long ago wearing a stole made of newspaper clippings that mentioned her. The authors of the articles were the club's guests of honor: chroniclers of the performers, artists, designers, fashion addicts and the self-styled ''fabulous'' who populate downtown Manhattan and fill the pages of New York City's newly resurgent alternative press.

title: FILIPINOS' BEST HOPE IS FOR A 'FAIRLY DIRTY' ELECTION
description: Out in the voting precincts, the political machine of Ferdinand E. Marcos fought for its life as the voters persisted through a maze of bureaucracy and knavery to get to the precious ballot boxes.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: THERE'S a new kind of art springing up in parks, plazas and lobbies around the country - a public art that is a hybrid of sculpture and architecture, and sometimes of sculpture and furniture. The artists are often prominent painters and sculptors who have switched from flourishing careers with exhibitions in leading art galleries to working mainly on commissions from city governments, universities and corporations. And their work is raising anew the familiar 20th-century question ''But is it art?''

title: OPINIONS DIFFER SHARPLY AS CONSULTANT USE RISES
description: New York City is spending more than ever before on consultants, a practice that has generated differences over how the consultants are hired, whether much of the work could be done by municipal employees, and even how much money is now being spent on such contracts.

title: MILLIONS WHO LOST PLANT JOBS LOSE PAY IN SHIFT TO SERVICES
description: A Congressional study has found that 11.5 million workers lost jobs because of plant shutdowns or relocations from 1979 to 1984 and that only 60 percent of them got new jobs in that period.

title: Red Apple Chairman Goes Grocery Shopping
description: John A. Catsimatidis likes to buy grocery stores. And lately he has been on a binge.

title: AUCTIONS
description: RUTH GORDON'S extensive collection of designer clothes - Mainbochers, Balenciagas, Diors and Chanels - as well as memorabilia of her 70 years in theater and films, will be auctioned next week at William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street. The collection of more than 500 items, valued by the auction house at $86,000 to $134,000, will be on view tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M., Monday from 9 to 7:30 and Tuesday from 9 to 5 before the auction on Thursday at 2 and 7 P.M.

title: Advertising; 2 Nivea Assignments Given to Posey & Quest
description: Biersdorf Inc., a subsidiary of the West German company that makes Nivea skin care products, has given two additional assignments to Posey & Quest, which does its work where other ad people play - Fairfield County, Conn.

title: DUVALIER SUMMONS U.S. ENVOY
description: President Jean-Claude Duvalier summoned the United States Ambassador today, prompting speculation that the Haitian ruler was preparing to leave the country. A spokesman for the United States Embassy would not comment on the meeting.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Letter: On the Economy; Planning Conversion for an Arms Accord
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stars and Stripes in Haiti
description: Haiti's commerce has been paralyzed and its President-for-Life is said to be shopping for a place of asylum. But his secret police - twice the size of Haiti's army - still spreads terror in the streets. What should be the United States' policy at this critical moment? Just what Secretary of State Shultz said on Monday that it was: to favor a government ''put there by the democratic process.''

title: British Hold Farrakhan For Questioning
description: Louis Farrakhan, the American Black Muslim minister barred from entering Britain, was detained for questioning by British immigration officers today when he landed at Heathrow Airport on his way to Nigeria.

title: Lebanese Leader Says He'll Serve Out Term
description: President Amin Gemayel said today that he had no intention of resigning under pressure from his Syrian-backed opponents and would serve out his term.

title: CRUMP, E H COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pension Fund Sells U.S. Steel Shares
description: The United States Steel Corporation's pension fund has sold 1.25 million shares of the company's preferred stock and 2,975,000 warrants through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: MOTHER GETS AIDS FROM ILL BOY
description: Federal health officials today reported the first known case in which a parent caught the AIDS virus from a child, but they attributed it to extensive contact with blood and bodily fluids, not ordinary contact among family members.

title: Stephen Patrick Traded
description: The Rangers acquired Stephen Patrick last season in the hope that he would become the physical scorer they needed. But he was benched this season for several weeks, demoted to New Haven on Jan. 25, suspended two days later for not reporting and yesterday he was traded.

title: CHARGES BRING LOSSES AT ALLIED, DOW
description: Both Allied-Signal and Dow Chemical yesterday reported fourth-quarter losses caused by big special charges.

title: To Go On Is the Best Tribute to the Astronauts
description: To the Editor:

title: Bedford Suspended
description: William Bedford, the center for Memphis State, has been suspended for two games by the National Collegiate Athletic Association because he borrowed luxury cars from school boosters. ''There is no doubt that this is a stiff penalty, but the N.C.A.A. has its rules and regulations and as members of the N.C.A.A. we must abide by them,'' said Charles Cavagnaro, the Memphis State athletic director, who announced the suspension. The suspension stems from allegations last year that Bedford was driving a 1983 Jaguar owned by a booster.

title: ART: THE OTHERWORDLY WORLD OF ROBERTO MATTA
description: THIRTY and some years ago there came into our lives a painter whose images had no precedent. In 1953, for instance, there was a painting in which a humanoid crayfish glowed red-hot as it presented the Host (or something like it) to a congregation of very small beings from outer space. Though really very peculiar, it carried conviction, such was the compelling power of its otherworldly color, its echoes of human behavior and the clear and total commitment of the artist. ''If that's the way he saw it,'' we said to ourselves, ''then that's the way it was.''

title: The Costs of Saving
description: Sometimes saving money is more expensive than not saving money. The new budget-balancing law is forcing spending cuts on Congress along with the rest of Government.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: DOWN in the subtropical and tropical latitudes, preparations are now under way for annual carnival celebrations - full-tilt, public parties that are the last chance for fun before Lent. In New Orleans, Tuesday will be Mardi Gras or ''Fat Tuesday,'' when revelers stuff themselves in preparation for the Lenten austerity that begins on Ash Wednesday. Farther south, some Caribbean islands and Brazil have their own festivities, with music, masks and dancing in the streets.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agri Industries, Des Moines, said it had tentatively agreed to form a grain marketing partnership with Cargill Inc. of Minneapolis.

title: 500 GATHER TO SUPPORT POLICE
description: As the Police Department's Emerald Society band played ''New York, New York'' on bagpipes and drums, 500 people gathered in a converted auditorium at Police Headquarters last night for the New York City Police Foundation's ninth annual dinner dance.

title: WORKERS ACCUSE DYNAMICS
description: Workers at the General Dynamics Corporation here have accused some managers at the company of falsifying time cards, and say the practice has led to overbilling on Government contracts.

title: RED CARPET FOR A REBEL, OR HOW A STAR IS BORN
description: Two weeks ago he was Jonas Savimbi, denizen of the inside pages of newspapers and the foreign policy ''think tanks.'' Now, suddenly, he is Jonas Savimbi, network television personality and welcome guest in the sanctums of the great and the near great.

title: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Bridge: A Tournament, Not Skiing, Draws Some to Switzerland
description: The appeal of Switzerland in winter is not confined to those who seek physical activity on the ski slopes. Some want mental activity at the bridge table, or perhaps a combination of the two. The annual tournament organized in St. Moritz by the Count and Countess Fabricotti attracts players from many countries.

title: Risk and Routine in Space
description: The cause of the accident that destroyed the shuttle Challenger is not yet known, but it appears the problem lay in the booster rockets attached to the orbiter's external fuel tank. If NASA's engineers can pinpoint the trouble, they can quickly fix it and put the shuttle fleet back into operation. Will the shuttle then be perfectly safe? No.

title: CHIEFTAIN DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in the Canadian dollars.

title: Prices on Bonds Slide Again
description: Bond prices declined for the second consecutive day as the Treasury sold $7 billion of new 30-year 9 1/4 percent bonds at an average yield of 9.28 percent.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You know Tammany Hall in New York? You know Daley's slow count in Chicago? We Filipinos learned our politics from the Americans.'' - Arturo Gabuma, an aide to President Ferdinand E. Marcos. [ A10:3. ]

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENTIAL PANEL HEARING ON LOSS OF SHUTTLE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, held in Washington yesterday by a Presidential investigating panel, as recorded by The New York Times. ROGERS: I would like to refer to the Executive Order that created the commission. It says:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SMALL-SCREEN DEAN Tomorrow would have been James Dean's 55th birthday, but he was killed before making it to his 25th. To his fans, he will live forever as a haunting, doomed youth. His film performances have long been classics, but for the next couple of months Dean aficionados will have an unusual opportunity to see some of the star-to-be's early television performances in a new show at the Museum of Broadcasting. The James Dean Exhibition is part of the museum's Discovery Series, a continuing search for television programs thought to be lost, some of which eventually turn up in archives and private collections around the country. The exhibition begins with Dean's first major television role in the ''Kraft TV Theater'' show ''A Long Time Till Dawn,'' a 1953 NBC drama in which he played a rebellious youth just released from prison. Also on this weekend's program is a ''Schlitz Playhouse of the Stars'' show, ''The Unfinished Road,'' a 1955 CBS drama in which Dean played a young drifter who unwittingly becomes involved in racketeering and murder. Screenings today and tomorrow are at 12:05, 1:45 and 3:30 P.M. at 1 East 53d Street. Museum admission is a suggested contribution of $3. Information: 752-7684.

title: GENERAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring net charge to income of $1,150,000, or 15 cents a share, for a loss on the disposition of the Port St. John utility systems.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period

title: HOLLYWOOD RETURNS TO CHINA
description: For the first time since the Communists took power in 1949, two major American film companies, Paramount Pictures and Universal Pictures, will distribute American films in China.

title: Irish Dancing
description: Amateurs and experienced hands at traditional Irish dancing can join the ceili dancing sponsored by the Irish Arts Center tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the Academy of Mount St. Ursula, 330 Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1986
description: International A proposed American counteroffer to Moscow's plan to eliminate nuclear weapons by the year 2000 has been proposed by President Reagan for allies to consider. Officials said the plan called for eliminating American and Soviet medium-range missiles from Europe and for cutting the Soviet SS-20 missile force in Asia by 50 percent. [ Page A1, Column 4. ]

title: TRANSNET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'MEN WHO COOK' BENEFIT
description: A feast for the gastronomically adventurous with some 200 dishes, including Grand Marnier sweet potato pies, crawfish etouffee, fried corn and ginger fish, and beef in cognac and cream sauce with spinach souffle, will be offered Sunday at the International House, 500 Riverside Drive, at 122d Street.

title: Western TV - Surrogate for Freedom?
description: There is a long and respectable history to the idea that totalitarian regimes stand or fall by their seamless control of public information. The experience, in recent years, of the effects of Western television in Eastern Europe raise a number of questions about that assumption.

title: SCARSDALE DRUG DEATH: DISBELIEF, THEN 'DENIAL'
description: At Scarsdale High School, students say that their ''druggie'' classmates are easy to identify. They gather together in the halls, they dress with a certain studied toughness and they often boast about their exploits with drugs.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including equity in earnings of associated companies of $4,985,000 for the quarter and $21,387,000 for the year. c-Including equity in earnings of associated companies of $4,387,000 for the quarter and $13,614,000 for the year.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: MARCELLO SILI is a big, compactly built man with an earnest demeanor and a smile as wide as the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. He is no stranger to habitues of Italian restaurants in New York, having logged 20 years in the business. His latest venture, Marcello, promises to be his crowning achievement.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Hollywood is always full of puzzled - and, often, sore - losers the day after the Academy Award nominations are announced. However, Steven Spielberg's failure to get an Oscar nomination for ''The Color Purple'' has caused unusual shock waves.

title: EASTERN TO RENEW TALKS WITH PILOTS
description: Negotiators for the Air Line Pilots Association and Eastern Airlines have agreed to resume talks Tuesday on concessions the airline says it needs to avoid defaulting on loans.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UPTOWN AND DOWNTOWN FESTIVALS IN THE SPOTLIGHT;
description: THE East/West Theater Festival will not present a Noh production of a Sam Shepard play. But that is about the only theater that won't be offered at the three-week festival, which opens tomorrow at theaters scattered across upper Manhattan, in an innovative project that offers the adventurous theatergoer the chance to see 19 events with a single $25 pass.

title: FIRE-RIDDEN COAL TOWN DIES SLOWLY AND QUIETLY
description: Hidden in the dining room breakfront, in a blue-enameled box bedecked with handpainted flowers, Molly Darrah keeps the keys to 18 neighbors' houses.

title: BLACK HISTORY ON PBS
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION is celebrating Black History Month with a scattering of programs in which quality is a sometime thing. Much of the emphasis is on black entertainers, usually grouped in eye-catching packages intended to cash in on the enduring value of star names. One of the glossiest, and most disappointing, of these productions is ''The Cotton Club Remembered,'' a ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $22,000 in the quarter and $44,000 in the six months. c-Including tax credits of $74,000 in the quarter and $90,000 in the six months.

title: DAVID L. BENETAR
description: David L. Benetar, a labor-management lawyer, died Tuesday at his law office. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Coca-Cola Deal For Shows Seen
description: The Coca-Cola Company is expected to announce soon, possibly today, that it has agreed to buy some of the assets of Merv Griffin Enterprises, including the popular television game show ''Wheel of Fortune,'' television industry sources said.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,136,000 in the quarter and $2,479,000 in the year, and after a loss in the year of $16,191,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net loss.

title: Palau to Vote on U.S. Ties
description: The Trusteeship Council agreed today to send four observers to the Pacific island republic of Palau this month to monitor a plebiscite in which voters will consider a ''compact of free association'' with the United States. The accord would leave Palau independent, but give the United States responsibility for defense. The request for observers came from the United States Mission here.

title: HOLIDAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Including an extraordinary net gain of $8,738,000 for the quarter and the year from the termination of a pension plan.

title: YEAR OF TIGER, AND NOT JUST IN CHINATOWN
description: THERE won't be a lighted apple descending in Times Square to mark this new year, but there will be fireworks and parades, banquets and family celebrations Sunday to herald the start of the Chinese New Year - the Year of the Tiger. While cymbals crash and roving lion dancers spread good luck across Chinatown, the occasion will also be observed throughout the city with concerts, dance performances and exhibitions.

title: 5 Goals by Andreychuk
description: Dave Andreychuk of the Sabres scored five goals, one short of the modern National Hockey League record, as Buffalo defeated the Boston Bruins, 8-6, tonight.

title: BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $16 million, or 1.52 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Pasadena property and after a charge of $14.1 million from writedown assets of certain operations for the quarter and year. c-Including a credit of $4.5 million from reversal of deferred taxes not required due to the 1984 tax law change regarding DISC.

title: Wheeling Loans
description: A bankruptcy judge delayed authorizing fresh loans today to the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, citing a new lender's concerns about repayment.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Net loss, including an extraordinary gain of $899,000. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,414,000. d-Including an extraordinary gain of $4,116,000, and after a provision for litigation settlement of $1.8 million.

title: Joplin's 'Treemonisha' To Be Shown on Channel 13
description: Scott Joplin's folk opera, ''Treemonisha,'' languished in obscurity for 58 years after the composer's death, until the Houston Grand Opera gave the work its first full production in 1975, directed by Frank Corsaro. Later that year, the production visited Broadway for a limited run. And now the illustrious ragtime composer's most ambitious work can be seen on television. A 1981 staging of the Houston production, filmed in the Miller Outdoor Theater, concludes PBS's three-part series, ''America's Musical Theater,'' on a ringingly joyous note. The 90-minute program, directed by Sid Smith, will be shown Sunday at 3 P.M. on Channel 13. It will be repeated Wednesday at 10.

title: FORD OFFICIALS SEE A HEALTHY INDUSTRY
description: Car and truck sales will decline slightly from the peaks set in 1985, but the industry should remain healthy, top sales executives of the Ford Motor Company predicted today.

title: INVESTIGATION OF MARCOS BY SOLARZ IS ISSUE IN U.S. AS WELL AS MANILA
description: The investigation by a New York Congressman into the financial holdings of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines has become a major issue in the Philippine elections and a source of controversy on Capitol Hill.

title: Advertising; New Drive By SSC&B Shoe Client
description: THE Timberland Company is the new shoemaking client for SSC&B:Lintas USA, which has created the advertising theme line ''More quality than you may ever need.'' It will be accompanied by photos of old, comfortable, perhaps mud-stained, but never unloved, Timberland shoes.

title: McKesson Names Chief Executive
description: The McKesson Corporation, the drug and beauty aid distribution company, announced yesterday that Thomas W. Field Jr., president and chief operating officer, would succeed Neil E. Harlan as chief executive following the company's annual meeting on July 23.

title: MUSIC: CINCINNATI PLAYS SCHOENBERG'S 'PELLEAS'
description: AT the turn of the century, Arnold Schoenberg had overdosed on Brahms and Wagner and was struggling to find a way out of what he came to consider the dead end of the traditional tonal system. Between 1899 and 1902, he composed three works that in effect bid farewell to the 19th century: ''Verklarte Nacht, ''Gurrelieder'' and ''Pelleas und Melisande.'' The first two are reasonably well known to concert and recording audiences, but ''Pelleas und Melisande,'' a massive tone poem based on the same Maeterlinck drama that inspired works by Debussy, Faure and Sibelius, is rarely taken off the shelf and, whether for that reason or not, has had trouble finding an audience.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Avondale Mills In Merger Pact
description: Avondale Mills, a textile manufacturer based in Sylacauga, Ala., said that it had approved a definitive agreement to merge into Walton Monroe Mills Inc. for $23.41 a share, or a total of about $93 million.

title: Plugging In the Capital
description: Information is power in the nation's capital. Access to it, or lack of access, can be the difference between success and failure.

title: MILITARY SAYS BUDGET ADDS UP
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today disputed charges that the Reagan Administration had understated the amount of military spending that would result from the new Pentagon budget.

title: Who Gets Last Laugh?
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford, who provided a broad and amiable target for comedy routines in his two years in the White House, is putting together a symposium on ''Humor and the Presidency'' to be held at the Ford Presidential museum in Grand Rapids, Mich., in September.

title: Reading of Poe Works
description: A free dramatic reading of works by Edgar Allan Poe is planned tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Fordham Library Center of the New York Public Library, 2566 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx. The reading, produced by Robert Kornfeld, will feature Mr. Kornfeld and the actors John Haag and Harriet S. Miller. Information: 881-8900.

title: I.B.M. in Group
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would join the Corporation for Open Systems, a computer industry group being formed to set standards for communication between computers. Most major computer concerns have joined the group, but analysts had suggested that it could not succeed without the cooperation of I.B.M., the largest computer company.

title: AT P.S. 122: WEEKEND OF PERFORMERS ART
description: PERFORMANCE SPACE 122 is offering a feast of avant-garde appetizers this weekend in its fifth annual fund-raising marathon. The fun begins in the lobby of the former East Village schoolhouse where you can play ''sonic miniature golf'' on a 15-by-30-foot putting course that includes a xylophone and a pool of water with miked mixing bowls. The game is one of three music-sculpture installations, including a ''sonic house'' and ''sonic pinball,'' designed by Bill and Mary Buchen.

title: TARPLEY HELPS MICHIGAN OVERCOME PURDUE, 80-79
description: Roy Tarpley scored 18 points as Michigan capitalized on a five-minute scoring drought by Purdue in the second half tonight to edge the Boilermakers, 80-79, and hold on to first place in the Big Ten conference.

title: TURNOUT HEAVY IN PHILLIPPINE VOTING AMID REPORTS OF WIDESPREAD ABUSES
description: Filipinos voted today in a bitterly contested election marked by reports of fraud and violence, the outcome of which many people said could lead to further polarization.

title: Shuttle Disaster Spurs Plan for a British Craft
description: Britain has decided to go ahead with development of a revolutionary spacecraft that could compete with the United States into the 21st century, Government officials said today.

title: CITY'S NEW TOP INVESTIGATOR
description: Kenneth Conboy was in his 14th-floor office, which overlooks City Hall, when a telephone call came from Mayor Koch yesterday afternoon.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $205,000.

title: Argentina Sale Planned
description: Argentine officials said tonight that the Government would sell its interests in a handful of companies.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1.1 million on sale of a manufaturing concern and after an additional provision for the restructuring program. c-After charges for the restructuring of certain telephone related operations of $2,079,000 for the quarter and $13.5 million for the year. The year results include a gain of $28.6 million on a litigation settlement.

title: Times Net Up 9.4%
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter of 1985 rose 9.4 percent, to $30.2 million, or 75 cents a share, from $27.6 million, or 70 cents a share, in the 1984 quarter.

title: ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $213,000 from discontinued opearation for the quarter and including a gain of $122,000 from discontinued operations for the year. c-Including a gain of $168,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and after a loss of $14,490,000 from discontinued operations for the year.

title: PRESIDENT AT 75: 'JUST LIKE I'M 39'
description: Saying he feels ''just like I'm 39,'' President Reagan celebrated his 75th birthday today with a six-layer cake in the morning, a surprise gift in the evening and an enduring wish that Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, would offer him ''a great present - his approval of everything we've done.''

title: THE SCREEN: 'F/X'
description: ''F/X,'' which opens today at the United Artists Twin and other theaters, is a cheerful send-up of all of us who've said at one point or another, ''Nobody cares about movies about people anymore - all they care about is special effects.''

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''My friends started messing around with this months ago,'' said Betty Friedan the other evening. ''At first I was reluctant because when I was 60 they gave me a surprise party and I was traumatized. But I gave in. This time there's a good mood, in a good place.''

title: OILERS DEFEAT DEVILS
description: It would not be hard to imagine that after games with the Edmonton Oilers the Devils go home wondering about how they almost but not quite manage to keep up with hockey's greatest team.

title: PRICES FALLING AS JERSEY MILK IS SOLD ON S.E.
description: The first out-of-state dairy to operate in New York City in decades has started to drive down the historically high cost of milk here.

title: Fumble Recovered
description: Accepting his award from Sport magazine as the Super Bowl's most valuable player here yesterday, Richard Dent, the Chicago Bears' defensive lineman, said, ''I want to thank The Sporting News'' for the award. After clearing his throat and correcting himself, he went on to heap praise upon his teammates for a job well done this past season, and on Buddy Ryan, the Bears' defensive coordinator, who has left to become coach of the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: NASA EXPANDS SEARCH OF OCEAN SURFACE TO AREA OFF NORTH CAROLINA
description: The search for surface wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger was moved to the coastal waters off North Carolina today, while recovery ships working near the coast of Florida continued to hunt for pieces of wreckage along the ocean bottom.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dan Marino, the Miami Dolphins' quarterback, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his right knee today. He had similar surgery on the knee after the last two seasons. . . Clark Kellogg, the Indiana Pacers' forward, who rejoined the team Jan. 15 after undergoing knee surgery in December, was placed on the injured- reserve list to give him more time to recuperate. . . John Weinert, the basketball coach at Bowling Green, said he would retire at the end of the season. . . Eddie Currie, a reserve goalie on the Jamaica national soccer team and a soldier in the Jamaica Defense Force, disappeared from the team in Miami, where it was participating in the Miami Winter Games.

title: Better With Age
description: The other players will be encouraged to hear that Chris Evert Lloyd thinks the professional tennis tour is becoming more competitive. ''There are no freebies anymore,'' she said.

title: MEASLES EPIDEMIC STRIKING INFANTS IN JERSEY CITY
description: More than a hundred people in Jersey City have contracted measles in an outbreak of the disease that state and national health officials say is unusual.

title: January Mortgage Rate Is Lowest in Six Years
description: Home mortgage rates fell sharply last month, reaching their lowest levels in six years, the Government reported yesterday.

title: BUSH STANDS BY ATTACK ON CUOMO BUT CONCEDES THAT IT WAS HARSH
description: Vice President Bush says he stands by ''the concept'' behind his recent attack on Governor Cuomo of New York, but he acknowledges that he should have chosen his words more carefully.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Columbia at Dartmouth, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 7:30 P.M.); Villanova at Pitt, 8 P.M.; Drew at Swarthmore, 7:30 P.M.; Ramapo at Kean, 7:30 P.M.; Glassboro State at Rutgers-Newark, 7:30 P.M.; John Jay at Lehman, 7:30 P.M.; Medgar Evers at Pratt, 7:30 P.M.; New York Martime at New Jersey Tech, 7:30 P.M.; Yale at Princeton, 7:30 P.M.; York at St. Francis (Brooklyn), 7:30 P.M.; St. Jo seph's Suffolk at Stony Brook, 7:30 P.M.; Baruch at Upsala, 7:30 P.M.; Ramapo at Kean, 7:30 P.M. Figure Skating United States National Championships, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L. I., 11 A.M., junior pairs, championship ladies' and championship men's short programs. Tiffany Chin, Debi Thomas and Caryn Kadavy are among the women in the short program.

title: PORTLAND GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $6,979,000 for unrecoverable costs of an abandoned nuclear project. c-After a net charge of $47 million, primarily from the elimination of a portion of allowance for funds used during construction of the company's 10 percent share of Washington Public Power Supply System Unit No. 3.

title: Dining Out Guide: Saigon to Seoul
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CUISINE DE SAIGON, #154 West 13th Street (255-6003) -

title: STATER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
OPTICAL SPECIALTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Goya's 'Flying Witches' Sells for Record in Spain
description: An oil painting by Goya titled ''Flying Witches'' fetched $520,757, a record auction price for the artist and for Spain, a spokesman for Sotheby's, the auction house, has said.

title: Keeping Tabs On Bobby Knight
description: John Feinstein has embarked on a program in which he hopes to be invisible for seven months.

title: KANSAS CITY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW HAMPHIRE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Stock Split By Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would split the stock of the corporation, issuing three shares for every two held by stockholders of record Feb. 20, 1986. In addition, the company said it would maintain a 25-cents-a-share quarterly dividend after the split, thus effectively raising the annual dividend from $1, to $1.50 a share.

title: KOCH ADVISER IS SUCCESSOR TO MCGINLEY
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named his adviser on criminal justice, Kenneth Conboy, to be the city's new Commissioner of Investigation. He succeeds Patrick W. McGinley, who announced his resignation under pressure a week ago.

title: TRIBUTE TO FRANCE AND MISS LIBERTY
description: A French marching band and the Paris Opera Ballet, a free Bastille Day concert in Central Park with American-style fireworks, Philippe Petit on high wire at Lincoln Center and the most comprehensive exhibition on the Statue of Liberty ever assembled are among highlights of a joint celebration of the Statue of Liberty centennial that will be announced today by Lincoln Center and the New York Public Library.

title: OLYMPIAN OFFERS STUDENTS BEST SHOT
description: The second-period assembly at Brandeis High School yesterday had a ''very important visitor,'' announced the principal, Murray Cohen.

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $75 million from discontinued operations. c-After a losses from discontinued operations of $68.6 million in the quarter and $83,039,000 in the year.

title: South Korean Dissident Joins Opposition Party
description: A key South Korean anti-Government leader announced today that he would join the main opposition group, the New Korea Democratic Party.

title: Pope, in India, Prays For the Bhopal Victims
description: Pope John Paul II prayed today for the victims of the Bhopal chemical disaster and told India's priests that their work on behalf of the poor must grow out of spiritual concerns.

title: JUDGE IN JERSEY REJECTS KIWANIS BAR TO WOMEN
description: A Federal judge ruled today that Kiwanis International's men-only membership policy violated New Jersey's laws against discrimination.

title: VENICE COPES WITH CARNIVAL AND 2 KINDS OF TIDES
description: The bawdy pagan feast of Carnival began with a flood this year. Some people here think it was an omen.

title: FILM: FROM WOODY ALLEN, 'HANNAH AND HER SISTERS'
description: FROM the first, soaring notes of Harry James's trumpet playing ''You Made Me Love You,'' which is heard behind the opening credits, until the series of reconciliation scenes that bring the film to a close, Woody Allen's ''Hannah and Her Sisters'' is virtually nonstop exhilaration - a dramatic comedy not quite like any other, and one that sets new standards for Mr. Allen as well as for all American movie makers.
