title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized gains of $1,032,000 for the quarter and $1,277,000 for the year, a loss from discontinued operations of $7,993,000 for the quarter, a gain from discontinued operations of $117,759,000 for the year and an extraordinary loss of $1,028,000 for the quarter and the year. c-Net income including realized gains of $2,471,000, a gain from discontinued operations of $2,669,000 and an extraordinary gain of $656,000. d-After realized losses of $23,184,000, a gain from discontinued operations of $55,640,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,928,000.

title: Pan-Electric Liquidation
description: Pan-Electric Industries has been put into liquidation by a court order issued Thursday, Price Waterhouse said today. The accounting firm said it had also been dismissed as the conglomerate's provisional liquidators.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $1,343,000 for the quarter and $40,749,000 for the year. c-Including capital gains of $6,975,000 for the quarter and $33,792,000 for the year.

title: Lieutenant Governing
description: To the Editor:

title: Curbs on Tax-Free Bonds Are Unconstitutional
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Milt Jackson, Bobby Hutcherson and Jay Hoggard, Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street (749-5838). The vibraphone, an instrument of the marimba type with electric motors to give it an eerie sort of vibrato, is difficult to master. Cold and metallic in unsympathetic hands, it has proved flexible, responsive, positively warm when played by a handful of improvising musicians. Lionel Hampton may have been the pioneer here. But the key figures of succeeding generations have been Milt Jackson, Bobby Hutcherson and the youngest heavyweight contender, Jay Hoggard.

title: KNICK OFFER TO KING IS RULED IMPROPER
description: The Knicks' salary-sheet offer of $3.3 million to Albert King last fall circumvented the National Basketball Association's salary-cap rule, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Advertising; People
description: * James E. McHugh has been promoted to senior vice president/ media director at Ketchum Advertising/New York.

title: Abrams and McBee
description: The pianist Muhal Richard Abrams and the bassist Cecil McBee will play duets tonight at 8 o'clock at Carnegie Recital Hall (247-7800). Tickets are $10.

title: MERRILL MAY SEEK SUBTENANT
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is seeking a tenant to sublet some 500,000 square feet of space at its new headquarters still under construction at Battery Park City, according to real estate industry sources.

title: ALLIED-SIGNAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After nonrecurring net charges of $675 million for the quarter and $656 million for the year. c-Net income. d-After a net charge of $16 million and including a gain of $15 million, or 19 cents a share, related to property damage insurance proceeds. The latest year results include consolidated results for signal cos. effective Oct. 1, 1985. The prior year results have been restated for comparative purposes.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S ECONOMIC REPORT TO CONGRESS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's Economic Report, sent to Congress today:

title: Foxmeyer Talks
description: The Foxmeyer Corporation said yesterday that it was involved in discussions that might lead to its acquisition.

title: A SUPPLIER TO SCHOOLS IN CITY ACCUSED OF ADULTERATING BEEF
description: Federal authorities are investigating allegations that a company that supplies up to a million pounds of beef a year to New York City public schools has been adulterating its products with vegetable filler and water, law-enforcement officials in Boston said yesterday.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ACCUSED OF MOVING BLACKS ANEW
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha, voicing opposition to Reagan Administration policies toward South Africa, renewed a call today for a regional conference to negotiate settlements of the conflicts in Angola and South-West Africa.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: In the largest decline since November, assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $1.19 billion, to $211 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 73 institutional funds led the decline, dropping $1.06 billion, to $54.54 billion. Assets of the 192 general purpose funds fell $183.2 million, to $60.43 billion, while assets of the 87 broker-dealer funds rose $50.4 million, to $96.03 billion.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $3.1 million due to a higher than expected response to the company's voluntary early retirement program in the U.S.

title: Britain Abandons Austin Rover Plan
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government backtracked today under heavy criticism and said it had abandoned talks about selling the Austin Rover car company to the Ford Motor Company.

title: SCREEN: 'LADY JANE'
description: HELENA BONHAM CARTER, the beautiful young actress who plays the title role in ''Lady Jane,'' has a physical presence that's quite startling. First seen in the flat, constricting costumes of the Reformation, she stands in a crabbed, gnomish posture, her head bowed and her wide-set features contorted by a scowl. But later on, as the character's early sternness disappears, Miss Bonham literally and figuratively lets her hair down. She appears by firelight, on horseback and in various bucolic settings, romping with the handsome blond nobleman she loves. One begins to have the uncomfortable suspicion that this could have been a role for Brooke Shields.

title: Apology by Theismann
description: The Washington Redskins quarterback Joe Theismann, saying he was ''jealous'' of Jim McMahon, is apologizing for disparaging comments he made about the quarterback of the Super Bowl champion Chicago Bears. ''You know, I just guess maybe I got a little envious, a little jealous of the fact that he could do such a great job of advertising,'' Theismann said. ''I've thought about it for a long time and never had the guts to go ahead and do it.''

title: SERVED IN THE NAVY
description: Spanish gunmen suspected of being Basque terrorists today assassinated a vice admiral who was a direct descendent of Christopher Columbus. His driver was also slain.

title: Delectables at Auction
description: The first winner of the Anne Crutcher Professional Fellowship for study and training in the food and wine industry will be announced Sunday when the Washington chapter of Les Dames d'Escoffier holds a Valentine Auction at the new Westin Hotel. The award is named for the former editorial page editor of The Washington Times and food editor of The Washington Star, who was the first local president of Les Dames, an educational organization of professional women in the food and wine industries.

title: GIBSON GREETINGS CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extaordinary loss of $563,000 in the quarter from early retirement of debt and an extraordinary gain of $2,797,000 in the year from the terminated acquisition of the company by Walt Disney Productions.

title: Bell & Howell Divests
description: The Bell & Howell Company, bowing to increased pressure from the investment community, said today that it would divest itself of its South African operations by the end of the year. The company said it would take a $14.1 million after-tax charge for 1985 reflecting costs of the divestment, the closing of an Italian subsidiary and a restructuring of the domestic visual communications division. In the fourth quarter, Bell & Howell earned $8.5 million, or 80 cents a share.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an after-tax gain of $34.8 million on the sale of selected foreign operations.

title: The Mideast Mirage
description: Lost somewhere in the desert air is King Hussein's much-heralded vow finally to start negotiating with Israel. For a year the Jordanian monarch held out what was simultaneously a promise and a threat. If given the cover of an international conference and the reassurance of more American arms, he would engage the Israelis at last, with Palestinians at his side. And if Yasir Arafat refused to approve, the King would show up anyway. The end of January was his deadline; gullible Americans were his messengers.

title: 5 Coal Workers Killed At a West Virginia Plant
description: A hatch beneath a coal silo was opened accidentally today, and five men who were standing on top of the pile suffocated as tons of the finely processed coal collapsed and engulfed them, the authorities said.

title: THERMO ANALYTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
L.I. EMPLOYMENT RISE IN 80'S
description: The economy of Long Island, showing dramatic growth through the first half of the 1980's, has added jobs at more than twice the national rate, according to an appraisal issued by the United States Department of Labor.

title: The Mondale Trap
description: Representative Barbara Boxer, a Democrat from California, recently said of Walter Mondale's 1984 campaign proposal to raise taxes to reduce the deficit: ''Everyone knows he was right, but we don't want to walk into the same trap.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about Wayne Gretzky misreported a suggestion about whom he might play with in the National Hockey League All-Star Game. Michel Goulet of the Quebec Nordiques was a member of the opposing team and could not play on the same line as Gretzky.

title: Argyll Raises Distillers Bid
description: The biggest corporate takeover battle in British history intensified today as Argyll Group P.L.C. raised its hostile bid to acquire the Distillers Company, a leading liquor producer.

title: NASA SEEMS SURPRISED BY AGGRESSIVE QUERIES
description: In its first public hearing, President Reagan's newly appointed commission to investigate the space shuttle disaster immediately homed in on some of the key unresolved questions surrounding the explosion of the Challenger.

title: Ranking System for Public Schools Failed in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Pianists at Sweet Basil
description: There will be piano solos tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, near Bleecker Street (242-1785). Paul Bley will perform tonight at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; tomorrow, Cecil Taylor will play solo sets at 10 and 11:45 P.M., followed at 1:30 A.M. by the trombonist Ray Anderson and his trio. Sunday, the trio Third Kind of Blue - John Purcell on saxophones and woodwinds, Anthony Cox on bass and Ronnie Burrage on drums - will perform at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: No Sandwich, Just the Cash
description: The Carnegie Delicatessen is known for corned beef, pastrami and chutzpah, which is what Leo Steiner thinks five men showed early yesterday when they burst into his Seventh Avenue restaurant and robbed it of $15,000.

title: U.S. VETOES ANTI-ISRAEL MOVE
description: The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution that condemned Israel for intercepting a Libyan plane and termed the action an ''act of aerial hijacking and piracy.''

title: In France, Day Care Is Part of the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Suns' Coach Signs
description: John MacLeod, the coach of the Phoenix Suns, signed a new three-year contract with the team yesterday.

title: Service for Linda Charlton
description: A funeral service for Linda Charlton Murray, a former reporter and Washington correspondent for The New York Times, is to be held Monday at noon at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street. Mrs. Murray, who wrote under the name Linda Charlton, died of a heart attack Sunday at the age of 49.

title: DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special pretax charge of $592 million for the quarter and year for a program of personnel reductions and asset-related writeoffs and writedowns. c-Net income. d-Including extraordinary gains from realization of foreign tax credits of $15 million for the quarter and $36 million for the year, a pretax gain of $183 million for the year on sale of investments and after a special pretax charge of $157 million for the year.

title: KNICKS LOSE
description: Faced with the loss of Bill Cartwright and Pat Cummings for the remainder of the season, the Knicks have hung out the ''Help Wanted'' sign. The job requirements call for a big, strong player, preferably about 6 feet 10 inches or taller, who can play both center and power forward and help the Knicks make the playoffs.

title: S.&P. Reviewing Ratings at Cigna
description: Ratings for about $1 billion of Cigna Corporation securities as well as other securities it has insured or guaranteed are under surveillance for possible reductions, analysts at the Standard & Poor's Corporation said in the latest issue of Creditweek.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Tops 1,600 Level In 7.57 Rise
description: A wave of last-minute buying helped the Dow Jones industrial average limp over the 1,600 level yesterday.

title: SILLS FINDS GOLF AN EASY TASK
description: Tony Sills finished jogging this morning and sat for breakfast at Torrey Pines Golf Club in his sweatsuit. An hour later, in neat yellow pants and a red argyle sweater to ward off the chilly wind, he was one of the first to tee off in the opening round of the Shearson Lehman Brothers Andy Williams Open at Torrey Pines.

title: JUDGE, ON TAPE, DENIES GRAFT
description: A Federal judge accused of influence-peddling and perjury called himself a poor businessman and flatly denied doing a favor in exchange for a lucrative oil deal, according to tapes played by his defense team today.

title: U.P.I. Planning Move For Tennessee Offices
description: United Press International, reorganizing for its impending sale, is moving some corporate business offices from Brentwood, Tenn., to its headquarters in Washington and to nearby Virginia, a spokesman said today.

title: KELLY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share figures reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in September 1985.

title: SPY SUSPECT SAYS HE STOLE PAPERS TO AID CHINA TIES
description: Larry Wu-Tai Chin, a retired Central Intelligence Agency analyst, said today that he stole classified documents from the agency for more than a decade and provided them to the Chinese in a personal campaign to improve relations between Peking and Washington.

title: Poor Health Linked To Blaze in Centralia
description: Living in Centralia is unusually unhealthy, a study released today has found.

title: DONORS FIND DEDUCTIONS BIGGER, RULES STRICTER
description: When it comes to charitable contributions, tax law has long embodied this tenet: Give, and you shall receive. Now taxpayers' good deeds are more amply rewarded. Those who do not itemize deductions can claim a larger share of their contributions, and anyone who uses a car in volunteer charity work gets a bigger mileage allowance.

title: EAST BLOC LANDS, IN REPLY TO U.S., LIMIT TRAVEL
description: Three East European Governments have informed the United States that they are taking travel measures against American diplomats and other officials in retaliation for steps taken by Washington last month against them, diplomats said today.

title: NEW YORK FILIPINOS EAGERLY AWAIT OUTCOME
description: Filipinos opposed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos gathered at St. Agnes Church in midtown Manhattan yesterday to pray for ''a clean and honest election'' in the Philippines. Then they began an election watch in the Ninoy Aquino Movement's election center.

title: A Trailblazer
description: Judy Glenney, a 36-year-old high school teacher in Farmington, N.M., who enjoys playing racquetball and skiing in her leisure time, has been selected by the United States Weightlifting Federation to be one of two American competitors in the first International Women's Weightlifting tournament, March 22-24, in Budapest, Hungary.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Wednesday about the relationship between Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens and Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, a former city official arrested on bribery charges, incompletely summarized interviews with some officials in the administration of former Mayor Abraham D. Beame. (Mr. Lindenauer joined the city government in 1976, during the Beame period.) The officials - Judah Gribetz, Sidney Frigand, Paul Gibson Jr. and James A. Cavanagh - said they had never heard of Mr. Lindenauer until he was arrested last month. Mr. Gribetz and Mr. Cavanagh, both former deputy mayors, left the Beame administration before Mr. Lindenauer's arrival.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOLY SMOKE. By G. Cabrera Infante. 329 pages. Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: DISMISSED TEACHER TESTIFIES
description: An English instructor who claimed she was dismissed because she protested what she felt was special treatment for athletes at the University of Georgia testified today that she would accept as little as $1 in damages if her lawsuit led to academic reforms.

title: Advertising; Hasbro Agency Search Chooses Six Finalists
description: Hasbro Industries, one of the nation's largest toy and game companies, has reached the penultimate plateau in its search for a second agency.

title: Queens Crash and Fire Kill Woman and Child
description: A car careered out of control after a crash in Queens yesterday, speeding in reverse onto a sidewalk, where it struck a woman and her 4-year-old daughter, killing them in a fiery explosion, the authorities said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Wednesday about Senator Edward M. Kennedy's current visit to the Soviet Union gave an incorrect figure for the number of Soviet families who were allowed to emigrate as a result of his 1978 visit. All 18 families on a list he provided to Soviet authorities at that time were allowed to leave.

title: Market Place; Technologies' Chief Is a Hit
description: SECURITIES analysts are giving high marks to Robert F. Daniell, who held his first meeting with analysts on Wednesday as the new chief executive of the United Technologies Corporation. The stock market also apparently voiced its approval yesterday, as the company's shares rose to record levels and closed at 50 3/4, up a point.

title: MUSICIANS DONATE TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Members of the New York City Ballet Orchestra are among the latest contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $169,568 for the quarter and $1,293,694 for the year. c-Including capital gains of $89,176 for the quarter and $444,020 for the year and an extraordinary nonrecurring tax credit of $25,395,506 for the quarter and year.

title: GORBACHEV WANTS RESULTS AT THE SUMMIT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that his next meeting with President Reagan should produce practical results rather than broad statements about reducing the threat of nuclear war, the official Soviet press agency reported.

title: To Go On Is the Best Tribute to the Astronauts
description: To the Editor:

title: THOMAS & BETTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Du Pont Relative Dies In Train-Car Collision
description: A member of the prominent du Pont family was killed and four children were injured in a train-car collision at an unprotected railroad crossing, officials said today.

title: FILIPINOS GO TO VOTE
description: Inspectors checking ballot boxes in Manila before voting began in contest between President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Corazon C. Aquino. Troops were deployed in a move the Government said was aimed at keeping order and the opposition said might be aimed at influencing the outcome. Page A10. (Reuters)

title: STUDY DOUBTS ANTACIDS' VALUE
description: The common practice of taking antacids for indigestion and stomachaches may actually be worthless for many people, even though doctors frequently prescribe the remedies, a Swedish study has concluded.

title: 2 More Strike Out
description: Two more baseball players learned yesterday that they had lost their salary-arbitration cases, giving the clubs a 3-0 record. The latest losers were Alan Knicely, a catcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, who submitted a request for $140,000 and will receive $80,000, and Kevin McReynolds, an outfielder for the San Diego Padres, who will earn $275,000 instead of the $450,000 he sought. Seven players who had filed for arbitration reached agreement with their clubs: Kevin Gross of the Phillies; Roy Thomas of the Seattle Mariners; Steve Crawford of Boston Red Sox; Kevin Bass of the Houston Astros; Onix Concepcion of the Kansas City Royals, and Tom Waddell and Jerry Willard of the Cleveland Indians.

title: GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net charge of $44 million for the quarter and year representing a provision for the company's restructuring program. c-Net income.

title: PLACER DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an after-tax charge of $12.8 million. c-Net income including a gain of $1.1 million from the company's investment in Delphax systems.

title: Diner's Journal
description: TIRED of dainty dishes that satisfy a chef's ego more than your appetite? Does the prospect of another golfball-size grilled quail excite you about as much as a tax audit? If you crave some real restorative midwinter victuals, you might head over to the Barclay Restaurant in the Hotel Inter-Continental, at 48th Street just east of Park Avenue, where a Hungarian festival is on through Feb. 15.

title: 5 NEO-NAZIS GET STIFF SENTENCES FOR CRIME SPREE
description: Five members of a racist, right-wing group that purportedly sought to overthrow the United States Government were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from 40 to 100 years.

title: Occidental Compliance
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had learned from the Federal Trade Commission that it had substantially complied with the F.T.C.'s request for more information in connection with its $3 billion acquisition of Midcon Corporation.

title: Waggoner Duo First
description: Despite a fall only 30 seconds into their four-and-a-half-minute freestyle program, Todd Waggoner and Gillian Wachsman became the national champions in pairs competition last night at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Trimming Down To Join the Force
description: John Englert has promised to eat a lot less. In return, he will be working a lot more - in the 47th Precinct in the Bronx.

title: ELI LILLY & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January.

title: GENDARMES FAN OUT TO KEY-SPOTS IN A JITTERY PARIS
description: The Government assigned a small army of police today to guard key points in Paris in an effort to increase security after three bombing attacks in as many nights in crowded districts of the city.

title: NASA WAS WORRIED BY COLD'S EFFECTS, COMMISSION IS TOLD
description: The space agency testified today that it held a telephone conversation with the manufacturer of the booster rockets for the space shuttle Challenger one day before launching because of concern that seals on the boosters might have been weakened by cold.

title: Economic Scene; Budget's Link To the Dollar
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S new budget has initiated intense public and Congressional debate over his proposals for reordering national priorities and shifting resources from the public to the private sector. Far less noticed, but of equal and possibly even greater importance, is the link between the budget and the Administration's strategy for dealing with national and international economic and monetary problems.

title: CHURCH PLANS IVES CONCERT
description: Manhattan's Central Presbyterian Church did not do particularly well by Charles Ives when he was its organist 85 years ago. After one of his experimental compositions was performed, the composer later recalled, the pastor, Wilton Merle Smith, ''turned around and glowered at the choir.'' That reaction seems to have been typical.

title: ADMINISTRATION PLANS RESTRICTIONS ON MORTGAGE LOANS FOR VETERANS
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it was imposing restrictions on its home-loan guarantee program that would sharply curtail the size and availablity of insured mortgages for military veterans.

title: DREAM LIVES FOR PILGRIMS AT CANAVERAL
description: All through the day tourists gather in small knots before the framed memorial that lists the seven names: Scobee, Smith, McNair, Jarvis, Resnik, Onizuka and McAuliffe.

title: The Speech That Failed
description: In his superbly delivered, warmly applauded joint session show, Mr. Reagan failed to step up to his own historic mission.

title: BROOKLYN DIOCESE JOINS HOMOSEXUAL-BILL FIGHT
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, which has publicly been less hostile to homosexual-rights measures than the Archdiocese of New York, joined yesterday with the archdiocese to oppose a new City Council bill that would forbid discrimination against homosexuals in hiring and housing.

title: A Time of Turmoil: Assassination to Election
description: 1>Military guards lift Benigno S. Aquino's body into a van. Sgt. Rolando de Guzman of the Philippine Air Force, at a hearing in November 1983, demonstrating how he shot Rolando C. Galman. President Marcos and Mrs. Aquino campaigning last month. xhrrAug. 21, 1983 Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition leader in self-imposed exile in the United States, returns to Manila and is shot dead upon arrival at Manila International Airport. Rolando C. Galman, the man the Government says is the assassin, is shot dead by guards on the tarmac. Aug. 31, 1983. Mr. Aquino's funeral procession is accompanied by more than a million Filipinos through the streets of Manila. His widow, Corazon C. Aquino, and their five children return to Manila for the funeral. Oct. 22, 1983 A fact-finding board headed by Corazon J. Agrava, a former justice of the Supreme Court, is named to investigate the assassination. Feb. 14, 1984 Voting for the National Assembly results in gains for the opposition. Oct. 24, 1984 All four members of the Agrava board except for Mrs. Agrava herself issue a report that names Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the military Chief of Staff and a cousin of President Ferdinand E. Marcos; 24 other military men, and a civilian as having been involved in the Aquino slaying. Mrs. Agrava issues her own report saying only six low-ranking military men were involved. Jan. 23, 1985 General Ver and the 25 other people named in the majority report are charged in the slaying. Feb. 1, 1985 The trial of the 26 defendants begins. Oct. 16, 1985 Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, visits President Marcos as the personal representative of President Reagan, bringing a message of concern. Nov. 3, 1985 Mr. Marcos announces that he will call for an election before the end of his term in 1987.

title: ART: ESTHETIC KINSHIP IN 'BROTHERS DUCHAMP'
description: THE Museum of Modern Art's Marcel Duchamp retrospective of 1973 numbered close to 200 objects, its catalogue 341 pages. Yet even this production, which was surely the last scholarly word on the master, left him as cryptic as it found him - his family, too.

title: Syringes Also Involved In AIDS Transmission
description: To the Editor:

title: LABOR LEADER AND TWO DOZEN STRIKERS ARRESTED AT HORMEL PLANT
description: The police today arrested a labor leader and two dozen striking meatpackers who tried to stop replacement workers from entering the struck plant of Geo. A. Hormel & Company. The labor leader, Ray Rogers, who was warned by a judge Tuesday that he would go to jail if he violated an injunction against picketing, was among those arrested outside Hormel's flagship plant. A court order forbids the strikers to block access to the plant and limits pickets to three at each gate.

title: REAGAN APPROVES U.S. COUNTEROFFER TO SOVIET ON ARMS
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan had suggested a proposal for allies to consider in response to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to eliminate nuclear weapons by the year 2000.

title: CAMPAIGN LAWS DUE FOR CHANGE, STATE PANEL TOLD
description: The New York City government corruption scandal has created an opportunity for major changes in state laws on campaign financing, city and state officials told a legislative hearing yesterday.

title: Traveling First Couple
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, had been scheduled to spend a six-day Lincoln-Washington birthday vacation at their ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif., starting next Wednesday, but they will both be cutting it two days short, for different, though related, reasons.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $19,753,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

title: ENGELHARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: c-After a nonrecurring charge of $63,100,000 to writedown certain assets and including a gain of $6,600,000 from the reversal of taxes related to DISC.

title: MR GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $900,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $4.5 million.

title: IMAGERY SEEKING DEMOCRATS
description: ''My life has changed,'' said Ruby Sampson, who was on the welfare rolls for 14 years and now works as an operating room technician. ''The old Ruby is dead. A new Ruby exists.''

title: REAGAN BUDGET SEEN IMPERILING WESTWAY DEAL
description: A provision in President Reagan's proposed budget that would stretch out payments of Westway trade-in money could be ''a serious setback'' to the city's mass-transit and highway improvement programs, the city's budget director said yesterday.

title: DIANE DIXON AT HOME
description: The population curve of track and field tilts heavily to the left coast. Sprinters and jumpers, putters and throwers, they have mostly emigrated to the land where you can run in shorts in the middle of the winter and not have your hamstrings twang in midstride.

title: Arco Debt Load Studied
description: The rating on about $6 billion of Atlantic Richfield Company debt is under review for possible downgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. Earlier this week Arco filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commision for the sale of up to $500 million of debt securities.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE name brings back visions of a young Ingrid Bergman lighting up the screen in her introduction to American audiences, but that seems to be the only similarity between the 1939 film and the ''Intermezzo'' that is scheduled to open Off Broadway late this spring. This one, which ran in London last year, is based on a drama by the Viennese playwright Arthur Schnitzler, translated and adapted by Robert David MacDonald.

title: F.A.A. Orders Airlines To Inspect Jet Engines
description: Federal aviation officials today ordered the nation's airlines to inspect hundreds of aircraft with certain Pratt & Whitney engines to look for cracks that could cause a major part of the engine to break loose.

title: Brooklyn Artist Lofts
description: To the Editor:

title: OMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss after a charge of $48,347,000 for an adjustment for the cumulative effect of an accounting change for deferred taxes.

title: LEWIS ENTERS TWO EVENTS
description: Carl Lewis, upset by a loss to one challenger and accusations from another, will sprint as well as long-jump Saturday night in the 17th annual Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational track meet in Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FERRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $2.3 million for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: RECITAL: WORKS BY LISZT OFFERED BY ANDRE WATTS
description: Because this year marks the 100th anniversary of Franz Liszt's death, the likelihood is that we will be hearing a lot of his music in the months to come. And since he was, above all, a man of the piano, piano music is certain to dominate.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $20 million associated with previously announced plant restructuring and work force reductions. c-After a charge of $21.8 million and including a tax credit of $45.4 million.

title: REFITTING TO BEGIN
description: The World War II battleship Wisconsin being moved from a wharf in the Delaware River to a pier at Philadelphia Naval yard. The ship, which has been inactive for 28 years, will undergo refitting and be reassigned to Corpus Christi, Tex. The 45-000 ton, 887-foot battlewagon was launched Dec. 7, 1943. (UPI)

title:
PATENTS;
Removing TV Noise And Interference
description: Quanticon Inc., a research company in West Long Branch, N.J., this week received one of a series of patents on the television technology it calls Quantimage.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline on an Atlanta dispatch in some editions yesterday, about a mother who contracted the AIDS virus from her child, misstated her condition. As the article said, she was infected with the virus but has not developed symptoms of the disease.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. Each line of this gift to President Reagan, a caricature of him, is of vital significance. Explain. 2. ''We went fishing, and we didn't catch the fish,'' said an Israeli official. To what was he referring? 3. ''The unpleasant sound Bush is emitting as he traipses from one conservative gathering to another is a thin, tinny 'arf' - the sound of a lapdog,'' wrote a political columnist. Who is he, to what was he referring, and what was the response of Vice President Bush? 4. ''I have decided not to let my name go forward as a candidate.'' Who made this remark and for what office did he decline to run? 5. The largest and most thorough study to date of members of the families of of AIDS victims concludes that the disease, from which no one is known to have recovered, is not spread through close, day-to-day personal contact. True or false? 6. After almost a year of stalemate, a bill to sell the Government's 85 percent interest in a corporation for $1.2 billion, a price that many critics say is too low, was approved by the Senate and sent to the House. Identify the corporation and the prospective purchaser. 7. Despite efforts to hold down spending, the Reagan Administration proposed money for development of a plane that could fly from Washington to (Moscow/Peking/Tokyo/Sydney) in (2/3/4/5) hours. 8.

title: Arrau Concert Canceled
description: The pianist Claudio Arrau will not perform tonight at Carnegie Hall, due to illness. The concert has been rescheduled for March 15 at 3 P.M.; tickets for tonight's show will be honored at the door on that day. Refunds are also available through Feb. 28.

title: Sanctions Won't Help Change South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOREHAM DRILL FOUND TO BREAK A SUFFOLK LAW
description: The Long Island Lighting Company would be violating a Suffolk County law if it participated in a federally supervised emergency drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant next Thursday, the County Legislature unanimously ruled today.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JEFFERSON SMURFIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SCHOOL ATTENDANCE DWINDLES AT THE FLU SEASON DESCENDS
description: Last Sunday at church, Kenneth Ucho thought his throat seemed sore. By noon, he thought his temperature was up and his chest seemed congested. By Monday morning, Mr. Ucho thought he was going to die. ''I was so out of it,'' he said.

title: NORTH AMERICAN SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $251,660 from a dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in the form of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock. No share earnings figure is available for the year-ago period because the company went public in September 1985.

title: FLEXSTEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $150,000 for the quarter and 6 months from termination of defined benefit pension plan.

title: PANCANADIAN PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $843,000 and a gain of $5,299,000 from a divestiture. Year-ago fourth quarter results have been restated for a change in the tax rate related to the sale of a major business.

title: HOUSE PANEL SAID TO ASK REAGAN TO RETHINK AID FOR ANGOLA REBELS
description: The House Select Committee on Intelligence has written a letter to President Reagan asking him to reconsider a plan to provide secret aid to rebels battling the Marxist Government in Angola, according to sources on Capitol Hill and in intelligence circles.

title: Yugoslav Oil Plan
description: Yugoslavia will seek to negotiate lower prices for oil it imports from the Soviet Union, according to the Foreign Trade Secretary, Milenko Bojanic.

title: SKATERS DISCOVER HIGH COST OF RISKS
description: The bumps and bruises are becoming more numerous, and occasionally there is also a serious injury to ponder, a sobering reminder for all those dynamic duos that they are skating on thin ice. The pairs competition in figure skating is evolving into something comparable to a trapeze act that doesn't use a net, and sometimes even the winners are in for a hard fall.

title: LEHIGH PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IN NICARAGUA TOWN, THE WAR INTRUDES
description: The continuing war between Nicaraguan Government forces and Miskito Indian rebels has transformed this once-tranquil Indian village into a battleground.

title: REP. FIEDLER, FACING A JUNE PRIMARY, GETS A MARCH 3 TRIAL ON ELECTION LAW CHARGE
description: Facing a June 3 primary election, Representative Bobbi Fiedler today was given a March 3 trial date on charges that she and an aide attempted to bribe a rival to drop out of the Republican race for the Senate.

title: Unocal to Shut 2 Plants
description: The Unocal Corporation, the oil and minerals company, has announced it is temporarily closing its molybdenum mine and mill in Questa, N.M., and a roasting plant in Washington, Pa., where the metal is processed. The closings will affect about 500 people in New Mexico and 100 in Pennsylvania, the company said. Both plants will reopen ''when economic conditions improve,'' the company said.

title: RORER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,028,000 and a nonrecurring charge of $2,970,000 for the settlement of litigation. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $826,000 and after a nonrecurring expense of $1,692,000 for a proxy contest defense and a nonrecurring charge of $2,970,000 for the settlement of litigation. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,850,000 for the quarter and $10,370,000 for the year. Results for both the latest and prior years have been restated to exclude operations of Cilco Inc. and Richards Medical Co. which will be sold in February 1986.

title: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY TIME An Episcopal cathedral is not the sort of place one usually associates with a bouncy, Latin-type Mardi Gras celebration, but, then, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on Amsterdam Avenue at 111th Street, is, like many churches, a community center and an arts center as well as a house of worship. And that is how it happens that today, at 2 and again at 8 P.M., it will be the scene of a carnival program that takes its inspiration from Carnival, the Brazilian rhythmic observance of the holiday.

title: Duvalier Arrives in France
description: Jean-Claude Duvalier began his exile here tonight, arriving aboard a United States military jet with aides and relatives after a 15-hour flight.

title: JOINT CHIEFS FIND NO SOVIET CHEATING
description: An intelligence estimate made public by the Joint Chiefs of Staff contradicts President Reagan's assertion that the Soviet Union has violated a key arms-control provision.

title: Wildlife Deception
description: To the Editor:

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BEGLEY DRUG CO.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $272,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months from a change in tax laws on domestic international sales companies.

title: N.F.L. CARDINALS EYE A CITY SITE
description: The St. Louis Cardinals yesterday became the first National Football League team to admit it is exploring the possibility of moving to New York.

title: WINTRY WEATHER ENCOURAGES GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASSES FUND
description: Snow and ice and an awareness that the homeless are faced with several more weeks of winter have inspired many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: REALLY LOSING BIG
description: When James (Satch) Sullinger accepted the position as head basketball coach at Franklin University in Columbus, Ohio, this season, he knew the job would be tough. But he didn't fully realize the frustration it would bring until Dec. 18, the day he abruptly resigned.

title: AFTER 9 BABIES DIE IN 14 YEARS, MOTHER IS HELD
description: Year after year, one after the other, the babies of Mary Beth Tinning died, nine of them over the past 14 years. The causes were listed variously as natural or undetermined or sudden infant death syndrome.

title: CARDINAL DISTRIBUTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1.1 million related to the November private placement of a minority interest in the company's Mr. Moneysworth Inc. subsidiary.

title: INVESTORS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Emergency Is Decreed In Two Cities in Peru
description: President Alan Garcia Perez tonight imposed a state of emergency in Lima and the neighboring port city of Callao, instituted a curfew to curb violence by leftist guerrillas and extended a freeze on the official rate of the national currency through the end of the year.

title: UPPER-CLASS LEFTIST
description: REBEL: THE SHORT LIFE OF ESMOND ROMILLY. By Kevin Ingram. 253 pages. E. P. Dutton. $22.50. During the 1930's, the English press referred to him as the ''Red Menace'' and Winston Churchill's ''Red Nephew''; his upper-class family and friends spoke of him alternately with irritation and affection as a romantic, a troublemaker and ''an impertinent little boy.'' Certainly Esmond Romilly enjoyed playing a variety of roles - schoolboy martyr, adolescent propagandist and Spanish Civil War volunteer - but for all his flirtations with leftist politics, he seemed to harbor few illusions about the sources of his rebellion. ''Sometimes,'' he wrote of his teen-age attempts to spread the gospel of Communism among his wealthy friends, ''I would persuade myself that my desire to change the conditions of my life was due to intellectual understanding; whereas, really it was probably due simply to the combination of a wish for change and excitement, with irritation and boredom.''

title: PENTAGON 'BOND' SEEN
description: Industry analysts and Congressional critics of General Dynamics said the lifting of the suspension was evidence of the Pentagon's urgent desire to resume ordinary dealings with one of its pivotal contractors, even while investigations and new charges of malfeasance continue.

title: RULING IS CALLED THREAT TO MAJOR CUT IN DEFICIT
description: The Federal court decision today striking down automatic spending cuts could make President Reagan less willing to negotiate with Congress over taxes and spending, undermining the chances for major deficit reduction this year, according to members of Congress.

title: DATA ON HOME PHONES
description: Seeking to blunt charges that higher local telephone charges force people to cancel service, the Federal Communications Commission has released figures showing more American households have a telephone than ever before. Data released Thursday showed 91.9 percent of American households have telephones, up fractionally from previous reports. Another 1.9 percent of households had access to a phone in a hallway or elsewhere nearby.

title: CITY BALLET: 'AUVERGNE,' FROM PETER MARTINS
description: Peter Martins showed dancegoers pretty postcard views of France in ''Songs of the Auvergne,'' his new ballet, which received its premiere by the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. It is a charming work. But charm is its defect, as well as its virtue.

title: GERNERAL LEADS NEW REGIME; JAMAICA SAID TO PLAY A KEY ROLE IN PERSUADING DUVALIER TO LEAVE
description: The Jamaican Government secretly played a central role in persuading President Jean-Claude Duvalier to flee Haiti, United States and Jamaican officials said today.

title: Anderson, Clayton Plan
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said its board had approved a recapitalization plan, providing for stockholders to receive cash for most of their investment in the company while retaining about 75 percent of the recapitalized company.

title: QADDAFI ORDERS HIS JETS TO INTERCEPT ISRAELI AIRLINERS
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that his air force would intercept any Israeli civilian plane found within range over the Mediterranean and would force it to land in Libya.

title: Carter, in Nicaragua, Meets With Officials and Opposition
description: Former President Jimmy Carter met separately today with leaders of Nicaragua's Government and with opposition figures here, after having talked in Costa Rica with rebels trying to overthrow the Government.

title: GUNMEN SEIZE VOTES AT POLLING STATIONS IN PHILIPPINE TOWN
description: The voting ended at 3 P.M., and 30 minutes later, just as the ballot boxes were unlocked for the counting, the gunmen arrived at the Bayanan elementary school.

title: STORM DISHES UP A TASTE OF WINTER
description: The wind howled again, and traffic followed custom and crawled. Pedestrians, late to work again, shuddered in the cold. But while the reaction to the latest ''weather event,'' as forecasters called it, might have been familiar, yesterday's snowstorm, unlike those that have preceded it this season, finally seemed to evoke the authentic spirit of winter.

title: MORE TO HIS LIFE THAN THE SPIKE
description: Like the flying stuff in basketball, the overhand smash in tennis and the slap shot in hockey, the spike is volleyball's muscular point producer, a combination of agility, timing and raw physical strength.

title: LIFE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $5,666,000 for the quarter and $3,413,000 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $980,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $5,215,000 for the year.

title: MARGIN BUYING HOLDS HAZARDS
description: MARGIN buying is at a record level these days, as many investors seek to increase their stock market profits without putting up additional cash. But the euphoria often associated with margin investing worries some specialists in this field because of the dangers that individuals face when utilizing this technique.

title: Oil Spilled Near St. Thomas
description: About 22,000 gallons of oil spilled off the coast of St. Thomas Thursday night after a barge hit an underwater object that ripped open its right side, the Coast Guard said today. A Coast Guard spokesman here said that it was trying to find the owners of the 262-foot barge.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $633,000 in the quarter and $1,433,000 in the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $5,000 in the quarter and $575,000 in the 9 months.

title: DOW HITS 1,613.42, A RECORD
description: Stocks moved deeper into record territory yesterday, in a session marked by abrupt swings in prices.

title: SOUTHWEST FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2.5 million from the termination of a retirement plan. c-After an extraordinary charge of $9,950,000 from a reserve to buy out some federal timber contracts. d-Net income. There were no common share earnings in the year-ago period because the net income did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: HE DID IT HIS WAY
description: In the third week of what had once been only a cold, I was lying in bed calmly awaiting death when unnatural sounds disturbed that sweet serenity.

title: BROWN & SHARPE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $605,000 for the quarter and $2,041,000 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $135,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses after a charge of $3,700,000 related to the closing and restructuring of certain operations.

title: NOWSCO WELL SERVICE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
The Last Days of the Condor?
description: One way or the other, 1986 probably will be the year in which all California condors disappear from the wild. Extinction of the species can be avoided.

title: BALLET: SADLER'S WELLS OFFERS TWO PREMIERS
description: Perhaps it is not really a surprise that the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet's performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music have become the dance season's hot ticket. Since the troupe's older and larger sister company, the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden, stopped coming to New York regularly, the void it left has never been truly filled.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: STERLING CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Latest net asset value reflects a provision equal to 24 cents per share for income taxes that may be payable with respect to net unrealized appreciation in the company's investments portfolio if said net appreciation is ultimately realized. Assets figures represent net assets.

title: Mr. Reagan Scores for Democracy
description: Whatever comes next in the Philippines and Haiti, dictators are reeling and America is their scourge. Hats off to President Reagan.

title: 'Meditative Chopin'
description: The pianist Roy Eaton will present ''The Meditative Chopin,'' a program of introspective solo pieces chosen to be played without interruption, at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock. Tickets are $10 to $15; information: 874-6770.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A report in ''Follow-Up on the News'' on Jan. 12 described the current condition of an American boy with an eye disease who traveled to Moscow in 1981 and 1983 for injections of ribonucleic acid. The treatment is not allowed in the United States.

title: Unseeded Player Upsets Curren
description: Mikael Pernfors of Sweden upset fourth-seeded Kevin Curren of the United States, 6-4, 6-2, today in the quarter-finals of the $315,000 Volvo Tennis United States National Indoor Championships.

title: Portugal Takes a Big Step
description: Portugal took a giant step toward stable democracy last month, in dramatic presidential elections that reduced a five-man field to two - the candidate of the right, Diego Freitas do Amaral, and the moderate socialist Mario Soares. Whatever the results of the runoff later this month, Portugal will be the winner, for both are solid democrats, and both are firmly committed to the Atlantic alliance.

title: A TALL ORDER FOR WEBB
description: Spud Webb finds himself back home for the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game weekend, a 5-feet-7-inch David preparing to trade slams and jams with the Goliaths of the game in the league's Slam-Dunk championship Saturday. Webb's dunking exploits are well known in this area, where he attended Wilmer Hutchins High School before going on to Midland College in Texas and North Carolina State. Saturday, he will be wearing an Atlanta Hawks' uniform.

title: Richard Krementz 3d Weds Miss de Araujo
description: Marialva Polonio de Araujo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cid Nunes de Araujo of Belo Horizonte, Brazil, was married yesterday to Richard Krementz 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Krementz Jr. of Morristown, N.J. The Roman Catholic ceremony took place at Nossa Senhora de Conceicao in Ouro Preto, Brazil.

title: Sheehan Leader By One After 69
description: The defending champion, Patty Sheehan, fired a 3-under-par 69 today that enabled her to retain a slender lead over Stephanie Farwig after two rounds of the $200,000 L.P.G.A. Sarasota Classic.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington on Monday about concern expressed by Pentagon officials over budget cuts affecting military research misidentified Donald A. Hicks. He is Under Secretary of Defense.

title: Jazz and Crayfish
description: Two of the great contributions to humanity that have come from New Orleans are music and food, and a gala featuring both has been put together to raise money at a benefit for the Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts.

title: JAZZ: CAYENNE BAND PLAYS
description: The largest of the six jazz groups taking part in the four-day ''Mardi Gras at the Market'' at Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 53d Street, is the eight-piece Cayenne Jazz Band, which is playing at Alfredo's.

title: STATE COURT OFFICERS' UNIONS AGREE TO DRUG TESTING
description: State court officers and some of the clerical staff for the state courts in New York City will be required to undergo mandatory drug testing - if reasonable cause is found - under a tentative collective-bargaining agreement announced yesterday by the State Office of Court Administration.

title: IRISH DANCING
description: Amateurs and experienced hands at traditional Irish dancing can join the ceili dancing sponsored by the Irish Arts Center today at 7:30 P.M. at the Academy of Mount St. Ursula, 330 Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx.

title: DORSEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOTH SIDES CLAIM THEY ARE LEADING IN PHILIPPINE VOTE
description: Corazon C. Aquino claimed victory today in the Presidential election while President Ferdinand E. Marcos said only, ''I probably have won.''

title: NASA KEEPS QUIET ON SLAVAGE WORK
description: Recovery forces have hauled in 12 tons of the space shuttle Challenger's wreckage and located many other underwater fragments, according to the Coast Guard, but the space agency has repeatedly refused to describe the findings and their importance to the investigation into the explosion.

title: EASTERN UTILITIES ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1986
description: International

title: NO JOB, NO APOLOGY
description: Don Eddy, the University of Texas at San Antonio basketball coach, resigned yesterday after he was accused of shoving one of his players during a basketball game.

title: UNIONS FOUND LOSING BIGGER SHARE OF YOUND
description: Union membership among young workers dropped dramatically in 1985, according to a survey released today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. It was the latest sign of a weakening in the union movement because of what analysts say is a shift toward a service-based economy.

title: ATLANTIC FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $683,000.

title: Legislative Aide Named
description: William L. Ball 3d, who performed liaison between the State Department and Congress for the past year, was named today as assistant to the President for legislative affairs. He succeeds M. B. Oglesby Jr., who is expected to join a Washington law firm.

title: REAGAN SEES MORE TEACHERS IN SPACE
description: President Reagan pledged today that civilian teachers would still serve as astronauts despite the explosion on the space shuttle Challenger that killed Christa McAuliffe.

title: TV: SIX NEW EPISODES OF 'SHERLOCK HOLMES'
description: The first batch of ''The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes,'' developed for Granada Television by John Hawkesworth (''Upstairs, Downstairs''), was a lumpy porridge but not without its nourishing moments, enough at least to prompt public television's ''Mystery'' to import six more episodes. Once again starring Jeremy Brett as Holmes and David Burke as Watson, the new instalments, produced in 1984 by Michael Cox, get under way tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET/Channel 13 with the case of ''The Greek Interpreter.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. The drawing, which has 75 different lines, was a gift to the President on his 75th birthday. 2. The interception and forced landing of of a Libyan executive jet by Israeli planes in an attempt to capture a Palestinian terrorist whom the Israelis mistakenly believed was aboard. 3. George F. Will, a conservative commentator, was referring to the Vice President's combative remarks about Governor Cuomo, which he characterized as a clumsy attempt to curry favor among party conservatives. Mr. Bush said he stood by his attack on the Governor but acknowledged that he should have chosen his words more carefully. 4. Henry A. Kissinger was rejecting pleas from party leaders to be the Republican candidate for Governor of New York. 5. True. 6. title: STAY-AT-HOME STRATEGY FOR BIG CALIFORNIA BANK
description: In bidding more than $1 billion for the Crocker National Corporation, Wells Fargo & Company has demonstrated how vast, rich and promising it considers the California banking market to be.

title: WHO'S MAKING THE RULES?
description: Among well-known adversaries, even in this, the nation's controversy capital, few groups have been as bitterly divided over the years as farmers and farm workers. And among the many issues they have fought over, none have caused so much heartache as injuries and deaths caused by exposure to farm chemicals.

title: PROGRESSIVE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $56,000 for the quarter and including a gain of $224,000 for the year related to capital loss carryforwards and also including capital gains of $4,874,000 for the quarter and $9,956,000 for the year. c-After capital losses of $1,923,000 for the quarter and $4,195,000 for the year.

title: WINNER IN ARBITRATION
description: Phil Bradley, the Seattle Mariner outfielder who was the eighth-best hitter in the American League last year with a .300 average, yesterday became the first player to win a salary arbitration case this offseason. Bradley, who also had 26 home runs, 88 runs batted in, 100 runs scored and 33 doubles in 1985, his second full season in the majors, was awarded the $475,000 he had sought after earning $125,000 last season.

title: U.S. JUDGES HOLD NEW BUDGET LAW UNCONSTITUTIONAL
description: A panel of three Federal judges ruled unanimously today that a key provision of a new budget-balancing law was unconstitutional because it violated the principle requiring separation of powers among the branches of Government.

title: AGAINST THE RULES
description: As a strict religious institution, Brigham Young University imposes some demanding standards on its students.

title: Sakharov Can't Leave, Gorbachev Says
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, says the dissident Andrei D. Sakharov cannot leave his country because he knows strategic secrets, according to an interview to be published Saturday in the French Communist Party newspaper.

Pope Visits Heartland Of Catholicism in India
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in this heartland of Roman Catholicism in southwestern India today preaching a message of unity among Christians who have been divided by politics, forms of worship and history.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I probably have won.'' - President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: KREMLIN SHIFTS ON 'STAR WARS,' DIPLOMATS SAY
description: The Soviet Union will not insist that the United States abandon development of a space-based missile defense as a condition for an agreement to reduce medium-range nuclear weapons, Western diplomats said today.

title: Lebanese Moslems Want Army to Be Neutral
description: Senior Moslem military officers said today that the Lebanese Army should be neutral in the conflict between President Amin Gemayel and his Syrian-backed opponents, and they asked that the regular troops be withdrawn from the confrontation lines.

title: BOND MARKET HOPEFUL DESPITE FULING
description: Credit market participants remained optimistic yesterday that Congress and the President would reduce Federal budget deficits even though a Federal district court yesterday struck down the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law that could have required automatic spending cuts.

title: NORFOLK CAN HALT BUSING OF PUPILS
description: Norfolk can end its busing of elementary schoolchildren for desegregation purposes, a three-judge Federal appeals court panel ruled today.

title: MENTOR GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,546,000.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP TO ADD FOXMEYER
description: National Intergroup Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Foxmeyer Corporation, a drug and beauty products wholesaler, for about $230 million in a move that will move National further away from its roots in the steel industry.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an unusual charge of $10.4 million and including a tax credit of $2.2 million.

title: JUDGE ASSERTS HE IS SUBJECT OF FALSE BRIBERY ALLEGATION
description: Judge Vito J. Titone of the State Court of Appeals said yesterday that he believed a disbarred lawyer convicted of drug charges has told authorities that the judge accepted bribes in two cases a decade ago. Judge Titone emphatically denied any wrongdoing.

title: MIZE POSTS 68 TO LEAD BY ONE
description: Larry Mize, saying he was on the right course at the right time, shot a 4-under-par 68 on the South Course at the Torrey Pines Golf Club today to take the second-round lead by a stroke in the Shearson Lehman Brothers Andy Williams Open.

title: Don't Disarm Diplomacy
description: Few Americans face greater dangers than the 4,100 members of our diplomatic corps, their staffs and dependents. Five ambassadors and two chiefs of mission have been killed by hostile action since 1968 - a total greater than the number of generals killed in battle in Vietnam and Korea.

title: Security Up in Air
description: At several sensitive locations around Washington, notably the Pentagon, the Supreme Court and the State Department, antiterrorist devices have been installed in the pavement.

title: CITY'S AGENCIES ORDERED TO AIR OUTSIDE AUDITS
description: First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff, saying that a consultant's criticism of the now scandal-ridden Parking Violations Bureau three years ago had eluded City Hall, ordered all city agencies yesterday to refer copies of outside audits to senior administration officials.

description: Short-term interest rates rose sharply in the credit markets yesterday, as traders reacted negatively to unexpectedly strong employment conditions in January.

Medication Injected by Body Pump

description: The army general who took command of Haiti today had been on close terms with the Duvalier family during its nearly three decades in power.

title: 2 ARE RECAPTURED BY OFFICIALS
description: Five prisoners awaiting trial hacksawed their way out of a sixth-floor dormitory, descended 80 feet on knotted bedsheets and scaled a 10-foot fence in an escape from the Bronx House of Detention early yesterday, the authorities said.

title: U.S. MAY FREE PRAGUE SPY SUSPECT
description: The United States plans to release a man accused of spying for Czechoslovakia, among other prisoners, in an exchange that is expected to include the Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky, Administration sources said today.

title: ATLANTIC CITY ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WARNINGS ON SNUFF SOUGHT
description: The Senate has approved and sent to the White House a bill that would require health warnings on chewing tobacco and snuff and bar radio or television advertisements for those products. The bill, which the House passed earlier this week, was prompted by concern about the increasing number of young people who use the products as an alternative to cigarettes. Medical studies have compiled evidence that chewing tobacco and snuff may be factors in the development of oral cancer and damage to gums, teeth and bones.

title: BETHLEHEM SETS TULL UNIT SALE
description: In a surprise turnabout, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell a steel distribution company acquired only last June.

title: ROBERT TSUDA
description: Robert Tsuda, a staff member for 44 years of the New York bureau of Asahi Shimbun, a leading Japanese daily newspaper, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home in Owls Head, N.Y. He was 70 years old. Mr. Tsuda was assistant to the bureau chief at the newspaper's New York office.

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC ECLECTIC ORDINAIRIES AT SWEET BASIL
description: Funk, Balkan music, minimalism, square dances, hard rock and Mozart all get scrunched together in the repertory of the Ordinaires, who performed Wednesday at Sweet Basil.

title: A Broken Connection
description: Halley's comet has proved to be something of a dud this time around at many places, including the United States Naval Observatory, where the phone has not been ringing very frequently. As a result, the Halley's hot line has been put on hold, according to Gail S. Cleere, spokesman at the observatory.

title: No Israeli Reaction
description: Israeli officials said they would have no direct comment today on Colonel Qaddafi's announcement.

title: SEA LAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After non-recurring charges of $9 million. c-Net income.

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $1,178,000 in the quarter and $2,757,000 in the year. c-After a capital loss of $196,000. d-Net income after a capital loss of $81,000.

title: Soviet Reports Ice Rescue
description: Rescuers using helicopters, ropes and makeshift bridges saved thousands of people who were fishing on a huge expanse of ice that suddenly broke loose from shore in the Soviet Far East last Saturday, the Soviet newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported today. The paper said no one was killed or injured in the incident on the shore of Sakhalin Island.

title: Withdrawal of Troops Begun at Hormel Plant
description: A rally for strikers at a meat processing plant drew only 120 people today, a quarter of the turnout a week ago, and the authorities began withdrawing some National Guard troops from the meatpacking plant.

title: City and Albany Sued On Home Heating Aid
description: The Legal Aid Society has filed a suit against the city and state, charging that at least 3,000 poor New York City families had been unfairly denied about $12 million in supplementary home heating fuel allowances since 1983.

title: EDUCATIONAL COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEIBELS BRUCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $5,190,212 and after a loss from discontinued operations of $475,475 in the quarter; and including a capital gain of $5,339,830 and net from discontinued operations of $45,549,344 in the year. c-After a capital loss of $8,477,166 and including net from discontinued operations of $60,980,117 in the quarter; d-Net loss after a capital loss of $8,149,421 and including net from discontinued operations of $66,242,956.

title: CONNECTICUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are after net charges for writedowns of the company's oil and gas operations equal to 18 cents a share for 1985 and 24 cents a share for 1984.

title: Auction of Drawings
description: More than 100 drawings by artists such as Keith Haring, Elizabeth Murray and Louise Bourgeois, which will be offered at a special auction Wednesday, can be seen today and tomorrow from noon to 6 P.M. at the Dia Art Foundation, 141 Wooster Street.

title: FOR COLDS AROUND THE WORLD, IT'S CHICKEN SOUP
description: ''Jewish penicillin'' is made by the French, the Italians, the Greeks, the Hungarians, the Vietnamese and people of countless other nationalities who know that chicken soup has mystical therapeutic properties. Science has never been able to isolate them, but not for lack of trying.

title: CONCERT: MIKLOS PERENYI, HUNGARIAN CELLIST IN RECITAL
description: Miklos Perenyi, a distinguished Hungarian cellist, is currently making his first American solo tour, and gave his local debut recital Tuesday night at the 92nd Street Y. As might have been expected, his finest work came in the music of his countryman, Bela Bartok. In the dashing and folk-like ''Rhapsody No. 1'' he found not just the sharp angles that sometimes emerge as Bartok's strongest characteristic, but also a full-bodied swing and a rich melodic line; he made it sing as well as dance.

title: Austrian Wins Close Downhill
description: In a World Cup downhill race in which 16 skiers finished within a minute of the winner, 27-year-old Anton Steiner of Austria won the first skiing race of his career today.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge; Japanese Capture First Title In Major International Event
description: The performance and reputation of Japanese players have been rising steadily in the past decade, and they recently recorded their first-ever major international triumph.

title: BRIDAL SHOPPING VIA VIDEO
description: IN February, thoughts turn to romance, and not only because of Valentine's Day. For those who plan on being June brides, bridal shop owners say, February is the time to order a wedding dress to insure that it will arrive in time to be fitted.

title: Steven Jobs's Stake in Pixar
description: Lucasfilm Ltd., based in San Rafael, Calif., said today that Pixar, formerly its computer graphics division, had been acquired by Steven P. Jobs and the division's employees. The new company will produce high-powered computers and software for computer graphics and image-processing applications.

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Budget Noose Remains
description: In throwing out a key provision of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, a Federal court addressed only procedure, not substance. The rest of the law remains in place and so does the first task for the President and Congress: to find a mutually acceptable way to reduce the deficit.

title: Revised Typescript Of Joyce Work Is Sold
description: ''The Mookse and the Gripes,'' a 24-page typed episode, heavily revised by hand, from James Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake,'' sold yesterday at Christie's for $132,000, the highest price at auction for a work by James Joyce and for a modern manuscript sold in America. The buyer was John Fleming, a New York dealer.

title: 12 TUMULTUOUS YEARS FOR CROCKER
description: Wells Fargo & Company's acquisition of the Crocker National Corporation announced today culminates more than 100 years of competition between the two California banks. The sale also follows more than 10 years of turbulence and troubles for Crocker. These are among some of the important developments that led to the acquisition:

title:
PATENTS;
Simulating the Sky
description: A celestial simulation device, to be hung from the ceiling and display representations of the moon, planets and galaxies, has been invented by DuWayne A. Wederski of Portland, Ore. According to patent 4,568,287, granted to him this week, the celestial bodies are to be charged so they glow in the dark, and an electric motor may turn the device to simulate rotation of the earth. The glow of the imitation stars may be created by a flashlight.

title: DANCE: ATLANTA BALLET IN NEW WORK
description: The Atlanta Ballet made a welcome return to Whitman Hall at Brooklyn College last Sunday afternoon with the New York premiere of an unusual narrative ballet and three graciously danced familiar works.

title: Ex-Judge Barred From Office
description: The state's highest court has barred a former Columbia County town justice, from ever holding judicial office again. The action by the State Court of Appeals came Thursday upon the expiration of a 30-day period in which the former justice, Joseph Jutkofsky Jr., could appeal a recommendation by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct. The commission had ruled that Mr. Jutkofsky, a judge in Taghkanic Town Court, should be barred because of violations that included handing out harsher penalties than allowed.

title: TRAFFIC AGENTS FIND SCOFFLAWS SCOFFING MORE LOUDLY
description: In New York's never-ending battle between the illegally parked and those who give them tickets, the illegal parkers attempted this week to seize the moral high ground.

title: ACCURAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRUMP FINDS BIG 'BONUS' ON 5TH AVE.
description: Donald Trump has undertaken only a handful of major projects over the last 15 years, and, by and large, they have turned out well.

title: CONGA LINES AND ANGRY MOBS: AFTER THE FALL JOY AND VENGEANCE IN HAITI
description: At 5 this morning, a lone church bell started persistently ringing over the sleeping city.

title: BENEFIT SQUARE DANCE
description: Pete Seeger and the singer Maryellen Healy will take part in a benefit square dance tonight at 7 at the Rombut Junior School, on Verplanck Avenue in Beacon, N.Y. Music will be provided by Pat Rust and the Oxidizers. Admission is $4 (free for those 12 and under); proceeds benefit the Beacon Sloop Club, which is a branch of the Hudson River Clearwater group. Information: (914) 561-7726.

title: DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $21,257,000 for the quarter and $23,457,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: Park Named for Heart Donor
description: A city park has been named for a 15-year-old boy whose dying wish was to donate his heart to an ailing school friend.

title: 40-REAY SENTENCES GIVEN TO 5 IN WHITE-WUPERMACIST GROUP
description: Five people convicted of racketeering for a Nazi-like group, the Order, were each sentenced today to 40 years in prison.

title: ZEHNTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income.

title: PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $7,884,000 in the quarter and $16,800,000 in the year. c-After capital losses of $6,511,000 in the quarter and $776,000 in the year.

title: WOHL SEEKING SOLUTIONS FOR NETS' WOES
description: Even a rookie coach needs time off. But Dave Wohl is resting uneasily this weekend, contemplating the night of horror he endured last Wednesday and the work he faces between now and the start of the playoffs in April.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Miami dispatch by The Associated Press on Jan. 30, on the release of Richard M. Nixon from a hospital, described his protection incorrectly. He uses private security, not the Secret Service.

title:
PATENTS;
An Artificial Iceberg To Collect Fresh Water
description: An artificial iceberg, regarded as useful in the collection and transportation of fresh water, was patented this week by Robert J. Horan of Endicott, N.Y.

title: TENNESSEE MERGER
description: The First American Corporation said it had agreed to acquire all outstanding stock of Tennessee National Bankshares Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $30 million. It said there would be no dilution of earnings on First American stock. The acquistion, and a second acquisition that is pending, will increase First American's assets to more than $5.2 billion, from $4.8 billion as of Dec. 31, the company said.

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $132,000 for the quarter and $4,678,000 for the 6 months and a pretax gain of $14,325,000 for the 6 months on the sale of the company's Detroit radio stations. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $1,254,000 for the quarter and $1,727,000 for the 6 months.

title: DEFENSE RESTS CASE IN TRIAL OF U.S. JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI
description: Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon today finished testifying in his trial on charges of influence peddling and perjury by denying that he used his office for financial benefit.

title: Backward Thinking About Disability
description: Nanette Davis is a spunky Ohioan whose efforts to walk with computer-energized muscles have become something of a prime-time television staple. Her personal grit aside, the media hype is a tribute to backward thinking. In the present era of crushing budget deficits, the celebration of this technological achievement is an emotional luxury we literally can't afford.

title: CANINE CIVILITY
description: Heads and tails high, a dozen dogs trotted jauntily in the snow down Fifth Avenue.

title: No Aid, Savimbi Says
description: Mr. Savimbi insisted yesterday that he had not received aid of any sort, covert or overt, from the United States Government. But he said he was hopeful of some kind of help from Washington.

title: BIRDVIEW SATELLITE COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring pretax charge of $5.5 million for the quarter and year from company restructuring. c-Net income including extraordinary credits of $888,000 for the quarter and $1,678,000 for the year.

title: OLD-TIMERS SPIN A DREAM
description: A bunch of old race trackers were sitting around in the Orchid dining room at Gulfstream Park yesterday afternoon, arguing with passion about who would win the ultimate Dream Race - the 11 winners of the Triple Crown going a mile and a quarter on the first Saturday of May in their championship seasons.

title: Boy Molested by Priest Given $1 Million by Jury
description: A jury awarded $1 million today to an 11-year-old boy who was molested by a priest who is now in prison for sexually abusing three dozen boys.

title: ROCA-ADAIR WIN DANCE
description: Renee Roca and Donald Adair won the championship dance title last night with a smooth performance in the free-dance.

title: CLAROSTATE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
STARRETT L S CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
