Lady Bird Johnson, Suffering From Fatigue, Is in Hospital
description: Lady Bird Johnson is in the hospital because of fatigue and pain from an injured left knee, her press secretary said today.

title: HAITIANS IN U.S. HOPEFUL FOR DEMOCRACY
description: Haitian leaders in the United States said today that the fall of the Duvalier Government presented the Caribbean nation with a long-forestalled opportunity for full democracy.

title: MERCHANTS BANCSHARES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year include operations of Sterling Trust Co., acquired in April, and of St. Johnsbury branches of First National Bank of Vermont, acquired in July.

title: American Can Set To Sell Unit Stake
description: The American Can Company said it plans to sell a 15 percent interest in its American Capital Management and Research subsidiary to the public at between $20 and $23 a share.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1986
description: The Economy

title: IMMUNITY GRANTED GENERAL DYNAMICS AS NAVY LIFTS BAN
description: The Navy announced today that it had restored the General Dynamics Corporation's eligibility to bid for Government contracts because the company had made progress in correcting its shortcomings.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S JOBLESS RATE 0.2% OVER DECEMBER FIGURE
description: The unemployment rate in New York City rose slightly last month but was lower than the rate of January 1985, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: CONCERT: I SOLISTI DE ZAGREB
description: Despite the Italian implications of its name, I Solisti di Zagreb is a distinguished Yugoslav string ensemble that has been a fixture on the international music scene for nearly three decades now. On Tuesday night, its concert at the Metropolitan Museum of Art took an uncommon turn with the appearance of a singer, Mira Zakai, as guest soloist.

title: MUSIC MANN AND HOUGH
description: Robert Mann and Stephen Hough continued their survey of the Beethoven violin and piano literature at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night. There were three sonatas - the A minor (Op. 23), the Sonata in G (Op. 30, No. 3) and the ''Kreutzer.''

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Tom Gorman, making his debut as the captain of the United States Davis Cup team, has tapped Jimmy Arias, Aaron Krickstein, Ken Flach, Robert Seguso and Brad Gilbert to play against Ecuador next month in the first round of the 1986 competition. . . . The Golden State Warriors said John Bach would remain as head coach through this season.

title: For Simplicity: '4 CFR 331.30 (b)(7)
description: My tiny company has been notified of its enrollment in the Department of Defense Contract Simplification Test Program. The candidate for simplification is a Federal renewal order for three one-year subscriptions to my sole product, a science newsletter. Total price: $555. Notification, accompanied by a 15-page form, arrived from the purchaser, Headquarters Wright-Patterson Contracting Center, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Dayton, Ohio, on Jan. 10, 1986, with a cover letter requesting return of the ''fully completed package'' by Jan. 1, 1986. A sheet after page 15 stated that mailing forms for the Contract Simplification Test Program had been delayed because of ''a problem with our computer labeling program.''

title: TOP PRETORIA OFFICIAL GETS REPRIMAND
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister has been rebuked by President P. W. Botha for suggesting that this racially divided nation might one day be led by a black President.

title: Elderly Residents Evacuated When Fire Hits Nearby Store
description: A rapidly spreading fire at a furniture store tonight forced the evacuation of at least 60 elderly residents of a nearby apartment complex, authorities said.

title: CONNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS ANALYSIS RULING ON BUDGET-BALANCING LAW: A BITTERSWEET VICTORY FOR THE PRESIDENT
description: The ruling today striking down crucial provisions of the new budget-balancing law was a significant if somewhat bittersweet victory for President Reagan, who signed the act into law in December.

title: TOY FAIR: FANTASY AND ELECTRONICS VIE
description: Devin Kaplan, 5 years old, held a plastic Rambo Uzi water pistol in his right hand and a Rambo M-16 water gun in his left. He sidled up to a man dressed in a Santa Claus costume, looked him in the eye and warned, ''Watch it, Santa. Here comes Rambo junior.''

title: TURNER TO SEEK TALKS ON MGM
description: Ted Turner, the cable television entrepreneur, expects to resume negotiations to sell part of MGM as soon as the merger has been completed, a spokesman said today.

title: EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $2,150,898. c-After a capital loss of $303,436.

title: TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NATIONAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $98,000 for the 6 months.

title: INTER-CITY GAS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a special net gain of $892,000 from tax credits, losses on the sale of business units and provision against investment in potential utility operations. c-After a writedown of $28,373,000 of an investment in MICC Investments Ltd.

title: Next Topic, Please
description: When Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, returns from observing the elections in the Philippines, he will find waiting on his desk a request from four Democrats on the committee that the panel hold hearings on another of the world's trouble spots, Northern Ireland.

title: 3 Skeletons Unearthed On Ranch in Colorado
description: Workers unearthed a third human skeleton today at a ranch whose former owner is charged with murdering a truck driver, and investigators said they are looking for up to six more bodies.

title: ADRIAN R. KRISTELLER
description: Adrian R. Kristeller, a dentist turned Wall Street broker, and the only known member of the New York Stock Exchange licensed to practice dentistry, died Thursday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., after a brief illness.

title: UNITED STATES ELECTRONICS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BANNED TRAINER GIVEN STAY
description: Alain de Royer Dupre, the French trainer whose license was revoked by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board on Jan. 16 because one of his horses, Lashkari, tested positive for a controlled substance last fall, has obtained a temporary restraining order staying that revocation until a hearing next Friday.

title: ROBOT DEFENSE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
The Editorial Notebook; Again, the Corleone Code
description: A prize for candor is surely owed to Salim Saleh Mohammed, the rising new leader of Southern Yemen, the only Marxist state in the Arab world. He dispensed with Marxist explanations for the massacre of his comrades at a Politburo meeting last month and cited instead a code of power popularized by Francis Ford Coppola and Mario Puzo.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT GAINS SEATS
description: Warner Communications and Chris-Craft Industries, indicating that they have ended their hostilities for the time being, yesterday announced an agreement for Chris-Craft to increase its representation on Warner's board.

title: JAZZ: TOMMY FLANAGAN AT VILLAGE VANGUARD
description: A set by the pianist Tommy Flanagan, who is leading his trio at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, near West 11th Street, on Sunday, can be a revelation to a listener on almost any level of jazz experience.

title: MOORE MCCORMACK REOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HIS PLACE TO KICK
description: Like many impressionable athletes with headstrong older brothers, as a youngster growing up in Chino, Calif., Alan Zendejas did not have much say in his choice of a sports specialty. His brother, Luis, was a place-kicker.

title: YANKEE COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $550,000. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $298,000.

title: Los Angeles City Council Softens Sanctuary Law
description: The City Council today rescinded a measure declaring Los Angeles a sanctuary for political refugees after opponents argued that it was an invitation to illegal aliens to break the law.

title: GENERAL SHALE PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains of $360,000 for the quarter and $482,000 for the year from the sale of surplus land. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January 1986.

title: CP NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CROSS A T CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Medical
description: An investment group led by the Bass family of Fort Worth said it had raised its stake in American Medical International Inc. from 10.2 percent, to 11.4 percent of the shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group did not amend its previously reported position that it held the shares for investment purposes only.

title: T.W.A LOSS WIDER IN 4TH QUARTER
description: Trans World Airlines reported yesterday that its 1985 fourth-quarter loss had widened to $123.4 million from $29.4 million in the 1984 period.

title: Baltimore Paper's Workers Join Bid
description: A group of employees at The Baltimore News-American has voted to join a local executive in his effort to buy the financially ailing daily from the Hearst Corporation. Today was the deadline for potential buyers to submit formal bids for the 213-year-old newspaper.

title: 2 Police Officers Are Suspended
description: Two New York City police officers have been arrested and suspended without pay in separate cases.

title: ADDDITIONAL TAX BREAKS CAN BE FOUND AT HOME
description: People searching for extra tax deductions and credits often have to look no further than their own home, where everything from storm windows to maids and nannies can often be written off.

title: BOXER SUSPENDED
description: When Francis Sargent was knocked out in the second round of a cruiserweight bout in Chicago on Dec. 14, the loss was especially embarrassing. The winner, Craig Bodzianowksi, was making a comeback after the amputation of his right foot.

title: DEVRY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,404,000 reflecting the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: 20 REPORTED DEAD
description: President Jean-Claude Duvalier boarded a United States Air Force jet and fled to France before dawn today, ending the 28-year grip of his family on this impoverished Caribbean nation.

title: Shuttle Inquiry Commission Holds 2d Session in Private
description: President Reagan's commission on the loss of the space shuttle Challenger held a closed session today to plan its investigation and to follow up the testimony it heard from officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in a public meeting Thursday.

title: TRANSWORLD AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary net gains of $526,000 for the quarter and $15,341,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: A.T.&T.'s Debt Is Downgraded
description: The senior debt and preferred stock rating of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was lowered yesterday to Aa-3, from Aa-1, by Moody's Investors Service.

title: AUDIT CRITICIZES H.R.A. ON CONSULTANT CONTRACTS
description: The city's Human Resources Administration hired several consultants without giving enough consideration to whether their services were needed and then failed to adequately monitor their work, according to a recent audit by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $2 million. The company said adoption of CICA recommendations in accounting for investment tax credits reduced 1985 year net by about $11 million.

title: MEMBERS OF RADICAL GROUP ON TRIAL ACCUSES POLICE
description: Two days after stalking out of her trial, the only adult survivor of the confrontation between the radical group Move and the police returned to a gilded courtroom here today and accused the police of murdering her colleagues.

title: TODAY
description: Basketball N.B.A. Legends All-Star Game, Slam Dunk contest and Long Distance Shootout, at Reunion Arena, Dallas. Bob Cousy, John Havlicek, Dave Cowens, Oscar Robertson, Elvin Hayes, Walt Frazier, Pete Maravich, Nate Thurmond and Adrian Smith are among old-timers playing after current players dunk and shoot. (Television - WTBS, 10:05 P.M., tape). Colleges: Michigan at Illinois (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.); Memphis State at Nevada-Las Vegas (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M.); Louisville at North Carolina State (Television -Channel 4, 3 P.M.); Notre Dame at Syracuse (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 4 P.M.); Texas at Arkansas (Television - MSG, 4 P.M.); North Carolina-Charlotte at Western Kentucky (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.); Boston College at St. John's (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 8 P.M.); Kentucky at Mississippi (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.); St. Peter's at Fordham, 3 P.M. (Radio -WFUV-FM 90.7, 3 P.M.); Columbia at Harvard, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 7:30 P.M.); Manhattan at Iona, 3 P.M. (Television - MSG, 8 P.M. tape. Radio - WFAS, 103.9; 3 P.M.); George Washington at Rutgers, 1 P.M. (Radio - WCTC, 1450; and WRSU-FM, 89.7; 1 P.M.); Seton Hall at Georgetown, 1 P.M. (Radio - WSOU-FM ,89.5; 1 P.M.); Rutgers-Newark at Baruch, 7:30 P.M.; Dominican at Brooklyn, 7:30 P.M.; City at Hunter, 2 P.M.; Dowling at Southampton, 7:30 P.M.; L.I.U. at Marist, 3 P.M.; U.S. Merchant Marine at Hartwick, 8 P.M.; N.Y.U. at Rensselaer Poly Tech, 7 P.M.; Brown at Princeton, 7:30 P.M.; Towson State at Rider, 3 P.M.; La Salle at Fairfield, 8 P.M.; Lehigh at Lafayette, 3 P.M.; Holy Cross at Army, 3:30 P.M. Figure Skating United States National Championships, at Nassau Coliseum, 11 A.M. Junior dance, free dance, junior pairs' freestyle and championship ladies' freestyle will take place in the afternoon.

title: Woman on Device in Arizona Receives Heart From Donor
description: Surgeons tonight transplanted a human heart into a patient who had become the second woman to receive an artificial heart.

title: TRANSIT AS A VOCATION
description: They may seem like an odd couple, but the Transit Authority and the Board of Education are joining hands at East New York High School to establish the first high school program in the city for transit technology.

title: 3 Books Nominated For Hemingway Award
description: Three books have been nominated for the $50,000 Ritz Paris Hemingway Award as the best novel of 1985: ''The Lover'' by Marguerite Duras (Pantheon Books), ''The Old Gringo'' by Carlos Fuentes (Farrar, Straus and Giroux) and ''Annie John'' by Jamaica Kincaid (Farrar, Straus and Giroux).

title: FAIRMONT FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $81,000 for the quarter and $622,000 for the year and tax credits of $622,000 for the quarter and $1,154,000 for the year. c-Including realized investment gains of $10,000 for the quarter and $18,000 for the year. Revenues for the year-ago periods reflect a $10.1 million reinsurance transaction which reduced revenue.

title: HIGH RENTS, BUT HIGH SALES, TOO
description: The Atrium in Trump Tower includes some of the most expensive retail space on Fifth Avenue, and the expensive stores that lease the space report some of the highest sales per square foot in the United States.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Jonathan Hollander was the only man not wearing a tie at a party recently at Fraunces Tavern at Broad and Pearl Streets. But he fit in easily among the dark-suited financiers.

title: AMERICAN CARRIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DROPS TO 6.6% AS MORE GET WORK
description: Surprisingly strong job growth helped drive the nation's overall unemployment rate down two-tenths of a point in January, to 6.6 percent, the lowest level in nearly six years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: EX-C.I.A. AID CONVICTED IN SPY CASE
description: A Federal jury today found a retired Central Intelligence Agency analyst guilty on charges of spying for the Chinese for more than 30 years.

title: STAGE: JAN FABRE'S 'THEATRICAL MADNESS'
description: Jan Fabre was billed by the Kitchen as Belgium's answer to Pina Bausch, Laurie Anderson, Peter Brook and Robert Wilson, and three and a half hours into his four-hour, uninterrupted quasi-operatic theatrical performance piece ''The Power of Theatrical Madness'' - offered for two nights only Tuesday and Wednesday - one began finally to believe that might be true. But it took a long time for Mr. Fabre to start suggesting that he did indeed have striking potential. And by then, half of Wednesday's audience had walked out.

title: PUBLIC SERVIEC CO OF N C INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HIS OWN DEFENSE
description: While pondering what present-day ballplayers might be considered as strong candidates for the Baseball Hall of Fame when they finish their careers, Brooks Robinson said that defensive deficiencies were not an important factor.

title: PITT WINS FOUL-PLAGUED GAME
description: Pittsburgh built first half leads of 21 points behind Demetreus Gore's shooting and went on to beat Villanova, 85-71, today in a physical Big East Conference game in which nine players fouled out.

title: INTERNATIONAL INCOME PROPRTY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,596,000, or 18 cents a share, on the sale of property.

title: INDIAN HEAD BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TGI FRIDAY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
WELLS FARGO TO BUY CROCKER
description: Wells Fargo & Company said today that it would buy the Crocker National Corporation for about $1.08 billion, creating the nation's 10th-largest bank, with assets of more than $40 billion.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income after a loss of $1.6 million from discontinued operations in the quarter and including income from discontinued operations of $17.5 million in the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $140.8 million.

title: PACIFICARE HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. EASES LIBYAN OIL CURB RULES
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was modifying its economic sanctions against Libya to allow American oil companies to continue to make profits from the sale of Libyan oil. The intent is to prevent the funds from going to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POP: KATHIE LEE JOHNSON
description: Kathie Lee Johnson, the popular star of morning television, is a polished singer and entertainer in a Las Vegas lounge tradition that substitutes glamour and charm-school cordiality for genuinely intimate communication with an audience. Although Miss Johnson, who is appearing at Freddy's Supper Club (308 East 49th Street) through Sunday, has a strong and steady pop voice, her singing lacks any identifiable personal stamp.

title: San Diego Acting Mayor Is Under Investigation
description: San Diego's acting mayor, who took over because his predecessor was convicted of a felony, has decided to quit the Feb. 25 mayoral primary because of a legal problem of his own.

title: UNITED SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC OF MISSOURI reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EWING UNLIKELY FOR ALL-STAR GAME
description: Patrick Ewing was limping through the airport in Salt Lake City this morning on the way for a flight here for Sunday's National Basketball Association All-Star Game.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Manila dispatch on Jan. 30 about Corazon C. Aquino's inner circle of advisers misidentified the president of IBM Philippines. He is Roberto R. Romulo, not Romulo del Rosario.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HOLLYWOOD FROM VIETNAM TO REAGAN. By Robin Wood. (Columbia University Press, $25.) Robin Wood, a professor of film studies at York University in Ontario, Canada, who styles himself a ''free-lance radical,'' has written one of the most dogmatic and irritating books on film in recent memory.

title: IN SYDNEY, FASHION TAKES A BOLD TACK
description: For years, Australian fashion designers deviated little from the whims of their upper-class clientele, who desired staid ball gowns for the Queen's visit, conservative navy blue linen dresses for the horse races and uncharacteristically racy swimsuits for their seemingly endless summers on the beach.

title: A Wall Street Rocker
description: As a fellow songwriter/musician/business person, I felt many similarities to Jim Fusilli's situation, with one major difference: you can have it all (''A Wall Street Rocker,'' About Men, Dec. 15).

title:
GARDENING;
FRUITS THAT LAST CAN DECORATE WINTER
description: TO provide an appropriate conclusion to the series of articles on woody plants having winter interest, one must consider those with attractive fruits.

title: Lanny Paykin
description: The cellist Lanny Paykin attended the High School of Music and Art, and later took degrees at Wesleyan University and the Juilliard School, where he received the Alumni Award; he has also won a prize from the Paderewski Foundation. Last Sunday afternoon, Mr. Paykin made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: F.A.A. BARS USE OF A DC-8 FLEET BY CHARTER LINE
description: The charter airline whose December crash killed 248 American soldiers may not fly its 10 DC-8 jetliners until it replaces unapproved spare parts, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: NO CHEAP COGNAC
description: SPY WEDNESDAY By William Hood. 282 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $14.95.

title: VETERANS' CONCERNS LEAD TO AID FOR NEEDIEST
description: Vietnam veterans expressing concern about the growing number of homeless men in the city's shelters are among the donors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: WITH ALL DELIBERATE SPEED: WHAT'S SO BAD ABOUT WRITING FAST?
description: IF, during spring term at Yale University in 1949 you wandered diagonally across the campus noticing here and there an undergraduate with impacted sleeplessness under his eyes and coarse yellow touches of fear on his cheeks, you were looking at members of a masochistic set who had enrolled in a course called Daily Themes. No Carthusian novitiate embarked on a bout of mortification of the flesh suffered more than the students of Daily Themes, whose single assignment, in addition to attending two lectures per week, was to write a 500-to-600-word piece of descriptive prose every day, and to submit it before midnight (into a large box outside a classroom). Sundays were the only exception (this was before the Warren Court outlawed Sunday).

title: Hijacker's Special?
description: An Austrian company named Glock produces a 9-millimeter automatic handgun with a plastic frame and wants to export it to the United States. Federal officials were worried at first that the weapon might elude airport metal detectors without a beep.

title: Who Gets Custody?
description: Question: When I was divorced, my wife got custody of the children, but nothing was said about the house, which is in both our names. I do not know where she is and I want to sell the house. I paid for the house and have made all the mortgage payments. How can I have the deed changed or sell the property without her cooperation? . . . J. V., Mount Vernon, N.Y. Answer: You cannot simply have title to the house changed without her signature. Flora Schnall, a partner in the real estate department of the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy, suggests that you sell the property by going to State Supreme Court for a proceeding for partition and sale. The court would consider the amount you have put into repairs, improvements and maintenance, and would hold your wife's half of the proceeds from the sale. See a lawyer. Co-oping in the Hamptons Question: I have found two houses on the same lot but I can't afford the purchase price of both and there is not enough property to subdivide. If I sell one of the houses to someone as a tenant in common, will this person or I have problems eventually selling the property? If I wanted to co-op these houses what governmental permissions would I need? . . . A. M., East Hampton, L.I. Answer: The 1984 zoning code for the Town of East Hampton prohibits converting houses to co-Redinger ops in zones designated for single-family residences, according to Russell Stein, town attorney.

title: A HIGH-YIELD OPTION FOR I.R.A.'S
description: FALLING interest rates may be welcome in some quarters, but they bring scant pleasure to people with Individual Retirement Accounts. Most I.R.A. money has gone into certificates of deposit, but the present one-year C.D. yield of about 8 percent has sent many investors in search of higher-yield options. For a growing number, the search is ending with publicly registered limited partnerships, which are riskier than C.D.'s but could produce double-digit compound yields.

title: ODDS VARY FOR PLAYERS TRYING TO COME BACK FROM INJURIES
description: RICK BURLESON, Jerry Remy and Joe Lefebvre played in no major league games last season. Charlie Lea pitched in none. Dennis Leonard, Alejandro Pena and Ernie Camacho each pitched in only two games. John Montefusco and Bruce Berenyi pitched in only three each.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The television highlights and listings today in The Guide, section 2A, carry an erroneous description of ''Saturday Night Live'' for Feb. 15 at 11:30 P.M. on Channel 4. The appearance of Ron Reagan as guest host occurred last night.

title: MASSACRE WITH TEA: SOUTHERN YEMEN AT WAR
description: Tea was being served to the Politburo members from a thermos bottle by one of the President's personal guards, Ali Salem al-Beedh recalled later, while another, as always, carried the leader's Samsonite attache case to the head chair. It was odd, Mr. Beedh thought, that the meeting was beginning almost on time - seven minutes after 10 - when there were still empty seats. Then the shooting began. ''The guard with the Samsonite, Hassan was his name, suddenly began raking Ali Antar up and down his back with a machine pistol, a Skorpion, as he was opening his briefcase,'' Mr. Beedh said, describing the death of Mr. Antar, the Vice President and former Defense Minister.

title: Geralyn Orlovitz Intends to Marry M. L. Rubenstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Orlovitz of Greenwich, Conn., have announced that their daughter, Geralyn Beth Orlovitz, plans to marry Michael L. Rubenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Rubenstein of Great Neck, L.I., and Danbury, Conn., in August.

title: SQUARING OFF IN THE STATEHOUSE
description: UNLIKE the 1985 session of the General Assembly, which seemed to blur the differences between Governor O'Neill and the Republican majorities, the 1986 legislative session began last week with sharper contrasts.

title: COMMISSION BEGINS ITS WORK ON HOMELESS
description: WESTCHESTER'S newly formed temporary Commission on the Homeless met officially for the first time last Tuesday morning and discussed an agenda of possible long- and short-term goals, ranging from building new housing to ''mending fences.''

title: INDIAN TRADERS FADING FROM WESTERN LANDSCAPE
description: A pickup truck rolled to a stop by the gas pumps at the Borrego Pass Trading Post and a young Navajo stuck his head through the door.

title: LIBYA HOLDING MANEUVERS AS 6TH FLEET NEARS
description: Libya announced today that its navy, air force and air defense units had started a week of maneuvers with live ammunition within the Tripoli area.

title: Unbalanced, and Not Just in Dollars
description: President Reagan's intentions stand. Regardless of what dental work the courts do on the teeth in the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction law, and regardless of which programs Congress rescues from being ''zeroed out,'' the President's budget tells unmistakably what he cares about.

title: Out of Africa
description: To the Editor: The individual traveler can, as Nancy Cooper writes, travel on one's own in a still-wild Kenya (''Nairobi, the Ngong Hills and Beyond,'' Travel, Jan. 12), but it takes more than a little planning. Driving through Africa is not quite as simple as motoring through the Loire Valley, as I discovered in the summer of 1984.

title: Like the Titanic
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWS PROVIDE FRAMEWORK FOR PROCEDURE
description: THE AVAILABILITY of reliable scientific procedures for detecting the presence of controlled substances in professional athletes has predictably stirred legal controversy. Initially used to discern illicit means of attaining a competitive edge, the tests are now being adapted to detect the residue of ''social drugs'' capable of adversely affecting on-field performance and, not infrequently, of destroying lives. Although these procedures have been attacked on privacy grounds, such tests are well within our legal framework.

title: OBSESSED IN IRAN
description: THE BOOK OF ABSENT PEOPLE By Taghi Modarressi. 206 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $15.95.

title: Paul A. Perlin to Marry Julie Ann Salzberg in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Salzberg of Paradise Valley, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daugher, Julie Ann Salzberg, to Paul Alan Perlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bart Perlin of Kings Point, L.I. A June wedding is planned. The future bride is the manager of promotional marketing for the United States division of Elizabeth Arden Inc. in New York and a guest lecturer of cosmetic advertising design at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Social Events; Parties, Big and Small
description: Roasting for a Cause Feb. 11 - Lily Tomlin, Barbara Walters, Kathleen Turner, Helen Gurley Brown, Beverly Sills, Nora Ephron and Dr. Ruth Westheimer are among those who are scheduled to participate in a roast of Liz Smith, The Daily News columnist, all for the benefit of the Women's Action Alliance, a 15-year-old organization devoted to promoting full equality for women. The evening at Studio 54, 254 West 54th Street, includes a 7 P.M. cocktail reception with the participants and the roast at 8 P.M., with Champagne, other wines and a Tex-Mex buffet. Tickets, $250 for the entire evening, or $125 for the roast and buffet alone, from 212-532-8330. Party at the Movies Feb. 13 - There is no known cure for systemic lupus erythematosus, a chronic inflammatory disease of the skin and the body's connective tisues that afflicts almost a million people worldwide, most of them women between the ages of 10 and 40. Two local chapters of the Lupus Foundation of America, which finances research and treatment centers, are holding a benefit with dinner and an opening-night screening of the movie ''Wildcats,'' starring Goldie Hawn. The evening starts at 6:30 P.M. at the Gemini II theater, Second Avenue near 63d Street. Tickets, $35, from 212-685-4118 or 516-541-5088. Summer-Camp Benefit Feb. 13 - For more than 800 underprivileged boys and girls, Camp Sussex in Sussex, N.J., provides three summer weeks of sports, crafts, play and fellowship, all without charge. Support for the camp, which opened in 1923, comes from contributions and benefits, including this year's Valentine's Eve Ball, to be held from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. at the Sporting Club, 99 Hudson Street, near Franklin Street.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: 86 ON NEW YORK POLICE FORCE FACED ARREST IN '85
description: Eighty-six officers of the New York City Police Department, most of them on the force for less than five years, were charged with crimes in 1985, according to a recently completed departmental report. The charges ranged from disorderly conduct to criminally negligent homicide.

title: LIVES IN SHORT
description: NINE WOMEN By Shirley Ann Grau. 204 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: JAPAN'S BUG PUSH ON WALL STREET
description: WHEN Yoshitoki Chino, the chairman of the Daiwa Securities Company, visited Daiwa's New York subsidiary last fall, he was upset about the Japanese art on the walls. ''The next time I'm here,'' he directed, ''I want to see only American paintings.''

title: HOW NONPROFITS CAN PROFIT
description: The Hudson River Museum's unhappy situation demonstrates what happens when a nonprofit makes a Faustian bargain with government. Fixers can't fix, the County Executive discovers that the County Legislature doesn't obey commands and the public is yet again reminded that politicians put more faith in polls than in cultural uplift.

title: PRINCETON RALLIES TO UPSET BROWN
description: The junior forward Aaron Belz came off the bench to score 8 of Princeton's last 12 points tonight and give the Tigers the lead for good as they rallied to defeat Brown, 54-53, in an Ivy League game.

title: Coordinating Tennis Colors
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE STORIES OF DENTON WELCH. Edited by Robert Phillips. (Dutton, $24.95.) The typical Denton Welch story centers in a consciousness a little outside the accepted patterns of social order, usually that of an artist or writer (both of which Welch himself was) or a rucksack-carrying stranger seeking shelter in an unfamiliar countryside. Some contact, emotional or physical - as slight as the touching of a tongue to the brass fixtures of a Chinese houseboat or a lingering handclasp between two men - causes a shift of perception that subtly alters a relationship or simply brings a fresh vision. The best of these stories are autobiographical, with the narrator even named Denton in some, and the collection records (though not chronologically) Welch's pivotal moments of revelation. Born in 1915, as Robert Phillips states in his preface, Welch was ''knocked off his bicycle by a 'woman driver' (as he said) on June 7, 1935.'' Until his death in 1948 Welch had to deal with the consequences of this accident: a fractured spine that became tubercular, and crippling pain. Now that most of Welch's writing -which included novels, poems and journals - is appearing in American editions, Mr. Phillips suggests that these stories offer the easiest entry to Welch's work. This is true, but it would have been even more useful, considering the seemingly arbitrary shifts in locale, to add that Welch was born in Shanghai, the youngest of three sons, to an Anglo-American couple. His father and brothers were ''hearty'' types, the sons revealing nothing of their mercurial American mother.

title: CAPITALISM, OR VIRTUE REWARDED
description: HOW THE WEST GREW RICH The Economic Transformation of the Industrial World. By Nathan Rosenberg and L. E. Birdzell Jr. 353 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Upside Down Values
description: The way new technology is seen to be critical to steady economic growth in the industrial world is coming to be linked perversely to defense spending. This is an unhealthy development.

title: WHAT TO BUY WHEN THERE ARE NO MORE GADGETS AND GIZMOS
description: OUR house is an expanded Cape Cod, and since our children left the nest, the sole occupants of the large upstairs bedrooms are our two cats who romp back and forth in our daughters' rooms.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: This New York Times/CBS News Poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 19 through 23 with 1,581 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Jews, Poles and Statistics
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Court Administrators Cited As Botein Awards Recipients
description: Four recipients of the 1986 Bernard Botein Awards, given for outstanding contributions to the administration of justice, were announced last week. The recipients are:

title: RENT STRIKE ON UPPER EAST SIDE SPAWNS 4-YEAR LEGAL TANGLE
description: Several tenants of an Upper East Side apartment building have resumed making rent payments after four years' refusal to do so. Their complaint was that living conditions had deteriorated because the landlord leased apartments as office space to nearly 100 psychiatrists, psychologists and other therapists.

title: Bears' Jersey Is 'Halas' Blue
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: YALE GLEE CLUB PLANS AN ALL-DAY BIRTHDAY PARTY
description: THE Yale Glee Club, whose alumni include Cole Porter, Vincent Price and the Rev. William Sloan Coffin, will celebrate its 125th birthday on Saturday with an elaborate campus reunion. Old members will come together, and the university as a whole will remind itself of the importance singing groups have traditionally enjoyed at Yale. The Whiffenpoofs, the Baker's Dozen, the Alley Cats and a dozen more like them have sprouted and flourished at the school over the past century, but it is the Glee Club that rolls most impressively on.

title: INVESTIGATORS BROADEN INQUIRY INTO CITY CORRUPTION
description: Investigators used their power of subpoena last week to extend their inquiries into New York City corruption to additional city agencies, to political organizations and across city lines to Yonkers.

title: Harriet L. Rogers Engaged to Wed Thomas Linskey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Harwood Rogers of Darien and Stonington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Harriet Lovell Rogers to Thomas Joseph Linskey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Linskey of Los Angeles. The wedding is planned for May.

title: 'Star Wars' - as 'Perfect' as Challenger?
description: The tragedy of the Challenger should serve as ample reply to those few who continue to argue that a space-based defense against nuclear weapons is feasible. The Strategic Defense Initiative - ''Star Wars'' - would turn the entire nation into a space shuttle, making the existence of 200 million people contingent upon ''flawless'' American technology.

title: AN ORCHESTRATOR OF BOOKS
description: ''WHAT'S new,'' said Harold Steinberg, ''is that we've expanded our publishing program by about 50-fold.''

title:
GARDENING;
FRUITS THAT LAST CAN DECORATE WINTER
description: TO provide an appropriate conclusion to the series of articles on woody plants having winter interest, one must consider those with attractive fruits.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FIREWATER POND. By Michael Kimball. (Putnam, $17.95.) As proprietor of Wind in the Pines, a backwoods Maine campground, Carl Mason is a model of tolerance.

title: Carol Lisa Lind Plans to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Carol Lisa Lind to R. Christopher Roberto has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Lind of Manhasset, L.I. Mr. Roberto is the son of Justice and Mrs. Robert Roberto Jr. of Manhasset.

title: TURNPIKE WIDENING: PLUSES AND MINUSES
description: FOR THE first time since a $2 billion widening of the New Jersey Turnpike was proposed last May, firm indications of the project's environmental impact have been disclosed.

title: CLASSIC COMIC ACTOR TAKES THE REINS OF A CLASSIC 20'S FARCE
description: Sitting sipping soup in a rundown room filled with fedoras and doors, Alan Arkin has the unmistakable air of a man who has been here before. It is not this particular rehearsal hall he has inhabited, but the roles: of director talking about a new production, of actor talking about a new movie, of author talking about a new book, of father talking about his sons. Alan Arkin has lived a charmed actor's life. He has had wonderful parts in good movies, directed terrific plays, written books, worked with his wife and his children, even recorded albums and appeared on ''Sesame Street.'' And he has been very, very good at all these things. Smart, thoughtful, articulate, he also happens to be very, very good at talking about them. He has, his black eyes periods at the end of his sentences, only the slightest air of a man who has been obliged to discuss what he does somewhat more than he would like to.

title: Still a Tossup
description: Bo Jackson, the star Auburn running back, is also a star Auburn outfielder, and one of the big questions of recent years is whether he will decide to play professional football or baseball. Jackson was asked about the choice again while he was in New Haven to receive the Walter Camp Football Foundation's player of the year award, and again he shed absolutely no light on the subject.

title: MUSIC VIDEOS TOP LIST
description: VIEWERS of MTV, the 24-hour music-video cable network, will be seeing a lot more of Hoboken, Secaucus, Freehold, Edison, Asbury Park, Fort Lee and Jersey City in the next few months.

title: Serious Business
description: THE BARS OF TELEVISION commercials are not the kind of bars I give my custom to.

title: Reinhold Niebuhr's Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: THE IMPACT OF IMPACT STATEMENTS
description: The article ''A Growing Debate on Impact Statements'' [ Jan. 5 ] was both timely and well-balanced. It focused on an increasingly gnawing problem faced by our industry: delay and procrastination in the approval of new communities.

title: THOMAS AND BOITANO WIN IN FIGUIRE SKATING
description: The practice sessions in the cold, damp rinks had been discouraging, Debi Thomas said. She was told by her coach that she would have to perform five triple jumps during her 4-minute long program in order to become the women's national figure skating champion, and she was struggling all week just to complete three without a stumble or fall. So when the dress rehearsals ended and it was time to perform today, Miss Thomas was hoping for the ''little miracle'' she would need to win, the one she would find on the ice a few minutes later.

title: LYNCH EXCELS
description: Shola Lynch led from start to finish tonight to win the Girls High Schools Invitation 1,000-meter run at the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The Hunter College High School junior was timed in 2 minutes 29.65 seconds.

title: CITY BALLET: 'EIGHT LINES' AND 'VALSE'
description: THE re-entry of two ballets into the New York City Ballet repertory added at least the fillip of novelty to a surprisingly tedious evening last Tuesday at the New York State Theater. Jerome Robbins's ''Eight Lines,'' set to music by Steve Reich, is a kind of sequel to the choreographer's ''Glass Pieces.'' Each dance has a geometric simplicity that can be tonic. But ''Eight Lines'' is distinctly minor Robbins, though it was danced with affecting clarity by Kyra Nichols and Maria Calegari, leading a cast that included Sean Lavery, looking slightly ill at ease, a vigorous Ib Andersen, and Paul Boos, Victor Castelli and Kipling Houston.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HEPBURN FESTIVAL Many facets of Katharine Hepburn's artistry may be seen this week when five of her films spanning a 30-year period are shown at Connecticut College. ''We are having a Hepburn Festival,'' said Julie Quinn of the college public-relations office, ''for no particular reason. We just wanted to.''

title: Emigration's Champion May Finally Be Packing
description: ON Tuesday, if all goes according to plan, a short, bald man with a winning grin will cross the fortified line from East to West Berlin. That journey, if it happens, will end one of the most dramatic cases of political imprisonment in the Soviet Union's post-Stalin history. And it will be an opening move of a discreet minuet that the two superpowers have begun in the delicate area of human rights.

title: Karen R. Boutelle Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Joan Boutelle of Branford, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Karen Renee Boutelle, to John D. Lethbridge Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lethbridge of Wilton, Conn.

title: STATE'S FILM INDUSTRY GAINS
description: WHEN Woody Allen decided to shoot a scene for his latest movie, ''Hannah and Her Sisters,'' in a quintessential turn-of-the-century ice cream parlor, he found one in Jersey City.

title: DOWNWIND FROM THE BOMB
description: ALTHOUGH AMERICA'S FIRST ATOMIC TESTS WERE conducted in secrecy in New Mexico, after World War II the United States shifted nuclear-weapons trials to the southern Pacific Ocean. The possibility of security breeches was offset, it was reasoned, by the lessened risk to public health and safety.

title: HOW SCENIC 1A LEADS THE TRAVELER ASTRAY
description: Coastal mythology immortalizes a Port Jefferson yachtsman who had difficulty sailing to Groton Long Point on the other side of Long Island Sound and was asked which chart he had used. He pointed to the little diagram in the Long Island Rail Road timetable. He was pleased to learn that someone had thought up something more specific, something with better details on, well, the water part.

title: Kaare Phillips Is Married To Richard Arthur Kumro
description: Kaare Phillips and Richard Arthur Kumro, both members of the Yale University class of '79 who received law degrees from New York University in 1984, were married yesterday at the Spanish Institute in New York.

title: TV STATION AIMS FOR A 'MIX' OF NEWS
description: STATE officials and the vice president of WOR-TV say that the station's sole responsibility is not to provide a preponderance of local news.

title: THIS VERSATILE UNIT DOES DOUBLE DUTY
description: Our mini-series on notable novelties in the 8-millimeter video format turns the spotlight today on Kodak's entries in this new field. Like most 8-millimeter video gear, Kodak's Modular Video System (MVS) centers on a camcorder - a camera/recorder combination that allows its owner to roam about freely on battery power, making his or her own video movies. But unlike the others, the Kodak camcorder is not a single unit. It splits apart - separating into a camera and a recorder.

title: PAPERBACK BSET SELLERS
description: Feb. 9, 1986 Fiction

title: POPS CONCERT: GRIEG AND MOVIE THEMES
description: THE kinship between oldtime Hollywood film music and late Romantic concert fare was pleasurably illustrated by the New York Pops Orchestra on Friday in a Carnegie Hall program that began with Grieg and ended with ''Body and Soul.'' For the first half of the evening, Skitch Henderson led the orchestra through smooth readings of Grieg's Lyric Suite and the Piano Concerto in A minor, the latter featuring Pamela Mia Paul as soloist.

title: COUNTY CONCERN FIRST IN JAPANESE ARKET
description: THOSE who bemoan the loss of manufacturing jobs in the county will be visibly cheered by the performance of V Band Systems Inc. in Yonkers. The telecommunications company, barely six years old, not only ranks among the top manufacturing firms in the county, but it is also the first non-Japanese telecommunications company to win approval to sell its systems for connection to the Japanese telecommunications network.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE SCATTER FUNERAL CROWD WITH TEAR GAS
description: The police used tear gas today to break up a crowd of 1,000 mourners singing freedom songs at the funeral of a 15-year-old girl killed in the black township of Kagiso last month, residents said.

title: IMAGINING JAPAN
description: THE SHOWA ANTHOLOGY Modern Japanese Short Stories. Volume One: 1929-1961. Volume Two: 1961-1984. Edited by Van C. Gessel and Tomone Matsumoto. 428 pp. New York: Kodansha International/ Harper & Row. $17.95 each.

title: BEN WEBSTER: A JAZZ GREAT IS STILL BEING DISCOVERED
description: Ben Webster, the tenor saxophonist who died in Amsterdam in 1973 at the age of 64, played in some of the most celebrated big bands of the 1930's and 40's, including those led by Duke Ellington, Fletcher Henderson, Cab Calloway, Benny Carter and Andy Kirk. He was also in Teddy Wilson's short-lived band in 1939 and the Bennie Moten band of the early 30's, which spawned Count Basie's Orchestra and was part of Norman Granz's touring troupe of jazz stars, Jazz at the Philharmonic, in the 1950's. In his last years, he led small groups and freelanced in this country and Europe.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHARM, INFORMALITY IN LARCHMONT
description: OCCUPYING the spot that was once Crawford's, John Charles Manor Place has undergone fitting refurbishing for its location among some of the the more elegant antique shops on the Mamaroneck-Larchmont stretch of the Boston Post Road. The wainscoting has been stripped and stained, brass fittings sparkle and Priscilla window curtains add hominess. And the clientele - from jacketed-and-tied men and carefully casual fur-coated women to diners in plaid flannel shirts and faded jeans - clearly appreciate the kitchen's efforts.

title: Haggis
description: To the Editor: Gloria Levitas seems to have liked the good haggis that she found in Scotland (''Haggis: History and Humor,'' Travel, Jan. 5).

title: DISPUTE OVER A MOSLEM DIVORCE ENSNARLS GANDHI
description: She was cast aside by her husband after 43 years of marriage, a not uncommon occurrence in much of the world. But Shah Bano reacted differently for an Indian woman, especially for a Moslem woman. She went to court to demand money from the man who divorced her.

title: PULSAR FINDING MAY HOLD CLUES TO BIRTH OF UNIVERSE
description: A new pulsing star, or pulsar, has been detected in the constellation Aquila spinning 186 times a second.

title: DEVILS ARE HANDED FIRST SHUTOUT LOSS
description: Mario Lemieux scored his 29th and 30th goals of the season, and Roberto Romano stopped 27 shots as the Pittsburgh Penguins beat the Devils, 4-0, tonight. It was the Devils' seventh consecutive defeat.

title: A BETTER WAY TO BUILD MODELS
description: SPREADSHEETS, by their very nature, pose a problem for their users. Unlike data base managers, these programs have almost no built-in structure that could discipline the user who is developing a financial model. It becomes difficult after a while to check the model's formulas, recall its assumptions, or even review its underlying logic. It can - and often does - lead to numeric chaos.

title: Affronted by Ashbery
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics Entrance Requirements; Not Private
description: When Ralph Lauren, the designer, rented the Union League Club in New York for a 1984 fashion show, he surely never imagined it would be the basis of a civil rights complaint. But that show is one piece of evidence for the charge that the Union League Club, and also the University Club and the Century Association, are not truly private and should therefore admit women to membership.

title: WITNESS IN A JERSEY MURDER TRIAL ADMITS TO LIES BEFORE HIS ARREST
description: The key witness in the state's case against an insurance broker charged with conspiring to murder his wife testified this week that he had lied from time to time about the slaying before he was arrested.

title: Beblurbed and Betrayed
description: To the Editor:

title: PROGRAMS BY BEN NIGHTINGALE
description: AS a black man who looks white, and as a Jew who grew up as a member of Philadelphia's First African Baptist Church, Ben Nightingale has a fascinating story to tell - and to sing. The tenor, who had performed with the New York City Opera, left his music career about 10 years ago to concentrate on writing, but recently he returned to his first love, and will be giving three programs in area libraries this month.

title: L.I.E. BERM SOUGHT AT ISLANDIA
description: HOMEOWNERS in the Islip community of Islandia are trying to insure that an extension of the Long Island Expressway service road, which will reach as close as 11 feet to their backyards, will not cause serious environmental and safety problems.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IMAGE AS INSIGHT: Visual Understanding in Western Christianity and Secular Culture. By Margaret R. Miles. (Beacon Press, $24.95.) Margaret R. Miles, the first tenured female professor at the Harvard Divinity School, argues that conventional history overemphasizes writing and devalues the more widely shared visual language of art.

title: POETRY IN MOTION: THE VIDEO MUSE
description: THE relation between printing and literature has always been intimate and all-inclusive, at times even incestuous: printing was the daughter of letters; today it is its lover. In contrast, the relations between literature and the modern means of communication - I am thinking of radio and, above all, television - have been distant, desultory and marked by indifference if not disdain and even hostility. Nevertheless, radio and television are powerful means of transmitting words; it is scandalous that they so rarely involve themselves with literature. I am referring, of course, not to theater but to poetry, the novel and the short story. Many of the reasons for this estrangement are social and economic. The explanation usually offered is that radio and television are mass media, while good modern literature, with a few exceptions, has never been an article of popular consumption.

title: MOBSTER TELLS JURY 3 DEFENDANTS WERE MEMBERS OF COLOMBO GROUP
description: James Fratianno, a 72-year-old man who has been called one of the most important witnesses against reputed mob figures in many years, told a jury in Manhattan last week that three of eight defendants on trial for bribery, extortion and racketeering were figures in the Colombo organized-crime family.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SKI-SNOWSHOE RACES ''We have two feet of snow right now and some of the best snowshoeing and cross-country skiing in the region,'' said Halbe Brown, executive director of the Frost Valley Environmental Education Center in Ulster County. The center, in the heart of the Catskills at an elevation of about 3,500 feet, is surrounded by a quarter of a million acres of forest, ''and we are half an hour closer to White Plains than Hunter Mountain,'' Mr. Brown said.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BEYOND HEARING AIDS
description: ''The whole field of assistive listening devices is a sleeping giant,'' said Rochelle Shotland, an audiologist at the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains.

title: Mary Elizabeth Poore
description: The soprano Mary Elizabeth Poore, who made her New York debut at the Merkin Concert Hall the night of Feb. 1, studied at Indiana University, and has sung leading roles with the Orlando, Sarasota and Michigan opera companies.

title: KINGS ARE BEATEN BY ISLANDERS, 4-3
description: The Islanders recovered from an uninspired start and beat the Kings, 4-3, tonight at The Forum.

title: 30 TO 40 REPORTED KILLED IN TRAIN WRECK IN CANADA
description: A Canadian passenger train collided with a 114-car freight train today in western Alberta, and a railroad spokesman said 30 to 40 people died in the heap of twisted, burning rail cars.

title:
ART;
DIVERSITY WITH A COMMON THREAD
description: ONCE a year, the Northport Galleries, one of the Island's four artists' cooperatives, opens its doors to nonmembers on a national scale through its Expo juried competition. Entries, in the form of slides sent from all over the country, are screened by an outside juror, who makes the final selection of participants in the group show - Expo's only award.

title: MENDELSSOHN'S MUSIC ABOUNDS ON CD
description: Compact disks have made it possible to encompass the symphonies of some composers in handy little boxes. The latest to profit from this recording ingenuity is the music of Mendelssohn. His five major symphonies, three overtures and a scherzo are available in a four-disk set from Deutsche Grammophon (415 353-2), performed by the London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus with soloists under the direction of Claudio Abbado.

title: SHOOTING ON EAST 72D ST.
description: A man was shot in the head on East 72d Street in Manhattan last night by at least two men who were riding in a black Cadillac, the police said. The victim, who the police said they believed to be a Cuban in his 40's, was shot several times at 7 P.M. as he was walking near the corner of Third Avenue and 72d Street, the police said. He was taken to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where he was listed in critical condition.

title: IN DAMASCUS, SKYSCRAPERS NOT OF AGES
description: In the last half-century, this city, which claims to be the oldest continuously inhabited settlement in the world, grew 35-fold, from 70,000 to 2.5 million.

title: A Case of Revenge?
description: Mark W. Hofmann, a dealer in rare Mormon Church historical documents, was charged with murder last week in Salt Lake City for bombings that killed a Mormon bishop and the wife of another bishop last October.

title: THE TYRANNY OF THE YALE CRITICS
description: THE ENGLISH department at Yale used to resemble a sort of English country estate. It included a great house of many wings and rooms (the Elizabethan Pavilion, the Metaphysical Poets Billiard Parlor, the T. S. Eliot Chapel and so forth) and, normally, one entered this house via certain well-marked paths and avenues that ran through a spacious park. The park looked as though Nature had placed it there, but it was actually quite artificial, a typical landscape a l'anglais. Now and then a dewy-eyed deer or tame peacock would walk past. Everything was in order. And despite the rival claims of such ancient estates as Oxford and Cambridge, and despite the genius of Harvard and a few other houses, Yale's English department was in many ways the envy of the English-speaking world.

title: JUDITH RESNIK
description: At Carnegie Mellon University, a plaque in Wean Hall bears the inscription, ''My heart is in the work.'' They are the words of the Pittsburgh school's founder, Andrew Carnegie, but they could be an epitaph for one of the school's most accomplished engineering graduates, Judith A. Resnik.

title: LANFORD WILSON'S LATEST REVIVAL PLUMBS LEVELS BENEATH LEVELS
description: ''Vanished without a trace'' - those words echo through ''The Mound Builders,'' Lanford Wilson's dramatic exploration of the world of archeology and its relevance to contemporary life. In the course of this probing drama (currently being revived by the Circle Repertory Company), the author contemplates the varying ways in which we can learn about the past; he asks what constitutes ''a trace'' - artifacts or collective memory? The play also deals with the environmental battle between conservationists and land developers. At the heart is the question of signs of life: what we know about our ancestors and what our descendants will learn about us. ''The Mound Builders'' is a moving, richly charactered play about people united in, and separated by, a shared activity.

title: Barber-Smith-Ives Concert
description: Samuel Barber's chamber opera ''Hand of Bridge'' - with libretto by Gian Carlo Menotti - shares a triple bill with Larry Alan Smith's ''Aria da Capo,'' set to a play by Edna St. Vincent Millay, and Charles Ives's rarely performed work ''Set of Pieces for Theater or Chamber Orchestra,'' in performances tonight by the American Chamber Opera Company. The performance starts at 8 P.M. at Public School 9, 100 West 84th Street. Information: 781-0857.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ORLANDO
description: For most travelers the name Orlando has only one connection, and that is Walt Disney World, the incomparable tourist attraction that is actually 20 miles southwest of the city's downtown. Disney-related growth, however, has helped Orlando develop to the point that it is now the hub of an expanding, diversified economy. Disney World The Magic Kingdom theme park, much larger than the original in California's Disneyland, is a lot of ground to cover on a single visit, especially during peak-season months, winter and summer, when a 20- or 30-minute wait in line is necessary to take in just one of the 45 major attractions offered in the six sections of the park: Main Street U.S.A., Adventureland, Frontierland, Liberty Square, Fantasyland and Tomorrowland.

title:
PERSONALLY SPEAKING;
FOR A 'Father' TURNED 'father,' RELIGION IS A METAPHOR FOR TRUTH
description: DURING my 20 years as a celibate Catholic priest, I could often evoke a chuckle by referring to myself as an ''unwed Father.''

title: SPECIAL FORCES ARE TERMED SHORT OF AIRCRAFT
description: The Pentagon's special military commando units are critically short of the aircraft they would need to fight terrorism or conduct unconventional warfare, two key Senators have warned Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: HASTINGS DEBATES USE OF 'CROWN JEWEL'   L>By BETSY BROWN
description: A PIECE of land in the heart of Hastings-on-Hudson that once belonged to Billie Burke and Florenz Ziegfeld has been proposed as a site for town houses, and on Tuesday villagers will have a rare opportunity: to vote on whether it should be developed.

title: Theater
description: There are some people who are important to our own history whom we ought to know about, and ''Celebration'' is a delightful, memorable way of learning about them. The spirit of this dramatic and musical review of black history is just what the title of the play suggests.

title: KASPAROV'S STYLE PLEASES THE CROWDS
description: It had been widely predicted that the world champion, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, would prove to be much more of a crowd-pleaser than his predecessor, Anatoly Karpov, and the prediction is already coming true.

title: Artificial Heart Patient Undergoes New Surgery
description: A woman kept alive since Monday with an artificial heart has been given a human heart transplant, but she underwent surgery again today in an effort to control bleeding, hospital officials said.

title: CABARET: MISS LOVE, POP-SOUL
description: DARLENE LOVE, whose incandescent, pop-gospel voice helped to propel the girl-group anthem ''He's a Rebel'' to the top of the pop charts 24 years ago, has lost none of her early-60's fervor. Last year, Miss Love was the only performer to emerge totally unscathed from the Broadway debacle, ''Leader of the Pack.''

title: MILITARY COST ESTIMATE IS DISPUTED AT HEARING
description: The Congressional Budget Office says President Reagan has underestimated military spending for the fiscal year 1987 by $14.7 billion, according to the chairman of the House Budget Committee.

title: INQUIRY RECRUITS UNION DISSIDENTS
description: Charging that corruption and racketeering were ''systemic and endemic'' in the construction industry, a state prosecutor urged dissident union members yesterday to come forward to help a seven-month-old state investigation into the industry in New York City.

title: Savory Steamed Lobster
description: If ever a recipe was inadvertently devised for malfeasance to the lobster, the one for boiled lobster is it (''Lobster Psychology,'' by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, Jan. 12.) Down here in coastal Maine, we steam them to preserve their distinctly delectable flavor.

title: PHILADELPHIA MINORITIES ASSAIL BANKS ON LOANS
description: When Julia M. Rivera and her husband, Jose D. Gonzalez, applied for a home improvement loan last year, they were turned down even though they had a steady income and $10,000 in their savings account.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: That Other Borges The part of him that writes, says Jorge Luis Borges, is like a difficult stranger who also lives in his body. This piece is in ''Dreamtigers'' (University of Texas), a collection of poems and prose translated by Mildred Boyer and Harold Morland.

title: Kerry Creedon to Wed Robert Paul Peterson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Creedon of Stamford, Conn., and Rancho Mirage, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kerry Joan Creedon to Robert Paul Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth P. Peterson of Coconut Creek, Fla., formerly of Stamford. The wedding is planned for April 26.

title: MUSIC: MANHATTAN PHILHARMONIA IN MODERN MIX
description: LIKE the Juilliard School, the Manhattan School of Music offers an annual contemporary-music festival. Unlike Juilliard, which has introduced a welcome thematic coherence to each year's event, Manhattan still offers a potpourri - unless you count a beginning cut-off date of 1925 as a focus.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE NEED FOR TENDER LOVING CARE
description: CODIFYING restoration efforts and long-term maintenance programs into a scientific discipline with recognized principles and procedures has created a growing class of specialists available to, but still by and large little known by, the public.

title: Ambivalent M. Scott Peck
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FIRE IN HEAVEN. By Malcolm Bosse. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) In this atmospheric sequel to ''The Warlord,'' the Russian-born Vera Rogacheva Embree, her daughter, Sonia, and Vera's American husband, Philip Embree, plunge into China's post-World War II strife while chaos dominates their private lives.

title: CRIME
description: British espionage fiction at its best is very stiff-upper-lippish. Oxbridge types speak elegant, if elliptical, English. Many of them are epicene. In their hearts lies a slumbering Shakespeare or Swift. Much of their conversation proceeds in soft, murmuring phrases tapering off in classical periods. Who is the hero, who the villain? The mole or the patriot? It is so hard to determine. So it is in THE CROCUS LIST by Gavin Lyall (Viking, $15.95). This is another Maj. Harry Maxim operation. He has to work with suave types in the Foreign Office or the various intelligence services. They are experienced bureaucrats, all of them, and they know well how to protect their flanks. When they feel threatened, they can be deadly.

title: Name Moons for Them
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 YEARS OF EVOLUTION FOR A KEY HISPANIC THEATER
description: The dream that Max Ferra had of a theater that would tell Americans what the millions of Hispanics who live in the United States had on their minds is now 20 years old. This dream, called the Intar Hispanic American Arts Center, starts celebrating that anniversary with the premiere today of ''La Chunga,'' a new play written especially for the theater by the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa. The play, translated by Joanne Pottlitzer, will be presented in Intar's main stage on West 42d Street, and a production in Spanish will be seen later this month in Lima, Peru.

title: RANKS OF MINORITY TEACHERS ARE DWINDLING, EXPERTS FEAR
description: American educators have begun to worry that at a time when the percentage of black and Hispanic students in public schools is growing, the ranks of minority teachers appear to be dwindling.

title: On Language; Watch My Style
description: STYLE, IN THE literary sense, is the way we use words to express what we think or feel. Too often, grammarians and less self-conscious writers limit the meaning of the word to the rules of spelling, punctuation or usage that can be found in a style book (or as some style books direct, stylebook); but the elements of style, to use the name of the best-selling little book on that subject, include not merely the agreed-upon conventions of the writing trade, but encompass the strength, precision, grace and honesty - or lack of those virtues - that characterize the way we communicate.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: From 30% to 70% Off Suggested Prices N.B.O. in 1983 moved north along Central Park Avenue from Yonkers to the Scarsdale mailing district south of Ardsley Road, the last shopping area with 5 3/4 percent local sales tax. The National Brands Outlet, part of a chain of 20 stores in New York, New Jersey and Washington, D. C., sells designer- and name-brand men's clothing - everything but shoes - at discounts of 30 to 70 percent off the manufacturers' suggested retail prices. Beyond that, this week Presidents' Sale Days discounts lower prices on selected suits, sport jackets and blazers, coats and dress furnishings, while the winter clearance area has sweaters, corduroy pants, outerwear and dress shirts.

title: NEW HYDE PARK
description: THE Mayor of New Hyde Park received a telephone call recently from an 86-year-old resident who complained that a business near her home was leaving debris in the neighborhood.

title: Andra Klein to Marry Ira B. Pollack, Lawyer
description: Andra Harriet Klein and Ira Burton Pollack plan to be married March 15. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Klein of Hollis Hills, Queens, and Montague, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Pollack of Brooklyn.

title: Miss Azrieli Engaged To Michael Schulder
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David J. Azrieli of Montreal of the engagement of their daughter Sharon Azrieli to Michael Schulder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bobby Shields of Fort Lee, N.J.

title: OLSON HITS 19-5 3/4 FOR VAULT BEST
description: Billy Olson's night started badly. It ended in ecstacy as the 27-year-old Texan bettered the world indoor best in the pole vault for the fourth time this season.

title: SOLITARY BANKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BIGGEST STORM OF THE SEASON ENDS ITS VISIT
description: The largest snowfall of the season ended yesterday morning after dropping between four and nine inches of snow on New York City and its suburbs.

title: INDIRECT TALKS BETWEEN ARAFAT AND U.S. COLLAPSE
description: Yasir Arafat and a special American envoy have left Amman after two weeks of indirect negotiations between the American Government and the Palestinians, having failed to reach any agreement that would help rescue the stalled peace intiative sponsored by King Hussein.

title: MARLENE WAS MOTHERLY, OLGA WAS VAGUE
description: PEOPLE WILL TALK By John Kobal. Illustrated. 728 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25. THE celebrity interview is a business transaction. It usually occurs when a star has a project to plug and a journalist has a space to fill. But ''People Will Talk,'' a collection of 41 interviews with Hollywood figures, lacks the odor of commerce. Most of these actresses, directors, choreographers and photographers have their greatest achievements behind them. They stand to gain nothing accept a fan's affectionate attention.

title: THE EXECUTIVE AS ARTIST
description: Venture capitalist Walter Channing likes to follow a day of deal-making with an evening of sculpting. Robert S. Whyte, a financial services executive, spends weekdays orchestrating corporate strategy and weekends as a banjo-playing bandleader. Attorney Joseph W. Bartlett, a former Under Secretary of Commerce, writes frequently about business and law, then pens plays about dilemmas in those two worlds.

title: JAPAN LEAVES SOME ITS PROFITS BEHIND
description: A $20,000 grant from a corporate foundation is helping high school teachers in Rhode Island and Massachusetts attend special seminars at Brown University. A junior high school in Manhattan received $25,000 for a new course in science and the arts. And the Hudson School, a private institution in Hoboken, used its $20,000 gift for scholarships and teacher salaries.

title: SPLIT ON RIGHT IS AN ASSET TO FRENCH SOCIALISTS
description: A campaign for key legislative elections has picked up momentum in France, but the most visible issue has been less the record of the Socialists, who have governed since 1981, than a series of public quarrels among the major figures of the rightist opposition.

title: THE MYTH BEHIND THE MAN
description: VINCENT VAN GOGH Art, Life and Letters. By Bernard Zurcher. Illustrated. 325 pp. New York: Rizzoli. $60.IN March 1886, Vincent van Gogh left his native

title: U.S. Consults China on Reply To Soviet Disarmament Plan
description: A United States envoy met here today with a Chinese official to discuss the planned American response to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to eliminate nuclear weapons by the year 2000.

title: SOOTHING RHETORIC AND A HARD SELL ON THE BUDGET
description: THERE is no pithier summary of President Reagan's view of government than his own, the one embedded in the set speech he gave all over the country in the late 1950's and early 1960's. ''The truth is,'' he used to say, ''that outside of its legitimate function, government does nothing as well or as economically as the private sector.''

title: DISK JOCKEYS, EGGPLANTS AND DESAPARECIDOS
description: WHERE WATER COMES TOGETHER WITH OTHER WATER By Raymond Carver. 130 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $13.95. THE WIND OF OUR GOING By Patricia Goedicke. 132 pp. Port Townsend, Wash.: Copper Canyon Press. Paper, $8. FIVE INDISCRETIONS By Alberto Rios. 98 pp. Riverdale-on-Hudson, N.Y.: Sheep Meadow Press. Cloth, $14.95, Paper, $7.95.

title: OIL PRICE CREATES TROUBLE IN TEXAS
description: Texas stands to lose a quarter of a million jobs over the next three to five years if the price of oil drops to $15 a barrel and stays there, a study prepared for Senator Lloyd Bentsen said today.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CHEFS' DAY
description: Chocolate sculpture and pulled sugar. Carved fruits and vegetables. Souffles. Rack of lamb, Swiss veal, roast turkey. A wedding cake.

title: Lou Little Seen As a Magician
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SENATE PANEL HOLDING HEARINGS ON TV COVERAGE OF THE STATE
description: AN OLD controversy - what kinds of television news coverage New Jersey gets and from whom - is being renewed here as a State Senate committee holds hearings on New Jersey Network, the country's only state-run public-television station.

title: THE CASE OF A POLLUTER
description: THE history of a major polluter on Hempstead Harbor - the Mattiace Petrochemical Corporation - illustrates the extent and complexity of the toxic waste problem.

title: REFLECTIONS ON VENTURING INTO PUBLLIC LIFE
description: JUDITH ELLIS had taken the risk and won. In her first venture into public life, the 42-year old businesswoman and mother placed first among four candidates in a special election held last month to fill two vacant seats on the Ardsley Board of Education. Mrs. Ellis will serve until June 1988; Howard Levitz, the second-place winner, will serve until June.

title: HOW TO FIX A LARGE HOLE IN THE WALL: FIRST, MAKE IT BIGGER
description: ALTHOUGH a small nail hole or crack in drywall can be easily filled in with spackling compound or joint cement, homeowners are often confused about how to fill in larger holes.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
TRIBUTE TO THE TRAIN
description: Canada's 1986 silver dollar is a twofold tribute to the development of the nation's west coast. It marks the centennial of the city of Vancouver, British Columbia, and commemorates the arrival in Vancouver in 1886 of Canada's first transcontinental train.''It is appropriate to have both themes on one coin, as together they contributed to the growth of our country,'' said James C. Corkery, president and master of the Royal Canadian Mint.

title: EWING IS UNLIKELY FOR ALL-STAR GAME
description: Still favoring the right-knee injury he aggravated in Thursday night's game against Utah, Patrick Ewing practiced lightly today with the East team for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game Sunday.

title: Who Shall Police Doctors?
description: With the cost of malpractice insurance soaring, doctors want to limit the patients' right to sue and the amounts they can recover. Such limits would be in the public interest but doctors' agitation will sound self-serving until they permit more rigorous supervision of their profession.

title: RULES ON DRUG TESTING FOR RAIL WORKERS TO GO INTO EFFECT MONDAY
description: The legal battling is far from over, but beginning tomorrow morning 100,000 railroad workers will be subject to drug tests that their unions argue violate their constitutional rights.

title: A Warning
description: A Washington motorist was stopped for speeding on a suburban Virginia highway the other day, and the officer noted that his license plate read ''CCCP-NT.''

title: The Attraction Of the Mormon Church
description: The Mormon church is not a ''democracy'' (what church is?), but further conversation with the ''liberals'' who run Dialogue and Sunstone might have demonstrated the active debate over such things as the moral issues raised by modern life and the relation of belief in Mormonism to a member's politics. Robert Lindsey might have mentioned that, as well as organizing against the proposed equal-rights amendment, the church was also instrumental in keeping the track-based MX missile system out of Utah, has spoken out against nuclear weapons and sponsors an extensive welfare system, aiding church members (and often people with little or no church connection) unable to support themselves. Interestingly, the welfare system developed out of the experimental socialist communities (Orderville, etc.) set up by the church during the 19th century.

title: Q&A
description: Question: We would like to spend 10 days bicycling in Vermont, New Hampshire or Maine in June, staying in local inns. Which organization can supply details? - J. F. F., Hong Kong Answer:Vermont Bicycle Touring (Post Office Box 711-AX, Bristol, Vt. 05443; 802-453-4811) is one company that runs group bicycle tours from May through October in the Northeast - in Vermont, New Hampshire and the Adirondacks in New York. The tours are of two days (on weekends) or five days. Groups of 12 to 28 riders go at their own pace, covering 25 to 45 miles a day, with two tour leaders and a support vehicle to carry baggage. A five-day trip in Vermont, with five nights' accommodations at inns, costs $409 a person in double occupancy in May and June and $469 the rest of the season. The price includes breakfast and dinner each day. Bike rental costs $18 a day. This summer, the company, which has been running tours since 1972, is offering a Lake Champlain sail and cycle tour on which participants will stay on board a schooner.

title: OLD AND NEGLECTED HEMLOCK TURNS OUT TO BE A SPECIAL TREE
description: A CENTURY-OLD tree in an undeveloped area of Branford may be one of the largest of its kind in the country, horticulturalists say.

title: A NEW POSTAL CARD FOR AMERIPEX
description: A new 33-cent airmail postal card was issued last week in Chicago. The card meets the international rate and promotes the Ameripex stamp show to be held in Rosemont, a suburb of Chicago, from May 22 to June 2.

title: FROM THE HEART OF TEXAS
description: HORTON FOOTE STEPS OUT OF HIS CAR and through the iron gates of the cemetery in Wharton, Tex., his hometown. He is looking for his grandfather's grave. It is a raw winter afternoon, the sky low and gray, the air damp. But Horton Foote is not melancholy. Here, he is a man surrounded by friends, by people he knew, by the characters who populate his plays and films. The route to his grandfather's plot is circuitous, constantly interrupted by the sight of a familiar name etched in granite.

title: Assisting A Police Inquiry
description: In his article ''Of Yobbos and Gits''(On Language, Jan. 5), William Safire reports that suspects undergoing intense interrogation by the police are said to be ''cooperating with the authorities.'' I don't know which git told him that. The usual (and more genteel) phrase used, even by the BBC, is ''assisting the police with their inquiries,'' which has a mellow, almost diffident sound, as if the suspect had been co-opted as a research assistant by a team of friendly boffins. PAUL WEST Ithaca, N.Y.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CELEBRATION IN VALENCIA, EXHIBITION IN VIRGINIA
