description: Fire, Fire Burning Bright Though Las Fallas is still two months in the future, the local artisans and carpenters of Valencia on Spain's Mediterranean coast are, as usual, already hard at work.

title: Affronted by Ashbery
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON COOL TO MAYORS' PLEAS
description: SEVERAL New Jersey mayors came to Washington last month, looking for higher Federal taxes and repeal of the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law.

title: Verbatim; The Spread of AIDS
description: 'Even after prolonged contact between AIDS patients and household members - contact that included the sharing of dishes, toothbrushes, towels and showers, for example, and close nonsexual interaction such as hugging and kissing - there was no evidence of transmission of the virus that causes AIDS.' Dr. Gerald H. Friedland of Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, describing the largest study to date of AIDS victims' families.

title: IN THE WORDS OF THE SILENCED
description: THE HOLOCAUST A History of the Jews of Europe During the Second World War. By Martin Gilbert. Illustrated. Maps. 959 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $24.95.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
MINKE WHALE
description: Balaenoptera acutorostrata Size: 25-foot average; can reach 33 feet and weigh more than 11 tons.

title: COMBING THE COUNTY FOR ITS MOST NOTABLE TREES
description: ARBOR DAY is months away but now is the time to comb the woods and fields, golf courses and estates, parkways and backyards in search of big trees, tall trees and monster trees that may qualify for the county's ''Big Tree Register.''

title: A Grueling Autopsy for the Challenger
description: The memorial services were over and flags were raised again to the top of the staff. But last week the investigation into the explosion of the Challenger was only beginning. On one level, the search was for the specific cause. The questions raised, however, were likely to trigger a reappraisal of the entire American space endeavor.

title: Costa Rica Elects Arias
description: Costa Ricans affirmed their longstanding commitment to democracy last week, choosing a President in voting that was peaceful and free from the fraud and army meddling that has plagued other Central American countries. President-elect Oscar Arias Sanchez is a 44-year-old lawyer who says he became an admirer of John F. Kennedy while watching the Nixon-Kennedy television debates in 1960, when he was a student at Boston University.

title: MEMORIES THAT WINTER BRINGS
description: THERE'S something about standing outside on a winter's night cooking on a gas grill; the summer gone, the cold night sky brushed clean and filled with the brightness of the stars.

title: Personal Diplomacy
description: For 90 minutes on Thursday afternoon, Larry Wu-Tai Chin took the witness stand to defend himself against charges that he spied for China for more than 30 years.

title: WHY THE DIGEST, FINALLY, WANTS TO MAKE MONEY
description: EVERY morning 16 chartered buses pull up to the white-columned red-brick headquarters of the Reader's Digest, on a campus-like setting in New York's Westchester County, and unload employees from Connecticut, New Jersey and other distant points. It has been that way for decades at the Digest, whose workers have long been among the best paid and the most pampered in America. But with costs rising, management has decided to end the subsidized bus service on June 30.

title: ELEMENTARY FOR THE ARGENTINES: THE ANALYST
description: The young Argentine woman asked if she might leave work early one recent day to attend her group counseling session. The day after, she went to couple's therapy instead of lunch. ''You see, I am the perfect example of the typical Argentine and her analyst,'' she said to her employer.

title: THE PROMISE IN PROFIT-SHARING
description: LAST year, the left-of-center magazine Mother Jones, citing a ''commitment to fairness, product and environmental quality, ethics and people,'' lauded Worthington Industries Inc. as one of the best companies to work for in America.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gale Sayers, the former Chicago Bears running back who has been serving as interim athletic director at Tennessee State, said he had withdrawn his name from consideration for the permanent post because of uncertainty surrounding the search for a new college president. . . . Steve Wilson, a Tampa Bay center since the team's first season in 1976, has retired, leaving Lee Roy Selmon as the only original Buccaneer on the roster. . . . Paul Hackett, the quarterback coach who helped shape the San Francisco 49ers' championship campaign two years ago, has been hired by the Dallas Cowboys. . . . Jack Charlton, who won a World Cup soccer medal with England 20 years ago, was named team manager of the Irish national team, becoming the first non-Irishman to hold the post. . . . The Chicago Bears named the former quarterback Greg Landry as an assistant coach. Landry, age 40, ended his playing days with the Bears in 1984 after 11 seasons with the Detroit Lions and stints with the Baltimore Colts and two United States Football League teams. Last season, he was quarterback coach with the Cleveland Browns.

title: NEW CARTRIDGES PROVIDE EXCEPTIONAL MUSICAL QUALITY
description: To be lastingly in love is, by general agreement, an enviable condition. Record collectors are lucky that way. Typically, they remain enamored of recordings they have cherished a long time.

title: Jody Lisa Abramowitz to Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Abramowitz of Whitestone, Queens, and Saltaire, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jody Lisa Abramowitz, to Andrew Burke Weisman, the son of Maj. Gen. Mortimer L. A. Weisman, Canadian Army, retired, and Mrs. Weisman, of Ottawa. The wedding is planned for May 3.

title: ECONOMIC POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM RECALLS SOUTH AFRICA'S PLIGHT
description: WHEN Lionel Rogosin talks of his film ''Come Back, Africa,'' it is with more than just pride in his artistic achievement as a film maker.

title: The Musical Scene in Yugoslavia
description: ''I think the Zagreb Philharmonic combines the academic precision of a great German orchestra with a distinctive Slavic warmth,'' the cellist Valter Despalj said recently. ''There are many fine orchestras in Yugoslavia - not just the three we have in Zagreb, but the Belgrade Philharmonic, an orchestra in Sarajevo and many others. We are a musical people.''

title: A PAMPERING AT SEA
description: It can hardly be said, hand on heart, that boarding a cruise liner is the prelude to high adventure. Rather, it is an experience for those who, at whatever age, feel that they deserve two weeks or so of being pampered, cosseted and, in general, overdosed with that most irresistible of drugs, tender loving care.

title: Teen-Ager Is Honored For Helping Homeless
description: More than two years after a television report awakened him to the plight of this city's homeless, 13-year-old Trevor Ferrell is continuing his crusade to help them with a small army of volunteers.

title: OVERSEAS FLIGHTS MAY BE NEXT STEP FOR EXPANDED BRADLEY
description: WITH the $100 million modernization of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks nearing completion, a debate is beginning on whether direct overseas scheduled flights should be added to the roster.

title: COMPACT DISKS ARE HERE TO CONQUER
description: Nearly three years ago, when the first compact-disk players and disks crept timidly onto the market, digital playback was a marginal experiment in an American record business that would seemingly be dominated for years to come by the LP and the cassette.

title: Postings; Grove Sq. Project
description: A 600-car garage for Grove Square, the $22 million residential, commercial and retail development near the center of New Haven, is due to be completed this spring. The facility is at the corner of Whitney Avenue and Grove Street next to the Yale Language Laboratory on the outskirts of the university complex.

title: Statistics Have Become Suspect in Sex Discrimination Cases
description: For Sears, Roebuck & Company, a Federal court decision last week that it was not guilty of sex discrimination ended 12 years of sparring with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Moscow Eases Its Conditions For an Arms Pact
description: For several weeks, the Reagan Administration had been uncertain whether the Soviet Union would agree to a reduction in medium-range nuclear weapons without a prior halt by the United States in the development of a space-based missile defense system. Last week, Moscow made it clear that an agreement on medium-range weapons was possible without being linked to the issue of what is commonly called ''Star Wars.''

title: COSTELLO FIGHTING FOR RESPECT
description: In the beginning, there were the fights for short money - $200 or $300 - to beat up rivals in places like Commack, L.I., and White Plains and Kiamesha Lake.

title: THE CONFESSIONS OF A CHOCOHOLIC
description: AH, Valentine's Day! I love it. But not for the reasons other people do. Except for an adolescent aberration, I never fell for the sentimental claptrap foisted on us every Feb. 14 by greeting-card manufacturers. What I live for is what happens on Feb. 15.

title: Postings; Lawyers' Condo
description: Construction is to begin next month in Mineola, L.I., on a 253,000-square-foot office condominium building catering to legal firms and related companies such as surveyors and secretarial services doing business at the Nassau County Courthouse across the street on Old Country Road.

title: Anne Elizabeth Behrens Plans to Wed Matthew E. Cafritz,Real-Estate Aide
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Behrens of Arlington, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Elizabeth Behrens to Matthew Eliot Cafritz, a son of Mrs. Laughlin Phillips of Washington and Vineyard Haven, Mass., and Conrad Cafritz of Washington. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Space Is Our Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: PLEASANTVILLE PROJECT: VIEWS AND REVIEWS
description: I read Ruth Seldin's recent opinion on the changing scene in the village of Pleasantville with considerable interest. Everyone is entitled to their opinion, and it is the rare individual who can express themselves as well as she did. While an opinion is by its nature biased, however, I think it was unfair of her to misstate certain facts in the presentation of her opinion.

title: JOURNALISTS SAY NASA'S RETICENCE FORCED THEM TO GATHER DATA ELSEWHERE
description: The space agency's unwillingness to release substantive information on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger has forced the nation's news organizations to rely for much of their coverage on information that was not officially confirmed and, in many cases, came from unnamed sources.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SHOOT LOW, BOYS - THEY'RE RIDIN' SHETLAND PONIES: Lewis Grizzard in Search of True Grit. By Lewis Grizzard. (Peachtree Publishers, 3.95.) The syndicated columnist for The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution searches for ''true grit'' and its possessors, finding a hopeful stripper, a happy shoeshine man, an honest mechanic and an assortment of boys, dogs and drunks.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CHANGE OF PACE Operating on the theory that variety can spice up musical life, the Minnewaska Chamber Players will expand their customary classical diet to include jazz when they appear today at Dowling College's Fortunoff Hall. In addition to Brahms's Sonata for Clarinet and Piano, Op. 120 in E flat major, the performance will feature Claude Bolling's Suite for Flute, Jazz Piano, Drums and Bass, and a piano medley devoted to women composers from Clara Schumann and other romantics to turn-of-the-century rag writers. The program, called ''Classics to Jazz,'' is at 2 P.M. at the college in Oakdale and is free.ORCHESTRAL IMPORTS

title: FROM FJORD TO FJORD IN NORWAY
description: The ship steams gently out to sea from the twinkling lights and glowing twilight sky of Bergen past wooden houses gleaming gold in the light of the setting sun. It is the end of May and 11 o'clock at night.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE GENE FACTORY: Inside the Genetic and Biotechnology Business Revolution. By John Elkington. (Carroll & Graf, $16.95.) In the introduction to ''The Gene Factory,'' John Elkington recalls that his ''reaction when first asked to write this book was: Not another book on biotechnology!'' Mr. Elkington, a director of a British biotechnology company, should learn to trust his first reactions.

title: The Attraction Of the Mormon Church
description: I was surprised to read in Robert Lindsey's splendid article the remarks from a speech by a distinguished elder of the church (and former president of Brigham Young University) that ''Satan can use truth to promote his purposes'' and ''the fact that something is true is not always a justification for communicating it.''

title: ECONOMIC POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: GILBERT UPSETS JARRYD
description: Brad Gilbert upset third-seeded Anders Jarryd, 6-3, 6-0, today to earn the right to meet the defending champion Stefan Edberg in the final of the $315,000 United States National Indoor championship.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT DOWNED 2 JETS
description: Iraq said today that it had shot down two Iranian warplanes as they headed for targets in southern Iraq.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My feeling is the count is being managed, manipulated.'' - Senator Richard G. Lugar, in the Philippines. [ 1:1. ]

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Four Seasons Farm, Readington, N.J. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (201) 788-1811.

title: KEAN: 'NO CUTS' IN BUDGET
description: GOVERNOR KEAN says that the budget he will send to the Legislature on Tuesday will present no problems but that the one for the following year could be ''a different story.''

title: THE NEED FOR A LINE OF SUCCESSION
description: IN HIS State of the State Message on Jan. 14, Governor Kean included a sobering reminder that New Jersey's good fortune in having healthy Governors who have served out their terms cannot be guaranteed to last forever and that it would be desirable to have ready as a successor an experienced person elected by all the people.

title: Violence Mars Opening Of Mardi Gras Weekend
description: The stabbing death of a Mardi Gras visitor marred the final weekend of the pre-Lenten Carnival season but did not discourage crowds from lining parade routes today.

title: Cast-Iron Preserved
description: A cast-iron and brick building erected 98 years ago at 411 West Broadway in what is now SoHo is being modernized and rehabilitated into gallery and boutique space, with a restored 19th century facade covering a 20th century interior. Known for years as the Marquardt Building - the owner was Marquardt & Company, a supplier of paper products to the printing industry - the six-story building in the Cast Iron Historic District is being gutted and completely renovated.

title: JAZZ: SHONGS BY ALICIA SHERMAN
description: IN the decade that Alicia Sherman has been singing with some frequency at Gregory's, a snug little bar at First Avenue and 63d Street, regular patrons have heard her develop from an earnest but uncertain beginner into a performer of presence, with the assurance to command the room and a voice that has grown in range and color.

title: INSIDE DR. DAMADIAN'S MAGNET
description: A MACHINE CALLED INDOMITABLE By Sonny Kleinfield. 250 pp. New York: Times Books. $16.95.

title: TWO RETREATS ON JAMAICA
description: Along the north coast of Jamaica, two celebrated writers, Noel Coward, the witty and elegant playwright and lyricist, and Ian Fleming, the creator of the James Bond spy thrillers, built tropical retreats where they lived as neighbors, taking refuge from the intensity of New York and London.

title: Revisiting 'Shall I Die'
description: To the Editor:

title: Steisel Has Spruced Up A Bureaucracy and a City
description: ''THE toughest job in this city?'' Mayor Koch asked rhetorically in 1979. ''I guess it's mine. But it really is Norman Steisel's.''

title: Cathleen M. and Mary Beth Crowley Are Engaged
description: Cathleen Marie Crowley plans to marry John Benjamin Dowling 3d in May. Her younger sister, Mary Beth Crowley, and Timothy Jerome Smith are planning an August wedding. Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Crowley of New Canaan, Conn., have announced their daughters' engagements.

title: A Mayor's Place In Baltimore
description: THE President has the White House, governors usually have a Governor's Mansion, but mayors just have to live at home.

title: Alicia Tanz, Ron Flaum, Television Aides, Marry
description: Alicia E. Tanz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman P. Tanz of Suffern, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ron Flaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Flaum of Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: BENNY GOODMAN COOKS UP SOME BIG-BAND SWING
description: The King of Swing strolled into the midtown rehearsal hall carrying his clarinet case and wearing a six-foot-long turquoise muffler with tassled fringes. He wasted no time, played a few warm-up scales and then gave the downbeat, ''One, two, one, two, three, four,'' and his new big band swung into ''Muskat Ramble.''

title: SOUTH JERSEY GETS HIGH-TECH ALLIANCE
description: ONE of the largest alliances ever put together to promote economic growth in high technology is officially ''in business'' with what one of its promoters calls ''firepower that can't be denied.''

title: TWO FAMOUS OPERAS IN EARLY GUISES
description: Shakespeare's ''Merry Wives of Windsor'' (1602) and Beaumarchais's ''Barbier de Seville'' (1775), both built around strikingly drawn, unforgettable characters, have endured in the theater for centuries. Thanks to Nicolai (1849) and Verdi (1893) on the one hand and Rossini (1816) on the other, both comedies have conquered opera, as well. These, however, were not the composers who created the first musical settings of these durable theatrical treasures. Thus it is refreshing, as well as instructive, to discover ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' by Giovanni Paisiello (1782) and ''Falstaff'' by Antonio Salieri (1799), newly released as Hungarian imports on the amazingly enterprising Hungaroton label.

title: STAGE: WILLIAM WISE'S 'CROWN CORK CAFETERIA'
description: MORE than half of the 16 characters in William Wise's ''Crown Cork Cafeteria,'' at the Working Theater, lose something through the play's two acts. People lose fingers in the presses that stamp out caps in the Crown Cork bottle-cap plant in Chicago in the 60's; one engaging character loses an arm. Another loses his wits over being suspended and has his bosses believing they are about to lose their lives at gunpoint. A cook loses her husband. The hint is that everyone in the plant has lost in the tawdry little games of sex and romance they all play; and finally an employee loses the world's greatest collection of damaged bottle caps when the box he is carrying them in drops its bottom and spills his treasure all over the cafeteria floor.

title: Dance
description: Mark Dendy attracted attention last season when he showed some exuberant works on a bill by several choreographers at the Dance Center of the Emanu-El Midtown Y. On Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Y, Mark Dendy and Dancers have a whole concert to themselves featuring several creations by the young choreographer. ''Face'' is his portrait of a young man swept up in the illusions of the mass media.

title: BRAZIL SURVEYS CARNIVAL VISITORS ABOUT AIDS
description: Brazilian health authorities, alarmed by the growing number of AIDS cases, have distributed questionnaires asking visitors arriving here for Carnival this week to answer questions about their sexual preferences and possible contacts with the disease.

title: Susan Therese Rodriguez Is Married To C. F. Lowrey Jr., Fellow Architect
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York yesterday Susan Therese Rodriguez, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Rodriguez of Darien, Conn., was married to Charles F. Lowrey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowrey of San Francisco. The Rev. Ambrose Eckinger performed the ceremony.

title: Nancy S. Gerrity To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joe W. Gerrity Jr. of Loudonville and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Sheffield Gerrity to Jonathan Newell Achilles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Laurence Achilles Jr. of Weekapaug, R.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Haggis
description: To The Editor: As a Scot I thank you for the article on haggis.

title: DOES 'ILARY EVER FIND AMORE? CIAO FOR NOW, BUT STAY TUNED
description: One day about two years ago I was invited to lunch by some neighbors who live down the road from me in the heart of the Tuscan hills. As the meal began, they warned me: ''We have to watch our installment,'' and explained that they were addicted to a dubbed soap opera called ''Sentieri.'' I had never heard of it. And with a superior smile, I observed the TV events: an illegitimate child, accusations of murder, blackmail, young love, middle-aged sex.

title: MUSIC: TEEN-AGE CELLIST IN PHILHARMONIC DEBUT
description: ON paper, the current New York Philharmonic subscription program looks like an odd lot of music -a long, stylistically incongruous grab bag that combines a 100th-birthday tribute to a great conductor, the Philharmonic debut of a 15-year-old cello prodigy in a frothy Saint-Saens concerto, and Bruckner's massive ''Romantic'' Symphony No. 4. After hearing the actual concert Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, one could still complain about the heterogeneity of the programming. But as an evening's entertainment, there was much to enjoy.

title: THE OCEAN AS A GARBAGE DUMP
description: ONE DAY before the start of last year's Labor Day weekend, several beaches were closed by the Monmouth County Health Coordinator, Lester Jargowsky, who found fecal coliform counts - an index of untreated sewage - 12 times higher than the state's standard for safe swimming.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: UP ON THE ROAD, A CUSTOM THE tree that suddenly appeared on the roof of a building on Roslyn's Main Street last week probably raised a few eyebrows.

title: Appearance by Deng Ends Rumors of Illness
description: Deng Xiaoping made his first public appearance in 55 days today, visiting his native province of Sichuan for lunar New Year celebrations.

title: Where's the Schools' Beef?
description: Federal law-enforcement officials said last week that they were investigating allegations that hundreds of thousands of pounds of beef bought each year by the New York City public schools was adulterated.

title: 26 Food Outlets Cited By New York Officials
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 26 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Nancy Tobkes to Wed John Glen Lunt in April
description: Nancy Judith Tobkes, who expects to receive a Ph.D. degree in biochemistry in May from Columbia University, and John Glen Lunt, a member of the class of '86 at Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, plan to be married April 20.

title: Turin
description: To the Editor: After spending 10 years of vacation time touring Italy and the last two years doing business full time in the north of Italy, I found William Weaver's article ''Turin's Elegant Piazzas and Palazzos'' (Travel, Dec. 29) totally correct.

title: TELEVISING THE DARK SIDE OF 'HUCK FINN'
description: The dramatization of a classic 19th-century American novel for a national television audience would seem, on the surface, to be a safe undertaking - familiar to readers, a sure thing for funding and delivering many viewers, and, above all, noncontroversial. Yet, television's special demands and traditional fears are such that only dedicated experts - who had better be expert dreamers, too - can dare to propose and then produce a series with ideas that are relevant to 20th-century America.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Busch Clash, at Daytona International Speedway, Daytona Beach, Fla. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Basketball East vs. West 36th annual N.B.A. All-Star Game, at Reunion Arena, Dallas. Although the West won last year, 140-129, the East holds a commanding 23-12 lead in the series. (Television - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M. live.) Georgia Tech at Duke (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.) Iowa at Minnesota (Television - MSG 4 P.M.) Connecticut at Villanova, 2 P.M. Boxing Alexis Arguello vs. Bill Costello, 10 rounds, junior welterweight bout at Reno. This is a nontitle bout between two former champions. Arguello, who has a 79-6 record with 64 knockouts, is from Nicaragua. He formerly held titles in the featherweight, junior lightweight and lightweight divisions. Costello, 31-1 with 18 knockouts, is from Kingston, N.Y. He was the W.B.C. superlightweight titleholder. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Marvin Johnson vs. Leslie Stewart, 15 rounds for the vacant W.B.A. light-heavyweight championship at Indianapolis. (Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.) Figure Skating United States national championships, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 2 P.M. The Exhibition of Champions will be the live event at the arena. On television will be tapes of the men's and the pairs competitions. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M., tape.) Hockey Devils vs. Whalers, at Hartford, 5:05 P.M. ( Radio -WMCA 570, 5 P.M.) Skiing Women's World Cup slalom, at Jasna, Czechoslovakia. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M.) Track and Field 44th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate Championships, at West Point, 4:45 P.M. Manhattan is the defending men's champion.

title: ANTI-MAFIA TRIAL TO OPEN IN SICILY
description: The largest criminal trial in Italian history is set to begin Monday with 474 men accused of crimes ranging from political assassination to auto theft.

title: WATCHDOGS IN FILIPINO VOTE
description: These are the five groups designated either to tabulate votes officially and observe the presidential election in the Philippines or take an unofficial role observing the voting and tabulation:

title: YISRAEL GALILI, 75, ISRAELI ADVISER
description: Yisrael Galili, an influential figure in several Israeli Governments and a leader in establishing Israel's weapons industry, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: 'KAOS' EMERGES FROM THE HARMONY OF VITTORIO AND PAOLO TAVIANI
description: With ''Padre Padrone,'' ''The Night of the

title: THE PHONE STOPPED RINGING
description: HE had greeted 19 football recruits on the Holy Cross campus in Worcester, Mass., last weekend. He had talked with them, one by one, and then had dinner with them. Now, at about 10 o'clock Saturday night, 42-year-old Rick Carter got up from his chair in the darkened room where he was watching high-school game films with his assistant coaches.

title: Custom Condos
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PLAYWRIGHT WITH A LEGAL EDGE
description: JOSEPH W. BARTLETT has been interested in theater for as long as he can remember. His mother was once an actress, and even in college drama fascinated him.

title: POPE PREACHES AT SACRED HINDU BEACH IN INDIA
description: Pope John Paul II, winding up his tour of India's Roman Catholic heartland, delivered a seaside sermon today at a sacred Hindu beach and urged the church to fight for social justice.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Feb. 9, 1986 Fiction

title: RONALD MCNAIR
description: In the harvest season, as a boy and as a young man, Ron McNair sweated his way down the lush green rows of the cotton and tobacco fields that begin just half a mile out of this quiet, back-country town.

title: Domineering Deficit
description: Excerpts from the January ''Special Report to New York,'' Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's monthly newsletter to constituents:

title: ATTACK OF THE KILLER SYNSECTS
description: ONE HUMAN MINUTE By Stanislaw Lem. Translated by Catherine S. Leach. 102 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95.

title: GLOW OF GREEN BEGINS TO DIM IN CALIFORNIA VALLEY
description: It was front page news here recently when a Salinas man said that a light bulb in his garage had burned nonstop since 1936.

title: Rescuing a Family's Rental Building
description: ''COME home,'' pleaded John Casalinuovo's father four years ago. The family-owned building at 116 Mott Street, on the corner of Hester Street in the Little Italy section of Manhattan, was about to fall into city hands for nonpayment of taxes and Dominick Casalinuovo, then 78 years old, thought that his son might save it.

title: Civility
description: To the Editor: Phyllis Theroux's article ''Under Britain's Fabled Civility, Real Civility'' (Travel, Jan. 5), brings back a 10-year old memory of a not-so-nice experience. I have always wondered if I or the cabdriver deserved censure.

title: NASSAU AMBULANCE STUDY CALLS FOR MANAGEMENT SHIFT
description: AN ACCIDENT occurs at an intersection in Nassau County. One person is hurt, and witnesses call for help. Two local fire department ambulances and one county police ambulance arrive at the scene to help a single injured person.

title: PETER BROOK'S CONTROVERSIAL 'CARMEN' STARS TWO CASTS
description: When the director Peter Brook's radical reinterpretation of Bizet's ''Carmen'' lighted up the long-dormant Vivian Beaumont Theater in 1983, it sparked a controversy in - and between - musical and dramatic circles in New York. Many observers of the theater found Mr. Brook's reductivist approach - in which the four-act opera was telescoped into an unbroken 80-minute piece - a welcome revelation. Prosper Merimee's tale of a proper Spanish corporal and a lusty gypsy temptress had been liberated to speak in modernist terms, said Mr. Brook's supporters.

title: A VAGABOND MAGUS WHOSE SPECIALTY WAS ICONOCLASM
description: If there is any one thing that can be said with certainty about the great sculptors of the past - Phidias, Michelangelo, Donatello, Giovanni Pisano, Bernini - it is that they would have rolled on the ground in disbelief had someone told them that in the last half of the 20th century a major sculptor of our own day would have taken time off to give a public lecture to a dead hare on the meanings of art. Yet Joseph Beuys did just that, during the course of his all-too-short life, and nobody in the audience walked out.

title: A FORMER CAPTIALIST EMERGES AS CHINA'S TOP DEALMAKER
description: IF there were a prize for the world's most improbable businessman, China's Rong Yiren would be a prime candidate. In a Communist country, he is, by his own account, a millionaire - in yuan, at least, which now trade at about 3.20 to the dollar.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
PREVIEWS, OVERVIEWS
description: WHAT is this? It's a sunny Sunday morning, Central Avenue is nearly empty and the shopping centers that line it are deserted, and people are going to - the movies? Movies are for evenings, after dinners with friends or dates; movies are for afternoon matinees. Here it is, an hour when, on Sundays, many people are just pulling themselves out of bed, and not one space remains in the Fine Arts Cinema parking lot.

title: A Reprieve For Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, which has been in and out of the Government's good graces, is back in again. On Friday, the Navy lifted a two-month suspension after the company, the largest military contractor, and four of its executives or former executives were indicted for, among other things, charging cost overruns on the Army's abandoned Sergeant York antiaircraft gun to other Federal contracts.

title: PSYCHOLOGISTS' ASSOCIATION SAYS POLYGRAPHS ARE UNRELIABLE
description: The American Psychological Association has adopted a resolution stating that scientific evidence on the effectiveness of polygraph, or lie-detector, tests ''is still unsatisfactory.''

title:
DINING OUT;
WHEN CHANGES ARE FOR THE GOOD
description: THE SIGN in front of the restaurant on the side of Route 46 in Pine Brook, Morris County, used to read Piccolo Mondo. A few months ago, the attractive building with arched windows was given a facelift, and the sign repainted; it now reads Ristorante Piccolo.

title: J. F. Smitka Jr. to Wed Miss Bormann June 21
description: The engagement of Amelia Elizabeth Bormann to John F. Smitka Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Smitka of Beaver Falls, N.Y., has been announced by Prof. and Mrs. F. Herbert Bormann of Branford, Conn., and Thornton, N.H., parents of the future bride. A June 21 wedding is planned.

title: It's a Start
description: Chignik Lake, Alaska, may be one of the most isolated spots in the United States. Halfway down the huge peninsula that stretches southwest into the Pacific, the village is unreachable except by boat, small plane or dogsled.

title: DAM-REPAIR LOANS
description: MUNICIPALITIES, water utilities and people who own dams that are deteriorating may be eligible for low-interest loans from a $2 million state fund.

title: STATE NEARS END OF $35 MILLION OFFICE CLEANUP
description: The state spent $17 million to build the State Office Building here in 1972. But in the last five years, since a 30-minute fire spread toxic soot throughout the 18-story tower, it has spent $35 million to clean and renovate the structure.

title: Miss Felder Weds P. T. Williams Jr.
description: Ammie Felder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alton Felder of Seattle, was married yesterday to Paul Towbin Williams Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Williams of Lawrenceville, N.J. The Rev. S. Howard Woodson performed the ceremony at the Shiloh Baptist Church in Trenton.

title: HAITIANS TAKE OUT 28 YEARS OF ANGER ON CRYPT
description: Emanuel Bourgogne wound up his right arm and hurled a 10-pound boulder against the marble tiles covering the crypt of Francois Duvalier, the Haitian dictator who died in 1971.

title: Terrorist Bombs In Central Paris
description: A series of explosions ripped central Paris last week, striking some of the city's most popular shopping spots during busy hours. No one was killed, but 21 people were injured, several seriously.

title: Gwendolyn Day Plans To Wed T. A. Malone
description: The engagement of Gwendolyn Elizabeth Day to Thomas A. Malone has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Day Jr. of North Caldwell, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: DUVALIER'S NEW PALACE: FRENCH HOTEL
description: Jean-Claude Duvalier, the deposed dictator of Haiti, spent the first full day of his political exile much as he lived at home - holed up in a luxurious residence behind armed police guards.

title:
GARDENING;
FRUITS THAT LAST CAN DECORATE WINTER
description: TO provide an appropriate conclusion to the series of articles on woody plants having winter interest, one must consider those with attractive fruits.

title: Posters Pulled
description: When Don Denkinger ruled that Jorge Orta was safe at first after the Kansas City Royals' batter hit an infield dribbler in the ninth inning of the sixth game of the 1985 World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals, the umpire created more than a controversy. He also created a marketing opportunity.

title: PROGRAM TRADERS
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRYING TASK: GETTING LAUGHS OUT OF SMILERS
description: There is nothing for kings and nothing for crowns in the capital, the Founding Fathers having turned their backs on royalty when they made George Washington President.

title: RECITAL: SCHULMAN ON GUITAR
description: THE eight-string guitar extends the register and capabilities of the standard six-stringed instrument without incorporating the distinctive twangy timbre of a 12-string. Andrew Schulman has played the eight-string guitar exclusively since 1979, and he made, for the most part, an eloquent argument for the instrument Thursday night, with a program of Baroque, Romantic and Modern music at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1986
description: International

title: CHOREGRAPHY SWAMPED BY DECOR
description: ''Portraits in Reflection,'' the new work by Lucinda Childs, is the latest entry in the choreographer-swamped-by-designer sweepstakes. Anyone who looks for a trend in the dance world would have to take this recurring and recent phenomenon into consideration.

title: Unemployment Lower in January
description: The Labor Department reported last week that in January the number of Americans at work reached nearly 109 million, an all-time high, and that the unemployment rate for the month had dipped to 6.6 percent, the lowest level in nearly six years. But a separate Congressional study suggested that many of the 11.5 million men and women who lost their jobs in plant shutdowns or relocations have failed to find work or are making do with comparatively low-paying service jobs.

title: Leslie Berger Engaged To Jeffrey B. Mendell
description: The engagement of Leslie Jill Berger and Jeffrey Brian Mendell has been announced by Terry R. Berger of New York and Hartsdale, N.Y., and Martin S. Berger of New York, White Plains and Quogue, L.I., parents of the future bride. Mr. Mendell is the son of Mrs. Lester Silverman of Edgewater, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 7. Miss Berger graduated from the Hackley School and Tufts University.

title: RIGHT TO PRIVACY IS A BASIC PRINCIPLE
description: BOB STANLEY pitches for the Boston Red Sox. As if that were not punishment enough, now his employers want him to submit to periodic urine tests. Stanley's reaction was swift and to the point: ''I don't take drugs,'' he said, ''and I don't believe I have to prove I don't.''

title: CABBAGES AND STUFF
description: ASK THE average food enthusiast - professional or otherwise - to name the lowliest vegetable in the garden, and the answer, more likely than not, is cabbage. Look up the word in a dictionary of quotations, and it invariably conjures up thoughts of contempt - from Juvenal's thought that ''warmed up cabbage. . . kills the wretch at last'' to Lewis Carroll's mention of ''cabbages - and kings.''

title: Bluebirds Are Making Comeback in the East
description: Bluebirds, noted for their songs and bright plumage, are making a comeback in parts of the Eastern United States after 40 years of declining numbers and vanishing habitats.

title: No Headline
description: THE HANDMAID'S TALE By Margaret Atwood. 311 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: LOOKING IN A BARN FOR PIECE OF THE 1800's
description: THE only octagonal, cobblestone barn in the state has some volunteers digging hard to turn up the secrets of its past.

title: Q & A WITH A PHILOSOPHER-EXPERT ON CITY'S HOUSING
description: Louis Winnick, deputy vice president of the Ford Foundation, retires April 30, after 23 years at the foundation and 35 years doing research about housing. He was head of research for the City Planning Commission and the Housing and Redevelopment Board, which was the predecessor for the present Department of Housing Preservation and Development. He has written extensively about housing and, over the years, has developed an independent perspective on housing. With his retirement at hand, he was asked for his views on housing issues.

title: The Attraction Of the Mormon Church
description: In writing ''The Mormons - Growth, Prosperity and Controversy'' (Jan. 12), Robert Lindsey must have wondered why contemporary Americans are attracted in such great numbers to a church that expects its members to have ''large families,'' ''tells them how to dress,'' ''how they should cut their hair'' and dictates a ''Republican and conservative'' political orthodoxy. How could such an institution take root and develop to the extent that today it is ''the fastest growing church among the major denominations in the United States?''

title: Caryn Botwin to Wed Jeffrey Martin Cohen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo Botwin of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caryn Lisa Botwin to Jeffrey Martin Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max A. Cohen of Flushing, Queens. The wedding is planned for June.

title: COUNCIL ON WOMEN FORMED IN HARTFORD
description: THIS city has become the third in the state to establish a local Commission on the Status of Women to complement the work of the state's Permanent Commission on the Status of Women.

title: Justice Facing Ethics Charge
description: WEST VIRGINIA'S Chief Justice, who once shocked some magistrates with his advice on ethics, was himself accused of an ethical breach last summer for requiring his state-paid secretary to baby-sit for his son.

title: Players Trying Natural Healing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dana Cuoco Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Dana Jean Cuoco to Edward Blake Droesch has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Cuoco of Princeton, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Richard Droesch of Syosset, L.I. Miss Cuoco, a student at the Brooklyn Law School, graduated from Hartwick College, as did Mr. Droesch, who is a municipal-bond broker at the J. J. Kenny Company in New York. The future bride's father is senior vice president and general counsel of the Squibb Corporation.

title: SQUAW VALLEY'S NEW LOOK
description: Last year, for the first time, tissue boxes were strategically placed where skiers waiting in lift lines at Squaw Valley could reach them.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS LEADERS CONTEND REAGAN BUDGET WILL HURT MINORITIES
description: Leaders of several civil rights organizations have responded to President Reagan's 1987 budget by saying that reductions in spending would weaken the already fragile status of blacks and other minorities.

title: Row Houses For Putnam
description: King William III might well be the patron monarch of Putnam County since he awarded the area to Adolphe Philipse in 1697. Now the king's name has been attached to a new project of modular row houses in the southern part of Putnam County near the Westchester line.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
HELPFUL BANNERS
description: ANYONE who has been stranded on the highway knows the feeling: the tire deflates, the gas gauge hovers around empty, the motor sputters into nonexistence. The car barely makes it to the shoulder.

title: ANGRY MOBS IN HAITI SAID TO TAKE REVENGE ON DUVALIER'S POLICEMEN
description: A day after the fall of the Duvalier Government that ruled Haiti for nearly three decades, sporadic violence erupted in the capital today, with many acts of vengeance reported.

title: VOICES OF 80 YEARS AGO FORM A PRICELESS LEGACY
description: The Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound in Lincoln Center has just issued ''The Mapleson Cylinders: 1900-1904.'' These six disks of all the known Maplesons are not going to be for everybody. It will take iron ears to listen to them, the dedication of an audio nerd to decipher them, the sophistication of an expert to extrapolate from the faint sounds under the appalling surface noise what this or that singer really represented.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CANADIAN BRASS TO PLAY Good they are, sedate they are not.

title: ENVIRONMENT
description: ASSEMBLYWOMAN Maureen Ogden, Republican of the 22d District (parts of Essex and Union Counties), says she will not immediately reintroduce her bill to regulate wetlands but will, instead, consider having the state take over a similar program now administered by the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: 2 MORE HOSPITALS AGREE TO 'WEDDING'
description: MORRISTOWN Memorial and Overlook in Summit are the latest in a string of hospital ''marriages'' in the state that are creating powerful new marketing forces in the health-care industry. In this case, the prenuptial agreement calls for the two institutions to retain their names and identities under a new, nonprofit holding company, Atlantic Health Systems.

title: THE TRUTH ABOUT 'MR. WONDERFUL'
description: ALTHOUGH Steven was not my first crush, the events that took place made it my most memorable.

title: SWISS EXPELLING A YUGOSLAV
description: Switzerland is expelling a Yugoslav diplomat accused of leading a spy ring that gathered information on opponents of the Yugoslav Government.

title: Carolyn Dunn Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. James P. Dunn of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Elizabeth Dunn to Richard Fownes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Fownes of Sarasota, Fla.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: WHEN I'M SLEEPY. By Jane R. Howard. Illustrated by Lynne Cherry. Dutton. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8) Trying to fall asleep, a little girl considers practicing the sleep habits of other animals - sleeping in a basket like a cat, in a nest with baby birds, standing up with a giraffe, snuggling in a den like a bear - and decides that her own bed, blanket and pillow are all the more appealing.

title: HANDLING A DIFFICULT DEFENSE
description: Half a century ago a leading British bridge personality, Hubert Phillips, wrote a parody of the Rudyard Kipling poem ''If'' that included this stanza: If you can bid in accents calm and level 'Twixt all emotions hold the balance true Whilst others in their haste invoke the devil If you can give that kibitzer his due.

title: THE INVASION OF THE HOUSE HUNTERS
description: I KNOCKED on the bathroom door. ''Some people are coming to look at the house,'' I shouted.

title: MARCOS CHARGES ELECTION WATCHERS VIOLATED LAW BY MANIPULATING TALLY
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today criticized the monitors for the citizens' election watch as violators of the law.

title: AQUINO AHEAD, MARCOS HINTS AT INVALIDATING VOTE
description: Corazon C. Aquino demanded today that President Ferdinand E. Marcos concede defeat in the presidential election held Friday, and the President said he had been considering the possibility of declaring the vote invalid.

title: SHRIMP: MAKING THEM GLOSSY AND FIRM
description: EVER wondered why shrimp in a good Chinese restaurant is so glossy and firm? When they are properly prepared, their texture can almost be described as silky. This can be achieved not merely by avoiding the most common pitfall with shrimp - overcooking -but by following a couple of other steps along the way.

title: RUSSIA'S LAST ICONOCLAST
description: SELECTED ESSAYS OF ANDREY BELY Edited, translated and with an introduction by Steven Cassedy. 311 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $35. THERE'S a photograph of the two Russian Symbolist poets Andrei Bely (real name:

title: SHOREHAM DRILL: DOWN TO THE WIRE
description: WITH the emergency preparedness drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant just five days away, Federal officials and Long Island Lighting Company employees were making final preparations last week despite efforts by Suffolk County and New York State to block the exercise.

title: DOING WHAT COMES NATURALLY
description: JOHN SALADINO HAS always been his own best client. Among a vast repertory of projects that includes scores of houses and apartments, as well as more unusual designs such as a wine-tasting room or a film auditorium for the Museum of Modern Art, the work he has done for himself is perhaps the most special.

title: WAGNER'S FORMER WIFE DIES
description: Barbara Cavanagh Wagner, the ex-wife of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner of New York, died Friday at the Boca Raton Community Hospital in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: INVESTING ADVICE OFFERED
description: AN INVESTMENT attorney from New York City gave some 300 business men and women a two-word tip here last Monday: nursing homes.

title: WCHRISTIE 'WHODUNIT' WITH PLENTY OF PLOT
description: ''THE HOLLOW,'' at the Arena Players Main Stage Theater, is a ''who's going to get it'' that quickly turns into a ''whodunit.''

title: 3 SCHOOLS RESTRICT ATTENDANCE AT GAMES
description: FOR many years Hartford's three public high schools -Bulkeley, Hartford Public and Weaver - have produced championship-caliber boys' varsity basketball teams that have drawn large crowds of spectators, particularly when the schools play each other.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: GORILLAS IN PHILADELPHIA Comic books and skulls are among the items on display at Temple University in ''From King Kong to Koko - The Image of the Gorilla.''

title: KEAN SHIFTS AIDES; MORE MOVES AHEAD
description: GOVERNOR KEAN is contining the major reshuffling of his administration that he forecast after winning re-election in November.

title: How Donald Regan Runs the White House
description: Your cover photograph shows how close Donald Regan is to the President. The jelly bean jar is almost empty and the Hershey's kisses jar is full. I'm sure the White House staff checks each day or more often. And who else would take them? THOMAS J. HICKEY Rochester

title: THE EAST PSYCHOANALYZED
description: ASIAN POWER AND POLITICS The Cultural Dimensions of Authority. By Lucian W. Pye with Mary W. Pye. 414 pp. Cambridge: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $25.

title:
GARDENING;
FRUITS THAT LAST CAN DECORATE WINTER
description: TO provide an appropriate conclusion to the series of articles on woody plants having winter interest, one must consider those with attractive fruits.

title: A FRIEND'S CONVICTION WINS MAN A NEW TRIAL
description: Over the objections of prosecutors, a two-judge appellate panel has granted a new trial to a man imprisoned for killing a woman that a friend of his was later convicted of murdering.

title: Trying to Slam The Door on Meir Kahane
description: The State Department has unveiled a new strategy in its battle to revoke the citizenship of Meir Kahane, the Brooklyn-born rabbi who last summer was elected to Israel's Parliament. According to a brief issued in the case by the department's legal adviser, religious and political affinity for Israel may be a reason to deprive an American Jew of citizenship.

title: Slayings of 2 Cabbies Are Studied by Police
description: The police are investigating possible links between the shooting death of a cabdriver Friday evening on Riverside Drive in Manhattan and the Feb. 1 robbery and slaying of another cabdriver about a mile away.

title: SCORE: CLUBS 5, PLAYERS 2
description: Baseball's salary-arbitration scoreboard went to two victories for the players and five for the clubs yesterday when Charlie Leibrandt won his case and Ron Kittle and Jeff Dedmon lost theirs. Leibrandt, who had a 17-9 record and a 2.69 earned run average for Kansas City last season, won a salary of $770,000.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN ARCHITECTURE NOW II. By Barbaralee

title: STATE MAY FORCE BUILDING OF A SCHOOL
description: IN A case expected to have a major impact on school districts and municipalities throughout the state, Saul Cooperman, the state's Commissioner of Education, has until April 3 to decide whether to order a multimillion-dollar bond issue to finance a new middle-school building in the Southern Gloucester County Regional School District.

title: Chasing a Dream: The Helistat
description: FRANK N. PIASECKI is an aviation dreamer. The Helistat, on which he received his first patent in 1961, has been one of his longest dreams.

title: DISPUTE AT PAPER PERSISTS
description: DELIVERERS for The News Tribune and its new owner have been at odds over whether the drivers are employees of the newspaper or a subcontractor.

title: Miss Riegel Is Married
description: Jennifer N. Riegel, assistant director of publicity for Ralph Lauren Womenswear in New York, was married yesterday to Paul Joseph Elmlinger, an associate in the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. The Rev. Frederic Hill, assisted by the Rev. Susan C. Harriss, performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: Equitable Seeks Park Ave. Rents On Seventh Ave.
description: INSURANCE companies have a reputation for being conservative in business. Nevertheless, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has poured $200 million into what some might regard as a risky venture, a 54-story office tower at 787 Seventh Avenue between 51st and 52d Streets - just north of tawdry Times Square. It is, by far, the most ambitious commercial building ever attempted in the Midtown West area.

title: MANUSCRIPTS THAT OFFER SEARING VISIONS OF JUDGEMENT DAY
description: The Apocalypse, or the Book of Revelation, is one of the most influential biblical books, and it is easy to understand why. It is the last and only prophetic book in the New Testament. Written toward the end of the first century A.D. by St. John the Divine on the Greek island of Patmos - apocalypse is the Greek word for revelation - where he had apparently been exiled because of his Christian belief, it prophesizes the Last Judgment and the second coming of Christ.

title: A BOOM TIME FOR FLORIDA'S STOCKS
description: FOR decades, Florida companies riding the wave of population growth have provided excellent returns to investors. The state's stocks, on average, have kept a jump ahead of the pace set by broad measures of market performance. In the 11 years through 1985, the Florida Stock Index -covering about 50 companies - had risen more than twice as fast as the Standard & Poor's 500, or the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: WHY MANY WOMEN OPT TO GO IT ALONE
description: CRITICS argue that women, despite strong gains in the business world, have been kept out of the board rooms by continuing male prejudice. They usually point out that of the 500 largest industrial companies, only one has a woman as the top executive (Katharine Graham of the Washington Post Company).

title: A TALE OF DOMESTIC TERROR WINDS UP IN A MUDDLE
description: ''Under Siege'' is about domestic terrorism, and it's both chilling and muddled. Americans get blown to bits; the Capitol is hit by rockets.

title: REAGAN PROMISES MORE DEFICIT CUTS
description: President Reagan pledged today that he would continue to try to end Federal budget deficits by 1991 despite a court ruling that a key portion of a new budget-balancing law was unconstitutional.

title: Wife Denies Knowing If Mandela Will Go Free
description: Winnie Mandela today denied any knowledge of a rumored Government decision to send her imprisoned husband, the black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, into exile in Zambia.

title: AGENT TELLS ABOUT TENSION IN BONANNO GROUP
description: An undercover agent who infiltrated the Mafia has testified about ''friction and tension in the Bonanno family.''

title: USING SCULPTURE AS A CONCEPTUAL AID
description: IN THE corner of CW Group's East Side office sprout huge wooden pencils, some of them five feet high. Soft, feminine forms, carved out of laminated wood, protrude from the walls.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE HAPPIEST ENDING By Yoshiko Uchida. 111 pp. New York: Atheneum. $10.95. (Ages 8 to 12) THE ETERNAL SPRING OF MR. ITO By Sheila Garrigue. 163 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $11.95. (Ages 8 to 12) IN the dark purple shadow of the sheer eastern face of the Sierra Nevada, near the hamlet called Independence, Calif., lies a desert plain. It is baking hot in summer, swept by freezing winds from the mountains in the winter and barren except for brittle clumps of tumbleweed. Here and there, half hidden by the blowing sands, are flat stretches of concrete, sealed-off drains, scraps of rusted barbed wire. At a discreet distance from the highway that passes through this stark landscape is a monument erected by the California State Park Service. ''May the injustices and humiliation suffered here as a result of hysteria, racism and economic exploitation never emerge again,'' it proclaims in bronze letters which have been nearly obliterated by vandals intent on denying our national disgrace. For this is the site of Manzanar, one of 10 relocation camps in which Americans of Japanese descent were interned during World War II.

title: Cable TV
description: The cable week's film roster includes some provocative newcomers. ''Heaven Help Us'' (1985) is a perceptive and sharply rounded comedy about a Brooklyn parochial school, with a cast headed by Andrew McCarthy, Donald Sutherland and John Heard - Saturday at 8 P.M. on Cinemax. The same channel has ''The Mean Season'' (1985), a colorful suspense yarn about a Miami reporter (Kurt Russell) and an elusive killer - Sunday at 8 P.M. and 3:35 A.M.; and Saturday on HBO at 8 P.M.

title: JURY BEGINS ITS DELIBERATIONS IN TRIAL OF U.S. DISTRICT JUDGE
description: A jury today began deliberations in the trial of Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr., who is charged with influence peddling and perjury.

title: Susan Wolf to Wed Richard Friedman
description: William B. Wolf Jr. and Edna Jacobs Wolf, both of Washington, have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan M. Wolf to Richard David Friedman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Friedman of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: The Scandal Still Unwinding In New York
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, summed up the progress of New York City's wandering municipal corruption inquiry last week: ''We're investigating all of the contracts with the Parking Violations Bureau over a four- or five- or six-year period, and then various other things that have kind of emerged from that.''

title: WOLFPACK EMERGES AS POWER IN A.C.C.
description: In a league dominated by giants, it is easy to get lost in the shadows. But despite the success of its Atlantic Coast Conference rivals North Carolina, Georgia Tech and Duke, the youthful North Carolina State Wolfpack has gradually established itself this season among college basketball's elite.

title: Millions of Hearts
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILIAR VOICES RELATE HISTORY OF LOWER EAST SIDE
description: It took some prodding, but Nancy Core, a senior at Seward Park High School, finally got her mother to talk about her past, about what it was like to move to New York from Bayamon, Puerto Rico, and make a new life on the Lower East Side.

title: SYRACUSE IS UPSET BY IRISH
description: Donald Royal scored 11 of his 20 points on second-half free throws today as Notre Dame upset Syracuse, 85-81, before a crowd of 32,397, third-largest ever in the Carrier Dome.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
The Swelling Tide of Waterfront Homes
description: DR. WILLIAM DAVIS, a Roslyn Estates dentist, and his wife, Sheila, recently contracted to buy a $102,000 one-bedroom co-op on Tiana Bay in Hampton Bays, in a 28-unit complex called Hampton Arms.

title: 7-Year-Old Shot in the Back Is Left at Brooklyn Hospital
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn girl with a gunshot wound in the back was dropped off at an emergency room yesterday by a man who then disappeared. The girl was reported in ''very serious'' but stable condition.

title: David Bilger
description: David Bilger, the first-prize winner of the 1985 Concert Artists Guild International Competition who played at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, is a proficient and musical young trumpeter. He does not play with the glint of Jericho in his eye; able to belt out a blast with the best of them, his playing is most notable for its taste and restraint.

title: KENNEDY REPORTS GAIN IN SOVIET EMIGRATION CASES
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy returned from a trip to the Soviet Union today and said 25 Jews for whom he had interceded were being permitted to emigrate.

title: Miss Tinney Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Judy Lewis Tinney of Los Angeles and Joseph Lewis Tinney Jr. of New York and Longport, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Maria Tinney, to Daniel Conway Dagit Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dagit of Haverford, Pa. The wedding is planned for April 4.

title: The Dow Is Watched More Than It Is Heeded
description: MORE than a century ago, Charles Henry Dow decided that he needed a way to show readers of his Customers Afternoon Letter how the stock market was performing. So he took 11 stocks, nine representing railroads, added their prices at the end of the day's trading, divided by 11 and reported the result. Thus was born the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

title: LINCOLN AS MYTH: BEYOND ANALYSIS BY HISTORIANS
description: IT MIGHT be said of Lincoln what Voltaire said of God: If there had been no Lincoln, it would have been necessary to invent him.

title: Where's It Hurt?
description: President Reagan took advantage of a personal appearance at the Department of Health and Human Services the other day to tell the new Secretary, Dr. Otis R. Bowen, and some employees one of his favorite medical stories.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last week about Harry Mulisch, a Dutch author, erroneously reported that his mother had died. Mrs. Mulisch lives in San Francisco.

title: Remembering Challenger
description: The capital's most popular tourist attraction, the National Air and Space Museum, has experienced a sharp increase in demand for replicas of the space shuttle Challenger since its demise Jan. 28. The museum shops sold out their kits for building larger models of the craft, and a 7-inch plastic model has been selling much more heavily than before, although it is still available.

title: Out of Africa
description: To the Editor: Reading the pieces on Kenya, unfortunately similar to much of the commentary on ''Out of Africa,'' to say nothing of the film itself, I am impressed with how little things have changed, not in Kenya, but in American thinking about Africa.

title: THE SHOREHAM PLANT: A SUPPORTER'S RESPONSE
description: Re Stanley S. Smilan's reply [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, Jan. 26 ] to my Opinion Page piece, ''Blocking Shoreham Blocks L.I. Growth'': My head is bloody but unbowed. A point-by-point exposure would be too lengthy, and I will only touch on some of Mr. Smilan's more obvious misleading statements:

title: HISPANIC CATHOLICS FOUND TO HEW TO TRADITON
description: Hispanic Roman Catholics in the United States overwhelmingly support the traditional beliefs of their faith, but, as with other immigrants, the tenacity of these beliefs appears to fade as they become more rooted in this country, master English, become more educated and increase their income, a new national study has concluded.

title: NASA HAD WARNING OF A DISASTER RISK POSED BY BOOSTER
description: The space agency was warned last year that seals on the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets might break and cause a catastrophic accident, according to documents from the agency's files.

title: REGAN ASKS SUPPORT FOR DROPOUT PLAN AUDIT
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has called on Mayor Koch, Governor Cuomo and state legislative leaders to urge the New York City Board of Education to submit to a state audit of its $21 million dropout prevention program.

title: Election Day Ugliness In Manila
description: IT has been said that the ultimate test of a democracy is whether an incumbent, having lost a bid for re-election, yields to the verdict of the voters. As Corazon C. Aquino's campaign to unseat President Ferdinand E. Marcos gathered steam and supporters, many believed democracy may have been facing such a test in the Philippines.

title: HEEEEERE'S JODY
description: A TOUGH ACT TO FOLLOW By Max Wilk. 347 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $14.95.

title: Talking Mortgages; Making Biweekly Payments
description: YET another type of home loan is gaining ground in the marketplace. Called the biweekly mortgage, it gives borrowers a chance to meet their normal monthly repayment obligation in two equal installments every two weeks instead of paying a lump sum once each month.

title: THE FANATIC FANS OF 'QUEEN LUCIA'
description: CHAUNCEY HOWELL, the feature reporter on WNBC-TV's ''Live at Five,'' loves her. William T. Beaty, executive director of the Ittleson Foundation, says he's ''a nut about her.'' As for Lowell Iberg, a retired public-welfare executive and past president of the National Council on the Aging, he describes his reaction as ''hooked.''

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HABITATIONS OF THE WORD, by William H. Gass. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) A collection of essays by the philosopher-novelist William H. Gass on such topics as Emerson and the essay, Plato's ''Phaedrus,'' the souls of sentences, and the word ''and.'' Paraphrasing from the Emerson piece, Frank Kermode wrote in The Book Review last year that the most moving moments in Mr. Gass's book are those ''when he lingers over a loved sentence or paragraph, perhaps by Rilke or Beckett, Browne or Jeremy Taylor, Joyce or Shakespeare. These are sentences with souls, and therefore alive, with a life not bursting out like a melon from a sack but held forever in its gray paradigms, like the night in the fir-trees.'' THE COLLECTED STORIES OF PETER TAYLOR. (Penguin, $9.95.) A collection of 21 stories, written from the 1940's to the 1960's, many of them set in the fictional town of Thornton, Tenn., and elsewhere in the South. Mr. Taylor ''is one of the best writers America has ever produced,''

title: YALE SINGERS MARK 125 WITH A CONCERT
description: THE Yale Glee Club, which has enjoyed a reputation as one of the country's most distinguished student choruses, will have a chance to pat itself on the back next weekend, when it celebrates its 125th anniversary.

title: MASSACHUSETTS WARNS DOCTORS IN PREMIUM PROTEST
description: Doctors in Massachusetts have been turning away a growing number of patients to protest rising insurance premiums, and state officials have threatened to discipline physicians who withhold emergency treatment.

title: WHOLE THEATRE, FIGHTING TO SURVIVE, STARTS NEW FUND DRIVE
description: ''KEEP the Lights On'' is what the Whole Theatre calls its new fund-raising drive. The actor Paul Winfield flew in from Los Angeles for the kickoff when the theater's current play, Samm Art Williams's ''Home,'' opened Jan. 17.

title: O'ROURKE MOVES ON ZONING PROPOSAL
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke began last week to develop the ambitious and controversial plan he unveiled Monday for a stronger county government role in zoning, assessments and other traditional functions of local government in Westchester.

title: Competitors Are Making Inroads in the Market; The Thinking Behind OPEC's Clearance Sale
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Oil Minister of Saudi Arabia, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain seemed determined last week to keep their countries producing oil at a rate that would continue to depress its price. Their policies held; the price continued to fall, and industry analysts kept guessing how low it would go and what would be the economic consequences.

title: F. J. Rodriguez to Wed Laura C. Harth
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Harth of Pittsburgh and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Cassandra Harth, to Francisco Javier Rodriguez, a son of Mrs. Luis Mendez and Francisco Rodriguez, both of Vigo, Spain. The wedding is planned for April 5.

title: WHY WRITE FOR THE THEATER? A ROUNDTABLE REPORT
description: How are playwrights affected by world events? Can art and politics coexist in the theater? From what sources do playwrights draw their inspiration? What is the future of a theater confronted by increasing economic pressures?

title: FALLOUT FROM THE $1 MILLION TEA TABLE
description: Ever since a Philadelphia tea table was auctioned at Christie's on Jan. 25 for $1,045,000, the highest price ever paid anywhere for a piece of American furniture, collectors and dealers have been discussing what possible effect this extraordinary price will have on the market for American furniture. Several believe that prices will continue to rise but they also see a corresponding increase in the appearance of quality works in the market and a growth of new scholarship in the field.

title: Parking-Ticket Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: APPROVAL SOUGHT FOR MEDICAL HOTELS
description: PROPOSALS for two medical hotels, which would give patients an alternative to prolonged hospitalization, will be presented to the State Commission on Hospitals and Health Care for approval in the next few weeks.

title: WOMAN WHO FOUGHT TO DIE IS BACK IN COURT
description: Elizabeth Bouvia, who lost a court fight for the right to die, is back in court battling the state over how she is being treated in a county hospital. She wants to end her forced feeding.

title: WHEN IDEALISM WAS IN FLOWER
description: THE BOLD EXPERIMENT JFK's Peace Corps. By Gerard T. Rice. Illustrated. 349 pp. Indiana: University of Notre Dame Press. $15.95. ''ASK what you can do for your country,'' John Kennedy urged in what was probably the most oft-quoted phrase of his oft-quoted inaugural. For the surprising number of Americans who did ask that question, the clearest if not the only answer of the Kennedy Administration was a brand-new Federal agency called the Peace Corps. Despite initial misgivings, the idea touched a chord in the country and the Peace Corps went on to become one of the few concrete successes of Kennedy's Presidency.

title: HOW HOBOKEN TRIES TO CONTROL GROWTH
description: OF the many issues in last spring's mayoral election campaign in Hoboken, none was as crucial as the city's unparalleled record of revitalization.

title: WOODY ALLEN TOPS HIMSELF - AGAIN
description: Tracking the career of Woody Allen is exhausting but exhilarating, like mountain climbing. Just when you reach the top, another peak appears. At the same time, the terrain below - through which you've passed and which you think you know -seems to change, taking on unexpected contours and colors that can only be seen from the new plateau. Some earlier peaks look small. Others cast surprisingly long shadows. The only constant is that you're in a land not quite like any other.

title: VIEWS OF PARTICIPANTS
description: AT this point, neither Elk nor Franklin Township officials are disputing the need for a new school; the issues are the type of building, the timing of the bond issue and who should pay.

title: VALENTINE 'SPECIALS'
description: AT Daniel Krevolin's office in West Haven on Friday will be a wedding cake, a bottle of Champagne and flowers on a table covered with red hearts for couples getting married there that day, Valentine's Day.

title: Long Year's Journey
description: Just how much doom and gloom will Washington theatergoers subject themselves to in one year? We'll soon find out.

title: Quivar Cancels Concert
description: The mezzo-soprano Florence Quivar has canceled her March 9th recital at Alice Tully Hall because of a recent illness, Lincoln Center has announced.

title: South Korean Dissident Under House Arrest
description: The dissident leader Kim Dae Jung was placed under house arrest today for the eighth time since he returned to South Korea a year ago from self-imposed exile in the United States, an aide to Mr. Kim said.

title: BRIDGE FOR WILDLIFE NEEDED AT DANBURY
description: A FULL-SCALE skirmish has broken out between the authorities and a family of beavers that are intent at raising the level of Sugar Hollow Pond in southern Danbury.

title: THE IMPACT OF IMPACT STATEMENTS
description: In ''A Growing Debate on Impact Statements,'' it is stated that environmental impact statements (E.I.S.'s) are being increasingly used by the public as a tool to delay development projects.

title: HIGH-GLOSS POP ALBUMS FLOURISH ONCE AGAIN
description: When the record industry was suffering from economic jitters three years ago, pop soothsayers pronounced the blockbuster Hollywood studio album to be a dying species. Lavishly produced mega-hits by Fleetwood Mac, the Eagles, Steely Dan and the Doobie Brothers had made the million-dollar album a reality by the late 1970's. But during the subsequent recession, confidence in the Hollywood blockbuster waned. Then Michael Jackson's ''Thriller'' began to reverse the tide, and now in today's robust economy opulent pop-rock albums that spare no expense are again a flourishing commodity.

title: Headliners; Postponing an Itinerary
description: He came dressed for the occasion but not for success -wearing long gray hair, beard and a swastika on his forehead. He was ready, as well, with a 20-page statement.

title: A SISHI BAR MORE THAN RAW FISH
description: LIKE its parent establishment, Taiko in Rockville Centre, Taiko Too in Merrick boasts one of the friendliest sushi bars on the Island.

title: Free Bridges
description: NOT many people nibble these days when someone tries to sell them a public bridge, but the Tennessee Department of Transportation hoped for a better response by offering to give away five bridges.

title: MINOUR YAMASAKI, ARCHITECT OF WORLD TRADE CENTER, DIES
description: Minoru Yamasaki, the architect, who arrived in New York City in 1934 with $40 to his name and went on to win renown as the designer of the World Trade Center, has died of cancer. He was 73 years old.

title: MORGENTHAU, IN APPEAL, ASSERTS JUDGE ERRED IN GOETZ CASE RULING
description: Whether Bernhard H. Goetz was justified in shooting four young men on a subway car should be judged by the standards of a ''reasonable man'' in that situation, rather than by Mr. Goetz's own subjective state of mind, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, has argued in court papers.

title:
ANTIQUES;
18-TH CENTURY ITEMS AT WINDHAM BENEFIT
description: SET in the center of a small 18th-century village, the 26th Annual Windham Antiques Show will be held in the Center School next Saturday and Sunday. The show, a benefit for the Windham Free Library Association, will include furniture made in both country and town cabinetmakers' shops, silver and glass and other attractive accessories popular in the 18th and early 19th centuries.

title: THE SPARTAN JOYS OF ICE FISHING
description: ICE fishing's main attraction, to this observer at least, is that one can visit any portion of a lake or pond without bothering with a boat.

title: MODERN WORKS IN ABUNDANCE
description: IT was Charles Ives who wrote that ''music must be a part of the great organic flow, onwards and always upwards, or else it becomes soft in spirit and dies.'' The Connecticut composer also wisely noted that ''no genius ever stopped creating because he knew he never could make a million dollars.''

title: DO WE REALLY NEED A SCIENCE HIGH SCHOOL?
description: WE Americans are having another crisis. We have lost our edge in high-technology development and we have an unfavorable balance of trade, which gets bigger each year. What can be done? As with every other crisis in American life since the launching of Sputnik in 1957, the answer appears to be that the public schools must improve.

title: Duvalier Hunts for a Home as a Junta Settles In
description: JEAN-CLAUDE DUVALIER called himself President-for-Life, but 15 years turned out to be enough. After weeks of street violence and a reprimand from Washington in the form of a partial suspension of aid, the 34-year-old Haitian leader slipped aboard a United States Air Force plane under cover of darkness last week and flew to France. Thus ended 28 years of family dictatorship under Francois Duvalier, the President from 1957 until his death in 1971, and Jean-Claude, his son.

title: The Difficulty in Regulating Religions That Turn a Profit
description: To many of his neighbors, the 74-year-old man who died at an isolated ranch near here nearly two weeks ago was something of an enigma. He rarely spoke to anyone and seemed far more intent on enlarging his already opulent house and adding a horse-racing track. Only after his death did they learn that he was Lafayette Ronald Hubbard, a Nebraska-born science fiction writer who in the 1950's established a network of mental health clinics that he would later rename the Church of Scientology.

title: Pity the Poor Voter!
description: Since the beginning of the new year, the politicians here have been battering the citizens with remedies for everything from the common cold to the cold war, from the Middle East to the Middle West, not forgetting outer space.

title: WESTMINSTER SHOW OPENS TOMORROW AT GARDEN
description: Westminster, the dog show of shows, opens a two-day run at Madison Square Garden tomorrow with 2,592 dogs, representing 140 breeds or varieties. They come from 48 states, with North Dakota and Wyoming the exceptions. There also are entries from the District of Columbia, Canada and Puerto Rico.

title: RABIES SHOTS URGED BY JUNE 1
description: A NEW state law requiring that dogs be vaccinated against rabies before they are licensed is expected to help prevent the spread of the disease, which has been threatening the East Coast in recent years, officials said. The law goes into effect June 1.

title: THE MID-LIFE CORONATION OF A GRANDMOTHER
description: IF you have children, a crown can spring from your head. It is not one that is earned. You cannot order it.

title: DISNEY'S AGGRESSIVE NEW LOOK
description: As readers of Sunday supplements and travel sections are undoubtedly aware, the just-renamed Walt Disney Company has in recent weeks initiated a huge advertising campaign to push its Florida showpiece, Disneyworld.

title: Gasoline Prices Finally Start Down
description: Why have prices at the gasoline pump been slow to reflect the recent drop of nearly one-third in the wholesale cost of crude oil? Partly because most refineries in the United States are still processing oil bought last November or earlier, when spot prices ranged from $26 to $32 a barrel, and partly because it is the natural tendency of business to take profits before competition forces restraint.

title: THE IMPACT OF IMPACT STATEMENTS
description: As one who has read numerous environmental impact statements for the wealth of information they provide as preparation for speaking at public hearings, I read ''A Growing Debate on Impact Statements'' with great interest.

title: PHILADELPHIA HOMELESS LEARN HOW TO PRESS CASE
description: Aggressive advocates for the homeless have won the right to food stamps, public housing and voting for the city's estimated 15,000 homeless, and now they have set up a program here to teach them to lead and organize themselves.

title: 'The Progress of a Fire'
description: To the Editor:

title: ST.JOHN'S PREVAILS AFTER BERRY INJURY
description: St. John's hopes for continuing its surprisingly successful season may have been interrupted last night when Walter Berry, the 6-foot-8-inch junior center, sprained his left ankle in the first half of the team's eventual 87-75 victory over Boston College at Alumni Hall.

title: ...And Some Bargain Hunting at the Pentagon
description: BURIED deep in last week's budget documents was a small surprise for critics who think of the Pentagon licensed by President Reagan's emphasis on a strong defense and its own inclinations to do all its shopping from the Nieman Marcus catalogue.

title: THEATER: IRELAND'S HEROES IN 'BEEF'
description: APPROPRIATELY for a work ''inspired by the legends of Ireland,'' ''Beef'' is carried along by bursts of language, like a rider on one of the great bulls that figure so largely in the plot. And if the carryings-on contain a sizable portion of bull, that is appropriate, too, since in David Pownall's telling, Ireland's legendary heroes were given more to blather than to action, and when, as here, they are driven to act, they mainly destroy themselves.

title: What We Have Gained
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Allendale $460,000 64 Farley Place *2*5-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-year-old colonial; *2*cedar solarium, deck, family room with fireplace; taxes $6,250.
