Livingston $150,000 13 Fairfax Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old split level; *2*covered patio, recreation room, carpeting; *2*taxes $2,294. North Plainfield $120,000 714 Ayers Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 37-year-old Cape Cod; *2*2-year-old roof, patio, fenced yard; taxes $1,917. Succasunna $173,500 32 Kentwood Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; *2*parquet floors, burglar-alam system, garage-door openers; taxes $2,891. Towaco $228,500 15 Brook Valley Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old ranch; *2*great room with fireplace, pool, spiral staircase; *2*taxes $2,717. Lawrence $210,000 1850 Lawrence Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; *2*tile foyer, ceiling-high stone fireplace, 3.65 acres; taxes $3,776. OTHER AREAS Franklin Square, L.I. $198,000 640 Arley Road *2*5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2*finished basement, vinyl siding, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. Eastchester, N.Y. $145,000 40 Park Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 63-year-old frame colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, aluminum siding; taxes $2,208. Danbury, Conn. $120,000 Thaddeus Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 bath, 40-year-old ranch; *2*private lake rights, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,121.

title: Botha Rebukes A Key Minister
description: Not so long ago it would have seemed unlikely that the idea of a black president of South Africa would cause public friction between ranking members of the white Government in Pretoria. But last week the Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, said ''it would possibly become unavoidable that in future you might have black presidents in this country.''

title: Reinhold Niebuhr's Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Stephanie Sava To Become Bride Of Banker in Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gerard Anthony Sava of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Anne Sava to Michael Moll Boeschenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Boeschenstein of Perrysburg, Ohio. An October wedding is planned.

title: NEW YORK CHURCH LEADERS DIVIDED OVER HOMOSEXUAL-RIGHTS MEASURES
description: The issue of homosexual-rights legislation has divided New York City's religious leaders and led to an uncommonly sharp exchange between John Cardinal O'Connor and Paul Moore Jr., the Episcopal Bishop of New York.

title: THE SNOWS OF YESTERYEAR
description: TIME OUT OF MIND By John R. Maxim. Illustrated. 502 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: COACH NAMED AT HOLY CROSS
description: The associate head coach Mark Duffner was named today to succeed Rick Carter as head football coach at Holy Cross, one week after Carter committed suicide.

title: WHERE TO GET MORE DETAILS
description: American Canadian Line, Post Office Box 368, Warren, R.I. 02885 (401-247-0955; 800-556-7450 outside Rhode Island). American Cruise Lines, 1 Marine Park, Haddam, Conn. 06438 (203-345-8551; 800-243-6755 outside Connecticut). American Hawaii Cruises, 550 Kearny Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94108 (415-392-9400; 800-227-3666). American President Lines, 1800 Harrison Street, Oakland, Calif. 94612 (415-272-8148). Bahama Cruise Line, 4600 West Kennedy Boulevard, Tampa, Fla. 33609 (Information: 813-879-3500, 800-237-7004 outside Florida, 800-282-6277 in Florida; reservations: 813-879-3470, 800-237-5361 outside Florida, 800-282-4766 in Florida). Barge About France c/o Salt and Pepper Tours, 7 West 36th Street, Suite 1500, New York, N.Y. 10018 (212-736-8226; 800-522-6558 in New York State; 800-223-7733 outside New York State). Carnival Cruise Lines, 5225 N.W. 87th Avenue, Miami, Fla. 33166 (305-599-2600). Chandris Cruise Lines and Chandris Fantasy Cruises, 900 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022 (212-750-0044; 800-223-0848). Clipper Cruise Line, 7711 Bonhomme Avenue, St. Louis, Mo. 63105 (314-727-2929; 800-325-0010 outside Missouri). Commodore Cruise Line, 1007 North America Way, Miami, Fla. 33132 (305-358-2622; 800-327-5617 outside Florida; 800-432-6793 in Florida). Continental Waterways, 11 Beacon Street, Boston, Mass. 02108 (617-227-3220; 800-227-1281 outside Massachusetts). Costa Cruises, 1 Biscayne Tower, Miami, Fla. 33131 (305-358-7330; 800-447-6877 outside Florida). Crown Cruise Line, Post Office Box 3000, Boca Raton, Fla. 33429-0900 (305-394-7450; 800-841-7447). Cruise and Charm, Osmond International Travel, 50 North La Cienega, Beverly Hills, Calif. 90211 (213-855-1844; 800-325-7217 outside California). Cunard Line and Cunard/NAC, 555 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017 (212-661-7777; 800-221-4770 outside New York State). Cycladic Cruises, Voyellas International, 370 Lexington Avenue, Suite 1404, New York, N.Y. 10017 (212-697-5647; 800-221-3014 outside New York State).

title: REPORT URGES LONG-TERM PLANNING TO AVERT WATER SHORTAGE IN NEW YORK
description: New York City is headed for a long-term water shortage, even if there are no further droughts, unless it significantly reduces its consumption of water, according to a new study.

title: Some Refuges No Longer Are
description: The Interior Department's preliminary finding that 10 national wildlife refuges are contaminated by toxic chemicals was a ''pleasant surprise,'' William P. Horn, Assistant Secretary for Fish and Wildlife and Parks, said last week. After all, in a 1981 survey, 121 refuge managers reported serious contamination.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review in the Arts and Leisure section last week of the two-volume video cassette ''One Night With Blue Note Preserved'' gave an incorrect retail price. Each volume is $29.95.

title: STOCKBRIDGE UNEASY OVER ROCKWELL MUSEUM PLAN
description: Lila Berle stood on a snow-covered slope and pointed out the landmarks in the distance. To the far left was Tanglewood, summer home of the Boston Symphony. Next came Greylock Mountain, whose elongated hump is widely believed to have helped inspire Herman Melville as he wrote ''Moby Dick'' in nearby Pittsfield. Straight ahead was Prospect Hill, on whose crescent stands the former estate of Cyrus Field, who set the first undersea Atlantic cable.

title: Metro-North Train Kills Man Who Was Walking on Tracks
description: An unidentified man was struck and killed by a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train here Friday night just after the train's engineer saw him walking on the tracks.

title: TV Turnabout In Massachusetts
description: A cable television system in Beverly, Mass., is doing the unexpected - it is asking customers not to watch.

title: MILITARY IN PERU TO IMPOSE CURFEW
description: The military announced plans today to impose a curfew in Lima and the port city of Callao under a state of emergency declared Friday by President Alan Garcia after several bombings.

title: CREME FRAICHE WINS EASILY IN THE DONN
description: Creme Fraiche, the popular gelding who won the Belmont Stakes last year but had lost his last four starts, overcame a slow pace to score a decisive two-length victory over Skip Trial in the $178,800 Donn Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Intar Hispanic American Arts Center misidentifies the director of Intar's Music Theater Laboratory. He is George Ferencz.

title: THE AMERICAN RENAISSANCE IN THE HUDSON COUNTY COURTHOUSE
description: AMERICAN art came of age in the early 1950's - by way of Abstract Expressionism -but, as it turns out, not for the first time.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: A TEST FOR HARTFORD'S PRESERVATION LAW
description: HARTFORD'S venerable residential neighborhoods, like many other similar areas in Connecticut, have been under increasing pressure to accommodate growth in commercial, medical and governmental activities.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH the 1960's are primarily remembered for civil-rights sit-ins and demonstrations, black protests of the decade actually took many shapes and forms and embraced a variety of philosophies.

title: RANGERS WIN, 3-2, IN PHYSICAL CONTEST
description: The goalie was hit in the jaw with a stick. Tomas Sandstrom saw one gloved hand after another jammed into his face. And the usually tranquil coach spent much of the afternoon crying out at the referee, wondering why his team, the Rangers, was taking so much abuse.

title: A Discarded Son
description: MY YOUNGER brother, Andy, lives in Paris and I in Hartford. Neither of us ever has any money to speak of, so we hardly get to see each other or even to talk on the phone. We keep in touch by sending letters back and forth across the Atlantic.

title: WHO'S WATCHING THE STORE?
description: FOR one of the few times in family history, the entire Webb clan abandoned the Webb Soul Market out near the Cotton Bowl yesterday afternoon.

title: POPE JOHN PAUL II PREACHES TO THE UNCONVERTED BUT RESPECTFUL
description: In Rome, Pope John Paul II is the supreme pontiff of the universal church. In India he is the leader of a tiny sect. And therein lies a key to much of what John Paul has been doing, and saying, over the last week.

title: BOSTON BID: A HOT DOG TAKEOVER
description: City officials are hoping to save 600 jobs by taking over the hot-dog factory that has long supplied Fenway Franks to baseball fans at Fenway Park, but opponents say the effort cannot succeed and will result in years of costly lawsuits.

title: Miss Monteagudo and Miss Rose to Wed Brothers
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Perez of Miami have announced the engagement of her daughter Yvonne N. Monteagudo to Micha Kroll, and Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Rose of Daytona Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Lisa Rose to Mr. Kroll's brother, Oren Kroll. The future bridegrooms are the sons of Marilyn Kroll of Astoria, Queens, and Eliezer L. Kroll of Jerusalem.

title: UTILITIES PLAN WAYS TO HANDLE HURRICANES
description: HURRICANE GLORIA is four months gone, but the efforts by state, local and utility officials to find better ways to cope with the kind of havoc the storm caused continue unabated.

title: THE BIZARRE LOGIC OF MARKET ANALYSTS
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, financial markets do not exist to provide BMW's for young stockbrokers. Financial markets exist to allocate capital efficiently within the context of a free society.

title: FOR THE BOATERS OF SUMMER, A TIME TO HIBERNTAE AND DREAM
description: THERE they were, idling near the bay: the Frog Prince, the Young Lion and the Gypsy. They knew it was only a matter of time for the sailors to return.

title: DIRECTOR MAINTAINS BASE IN NEW HAVEN
description: IT may appear that John Tillinger is leading the glamorous -and lucrative - life. While directing one play for Broadway (''Corpse,'' the comedy-thriller now running), he was staging Terrence McNally's ''It's Only a Play,'' a parody of show people, for the Manhattan Theater Club at The Space at City Center.

title: NORTHERN TOWNS WEIGH GARBAGE-DISTRICT ISSUE
description: INCREASES in the tax levy that would be charged to six northern Westchester towns for their share of operating the county's garbage-to-energy plant in Peekskill have caused the communities to reconsider the agreements that allow them to dump trash at the facility and that give them the chance to join an extended garbage district.

title: NJ TRANSIT HAILS ITS NEW STRATEGY
description: THE strategy by NJ Transit of offering cut-rate fares, rather than free rides, to New Year's Eve celebrators apparently succeeded.

title: A Bounty for The Homeless
description: The solution to a homeless family's problems is, of course, a home. And in New York City at least, that most often means renting an apartment. For several years, city and state officials have been trying to encourage landlords to rent apartments to the homeless; last week, the state formally approved a plan that will permit New York City to offer bonuses averaging as much as $12,000 to landlords for each apartment they make available.

title: Vermont Raises Drinking Age
description: Vermont became the last state in the Northeast to raise its drinking age to 21 under a measure signed into law Friday.

title: Zagreb Philharmonic Set for Carnegie Hall
description: The Zagreb Philharmonic, under the direction of Pavle Despalj, its music director, will play at Carnegie Hall on Thursday for the first time in five years.

title: Bids on a House
description: To the Editor:

title: It's No Picnic for New York Supermarkets
description: The marriage last week of Red Apple supermarkets to the Gristede Brothers grocery chain seemed a mismatch, no doubt, to many New Yorkers. Red Apple operates cost-conscious, cash-and-carry stores, while Gristede's has for 95 years offered gourmet fare to a more affluent clientele.

title: MICHIGAN BEATEN BY ILLINOIS, 83-79
description: Tony Wysinger, a junior guard, made four free throws in the final seconds of overtime today to give Illinois an 83-79 victory over Michigan in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: Miss Weissman Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Weissman of New York of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Sari Weissman to Jeffrey Neal Lavine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold L. Lavine of Providence, R.I.

title: SEAWEED SUPPER IN WALES
description: Visitors to Swansea in Wales who order laverbread are invariably surprised when they are served a plate full of something that looks and tastes like strong, somewhat slippery spinach. Laverbread is not bread; presumably it got its name because it was the staff of life for many coastal Welsh households.

title: OLD MONTGOMERY FOES GATHER TO RECALL ROLES IN '56 BOYCOTT
description: Thirty years after the Montgomery bus boycott that started the civil rights movement and the career of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., former antagonists, both white and black, came together today on the grounds of the Capitol to commemorate the event.

title: MANAHAN LEAVING STATE ORCHESTRA
description: WHEN George Manahan, associate conductor of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, ends the 1985-86 season - his fifth with the orchestra - he will step down to fulfill an international series of operatic and symphonic engagements.

title: CONSUMER RATES
TO MOVE FORWARD, GO BACK TO GOLD
description: The damage inflicted on our workers and industries by the overvalued dollar has demonstrated that free trade without stable exchange rates is a fantasy. The trade crisis caused by overvaluation has also given us a clear choice: Either we continue to live with floating exchange rates, in which case we will face bitter trade wars and the gyrations of inflation and deflation, or we can choose a stable currency based on the gold standard. The argument for gold has rarely been stronger than it is today.

title: INSURANCE COSTS TROUBLE FISHERMEN
description: LONG ISLAND'S commercial fishermen, like fishermen everywhere, have always had to contend with bad weather, fluctuating fish markets, boom-and-bust fish populations and foreign competition.

title: 4 SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS SHOT
description: Four blacks were wounded today when at least three white men roamed through a wealthy Johannesburg suburb in a pickup truck, shooting randomly at blacks, the police said.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE OXFORD ANTHOLOGY OF AUSTRALIAN LITERATURE. Edited by Leonie Kramer and Adrian Mitchell. (Oxford University, $39.95.) This is not a treasury of the highest moments from classic Australian literature, but a collection that samples the prose and poetry of 124 representative writers.

title: Harvard Tenure for Woman
description: The John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University has for the first time granted tenure to a woman, Mary Jo Bane, an expert on poverty, welfare and the American family. Professor Bane, 43 years old, has been an associate professor of public policy at the school for several years. She is currently on leave, serving as executive deputy commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services, and is to return to Harvard in the spring of 1987.

title: AROUND THE WORLD IN PURSUIT OF TROPICAL PLANTS
description: There is a map of the world on a wall in Alfred Byrd Graf's New Jersey home that is peppered with pin dots -red ones, blue ones and green ones. Few countries are ''dotless.'' Each pin represents a trip made by this noted botanist in search of plants. Travels took him to tiny islands and big countries. Red dots represent repeat trips, blue is for trips Mr. Graf and his wife, Lieselotte, took together and green represents some of the early trips Mr. Graf took alone.

title: HAWKINS HOSPITALIZED
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, has been hospitalized for several days for a series of tests and evaluations, her office said in a statement Friday.

title: AMERICAN ROLE SEEN BY TASS
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass accused the United States today of engineering the fall of President Jean-Claude Duvalier and said Washington wanted to replace his Government with one that would ''serve obediently'' United States interests. Tass said protests against Mr. Duvalier compelled the United States ''to sacrifice the dictator to prevent the further spread of the people's struggle in Haiti.''

title: U.S. AIDES ALARMED AT FRAUD IN VOTE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Washington was extremely disturbed by what appeared to be widespread acts of fraud and intimidation in behalf of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the Philippine vote count.

title: HOSTILITY TOWARD THIN PEOPLE STEEPED IN MISCNCEPTIONS
description: IT is a clear and evident truth that thin people are victims of prejudice, the objects of misconception and hostility. While most people know better than to tread upon an individual's race, religion, and so on, few possess similar decency when it comes to a person's height-to-weight ratio.

title: SPOT CHECK ON FAKE FURS
description: WHAT are these things prowling the sidewalks of New York -leopards, cheetahs, tigers, ocelots, jaguars, zebras, Mickey Mouse? Fear not, it's merely the latest wrinkle in fake fur, the garment industry's version of costume jewelry.

title: How Donald Regan Runs the White House
description: Bernard Weinraub's article ''How Donald Regan Runs the White House'' (Jan. 5) successfully explicated the job of the President's chief of staff. Mr. Regan appears to be a candid, decisive, sometimes harsh individual who is more admirable than likable. But his achievements may be attributed to these qualities, and, certainly, his boss seems pleased with his performance. MIN JIN LEE Demarest, N.J.

title: HOUSING PROJECT OPPOSED
description: A SUFFOLK County Legislator is seeking to have the county preserve a 260-acre tract of waterfront property in East Moriches slated to become condominiums.

title: WHOSE SIDE ARE YOU ON, TEDDY MAKI?
description: SOLDIERS IN HIDING By Richard Wiley. 199 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $14.95. TEDDY MAKI, the narrator and aging hero of Richard Wiley's first novel, ''Soldiers in Hiding,'' is the host of a popular Japanese television program called the ''Original Amateur Hour.'' The show always begins and ends with Maki's rendition of Duke Ellington's ''Mood Indigo'' on the guitar. He addresses his audience in both English and Japanese, although he reads the latter poorly and must have his cue cards written out in roman letters rather than ideographic characters. Maki delights in occasionally misdirecting lost American tourists. He has a son named Milo and a mistress named Sachiko, whose scarred torso recalls the blast that razed her hometown of Hiroshima when she was a little girl.

title: FARRAKHAN ARRIVES IN NIGERIA
description: The American Black Muslim leader Louis Farrakhan has begun a five-day lecture tour in Nigeria. Mr. Farrakhan flew here Friday with his wife and 14 aides and bodyguards after being denied entry to Britain.

title: PROSECUTOR STARTS HIS FINAL PLEA IN POPE PLOT TRIAL
description: The prosecutor in the trial of seven Bulgarians and Turks accused of conspiring to murder Pope John Paul II began his final plea this week, contending that there was enough evidence to prove there was a plot but that the state's key witness had sought to torpedo the case by feigning madness.

title: House Ethics Unit To Investigate 3 Congressmen
description: No formal charges have been filed, but the House ethics committee announced last week that it would investigate published allegations that Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the Banking Committee, and two other Representatives had improperly used their stature and status as Congressmen to enrich themselves.

title: Extra Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: A NOVEL WAY OF LOOKING AT LISZT
description: This year marks the centenary of the death of Franz Liszt, perhaps the greatest pianist of history, and certainly one of music's most recondite personalities. During his long life he was called many things -not all of them flattering. ''A smasher of pianos'' was Clara Schumann's opinion, while the conductor Hermann Levi dismissed him as ''an inspired charlatan.'' Yet the antipathetic Brahms once declared that ''whoever has not heard Liszt cannot even speak of piano playing.''

title: AT TH SHELTER THE PEOPLE COME AND GO -- AND SOME HAVE TO BE TURNED AWAY
description: IT is shortly before 9 P.M. and my chest tightens with misgiving as I ascend the stone staircase toward the large wooden doors. I wonder what misfortune and misery will soon lie beyond those doors, and whether I have the strength of spirit to withstand it.

title: Gandhi Copes With Corruption; Cash and Carry Government in India
description: People were surprised when a prominent businessman was arrested at Ahmedabad Airport last spring on foreign exchange law charges. He had been clumsy enough to try to board a plane with a suitcase full of cash.

title: MUSIC LOVERS SHOULD CHERISH THEIR GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: Expect nothing and never be disappointed. If that isn't an old folk saying, it should be. Many people seem to run their lives by some such rule, either because they were born cautious or have been bruised into cautiousness by some hope-shattering trauma. Those guarded souls, however, probably do not grow up to be concertgoers, a variety of human being that is able to bear innumerable disappointments without quite losing the edge of anticipation. The irrational feeling that great expectations will surely be realized on this night, or the next, or the next is what continues to draw the helpless devotee of music into concert halls and opera houses when reason and experience offer him little hope.

title: Chipping Away at the Idea of 'Entitlement'. . .
description: ONCE again in his budget last week, President Reagan proposed changes in many Government programs that provide benefits to which Americans once thought they were clearly entitled. Social Security payments would be exempted, but restrictions would be put on Medicare and Medicaid, guaranteed student loans and Civil Service retirement pay, among others.

title: U.S., IN SHIFT, JOINS WORLD BANK UNIT ON AFRICA
description: The United States, in a policy change forced by Congress, has joined an agency of the World Bank that helps African countries and has sent it a $71.8 million contribution.

title: HAS CANADA LOST ITS OIL GAMBLE?
description: IN ''Iceberg Alley,'' just off the coast of Newfoundland, lies the biggest pool of oil ever found off the East Coast of North America. To plumb it, the Mobil Oil Corporation and its partners must contend with lashing winds, 100-foot waves and ice chunks of a magnitude that sank the Titanic a few miles away.

title: Rhode Island Law Holds Back Dogs
description: RHODE ISLAND officials say a new state law is helping to control a major problem: vicious dogs.

title: GERMANY'S WHITE FOREST
description: The name ''Black Forest'' - West Germany's Schwarzwald - suggests a formidable wilderness of dark woods and twisted growth, obscured from sunlight by the dense foliage of the trees; an inhospitable region haunted by lurking witches, howling wolves and hooting owls. The picture is wrong.

title: A.N. PRITZKER, 90, HYATT HOTEL CHAIN OWNER
description: A. N. Pritzker, founder of the business group that owns the Hyatt hotels, Braniff Airlines and McCall's magazine, died today at the age of 90.

title: How Donald Regan Runs the White House
description: That the President's chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, takes the pulse of the stock market and glories when it's strong is not surprising, considering his background, but it gives away the narrow focus of this Administration. A healthy stock market does not signify well-being among farmers, the disadvantaged elderly or black teen-agers, to mention only a few of the groups suffering under a Government run by Ronald Reagan and Donald Regan. MALVINE COLE Jamaica, Vt.

title: A MACHISMO THAT DRIVES WOMEN OUT
description: AMERICAN corporations are suffering a female ''brain drain'' that they can ill afford.

title: Lysa Toccoli Wed To S. C. Stenard
description: Lysa Diane Toccoli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simone L. Toccoli of Stockton, Calif., was married there yesterday to Steven Charles Stenard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles E. Stenard of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Lawrence McGovern performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Annunciation.

title: Sally Quackenbush Plans To Marry Robert Mason
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Quackenbush of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sally Virginia Quackenbush to Robert Carter Mason, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Mason 3d of Birmingham, Mich.

title:
ART;
JIM DINE'S PRINTS OF 1977-85 AT WESLEYAN
description: A DECIDEDLY major exhibition - ''Jim Dine Prints 1977-85'' - is currently at the Davison Art Center and Zilkha Gallery of Wesleyan University in Middletown. Organized by Ellen D'Oench and Jean E. Feinberg of Wesleyan, the exhibition will go on a two-year, nationwide tour of seven museums following its March 9 closing.

title: What It Means for Moscow and the Refuseniks
description: IF Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet Jew who has spent eight years in prisons and labor camps, is released as expected Tuesday, it will be in part because the Kremlin hopes to relieve itself of an international symbol of the plight of human rights activists here. His release may help Moscow's standing abroad, just as permission for Yelena G. Bonner to leave for medical treatment and the release of some members of divided families have.

title: FIREFIGHTER CHARGED IN FIRE
description: A West Islip firefighter, described as ''a good fireman'' who ''performed well,'' was charged with setting fire to a town firehouse, the authorities said today. William Davolio, 19 years old, of 518 Kime Avenue, West Islip, was charged with setting a fire at a substation at Watts Place and Udall Road about 11:30 P.M. Friday, according to Sgt. Warren Grubner, a spokesman for the Suffolk County police. No one was injured in the fire, which caused an estimated $50,000 in damage, he said.

title: LEGACY OF WASTE HAUNTS HARBOR
description: MORE than a century ago, industry began to develop around the sheltered waters of Hempstead Harbor, and today the residents near the harbor face a legacy of toxic waste and pollution that Federal, state and local officials say constitutes one of the biggest environmental time bombs on Long Island.

title: PORT AUTHORITY HEAD URGES COOPERATION WITHIN REGION
description: New York and New Jersey must replace parochial argument with regional cooperation or be surpassed as an aviation and maritime center by other areas of the country, the executive director of the Port Authority said last week.

title: POLL FINDS AMERICANS DIVIDED ON REPLY TO TERROR
description: Most Americans believe the United States Government could be doing more to combat international terrorism, but they are divided and uncertain about the value of military action, a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll has shown.

title: FOR YOUNG SKATERS, A SHOWER OF BOUQUETS
description: Frankly, a lot of the spontaneous flower-throwing at the national figure skating championships here this week was rigged.

title: Nigeria's New Face Has His Ear to the Ground
description: Barely a month after seizing power in a quietly managed coup, Nigeria's new President, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim B. Babangida, was reviewing the troops during independence day celebrations. As it happened, it was raining, and the soldiers arrayed before him were drenched. So was the President. ''If my boys stand in the rain, so do I,'' he is reported to have said.

title: Israel Stops The Wrong Jet
description: Libya sent a Grumman Gulfstream executive jet to Syria last week to fetch George Habash, a Palestinian leader who has adamantly opposed compromise with Israel. When the Grumman flew back toward Syria, Israeli warplanes intercepted it over the Mediterranean and forced it to land in Israel.

title: SELLING CO-OPS TO HELP RENTERS
description: THE New York Urban Coalition is planning to rehabilitate five adjoining brownstones on Underhill Avenue in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, using proceeds from the sale of 24 co-ops in three of the buildings to maintain 16 apartments at low rents in the other two.

title: MEMPHIS STATE FALLS BY 67-66
description: Freddie Banks scored the team's last 7 points, including a jump shot with 1 minute 9 seconds remaining, to give Nevada-Las Vegas (23-2) a 67-66 upset of Memphis State today, its 14th consecutive victory.

title: The State of Disunion in Government Deliberation
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH CAROLINA A CALCULATED SUCCESS
description: LESS than two minutes remained as Kenny Smith, the North Carolina guard, hurriedly drove downcourt, his team trailing by 5 points. The top-ranked Tar Heels had come back from a 13-point second-half deficit against a highly ranked Georgia Tech team drawing support from a wildly enthusiastic home crowd. Time was running out.

title: Music
description: The sacred music and dance of Haiti and Cuba, intended to accompany rituals derived from the major West African traditional religions, are rarely performed for the general public. But on Friday night at Washington Square Church, two outstanding ensembles will represent these traditions.

title: IN BRIEF: FILMS ON CASSETTE
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening. Excerpts are from reviews by Times critics. Pale Rider

title: NAVY DIVERS HUNT FOR SUNKEN DEBRIS
description: Navy divers joined the search for the Challenger wreckage today, making the first attempt to examine underwater fragments from the space shuttle and recover them for examination by engineers investigating the explosion.

title: STUDENTS IN 2 DISTRICTS EXCHANGE NOTES VIA COMPUTERS
description: SEATED at a computer terminal, Megan Whiteside and Jenna Levitt, fifth graders at the Edward Morley School in West Hartford, were sending a message to their pen pals at the Annie Fisher School in Hartford.

title: WHO'S GOT THE OLDEST HOUSE? TOWNS PUZZLE IT OUT
description: WHILE house hunting in Wethersfield six years ago, Paul and Donna Courchaine were smitten by a handsome, 17th-century home like some they had seen at such reconstructed historical villages as Plimoth Plantation in Massachusetts.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AS WE FORGIVE. By Barbara Neil. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Barbara Neil's first novel concerns an older man's passion for a younger woman - a theme that if not exactly new is nonetheless nearly always intriguing.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Too Much Too Soon?

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: BARBARA A. MARROW, the first woman, first black and first full-time clerk of the first woman, first black and State Assembly, is taking the mounds of paper work and her though she says she sometimes feels like ''wife and mother'' to the 80 legislators.

title: Challenger Questions, Hopes, Fears and Wishes
description: To the Editor:

title: FABRIC JEWELRY? NO -- IT'S METAL
description: UNTIL the year 2002, Mark Keyasko alone can legally exploit his ''new and useful invention,'' a method of electroforming metal over cloth, for which he recently received a patent for 17 years.

title: Two Views of O'Neill's Budget
description: With Gov. William A. O'Neill and all 187 state legislators up for re-election in the autumn, the presentation of the Governor's proposed budget last week provided a rhetorical warm-up for the coming campaign.

title: HOW TO FIX A BIG HOLE IN THE WALL: FIRST, MAKE IT BIGGER
description: ALTHOUGH a small nail hole or crack in drywall can be easily filled in with spackling compound or joint cement, homeowners are often confused about how to fill in larger holes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SEARCH. By Robert Mayer. (Doubleday, $16.95.) A world-weary photojournalist in midlife crisis, a 60's activist regaining her trust in society, and a conscience-stricken physicist with a plan for world peace are the leading dramatis personae in Robert Mayer's latest novel, set in contemporary Santa Fe and Los Alamos, N.M. Obviously these characters are packaged for suspenseful entanglements.

title: Kathleen Sloan To Wed in April
description: Kathleen Lynn Sloan, the staff director for United States Representative Jan Meyers, Republican of Kansas, and Gregory Lynne Musil, a legislative assistant to Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, plan to be married in April.

title: UNHAPPY FAMILIES ARE ALL ALIKE
description: THE DIARIES OF SOPHIA TOLSTOY Edited by O. A. Golinenko, S. A. Rozanova, B. M. Shumova, I. A. Pokrovskaya and N. I. Azarova. Translated by Cathy Porter. Introduction by R. F. Christian. Illustrated. 1,043 pp. New York: Random House. $35. TOLSTOY'S DIARIES Volume One: 1847-1894. Volume Two: 1895-1910. Edited and translated by R. F. Christian. 755 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $60.

title: OFFERING SUPPORT DURING JOB HUNT
description: BOB STEED of Rye knew the anguish of losing a job. As vice president in charge of personnel for a major publishing company, he ''wound up second in a two-man horse race to replace the boss.''

title: CHLDREN AND PETS: IDEA FULL OF WONDER
description: I ALWAYS thought that whoever said a pet for a child was a wonderful idea either did not have children or pets themworld.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: YANKEE BLUES: Musical Culture and American Identity. By MacDonald Smith Moore. (Indiana University, $29.50.) Daniel Gregory Mason, descended from one of America's foremost musical families, attained only modest rank as a composer. As an author, professor and chairman of the music department at Columbia University during the 1930's however, he was an influential spokesman for what MacDonald Smith Moore terms ''redemptive culture'' - the spiritual uplifting of a nation or race through the mediation of the arts, particularly music. Mason is the protagonist in Mr. Moore's ''Yankee Blues,'' an intriguing, scholarly account of the ideological clash between Mason's generation of New England composers and the younger, more ethnically diverse proponents of modernism and jazz. Charles Ives, a far more estimable composer whose Yankee pedigree was nearly as impeccable, is cast as Mason's foil, sharing his colleague's transcendentalist vision but disdaining his racism and anti-Semitism. Mr. Moore, a jazz critic and president of a New York digital recording company, sets the stage in a lengthy philosophical analysis that describes both men's struggle to reconcile the paradoxical ideals of gentility and democracy. Ives ultimately resigned himself to public indifference, but Mason, inflamed by the popular rage for jazz, grew increasingly truculent, denouncing such Jewish composers as Aaron Copland and George Gershwin for bringing jazzy dissonance into the concert hall and for daring to express an American ethos without proper racial credentials. The drama culminates in the 1930's with the critical acclamation of Roy Harris - a flag-waving protege of one of Mason's contemporaries - as the ''white hope of American music,'' a man who ''would put the jazzers in their place.''

title: WORK ALL WEEK, STRUM ALL WEEKEND
description: OFTEN, college graduation means the end of the extra- curricular activities that made college fun in the first place - the student newspaper, the campus debating team, the student band.

title: U.S. Forces Reported Ready For Philippine Rescue Move
description: The United States has canceled Marine Corps exercises off Japan and placed the forces on standby to help evacuate Americans from the Philippines in the event of election-related violence, the Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported today.

title: A RELIABLE STANDBY STILL PLEASES
description: IT has been eight years since we reviewed Dameon in Westport. The Connecticut restaurant scene has changed radically in the intervening years, but Dameon, with its good food and live music in a cosy, bistro setting, has gone blithely on. Obviously, Dameon is doing something right.

title: Alix de Nicolay to Wed Anthony Mohl
description: Announcement has been made by Count and Countess Aymard-Claude de Nicolay of Paris and Savigny-les-Beaune, France, of the engagement of their daughter Alix de Nicolay to Anthony Steven Mohl, the son of Mrs. Antoine de Laire de Verdonnet of New York and Bedford, N.Y., and the late Steven Mohl. A June 14 wedding is planned.

title: FOR CITY LAWYERS, SECOND OFFICES ON L.I.
description: ON Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, Richard B. Kelly can usually be found in his office in the Helmsley Building on East 46th Street in Manhattan.

title: A March 8 Bridal For Kirby Delany
description: Kirby Delany, director of human resources for the Special Retailing Group of General Mills in New York, and Joseph L. Williams 3d, a vice president and partner in Eastdil Realty Inc. in New York, plan to be married March 8.

title: KEAN PROPOSING A 'TIGHT' BUDGET WITH NO NEW TAXES
description: Governor Kean will submit a $9.28 billion state budget to the New Jersey Legislature on Monday that calls for no new state taxes, but includes no money to offset expected cuts in Federal aid.

title: NEAR KYOTO, RURAL RICHES
description: The ancient province of Tanba, directly west of Kyoto, draws visitors today to the still-active kilns of Tachikui, where the warm, rich tones of Tanba-ware pottery are produced and to the nearby castle town of Sasayama. Isolated by rail lines that bypass the town, the area remains an appealing retreat for a few days' visit to rural Japan.

title: RAIN AFFECTS GOLF EVENTS
description: Heavy rain over the weekend has delayed two golf events. The third round of the Shearson Lehman Brothers Andy Williams

title: THEATER: REPERTORIO ESPANOL'S 'FUENTE OVEJUNA'
description: THE possibilities of seeing fine Spanish classics, and other productions, too, staged in their native idiom are remote outside of Spanish-speaking countries. That is why New York is fortunate to have the Repertorio Espanol, a company that has been working here for 18 years and is one of the few truly repertory companies in the city.

title: A CLOUDED FUTURE FOR THE 1987 BUDGET
description: The President proposed the first budget under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing bill. The budget calls for outlays of $994 billion in the 1987 fiscal year, a spending increase of just 1.4 percent over 1986 and one that would result in a deficit of $143.6 billion - down 29.2 percent from this year and the lowest since 1982. Military outlays would increase 6.2 percent, so, as usual in President Reagan's budgets, domestic and social programs would be cut. The budget is also likely to heighten tensions between the legislative and executive branches over spending: Legislators have been leaning toward a tax increase; the White House flatly rejects that possibility, although the President did say he might consider an oil imports tax.

title: Going After TV 'Monopoly'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BRANDED FOR LIFE
description: The recent outcry when the Coca-Cola formula was changed shows that Americans are quicker to vote for a product than for a politician. Leaf through SYMBOLS OF AMERICA (Viking, $35) by Hal Morgan and you will see how important brand-name products have become to Americans.

title: ABUSE CASES AND THE CLERGY
description: MORE than a year ago, a mother took her 4-year-old daughter to a local hospital emergency room because she said she had found unusual red marks on her back. The pediatrician on call suspected that the marks were made by an electrical cord.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: CRUISES FEATURE STARS AND A COMET
description: There are many criteria for selecting a cruise. Among them are your budget, how long you plan to be away and what part of the world you want to sail in - the Caribbean, Mexico, Alaska, Europe, the Mediterranean or the South Pacific. Other considerations are time of year and whether, depending on your preference, the itinerary calls for a preponderance of lazy days at sea or frequent stops at ports. One of the most important factors, however, is what sort of entertainment the cruise offers.

title: OLD ORGAN FACES AN UNCERTAIN FATE
description: THE Moon Dogs wrestling team and the Iron Sheik had no organ music playing in the background when they body-slammed their opponents in wrestling matches at the County Center. Nor did the local high schools that played in the volleyball and basketball tournaments there.

title: Cuban Communist Party Reshuffles Its Politburo
description: Cuba's Communist Party reshuffled its Politburo, promoting a women to full membership for the first time and ousting four of President Fidel Castro's revolutionary comrades.

title: SLAYER FACES TRIAL IN 2 APPARENTLY RACIAL KILLINGS
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, a convicted murderer who has been a suspect in a series of racially motivated shootings from Pennsylvania to Utah, will go on trial here Monday for the 1977 slaying of an interracial couple in a shopping mall parking lot.

title: Guru's Ex-Aide Denies Sham Marriage Charges
description: Ma Anand Sheela, former personal secretary of the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, pleaded not guilty Friday to charges that she broke immigration laws by arranging sham marriages for the guru's followers.

title: NIKON'S MOST AUTOMATED ENTRY
description: NIKON has entered the professional 35-millimeter autofocus market with the introduction last Friday of the N2020 camera. The company also added two 35-millimeter autofocus cameras to its lower-priced compact line: the Tele-Touch, featuring built-in telephoto, wide-angle and macro close-up lenses, and the all-weather, underwater Action Touch.

title: Deception and Delusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Faces Life
description: Did you hear the sound of breaking glass in Washington last week? That was the collapse of a conservative Crystal Palace - the theory, so beloved of Jeane Kirkpatrick and other Reagan ideologues, that America should and can keep right-wing tyrants in power indefinitely.

title: ARGUELLO'S VICTORY BOLSTERS COMEBACK
description: Thirty-three-year-old Alexis Arguello took a giant step forward in his comeback today when he knocked out Billy Costello, the former World Boxing Council super lightweight champion, 1 minute 42 seconds into the fourth round.

title: BERRY HOPES TO PLAY TONIGHT
description: On the eve of a pivotal game with its fiercest rival, St. John's faces the prospect of playing Georgetown without its best player.

title: THOMAS AND BIRD BRING VICTORY FOR EAST ALL-STARS
description: All-star games are usually showcases for individuals. This one started with a passing show by Earvin (Magic) Johnson, but ended with a display of coaching strategy.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
In Conflict
description: Ken McFadden's name was never included in the lists of the best college basketball prospects. For one thing, he played only a handful of games at Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. For another, he never graduated.

title: GAMBINO TRIAL STATEMENTS TO RESUME
description: Summations resume today in the Federal trial of eight reputed members of the Gambino crime family on charges of murder conspiracy and car theft, and defense attorneys are expected to challenge assertions by the prosecution that ''tens of thousands of dollars a week in take-home pay'' motivated the defendants to play a part in five murders.

title: SHANGRI-LA BY THE BAY: CIVIC CRUSADES, SAFE STREETS AND THE BIG BOW WOW
description: Even before the silvery pterodactyl swooped into view, Augustus C. Agate knew it was there. Even with his car windows rolled up and heater going full blast and traffic clanging on the Cross Bay Boulevard - even above the sound of his own voice -Mr. Agate could distinguish the low growl. ''There's the

title: S.O.R.C. ENTRIES DECLINE
description: THE Southern Ocean Racing Conference, sailing's premier offshore-racing series, is traditionally the sport's annual test of new boats and gear. But this year, there appears to be substantially less interest than usual. Fewer boats are new. And many top sailors have instead turned to the America's Cup. The entry list for the six-race series, which began Thursday at St. Petersburg, Fla., is lower than it has been in the 40-year history of the event. While the change is not dramatic - 56 boats are entered, compared with 75 last year - yachtsmen are questioning whether it is temporary.

title: For Many, TV Comes in a Dish or Not at All
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER YEARS OF REJECTION, MCDONALD NOVEL IS A HIT
description: In an era when some authors receive seven-figure advances, Gregory Mcdonald, the author of the popular Fletch and Flynn detective novels, received an advance of $10 for ''Safekeeping,'' his most recent work. After paying the William Morris Agency its standard 10 percent commission, he cleared exactly $9.

title: DUARTE'S CRITICS ON THE RISE AT HOME
description: He came into office promising revolutionary change in El Salvador, but many of his supporters now appear to see President Jose Napoleon Duarte as a far more adept political campaigner than President and administrator of their country.

title: POINT MAN FOR TAX COMPLAINTS
description: For a man who runs what may be the world's biggest ''complaint department'' - last year brought 506,000 -Jack G. Petrie seems remarkably composed as he sits in his Constitution Avenue office and fields yet another round of questions about whether the Internal Revenue Service will be able to avoid repeating 1985's filing-season disaster.

title: Just Deserts
description: The current Washington fervor for economy in Government isn't restricted to the big-ticket items with perceptible impact on the budget.

title: Murdoch Plan Reported
description: The publisher Rupert Murdoch is negotiating to acquire European Travel and Life magazine, publishing industry sources said.

title: Opportunity Raps
description: The Chicago Bears warmed up for Super Bowl XX with their rock video ''Super Bowl Shuffle.'' Boston College's hockey team prepared for the 33d Beanpot Tournament with a rock video of its own - the ''Beanpot Trot.''

title: ARCHITECTURE: MIES SHOW AT MODERN
description: THE Museum of Modern Art's sprawling exhibition celebrating the centennial of the birth of Mies van der Rohe, which opens to the public today, begins not with a glimpse of the Barcelona Pavilion, or the Seagram Building, or, indeed, with any of the designs for which the great architect is well known. It opens, instead, with a huge photograph of a temporary mock-up of the Kroller-Muller house, a design made in 1912 for a large villa near The Hague that was never, in fact, built in final form.

title: DIPLOMATAND LEGAL SCHOLAR
description: John C. H. Wu, diplomat, scholar and authority on international law, died of heart failure on Feb. 5 at the Veterans Hospital in Taipei, Taiwan. He was 86 years old.

title: ALIEN TELLS OF AID IN ENTERING U.S.
description: The Federal prosecutor continued to call Central Americans to the witness stand last week in the case against 11 church workers accused of smuggling aliens into the United States.

title: Washington Pay Accord Accepted by U.S. Judge
description: The Federal judge who found Washington state guilty of discrimination against women workers has given preliminary approval to a settlement of the dispute.

title: Advertising; Campaign On Health Set to Start
description: ''US HEALTHCARE. It's coming to Greater New York and it's going to have a big effect on your health,'' is the ending of four 10-second TV spots that will begin to air here today signaling the entry of United States Health Care Systems Inc. into the nation's wealthiest market.

title: 2 Bomb Squad Officers Die in House Blast
description: At least one pipe bomb exploded inside a house here Saturday, shaking the neighborhood and killing two bomb squad officers who were trying to de-fuse the device, the authorities said.

title: STATES SAID TO BE ILL-PREPARED FOR TEEN-AGE PREGNANCIES
description: One million teen-agers will have unwanted pregnancies each year in the foreseeable future, and state and local governments are ill-equipped to deal with the problem, according to a Congressional report made public yesterday.

title: MORGENTHAU ENLARGES CITY CORRUPTION INQUIRY
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, has widened his investigation into allegations of city corruption, issuing dozens of subpoenas to city agencies over the last few weeks. He has extended his inquiry beyond the Parking Violations Bureau's contract with one company, he confirmed yesterday.

title: AFTER VAULTING TO WORLD BEST, OLSON AIMS HIGHER
description: Saturday morning, Billy Olson awakened in his hotel room. That night, he would pole-vault in the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational track meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, but for now he had hours to rest and think.

title: Advertising; Bloomingdale's Project Assigned to F.M.R.
description: Talk about reaching the heights of chic. Fallon McElligott Rice, the Minneapolis agency that successfully gambled that an intense effort at winning advertising awards would result in being awarded advertising accounts, has just become a creative resource for none other than Bloomingdale's, that bastion of the big time.

title: Girl, 10 to 12, Is Found Slain In Room Off Subway Tracks
description: The body of a girl who was apparently killed and set on fire was discovered in a small underground room off the IRT subway tracks in Brooklyn yesterday her hands tied behind her back, the police said.

title: PUGET SOUND OIL SPILL BRINGS MOVE FOR STATE CONTROL OF HARBOR PILOTS
description: An oil spill that resulted from the grounding of a tanker at Port Angeles, Wash., in December has set off a move to tighten state authority over harbor pilots.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1986
description: International

title: MANDELA FORECASTS HUSBAND'S RELEASE
description: Winnie Mandela, the activist wife of the jailed black nationalist Nelson Mandela, forecast today that her husband would be freed but said she did not know when or where.

title: Lecture by Farrakhan Is Prohibited in Nigeria
description: A scheduled public lecture by the American Black Muslim leader Louis Farrakhan was barred today by the authorities. No reason was given.

title: MACLAINE PORTRAYING MACLAINE
description: Shirley MacLaine will soon appear on television playing - Shirley MacLaine. Ann Jillian will soon play - Ann Jillian. And Joan Collins may add a new role to her repertory - Joan Collins.

title: FILM ABOUT MARY BANNED IN BRAZIL
description: Less than a year after Brazil's new civilian Government announced the end of all censorship, a French movie about the Virgin Mary has been banned from exhibition here at the request of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Toyota Favors Quotas
description: Toyota said it favored an end to the quotas limiting the number of cars it can export to the United States, but assumes that the restrictions will continue, according to top executives. Robert McCurry, senior sales vice president for Toyota's United States division, said at the Chicago Auto Show that his company was assuming the Japanese Government would not loosen or end its so-called voluntary restraints on car exports, which are due to expire March 31. Toyota sold 949,000 cars and trucks in the United States in 1985.

title: OBSERVERS OF VOTE CITE WIDE FRAUD BY MARCOS PARTY
description: International election observers said Sunday that they had witnessed widespread fraud by supporters of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, and 30 computer workers in the Government's vote-counting agency walked out, saying returns were being falsified in favor of Mr. Marcos.

title: Telecommunications Problem
description: White House personnel officials are trying to figure out how to resolve a politically embarrassing situation regarding the selection of a new Assistant Secretary of Commerce and director of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, the agency that advises the White House on telecommunications policy.

title: DONALD MacCORQUODALE
description: Donald W. MacCorquodale, a biochemist who was a member of a research team that shared the 1943 Nobel Prize in Medicine for work on the isolation and synthesis of vitamin K, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 97 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary Thursday of George C. Sherman Jr., the former polo player and official, incorrectly identified his business affiliation. He was a senior vice president of Rollins Burdick Hunter, the insurance broker, and chairman of its office in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. B6

title: Arson Now Considered In a Fire That Killed 7
description: A house fire in which seven people, including five children, died might have been set after an argument between two of the victims, according to investigators who originally blamed a faulty kerosene heater.

title: SHUTTLE LAWSUITS: QUESTION IS WHEN
description: Experts in the law of space, defective products, and air disasters predict that whatever the investigation into the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger ultimately reveals, lawsuits by the families of those killed, seeking millions of dollars in damages, will almost inevitably follow.

title: EYES OF TEXAS ARE ON NATIONAL CROWN
description: IT was an evening that had to be believed before it could be appreciated, an evening when more than 11,000 people turned out at the Frank Erwin Center on the University of Texas campus to see a basketball game between Texas and U.S.C.

title: L. F. ROTHSCHILD FILES PUBLIC OFFERING
description: L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin - one of the last major private partnerships on Wall Street and a leading underwriter for emerging high-technology companies - plans to go public.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Specialties Inc. of Yonkers, which makes washroom accessories, has promoted Donald Grasso to senior vice president, in charge of its Sanitary Supply Division.

title: Paper Is Said to Get Letters by Sakharov
description: A British newspaper said today that it had obtained letters from Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident and physicist, that detail his allegations of torture and torment at the hands of the K.G.B.

title: SHUTTLE CRASH INSPIRES AID TO NEEDIEST
description: Donations in the memory of the seven crew members killed in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger are among the contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: A Matter of Timing
description: It hasn't happened within political memory, but the Democrats' eagerness to recapture their former Senate majority in November may influence them to announce their 1988 national convention city even before the 1986 campaign is over.

title: BONN URGES NEW MISSILE DEFENSE
description: The Defense Minister of West Germany, Manfred Worner, has urged that Europe build a new defense against what he sees as an increasing threat from Soviet medium-range missiles.

title: Advertising; People
description: Richard Swanson has come to Lowe Marschalk as a senior vice president.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: AT DUVALIER HOME, SPLENDOR IN RUINS
description: Discarded on a living room floor here lay a state invitation engraved with the name of the villa's owner: Son Excellence Jean-Claude Duvalier.

title: STUDY FINDS THAT ABUSE CAUSES CHILDREN TO FLEE
description: A study of adolescent runaways has provided new evidence that physical and sexual abuse are important contributors not only to chronic runaway behavior, but also to delinquency and emotional difficulties.

title: TOUGH U.S. CHOICE ON MARCOS IS SEEN
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan would face one of his most difficult foreign policy decisions if President Ferdinand E. Marcos insisted on remaining in power in the Philippines despite evidence that he had lost the presidential election.

title: Robin Rose Cohen Is Married to Alan C. Rothfeld
description: Robin Rose Cohen, the daughter of Jerome M. Cohen and Joan J. Cohen, both of New York, was married at the Pierre Hotel in New York yesterday to Alan C. Rothfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Rothfeld of Brooklyn. Rabbi Martin I. Silverman officiated. Mrs. Rothfeld, a writer, graduated from the Fieldston School and Sarah Lawrence College and received a master's degree in fiction writing from Columbia University.

title: KOCH TO PROPOSE TIGHTER CONTROLS OVER LOBBYISTS
description: The Koch administration is proposing to increase the regulation of lobbyists who represent contractors and other private interests before the Board of Estimate, the City Council and city agencies, city officials said yesterday.

title: TRACING THE RICH HERITAGE OF RYTHM AND BLUES
description: Rhythm and blues created a new market for black artists in postwar America, rejuvenated the record industry that had declined during the Depression and World War II, and greatly influenced the course of popular music, according to panelists at a two-day academic symposium at the Smithsonian Institution over the weekend.

title: WOMAN RECEIVES 2D JARVIK HEART
description: Doctors today implanted a second artificial heart into a woman whose transplanted human heart had failed hours earlier, apparently making her the first person to receive two of the devices, hospital officials said.

title: KEY APPEAL BY PENNZOIL SET TO OPEN
description: Armed with some of the country's top lawyers, Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company plan to take a key portion of their dispute to a Federal appeals court today.

title: Knick Trade Unclear
description: Scotty Stirling, the Knicks' general manager, reaffirmed today that he was not conducting a ''fire sale'' for Darrell Walker, the guard who has been mentioned in trade talks throughout the season, and especially since his altercation with Coach Hubie Brown last month. The trading deadline is midnight Feb. 15.

title: UNITED-NORTHWEST BATTLE SEEN
description: When Pan American World Airways turns its Pacific routes over to United Airlines tomorrow, it will mark the end of a remarkable era in aviation history. It will also mark the start of what is expected to be a fierce battle between United and Northwest Airlines, the United States carrier with the largest share of the lucrative and expanding Pacific market.

title: Merrill Lynch Promotions
description: The senior vice president and director of Merrill Lynch Securities Trading, Samuel E. Hunter, has been named vice chairman of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in an effort to increase Merrill's presence in global markets, the company said Friday.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 10, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on situation in southern Africa. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: INDIA MEALS' PIZZA JOINS MENU
description: As Lakshmi Chand Nirula, the white-haired patriarch of the family running India's best-known pizza and fast-food chain, tells it, he and his brother went into the restaurant business here more than 50 years ago because their cook had run away.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''America will continue to experience the epidemic of babies having babies into the next decade.

title: UNION AIDE SAYS STRIKE AT HORMEL COULD CONTINUE INTO THE SUMMER
description: Strikers at the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant at Austin, Minn., could carry their strike ''into the summertime,'' Ray Rogers, the key strategist for the union, said over the weekend.

title: Advertising; Rosenfeld Prepares Ads For Hunger Campaign
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey, as a volunteer Advertising Council agency, has prepared a multimedia advertising campaign to help the United States Department of Agriculture in the fight against hunger in America.

title: BALLET: 2 NEW CASTS IN ENGLISH 'SLEEPING BEAUTY'
description: THE Sadler's Wells production of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' performed by new casts on Saturday afternoon and evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is a magical one. From the moment the master of ceremonies came onto the stage, puzzling gravely over his list of guests to the christening of Princess Aurora, it was clear that this would be a production of quiet but considerable pleasures.

title: MIXED NOTICES FOR SKATING
description: The competition was often close and exciting, the highlight occurring Saturday afternoon when Debi Thomas, a freshman premed student at Stanford, won her first national women's singles championship by virtue of an almost flawless free-skating program. But the United States Figure Skating championships also encountered some ruts and thin ice during its five-day run on Long Island last week, which resulted in mixed reviews.

title: For Many, TV Comes in a Dish or Not at All
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: MUSICA SACRA
description: THIRTY years after his death - and more than half a century after he completed his last important work -Charles Ives remains a controversial figure. The pianist John Kirkpatrick calls him the most profound and original musical creator the United States has yet produced. The composer Samuel Barber had disagreed: ''I can't bear Ives,'' he told an interviewer in 1978. ''It is now unfashionable to say this, but in my opinion he was an amateur; a hack who didn't put pieces together well.''

title: Rough Road
description: Tom Wolfe dubbed him ''the last American hero.'' As a driver, Junior Johnson roared out of the North Carolina hill country and won over 50 stock car races, including the Daytona 500 and just about every other event of note. Since hanging up his helmet 20 years ago, Johnson, as a car owner, has watched his cars win nearly a hundred more Grand National races and taken Nascar's Winston Cup in six of the past nine seasons.

title: INSURERS REFUSING TO PAY SOME COSTS IN INFERTILITY CASES
description: A thick folder of insurance claims commands a vital spot these days on the desk of Dr. Marc Goldstein, director of the male reproduction and urologic microsurgery unit at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: An Ornamental Dispute Over a Subway Station
description: ''They are instructive and decorative, as well as practical, and will have their effect on public taste.'' So claimed the Interborough Rapid Transit Company about the faience plaques with which it adorned some subway stations in 1904.

title: Central Park Counterpoint: Bronze and Snow Statuary
description: Turner might have painted the twilight that was falling over Central Park. The low sun was diffused into a soft, golden oblong.

title: Crocker's Employees Dismayed at Sale of Bank
description: The officers and employees of the Crocker National Corporation had struggled through two years of losses and thought they finally had their bank on the mend.

title: Outlet Buyout Revives 'Deal-Maker' Memories
description: Bruce G. Sundlun, chairman and chief executive of Outlet Communications Inc., has been buying television stations for the better part of 25 years. But in order to cut his latest -and biggest - deal, he had to turn to his son for advice.

title: PIANO OF U.S. ENVOY IN MOSCOW IS VANDALIZED
description: Unknown vandals damaged several strings of the grand piano at Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman's residence tonight only hours before Vladimir O. Feltsman, a prominent pianist and Jewish dissident, was to perform there.

title: Burger Bids Bar Group Tell World of U.S. Way
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called on ''the lawyers of America'' today to urge other nations to emulate the United States by using ''a written constitution, reasonably enforceable,'' to preserve freedom.

title: Treasury to Sell $23 Billion in Bills
description: Investors face a relatively light calendar of new offerings this week. The Treasury, as usual, heads the list with its regular weekly bill auctions today, which will total $14 billion, equally divided between 90-day and six-month bills.

title: MINDING THE STATE IS 'JUST FINE' FOR NOW
description: It's not easy to get into the State Department these days. At the entrance on C for Charlie Street, they have erected a line of formidable cement anti-terrorist barriers that will probably be planted with petunias in the spring. And on the seventh floor, where George P. Shultz hangs out, they're creating a series of beautiful rooms full of 18th-century furniture and paintings, with intimidating strong doors, surrounded by cops and electronic security devices.

title: GEORGIA TECH STUNG BY DUKE
description: Duke broke open a close game with a 16-6 run to start the second half and cruised to a 75-59 Atlantic Coast Conference victory over Georgia Tech today.

title: Advertising; New Circulation Plans For 2 Time Publications
description: Time Inc. is exploring a new area of publishing, controlled circulation, which means sending magazines free to selected consumers. The company has two titles due out in the spring.

title: LOOKING TO MUGABI
description: HE had finished sparring, and now, up in the ring inside the green-and-white tent, Marvelous Marvin Hagler was moving around with his trainer. As the world middleweight champion threw combinations, Goody Petronelli caught the punches with thick red gloves. In the cool of evening, Dionne Warwick's voice could be heard floating up from the tape deck below the ring.

title: THE LONG AND SHORT OF IT
description: THEY both played college basketball in the state of Indiana; that's one similarity. They have both been known to give up the ball on a fast break; that's another similarity.

title: Gulton Opposes Bid
description: Gulton Industries said its board, with the advice of its financial adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Company, had determined that Mark IV Industries' $30-a-share offer for all Gulton shares was inadequate.

title: No Elbows on the Table, Please
description: Senator William Proxmire regularly singles out examples of egregious government waste for his ''Golden Fleece'' awards. But now the Wisconsin Democrat has found some Government saving to commend.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: For Many, TV Comes in a Dish or Not at All
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG 1985 APPLE CROP CUT BY STORMS IN NEW YORK
description: New York State farmers grew more apples in 1985 than in 1984, but sold fewer of them because of storm damage, according to figures released this week by the State Crop Reporting Service.

title: 3 Suicides in One Week Upset Omaha School
description: Three apparent suicides in a week have shattered students at a city high school, and officials have begun special programs to help teen-agers.

title: WARMUPS FOR WESTMINSTER
description: With 18 specialty shows at 11 sites, the metropolitan area yesterday became the canine capital of America. But all these events were but a prelude to Westminster, this country's most prestigious dog show, which this morning opens a two-day run in Madison Square Garden.

title: Advertising; Videotape for Doctors Is Planned by Everdale
description: People who know about advertising to the health care professional know that the favorite magazines of physicians, who are inundated with free publications, often tend to be those that deal with the economics of their practices or the spending of their money and leisure time, and not about medicine.

title: RECORD SET BY HALPIN
description: Two years ago, Gary Halpin was one of the top-rated junior rugby players in Ireland. He gave up a promising career in rugby to accept a scholarship from Manhattan College because he also was an outstanding hammer thrower.

title: TWAY TOPS LANGER ON 2D EXTRA HOLE
description: Bob Tway, a 6-foot-4-inch Oklahoman in his second year on the PGA Tour, gained his first tour victory today when he sank a 3-foot par putt on the second playoff hole to beat Bernhard Langer in the Shearson Lehman Brothers Andy Williams Open.

title: I.B.M. Details Its U.S. Decline
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, in its first detailed description of the effects of the domestic computer slump last year, disclosed Friday that sales and rentals of both its mainframe computers and small office systems in the United States declined in 1985.

title: Interest Rate Stability Is Seen
description: Prices of fixed-income securities melted under the glare of brightening economic indicators last week, with the notable exception of the new bellwether long Treasury issue, the 9.25 percent bonds of 2016, which continued to be favored by Japanese investors.

title: Advertising; More Hyundai Business For Backer & Spielvogel
description: Last July Backer & Spielvogel won the account of Hyundai Motors America, which would market the low-priced Korean car.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball St. John's vs. Georgetown, at Landover, Md. St. John's may be without Walter Berry, who sprained his left ankle in the Redmen's victory over Boston College on Saturday, for their showdown with the Hoyas.

title: ERVING SEARCHING FOR A NEW NICHE
description: All the player wants is a bag of ice to cool his aching knee. But at the moment, he just can't seem to get anyone's attention amid the rumbling chaos in the locker room of the Eastern Conference All-Star team after their 139-132 victory.

title: Letter: On International Law; The Right to Snatch Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: PATRONAGE BY JUDGES TARGET OF RULES
description: New York State court officials are preparing to put into effect rules intended to curb favoritism and political influence in the appointment of guardians and conservators.

title: GUITAR: DAVID STAROBIN PLAYS
description: FOR originality and breadth, David Starobin's guitar program at the 92d Street Y yesterday afternoon was a thing of beauty if only in its choice of music. Mr. Starobin's technique and musicality, moreover, are so firmly rooted that everything that emerged - regardless of style - seemed perfectly natural. Sor's ''Fantaisie Elegiaque'' had a forceful Romantic voice, eight Preludes by Ponce a delicate miniaturism; and the Villa-Lobos ''Mazurka-Choro'' caught perfectly the genre's tempo shifts and metric stretchings.

title: AMID THE WINTER COLD, ISLANDERS FIND NEW LIFE
description: IN the middle of January, a month when the National Hockey League season appears to be at its longest and most discouraging and its players grow dispirited, the Islanders, everyone's favorite disappointment, suddenly began to look like a shadow of their former selves.

title: Washington Watch; Industry Fears Oil-Import Tax
description: CONGRESSIONAL proponents of higher oil-import taxes are encountering unexpected opposition from a large segment of the domestic petroleum industry, despite some predictions that the industry could reap higher profits with a tax increase.

title: SALES LAG AT RETAILERS IN REGION
description: New York's biggest retailers completed their poorest fiscal-year sales performance of the 1980's last month, a spot-check has found. Erratic consumer buying, excessive price cutting and only a small rise in tourism were cited by the retailers as key reasons for the disappointing results.

title: FIRECRACKERS GREET YEAR OF THE TIGER
description: The Chinese calendar designates it Lao Hu Nian, the Year of the Tiger, but all through Chinatown yesterday, it was lions and dragons that danced and paraded through a cloud of acrid smoke past gaping, wide-eyed children and reveling adults.

title: New Chief Named At Computervision
description: James R. Berrett, who resigned last week as president and chief executive of the beleaguered Computervision Corporation, has been succeeded by Robert L. Gable, the vice chairman and chief operating officer.

title: SANTUCCI INVESTIGATING CITY SALE OF QUEENS LOTS
description: Possible irregularities in the city's sale of hundreds of house lots on an island in Jamaica Bay are being examined by investigators, according to the Queens District Attorney's office said.

title: GREGORY JARVIS
description: Close to the end, when problems delayed the launching of the Challenger for days before its fatal flight on Jan. 28, Gregory Jarvis told jokes to break the tension.

title: Advertising; Della Femina Assigned 2 Perry Ellis Licensees
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, a fashionable group, has been given two advertising assignments involving licensees of Perry Ellis, the fashion designer.

title: CHRISTA MCAULIFFE
description: Christa McAuliffe spent her last few days on earth excited and anxious about her space mission, answering mail from well-wishers and telephoning friends as she waited through the delays in the launching of the Challenger.

title: AROUND THE WORLD Hard-Line Palestinians Meet in Syria
description: Hard-line Palestinian guerrilla leaders met in Damascus today to plan what strategy they will adopt next toward Israel and the United States.

title: A Sour Note in Industry's New Harmony
description: In the past half decade of challenge for the economy, relations between unions and employers in many beleaguered industries have undergone a welcome transformation. Squeezed by imports, deregulation and technological change, leaders on both sides have sought to strengthen the competitiveness of their enterprises by shelving old antagonisms and moving toward cooperation and shared decision-making in the workplace.

title: Nicaragua: No East-West Issue
description: The Sandinistas' quick seizure of power in 1979 completely changed the rules of the game between the United States and Nicaragua. Twenty years after Fidel Castro entered Havana, it constituted a second major change in the rules that govern relations between the United States and Latin America.

title: LARGE CROWDS GREET AQUINO
description: Corazon C. Aquino attended services today at two churches here and attracted huge crowds. The services were for opposition party workers who were attacked, kidnapped or slain in the Presidential campaign.

title: MERC LEAVES POTATOES BEHIND
description: Few in the commodities world took much notice in 1978 when a 28-year-old floor trader named Michel D. Marks suddenly emerged as chairman of the ailing New York Mercantile Exchange and dusted off a futures contract on heating oil that had already failed once before.

title: POPE TALKS OF BIRTH CONTROL IN INDIA
description: Pope John Paul II, on the eve of his departure from India, raised the birth control issue today for the first time in his nine-day visit. But he did so in the most guarded terms and avoided any criticism of the Indian Government, which, faced with a swelling population, strongly advocates birth control.

title: A PATCHWORK OF RULINGS ON FREE SPEECH AT MALLS
description: At the sprawling Eastridge Mall here, shoppers regularly find ideas being marketed alongside women's sportswear, stereo systems and running shoes.

title: Angolan Facts and Fictions
description: The United States is not at war with Angola and has no quarrel with that Marxist Government's treatment of Americans and their sizable businesses there. But you'd never know that from the reception Washington recently gave to Jonas Savimbi, whose Unita rebels are battling the Luanda regime. The State Department, which so diligently opposes disinvestment in South Africa, came close to urging American oil companies to quit Angola.

title: HOUSE REPORT SUPPORTS SINGLE-WARHEAD MISSILE
description: Much of a proposed force of small intercontinental missiles would be invulnerable to any plausible attack by the Soviet Union, and development of the force should not be delayed by efforts to arm the missiles with multiple nuclear warheads, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee argued today.

title: EUROPEANS DEBATE TV REVENUES
description: Europe is showing increasing interest in commercial television these days.

title: Pakistan Registers 2 Parties
description: Pakistan's election commission today legalized the ruling Pakistan Moslem League of Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo by officially registering it, the official news agency reported. The agency said the party and another group were the first to be registered by the commission under a law that followed the end of martial rule on Dec. 30. Most opposition parties have rejected the law, which forbids them from criticizing the military or judiciary.

title: Licensing Suit Is Cited In Microsoft Stock Offer
description: Rod Brock, president of Seattle Computer Products Inc., must feel a little like Pete Best, the drummer who left the Beatles just before their rise to stardom. Mr. Brock's company developed the program that would become MS-DOS, the standard disk operating system for the I.B.M. PC and compatible computers, but sold it to the Microsoft Corporation for $50,000 and certain licensing rights.

title: Flight Restriction
description: Political analysts searching for an issue on which Vice President Bush has broken with President Reagan need look no longer. Air Force Two, the jet that carries Mr. Bush to conservatives' conferences and state funerals, now has an absolute ban on smoking.

title: DEVILS WIN, 6-3, END 7-GAME STREAK
description: Aaron Broten, Greg Adams and John MacLean scored two goals each today as the Devils snapped a seven-game losing streak with a 6-3 victory over the Hartford Whalers.

title: Say No to Drug Use in the Work Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Aide Says South Yemen Will Retain Its Policies
description: Prime Minister Yasin Said Numan of Southern Yemen was quoted today as saying his newly installed Cabinet would seek to ''rejuvenate'' the Marxist Government after the fierce 12-day civil war.

title: WHEN THE AGED START TO STEAL
description: AN 82-year-old widow pushes a shopping cart along the aisle of a supermarket on the Upper West Side. She walks with a limp, the result of a hip fracture two years ago. She pauses, takes an item from the shelf and drops it into the shopping cart, pauses again and drops another item into a tote bag on her arm. At the checkout counter, she pays only for the items in the cart and then walks out.

title: Venezuelan Oil Price Cut Seen
description: Venezuela has decided to protect its share of the world oil market by cutting the price of its oil, possibly to as low as $17 a barrel, Government sources said today.

title: Tokyo Marathon Goes to Tanzanian
description: Juma Ikangaa of Tanzania ran the fifth-fastest marathon in history today when he was timed in 2 hours 8 minutes 10 seconds, winning the Tokyo International for the second time.

title: 30 COMPUTER AIDES SAY VOTE IS RIGGED
