description: Weeping and fearful, the 30 Government computer workers arose from their terminals and, data disks in hand, darted from the Commission on Elections to make the charge that the Marcos Government was rigging the presidential vote tally.

title: Program Helps Blacks Enter Medical School
description: To the Editor:

title: CHURCH IN HAITI ASKS THAT VENGEFUL KILLINGS STOP
description: The Archbishop of Port-au-Prince today described the ouster of the Duvalier Government as a ''victory of truth, justice, prayer and love'' and urged Haitians to stop the bloody wave of vengeance that has swept the capital.

title: THE OPERA: 'THERESE' AND 'PORTRAIT DE MANON'
description: A PAIR of minor one-acters by Massenet - ''Le Portrait de Manon'' and ''Therese'' -made a most enjoyable evening Saturday at the Joan of Arc School on West 93d Street. Unlike some grander works the Bel Canto Opera company has tried, they are eminently suitable for low-budget semiprofessional revival (indeed ''Le Portrait'' was described at its premiere as ''more for the salon than the theater,'' and had its New York premiere in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel). The gap between resources and requirements is only slight, and so there is the possibility of enjoyable - as opposed to dutiful - exposure to a rarity.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly described Irving Trust's status as Morgan Stanley's clearing agent for mortgage-backed securities. Morgan Stanley said that Irving Trust would remain an important part of its mortgage-backed clearing operations.

title: Market Place; Bullish Outlook For Equities
description: THE stock market edged gingerly past another milestone last Thursday - 1,600 on the Dow Jones industrial average - and then suddenly picked up speed the next afternoon to finish a whirlwind week signaling that the bull market remains alive and well.

title: Control Data in India Deal
description: The Control Data Corporation and the Government of India said yesterday that they had reached an agreement for the Minneapolis-based computer concern to supply India with mainframe computers and technical assistance over an eight-year period.

title: 4-PART 'HUCKLEBERRY FINN' BEGINS
description: INSTEAD of calling Huck ''honey,'' Jim insists on calling him ''son.'' That is just one of the clear indications that television's new four-part adaptation of ''Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,'' beginning on Channel 13 tonight at 9, has been carefully adjusted for popular consumption, although it claims to be exploring the darker, non-Hollywood aspects of the Mark Twain story.

title: A 'Tremendous Dusting' For 100-Year-Old Symbol
description: There were twice as many kisses as usual at the New York Public Library on Friday night, as many French guests sprinkled them on hands and both cheeks as well.

title: Shubert Inquiry Finds No Conflict of Interest
description: The New York State Attorney General's office has announced that it has found no conflict of interest in the compensation practices of the Shubert Foundation, which is the sole stockholder in Broadway's Shubert Organization, and has closed a routine investigation into its finances.

title: Outdoors: Picking a Ski Slope
description: Western skiers tend to demean the quality of Eastern slopes in the belief that they are not up to the Rockies or the Sierras. In reality, although Eastern mountains are not as high as the Rockies, they have some of the steepest terrain in the world as well as some of the most scenic longer trails found in any winter environment.

title: This Way Out
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Floor Broker Study
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission decided Friday to review a New York Stock Exchange ruling that floor brokers cannot receive phone calls directly from customers.

title: QUESTION RAISED ON PAIEMENT TRADE
description: It was not exactly an auspicious debut: a few shifts on ice, one shot at the net, then the pain that could not be ignored, and finally the news that he had a broken right foot. That's how Wilf Paiement's career with the Rangers began on Saturday in Boston.

title: PANEL ASKS NASA FOR ITS REPORTS ON BOOSTER RISKS
description: The commission investigating the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger asked the space agency today to produce all records relating to problems involving safety seals on the booster rockets.

title: UNITED PARCEL HOPING TO WIN ITS FIGHT TO OPERATE IN TEXAS
description: The 20-year battle that the United Parcel Service has waged to provide the same delivery service between points in Texas that it offers elsewhere may be nearing an end.

title: Staying Power
description: It didn't surprise many Washingtonians that Florence S. Lowe not only survived but flourished in the politically insecure post of chief public affairs adviser at the National Endowment for the Arts - through the Nixon, Ford, Carter and Reagan administrations. Now that she is retiring from Government this month, her friends will not be surprised that Mrs. Lowe is moving to a private job, as senior consultant on cultural affairs to the Kamber Group, one of the capital's prominent governmental policy and public relations concerns.

title: Mrs. Johnson Quits Hospital
description: Lady Bird Johnson, who collapsed at a funeral Wednesday and was hospitalized for fatigue, was released today from St. David's Community Hospital. Robin Byrne, an aide to the 73-year-old Mrs. Johnson, said she had also felt ''some distress'' from a knee injury suffered Tuesday when she fell on a hiking trail near Austin.

title: Soviet Ratings Week
description: Comrades: This is Pytor Dzhenninks in the Moscow TV ankabut overlooking the Communist Party Congress of the Soviet Union.

title: Good Times Help Czechs Subdue Trauma of '68
description: There is a new state-run shop here that sells Christian Dior perfume and toilet water for three and four times airport prices. The store is very busy. Prague's wine bars, taverns, theaters and concert halls are similarly full of people.

title: FALL IN OIL PRICE IS CALLED A SPUR TO MEXICO CRISIS
description: The steady decline in world crude oil prices during the last three weeks has pushed Mexico to the edge of economic disaster, Government and private economists, bankers and diplomats say.

title: NAVY DIVERS SEARCH SEA FLOOR FOR BOOSTER ROCKET
description: Navy divers, taking advantage of calm seas and bright sunshine, today methodically searched a small and murky area of the ocean floor for a satellite booster rocket that was hurled free of the disintegrating space shuttle Challenger 13 days ago.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. IS HELPFUL
description: The United States is working closely with debt-burdened Mexico, as well as with the International Monetary Fund and private banks, to prevent a Mexican financial collapse that could result from falling world oil prices, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: FRANCE IN UPROAR OVER TV LICENSING
description: ''A license to print money'' is how Lord Thomson of Fleet, the Canadian-born newspaper and broadcasting magnate, described a commercial television franchise.

title: Church, State and Homosexuality
description: Two leaders of the Roman Catholic community, New York's Cardinal O'Connor and Brooklyn's Bishop Francis Mugavero, have declared themselves opposed to passage of the homosexual rights bill pending in the City Council. They find the bill, which forbids discrimination against homosexuals in jobs, housing and public accommodations, ''exceedingly dangerous to our society.'' They contend that it promotes homosexuality and undermines Catholic teaching.

title: Search for 4 Halted After 17 Spill From Boat
description: The Coast Guard today gave up its search for four people missing from a charter fishing boat hit by a freakish wave that pitched 17 people into the sea. Five bodies have been recovered.

title: Iranian Says Ties With Soviet Improve
description: Iran's relations with the Soviet Union and the Eastern bloc are improving, but there is no such prospect now for relations with the United States, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, said today at a news conference.

title: ESKIMO GROUPS FIGHTING OVER ALASKA ZINC AREA
description: A two-million-acre section of northwest Alaska is the prize in a border dispute between two groups of Inupiat Eskimos. Mining experts say the land contains the world's richest untapped zinc reserves, and both sides expect it to produce millions of dollars in tax revenue.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Friday about Merrill Lynch & Company's plans for its new headquarters in Battery Park City misstated the effect of the sale of its current headquarters on 1984 earnings.

title: U.S. TO RESTRICT SUPERCOMPUTER USE BY SOVIET SCHOLARS
description: Tight restrictions will be placed on Soviet bloc scholars' access to supercomputers in the United States, according to National Science Foundation officials and university officials, who have reluctantly agreed to the move.

title: COMPLYING WITH RULES ON BUSINESS EXPENSES
description: To many American taxpayers the good life involves not only enjoying lunch at ''21,'' front-row seats at the Metropolitan Opera, a midwinter trip to Miami Beach or an orchid-growing hobby - but writing them off as business expenses as well.

title: SHEEHAN LEADS CLASSIC
description: Patty Sheehan shot a 1-under-par 71 today to hold off Juli Inkster and open a two-stroke lead at the end of three rounds of the L.P.G.A.'s rain-delayed $200,000 Sarasota Classic.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PROVIDENCE. By Geoffrey Wolff. 217 pages. Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $16.95. ''PROVIDENCE'' is the title of Geoffrey Wolff's fourth and latest novel, the earlier ones having been ''Bad Debts,'' ''The Sightseer'' and ''Inklings,'' all of which this new book easily surpasses. Providence is the Rhode Island city where the action of the novel is set, a ''runt town of 156,000, declining population,'' where on a typical evening in Mr. Wolff's story a pretty singer named Lisa with ''a batty smile'' tries to entertain the crowd at the 19th Hole, a Shriners' roadhouse.

title: RECITAL: ROY EATON, PIANIST
description: THE pianist Roy Eaton's Sunday afternoon recital at Alice Tully Hall, entitled ''The Meditative Chopin,'' proved an original idea that worked. Mr. Eaton conceived his program as an unbroken totality; the audience was instructed not to applaud, but to experience what the pianist called the ''sound of silence - the quiet from which Chopin's music evolves.''

title: SHEA COULD LURE AN N.F.L. TEAM HERE
description: New York's chances to get another football team are either (a) dead; (b) alive; or (c) unsettled.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many times in his career has Reggie Jackson driven in more than 100 runs in a season and how many times has he hit .300?

title: Al Smith, a Triumph of New York's Melting Pot
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1986
description: International Widespread election fraud in the Philippines by supporters of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was reported by an international team of observers. Some members of the Government's own vote-counting agency walked out, saying returns were being falsified in favor of Mr. Marcos. The observers' report said, ''The electoral anomalies which we have witnessed are serious and could well have an impact upon the final result.'' The team has 44 observers from 19 countries. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: Futures/Options; Deficit Cutting And Spreads
description: TREASURY bond futures make up an elastic world, a fact that has rarely been more evident than in the last several months.

title: LAWYERS GIVING SERVICES TO SETTLE STALLED DIVORCES
description: The couple, in their mid-30's, separated two years ago after 12 years of marriage, and their divorce proceedings had stalled. The husband, citing financial problems, had not paid any support to their three children.

title: RADICAL ACQUITTED ON 10 CHARGES, CONVICTED ON 2, IN PHILADELPHIA BOMBING AND FIRE
description: The only adult survivor of the confrontation between the radical group Move and the police was acquitted today on the 10 most serious charges stemming from the May 13 incident, but was convicted on two lesser counts.

title: Bridge: Widely Used in Scandinavia, Bidding Box Is Rare in U.S.
description: For more than two decades the players of Scandinavia, in every small bridge club, have had the convenience of using bidding boxes, devices developed by the late Eric Jannersten.

title: JOHNSON AGAIN WINS LIGHT-HEAVYWEIGHT TITLE
description: Marvin Johnson of Indianapolis won his third light-heavyweight title today when he stopped Leslie Stewart in the seventh round of their World Boxing Association bout.

title: NEW YORK FOUNDATION PLANNING PROGRAM FOR AGED
description: A $5 million program to assist older people who live alone is being developed by the Commonwealth Fund of New York, which says the eight million Americans in this group are ''significantly poorer, older and more disabled and discouraged than the over-65 population as a whole.''

title: Japanese Air Cargo Plea
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan, citing rising political pressures in Tokyo, has appealed personally to President Reagan to get concessions for Japanese air cargo carriers seeking new routes in the United States, according to Congressional sources.

title: Chinese President Faults 'Decadent' Party Aides
description: In a Lunar New Year message today, President Li Xiannian criticized Communist Party officials who he said had violated the law and damaged the party's image with ''decadent capitalist thinking.''

title: A PUBLIC PEACE FOR SPRINKEL
description: With the publication of the 1986 Economic Report of the President last week, the real Beryl W. Sprinkel came forward. He went after the Federal Reserve Board, following a long silence on the subject, and he might have set himself up for skirmishes within the Reagan Administration as well.

title: For Many, TV Comes in a Dish or Not at All
description: To the Editor:

title: The Price of Monopoly Milk
description: The cost of monopolized milk distribution in New York is now apparent. The state's decision to permit more competition among dairies in Staten Island has cut the retail price of milk there by 40 cents a gallon, or 20 percent. Now Farmland Dairies, the New Jersey-based milk processor that so dramatically broke the grip of the entrenched dairies in that borough, is asking permission to compete citywide. The quicker the Cuomo administration approves, the better for consumers.

title: 3d Skating Title To East German
description: Karin Kania of East Germany won the women's world speed skating championship today, capturing the title with victories in three out of four distances.

title: SMALL ARTS GROUPS CONCERNED OVER U.S. CUTBACKS
description: President Reagan's request to Congress to cut 12.5 percent from the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts would have the harshest and most immediate impact on small, financially fragile theater, dance, visual arts and music groups, according to directors of such organizations. They also asserted that private contributions stimulated by Government giving would fall off sharply.

title: GEORGIA FARMER VALUED LAND MORE THAN LIFE
description: Like farmers throughout the South, L. D. Hill was raised on the morality of the Bible, the ethic of hard work, and the obligation to pay your bills on time.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ART OF LIVING There has always been an art to living in New York, a way of enjoying its pleasures in addition to its tribulations. ''Urban Pleasures: New York 1900-1940'' is an exhibition that illustrates how leading artists perceived recreation and leisure in the city in the first half of the 20th century. It has just opened at the Whitney Museum of Art's branch in the Philip Morris building, 42d Street and Park Avenue (878-2550).

title: WIFE OF VICTIM OF SHIP HIJACKERS
description: Marilyn Klinghoffer, the widow of Leon Klinghoffer, who was slain by terrorists aboard the hijacked Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro last fall, died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JAPAN UNDECIDED ABOUT 'STAR WARS'
description: Despite more than a year of Government study and internal debate, Japan has been unable to make up its mind about whether to take part in President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' missile-defense program.

title: VILLANOVA DEFEATS CONNECTICUT, 59-53
description: Harold Jensen had 8 points in the second half to lead Villanova to a 59-53 victory over Connecticut today in a Big East Conference game.

title: FANTASIES SOAR FOR TEXAS MARDI GRAS
description: Stanley Tigerman of Chicago built a huge arch of steel clad with plywood and topped with mannequins representing heros of the Texas revolution. Boone Powell of San Antonio put up a light airy structure with masts, rigging and pennants that prefigures Galveston's glory days as a major seaport. And Michael Graves, the Princeton, N.J., architect, came up with a huge four-legged gateway topped with a metalwork pediment framing a lone star of Texas.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THEATER: 'SECOND MAN,' 1927 BEHRMAN COMEDY
description: WITH its glossy 1920's drawing room, crystal champagne flutes and mismatched pairs of elegant lovers, ''The Second Man'' looks like a comedy one has seen a thousand times, even if one has never actually encountered it before. But S. N. Behrman's play of 1927, which marked its author's Broadway debut and his first collaboration with the Lunts, has surprisingly sour undercurrents that keep tarnishing the familiar, lustrous comic surface. ''Life is sad,'' says one of Behrman's swells, ''but I think it's gallant to pretend that it isn't.'' By the third act, it's life's sadness, not the pretense of pleasure, that remains.

title: SCREEN: 'CRAZY FAMILY,' FROM JAPAN
description: DOMESTIC warfare reaches a wild new pinnacle in Sogo Ishii's ''Crazy Family,'' an antic comedy about a group of suburbanites who turn their brand-new dream house into a battle zone. The wife and children of Katsukuni Kobayashi (Katsuya Kobayashi), an office worker, are first seen ecstatically moving into a tiny new house, for which they are immensely grateful; the mother, Saeko (Mitsuko Baisho), even covers herself in gift wrap to thank her husband for the new house and the wonderful new life it will bring.

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $682,000 from the settlement of litigation.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Del Monte Fresh Fruit Co., Miami, a division of Nabisco Brands Inc., has named John P. Polychron president and chief executive officer.

title: 5 HELD IN SCHEME FOR LAUNDERING MILLIONS OF DOLLARS IN DRUG PROFITS
description: Government agents have arrested five people suspected of involvement in laundering money in connection with a multimillion-dollar drug trade centered in Los Angeles and Miami, Federal prosecutors said today.

title: OPERA: 'WATER BIRD TALK' AND 'MEDIUM' IN SYRACUSE
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 9 -The Syracuse Opera, now in the midst of its 12th season in this snowy city, has found warmth - even prosperity - in togetherness. Six years ago, it joined the Indianapolis Opera in a production-sharing agreement, and last year this was extended to Opera Memphis.

title: Late Innings
description: Sometimes those baseball fantasy camps fulfill all of a participant's Walter Mitty dreams, and sometimes they come up a trifle short. Take Albert Kelley of Freehold, N.J., who, like each of 105 other campers, paid $2,895 to rub elbows with the likes of Jerry Grote and Ron Swoboda at the second annual Met Dream Week in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: 3D SUICIDE STUNS STUDENTS IN OMAHA
description: Grieving students walked the halls and filled the classrooms of Bryan High School today, wearing yellow buttons to show their concern. Many others left the campus to attend the funeral of the third of their classmates to commit suicide in five days.

title: Trial Begins in Slaying Of Interracial Couple
description: The man accused of gunning down an interracial couple here in August 1977 said at his trial today that he had concocted a confession to the crime.

title: Control Data
description: Control Data Corporation said it had been unable to find a buyer and had discontinued its product line of disk and tape drives intended for users of International Business Machines personal computers. The line employed 25 people and accounted for less than $10 million in sales in 1985, it said.

title: Playing Politics With a Prisoner
description: The Reagan Administration has jumped at an opportunity to politically lynch Governor Cuomo. Its pawns are the ambitious Michael Kavanagh, Ulster County's District Attorney, who has made bewildering statements to the media, and Gary McGivern, who has spent 19 years in prison after having been convicted in the murder of a deputy sheriff.

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales figures are net of excise taxes.

title: LED IN PLATE TECTONICS STUDY
description: H. William Menard, whose discoveries on the Pacific Ocean floor helped set the stage for the revolutionary geological theory known as plate tectonics, died of cancer Sunday after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: NEW HAITI LEADER PLEDGES ELECTIONS
description: The leader of Haiti's four-day-old interim Government said today that the new ruling body was committed to the development of a ''real and functional democracy.''

title: CHARGES OF CHILD ABUSE CHALLENGE LEGAL SYSTEM
description: In the last two years, in rural and suburban and urban communities around the nation, small children have taken the witness stand to accuse adults of sexually assaulting them.

title: Bridge: Even With 52 Cards Visible, Best Move Can Be Obscure
description: When a situation calls for a most unusual play, it is unlikely to be discovered before the post-mortem and, perhaps, not even then. An example is the diagramed deal, and the reader may care to consider whether four spades can be defeated.

title: CHAMPION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $396,000 from the sale of the company's Casa Grande Arizona plant. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $213,000.

title: DREXLER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: New '85 Corn Crop Record
description: Last year's record corn harvest turned out even larger than had been expected, the Agriculture Department said today in an annual review.

title: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,621,200 for the quarter and $3,051,700 for the year. c-Net income. d-After losses from discontinued operations of $866,900 for the quarter and $1,160,000 for the year.

title: ENDS INDIA TRIP
description: Pope John Paul II ended a 10-day journey through India today with a mass in this stronghold of Hindu radicalism and an appearance in nearby Bombay, the main commercial center.

title: ADIA SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Including a gain of $1,765,340, or 99 cents a share, on the sale of land and buildings by the company's subsidiary in England.

title: PLAN TO FREE DISSIDENT: THE SOVIET MOTIVES
description: When the Soviet Union deports imprisoned dissidents, it usually gambles that its opponents will prove less nettlesome as spokesmen in the West than as symbols of oppression in a labor camp.

title: BRADLEY WINS 15TH STRAIGHT
description: Hersey Hawkins scored 19 points and Jim Les added 18 tonight to lead Bradley to a 74-67 victory over Illinois State in a Missouri Valley Conference game.

title: Chad Reports an Attack By Libyan Forces
description: Libyan forces attacked Chadian Army troops today in central Chad, the Chadian Government announced tonight in a communique received in Paris.

title: INVESTMENT FOUND UNAIDED BY TAX SHIFT
description: The large companies that have taken most advantage of tax incentives designed to stimulate investment and employment have by and large reduced their capital spending and cut their work force since the incentives were enacted, according to a study released today.

title: COMMODORE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Dr. Henry Aranow Jr., Ex-Medical Professor
description: Dr. Henry Aranow Jr., who taught at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University for nearly 40 years, died Sunday at Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: COMET PUTS ON BIGGEST SHOW, BUT AWAY FROM EARTH'S VIEW
description: In a cataclysmic drama played out once every 76 years, Halley's comet has swept to within 55 million miles of the surface of the Sun and once again has been hurled back toward exile in the farthest reaches of the solar system, renewing a cycle as old as history.

title: FOR ONCE, SPOTLIGHT WAS ON WILLIAMS
description: Buck Williams didn't have much of an opportunity to bask in the glory of his unexpected success in Sunday's All-Star Game in Dallas.

title: Moonlets of Uranus Confound the Theorists
description: To the Editor:

title: TYLENOL IS LINKED TO A CYANIDE DEATH IN YONKERS
description: The A.&P. supermarket chain removed all containers of Tylenol capsules from its shelves late yesterday after a woman in Yonkers died of poisoning from cyanide believed to have come from an Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule.

title: The Usurper
description: President Marcos of the Philippines seems poised to complete the theft of an election that had its origin in the murder of his leading opponent, Benigno Aquino. Mr. Marcos intends to have a captive National Assembly declare him the winner over Mr. Aquino's widow, whatever his people or the world may think. The world, notably the United States, must show him - in unmistakable ways.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST VOICE THEIR CONCERN FOR CHILDREN'S CARE
description: Concern for the young, particularly for children who are in need of care and shelter, has inspired many of the contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $40 million for the quarter and $368,012,000 for the year representing provisions for the settlement of South Texas nuclear project litigation and a nonrecurring charge of $257,830,000 for the year in connection with a writedown of marine operations. c-Net income.

title: SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in November 1985.

title: Concerts at Columbia U.
description: A four-part series of concerts called ''Old and New Masters'' begins Feb. 23 at 3 P.M. at the Low Memorial Library at Columbia University, Amsterdam Avenue and 116th Street.

title: PEOPLE AIR CUTS FARES IN WEST
description: People Express Inc., in a bold attempt to expand its low-cost system to the recently acquired Frontier Airlines and open the West to more East Coast travelers, said yesterday that it had cut the one-way fare between Newark and Denver from $99 to $69. It also cut fares to more than 100 other cities served by its new subsidiary.

title: E.B. WHITE IS RECALLED IN READINGS
description: E.B. White, the American essayist and stylist who died Oct. 1, was recalled in his own words last night in a reading built around his books, letters, poems and magazine pieces. The benefit reading by some of his friends and two professional actors at the City Center Theater opened the 15th season of the Manhattan Theater Club's ''Writers in Performance'' series.

title: CD INDUSTRY'S GROWING PAINS
description: The recording industry, while enjoying the booming market for compact disks, is also having to grapple with the new product's inevitable growing pains.

title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a DISC tax credit of $700,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: BUDGET-PANEL, VISITING CHICAGO, HEARS COMPLAINTS
description: A daylong parade of witnesses charged before the House Budget Committee here today that President Reagan's budget proposals would cripple efforts to revitalize the aging industrial cities of America and undermine the very family values that Mr. Reagan stressed in his State of the Union Message.

title: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Employer Sanctions Are Key to Immigration Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND CITY PROSECUTORS CLASH ON MUNICIPAL CORRUPTION INQUIRY
description: Two powerful prosecutors, the United States Attorney in Manhattan and the Manhattan District Attorney, clashed publicly yesterday over who should be investigating charges of corruption in New York City government.

title: Kin Are Paid $42,000 For Sakharov Letters
description: Relatives of Andrei D. Sakharov in the Boston area were paid $42,000 by The Observer, the British Sunday newspaper, for the right to print letters he smuggled out of the Soviet Union, the weekly's editor was quoted today as having said.

title: THE THEATER: 'KEROUAC'
description: WHETHER the title of ''Visions of Kerouac,'' now at the American Theater of Actors, signifies the playwright Martin Bauml Duberman's vision of Jack Kerouac or Jack Kerouac's visions, the result is an evening of clamorous incoherence.

title: Stake in GAF Cut
description: The Dallas investor Harold Simmons said he had reduced his stake in the GAF Corporation to 12.1 percent, from 13.2 percent, of the chemical concern's outstanding shares. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons said he sold 200,000 GAF common shares from Feb. 4 to Feb. 6 on the open market, for $56.75 to $57 a share. The stock closed today at $55.75, unchanged, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corp. is a wholly owned subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co.

title: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. ANNOYED, PRESSES SOVIET ON A DATE FOR NEXT SUMMIT MEETING
description: The Reagan Administration expressed impatience today with the failure of the Soviet Union so far to agree on a date for the planned visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the United States this year.

title: KIDDER, PEABODY CENSURED BY S.E.C.
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company, the Wall Street securities firm, and its director of operations have been censured and ordered to tighten procedures for managing customer-owned securities because of charges that they mishandled $145 million in customers' securities in late 1983 and 1984, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: LATIN MINISTERS URGE U.S. TO HALT AID TO CONTRAS
description: Eight Latin American foreign ministers met today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz to urge that the Reagan Administration halt its aid to anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua and instead back a negotiated settlement in Central America.

title: COMMODORE REPORTS $53.2 MILLION LOSS
description: Stung by price cutting and charges from plant closings, Commodore International Ltd. yesterday reported a loss of $53.2 million in the fiscal second quarter, ended Dec 31. The loss came despite company predictions that Christmas sales of its new Amiga computer would return it to profitablity.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net loss of $57,326,000 on the disposition of substantially all of the company's Western Union Corporation investments in mid-December. c-Net income after a corresponding reduction of $15,823,000 attributable to the Western Union investment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think any of us would be concerned. But I think what we have to watch for is that, in spite of all these charges, there is at the same time the evidence of a strong two-party system now in the islands.

title: AUTO-TROL TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $359,000 for the quarter and $1,300,000 for the year.

title: PULLMAN-PEABODY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NO RETURN DATE SET FOR NYSTROM
description: Bob Nystrom, the 14-year Islander veteran who underwent surgery on Jan. 15 on his left eye, met yesterday with Bill Torrey, the team's general manager, but his future with the team remained unresolved.

title: POINTER, ELKHOUND AND GRIFFON IN FINAL
description: A pointer, Ch. Marjetta National Acclaim, an elkhound, Ch. Vin-Melca's Call To Arms, and a Brussels griffon, Ch. Berryhill Gandalf, last night became finalists in the 110th annual Westminster Kennel Club show, which opened a two-day run in Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. JURY HEARS KEY WITNESS IN PARKING CASE
description: The man who first implicated Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes in the city's growing corruption scandal appeared yesterday before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan.

title: IRAN REPORTS ITS FORCES CAPTURED STRATEGIC ISLAND
description: Iran said today that it had captured a strategic island in the Shatt al-Arab waterway, and Iraq acknowledged that Iranian forces had established a ''shaky foothold'' across the wide river in an overnight offensive.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $12,849,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $303,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $67,669,000 for the quarter and $75,162,000 for the year, a capital loss of $8,588,000 for the quarter, a capital gain of $1,949,000 for the year and a gain of $8.7 million, or 27 cents a share, for the quarter and year related to tax forgiveness.

title: SUPERIOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THE COTTAGE CHESSERS CRASH THE SEXUAL FRONTIER
description: Earlier this winter, 85 percent of the student members voted to fight a sex bias suit and keep the Cottage Club what it had been for 100 years at Princeton University - a selective, all-male eating club. But in January, the alumni board that directs the club overruled the undergraduates and ordered Cottage to go coed.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $681,000 for the quarter and $649,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $82,000 for the quarter and $800,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $22,000 for the quarter and $45,000 for the 6 months.

title: HARLYN PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: Chrysler Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation, a day after the United Automobile Workers agreed to negotiate work rules at an engine plant in Trenton, Mich., said it would invest $280 million to add production of a V-6 engine to the plant, which currently makes four-cylinder engines, Chrysler said. Chrysler's chief labor negotiator, Anthony St. John, had told the union the new engine would not be added in the ''absence of a modern, progressive labor agreement.''

title: LINEAR FILMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Boeing Gets Order
description: British Airways has ordered two 747 jumbo jetliners and one twin-engine 757 jet aircraft at a cost of more than $245 million, the Boeing Company said.

title: Talking Business/with Phillips of Commodity Commission; Tougher Rules On Futures
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, long known in Chicago's commodity pits as a puppy dog regulator, demonstrated last year that, not only can it bark, but it has quite a bite, too.

title: AGE OF SUNRISE TV DAWNS IN BLEARY-EYED SPAIN
description: ''Buenos dias, Espana,'' said a cheery if somewhat bleary-eyed television host at 7:30 A.M. one day last month - and with that, the era of morning television dawned in Spain.

title: The Annals of Spies and Information
description: A few weeks ago, the Department of Energy instructed its employees to tell their superiors immediately about any outside requests for ''illegal or unauthorized access to classified or otherwise sensitive information.''

title: BUCKNELL PROVOST NAMED PREISDENT OF VASSAR
description: Vassar College today named Dr. Frances Daly Fergusson, the 41-year-old provost and vice president for academic affairs at Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa., as its ninth president.

title: Advertising; Campaign for Wine Coolers
description: THE Canandaigua Wine Company of Canandaigua, N.Y., has so far managed to succeed where a lot of other small- and medium-sized beverage companies have failed: in establishing itself as a major player in the booming wine cooler business.

title: Penn Central Plan To Spin Off Unit
description: The Penn Central Corporation said its board had authorized management to develop a plan to spin off to shareholders a new company that would consist principally of the Marathon Manufacturing Company.

title: JAPAN EASING ENTRY OF U.S. DRUG ITEMS
description: Japan will accept foreign clinical test data in approving the sale of pharmaceuticals and will ease the transfer of manufacturing licenses within Japan under agreements announced today to widen access of American companies to the Japanese market.

title: Mesa Used Oil Futures Shrewdly
description: It was shrewd financial maneuvers that elevated T. Boone Pickens to national prominence, but Mr. Pickens evidently has not lost his touch in the oil business.

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $5,630,000 on the sale of the company's bulletin board business. c-Net loss.

title: SHCHARANSKY TO BE RELEASED IN A BERLIN EXCHANGE TODAY
description: Swans and ducks paddled among chunks of ice in the Havel River under the green metal spans of the Glienicke Bridge today. Occasionally, an American or French military vehicle would rumble across the bridge from Potsdam, making a seemingly effortless transit from a Soviet command post behind the Berlin wall to the American sector of West Berlin.

title: NASA OFFICIALS' INQUIRY FOCUSING ON HOW WARNINGS WERE HANDLED
description: The Presidential commission studying the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger is now focusing on how the space agency handled warnings of problems, Administration officials close to the investigation said today.

title: ROBERTSON, H H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary losses of $9,034,000 for the quarter and $11,284,000 for the year. c-Net income

title: ISOMEDIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LARGEST MAFIA TRIAL OPENS IN SICILY
description: The men accused of building the Sicilian Mafia into a global criminal enterprise went on trial today along with hundreds of others accused of serving as their agents, gunmen and couriers.

title: Structures That Adapt
description: A professor of civil engineering at the State University of New York at Buffalo is exploring the possibility of building ''active'' structures that, like a person in a high wind, would adjust their shape to avoid damage. The concept, he says, could be applicable to high-rise buildings, nuclear power plants, deep-water drilling rigs, radio telescopes and structures in space.

title: NETS' RICHARDSON SAID TO BE MISSING
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, the Net guard who spent nearly three weeks in a California rehabilitation facility after an admitted drug relapse in December, was missing from the team yesterday after calling in sick for a practice, then missing a scheduled appointment with a doctor.

title: Anderson, Clayton Chief Slimming Operations
description: W. Fenton Guinee has been president and chief executive of Anderson, Clayton & Company, which among other products makes Seven Seas salad dressing and Chiffon margarine, since only April 1985. But over the last 10 months the 57-year-old Mr. Guinee has moved fast. To a great extent, he had no other choice.

title: Cray Research Offering Rated
description: In advance of its debut in the public debt market, Cray Research Inc. received a Ba-1 rating from Moody's for its proposed $100 million issue of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bell Atlantic Mobile Systems, the cellular subsidiary of Bell Atlantic Corp., said it had filed for approval from the F.C.C. to provide cellular mobile telephone service in Trenton and Atlantic City.

title: ATTEMPT TO TEST WRITING SKILLS SPURS DEBATE
description: IN the next 11 months, 13,700 students now in the 11th grade in Maryland will have to pass a statewide writing test to be eligible to graduate next year. The test has already been passed by 41,000 of their classmates.

title: NEW CROSBY GOLF IS BACK TO BASICS
description: Bing Crosby's name will be associated with golf again in the way he originally wanted when he started his own golf tournament in 1937, his widow says.

title: C. LEIGH DIMOND
description: C. Leigh Dimond, a retired marketing vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau in Manhattan, died of cardiac arrest Saturday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: Teaching and Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: HEIST, C H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $14 million. c-After net from discontinued operations of $17.3 million for the quarter and $36 million for the year. d-After net from discontinued operations of $43.5 million, an extraordinary credit of $16.4 million and a gain from cumulative effect of a change in accounting method of $11.8 million. Textron said the results reflect the acquisition of Avco Corp. in January 1985.

title: PUNCTURE OF LARGE FUEL TANK BY PIVOTING BOOSTER IS CITED
description: After the Challenger's right booster rocket malfunctioned, its base tore away from the huge tank carrying volatile fuels and the rocket's nose, pivoting, punctured the tank and caused the space shuttle's explosion, according to Aviation Week and Space Technology.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $300 million of floating-rate notes due Aug. 14, 1986, at a price of par, through various securities dealers.

title: SUBURBS ARE A MAGNET TO MANY HOMOSEXUALS
description: Many of New York's homosexuals - for years in the forefront of social upheaval - are now adopting more traditional lives outside the city, where they are quietly slipping into the fabric of suburban and small-town life, researchers and other experts say.

title: Hawaiian Folk Artists To Give Two Concerts
description: A group of Hawaiian folk artists will offer two concerts of traditional music and dance at Carnegie Recital Hall, Saturday night at 8:30 and midnight. Representative Daniel K. Akaka of Hawaii will be master of ceremonies for the two performances, which feature Kamaki Kanahele and Company and Mahina Bailey in chants and dances; Jimmy Kaina singing traditional songs, in English, and Clyde Sproat and Karin Haleamau singing Hawaiian-language songs accompanied by slack-key guitar and ukulele.

title: A CITY COMPUTER CONTRACT THAT HAD NO CONNECTIONS
description: Carol Felstein was recommended for her first management job with New York City not by a functionary in a political clubhouse but by a fellow player in a tournament ''Scrabble'' league.

title: One More Time
description: Stu Starner, Montana State's basketball coach, after a 25-point upset of Northern Arizona: ''I'm surprised. I know I'm not surprised to be surprised, but I'm surprised.''

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $19 million for the quarter and $241 million for the year. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: OIL RALLY FAILS, BUOYING WALL STREET
description: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products opened strongly, but then slumped sharply yesterday on world markets as a tentative two-day attempt to sustain a rally sank under a barrage of bearish news.

title: TENANTS LEADER FACING CHARGES IN BRIBERY CASE
description: Federal prosecutors announced extortion and embezzlement charges yesterday against the former head of a council that represented all tenants in housing projects of the New York City Housing Authority.

title: MARTIN PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $483,000 for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit and a tax credit of $1,142,000 for the year and after a provision of $1,329,000 for the quarter for the termination of certain textile and carpet yarn operations. c-Net income. d-Including tax credits of $655,000 for the quarter and $1,350,000 for the year.

title: REAGAN PRAISES 2-PARTY-SYSTEM OF PHILIPPINES
description: President Reagan reserved judgment today on reports of fraud by supporters of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the Philippine election, and called on both sides to ''work together to form a viable government.''

title: Jury Deliberates In Georgia Case
description: A Federal court jury began deliberations today in the lawsuit of a former University of Georgia instructor who charged she was dismissed from her job because she protested preferential treatment for athletes.

title: A NEW DATA BASE MANAGER WITH FLEXIBILITY
description: THERE'S a marked trend in today's software toward combining ease of use with power, as if the software developers have finally come to the realization that people must actually be able to use the programs they concoct.

title: HADRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains of $204,000 for the quarter and $402,000 for the 9 months from investment income derived from a partnership. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $211,496 for the quarter and $347,837 for the 9 months. d-Net loss.

title: 5 Plead Guilty in Case Of School Vigilantes
description: Five teen-agers pleaded guilty today to participating in a vigilante group that said it was trying to fight crime and drug use by such tactics as threatening students and bombing cars.

title: OCCIDENTAL FALLS 71.4%
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings plunged 71.4 percent from the 1984 period, when the company had a large gain from the sale of geothermal operations.

title: More Honors for Ditka
description: For the second time in three weeks, Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears became a big winner. The coach of the Super Bowl champions headed the list of 11 former all-America football players who were named to the National Football Foundation Hall of Fame's Collegiate Class of 1986.

title: ALEXIS OBOLENSKY
description: Prince Alexis Obolensky, a member of a Russian emigre family and president of the World Backgammon Club, an organization in Manhattan that sponsors international tournaments, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Whither Here
description: Two political fixtures in Washington will definitely be leaving office this year, and what better excuse for throwing $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinners?

title: New Type of Eurobond Is Offered for Gannett
description: After a flurry of successful offerings in the American bond market last week, officials at Shearson Lehman Brothers have introduced to the Eurobond market an unusual kind debt security called ''step-up coupon puttable bonds.''

title: May Stores Announces Executive Reshuffling
description: The May Department Stores Company, the nation's third-largest department store retailing chain, announced a reshuffling of veteran executives at three of its department store divisions.

title: Arrested in India In Protests Over Prices
description: At least 900 opposition party workers were arrested here today during a widely observed daylong work stoppage called to protest price increases.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1.1 million for the quarter and $5 million for the year. The year-ago results were restated to reflect a change from the full cost to the successful effort method of accounting for oil and gas operations.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $18,346,000, or 39 cents a share.

title: U.S. INDIAN SAYS SANDINISTAS BOMB VILLAGES
description: Three North American Indian activists denounced the Nicaraguan Government today and said they would step up their activities against it.

title: WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Shamrock Purchases Stake in Foote, Cone
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc., an investment company controlled by the Disney family, said yesterday that it had purchased a 5.2 percent stake in Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Shamrock said it had purchased the shares for ''investment purposes,'' but added that it might seek representation on the advertising agency's board.

title: Oh, to Breathe in Nassau County . . .
description: ''Ventilation in most restaurants is now so good that smoking doesn't cause a problem.'' So said Fred Sampson, president of the New York State Restaurant Association last year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE. The Making of the British Intelligence

title:
Careers;
Harm Seen In Gothic Romances
description: THERE are too few good novels about working women and too many bad, overromanticized ones, according to Dr. Gayle Greene, a California teacher and writer. For women starting careers Dr. Greene has a warning: Avoid paperback romances because most are ''quack medicine,'' dangerous to career planning.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOUTH PACIFIC Thousands of Americans came to know Papua, New Guinea, in the least benevolent circumstances of World War II, when they fought there. Before and after their visit, New Guinea and its nearby islands have been the preserve of students interested in the people and their customs. The fruit of such exploration is now on view in the Bronx, in the Lehman College Art Gallery, in the college's Fine Arts Building, at Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue.

title: NEW RULES FOR INVESTORS IN LISTING CAPITAL GAINS
description: For millions of investors, 1985 was a richly rewarding year in the stock and bond markets, which means profit-takers will have a bundle of taxes to pay by April 15.

title: MILENA CANONERO: FASHION ON AND OFF THE BIG SCREEN
description: A young woman searched the lobby of a theater showing the film ''Out of Africa'' one recent night, turned to her companion and said, ''If they had a concession stand selling the clothes in this movie, I'd buy a whole new wardrobe.''

title: COMMON CAUSE TIES TAX REVISION TO INCREASE IN GIFTS TO CAMAPIGNS
description: It remains to be seen what the tax-revision bill making its way through Congress will mean for taxpayers, but it appears to have eased considerably the fund-raising burden of members of the tax-writing committees in the House and the Senate, according to a study made public today by Common Cause, the public affairs lobby.

title: CENTER FOR ARTS TO OPEN IN A PALACE IN VENICE
description: A new center for the arts will open in a restored palace on the Grand Canal in Venice in May, becoming perhaps the largest corporate-sponsored arts institution in Europe, it was announced yesterday.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $442,000 for the quarter and $1,272,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $274,000 for the quarter and $1,103,000 for the year.

title: THE 'PLUS' IN MACINTOSH
description: IT is time to burrow through the mound of mail that accumulated during the busy Groundhog Day week. From Apple

title: Kaiser Loses Court Ruling
description: An investment group led by Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., said it had won a court order in Federal District Court here compelling the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation's chairman, Cornell C. Maier, to testify regarding details of the company's planned restructuring and debt refinancing.

title: HOME BENEFICIAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $44,473. c-After a capital loss of $59,104 and an extraordinary gain of $9.6 million.

title: FINNIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $318,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $771,000, or 16 cents a share, for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $398,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: COPYTELE: WALL ST. BARRLEFIELD
description: The annals of Wall Street are replete with classic battles between the bulls and the bears. But rarely has such a trading frenzy erupted in such a small stock as Copytele Inc., one of the hottest over-the-counter issues of 1985.

title: OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JACLYN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net income

title: West Virginia Jury Indicts Attorney General
description: The State Attorney General was indicted today on eight misdemeanor counts of violating state election laws by soliciting funds from employees to pay a campaign debt.

title: K.G.B. SUBVERSION TACTICS DESCRIBED
description: There was a time when a Western correspondent arriving in Moscow might have been told, that, regrettably, no apartment was available; he must live in a hotel.

title: OF FAT HEADS AND CATERPILLARS
description: ANIMALS that eat grass, which is more fibrous and harder to chew than most foods, tend to have chisel-like teeth and other special features in their jaws.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Carmine Abbatiello became the second harness driver to win more than $40 million in career purses when he steered Manfred Hanover to victory last night in the Su Mac Lad Trot at Meadowlands Race Track. The triumph pushed Abbatiello's total to $40,007,820. He trails only Herve Filion, who has earned more than $47 million in purses.

title: BUBKA JOINS FIELD FOR MILLROSE VAULT
description: The confrontation among Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union and Billy Olson and Joe Dial of the United States, who have broken the world indoor best in the pole vault seven times in the last six weeks, will take place earlier than expected. It will be Friday night in the Wanamaker Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden.

title: McNair Scholarship Fund
description: Carl McNair Sr. spent many years in New York running an automobile-repair shop in East Harlem.

title: BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 21
description: b-Including a gain of $137,000 from discontinued opererations.

title: LA PETITE ACADEMY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 25 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 31, 1986.

title: ANCHORAGE'S OLYMPIC BID
description: It's the best American city nobody knows. Anchorage is up there in Alaska, the last frontier. Moose graze in backyards and whales float in the Cook Inlet harbor in the shadow of new glass-and-steel office buildings. Anchorage's population is nearly 250,000 now and it describes itself as the ''air crossroads of the world.'' In a city equidistant from London, Tokyo and Houston, jets from 20 international and national airlines rumble in and out of the airport after refueling on the way to the Orient, Europe and the Lower 48.

title: ANHEUSER GAINS 10.2%
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies, the nation's largest brewer, said today that its fourth-quarter net income rose 10.2 percent, despite intense competition in the beer industry.

title: Punish the Prosecutors in Unjust Convictions
description: To the Editor:

title: South Yemen Reports Ex-Chief Died in Battle
description: The new Government in Southern Yemen announced today that former President Abdul Fattah Ismail died within hours after fighting broke out Jan. 13 in the Marxist Arab nation.

title: C.I.A.'S SECURITY WAS LAX, ACCCORDING TO CONVICTED SPY
description: Larry Wu-Tai Chin, the former C.I.A. analyst convicted last week of spying for China for 30 years, said today that it was ''easy'' to evade the Central Intellience Agency's security procedures and steal reams of classified documents.

title: Q & A
description: Q. By what method did Voyager 2 take photographs of Uranus and its moons?

title: 2 Top 3M Posts Go To Domestic Head
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that Allen F. Jacobson, president of the concern's domestic operations, had been named chairman and chief executive, effective March 1.

title: CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $48,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $93,000 for the 6 months. c-Net losses including a gain of $162,000 from the forgiveness of debt for the year.

title: DROPOUTS: HORACE MANN WAS WRONG
description: TEACHERS COLLEGE RECORD, the quarterly published by Teachers College at Columbia University, will devote its entire spring issue to the problem of high school dropouts.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: CATHERINE de CASTELBAJAC breezed into the exhibition hall at the Fashion Institute of Technology last Friday morning, wrapped in a blanket coat of azure blue and green and lugging several canvas bags. ''I'm bringing the bags for the exhibition,'' she said. ''I have no more clothes to give. They're all in the show. It's wonderful. I'm just overjoyed.''

title: Fourth-and-Long At a Small School
description: The football team at Mississippi Valley State University has averaged more than 50 points a game the last two years with a bombs-away offense that has frequently been described as ahead of its time. Until a reprieve last week, however, it looked as if Valley's time might in fact be a thing of the past. Even now, there are no guarantees that the school can survive for long.

title: IOWA-ILLINOIS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DANCE: CHUCK DAVIS
description: THE Chuck Davis Dance Company honored Charles Moore with a performance Saturday night in the Triplex Performing Arts Center of the Borough of Manhattan Community College. Mr. Moore, who died Jan. 23, was a dancer and choreographer noted for his sensitive reconstructions of African dances. Therefore it was only appropriate that this tribute consisted of works adapted from African sources.

title: INTECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest year include a $7.6 million provision for excess and obsolete inventory taken in the second quarter.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a DISC tax credit of $425,000.

title: SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIRMINGHAM STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENTRAL LOUISIANA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Strangling Superfund With Affection
description: Toxic chemicals leak into the water supply from thousands of abandoned dumps around the country. Five years of the Superfund, the Federal program to clean up the dumps, has barely scratched the surface. Yet within weeks the Environmental Protection Agency will have to wind down even this program, for lack of funds.

title: 4 Given Up for Drowned
description: The Coast Guard said today that four people missing after a large wave struck the 65-foot fishing-party boat Merry Jane Saturday were presumed to have drowned, along with five others.

title: Dow Hits 1,626.38, Another Record
description: Interest rates and oil prices declined again yesterday, pushing share prices on Wall Street sharply higher and sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its third consecutive record close.

title: Shopwell Reports Three Overtures
description: Shopwell Inc., the Bronx-based supermarket chain, said three companies had approached it in the last few weeks to express interest in acquiring the chain.

title: IEC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eastern Attendants Ask $33 Million in Back Pay
description: Eastern Airlines flight attendants asked a Federal district judge today to award them $33 million in back pay they contend was illegally deducted from their paychecks in 1985.

title: AMERICAN CARRIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $6,221,000 for the quarter and $12,747,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1986
description: Companies

title: Michael Smith
description: This part of the country invites flight, with its warm, buoyant air currents and table-flat fields ready-made for landing strips. The wide Atlantic sky is speckled with motion, from the graceful dance of sea birds to the sharp, swift flight of military aircraft.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BERRY SCORES 22 AS REDMEN WIN
description: Walter Berry put an end to two days of speculation over his injured left ankle with an overpowering performance tonight.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OIL SLUMP LIFTS BOND PRICES
description: After languishing most of the day, prices of debt securities rose sharply in midafternoon to end yesterday with gains of as much as 7/8 point for recently auctioned 30-year Treasury bonds.

title: Reagan News Parley Is Televised Tonight
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference tonight to be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks and on CNN, the Cable News Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS will carry the conference, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast. Channel 13 in New York City, for example, will broadcast the conference at 12:30 A.M.

title: WIDENING CHICAGO INQUIRY PARALLELS NEW YORK CITY'S
description: In a situation with parallels to New York City's parking fines scandal, major investigations into the awarding of city contracts here are widening.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS AND LOAN ASSN (SAN DIEGO, CALIF) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,714,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and year, from a dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in the form of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock. Revenue figures represent total investment revenue.

title: Cardinals Name Coach
description: Gene Stallings, an assistant with the Cowboys since 1972, was named head coach of the St. Louis Cardinals, whose entire coaching staff was dismissed 15 minutes after the team ended last season with a 5-11 record. ''It's been a long search and I've talked to a lot of fine football coaches and fine men,'' William V. Bidwill, the owner of the Cardinals, said.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest results include operations of CMX Corporation and Digital Services Corporation. Share earnings have been adjusted for the 10 percent stock dividend of Aug. 15, 1985.

title: Gorbachev's Preference for Technocrats
description: On the eve of the Soviet Communist Party Congress, scheduled to begin Feb. 25, the world is watching for hints about what kind of reform program Mikhail S. Gorbachev intends to pursue. So far, Mr. Gorbachev's leadership appears to be managerial and reformist. But reformism in the case of the new Soviet leaders has nothing in common with liberalism -a connection too often made erroneously in the West.

title: CITY BALLET: 'SLAUGHTER' AND 'SONATINE'
description: IN ''Slaughter on Tenth Avenue,'' which the New York City Ballet presented Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater, George Balanchine viewed some of ballet's classics in comic-strip terms.

title: MUSEUMS REVIVING 'PICASSO' FILM, A FAILURE IN '57
description: ''The Mystery of Picasso,'' which was a resounding failure in America in 1957, is being shown at art museums around the country this month in preparation for re-release in art theaters this spring to what the distributor hopes is a more sophisticated public.

title: Individualist in the Armada
description: Among the armada of tall ships in New York Harbor during the Fourth of July rededication of the Statue of Liberty will be the Calida, a 135-foot, fully rigged vessel representing Scotland.

title: QUANTUM THEORY: DISTURBING QUESTIONS REMAIN UNRESOLVED
description: WOULD a falling tree make a sound if no observer were present to hear it? Does anything in the universe have a real existence independent of the act of observation, and if so, what does ''real'' mean? Could a ''reality'' prevailing at one point in the universe instantaneously reflect a change in a corresponding ''reality'' at some astronomically distant point?

title: Crispo Sentenced to 7 Years For Evasion of Income Taxes
description: Andrew Crispo, the Manhattan art dealer who was implicated in but never charged in the sadomasochistic slaying of a Norwegian art student, was sentenced yesterday to seven years in prison for tax evasion.

title: Newspaper Challenging Federal Court Order
description: The Providence Journal ignored a Federal court order barring publication of an article about the family of a reputed crime figure because the newspaper believed the order violated constitutional guarantees of a free press, the executive editor testified today.

title: FOR AMERICANS IN HAITI, DAYS OF FEAR AND FASCINATION
description: Margaret Vanka sat ensconced in her peacock wicker chair and declared the veranda of the Grand Hotel Oloffson ''a wonderful place to watch this revolution.''

title:
3 BOYS' DREAMS OF SPACE, 3 DEATHS IN THE SKY;
Ellison Onizuka
description: Growing up on the Kona coast of Hawaii, Ellison Shoji Onizuka picked coffee beans, played basketball and dreamed of hurtling through space in an imaginary supercharged craft.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring charges of $486 million, or $1.63 a share. c-Net income d-After the nonrecurring charges related to Fairchild Semiconductor announced in the second and fourth quarters totaling $511 million, or $1.71 a share. The acquisition in 1984 of 50 percent of Dowell operations in North America, and of Sedco increased revenue for 1985 by $435 million. The Sedco acquisiton reduced 1985 earnings by 33 cents a share. The nonrecurring charges relate to Fairchild Semiconductor and include the fourth quarter charge of $486 million consisting of the writeoff of the balance of goodwill of $250 million, a provision of $106 million for disposal of certain assets, and $81 million for the consolidation of certain production facilities. For the fourth quarter, the acquisition of Sedco increased revenue by $71 million and reduced earnings by 12 cents a share.

title: LONE STAR STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $89 million for the quarter and year for a writedown of assets.

title: Chess:With Unorthodox Openings, Ubilava Takes a Major Title
description: The international master Elizbar Ubilava of the Soviet Union won the Trencianske Teplice International Tournament in Czechoslovakia. His 10-5 score also earned him a norm toward the grandmaster title.

title: Fox of Iroquois Reduces Stake
description: Terence J. Fox, chief executive officer of Iroquois Brands Ltd. who has been accused of possessing cocaine, said today that he had reduced his stake in the company to 21.4 percent from 23 percent.

title: ENDOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SALE OF ALASKA OFFSHORE OIL OPPOSED
description: An alliance of Eskimos, fishermen, environmentalists and eight coastal states, including Alaska, is preparing for the second round of a lawsuit to keep offshore oil rigs out of Federal waters near Bristol Bay, said to be the richest salmon fishery in the world.

title: BRITTON LEE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $176,000 for the quarter and including an extraordinary tax credit of $889,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $456,000 for the quarter and $1,612,000 for the year.

title: 'SECRET LANGUAGE' FOUND IN ELEPHANTS
description: ELEPHANTS emit low-frequency vocal sounds, inaudible to man, that may be used as a ''secret'' language to communicate with other members of a herd over both long and short distances, researchers at Cornell University have discovered.

title: STUDY OF ROCKETS BY AIR FORCE SAID RISKS WERE 1 IN 35
description: A report received by the space agency two years ago sharply criticized safety planning for the space shuttle, saying the chance of a catastrophic accident involving the solid-fuel booster rockets was 1 in 35.

title: Salvadorans Call a Strike To Protest Carter Visit
description: Right-wing businesses called a two-hour strike today to protest a visit by former President Jimmy Carter, who is on a tour of Central America.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing on Thursday of programs that President Reagan proposed to drop in his 1987 budget misstated the amount of savings anticipated if filling of the strategic petroleum reserve were suspended. It is $399 million in 1987 and $371 million in 1991.

Advertising; Sales Executive at ABC
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday named John B. Watkins president of ABC television spot sales. Mr. Watkins, who had been general sales manager for WABC-TV since 1981, succeeds Walter K. Flynn, who resigned last month. Mr. Watkins will be responsible for providing national sales representation for the four television stations owned by ABC: WABC in New York, KABC-TV in Los Angeles, WLS-TV in Chicago and KGO-TV in San Francisco.

title: COLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Action for Old-Timers
description: There will be plenty of baseball action this summer for such former stars as Warren Spahn, Whitey Ford, Bob Gibson and Brooks Robinson. A series of old-timers' games will be played at major league ball parks to raise funds for former ballplayers not covered by the current pension system.

title: Coast Power Unit Sets Bond Sale
description: The Southern California Public Power Agency is offering $180 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 8.37 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

description: b-Including tax credits of $151,000 for the quarter and $305,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,179,131 for the quarter and $2,798,718 for the 9 months.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1986
description: International The Philippine presidential election was put to the National Assembly for certification after three days of violence and widespread reports of vote-rigging by backers of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Both President Marcos, whose forces dominate Parliament, and Corazon C. Aquino have claimed victory. [ Page A1, Col. 1. ]

title: Pentagon; Passing the Cerebral Ammunition
description: What is Caspar W. Weinberger's defense strategy?

title: STAGE AND FILM STAR ADMIRED FOR SUAVITY
description: Brian Aherne, a British-born actor who played the classic handsome leading man in films and on stage, died yesterday at Venice (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 83 years old and had been living at his winter home in Boca Grande. He also had homes in Vevey, Switzerland, and New York City.

title: Motorola Studied Toshiba Venture
description: Motorola Inc. acknowledged that it had studied the possibility of a joint venture between its semiconductor unit and that of Toshiba, the Japanese electronics manufacturer.

title: Interface Buys A Competitor
description: Interface Group Inc., an operator of chartered vacations and computer trade shows, said it had acquired International Weekends, a large charter vacation company based in Boston.

title: Westland Rejects Offer by European Group
description: Shareholders of Britain's Westland helicopter company today spurned an offer to sell their holdings to a West European consortium, clearing the way for the giant American helicopter company, Sikorsky, to buy into the company.

title: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
War of Wallets
description: If a day's wage and a day's work are tightly linked, then a close N.B.A. All-Star Game was probably inevitable: The Eastern Conference squad that edged the West by 7 points at Dallas on Sunday was also a narrow winner in the war of the wallets, averaging $1,022,916.60 in annual salary, to the West's $1,022,520.80, for a pocket-change difference of $395.80.

title: Market Place; Many Eyes On Microsoft
description: THE Microsoft Corporation, a leader in the personal computer-software industry, plans to go public next month, selling 2.5 million shares. Its reception in the marketplace, according to industry followers, could determine whether a host of other prospective new issues related to computers will see the light of day later this year.

title: FRIEDMAN HEADS BRONX BUSINESS AID
description: A Bronx economic development group that oversees multimillion-dollar Federal, state and city loans and grants to business concerns is headed by Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and a political associate whose qualifications have been questioned by the City Comptroller.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Successful Surgery
description: The Knicks announced that the surgery on Pat Cummings's right ankle was successful, but that the forward would still be out for the remainder of the season. The Knicks also announced that Patrick Ewing, who has a sore knee, was on a day-to-day basis.

title: History for Sale, $41,000 per Stick
description: Ethel S. Garrett will celebrate her 90th birthday next May with a ceremony that she has been awaiting for more than a quarter-century.

title: Topics; Setting Two Examples
description: Quiet Courage Had they not chosen to take a cruise on an Italian liner called the Achille Lauro last fall, Leon and Marilyn Klinghoffer might have lived out their lives as quietly as most Americans. But the wheelchair-bound Mr. Klinghoffer was shot by Palestinian terrorists who hijacked the ship; suddenly an aging stroke victim and his grief-scarred wife became known to the world.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $187,000. c-Net loss, including tax credits of $6,589,000.

title: SOUTHWESTERN ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After pre-tax provisions for restructuring costs and asset writedowns of $23 million for the quarter, $96,105,000 for the year. c-Net income including tax credits of $1,801,000 for the quarter, $4,768,000 for the year. Prior year results have been restated to deconsolidate the Clark Michigan Co. to reflect the investment on the equity method of accounting. The change had no effect on net income.

title: MANILA ASSEMBLY MEETS TO DECIDE ELECTION OUTCOME
description: After three days of violence and widespread reports of vote-rigging, the Philippine presidential election was put to the National Assembly on Monday evening for certification. But within minutes, legislators began arguing over procedure, and their official vote count was postponed until today.

title: 'FRONTLINE' VISITS RUSSIA
description: WHAT is the Soviet Union really like? Our television picture is muddled.

title: Hormel Plant Resumes Some Production Work
description: For the first time since meatpackers began a bitter strike nearly six months ago, hog slaughtering resumed here today at Geo. A. Hormel & Company's flagship plant.

title: EXXON'S TIME OF OPPORTUNITY
description: When John D. Rockefeller, a young partner in a produce business in Cleveland, ventured into the oil business in 1863, the industry was in the midst of a disastrous glut, with wildly fluctuating prices and wholesale bankruptcies. Mr. Rockefeller saw opportunity in the chaos, and by 1882 he had established the Standard Oil Trust, the leviathan that eventually gave birth to the modern Exxon Corporation.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 11, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the Situation in Southern Africa at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SHOREHAM DRILL BACKED IN COURT
description: A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction today barring Suffolk County from enforcing a local law designed to block an emergency preparedness drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Whither Wachtmeister?
description: After 12 years as Swedish Ambassador to the United States, Count Wilhelm Wachtmeister is said by friends to be preparing to leave his post. The Count said yester-day that he would not be able to comment on the matter for a week or two. Given his considerable skills and extraordinary length of tenure, his departure would create a void in the Washington worlds of both diplomacy and tennis.

title: BASEBALL TROUBLE IS BREWING
description: Never say television doesn't have a heart. Just when baseball junkies needed a fix to ward off snowstorms and back-and-forth winter sports, the folks in TV-land have come through. Like robins heralding spring, television has reminded us that pitchers and catchers are packing their bags by engaging in two contract disputes over the coming season.

title: The Last Chance?
description: Foreign ministers of the most important Latin American nations met yesterday in Washington with George Shultz in what may have been the last chance to move the Reagan Administration away from a military and toward a negotiated settlement in Central America.

title: Oil Snags Mexico's I.M.F. Bid
description: Mexico's efforts to obtain new loans from the International Monetary Fund have almost ground to a halt because of the drop in oil prices, commercial bankers said today. They added that it could be months before an agreement was reached.

title: TECHAMERICA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Cloud of Black Holes
description: A Yale University astronomer suggests that the Milky Way Galaxy is enveloped in a gigantic cloud of black holes. He envisions two modes of star formation, one of which, early in the history of the galaxy, produced the giant stars that have now collapsed, forming the hypothetical cloud of black holes.

title: Life in a Beige Office
description: ELIZABETH HOLTZMAN has just admitted she sometimes has fun. The stern, 44-year-old Brooklyn District Attorney reluctantly mentions opera, music, the movies and a circle of friends.

title: RULING ON BUDGET STIRS UNCERTAINTY
