description: A Federal court decision striking down a key provision of the new budget-balancing law leaves the Congressional budget process in a state of uncertainty and confusion, according to legislators and Reagan Administration officials.

title: ARCHEOLOGIST AND INDIANS AGAINST BULLDOZERS
description: Next week leaders of the Hopi and Pueblo tribes are expected to purify a 750-year-old pit house on Albuquerque's West Side before bulldozers move in to clear land for a new state road. Meanwhile, an archeologist is scraping away at the ancient dwelling, collecting potsherds and other artifacts.

title: Western Union Charge
description: The Western Union Corporation, the large telecommunications concern, said yesterday that it would take a $300 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings and that it expected to report a loss of about $370 million for the year.

title: ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $3,314,000 from an exchange of common shares for Treasury stock.

title: Colgate to Cut 250 From Staff
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said it was eliminating 250 salaried positions from its corporate staff and its American household and personal-care operations.

title: Dick Scobee
description: When Dick Scobee went home to Auburn, Wash., for a family reunion in October, he told people that, with 109 astronauts in the shuttle program, his next flight into space might be his last. An aunt who was present, Naomi Allen, recalls that her nephew, who had never wanted to be anything but an airplane pilot, was nonetheless content. ''He said he had acquired everything he wanted in life,'' she said.

title: Whither Fowler?
description: Mark S. Fowler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, says he has not made up his mind, but industry insiders and Congressional aides say he will probably not seek reappointment when his term expires in June.

title: Celtics Are Cruising on a 13-Game Streak
description: Red Auerbach has always considered the Boston Celtics, past and present, as part of a family.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Detroit Pistons, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Isiah Thomas, the most valuable player of Sunday's All-Star Game, and the Pistons have won two of the last three games with the Nets this season. Buck Williams is battling with Bill Laimbeer for the N.B.A. rebounding lead. The Pistons fly home after the game to meet the Knicks tomorrow night in Pontiac, Mich. (Television - SportsChannel, 11:45 P.M., tape delay. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) Golden State Warriors vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Oakland, Calif. (Television - WTBS, 7 P.M.) Colleges: Fordham at Notre Dame (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 8 P.M.); DePaul at Old Dominion (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.); City College at John Jay, 6 P.M.; Stony Brook at Hunter, 8 P.M.; Army at Manhattan, 8 P.M.; United States Merchant Marine Academy at Manhattanville, 8 P.M.; Yeshiva at New York Maritime, 7:30 P.M.; Baruch at Kings, 8 P.M.; Pittsburgh at Connecticut, 8 P.M. Dogs 110th Westminster Kennel Club Show, at Madison Square Garden, 8:30 A.M. The 1,291 working, terrier, non-sporting and herding breeds will be benched and judged today, including the German shepherd that is the favorite for best in show, Ch. Covy Tucker Hill's Manhattan, the winner of 147 bests in 1985. (Television - MSG, 8 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Vancouver Canucks, at Uniondale, L.I., Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. The Islanders met the Canucks twice in the first month of the season but have not managed a victory against them this season.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from the sale of the radio stations of $1,733,000 for the quarter and $3,846,000 for the year, and after the losses related to the company's share of losses at MCCAW Communications Cos. of $2,002,000 for the quarter, $7,772,000 for the year. c-After losses related to the company's share of losses at MCCAW Communications of $1,358,000 for the quarter and $3,718,000 for the year. Share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock splits paid in January 1986 and January 1985.

title: CYCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: An accounting change increased net by $300,000 in the latest quarter and by $1.2 million in the latest year.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Topics; Setting Two Examples She Is Driven
description: ''I can confidently predict 100 percent attendance at all Republican caucuses.'' So joked Susan Molinari on being elected the first minority leader of New York's City Council since 1983.

title: INNOVEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KARAN'S SUMMER SLEEKNESS
description: With her summer collection, Donna Karan continues the sleek, sophisticated look she initiated for fall, extending the boundaries of sportswear. When she showed her first collection under her own name last May, her draped sarong skirts and body suits looked like a fashion breakthrough. Now they have become familiar. They also have been widely copied, a sure sign of acceptance. Her summer clothes are a natural extension of the ideas she proposed just eight months ago.

title: Eisenhower Heard From
description: For his 10th book, the award-winning biographer Robert J. Donovan has come across a bit of news that is bound to stimulate a great deal of curiosity that, alas, will probably not be satisfied for most people alive today.

title: Hotel Blaze Kills 24 At a Japanese Resort
description: Fire raged through a seaside hotel early today, trapping and killing 24 people, the authorities said.

title: GIBSON, C R, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring reversal of federal income taxes of $157,000 due to the Tax Reform Act of 1984.

title: KEAN PROPOSES STUDY OF FUNDS FOR EDUCATION
description: While proposing major increases in spending for education in his annual budget message, Governor Kean today called upon the State Board of Education to give an accounting ''in the near future'' of how the billions of dollars are being spent.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editing change arising from ambiguity in the author's manucript led to an error Feb. 4 in ''A Morality Test for South Africa's Opposition,'' by Gregory A. Fossedal. The published article said Bishop Desmond M. Tutu had solicited funds for the African National Congress with leaflets extolling Muammar el-Qaddafi and Daniel Ortega Saavedra. Some people at a Stanford rally handed out such leaflets, apparently without the bishop's assent.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period

title: JAPANESE-AMERICAN WINS INTERNMENT APPEAL
description: A Federal district judge today overturned the 1943 conviction of a Japanese-American who defied Government orders for internment in World War II.

title: Foreign Infringement on U.S. Process Patents
description: To the Editor:

title: A QUIRK AIDS LAW AT BRIDGE
description: To the millions of drivers who cross the Delaware Memorial Bridge in a year the short stretch leading to the New Jersey Turnpike is notable only for the sweeping vista framed by the twin suspension bridges.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a deferred gain of $7.3 million, or 31 cents a share, related to the prior restructuring of Tosco's bank debt. Other significant adjustments included a LIFO inventory profit of $9.7 million, which was offset by both a $5.3 million writedown in assets, primarily energy-related, and a $5.5 million reserve for the proposed settlement of shareholder litigation. c-Net loss and includes a non-cash writedown of $131.7 million for the quarter. d-After tax credits of $1 million for the latest year and $2 million for the year-earlier period.

title: INFERTILITY: A GROWING ARRAY OF REMEDIES
description: THE technique that eight years ago produced the world's first ''test-tube'' baby is being modified and elaborated in ways undreamed of a few years ago. Prematurely menopausal women are giving birth. Embryos are being frozen to be thawed later and inserted into the womb. Mixtures of sperm and egg cells are being injected into the female reproductive system to undergo fertilization there. Sperm have been extracted surgically from a man's genitalia to fertilize an egg cell from his wife, leading to a normal pregnancy.

title: DIANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $12,268,000 for the quarter and $14,397,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a gain of $84,000 from discontinued operations and after an extraordinary charge of $1,308,000. d-Net income.

title: ROTO-ROOTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'VITAL SIGNS,' ON CBS
description: ONE in 10 doctors will become impaired by alcohol or drugs at some time during his career. That is the statistic, source undisclosed, providing the underpinnings for ''Vital Signs,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock. Edward Asner is Matthew, a hard-driving surgeon who refuses to recognize that he is an alcoholic. Gary Cole is David, a young doctor who has become addicted to amphetamines and morphine during his highly pressured student years. Their individual cases are certainly affecting but, apparently for purposes of convenient symmetry, Lee Hutson's script has decided to make them father and son. It is a severe case of familial overload.

title: PRETORIA REPORTS 10 BLACKS SLAIN
description: The police said today that 10 black people were slain over the weekend in what appeared to be largely the result of violence between rival black factions.

title: MASCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net charge of $27 million from a writedown of various oilfield assets. c-Net income.

title: IN MANILA: AND NOW?
description: Although the official outcome of the Philippine presidential election appears to be far from settled, most Filipinos from both parties believe that President Ferdinand E. Marcos, intends to remain in power by whatever means necessary.

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $1.5 million writeoff of inventory and a charge of $250,000 from the discontinuation of a product line.

title: FOR HEATED RIVALRY, CHEERING FADES
description: The New Rochelle High School cheerleaders did their best imitation of a crowd as the Mount Vernon basketball team arranged itself for a free throw, straining their lungs to shriek, ''Miss it.''

title: Beanpot Tourney to Boston U.
description: Boston University took a 3-1 first period lead, then checked Boston College into submission to win the 34th Beanpot hockey tournament, 4-1, before 14,451 fans tonight at Boston Garden.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ROBERT A. LOWE may or may not love New York. However, when it comes to the baseball-type caps the city's Transit Authority has been issuing to bus drivers, Mr. Lowe is full of more than mere token approval. He is, in fact, quite enthusiastic about these jaunty, navy-blue caps, each of which sports a patch emblazoned with the name or number of one of the city's 21 depots.

title: BAIL REQUEST IS DENIED FOR EX-JUDGE BRENNAN
description: A Federal judge rejected a request yesterday that former Justice William C. Brennan be allowed to remain free while appealing his conviction for taking bribes to fix criminal cases in State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, has elected to its board Roy A. Anderson, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Lockheed Corp.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF TESTIMONY AT HEARING ON SHUTTLE CATASTROPHE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, held in Washington yesterday by a Presidential investigating panel, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News.

title: 'CAN A GUY SAY NO?'
description: SCOTT TAUSCHER is 17 years old and, believing the greatly exaggerated tales of his friends, is convinced that he is the last high-school-senior virgin living in America. Having already alienated his regular girlfriend with pressures to go beyond kissing, Scott turns to the girl next door. He knows that Paula Finkle is ''loose'' because he has seen the O'Connor boy hastily climbing out of her bedroom window. Setting out to seduce Paula, Scott ends up being surprised about himself.

title: BALLET: CHANGE IN 'AUVERGNE'
description: DEL-LOUISE MOYER, an American mezzo-soprano who performs in Europe as well as the United States, stepped into the singing role in Peter Martins's new ballet ''Songs of the Auvergne'' Sunday night at the State Theater.

title: Commonwealth Edison Offering
description: Commonwealth Edison Company, the Chicago-based utility, is offering $150 million of 10 1/2 percent first mortgage bonds due 2016 at a price of 99 1/2, to yield 10.555 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Valentine's Day Valentine's Day is less than 48 hours way. While diamonds and rubies are all well and good, if you want to observe the most hallowed traditions surrounding the midwinter feast for lovers, you will give your honey sweets.

title: SMITH PERFECT IN GOAL
description: The Islanders, whose last five games have been decided by one goal, played the ultimate in low-scoring, close-checking games tonight as they defeated the Vancouver Canucks by 1-0 at Nassau Coliseum. The victory snapped Vancouver's seven-game unbeaten streak and brought the Islanders new confidence in their ability to handle pressure.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include the effect of the company's discontinued life insurance business.

title: Goodyear Net Declines 19.8%
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, citing a decline in foreign earnings and increased competition from lower-cost imported tires, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1985 fell 19.8 percent on a 2.5 percent rise in sales.

title: VIOLIST, 20, ATTAINS PHILHARMONIC POST
description: When the New York Philharmonic and the Juilliard Orchestra end their giant, 200-player concert at Avery Fisher Hall this evening, Zubin Mehta will turn to the audience and celebrate an unusual rite of passage. He will introduce from the players' ranks Rebecca Young, a 20-year-old student violist in the Juilliard Orchestra, who will become the Philharmonic's newest and youngest member.

title: Arab-Americans Urge Discrimination Inquiry
description: Arab-American leaders today asked the Federal Commission on Civil Rights to investigate ''an ugly, racist type of anti-Semitism'' against Americans of Arab descent.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DESPITE dozens of public pronouncements about the nature of AIDS and how it is and is not transmitted, myths and fears about this fast-growing public health menace continue to grow, accompanied at times by panic and hysteria.

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $111.1 million for the latest year and $50.1 million for the prior year.

title: COL. JOSEPH MURPHY, FOUNDER OF SCHOOL PRESS GROUP, DIES
description: Col. Joseph M. Murphy, the founder of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association, died Monday at York (Me.) Community Hospital, near his home in Ogunquit. He was 87 years old.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Higher Profile
description: Spud Webb, the Atlanta Hawks' 5-foot-7-inch rookie guard, earns the National Basketball Association's minimum salary, $75,000, and has only one endorsement contract, with a sneaker company. But after winning the league's slam-dunk competition in Dallas last Saturday, he may become as big, in a manner of speaking, as William Perry.

title: NBC NEWS MAY ADOPT 90-MINUTE 'NEWSWHEEL'
description: NBC News is considering a plan to replace its 30-minute ''Nightly News'' program with a 90-minute broadcast package that would enable individual stations to blend network news with local news in one program, the network acknowledged yesterday.

title: Strauss Retires At Internorth
description: HNG/Internorth Inc. said yesterday that Willis A. Strauss, 63 years old, had retired as chairman and board member, effective immediately. As expected, Kenneth L. Lay, 43, the president and chief executive, was named to succeed Mr. Strauss.

title: Warning: Have a Nice Day
description: The Federal bureaucracy has rarely displayed much concern for niceties of language, so perhaps we should not be surprised that one of the four Surgeon General's warnings now on cigarette packages and advertising turns out not to be a warning at all. To warn, according to Webster's New World Dictionary, is ''to tell of a danger, coming evil, misfortune.'' Three of the warnings deal with dangers to pregnancy, lung cancer and carbon monoxide poisoning, but the fourth reads: ''Surgeon General's Warning: Quitting smoking now greatly reduces serious risks to your health.''

title: HAVING CHILDREN DESPITE ILLNESS
description: A PORTABLE respirator is in Dorothea Ridenour's bedroom, a $2,500 device that strapped the family budget and was unnecessary until the birth of her son four years ago. In those four years, there have been dozens of trips to the hospital for Mrs. Ridenour, a 28-year-old victim of cystic fibrosis; dozens of times when her son, Charles Jr., stayed with his grandmother in a nearby Bronx apartment, and dozens of sleepless and terror-filled nights for her husband, Charles Sr., a Transit Authority flagman.

title: GLATFELTER, P H CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $24,574,000 on the sale of the West Carrollton, Ohio paper mill.

title: Shortcut Alternatives To Westway Studied
description: Consultants examining alternatives to Westway are looking into the possibility of a roadway that could be built without lengthy environmental-impact studies, the New York State Commissioner of Transportation said yesterday.

title: Terrorism and Tourism
description: Donna F. Tuttle, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Travel, believes foreign leaders must reassure the traveling public of their firm commitment to combat terrorism and insure visitors' safety abroad.

title: Artificial-Heart Patient Suffers Kidney Problem
description: The first person ever to receive two artificial hearts has developed a kidney problem and still shows signs of the flu virus that destroyed her natural heart, hospital officials said today.

title: Exits by Soviet Jews Remain at Low Level
description: Seventy-nine Jews were allowed to emigrate from the Soviet Union last month, the lowest number since August, according to the Geneva-based Intergovernmental Committee for Migration.

title: 2 Planes Avert Crash In Controller Error
description: A Delta Air Lines 727 had to drop 200 feet Monday to avoid an Eastern Airlines 727 after a controller mistakenly put the jetliners on a collision course, officials said today.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $45.4 million for the quarter, $59.5 million for the year, and after losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $29 million for the quarter, $43.1 million for the year. The year results also include a gain of $16.6 million on the sale of real estate. c-Including a gain of $2.1 million from joint venture sale of stock, a loss from discontinued operations of $56.5 million and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $120.8 million.

title: KOCH, IN REVERSAL, WILL REVIEW HIRING FOR HIGHER-PAYING POSTS
description: Mayor Koch, in a policy reversal, said yesterday that from now on, appointments of most higher-paid municipal employees would need his approval.

title: South Carolina Utility Issue
description: A $200 million tax-exempt bond issue for the South Carolina Public Service Authority was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 8 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2019, through underwriters led by the Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: A Debt Rating Review For Many Oil Concerns
description: Debt securities of many oil companies have been taking a beating as falling oil prices cause investors to worry about the companies' ability to service their debt.

title: Washington Opera To Do Menotti's 'Goya'
description: The Washington Opera announced today that it would present the premiere of Gian Carlo Menotti's long-awaited opera, ''Goya,'' in the fall with the Spanish tenor Placido Domingo singing the title role.

title: Britain and Nigeria Resume Full Relations
description: Britain restored full diplomatic relations with Nigeria today, repairing a rupture that began two years ago after an attempt to smuggle a kidnapped former government official back to Lagos in an aircraft crate.

title: No Headline
description: Dance and Music of Senegal

title: JUDGE BACKS AIDS POLICY OF SCHOOLS
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that children with AIDS cannot automatically be excluded from regular classes in New York City public schools.

title: THEATER: 'FULFILLING KOCH'S POSTUALTE'
description: JOAN SCHENKAR'S bizarre notion in ''Fulfilling Koch's Postulate,'' playing at the Theater for the New City, is to bring Typhoid Mary and the great German medical scientist Robert Koch together in a comic romp, apparently on the grounds that some of Koch's scientific postulates allowed researchers to discover the source of typhoid fever. The fact that the famous cook who spread typhoid among hundreds in New York never really encountered Koch, who died in Berlin five years before New York authorities finally apprehended Mary and confined her to an island, is not pertinent here.

title: RESILIENT NETS DEFEAT PISTONS
description: Dave Wohl called the Nets resilient, and he might have been right. Tonight, they played without their leading playmaker, their imposing backup center and a top reserve, yet they overcame the Detroit Pistons and a scintillating fourth-quarter performance from Kelly Tripucka in a 130-122 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Sacrifices for Lent
description: As a charter member of the Immoral Minority, I have decided, after painful meditation, to give up the following things for Lent: 1. President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines. 2. All President Reagan's statements about Mr. Marcos until somebody makes up his mind. 3. Former President for Life Duvalier of Haiti and other political scoundrels. 4. All New Year's resolutions. 5. Basketball, both pro and college, until the playoffs. 6. Pravda, Izvestia and all other obedient government lapdogs. 7. All sports heroes who wear gold chains. 8. Popularity polls. 9. Political bumper stickers. 10. Political speechwriters. 11. Political television preachers. 12. Columnists who give Lenten advice.

title: Rights Group Critical Of 2 Sides in Nicaragua
description: Amnesty International today issued a report on human rights in Nicaragua that criticized both the Government and the American-backed rebel forces.

title: U.S. OBSERVERS DISAGREE ON EXTENT OF PHILIPPINE FRAUD
description: Members of a United States delegation that observed the presidential election in the Philippines said today that there had been some fraud and violence, but they disagreed on how extensive the problems had been.

title: SHCHARANSKY GETS WELCOME IN ISRAEL
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky arrived in Israel today to a joyful welcome from Government leaders, friends and tumultuous crowds of supporters.

title: SCREEN: YEVGENY YEVTUSHENO'S 'KINDERGARTEN'
description: ''THE KINDERGARTEN,''

title: OPERATING NET AT CBS FALLS 49.9%
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that earnings from continuing operations fell 49.9 percent in the fourth quarter, hurt by much lower profits from the broadcast and publishing divisions.

title: NASA'S CONFLICTING REMARKS: QUESTIONS RAISED ABOUT CONTROL OF AGENCY
description: In the days that have followed the explosion of the shuttle Challenger, space agency officials have offered a number of conflicting explanations and statements about the reliability of critical shuttle equipment and the agency's preparedness for disaster.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Budget Caution in Trenton and Hartford; How Much for New Jersey's Toxic Waste and Welfare?
description: With his landslide re-election in November, Governor Kean of New Jersey earned the right to be daring. Yet his new budget is cautious and conservative.

title: Jury Is Recessed In Georgia Suit
description: A Federal court jury deliberated for a second day today in the lawsuit brought by Jan Kemp, a former University of Georgia instructor, who maintained she was dismissed by the school because she protested preferential treatment for athletes. The panel recessed shortly before 5 P.M. and will resume deliberations Wednesday morning.

title: YONKERS INTEGRATION PLAN IS OUTLINED
description: The Yonkers Board of Education, facing a court-imposed deadline of next Monday to present a plan to integrate the city's schools, released the outline of a plan today that would close some buildings, convert others to ''magnet'' enrichment programs, and redraw district lines.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: POPE IN THE LAND OF GANDHI
description: For a while this morning it seemed that this would be the papal trip that would never end.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Barry Beck, the Ranger captain, skated with the team in practice yesterday for the first time since he injured his left shoulder last Nov. 9. The defenseman is expected back before the end of the season, but an exact time has not been set. . . . Matt Christensen, a hockey player for Minnesota-Duluth, collapsed during a pickup game Sunday night and was reported in serious condition yesterday with what doctors said was a stroke. Christensen was found to have a blood clot in what his physician said was an abnormal artery in the brain. . . . Evelyn Ashford, the sprinter who won two gold medals at the 1984 Olympics, has entered the 60-yard dash in the Millrose Games Friday, a week after she returned from a 17-month maternity layoff to win the 55-meter dash at the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational track meet. . . . John Cannon, a defensive end for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, was arrested yesterday at a Tampa restaurant and charged with disorderly intoxication, criminal mischief and resisting arrest, the police said.

title: CONNECTICUTT DEFEATS PITT, 77-73
description: Earl Kelley scored 30 points as Connecticut defeated Pittsburgh, 77-73, in a Big East Conference game tonight.

title: A Jew and a Carmelite
description: To the Editor:

title: SHCHARANSKY'S STATEMENT ON ARRIVAL AT AIRPORT IN ISRAEL
description: Following are excerpts from Anatoly B. Shcharansky's remarks in English on arrival in Israel today at Ben-Gurion International Airport:

title: Troyanovsky Leaving; He'll Return to Moscow
description: Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the chief Soviet delegate to the United Nations, will give up his post on Friday and return to the Soviet Union, a spokesman at the Soviet Mission said today.

title: Success on the M31 Line
description: People can make a difference, as the people in two East 79th and 80th Street block associations have proved.

title: Shareholders Clear U.S. Steel Merger
description: Shareholders of the United States Steel Corporation and the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation easily approved a $3 billion merger yesterday that will increase U.S. Steel's dependence on energy and reduce steel operations to less than one-third of its business.

title: Allegheny Selling Four Subsidiaries
description: Allegheny International Inc. said that it planned to sell its American commercial financing subsidiary, the Allegheny International Credit Corporation and that negotiations were near completion to sell H. W. Chapman, a British packing business; Graviner, a British manufacturer of fire detection and suppression systems, and Deugra, a West German affiliate.

title: LIBERIA ASSERTS IT IS PREPARED TO OFFER POLITICAL ASYLUM TO DUVALIER
description: Liberia said today that it was prepared to offer political asylum to Jean-Claude Duvalier, who fled Haiti aboard a United States Air Force plane four days ago.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: The New York Public Library's 1986-87 institutional campaign to Jameson Advertising.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Budget Caution in Trenton and Hartford A Test of Election Interests in Connecticut
description: To fend off a Democratic challenge to his renomination, Governor O'Neill of Connecticut describes his $4.9 billion election-year budget as ''bold.'' But to match the Republicans who will seek in November to renew their lease on the Legislature, he calls it ''prudent.''

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S STATEMENT ON HABIB
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's written statement today on his decision to send Philip C. Habib to the Philippines as a special envoy:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: CERTAIN basic cooking techniques always amuse and sometimes astonish guests in my kitchen. A worthwhile one is simply wrapping food such as chicken or fish before steaming it. I often enclose the item in clear plastic wrap. The package or packages are placed in a skillet with a little liquid or on a steamer rack over boiling water. Some guests observe the process in wonderment, presuming that the plastic will melt. It doesn't.

title: QUINOA, ANDEAN LEGACY, ARRIVES
description: QUINOA, a tiny ivory-colored seed, has been recently introduced to the American market. High in protein -an average of 16.2 percent compared with 14 percent for wheat - it represents a better balance of amino acids than wheat, according to Eugene Anderson, professor of anthropology at the University of California at Riverside.

title: CLOSING WORDS AT 1978 TRIAL
description: On July 14, 1978, Anatoly B. Shcharansky was sentenced by a Moscow court to 13 years in prison and labor camp for treason, espionage and anti-Soviet agitation. Here are his closing words to the court before sentencing, as drawn from notes taken by his brother, Leonid.

title: First Boston Broadens Roles of 3 Executives
description: The First Boston Corporation has reorganized its capital markets activities and given three of its younger executives broader responsibilities, sources at the firm said yesterday.

title: TYLENOL MAKER FINDING NEW CRISIS LESS SEVERE
description: The announcement that a 23-year-old Peekskill, N.Y., woman died last weekend after taking a cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule has rekindled a crisis for Johnson & Johnson that the company hoped had ended more than three years ago.

title: THE DANCE: MONTREAL'S MISS GILLIS
description: A TERRIFIC dancer, Margie Gillis has come down from her native Montreal from time to time over the last four years to tackle, usually, the difficult format of a solo concert.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS BUDGET FOES SEEK TAX INCREASE AND VOWS TO VETO IT
description: President Reagan tonight accused Congressional opponents of his new budget proposal of maneuvering for a tax increase. He pledged a swift veto if they succeeded.

title: WORLDWIDE POVERTY MOVES CONTRIBUTORS TO GIVE TO NEEDIEST
description: By helping to care for the homeless, the ill and the despairing in the New York metropolitan area, many donors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund hope to do their share in the larger battle against world poverty, disease and hunger.

title: CONSUMERS' DEBT UP BY $5.1 BILLION
description: Americans took on $5.1 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in December, the Federal Reserve Board said today. December's increase was somewhat more than November's but still was well below the torrid growth of debt in earlier months.

title: A FREE MAN AT LAST
description: It is a rare man who can make a joke of his imminent arrest, and Anatoly B. Shcharansky is such a man.

title: BDM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cup Group to Fund 36 Races
description: Breeders' Cup officials announced today that they will spend $3 million to sponsor 36 new thoroughbred races around the country this year.

title: BBDO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for the latest and previous years are after a loss of 50 cents a share from the transfer of ownership of the South African operation to local management.

title: Israeli Official Resigns
description: The Attorney General of Israel, Yitzhak Zamir, who has clashed frequently with right-wing politicians and Israeli settlers in occupied Arab territories, resigned tonight.

title: THE SCREEN: 'WINTER FLIGHT'
description: ''WINTER FLIGHT,'' the English film that opens today at the Embassy 72d Street Theater, is a dozy story of young love, about Mal (Reece Dinsdale), a shy, young recruit in the Royal Air Force, and Angie (Nicola Cowper), who talks tough but is an innocent. She's also careless, having never caught the name of the fellow who made her pregnant during a one-night stand.

title: THOUSANDS CELEBRATE RULER'S FALL IN HAITIAN CITY
description: Thousands of Haitians converged on this city today for celebrations that combine traditional Mardi Gras festivities with joy over the fall of the Duvalier dictatorship.

title: LIBERTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $363,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $3,739,000 for the year. c-After capital losses of $3,421,000 for the quarter and $2,518,000 for the year.

title: Ex-Gov. Bond in Senate Race
description: Christopher S. Bond, the former Governor of Missouri, announced Sunday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the Senate seat being vacated by Thomas F. Eagleton.

title: Peru Rejects I.M.F. Order
description: President Alan Garcia Perez has rejected a deadline he said the International Monetary Fund issued regarding repayment of Peru's debt arrears.

title: Advertising; Scali Gets Majority Of Fallon
description: SCALI, McCABE, SLOVES WORLDWIDE, the 19-year-old advertising agency that is a subsidiary of the Ogilvy Group, is making its first domestic acquisition: a majority interest in Fallon McElligott Rice, the Minneapolis-based agency. Fallon McElligott, founded in 1981, was selected by Advertising Age only two years later as the ''Agency of the Year.''

title: TOMB OF TUTANKHAMUN'S TREASURER REPORTED FOUND
description: After a 10-year search, a British-Dutch archeological team says it has discovered the anteroom of the burial chambers here of Maya, believed to have been King Tutankhamen's treasurer more than 3,000 years ago.

title: A FEW NEW TAX RULES ON RETIREMENT ACCOUNTS
description: The last-minute rush to pick up an extra tax deduction by pouring money into an Individual Retirement Account or Keogh plan has become an annual ritual. So have the rule changes.

title: CHARGE AGAINST WALESA IS DROPPED
description: A provincial court today threw out slander charges brought by the Government against Lech Walesa.

title: PARKING BUREAU CRITICIZED IN AUDIT ON COLLECTION COST
description: Top officials of the city's Parking Violations Bureau unilaterally decided to pay private collection agencies more than the agencies had agreed to charge to collect unpaid parking tickets, the State Comptroller reported yesterday.

title: Justice Black
description: The centennial of the birth of Justice Hugo L. Black, one of the most influential members ever of the Supreme Court, will be celebrated Feb. 27 on at least three fronts. The United States Postal Service will issue a 5-cent stamp carrying his portrait as part of the Great Americans series; ''Mr. Justice and Mrs. Black,'' a combined memoir of the justice and his wife, Elizabeth Seay Black, will be published by Random House, and a memorial service will be held at the Supreme Court with Chief Justice Warren E. Burger presiding.

title: How to Make Amends to the Haitians
description: Now that Jean-Claude Duvalier has been forced by the Haitian people to abandon his inherited dictatorship, the United States has an opportunity to improve its policy toward Haiti and help the junta that controls it.

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH EMERGENCY AID FOR MEXICO
description: The United States Government is deliberating over a package of emergency aid, including American export and trade credits and oil purchase commitments, to help Mexico resolve financial problems aggravated by lower oil prices and the earthquake last September, Administration officials said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1986
description: Companies

title: ROOKIE AN EXCEPTIONAL HITTER
description: It is not too difficult to spot Davis Love 3d, the youngest of the long-ball hitters on the PGA Tour. He has a big white golf bag with only one wood sticking out of it. Love's driver stands alone among his irons like a symbol of pure power.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't intend to start a national scare, we don't believe the nation is smothered with tainted Tylenol.'' -Owen J. McClain, deputy police chief in Yonkers., [ A1:4. ]

title: U.S. REBUFFS SOVIET ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The United States today dismissed a proposal by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, for an interim agreement barring the spread of chemical weapons.

title: Tired Children
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Ewing to Sit Out At Least 2 Games
description: Patrick Ewing will miss at least two games this week, and possibly more, because of an ailment known as jumper's knee.

title: Tie Athletic Scholarships to Graduation Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ARCTIC DREAMS. Imagination and Desire in a Northern Landscape. By Barry Lopez. 464 pages. Scribner's. $22.95.

title: Journalists Rebuffed in Plea On Spy Retrial of F.B.I. Agent
description: A Federal appeals court today rejected a request by broadcast journalists to lift an order barring discussion with lawyers in the espionage retrial of Richard Miller, a former agent of th Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After a charge of $601,000 related to liquidation of the European subsidiary for the quarter and a charge of $46.3 million related to the restructuring of manufacturing operations for the year. c-Net income, including an extraordinary tax gain of $6 million and after charges of $2.1 million related to liquidation of a European subsidiary.

title: MACKLOWE DEMOLITION MAN IS GIVEN A NO-JAIL SENTENCE
description: A Brooklyn contractor was sentenced yesterday to a conditional discharge for his role in the nighttime partial demolition last year of four buildings on West 44th Street.

title: ASSEMBLYMAN SEEN AS CONTENDER TO REPLACE MANES IN BOROUGH JOB
description: Queens Democratic leaders focused last night on Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi as a leading contender to succeed Donald R. Manes as Queens Borough President.

title: KAY JEWELERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Net Income Gains 20% At BBDO International
description: BBDO International reported net income in the fourth quarter of $9 million, or $1.40 a share, an increase of 20 percent over the $7.5 million, or $1.18 a share, posted in the corresponding period last year.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable Feb. 14.

title: EVOLUTION OF THE LENTEN FAST
description: TRADITION implies stability, the passing of customs - virtually unchanged - from generation to generation. In reality, traditions do change, sometimes drastically and often as a response to societal pressures.

title: Oil Prices Drop Again; Heating Fuel Stocks Off
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products slumped again yesterday after several wide swings during light trading.

title: Economic Scene; Shultz Takes Broad View
description: SECRETARY OF STATE George P. Shultz brings an economist's perspective to foreign policy. Unlike many ideologues, the conservative Mr. Shultz, once dean of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, does not regard the name John Maynard Keynes as a dirty word or his work as irrelevant to solving current problems.

title: ARROW AIR HALTS FLIGHTS AND FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Arrow Air, operator of the DC-8 jetliner that crashed last December in Newfoundland, killing 248 American soldiers, halted all scheduled passenger flights yesterday and filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code.

title: DOW DECLINES 3.56 IN MIXED MARKET
description: For the first time in four sessions the stock market stumbled, but only slightly, as share prices closed mixed in an uncharacteristically dull session.

title: NEW MEXICO TELLS NATURAL HISTORY WITH ELECTRONIC MAGIC SHOW
description: Jonathan F. Callender, director of New Mexico's new Museum of Natural History, ran his hand over the bumps and streaks in a plaster partition between exhibits. ''Another volunteer wall,'' he said affectionately. ''We'll fix it eventually.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: PENTAGON ORDERS SECURITY CHANGES
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today ordered an overhaul of security procedures, including a reliability program for holders of top-secret clearances.

title: Minor Quakes Felt in West
description: Moderate earthquakes rattled western Washington and shook an area off the California coast Monday but caused no damage. The strongest Washington temblor occurred about 10:05 A.M. and registered 3.6 on the Richter scale, according to the University of Washington Geophysics Department. An earthquake described as ''moderate'' was recorded off the coast of California, about 75 miles west of Crescent City, at 5:15 P.M.

title: BRITAIN ATTACHING PRINT UNION FUNDS
description: All the assets of Britain's largest print union were frozen today as a penalty for its attempt to stop the distribution of Rupert Murdoch's four British newspapers.

title: Auschwitz Artifacts
description: ''Auschwitz: A Crime Against Mankind,'' an exhibition of photographs, documents and artifacts on loan from Poland, has been extended through Feb. 28 in the lobby of the United Nations Headquarters Building, 46th Street and First Avenue.

title: DARTMOUTH SUSPENDS 12 FOR ATTACK ON SHANTIES
description: A Dartmouth disciplinary committee suspended the 12 students who participated in a sledgehammer attack last month on shanties erected on the College Green by a group protesting the policy of racial separation in South Africa.

title: GRAINGER, W W INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,502,000 for the quarter and $4,040,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,072,000 for the quarter and $4,811,000 for the year.

title: United Flies New Routes in Pacific
description: United Airlines began flying to a dozen points in Asia and the Pacific today over the routes that it recently acquired from Pan American World Airways.

title: RICHARDSON TESTED AFTER ABSENCE
description: Micheal Ray Richardson today was assessed an undisclosed fine and a one-game suspension from the Nets for missing a team practice and a scheduled appointment with a doctor Monday. He was also given a test to determine if his disappearance was related to a drug relapse, but results were not expected to be available until Wednesday.

title: FUEL SAVING NOW ENTRENCHED
description: The twin oil shocks of 1973 and 1979 have caused American business and consumers to make such great strides in conserving energy that falling oil prices are not likely to lure the nation into reverting to its wastrel ways.

title: PICKENS ON THE PROWL AGAIN
description: When the Mesa Petroleum Company announced seven months ago that it was turning itself into a partnership, its chairman, T. Boone Pickens, was asked whether this meant he was retiring from the takeover game. Mr. Pickens was characteristically vague, saying that the partnership may get involved in corporate buyouts ''some time in the future.''

title: Grace Trims Restaurants
description: W.R. Grace & Company, the multibillion-dollar conglomerate, said yesterday that it was putting up for sale 124 restaurants, or about 15 percent of its 845 outlets. The company said the restaurants were losing about $5 million a year and that it expected to get about $30 million from the sales.

title: THE CULNINARY SKILLS OF 200 MEN HELP YOUNG ART STUDENTS
description: WHAT do a lawyer, a graphic artist, a musician, an architect, a publisher of a women's magazine and the director of a financial services company all have in common? They were among the 200 men, including Dr. Roscoe Brown, president of Bronx Community College, and Alan Lewis, director of Windows on the World, who cook for pleasure - and from necessity - at home and who prepared their specialties for the fifth annual ''Men Who Cook'' last Sunday. The event benefits the Children's Art Carnival in Harlem, an independent art school serving more than 14,000 youngsters from the New York area.

title: ROUTINE FOLLOWED IN INCIDENT'S WAKE
description: An official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that one segment of a solid-fuel booster rocket of the space shuttle Challenger was replaced after it was damaged in an accident last November but that no special inspections were then made of the other segments.

title: ATLANTIC RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year results have been restated to reflect acquisition on Sept. 30, 1985 of Systematics General Corporation.

title: 376 People in Lima Arrested On First Day of New Curfew
description: A total of 376 people were arrested in Lima on Monday night, the police said, as troops enforced the first day of a 1 A.M. to 5 A.M. curfew aimed at curbing attacks by leftist guerrillas in the Peruvian capital.

title: G.E. Contracts
description: The General Electric Company has been awarded four military contracts totaling $343.2 million, the Defense Department said. Two Army contracts totaling $302.6 million are for helicopter engines. Two Navy contracts totaling $40.6 million are for work on engines for F-18 jets.

title: VICTORY BUILDS EGOS AT ST. JOHN'S
description: In the days leading up to Monday night's game with Georgetown, there had been a collective feeling among the St. John's players that the team needed an inspirational victory.

title: Collision of Navy Ships Leaves a Sailor Dead
description: Two Navy ships returning to Pearl Harbor from training maneuvers collided Monday night, killing one sailor and injuring eight others, a Navy spokesman said today.

title: Facing Reality
description: You can look for the Brooklyn College basketball team to lower its sights a bit when scheduling future opponents.

title: Iraq Says It Retook Isle From Iranians
description: Iraq reported today that it had recaptured an island in the strategic Shatt al Arab waterway after an 18-hour battle with Iranian forces.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. - Not available because of Lincoln's birthday * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE STAGE: 'LA CHUNGA,' BY MARIO VARGAS LLOSA
description: IN his new play, ''La Chunga,''

title: The Savage Breast
description: News bulletin: Unknown vandals damaged several strings on the grand piano at American Ambassador Arthur Hartman's Moscow residence Sunday just hours before Vladimir Feltsman, a prominent pianist and Jewish dissident, was to perform there. One string had been cut, three others bent and two more put out of tune.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Signed Rufino Linares, outfielder.

title: STAGE: 'FRESH HORSES,' LARRY KETRON COMEDY
description: THE first sound the audience hears in ''Fresh Horses,'' the new Larry Ketron comedy at the WPA, is the panting of sweaty young lovers having sex. Although it's not heard again, that deaccelerating panting becomes the music - by turns boisterous, sweet and somber - that permeates Mr. Ketron's play. The tale of mostly college-age kids in rural Tennessee, ''Fresh Horses'' captures its youthful characters at that precise moment when their adolescent fantasies begin to fade into the morning-after realities of adulthood. Mr. Ketron's writing has so much heat - the boil of idiosyncratic language and observation as well as teen-age sexuality -that his people continue to horse around in our imagination well after his play's drama has been spent.

title: New York City's Borough President System Is Unnecessary
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXACO HEARINGS DRAW BIG TURNOUT
description: The legal battle between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company went before a Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday, providing an overflow crowd a chance to see some of the nation's top lawyers argue one of the most dramatic and widely publicized cases in corporate history.

title: PRESIDENT TO SEND AN ENVOY TO SEEK VIEWS OF FILIPINOS
description: President Reagan announced today that he was sending Philip C. Habib, a veteran diplomat, to the Philippines ''to assess the desires and needs of the Filipino people'' in the aftermath of the disputed election there.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A PEAL FOR LINCOLN At noon today the bells will ring -beginning with the national anthem. The Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial Carillon at the Riverside Church will peal to commemorate today's 177th birthday of Abraham Lincoln, the 16th President of the United States. The program will include Civil War songs, three songs by black Americans, three by Stephen Foster, two early American hymns and ''Paraphrase on the Battle Hymn of the Republic.''

title: CARTER SEES NEW AVENUES TO NICARAGUA PEACE
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, who met last week with high-ranking officials in Nicaragua as well as with opponents of the Managua Government, said here today that he believed there were opportunities to seek peace in the region that had not been fully explored.

title: Bernard Katzen Dies; Served on Rights Panel
description: Bernard Katzen, a former New York State Commissioner of Human Rights, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1986
description: International

title: NBC'S 'ALMANAC' IS POSTPONED AGAIN
description: The NBC prime-time news program 'American Almanac,' delayed once this year from a regular spot on the network's schedule, has been postponed again.

title: A MISSION IN MANILA FOR HABIB
description: Philip C. Habib was spotted by a couple of reporters on Monday having lunch in the State Department cafeteria.

title: REAGAN TELLS OF WEIGHING PLANS TO REVISE MINORITY HIRING RULES
description: President Reagan said tonight that his Administration was still weighing proposals to change an executive order under which the Labor Department requires many Federal contractors to set numerical goals for hiring women and members of minority groups.

title: FOR FIRST TIME, CITY ADMITS NEED FOR NEW WATER SOURCES
description: New York City's reservoir system is insufficient to meet rising water consumption, city officials publicly acknowledged for the first time yesterday.

title: Stuck on the Waterfront At Atlantic Ave.
description: Abandon ship!

title: BUTLER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $627,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and year. c-Including a gain of $10,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and the year results are after a loss of $1,059,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $5 million on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Potomac Fever, Potomac Phobias
description: For 10 years Dennis F. Schroff, a supervisor in the accounting branch of the General Services Administration, had panic attacks, disorientation and a choking sensation every time he had to travel away from home or cross a busy intersection.

title: REPORTING ON SHUTTLE INQUIRY IS CALLED 'FAIR AND ACCURATE'
description: William P. Rogers, chairman of the Presidential commission investigating the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, said at a special public hearing with officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration yesterday that news organizations' reporting on the investigation was ''quite fair and accurate.''

title: COMPUTERVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After unusual charges of about $14.1 million covering reserves for adjustments in asset carrying values and for disposition of excess facilities. c-Net income d-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,715,000 and after a loss of $10 million from discontinued operations.

title: A POINTER IS BEST IN WESTMINSTER SHOW
description: A liver-and-white pointer, Ch. Marjetta National Acclaim, who answers to the name of Deputy, was acclaimed as the best of 2,591 dogs at the 110th Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Bass Group Cuts Stake in Disney
description: A group of investors, led by the Fort Worth-based Bass family, said it had reduced its stake in the Walt Disney Company to 20.8 percent, from 22.1 percent, of the shares outstanding. Since Dec. 24, the Bass group said it has sold almost 3 percent of its Disney holdings.

title: WINE TALK
description: PROBABLY the best thing to be said about most wine books is that they are hefty and, stacked against a north wall, are better insulation than glass wool. Certainly, more nonsense seems to be written about wine than about any subject - except politics. That is why the reappearance of a great wine book of the past can be at least as important as the publication of yet another new book with nothing new to say.

title: Mission Accomplished
description: Fairfield University hired Mitch Buonaguro to coach its men's basketball team with the hope that he could improve on the squad's last-place finish in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, and the former Villanova assistant has more than delivered. In Buonaguro's rookie season, the Stags have improved from 4-10 in the league and 11-17 over all last season to 10-1 and 17-5. Even better, when Holy Cross lost to La Salle on Monday night, Fairfield became the first Division I team in the country to clinch a regular-season conference title.

title: YOUNG MEN COOKING AT HOME: NEW ROLES, UNFAMILIAR TERRAIN
description: MARK ENGEBRETSON earns his living as a production manager for a women's apparel company, but he does some of his best work in the kitchen of his Greenwich Village apartment. His specialties are home-made stews and spaghetti sauce.

title: CALL IT GRAVEY OR SAUCE, BUT KEEP THE LUMPS OUT
description: THE subject of gravies is a vexed one.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Rise
description: Bond prices continued to improve yesterday, and ended the day with prices of long-term Treasury issues within about a point of the highest levels reached in early January.

title: A LEADING MARCOS FOE IS CHASED ACROSS TOWN SQUARE AND KILLED
description: A leading member of the nation's political opposition was chased by masked gunmen across the town square here this morning and shot dead after he was trapped in a backyard outhouse.

title: SHCHARANSKY WINS FREEDOM IN BERLIN IN PRISONER TRADE
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet human rights activist and campaigner for the right of Jews to emigrate, was freed here today after eight years in prisons and labor camps.

title: Rate Request By A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Government today to approve a pricing plan that would give a 10 percent discount on all long-distance calls in exchange for a $15 monthly fee, effective March 28.

title: ROCCO PARISI
description: Rocco Parisi, a former Deputy Borough President of Staten Island, died Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Castleton Corners, S.I. He was 69 years old and lived in Castleton Corners.

title: Philadelphia Hotel Set For $40 Million Overhaul
description: The Bellevue Stratford, the grand hotel on Broad Street that survived a bout with Legionnaire's disease but suffered an acute decline in business, will be renovated into a small luxury hotel, it was announced today.

title: Yields Are Set In C.M.O.'s Offer
description: The Collateralized Mortgage Securities Corporation is offering $550 million of collaterlized mortgage obligations, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: MESA PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OFFICIALS SAY FATAL TAMPERING OF TYLENOL WAS ISOLATED CASE
description: Authorities investigating the case of a woman who died in Yonkers after taking Extra-Strength Tylenol tainted with cyanide said yesterday that they were convinced the death was an isolated case of tampering and that there was no reason to believe that other batches of the drug contained the poison.

title: Copter Missing on Volcano
description: More than a dozen aircraft searched the slopes of Mount St. Helens without success today for an overdue chartered helicopter carrying a free-lance photographer and two crew members. The helicopter flew over and landed on the volcano Monday so that the photographer, Raph Perry of Camas, Wash., could take photographs for National Geographic magazine.

title: STEPLADDER FOR UPPER REACHES OF KITCHEN
description: WHILE most New York kitchens are short on counter and floor space, some at least have the advantage of vertical space. Many older city apartments have ceilings 10 to 12 feet high, with walls that can be adapted for storage.

title: N.F.L. IS SUED BY CARDS
description: The St. Louis Cardinals yesterday filed an antitrust suit against the National Football League and its commissioner, Pete Rozelle, charging the that the league's procedures governing franchise relocation are illegal.

title: 2 ULILITIES HALT DUES FOR DETROIT MEN'S CLUB
description: Two major Michigan utilities have told their executives that the companies will no longer pay their membership dues in the Detroit Athletic Club because it reaffirmed its men-only membership policy last month, spokesmen said today.

title: Sixth Fleet in Position For Games Off Libya
description: Warships of the United States Sixth Fleet took up positions off Libya today for four days of maneuvers near the Gulf of Sidra, officials said today.

title: THE STAGE: 'NUCLEAR FOLLIES,' A REVUE
description: ''NUCLEAR FOLLIES'' is an exuberant but rough satirical revue devoted to the proposition that the end of the world is a hoot. Written by Gregory Langdon and Joseph Peret and produced at the Second Stage of the New Theater of Brooklyn, the show weaves ''Saturday Night Live''-style skits together with songs that aspire to the acidic wit of Tom Lehrer, and vaudeville routines that recall Mabou Mines' ''Dead End Kids'' into a cartoonlike fantasy of nuclear holocaust set several years hence.

title: TENNESSEANS FIGHT A MILITARY CENTER
description: High on a bluff overlooking a hazy blue-green valley, this community about 100 miles west of Chattanooga has long been a summer resort where city people came to regain their perspective.

title: Eating New York City's Lunch
description: It has been only a month since Queens Borough President Donald Manes was found in his car, blood pouring from knife wounds, thus prompting the investigations of corruption that have fanned out in several directions. His resignation yesterday ends nothing. The public can expect indictments soon involving the Parking Violations Bureau scandal and more, perhaps much more. Welcome as these prosecutions will be, a larger question remains.

title: Ethics Panel Clears Virginian
description: Representative Dan Daniel violated House rules by accepting $7,663 in free flights from a military contractor from 1977 to 1985, but the violations were unintentional, the House ethics committee says.

title: MANES RESIGNS 2 QUEENS POSTS, CITING 'BURDEN'
description: Donald R. Manes resigned yesterday as Borough President of Queens and county Democratic leader, saying he had to devote his attention to his ailing health and the corruption accusations against him.

title: It's True, TV Violence Is on the Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Put the Heat on Marcos
description: President Reagan offered Ferdinand E. Marcos a carrot. Now he ought to wield the stick.

title: TO DELIGHT THE HEART AND NURTURE IT, TOO
description: SCHOLARS suggest that gifts popular during certain eras reflect the concerns and tastes of the time, and indicate what people prize in true love. In ''An Illustrated Encyclopedia of Traditional Symbols'' (Thames & Hudson, 1978), J. C. Cooper notes, for example, that early Victorians bestowed violets, confections and sonnets written on paper hearts to communicate feelings of joy, modesty and sweetness.

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: 2 ON LOCAL SCHOOL BOARDS OWE CITY $11,000 IN FINES
description: At least 40 members of New York City's community school boards have failed to pay thousands of dollars in outstanding parking tickets, including two who owe more than $11,000 each, an examination of city records shows.

title: British Textile Merger Deal
description: Vantona Viyella P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy the Scottish clothier Coats Patons P.L.C. for about $1 billion.

title: 'This Is Sadness'
description: Clouds Form Over Sugar Ray. Richardson Puts Drugs Behind

title: Suspect Indicted In One of 9 Deaths
description: A woman suspected of killing nine children since 1972 has been indicted on a charge related to the most recent death, officials said today.

title: Lingering Hurt
description: It's been several years since Joe Paterno, the Penn State football coach, said he wasn't ready to retire because if he did, it would leave college football in the hands of ''the Jackie Sherrills and the Barry Switzers.'' The comment understandably upset Sherrill, a former Pitt coach who now coaches at Texas A.&M., and Switzer, the Oklahoma coach.

title: RODEO, NEW STYLE: BOXES FOR $10,000
description: The painting on the wall across from Neal Gay's desk shows Mr. Gay in a blue Western shirt and white cowboy hat looking wistfully toward a dusty rodeo arena, with a sign reading Mesquite Championship Rodeo. Its title is ''The Way It Was.''

title: ALEXIS OBOLENSKY
description: Prince Alexis Obolensky, a member of a Russian emigre family and president of the World Backgammon Club, an organization in Manhattan that sponsors international tournaments, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Bridge: Gray Areas Can't Be Ignored In Learning 'Rules' of Game
description: Luckily for the game, few of the basic guidelines that beginners learn are written solely in black and white. They have gray areas in which the player must use brains and experience.

title: Arbitration Scoreboard
description: Frank Viola, the Minnesota pitcher, ran Tal Smith's losing streak to four yesterday before Gary Gaetti, Viola's teammate, ended the streak. Smith is a consultant to 13 clubs in baseball's salary arbitration, and entering Monday's hearings with Viola and Gaetti, he had lost consecutive cases to Phil Bradley of Seattle, Charlie Leibrandt of Kansas City and Bob Kearney of Seattle.

title: Lendl Tested In First Round
description: Ivan Lendl struggled today before defeating John Sadri, 6-2, 3-6, 7-6, in a first-round match in the Lipton International Players Championships tennis tournament.

title: Mayor's Book Tour Is Headed for Boston
description: Mayor Koch will be in Boston today, the sixth city he has visited in less than three weeks as he tours the country to promote his new book, ''Politics,'' and to talk about Federal cuts.

title: I.B.M. EXPANDS LINE, CUTS PRICES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced 10 percent price cuts on the two members of the Sierra family of mainframes introduced last year and introduced two less expensive members of the line, which is formally known as the 3090 series.

title: PRETORIA REFUSES TO FREE MANDELA DESPITE RELEASE OF SHCHARANSKY
description: The South African authorities tonight ruled out the immediate release of Nelson Mandela, saying the freeing today of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet dissident, did not meet terms set out on Jan. 31 for the liberty of Mr. Mandela.

title: BAR GROUP URGES HALT IN USE OF PRIVATELY RUN JAILS
description: The American Bar Association today called for a halt in the move toward privately operated prisons and jails, lamenting ''a rush toward total privatization'' of corrections facilities.

title: WINTER DELIVERS ITS SECOND BLOW IN 4-DAY PERIOD
description: The second major snowstorm in four days brought a steady fall of snow, sleet and drizzle to the New York area for much of yesterday. It snarled traffic, stopped air transportation, closed schools, delighted children and cross-country skiers and transformed Manhattan into a dreary, barely navigable sea of slush.

title: AFGHAN REBEL ATTACKS REPORTED
description: Islamic guerrillas apparently killed or wounded nearly 200 Soviet and Afghan Government soldiers during recent heavy fighting in Afghanistan, and repeatedly hit the capital with rockets in the past 10 days, Western diplomatic sources said today.

title: Hyatt Hotels Gets A New Chairman
description: The Hyatt Corporation announced yesterday that Patrick Foley had been promoted to chairman of the Hyatt Hotels Corporation and that Darryl Hartley-Leonard had been named president, effective immediately.

title: NEW LINCOLN INSIGHTS EMERGE FROM LETTERS
description: Documents that have recently surfaced in private collections disclose new facts about Abraham Lincoln and the Emancipation Proclamation, the Lincoln-Douglas debates and Lincoln's unsuccessful effort to obtain a Federal post as Commissioner of the General Land Office in 1849. That year he completed his single term as a Whig Congressman after having offended many Illinois constituents by opposing the Mexican war.

title: James Dillon, 83, Dies; Ex-Chief of Irish Party
description: James Dillon, a former Cabinet minister whose opposition to Ireland's neutrality in World War II estranged him from his party for nine years, died Monday, his family said. He was 83 years old.

title: REAGAN ENCOURAGED BY SHCHARANSKY RELEASE
description: President Reagan said today that he was encouraged by the release of Anatoly B. Shcharansky from Soviet confinement and that he hoped this was just a start.

title: MUSIC: 'ARIA DA CAPO'
description: THE New York premiere of Larry Alan Smith's ''Aria da Capo,'' a one-act setting of a playlet by Edna St. Vincent Millay, provided most of the interest in the American Chamber Opera Company's triple bill at Public School 9 in Manhattan Sunday night.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Real Estate; Carnegie Hall Plans Office Site
description: IN yet another change in plans for the important site next to Carnegie Hall, the designated developer and hall officials have agreed to erect an office building instead of a combined residential and commercial structure. Earlier in the tangled history of this narrow site, which runs from 57th to 56th Streets just east of the hall, a hotel had been planned.

title: Chip Orders Top Shipments
description: Semiconductor companies based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported orders in excess of shipments for the first time in 17 months, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today. The so-called book-to-bill ratio for the American semiconductor market rose in January to 1.04, its fifth consecutive increase, according to the the association, a trade organization based in San Jose, Calif.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE classical composer Philip Glass has made an album with lyrics by Paul Simon, David Byrne and other pop musicians, and among the featured vocalists are Linda Ronstadt and the Roches.

title: Grogan Stadium
description: A couple of years ago, when the football booster club at Ottawa High School in Ottawa, Kan., proposed naming the school's stadium after one of the school's leading athletes, Steve Grogan, the New England Patriot quarterback, the local school board decided the time wasn't ripe. Then last season Grogan added to his athletic credentials when he replaced the injured starter Tony Eason for six games and helped the Patriots make it to the Super Bowl, where he was again called on to replace Eason. That showing, coupled with a realignment of the school board, apparently did the trick for the 1971 Ottawa graduate. Monday night the board voted by 7-0 to name the field Steve Grogan Stadium.

title: Russia as Seen From Inside Its Vast Bulk
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind Surge At Wells Fargo
description: EVEN in this bull market it is unusual for shares of a bank holding company to jump 20 percent in two trading days after announcing an acquisition. But that happened to the stock of Wells Fargo & Company after it announced plans to buy the Crocker National Corporation for about $1.08 billion in cash and stock.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 28 about the decline of oil revenues in Saudi Arabia incorrectly characterized the financial status of a Saudi trading concern, the Jameel Company. It is in sound financial condition, not forced to restructure its debts.

title: JEWISH GROUPS AND RIGHTS ACTIVISTS EXPRESS DELIGHT OVER RELEASE
description: After eight years of lobbying, demonstrations, letter writing and hunger fasts, Jewish groups and rights activists yesterday hailed the release of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, but vowed to continue efforts on behalf of others who want to leave the Soviet Union.

title: GLAMOROUS MULES AND VINTAGE LACE
ERBAMONT NV reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Dollar results have been translated from Italian lire at the rate of 1,665 lire equals $1 in U.S. currency in 1985 and 2,057 lire equals $1 in 1984. Latest year results include a gain from the sale of Carlo Erba Strumentazione, and prior year results are after a reserve provision for the suspension of Flosnit in June 1984.

title: JUDGE'S CONVICTION ADDS SOMBER NOTE TO BILOXI MARDI GRAS
description: In between parties and parades, as this old coastal city celebrated Mardi Gras today, its lawyers and political leaders reflected on a surprising and sobering event: the conviction of its resident Federal district judge, Walter L. Nixon Jr., on two counts of perjury before a Federal grand jury.

title: KODAK SETS 10% CUT IN EMPLOYEES
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, hurt by sharply reduced earnings and rising costs, said yesterday that it planned to reduce its worldwide work force by 10 percent this year.

title: 2 Appointed at Instinet
description: The Instinet Corporation, which provides professional investors with a computer-based market access network, announced the appointment yesterday of Peter D. Byrne, a senior vice president at Dean Witter & Company, as vice chairman and Murray L. Finebaum, executive vice president at Cantor, Fitzgerald & Company, as president.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Pontiac, Mich., 7:30 P.M. The Knicks, now without Patrick Ewing, who is out for at least two games with a knee injury, come to the end of their six-game road swing. They have split their previous two games against the Pistons this season. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Colleges: Fairfield vs. Navy, 7 P.M., and Providence vs. Seton Hall, 9 P.M. at Byrne Meadowlands Arena (Radio -WSOU-FM, 89.5; 9 P.M.); Monmouth at Long Island, 7:30 P.M. (Television -Cablevision Channel 25, 9 P.M. tape); Upsala at New York University, 7 P.M. (Television - MSG, 10:30 P.M., tape. Radio - WNYU-FM, 89.1; 6:50 P.M.); Villanova at Syracuse, 8 P.M. (Television - USA, 8 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 7:35 P.M.); Queens at C. W. Post, 7:30 P.M.; Dowling at Philadelphia Textile, 7:30 P.M.; Jersey City State at Glassboro State, 7:30 P.M.; Rider at Hofstra, 7:30 P.M.; Lehman at St. Thomas Aquinas, 7:30 P.M.; Marist at St. Francis (Brooklyn), 7:30 P.M.; New York Tech at Southampton, 7:30 P.M.; Vassar at SUNY-Purchase, 7:30 P.M.; Rutgers-Camden at Kean, 7:30 P.M.; York at Staten Island, 7:30 P.M.; Bloomfield at Stevens Tech, 7:30 P.M.; Mercy at Adelphi, 7:30 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Vancouver Canucks, at Madison Square Garden. The Canucks face the Rangers for the final time this season. The Rangers are poised for a sweep of the series.

title: Raymond O'Keefe, Executive Of the Chase Manhattan Bank
description: Raymond T. O'Keefe, a former executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Sunday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 78 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc., Greenwich, Conn., said its new subsidiary, Castle Gate Coal Co., had agreed to acquire the Price River underground mine near Helper, Utah, from American Electric Power Co.

title: Jersey Renews Resorts' License
description: The Casino Control Commission voted unamimously today to renew the license of Resorts International Inc. to operate a casino in Atlantic City, despite concerns about the company's failure to engage in more rapid development of the city.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline of a brief article in Business Day on Monday about the Toyota Corporation misstated the company's position on quotas to limit the number of cars it can ship to the United States. Toyota does not favor the quotas; it favors an end to them.

title: The Deadly Games The Government Plays
description: This spring the National Security Council plans to run a war game simulating a crisis in the Middle East that will include terrorists, Libya and several other Arab nations, Israel and the Soviet Union.

title: TOXIC WASTE BILLS: UNRELATED ISSUES SNARL RESOLUTION
description: Congress last week finally appointed members to resolve differences between the House and Senate versions of legislation to renew the toxic waste cleanup law.

title: LOVE IN THE PROPER PACKAGE
description: IT is the one holiday when gift-givers and recipients care as much about the box as what is inside. On Valentine's Day, suitors, lovers and spouses will pay tribute to one another with flowers and cards and candy and gifts. The boxes - be they pale pink or burgundy, satin or velveteen, small and simple or outright excessive - are nearly always in the shape of a heart.

title: Tired Children
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press in Business Day on Jan. 30 about testimony on tax revision in Congress misstated a prediction made by Chase Econometrics about tax cuts and the Federal deficit. In 1981, Chase forecast that the cuts would substantially increase the deficit, not reduce it.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NASA ACKNOWLEDGES COLD AFFECTS BOOSTER SEALS
description: The space agency acknowledged today that cold temperatures diminish the effectiveness of critical safety seals that are designed to prevent the escape of hot gases and flames through the joints of the space shuttle's booster rockets.

title: Special Delivery From Ivory Coast
description: Akeem was a dream at the University of Houston, and Manute spent a minute at Bridgeport. Now the immigration of 7-footers from Africa continues with the recruitment of Michel Bonebo, who played four years with the national basketball team of the Ivory Coast before winding up in Winooski, Vt.

title: Utility Asks Rise; Is Told to Cut Rate
description: The State Public Service Commission, for the first time in more than 15 years, ordered a major electric utility today to reduce customers' bills when the company had asked to increase them.

title: Advertising; MCI Will Consolidate Advertising at D'Arcy
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced that as of May 31 it would terminate its seven-year relationship with Ally & Gargano and consolidate all of its advertising with its other agency, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $954,000 for the quarter, $2,872,000 for the year. The year results also include a gain of $1.8 million from the sale of excess processing facilities and gain of $700,000 from property transactions by the Connecticut real estate subsidiary. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $1,355,000 for the quarter, $3,665,000 for the year, and gains from extraordinary tax credits of $448,000 for the quarter and $4,800,000 for the year. The year results also include a pretax gain of $11 million from sales of office buildings and an industrial park.

title: Mid America Sale Set
description: Mid America Media has announced the proposed sale of all the company's holdings - seven radio stations and two cable TV properties in five states.

title: One Man Who Made a Difference
description: The heroism of Anatoly Shcharansky must not be obscured in the convergence of multinational interests that brought him across the Glienicke Bridge in Berlin yesterday. For a decade he has defied torture and cruelty in the cause of human dignity and freedom.

title: Dept. of Mousetraps
description: If you can make a better mousetrap, Ralph Waldo Emerson reportedly observed, the world will beat a path to your door. If you can make a better flying dinosaur, it then follows, the press will beat a path to watch and record its flight, even as far away as the Mohave Desert.

title: MOTHERS SOBS WITH RELIEF AT THE NEWS
description: ''Tolya is free, God Almighty, Tolya is free!'' Anatoly B. Shcharansky's mother exclaimed today, her wrinkled face beaming, wet with tears.

title: Kings Stop Celtic Streak
description: The Sacramento Kings played an impressive third quarter and then held on to defeat Boston, 105-100, tonight and end the Celtics' 13-game winning streak.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Slain Naturalist's Concerns Went Beyond Gorillas
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 12, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the situation in southern Africa at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MARCOS CALLS FRAUD PROTESTS 'A CHILDISH DISPLAY'
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said Tuesday that his opponents' protests over electoral fraud and violence were ''a childish display of petulance.''

title: Killer Jaguar Is Spared
description: A 200-pound male jaguar that escaped from its holding cage and killed a pregnant zookeeper last December will not be destroyed, city officials said today. Zoo personnel have determined that the 6-year-old neutered cat acted instinctively when it pounced on Gayle Booth, 30, as she entered an employee service area in the zoo's South American exhibit.

title: Needs and Programs
