Yields Off In Money Markets
description: The national average yield for six-month certificates of deposit for the week ended yesterday held steady, while yields on bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds declined.

title: LIQUI-BOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.N. Today; Feb. 13, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the situation in southern Africa at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EAST RIVER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-The result has been composed of operating income of $10.7 million and net gains from securities transactions of $7.4 million. c-Net loss.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: LCS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DECOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DEFIANCE PRECISION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Texas Women Trounce Baylor
description: Texas raced to a 36-18 halftime lead and used sharp field-goal shooting to hand Baylor a 77-45 defeat in a Southwest Conference women's basketball game tonight.

title: INEXPERIENCE OF AUTHOR LED NASA TO DISCOUNT WARNING
description: Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration say they discounted warnings last July that space shuttle safety was being compromised, in part because the warning came from a budget analyst who was new to the agency and inexperienced in space matters.

title: On the Payroll
description: There's been a certain coolness between Willie Mays and the San Francisco Giants in recent years. It began when Mays, a 20-year star for the Giants in New York and San Francisco, was abruptly traded to the Mets in 1972 without being told in advance by the club's former owner, Horace Stoneham.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adams-Millis Corp., High Point, N.C., said it had agreed in principle to buy closely held Maro Hosiery Corp. for about $36 million.

title: J.P. MORGAN REALIGNING DIVISIONS
description: J.P. Morgan & Company told employees yesterday that it would undertake a major restructuring that would put its commercial banking division under the umbrella of a new corporate finance group.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American President Cos., Oakland, Calif., a transportation services company, has elected to its board Calvin S. Hatch, chairman of the Clorox Co.

title: PETER BROOK'S 'CARMEN'
description: FOR those who thought, or perhaps hoped, they had heard the last of Peter Brook's unorthodox version of Bizet's ''Carmen,'' cable television's Arts & Entertainment Network has acquired a film version of the 82-minute stage production. It can be seen at 8 this evening, introduced by Joan Fontaine, who reminds us that the Bizet work was considered a failure after its premiere in 1875. Soon after, though, following Bizet's death, it caught the public's fancy and its melodies became among the most popular in the opera repertory.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Cost, Not Accountability, Is the Malpractice Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soviet Called Vague On Proposal in Geneva
description: A group of United States senators monitoring the arms negotiations here said today that the Soviet Union had failed to put specific, detailed elements of its latest arms proposal on the negotiating table in Geneva, a month after it was announced by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: U.S. OUSTS IACOCCA AS CHAIRMAN OF ADVISERS ON STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel today removed Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, as head of a Federal advisory commission on restoration of the Statue of Liberty and historic buildings on Ellis Island.

title: Senators and Serious Stuff
description: When things are getting too heavy on Capitol Hill, Senator Charles E. Grassley has an antidote. He goes to his closet and withdraws a briefcase marked ''Top Secret.''

title: MORE FACING SPECTER OF THE ALTERNATIVE TAX
description: From Park Avenue to Palm Beach, the biggest fear among the well-to-do at this time of year is the threat posed to their pocketbooks by the ''alternative minimum tax.'' This year there is more concern than usual.

title: CHARLOTTE C. MADISON
description: Charlotte C. Madison, a former director and president of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, died at Syosett Hospital in Long Island Sunday.

title: BRITTON LEE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $176,000 for the quarter and including an extraordinary tax credit of $889,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $456,000 for the quarter and $1,612,000 for the year. Corrected from Tuesday's editions.

title: Advertising; Ally Faces The Perils Of Success
description: THE scenario has played itself out many times on Madison Avenue.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $68,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, and gains from extraordinary tax credits of $461,000 for the quarter, $648,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $142,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months. The quarter results are also after a writedown of $234,000 for a marketable security sold by the company.

title: ANDAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $2,667,000 for the quarter, $3,107,000 for the year. Results for the latest year is also after a loss of $956,000. c-After an extraordinary loss of $87,000 for the quarter, including an extraordinary gain of $1,309,000 for the year. Results for the prior year also includes a gain of $2,420,000 from the company's equity in the results of Kinney Systems Inc.

title: NEW IRANIAN DRIVE SEEN AS DIVERSION
description: Iranian troops occupied a small, marshy wedge of Iraq's southern territory this week, but several American officials and military analysts said they saw the offensive as a feint and possible prelude to another attempt to cross the Tigris River north of Basra, Iraq's second largest city.

title: Out From Teller's Cage
description: At the not very ripe age of 38, Nat Bailey is going to retire from the Bankers Trust Company, where he works as an account manager.

title: BETTY ELDER THOMAS
description: Betty Elder Thomas, a lawyer active in social welfare and women's rights, died of cancer Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital in San Francisco, where she had lived for the last two years. She was 55 years old.

title: MCGRATH RENTCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
By Any Name
description: When he let it be known last fall that he no longer wanted to be referred to by the nickname that had been pinned on him as a left-handed schoolboy in Norfolk, Va., Charles G. (formerly Lefty) Driesell, the Maryland basketball coach, didn't realize what a nomenclatural storm he was stirring up. ''Being called Lefty is disrespectful,'' he explained at the time.

title: GOVERNOR TO PLAY A ROLE IN WHO'LL LEAD QUEENS
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would play a role in the selection of a new Queens borough president and county Democratic leader to succeed Donald R. Manes, who resigned Tuesday.

title: The High Price Nonsmokers Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from the sale of property of $1,000 for the quarter and $1,925,000 for the year. c-Including gains from the sale of property of $105,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for the year.

title: No Supporters of Athenian Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors v. Lawyers: 'A Real Nasty Fight'
description: Around the United States doctors and lawyers are at war over malpractice suits, and in the last few weeks Washington has become an especially important battlefront.

title: Bridge: A Splinter Bid Is a Weapon For a Von Zedtwitz Match
description: Modern experts are much more successful than those of earlier generations in bidding slams based on a perfect fit. If all the high-card strength is in the right places, a slam with a low point-count becomes possible, but diagnosis is difficult and special weapons are needed.

title: Combined to Grow By Buying Insurer
description: The Combined International Corporation, a Chicago-based insurance holding company with $3 billion in assets, said today that it had agreed to buy a life insurance subsidiary of Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc. for $557 million.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Chuck Klausing, who compiled a 77-15-2 record in 10 years as head football coach at Carnegie-Mellon in the Division III Presidents' Athletic Conference, has stepped up three divisions and down a position by moving a few football fields away to take over as assistant head coach at Pitt under Coach Mike Gottfried. . . . Steve Calabria, the quarterback from Carle Place, L.I., who set 43 records at Colgate, and three other free agents have signed with the New England Patriots. Besides Calabria, a ninth-round draft choice of Tampa Bay last spring, the Patriots signed the defensive ends Aaron Moog of Nevada-Las Vegas and Leonard Wingate of South Carolina State and the fullback Scott Napier of Redlands. . . . Saying it was time to make a change, Oklahoma State has told its head basketball coach for the last seven seasons, Paul Hansen, that it will not renew his contract next season, but that he would be welcome to remain in the program as an assistant athletic director. Hansen, whose record is 12-10 this season and 104-86 at the school, declined the offer.

title: NAVY DOCTOR SUTURES GLOVE FINGERS IN TRIAL DISPLAY
description: Dr. Donal M. Billig, a Navy surgeon defending his conduct in open-heart operations in which five patients died, rolled up his sleeves today and demonstrated to jurors that he can sew surgical stitches.

title: Title Fights
description: The unbeaten fighters Pinklon Thomas and Hector Camacho will be among three champions who will defend their World Boxing Council titles March 22 at Las Vegas, Nev., the promoters Butch Lewis and Don King announced yesterday.

title: Times Mirror Net Off 30.5%
description: The Times Mirror Company said today that its net income dropped 30.5 percent in the fourth quarter, to $58.2 million, or 90 cents a share, from $83.7 million, or $1.21 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 7.3 percent, to $803.6 million, from $748.7 million a year ago.

title: ROMANTIC DINING, WHAT IS IT AND WHERE IS IT BEST?
description: A RESTAURANT writer's mail is a fairly accurate social barometer.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $321,000. c-Net loss. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter. There were no such requirements in the year-earlier period.

title: Irish Prime Minister Shuffles Cabinet Posts
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald announced a major reorganization of his coalition Government today in an apparent effort to revive lagging support.

title: Homeless Shelter Operator Begins New Fast in Capital
description: The operator of Washington's largest shelter for homeless people has begun a new fast that he vowed to maintain until he saw a ''change of heart'' from the White House.

title: CITY SCHOOLS' DROPOUT RATE SHOWS BIG DECLINE FOOR YEAR
description: The dropout rate in the New York City public school system declined by more than six percentage points last year to its lowest level since the city's Board of Education began keeping such statistics in 1977, school officials announced yesterday.

title: When Washington Left
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavs to Try Croat Accused of War Crimes
description: An 86-year-old Croat described as the highest-ranking Nazi war criminal to enter the United States is to stand trial in Zagreb on charges of committing war crimes against civilians and war prisoners, a Yugoslav justice official said today.

title: Retail Sales Up a Slim 0.1%
description: Retail sales rose a mere one-tenth of 1 percent in January as setbacks at department stores and clothing stores offset strong demand for new autos, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Standard Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Mosler Safe Co. to a new company owned by an affiliate of Kelso & Co., Mosler's management and an employee stock plan.

title: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAZARE KAPLAN, DIAMOND DEALER, DIES AT 102
description: Lazare Kaplan, one of the world's best-known diamond merchants and the man who cut the 726-carat Jonker diamond in 1936, died Wednesday morning at his farm just outside Lew Beach in Sullivan County, N.Y. He was 102 years old.

title: South Korean Police Raid Opposition Offices
description: Policemen sealed off the headquarters of two opposition groups today, apparently in an effort to stop a petition drive for direct presidential elections.

title: JUDGE BARS STEP IN U.P.I. CASE
description: A Federal district judge in Washington delivered yet another blow late yesterday to efforts by the Financial News Network to acquire United Press International.

title: THE SCREEN: 'WILDCATS,' WITH HAWN
description: GOLDIE HAWN plays the flossy blond coach of an inner-city high-school football team in ''Wildcats,'' which opens today at the RKO Warner Twin. At first she meets resistance from the players, but she eventually wins them over with her sheer stick-to-itiveness and grit. This is another of the iron-buttercup roles in which Miss Hawn has been specializing since ''Private Benjamin,'' films in which her inspired dizziness masks an unexpectedly strong will. Initially, that contrast was delightful. But it has begun to seem less and less funny as Miss Hawn's films develop a preachier edge.

title: C.I.A. ACCUSED OF TOLERATING KILLINGS IN HONDURAS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency aided Honduran security forces that it knew were responsible for having killed a number of people they detained for political reasons between 1981 and 1984, according to two American officials and a Honduran military officer.

title: It Isn't a 'Gay Rights' Bill
description: The deep feelings across New York City and in the City Council triggered by the bill to outlaw discrimination in employment, housing and public accommodations on the basis of ''sexual orientation'' - incorrectly called the ''gay rights bill'' - are often triggered by misconceptions about its scope and nature.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share results for both periods reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 31, 1986.

title: Morgana King
description: Morgana King will sing tonight through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight and tomorrow, 8 and 10 P.M. Sunday; there is a $15 cover tonight and tomorrow, a $12.50 cover Sunday and a $7.50 minimum each night.

title: GENUINE PARTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,339,000 for the quarter and $3,118,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $5,797,000.

title: Yeager
description: Perhaps because of the Challenger disaster, Chuck Yeager seems even more of an authentic American hero than ever.

title: SCREEN: 'DELTA FORCE'
description: IN his ''Missing in Action,''

title: Reagan TV Speech Planned
description: President Reagan will deliver a nationwide television address on his budget for the Pentagon toward the end of the month, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said today.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges for establishment of reserves of $105 million for the closedown of the company's project to adapt its System 12 digital switch for the United States and $55 million for the disposal of its message terminal rental and facsimile transmission businesses, and a loss of $25 million on the sale of a major part of ITT Grinnell Corp. Also, including a gain of $46 million from the sale of limited partnership units in ITT Rayonier Inc. timberland properties. c-Net income Year-ago revenue figures are restated principally to reflect divestitures. Revenue figures for the latest periods include insurance and finance revenue of $2.3 billion for the quarter and $8.1 billion for the year, compared with $1.8 billion and $6.8 billion for the year-earlier quarter and year, respectively.

title: EASTERN CRITICIZES DISCLOSURE OF DRUG INQUIRY
description: The chairman of Eastern Airlines, Frank Borman, today criticized the disclosure that dozens of Eastern baggage handlers were the target of a Federal inquiry on cocaine smuggling, calling it ''unfortunate.''

title: FILM: 'THE GO MASTERS,' DESTINY OF TWO PEOPLES
description: IT'S easy to credit the claim that ''The Go Masters,'' which opens at the Thalia today, has been seen by more people in Asia than any other movie. This Chinese-Japanese co-production, the first, is chockfull of elements that have stirred audiences on many continents - a lost child and a searching parent, enduring friendship and true love, the pain of war and the joy of new life. And it is put together most scenically by the co-directors, Junya Sato of Japan and Duan Jishun of China. It's like a well-served banquet of the People's favorite dishes, never mind the fastidious palate or the delicate digestion.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
FRANCE MAY ASK U.S. TO TAKE DUVALIER
description: France may ask the United States to provide a home for the ousted Haitian dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier if Liberia refuses to accept him, according to Government officials.

title: SCREEN: 'TURTLE DIARY,' WITH PINTER SCREENPLAY
description: HAVING chucked - sometime in the past - his wife, his children and the shabby victories of life as an aspiring, middle-class London businessman, William Snow (Ben Kingsley) lives in one room in a boarding house and works as a bookstore sales clerk. Besieged by aimlessness, William survives each day by concentrating on those essential functions required to stay alive. He looks normal enough, but often sounds as mad as a hatter.

title: THE PLUSES AND MINUSES OF RETAIL PAINKILLERS
description: The active ingredient in Tylenol, acetaminophen, is one of the three widely used painkilling drugs available without prescription, each of which has pluses and minuses.

title: AMR CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WEAN UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $9,055,000 for the quarter and the year from the termination of a benefit plan for salaried employees in 1984 and certain tax credits. c-Net income.

title: 7 Children Killed in Fire; Escape Routes Blocked
description: Fire swept through a three-room house whose back door and windows had been nailed shut, killing seven children from two families early today, officials said.

title: ART: PORTRAITS BY MILTON AVERY AT BORGENICHT
description: SINCE Milton Avery's death in 1965, no aspect of his work has gone unexamined. The early years, the late work, ''important'' paintings, Avery in black and white, Avery in Mexico -these are just a few of the themes that shows have been built around, both before and after the Whitney retrospective of 1982. It's not a matter of whether a year has gone by without an exhibition (it hasn't), but of how many shows there have been in any given year, country and worldwide.

title: ...And What They Still Need Help With
description: To the Editor:

title: BRONX BOROUGH CHIEF SUBPOENAED AS WITNESS IN CORRUPTION INQUIRY
description: Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon said yesterday that he had been subpoenaed as a witness in the continuing Federal investigation of political corruption in New York City.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $78,000 for the quarter and year and an extraordinary net gain of $1,979,000 for the quarter and year from reversion of excess pension plan assets. c-Including equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $178,000 for the quarter and $115,000 for the year.

title: PORTRAIT OF COLEMAN
description: ''Ornette: Made in America,'' a portrait of the jazz great Ornette Coleman by the film maker Shirley Clarke, will be shown at the Public Theater from next Friday through Thrusday, Feb. 27, in honor of Black History Month. The film's locations include Morocco, Nigeria, Fort Worth and New York City.

title: End of 11-Year Journey: U.S. Citizenship
description: ''I saw light, like the sunrise, when I got to the border,'' Dith Pran recalled, ''but I felt nervous until today - when I get complete freedom.''

title: CUOMO MIGHT PUT OFF STATE SENATE RACE IN BRONX
description: Governor Cuomo is considering not calling a special State Senate election in the Bronx in an unusual attempt to reduce the influence of Stanley M. Friedman, the county Democratic leader, in the selection of a candidate.

title: FILM: TAVIANIS' 'KAOS,' FOUR TALES OF SICILY
description: ''Kaos'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 13. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 63d Street. ''KAOS,'' the Greek word for

title: Imperial, Hanson
description: The Imperial Group P.L.C. said it had rejected a request from Hanson Trust P.L.C. for a meeting to agree on conditions for a recommended bid. Imperial is fighting off Hanson's bid of $:1.8 billion, or about $2.5 billion, which was cleared Wednesday by the British Office of Fair Trading. An Imperial statement said the company continued to believe that its independence was in the best interests of shareholders.

title: ART: MOSKOWITZ'S VIEW OF SCULPTURAL AND ARCHITECTURAL ICONS
description: ROBERT MOSKOWITZ uses the pictorial conventions of late modernism as tools for artistic, emotional and psychological exploration. In the course of working the surface, flattening shape, analyzing line and developing the relationship between figure and ground, Moskowitz gets inside the image. When his paintings are most successful, it is impossible to tell whether he has been making a painting about a familiar image or monument or whether the image or monument has been making a painting about him.

title: Diner's Journal
description: LE MADELEINE, an engaging little French bistro on West 43d Street near Ninth Avenue, is often overlooked as a moderately priced dining option in the theater district, although it shouldn't be. It is a lively spot at night, where theater people gather at the long bar to leaf through issues of Variety and talk shop. The dining room is low key and charming, with brick walls, wooden banquettes and butcher paper-covered tables. During the warm months, a backyard garden is open for dining.

title: Going to the Top
description: Bill Cunningham, a nighttime radio talk-show host in Cincinnati and a fan of that city's Xavier University basketball team, is convinced that the only thing standing in the way of a major Middle Western conference of Catholic schools is Notre Dame. Or, more specifically, Digger Phelps, the basketball coach at Notre Dame, a school that has never needed a conference to drum up interest in its own sports programs.

title: Pacific Lumber Wins a Ruling
description: A last-ditch attempt by six dissident stockholders of the Pacific Lumber Company to block the $832 million takeover of the timber giant by Maxxam Group Inc. has been rejected by a Federal judge, who said the buyout was in the stockholders' interest.

title: Court Says Judges Can't Get Both Pensions and Salaries
description: A state appellate court ruled today that eight judges, including former State Supreme Court Justice William C. Brennan of Queens, had no legal right to use a loophole in the State Civil Service Law to collect both their judicial salaries and retirement benefits.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ISLANDERS FALL AS FLYERS RALLY
description: In their last four meetings with the Philadelphia Flyers, the Islanders were the dominant team, and they had actually used the Flyers, a team they had been intimidated by last season, to fuel their January renaissance. But tonight there was a complete turnaround as the Islanders went from leading the game, 2-0, to losing it, 6-3, at the Spectrum.

title: Advertising; Postage Stamp as Ad Medium
description: IN the contest to come up with the most offbeat advertising medium, American Discount Stamps Ltd. of Houston may be the hands-down winner.

title: ROANOKE ELECTRIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PROJECT IN FLUSHING ADDS TO MIX OF HOUSING STYLES
description: New housing development in Queens does not always occur in obvious places. It finds its way to sites off the beaten track. The builders, willing to undertake a few apartments here and a few more there, go where the land is available and the sales market is proven.

title: Art of the Hologram
description: About 20 holograms will be on view beginning Sunday at the Bruce Museum, Museum Drive, Greenwich, Conn.

title: Mr. Speaker
description: In his State of the Union Message last week, President Reagan personally addressed Speaker O'Neill. ''Mr. Speaker,'' he said, ''you know, I know, the Federal budget system is broken, it doesn't work. Before we leave this city, let's you and I work together to fix it.''

title: REAGAN PLANS TO SEEK NEW MILITARY AID TO CONTRAS
description: The Reagan Admnistration plans to proceed with a request for renewed military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, despite lukewarm support in Congress and adamant opposition from leaders of some other Governments in the region, senior officials said today.

title: Late Surge Lifts Dow to Record Again
description: A flurry of buying in the last hour of trading sent the stock market sharply higher yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average to its fifth record close in the last six sessions.

title: SEAL ON DRUG PACKAGE CAN BE FORGED
description: Attempts to make tamper-proof containers are at least as old as the hollow clay tokens sealed with cuneiform writing that were used in commerce in ancient Mesopotamia. Then, as today, the object was to make a seal so difficult for a forger to reproduce that tampering would be immediately evident.

title: WHEN SPIES ARE TRADED, WOLFGANG VOGEL IS THERE
description: At an improvised little ceremony at Tempelhof Airport on Tuesday, Wolfgang Vogel, an East German lawyer, was handing out china plates. The recipients were the American diplomats and officials who had been involved in the negotiations that would soon lead to the freedom of Anatoly B. Shcharansky.

title: KENTUCKY TRIUMPHS BY 73-71
description: Roger Harden hit a 22-foot shot with five seconds to play to give Kentucky a 73-71 victory over Alabama tonight in the the Southeastern Conference game.

title: BROADWAY SURVEY DEFENDS PRICES
description: In an effort to combat public perceptions of the high cost of Broadway theater tickets, the League of New York Theaters and Producers, Broadway's official trade association, released a study yesterday asserting that Broadway ticket prices have risen less than the cost of theater operations and less than the purchasing power of consumers.

title: Connecticut Fines Hutton $350,000
description: The State of Connecticut today fined E. F. Hutton & Company $350,000 and put the brokerage firm on a year's probation for its admitted overdrafting of bank accounts.

title: AMERICAN MAIZE-PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from minority interest of $230,000 for the quarter and $315,000 for the year. The year results also includes a nontaxable gain of $462,000 from the sale of previously unissued shares of a subsidiary, American Fructose Corporation. c-Net income after losses from minority interest of $369,000 for the quarter and $1,910,000 for the year. The year results also includes a nontaxable gain of $6,275,000 from the sale of previously unissued shares of a subsidiary, A.F. Corp.

title: Sator Sounds Off
description: ''We want to put a class team on the ice,'' Ted Sator said yesterday, ''and we wouldn't want Madison Square Garden to give the game a black eye.'' The Ranger coach made his remarks after Garden fans drenched several members of the Vancouver Canucks with beer and soft drinks in the waning moments of the Rangers' 5-2 victory Tuesday night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1986
description: Companies

title: HASBRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Neo-Nazis' 'Banker' Gets 5-Year Jail Sentence
description: Kenneth Loff, whom prosecutors called the ''banker'' of a neo-Nazi group, the Order, was sentenced today to five years in prison.

title: CRACOW BANNERS OF RIDICULE RECALL THE DARK 50'S
description: The courtyard of the medieval palace on Cracow's Guildhall Square was decorated in the style of 1956. A poster three stories high depicted the Stalinist leader of postwar Poland.

title: ART: ITALIAN DRAWINGS AT THE MORGAN LIBRARY
description: TO do justice to Duke Roberto Ferretti whose collection of Italian Old Master drawings is now on view at the Pierpont Morgan Library, we really need Giuseppe di Lampedusa, the author of ''The Leopard.'' He, if anyone, could handle the ancient lineage, the happy and privileged childhood (winters in Milan, summers in Ancona), the collection of antiquarian books begun at the age of 10, the service in the Noble Guards at the Vatican during World War II, the subsequent and enviable successes in business worldwide and the wonderfully casual way in which the Duke came to collect drawings. (Coming upon some very pretty antique frames at home, he decided to buy a few drawings to put in them).

title: Romantic Arias
description: Love, opera-style, will be celebrated Sunday at 2:30 P.M. with a performance of romantic arias by Il Piccolo Teatro Dell'Opera at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section.

title: Alaska Pilot Rescued
description: An injured pilot was trapped in his crashed airplane in the mountains for three days and suffered frostbite before being rescued, state troopers said today. The pilot, Michael Harbough, 33 years old, was hoisted from his single-engine Cessna Wednesday night by a helicopter from Elmendorf Air Force Base.

title: Congress; A Dissertation on the Mail
description: Hundreds of millions of letters arrive on Capitol Hill every year, most of them requesting assistance of some sort or urging members of Congress to take some particular legislative action.

title: Ex-Federal Prosecutor Convicted in Drug Case
description: A former Federal prosecutor was convicted Thursday in Federal District Court here on four of six counts stemming from charges that he sold confidential information to drug smugglers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They say good things come in threes, so. . . .'' - Evelyn Marie Adams, two-time million-dollar winner in the New Jersey lottery. [ A1:1. ]

title: Koch Seeks Amnesty For Parking Violators
description: Mayor Koch proposed an amnesty period yesterday for people who owe parking fines.

title: 2 Salvadorans Guilty In Americans' Deaths
description: Two former National Guardsmen were found guilty of homicide late today in the 1981 shooting deaths of two American land-reform experts and a Salvadoran in a hotel coffee shop.

title: PRISON PORTRAYED BY SHCHARANSKY
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky today described life in Soviet jails, detailing methods of psychological and physical pressure to force political prisoners to inform on others or confess to fictitious crimes.

title: CHALLENGER, DISCLOSURE AND AN 8TH CASUALTY FOR NASA
description: Shock, confusion and a lapse of self-confidence seemed to lead the space agency to ignore its own contingency plans for giving the public all the known facts in the first hours and days after the explosion of the space shuttle.

title: Article 935686 -- No Title
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that it lost $33.5 million in the fourth quarter, narrowing the loss from $91.1 million a year ago. Sales rose 9.5 percent, to $1.15 bilion, from $1.05 billion, a year ago.

title: JURORS TOLD THAT TAPES HOLD KEY IN BOSTON RACKETEERING TRIAL OF 5
description: Attorneys in the Federal racketeering trial of five reputed New England mobsters finished two weeks of final arguments today, telling jurors they would find proof of a criminal enterprise, or the lack of it, in hundreds of secretly recorded conversations.

title: RIVER OAKS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BROWN EMERGING IN A LEADING ROLE
description: Since the Ivy League began crowning a men's basketball champion, Brown has never finished higher than a tie for second place. Last season, the Bruins finished seventh in the league and lost an all-conference forward and their starting center to graduation.

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES RISE 4.3%
description: Propped up by low-rate financing campaigns, sales of new American-made automobiles rose 4.3 percent, to 172,373, in the first 10 days of February over the corresponding period last year, the seven major manufacturers reported today.

title: HASSEY RETURNS TO YANKEES
description: Nine weeks after they traded him, the Yankees re-acquired Ron Hassey from the Chicago White Sox yesterday to bolster their catching corps. The catcher was part of a seven-player trade in which the White Sox received the relief pitcher Neil Allen, the catcher Scott Bradley, Glen Braxton, a minor-league outfielder who was in the original Hassey trade, and an unspecified amount of cash.

title: Gooden Pact Is Near
description: Dwight Gooden's agent said yesterday that he was just ''one telephone call away'' from reaching agreement with the Mets on a one-year contract that would make the 21-year-old strikeout pitcher the youngest millionaire in baseball history.

title: Smoke and Fire in the Iacocca Flap
description: Why did Interior Secretary Donald Hodel remove Chrysler's chairman, Lee Iacocca, from one of his two Statue of Liberty restoration positions?

title: No Unsuspecting Public In TV Call-In Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: LURIA, L & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Leader of New Group Has 29 Years at Morgan
description: A day after he was given greatly expanded responsibilities at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, Robert G. Engel was not sure how many people would be working for him.

title: Our Legal System Turns Winners Into Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHER PROJECT GOES ON, NASA SAYS
description: The program to put a teacher in space will continue, the space agency announced today, and Christa McAuliffe's backup has been offered the chance to fly aboard the shuttle.

title: ITALY'S MALES ARE, WELL, ITALIAN
description: There was a proverb once popular among Italian men: ''A woman is like an egg. The more she is beaten the better she becomes.'' But it seems today's woman has developed a much harder shell. As a result, many Italian males are finding it more difficult to be a man today than it was 20 years ago.

title: What Kids Can Teach Adults . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIAL REPORTS TEXAS IS FALLING SHORT ON BUDGET
description: State Comptroller Bob Bullock, saying falling oil prices had produced a fiscal crisis, reported today that Texas was facing a $1.3 billion shortage in its current 1986-1987 budget.

title: Lost Hearts Found
description: Just before St. Valentine's Day, Patricia Mulcahy got back the silver hearts that she was certain she would never see again.

title: FILM: 'AMERICAN RABBIT'
description: IN ''The Adventures of the American Rabbit,'' the animated feature that opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters, a young rabbit named Robert is chosen to be his generation's super-rabbit.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $104,000 for the quarter and $707,000 for the 6 months. c-Net losses.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: ''WHEN you find something in music that interests you, you start looking for the secret,'' says the tenor saxophonist Bill Barron, who will be making one of his infrequent New York appearances tomorrow night for the Universal Jazz Coalition. ''As long as it eludes you, you have to keep digging. And then, when you think you've got it, it's really easy to start boring yourself. So you have to keep changing.'' These remarks could stand as a career summary for the Philadelphia- born musician. In jazz circles, Philadelphia is especially noted for the many formidable tenor saxophonists who grew up and learned to play there - John Coltrane, Jimmy Heath, Benny Golson, Archie Shepp and Odean Pope, to name a few. Mr. Barron is one of the very best of these saxophonists, a contemporary of Mr. Coltrane and Mr. Heath who exercised considerable influence on younger players. He may also be the least widely known. Part of the reason is that he has been a full-time educator since 1972. He is now chairman of the music department at Wesleyan University in Connecticut.

title: Advertising; Foote, Cone Net Up 24.1%
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc. reported that its fourth-quarter earnings were up 24.1 percent over the corresponding period the year before, increasing to $7.2 million, or $1.89 a share, from $5.8 million, or $1.53 a share. Revenues reached an all-time high for any quarter, climbing to $80.5 million - an increase of 8.5 percent over the previous year.

title: SCREEN: 'HUEY LONG'
description: ''Huey Long'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 28. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street, at La Guardia Place.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'ROMANCE ON ICE' Valentine's Day brings an ice show called ''Romance on Ice'' to the South Street Seaport, which is celebrating a Winter Festival this weekend with free festivities ranging from ice sculptures to wandering minstrel singers. ''Romance on Ice,'' with a cast of 12 led by Laurie and Greg Welch, will be presented today at 5:30, 6:15 and 7 P.M. at Pier 17, off South Street. Performance times Saturday and Sunday are at 2:30, 3:15 and 4. An ice extravaganza of a different sort is offered up in the Masters Gallery of Ice Sculpture, which opens today at 2 in Market Square, between Fulton and South Streets. Created by chefs from restaurants and hotels, the ice sculptures include an 1,800-pound Cupid and a frozen jungle complete with a giraffe, tiger, bear and elephant. Meanwhile, a video theater at 14 Fulton Street will provide continuous screenings of six films on skiing, while outdoors a band of ''Currier and Ives'' singers roams the seaport in 19th-century attire. Information: 732-7678. CLOWN AND MIME

title: DANCE: 'BIRD/BEAR' BY LEE NAGRIN
description: LEE NAGRIN'S ''Bird/Bear,'' which the Sky Fish Ensemble presented Wednesday night at the Silver Whale Gallery, was like a fairy tale. To be strictly accurate, it was like several fairy tales jumbled together.

title: U.S. Pressure Won't Cause the Sandinistas to Collapse
description: The Reagan Administration remains convinced that ''increasing the pressure on the Sandinistas'' - to quote Assistant Secretary of State Elliot Abrams - will lead to the ultimate collapse of the Sandinista Government and the emergence of a new government, more ''democratic'' and more responsive to United States interests. My own observations during a recent trip to Nicaragua, as well as the views of every single diplomat and independent observer I saw, suggest that this seemingly plausible, comforting assumption is dangerously wrong.

title: Boris Smolar, Retired Editor of Jewish Telegraphic Agency
description: Boris Smolar, editor in chief emeritus of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, died on Jan. 31 at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Market Place; Southland's Venezuela Deal
description: ANALYSTS applauded the Southland Corporation's announcement last week that it intends to sell half of its Citgo refining and marketing unit to Venezuela's state-owned oil company for approximately $300 million plus perhaps $250 million more in working capital.

title: 76ERS EDGE KNICKS
description: It is rare that a single play can capsulize an entire season, but such a play occurred last night at Madison Square Garden in the final 10 seconds of the Knicks' disheartening 95-92 loss to the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: HOW 'BOUT THEM DAWGS?
description: If there is one good thing that will come from the awarding of $2.5 million to Jan Kemp in her suit against the University of Georgia, it is that standards will have to be raised at the major sports colleges around the country.

title: FORD AND CHRYSLER FINISH STRONG YEAR
description: The American automobile industry wrapped up the second-most-profitable year in its history today, as the Ford Motor Company reported 1985 earnings of $2.52 billion and the Chrysler Corporation reported $1.64 billion.

title: CAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Rash of Flats on I-20
description: Sharp chunks of scrap metal spilled from a truck on Interstate 20 east of Jackson, Miss., today, flattening tires of nearly 80 vehicles in the rush hour, the police said.

title: Campbell Soup Net Up
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that it earned $69.7 million, or $1.08 a share, in its second fiscal quarter, up 15.8 percent from $60.2 million, or 93 cents a share, a year ago. Sales totaled more than $1.18 billion, up 11.3 percent from $1.06 billion a year ago.

title: DAIMLER-BENZ
description: The Federal cartel office today approved Daimler-Benz's takeover of A.E.G. to form West Germany's biggest industrial conglomerate.The cartel office approved the auto maker's acquisition of a majority stake in A.E.G., an electronics producer, after the two companies agreed to sell interests in four small subsidiaries.The approval clears the way for Daimler-Benz to buy a 30 percent stake in A.E.G. offered by a consortium of West German banks. When combined with previously owned shares, the purchase will give Daimler a 54 percent stake in A.E.G.

title: English Club To Play in Italy
description: Manchester United announced today that it would play an exhibition game against AC Milan in Italy on April 29, the first time since a ban on English teams was relaxed that a game involving an English club has been arranged on the European mainland.

title: 'Newport Jazz '85,' With B. B. King
description: Contemporary jazz has a lot more vitality than the bland performances offered on the hourlong ''Newport Jazz '85'' could lead one to believe. The show, which will be on Channel 13 tonight at 10, features some of the biggest names in blues and jazz, including the blues giant B. B. King, the hotshot Texan guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan and his band, Double Trouble, the trumpeter Freddie Hubbard leading an all-star quintet, and the popular jazz-fusion group Spyro Gyra.

title: GROLIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit equal to 7 cents a share. c-Including a tax credit equal to 8 cents a share.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $88,075,000. c-Net income.

title: JAPAN CONCERNED OVER PHILIPPINES
description: Japan, as the dominant economic force in Southeast Asia, has followed the Philippine election with concern but with no sense of how to deal with charges of fraud.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $9.3 million for the quarter and $28.8 million for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $10.8 million.

title: SLATTERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $51,000 in the quarter and including a gain of $109,000 in the year from discontinued operations. c-Net income. d-After a loss of $48,000 in the quarter and including a gain of $423,000 from discontinued operations.

title: 2D TAINTED BOTTLE OF TYLENOL FOUND BY INVESTIGATORS
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had found a second bottle of Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules laced with cyanide that had been seized from a store in Westchester County. The discovery came five days after a woman died in Yonkers from a Tylenol capsule that contained the poison.

title: 600 in Squash Event
description: Six hundred of the country's top players will compete at 13 Manhattan clubs this weekend in the 80th United States Squash Racquets Association Singles Championship.

title: A Strike That Failed
description: The sad and highly publicized failure of a strike by Minnesota meatpackers against Hormel is costing most of the workers their jobs. Less a labor action than a defiant shaking of fists at large economic forces, it resembled the demonstrations by farmers trying to keep banks from repossessing their land.

title: FATEFUL CHOICE IN FATAL ILLNESS: HOW LONG TO LIVE
description: When the 69-year-old man entered the hospital here recently he thought he had only a back problem. When he left for home six days later he had chosen to die.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUACTURERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest 6 months results include the operations of Jonathan Logan Inc., which was acquired in fiscal 1985 for the entire period, compared with last year's first 6 months, which included Logan's operations from September 1984.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an net gain of $1.2 million, or 8 cents a share, from the sale of non-oil and gas assets.

title: New Lineup
description: Willie Mays, reflecting on his return to the San Francisco Giants: ''I only know three or four of the players, but I think they know me.''

title: SAILOR SAYS HE 'SNAPPED' IN SLAYING OF OFFICER
description: A black sailor seeking to avoid the death penalty testified today that he was abused as a child and faced racial harassment in the military. ''I just snapped,'' he said, recalling the day he murdered a white officer at sea.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $1.18 billion, to $209.96 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: 'ANNE OF GREEN GABLES' ON PUBLIC TV
description: IT would almost seem as if Sunday's premiere of ''Anne of Green Gables'' on Channel 13 at 7 P.M. were designed as a rebuke and object lesson to the leaden adaptation of ''Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' that began on the same station last Monday. Both productions are based on novels that have become classics for younger audiences. Both are four hours long. And both feature an orphaned child on a quest for survival and fulfillment. But while television's ''Huck Finn'' sinks in its own self-conscious waters, ''Anne'' emerges with its irascible charm thoroughly intact.

title: AMERICARE HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A CITY NERVOUSLY WAITS FOR LAYOFF NEWS
description: James Anderson, an engineer for the Eastman Kodak Company, described a sense of nervous anticipation in the company's vast factories, laboratories and offices here. ''It's like thinking about a car wreck,'' said Mr. Anderson, one of 54,000 who work for Kodak in Rochester.

title: PRIME MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CYCLOPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,766,000 from insurance settlement.

title: KN Energy's Chief Relives Old Battle
description: J. Robert Wilson is in the midst of a rematch with an old nemesis. For the second time in three years, KN Energy Inc., a Colorado-based natural gas distribution concern, is the object of an unsolicited takeover offer from T. Boone Pickens, general partner of Mesa Limited Partnership.

title: REPO STANDARDS CREATED
description: Securities dealers and their lawyers have agreed on a standardized form for repurchase agreements, the Public Securities Association, a trade group representing firms that trade in United States Government, tax-exempt and mortgage-backed securities, announced this week.

title: GIRL, 16, IS ACCUSED OF GIVING CLASSMATE $400 TO KILL FATHER
description: A 16-year-old high school cheerleader was arrested by the Suffolk County police yesterday and charged with paying a classmate $400 to murder her father, who was shot to death in the driveway of his home 10 days ago.

title: CHRYSLER TAKES ON KOREA'S HYUNDAI
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would try to stem the influx of low-priced foreign cars, such as the Korean-made Hyundai, by selling a version of its Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon for $5,499 - $710 below the current base price for the subcompact model.

title: JOHN P. MARTINCO
description: John P. Martinco, a former foreign correspondent and foreign news editor for United Press International, died of cancer yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan.

title: U.S. and Soviet Sign a Pact Covering Direct Air Service
description: The United States and the Soviet Union formally agreed today to resume air service between the two countries on April 29.

title: HIGH COURT APPELLANT FOUND GUILTY IN 2D TRIAL
description: A man whose 1980 murder conviction was overturned by the United States Supreme Court a year ago because Oklahoma did not provide a psychiatrist to aid in his insanity defense was again found guilty Wednesday in the shooting of a minister and his wife.

title: Dining Out Guide: Three-Star, Part I
description: Following is a summary of reviews of three-star restaurants - other than French - that have appeared in The New York Times, including the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE FOUR SEASONS, #99 East 52d Street (754-9494) - (Nov. 22, 1985) This grand vessel of luxury has managed to stay on course during its 25-year voyage, maintaining standards of food quality and service that are paragons of the industry. Dining here differs according to where you sit: the Grill Room menu is lean and spirited; the lavish Pool Room with its lofty foliage and illuminated marble pool is romantic and extravagant. In the latter, the terrines are consistently superior, particularly one combining pheasant, quail and mallard duck; and the cold breast of pigeon with red currants is a winner. The roster of superior dishes is extensive -from duck au poivre with a brassy cracked-pepper sauce, to snapper baked in a crust of sea salt and pepper with two sauces, a rich tarragon and a lighter blend of lemon, olive oil and parsley, to scallops of veal with ginger. Grill Room dinner entrees, $25 to $30. Fridays, noon to 1:45 P.M. and 7:30 to 11:30; Saturdays, noon to 1:45. Pool Room dinner entrees $31 to $39. Fridays, noon to 2:30 and 5 to 11:30; Saturdays, 5 to 11:30. Closed Sundays. GOTHAM BAR AND GRILL, #12 East 12th

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $17.5 million attributable to restructuring and consolidation of the company's operations and writedowns of $5.3 million for inventory spare parts and other reserves. c-Net income.

title: Car Price Increase Seen
description: Japan's decision to keep a limit on auto exports will lead to higher car prices in the United States, but burgeoning Japanese production here may soon make such quotas irrelevant, industry analysts say.

title: BARNES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $669,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and including a gain of $622,000 from discontinued operations for the year. c-After a loss of $4,324,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ALL THE MAKINGS OF A VERY FUNNY WEEKEND
description: COMEDY has been called ''the rock of the 80's'' for very good reasons. With stand-up clubs booming and the Johnny Carson and David Letterman shows and ''Saturday Night Live'' turning young comedians into overnight sensations, there is a feeling that in comedy the sky's the limit, that all it takes to win the entertainment sweepstakes is the right oddball character spouting the right shtick.

title: CAVALIERS ROUT SAGGING NETS
description: Dave Wohl, the Nets' coach, held to his promise tonight and played Micheal Ray Richardson as the fourth guard instead of starting him in the backcourt. But the real punishment of the night came from the Cleveland Cavaliers, who defeated the Nets, 135-117.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
What's a Low Unemployment Rate?
description: Each month the White House trumpets yet another increase in the number of Americans with jobs. Now the eagerly awaited parallel seems also to have occurred: unemployment has taken a welcome dive. At 6.6 percent, the rate of joblessness last month was lower than the Government's forecast for the end of the year and is finally down to a level not seen since a year before President Reagan took office.

title: HNG/INTERNORTH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $34,778,000 for the quarter and $38,140,000 for the year and after an extraordinary charge of $218 million for the quarter and year. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $2,499,000 for the quarter and $10,781,000 for the year.

title: Soviet and Japanese Claims to the Kuriles
description: To the Editor:

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $750,000 for the latest first quarter and $1.2 million for the year-ago first quarter.

title: CASTING THE CHARACTERS FOR SUCCESSFUL CLUBS
description: Elizabeth Saltzman, 20 years old, works for Giorgio Armani, the designer. Simon F., her 24-year-old friend, is a rock singer. They are considered catches on Manhattan's late-night circuit. So when Miss Saltzman got home from work Wednesday night, she found their mailbox brimming with invitations from nightclubs vying to waive entry fees of up to $20 in exchange for their patronage.

title: 2 KEY SENATORS FAULT PRESIDENT ON PHILLIPINES
description: Philip C. Habib flew to the Philippines today on a fact-finding mission for President Reagan, as Senate criticism erupted over Mr. Reagan's handling of the issue of fraud in the presidential elections there.

title: INSURANCE GAP TO CLOSE TRAM TO ROOSEVELT I.
description: The red-and-blue cabins of the Roosevelt Island tramway will be grounded at midnight tonight when liability insurance for the aerial link to Manhattan runs out.

title: RUN AGAINST THE DOLLAR CONTINUES TO ACCELERATE
description: The decline of the dollar, managed by central banks since September at a slow and steady pace, has suddenly turned into a rout.

title: Manville Gets A Warning
description: A Federal District Court judge today accused the Manville Corporation of deliberately thwarting adjudication of thousands of claims against it by failing to provide information to victims of asbestos-related diseases.

title: Bill Berry, Trumpet
description: The trumpeter Bill Berry, who played in the Duke Ellington band, will lead a quintet tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, and at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: Advertising; People
description: Alix Nelson, president of Franklin Spier Inc., a subsidiary of BBDO International, has been appointed to the additional post of chief executive.

title: A Boil in the House
description: In the otherwise somnolent House, contests for Democratic leadership posts in the next Congress are coming to a boil, even though the elections in November may change the cast of lawmakers who vote in these contests. In past sessions, the Speaker and majority leader were elected and the whip was appointed by the Speaker, but so many whips have moved up over the years to become Speakers that that post was made elective, too, beginning in 1987.

title: Horace S. Manges, 87, Copyright Law Expert
description: Horace S. Manges, a founding partner of the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges and senior partner for many years, died Tuesday at his home. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ameriwest Financial Corp., Albuquerque, N.M., said John W. Thompson had resigned as president and chief operating officer.

title: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Asian Nations Alarmed
description: After nearly a week of unresolved disputes over almost every aspect of the Philippine election, many of Manila's partners in Southeast Asia are growing alarmed.

title: REMARKS ON C.I.A.'S POLICY
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech by Robert M. Gates, the Central Intelligence Agency's deputy director for intelligence, prepared for delivery tonight at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government:

title: C.I.A. AIDE SAYS AGENCY WILL LET SCHOLARS ACKNOWLEDGE BACKING
description: A senior official of the Central Intelligence Agency said tonight that the agency had relaxed rules that had barred professors from publicly acknowledging the C.I.A.'s support for their research.

title: Smithsonian in Dispute Over Indian Skeletons
description: Officials of the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of Natural History, criticized by two American Indian groups, say they would turn over to recognized tribal leaders Indian skeletons that have a ''clear biological or cultural link'' to modern-day tribal units.

title: SUSQUEHANNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
S-K-I LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Net loss.

title: NASH FINCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics; Safety Patrols Fighting Fear
description: Crime destroys urban neighborhoods - and so does the fear of crime. That's why police departments in New York and a few other cities have begun ''community patrol'' programs.

title: Topics; Safety Patrols Back on Track
description: A year ago New York City's Transit Authority won the removal of 1,189 supervisors from Civil Service and union jurisdiction. That and new technology now are showing results: a drastic reduction in the number of subway derailments caused by faulty track.

Flight Crew Grounded After 3 Missed Landings
description: Federal aviation officials today grounded an American Airlines pilot and his flight crew who had to abort three attempts to land a Boeing 727 with 125 passengers aboard.

title: EARLY MUSIC: GENTLE GRACE AND TEMPTING CHOICES
description: IN the booming field of early music, what's old is what's new.

title: Undaunted Author
description: Two years ago this month, with his first book surprising everyone by surging to the top of the best-seller list, the author, Edward I. Koch, was asked if he planned a second.

title: Economic Scene; Threats Posed By Budget Rift
description: THE unanimous ruling of a panel of three Federal judges that a key provision of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law is unconstitutional has cast doubt on the likelihood that Congress and the President can reach agreement on a plan to shrink the deficit.

title: ANALYST WHO GAVE SHUTTLE WARNING FAULTS 'GUNG-HO, CAN-DO' ATTITUDE
description: The analyst who warned last year of a possible space shuttle catastrophe said today that a ''gung-ho, can-do'' ethic at the space agency made it difficult to raise concerns about safety seals on the space shuttle's booster rockets.

title: TAMBRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,372,000 for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary loss of $4,266,000. The latest year extraordinary charge results from a product replacement program. The prior quarter and year extraordinary gain results from Canadian Federal sales tax refund.

title: INDIANA SCHOOL TOLD TO READMIT 14-YEAR-OLD STUDENT WITH AIDS
description: A county medical officer ruled today that a 14-year-old victim of AIDS posed no health threat to his fellow classmates and teachers and should be allowed to return to school.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
The U.N. Today; Feb. 14, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Tenneco Reduces Capital Spending
description: Citing the recent sharp decline in oil prices, Tenneco Inc., the Houston-based oil and gas company, said yesterday that it had reduced its 1986 capital spending budget by 25 percent, to $1.3 billion, from $1.7 billion in 1985. On Wednesday the Atlantic Richfield Company said it had reduced its 1986 capital budget to $2 billion, from $3 billion, because of the monthlong price slide that has shaken the oil industry.

title: RULE KEEPS HIGH SCHOOL COACHES ON BENCH
description: Like some other high school basketball coaches across the country, Ron Bell never forgets to buckle up. When his Marist High School War Eagles take the court, he straps himself in.

title: TRADE BILLS STILL PUSHED IN CONGRESS
description: Japan appears to have defused an explosive situation in trade relations with the United States by maintaining car export quotas for a sixth year. But members of Congress refused to rule out the possibility that Japan could become the target of protectionist action later this election year.

title: AT THE STATE LEVEL, TAX RELIEF
description: Although the Federal income tax burden was little changed for 1985, taxpayers in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey will find significant tax relief at the state level.

title: Latin-Jazz Show
description: There is a Latin-jazz double bill through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). The alto saxophonist Paquito d'Rivera and his band, and the keyboardist Jorge Dalto and his Inter-American band will trade sets, with complete shows at 9 and 11 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow. There is a $12.50 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain in the quarter and a loss in the year from discontinued operations of Foxmoor division.

title: IRAN SAYS ITS SOLDIERS ARE ADVANCING
description: Iran said today that its soldiers were advancing north along the highway from the Persian Gulf oil port of Fao to Basra, Iraq's second-largest city. Each side accused the other of using chemical weapons.

title: BROADWAY
description: CAN we wait? Let's try, because this one should be interesting. It's Robert De Niro of ''Raging Bull,'' ''Taxi Driver'' and ''Deer Hunter'' fame, with Burt Young, the brother-in-law of ''Rocky,'' and Ralph Macchio, ''The Karate Kid,'' together on stage. Or they will be as of April 15, when performances of ''Cuba and his Teddy Bear'' begin at the Public Theater.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: LAST weekend brought empirical evidence of something film industry experts have always been aware of: that audiences really do know what they want. Without unusual prodding from Orion Pictures, Woody Allen's ''Hannah and Her Sisters'' did extraordinary business; in Manhattan, it opened in three theaters during a nasty snowstorm and still managed to sell out every show.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $6,183,000. c-After a capital loss of $2,527,000.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ART and antiques from the private collection of Marjorie Acker Phillips - who with her husband created Washington's Phillips Collection, the nation's first major museum of modern art - will be auctioned in April at Phillips, Son & Neale. The sale does not include any of the museum's holdings of 2,500 modern-art works that Mrs. Phillips and her husband, Duncan, an heir to the Jones and Loughlin steel fortune, assembled and opened to the public in 1921.

title: NASA PHOTOS HINT TROUBLE STARTED RIGHT AT LIFTOFF
description: The space agency tonight made public new photographs of the shuttle Challenger that appear to show dark smoke shooting out of the right booster rocket only 1.4 seconds into liftoff.

title: Lincoln the Party Hack?
description: Lincoln was a man who rose above politics, many Americans believe; no mere partisan, our Abe. That is why politicians striving to appear Presidential like to twang the mystic chords of his memory.

title: SCREEN: 'TERRORVISION'
description: ''TERRORVISION'' again shows off the slime-happy special-effects style of John Buechler, who recently directed ''Troll.'' Next to ''Terrorvision,'' which was written and directed by Ted Nicolaou, that film looks like a model of restraint.

title: IACOCCA AND SECRETARY OF INTERIOR CLASH OVER STATUE PANEL OUSTER
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel angrily exchanged charges today over Mr. Hodel's dismissal of Mr. Iacocca from a Federal advisory commission on the future of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Signed Ed Jurak, utility infielder, to a one-year contract.

The year result also is after a charge of $62.5 million from sale of discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $24,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a nonrecurring gain of $9.2 million and other gains for the year. The year result also is after a pretax charge of $174 million for restructuring.

title: 'La Belle Helene'
description: A new version of ''La Belle Helene,'' the Jacques Offenbach operetta, is being presented through March 9 by the AMAS Repertory Theater, 1 East 104th Street.

title: Treasury Prices Climb Again
description: Treasury note and bond prices continued to rise yesterday, reducing the yield of new 30-year bonds to within shouting distance of 9 percent - a level not seen since August 1979.

title: ACKERLEY COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SOME DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST ARE MAILED IN ANONYMOUSLY
description: A contribution of $20,000 from an anonymous donor has helped to increase the record total of contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Gambino Jury Deliberating
description: After hearing nearly four and a half months of testimony, a Federal jury began deliberations late yesterday in the car-theft and murder-conspiracy trial of eight reputed members of the Gambino crime family.

title: STAGE: 'ROOM SERVICE,' 1937 FARCE, IS REVIVED
description: FOR anyone who's forgotten what Broadway used to be, there's always ''Room Service,'' the 1937 farce by John Murray and Allen Boretz now in revival Off Broadway, at the Roundabout. Set in a Times Square hotel and populated by theatrical types who really knew from Lindy's and Billy Rose, this entertainment harks back to a romantic era when putting on a hit play could be regarded as a handy antidote to all of life's woes. Even for the original audiences at ''Room Service,'' who were suffering through the Depression, the authors' faith in the curative powers of overnight Broadway success was an invitation to escapist dreaming. Now the play's fantasy of show-biz glory comes wrapped in nostalgia. When was the last time that anyone produced a 22-character drama on Broadway, as the protagonist of ''Room Service'' does, with the hope of making a mint?

title: RUNAWAY VICTORY STIRS DERBY DREAMS
description: ''Is it too late to nominate for the Derby?''

title: CONCERT: LISZT PIANO SERIES BY EARL WILD
description: THE pianist Earl Wild began his three-concert series of works by Franz Liszt with a program entitled ''Liszt the Poet'' at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night.

title: All-Sibelius Program
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic, under the direction of Lukas Foss, will present an all-Sibelius program tonight and tomorrow night at 8, and Sunday afternoon at 2 in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: CMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MILLROSE VAULTERS ARE READY TO SOAR
description: Sergei Bubka and Billy Olson will begin their two-week, five-meet battle tonight to determine who is king of the indoor pole-vaulters. Joe Dial can hardly wait, mainly because he expects to beat both.

title: Equality Makes A Pit Stop
description: Bill Venturini is a stock car racer, and out on the track his 1986 Chevy Monte Carlo SS looks much like the other entries on the Automobile Racing Club of America circuit. It's when the 33-year-old Chicagoan pulls into the pits that things are different. It's his pit crew - all-female. The idea first came to Venturini back in 1982. His wife, Kathy, had always helped out at the races, timing laps or flashing him his race position on the pit board. Why not, he thought, put together a whole crew of women whom he could train? It ought to be great for publicity, and perhaps help him attract sponsorship for his car. ''Everyone loved it,'' Venturini recalls. ''We were always being invited to make appearances at shopping malls and auto shows. It was great -except that I couldn't afford the expenses of taking the girls everywhere.'' So the crew disbanded for a couple of years but was re-formed last spring, when Venturini persuaded Permatex, a manufacturer of automotive sealants, to pick up the women's travel costs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1986
description: International

title: THE DANCE: CATLIN COBB'S '90 SHOES'
description: THERE was a hint of the exasperation to come in Catlin Cobb's title for her new evening-long piece, ''90 Shoes and the Way of Desire,'' performed on Tuesday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. This was of the laundry-line school of choreography: pin up a shirt here, a pair of socks a little farther along the line, and finish off with a stripy towel. They share the rope, and the items are often of some interest. But the end effect is of a chaos of bright bits.

title: Letting Reagan Go Unchallenged
description: Reporters at President Reagan's news conference let him get away unchallenged with at least one misleading charge and one confusing proposition.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE smart little restaurant Carolina took root along the West 46th Street restaurant row three years ago just as the campfires of regional American cuisine were beginning to ignite. It was an engaging spot offering a refreshing change of pace from the old French bistros that had dominated the block for decades. It may be hard to believe in this mesquite-crazed age, but only a few years ago the concept of wood-grilled meats and fish was a novelty, at least in these environs, and Carolina did a creditable job.

title: Sidney Stone Is Dead at 83; Announcer on Berle TV Show
description: Sidney Stone, a vaudevillian and stage actor who was perhaps best known as the commercial announcer on Milton Berle's television series from 1948 to 1951, died of heart failure Wednesday in New York. He was 83 years old.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS SAYS NET FELL 14.7% IN QUARTER
description: The General Dynamics Corporation yesterday announced a 14.7 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings.

description: The Control Data Corporation, which has long faced turmoil in several of its divisions, said yesterday that it lost $297.9 million in the fourth quarter, compared with earnings of $4.5 million in the 1984 quarter. Revenues for the quarter were $981.4 million, compared with $1.01 billion.
