title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: DR. RUTH WESTHEIMER admitted that she had been unfaithful to Vincent of Elizabeth Arden with Richard of Cleveland, where she had been lecturing earlier that day. Wherever you are, Dr. Ruth explained, you get your hair done when you're invited, along with some 400 other movers and shakers and such, to a sold-out bash to dine on Tex-Mex and ''roast'' Liz Smith. The event, Tuesday night at Studio 54, was the Second Annual Woman's Roast to benefit the Women's Action Alliance, a national nonprofit organization founded in 1971 and committed to full equality for women. (Geraldine Ferraro was roasted last year.) Gloria Steinem was master of ceremonies, Marvin Hamlisch played a white baby grand and the roasters were Beverly Sills, Kaye Ballard, Elaine Stritch, Nora Ephron, Kathleen Turner, Marilyn Michaels, Holland Taylor, Hal Wingo, Diane Sawyer, who sang a duet with Miss Smith, Dr. Ruth, who said that ''gossip is sexually arousing,'' and Helen Gurley Brown, who compared Miss Smith to Mother Teresa.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Arthur Blythe
description: The alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe will lead a trio - with Fred Hopkins on bass and Abdul Wadud on cello -tomorrow at Jazztrack, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South (431-3009). Sets are at 9:30 and 11 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: 50 IN SOUTH AFRICA SEIZED BY POLICE
description: Policemen using helicopters and cars were said today to have raided a church building west of Johannesburg and detained more than 50 young blacks who had fled township violence. An Anglican Bishop said five blacks had been wounded by gunfire.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing International Race of Champions, at Daytona Beach, Fla. Darrell Waltrip is the defending champion in this series of four races in which drivers from different circuits compete. Basketball Trail Blazers vs. Boston Celtics, at Portland, Ore. The only defeat the Celtics suffered in Boston Garden this season was to Portland, and now Boston is making its only visit of the season to Memorial Coliseum. (Television - WTBS, 10 P.M.) Colleges: Columbia at Yale, 7:30 P.M. (Radio -WKCR-FM, 89.9; 7:30 P.M.); Oregon State at Washington (Television - ESPN, 11 P.M.); Baruch at Hunter, 8 P.M.; York at John Jay, 7:30 P.M.; Lehman at Medgar Evers, 7:30 P.M.; Manhattanville at Colgate, 7:30 P.M.; New Jersey Tech at Kean State, 7 P.M.; Princeton at Harvard, 7:30 P.M.; Glassboro State at Trenton State, 7:30 P.M. Boxing Sammy Fuentes vs. Marvin Garris, junior welterweights, 10 rounds, at Resorts International Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8:20 P.M. In his 12-1 record (nine knockouts), Fuentes, from New York, has a victory over Harry Arroyo, the former International Boxing Federation lightweight champion. Garris, from Philadelphia, is 8-3, with three knockouts. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Red Wings, at Detroit, 7:35 P.M. The Rangers scored five times in the first two periods and five more times in the final period on the way to a 10-2 rout in the only other meeting this season, on Dec. 23 at Madison Square Garden.

title: AQUINO HELPS TO MOURN AN OPTIMISTIC POLITICIAN
description: Relatives, friends and a throng of political believers stood at a mass of mourning here today for Evelio Javier, a politician and teacher considered by some of his friends as too much the optimist to survive in the lethal world of Filipino politics.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Friends of Alec Wilder, Carnegie Recital Hall (247-7800). The composer Alec Wilder, who died in 1980, had close friends among performing artists in both the classical and popular fields and many of his compositions were written for one or another of them. Some of these friends will gather at Carnegie Recital Hall tomorrow at 2 P.M. to celebrate ''his life and music'' in the second annual Alec Wilder Birthday Tribute. His pop songs, which include ''I'll Be Around'' and ''While We're Young,'' will be sung by Marlene VerPlanck with an instrumental trio led by Wilder's frequent collaborator, the pianist Loonis McGlohon. One of her songs will be Wilder's last composition, ''South to a Warmer Place,'' written with Mr. McGlohon specifically for Miss VerPlanck. His chamber music, including sonatas for bass trombone, flute and trumpet, and selections from his ''Children's Piano Pieces,'' will be played by the bass trombonist Thomas Everett, the flutist Samuel Baron, the trumpeter Robert Levy and the pianists Barry Snyder and Carol Baron. Tickets are $6.

title: Complete Reportage, Give or Take a Fact
description: Over the past several years, the regents of the Smithsonian Institution have periodically been criticized for conducting their business meetings in private. The bulk of the institution's financing comes from the Federal Government.

title: OPERA: 'FRANCESCA DA RIMINI,' AT MET
description: WHEN Riccardo Zandonai's ''Francesca da Rimini'' re-entered the Metropolitan Opera's repertory in 1984 after an absence of 66 years, there were several plausible reasons for the revival. First, it served as a vehicle for Renata Scotto, a soprano somewhat past her prime but still highly valued by the company and one deemed worth catering to. Second, though abandoned by audiences and left for dead many decades ago, the work does have a place on the fringes of opera history and apparently had in James Levine, the Metropolitan's music director, a stout believer.

title: Nathaniel Gibbon Jr. Is Dead; Former Insurance Executive
description: Nathiel Gibbon Jr., former president and chief executive officer of the United Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Tuesday at the Howe Nursing Home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 68 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Still Grounded
description: It took his agent, his employers and three doctors to talk him into it, but Michael Jordan has decided to wait at least another month before rejoining the Chicago Bulls. ''I have decided that the best course of action is not to play until I go through another exam in four weeks,'' said Jordan, the 1984-85 National Basketball Association rookie of the year, who has been out since he broke a bone in his right foot in the third game of the season.

title: Caterpillar's Name
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, ironically very close to introducing its first tractor exclusively for farm use, says that, after 61 years, it no longer wants the word ''Tractor'' in its name. The word does not aptly describe Caterpillar's diversified line of products, the world's leading maker of earthmoving and construction machinery said. Caterpillar is asking stockholders to ratify changing the company's name to Caterpillar Inc. at their annual meeting on April 9 in San Francisco.

title: Charges Denied
description: The Boston Red Sox have denied that their former player and coach Tommy Harper, who has accused the team of racial discrimination, was dismissed because he complained that the Red Sox distributed passes to the segregated Elks Club at the team's spring training site in Winter Haven, Fla. Harper's contract expired last Dec. 31 and ''was not renewed because of management's dissatisfaction with his performance of his assigned responsibilities,'' the Red Sox said in a statement.

title: Jean-Pierre Rampal
description: Jean-Pierre Rampal will head a program called ''A Multitude of Flutes'' at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night at 8. The program will also feature Julius Baker, Eugenia Zukerman and a wind choir made up of 20 flute students. Tickets are $12 to $20; information: 247-7800.

description: Robert P. Mills, a literary agent and magazine editor in New York for more than 25 years, died of a heart attack last Friday in San Diego.

description: ALEXANDER POPE. A Life. By Maynard Mack. Illustrated. 975 pages. Yale University Press in association with W. W. Norton. $22.50.

Good Ghent
description: For Washingtonians who think it's about time someone celebrated the 171st anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Ghent, the Octagon Museum is having a re-enactment and handbell concert to-day. The treaty ending the War of 1812 was signed by President Madison in 1815 while he and his wife, Dolley, were living in the Octagon after the British had burned the White House.

title: FOXMEYER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRIAL LAWYER FOR COMPANIES
description: Ralph L. McAfee, senior partner of the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, died at a hospital in Great Falls, Mont., Tuesday after suffering a heart attack while flying from New York to Seattle. He was 71 years old and lived in Tarrytown, N.Y., and Pleasanton, Calif.

title: ITT DROPS BIG PHONE PROJECT
description: ITT yesterday canceled a costly project to develop a digital telephone switch for the United States market, resulting in the layoff of 1,600 workers and producing a loss in the fourth quarter.

title: Japan Makers' Reaction
description: Japanese auto makers appeared resigned today to the Government's decision to continue automobile export quotas. Their comments reflected a widespread recognition here that the continuance was a political necessity.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Atlantic Richfield Company's decrease in capital spending for 1986 misstated the reduction. Outlays are being cut by $1 billion from a level that had already been reduced to $3 billion.

title: Ecuador Action on Oil
description: Ecuador suspended exports of crude oil for a week Thursday because its oil had dropped to $13.50 a barrel. The country, an OPEC member, also said it would begin a flexible pricing system to cope with the present volatile market. The Energy Minister, Javier Espinosa, said the nation would let prices float, with levels determined by selling prices of refined products at each crude shipment's destination.

DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DEVILS WIN AT HOME ALEX YANNIS
description: With Glenn (Chico) Resch leading the way with 34 saves, the Devils withstood severe pressure toward the end of the game tonight and preserved a 4-3 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens for their first victory in the last 10 games at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: STAGE: SPIRIT OF 8 BC IS EVOKED AT THE KITCHEN
description: THE Kitchen, the newly relocated performance space now on the far-west reaches of 19th Street, is many things to many people - perhaps too many things. One of its functions seems to be as a showcase for Lower East Side performing arts, although it's way across town from the actual Lower East Side, and why uptowners would find 512 West 19th Street any more accessible than Avenue C is one of life's little mysteries.

title: Chad Seeks French Aid Against Libyan Attack
description: Chad said today that it had asked France and other friendly countries for military assistance to help it repel a four-day Libyan attack on a string of Government positions.

title: SCREEN: 'QUICKSILVER'
description: YOU may need a soft spot for the bicycle messengers who bring such thrills, chills and spills to New York's streets and sidewalks to get a bang out of ''Quicksilver,'' which opens today at RKO Warner Twin and other theaters. The title of the movie is also the title of the movie's New York messenger outfit, staffed by as swell a bunch of daredevils as you'd care to get knocked down by while looking the right way up a one-way street.

title: LILCO STAGES SHOREHAM DRILL, AS STATE AND COUNTRY REFUSE TO ATTEND
description: After months of contention between the Long Island Lighting Company and state and local governments, Lilco officials and employees today conducted a mock emergency at the nuclear power plant in Shoreham, L.I.

title: AQUINO IS WARNING OF DIRECT ACTION
description: Corazon C. Aquino, warning that the Philippines faced a ''prolonged political crisis,'' indicated today that the opposition was considering some form of direct action to make ''the will of the people heard.''

description: Defying odds in the realm of the preposterous - 1 in 17 trillion - a woman who won $3.9 million in the New Jersey state lottery last October has hit the jackpot again and yesterday laid claim with her fiance to an additional $1.4 million prize.

TV: 'FORTUNE DANE,' ACB SERIES
description: Barney Rosenzweig, the producer who gave working women on television a feistier image with the series ''Cagney & Lacey,'' is now turning his attention to the phenomenon of male television ''hunks.'' Not surprisingly, Mr. Rosenzweig puts his own spin on the product. The title character in ''Fortune Dane,'' a new series starting on ABC at 9 o'clock this evening, is black. He is played by Carl Weathers, perhaps best known as one of the many opponents demolished at one time or another by Sylvester Stallone's ''Rocky.''

description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday Alice Lee Marshall and Mark Richard Ellis were married by the Rev. Richard Leonard. The parents of the couple are James Josiah Marshall of New York and Lyndl Thorsen Marshall of Dallas and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Benjamin Ellis of Minneapolis.

title: IF TEACHING IS AGAIN TO BE ATTRACTIVE
description: America was once a largely self-sufficient nation. Today we are importing many resources, including teachers. Figures compiled by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service show that more than 20,000 teachers from abroad came to work in the United States over the past two years.

title: BUJONES IS AWARDED SECOND FLORIDA PRIZE

The award, which carries a $10,000 stipend, is given to artists who were born in Florida or presently live in the state.

title: Terrorism and the Law
description: The savage murders of Robert Dean Stethem and Leon Klinghoffer by Arab terrorists last summer left Americans with a deep sense of helplessness. President Reagan, arguably the most powerful man in the most powerful nation on earth, conceded that even he could do little save pound the walls in frustration. Senator Arlen Specter felt the same emotions. And now, as a result, he wants to do something legislatively about terrorism aimed at Americans.

description: Waves of heavy snowfall, improved snow-making equipment and a strong economy are giving the ski industry hope for another record season in attendance and revenue.

LIMBO OR BITTER EXILE: THE DISSIDENTS LEFT BEHIND
description: While rejoicing crowds surrounded Anatoly B. Shcharansky on his arrival in Israel on Tuesday, Yuri F. Orlov was probably alone, according to his wife, stoking up his drafty wood stove in a remote, frozen settlement in Siberia.

title: PLANNING INVESTMENTS IN FACE OF TAX REVISION
description: With Congress at work on a plan to restructure the income tax system, Americans may have more decisions to make over the next few months than just those associated with filling out their returns.

title: ZEALOUS DAYS AT THE I.C.C.
description: On the day in December when Heather J. Gradison was sworn in as chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, she was also told by the White House Office of Management and Budget that the Reagan Administration would seek no funds for her agency in its budget proposal for the fiscal year 1987, which begins in October.

title: G. Rebecca Morter Is Wed to David Park Curry
description: G. Rebecca Morter and David Park Curry were married yesterday at the New Haven home of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Adams. Myron Curry, the bridegroom's father and an elder of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, officiated.

title: Happy Budget
description: A week or so ago the 271 members of the House who had voted for the new budget-balancing law got a nice letter from James C. Miller 3d, director of the Office of Management and Budget, noting their sup-port for ''this important measure.''

description: b-Including a pretax gain of $6.3 million from the sale of a Holiday Inn and surplus parcel in Dallas. c-Net loss.

IACOCCA DISPUTED ON CRITICISM OF ELLIS I. PLAN
description: The sponsor of a hotel-conference center proposed for Ellis Island said yesterday that at two meetings last week he had offered to meet the objection by Lee A. Iacocca that the project was too commercial.

title: Doubleday Sale Of Radio Units
description: Doubleday & Company said today that its broadcasting subsidiary is putting its remaining three radio stations up for sale as part of its restructuring program. The stations include WHN-AM and WAPP-FM in New York, as well as WAVA-FM in Washington.

title: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains of $3.6 million and $7.8 million from sales of investments. c-Net loss. d-Net income.

title: DOCTOR CONCEDES HE LOST PRIVILEGES
description: A Navy surgeon, Donal M. Billig, conceded at his court-martial today that he failed to tell the Navy that a New Jersey hospital had taken away his credentials. He said that if he had, ''I might not be sitting here,'' accused in the deaths of five patients.

title: Man Sets Himself Afire At White House Gates
description: A man doused himself with gasoline and set himself ablaze tonight in front of the White House gates. Another man raced across a street and extinguished the flames in the incident, which occurred about 9:50 P.M.

title: CENTURY PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EL SALVADOR CONVICTS 2 IN SLAYINGS OF AMERICANS
description: After a legal process that American diplomats strongly criticized, two policemen were convicted here Thursday night of the machine-gun murders of two American land redistribution experts and the head of the Salvadoran land redistribution agency five years ago.

title: MORGAN'S PROSPECTUS DISCLOSES SHARP GAINS
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking house that plans to go public, issued a prospectus yesterday for the sale of its stock, thereby revealing hitherto guarded financial information about the company.

title: 17 Policemen Killed In Mexican Village Feud
description: A land dispute that has smoldered since 1941 between two villages in the Mexican state of Oaxaca erupted into violence Wednesday, leaving 17 police officers and two farmers dead, Government officials said today.

title: FIERY END OF CHALLENGER DESCRIBED IN NEW DETAIL BY NASA OFFICIALS
description: Space agency officials tonight released a precise chronology of strange, rapid-fire events leading up to the last fiery seconds of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: PT COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AILING DOMINGO CANCELS TWO MET PERFORMANCES
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that Placido Domingo, who is still recovering in Europe from double-hernia surgery, will be unable to sing in the first two scheduled performances of the company's new production of ''Carmen'' on March 10 and 14.

title: PHILIPPINE BISHOPS ASSAIL VOTE FRAUD AND URGE PROTEST
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of the Philippines today described the presidential election a week ago as ''unparalleled'' in its fraud and endorsed nonviolent resistance to the expected outcome.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Patrick Ewing's return to the Knick lineup was still uncertain yesterday. The rookie center has not played since his right knee began to pain him against the Utah Jazz 10 days ago.

title: I.M.F. ECONOMIC INSPECTION TEAM PUTS OFF MANILA VISIT INDEFINITELY
description: The International Monetary Fund has postponed indefinitely an economic inspection team's visit to the Philippines, where a dispute rages over the winner of the Presidential election, Philippine and I.M.F. sources reported today.

title: DESPITE 'MYSTIQUE' OF CAPSULES, MANY DRUGS WORK IN OTHER FORMS
description: The recent discovery in Westchester County of Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules laced with cyanide has focused new attention on the use of capsules for drug delivery.

title: KERR GLASS MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an unusual net charge of $3,888,000 for the quarter and year for the restructuring of facilities. c-Net income. For the previous year net income was exceeded by preferred dividends so the is no share earnings figure.

title: RANGERS WIN THIRD IN ROW
description: First, he scored when the puck trickled by the goalie's knee and he was standing free in front of an open net. The second time, he let loose with a 40-foot shot and scored that way. With those goals, Pierre Larouche showed again tonight that in his short time back he has restored some scoring punch to the Rangers.

title:
Patents;
Lung Cancer Detection
description: Means of detecting human lung cancer of the non-small-cell type and distinguishing it from other types and normal tissues has been patented for the Department of Health and Human Services. Patent 4,569,788 was granted this week to James L. Mulshine and John D. Minna, employees of the National Institutes of Health. Two monoclonal antibodies proved effective, and may be obtained from the American Type Culture Collection in Rockville, Md.

title: COORS, ADOLPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including credits of $4 million relating to a reduction in the company's income tax rate and $2 million relating to the resolution of certain income tax contigencies.

title: PERFECT RICE, QUICKLY COOKED
description: There are, perhaps, no more intimidating food ads than those that admonish cooks to stay away from regular long-grain rice. The ads imply that it is difficult, if not impossible, for anyone with average kitchen skills to cook it properly and that no matter what is done, the rice is bound to emerge in clumps of stuck-together grains. This is a sin equal to, if not worse than, greasy fried chicken and layer cakes that sink.

title: Meese and Friends
description: An ad hoc group, the Friends of Ed Meese, is sending out invitations to a gathering Feb. 24 in the ballroom of the Hotel Vista International to ''celebrate the achievements of his first year as Attorney General of the United States.''

title: EX-OFFICIAL SAYS KOCH CUT SHORT STING OPERATION
description: A former city Investigation Commissioner said yesterday that Mayor Koch had cut short an undercover operation by refusing to reappoint a corrupt taxi official who had bragged of his association with former Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes.

title: Typescript of 'Cancer' Auctioned for $165,000
description: The original typescript of Henry Miller's ''Tropic of Cancer'' was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's for $165,000, the highest price at auction for a modern manuscript sold in America. It was purchased by John Fleming, the rare book dealer, who was bidding for a private buyer.

title: Chase Will Buy Bank in Florida
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said last night that it had submitted the winning bid to take over an insolvent commercial bank in Florida from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Chase said it paid $62.6 million.

title: In Vast Pursuit Of Top Recruits
description: The collegiate recruitment of schoolboy football players has not necessarily ended for the year, but almost all the biggest, fastest and strongest of them were wrapped up as of Wednesday. That was national-letter-of-intent day, the annual date on which the National Collegiate Athletic Association allows its member citadels to begin applying formal lassos to the young gladiators. Which school made out the best will not be known for certain until the recruits begin flexing their muscles next fall. But by one respected count, three already powerful programs assured themselves some measure of success in the coming seasons.

title: Occidental Agrees To Gas Divestiture
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation agreed today to sell a 2,200-mile natural gas pipeline to stop the Federal Trade Commission from blocking its $3 billion acquisition of the Midcon Corporation, one of the largest natural gas pipeline companies in the United States.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHEAR FACTS The branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art that is devoted to the art and architecture of the Middle Ages (A.D. 476-1450, or thereabouts) is the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park in Upper Manhattan. Currently, on Saturday afternoons, The Cloisters (923-3700) presents programs for children from 5 to 12 years of age. Today's program consists of a talk and demonstration about sheep in the Middle Ages.

title: FILM: 'CAGE AUX FOLLES 3' SERRAULT AND TOGNAZZI
description: If anything, Michel Serrault is even funnier in a business suit than he is in a dress. Mr. Serrault plays Albin, the transvestite entertainer who co-stars with Ugo Tognazzi's straighter-laced Renato in the ''La Cage Aux Folles'' films, and he must wear conservative mufti during the early part of the series' latest installment. It seems that Albin, who affects the suit to attend a reading of his Aunt Emma's will in Scotland, has been left a large part of that country plus a good deal of money, provided he can marry a woman and father a child.

title: U.S.-SOVIET ARMS MEETING
description: United States and Soviet arms negotiators held an unannounced session today at the headquarters of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency offices in Geneva.

title: Stay Tuned
description: The other day Martin Rubenstein received a letter and a follow-up telephone call from Arbitron, the commercial broadcast rating service, asking him if he was interested in keeping a log of his radio listening habits.

title: A SMALL-BUSINESS SISTERHOOD ON AMSTERDAM AVE.
description: PAULA SHIRK, who owns a women's athletic wear shop on Amsterdam Avenue, cheers up every time she looks in at Womanbooks, a bookstore two doors north. ''I see all these women in there, and it gives me hope,'' she said.

title: OPERA: THE MET OFFERS 'FRANCESCA DA RIMINI'
description: When Riccardo Zandonai's ''Francesca da Rimini'' re-entered the Metropolitan Opera's repertory in 1984 after an absence of 66 years, there were several plausible reasons for the revival. First, it served as a vehicle for Renata Scotto, a soprano somewhat past her prime but still highly valued by the company and one deemed worth catering to. Second, though abandoned by audiences and left for dead many decades ago, the work does have a place on the fringes of opera history and apparently had in James Levine, the Metropolitan's music director, a stout believer.

NYSTROM CAN'T STAY AWAY FROM THE ICE
description: He was the skater with the devious dark eyebrows, the windblown blond hair and the decisive masculinity that made him his team's own Marlboro man. Bob Nystrom, the most congenial of men off the ice, was the meanest of competitors on it.

title: BRONX DEMOCRATS TOLD TO GIVE UP FILES
description: The Bronx Democratic Committee was told by a Federal court yesterday to turn over party records to Federal investigators. The records, among other things, would identify contributors to the party's internal funds.

title: ORGAN TRANSPLANTS: FROM DEATH COMES LIFE uf1013>
description: This is the story of how two sudden deaths restored 10 lives and how medical technology and some silk stitches have forever linked the lives, deaths and bodies of these complete strangers.

title: City to Open 2 Shelters
description: The city plans to open two new group shelters for homeless families in the Park Slope Armory in Brooklyn and the Jamaica Armory in Queens, a move that was criticized yesterday by advocates for the homeless because the shelters would house men, women and children together in one large communal room. Suzanne Trazoff, a spokesman for the city's Human Resources Administration, said yesterday that the Park Slope Armory, at 1402 Eighth Avenue, was ready to receive about 75 people. She said the city was now preparing the Jamaica Armory, at 170-21 88th Avenue, for about 57 people.

title: HELPED DEVELOP PLAYWRIGHTS
description: Clinton Wilder, a leading theatrical producer who helped develop new playwrights, died yesterday at his home in Bedford, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

description: Two streets were particularly vulnerable yesterday - Valentine Avenue in the Bronx and Love Lane in Brooklyn.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock and commodity markets will be closed Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Government offices, banks and many businesses also will be closed. The weekly Treasury bill auction will be Tuesday instead of Monday.

title: LONDON TRADING IN TURMOIL
description: The threat of default by several trading companies is disrupting the world's most active spot-oil market, based here, with the volume of trading slowing to a trickle this week.

title: Year of Renovation For Yorkville Library
description: If you have not returned the Harold Robbins novel and the history of Hegelian thought you borrowed from the Yorkville branch of the New York Public Library last summer, do it quickly. The branch, at 222 East 79th Street, is closing Monday for a year of renovation.

LTV Selling Unit
description: The LTV Corporation said that it agreed to sell the assets of its subsidiary, the LTV Steel Specialty Products Company, to a group of private investors, including the unit's senior management and institutional investors. LTV will retain a 20 percent interest in the concern. The value of the transaction was not disclosed, but the company said the unit had sales of more than $350 million in 1985, representing about 7 percent of LTV's total steel business.

description: To the consternation of prosecutors, a Superior Court judge here who is hearing a case involving nine people arrested in an anti-abortion protest has acknowledged that he took part in the protest.

description: The need for better shelter for the city's homeless and despairing is cited by many donors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

description: The Reagan Administration has proposed a $387 million satellite that would study ocean currents and be launched by an Ariane rocket of the French space agency rather than by a space shuttle.

title: DUBIOUS FERVOR IN LOS ANGELES
description: The indictment of Representative Bobbi Fiedler of Los Angeles for a form of political bribery invites suspicion about the motives of her accusers and skepticism about the law they invoked. title: THE QUESTION IN ISRAEL: WHITHER SHCHARANSKY?

title: BRENNAN MISSES DEADLINE TO PAY BRIBE-CASE FINE
description: William C. Brennan, the former State Supreme Court justice who was convicted of bribe-taking, missed a Wednesday deadline to pay a fine and penalties totaling $224,300, and his lawyer told a Federal judge yesterday that Mr. Brennan could only afford to pay $110,000.

Patents;
Sound on Paper Track Improved by Scanner
description: An improved system for generating audible information from a sound track printed on paper by conventional methods was patented this week for CBS Inc. In the system, an optical scanner is moved along the sound track.

title: MEMOIRS OF INNOCENCE
description: A WIDER WORLD. Portraits in an Adolescence. By Kate Simon. 186 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95. In ''Bronx Primitive'' (1982), her first volume of memoirs, Kate Simon created an indelible portrait of immigrant life in post-World War I New York, and she also introduced a wonderfully spirited heroine - herself. Headstrong, curious, at once terrified and dazzled by the exigencies of life around her, little Kaila - or Kate, as she's soon called - possesses the quick, intuitive intelligence of Anne Frank, the artistic yearnings of the young Mary McCarthy (in ''Memories of a Catholic Girlhood''), and the end of that earlier volume sees her poised, at the age of 13, on the brink of womanhood and independence.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33.

title: LOCAL AND NATIONAL UNION CLASH OVER TACTICS IN HORMEL STRIKE
description: As in any strike, the six-month struggle at the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant in Austin, Minn., pits workers against employers, but the labor dispute has at times been almost overshadowed by an extremely bitter fight between strikers and their parent union, the United Food and Commercial Workers.

title: Rev. Paul Weed, Vicar Of Manhattan Church
description: The Rev. Paul Charles Weed, an Episcopal priest who served as vicar of St. Luke in the Fields Church and as headmaster of St. Luke's School for 22 years, died Sunday at his home in Gaylordsville, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: MAN IS CONVICTED OF KILLING INTERRACIAL COUPLE IN WISCONSIN IN '77
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, who is already serving a prison term for killing two blacks in Utah, was convicted today in the deaths of an interrracial couple that a prosecutor said were close to ''killing for sport.''

title: TRANSFORMING A FUR: MANY ARE THE WAYS

title: Your Money; Joint Tenancy's Drawbacks
description: THE story is a familiar one. A husband and wife, who have two children, jointly own all of their assets and the wife dies. The man remarries and jointly holds the family property with his new wife. Then the man dies, so his wife inherits everything - and his children from the first marriage get nothing.

title: IT'S GETTING TOO EXOTIC
description: In the beginning, there were two guys who bet a barrel of apples or something on who had the faster horse. This was horse racing. Then there were side bets, and everyone watching the race could bet on who had the better horse. Then there were race tracks. To pay for upkeep and to pay off the Government for letting them operate, the tracks began charging a fee for holding the money on the side bets. This was known as the parimutuel system.

title: THE NINTH LIFE OF CONTADORA
description: Though often pronounced dead, most recently in this space, the Contadora peace plan for Central America refuses to die. It was recalled to life again this week and resubmitted to a less than exhilarated Secretary of State Shultz by eight Latin American foreign ministers. They appealed for direct negotiations with Nicaragua and an end of American aid for the ''contra'' army of exiles. To the same end, Guatemala's new civilian President wants to meet with other Central American leaders next month.

title: Maryland Suspensions
description: After upsetting North Carolina State Thursday night to overall raise its record to 13-10, a resurgent Maryland team seemed to be on the road again to the postseason playoffs, but an unauthorized sidetrip by three players may have stalled the Terrapins. The three, including the team's leading scorer, Len Bias, were suspended indefinitelty after they violated curfew by leaving their hotel room in Raleigh, N.C., at midnight to visit friends at North Carolina State.

title: WHY THE WORK CAMP DIDN'T WORK
description: Mayor Koch had a bright idea: to create a work camp on Harts Island to which New York could for short periods send thousands of graffiti writers, subway-fare beaters and others convicted of minor crimes. The thousands never materialized and the idea is now dead. For what its failure says about the city's broader criminal justice problem, it ought not to be forgotten.

description: 'For the first time in its history, the United States could ally itself with an Indian cause.' Russell Means a leader of the American Indian Movement, ending a trip to Nicaragua and promising to campaign for United States aid to the Miskito Indians, who oppose the Sandinista Government there.

title: JERSEY SCHOOL BOARD PROPOSES LAYING OFF 31
description: In an effort to eliminate a $308,000 budget deficit, public school officials here have proposed laying off 31 teachers and custodians and canceling the spring athletic program.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN A SMALL, WELL-HIDDEN HOUSE...
description: WORD of mouth has brought diners flocking to a year-old restaurant in an unpretentious little house in semi-rural Passaic County. Stephen is hard to find, hidden as it is behind a church parking lot in North Haledon. In fact, first-timers who call for directions may be instructed by the friendly voice on the telephone: ''When you get in the vicinity, call from a gas station and we'll 'walk you in.' '' This is advice well taken. Adventurers who make the journey will find rewards in some standout dishes and in the convivial ambience, but they may also be equally disappointed by lackluster entrees and frazzled by the overwhelming decibel level.

title: SETTINGS FOR MANY TASTES
description: Party at N.Y.U. Feb. 22 - During the last six years, Friends of Washington Square Park have spent more than $60,000 on numerous projects to improve the park, cleaning and planting, painting and repairing. A much older group, the Washington Square Association, founded in 1906, is holding the sixth annual George Washington Ball to help raise funds for the friends group. There will be cocktails at 6:30 P.M., dinner at 7:30 and dancing till midnight at the Bobst Library of New York University at 70 Washington Square South, with John Brademas, the N.Y.U president, the guest of honor. Black tie or period costume is requested. Tickets, $75, from 212-764-6330. Polish Ball at the Plaza Feb. 22 - In addition to maintaining three homes for the elderly in Ocean Grove, N.J., Polish Assistance provides financial aid and other support to Poles who have left their homeland. An important source of income for the group is its annual Polonaise Ball. The 30th annual event will be held at the Plaza starting with cocktails at 8 P.M. Tickets for the black or white tie event, $130 or $160, depending on seating, from 212-751-3670. Granting Wishes Feb. 25 - Cocktails at 7 P.M., dinner at 8 followed by a fashion show with 25 models showing the creations of 12 designers, all at the Grand Hyatt Hotel will benefit the Starlight Foundation. Founded in 1983, the group, which has gained the backing of several corporations and foundations, seeks to grant the wishes of critically, chronically or terminally ill children.

title: Extradited Croat Is Charged With Mass Murder in the War
description: Andrija Artukovic, who was extradited by the United States this week, has been formally charged with ordering the murder of 231,000 people in World War II while an official in the German-supported state of Croatia, the press agency Tanyug said today.

title: FRITES
description: To the Editor: Peter Maass's article gave me pleasure, inasmuch as on my many visits to Belgium I indulge in the luxury of the frites he so eloquently writes about.

title: COOK BEATS ELLENBURG
description: Steve Cook of Roseville, Calif., defeated top-seeded Frank Ellenburg of Mesa, Ariz., by 245-211 in the title game today to win the $200,000 Bowling Proprietors Association of America United States Open.

title: DUTCH SKATER TAKES 5,000 AND LEADS MEET
description: Hein Vergeer of the Netherlands charged to victory in the 5,000-meter race today to take the point-standing lead in the men's World speed-skating championships.

title: THE LONE STAR STATE
description: A 22-cent stamp honoring the 150th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of Texas will be issued March 2 in San Antonio. On that date in 1836 Texas declared its independence from Mexico.

title: IN THE HEART OF THE HEART OF THE COUNTRY
description: DEATH'S MIDWIVES By Margareta Ekstrom. Translated by Eva Claeson. Preface by Nadine Gordimer. 149 pp. New York: Ontario Review Press/ Persea Books. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: VYING FOR TRAFFIC-JAM CAPITAL OF NATION
description: The nation's capital is well known as a city of ample avenues. That was the way its planner, L'Enfant, designed things.

title: Things That a President's Age Tell Us
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FLASHER OF THE APOCALYPSE
description: RAT MAN OF PARIS By Paul West. 180 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $15.95.

title: LEMIEUX REACHES 100TH POINT
description: Doug Shedden had his second career three-goal game, and Mario Lemieux had two goals and two assists for his second consecutive 100-point season to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 9-4 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: A 'COMFORT FOOD' FROM CHILDHOOD: EGG ROLL AND LO MEIN
description: THERE has been a great deal of attention focused in recent months on ''comfort foods,'' such as meat loaf, mashed potatoes and chocolate pudding. It is the sort of menu that does not require trendy ingredients, exotic cooking techniques or equipment. In their old-fashioned honesty these dishes should also be made from scratch, like mother would have prepared.

title: HOSPITALS SAY AIDS STRAINS RESOURCES
description: EMACIATED and too weak to walk alone, 20-year-old Yvonne lies in Jersey City Medical Center, slowly dying of AIDS. This is her third admission since last May; she once stayed three months.

title: Q AND A
description: SUBLETTING A CO-OP Question: In a rent-stabilized building that has been converted to cooperative ownership, can the owner of a co-op apartment sublet it at market rent?. . . G. G. G., Brooklyn Answer: In New York City, after the tenant moves out, the apartment is deregulated and the owner can charge a market rent, according to Thomas R. Viola, assistant commissioner of the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal. In regulated apartments outside New York City, the apartment stays rent-stabilized. Sparing the Paintbrush Question: I reside in Washington Square Village owned by New York University, in a rent-stabilized, one-bedroom apartment. Though I have always had three year leases in the past, I was recently offered a two-year lease and informed that N.Y.U. had to paint only my bathroom and kitchen, not the living room or bedroom. Is this true?. . . S. T., Manhattan Answer: In 1983 the Omnibus Housing Act established that landlords had to offer only one or two-year leases. Painting, however, is required by the housing maintenance code every three years, so the state housing agency established regulations that said: If the apartment is painted the tenant signing a two-year lease must place one-third of the cost of the paint job with the landlord as security in case the tenant does not renew the lease; if the tenant renews, the deposit is refunded.

title: A 'STREET FIGHT' OVER EGG MCMUFFINS
description: DENNY LYNCH, vice president for communication at Wendy's International Inc., describes the competition among the fast-food chains for the breakfast crowd as ''street fighting.''

title: HE'S CRUSADING FOR THE BLUES
description: DOUG (Harmonica) McLean's calling cards read ''Blues is my business,'' so the Rocky Point musician takes more than a casual professional interest in the music he has been playing since he was a junior high student in Bellport.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: COLONIAL CHEF COOKERY William and Cindy Clark, a husband and wife team of self-taught Colonial chefs, will give a demonstration of open-hearth cookery at 7 P.M. Friday in the main hall of the Teatown Lake Reservation, on Spring Valley Road in Ossining.

title: A Jury Decides Georgia Fouled A Teacher
description: The million-dollar revenues produced by the University of Georgia's football and basketball teams may be needed this year for more than the pursuit of halfbacks. Under a decision last week by a Federal jury in Atlanta, the university must pay more than $2.5 million to an instructor who was dismissed after opposing favored treatment for athletes.

title: A 'MISCONCEPTION' ABOUT COACHING
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ecology and Crowding Are Problems for Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ANTHONY WAYNE: Soldier of the Early Republic. By Paul David Nelson. (Indiana University, $27.50.) This biography of Anthony Wayne, the Revolutionary War general sometimes known as Mad Anthony, implicitly asks whether soldiers are content to be the servants of a democratic society.

title: Topics Overproductions; Quitter
description: If everyone were to quit while still ahead, the world would be a happier place. Old movie actors could give up toupees, eye lifts and very wide belts; certain opera stars wouldn't have to work so hard to make style do what their voices no longer can; tired politicians could give up shopping for new rhetoric.

title: SPONSOR'S REVERSAL OF L.I. CONVERSIONANGERS BUYERS
description: IN January 1984, a condominium conversion plan for the 107-unit Mendicino Green garden-apartment complex in Baldwin, L.I., was accepted for filing by the State Attorney General's office.

title:
ANTIQUES;
STYLES OF VARIOUS EPOCHS IN GUILDFORD
description: CONNECTICUT is a small state but perhaps it has more antiques collectors, more restored houses and more shops and shows to offer advice on how to furnish them than any other. But the purist and the pragmatist differ over what can be called an antique. The first believes antique furniture must have been made with hand tools before 1840. The second puts the date at 1870, or well after mass production had begun.

title: Hitting the Bricks in Argentina
description: It was a normal week for Argentina. On different days, the wholesale beef business halted, court workers and porters marched in protest to the Presidential Palace and lifeguards abandoned the resort beaches of Mar del Plata. In previous weeks, striking bus drivers had swung their vehicles around to block traffic and telephone operators had walked out, leaving this capital without communications.

title: A WORKING BASKET
description: WHEN it comes to describing their foods, the French have a delicious way with words. Such is the case when they use appareil, which most often means apparatus, or apparel, to apply to the ingredients that they toss in in the preparation of hors d'oeuvres, entrees, desserts, or whatever.

title: ANNIVERSARY BROADCAST
description: The American Composers Orchestra will celebrate its 10th anniversary with a seven-hour live broadcast tomorrow on WNYC-FM, starting at 8:05 A.M. Interviews with composers and musicians will be interspersed with concert tapes and commercial recordings. Milton Babbitt, Bethany Beardslee, John Cage, Elliott Carter, Dennis Russell Davies, Gunther Schuller and Charles Wuorinen are among those who will be interviewed.

title: Two Reasons To Be Bullish
description: In all but the most dismal periods, Administration officials comment with cheer on the Government's economic reports. Last week, the good feeling came with very little strain, and with concurrence on the part of most private analysts.

title: Welcome to the Club
description: Saudi Arabia may differ from the United States in language, religion, customs and climate. But lately it's begun to share an all-too-familiar economic problem.

title: PROSECUTOR IN ROME TRIAL DENOUNCES BULGARIA
description: A Government prosecutor, summing up his case against three Bulgarians and four Turks accused of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II, today denounced Bulgaria for harboring the conspirators and misleading Italian investigators in the case.

title: 30-TON 'BRAIN' EVOKES BIRTH OF COMPUTER AGE
description: When the Army decided in World War II that it needed better calculations of the trajectories of artillery shells, engineers and scientists at the University of Pennsylvania set about building a machine they called an electronic numerical integrator.

title: PEGGY L. EPSTEIN TO WED IN AUGUST
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Epstein of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Peggy Louise Epstein to David Allen Tanner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tanner of Scarsdale, N.Y. An August wedding is planned. Miss Epstein, an associate in the fixed income sales department at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, graduated from Dartmouth College and is a member of the Dartmouth College Alumni Council.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PREPARING FOR POWER: America's Elite Boarding Schools. By Peter W. Cookson Jr. and Caroline Hodges Persell. (Basic Books, $19.95.) From Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who graduated from Groton, to George Bush, who went to Andover, a sizable segment of America's leaders have been shaped by their experiences in private boarding schools.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET PERFORMS 'WHO CARES?'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Who Cares?'' and Jerome Robbins's ''Goldberg Variations,'' two long ballets about the joys of living and dancing, shared the New York City Ballet's program on Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Dance
description: Even a cursory look at this week's dance events suggests that this is a very good time to explore the wealth of new choreography and dancing by women throughout the city. The variety of the work suggests, too, the great variety of their dances.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGET: THE COST TO L.I.
description: LONG ISLAND'S Democratic representatives in Washington say the Reagan Administration's proposed 1987 budget could mean major trouble for the Island's economy. But Republican representatives say most of the cuts are necessary if the nation is ever to balance its budget.

title: DECLINE AND TURNAROUND?
description: WE'RE STILL HERE The Rise, Fall, and Resurrection of the South Bronx. By Jill Jonnes. Illustrated. 422 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $24.95. THERE are three periods in the history of the Bronx. The first was one of remarkable rise from bucolic farmlands to thriving urban community. The next, following World War II, was marked by rapid decay. The current period, as Jill Jonnes sees it in ''We're Still Here,'' is one of hope, a time when those who have remained have begun to conquer the forces of blight and to rebuild the South Bronx. Miss Jonnes, a freelance journalist, explains this complicated history with clarity.

title: TRANSIT AGENCY FAULTED OVER SUBWAY INCIDENT
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter, Democrat of Manhattan, has accused the Transit Authority of covering up details of an incident in which the doors on a packed rush-hour F train opened as it moved between subway stations in Brooklyn.

title: LET'S DISTANCE OURSELVES FROM MARCOS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos's decision to have himself declared the winner of the Presidential election - in spite of the fact that he really lost it - is likely to bring the Philippines to the brink of civil war and seriously jeopardize important American interests in Asia. How the United States responds to this crude and cynical effort to thwart the will of the Filipino people will go a long way toward determining the fate of democracy in the Philippines and the future relationship between our two countries.

title: MARTHA'S VINEYARD GETTING JETS AGAIN
description: For the first time in 11 years, jet airplanes will fly in and out of Martha's Vineyard this summer. But the prospect of quicker access is not pleasing to some islanders.

title: Refugee Commissioner Tries to Keep Up With the Flow
description: In less than a decade, the workload of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has more than doubled: the agency says it now keeps watch on nearly 11 million people around the world. But the high commission, which received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1954 and 1981, has not succeeded in persuading member governments to make their contributions match the rising need.

title: REAGAN'S MASTER OF COMPROMISE: RICHARD DARMAN
description: AT THE END OF A BUSY DAY, OTHER PEOPLE SIM-ply go to sleep, maybe say a prayer first in the dark, or slip off in a final draught of worry. Not Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Richard G. Darman. He puts the finishing touches on a letter to himself - a careful, tightly penned, and quite idiosyncratic single-sheet diagram of whatever major issue has been on his mind that day. It might be a plan for the miasmic tax-overhaul struggle in Congress, for which he has been President Ronald Reagan's pointman, or perhaps a dicey stratagem for advancing the Administration's effort to bring order to the volatile world of international monetary rates.

title: LONG BRANCH REBUILDING ITS OCEANFRONT AND ITS IMAGE
description: CONSTRUCTION has begun on the long-awaited redevelopment of the oceanfront here amid expectations that it will spur efforts to revitalize the city, which is showing signs of rebirth after years of decline.

title: A 22-ACRE CENTER
description: Realty Research Properties broke ground last month on the first stage of a 150,000 square foot shopping center on a site it has owned in Washington Township for 10 years.

title: Restraint of Power In Philadelphia
description: IF there ever was an elephant-size energy conservation nightmare, it might well be the Philadelphia Museum of Art, all 450,000 square feet of it, with an annual heating and lighting bill of $1.5 million.

title: How 'Civic Virtue' Got From City Hall to Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE EMANCIPIST. By Victoria Geoghegan Sweeney. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95). Victoria Geoghegan Sweeney has crammed every possible event into the 1,048 pages of this melodramatic novel.

title: GOVERNMENT TRUST: LESS IN WEST EUROPE THAN U.S.
description: Citizens of the leading Western European democracies trust their governments less than Americans trust theirs and are far less inclined to express pride in their countries, polls by The New York Times have found.

title: TOTAL OF BRIBES FOR PARKING CONTRACTS ESTIMATED TO BE AS HIGH AS $2 MILLION
description: Federal prosecutors investigating corruption in the New York City Parking Violations Bureau now believe that as much as $2 million in bribes was paid over the last five years by collection companies seeking to keep contracts with the agency.

title: CLUB TO PERK UP WESTPORT NIGHT LIFE
description: WESTPORT has long been seen by outsiders as a sophisticated, artsy town - the home of Paul Newman, Neil Sedaka, advertising copywriters and novelists. But some residents were not so sure.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Short Pants, Long Career One thinks of Count Basie, the late pianist and band leader, as sophisticated and dapper in his dress. In his autobiography, we find him playing the piano in a dance hall while still wearing short pants. This is from ''Good Morning Blues'' (Random House), with Albert Murray.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE State Supreme Court will hear arguments this week in a pollution case often linked to the current environmental liability insurance crisis.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
NEWBERY WINNER
description: On a 45-acre spread in Yorktown Heights called Faraway Farm, Rhoda Blumberg writes books for youngsters that often deal with long ago and far away. Her book, ''Commodore Perry in the Land of the Shogun,'' published by Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books, tells the story of the opening of the Japanese harbors to American ships in the mid-19th century. It was recently named a 1986 Newbery Honor Book. The book also won The Boston Globe Horn Book Award for Excellence in Children's Literature in the nonfiction category for 1985.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development will participate in a business seminar to be held in Seoul, Korea, on Feb. 25 and 26.

title: DAWKINS PACES DUKE
description: Fouled on a desperation jump shot, Johnny Dawkins made two free throws with two seconds remaining to lift Duke to a 72-70 comeback victory over North Carolina State tonight.

title: CABARET: CLARKGRANVILL
description: LEIGH CLARKGRANVILLE is a brash, promising young comedienne and singer who invents oddball characters that she calls her ''multiple personnel.'' In ''Hatbox,'' her one-woman show that plays Thursday evenings at Panache (149 East 57th Street), Miss Clarkgranville impersonates half a dozen eccentrics that range from a singing nightclub psychic who strolls through the audience reading tarot cards and offering flippant observations, to a stammeringly hysterical ''food critic ordinaire,'' whose reviews string together bad puns.

title: THE ROAD TO TWEEDLEDUM
description: THE TENNIEL ILLUSTRATIONS TO THE ''ALICE'' BOOKS By Michael Hancher. Illustrated. 152 pp. Columbus: Ohio State University Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $17.50. THE Alice books continue to fascinate us.

title: CUOMO VISITS NEW ROCHELLE TO DEFEND BUDGET PLAN
description: GOVERNOR Cuomo came to Westchester last week to defend his proposed budget and to warn organization leaders and elected officials seeking extra funds that they will either have to do without or find the money at the county or national levels.

title: LATEST PICTURES FROM NASA SHOW WODER FIRE ON BOOSTER
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today released 16 striking photographs that depict the space shuttle Challenger in its death throes.

title: 'THE MIDDLE AGES,' COMEDY OF REBELLION
description: A. R. GURNEY has, like Philip Barry before him, appointed himself a chronicler of the American monied classes. The Studio Theater is presenting his work ''The Middle Ages,'' a wry comedic drama, which predates ''The Dining Room,'' Mr. Gurney's best-known play.

title: DINING IN, LOOKING OUT
description: GARDENS IN BACK OF CITY brownstones are private oases. Hidden from the street and shaded by mature trees, they provide pleasing views from inside the house and an extra outdoor room during warm weather.

title: WHO WRITES THE LAWS
description: A HISTORY OF AMERICAN LAW Second Edition. By Lawrence M. Friedman. 781 pp. New York: A Touchstone Book/Simon & Schuster. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $18.95. WHEN Lawrence M. Friedman's ''History of American Law'' was first published in 1973, it filled a deep, chronic need and captured the market, in part because it had no competition. Until then, if one surveyed the literature of American law, or even Anglo-American law, he would find few comprehensive books on the subject. On the English side, there was ''The History of English Law'' by Edward Pollock and Frederic W. Maitland - but it had the foreboding subtitle ''Before Edward III'' (he died in 1307); there was Sir William Holdsworth's endless ''Legal History'' in 15 volumes; and there was T. F .T. Plucknett's ''Concise History of the Common Law,'' a 900-page volume that essayed the whole range and depth of that wildly complex subject with magisterial command.

title: PLANNING THROUGH A GARDEN WINDOW
description: Window landscapes are fun to plan. They require little in the way of maintenance or expense and allow me to appreciate my garden any moment of the year.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's statement today on the Philippine presidential election:

title: Pennsylvania Turnpike Tolls May More Than Double by '92
description: Tolls on the Pennsylvania Turnpike may more than double in the next six years to help pay for the first phase of a $4 billion expansion program, according to a new report.

title: Haiti Looks To the U.S. For Aid and Comfort
description: In the wildest moments of stampeding and looting that preceded Jean-Claude Duvalier's flight to France, Haitians often paused to smile, wave and even shake hands with American onlookers. ''Vive l'Amerique!'' they would call.

title: CONSUMER RATES
5 Killed in Rioting In South Africa
description: At least five people were killed today in rioting in South Africa's segregated townships, the police said.

title: Cable TV
description: The Broadway production of ''Sunday in the Park with George,'' the landmark musical by Stephen Sondheim (music and lyrics) and James Lapine (book), has been preserved with complete integrity in the videotaped version to be presented initially by Showtime on Tuesday at 8 P.M. and later this year by the Public Broadcasting System. Directed for television by Terry Hughes, who also did the fine video version of Mr. Sondheim's ''Sweeney Todd,'' this ''Sunday'' can't always preserve every grace note in the stage musical's delicate visual and musical palette.

title: 15 Injured During Evacuation Of Plane With Engine on Fire
description: An engine of an Eastern Airlines plane preparing to take off from Kennedy International Airport caught fire last evening and 15 passengers were hurt during an emergency evacuation of the craft, authorities said.

title: Southern Yemen Appeal
description: Southern Yemen appealed today for blood donations for its hundreds of wounded in January's battles between Marxist factions.

title: 'SUNDAY IN THE PARK' IS STAGED ANEW FOR SHOWTIME
description: In many ways, the production of ''Sunday in the Park With George'' that comes to Showtime Tuesday night at 8 is concerned with matters of creation and re-creation. With a score and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim and a book by James Lapine, the two-and-a-half-hour musical speculates about the creation of Georges Seurat's pointillist masterwork ''A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of Grand Jatte,'' in which a cross-section of late 19th-century Parisians are depicted at irridescent leisure in a tree-shaded park.

title: HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY DEAN WITH STUDENTS FROM 3 TO 83
description: ''WHAT I do is develop programs,'' said Dr. Deanna Chitayat. ''That's the main thing I do well.''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Nascar Daytona 500, at Daytona Beach, Fla. Bill Elliott, who won this race last year, won the pole position last Monday in his Ford Thunderbird. (Television -Channel 2, noon.) Basketball Los Angeles Lakers vs. Boston Celtics, at Inglewood, Calif. The first meeting of the season between the championship-round opponents of the last two seasons went to the Celtics, 110-95, in Boston. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) L.I. Basketball Association All-Star Game, at Holy Trinity High in Hicksville, L.I., 7 P.M. For the benefit of the Marty Lyons Foundation for children on Long Island with terminal diseases. College: Notre Dame at Duke (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.) Boxing Livingstone Bramble, champion, vs. Tyrone (Butterfly) Crawley, at Reno, 15 rounds, for the World Boxing Association lightweight championship. This is the third defense for Bramble, who is 22-1-1 with 14 knockouts. Crawley, from Philadelphia, has a 19-1 record. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.) Mike Tyson vs. Jesse Ferguson, at Troy, N.Y., 10 rounds, heavyweights. Tyson is undefeated in 17 bouts since turning pro, all knockouts. Carl (The Truth) Williams vs. Mike Weaver, 10 rounds, heavyweights. (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Detroit Red Wings, at Madison Square Garden. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.) Devils vs. Pittsburgh Penguins, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 5:05 P.M. (Television - MSG, 5 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 5 P.M.) Minnesota North Stars vs. Boston Bruins, at Bloomington, Minn.

title: THE MYSTERY OF CASTING AT THE MET
description: Scratch any operagoer and you will find a casting expert. This remarkable person has only to get on the phone for a moment with Madame X and Mr. Y to nail down those eminent singers to commitments insuring their presence at the Metropolitan throughout their prime years and perhaps a few more. Without knowing or caring much about the logistical problems that confront the officials actually in charge of filling opera casts, the fan is easily able to conjure up dream productions of his favorite works. Managers of the world's most renowned artists sit by their telephones night and day waiting for the casting expert's call.

title: HOMAGE TO A PAINTER WHO CELEBRATED PRIVILEGE
description: An exhibition of quite exceptional promise is the panoramic survey of the achievement of Francois Boucher (1703-1770) that opens Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum. To a degree that is almost ridiculous, Boucher is the invisible man of French 18th-century painting. This is not, of course, to say that he is unknown. He is famous the world over both for his delicate (and sometimes not so delicate) improprieties and for the apparatus of seduction that he brought to the portraiture of women - above all, to the portrayal of his patroness, Madame de Pompadour.

title: AN AMERICAN LIVING IN EL SALVADOR IS KILLED
description: An American who had lived in El Salvador for five years was shot dead early today, and a United States Embassy spokesman said it was not known if the shooting was connected with this country's civil war.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKS SMALL RISES IN SOME PROGRAMS
description: WHILE recommending a $9.3 billion state budget that earmarks billions for a variety of programs, Governor Kean, in his annual budget message to the State Legislature last week, emphasized several programs that carry comparatively modest price tags.

title: Emma Lazarus or Elizabeth Arden?
description: The deadliest shot in all the furor over the Statue of Liberty and Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca is ''commercialization,'' and it's being fired by both sides.

title: RUDOLF SERKIN AT FISHER HALL
description: Rudolf Serkin will be the guest soloist in a New York Philharmonic performance of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4, Thursday at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THERE are no two ways about it, many say: Some people just need to have good sense knocked into them. And ''The Convincer'' does just that. It is not a 6-foot-2 organized-crime enforcer in a black suit, black shirt and white tie, and it means no harm.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: ITHACA'S SLUSH Soggy but undaunted, Ithaca, N.Y., will celebrate its bad weather March 1 with a Slush Festival. It held one last year, even though there was no slush.

title: FROM THE LAND WHERE POLAR BEARS FLY
description: ARCTIC DREAMS Imagination and Desire in a Northern Landscape. By Barry Lopez. Maps. 464 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $22.95. IF you lowered a microphone into Lancaster Sound off Baffin Island in the Canadian Arctic on a summer day, you might hear all at once the tremolo moans of bearded seals, the baritone boom of a walrus, the high-pitched bark and yelp of ringed seals, the electric crackling of shrimp, the birdlike trills and clicks and other harmonics of white beluga whales and horned narwhals, and the elephantine trumpeting of huge bowhead whales. And it is this synchronous wealth of life - of all life - that Barry Lopez is celebrating in his jubilant new book. Among contemporary nature writers Mr. Lopez is especially a rhapsodist, and what he has done in this passionate paean to the Arctic and its cycles of light and darkness, its species of ice, its creatures and waters, is to present a whole series of raptures and riffs on the subject of musk oxen, ivory gulls, white foxes, polar bears, icebergs and sea cur-rents. Speaking of the effect of the Arctic upon an explorer, he describes how ''the land becomes large, alive like an animal; it humbles him. . . . It is not that the land is simply beautiful but that it is powerful. . . . Darkness and light are bound together within it, and the feeling that this is the floor of creation.''

title: I THINK, THEREFORE THE UNIVERSE IS
description: THE ANTHROPIC COSMOLOGICAL PRINCIPLE By John D. Barrow and Frank J. Tipler. Diagrams. Tables. 706 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95 EVER since Copernicus removed humankind from the center of the universe, scientists have tended to proceed on the assumption that we inhabitants of one tiny planet are nothing special and have little to do with the vasty workings of the stars. But in recent years this Copernican assumption has been challenged by researchers wielding what is called the anthropic cosmological principle - ''anthropic'' meaning ''of mankind'' and ''cosmological'' pertaining to the study of the universe as a whole.

title: WITH A LOT OF HELP FROM HIS FRIENDS
description: NO LAUGHING MATTER By Joseph Heller and Speed Vogel. 335 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: LAST CIVILIAN BEACON KEEPER STANDS WATCH NEAR CONEY I.
description: Frank Schubert says life in a lighthouse is a lot easier now than it was when he started out in the business nearly a half-century ago.

title: FAIR STRESSES CHILDREN'S SAFETY
description: BECAUSE safety experts say teeth are useful in locating and identifying lost children, a New Haven hospital and the Connecticut Children's Museum are holding a Child Safety Weekend next Saturday and Sunday for youngsters from all over the state.

title: TRUMP FACES FIGHT OVER MARINA LEASE
description: MAYOR James L. Usry says he is ''apprehensive'' that the recent awarding of a 25-year lease to the Trump Organization to improve and operate the Frank S. Farley State Marina alongside the Trump Castle Hotel-Casino ''will add to the perception, already very strong, that Atlantic City is being dominated more and more by the specter of casinos.''

title: THE LIFE THAT WAS AND THE LIFE THAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN
description: A FEW months ago I attended the wake of my cousin. It might as well have been yesterday, because the image of him in repose preys on my mind as if it had been my own brother's.

title: EXPANDING THE HORIZONS OF LOCAL SCHOOLS
description: In this capital, even inner-city children are involved in diplomatic doings.

title: ART: BY 19TH-CENTURY BLACK ARTISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 - In celebration of black history month, the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore is presenting the works of five 19th-century black artists who, despite discrimination, became respected practitioners of their craft.

title: OLSON WINS POLE VAULT, CLEARING 19-0 1/4
description: It was 1:15 A.M. yesterday. A weary Billy Olson sat on the deserted board track in Madison Square Garden, packing his vaulting poles into a carrying case. He searched for words to describe the battle of the pole vault titans.

title: HELPING THOSE WHO NEED US
description: I just had to respond to Barbara Gerbasi's article ''The Best Charity: Give of Yourself and Your Wallet'' [ Opinion Page, Dec. 29 ] . Most people just sit, read a really moving piece of work, respond mentally for a few minutes and then get up and carry on; this time I couldn't.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO PREVENT STORM DAMAGE
description: WHEN Hurricane Gloria hit our region last fall, the damage that proved most costly and that resulted in the greatest inconvenience was the loss of electrical power, most of which could be blamed on falling trees and branches. Can anything be done to prevent this from happening again?

title: SAVORIES FROM THE MIDDLE EAST
description: A FIRST for lower Fairfield County is the arrival of a Middle-Eastern restaurant, Marcella's in Westport. In a pleasantly decorated, storefront setting, Marcella's offers the chance to sample a cuisine that has been under-represented in Connecticut far too long.

title: Justice Can Be Beautiful
description: DO YOU EVER WISH you were one of the Beautiful People? Sure you do, especially in February when the Beautiful People are being photographed loafing on their private Caribbean islands.

title: CUOMO URGES TIGHTER BAN ON SEX BIAS IN SCHOOLS
description: Students' protection against sex discrimination in any public or private school that receives state assistance would be broadened by legislation introduced by Governor Cuomo.

title: CATHARINE MOYER TO MARRY IN FALL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Weil Moyer of Crozet, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catharine Foster Moyer, to Carrington Waddell Ewell, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel McGregor Ewell Jr. of Charlottesville, Va. An October wedding is planned.

title: 12 KOREAN ARTISTS SHOW AT THORPE
description: TO New Yorkers, the influx of Korean immigrants seems recent. But, in fact, it dates to before the Sino-Japanese War of 1894-1895, when Korea was under Chinese control, though did not begin in earnest until Japan gained control of the country after its 1904-1905 war with Russia.

title: Toxic Waste Technology Still Has Something to Prove
description: At a time when many Government agencies are trying to make do with less, the Environmental Protection Agency says it cannot spend all the money Congress wants to give it to clean up toxic wastes.

title: PLAINTIFFS PRESS INQUIRY ON U.S. SUPPORT FOR NICARAGUA REBELS
description: Attorneys for the plaintiffs in a civil lawsuit asked an appeals court here this week to lift an order that has delayed an investigation of the Reagan Administration's support for Nicaraguan rebels.

title: INVITING MERGERS THAT ARE SURE TO FAIL
description: THE Reagan Administration proposes to reform the antitrust laws. In fact, its proposal is not reform at all; it is war on America's competition policy. Masquerading laissez-faire as efficiency, the Administration would set back American business in the race to be the best.

title: THE MAN WHO KNOWS WHAT EVERYONE'S DRINKING
description: SUCCESSFUL men often enjoy rehashing their youthful shortcomings - it puts their later achievements in an even more impressive light. Take Marvin Shanken. He loves to recall that he finished last in his class at the University of Miami back in the 1960's. It is a dubious distinction that is easy for him to admit - he has not been last at much of anything since.

title: SALLY STIEFVATER BRIDE OF MICHAEL J. TEDESCO
description: The marriage of Sally Lynn Stiefvater to Michael James Tedesco took place yesterday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Dennis Keane performed the ceremony.

title: FORFEIT RULING
description: Joseph Bertagna, executive director of ice hockey for the Eastern College Athletic Conference, has ruled that the St. Lawrence University team must forfeit its Jan. 4 victory over Army for using an ineligible player, Joseph McEachern, who transferred from Boston College to St. Lawrence at mid-year, and did not wait the required year before competing. McEachern registered an assist in the 6-4 victory over Army, the only game in which he has been in uniform for St. Lawrence.

title: MANY EVENTS FOR CHILDREN ON VACATION
description: WITH many children in the county on vacation this week, there are numerous scheduled activities to amaze, educate, challenge, and, in some cases, exhaust them.

title: HELPING TO BUILD A LOVE FOR READNG
description: EACH day at the Roberto Clemente Elementary School in Bridgeport, 60 students take a trip to better learning skills at the Railroad Reading Lab. They move their trains from station to station, and advance along the tracks as they master phonics, vocabulary and comprehension skills.

title: BASEBALL EVER RETURN?
description: Snow blanketed vacant Robert F. Kennedy Stadium this week, but small clusters of unregenerate baseball fans, fearful that the major leagues will never return to Washington in their lifetime, were already organizing spring rites to celebrate clubs in more fortunate jurisdictions.

title: BETTE DAVIS IS THE STAR OF A 37-FILM RETROSPECTIVE
description: IN 1935, shortly after Bette Davis received her first Academy Award, for the movie ''Dangerous,'' the actress wheedled out of her husband, Harold O. Nelson, the closely guarded secret of his middle name. It turned out to be Oscar. ''To tease him, I began to call my statuette 'Oscar,' '' the actress reminisced 20 years later. ''Soon, 'Oscar' was adopted by the industry - and that's how the Academy Award statuettes got their nickname.''

title: CASE OF THE JUDGE VS. PROSECUTORS
description: A DISPUTE that could have broad implications for the criminal justice system in Suffolk County has embroiled a County Court judge and the Suffolk County District Attorney's office.

title: OUTSIDE OF ROME, A MEDIEVAL WHODUNIT UNFOLDS
description: Just beyond Rome city limits, the hurly-burly of modern high-rises, outdoor vendors and ramshackle houses gives way abruptly to the expanse of the Lazio countryside.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Juror in Rackets Trial
description: A Federal judge decided today to keep a woman on the jury panel hearing the racketeering trial of reputed leaders of Boston's crime syndicate, saying he had no evidence that she discussed the case with her boyfriend.

title: SARAH STANGER TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. William McKee Stanger of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Brook Stanger to Brian T. Mahoney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Mahoney, also of Summit. Miss Stanger and her fiance graduated from the Newark Academy and are seniors at West Virginia University. A September wedding is planned.

title: SUING A BOARD
description: To the Editor:

title: MARIA B. DOELGER TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Doelger of New Canaan, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maria Barbara Doelger to Bennett Karl Langlotz, a son of Lanie B. Bryce and Philip F. Langlotz, both of St. Paul. The wedding is planned for June 21.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY PLANS DETAILED STUDY OF NEW YORK'S WATER SYSTEM
description: Harvey W. Schultz, who was sworn in as Commissioner of Environmental Protection last week, says his agency will make a detailed assessment of New York City's water system, from its management to its distribution.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO PREVENT STORM DAMAGE
description: WHEN Hurricane Gloria hit our region last fall, the damage that proved most costly and that resulted in the greatest inconvenience was the loss of electrical power, most of which could be blamed on falling trees and branches. Can anything be done to prevent this from happening again?

title: ENERGY UNIT TESTED
description: A HOME energy device that combines the functions of a furnace, water heater and air-conditioner in one unit is being tested in two condominiums in Middletown by Northeast Utilities.

title: Koch Gives New Duties To Three at City Hall
description: Mayor Koch named a new criminal-justice coordinator and a new executive director of city planning Friday, and gave added duties to a third city official.

title: WOMEN TACKLE THE CONSTRUCTION TRADES
description: ''I WAS out in the snow, with no shoes on - I had to use my knowledge to earn money to support myself and my two children,'' Lenore Janis said last week when asked why she had decided to start a construction company. Mrs. Janis, president of Era Steel Construction Corporation in White Plains, is one of a small number of women who own construction companies. Era, a subcontractor, furnishes and erects structural steel and provides miscellaneous iron and heavy equipment on building projects for bridges, subways and railroad facilities.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AUCTION RECORD
description: An exceptional 1794 silver dollar, said to be the finest known, brought $209,000 to set the pace at a blockbuster coin auction held last month in Los Angeles. The auction, conducted by Superior Stamp & Coin Company Inc. of Beverly Hills, realized more than $6 million making it one of the highest-grossing sales in numismatic history. According to the catalogue, the silver dollar is in Mint State-63 condition and has prooflike surfaces.

title: Dartmouth Is Assailed On South Africa Policy
description: More than 100 students at Dartmouth College attended an open meeting of the school's board of trustees today and exchanged barbed comments on whether the university should sell its holdings in companies that do business with South Africa.

title: SOLVING THE BAY AREA'S BASEBALL PROBLEM
description: FOR the 19th consecutive season, the San Francisco Giants will play their home games at Candlestick Park, where that city's southern border meets the shore of San Francisco Bay, and the Oakland A's will play their American League home games in the Oakland Coliseum, nine miles east in the southwest corner of Oakland.

title: MICHAEL HAYDN: OUT FROM THE SHADOW OF HIS ELDER BROTHER
