description: The composer whose name Michael Haydn's evokes is, of course, his elder brother, Joseph Haydn. But, as two new recorded volumes of Michael's symphonies make clear, his nearest musical kinsman is his fellow Salzburger, Mozart.

title: SETON HALL WINS IN OVERTIME
description: Seton Hall, which rallied for 4 points in 42 seconds to tie Boston College at the end of regulation, scored the first 8 points in overtime and went on to a surprising 84-75 triumph today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It has already become evident, sadly, that the elections were marred by widespread fraud and violence perpetrated largely by the ruling party.'' - White House statement on Philippine election. [ 1:4. ]

title: Making Jojoba While the Sun Shines
description: Across arid stretches of southern California and Arizona, pioneering farmers were busy last week preparing fields of jojoba, a desert shrub that was unknown to commercial agriculture 10 years ago. Since they started growing it in 1979, Southwestern farmers have planted 45,000 acres of the hearty bush, which produces an oil so versatile that cosmetics manufacturers use it in facial creams and petroleum companies are testing it as an industrial lubricant.

title: MELK
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest the article about the restoration of the Abbey in Melk, Austria.

title: RETURN OF SALMON PLANNED
description: AMERICAN shad and Atlantic salmon, two species prized by anglers and welcomed by diners, may return to the Thames River and its tributaries after an absence of more than 150 years.

title: MICHIGAN RECOVERS TO ROUT IOWA, 82-66
description: Antoine Joubert and Gary Grant led a 13-0 spurt midway through the second half to help Michigan (22-3, 10-3) to an 82-66 Big Ten Conference victory today over Iowa (16-9, 6-6). Michigan trailed by 44-43 with 13 minutes 57 seconds remaining when Roy Tarpley connected on short jumper and was fouled by Roy Marble. Tarpley completed the 3-point play, and Michigan scored 10 more points to take a 56-44 lead with 10:53 to play. Grant and Joubert, the starting guards, combined for 28 second-half points and forced Iowa into a number of turnovers. Joubert finished with a game-high 19 points, and Grant added 18. Kansas 79, Nebraska 61

title: A CHOREOGRAPHER FINDS INSPIRATION IN BECKETT'S THEATRICS
description: Maguy Marin, whose dance company makes its New York City debut this week at City Center with a series of performances of ''May B,'' her dance-theater piece inspired by the theatrical world of Samuel Beckett, is one of the young modern-dance choreographers who have been changing the look of the French dance scene in the last few years.

title: SUNDAY IN THE APARTMENT WITH GEORG
description: GEORG LUKACS And His Generation 1900-1918. By Mary Gluck. Illustrated. 265 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: A VIEW OF WASHINGTON'S CHARACTER AS SEEN IN THE LAST WILL AND TESTAMENT
description: A FEW years ago my wife and I participated as students in a January semester course given at Williams College, where our son was a student. The course, ''The Historian as Detective,'' involved historical editing of 18th- and 19th-century original American documents.

title: PATERNTIY LEAVE FOR POLICEMEN
description: WHEN Timothy M. Hogan, a lieutenant in the Hartford Police Department, requested paternity leave for the birth of his third child two years ago, his superiors told him he must be kidding and said no.

title: METRO-NORTH QUEST: A HAVEN FOR BRIDGE
description: CARD PLAYERS on Metro-North trains are a raffish bunch, not to be confused with your ordinary submissive, silent, resigned rider.

title: CRAWLEY GOES FOR BRAMBLE'S TITLE
description: ON the fight posters and in newspaper advertisements, today's World Boxing Association lightweight championship bout is being billed as ''The Grand Slam.''

title: TWO PIANISTS, A VIOLINIST AND A CELLIST IN RECITALS
description: Arthur Rowe The Canadian pianist Arthur Rowe made an immediate and positive impression in his debut recital last Sunday evening at Merkin Hall; before eight bars of Mozart's Sonata in D (K.384) had gone by one knew he was capable of vigor without heaviness, energy without excess of drive. It was first-rate ''modern school'' playing: a kind of execution tinglingly alive to the shape and potential contribution of each little phrase or part of a phrase. Rather than a vibrant, pulsing sweep, Mr. Rowe sought a cleanly articulated, buoyant step; the sonata was quick with the energy of Mozart. The slow movement was not particularly songful, but he played the opening theme of the finale with such lively feeling for its shape and latent yield that one was more than usually curious to hear the variations.

title: DATA BANK February 16, 1986
MUSIC: MEHTA AND YO-YO MA
description: ZUBIN MEHTA'S New York Philharmonic program this week at Avery Fisher Hall ends with the same blockbuster that concluded last week's program, Bruckner's ''Romantic'' Symphony No. 4. But the beginning is different: Yo-Yo Ma as soloist in the 30-minute Elgar Cello Concerto (1919).

title: Sexism in Orbit
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN'S NIGHT OF 'DRUHA NAHODA'
description: AFTER six and a half hours, enough time for even the stragglers of a marathon to finish, the pole vault at the Wanamaker Millrose Games ended shortly after midnight Saturday morning with Billy Olson declared the winner at 19 feet, even though Dave Volz had soared three-quarter of an inch higher. It had begun with Joe Dial using borrowed poles because his fiberglass swizzle sticks were still in the St. Louis airport. And in between, it had been punctuated by Sergei Bubka's anguished squawks about ''additional attempts'' granted Billy Olson and Joe Dial, his primary American rivals.

title: JURY DELIBERATING IN RADICALS' TRIAL
description: A Federal jury in Brooklyn is to resume deliberations Tuesday in the case of six self-described revolutionaries accused of a series of terrorist bombings in the metropolitan area.

title: USE OF PRIVATE SUITS IN HOUSING BIAS CASES IN FEDERAL COURTS IS INCREASING
description: Just before Christmas a Federal judge granted $80,000 to two young black women and a Hispanic couple who had been denied housing in a large rental complex in Alexandria, Va., because of their race or ethnic origin.

title: MATCH TO FEATURE SENIOR TENNIS STARS
description: TENNIS stars of the 1950's, 60's and 70's will reunite in competition Thursday through next Sunday at the third annual Merrill Lynch Tennis Classic at the New Canaan Racquet Club.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: The pinhole camera has no lens and no shutter and it is too slow to stop the motion of a leaping athlete or a humming bird poised in midair at the feeder. But when the subject stands still - a landscape, a still life, even perhaps a sleeping model - this box with a tiny aperture at one end can help the photographer achieve a truly poetic beauty.

title: STATE FEARFUL OF BOARD CUTBACK
description: AMONG the anticipated changes in the Federal tax structure feared by New Jersey officials is the demise or diminution of state programs that provide low-interest, tax-free financing for the construction of industrial, commercial or office buildings and the acquistion of equipment.

title: MEXICO TRIES AN OPEN-DOOR POLICY
description: FOR many months, radio stations here have run public service announcements informing listeners that Mexico is undergoing ''structural changes'' that will benefit all Mexicans. And scarcely a day passes in which a Government official is not quoted calling for the same ''structural changes,'' saying that Mexico cannot progress without them.

title: Our Champagne Era Recalls Brut Times
description: May I proclaim the Champagne Era?

title: A LIFE SPENT SHOVELLING SNOW
description: WHY is it that when a snowstorm is predicted, cheerful weather forecasters invariably proclaim:

title: JERSEY AIMS AIDS EDUCATION DRIVE AT DRUG USERS
description: New Jersey, which ranks fourth among the states in the number of AIDS cases, is the only state in which AIDS patients who are intravenous drug users outnumber those who are believed to have contracted the disease from homosexual activity, according to the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: TV TURNS TO THE HARD-BOILED MALE
description: For most of the past decade, the ideal American man as rendered by television was decidedly of the Alan Alda school, a sensitive doctor/policeman/lawyer who cared, and whose consciousness, if not already raised, was rising. One embodiment of the type, Frank Furillo, the painstakingly sensitive police captain of NBC's ''Hill Street Blues,'' is so fully liberated that a sociologist was once moved to write, ''No social engineer could do much better than the creators of Captain Furillo.''

title: TOWNS PREPARE FOR PLANT CLOSINGS
description: THE long-running debate that usually occurs in the state legislature over how to deal with plant closings has moved to Connecticut's cities and towns this year.

title: REVENGE FOR '69 CUBS?
description: The 1969 Chicago Cubs, who blew the National League's Eastern Division championship to the eventual world champion Mets, will try to get some revenge in Phoenix today in ''Dream Game '86,'' a seven-inning benefit game. In 1969, the Cubs squandered a nine-and-a-half-game lead in mid-August, were overtaken by the Mets on Sept. 10 and wound up eight games behind at season's end.

title: PLENTY OF BARK BUT NOT MUCH BIT IN 'BEVERLY HILLS'
description: Consider Matisse - the dog, not the artist. Matisse is the name of the character of the Scottish border collie in ''Down and Out in Beverly Hills,'' Paul Mazursky's very free adaptation of Jean Renoir's 1932 French comedy, ''Boudu Saved From Drowning.'' The Renoir film, itself adapted from a play by Rene Fauchois, has been updated and transferred to southern California, where the River Seine of the original is now a heated swimming pool.

title: OVER-THE-HILL GANG FULFILLS A DREAM
description: THE baseball zipped around the infield. The veteran pros stretched their limbs after a winter indoors, while scouts holding clipboards jotted down their observations about the eager recruits.

title: A Drug Inquiry At Eastern
description: With Eastern Airlines negotiating a difficult labor dispute while facing bankruptcy, chairman Frank Borman has recent experience with adversity. Still, his reaction to the disclosure that 50 of his baggage handlers in Miami were the target of a Federal cocaine-smuggling inquiry was one of the more restrained.

title: Are Mothers Losers?
description: To the Editor:

title: REVAMPING THE OLYMPIC FRANCHISE
description: AT the 1988 Olympic Games, the Coca-Cola Company will not have the option of playing favorites. When it decided to associate itself with the event, it had to pay to become the ''official'' soft drink of not only the American team, but of the athletes from Nicaragua, Israel, Syria - in fact, of the Olympic squads of at least 120 other nations.

title: ALLIES GENERALLY BACK REAGAN'S RESPONSE ON ARMS
description: President Reagan's proposed response to Mikhail S. Gorbachev plan to eliminate nuclear weapons by the year 2000 has been given a generally positive reaction from the United States' allies, according to Administration officials.

title: KEAN'S HELP ASKED ON MARINE LAB
description: NEW JERSEY'S two Senators and four of its Representatives have asked Governor Kean to help keep the National Marine Fisheries Laboratory at Sandy Hook.

title: Iran and Iraq Are At It Again
description: The war between Iran and Iraq, which began in September 1980 and has survived frequent lulls, erupted again last week. Iran, promising that it had no intention of invading Kuwait or Saudi Arabia, contended that its troops had invaded southeastern Iraq, killed 10,000 enemy troops, taken 1,400 prisoners and were marching north from the Persian Gulf oil port of Fao to Basra, Iraq's second-largest city.

title: LAURI ANN ROHAN TO WED A LAWYER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Rohan of Bronxville, N.Y., and Cotuit, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauri Ann Rohan, to Timothy Gerald Griffin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Hancock Griffin of Bronxville and Ocean Ridge, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: CALCIUM 'FAD' BOON TO JERSEY CONCERNS
description: CALCIUM, which is being promoted to prevent a debilitating bone disease in older women, is becoming a booming industry in New Jersey. However, a debate is stirring among health-care professionals over what they call ''oversell'' of calcium supplements.

title: CABLE TV CONCERN HAS PAID FEES OF $220,000 TO BRONX DEMOCRAT
description: A Bronx Democratic Party official has been paid more than $220,000 since 1981 for working a few days a month as a consultant to a company that won the borough's cable television franchise, according to city records.

title: EXTORTION BY FORGERY GIVEN AS MOTIVE IN UTAH MURDERS
description: Court documents indicate that prosecutors will try to prove that a murder suspect here set out to extort hundreds of thousands of dollars from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints by forging embarrassing historical documents and then offering to sell them secretly to church leaders.

title: VANLANDINGHAM RALLIES FOR VICTORY
description: Vanlandingham, last year's champion older male, made his first start of the year a winning one with a hard-fought victory in the second division of the Canadian Turf Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: A VINTAGE COLLECTION FOR RADIOPHILES
description: Stephen Despres calls himself a radiophile, an ardent collector-dealer of early modern machines produced between 1920 and 1950. And he has selected 100 examples from his stock of period designs for an exhibition called ''Radiophile,'' on view through March 1, at O.K. Harris, 383 West Broadway.

title: The Risks Labor Is Running At Hormel
description: For six months, meatpackers at the Austin plant of Geo. A. Hormel & Company have been conducting a bitter strike that has split the town and captured the attention of management and labor across the country.

title: OWNERS SAY ABUSE GROUNDED BIG FLAG
description: ON and off for the last 20 months, a huge American flag - believed to be the largest ever flown in the state - has been displayed on a flag pole atop a hillside on the east side of Route 7 north of the Merritt Parkway in Norwalk.

title: One of 'Most Wanted' Held
description: David Sterling, a fugitive from a mental hospital who was on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of 10 most wanted people, was arrested Thursday by the state police. Mr. Sterling, 31 years old, had escaped from Western State Hospital in Vancouver, Wash. He and Ronald Johnson, 23, were arrested in a car driven by Mr. Johnson. The men were also wanted by the F.B.I. in connection with four bank robberies, the police said.

title: A 'COMFORT FOOD' FROM CHILDHOOD: EGG ROLLS AND LO MEIN
description: THERE has been a great deal of attention focused in recent months on ''comfort foods,'' such as meat loaf, mashed potatoes and chocolate pudding. It is the sort of menu that does not require trendy ingredients, exotic cooking techniques or equipment. In their old-fashioned honesty these dishes should also be made from scratch, like mother would have prepared.

title: MELANCHOLY MEN, WANTON WOMEN
description: LIFE ON THIS PLANET And Other Stories. By Matt Cohen. 182 pp. New York: Beaufort Books. $14.95.

title: 'JEWEL' UNSOLD
description: RESIDENTS of the Hasting-on-Hudson school district voted almost 2 to 1 - 1,144 to 669 - on Tuesday against selling what some called ''the crown jewel'' of the village, an estate once owned by Billie Burke and Florenz Ziegfeld, for development of 66 town houses.

title: PARIS ANTIQUES: BUY, THEN FLY
description: An American visitor to Paris bought an Art Deco deep blue ceramic vase for $325 - ''It would be a lot more in New York,'' she said. An Italian fell for a dog-headed cane, because ''I collect them,'' he said. At $180 it was not such a bargain, but animal-headed canes are apparently hard to find. And a Japanese visitor bought an exquisite, lace-edged linen handkerchief for a fairly reasonable $85.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Fairfield County Hunt Club, Westport, Conn. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (203) 259-7783.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
POSTDATE
description: DEAR SELF, Right now I'm in seventh grade. I'm trapped in middle school eagerly awaiting the beginning of high school . . .

title: COMMUTERS RATE NEW METRO-NORTH CARS SET FOR DANBURY
description: AS he rode toward Grand Central Terminal in one of the newest Metro-North cars, a Bombardier Shoreliner, Joseph Alberti of Montrose, near Peekskill, N.Y., pronounced it not very comfortable.

title: DOCTORS' DELIGHT
description: A 30-room house built in 1799 at 2103 Main Street, Stratford has been converted into The Family Health Network of Stratford, a medical center founded by a group of doctors who were looking for a homey atmosphere.

title: FEMALE DOCTORS BREAKING BARRIERS
description: WHEN the male doctor who had been treating her since she was a teen-ager died recently, Loretta Lerner had to find a new physician for her North Shore family. The family got together, talked to friends and professionals, and selected two doctors who practice together - both of them women.

title: A Mixed Verdict In the Move Trial
description: After deliberating 13 hours over three days, a jury of seven whites and five blacks delivered its verdict last week in a trial that the defendent, Romana Johnson Africa, had tried to turn into a referendum on Philadelphia's handling of last year's confrontation between police and the radical group Move. Miss Africa was found guilty of one riot count and one count of conspiracy.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A RUSSIAN-JEWISH FAMILY FINDS A NEW LIFE IN NEW JERSEY
description: WHEN Anna left her native Leningrad 10 years ago, she did not know that a decade later she would not have again seen her parents or her brother Alexei and that they would not have seen her three children.

title: NASA, IN '73, CHOSE LOW-RATED BIDDER
description: The Thiokol Chemical Corporation, builder of the solid-fuel booster rocket that is a focus in the search for the cause of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, ranked last among four competitors on its proposal for design and development of the rocket, according to space agency documents.

title: VALENZUELA GETS $5.5 MILLION
description: One day after Dwight Gooden eclipsed one of Fernando Valenzuela's salary records, the Los Angeles Dodger pitcher reached two historic salary plateaus yesterday. He became the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history, and he became the first pitcher to sign a contract that included a one-year salary of $2 million or more.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BIMWILI & THE ZIMWI A Tale From Zanzibar. By Verna Aardema. Illustrated by Susan Meddaugh. 32 pp. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8) INTRODUCING a folk tale to an alien culture is a challenging task, especially when it is for a picture-book audience. Verna Aardema has often met that challenge with her elegant, authentic-sounding versions of traditional African tales, including ''Why Mosquitoes Buzz in People's Ears'' and ''Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain.'' Her latest venture is a curious tale from Zanzibar (now part of Tanzania).

title: Zurich
description: To the Editor: In October we spent two weeks in Zurich, and we agree that it is a city that has much to offer visitors (''What's Doing in Zurich,'' Travel, Jan. 26). For a change of pace from the shops on the Bahnhofstrasse, however, I would suggest exploring on foot the areas near the city.

title: EXETER, AT 205, EXPANDS ON THE BASICS
description: One of the nation's leading preparatory schools, Phillips Exeter Academy, will begin changing its curriculum in the fall to give students a broader education, a step the school says is needed because students specialize too early in college.

title: NEW BILLING FOR THOSE OLD MOVIE HOUSES
description: CENTRAL AVENUE in Cedarhurst is what townspeople like to refer to as ''upscale.'' Its stores include fur salons and fashion boutiques such as Benneton. Soon to come is the Cedarhurst Center, an indoor mall with more fashion boutiques, home furnishing stores, interior decorators,a wine store and an art gallery.

title: GLIMPSE OF SPRING AND DREAM GARDENS
description: Just about now a certain impatience with winter sets in. Not, of course, among those who fancy skiing in the Alps or snowbirds who've flown off to warmer climes. It is gardeners and garden watchers who are tortured almost daily by the arrival of yet another gaudy catalogue with images of outragously exquisite plants. Meanwhile, winter howls behind the door and spring's reality is far away. If sanity is to prevail, the antidote might just be a pilgrimage to as many of the season's flower shows as possible - there to savor splendidly perfumed hyacinths, covet flashy prize-winning orchids (and brush soft herbs when the exhibitor isn't looking). Never mind the ice pockets that dot the landscape beyond. Within the show's cavernous hall, there is that intoxicating aura, however brief, of the garden's aromatic, humid air.

title: Who Knew Keats and When
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO BOTTLES OF POISONED TYLENOL WERE SHIPPED BY SAME DISTRIBUTOR
description: Investigators tracing the routes of two bottles of Extra-Strength Tylenol containing cyanide-laced capsules have found that both were handled at the same distribution center in Pennsylvania two weeks apart last summer.

title: TRADITIONAL CHINESE MUSIC MAY BE ON THE WAY BACK
description: China, with a third of the world's population and a history of cultural achievement dating back over 4,000 years, might be presumed to have been an overwhelming force in human culture in general and music in particular. Yet for various reasons, we in the West hear less Chinese music than the ''barbarian'' -what the Chinese call anyone or anything unfortunate enough not to be Chinese - musics of India, Japan, Indonesia, Africa and the Caribbean.

title: 'Non Fumer'?
description: To the Editor: Frank J. Prial's exciting, fascinating, mouth-watering article on the Nouvelle Premiere (Travel, Jan. 19) makes me want to book a reservation immediately. But before I do I'd like to know what protection nonsmokers have from smokers.

title: TERRORISM FEARS CANCEL SCHOOL TRIPS
description: A NUMBER of Long Island school districts have canceled overseas trips planned for their students because of the possible danger of terrorist attack. Other districts, however, have decided to continue such trips for the time being.

title: FIESTA IN TUCSON, BLACK FOREST WALKS
description: The Heritage Of Tucson Is Celebrated It all starts with mountain men and trappers in a tepee camp, and United States cavalry with their cannons and muskets.

title: TALES OF APARTMENT-HUNTING: HOW SOME SUCCEEDED
description: ''I'VE had to look for an apartment five times in five years and it's been terrible every time,'' said Elizabeth Pearson, a production editor at Random House, the New York publisher.

title: TRANSIT FARES TO RISE
description: IT APPEARS certain that riders of NJ Transit buses and trains will be paying more later this year, according to top transit officials.

title: To Do Well on the S.A.T., It Helps to Be an Only Child
description: To the Editor:

title: JOAN M. SALZMAN TO BECOME BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Salzman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Mindy Salzman, to Michael Ivan Grant, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Grant of Cranston, R.I. A September wedding is planned. The future bride is senior counsel of Columbia Pictures Industries Inc. in New York and a former associate in the New York law firm of Shea & Gould.

title: NEW SUMMARY SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1986
description: International President Marcos won the election, the Philippine National Assembly decided. The move came after a week of slow and conflicting counts of the balloting on Feb. 7. His opponent, Corazon C. Aquino, planned a rally today at which her supporters were expected to endorse her as the winner. The assembly said Mr. Marcos's running mate, Arturo M. Tolentino, had been elected Vice President. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] President Reagan directly blamed the Marcos party for widespread fraud and violence in the election. A statement issued by the White House said the evidence ''was so extreme that the election's credibility has been called into question both within the Philippines and in the United States.'' The statement marked a shift in public posture from Mr. Reagan's remark at his news conference Tuesday that fraud ''could have been occurring on both sides.'' [ 1:4. ] Suicide terrorist bombings in Lebanon in the last year have increasingly been directly linked to pro-Syrian secular groups, according to evidence gathered by the Israeli Army, counterterrorism experts and residents of southern Lebanon. The officials and experts say they have concluded that there is no truth to previous assumptions the bombings were the work of pro-Iranian fanatics. [ 1:2. ] Anatoly B. Shcharansky is unchanged from the man he was in Moscow before his imprisonment nine years ago on treason charges. In an interview in Jerusalem, he said he remained true to ''the principles which I formed for myself after my arrest until the minute I left the plane'' in East Berlin on Monday as part of an East-West exchange of prisoners.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN SHELTON
description: ADECADE ago, when other Fairfield County communities were developing at an unprecedented rate, Shelton was in the doldrums.

title: ECONOMIC CONTRASTS INSPIRE GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: The contrast of wealth and luxury existing side by side with poverty and despair in New York City has prompted many contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: The Board of Estimate and Its Critics
description: Some people think it should be abolished. Others think it should be changed. And still others like New York City's Board of Estimate just the way it is. Not an agency, and not a legislature, it is the most powerful arm of city government besides the chief executive.

title: KATHERINE BLENKO ENGAGED TO MARRY JOSEPH BELANOFF
description: Mr. and Mrs. Don B. Blenko of Haverford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Ardis Blenko, to Joseph Kenneth Belanoff, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Belanoff of Mount Kisco, N.Y. A spring wedding is planned. Miss Blenko, a third-year student at the New York University School of Medicine, graduated from the Shipley School and magna cum laude from Amherst College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

title: CASINOS RACK UP A RECORD JANUARY
description: THE eight-year-old New Jersey casino industry enjoyed its best January last month.

title: EFFECTS OF NEW CUTBACKS
description: THE announcement this month that the Veterans Administration will sharply curtail its program of insuring home-mortgage loans is bad news for veterans with low incomes.

title: SWEET TEMPTATIONS IN ST. MORITZ
description: St. Moritz, the fashionable resort in Switzerland's Engadine Valley, has attracted the world's rich, titled and famous for more than a century. But the English get credit for starting the fashion. Back in 1864 they were the first international travelers to try out its winter, to discover that the sun shines there in December and to establish the St. Moritz ''season'' of winter sports in the Alps.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WATCHING THOSE PENNIES THE new automated coupon dispensing machine at the Waldbaum's supermarket in Oakdale had all the avid coupon shoppers stopping and staring. Even Howard C. DeMartini, Deputy County Executive of Suffolk County and, let it now be known, a serious coupon shopper, took a break from his weekly Saturday morning shopping to glance at the machine.

title: SCHOOLS COMPETING
description: Nine Westchester elementary and middle schools have been included on a list of the state's 36 top elementary schools that was submitted to a national competition last week.

title: 5 SITES TO AID MENTALLY ILL OF HOMELESS
description: FIVE emergency-care centers are being opened around the state for homeless people who are mentally ill, as well as for other poor and low-income residents with mental problems.

title: THE ELUSIVE RENT-REGULATED APARTMENTS
description: Finding a decent, affordable rent-regulated apartment in New York is like trying to recover a contact lens from a subway platform at rush hour. It can be done, but it takes dogged determination and a lot of luck.

title: TACTICS IN 3-D
description: Conventional maps have always made it difficult for armchair historians to understand the problems that terrain imposes on military leaders. In John Macdonald's lavishly illustrated volume, GREAT BATTLEFIELDS OF THE WORLD (Macmillan, $35), computer technology has created 9 1/2-by-12-inch three-dimensional maps of 30 famous battlefields that provide a much-enhanced perspective of the locales in which these battles were fought.

title: More Dollars For N.J. Scholars
description: During his five years in office, Governor Kean has staunchly supported increased state aid to education. It was no different last week in Trenton, as the Governor proposed a $9.3 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: MIAMI SOUND MACHINE ACHIEVES A CROSSOVER DREAM
description: ''Crossover Dreams,'' the title of a recent movie starring the Panamanian-born salsa singer Ruben Blades, embodied the longstanding aspirations of many Hispanic musicians to score a hit in the English-speaking market. In the film, Mr. Blades's character lands a lucrative recording contract by switching from salsa to American pop music, but enjoys only fleeting success. In real life, Mr. Blades's two musically eclectic, politically committed, Spanish-language ''crossover'' albums have likewise sold disappointingly, despite nearly unanimous critical acclaim.

title: INVESTING IN SUCCESS
description: GRAPES AND VINES are everywhere, along with stakes and tractors and masons and front-end loaders and some expectant wine people. This picture-postcard Tuscan countryside between Rome and Florence is ancient wine country. In the town of Montalcino, stone houses with their brown-tiled roofs have been built for a thousand years.

title: On Language; Moon Of My Delight
description: IN THE LANGUAGE OF the heavens, myth has become reality. You cannot look into the night sky without knowing your gods and goddesses, and cannot speak of space without an ear for current pronunciation.

title: LILLIAN H. HOFFMAN MARRIED IN FLORIDA TO DEREK ELLSWORTH OSTERGARD, CURATOR
description: The marriage of Lillian Holmes Hoffman, an administrator at Christie, Manson & Woods International in New York, to Derek Ellsworth Ostergard, a curator with the American Federation of Arts in New York, took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. The Rev. James H. Cooper performed the ceremony.

title: BEYOND DRILL, QUESTIONS HOVER OVER SHOREHAM
description: WHEN the Long Island Lighting Company won a Federal court ruling last week that allowed a Federally monitored emergency drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the company hailed its victory as another significant step toward the licensing of the plant for commercial operation.

title: East and West Germany Are Speaking the Same Language
description: The passage of Anatoly B. Shcharansky across a snow-incrusted bridge in this divided city last week had implications that went beyond the Russian dissident's own passionate story. His journey to freedom, a reunion with his wife and a new home in Israel also affected the relations between the United States and the Soviet Union and, perhaps more significantly, between the two German states.

title: FOR ROOSEVELT ISLAND, DETOURS ON FIRST DAY WITHOUT TRAM
description: By the time Richard Babat, who has lived on Roosevelt Island nine years, boarded a bus to the subway in Queens yesterday morning, he was angry.

title: PHILOSOPHER-KING OF CITICORP
description: RISK & OTHER FOUR-LETTER WORDS By Walter B. Wriston. 243 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95. THE epigraph of the first chapter of my book ''The Bankers'' in 1975 was a quotation from Henry Harfield, a senior partner in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, addressing a lawyers' group: ''Just remember this: If bankers were as smart as you are, you would starve to death.'' I am reliably informed that when a copy of this book crossed the desk of Walter B. Wriston, then chairman and chief executive officer of Citicorp, he put in a call to Shearman & Sterling, which is Citicorp's lead counsel, to inquire whether Mr. Harfield had really said that. As the quotation had been taken from the transcript of a meeting, Mr. Harfield could not disown it. ''I have a problem,'' Mr. Wriston is reported to have said. ''I can spell Sullivan, but I'm not sure how you spell Cromwell.''

title: 9 YEARS LATER, SHCHARANSKY SEEMS THE SAME
description: The news about Anatoly B. Shcharansky is that he has not changed very much.

title: MUSIC: BROOKLYNITES PLAY SIBELIUS
description: IN 1926 Jean Sibelius wrote the tone poem ''Tapiola,'' an epilogue to his series of vast, searching symphonies, and then fell silent (or nearly) for the three decades left to him. So, eventually, did the chorus of critical acclaim that had hailed in him our century's worthiest heir to the great symphonic line. But we have been for some time in the midst of a searching re-examination of 20th-century musical conservatives, and so it hardly seemed surprising that Lukas Foss and his Brooklyn Philharmonic should give an all-Sibelius program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Friday night (the program will be repeated there today at 2 P.M.).

title: KLANGFARBENMELODIEN AND THE DUKE
description: MUSINGS The Musical Worlds of Gunther Schuller. By Gunther Schuller. 303 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.50. WHEN, in the midst of ''Musings: The Musical Worlds of Gunther Schuller,'' you come upon the words ''I am not by nature a polemicist or a crusader,'' don't believe them for a minute. Whether or not Gunther Schuller was born to be a crusader, his life has been devoted to many causes, all working toward a common purpose - opening the ears and minds of Americans to the music of their time and land. By definition, it seems, an American composer has to be a fighter. But few have struggled on so many fronts so ceaselessly; Mr. Schuller not only promotes his own music and that of composer colleagues but embraces jazz with open arms and subscribes to what he terms ''a global view of music.''

title: L.I. RADIO BEATS CITY STATIONS FOR LISTENERS' HEARTS AND EARS
description: FOR decades, Long Island radio stations broadcast in the shadow of their powerful rivals in Manhattan. Island radio found it difficult to compete for the big advertisers and the big audiences that gravitated to the 50,000-watt stations in New York City.

title: Curbing the Fear of AIDS
description: An important new study confirms that there is virtually no chance of acquiring AIDS through casual contact. The study discovered no such cases in households of AIDS patients. There is no justification, hence, for society to turn victims of AIDS into pariahs, forcing them out of jobs and apartments, refusing to provide them services or to let them, in the case of children, stay in school.

title: HOW PASSENGERS RATE NEW CARS ON HUDSON LINE
description: AS he rode toward Grand Central in one of Metro-North's newest cars, a Bombardier Shoreliner, Joseph Alberti, a Montrose resident, pronounced it not very comfortable.

title: L.I. GROUP WORKS TO SAVE LIGHTHOUSE FROM RUIN
description: For 73 years, a small, boxy, white building perched atop a rock has weathered the storms in Huntington Bay. But it has been a generation since anyone lived in or cared for the lighthouse, the Lloyd Harbor Light, and now it is rapidly becoming a ruin.

title: JILLSON KNOWLES BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Jillson Bunce Knowles and Paul Donald Sullivan were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan by Canon David Lowry and the Rev. James Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Courtland Knowles of Plandome, L.I., Wakefield, R.I., and Wimbledon, England. Mr. Sullivan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Sullivan of Milton, Mass.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Discounted Furniture, Domestic and Imports T Mark Furniture Galleries was established as a furniture manufacturer, wholesaler and retailer in 1959 in a former Alexander Carpet Company building in Yonkers, but after 10 years the management decided to concentrate on discounted sales of American-made furniture, plus imports from France, Italy, Canada, Yugoslavia and the Far East.

title: STEVEN D. COHN IS WED TO JANA JAGOLKOWSKY
description: Jana Rosa Jagolkowsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Moises Jagolkowsky of Lima, Peru, and New York, was married last night to Steven D. Cohn, the son of Lillian Cohn of New York and Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and the late Judge Harold W. Cohn of Civil Court. Rabbi Ben Amun performed the ceremony at Sharon Synagogue in Lima.

title: DEMOCRATS FOCUS ON FARM CRISIS IN MID WEST
description: It was ''Reagan-bashing'' time in Kansas City this weekend, in the words of one Democrat who attended a policy-making session here on farm and rural problems.

title: MASSACHUSETTS LAW: A LONGER ARM FOR SCOFFLAWS
description: For years a sign at the Brodie Auto Rental Office in Harvard Square has been telling customers they must paying all parking tickets, but Brodie still gets more than 40 notices of unpaid tickets a week.

title: JAPAN'S AUTO QUOTAS DON'T SOOTHE CRITICS
description: Japan extended auto export quotas, in a move that is considered by most analysts to be politically, rather than economically motivated. Given the protectionist sentiment in Congress and the widening trade gap, Japanese officials apparently felt that extending the quotas would indicate good intentions, at some cost to Japanese auto makers who seek more sales in the United States. But Congressional leaders and the Administration say that Japan should open its markets to American products rather than restrict sales here.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO PREVENT STORM DAMAGE
description: WHEN Hurricane Gloria hit our region last fall, the damage that proved most costly and that resulted in the greatest inconvenience was the loss of electrical power, most of which could be blamed on falling trees and branches. Can anything be done to prevent this from happening again?

title: JUNE WEDDING PLANNED FOR MAUREEN M. AHN
description: A June wedding is planned by Maureen Miran Ahn, a corporate strategic planner at Dow Jones & Company, and Gene Kyum Kim, an assistant vice president in investment banking at Nomura Securities International, both in New York. Dr. and Mrs. Kyung Jin Ahn of Chicago and Munster, Ind., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Young Taek Kim of Los Angeles.

title: EMBRACED BY DEATH
description: GATHERING EVIDENCE A Memoir. By Thomas Bernhard. Translated by David McLintock. 340 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: NANCY GRAY PARKER PLANS TO BE WED TO WILLIAM F. WILSON IN SEPTEMBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Parker of Bedminster, N.J., and Portsmouth, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Gray Parker to William Fisher Wilson, a son of Mrs. Robert P. Wilson of Woburn, Mass., and the late Colonel Wilson, U.S.A. A September wedding is planned.

title: SAKHAROV LETTER PRINTED IN LONDON
description: Details of methods used by the Soviet authorities to break a 1984 hunger strike by Andrei D. Sakharov emerged here today in a letter said to have been written by the dissident Soviet physicist from Gorky, the industrial city to which he has been confined for six years.

title: BETTING ON A BROADWAY DREAM
description: BAM! ZZAAK! WHOOSH! POW! Captain America's gonna star in a Broadway show, and, for a price, you can be one of his behind-the-scenes backers.

title: WYATT BAKER WEDS RODERICK TOWNLEY
description: At the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights yesterday Wyatt Baker, an actress, and Roderick Carl Townley, a staff writer for TV Guide in New York, were married by the Rev. Orlanda R. Brugnola.

title: WHEN DOES THE OCEAN CRY 'UNCLE!'?
description: THE soundness of ocean-dumping policies, many regulators and scientists agree, rests on an as-yet unanswered question: How much contamination can the ocean absorb before it suffers environmental harm?

title: MORNING MEALS, FRESH FROM THE FREEZER
description: ''OMELETS are not made without breaking eggs,''

title: Joseph Heller: The Road Back
description: While treating people with Guillain-Barre syndrome, I have argued with residents, as Mel Brooks did, regarding the indiscriminate use of Valium. One thing is, therefore, obvious - if I ever get that disease, please, I hope Mr. Brooks will handle my case. Perhaps they'll listen to him. M. SATLOW, M.D. Southbury, Conn.

title: Lawyers Score Jail Privatization
description: Proponents contend that private prisons are efficient and economical. But when lawyers get together, as they did last week at the American Bar Association's winter meeting in Baltimore, such practical considerations take a back seat to ''complex constitutional, statutory and contractual issues.''

title: ENROLLMEMT LOW, COLLEGE HOLDS CLASS AT INN
description: The 52 students enrolled at Pace University's new center in Mount Kisco have attended classes this month in three conference rooms at the Ramada Inn here instead.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FELLINI, SINATRA AND BEDTIME STORIES
description: La Strada Starring Anthony Quinn, Giulietta Masina, Richard Basehart; directed by Federico Fellini, 1954 Embassy Home Entertainment 115 minutes. $29.95 ''She looks a little queer, but she eats regularly.''

title: ON FOOT IN OLD AMSTERDAM
description: Amsterdam's town planners endowed the city in its Golden Age with a crescent shape, enclosing the center in a half circle of canals. Today, the principal attractions of the largest city and constitutional capital of the Netherlands are found in this historic area. And the best way to explore it is on foot.

title: DURGIN-PARK
description: To The Editor:

title: Latin American Police Get Some Pointers From Washington
description: Concern about human rights abuses by foreign police forces in the 1970's prompted Congress to prohibit United States training for such organizations. Congress later made some exceptions for programs to combat terrorism, and the Reagan Administration seems intent on making the most of them. ''Our support for democratic development in Latin America must be highlighted by our support to counterterrorism,'' James H. Michel, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, said in November.

title: Rumors Swirl but Mandela Stays Behind Bars
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa may have thought he was speaking purely in the abstract when he offered to consider freeing Nelson Mandela if the Soviet dissidents Anatoly B. Shcharansky and Andrei D. Sakharov were let go together with a South African commando captured in Angola. But last week, when the Soviet Union freed Mr. Shcharansky, the pressure rose for the release of the 67-year-old African National Congress leader, who has been in prison for more than two decades serving a life sentence for sabotage and plotting revolution.

title: SECURITY BLANKETS NEVER REALLY VANISH
description: IF we can think back that far, there was a time when we couldn't visualize life without it. It was usually pink or blue, but sometimes it was a checked pattern or a tartan. It was soft, warm and cuddly, and it enveloped a little body in a cocoonlike embrace. Even when it became threadbare, it was clutched and treasured, and no one could pry it loose. Somebody named it a security blanket, and that was a pretty good description.

title: TOPICS
description: WHEN I look at my children's feet, I am sorely reminded that the investment in their sneakers over the last few years has now exceeded the cost of our house.

title: Ianniello Is Sentenced In Racketeering Trial
description: A reputed Mafia leader, Matthew (Matty the Horse) Ianniello, has been sentenced to six years in prison on a racketeering charge that involved skimming more than $2 million from bars and restaurants.

title: REAGAN IS PUSHING THE WELFARE ISSUE
description: President Reagan today deplored ''misguided welfare programs'' that he said had led to a ''national tragedy'' involving family breakdowns, teen-age illegitimacy and worsening poverty.

title: BROWN AND CORNELL WIN TO SHARE LEAD
description: Jim Turner had a game-high 35 points tonight as Brown held off Columbia for a 97-95 victory and kept its share of the Ivy League lead with Cornell.

title: ONCE-BANNED DOCUMENTARY LOOKS AT A DIVIDED IRELAND
description: ''Northern Ireland: At the Edge of the Union,'' the most controversial documentary made for the British Broadcasting Corporation in years, will be shown Tuesday night at 11 on Channel 13.

title: JEWISH DAY SCHOOL'S SHARING OF SPACE
description: A correction of a statement in the otherwise excellent article on the new Liberal Jewish Day School [ ''Judaica Meets Math at New School,'' Jan. 26 ] :

title: Recent Sales in Westchester and Connecticut
description: Ossining, N.Y. $159,000 Forrest Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 66-year-old frame colonial, *2*eat-in kitchen, renovated interior; taxes $2,775. Somers, N.Y. $145,000 Carpenter Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; *2*den, lake rights; taxes $2,456. Tuckahoe, N.Y. $215,000 83 Haighner Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; *2*eat-in kitchen, playroom with wet bar, deck, dining room; *2*taxes $4,206. Darien, Conn. $240,000 385 West Avenue *2*6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 16-year-old raised ranch; *2*in-law suite, central air-conditioning, half acre; *2*taxes $2,426. Hamden, Conn. $80,000 5 Windsor Road *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; screen porch, *2*large master bedroom; taxes $1,581. Wilton, Conn. $271,500 617 Ridgefield Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; *2*pond view, 3 fireplaces, pool, 2.1 acres; taxes $3,079. OTHER AREAS Budd Lake, N.J. $127,500 8 Wildwood Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old ranch; *2*1 acre, lake view, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $3,001. Harrington Park, N.J. $242,500 596 Lynn Street *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; *2*new roof, vinyl siding, 2-car garage; taxes $3,929. Lake Grove, L.I. $162,000 22 Ashford Drive *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath 16-year-old colonial; *2*finished basement, workshop, portico, deck; taxes $3,300.

title: Bishops in Philippines Challenged by Marcos
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos demanded today that the nation's Roman Catholic bishops prove their allegations that the Philippine presidential election was fraudulent, and he threatened to prosecute some members of the clergy.

title: TOP SOUTH KOREA FIGURE STILL DETAINED
description: The South Korean Government today released four of five opposition leaders they had placed under house arrest. But Kim Dae Jung, the most prominent critic of the Government, remained under house arrest tonight and under the threat of imprisonment.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: TALES FOR THE PERFECT CHILD. By Florence Parry Heide. Illustrated by Victoria Chess. Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $13.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN NEWSLETTERS
description: Each year, a handful of new newsletters appear for travelers who are hungry for more specialized, inside, up-to-date information than guidebooks can normally provide. Some of them last only a few issues and then quietly disappear. Others, however, build devoted followings because of the authority with which they speak - in evaluating restaurants, hotels or shops, perhaps, or in suggesting exclusive vacation hideaways or in helping to find the best cruise bargains or lowest air fares.

title: DOROTHY HARDIN AFFIANCED TO WILLIAM PERRY HOLMES
description: The engagement of Dorothy Ruth Hardin and William Perry Holmes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Holmes of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hardin of Madison, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: 4 YOUNG LAUREATES BASK IN THE LIMELIGHT OF A POETRY TOUR
description: FOR several weeks now, Meg Bishop has been reading her poetry to fellow college students throughout Connecticut.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LAST RESORTS. By Clare Boylan. (Summit, $16.95.) Clare Boylan's gift for stunning prose and unorthodox images is wonderfully evident in her second novel (her first, ''Holy Pictures,'' was highly praised). But she overburdens her central character, Harriet Bell, with more problems than even the strongest character could resolve in this novel. An unenviable sad sack, Harriet is chronically at sea, without the faintest notion of how to fulfill herself. Fittingly, she is vacationing in the Aegean with her three children on the none-too-subtly named isle of Keptos, which has kept her returning every year for a decade with its promise of idyllic stasis. This character without drive knows herself only in terms of her many unsatisfying relationships. Yet her children, noisy slobbering teen-agers, are not the monsters Harriet likens them to, just typical adolescents bumbling through one postpubescent trauma after another. She obsessively schemes to lure Joe Fisher, an unexceptional businessman, away from his wife, but doesn't see that his dalliance with her is a pathetic attempt to absolve himself of guilt about his dead daughter, who resembled Harriet. Even her imaginary childhood companion, the toothy Hawna Maroyle, keeps cropping up to taunt her. Harriet's estrangement from Joe and her children is just the beginning; she no longer recognizes her own vision of paradise, as Greek entrepreneurs set about modernizing Keptos and the neighboring island into tourist resorts. ''Last Resorts,'' although a third-person narrative, is too often told from the murky recesses of Harriet's mind.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BREAD OF EXILE. By Karen Gershon. (Victor Gollancz/David & Charles, $18.95.) ''You are the ones who were saved'' - what should be an affirmation becomes an admonition in this short Bildungsroman, and the words ring in the ears of its Jewish refugee heroine, Inge Stein.

title: WHY DRAMA FLOURISHES SO VIGOROUSLY IN BRITAIN
description: This article has been excerpted from ''Fifth Row Center: A Critic's Year on and Off Broadway, c 1986 by Benedict Nightingale, to be published Feb. 26 by Times Books, a division of Random House Inc. I've spent enough ink berating American dramatists for not quite managing to be capsule reincarnations of Shakespeare and Buchner, Ibsen and Brecht. Maybe it's time to acknowledge the difficulties they face at a time when the traditional center of their theater is so inhospitable to even their less serious efforts, let alone their more challenging ones. Nearly 15 years ago William Goldman complained in his book about Broadway, ''The Season'': ''We have not had a first-rate playwriting debut in almost a quarter of a century, and the wait is getting painful.'' Since he wrote that, the prospect of such a debut has become so slight, so slim that any sane person would give up the wait as hopeless. Indeed, the best may not be seen on Broadway at all. David Mamet's ''American Buffalo'' may have slipped past the sentries, but Sam Shepard, whom many would regard as the first among the first-rate, has yet to have a play produced there.

title: FRANCE SAYS CHAD REPULSED REBEL OFFENSIVE
description: Prime Minister Laurent Fabius said today that renewed attacks by Libyan-supported rebel forces in Chad had been repulsed by Government troops.

title: RECITAL: JAN OPALACH
description: JAN OPALACH'S song recital at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night marked the continuing progress of one of our more intelligent and endowed voices. Mr. Opalach's broad, well-padded bass-baritone embraced Schumann's ''Liederkreis'' (Op. 39) with particular warmth, and it was in this particular style that his verbal talents - the sure, clear pronunciation of German, to be exact - served music best.

title: Q AND A
description: Question: On a visit to Spain we may spend one or two nights in Cordoba, Seville or Granada. What is there of special interest in these cities? -B. S., Elkins Parks, Pa.

title: COUNTY ARRANGING CENTURIES OF RECORDS
description: PHOTOGRAPHS, letters, documents and newspaper clippings need to be organized but instead are stashed away in boxes and drawers, gathering dust. This situation is faced not only by individuals but also by municipalities, historical societies, libraries, businesses and universities.

title: How to Quench New York's Thirst
description: New York City will have to spend hundreds of millions of dollars in the next 10 to 15 years - possibly billions by the year 2030 - on new sources of water, a task force concluded in a report released by City Hall last week. It was the first public acknowledgment by municipal officials that even Draconian conservation measures will not serve to meet a growing demand.

title: N.A.A.C.P. EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR REBUTS HIS CRITICS
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People ended its annual meeting here yesterday with its executive director sounding an upbeat note in contrast to allegations that the organization was losing ground as the nation's most prominent civil rights group.

title: HENRY JAMES, LEE MARVIN AND THE LAW
description: ''WHY would a law professor be interested in a course in literary theory?'' a friend who teaches literature at Harvard University asked me recently. I was auditing her course, so her question was fair enough. The truth is, more and more lawyers these days recognize that law can be read the way one reads literature, and they are using works of literature and the techniques of modern literary theory to explain and analyze their subject. One of the more interesting currents is critical legal studies, whose proponents argue that law, like literature, is the product of - and a vehicle for creating - political and moral values. Drawing on critics of the feminist, structuralist and deconstructionist schools, lawyers engaged in critical legal studies argue for demystification of the law. They assert that the prevailing views of law, and the kind of society these views reflect and perpetuate, are grounded on inconsistent and contestable premises, and they seek to use their analysis of law to change the relationship between their profession and society as a whole.

title: STATUS OF TAYLOR STILL UNDETERMINED
description: Lawrence Taylor has not been seen publicly for a week and his whereabouts remained unclear yesterday. On Friday, the Giants' celebrated linebacker, was reported to have entered a drug-rehabilitation clinic because of cocaine and perhaps alcohol abuse. According to the reports in The New York Daily News, The Dallas Morning News and by Howard Cosell on ABC radio, Taylor entered the clinic, possibly in Texas, last week.

title: DO-IT-YOURSELF BUILDING WITH WOOD JOINTS: FIVE EASY PIECES
description: THERE are literally hundreds of different kinds of wood joints that craftsmen can use when assembling furniture, cabinets and similar projects, but the average do-it-yourselfer will seldom find it necessary to use more than five or six. All can be easily completed with hand tools, but power tools generally make the job faster, easier - and more accurate.

title: ...AS THE COOKIES CRUMBLE
description: RECENTLY I began working at home. I anticipated many changes, among them wearing sweatsuits instead of business suits and saving time, money and stress by not commuting. I did not anticipate becoming a contender, if there were one, for the Housewives' Hall of Fame.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JUGGLERS TO PERFORM The Flying Karamazov Brothers, the juggling troupe with the confusing name, are coming to the Strand Theater in Lakewood Thursday and to Somerset County College in North Branch on March 1.

title: JILL JOHNSON ENGAGED
description: Mrs. Glenn Dawson Johnson of Locust Valley, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter Jill Gretchen Johnson to John Scott Richardson, the son of Charles Richardson of Franklin, N.C., and Joan Richardson of West Chester, Pa.

title: CONQUERING PERSISTENT FEARS
description: IN doing some research recently on the topic of phobias for a speech class I am taking at college, I discovered some facts that served to comfort me. Now, at least, I know I am not alone. There are about 25 million Americans out there as riddled with fear as I. My fear of birds, I learned, is known as ornithophobia. I vividly recall how it started. I was about 4 years old and playing in a neighbor's yard. We were looking at her pet chicken, peeping through the mesh pen, when the chicken bit my finger. I have carried a fear of birds around with me ever since.

title: JAZZ HAND KNICKS FIFTH LOSS IN ROW
description: It was about 10 o'clock last night, two hours before the National Basketball Association trading deadline, that the word came from Scotty Stirling.

title: CHURCHES BECOME BURGLARY TARGET
description: Thieves have broken into scores of churches in New York City and its suburbs in the last several years, taking valuable and sometimes priceless silver objects.

title: L.I.R.R. TRAINS GET POLICE PATROLS
description: WHILE maintaining there has been no rise in crime, the Long Island Rail Road has started regular police patrols on trains for the first time in the commuter line's history.

title: STEIN BACK SCHOOL PRAYER?
description: At a recent weekend retreat, the senior staff at the American Enterprise Institute spent hours debating political issues of the day.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a review Feb. 2 of Jeffrey Potter's ''To a Violent Grave'' misstated the titles of two paintings by Jackson Pollock. The correct titles are ''One'' and ''Lavender Mist.''

title: DARRELL WALTRIP TRIES IT AGAIN George Vecsey
description: BJORN BORG never won the United States Open in tennis, Sam Snead never won the Open in golf and Don Newcombe never won a World Series game for the Brooklyn Dodgers. Darrell Waltrip is hoping he doesn't become the Borg, the Snead, the Newcombe of stock-car racing.

title: MARCY AND JODY BECKER PLANNING THEIR WEDDINGS
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman Becker of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagements of their daughters, Marcy Susan Becker and Jody Lynn Becker, to Michael James Corcoran and Leonard Scott Zohn respectively.

title: RANGERS' LAROUCHE ADDS SCORING HELP
description: It is not always easy to discern what Pierre Larouche does right. He does not check. He plays defense in a cursory way, waving his stick, seeming distracted by the idea of breaking away from the crowd in case the puck should squirt loose his way. One eye is always on the goal and so there is the temptation to describe him as self-centered.

title: HIS BUILDINGS HAVE THE SIMPLICITY OF POETRY
description: The great buildings of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe are often thought of as temples of reason, odes to a pure and rational system of architecture. It was Mies, after all, who sought a universal Modernist style of absolute rigor and austerity, who struggled to boil architecture down to its essences, who disdained frivolity in architecture with more earnestness than anyone since Ralph Adams Cram. If Mies's buildings of glass possess a kind of poetry, the common view goes, it is that of absolute minimalism - the poetry of true simplicity.

title: FAIRFIELD WINS
description: Jeff Gromos led four Fairfield players in double figures with a game-high 19 points today to pace the Stags in a 73-55 victory over Army in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: The Houston Oilers completed the coaching staff for Jerry Glanville by hiring Dick Jamieson, formerly of the St. Louis Cardinals, as offensive coordinator and running back coach. . . . Roy Chipman said he planned to be a vice president for marketing at a cardboard box company in Pittsburgh after his resignation as the basketball coach at Pitt at the end of the season. . . . Lute Olsen of Arizona has been named coach of the United States national basketball team that will play in the world championships July 6-20 in Spain.

title: LENKOWSKY HEARD FROM
description: Leslie Lenkowsky, an assistant director of the United States Information Agency who failed to win Senate confirmation as deputy director two years ago, has been made president of the Institute for Educational Affairs, an organization he helped establish in 1978.

title: DAVID AND GOLAITH BATTLE IT OUT
description: Vanquish the enemy with an army that can put only two pieces in the field? Not likely, but every once in a rare while, a campaign that approximates the David and Goliath tale does succeed.

title: BOSSY SCORES 3 AS ISLANDERS WIN
description: The Islanders, who have now beaten the Devils by a one-goal margin in all three meetings this season, managed to drum up sufficient spirit in the last five minutes of the game tonight to obtain a 6-5 victory at Nassau Coliseum. But to do it, they needed a hero.

title: LESLIE SACKS ENGAGED TO BE MARRIED IN JUNE
description: Announcement has been made by Marjorie Sacks of Rye, N.Y., and Harry P. Sacks of New York of the engagement of their daughter Leslie Anne Sacks to Peter David Baum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner G. Baum of White Plains. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Joseph Heller: The Road Back
description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a devastating disease that needs to be diagnosed quickly, but, unfortunately, not all physicians are able to recognize the symptoms. I hope Joseph Heller's article will increase their awareness.

title: WHAT PRICE FITNESS?
description: ONE RECENT SUNDAY morning I went to my local community center for a ''personal physical fitness review.'' A matched pair of trim, perky, helpful young people took my vital signs and administered simple tests for muscular strength, flexibility and cardiorespiratory endurance. Except for my flexibility, which was below average, everything was normal or fair or average or O.K. No red flags and no gold stars. I was told, in a friendly and positive way, that there was a lot of room for improvement and that more walking, running and swimming, plus aerobic exercises, stretching and racquetball would make me more fit, help me carve off 10 pounds of fat and probably contribute to my overall health. The young people counseled against lifting weights; it would add nothing to my fitness or health. They suggested moderate activity, especially at first, and a medical checkup. They were sensible, supportive and, according to everything I've been reading and hearing, absolutely right. So, now what? This current fitness craze, the biggest in a series that predates the Revolution, has produced more confusing information than can be lifted or leaped over by a well-conditioned young athlete. I am 48 years old and my own sports confessional is a typically sorry story. I make an effort to run or swim at least three times a week, but I travel too often and too irregularly to maintain a pattern. Even when I manage to get into a regular rhythm of exercise, I am not passionate about it.

title: WHO CONTROLS A CO-OP APARTMENT?
description: MICHAEL McVANN has discovered that owning a co-op apartment in Westchester County can be something less than a blessing.

title: TEACHING CHILDREN A SYSTEM OF VALUES
description: Dr. Michael McGill's ''The First Word in Parenting: Listen'' [ Opinion Page, Jan. 5 ] creates a sound basis for parenting but fails to address a most serious issue in child development.

title: EARLY SHEPARD PLAY AT HARTFORD STAGE
description: FINALLY, Connecticut is having its first professional production of a Sam Shepard play, or so the Hartford Stage Company is heralding ''The Tooth of Crime,'' which he wrote in 1972.

title: Headliners; Moving Violations
description: Ignorance of the law is seldom an excuse, except apparently in the House of Representatives.

title: GET READY FOR VIDEOS OF THE CLASSICS
description: Classical music has discovered the video. The Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra has made a six-minute pilot video of ''The March to the Scaffold'' from Hector Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique.'' All of the actors are members of the orchestra, and the leading role of the young artist is played by Enrique Arturo Diemecke, the orchestra's Exxon-Arts Endowment conductor who leads the performance.

title: AUSTRALIA III WINS TITLE
description: Australia III has sent a clear message to the rest of the America's Cup challengers: Don't expect the Australians to be pushovers next year.

title: BETTE SACKS BECOMES BRIDE OF DR. JAMES DAVID ALBERT
description: Bette Ann Sacks, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Sacks of Norfolk, Va., was married last evening to Dr. James David Albert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Albert of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: CONCERT: THE ZAGREB PHILHARMONIC
description: THE Zagreb Philharmonic, under the direction of Pavle Despalj, brought its distinctive blend of warm, heavy elegance to Carnegie Hall Thursday night.

title: TOMBIGBEE WATERWAY USE FALLS SHORT OF FORECASTS
description: For decades Congress hotly debated the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway, a 234-mile-long system of rivers, dams, locks and canals that snakes through the cotton fields and poor rural landscape of eastern Mississippi and western Alabama.

title: NEGOTIATORS IN BEIRUT FAIL TO FIND ACCORD AS FIGHTING SPREADS
description: Moslem and Christian militiamen fought with artillery and rockets today across Beirut's dividing line as the latest attempts to break the country's political deadlock ended in failure.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''All I get from this is that the Japanese have learned to play the U.S. trading relationship like a violin.'' Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, on Japan's extension of auto quotas

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: STARS AT FILM FESTIVAL Enjoyment of a film festival is considerably enhanced when the star of the films is there in person, as will be the case at the Norma Terris Theater in Chester for the next few weeks. At 2 P.M. today Debbie Reynolds will introduce her film ''How the West Was Won.'' At 8 P.M. Friday, 2 and 8 P.M. Saturday and 2 P.M. Feb. 23 it will be Eileen Heckart's turn to comment on ''Butterflies Are Free,'' ''Bus Stop'' and ''The Bad Seed.''

title: LAUGHING OUR WAY TO DEFEAT
description: PROVIDENCE By Geoffrey Wolff. 217 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $16.95.

title: No Headline
description: The Audi Ski Guide #336 pages. The Daily Mail, London. Paperback, $19.95. Is there a skier in the United States who doesn't dream about the Alps? I am sure there is, I just haven't met him, or her, yet. And the happy fact for an increasing number of American skiers is that a strong dollar has, over the last couple of years, turned that dream into reality. While the exchange rate this season isn't quite as favorable as it has been, the lure of skiing in Europe nevertheless remains, just like that irresistible urge to blow half the week's paycheck on a new pair of slalom skis you don't really need.

title: REPLACEMENT FOR LENDL
description: Just hours after Milan Srejber upset Boris Becker at a tournament in Florida, the 6-foot-8-inch Czechoslovak, as expected, replaced his more famous countryman, Ivan Lendl, who is off Czechoslovakia's team for next month's Davis Cup qualifying match against India. Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, had said in a recent interview that he would would not play in the Davis Cup for his country this year.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''FOR MANY years, people have been trying to get me to do a book about myself, or to let somebody else do one about me, and up to that afternoon I had always put them off.''

title: A PREMIERE FOR CHICK COREA
description: ''MUSIC must be a part of the great organic flow,'' wrote Charles Ives; ''onward and always upward, or else it becomes soft in spirit and dies.'' It was also Ives who wisely noted that ''no genius ever stopped creating because he knew he never could make a million dollars.'' These thoughts were recalled by the gratifyingly large number of contemporary works on the music schedule over the next couple of weeks.

title: Seeking Clues To Suicides
description: Suicide is the second leading cause of death among teen-agers, but is it a disease? If so, can it be prevented?

title: NOEL PICK TO WED MARY L. D'AMICO
description: Mary Lisbeth D'Amico and Noel Christopher Pick, graduates of Bucknell University, class of '83, plan to be married April 26, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. D'Amico of Princeton, N.J., have announced.

title: Did Tenant Leader Extort Bribes?
description: Harold Pinkney used to head a council that represented the 500,000 tenants in projects operated by the New York City Housing Authority. And in that capacity, Federal prosecutors charged last week, Mr. Pinkney was far busier taking care of his own business than that of the people he was supposed to represent.

title: THE MEL LEWIS ORCHESTRA CELEBRATES ITS 20-YEAR VILLAGE VANGUARD GIG
description: THE 17-piece Mel Lewis Jazz Orchestra sets a new long-run record every Monday night at the Village Vanguard. It has been playing there on Monday nights since it made its debut in 1966 and, starting tomorrow, it will celebrate 20 years of Monday night performances and its 20th anniversary as a group by starting an eight-day engagement at the jazz club at 178 Seventh Avenue South, near 11th Street.

title: BANGKOK
description: Bangkok is a challenge, particularly now in the hot, dry months that precede the cooling summer monsoons. Many a visitor who arrives expecting to find an old, exotic Asian city is soon disappointed by a nondescript town where the traffic seems long ago to have gone out of control. Perspiring under the tropical sun or choking on fumes, the visitor flees indoors, which is not such a bad idea.

title: A TRIBUTE TO A TIRELES FIGHTER FOR HUMAN RIGHTS
description: WHEN the National Urban League celebrated its 75th anniversary in Washington last summer, the spotlight shone on the center of the dais, where William M. Ashby sat. It was a special moment, but Mr. Ashby has always had a glow about him.

title: HANOI REPORTED TO SAY G.I.'S MAY BE THERE
description: A group of American members of Congress said today that Vietnamese officials had acknowledged for the first time that missing Americans might be living inside Vietnam, in remote areas not under full Government control.

title: 32-YEAR TRADITION IN PHILADELPHIA IS FACING CHANGE
description: HE Big Five faces fundamental changes after three decades as college basketball's biggest and best intracity rivalry.

title: SALVADOR ARMY SEES GAINS IN NEW DRIVE
description: Salvadoran Army commanders said today that they were continuing what appears to be the most sustained Government drive against a strategically vital rebel base just outside the capital on Guazapa Volcano.

title: PITCHERS TOPS ON SHOPPING LIST
description: One ingredient of the Kansas City Royals' World Series championship last fall stood out above the rest: their pitching. Except for George Brett, the Royals had no legitimate offensive threat, so if there ever was any question, the Royals re-established the idea that pitching can carry a team.

title: MERKIN NAMES DIRECTOR
description: Andrew Berger, the music director of WNYC-FM, has been named director of the Merkin Concert Hall at Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. Mr. Berger will begin his new job on Tuesday. He replaces Lydia Kontos, who was named executive director of the Hebrew Arts School, which oversees the concert hall's operation.

title: WHAT'S NEW WITH BREAKFAST
description: ON a typical day, 89 percent of Americans eat breakfast. At least, that is the figure that keeps turning up in surveys run by M.R.C.A. Information Services, which regularly measures consumer trends for manufacturers and marketers of grocery products.

title: SYRACUSE 76, PROVIDENCE 75
description: Dwayne Washington scored 27 points, including four free throws in the final minute of play, as Syracuse held off a surprisingly strong challenge by Providence.

title: WATSON LEADS BY 1 IN HAWAIIAN GOLF
description: Tom Watson scored a 66 despite gusty winds and moved into the lead after the third round today in the $500,000 Hawaiian Open golf tournament.

title: LYNN SIMMONS ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Lynn Carol Simmons and Joseph Francis Nemia, graduates of Pace University, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Linwood A. Simmons of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Nemia of Walden, N.Y., is an assistant vice president of the Bank of New York Commercial Corporation in Manhattan. Miss Simmons is an accountant for the Merrill Lynch Mortgage Corporation in Stamford, Conn.

title: WHEELING AND DEALING OVER COFFEE
description: FOR many years, business was conducted over the proverbial three-martini lunch. America's movers and shakers jockeyed for table position in the finest restaurants as the ''power lunch'' became a symbol of prestige and position.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A CAST OF HAWKS: A Rowdy Tale of Greed, Violence, Scandal, and Corruption in the Early Days of San Francisco. By Milton S. Gould. (Copley Books, P.O. Box 957, La Jolla, Calif. 92038, $24.50.) Milton S. Gould, a New York attorney, has turned his attention to the soap-operatic history of in re Neagle, a landmark case in constitutional law. The 1890 case first interested Mr. Gould when, as a law student in 1932, he discovered an illicit love affair at its heart. His half-century obsession with this episode in California history culminates in ''A Cast of Hawks,'' a peppy tale of greed, politics, lust and murder. In this handsome, illustrated volume, Mr. Gould vividly describes San Francisco after the gold rush, when unscrupulous judges, crooked senators and mercenary prostitutes fought private wars with public consequences. Mr. Gould's narrative is most valuable when it points out the scars personal indiscretions can leave on the national complexion. Sarah Hill, a prostitute, had claimed to be secretly married to William Sharon, a goatish United States Senator. Charging him with desertion, she sued for ''divorce.'' The case eventually reached Federal court. When the court found against Hill, her lawyer - a former California Supreme Court justice whom she had married during the proceedings - tried to stab the judge and was later killed by David Neagle, a Federal marshal who was acting as the judge's bodyguard. In re Neagle affirmed that the marshal was not answerable to the State of California because he was acting on the authority of the Government. Mr. Gould lays out the story with a lawyerly passion for facts.

title: TAX DISPARITIES TROUBLING HOMEOWNERS
description: THE average Westchester condominium or cooperative apartment owner pays about 30 percent less in property taxes than the owner of a house of equivalent value, according to those who like the system and those who do not.

title: POLICE PROMISE TO KEEP SUBWAY PATROL LEVEL
description: The New York City Police Department has promised to keep at least 1,100 officers, the present level, patrolling the subways for the next four years if it is allowed to absorb the transit police force.

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY NANCY AMEEN
description: Dr. and Mrs. Lane Ameen of New Haven and Menemsha, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Adele Ameen, to Alan George Hoden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Hoden of Warren, Pa.

title: HOW VICTIMS PLAY A PART IN THE PAROLE PROCESS
description: FOR MORE than two centuries, American criminal law has jealously guarded the rights of a person accused of a crime. It has proceeded from the basic tenet that a defendant is innocent until proved guilty, thus placing the burden of proof of guilt on the state.

title: Joseph Heller: The Road Back
description: Joseph Heller pays tribute to his famous friends who took time from their busy lives to visit and encourage him in his recovery from Guillain-Barre syndrome (''The Road Back,'' Jan. 12). He is touched by their response to his everyday needs.

title: Slow Snow Motion
description: February has seen New York City repeatedly blanketed with clean snow - and then half-blanketed with dirty ice. For days, street after street has been constricted by the rock-like crusts, embedding cars and impeding foot traffic.

title: FLAMBOYANCE AND VIRTUOSITY ARE POGORELICH'S TRADEMARKS
description: To his waiting audience, Ivo Pogorelich appears slowly, leaning his tall body toward the piano as if blown by a wind from the wings. The eyes raise to his audience, pained, stoic but curiously sharp. What are we to make of this enigmatic gaze? Is it a summoning of great effort about to be made in the name of art, or could it be that Ivo Pogorelich is counting the house?

title: WINTER PRUNING WILL TRANSFORM OLD MOUTAIN LAUREL
description: One of the finest shrubs which can be grown in most temperate regions is the mountain laurel (Kalmia latifolia). A relative of rhododendrons, azaleas and blueberries, it is endowed with a multiplicity of attributes which make it a prime landscape feature. A broadleaved evergreen, it is hardy and gives a grand floral show in mid-June in the Northeast.

title: Israelis Shoot Man in Gaza
description: Israeli soldiers in the occupied Gaza Strip shot and killed a Gaza resident today when he fled after being detained for questioning, a military spokesman said. The spokesman said that the dead man was one of two men stopped by a patrol this morning in the center of the city of Gaza, and that the second escaped unhurt.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CYCLOPS. By Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Devotees of Clive Cussler's previous thrillers, such as ''Deep Six'' and ''Raise the Titanic!'', will extract the expected pleasures from this latest outing by the ultracapable Government agent Dirk Pitt.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A TESTATMENT OF HOPE: The Essential Writings of Martin Luther King, Jr. Edited by James Melvin Washington. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) Here, in his own words, are the philosophy and strategy of nonviolent protest that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. taught during America's civil rights struggle.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE VIGIL. By Clay Reynolds. (Marek/St. Martins, $13.95.) This engrossing first novel revolves around a single incident: the mysterious disappearance of an 18-year-old girl traveling with her mother through a small Texas town.

title: A Federal Judge Is Found Guilty
description: Sitting at the defense table instead of on the bench, District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. was found guilty of two counts of perjury in a Hattiesburg, Miss., courtroom last weekend, thus becoming the second sitting Federal judge to be convicted of a crime.

title: FATAL MARRIAGE
