description: DAVID and Ruth Lucas were described in Paducah, Ky., as ''perfectly happy'' at the outset of their wedding day, but before the day was out, the 23-year-old Mr. Lucas was dead and his wife, Ruth, 28, was accused of shooting him after an argument.

title: CHERYL SCHUCHMAN TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Schuchman of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cheryl Schuchman to Gary Newman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Newman of Bayside, Queens. The future bride graduated from the State University of New York at Albany and is a candidate for a master's degree in special education and reading at Hofstra University. Mr. Newman, an architect in New York, received a Bachelor of Architecture degree from the New York Institute of Technology.

title: A CONCERTO PREMIERE OF COLLABORATION
description: TWO years ago, three men made a pact in front of 120 witnesses. The composer David Diamond, the flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal, and the conductor of the New Haven Symphony, Murry Sidlin, agreed during a panel discussion in New Haven to reunite to perform the world premiere of a flute concerto Mr. Diamond was going to write for Mr. Rampal.

title: Melk
description: To the Editor: On my first visit to Melk's gorgeous explosion of light and gold (Travel, Jan. 12), my most vivid memory was of the beauty of the library; the thousands of leather-bound and gold-tooled volumes glowed in the afternoon sunlight.

title: The Bright Side Of 50
description: For most of my life, I have been an outcast, tottering on the fringes of various groups, but never actually belonging (''The Bright Side of 50,'' by Kenneth H. Brown, About Men, Jan. 12). Now, after reading Kenneth Brown's article, I realize that I finally do belong - to the group of guys over 50 who are living with ''dashed dreams and unrealized ambitions.''

title: Race Violence Protested At Rally in Philadelphia
description: Some 3,500 people, chanting and waving banners, rallied in front of City Hall today and marched through downtown in a protest against racial violence from ''Cleveland to South Africa.''

title: Music
description: New music is all over town on Sunday, and a dedicated listener, through careful calculation, can hear at least three premieres.

title: HELP GIVEN DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: DATA compiled last week by the state's Department of Health show that about half the people evaluated in a new state-sponsored program for drunken drivers were referred fortreatment for serious problems with alcohol.

title: PACERS 105, CAVALIERS 99
description: Herb Williams scored 24 points and pulled down 11 rebounds to lead Indiana.

title: IT'S FUN AND IT'S NOT VIOLENT
description: Coming on the heels of triumph for NBC's ''Cosby Show,'' all about a middle-aged father imaginatively disciplining his bright brood of children, the steadily building success of ''Murder, She Wrote'' on CBS signals an intriguing shift in the tastes of the American television audience. Here, even as such glittery nighttime soaps as ''Dynasty'' and its spinoff ''The Colbys'' flounder in the ratings this season, is a weekly format about an amateur sleuth, a widow being played on a medium that shamelessly extols youth by an actress who has just turned 60. Of course, that actress is Angela Lansbury, award-winning survivor of a first-class career on stage and film. It could be argued that ''Murder, She Wrote'' simply illustrates that talent will out.

title:
INVESTING;
GIVING YOUR I.R.A. TO A MONEY MANAGER
description: IN the 1970's, when cash was surging into corporate pension funds, some investment managers would not touch any account of less than $10 million, and concentrated on the giant funds such as those of Xerox and International Business Machines. Even in recent years, many money managers have looked askance at small investors, reserving their advice - and their fees - for institutions or rich individuals. Mario Gabelli's firm, Gamco Investors, for instance, maintained a strict minimum account of $250,000.

title: 100 Injured in India In Moslem-Hindu Fights
description: At least 100 people were injured today as Moslem-Hindu violence spread to India's northernmost state, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: WOODARDS ADD A SPECIAL SPIRIT TO GLOBETROTTERS
description: THERE were squeals of delight - actual squeals - from the kids in the crowd, a full house of about 11,000, nearly evenly divided between children and parents. This was last Thursday in the Stabler Arena on the Lehigh University campus in Bethlehem, Pa., and the crowd had come on this nippy night and across the snow-covered hills to see the Harlem Globetrotters, a team that kids and parents similar to this group have been witnessing for 60 years, from Hinckley, Ill., to Hong Kong, from Bean Town to Berlin, from a handful in a barn in their early days to 75,000 in a huge outdoor arena, to an audience of one, Pope Pius XII in 1952 at the Vatican.

title: SHUTTLE PANEL SUGGESTS DECISION TO LAUNCH CRAFT WAS 'FLAWED'
description: The chairman of a Presidential panel investigating the space shuttle disaster said today that the process by which the decision was made to launch the craft ''may have been flawed.''

title: The Total Gene Screen
description: Anyone afflicted with an occupational disease surely wonders ''Why me?'' However, there is simply no good evidence yet that genetic susceptibility is the answer in most cases, as Morton Hunt claims. A more widely held view about the origins of industrial cancers, for example, is that exposure causes mutations in the DNA of all, or most, workers, and that these mutations sometimes land - at random - in a cancer-causing gene.

title: COWBOYS, PLAYBOYS AND OTHER SPIES
description: HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE The Making of the British Intelligence Community. By Christopher Andrew. Illustrated. 619 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $25.

title: THE DOUBLE CARRIES A VARIETY OF MESSAGES
description: Once upon a time life was simple. Doubles were either for take-out or for penalties, and that was that. But the late Theodore Lightner began a trend toward mystery doubles. If out of a clear blue sky you doubled a contract that your opponents clearly expected to make, you must be attempting to suggest a lead to partner.

title: Bitter Memories and Hopeful Signs on the Way Out
description: A few days after he landed in Israel last week, Anatoly B. Shcharansky, speaking in English, told of his imprisonment and his release at a news conference in Jerusalem. Excerpts follow:

title: ALL THE CZAR'S MEN
description: CIVIL-MILITARY CONFLICT IN IMPERIAL RUSSIA #1881-1914. By William C. Fuller Jr. Illustrations. Tables. 295 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $39.50. MUTINY AMID REPRESSION Russian Soldiers in the Revolution of 1905-1906. By John Bushnell. Tables. 334 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $24.50.

title: Are Mothers Losers?
description: To the Editor:

title: TOWNS MEET ON ISSUE OF I.B.M. TRAFFIC
description: THE supervisors of Bedford, Lewisboro, North Salem and Somers met with county planners last week in a new effort to discuss regional solutions for the commuter traffic jams expected to accompany the International Business Machines office project under construction in Somers.

title: TROPICAL EASE
description: MEN ARE INCREASINGLY DISCOVERING that tropical-weight suits fulfill their business-dress needs throughout the year. What was once considered merely appropriate for warm or transitional climates is rapidly becoming the mainstay of the male wardrobe.

title: NICO, IT'S OVER AT LAST
description: DEAR NICO, it's over. Ending our relationship after 12 years is one of the most difficult things I've ever done, but leave you I must.

title: MY SON, THE RASTAFARIAN
description: UNTIL I WAS A JUDGE AT THE BERLIN FILM FESTIVAL two years ago, I firmly believed that the best thing that could ever happen to anyone was to be a judge at a film festival. I had already done it -at Cannes, at San Sebastian, at the Semana de Cine en Color in Barcelona - and each time I left certain that earthly happiness could be achieved. I love movies, and seeing four or five films a day, even if they're bad, is something I enjoy. (This isn't true for everyone. At Cannes, in 1976, one of my fellow judges, the Lebanese poet Georges Schehade, confessed that this cinematic overindulgence gave him nightmares. He normally went to the movies at most once or twice a year.) The best hotels, the best seats, invitations to all the press conferences, shows, parties, and the chance to contemplate stars and starlets in monokinis or au naturel: what more could one want in life?

title: JAN KEMP'S AGONY IN BEATING A SYSTEM
description: Jan Kemp feels like the most popular person in the world. Somebody is always calling. Newspapers, magazines, even the Phil Donohue show wants her. She is coming to New York to talk about a book and then going to Hollywood to talk about a movie. Strangers offer to help her invest those sacks of money she no doubt has in her basement.

title: Philadelphia Leads the Way in Parental Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Again, Tainted Tylenol And a Tragedy
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation assigned its highest priority last week to the cyanide-stuffed Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules that killed a Westchester County woman, 23-year-old Diane Elsroth, and were found in another bottle of the painkiller also bought in the county. Five capsules in each bottle contained potassium cyanide, similar to the substance found in the Tylenol capsules that took the lives of seven people in Chicago and four suburbs in 1982, but not identical.

title: A CHAIN OF RELATIONSHIPS FULIFILLS THE MEANING OF LIFE
description: SOMETIMES people ask, ''What's the meaning in life, or for what purpose do we carry on?'' From time to time a void sets in for some, and life seems pointless because of personal, financial or world troubles. I am reminded of Ishmael in Herman Melville's novel, ''Moby-Dick.'' Ishmael takes to the sea as a way of ''driving off'' his ''spleen,'' and the ''damp drizzly November in'' his ''soul.'' At sea, Ishmael finds relief and especially, at last, a meaning in life on his voyage aboard the Pequod. That purposeful feeling he discovers in his relations with his fellow men, his ship community, and most importantly in his involvement with Queequeg whose coffin literally saves his life.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FELLINI, SINATRA AND BEDTIME STORIES
description: U2: The Unforgettable Fire Collection With U2, plus Brian Eno and Daniel Lanois MusicVision 60 minutes. $29.95 With five video clips based on the album ''The Unforgettable Fire,'' plus a casual documentary on the making of the album, this cassette is primarily for the Irish rock band's most dedicated fans.

title: PRESIDENT FAULTS MARCOS FOR FRAUD BUT ANNOUNCES NO U.S. RESPONSE
description: President Reagan, in a shift of emphasis, today directly blamed President Ferdinand E. Marcos's party for widespread fraud and violence in the recent Philippine presidential election.

title: MISS JUSTICE IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Cecelia Chapman Justice of McLean, Va., of the engagement of her daughter Cecelia Chapman Justice, to Serge Obolensky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Obolensky of New York. A fall wedding is planned.

title: LAWYERS LECTURE IN SCHOOL PROGRAM
description: ''I'D like to just get an indication from you - how many of you feel, if someone was convicted of a murder, that the death penalty would be a proper penalty? And how many would be opposed? And how many would be undecided?''

title: IN PURSUIT OF THE PERFECT GOLF BALL
description: WHOOSH. A golf ball rockets off the tee in a perfect trajectory and then plunks down, skitters a bit, and comes to a stop 247 yards away, slightly down the right side of the 9th hole of the Kittansett Country Club in Marion, Mass.

title: NETS' SLUMP CONTINUES WITH 112-94 LOSS
description: The past week has not been the best of times for Micheal Ray Richardson and the Nets, and their troubles continued here tonight.

title: More Mideast Trouble
description: Trouble is mounting again in the Persian Gulf and the Middle East. The Iranian offensive has caught Iraq off balance. Teheran is probably prudent enough not to push its forces into nearby Kuwait, a move that would provoke a dangerous spread of the war.

title: Q & A: John S. Dyson on Utilities; Where to Send Long Island's Electric Bill
description: LONG DELAYED and much contested, the Shoreham nuclear power plant reached a milestone last week. The Long Island Lighting Company, which owns the facility, conducted a mock emergency drill. Using Lilco employees instead of Suffolk County and state workers - the county and state refused to participate - the company tried to show that it could organize an evacuation of the communities around Shoreham. Federal officials will now evaluate how well the utility managed the exercise, in which no civilians were evacuated. Approval of an emergency plan is one of the final hurdles before Shoreham can win an operating license, but it is by no means the last act. Many important questions remain, and Clifford D. May, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, discussed some of them last week with John S. Dyson, former head of the New York Power Authority who is now chairman of Wakefield National Inc., a manufacturing concern. Excerpts follow. Question. Some

title: GILBERT UPSET BY TULASNE, 7-5, 6-2
description: Brad Gilbert, one of the hottest players on the pro tennis circuit, was upset, 7-5, 6-2, today by Thierry Tulasne of France in the third round of the Lipton International Players Championships.

title: JEWISH DAY SCHOOL'S SHARING OF SPACE
description: I was interested in the article about the Liberal Jewish Day School. It appears that the school is meeting a specific need on Long Island, and more exactly in Nassau and Queens.

title: Frites
description: To the Editor: Peter Maass's article, ''In Belgium, Frites Are a Salty Tradition,'' (Travel, Jan. 26) brought back mouthwatering memories of frites with globs of mayonnaise.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Feb. 16, 1986 Fiction

title: MARCOS'S VICTORY MAY BE COSTLY FOR HIS COUNTRY
description: THE election is over, a winner has been declared.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PENICILLIN: Meeting the Challenge. By Gladys L. Hobby. (Yale University, $32.50.) In 1928, according to the traditional tale, a strange mold spore drifted through the open window of a London hospital laboratory, landed in a culture dish containing staphylococcus microorganisms, grew there and killed them. Dr. (later Sir) Alexander Fleming, a bacteriologist, knew he had happened on something important.

title: SHUTTLE DATA ARE NOW REVEALING THE HIDDEN CLUES TO DISASTER
description: Computer and photographic data made public over the last two days have cleared up one of the mysteries that lasted for days after the space shuttle Challenger exploded: why there was apparently no warning in the 73 seconds before the mission's fiery end.

title: GEORGE ST. BOOKS A HIGHLY PRAISED FILM
description: WHAT is in the planning stages for the George Street Playhouse is considerably more interesting than what is actually happening on stage, where ''Greater Tuna'' began performances on Feb. 5 and runs through March 2.

title: IN THEATER OF PAIN, JERSEY ACTING COMPANY TEACHES DOCTORS
description: When Margaret McGovern went back to school to study acting in 1974, she relied on trade publications such as Backstage to keep her informed of opportunities in her field. She had never heard of a book called ''Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorder,'' let alone read it.

title: SUSAN GEOGHEGAN WED TO C. E. HENSHALL 4TH
description: At Grace United Methodist Church in Wilmington, Del., yesterday Susan Geoghegan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Geoghegan of Wilmington, was married to Charles E. Henshall 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henshall 3d of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Edwin C. Thomas performed the ceremony.

title: ANNE FOMON PLANS TO WED
description: The engagement of Anne Quaintance Fomon to John Samuel Armstrong 4th has been announced by Marilyn Quaintance Fomon of Los Angeles and Robert Michael Fomon of New York and Southampton, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Armstrong 3d of Scottsdale, Ariz., and La Jolla, Calif.

title: MISTRESS TESTIFIES AT BROKER'S MURDER TRIAL IN JERSEY
description: The former mistress of a prominent Toms River insurance broker testified this week that he was heavily in debt, that he had told her the insurance on his wife would cover the debt if he could ''get rid of her'' and that he had asked her whom he could get to kill her.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Feb. 16, 1986 Fiction

title: SHOULD THEATER BE SUBSIDIZED? A RINGING 'YES' VOTE
description: Theater is one of the main reasons s why people come to Britain - 1985 was the country's best year for tourism yet - but as hundreds of thousands of visitors from abroad packed our theaters, they might have been surprised to learn that there is a serious crisis in our performing arts. It is one that can now be expected to worsen, and which will inevitably weaken one of Britain's few remaining international success stories. For step by step the Thatcher government has been changing the pattern of subsidy for the performing arts, and thereby threatening our whole artistic endeavor.

title: SUSAN S. SMIRNOFF ENGAGED TO DR. KIRK J. ZACHARY
description: Mrs. Nathan B. Smirnoff of Fairfield, Conn., and New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Sandford Smirnoff, to Dr. Kirk Jonathon Zachary, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan T. Zachary of Brooklyn and Milford, Pa. The wedding is planned for April 3.

title: STRAINS IN SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE
description: THE bipartisan honeymoon in the Suffolk County Legislature is showing some strains - at least partly because of a personality conflict among Democrats.

title: PRIVATIZATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Withdraws in Trial of 8 Arrested at March He Joined
description: The judge in the trial of eight anti-abortion demonstrators arrested at a protest outside the Supreme Court has withdrawn from the case because he participated briefly in the same march.

title: DUVALIER REJECTS ASYLUM IN LIBERIA
description: The ousted Haitian President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, today rejected an offer of asylum by Liberia and said he wanted to remain in France.

title: Boston Beans For Circulation
description: Dreaming up a circulation-promoting giveaway may not come naturally to The Boston Globe, the more genteel of the city's two major dailies. Games like Wingo! or Zingo! are out of the question, although a case could perhaps be made for By Jingo.

title: The Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: LAURIE G. GREAVES BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Laurie Gail Greaves, a vice president in the private banking division of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, to Chase Wright Landreth, a vice president in Morgan Guaranty's corporate banking division, took place yesterday at the Brookville (L.I.) Reformed Church. The Rev. Allan B. Ramirez performed the ceremony.

title: SHOREHAM DRILL GETS POSITIVE INITIAL APPRAISAL
description: Federal officials issued a generally positive appraisal today of the Long Island Lighting Company's emergency-response drill at the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station on Thursday.

title: FLORIO HOLDS A KEY TO CONRAIL'S FUTURE
description: THE Norfolk Southern Corporation may have won approval of the United States Senate in its effort to acquire Conrail, the Government-controlled, all-freight rail carrier, but skepticism over the sell-off plan still remains in the House.

title: ILLICIT WEEKLY HAS SURVIVED POLISH RAIDS
description: An illicit Solidarity weekly, founded in 1982, has become an influential source of noncensored information in Poland.

title: CARL REICHARDT'S CALIFORNIA PLAYPEN
description: WHEN Carl E. Reichardt was named president of the Wells Fargo Bank in 1978, few in the banking community knew who he was. In stark contrast to Richard Cooley, the Wells Fargo & Company chairman who was widely known for having made Wells Fargo into an aggressive international bank, Mr. Reichardt often walked into his own bank's branches, introduced himself by name - and still was greeted with a blank stare.

title: CANADA'S BELOVED 'ANNE OF GREEN GABLES' CROSSES THE BORDER
description: ''My life is a perfect graveyard of buried hopes,'' wails the redheaded heroine of that Victorian children's classic ''Anne of Green Gables,'' and it is hard at first to argue with her. A scrawny 13-year-old, all carrot-colored pigtails and outrageous chatter, Anne seems fated to go nowhere but back to the orphanage. Her new family, after all, ordered a boy and she was delivered by mistake. But by turning adversity to advantage with lots of spunk, ''Anne of Green Gables'' has enchanted four generations of children and their elders since the world's most widely read Canadian novel was first published in Boston in 1908.

title: THE 'VIRTUOSO' TROYANOVSKY: A U.N. FINALE
description: Diplomats here often tell the story about a Security Council meeting six years ago when Maoists disguised as photographers suddenly doused the Soviet chief delegate, Oleg A. Troyanovsky, with red paint.

title: Ending Random Soviet Access
description: When the Government disclosed this month that it would restrict the access of Soviet-bloc scholars to supercomputers in the United States, some people were surprised that such rules did not already exist. After all, the powerful computers can design weapons, break codes and solve tough problems in nuclear physics and aerodynamics.

title: Unionists Join at Austin To Back Meatpackers
description: Union members from around the country gathered here today for a rally to back meatpackers who have been replaced in the six-month strike against Geo. A. Hormel & Company.

title: SUZANNE MOORE IS WED TO JEFF MARTIN
description: Suzanne Moore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Moore of Cumberland, R.I., and Jeff Summerlin Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Martin of Houston, were married yesterday. The ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan was performed by Max Iverson Summerlin, the bridegroom's grandfather, who is on the board of deacons of the Church of Christ.

title: Intelligence Colonel Convicted
description: An Army intelligence officer has been convicted of theft and two counts of filing false claims against the Government but was acquitted on two counts of making false claims.

title: U.S. SAID TO HAVE TAPES OF A DRUG AGENT'S TORTURE
description: The United States authorities have obtained tape recordings of the torture of an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration and believe that a high official of the Mexican national police may have participated in the agent's torture and murder, a senior Justice Department official said yesterday.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SEPIA TONES: Seven Short Stories. By Anne Attura Paolucci. (Rimu Publishing/Griffon House, Box 81, Whitestone, N.Y. 11357. Paper, $10.) If more Italian-American writers do not speak up soon, much of their experience in the 20th century will go unrecorded.

title: MEXICAN OFFICIAL SEES HARM IN U.S. BILL ON ALIENS
description: With Congress considering stringent new measures to stem immigration, a Mexican Senator is warning that the measure would only worsen their nation's grave economic crisis.

title: WHY A BASEBALL FAN'S WINTER IS SO LONG
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW LINKS TO SYRIANS FOUND IN SUICIDE TERROR BOMBINGS
description: Suicide terrorist bombings in Lebanon, once believed to be the work of pro-Iranian fanatics, have in the last year become directly linked to pro-Syrian secular groups, according to evidence collected by the Israeli Army, counterterrorism experts and residents of southern Lebanon.

title: TENANTS' INCOME VS. RENT
description: MOST tenants in New York City's rent-regulated apartments pay relatively low rent, a city housing survey has found, for the median monthly payment was $330. But the burden falls disproportionately on the poor.

title: SIGN'S '?' ON GOVERNOR ANSWERED, MASSACHUSETS G.O.P. SEEKS END TO SLIDE
description: Nicholas M. Nikitas used to carry a sign to campaign events that read ''? for Governor, Nikitas for Lieutenant Governor.''

title: REPUBLICANS AVOID SCANDAL ISSUE IN QUEENS SPECIAL ELECTION
description: A special election in Queens on Tuesday for a State Assembly seat may provide the first test of voter sentiment on allegations of corruption involving top Democrats in the borough.

title: Recent Sales in New Jersey
description: Budd Lake $127,500 8 Wildwood Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old ranch; *2*1 acre, lake view, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $3,001. Harrington Park $242,500 596 Lynn Street *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; *2*new roof, 2-car garage; taxes $3,929. Highlands $226,000 16 Portland Road *2*6-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old colonial; *2*family room, patio, finished basement; taxes $3,715. Pompton Lakes $145,900 911 Hamburg Turnpike *2*2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new town-house condominium; *2*foyer skylight, deck, $50 monthly charges; taxes to be assesed. South Orange $135,000 42 South Ridgewood Road *2*5-bedroom, 1-bath, 1839 colonial; library, *2*open porch, detached garage; taxes $1,989. OTHER AREAS Hamden, Conn. $80,000 5 Windsor Road *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2*screen porch, large master bedroom;, taxes $1,581. Somers, N.Y. $145,000 Carpenter Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; *2*eat-in kitchen, den, lake rights; taxes $2,456. Lake Grove, L.I. $162,000 22 Ashford Drive *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath 16-year-old colonial; *2*finished basement, workshop, portico, deck; taxes $3,300.

title: WHERE PASTA AND PRICE ARE RIGHT
description: EVER so slowly, the gradual sophistication of northern Italian menus on the Island is becoming evident. Osteria La Favorita in Glen Cove, which opened a few months ago, is one example of this trend.

title: The Mafia Goes On Trial in Sicily
description: The general in charge of Sicilian law-enforcement and at least a dozen officials investigating the Mafia had been killed. So there were 2,000 policemen guarding the grounds when the trial of 473 defendants accused of Mafia-related crimes opened last week in a new $18 million concrete courtroom inside a Palermo prison compound.

title: THE CASE FOR BUILDING MORE I.B.M.'S
description: DURING the past month or so we have seen some remarkable events in business. A merger of B.F. Goodrich and Uniroyal, the third- and fourth-largest tire manufacturers, elicited cheers from Goodyear, the largest. Perhaps more surprising, neither the Department of Justice nor the Federal Trade Commission were expected to object. More recently, Northwest Airlines absorbed Republic. Again, ho hum.

title: STAGE: MILLER'S 'CRUCIBLE' AT TRINITY REPERTORY
description: There will always be a debate about which dramatic approach has the greater artistic and political validity - the dramatization of an immediate historical episode or its metaphorical representation through a screen of symbolism. One thing is evident: ''The Crucible,'' in which Arthur Miller articulated his outrage at McCarthyism by investigating the Salem witch hunt of the 17th century, scores on several dramatic counts.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Feb. 2 about China's hiring of Elliot L. Richardson to study its commercial relations with the United States misstated his former diplomatic role. He was United States delegate to the Law of the Sea Conference, not United Nations representative.

title:
ART;
'INTERNATIONAL PRINTS': 103 ON VIEW IN NEW CANAAN
description: ALTHOUGH it is not exactly the four corners of the globe, the statistic is impressive enough: 733 artists from 27 countries and 45 states plus the District of Columbia entered the competition that resulted in ''International Prints'' at the Silvermine Guild Center in New Canaan through March 2.

title: LAUREN A. DALY IS THE BRIDE OF JEROME B. KEATING
description: Lauren Ann Daly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Daly of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Jerome B. Keating, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence C. Keating of Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Thomas J. Joyce performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title:
MUSIC;
A 1724 'TE DEUM' TO HAVE PREMIERE
description: THE New Brunswick Chamber Orchestra and the Westminster Oratorio Choir, conducted by John Eric Floreen, will perform the modern-world premiere this week of Jan Dismas Zelenka's ''Te Deum a 5'' in D, composed in 1724.

title: PIGGYBACK CONDOS
description: Demolition has begun on a through-block site from 72d to 71st Streets near the East River for a 40-story building that will piggyback 189 luxury condominiums over 103 below-market rental apartments and offices for the Hospital for Special Surgery.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FELLINI, SINATRA AND BEDTIME STORIES
description: Five Stories for the Very Young From the ''Children's Circle'' series CC Studios, Inc. 33 minutes. $29.95 There are five animated adaptations of deservedly popular picture books for young children on this enchanting cassette.

title: 53 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 53 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: JACQUELINE LAKIN, A NURSE, TO WED WILLIAM NORK 3D
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Harold Lakin of Old Tappan, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Jacqueline Ruth Lakin to William George Nork 3d, a son of Lieutenant Colonel Nork Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Nork of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The wedding is planned for September.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WINNING BACK THE SKY: A Tactical Analysis of Terrorism. By David G. Hubbard. (Saybrook, $14.95.) Today's terrorist is neither Superman nor Satan, says David G. Hubbard in ''Winning Back the Sky,'' a 140-page book that is slim on facts but fat on pronouncements. Dr. Hubbard, a Dallas psychiatrist who says he has interviewed hundreds of skyjackers and terrorists over the last 20 years, is a former consultant to the Federal Avia-tion Administration and author of an earlier book on skyjackers. Dr. Hubbard writes that the first skyjackers were usually personal failures who wanted to stage a dramatic act but were not necessarily great planners.

title: OPERA: RARE DOUBLE BILL FROM WEILL AND BRECHT
description: THE best known of Kurt Weill's works are among the most popular of our century. But that hardly means that we know all of his music, and so the Center for Contemporary Opera's Weill double bill Thursday night at the Universalist Church on Central Park West served a real service.

title: The Total Gene Screen
description: It is not without reason that the issue of screening for genetic makeup is to be approached with caution (''The Total Gene Screen,'' by Morton Hunt, Jan. 19). Plato recommended screening people based on their natural abilities; Huxley decried such determinations; Stephen Jay Gould has documented the scientific misapplication of similar principles in ''The Mismeasurement of Man.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
MORRISTOWN IN WASHINGTON'S DAY
description: DURING the winter of 1777, the Continental Army, after successes in Trenton and Princeton, marched northward through Pluckemin to Morristown, a village of about 250 inhabitants, many of whom had emigrated from New England and supported the cause of independence.

title: CASSETTE CAPTURES PINE BARRENS MUSIC
description: SOME years ago, an admirer of Merce Ridgway and the Pinehawkers, a Pine Barrens folk-music group, lamented that its original music had never been recorded and might be lost one day.

title: Joseph Heller: The Road Back
description: Dustin Hoffman's thought of getting a Walkman for Joseph Heller was inspired.

title: CANADA SAYS 3 BOURBON BRANDS POSE HEALTH RISK
description: Three brands of bourbon imported into Canada have been found to contain small amounts of ethyl carbamate, a cancer-causing substance, according to Canadian health officials.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SUGAR TIME Since naturalists suspect that a winter with days above freezing accompanied by nights below helps trees produce the sap that satisfies a sweet tooth, this has all the earmarks of a record maple sugar season. At least, that's what the folks at Hoyt Farm think is in store for Long Islanders who have a yen for the stuff - and a desire to learn how to do it themselves. Today at 1:30 P.M. the staff at the farm, on New Highway in Commack, holds the first of four successive Sunday maple sugaring classes, letting the uninitiated in on the secrets of preparing maple, birch and even walnut syrup or sugar at home. Participants must bring a pocket knife and an eight-inch length of stiff wire hanger along as tools. The fee for the class is $1, $3 for a family. For information call 543-7804.

title: CYNTHIA HOOD, EXECUTIVE, MARRIED TO JOHN J. MAURO
description: Cynthia June Hood and John J. Mauro were married yesterday at the Greenwich (Conn.) Country Club. The Rev. Dr. Harry S. Adams, associate dean of the Yale School of Divinity, officiated at the nondenominational service.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE LETTERS OF VITA SACKVILLE-WEST TO VIRGINIA WOOLF, edited by Louise DeSalvo and Mitchell A. Leaska. (Quill, $8.95.) Vita Sackville-West and Virginia Woolf met in 1922, became lovers a bit later and finally were devoted friends and correspondents until Woolf's death in 1941. This collection, which includes 175 extracts from Virginia Woolf's correspondence, includes letters of passion but also ''satisfying amounts of artifice, inconsequence, gossip and feeling,'' Thomas Mallon wrote here in 1984. And he said that the collection ''reads like a book, not just a gathering of marvelous scraps.'' THE OLD MAN, by Yuri Trifonov. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) An aged widower sets out to learn the truth about the civil war that followed the Russian Revolution, a war in which he and his friends fought. The theme of Yuri Trifonov's novel, Harlow Robinson wrote here last year, is ''the dangerously insecure grasp the dying Soviet generation has of its own constantly rewritten history.'' While he found the translation by Jacqueline Edwards and Mitchell Schneider pedestrian, he said this is a ''provocative and wise'' novel. In a companion volume the same publisher has reissued ANOTHER LIFE and THE HOUSE ON THE EMBANKMENT ($8.95). In the first novella, a woman's sudden widowhood forces her to reinterpret her past; the second recounts a literary bureaucrat's climb to the top. Richard Lourie wrote here in 1984 that they ''are as formless and self-interrupting as conversation and make use of the telling detail a la Chekhov. . . . Michael Glenny's translation is nearly always . . . effortless.''

title: Ideas & Trends; NASA May Be a Victim of Defects in Its Own Bureaucracy
description: Beyond the problem of identifying the exact cause of the Challenger's disaster, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will be facing tough questioning about its ability to do what it was reputed to do so well: run large-scale technological enterprises efficiently, safely and successfully.

title: PHOTO EXHIBIT
description: In the last decade, working hard and quietly, more than 30 community-based housing organizations have helped revive Brooklyn's poorer neighborhoods and now their efforts are to be recognized in an exhibit by the Brooklyn Historical Society.

title: Betting on PAC's
description: To the Editor:

title: REMEMBERING POLAND
description: REPORT FROM THE BESIEGED CITY And Other Poems. By Zbigniew Herbert. Translated by John Carpenter and Bogdana Carpenter. 82 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $12.50. TREMOR Selected Poems. By Adam Zagajewski. Translated by Renata Gorczynski. 83 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. HAPPY AS A DOG'S TAIL By Anna Swir. Translated by Czeslaw Milosz with Leonard Nathan. 116 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: WESTPORT STARTS TRAILER-PARK PUBLIC HOUSING
description: THE first public-housing complex in Connecticut consisting entirely of mobile homes will begin renting March 1 in Westport.

title: Zachariah Shuster, Ex-Aide With American Jewish Group
description: Zachariah Shuster, a former director of the European office of the American Jewish Committee, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PLIGHT OF HOMELESS TARNISHING IMAGE OF THE 'NEW' HOBOKEN
description: ROW after row of renovated brick and limestone homes line the riverfront and avenues here. For developers, it is a dream fulfilled; for many older residents, however, the revival is a nightmare.

title: BROWN PENSION TO OFFER CHOICE ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Brown University has changed its benefits system so that employees can put their pension money in a fund that does not invest in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: 3d Democrat Enters Contest For U.S. Senate in Maryland
description: Donald Hutchinson, the Baltimore County Executive, has announced that he will seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Charles McC. Mathias Jr., a Republican.

title: TURNTABLE IMPROVEMENTS SERVE THE LP CONSTITUENCY
description: For all the digital dazzle and the allure of laser beams, the fact remains that in this country CD players are outnumbered by conventional turntables by about 80 to 1. A million CD players spin at the frontiers of audio while an estimated 80 million traditional turntables are sprinkled among the general population. In short, the old LP retains a vast constituency whose needs must be served.

title: THE LOOKS, STYLISH
description: IT certainly is a nuisance, all this snow, when one is trying to maintain fashion standards. The wind is blowing, the temperature is dropping, the slush factor is rising.

title: CHASING THE DUTCH MUSE BY RAIL
description: Those who are sound of limb, clear of eye, and absolutely bonkers can do it in a day. Say two days, just to allow for the odd shoelace coming undone.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE RKO BALDWIN, built when they named Long Island movie theaters after their villages, is at the top of a slope where its marquee can't be missed if you're downhill at Merrick Road and Grand Avenue, the original hub of this village's business district.

title: GEORGETOWN IS UPSET; REDMEN DEFEAT CONNECTICUT, 74-54
description: Nearly a month after escaping with a 1-point victory over Connecticut in Hartford, St. John's met the Huskies on familiar ground last night and cruised to a 74-54 victory at Alumni Hall.

title: HOLE-IN-ONE
description: A 99-year-old duffer from Switzerland helped make 1985 a record year for holes-in-one in golf.

title: TEACHING AT HOME: DEBATES CONTINUE
description: WHEN Harold Brewer of Plainsboro, a South Brunswick High School teacher, looks at his freshman students, he says, he sometimes thinks, ''Most of them should be at home.''

title: SUSSEX IS NO LONGER A RURAL BACKWATER
description: TUCKED into the northwestern corner of New Jersey, Sussex County, with all its farms, lakes and roadside vegetable stands, has managed somehow to insulate itself from the rest of the state.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
RED-BREASTED NUTHATCH
description: Sitta canadensus Size: Four and a half inches.

title: AMY OLMSTEAD IS ENGAGED TO DAVID GILBERT VANECEK
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Cecil J. Olmstead of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Amy Louise Olmstead to David Gilbert Vanecek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vanecek of St. Louis.

title: FOREIGNERS IN THEIR OWN LAND
description: WHEN KAI POLTER AND HIS BEST FRIEND, ROLAND Reiss, arrived four years ago at an ''emergency acceptance camp'' in central West Germany, they asked for train tickets to Hamburg. Next to West Berlin, the biggest city in West Germany, Hamburg seemed as good a destination as any, they remember thinking.

title: Settling a Debt From War World II
description: Gordon K. Hirabayashi refused to be evacuated to a wartime internment camp in 1942, was found guilty and has been fighting ever since. Last week, a Federal judge overturned his conviction and, Mr. Hirabayashi said, lifted a legal cloud that had hung over Japanese-Americans for more than 40 years.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO PREVENT STORM DAMAGE
description: WHEN Hurricane Gloria hit our region last fall, the damage that proved most costly and that resulted in the greatest inconvenience was the loss of electrical power, most of which could be blamed on falling trees and branches. Can anything be done to prevent this from happening again?

title: STAKING A CLAIM TO MISS LIBERTY
description: A group of New Jerseyans won the first round in their legal challenge to New York State's sovereignty over both Liberty Island, home of the Statue of Liberty, and nearby Ellis Island.

title:
ART;
STILL LIFES AND 'MASK' FACES: OPPOSITES THAT ATTRACT
description: AT first glance, the two artists currently exhibiting their monotypes at the Graphic Eye Gallery, a printmakers' cooperative in Port Washington, represent diametrically opposite sensibilities.

title: EVEN SOME REPUBLICANS FIND THE BUDGET HARD TO LIVE WITH
description: Manny Hoffman is the mayor of Homewood, a suburb south of Chicago, and an active Republican. But at a hearing conducted by the House Budget Committee here last week, the mayor lacerated President Reagan's spending blueprint and said it would deprive towns like his ''of the tools we need to revitalize and maintain our economies.'' When the Mayor was asked how Homewood could continue to provide the same services with less money, he answered, ''It's a good trick if you can do it.''

title: 'MY MOTHER WOULD BE TREATED BETTER IF SHE WERE A DOG'
description: WHEN I walked into my mother's room at the nursing center she was tied to the bed. She started to cry and said she was being kept prisoner. Of course not, the floor nurse said, it's just that my mother had been falling a lot recently. Her Parkinson's has been getting worse, she can't learn to manage a cane (she waves it like a baton) or a walker (ditto, only clumsier) and she can walk safely only if she holds the rail on one side while someone supports her arm on the other. The trouble is that she either forgets to ask for help or, if she does, it's not always available.

title: LEARNING TO LOVE NOODLES
description: Why do Americans go to Japan?

title: MEXICO'S QUIET PACIFIC PLAYGROUND
description: The next to last thing I expected to do in 1985 was to fall in love with a young Mexican resort, but that's what happened during a week in Ixtapa last February. The last thing I expected to do in 1985 was to go back to Ixtapa for two weeks in December and find the object of my affection transformed from a thriving, reasonably priced place in the sun to a half-deserted low-cost playground waiting to be reoccupied.

title: COURTROOM CRIME
description: NOT many defendants would spit in a prosecutor's face in court. Fewer still, perhaps, would challenge him: ''Why don't you step outside, and we'll settle this, you punk.''

title: AQUINO CAMP SUSPICIOUS ON GOAL
description: President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived here today for an assessment of the Philippine election.

title: PORTUGUESE VOTERS CHOOSE A PRESIDENT TODAY
description: The Portuguese will vote Sunday for their first civilian president since the 1974 revolution.

title: WHY A LAW TO RETEST DRIVERS' VISION, ESPECIALLY FOR THE ELDERLY, IS NEEDED
description: THIS year, 24 people who are 98 and older in the state will be given a license to drive with no questions asked. It is absurd, of course!

title: Where to Look Up Yiddish
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Twice Blessed
description: The odds were 1 in 3,200,000 when Evelyn Marie Adams won almost $4 million in the New Jersey state lottery in October. Last week, Mrs. Adams hit on a real longshot - 1 in 17,300,000,000,000, according to a Rutgers University professor - to win again, making the manager of a 7-Eleven store in Point Pleasant Beach the first two-time million-dollar winner in any of the nation's 22 state lotteries. Since winning in October, Mrs. Adams had increased from 25 to 100 the number of $1 tickets she purchased each week. After laying claim to her new $1.4 million prize, she reflected, ''They say good things come in threes, so. . . .''

title: CYNTHIA PIGOTT MARRIED TO LOUIS BACON
description: In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Cynthia Ingraham Pigott, a daughter of James Stanley Glanville Pigott of New York and London and the late Corinne Ingraham Pigott, was married to Louis Moore Bacon, a son of Zack Hampton Bacon Jr. of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Ann Moore Bacon of Wilmington, N.C. The Revs. Thomas Pike and Judith Baumer performed the ceremony.

title: REAGAN CALLS VOTE SUSPECT
description: The National Assembly tonight proclaimed President Ferdinand E. Marcos the winner of the Feb. 7 presidential election. His opponent, Corazon C. Aquino, planned a rally Sunday at which her supporters were expected to endorse her as the winner.

title: Do We Really Care?
description: Among the many imposing sights in Washington these days you would have to include the tall figure of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, striding along with an old, battered Irish hat on his head.

title: Rebuked Member of D.A.R. Sues Group in Bias Dispute
description: A Massachusetts woman has filed a $3 million lawsuit against the Daughters of the American Revolution, charging the group had illegally retaliated against her for accusing its leaders of following racist policies.

title: MCGUIGAN WINNER BY KNOCKOUT
description: Barry McGuigan of Ireland retained his World Boxing Association featherweight title today, stopping Danilo Cabrera of the Dominican Republic at 1:40 of the 14th round.

title: PLAYLAND TO RENOVATE ITS BOARDWALK
description: WHILE snow fell steadily across the county early last week, E. Richard Keeler sat snugly in his office, his mind churning with images of warm beaches covered with white sand and whipped by crisp blue waters. Bermuda? Palm Beach? Rye. Mr. Keeler's thoughts were of Playland, the 279-acre county-owned amusement park situated there.

title: A BID FOR STARDOM AFTER 19 YEARS IN THE SHADOWS
description: Leslie Uggams is back on Broadway. She stars along with Chita Rivera and Dorothy Louden in ''Jerry's Girls,'' a revue of Jerry Herman songs from such shows as ''Mack and Mabel,'' ''La Cage Aux Folles,'' ''Mame'' and ''Hello, Dolly!''

title: LOVE, NOSTALGIA AND NIAGARA
description: LOVE is not a cheerful subject in contemporary fiction. Usually it's grim, or glum; the best a lover can hope for is irony, a kiss before dying.

title: MISS WIESE TO MARRY ROBIN WYCKOFF
description: Christiane Carden Wiese, a daughter of Peter C. Wiese of New York and Mrs. Charles T. Maxwell of Bronxville, N.Y., plans to marry Robin Kurt Wyckoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald V. Wyckoff of Atlanta, it has been announced. The wedding is planned for August.

title: THE SADLER'S WELLS PRODUCTION OF 'BEAUTY' IS A WINNER
description: ''The Sleeping Beauty'' remains one of the great touchstones of classical ballet and that is reason enough to produce it, as the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet is splendidly demonstrating on its current American tour.

title: Trouble Arises at Sea In Fishermen's Strike
description: Several nonunion fishermen who returned to work despite a strike against fishing boat owners sought refuge Friday aboard a Coast Guard cutter because of friction with union members aboard their boat, officials said.

title: Privatization
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Deferred Royalities
description: To the list of celebrated novels spurned by numerous publishers before finding their way into print, add another, ''Safekeeping'' - something Gregory Mcdonald says he did with his oft-rejected manuscript for nearly 12 years.

title: RUSSIANS SOUGHT U.S. BANKS TO GAIN HIGH-TECH SECRETS
description: The Soviet Union secretly tried to acquire three banks in northern California and an interest in a fourth to gain access to advanced American technology, United States intelligence and military officials say.

title: CORRECTION
description: A film listing today in The Guide, section 2A, misidentifies the theater where ''French Lesson'' will open Friday. It is the Festival, 6 West 57th Street.

title: SCULPTOR ACHIEVES A 50-YEAR DREAM
description: FOR 50 years Gifford Proctor has nurtured a dream. It first took shape, in his mind's eye, in pre-war Europe. He pursued it over decades, committing it to paper, forming it in clay and shaping it in plaster.

title: OFF THE TOURIST TRACK ON ST. THOMAS
description: Fungi dancing, anyone? Chances are you won't say no if you've just eaten at Tasha's Place and if the beat of the Third World Nice and Sweet International Steel Orchestra is lifting you out of your seat beneath a full tropical moon rising over the island of St. Thomas.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FELLINI, SINATRA AND BEDTIME STORIES
description: The Huberman Festival Program III: Henryk Szeryng and Chaim Taub performing with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Zubin Mehta Pacific Arts Video 48 minutes. $39.95 This performance was recorded during the 1983 Huberman Festival in Jerusalem - a sort of summit meeting for violinists.

title: PITTING BUSINESS SKILLS AGAINST A PC
description: THE ''What if?'' scenarios offered by spreadsheets and the data bases that sort one's data every which way from Monday have nearly managed to turn the business computer into a game machine, albeit a sophisticated one. Business Simulator may be the final step in that transformation.

title: LIGHTNING IN TELEPHONE LINES CAUSED JERSEY YOUTH'S DEATH
description: The mysterious death of a high school honors student from Piscataway, N.J., who was found last May lying on a bed with a telephone to his ear, was caused by lightning, according to investigators.

title: Franchise Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title:
About Men;
Golden Gloves
description: THE BANKS CLOSED DOWN, and people began throwing themselves out of windows. It was a strange time in which to be growing up. There were few psychiatrists, fewer welfare programs, and the word ''depression'' referred to an economic condition that saw grown men crying when they thought no one could hear them. I heard my father one afternoon when I came home from school. He'd been out of work for months, like millions of others. The sounds he made frightened me.

title: KIDNAPPING STILL TAKING A TOLL ON DUARTE
description: Three months after the release of President Jose Napoleon Duarte's eldest daughter, her kidnapping continues to hold political costs for the Salvadoran leader and emotional distress for his family, according to friends of the President and Salvadoran military and political officials.

title: REFEREES MUST GIVE GOONS A HEAVE-HO
description: MAJOR league hockey is a marvelous spectator sport, but in the National Hockey League's 60th year it can be made better.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Let There Be Debt When will the installment debt burden finally become so heavy that consumers will stop borrowing and spending? ''Not for a long time,'' said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Even before December's consumer debt figure - a relatively low increase of $5.1 billion, was released last week, Mr. Kellner was not particularly worried. He does not consider the high debt levels onerous, for consumers or for the economy. Why? For one, recent surges in employment have made more consumers eligible to assume debt, he says. For another, the average consumer's debt-to-net-assets has been improving - in part because of the stock and bond market rallies.

title: Greece Stops 4 Russians Driving by U.S. Embassy
description: Four Soviet representatives in Greece, including a diplomat and a journalist, were briefly held by the police early today after they were spotted repeatedly driving past the United States Embassy, police sources said.

title:
ART;
HONORING A PAINTER OF VISION
description: A GIFTED artist has the ability to see the world in an original way. The late Ted Stamm is a fine example, and his ideas inspired scores of students at the School of Visual Arts in New York City and Hofstra University and the C. W. Post Center on Long Island.

title: GUARDING A STATUE OF HARRY TRUMAN
description: VANDALS seemed drawn to Harry S. Truman's cane.

title: AN ALTERNATIVE TO 'MEDICINE FOR PROFIT'
description: The letter to the editor by Jacqueline L. Milch, R.N. [ Dec. 15 ] has a great deal of validity. I must point out, however, that the health maintenance organizations to which she refers are ''medicine for profit'' organizations, and obviously they are going to seek out those who will be expected to be low utilizers.

title: 'RING' CONDUCTOR CANCELS
description: The Seattle Opera has announced that Armin Jordan, who was to conduct the company's new production of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' this summer, has withdrawn because of back surgery. He will be replaced by the 81-year-old Manuel Rosenthal. The Seattle ''Ring'' cycles, to be directed by Francois Rochaix and designed by Robert Israel, are scheduled for Aug. 2 to 7 and 10 to 15.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WHEN the curtain falls on the coming performances of ''Annie'' at the John Harms Theater in Englewood, the cheerful orphan's hopes and dreams will have been realized.

title: CITIZENS' GROUP TELLS OF INGENIOUS VOTE-FRAUD PLOY
description: The citizens' watch committee for the presidential election has concluded that an ingenious method of registration fraud helped to produce wholesale disenfranchisement of up to two million opposition voters.

title: The Nassau Jail's Undercover Story
description: THE MEN AND WOMEN confined in the Nassau County jail in East Meadow, L.I., get uniforms from the county and, if they wish, underwear. ''We supply them with just about everything,'' said Sheriff Joseph J. Santacroce.

title: HELPING CHILDREN TO TAKE PICTURES
description: NO one has ever come up with better advice on buying the right camera for a child than the late Life magazine photographer Philippe Halsman. He said, ''Buy the camera you can see through.''

title: MUSIC: BRANDENBURG GROUP
description: ALEXANDER SCHNEIDER brought his distinctive brand of energetic Classicism to Avery Fisher Hall Friday night, conducting the Brandenburg Ensemble in a program of Bach, Haydn and Mozart.

title: AIDS and the City's Schools
description: How should officials decide whether a child with AIDS may attend regular classes in a New York City public school? According to State Supreme Court Justice Harold Hyman, case by case.

title: SETTINGS ASUNDER
description: CONJUGAL RITES By Ellen Feldman. 236 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
FRESHNESS PREVAILS IN LARCHMONT
description: ON weekends, the air is thick as eager crowds press into the foyer and bar to wait for closely spaced tables already packed with regulars. They come for the service, and they come for the food, dependably good even when the chef cooks under the pressure of a full house.

title: CAMDEN PORT LOOKS TO CONTINUED GAINS
description: THE Port of Camden, revived 16 years ago by a state-sponsored group of community leaders, topped the two million-ton mark in exports and imports last year, according to its annual report to Governor Kean.

title: REAGAN BACK D'AMATO?
description: The campaign that President Reagan started this week in Missouri in behalf of 1986 Republican Senate candidates is clearly going to test the popular President's willingness to speak for Republicans who have disagreed with him from time to time in the past. Will Mr. Reagan draw the line and not campaign for some Republicans, as the predecessor he so often cites so warmly, Franklin D. Roosevelt, once did with dissident Democratic Senators?

title: Symposium: Ends and Means in the Laboratory; Balancing Animal Rights With the Imperatives of Research
description: THE argument against animal research has always been self-evident - ''Pain is pain, whether it is inflicted on man or beast,'' Humphrey Primatt, a British cleric, wrote in 1776 - but the arguments for it have usually won the day. What was the death of a rabbit compared to the perfection of a life-saving surgical procedure? In recent years, however, growing complaints about unnecessary cruelty have made animal research a national issue. Last year, Congress expanded enforcement of the Animal Welfare Act, required training for workers who handle animals and gave the National Institutes of Health the right to revoke Government money if violations are found. This month Federal financing for some animal studies at Columbia University was suspended because they failed to meet new rules. Last week, panels of the National Academy of Sciences that are investigating animal research heard testimony from more than 50 scientists, animal-rights activists and other interested parties. Excerpts follow. FALSE PROMISES The mere fact that we are attending a scientific hearing concerning the use of animals in research indicates how, in the past decade, the legitimacy of the animal rights argument is being seriously considered. Many scientists are questioning not only accepted assumptions concerning the use of animals in research but also the merits of basic research itself. The public has been duped through extensive propaganda into believing that research using animals as substitutes for human clinical observation will lead to the discovery of the cause and cure of disease.

title: Cohn Says Koch Made '80 Deal With G.O.P.
description: Roy Cohn, the politically influential Manhattan attorney, said in a television interview that Mayor Koch made a deal in 1980 to harm Jimmy Carter's re-election campaign in exchange for Republican support in the New York mayoral race the next year.

title: MAGIC OF CORVETTE LASTS TO THIS DAY
description: WHEN Chevrolet turned its first Corvette loose in 1953, we fans got pretty excited, particularly we teen-age fans. I remember my first glimpse, outside a dealership in Pennsylvania. Chevy's gem was glinting in the sun, shiny white fiberglass, chrome mesh over the headlights, Blue Flame engine nestling under the hood.

title: Headliners; Extradited and Facing Trial
description: Less an an hour after exhausting his final legal appeal, Andrija Artukovic, an 82-year-old Croat described as the highest-ranking Nazi war criminal to have entered the United States, was placed on an airplane last week and flown to Yugoslavia to face mass murder charges. The Government accused Mr. Artukovic of having had a role in the killing of 200,000 people, including Serbs, Jews, Gypsies and others, while he was Minister of Interior and Minister of Justice in the Nazi puppet regime that ruled the State of Croatia from 1941 to 1945. Mr. Artukovic entered the United States on a 90-day visitor's visa in 1948 under a false name.

title: HOUSEWIVES GET NO RESPECT...
description: WHILE society as a whole has become more tolerant of the freedom of the individual, the smaller groups with which we interact daily tend to lag far behind. The same people who were so eager for you to settle down, get married, buy a house and two cars and start a family are ready to exert their influence on the next stage of your life.

title: PACT URGED ON 'FREEZE'
description: NEW JERSEY'S peace and disarmament organizations have begun a 50-day countdown aimed at urging official and positive response from the United States to the Soviet Union's initiative to halt nuclear testing.

title: TOWN RULES AFTER LANDSCAPE
description: JUST a few blocks separate East Moriches Boulevard and Valley Drive in Brookhaven Town, but esthetically the two neighborhoods are very different.

title: ARTIST CHRONICLES CIVIL RIGHTS ERA
description: ROBERT TEMPLETON, a Woodbury artist who for 19 years recorded the civil rights movement on canvas, from the abolitionists to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., is having the first major exhibit of that project this month.

title: Reason to Rethink Adoption Cases
description: I am writing to you as co-founder of the Birthparent Support Network and as a social worker who has supervised in both a foster-home agency and group-home setting. This is in response to the article, ''County Adoption Unit Cites Potential of State's New Computerized Registry'' [ Jan.26 ] .

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on Jan. 26 about recordings of works by English composers referred incorrectly to the conductor Norman Del Mar. He is not ''late''; his age is 66.

title: DALLAS RAIL PLAN IS IN TROUBLE BEFORE IT CAN START
description: When Dallas voters approved an $8.7 billion transit plan in August 1983 that included a 147-mile commuter rail system, it was viewed as a historic commitment in a city where the automobile had long been king and mass transit had never been a major public priority.

title: Recent Sales on Long Island
description: Commack $165,000 3 Wenmore Court *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 21-ear-old high ranch; *2*den, new eat-in kitchen, central air-conditioning, pool; taxes $2,800. Hauppauge $189,900 Bedford Road *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new center-hall colonial; *2*den with fireplace, basement, 1 acre, 2-car garage; taxes $3,500. Lake Grove $162,000 22 Ashford Drive *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath 16-year-old colonial; finished basement, *2*workshop, portico, deck; taxes $3,300. North Massapequa $180,000 411 Queens Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; *2*den with fireplace, skylights, central air-conditioning; taxes $3,600. Mineola $172,000 206 Horton Highway *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old colonial; dining room, *2*living room with fireplace, enclosed porch; taxes $1,600. Wantagh $172,000 3479 Ella Road *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath 24-year-old high ranch; *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen, patio, deck; taxes $3,200. OTHER AREAS Hamden, Conn. $80,000 5 Windsor Road *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2*porch, large master bedroom;, taxes $1,581. Somers, N.Y. $145,000 Carpenter Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; *2*eat-in kitchen, den, lake rights; taxes $2,456. Harrington Park, N.J. $242,500 596 Lynn Street *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; *2*new roof, 2-car garage; taxes $3,929.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The European polls by the New York Times are based on face-to-face interviews, conducted by Gallup International with people 18 years of age and older in France, Britain, West Germany, Italy and Spain. The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on 1,581 telephone interviews with people 18 years of age and older who live in the continental United States, conducted from Nov. 6 through 10.

title: HUNTERS' GROUP IS UNDER ATTACK
description: UNTIL late last year, Ducks Unlimited was admired by most who knew of its work.

title: AS SEASON STARTS, DRIVERS AIM AT ELLIOTT
description: One of the odd things about stock-car racing is that the sport's equivalent of the Super Bowl, the Daytona 500, is held at the beginning rather than the end of the season. Last year, Bill Elliott's Ford Thunderbird totally dominated stock-car racing, winning the Daytona and 10 other events.

title: U.S. ADVOCACY GROUP FOR HOMELESS IS BORN
description: Efforts to deal with the evergrowing army of the nation's homeless have so far tended to focus on emergency measures such as temporary shelters.

title: DEAF COUNCILMAN'S BUSY ROLE IN A HEARING WORLD
description: Kevin J. Nolan is unabashed about comparing himself with Ronald Reagan. ''We have four things in common,'' he says. ''We are both fans of Calvin Coolidge, we both enjoy jelly beans, we both were actors, and we are both hearing-impaired.''

title: NINA KIMBERLY, AN ARTIST, PLANS A JUNE WEDDING
description: The engagement of Nina Adams Kimberly to Michael Martin Ives has been announced by Mrs. Bowman Gray 3d of New Canaan, Conn., and New York, mother of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Jill Martin Ives of Brooklyn and Kenneth Appleton Ives Jr. of Hamilton, Mass.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FELLINI, SINATRA AND BEDTIME STORIES
description: Frank Sinatra: Portrait of an Album A documentary of the recording of Mr. Sinatra's 1984 album ''L.A. Is My Lady,'' with Quincy Jones and orchestra; directed by Gary Weiss MGM/UA Home Video 60 minutes. $39.95 This is an adorational yet appealing look at Mr. Sinatra's recording practices.

title: IN FEDERAL WAR ON DRUG TRAFFICKING, WOMEN ARE PLAYING A GREATER ROLE
description: For Joan T. Marin, the first proving grounds were the fields and marshes on the outskirts of Houston, her childhood home. It was there that she was taught how to handle a gun by her father, who also tested her pluck by pitching garden snakes in her direction to see if she would balk.

title: Why Iacocca Is Carrying A Torch
description: Lee A. Iacocca has never let a pink slip get him down. Abruptly stripped of the Ford Motor Company presidency in 1978, he has since rebounded smartly, leading Chrysler Corporation away from the brink and in the process emerging as American industry's best-known spokesman.

title: BEHIND THE RIGID FACADE, DAMASCUS HAS A SOFTER SIDE
description: Syria shows a stern face to the outside world, with its domestic system of rigid control, its Soviet-supplied military and its foreign policy of rejecting any Middle East peace plan that excludes Damascus.

title: A NEW STRAIN ON RELATIONS WITH JAPAN
description: THE continuing plunge in oil prices - so favorable for Japan and unfavorable for the United States - threatens to crash the dollar and worsen economic and financial relations between Tokyo and Washington. Properly handled, however, falling oil prices could sharply improve relations.

title: ANOTHER KNOCKOUT FOR TYSON
description: IN Atlantic City last June 20 in his fourth fight as a pro, Mike Tyson knocked out Ricardo Spain in the first round. Later that night the teen-age heavyweight was sitting with his mentor, Cus D'Amato, as they watched Jesse Ferguson box Tony Anthony for the ESPN heavyweight title. After the sixth round of what would be a 10th-round knockout for Jesse Ferguson, a Philadelphia heavyweight, Cus D'Amato turned to his protege.

title: Spotlight Put On Insurance
description: EXPECT further illumination on Capitol Hill of the troubles besetting liability insurance buyers and sellers - and possibly a clue this week as to whether Congress will intervene.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S STRIFE: QUAGMIRE WITH NO ESCAPE
description: After 18 months of sustained violence and protest, this racially divided land seems caught in a quagmire of its own making.

title: PAVIN OVERTAKES WATSON TO TAKE OPEN
description: Corey Pavin destroyed Tom Watson's hopes with an eagle 3, then hung on for a two-stroke victory today in the Hawaiian Open golf tournament.

title: Determined Celtics Beat Lakers, 105-99
description: Dennis Johnson had 23 points and Larry Bird added 22 today as the Boston Celtics swept the two-game season series from the defending champion Los Angeles Lakers with a 105-99 triumph.

title: DUVALIER FLIGHT LEAVES HAITI INDUSTRY HOPEFUL
description: When the Duvalier family fled Haiti on Feb. 7, they left behind a looted treasury and a country with one of the lowest per capita incomes in the third world.

title: SYSTEMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MUSIC: GOODMAN CHOIR
description: THE Goodman Chamber Choir is an ensemble of 18 well-formed voices that performs under the direction of Andrea Goodman at St. Peter's Lutheran Church. To judge by Saturday evening's concert there, Miss Goodman and her singers are more interested in the music of our century, and less in that of the Baroque, than most similar groups.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Y Chamber Symphony In Aitken Concerto
description: All three of the works the Y Chamber Symphony played Saturday night at the 92d Street Y received first-class performances, but Maurice Ravel's ''Mother Goose Suite'' and Schubert's Symphony No. 9 in C (''The Great'') are known quantities, so let's begin with Hugh Aitken's Violin Concerto.

title: PHYSICAL SUFFERING IS NOT THE ONLY PAIN THAT AIDS CAN INFLICT
description: Todd Shuttleworth had been a Broward County budget analyst for 15 months when it became known that he had AIDS.

title: U.S. AIDES SAY SOVIET URGED P.L.O. TO SHUN TALKS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials say the Soviet Union apparently played a central role in persuading the Palestine Liberation Organization to frustrate American efforts to organize Middle East peace talks between Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation.

title: DEVILS GET 5-5 TIE ON GOAL BY PICHETTE
description: The Devils went from elation to dejecton to relief tonight, all in one game. They fell behind after leading by 3-0 but rallied and managed a 5-5 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: COFFEE PRICE BOOM STIRS FEAR IN BRAZIL
description: Jose Francisco Jacinto chose to buy a house and add 90 acres to his property, while Motomu Shimota finished building his home and then bought three new cars, a color television, a personal computer and a radio telephone.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a front-page article on Saturday about organ transplants appeared without a byline. The writer was Andrew H. Malcolm.

title: O'CONNOR'S WAY: ASSERTIVE AND HEARD
description: John Cardinal O'Connor has brought a fresh assertiveness to the role of Archbishop of New York and has expanded the influence of the Roman Catholic Church on the life and politics of the city, government and church officials say.

title: GROUP CITES DONATIONS TO JERSEY CONGRESSMEN
description: Representatives Frank Guarini of Jersey City and James J. Howard of Spring Lake Heights, both Democrats, were among 27 Congressmen who received more than $100,000 each in contributions from political action committees, according to a report by Common Cause, the public interest lobbying group.

title: STEPHEN R. HERM WED TO MIRANDA S. SPIVACK
description: At Temple Emanuel in Kensington, Md., yesterday Miranda Sheila Spivack, a daughter of Dr. Adrienne R. Mindel of Frederick, Md., and the late Robert G. Spivack, was married to Stephen Robert Herm, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Herm of Keene, N.H. Rabbi Harold S. White, assisted by Cantor Charles Bernhardt, performed the ceremony.

title: Boeing Takeover Backed
description: Investment Canada has approved the Boeing Company's $110 million takeover of de Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd., the federal agency said Friday. Boeing closed the deal to acquire the commuter aircraft maker from the Government's holding company, the Canada Development Investment Corporation, late last month.

title: U.S. SEES MARCOS LOSING HIGH AIDES
description: Authoritative Administration officials said today that they expected high-level resignations from the Philippine Cabinet and financial institutions to increase pressure on President Ferdinand E. Marcos to seek accommodations with the opposition.

title: Soviet Said to Grant Bonner A 3-Month Extension of Visa
description: Yelena G. Bonner, wife of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, has been granted permission to stay in the West until May 28, according to a Soviet journalist who often relays official information to Western news organizations.

description: THE series ''Heritage Conversations With Bill Moyers,'' although it never quite puts it that way, asks a perennial, elusive and possibly unanswerable question: What is a Jew? It is simplifying a great deal to say the program answers by saying a Jew is someone who remembers, but clearly remembrance plays a part. What remembrance is made of, however, is another question. The program, the first in a three-part series, will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: STAGE: 'HELP WANTED,' AN ANTHOLOGY
description: FRANZ XAVER KROETZ is the most frequently produced and fascinating of contemporary West German playwrights, and JoAnne Akalaitis is the foremost American director of his work. Yet the latest Kroetz-Akalaitis collaboration, a 50-minute anthology of six sketches titled ''Help Wanted,'' leaves one wondering if this creative partnership is now serving either of these gifted artists, let alone the audience. Mr. Kroetz's dramatic style has changed its gait of late, moving away from the terseness of his plays previously seen in New York. At the same time, Miss Akalaitis, whose memorable Kroetz stagings include ''Request Concert'' and ''Through the Leaves,'' may be spreading herself too thin: Like her current production of ''The Balcony'' at Harvard's American Repertory Theater, ''Help Wanted'' looks hastily assembled.

title: REBELS SAY THEY KILLED 55 IN SRI LANKA AMBUSH
description: Tamil rebels said today that their guerrillas had ambushed an army convoy in northern Sri Lanka, killing 55 soldiers and destroying three trucks with rocket-propelled grenades and automatic weapons.

Fill It Up

So he started out in Reno, Nev., at 3 o'clock in the morning on Jan. 29, heading for Los Angeles in a Porsche 944 Turbo. Plattner is due to arrive in New York later this month - by way of Australia, Asia, Europe and Africa.

title: Gewandhaus Orchestra Plans Brahms Concerts
description: The Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig will give four concerts devoted wholly to the music of Johannes Brahms, at Avery Fisher Hall next Sundayat 7:30 P.M. and Feb. 24, 26 and 28 at 8 P.M. Under the direction of Kurt Masur, the orchestra will play the four symphonies; the First Piano Concerto, with Garrick Ohlsson as soloist; the Violin Concerto, with Kyung-Wha Chung as soloist, and the German Requiem, with the soprano Elisabeth Soederstroem, the baritone Theo Adam and the Westminster Choir.

Performing together for the first time in America were the fiddler Kevin Burke of the Bothy Band; Andy Irvine, the mandolinist and singer from Planxty; Jackie Daly, formerly of De Danaan, who plays the button accordion, and the guitarist and singer Gerry O'Beirne.

title: ABC PRESENTS 'CHOICES,''' DRAMA ABOUT ABORTION
description: TACKLING the volatile issue of abortion, ''Choices'' visits the playing fields of the very rich where, presumably, momentous decisions needn't be muddled by crass materialistic considerations. The ''ABC Theater'' presentation, at 9 this evening, carefully touches on the weightier arguments against and in favor of abortion rights, and then, in typical television-movie fashion, ends up squarely in the middle of things, with a smidgen of consolation for all sides. Commercial television is still squeamish about antagonizing potential consumers of any stripe.

title: MUSIC: 'AMERICATHON' '86' PROFILES A GENERATION
description: PERHAPS the best way to enjoy ''Americathon '86'' at the New School on Sunday would have been to stay at home. It was after all a radio program - an exploration of contemporary American music broadcast by WNYC-FM and stretching from 1 in the afternoon till long past 10 at night. There were 13 composers on the program and a lot of talk by them as well - most of it efforts to fend off less than incisive questions from an interviewer laboring mightily to fill dead airspace between stage setups. One longed for a few domestic luxuries -a switch to turn or a trip to the beer cooler or bathroom to break the tedium.

title: Copytele Gains Display Patent
description: Copytele Inc., a three-year-old high-technology company based on Long Island, said in a statement Friday that it had been awarded a patent for a flat-screen display device that could reduce the size of computers and other equipment using cathode-ray tubes.

description: As millionaires' week in salary arbitration began, the Yankees yesterday tried to induce Don Mattingly to stay away from the arbitration table with a Dwight Gooden offer, but Mattingly rejected the $1.32 million salary. Both sides said they expected to be in arbitration at the scheduled time tomorrow.

title: RADIO CITY DEMONSTRATION GETS A RESUME TO COSBY
description: The scene bewildered passers-by at Radio City Music Hall last weekend: two dozen people, holding giant posters and placards, marched and chanted outside the stage door of the hall, where Bill Cosby was appearing.

title: SLIGHT PROGRESS IS REPORTED IN EGYPT-ISRAEL BORDER TALKS
description: A team of Egyptian officials left Israel today after the latest round of talks to define arbitration terms in the border dispute over Taba, a tiny enclave at the northern tip of the Red Sea that is now controlled by Israel.

title: NASA SAYS SUBMARINE MAY HAVE FOUND ROCKET
description: A small manned submarine today found what appears to be wreckage of the booster rocket that has been implicated in the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger and its crew of seven astronauts Jan. 28, space agency officials say.

title: New Shadow Committees
description: Taking a page from the Shadow Open Market Committee - a group of economists who follow, and comment on, the monetary policy actions of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee -two more shadows have appeared to monitor Government operations.

title: DANCE: NEWARK TROUPE AT THE RIVERSIDE CHURCH
description: THERE was a sense of all being right with the world in the stark but intensely emotional opening moments of Talley Beatty's ''Mourner's Bench,'' performed by Gallman's Newark Dance Theater yesterday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The economy with which Mr. Beatty sets forth grief and redemption are as affecting as the choreography, in which the mourner folds and unfolds his body, seated on a long bench, moving slowly along it, stretching atop it and falling back against it. And Gregory Hinton gave the solo just the quietly exalted performance it deserved.

title: Gelsey Kirkland Plans To Return to Dancing
description: Gelsey Kirkland will return to the stage in April, after an absence of nearly two years. The ballerina will perform with Britain's Royal Ballet in ''Romeo and Juliet'' in London on April 16 and 19, dancing with Anthony Dowell.

title: Marilyn Horne Recital
description: Marilyn Horne will give her only New York recital of the season on Feb. 27 at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Her program will consist of four excerpts from ''Des Knaben Wunderhorn'' by Gustav Mahler, six songs by Samuel Barber, and works by Vivaldi, Handel, Alvarez, Nin, Montsalvatge, Donaudy, Rossini, Verdi, Tosti and Arditi. Remaining tickets, at $25, $20, $17.50 and $13, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.
