title: NO BALM IN GILEAD FOR MARGARET ATWOOD
description: The President and Congress have been assassinated by right-wing religious fanatics who have overthrown the Government and set up a monotheocratic dictatorship based on biblical principles in a land they now call Gilead. Women may no longer possess jobs, or property, or money of any kind. Pollution has sharply reduced fertility, and certain women, selected for their ability to breed, have become slaves - Handmaids -forced to try to conceive through joyless copulation in bizarre menages a trois with their Commanders and the Commanders' barren wives.

title: GLASS IN A JAR CAUSES BABY FOODS' REMOVAL
description: A major supermarket chain in the Northeast ordered the removal of all Gerber baby food products from its shelves today after a Schenectady mother returned a jar with slivers of glass in it, officials said.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Burdsall Captures Equestrian Event
description: Katharine Burdsall of North Salem, N.Y., rode The Natural to victory today at the $30,000 Gold Coast Grand Prix, the first grand prix of the 1986 Michelob Winter Equestrian Festival.

title: CHANGES IN ROCKET STRAINED BOOSTER'S SEALS, EXPERTS SAY
description: Critical points in the space shuttle booster rockets were put under increased stress because of structural changes in the boosters ordered by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in 1983, according to public documents and former officials of the space agency.

title: ONE VICTIM'S EXPERIENCE
description: For the woman who is a victim of group rape, the attack and its aftermath can be devastating. One victim, a 19-year-old Brown University sophomore who said she was raped four years ago when she was in high school, agreed to an interview on condition that she not be identified.

title: CUCOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 12
Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: POPE URGES PHILIPPINE PEACE AFTER BACKING BISHOP'S STAND
description: Pope John Paul II appealed today for a peace in the Philippines after the Vatican expressed its full support for the country's Roman Catholic bishops, who have denounced President Ferdinand E. Marcos's re-election as fraudulent.

title: NO KNICK TRADE AS DEADLINE PASSES
description: The National Basketball Association's trading deadline has come and gone, and Darrell Walker is still a Knick, Norm Nixon is still with the Los Angeles Clippers and Terry Tyler is still a member of the Sacramento Kings. Moreover, the Knicks still have their top draft choice, which could put them into the lottery for the first seven picks in the draft for the second straight year.

title: Britain Plans Guinness Study
description: The Government stepped into the biggest corporate takeover battle in British history Friday, ordering an antitrust investigation of an attempt by a brewing giant, Guinness P.L.C., to gain control of the Distillers Company, the maker of gin and Scotch whisky.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ WAGE FIGHT OVER A KEY PORT
description: Ground, air and sea battles raged near the Persian Gulf's northern tip today as Iraq tried to recapture a port that controls its access to the gulf, according to military communiques from both Iraq and Iran.

title: SEOUL CONTINUES SEARCH FOR SIGNERS OF A PETITION
description: The South Korean Government continued its crackdown on opposition political leaders today, with reports that several opposition party members were being held by the police for their part in a petition drive to revise the nation's Constitution.

title: EIGHT TO THE BAR?
description: The other day on the Metro, a young woman was overheard telling a companion that 6 out of 10 Washingtonians were lawyers.

title: GURU WHO QUIT OREGON HEADS FOR CRETE AFTER A NEPAL VISIT
description: The guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh of India has left Nepal for Crete, one of his Nepalese followers said today.

title: NASA TAKEN ABACK BY CALL TO SCREEN ITS INQUIRY PANEL
description: A Presidential commission's request that NASA exclude key personnel from its investigation of the Challenger explosion aroused uncertainty at the agency today, but should not disrupt the investigation, sources at the commission and the agency say.

title: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS ASAIL DECISION
description: President Reagan signed an executive order Friday retaining the hotly debated low fees for ranchers whose cattle graze on Federal lands in the West.

description: Companies

description: Harry Van Arsdale Jr., president of the New York City Central Labor Council and one of the last surviving giants of the George Meany era in labor relations, died yesterday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 80 years old.

description: At the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday Teri Christina Dombeck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Dombeck of East Rockaway, L.I., was married to Christopher Alan Giannetto, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Giannetto of New York. The Rev. William J. Winterrowd performed the ceremony. The bride is a product consultant for Erisco, a Dun & Bradstreet company in New York. Mr. Giannetto is a senior underwriter for M O N Y Financial Services in Purchase, N.Y.

title: COPLEY PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the 6 months are actually for 5 months period beginning July 29, 1985, when company began operations after its initial public offering, through Dec. 31.

title: PHYSIO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SABERHAGEN IN HIS GLORY
description: FOUR months have passed, but the moment remains. The catch. The joyous hug. Bret Saberhagen - a bright, innocent smile stretched across his angelic face - wrapping his arms around George Brett in explosive celebration. In sports, these scenes have almost become commonplace; we see them often enough to become immune. But we never forget them. We still haven't forgotten Bret Saberhagen, either. The gifted young pitcher had done more than just escort the Kansas City Royals to a World Series championship over the St. Louis Cardinals. He seemed to crawl through our television screens and take a seat on the couch, and then he willingly opened his life to an American sporting public.

title: AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $9 million on the sale of Williamsburg Hospitality House.

title: HAPPY WHATEVER
description: The Democratic National Committee has compiled an ethnic calendar for 1986, lest any leader or candidate inadvertently fail to note a holiday of consequence to any national, religious or racial minority with voting members. Many of the 106 holidays listed are predictable: St. David's Day; the Welsh national holiday (March 1); Verrazano Day, birthday of the Florentine explorer (April 17); Vidovan, Serbian national holiday celebrating victory over the Turks (June 28).

title: TRI-STAR TV DEAL REPORTED IN WORKS
description: Tri-Star Pictures, the movie company owned by Columbia Pictures Industries, Home Box Office and public shareholders, is entering the television business, according to sources familiar with Tri-Star's negotiations to form a joint venture.

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: LEBANESE JEW SLAIN BY MOSLEM RADICALS WHO ABDUCTED HIM
description: The police found the body of a Lebanese Jew today in Moslem West Beirut, 24 hours after an underground Moslem radical faction said it had kidnapped and killed him.

title: Brazil Backs Its Computers
description: In a terse and strongly written communique published Friday, the Brazilian Government said that ''under no circumstances'' would it change its so-called market reserve policy, which protects local computer industries at the expense of foreign-owned companies.

title: UPPER PENINSULA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WORDS AND ACTIONS
description: Last summer Western banks worried about instability in South Africa, said they would not renew loans there unless and until Pretoria made meaningful political changes. South Africa then suspended repayment of its foreign debt.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT PROVOKES CONFIDENCE AND WORRY
description: Here, among the wooded hills and tidy homes along Long Island Sound, there are only a few issues that pit neighbor against neighbor.

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ruling Backs Boston Bank
description: A Federal district judge has acquitted the Bank of New England, two former head tellers and a convicted gambler of charges they conspired to conceal large cash transactions from the Federal Government.

title: BODINE DAYTONA WINNER
description: Nearly three hours remained before the familiar command, ''Gentlemen, start your engines,'' would be heard, but activity was brisk in the garage area at Daytona International Speedway this morning. Pit crews made last-minute adjustments on the colorful, decal-studded stock cars, gleaming with waxed shines and finely tuned to run 500 miles at speeds approaching 200 miles per hour on the long backstretch. Admiring visitors snapped photographs of the racing machines - perhaps for posterity -and drivers such as Tim Richmond and A. J. Foyt came by for a final inspection.

title: RANGERS CAPTURE FIGHT-FILLED GAME
description: There were the pictures of Pierre Larouche and of Mike Ridley, streaking down the ice all alone, going for the penalty shot. There was the sight of James Patrick, his sweater off, his chest gear exposed, punching away.

description: In a period of generally cold relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, academic cooperation in archeology, a potentially controversial field, has been steadily expanding since 1979.

title: Imperial Drops Takeover Bid
description: Imperial Group P.L.C., the large British tobacco, beer and food company, said Friday that it was abandoning a bid for United Biscuits P.L.C. afer the Government referred the proposed merger to the National Monopolies and Mergers Commission.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Li'l Queenie Returns For Mardi Gras Special
description: The New Orleans rock-blues singer Leigh Harris, who is better known as Li'l Queenie, created quite a critical stir when she appeared for the first time in New York nearly six years ago. Miss Harris, who possesses a wonderfully insinuating ''tough mama'' voice with silky jazz edges, elicited favorable comparison with Janis Joplin, and big things were predicted for her.

title: TOP BRASS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Banctec Inc., Dallas, which makes document and information processing systems, has promoted Nort A. Stuart to executive vice president, operations, and William E. Bassett to senior vice president, customer services.

title: EYE CARE CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Most of the prior year results are not available because the company began its startup phase in the 1984 second quarter and went public in March 1985.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day last Wednesday about extended service on the M31 bus line incorrectly identified the block associations that lobbied for the extension. They were the East 79th Street and East 87th Street 400 associations.

title: JOSEPH DUELL, A LEAD DANCER FOR THE NEW YORK CITY BALLET
description: Joseph Duell, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet who had also choreographed for the company, died yesterday after a fall from the fifth floor of his apartment building in Manhattan. He was 29 years old.

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VILLANOVA COULD PROVE TROUBLESOME FOR ST. JOHN'S
description: A half-hour after St. John's defeated Connecticut, 74-54, Saturday night, Willie Glass, St. John's high-flying forward, sat in the cavernous interview room in Alumni Hall fielding questions about the evening's work. Since there wasn't much to say about the rout, the focus shifted to the Redmen's rematch with Villanova tomorrow night in the Wildcats' new $9.5 million field house.

title: NET MURDER AT SEA
description: An unusually destructive method of ocean fishing now jeopardizes the Alaska salmon catch. Even more is at stake, however, and the United States has only begun to do anything about it.

title: NASA PICKS RESEARCH SITE
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has picked the Langley Research Center here as its headquarters for developing the experimental aerospace plane President Reagan referred to in his State of the Union Message, officials said last week. The center would manage research at three laboratories and work with Defense Department agencies on the project, officials said. A prototype of the experimental plane could be ready by 1992.

description: rr(Loss) * not applicable, loss in 1984 period. (1) Quarter ending in Sept. (2) Quarter ending in Oct. (3) Quarter ending in Nov. (4) Quarter ending in Jan.

title: ADVICE FOR TENANTS AFTER APARTMENT FIRES
description: After the immediate horror of a fire subsides, people who have lost their apartments face confusion over where they can live, how they can recover and who will help them.

title: TAIWAN PLANE IS MISSING ON FLIGHT FROM TAIPEI
description: A China Airlines Boeing 737 carrying six passengers and seven crew members was reported missing today on a flight from Taipei to the offshore island of Penghu, airline officials said.

title: FRANCE BOMBS A REBEL AIRFIELD IN CHAD
description: French Air Force planes today bombarded an airfield that was a hub for supplying Libyan-supported rebels in northern Chad, Defense Minister Paul Quiles said.

title: PASSENGERS FLED PLANE ON OWN, AIRLINE REPORTS
description: The emergency evacuation of an Eastern Airlines plane before takeoff at Kennedy International Airport Saturday night was initiated by passengers, not by members of the flight crew, a spokesman for the airline said yesterday.

title: Olajuwon Is Out With Knee Injury
description: Akeem Olajuwon, the Houston Rocket center who injured his right knee Saturday night, left the team today for Houston where X-rays will be taken Monday, Coach Bill Fitch said.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS UP IN QUARTER
description: A spurt in consumer spending in December bolstered corporate profits at the end of the fourth quarter in 1985, but economists differ over how much the growth helped an otherwise sluggish economy during the period.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: PAULA BERNHARDT MARRIED TO DAVID TOUGER, LAYWER
description: Paula Bernhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Bernhardt of Freeport, L.I., was married yesterday to David Touger, a son of Mirel J. Touger of Lynbrook, L.I., and the late Benjamin Touger. Rabbi Reuben Katz performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth David in Lynbrook with Cantors Abraham Schapiro and Harry Altman.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed. The weekly Treasury bill auction will take place tomorrow instead of today.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Simple Explanation
description: So what's a nice Israeli boy doing at Notre Dame?

title: STATE COMPTROLLER URGES AID FOR LOCALITIES ON INSURANCE
description: New York State's Comptroller, citing ''potential fiscal disaster for local governments,'' has urged Governor Cuomo and leaders of the State Legislature to act immediately to ease what he called ''the statewide liability insurance crisis.''

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Regan Asserts City Agencies Seem to Ignore Audit Advice
description: New York City agencies have apparently been ignoring recommendations by auditors about contract awards to collection agencies and consultants, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: SIGMA RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

NORMALIZING RELATIONS SERVES OUR INTERESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: INDUSTRY ANALYSTS DOUBT FUTURE OF DRUG CAPSULES
description: The recent discovery of Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules laced with cyanide has raised considerable doubt among drug industry analysts and marketing experts about the future use of capsules for over-the-counter drugs.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UNCOVERING A PAST The current exhibition at the Bronx Museum of the Arts offers New Yorkers a rare opportunity to view representative works from a range of art produced by black American artists in the United States during a 100-year period. The show is ''Hidden Heritage: Afro-American Art, 1850-1950.'' It consists of 85 paintings, sculptures and works on paper gleaned from more than 50 museum and private collections. The artists include David Bowser, Joshua Johnston and Robert S. Duncanson among the early 19th-century (slavery period) artists; and from the late 19th century, Edward M. Bannister, Henry O. Tanner and the sculptor Mary Edmonia Lewis.

title: CONTRIBUTORS AIDING NEEDIEST TO HONOR FRIENDS AND FAMILY
description: Honoring a friend or loved one is cited by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: WEIGH-TRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DESPITE CRITICISM, FOSTER IS EAGER TO KEEP PLAYING
description: GEORGE FOSTER has a message for all those people who think he should stop taking the $2 million a year and quit: He wants to play six more years in the big leagues and end his career with 500 home runs.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about a Soviet attempt to acquire three California banks and an interest in a fourth misspelled the name of the Soviet bank that provided financing. It was the Moscow Narodny Bank.

title: General Felt Seeks Sheller
description: General Felt Industries, a furniture, carpeting and floor products company, said Friday that it had made a friendly offer to acquire the Sheller-Globe Corporation for more than $378.4 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am the President. They are not going to drive me out, because the people are behind me.''

title: SHHH! DON'T TALK (MAYBE)
description: The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration got himself into a bit of hot water last week over an issue that confronts Federal investigators nearly every day.

title: A NEW SET OF HURDLES FOR MANVILLE
description: Three and a half years after the Manville Corporation went into bankruptcy proceedings, all the initial hurdles to reorganization -most significantly, how to handle thousands of present and future claims by workers with asbestos-related injuries - have been cleared.

title: JURY BEING PICKED TO DECIDE WHO OWNS JOHNSON FORTUNE
description: As Johnson & Johnson, the giant New Jersey-based pharmaceutical firm, copes with yet another crisis involving its product Tylenol, the family made wealthy by the company will be in court in Manhattan this week to battle over the ownership of the enormous Johnson fortune.

title: CITIZENS CABLE COMMUNICAIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DUKE HOLDS OFF NOTRE DAME SPURT, 75-74
description: For the second time within 18 hours, the Duke Blue Devils found themselves facing a last-shot situation. And for the second game in a row, it was Johnny Dawkins who made the difference. Dawkins blocked a jump shot by Notre Dame's David Rivers with two seconds remaining today to preserve a 75-74 victory.

title: JUSTICE FOR RECKLESS WRECKERS
description: Eddie Garofolo, the demolition contractor who did not bother to turn off the gas and electricity before he illegally knocked down an empty hotel on Manhattan's West 44th Street a year ago, walked out of court this week without a jail sentence or even, as yet, a fine. Alfred Kleiman, the judge who found him guilty without a jury, excused the leniency by noting that Harry Macklowe, the real estate developer who paid the Garofolo firm $380,000 for the demolition, also got off without a jail sentence.

title: THE AGE OF ACCESS
description: The new public relations firm launched by Michael Deaver, who is like a son to the President and Mrs. Reagan, is currently taking over $2 million a year out of South Korea. Not including expenses.

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RISE IN COST FOR TRANSIT IS ASSAILED
description: The steep rise in operating expenses on New York City's bus and subway system in the last 20 years has led to service cuts and reduced ridership because of fare increases, an independent research agency said in a report to be released today.

title: PATIENT ON JARVIK PUMP GETS HEART IN PITTSBURGH
description: A 39-year-old businessman kept alive by an artificial heart for nearly two weeks was in critical condition today after receiving a human heart.

title: SOCIALIST, IN BIG COMEBACK, WINS PORTUGAL'S PRESIDENCY
description: Former Socialist Prime Minister Mario Soares was elected Portugal's first civilian President in 60 years today.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: CHARLOTTE CHARLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AN EX-MAYOR ON THE ALERT FOR PROBLEMS IN SUBWAY
description: When it comes to measuring track conditions with great sensitivity, the Transit Authority counts on a $1.39 million inspection car that has computers on board.

title: THE $1,000 JOB TAX ON CARS
description: Japan's decision to hold down its auto exports to the United States for a sixth year seems tactfully designed to please almost everyone, even Japanese automakers. The only losers, at least in the near term, are the people who ought to count most: American consumers.

title: WESTCHESTER LEADER CALLS ON U.S. TO BAN NONPRESCRIPTION CAPSULES
description: The Westchester County Executive called yesterday for a Federal ban on the sale and distribution of capsule forms of Tylenol and other nonprescription medicines, with exceptions only for cases of medical necessity.

title: Outdoors: Ritual of Swapping
description: I AM now engaged in ridding myself of various rods, reels and guns that once seemed essential to my activities afield.

title: Clues to Succession In G.M.'s Reshuffle
description: When the General Motors Corporation announced a major executive reshuffle recently, most of the attention focused on Lloyd E. Reuss, 49 years old, and Robert C. Stempel, 51, the newly appointed executive vice presidents of the automotive giant. That is not surprising, since it is widely felt within the automotive industry that one of the two men will succeed F. James McDonald as president of G.M. when Mr. McDonald retires next year.

title: CHARLES FLYING TO DALLAS FOR TEXAS CELEBRATION
description: Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, arrives Monday to offer best wishes to a republic that lasted only nine years more than a century ago.

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: DNAP PLANT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MAKING A PEER OF A CHILD
description: WHENEVER she is at loose ends on a Saturday night, Phyllis Rosenblum, a single parent in Suffern, N.Y., likes to invite her 8-year-old son, Jared, to dinner and a movie.

title: WHEN CELEBRITY IN TEXAS ISN'T THE COWBOYS
description: A first-term lawmaker usually has trouble getting recognized by anybody outside his immediate family. But Senator Phil Gramm is being greeted around Texas these days with the sort of enthusiasm usually reserved for the Dallas Cowboys and the Kilgore Junior College Rangerettes.

title: BRENTWOOD INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Suspects Are Seized After Double Murder
description: A man and a woman were shot to death early yesterday in an apartment building in the South Bronx and moments later two men carrying five guns were arrested nearby.

TAX DEDUCTIBILITY A BALANCE WHEEL OF FEDERALISM
description: To the Editor:

HALE S. ANSBERRY, A LAWYER, IS WED
description: Hale Steinman Ansberry, a daughter of Louise Steinman Ansberry of Alexandria, Va., and the late T. Peter Ansberry, was married yesterday to Robert Morris Krasne, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Louis Krasne of Overland Park, Kan. Judge Christine Cook Nettesheim of the United States Claims Court performed the ceremony at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Dazzy Vance once pitched a no-hit, one-run game for the Brooklyn Dodgers. Who was the losing pitcher and how did the opposing team score?

title: Conrail Dispute Growing
description: The House is gearing up for battle with the Reagan Administration over the Transportation Department's plan to sell the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Corporation, although it will be late March or April before hearings on the proposed sale resume in the House.

title: SYLVAN LEARNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 31.

title: AMBASSADOR FINANCIAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: R. J. REYNOLDS NET UP
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries reported yesterday that net income for 1985 was $1 billion, up 18.6 percent from $843 million in 1984. Total sales for the year were $16.6 billion, up 27.7 percent from $13.0 billion in 1984. J. Tylee Wilson, chairman and chief executive, said the results reflected good performances by all the corporation's business's, including Nabisco, which Reynolds purchased in 1985.

title: WALKER EYEING DALLAS
description: If the United States Football League delays its season, Herschel Walker could join the Dallas Cowboys this season, his agent said. ''Herschel will be playing this fall, either for the Generals or the Cowboys. I can't get into specifics about his contract, but he is not going to wait for the U.S.F.L. if they don't play this year,'' Peter Johnson told The Dallas Morning News. U.S.F.L. owners are meeting today in New York, and one owner, Baltimore's Myles Tannenbaum, has suggested the league suspend play until the resolution of the U.S.F.L.'s $1.32 billion lawsuit against the National Football League.

title: 3 CHOICES IF MAKING ONE BID BUT REALLY MEANING ANOTHER
description: The player who makes one bid when he really means another has three choices.

title: Toward a Nuclear-Free Globe
description: The Administration is consulting friends and allies in Europe and Asia concerning a response to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's sweeping arms control proposal made in January. The Administration answer, however, is reportedly restricted to that part of the Gorbachev offer that would limit intermediate-range missiles, and, regrettably, would ignore the call for eliminating all nuclear weapons by the year 2000.

title: WITHERSPOON PROBATION
description: The Georgia Boxing Commission yesterday imposed a one-year probation on Tim Witherspoon, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, in the wake of tests that showed that he had used marijuana before his Jan. 17 title fight against Tony Tubbs.

title: BACK ON TOP IN PORTUGAL
description: Mario Soares had finally escaped the crush of well-wishers early this morning and had secluded himself with his family and a few others in a back room of the mansion that served as his campaign headquarters here.

title: COLLEGES COURSES STUDT TERRORISM
description: ERIC LIEBLER allows his imagination to run freely. He has just hijacked a planeload of Americans to Sicily.

title: Oil - Benefits and Dark Clouds
description: To Americans who remember the twin oil shocks of the 1970's, the plunge in oil prices comes as welcome relief (or even sweet revenge). The immediate consequences are beneficial: improved economic growth, reduced inflationary pressures and lower balance of payments deficits. But we should be wary of complacency.

title: A Key Affirmative-Action Case
description: Among several cases pending before the United States Supreme Court is one that reveals in microcosm the basic conflicts of interest in the affirmative action controversy. Later this month, the Court is scheduled to hear oral arguments on a petition from a New York City construction union that is seeking to reverse a Federal court order requiring it to comply with an affirmative action plan.

title: OLAJUWON OUT 2 WEEKS
description: Akeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets will be sidelined for at least two weeks by a sprained ligament in his right knee.

title: U.S. Warns of Possible Taint In Four More Brands of Brie
description: The Food and Drug Administration warned Sunday that bacteria that could cause flu-like symptoms had been found in four more brands of brie cheese.

title: Rapping to 'Job Plan'
description: It might not be poetry, but the rap song ''Job Plan'' does offer useful advice. Information on your application Becomes a permanent record, you see.

title: Life Term Is Sought For a Turk in Pope Trial
description: A Government prosecutor said today that he would seek a life sentence for a fugitive Turk accused of helping coordinate what the prosecution says was a conspiracy to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: CANCER CARE WHERE EVEN PAIN SERVES A PURPOSE
description: On the fourth floor of Mount Sinai Hospital is a cramped office crowded with shelves of computer printouts. Few patients get to see it. But it is a place at Mount Sinai where the search for scientific truth and the practice of medicine intersect; a room of graphs and charts and statistics where patients appear as tiny dots and lives are measured by the length of black lines.

title: MATTINGLY AGREES TO A $1,375,000 DEAL
description: Having already prepared to confront each other in salary arbitration, Don Mattingly and the Yankees reached agreement on a one-year contract for $1,375,000 early today. The agreement came shortly after midnight, or less than 10 hours before their arbitration hearing was scheduled to begin.

title: DEPLETED KNICKS AND NETS LOSE: MAVS 126, NETS 124
description: The discrepancy was simply too big to ignore. When Dave Wohl, the Net coach, heard about it late this afternoon, he offered a half-smile and shrugged.

title: SQUASH TITLE WON BY YALE STUDENT
description: Hugh LaBossier, a senior at Yale, upset the three-time defending champion, Kenton Jernigan, yesterday to take the 80th United States Squash Racquet Association men's singles championship. The scores were 15-11, 8-15, 15-7, 18-16.

title: SHOPPING DEFENSIVELY
description: FOR Judith and Paul, the excitement of buying their first computer turned quickly to despair. When the store finally delivered the computer, two days later than promised, it arrived in a dozen boxes and what seemed to be about a hundred parts. There were screwdrivers and long cables and circuit boards in black bags affixed with stickers that warned about all the terrible things static electricity can do.

title: Wiley T. Buchanan Jr.; Former Protocol Chief
description: Wiley T. Buchanan Jr., the United States chief of protocol from 1957 to 1961 and a former Ambassador to Austria and Luxembourg, died Sunday at a nursing home. He was 72 years old.

title: KODAK MOVES ACCOUNT OUT OF MCCANN AGENCY
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said last week that it would consolidate its advertising with two of its three major agencies. The loser is McCann-Erickson, which has handled Kodak's consumer electronics division and some of its international film and camera business.

title: Don't Slam the School Door in the Face of Returning Absentees
description: To the Editor:

title: Prince's Visit Honors Old Texas Republic
description: Prince Charles stepped off a jet today from Britain to the music of bagpipes playing the ''Yellow Rose of Texas'' as he began a visit for the 150th anniversary of the state's break with Mexico.

title: STATEN I. DEFEATS EVERS
description: The College of Staten Island, undefeated in league play during the regular season, scored a 67-50 victory over Medgar Evers yesterday as the City University of New York Conference men's basketball tournament began.

title: GREY INCOME FELL 10% IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: Grey Advertising said its fourth-quarter net income declined 10 percent, to $2.7 million, or $3.96 a share, from $3 million, or $4.78 a share.

title: ORATORIO: 'SAN GIOVANNI BATTISTA'
description: ALESSANDRO STRADELLA'S life, which was ended in 1682 by the brothers of a lady he had ''wronged,'' as they say, was adventurous and amorous enough to make him the subject of an opera by Flotow. Stradella's own operas have not figured prominently in the Baroque revival of our time, but if they are comparable in dramatic force to the oratorio ''San Giovanni Battista,'' performed Sunday afternoon in the ''Music Before 1800'' series at Corpus Christi Church, they ought to be investigated. Even in a performance that was only partly satisfactory, this version of John the Baptist's death suggested that Stradella's dramatic flair in life was reflected in his music.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We feel the company can no longer guarantee the safety of capsules to a degree consistent with Johnson & Johnson's standards of responsibility to its consumers.'' -James E. Burke, the chairman of Johnson & Johnson. [ A1:4. ]

title: MARCOS RUNNING MATE SAYS HE IS STILL UP AND AROUND
description: The night before the Philippine National Assembly proclaimed him Vice President, Arturo M. Tolentino appeared on television to assure the nation that he was still alive and that he still backed his running mate, Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: EXPERT TESTIFIES YOUTH KILLED PARENTS BECAUSE OF 'ADOPTED CHILD SYNDROME'
description: When John and Judith DeGelleke died in 1984 in a fire set by their adopted son, this small farming town near Rochester mourned.

title: Sell the Mint but Keep Paris Air Show?
description: Perhaps it's the lure of April in Paris. Perhaps it's a concern for exports. Perhaps it's the tug of tradition or a fascination with aerodynamics. Whatever it is, a curious exception to the Reagan Administration's penchant for transferring Government functions to private enterprise is the Commerce Department's continuing participation in the Paris Air Show.

title: RELIGIOUS PHILOSOPHER FROM INDIA
description: Jiddu Krishnamurti, the religious philosopher and teacher, died of cancer yesterday at his residence at the Krishnamurti Foundation in Ojai, Calif. He was 90 years old.

title: MCA IS TERMED A SERIOUS BIDDER FOR WOR-TV
description: MCA Inc. is a serious bidder for WOR-TV, the New Jersey-based television station that covers the New York market, according to sources familiar with the company. MCA is the parent company of Universal Pictures and Universal Television, a leading producer of TV shows.

title: THE 'PRIVATE AGONY' AND DEATH OF JOSEPH DUELL, GIFTED DANCER
description: When George Balanchine went into the hospital in the fall of 1982, Joseph Duell went to visit him. The famous choreographer knew that his protege at the New York City Ballet was prone to get frustrated with himself. Unlike many young dancers, he was not satisfied to convey beauty and grace; he wanted to pick apart and understand these gauzy concepts.

title: Dept. of Hundred-Dollar Toilet Seats
description: Disclosures about the Defense Department paying hundreds of dollars for a hammer and hundreds more for a toilet seat have infuriated President Reagan, who has called the reports a ''constant drumbeat of propaganda'' and not typical of the way the Government operates.

title: Death Ends Candidacy
description: Stanley Goldman, candidate for Mayor, denounced the incumbent, David Keating, in a campaign appearance Sunday as being too old to lead the city, then moments later suffered a fatal heart attack. Mr. Goldman, 69 years old, was pronounced dead an hour after collapsing at a campaign forum. Mayor Keating is 77.

title: Topics; On the Shoals Stranded Island
description: The cable tram by which 3,000 New York commuters hop from Roosevelt Island to Manhattan and back is stuck on an insurance problem. Underwriters who protect the state against tram liability claims want to increase their annual premium, now $677,000, by at least $3 million.

title: South Korea Continues Crackdown on Dissidents
description: The Government and opposition political leaders clashed again today as the police broke up an opposition meeting, placed a Government critic under house arrest and took scores of opposition politicians into custody.

title: Measles Immunization for Younger Infants
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATOR SUGGESTS MARCOS STEP DOWN
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, who headed a delegation of observers in the Philippine elections, said today that President Ferdinand E. Marcos should step aside if he is unwilling to hold new and fair elections.

title: Working Profile:Donald A. Hicks; Pentagon's New Yes-and-No Man on Weapons
description: Soon after he arrived at the Pentagon from the aerospace industry, it came home to Donald A. Hicks that the Government was different from the Northrop Corporation.

title: CHIEF RESIGNS AT FERMENTA
description: Refaat el-Sayed, an Egyptian-born entrepreneur whose confession that he lied about having an American doctorate, which rocked Sweden's business world, said today that he is resigning as chief executive of Fermenta, the highly successful biotechnology company.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Israeli-Egyptian Relations Are a Two-Way Street
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: 'TROMBA MARINA'
description: THE gem of the New York Philharmonic Ensembles concert Sunday at the Church of the Holy Trinity was an unlikely study for four contrabasses by Jacob Druckman, the parent orchestra's resident composer. It's a delightful bagatelle named ''Tromba Marina'' after a sort of Italian folk instrument, a big one-stringed bass fiddle that was played entirely in harmonics (that is, by touching the string lightly with the right hand instead of pressing it to the fingerboard).

title: Scofflaws in and Out of Government
description: How much money in unpaid parking fines will it take to revolutionize New York City's method of collecting them? Scofflaws now owe nearly $1 billion, a new inventory shows. One Queens man has been allowed to get away with $66,765 in unpaid tickets; a Brooklyn woman owes $63,575. A member of a community school board has run up a bill of $14,255, another has a bill totaling $11,068.

title: Cupid Is Faster
description: ''We'll deliver last-minute gifts to your sweetheart overnight,'' promised the promotional mailing from the United States Postal Service.

title: NEW CHIEF NAMED AT BETHLEHEM
description: Donald H. Trautlein, chairman and chief executive of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, will relinquish the chief executive's post to Walter F. Williams, the company's president, effective March 1, Mr. Trautlein announced yesterday.

title: DEPLETED KNICKS AND NETS LOSE: CAVALIERS 111, KNICKS 97
description: The Knicks were hoping this afternoon to gain some ground on the Cleveland Cavaliers in their quest for a playoff berth. But as has been the case so many times this season - especially since New York lost Patrick Ewing 11 days ago - the available bodies just weren't able to do the job.

title: MOTIVE UNCLEAR
description: The Central Bank of the Philippines raised interest rates sharply today, and the bank's governor said the economy would slow as a result and probably not grow at all.

title: FICTION AWARD TO TYLER
description: Anne Tyler, author of ''The Accidental Tourist,'' published by Alfred A. Knopf, has won the National Book Critics Circle award for the most distinguished work of fiction published in 1985. The novel is the story of a stodgy writer of travel guidebooks who, through a series of events in and out of his control, comes to grips with changes he must make in his life.

title: Cohn's Health Called 'Precarious' by Doctor
description: The condition of Roy M. Cohn, who is suffering from liver cancer, remains ''very precarious'' after four months of treatment with ''a new, experimental drug,'' his physician said in an affidavit filed last week The physician, Dr. Bijan Safai of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, said in the affidavit that the lawyer appeared to have made progress in ''important areas,'' but that it was ''too early to determine what overall effect this drug is having on the disease, which is threatening Mr. Cohn's life.''

title: MAKER OF TYLENOL DISCONTINUING ALL OVER-COUNTER DRUG CAPSULES
description: Johnson & Johnson yesterday discontinued the manufacture and sale of all its over-the-counter medications in capsule form to prevent the kind of tampering that recently killed a woman who took cyanide-laced capsules of Extra-Strength Tylenol.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Bob James and Gene Nelson, pitchers, to one-year contracts.

title: Where to Dump Dictators
description: The world cheered when Jean-Claude Duvalier agreed to flee Haiti, but no country except Liberia will give him a home. No one wants to let a man who bled and pillaged his country live in safe luxury off his lootings and no one wants to pay for his protection. But in Mr. Duvalier's case - and others that will surely develop - asylum is a price worth paying to rescue suffering societies from further ruin.

title: 3 LOSE IN ARBITRATION
description: In baseball arbitration decisions rendered yesterday, Julio Franco of Cleveland, Mike Moore of Seattle and Tim Laudner of Minnesota lost, giving the clubs 13 victories and the players 9.

title: Burger Argues for New Court
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger argued again today for creating an intermediate appeals court that would siphon cases from a Supreme Court he says is overburdened.

title: AFGHAN WAR, AFTER 6 YEARS, BECOMES A SOVIET FACT OF LIFE
description: After six years, the Afghan war has begun coming home.

title: MILLROSE VAULT WAS EVENT TO REMEMBER
description: The pole vault confusion and controversy in Friday night's Wanamaker Millrose Games is gone, but hardly forgotten.

title: ON THE ROPES
description: Now that the Edmonton Oilers have been swept in their three-game regular-season series with Washington, it should be apparent that they have the Capitals right where they want them.

title: Dr. Cornelis de Kiewit, Ex-Head of 2 Colleges
description: Dr. Cornelis W. de Kiewit, a retired president of the University of Rochester and a historian of South Africa, died of cancer Saturday at Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital in Arlington. He was 83 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: Periodical Nuggets
description: Anyone who keeps old magazines around the house understands the peculiar attraction of learning anew that the United States and China have established relations or that the Beatles have severed theirs.

title: REGULATION OF BANKING ON THE RISE
description: Contrary to the Reagan Administration's goal of reducing Government regulation, Federal banking agencies have been moving toward more regulation and supervision of commercial banks and thrift institutions.

title: Telltale Meteorites
description: Since 1969 Antarctica has been recognized as the richest hunting ground for meteorites in the world. A new study shows that meteorites found in Antarctica are not only more numerous than those found elsewhere; they are also chemically different.

title: AN INQUIRY INTO ELECTION VIOLENCE AWAITS THE END OF THE GAME
description: As promised, a special investigation team sent by the Government to look into the slayings of political opposition figures in the Quirino region was in that area of northern Luzon Province this morning.

title: PROFITS SEEN BY 2D QUARTER
description: For decades, there has been a mystique about the Inland Steel Company. It was thought to be a little more savvy and more technologically sophisticated than its domestic competitors.

title: KIRKLAND JOINS IN PARENT UNION'S CRITICISM OF HORMEL STRIKERS
description: The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. expressed strong reservations today about the tactics being used by meatpackers in Austin, Minn., in their six-month struggle with Geo. A. Hormel & Company.

title: CHIEF SAYS GATX IS BEST LEFT INTACT
description: James J. Glasser has spent the last seven years improving operations of the GATX Corporation while shedding its unprofitable manufacturing businesses. But now, as GATX is poised to enjoy an upswing in the economy, Mr. Glasser, chairman and chief executive, could soon have his company taken away from him.

title: VOTING IS MARKED BY ODD BOUNCES
description: Call it superstition, misplaced humility or simply dogged, if curious, opinion. Whatever the reason in individual cases may be, basketball coaches who cast votes for United Press International's weekly rankings of college teams are frequently given to expressing judgment that is, to say the least, unconventional.

title: AGRICULTURE ECONOMICS: BROAD AREA
description: STARVATION in parts of the third world and crop surpluses that depress farm prices in the Middle West have led to renewed interest in an old subject - agricultural economics.

title: ANALYSTS VIEW GROWTH STOCKS
description: DESPITE the sharp run-up of prices during the strong 1985 stock market, analysts say many bargains can still be found among growth issues.

title: IMPORTANT WEEK FOR SPARTAN STAR
description: Scott Skiles, the senior guard for Michigan State, will make two important public appearances later this week within less than 24 hours.

title: STRATEGIC GRAVEL DEFENSE: ROAD TO PEACE?
description: A BRITISH scientist known for his tongue-in-cheek but sometimes startlingly practical ''inventions'' has proposed an antimissile defense scheme which, he suggests, would be far more reliable than any of the plans being considered under President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: ANALGESIC MAKERS IN A BATTLE
description: An already competitive battle for the huge market for pain relievers can only become more complicated after the latest Tylenol poisoning episode.

title: Uranus and Ouranos
description: To the Editor:

title: DOLLAR AGAIN FALLS ABROAD
description: The dollar, which plunged to a seven-year low against the Japanese yen in Tokyo, fell against all major currencies except the Canadian dollar in European trading today.

title: SUPERSONICS 100, HAWKS 87
description: Gerald Henderson scored 23 points and had 10 assists and Jack Sikma had 20 points and 12 rebounds to spark Seattle.

title: ART PRIZE HONORS 'INDERRECOGNIZED'
description: Five prominent art-world figures, including the artist Robert Motherwell and the Guggenheim Museum director, Thomas Messer, will each personally endorse an artist who they feel is of great merit but not sufficiently known, as part of a new annual award established by a Manhattan real-estate entrepreneur and art collector.

title: CUT-RATE HELP
description: Ron Newman of the San Diego Sockers, coach of the injury-plagued West squad in tonight's Major Indoor Soccer League All-Star Game, takes a page - er, half a page - from the book written by the Chicago Bears: ''I thought of bringing in an acupuncturist from Japan. When I heard how much it cost, I called a dart thrower from Tijuana.''

title: SIGNIFIGANT RISE IN SEA LEVEL NOW SEEMS CERTAIN
description: MANY scientists are so sure that the sea level will rise visibly in the coming decades that they are advising planners to adopt new strategies now. A predicted rise in sea level of one foot within the next 30 to 40 years will drive much of the Atlantic and Gulf shoreline inward by a hundred feet and some of it by more than a thousand feet, according to marine geologists. The environmental and economic consequences will be felt much farther inland.

title: 'PAPER CHASE' CANCELED BY GRADUATION
description: ''The Paper Chase,'' the television series about a group of Harvard Law students that has had an unusual history since its premiere in 1978, has just completed filming its final five episodes for broadcast this summer. The series has been canceled by Showtime, the pay-cable network that has been broadcasting it since 1983, because both the network and and the program's creators felt the series had reached its logical conclusion with the graduation of the main characters.

title: INFLUENCING OTHERS: SKILLS ARE IDENTIFIED
description: WATCH any childhood battlefield. Some children are fighting, others -maybe just one - may be trying to settle it. That child, the mediator and not the combatants, is likely to develop and use the skills that will lead to the exercise of influence and the possession of power in adult life.

title: IRISH ISSUE: A LOOK AT BOTH SIDES
description: THE essential thing about ''Northern Ireland: At the Edge of the Union'' is that it's a fine, as well as grim, piece of work. It should be seen. The controversy of last summer is secondary; indeed, the controversy ought never to have happened. The BBC documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, takes a defensible, supportable position: Ulster extremists on both sides look and sound alike.

title: Republicans at Exhibition
description: Several prominent Republicans will be on hand when a gallery of 12 oils depicting outstanding black officials - including Cleveland's Carl B. Stokes, the first black mayor of a major city, and Mary McLeod Bethune, the first black female adviser for the National Youth Administration - is unveiled tonight at the Sheraton Grand, 525 Jersey Avenue N.W. Among those who have accepted invitations are Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader; Frank Fahrenkopf, chairman of the Republican National Committee, and Representatives John Paul Hammerschmidt of Arkansas and James H. Quillen and John J. Duncan of Tennessee. TreasAttorney General Edwin Meese 3d say they may drop by.

title: CHANCE ENCOUNTER LED TO WORLD WAR II NOVEL
description: Richard Wiley's first novel, ''Soldiers in Hiding,'' has been acclaimed for its realistic descriptions of World War II's Pacific Theater, although the author, a member of the postwar generation, was born just a few months before Japan surrendered.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: FIREFIGHTER TEST ALTERED
description: A Federal judge has once again modified the way in which the city's firefighters are chosen, invalidating the scores of a written test that, along with a physical examination, determine a candidate's rank in the hiring list for the Fire Department.

title: STAMFORD BARGAIN: PARKING TICKETS
description: Let others clip supermarket coupons. These bargain hunters collect parking tickets.

title: PUT A '?' ON HIS CHEST
description: Early in the 1984 season, Lawrence Taylor had played another routinely spectacular game. In the Giants' 17-14 victory over the Tampa Bay Bucs, the All-Pro linebacker had sacked the quarterback Steve DeBerg four times and also hurried him into an interception. After that game, at their adjoining lockers, the linebacker Harry Carson was talking about his teammate.

title: Tougher Inspections Of Boeing 747's Ordered
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today required all domestic airlines to make closer inspections of aging Boeing 747 jumbo jets, revising requirements ordered two weeks ago.

title: 'CANDIDE' WILL OPEN 1986 CITY OPERA SEASON
description: The 1986 season of the New York City Opera will open on July 1 at the New York State Theater with a week's run of Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide.'' Another week of ''Candide'' will close the 20-week season in November, after 136 performances of 18 operas.

title: BRILL'S LEGAL NEWSPAPERS
description: LAWYERS, take note: Steven Brill is on the move again.

title: France Presses U.S. To Find Duvalier a Home
description: France continued to press the United States today to take Jean-Claude Duvalier, the former President of Haiti, off its hands.

title: STEEL WORKERS OPEN PICKETING OF CAN MAKERSS
description: The United Steelworkers of America set up picket lines today against the nation's four largest can makers after rejecting offers of $400 year-end bonuses instead of wage increases.

title: 'SUNDAY IN THE PARK,' PRESENTED ON SHOWTIME
description: IF you saw the show on Broadway, the television production of ''Sunday in the Park With George'' should revive fond memories of a very special evening in the theater. If you didn't, be prepared to wonder what all the testimonials and awards were about. Being unveiled on pay cable's Showtime this evening at 8, this version of the Stephen Sondheim musical falls curiously and at times distressingly flat. In the process of being transferred from stage to a small screen, much of the delicate magic has been clipped.

title: LENDL, CONNORS POST TRIUMPHS
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia had trouble finishing off Jimmy Arias today in the fourth round of the Lipton International Players championship, but he finally won the match, 6-1, 7-5, on his seventh match point.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PEOPLE OF CHANCE. Gambling in American Society From Jamestown to Las Vegas. By John M. Findlay. Illustrated. 272 pages. Oxford University Press. $19.95. IN 1612, when the fortunes of its plantation at Jamestown were foundering, the Virginia Company in London fell back on the expedient of raising fresh capital by organizing a lottery. John M. Findlay takes this as a symbolic starting point for his study of gambling in American history. From the very outset, he maintains, the advancing frontier of American culture has been marked by an exceptional readiness to bet on the future - and to bet on lots of lesser things as well. So doggedly does he iterate this thesis (and, on the whole, so convincingly) that by the time you get very far into ''People of Chance,'' the spirit of the frontier and the spirit of gambling have come to seem virtually synonymous.

title: Topics; On the Shoals Turtle Government
description: A year ago the ferryboat A. Regina, headed for the Dominican Republic, plowed onto a coral reef near Mona, an uninhabited Puerto Rican island. The 330-foot vessel still lies there, threatening the habitat of several hundred hawksbill sea turtles.

title: KOHL IS UNDER INVESTIGATION IN POLITICAL CORRUPTION CASE
description: A West German prosecutor announced today that Chancellor Helmut Kohl was under investigation in a political corruption case.

title: EXOTIC GEOMETRY POINTS TO A THEORY OF HEAT
description: Using an exotic branch of mathematics, a group of physicists has devised a novel way to explain how heat fundamentally moves through most solid matter.

title: TACTICAL PREPAREDNESS TURNS A TRAP AROUND ON TRAPPER
description: The 48th Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk aan Zee, the Netherlands, was a triumph for the 21-year-old British grandmaster Nigel Short, who put distance between himself and the rest of the field with a 9 1/2-3 1/2 score.

title: SOUTH LEBANON IS CALLED EXPLOSIVE
description: The situation in southern Lebanon is more explosive than it has been since Israel invaded the country in 1982, according to United Nations peacekeeping officials in the southern Lebanese city of Tyre and in Jerusalem.

title: SOME EARLY SIGNS OF FALL FROM 7TH AVENUE
description: Waist-length jackets are due for a comeback. Clean, spare clothes built closer to the body are presented with a minimum of decoration. And frankly fake furs have climbed to high fashion ground.

title: FIVE YEARS AFTER KIDNAPPING, GIRL CELEBRATES 10TH BIRTHDAY AT HOME
description: Inez Jean Sanders has celebrated her 10th birthday at home, five years after being kidnapped by an acquaintance of her mother.

title: COKE TO SHED A VIDEO UNIT
description: Embassy Home Entertainment, a video cassette company, said Friday that Andre Blay, its chairman and chief executive, intends to buy the company from its parent, the Coca-Cola Company, for less than $80 million.

title: DEBUNKING THE MYTH ABOUT WHAT COMPUTERS DO
description: ''IF only girls were as easy to understand as computers,'' said a 14-year-old boy who apparently was trying simultaneously to learn how to deal with computers and girls.

title: THE LONG UNHAPPY LIFE OF MISS SCHAFF
description: When word of Miss Schaff's $105,000 kindness spread, townspeople here all had the same question: Who was Miss Schaff? Town officials could not say.

title: EAST GERMAN ENTRIES
description: Eleven East German women and five men have entered the USA/ Mobil national indoor track and field championships Feb. 28 in Madison Square Garden. They include Marita Koch, who on Sunday in Senftenberg, East Germany, ran 200 meters in 22.33 seconds, a world indoor best for women. The East German women's contingent includes three world-record holders outdoors - Miss Koch (200 and 400 meters), Sabina Busch (400-meter hurdles) and Heike Drechsler (long jump).

title: TWO EXHIBITIONS SHOW ARTWORK BY 71 WOMEN
description: Two exhibitions of artwork by 71 women are on view through the end of this month. There are 43 artists displayed in ''Transforming Landscape,'' an exhibition organized by Bernice D'Vorzon, Sandra Langer and Idelle Weber.

title: UNION CHIEFS DISCUSS VAN ARSDALE SUCCESSOR
description: When labor leaders gather in New York City this week for the funeral of Harry Van Arsdale Jr., they will salute a man who maintained the appearance of power for a decade after the reality of it had largely passed him by.

title: 19th-Century Yiddish Stories Are Printed by Soviet Union
description: The Soviet Union has brought out a collection of the 19th-century works of Mendele Moikher Sforim, one of the classic writers in Yiddish literature, according to Tass, the Soviet Government press agency.

title: Stamp et Stamp
description: A stamp commemorating the 100th anniversary of the placement of the Statue of Liberty will be unveiled simultaneously in American and French editions Friday morning.

title: PERU WARNS ON RETALIATION
description: President Alan Garcia Perez has warned that his hard-line foreign debt stance could drive the world banking community to retaliate with stiff, unprecedented sanctions against Peru.

title: SHOOTING FOR PERFECT COLORS
description: PHILIP JOHNSON makes it all sound so essential. He says he knows the colors he wants for his buildings but paint companies don't supply them. That's where Donald Kaufman has made himself indispensable. He mixes the paints.

title: Moynihan and Cancer Expert Honored
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and Dr. Lewis Thomas, a prize-winning author, were among five recipients of a new international award for communicating knowledge, it was announced yesterday by the Encyclopedia Britannica, which has established the prize.

title: EX-SOFT-DRINK LEADER GETS AHEAD IN APPAREL
description: Richard Q. Armstrong, who first made his mark as a leader in the soft-drink business, is now moving ahead in the apparel industry.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 18, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, Scientific and Technical Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1986
description: International

title: Let's Choose Peace Over War in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: WITH LOBBIES IN FULL CRY, CALIFORNIA DEBATES REPEALING MULTINATIONAL TAX
description: While most states are scrambling to replace money that they expect to lose under the new Federal budget-balancing bill, most of this state's political leaders support a bill that would lead to a revenue loss estimated at $300 million to $600 million.

title: Hearing Mantises
description: Praying mantises have long been thought to be deaf. But two scientists from Cornell University have discovered that the insects have a single hearing structure in the center of their bellies that the scientists have dubbed a ''cyclopean ear.''

title: MAYOR PLEDGES TO ENFORCE FULLY RESIDENCY RULE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would dismiss any city official found to be violating his rule that commissioners, heads of agencies and high-level officials must live in the city.

title: SWANSON, NEW ABC CHIEF, PROVES DEFT
description: The new president of ABC Sports, Dennis Swanson, invited about 15 reporters to lunch last week. The food was good. Swanson was harder to define.

title: The Reagan Foundation
description: The trustees of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation, formed a year ago to finance and build Mr. Reagan's Presidential library on the campus of Stanford University and a Center for Public Affairs in the San Francisco Bay Area, have announced a 101-member board of directors described in a press release as ''a distinguished bipartisan group of some of the nation's leading citizens.''

title: STAGE: 'CONSTANT WIFE,' A MAUGHAM COMEDY
description: ''D RAWING-ROOM comedy'' has long served as a dismissive phrase in serious circles. It calls up shallow characters uttering brittle lines about frivolous affairs. Yet from that silly provenance, adept playwrights have wrought smart theater, and as the stylish production of ''The Constant Wife,'' now at the Equity Library Theater, demonstrates, W. Somerset Maugham was highly adept.

title: SALE OF NEW 2-YEAR NOTES EXPECTED
description: Treasury financings this week consist of today's auctions of new bills, followed tomorrow by a $9.5 billion sale of new two-year notes.

title: Deliberations Hit Snag In Racketeering Case
description: Three jurors in the trial of five people accused of racketeering found news articles about the case between boxes of evidence today, the first day of deliberations by the panel, which was sequestered.

title: ARMED WITH NEW DRUG, TEAM FLIUES TO HEART VICTIMS
description: The call comes in to Emergency Services at 6:45 A.M. A 73-year-old man who was shoveling snow the previous day is suffering severe chest pains, in all probability a heart attack.

title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS RAISED BY TYLENOL INQUIRY
description: On Saturday, Feb. 8, 23-year-old Diane Elsroth died after taking two Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules laced with potassium cyanide. The pills had been purchased at an A.&P. store in Bronxville, N.Y. An investigation was begun involving two local law-enforcement agencies, the Federal Food and Drug Administration and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 2 NEW YORK PREMIERES
description: Two New York premieres will highlight a performance by the Adirondack Chamber Players on April 9 at 7:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall. The concert is the last of the season in the series ''New Music for Young Ensembles.''

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: EXCEPT for the purple and green spikes of the punksters, there hasn't been much excitement in hairdos in recent years. So when Sergio Valente came to New York last week, we thought we'd ask him if there was anything new on the European front. This is, of course, not the Sergio Valente whose label is in jeans but the one who has beauty salons in Rome and in Bergdorf Goodman.

title: HOPE SEEN IN PRETORIA DEBT DISPUTE
description: When South African officials meet with foreign bankers here Thursday, the chances for reaching an agreement will be better than at any time since Pretoria froze its loan repayments last September.

title: LOST IN HISTORY: CHIPS PATHFINDER
description: ANYONE who has read anything at all about personal computing has heard ''the chip'' heralded as what made it all possible. True enough, with the equivalent of thousands of electronic components crammed onto a fingernail-size wafer of silicon, the chip is not only what made personal computing possible, but what launched the third industrial revolution, replete with a profusion of unbelievably inexpensive electronic consumer goods.

title: SELF-HELP ADVISERS PROFITING FROM FARMERS' WOES
description: For fees up to $1,000, financially troubled farmers across the Middle West are buying unorthodox legal advice on how to save their property from foreclosure by banks or other creditors.

title: BUCKS 111, SIXERS 106
description: Sidney Moncrief scored 28 points, including two free throws with 27 seconds left in the game, to lead Milwaukee to its fifth straight victory.

title: SYRACUSE BEATS PITT, 69-62
description: Dwayne Washington scored 23 points, including 6 key points down the stretch, as Syracuse held off Pittsburgh, 69-62, tonight to remain atop the Big East.

title: FUTURE OF CAPSULE PRODUCTS UNCERTAIN AT DRUG CONCERNS
description: Several manufacturers of over-the-counter pharmaceutical products said yesterday that they were undecided on whether to join Johnson & Johnson, the maker of Tylenol pain relievers, in halting production of their capsuled products.

title: FLYERS BEAT JETS AS EKLUND STARS
description: Pelle Eklund scored a goal and made two assists today as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Winnipeg Jets, 8-4.

title: AFTER THATCHER, KINNOCK DOESN'T SPRING TO MIND
description: If British politics were still being played in the traditional way as a two-party game, then the leader of Her Majesty's Opposition would be the obvious and automatic beneficiary of the waning of a Prime Minister's popularity and power such as Margaret Thatcher is now having to endure at the end of her seventh year in office.

title: LEBANESE GROUP ATTACKS ISRAELIS, SEIZES 2 SOLDIERS
description: Lebanese guerrillas ambushed a group of Israeli soldiers today in Israel's so-called security zone in southern Lebanon, and reports here said two of the Israelis were captured.

title: ASSESSING THE DOW'S STRENGTH
description: Steven Kroll was a rare breed on Wall Street last week. While the stock market continued its march toward higher and higher ground, he was feeding the new buyers with the sale of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of issues out of his portfolio.

title: LAPSE ON WARNING AT NASA 'STARTLED' PANEL OF INQUIRY
description: An ''alarming lack of communication'' in the space agency before the launching of the shuttle Challenger was the primary motive behind the request to exclude top agency officials from major roles in the investigation, a source close to the Presidential commission studying the disaster said today.

title: Russian Feared Drowned In New Zealand Sinking
description: A Soviet seaman was missing and believed drowned today after the sinking of the Soviet cruise liner Mikhail Lermontov on Sunday.

title: WHITES FIRE ON BLACKS AT FACTORY AMID RIOTING NEAR JOHANNESBURG
description: White civilians armed with shotguns and pistols said today that they had opened fire on blacks who attacked their factory in this black township, possibly wounding at least one black.

title: FRENCH REPORT LIBYANS RAID AN AIRPORT IN CHAD
description: An airplane described by the French as Libyan dropped a bomb today on the airport in Ndjamena, the capital of Chad.

title: Icon and O Rings
description: After the explosion of the shuttle, and in the outpouring of emotional tribute to the seven astronauts lost in that fearful fireball, most Americans probably believed the cause would be found in some bloodless malfunction of technology - a failure of hardware betraying the genius and judgment of human engineers.

title: ACTOR, DIRECTOR AND AUTHOR
description: Howard da Silva, the actor, director, producer and author, whose show-business career spanned more than 55 years, died of lymphoma Sunday at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1986
description: The Economy

title: MUSIC: LINCOLN CENTER GROUP
description: THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center seems to be taking its duties more seriously. Most of the group's recent concerts have been distinguished by unusual repertory and diligent, well-thought-through performances. Sunday afternoon's program in Alice Tully Hall contained only one work that could remotely be considered a warhorse -Beethoven's Trio in C minor (Op. 1, No. 3) - and three less known works: Prokofiev's ''Overture on Hebrew Themes'' for Clarinet, String Quartet and Piano (Op. 34), Elgar's Quintet for Piano and Strings in A minor (Op. 84) and the world premiere of William Thomas McKinley's Sonata for Viola and Piano.

title: Rockefeller as Washington
description: Each year since 1901, the Senate has commemorated Washington's Birthday with a reading of his farewell address of Sept. 19, 1796, in which he withdrew from running for a third term. In the 7,641-word speech, read yesterday in 44 minutes by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Washington magisterially and modestly proclaimed, ''The acceptance of, and continuance thereto in the office to which your suffrages have twice called me, have been a uniform sacrifice of inclination to the opinion of duty, and to a deference for what appeared to be your desire.''

title: Sadi Koylan, a Poet, Is Dead; Broadcast News in Turkish
description: Sadi Koylan, a retired announcer who broadcast news to Turkey for the Voice of America, died of cancer Friday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 67 years old. Mr. Koylan was a Voice of America broadcaster from 1949 to 1972. He was also a poet, writing in Turkish, and a translated into Turkish works by T. S. Eliot, William Butler Yeats and Arthur Rimbaud.

title: AIDS CLUE IN SALIVA
description: HARVARD researchers have reported finding antibodies to the AIDS virus in the saliva of individuals who also have such antibodies in their blood. This finding, they said, may help unravel some of the puzzles associated with acquired immune deficiency syndrome and saliva.

title: HOUSE PANEL ON PAYMENTS
description: The chairman of a House Government Operations Subcommittee charged Sunday that Federal officials operating the system disbursing $1 trillion a year in Government payments have failed to solve its dangerous security problems.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about ''American Almanac,'' NBC's planned prime time news magazine, incorrectly described the departure of Robert Chandler as a vice president of CBS News. He took early retirement before Van Gordon Sauter replaced Edward M. Joyce as president of CBS News.

title: UNCERTAINTY ON INTEREST RATES
description: As Treasury bond yields have declined to their lowest level since August 1979, analysts have begun debating whether the Federal Reserve Board will soon begin pushing for a drop in short-term interest rates or will continue to hold rates at about the same levels that have prevailed since mid-1985.

title: Of Cloak and Scholar
description: It is not immoral and is certainly useful for the Central Intelligence Agency to seek the advice of American scholars and even to subsidize some research. The important thing, for academe, is that its associations be openly acknowledged.

title: SURGE IN INDIANS' DIABETES LINKED TO THEIR HISTORY
description: Carol Yuselew went to the Indian Health Service Hospital here three years ago and received confirmation of her fears: She was diabetic, and her heavy weight and relative inactivity were almost certainly the cause.

title: ECONOMIC FORECASTS BRIGHTER AS RESULT OF OIL PRICE SLUMP
description: Prospects for the nation's economy this year, which many experts found troubling as recently as a month ago, have abruptly brightened with the sharp decline in oil prices.

title: Train Crash Kills 15 in Chile
description: At least 15 people were killed and 190 were injured tonight when two passenger trains collided on a bridge 20 miles east of Valparaiso, the Government said. Terrorists damaged the bridge last year, leaving only one track.

title: UPSETS CLOUD ROAD TO DERBY
description: The road to the Kentucky Derby May 3 appeared no clearer today after My Prince Charming and Ensign Rhythm posted upset victories in divisions of the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

title: RIGHTS TO A MYTHICAL TEXAN DISPUTED IN A LAWSUIT
description: For The Dallas Times Herald, a mythical Texan named Joe Bob Briggs with every possible bias is proving to be a source of enduring trouble, which is probably just the way Joe Bob would want it.

title: GOODRICH LOSES $5.2 MILLION
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said that it lost $5.2 million in the final quarter of 1985, slightly less than the $7.2 million loss a year earlier.

title: U.S. ENVOY MEETS PHILIPPINE RIVALS
description: President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, met separately today with President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Corazon C. Aquino, both of whom said later that the American had assured them he was here only to gather information in the aftermath of the presidential election.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the About New York column in some editions on Saturday misidentified Richard J. Walton, a patron helping to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the Lion's Head bar. He was the Vice-Presidential candidate of the Citizens Party in 1984.

title: SHOULD THERE BE A MEANS TEST FOR VETERANS' CARE?
description: Congress appears close to agreement on a proposal that would require many veterans to show financial need as a condition of receiving medical care benefits from the Veterans Administration.

title: RETIRED NUMBERS
description: Cheryl Miller will have her jersey retired by the University of Southern California in a ceremony Thursday night at halftime of the men's game against Stanford. The women's team, for whom the 6-foot-3-inch senior has been an all-American for three years, faces the Stanford women earlier in the evening. Miss Miller was a member of the United States women's basketball team, which won a gold medal in the 1984 Olympic Games.

title: ASTRONAUTS ACTIVE IN QUEST FOR ANSWERS ABOUT DISASTER
description: The astronauts whose lives depend on the safety of the space shuttle are emerging as active participants in the search for answers to the Challenger explosion. They are expressing their sense of urgency that a safer space program must come out of the shuttle disaster.

title: N.A.I.A. DROPS AD
description: The executive director of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics says a newspaper advertisement that takes a slap at big-time college sports while praising the N.A.I.A. is in poor taste and will not be repeated. ''I did not write that ad copy and I'm not particularly proud of it.

title: COKE AIMS ITS ADS AT 2 MARKETS
description: SINCE the Coca-Cola Company did its celebrated flip-flop last summer and revived the original formula of its flagship brand as Coke Classic, its advertising strategy has been in something of a shambles.

title: G.M. BUILDS ADVANCED ENGINE
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it had developed an advanced technology four-cylinder engine with performance exceeding most of the V-8 engines in use today. The new engine, called the ''Quad Four,'' will be installed in some Oldsmobile and Buick models starting with 1988 models.

title: ST. JOHN'S FACES TEST
description: St. John's could have a steep climb tonight when it faces Villanova at the Wildcats' $9.5 million fieldhouse, which opened on Feb. 1.

title: CONCERT: PRAGUE ORCHESTRA
description: MUSIC lovers who have always secretly wondered what it was, exactly, that conductors did could have had most of their questions answered by the Prague Chamber Orchestra's Sunday afternoon concert at Avery Fisher Hall. This small orchestra functions without a podium leader; downbeats and entrances are signaled by the first violin.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Company, elected Robert S. Mason executive vice president.

title: GREEN SHEKEL AQUEDUCT WINNER
description: Green Shekel, a 4-year-old gelding, scored a front-running half-length victory yesterday in the $67,600 Sporting Plate Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct.

title: TWO DANCE PREMIERES
description: Two dance premieres will be presented by Eric Barsness and Dancers in performances from Feb. 27 to March 1 at St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue at 10th Street.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Second game in a home-and-home series. The Cavaliers beat the Knicks yesterday, 111-97, at Richfield, Ohio.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LATIN IN MANHATTAN The phrase ''Latin jazz'' generally refers to the entire panoply of jazz performed by Central and South American musicians. The expression conceals the fact that ''Latin'' music is, for example, actually Brazilian music, or Cuban music, or Dominican music, or Puerto Rican music, or slight mixtures. Cuban musicians were prominent here in the 1940's and 1950's, after which widespread interest in their music waned. In the 1970's, however, Cuban and Puerto Rican musicians came to the forefront again, and what the general public heard was something called salsa, a term some say means Cuban-plus-jazz. And these days there are many terms - Latin rock, Latin soul, rock salsa - supposedly designating stylistic combinations.

title: AIDS Victim 'Nervous' About Return to School
description: Ryan White, an Indiana teen-ager who has AIDS, said in a television appearance yesterday that he just wanted to be treated ''like everybody else.'' His mother said that might not be possible because of objections still being raised by other parents.

title: BROWN PLANS TO STAY
description: On Feb. 2, Dale Brown, the basketball coach at Louisiana State University, said in a televised interview that he was considering leaving the profession. But yesterday Brown said he would return to L.S.U. next season, declaring, ''I am proud to be a part of this team. I could never quit them.'' L.S.U. is 19-8 after beginning the season with a 14-game winning streak.

title: Secondo Proto, 69, Violinist With City Opera for 30 Years
description: Secondo Proto, a violinist with the New York City Opera for more than 30 years and its orchestra personnel manager since 1960, died last Tuesday at Christ Hospital in Jersey City. He was 69 years old and lived in Weehawken.

title: SHOPPERS HONOR WASHINGTON BY THRONGING TO CITY STORES
description: The Yonkers School Board today unanimously approved a proposal to integrate the city's public schools a day before the plan must be submitted to a Federal judge.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS REPORTS A LOSS
description: People Express Inc. yesterday reported a loss of $38.2 million for the fourth quarter of 1985, compared with a loss of $14.1 million in the corresponding 1984 period. The airline reported $270.5 million in operating revenues, up 60.6 percent from $168.4 million in the 1984 quarter.

title: 7-FOOTER HAS A LOWER PROFILE
description: The requirements for his college degree have been completed.

title: DARTMOUTH TRUSTEES SUPPORT PRESIDENT IN A TRYING WINTER
description: The trustees of Dartmouth said in a statement today that they would try to improve communication with the faculty, but that they strongly backed the college president, David T. McLaughlin, the object of recent faculty and student complaints.

title: Secularization Plays Into Kahaneist Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Whitbread Account To MacNamara, Clapp
description: Whitbread North America last week named MacNamara, Clapp & Klein to handle the $15 million account for its Buckingham Wile and Fleischmann Distilling divisions. It is the largest new account won by the $25 million agency since its founding in 1981.
