title: IN NEW SONGS, ELVIS COSTELLO REDISCOVERS THE SIMPLE WAY
description: ELVIS COSTELLO, the most talented songwriter to emerge out of the ferment of English new-wave rock, has gone back to basics on his excellent new album, ''King of America'' (Columbia).

title: AMERICA'S CUP SAILORS HITCH THEIR HOPES TO WINGED KEELS
description: Don Huseman makes keels for sailboats. Until last year, most of the keels that he created from molten lead were conventional in design -mostly linear, wedge-shaped forms that were bolted to the bottoms of boats. Now the keels he makes are sprouting wings, and, in some cases, bulbed-noses as well.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch last Thursday from Hanover, N.H., about The Dartmouth Review misstated the affiliation of Gregory A. Fossedal, a founder of the magazine. He continues to support The Review but is no longer a director.

title: Armstrong Rubber Shift
description: The Armstrong Rubber Company, the major supplier of tires to Sears, Roebuck & Company, yesterday named Frank R. O'Keefe Jr. to succeed James A. Walsh as chief executive.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Announced that the team had won its arbitration case with Rich Gedman, catcher, and lost its arbitration case with Marty Barrett, second baseman. Re-signed Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, pitcher, to a one-year contract.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Overmatched
description: After 7-foot-6-inch Manute Bol blocked 10 shots in a Washington victory over the Los Angeles Clippers, Cedric Maxwell acknowledged that Bol took him out of his game: ''It was like David and Goliath, and we didn't have anybody out there with a slingshot.''

title: Iraqi Says Offensive Unmasks Iranian 'Lies'
description: Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq today called Iran's nine-day-old offensive into Iraq a ''grave escalation'' that ''unmasks the lies and prevarications which Iran has used throughout six years of continued aggression against Iraq.''

title: SAILOR GETS LIFE IN KNIFE SLAYING OF OFFICER AT SEA
description: A black sailor was sentenced today to life in prison for stabbing a white lieutenant to death aboard a Navy frigate at sea. The penalty could have been death.

title: Beck Is Set to Return
description: Although there is still some question in his mind as to how he will react to the first blows he delivers and the first ones he absorbs, Barry Beck is coming back. After missing the last 43 games with a badly bruised left shoulder, the captain of the Rangers will return to the lineup this week, perhaps as early as tomorrow night when the Rangers play the St. Louis Blues at Madison Square Garden.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: The latest year results include the operations of Lerner Stores since its acquisition in April 1985.

title: No Riviera for Doc
description: In the old days you went to the Riviera, and nobody made a fuss about it. A man needed a place to go when the weight of years began to slow his reflexes, and it was nice having the Riviera to look forward to.

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a $39 million pretax charge for a voluntary severance program.

title: Alpine Weed Banned Through Latin Error
description: Legislators thought they were acting to ban poisonous jimsonweed seeds in schoolyards last week, but they mixed up the Latin and banned a harmless plant that grows in the mountains of Europe.

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Games Children Play
description: At the Children's Museum of Manhattan yesterday children romped through games ranging from ancient Egyptian ones dating back to 2000 B.C. up to those played on a computer.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share figures reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in November.

title: Rank Bidding For Granada
description: The Rank Organization, the British film, television, hotel and catering group, announced today a billion-dollar takeover bid for the Granada Group, which is known for producing such television programs as ''Brideshead Revisited'' and ''The Jewel in the Crown.''

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income, after a one-time gain of $14.5 million from the sale of an aircraft.

title: HEALTHAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DIXON TICONDEROGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $205,427 from termination of certain pension plans. c-Including a gain of $28,018 from the sale of the discontinued Dixon Sintaloy division.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: HUNGARIAN-style spatzle, or egg and flour dumplings, are easy to make with the inexpensive utensil pictured here. Sold by Paprikas Weiss, a Hungarian food emporium in Manhattan, it is made of tin with a wooden handle for cranking.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ECONOMIC TROUBLES WORSEN FOR MANILA
description: The Philippines' economic troubles worsened today in the aftermath of the recent presidential election as the country's currency fell to its lowest point in years.

title: Artificial Heart Moved In Recipient in Arizona
description: Doctors today repositioned the second artificial heart implanted in a woman to remove an obstruction to an important vein.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,743,000 from the sale by an affiliate, Lowe Howard- Spink of its own stock.

title: 2 OFFICIALS' DEAL ON A PARKING LOT IS UNDER REVIEW BY CITY AND U.S.
description: A real-estate partnership involving William C. Brennan, the former State Supreme Court justice who was convicted of bribe-taking, and Anthony R. Ameruso, the city's Transportation Commissioner, is under investigation by Federal and city authorities.

title: STAGE, SCREEN AND TV ACTOR
description: The actor Paul Stewart, who made his film debut in Orson Welles's ''Citizen Kane'' and went on to a lengthy career in movies, theater, radio and television, died of heart failure Monday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: IN WINES, DOES A WOMAN'S NOSE KNOW?
description: THE ritual is familiar. A waiter seats a couple, hands each a menu but gives him the wine list. He and she decide on the dishes. He chooses the wine. But the odds are that if she chose the wine to match the food, they might enjoy the meal more.

title: CONQUEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $3.2 million from the sale of a Canadian subsidiary. c-Including a net gain of $1.1 million from the sale of a Canadian subsidiary.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After a charge of $10 million for estimated costs of disposing of two warehouses. c-After a loss of $4.7 million from the sale of the company's apparel division.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Rise
description: Treasury bond prices rose for the sixth consecutive day as falling oil prices and hopes for an easier monetary policy were enough to entice investors and speculators.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE TO CAPITALS, 5-4
description: The two teams most likely to clash within the Patrick Division in the first round of the playoffs, the Islanders and the Washington Capitals, evened their series at two games apiece tonight at Nassau Coliseum. The Capitals won this contest, 5-4, largely on the strength of three unanswered second-period goals, but the way the Islanders saw it, the game was something of a dud.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After unusual pretax charges relate mainly to the company's withdrawal from the instant photography business of $551 million for the quarter and $561 million for the year. c-Net income.

title: Eggs for Udall
description: These days in the capital, government economy is absolutely everywhere. Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona got a package from the White House yesterday containing an orange wooden egg, destined presumably for the Easter egg roll on the South Lawn, and a green marker pen.

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VERMONT AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $10 million for restructuring for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MORE MOTHERS ARE WORKING
description: Increasing numbers of mothers, choosing to work outside the home, are leaving their children at home with baby sitters or in day-care centers, the Government says.

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANTI-MARCOS PRESSURE MOUNTING IN CONGRESS
description: Congressional pressure mounted today for an end to United States assistance to the Philippine Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, but the White House said it was ''far premature'' to cut off aid and close the two United States military bases there.

title: 'MASTERS OF DISASTER,' YOUNG CHESS WINNERS
description: YOU don't have to care at all about chess to care a great deal about the young players on ''The Masters of Disaster,'' celebrated tonight on Channel 13. They make up an all-black team from an Indianapolis elementary school who, starting with nothing more than the determination of a teacher-coach and their own unsuspected ability, became champions.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARARA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $292,600 for the quarter and $1,146,600 for the year. c-Including extraordinary gains of $1,413,000 for the quarter and $1,413,000 for the year. d-Net loss.

title: ROCKET ENGINEER DESCRIBES ARGUING AGAINST LAUNCHING
description: The top Morton Thiokol engineer present at the Kennedy Space Center before the Jan. 28 liftoff of the space shuttle Challenger said tonight that he had argued for hours with space agency officials not to launch the craft because of low temperatures.

title: DEERE & COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Yields Are Set By Platte River
description: The Platte River Power Authority of Colorado is offering $115.7 million of electric revenue bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7.79 percent for bonds due in 2016, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Dr. Richard Youtz, Professor And Researcher at Barnard
description: Dr. Richard P. Youtz, a retired Barnard College psychology professor who conducted research on whether fingertips can identify colors, died Thursday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Leonia, N.J.

title: KEY MARCOS ALLY IS INDICTED IN 1984 AMBUSH
description: A leading National Assembly supporter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was charged with murder today in connection with an ambush of opposition figures dating from the 1984 political campaign.

title: POWERFUL STORMS BATTER THE WEST
description: The most explosive storm system to hit the region in decades battered the West over a broad front today, causing flooding, mud slides, high winds and avalanches from central California to northern Utah.

title: MATTINGLY GETS $1.375 MILLION
description: Don Mattingly vividly recalls the paycheck he collected every two weeks during the summer of 1979. He was 18 years old, in his first season of professional baseball and playing at Oneonta, N.Y.

title: U.S. SEEKING DELAY IN REPUBLIC MERGER
description: The Justice Department suggested today that the proposed merger of Republic Airlines into Northwest Airlines could reduce competition on up to 45 routes served by both carriers.

title: U.P.S. IN DISPUTE WITH CITY OVER $1.2 MILLION IN TICKETS
description: The United Parcel Service owes more than $1.2 million in New York City parking fines, more than any other company or individual, according to city records.

title: DISCOVERIES
FARM LOAN SYSTEM'S HUGE LOSS
description: The Farm Credit System, the nation's largest agricultural lender, today announced a net loss of $2.69 billion for 1985, by far the biggest in the system's 70-year history.

title: State Department; Stalking a Perfect Embassy and Money to Build It
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said recently that in the wake of the Beirut bombings and other attacks on Americans, United States diplomats and their families ''are on the front lines - they are being shot at, they get killed and we owe it to them to do all we possibly can to see that a secure environment is created.''

title: LINK IS SOUGHT IN 5 CITY U. ROBBERIES
description: Five robberies in the last two months at two campuses of the City University - one of them a classroom holdup -have prompted the police to seek a link between the incidents.

title: Key Meeting For U.S.F.L.
description: The United States Football League's owners meet here today to affirm the league's proposed 18-game fall schedule that will end with the league championship game at Jacksonville, Fla., on Jan. 18. The agenda at the Grand

title: Accused I.R.A. Bomber Cleared for Extradition
description: More than four years after his arrest and jailing here, a panel of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today that William Joseph Quinn may be extradited to Britain to face trial on charges of murder of a police officer.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: WHAT AGE FOR A CHILD'S MUSIC LESSONS?
description: WHEN his daughter, Karen, was 3 years old, Bob DiYanni of Bedford, N.Y., saw a group of young violinists playing Mozart on the evening news.

title: Papal Power Injured
description: Papal Power, who finished third as the favorite in the second division of the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park Monday, came out of the race with an unspecified leg injury, and his jockey said he should have been scratched.

title: The Real Iacocca?
description: The removal of Lee A. Iacocca a week ago as chairman of a Federal advisory commission on the Statue of Liberty has caused some confusion on Capitol Hill.

title: REAGAN SAYS SUPPORT FOR THE CONTRAS MUST GO BEYOND 'BAND-AIDS'
description: President Reagan said today that the United States must do more to assist the Nicaraguan rebels, saying they could not fight the Government in Managua with ''Band-Aids and mosquito nets.''

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings were adjusted for 50 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 14.

title: AMERICAN WESTERN SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ST. PETER'S , SETON HALL TRIUMPH
description: Using a pass-oriented offense and its usual tenacious defense, St. Peter's surprisingly built a 10-point halftime lead against Dayton tonight, then even more surprisingly maintained the 10-point margin in the second half and won, 66-56, in a non-conference game at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Gannett Acquires Evening News
description: The Gannett Company completed its purchase of the Evening News Association, a $717 million transaction that gave Gannett ownership of The Detroit News and other media properties.

title: LEOPARD NO TIGER AT ROMANCE
description: Bisser, the Soviet snow leopard, is willing to chuffle. But, unfazed by the spirit of the Geneva summit, that is about all.

title: EMERY AIR FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontionued operations of $1,283,000 for the quarter and $1,575,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $60,000 for the quarter and $245,000 for the year.

title: INDUSTRY'S OPERATING RATE RISES
description: Industry operated at 80.8 percent of capacity in January, the third consecutive increase, but an improvement of only one-tenth of a percentage point over December's revised figure, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: HABIB MISSION: U.S. AIM IS COMPLEX
description: Philip C. Habib's mission to Manila is officially described as fact-gathering. But Reagan Administration officials say the special envoy will also be telling Philippine leaders about political realities in an effort to create space for compromise.

title: 2 Are Killed in Basque Area
description: Gunmen shot and killed two people outside Bidarray in France's Basque region and escaped in a car with Spanish license plates, the police said.

title: A Mayoral Mistake
description: It is an infrequent occurrence but it has happened, at a time when the uncharacteristic is approaching the commonplace at City Hall. Mayor Koch made a mistake.

title: Fiedler's Attorneys Ask For Dismissal of Charges
description: Representative Bobbi Fiedler's attorneys asked a judge today to dismiss political corruption charges against her on the ground that a prosecutor's undercover investigation improperly interfered with an election.

title: ABS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $303,000 from discontinued operations and including a tax benefit of $68,000, or 7 cents a share. c-Including a tax credit of $248,000, or 28 cents a share.

title: Afghan Students Evicted From Warsaw Embassy
description: Several dozen Afghan students were evicted today from the Afghan Embassy garage that they had occupied overnight in protest of orders from Kabul that some among them return home before finishing their studies.

title: 3 WITNESSES FOUND IN CONTEMPT FOR REFUSING TO TESTIFY ON ALIENS
description: A Federal judge today held three potential witnesses in contempt of court for refusing to testify here in the alien-smuggling trial of 11 church workers. The three were ordered confined to their homes for the duration of the trial.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Friday about a study of Broadway theater ticket prices misidentified the group that issued the report. It is now known as the League of American Theaters and Producers, no longer the League of New York Theaters and Producers.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FRENCH CAMPAIGN ABANDONS STAID TRADITION
description: A kind of chorus line of 10 men and 2 women, all of them smiling aggressively, their teeth flashing in the sun, are striding forward across a grassy field. The image, seen on a poster all over France these days, is casual and youthful, and that alone represents a change in the nature of political image-making in this country.

title: Helping the Displaced Worker to Get a New Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Rustin McIntosh Dies; Ex-Chief of Pediatrics
description: Dr. Rustin McIntosh, retired director of pediatrics at Babies Hospital, a unit of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, died Friday at his home in Tyringham, Mass. He was 91 years old.

title: Captors Threaten Killing
description: A Iranian-linked Moslem fundamentalist group responsibility today for seizing the two Israeli soldiers, and warned that it would kill one of them if Israel did not withdraw from southern Lebanon within 24 hours.

title: COSTS OF NAVY BASE ON S.I. QUESTIONED IN AUDIT BY G.A.O.
description: A Congressional audit has concluded that the new construction required to base the battleship Iowa and a six-ship support group at Staten Island would cost up to $362 million more than assigning them to existing piers at the naval base in Norfolk, Va.

title: Staten Island Basketball: Not Fancy, Just Good
description: Tom Keenan paused to assess his college baseball career. What kind of player was he? Well, he was a solid catcher at St. Francis in Brooklyn. He was not a star. He did his job. ''I was all right,'' he said, a smile creasing his cherubic face. ''I was no jerk out there.''

title: MCA TO BUY WOR-TV FOR A HEFTY $387 MILLION
description: MCA Inc. yesterday announced an agreement to acquire WOR-TV from Gencorp Inc. for $387 million, a price that analysts said reflected an unusually high premium over its established earning power.

title: EMANUEL PERLMUTTER, REPORTER
description: Emanuel Perlmutter, a reporter for The New York Times for more than 40 years and an authority on organized crime, died yesterday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn after a short illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Reston Land Venture
description: The Reston Land Corporation, said that it was forming a partnership with the Boston-based Himmel/MKDG real estate development and investment firm to design and build an 85-acre urban center in the planned community of Reston, Va. Himmel/ MKDG has been involved in the development of similar projects such as Boston's Copley Place, Chicago's Water Tower Place and Denver's City Center.

title: DANCE: PROGRAM OF SUSAN RETHORST
description: THERE were very few literal or readily apprehensible moments in a program of dances by Susan Rethorst performed on Monday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. But Miss Rethorst's dance has an inherent logic of its own. Partly, that logic is due to the performers' focused concentration and look of inevitability. Miss Rethorst further refines the work by having her dancers move in silence. She is also a fearless editor - that rare thing in dance today - who doesn't waste a moment on the stage.

title: What Misguided Overmanagement Did to Central Park's Ramble
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMO ON ROOSEVELT'S HEALTH MAY BE RELEASED, COURT SAYS
description: A physician's secret memorandum that could help end the mystery regarding Franklin D. Roosevelt's health when he sought a fourth term as President should be released to the doctor's former associate, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today.

title: The U.N. Today: Feb. 19, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Iran-Iraq conflict at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EDO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A NEW JERSEY man who says he is homosexual, in his late 30's and ''been around'' writes that his No. 1 health concern is AIDS. ''So far I have not experienced any symptoms, but every single day I worry about what might happen next week, next month, next year,'' he says, adding that he would like to take the test for AIDS virus antibodies but doesn't know if he ''could deal psychologically with a positive result.''

title: LOSING STREAK HITS SEVEN FOR KNICKS
description: It took only 31 hours, a small amount of time considering how many months it takes professional basketball teams to establish themselves as championship contenders, pretenders or something in between. Yet 33 hours was all the time the Cleveland Cavaliers needed to determine to which category the Knicks belong this season.

title: Dr. David Rutstein, 77, Dies; Ex-Harvard Department Chief
description: Dr. David D. Rutstein, retired head of the department of preventive medicine at the Harvard Medical School, died of a heart attack Friday in Boston. He was 77 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Union Sq. Renewal's Promise
description: SURVEYING the string of discount clothing, shoe, housewares, fabric and appliance stores that line East 14th Street near Union Square, it is hard to imagine the time in the late 1800's when this thoroughfare was the location for some of the city's most fashionable shops.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Crowning Tribute in Portugal
description: Portugal's democracy would have been strengthened no matter what the outcome of this week's runoff election for the first civilian President in six decades. Both Mario Soares, the Socialist, and Diogo Freitas do Amaral, the Christian Democrat, stand in the political center. But Mr. Soares's victory is particularly welcome, for no one has contributed more to his country's 12-year transition from Fascist dictatorship.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BLOWIN' IN THE WIND Few women lead jazz and popular music groups. One who does is Fostina Dixon, the woodwind instrumentalist whose ensemble is Winds of Change. Last year Miss Dixon toured with Roy Ayers, worked with the Charli Persip big band and put a lot of time into composing. She has also made television commercials and has worked with Marvin Gaye and Melba Liston.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $576,000 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations.

title: BROCK MIGHT CALL TEAMSTER INQUIRY
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock said today that Labor Department officials would inquire into whether the teamsters' union's way of selecting its top officials was illegal.

title: Popularity Increases For 30-Year Eurobonds
description: The Eurobond market, traditionally a financing arena where corporations and governments could sell fixed-rate bonds with maturities of no longer than 15 years, is turning increasingly hospitable to 30-year offerings.

title: CBS TO START 'WEST 57TH,' NEWS PROGRAM, IN APRIL
description: ''West 57th,'' CBS's long-delayed news magazine program, has now been scheduled to begin during the week of April 21, a week after the current prime-time season ends.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Just four months after being named the president of Spendthrift Farm Inc. in Lexington, Ky., Timothy T. Green has been dismissed for what officials of the prestigious thoroughbred farm called ''continuous neglect and misconduct.'' A $57 million deal to sell Spendthrift's stock fell through after Seattle Slew, former Triple Crown winner, was moved to another farm. . . . Jim Craig, the hero of the 1980 United States Olympic gold medal hockey team, has pleaded not guilty in Wareham, Mass., to charges of drunken driving and speeding after being arrested Sunday.

title: English Rewarded
description: Alex English is getting some statistical balance in his life. The 32-year-old Denver Nugget forward who has been leading the National Basketball Association in scoring with an average of 29.1 points a game, has signed a four-year contract that will reportedly make him one of the highest-paid players in the league and could bring him a total of $6.5 million.

title: Lloyd's Market Selects Leader
description: The Lloyd's of London insurance market said today that Alan Lord, former chairman of the Dunlop Corporation, would become chief executive following the resignation of Ian Hay Davison, effective March 1.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUNSHINE-JR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mercedes Raises Prices
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America said it had raised the prices on its 1986 models by 5.8 percent, effective for cars delivered to dealers beginning today. The subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G. of West Germany said the new prices range from $25,000 for its 190D 2.5 and 190E 2.3 sports sedans with manual transmissions to $62,110 for its limited-edition 560SEC coupe.

title: Understaffed Stores
description: To the Editor:

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,550,000 from retirement of notes.

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEACHER GIVEN A PROMOTION SAYS SHE GAVE CHIEF A LOAN
description: An assistant principal at a Brooklyn junior high school said yesterday that her supervisor had solicited $6,000 in loans from her while she was seeking a promotion. She said the supervisor had later refused to return the money, telling her that it should be considered a campaign contribution to his father, a member of the local school board.

title: SCREEN: A COUPLE'S 'PARTING GLANCES'
description: BILL SHERWOOD'S ''Parting Glances'' begins with a passionate reunion between Michael (Richard Ganoung) and Robert (John Bolger), who are lovers and roommates, and who do not appear to have been separated for longer than a day. Things continue on this same ecstatic note. Robert, it turns out, is being transferred to Africa by his employer. And the film follows him and Michael through an all-night round of farewell festivities, including a lengthy, well-populated send-off at the loft of a woman named Joan (Kathy Kinney).

title: Mintz and the Philadelphia
description: The violinist Shlomo Mintz will be guest soloist in the Philadelphia Orchestra's concert Tuesday at Carnegie Hall, in a performance of Bela Bartok's Second Violin Concerto.

title: Older Women and Men
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net charge of $29 million for the quarter and year from anticipated costs of asset and staff consolidations associated with the acquisition of American Hospital Supply Corporation last November. c-Net loss. d-After a net charge of $116 million for the quarter and year from consolidation of worldwide manufacturing operations and revaluation of certain assets.

title: CONTRACTOR SETTLES SUIT
description: A Navy contractor and its corporate parent, Talley Industries, have agreed to pay $2.5 million to the Government to settle a dispute involving charges of false billing on a contract for aircraft ejector seats, the Justice Department announced today.

title: Minnesota Guard to End Strike Duty This Week
description: Gov. Rudy Perpich today ordered the Minnesota National Guard to remove its troops from the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant by the end of the week.

title: OIL AND GASOLINE PRICES CONTINUE SLIDE
description: Oil prices fell sharply yesterday. The contract price of the major American crude oil closed under $15 a barrel, and contract prices for gasoline also declined.

title: Talks Seek to Avert A Canadian Can Strike
description: Talks between the United Steelworkers of America and a Canadian can-manufacturing company continued today in a effort to head off a strike, while a walkout by about 13,600 American workers entered its second day.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of $4,961,000 for the quarter and $26,515,000 for the year. c-Including realized gains on investments of $9,646,000 for the quarter and $18,678,000 for the year.

title: TACKY, TACKY, TACKY
description: The New York Cardinals. The combination of words curdles on the tongue like a puree of ice cream and pickles. The Queens Cardinals? The Flushing Cardinals? The Willets Point Cardinals? Gack.

title: STAGE: 'ANOTHER PARADISE,' REVISED
description: THE resilience of rural women in facing economic and emotional adversity is a familiar subject in movies and fiction, topography well cultivated by, for one, Sally Field. In Donna Spector's play ''Another Paradise,'' there is a moderately interesting variation on this theme. At a distance, her heroine brightly colors the bleakness of her background. A hopeful writer, this young Appalachian woman turns her back on the truth of deprivation and makes her upbringing in the tiny town of Paradise, Ky., seem like paradise itself.

title: SHCHARANSKY'S CELLMATES: VAST PAGEANT OF DISSENT
description: A Soviet teen-ager jailed for advocating the tenets of Western European Communists. A Latvian arrested for passing a petition for a nuclear-free zone in the Baltic republics.

title: Bubka, Part II
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union, the world-record holder in the pole vault, diminished the accomplishments of his American rival, Billy Olson, who has the best indoor vault.

title: Market Place; How to Choose A Mutual Fund
description: ''READ prospectus carefully before investing.'' That familiar advice is carried in advertisements of equity mutual funds, and any potential buyer should pay it heed. A prospectus can provide valuable information ranging from the fund's financial history and performance to exchange privileges and how to redeem shares.

title: Dr Pepper Reportedly for Sale
description: The owners of the Dr Pepper Company, the nation's fourth-largest soft-drink concern, are considering selling, according to industry sources. A number of companies, including Pepsico Inc. and R. J. Reynolds Industries, are believed to be interested in the Dallas-based Dr Pepper, the sources said.

title: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $3,955,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRACOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,089,000 for the quarter and $5,491,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $741,000 for the quarter and $982,000 for the year.

title: More Candidates, Please!
description: Governor Cuomo was here the other day, and in a waspish exchange with some reporters, suggested that Secretary of the Treasury James Baker would be a formidable Republican candidate for the Presidency in 1988.

title: Song Not a Hit With N.C.A.A.
description: Ron Harper gives basketball fans at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, something to rap about. And that's a problem, in the judgment of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, whose interpretation of the N.C.A.A. constitution has caused a rap-music number about Harper to be bounced from the airwaves.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''None of us want to go again until we understand what happened and have a fix.'' - Neil A. Armstrong, a former astronaut and the vice chairman of the Presidential commission on the shuttle explosion. [ B9:2. ]

title: F.B.I. FINDS NO TAMPERING WITH PACKAGING OF TYLENOL
description: A Federal official said yesterday that investigators examining bottles that held cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules had found ''no evidence of tampering'' so far with the containers or their packaging.

title: HARSH RESTRICTIONS AND HOSTILE PROTESTERS HAMPER THE PRESS
description: By official accounts, the death toll was 19. At the same time, there were unsubstantiated reports that it was as high as 80. But for a variety of reasons, no outsiders could seek to find the reality that lay, possibly, somewhere between the two.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1986
description: International

title: HAZLETON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $25,000 for the qu,rter and $82,000 for the 6 months, and after a loss of $54,000 on sale of assets of discontinued operations for the quarter and including a gain of $789,000 on the sale of assets of discontinued operations for the 6 months. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $78,000 for the quarter and $42,000 for the 6 months.

title: Gas Leak Shuts 2 Schools
description: Two elementary schools were ordered closed today as Northeast Utilities crews tried to find a natural-gas leak, authorities said. The schools, St. Mary's and Irving, were ordered shut as a precaution, the police said.

title: Anchorage Begins $57 Million Offer
description: A $57 million financing by Anchorage was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: IN MOSCOW, A SHUFFLE BEFORE CONGRESS
description: Viktor V. Grishin, ousted in December as the party chief of the city of Moscow, was also dropped today from the ruling Politburo. The move was likely to be the last major personnel shuffle before a party congress opening Tuesday.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $1,200,000,000 for the quarter and year for an adjustment for property and casualty reserves for the quarter and year, and including gains on investments of $70,600,000 for the quarter, $122,100,000 for the year. c-Net income including gains on investments of $18,500,000 for the quarter and $64,200,000 for the year.

title: A LEADER IN A CRISIS: JAMES EDWARD BURKE
description: In the days since Diane Elsroth died after taking cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol, James E. Burke, chairman of Johnson & Johnson, once again has had to deal with a public crisis. In doing so in a forthright way and with his decision to stop selling Tylenol in capsule form, Mr. Burke is receiving praise from analysts, marketing experts and from consumers themselves.

title: YOUNG FOREIGNERS TO BE BROUGHT TO U.S. AS CHILD-CARE WORKERS
description: THE Federal Government has approved a program to permit young foreigners to legally care for children in American homes.

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Smaller, Broader Tax Is Preferable to Oil-Import Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: Minebea Assails Trafalgar, Glen
description: Takami Takahashi, president of the Minebea Company, has denounced as ''empty bluster'' and ''price-hyping'' the legal and governmental filings made last week by Trafalgar Holdings Ltd. and Glen International P.L.C. of London, who are attempting to make a tender offer for the Tokyo-based manufacturer.

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $51,000 for the quarter and $61,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $23,000 for the quarter and $53,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. Seeks Hospital Sanction
description: The Reagan Administration is attempting for the first time to kick an entire hospital out of the Medicare system on the ground that it is providing substandard care.

title: DR. LESTER J. EVANS
description: Dr. Lester J. Evans, a retired medical and health consultant, died Monday at his home in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 88 years old and a former resident of Manhattan and Salisbury, Conn.

title: Northrop Net Off 48%
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it earned $29.2 million, or 63 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, down 48 percent from $56.2 million, or $1.22 a share, a year ago.

title: GTE Case Delayed
description: The trial of three men accused of conspiring to steal classified Pentagon documents for a military contractor, due to begin today, was postponed at the request of the prosecution. Prosecutors said they would appeal the pretrial ruling by Federal District Judge Richard Cacheris to allow the defense to use classified material as evidence.

title: Refurbished Liberty Is Iacocca's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALLER, BROADER TAX IS PREFERABLE TO OIL-IMPORT FEE
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Continued Oil Instability Seen
description: OIL prices have fallen from a peak of $40 a barrel in the spot market in 1981 to nearly $15 now. Where will they hit bottom?

title: SINGER MAY BID SEWING ADIEU
description: The Singer Company says it may spin off its sewing machine operations, a business that over the past 135 years has made Singer one of the most recognized American names in the world.

title: Steven Mayer, Pianist
description: Steven Mayer, one of the finalists in last year's Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition for pianists, will give a recital on Feb. 26 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Mayer, who won second prize in the competition and has appeared with orchestras around the country and in Europe, will perform works by Liszt, Stravinsky, Charles Ives and Art Tatum.

title: Deere Posts Wider Deficit
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest producer of farm equipment, said today that it lost $34.4 million in the first quarter, compared with a loss of $28.2 million a year ago.

title: Key Rates
description: N.A. - Not available because of President's Day* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BOMB BLAST AT U.S. EMABSSY IN LISBON
description: A bomb exploded in an American's car at a checkpoint of the United States Embassy here Tuesday night, but no one was wounded, embassy officials said.

title: Hearing Thursday In Texaco Case
description: A Texas state court is scheduled to hear arguments tomorrow on Texaco Inc.'s motion for a new trial in its high-stakes legal battle with the Pennzoil Company.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
M.I.S.L. COMMISSIONER ANGERS OWNER
description: Owners in the Major Indoor Soccer League are trying to avoid repeating the mistakes that brought about the demise of the North American Soccer League.

title: VALERO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of assets of $1.4 million for the quarter and $57.4 million for the year. c-Net loss

title: Older Women and Men
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Brief Setback for College Gladiators
description: ''Who do you think is more important at this university, you or a very prominent basketball player?'' That's what her superiors asked Jan Kemp, an English instructor at the University of Georgia, after she refused to change failing grades for five athletes. She didn't need to guess at the answer, and her protests against favoritism for athletes eventually led to her dismissal.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * New York State Electric and Gas Corp., has elected Richard A. Jacobson senior vice president

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Police Disperse Haitians Protesting New Leaders
description: Roving bands of youths protesting the makeup of the new Government raced through the streets of the capital today, forcing the closing of schools that had reopened Monday.

title: WINNERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a pre-tax provision of $2,370,000 for anticipated losses from the closing of six Mrs. Winners restaurants and the disposition of other restaurants and surplus properties of which $800,000 was recorded in the fourth quarter.

title: Physicians to Study Stress Fractures
description: Concerned by the growing number of stress fractures this season, the National Basketball Association Physicans' Association has undertaken an extensive study to seek the reasons and find a solution to prevent similar injuries. Meeting before the All-Star Game in Dallas, the association asked Dr. Norman Scott of the Knicks, Dr. Steve Haas of the Washington Bullets and Dr. Pat Evans of the Dallas Mavericks to undertake the study and report their findings at the group's meeting in September.

title: DOW RISES 14.33 TO RECORD 1,678.78
description: Stock prices rose sharply on Wall Street yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average posting its third straight double-digit gain, as investors reacted once again to weakness in oil prices.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A FEW short decades ago the home cook had to travel to fairly obscure New York markets to find a few leeks, and only the most knowledgeable nonprofessionals dared to experiment with them.

title: Coke Purchasing Merv Griffin Unit
description: The Coca-Cola Company said it had reached agreement in principle to acquire Merv Griffin Enterprises, which produces television game shows including ''Wheel of Fortune.''

title: Shcharansky Voices Annoyance at Press
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Jewish activist who was freed last week after nine years in Soviet confinement, expressed annoyance Monday at the assertions of some Israeli newspapers that he was being made the captive of the extreme religious right.

title:
WHAT SHCHARANSKY MEANS TO THE WORLD;
Need Help
description: Decent people everywhere are elated, celebrating the release of Anatoly B. Shcharansky - let us call him by his new Hebrew name, Natan - from Soviet prisons. This is understandable: It is their victory as much as his. But in our exultation we forget Vladimir Slepak - and that is both ethically regrettable and politically dangerous.

title: Kisses for Regan
description: Sometimes the target of a political joke finds it more memorable than the teller anticipates. Representative Lynn Martin, Republican of Illinois, got the biggest laugh of the Washington Press Club Foundation's Salute to Congress Dinner last month when she said that Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, had undergone a religious conversion and been made a member of the College of Cardinals.

title: TENNANT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MANY DRUG MAKERS PLAN TO CONTINUE CAPSULE USE
description: An association of companies that make nonprescription drugs said today that its members had no intention of following the lead of Johnson & Johnson in withdrawing capsules from the market.

title: Politics; Commercials and Real People
description: Paul Goldman remembers it well, that sweltering day in a small Virginia town when the perfect image walked into his life, in the person of Joe Alder, police officer.

title: LYDIA WEISSMAN
description: Lydia Weissman, a former ballet dancer who taught dance at the Fieldston School in the Riverdale section of the Bronx until her retirement in 1970, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF NASA TESTIMONY AT SENATE PANEL'S HEARING
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the hearing by the Senate Subcommittee on Science, Technology and Space yesterday in Washington on the loss of the space shuttle Challenger, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Head of Pfizer Unit Named Searle Chief
description: In a major recruiting coup, the Monsanto Company announced yesterday that Dr. Sheldon G. Gilgore, president of Pfizer Pharmaceutical Products, had been named president and chief executive of Monsanto's G. D. Searle & Company subsidiary.

title: THE MAN WHO GETS WHAT YOU PUT AWAY FOR A RAINY DAY
description: ''Nice day,'' remarked Makhete Badiane, standing out in a driving rain.

title: CONGRESS AND COMPTROLLER URGING HIGH COURT TO UPHOLD BUDGET LAW
description: Lawyers for the Senate, the House of Representatives and the Comptroller General of the United States filed appeals with the Supreme Court today defending the constitutionality of a new budget-balancing law whose key provision was struck down by a lower court earlier this month.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COLLABORATORS. By Janet Kauffman. 134 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary item of $795,000 for the quarter and year, and after a loss from discontinued operations of $511,000 for the year. c-After lossses from discontinued operations of $560,000 for the quarter and $1,234,000 for the year. d-Net loss.

title: REYNOLDS, R J INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $266 million in the quarter and $367 million in the year.

title: Article 067986 -- No Title
description: A record $1.3 million in winnings at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga have gone uncollected and will revert to the state if the winners do not come forward by April 1, racing officials said yesterday.

title: Body of a Missing Girl Found In a Bag on Lower East Side
description: The police found the body of a 12-year-old girl, who was missing for nearly two weeks, stuffed in a bag near her Lower East Side home yesterday.

title: JEWISH TORIES AND RED-BLOODED ENGLISHMEN
description: When the Trade and Industry Secretary resigned in the middle of a political furor recently, a television interviewer asked a member of the House of Commons what sort of person should be chosen as a replacement. ''A red-blooded Englishman,'' the legislator replied.

title: KODAK REPORTS A LOSS AFTER TAKING WRITEOFF
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday that it took a charge against earnings of $494 million in the fourth quarter to pay for its forced withdrawal from the instant-photography business. As a result, the company reported a net loss of $194 million for the quarter.

title: THE DANCE: 'MAY B,' BY MARIN
description: WITHIN the current phenomenal dance boom in France, whose effects are beginning to trickle over here, the choreographer, Maguy Marin, holds a special place.

title: WERNER TUBKE SHOW OFFERS EAST GERMAN ART
description: A casual visitor to the gallery might, at first glance, think he had stumbled upon the work of a forgotten 16th-century mannerist painter, a contemporary of El Greco and Tintoretto who had somehow slipped through the web of history and surfaced in 1986.

title: Puerto Rican Institute To Mark Anniversary
description: The Puerto Rican Family Institute, a nonprofit service agency working to preserve and strengthen Puerto Rican and other Hispanic families in New York and Puerto Rico, will mark its 25th anniversary with a celebration March 6 at the Hotel Pierre.

title: US SHELTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Oligarchy Reigns in Queens
description: By rights, Donald Manes's successor as Queens Borough President should be chosen in a multiparty election that highlights the disgrace of the Democrats he misled. But not in one-party New York. At the least, a successor would be chosen in an open primary that gave independent politicians a chance to promote reform. But not in cozy New York. The all-but-inevitable victor in this fall's election will be the interim president chosen next week by Queens's nine City Council members, all Democrats and associates of the fallen leader.

title: UNITED HEALTHCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $785,000. c-Net loss. The company said results for all periods have been restated on a pooling of interests basis to reflect the merger of Share Development Corp. into United Healthcare in September 1985.

title: INQUIRY FOCUSING ON COLD SPOT REPORTS
description: A member of the Presidential panel investigating the Challenger accident conducted a special investigation here today into reports that abnormally low temperatures were recorded on the launching pad before the space shuttle was launched.

title: Mitsubishi Cleared Of Tandon Charge
description: Mitsubishi Electronics America Inc. said that the International Trade Commission had rejected the Tandon Corporation's allegations that the Japanese manufacturer had infringed on Tandon's patent on 5 1/4-inch floppy disk drives.

title: The Trouble With Redefining Stealing
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Hands
description: During his well-publicized recent streak of nine games without a goal, Wayne Gretzky was not entirely lacking, of course, in offensive output. In fact, the drought was marked by 27 Gretzky assists - some slump -which raised his average for the season to better than two a game.

title: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HELICOPTERS EVACUATE FLOOD VICTIMS
description: Military helicopters and boats converged on this flooded resort town today to evacuate hundreds of residents made homeless by the rampaging Russian River.

title: House Urges Reagan To Drop Liberian Aid
description: The House adopted a nonbinding resolution today that urged President Reagan to suspend aid to Liberia until that country improves its human rights record and makes progress toward democracy.

title: PRESIDENT DECIDES TO SEND WEAPONS TO ANGOLA REBELS
description: The Reagan Administration told Congress today that it had decided to provide rebels in Angola with antiaircraft and antitank missiles.

title: SENATORS PRESS PANEL FOR DETAILS ON SHUTTLE
description: ''Mr. Graham,'' an irate Senator Ernest F. Hollings said today, addressing the acting administrator of the space agency, ''can you think of any information you would give to the Presidential commission and not to this committee?''

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TUTU DEFUSES A TOWNSHIP CONFRONTATION
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu interceded between the police and black protesters today, persuading thousands of people holding a mass rally to disperse rather than risk confrontation with heavily armed soldiers and policemen.

title: PRIMER ON MARCUS GARVEY ON CHANNEL 13 TONIGHT
description: MARCUS GARVEY is a significant figure in American history: part prophet, part salesman and the first black nationalist to awaken a mass movement. ''Marcus Garvey: Toward Black Nationhood'' doesn't tell us nearly enough about the man, but it's looking at a fascinating topic. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Long Island Savings Bank to Muir Cornelius Moore.

title: Disciplinary Action
description: The University of Minnesota has begun disciplinary action against the former head basketball coach, Jim Dutcher, and the acting head coach, Jimmy Williams, for what the school felt was their role in an effort to raise funds for the defense of a basketball player on a rape charge. Athletic Director Paul Giel said yesterday an investigation had shown that, contrary to statements by both coaches, Williams and Dutcher not only knew about the fund-raising effort but that Williams, at Dutcher's instruction, suggested it to a member of the Gopher booster club.

title: Harnischfeger Set To Buy Beloit
description: The Harnischfeger Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy the Beloit Corporation, a closely held manufacturer of paper making machines and related products, for $175 million.

title: JOHNSON URGINH PUBLIC TO TRY CAPLETS
description: To retain its leadership in the analgesic market after the recent Tylenol poisoning, Johnson & Johnson has embarked on a major advertising and public relations campaign to convince consumers that its caplets - coated, capsule-shaped tablets - work as well as capsules.

title: Arco Financing
description: A $250 million issue of the Atlantic Richfield Company's 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1993 was offered yesterday at 99.90, to yield 9.272 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. When the notes were initially offered, their yield was about 79 hundredths of a percentage point greater than Treasury notes of similar maturity. Moody's recently reduced its rating for the company's debt to A-2 from Aa-3, while S.&P. rated the issue AA-.

title: WACKENHUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: AT HARVESTER, SHARP CHANGES
description: When International Harvester's shareholders vote Thursday to change their company's name to Navistar International, officials at the Chicago-based truck manufacturer hope the new name will show that the company is breaking with its past.

title: WINE TALK
description: THIS may seem, at the outset, to be an article on French wines. It isn't. Nor is it about California wines, although they end up being the heroes of the story.

title: Let Them Read Want Ads
description: President Reagan professes to be serious about welfare reform. On the radio last weekend he echoed his State of the Union call for ''real and lasting emancipation, because the success of welfare should be judged by how many of its recipients become independent of welfare.'' He insists, with the eloquence of truth, that ''The waste in dollars and cents pales before the most tragic loss - the sinful waste of human spirit and potential.''

title: Home Care for the Old
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BROKER HELD IN UNCLE'S LOSSES
description: Leslie Howard Roberts, a broker for Merrill Lynch & Company, was denied bail yesterday at a pretrial hearing in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was charged last Friday with defrauding a customer, his great-uncle, of tens of millions of dollars.

title: On the Outside Looking In
description: There is something about running a government that makes you want to keep on doing it, even after you're out of office. To continue promoting their views, avoid wasting their collective experience and perhaps even provide a springboard for a return to power, two dozen former officials of various countries got together three years ago and organized the InterAction Council of Former Heads of Government.

title: Oak Industries Tie To Allied Signal
description: Oak Industries said it had agreed to sell its Oak Material units to Allied Signal for about $160 million.

title: Ban on Bankers Trust
description: Judge Joyce Hens Green of Federal District Court in the District of Columbia today ordered the Bankers Trust Company of New York to stop selling commercial paper issued by corporations, effective March 1.

title: RESURGENCE OF FRANCE'S HEARTY CLASSICS
description: IN today's ever-changing world of fashionable food, diners are presented with choices from the merely exotic to the fantastic. Faced with a menu offering rare-roasted breast of duck with pickled sour cherries and warm goat cheese on radicchio with a hazelnut-oil dressing, I feel a powerful yearning lately for hearty, classic French fare. Nor am I alone. The cuisine de grand-mere that is returning to favor in ovens and hearts in France these days is the latest sign of a renewed appreciation for home cooking. Young up-and-coming chefs are no more impervious to it than those of us brought up on these classic dishes.

title: Outdated Welcome
description: ''Welcome to Queens. Donald R. Manes, President.''

title: Lloyd and Graf Gain Semifinals
description: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd defeated unseeded Terry Phelps, 6-2, 6-0, in just 50 minutes tonight in the quarterfinals of the $1.8 million Lipton International Players Championships.

title:
WHAT SHCHARANSKY MEANS TO THE WORLD;
'Set a Standard'
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky knew, when he began speaking out against the Soviet Government, that he would face many years in jails and isolation cells undergoing extreme psychological and physical pressures. When I first met him, in 1977, a month before be was arrested, it was clear he was not only out on a limb but was sawing himself off.

title: EX-CHURCH MEMBERS ESTABLISH A GROUP
description: AT a time of growing religious awareness, when thousands of Americans are joining fundamentalist Christian groups, thousands are also leaving them in disillusionment. According to sociologists and experts on religion, many of those who leave may experience loneliness, anxiety, guilt or other problems.

title: HOT-DOG VENDOR TAKING ON HOUSTON
description: Shirley Rubenstein said she knew she was being a little extreme when she chained herself to her hot-dog stand in downtown Houston three weeks ago.

title: ST. JOHN'S TOPS VILLANOVA ON CLUTCH FOUL SHOOTING
description: The ability of St. John's to play breathtaking basketball without rest or much depth was tested almost to its breaking point here tonight. After dominating Villanova in the first half and threatening to rout the Wildcats in their brand new gymnasium, St. John's was outscored, 54-34, in the game's final 15 minutes and had to hang on for a 79-76 at the John duPont Pavilion.

title: Bridge: Role of the Negative Double When It Is Not Being Used
description: One of the principal advantages of the negative double is the definition it gives to other bids when it is not used.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Brie Cheeses Recalled Four more French Brie cheeses suspected of being contaminated with the bacterium Listeria monocytogenes have been recalled by the Federal Food and Drug Administration. Two other Brie cheeses were recalled last week. The brand names in question in both recalls are: Joan of Arc, Esprit Nouveau, Rue LePic, Louis XIV, Prestige and Jean Lincet, all produced by the Besnier Export Company in Sorcy, France.

title: FOSTER, L B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax benefits of $3,927,000 for the quarter and $3,230,000 for the year. c-Net income including a tax benefit of $230,000 for the quarter.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Chicago Bulls, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Nets have won both meetings this season, both after Michael Jordan broke his left foot on Oct. 29. The Nets prevailed by 106-97 on a 23-point performance by Buck Williams on Nov. 7. On Jan. 7, Darryl Dawkins and Otis Birdsong overshadowed a 28-point performace by George Gervin, who had been acquired from San Antonio to take up some of the scoring slack left by the injury to Jordan. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) Colleges: La Salle vs. Army, 7 P.M., and Notre Dame vs. Manhattan, 9 P.M., at Madison Square Garden (Television -MSG, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M.); Auburn at Georgia (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.); Florida State at Louisville (Television -ESPN, 9 P.M.); Pittsburgh at Providence (Television - USA, 8 P.M.); CUNY Tournament, semifinals at Hunter College Sportsplex, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue, York vs. Staten Island (Radio - WSIA FM, 88.9; 6 P.M.) and City College vs. Hunter (Radio -WNYE FM, 91.5, 8 P.M.); Queens at Dowling, 7:30 P.M.; Drew at New Jersey Tech, 7:30 P.M.; Monmouth at Fairleigh Dickinson, 7:30 P.M.; Hofstra at Towson State, 7:30 P.M.; Manhattanville at Upsala, 7:30 P.M.; United States Merchant Marine at N.Y.U., 7 P.M.; SUNY-Purchase at New York Maritime, 7:30 P.M.; Pratt at Old Westbury, 7:30 P.M.; Southamption at Pace, 7:30 P.M.; Rider at Lehigh, 8 P.M.; Cathedral at Stevens Tech, 7:30 P.M.; New York Poly at Yeshiva, 7:30 P.M.; Women: CUNY semifinals at Hunter College Sportsplex, Hunter vs.

title: Article 085686 -- No Title
description: New York State's 90-day tax amnesty has yielded $334 million in back taxes from nearly 145,000 individuals and corporations, the largest amount raised and the highest turnout of any tax amnesty measure in the country, officials announced today.

title: Chicago Judge Convicted Of Extortion and Fraud
description: A judge was found guilty today of extortion and mail fraud, becoming the fourth judge convicted as part of an investigation of corruption in the Cook County court system.

title: WESTBRIDGE CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter include a $1,588,000, or 37 cents a share, gain from income tax benefits, representing a revision of the estimate for 'fresh-start' under legislation adopted in the prior year and a gain of $745,000, or 18 cents a share, from net realized investment gains.

title: STAGE: JOE ORTON'S 'LOOT,' DIRECTED BY TILLINGER
description: ''WE must keep up appearances,'' says a young English nurse named Fay at the final curtain of Joe Orton's ''Loot.'' Fay has already murdered at least eight people - seven of them former husbands - but, as she says, the appearances of middle-class propriety must be upheld. In Orton's lethal farce, one of the funniest and meanest in the contemporary theater, the characters often act like prim, well-mannered, God-fearing representatives of the bourgeoisie, even as their every private deed and thought reek of greed, blasphemy, sadism and lust. As the curtain descends on ''Loot,'' Fay may be contemplating a new homicide, but first she must bow her head in silent prayer.

title: British Nuclear Site Reports Its Second Leak in a Month
description: The only nuclear reprocessing plant in Britain today had its second radioactive leak this month, according to the company that runs the plant on the northwest coast of England.

title: Lafayette Unit Will Be Closed
description: Circuit City Stores, a leading retailer of brand-name consumer electronics, said yesterday that it would close the 15 Lafayette stores it operated in the metropolitan New York area around March 31 as part of a restructuring program.

title: Life Sentence Sought For Pope Plot Defendant
description: Prosecutor Antonio Marini, saying he had ''certain, sure and unequivocal evidence'' that Musa Serdar Celebi helped organize and finance a plot in 1981 to assassinate Pope John Paul II, today demanded that Mr. Celebi be sentenced to life in prison.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * International Business Machines Corp. announced 35 I.B.M. personal computer educational software programs ranging from basic courses for elementary- and middle-school students to science courses for secondary-school students.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST CITE HOPE
description: Hope for a better life for the homeless, the ill and the despairing is cited by many donors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Advertising; Greece Campaign Is Set
description: FOR George Lois, the job of creating a print and broadcast ad campaign to stimulate American travelers to visit Greece has been ''like coming home.''

title: SCIENCE BOOK WITHDRAWN BY PUBLISHER
description: Viking Penguin has withdrawn a book from its scheduled publication on March 4 after copies had already been printed and partly distributed.

title: DR. JEANNE V. PLEASANTS
description: Dr. Jeanne Varney Pleasants, professor emeritus of French at Columbia University, died Sunday at her home in Memphis.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene is Grand Central Terminal, where Hinda Gonchor is almost knocked down by two women who, after having spotted each other, leave their respective companions in a rush to hug.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUPERIOR SURGICAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ex-Im Bank President Nominated by Reagan
description: John A. Bohn Jr., first vice president and vice chairman of the Export-Import Bank, was nominated by President Reagan yesterday to succeed William H. Draper 3d as president of the 52-year-old agency.

title: DEAL FOR FRENCH CAPTIVES FAILS
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria was quoted today as saying that he and President Francois Mitterrand had reached an agreement earlier this year to free six French hostages in Lebanon, but that it fell through when the Moslem kidnappers backed out on the deal.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $5 million representing company's portion of settlement of lawsuit for the quarter, including a tax credit of $18.7 million for the year. c-Net loss, after a loss of $118.6 million related to the disposition of the Adam Family of Computer Systems for the quarter.

title: ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,586,000 for the quarter and $6,280,000 for the year. The year result also includes a gain of $9,813,000 from a change in accounting principle. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,422,000 for the quarter and including a gain of $359,000 for the year. d-Net loss.

title: ISRAELIS SEARCH SOUTH LEBANON FOR 2 CAPTIVES
description: Hundreds of Israeli troops carried out a second day of intensified ground, naval and air operations today to rescue two soldiers captured by guerrillas in southern Lebanon, But the armed search, which began soon after the soldiers were ambushed Monday, again turned up no trace of the missing men. [ In Beirut, a Moslem fundamentalist group called the Islamic Resistance Front took responsibility for seizing the two soldiers. The organization, an alliance of Shiite and and Sunni Moslem fundamentalist groups led by the pro-Iranian Party of God, later issued a statement threatening to kill one of the captured soldiers if Israeli troops did not withdraw from southern Lebanon within 24 hours. [ In a communique read on Lebanese television, the group said the two captured Israelis were badly wounded and were under medical care. Lebanese television broadcast pictures of a wounded man who was said to be one of the Israelis, but there was no confirmation of his identity. ] Prime Minister Shimon Peres, speaking of the captured soldiers, vowed that Israel would not rest ''until we exhaust all the possibilities of discovering their whereabouts and seizing the guilty.

title: HEALTH CLAIMS ON FOOD PUT F.D.A. IN A CORNER
description: ON Oct. 7, 1984, Kellogg's put a label on its All-Bran cereal implying that eating high-fiber foods such as bran cereals could reduce the incidence of several cancers. Faced with Kellogg's precipitate action, the Federal Food and Drug Administration decided to move ahead with a review of its policy of virtually prohibiting such health claims on food labels.

title: New Bids Made For Imperial
description: The chairman of Imperial Group P.L.C. said the British tobacco and food giant was giving ''careful consideration'' to a fresh offer from United Biscuits Holdings.

title: CORRECTION
description: On Jan. 20, this page carried an article by Albert Vorspan, senior vice president of the Union of Hebrew Congregations, which stated that in 1979 the Rev. Joseph Lowery, head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, led a delegation to Libya ''to bestow on Muammar el-Qaddafi an award of appreciation called 'The Decoration of Martin Luther King.' ''

title: Older Women and Men
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Bowie Wants Surgery
description: He was scheduled for a further round of medical examinations, but his aching shin was all the diagnosis Sam Bowie needed. The Portland Trail Blazer forward announced that he would have bone graft surgery and would be out for the season.

title: Queens District Elects Democrat to Assembly
description: David M. Kramer, the Democratic candidate, won a State Assembly seat yesterday by a narrow margin in a three-way special election in northern Queens. The vote was the first test of voter preference in the borough since Donald R. Manes resigned as Borough President and Democratic county leader.

title: Baby-Food Tests Find No Fragments of Glass
description: Six jars of baby food from the Gerber Products Company with the same code number as a jar that reportedly contained glass fragments were found free of any foreign substances, according to a company spokesman.

title: KANEB SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8,173,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,048,000 for the quarter and $20,506,000 for the year. d-Net loss and after a gain of $1,364,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. e-After income from discontinued operations of $360,000.

title: SAFEGUARD BUSINESS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
T. ROWE PRICE PLANS STOCK OFFER
description: Preparing to cash in on a booming market for mutual fund shares and for the stock of the managers of those funds, T. Rowe Price Associates filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the proposed initial public offering of 1.3 million shares of common stock. The offering, which is expected to raise as much as $30 million, represents about 18 percent of the mutual fund company's shares.

title: HOMELESS ARE NOT DUTY OF U.S., REAGAN AIDE SAYS
description: The director of the Office of Management and Budget said today that the homeless of America were a problem for state and local governments, not for the Federal government.

title: SHUTTLE CHIEF SAYS HE WAS NOT TOLD OF COLD SPOTS ON BOOSTER
description: Although temperatures as low as 7 to 9 degrees Fahrenheit were recorded in the right-hand booster rocket of the shuttle Challenger on the day it exploded, the head of the space shuttle program said he was not informed about it.

title: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1986
description: The Economy

title: A PROTECTED WITNESS IN THE GAMBINO TRIAL IS TERMED A SUICIDE
description: A key witness in the Federal trial in Manhattan of reputed members of the Gambino crime family has been found dead in San Antonio, and the medical examiner there said yesterday that the man had hanged himself.

title: INTERFACE FLOORING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JET STREAM DETOUR IS CULPRIT IN FLOODING
description: The torrents of rainfall that have indundated northern California and neighboring states for the last week result from a southward dip of the jet stream that gathers water-gorged air around Hawaii, delivering it to Western states in a relentless succession of storms.

title: KOREA'S $4,995 EXCEL ENTERS U.S. AUTO FRAY
description: A car called the Excel is to go on sale in the United States for the first time Thursday morning. It is an unremarkable looking vehicle, resembling many of the small, efficient Japanese cars that have wrested a large share of the market from the domestic Big Three.

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN THE SENATE
description: Following is the 85-to-9 roll-call vote today by which the Senate adopted a nonbinding resolution critical of the Philippine presidential election:

title: Nevada Town Adopts 7% Tax On Room Rentals in Brothels
description: Storey County, which a decade ago legalized brothels, has now imposed a tax of 7 percent on rooms rented by prostitutes.

title: HORMEL LOCAL GETS COLD SHOULDER AT A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Leaders of the meatpackers on strike against the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant in Austin, Minn., ventured today onto the winter meeting ground of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. but were shunned by labor leaders who oppose tactics used in the six-month struggle.

title: REDLAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $1,361,000 gain from equity in the life insurance proceeds to an affiliate.

title: HERS
description: LANGUAGE is the subject. It is the written form with which I've managed to keep the wolf away from the door and, in diaries, to keep my sanity. In spite of this, I consider the written word inferior to the spoken, and much of the frustration experienced by novelists is the awareness that whatever we manage to capture in even the most transcendent passages falls far short of the richness of life. Dialogue achieves its power in the dynamics of a fleeting moment of sight, sound, smell and touch.

title: MARCOS REPORTS SOVIET GREETINGS
description: While President Ferdinand E. Marcos's traditional allies kept their distance, he was congratulated today by the Soviet Union on his disputed election victory over Corazon C. Aquino.

title: OPERETTA: IN 'HELENE,' TROJAN FARE
description: ''FATHER was always fond of the water, and Mother took one bath too many,'' muses Helen of Troy, remembering how she was sired by Jupiter, who visited Leda disguised as a swan. Brooding over her susceptibility to erotic temptation while her husband, Menelaus, is away, Helen decides to disguise herself as a social worker. But her resolve quickly crumbles. Minutes later, she is swooning in the arms of Paris as the two make passionate love while sharing the delusion that since they are dreaming, ''What we feel is not real.''

title: Du Pont Job Applicants To Be Tested for Drugs
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company plans to test job applicants for illegal drug use and turn away any who fail the test.

title: 'Thanks for the Memories'
description: As slim and smooth as ever, Earl (the Pearl) Monroe will hear the cheers again a week from Saturday night when the Knicks hoist his No. 15 to the rafters of Madison Square Garden, finally putting it up there where it belongs with the retired numbers of Willis Reed, Walt Frazier, Dave DeBusschere and Bill Bradley.

title: The Thank-You File
description: Last month the office of Senator Pete Wilson of California churned out great batches of thank-you letters to people, mostly constitutuents, who had sent him holiday greetings. One went to Gary Hart of Colorado.

title: 7 COMPETING TO BUILD FIGHTER
description: Seven of the nation's biggest military contractors are competing for a share of the largest aircraft project on the horizon: A new jet fighter for the Air Force at a cost of up to $50 billion.

title: GOULDS PUMPS inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mexico Has to Help Its Helpers
description: Mexico, the first Latin debtor to call for extraordinary help four years ago, is in trouble again, deep trouble. The world may have grown accustomed to these debt crises, but it should be no less wary of a collapse. Another rescue must be arranged even as the arrangers, in Washington, New York and foreign capitals, properly insist that Mexico mend its ways - again.

title: East German Aide Visits West Germany
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl warmly greeted East Germany's third-highest official today and agreed that Erich Honecker, the East German leader, should visit Bonn, Mr. Kohl's press office said.

title: UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Q&A
description: Q.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $6,313,000, or 25 cents a share, from a change in accounting of pension fund assets.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE BRIGHT LIGHTS Occasionally, when Felix Mendelssohn performed his compositions in concert he would, without telling anyone, slip in works written by his sister, Fanny. He stopped this practice after a concert in which reviewers gave her pieces higher praise than they gave his. Her luster obscured, Miss Mendelssohn never achieved the prominence she could have. With a six-part series, ''Illustrious Women,'' that begins this evening, the 92d Street Y is taking care that contributions of some contemporary women are not overlooked.

title: BANKERS TRUST PLANS A APPEAL
description: The Bankers Trust Company said yesterday that it would continue operating in the commercial-paper market while it tries to stay a court order forcing it to leave the business by March 1.

title: Most U.S. Abortions Are in First Trimester
description: To the Editor:

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Waiting for Marcos
description: Corazon Aquino put it succinctly.

title: TEEN-AGE TROUBLES
description: ''TEENS IN TURMOIL,'' an hourlong program to be shown today at 8:30 P.M. as part of Channel 13's ''Currents'' series, might just as accurately have been titled ''Blame the Parents.'' Martin Goldensohn, the able host, and Jane Petroff, the producer, play it down the middle, spreading the anger and the anguish evenly between the generations at home.

title: V.A. IS DELAYING MORTGAGE CUTS
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it would continue its home-loan guarantee program for military veterans without restrictions until it reached the loan commitment limit for the fiscal year.

title: Gemayel Meets With Pontiff But No Statement Is Issued
description: Pope John Paul II interrupted his Lenten retreat today to meet with Lebanon's beleaguered President, Amin Gemayel.

title: Freed Suspect Is Seized In 3d College Robbery
description: A man free on bail after being charged with two robberies at Hunter College was arrested Tuesday night and charged with a robbery at Lehman College in the Bronx, the police said.

title: G.M. AIDE CHALLENGES APARTHEID
description: An American company operating in South Africa directly challenged apartheid today, saying it would offer financial and legal support to its employees who defy a law that calls for racial segregation of beaches.

title: The Late Yul Brynner In Anti-Smoking Ads
description: Onto the blank screen flashes ''Yul Brynner 1920 - 1985'' stark, just like a tombstone or memorial ad.

title: DYNALECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,538,000 for the quarter and $4,277,000 for the year. c-Net income. d-Including gains from discontinued operations of $1,783,000 for the quarter and $174,000 for the year.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND GUILTY
description: A Federal jury today found the Bank of New England guilty of deliberately withholding information from the Government about dozens of large cash transactions by a convicted gambler. The transactions totaled $817,200. The District Court jury still is to return verdicts on related misdemeanor charges against two former bank tellers.
