title: Apple Buys Loan On Computercraft
description: In an unusual move, Apple Computer Inc. has helped bail out a computer store chain by purchasing a loan from a bank. The chain, Computercraft Inc. of Houston, is one of the biggest supporters of Apple among computer retailers, with Apple products accounting for about half of the chain's sales.

title: On Getting Back International Ill-Gotten Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: HUSSEIN DROPS A YEARLONG EFFORT TO JOIN IN PEACE BID WITH ARAFAT
description: King Hussein announced today that he was ending a yearlong effort to devise a joint peace strategy with Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: CHICAGO'S COUNSEL QUITS IN FEE ROW
description: The top lawyer for the city resigned today after weeks of controversy over whether he and another top aide to Mayor Harold Washington had conspired to conceal an official's acceptance of a questionable $10,000 payment.

title: Tradition Resumes At Bethlehem Steel
description: When the Bethlehem Steel Corporation named Donald H. Trautlein chairman and chief executive officer in 1980, it broke a long tradition of promoting career employees to the helm of the nation's third-largest steel company.

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $183,000 for the year.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Toyota Considers Raising U.S. Prices
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation is considering another increase in the price of cars it exports to the United States because of the yen's sharp rise against the dollar, the company's president said. Shochiro Toyoda, president of Japan's largest auto maker, said he ''would like to revise the present price again as soon as possible'' because of the yen's rapid rise against the dollar in the past several weeks, according to a company official, who asked not to be identified.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Phibro-Salomon Reports Gain
description: Phibro-Salomon Inc., the investment banking and commodities concern, said yesterday that strength in its three businesses resulted in net earnings of $132 million, or 90 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: SAGE ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Long Streak Ends
description: It took two high-scoring all-Americans to do it, but Northeast Louisiana has snapped Louisiana Tech's women's national collegiate record of 62 straight home-court victories.

title: People
description: * David Cathers was named executive vice president, director of client services, at Franklin Spier Inc., a subsidiary of BBDO International.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect 3-for-2 stock split which was distributed on April 19, 1985.

title: SHULTZ DENOUNCES PHILIPPINE FRAUD
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today assailed what he called ''fraud and violence on a systematic and widespread scale'' carried out by the supporters of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the election in the Philippines.

title: REAGAN SAYS NICARAGUA RUNS A CAMPAIGN OF LIES
description: Reagan Administration officials accused Nicaragua today of a vast campaign to influence United States public opinion. They asserted that the effort by the Sandinistas included the use of ''disinformation.''

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Powerful Consensus
description: The reaction to events in the Philippines has taught us something extremely important about the United States. There is a new consensus in this country on human rights in foreign policy. Americans across the political spectrum are not prepared to tolerate crude abuses of power by tyrants simply because they call themselves ''pro-American.''

title: Shula Promotes Son
description: Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins' head coach, appointed his 26-year-old son, David Shula, as his chief assistant. Shula had recently been considered for the head coaching post with the Philadelphia Eagles, but Buddy Ryan, the Bears' defensive coordinator, got the job. Shula was promoted after four seasons as the Dolphins' quarterbacks and receivers coach.

title: Phoenix Offering At Lower Rates
description: The city of Phoenix, which rejected the only bid it received at an early January financing, returned yesterday to the market with bonds carrying interest rates more than a percentage point lower than it might have paid early in the year.

title: PHIBRO-SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After special charges of $224 million for the quarter and year. The net income for the latest periods reflect a special charge equal to 5 cents a share.

title: Market Place; Long-Term Intel Prospects
description: MANY semiconductor stocks have rallied sharply since the end of October, thanks to a general rebound in technology issues and, more recently, signs of improvement in the roller-coaster semiconductor industry itself. But one former superstar, the Intel Corporation. has been a notable laggard, thanks partly to disappointing profits.

title: A ROSE BY ANY OTHER NAME COULD BE FUNNY
description: THE 18th-century English poet William Shenstone once wrote, ''I thank God that my name is susceptible to no pun.'' (Compulsive punsters will doubtless regard this as a challenge, but I think they will have their work cut out.) In whatever 18th-century corner of heaven he occupies, Shenstone must currently be taking a little complacent satisfaction in the appearance down on earth of a small volume - a sequel to earlier collections by the same author - called ''John Train's Most Remarkable Names'' (published by Clarkson Potter).

title: The Flag File
description: Marching purposefully along downtown 18th Street this week, a man stopped in midstride in front of a store at the corner of M Street.

title: CARPETS FROM WALL-TO-WALL
description: BORN in the Dominican Republic, Fernando Mateo, above, opened his first store at the age of 17.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: New on the Block
description: With his league-leading 270 blocked shots in 52 games, Manute Bol of the Washington Bullets needs only half a dozen more to break the National Basketball Association's rookie record, set by Mark Eaton of Utah three years ago. More than that, Bol is on pace for a total of 415 rejections this season, which would be the second-highest figure since the N.B.A. began recording blocked shots as an official statistic 12 years ago.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
AIRCAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,282,000 for the quarter and $4,212,000 for the year. c-Net income. d-Including tax credits of $1,123,000 for the quarter and $3,946,000 for the year.

title: PVC CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lotus Buyback
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said it intended to repurchase up to 10 percent of its shares and that the First Boston Corporation would buy the shares on behalf of Lotus.

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JAZZ: MEL LEWIS ORCHESTRA
description: THE Mel Lewis Jazz Orchestra, which is celebrating its 20th year of Monday-night engagements at the Village Vanguard (Seventh Avenue South near 11th Street) by playing an eight-day engagement there through Monday, is welcoming back one-time members of the band each night during this gala week. The saxophonists Pepper Adams and Jerry Dodgion were guests on Monday evening and the valve trombonist Bob Brookmeyer, who is still associated with the band as an arranger, brought his horn in with him on Tuesday.

title: Grenada Revisited
description: President Reagan comes to Grenada today as a conquering hero - as well as to attend a summit conference of pro-Western Caribbean leaders. The military forces he dispatched in October 1983 rid that tiny island of an erratic, increasingly tyrannical far-left regime. While that use of force has never been adequately justified, the invasion has had mostly happy political consequences. Today's celebration ought not, however, to obscure the economic problems that continue to threaten Grenada and other Caribbean states.

title: SHCHARANSKY BIOGRAPHY SET
description: An authorized biography of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet Jewish dissident who gained his freedom last week and is now living in Israel, will be published in May by Viking Penguin under its Elisabeth Sifton imprint. The author is Martin Gilbert, the British historian who is the author of an eight-volume life of Winston Churchill.

title: MYSTERY BOMBER IS HUNTED IN SERIES OF BLASTS
description: The explosion roared through a shopping center in a suburb of Sacramento and left Campbell Scrutton dying in an alley, the latest victim of a mysterious bomber who has eluded law-enforcement officials around the country for nearly eight years.

title: BERLIN FILM FESTIVAL SCREENS 'SHOAH'
description: Hundreds of people crowded into the Delphi Palast cinema here this week for the premiere of ''Shoah,'' Claude Lanzmann's nine-and-a-half-hour documentary about the Holocaust.

title: NEW YORK'S HOMELESS ON 'METROLINE'
description: NEW YORK'S homeless generally come to public attention when winter drives them off the streets and into bus terminals and railroad stations, or when a newspaper exposes the conditions in the welfare hotels for which the city pays upwards of $1,500 a month per room. Whether in the headlines or out, this week's edition of ''Metroline'' reports, the number of people without roofs of their own keeps growing, particularly the number of children among them. Nobody can say with precision how many there are.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSUENCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Women Shot, One Fatally, In a Queens Massage Parlor
description: Three women were shot, one fatally, in a Queens massage parlor during a dispute with three men yesterday morning, the police said. The three men fled.

title: BLUES: JUNIOR LOCKWOOD
description: ROBERT (JUNIOR) LOCKWOOD has carved out his own blues territory - a style and a repertory that delves into jazz harmonies without losing the visceral emotionality of basic blues. Tuesday at the Lone Star Cafe, he was equally at home with songs from Robert Johnson, T-Bone Walker, Count Basie and Tin Pan Alley, playing his electric 12-string guitar and singing a playful but pointed tenor.

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $3,731,000 for the quarter and $19,131,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $17,324,000 for the quarter and $28 million for the year.

title: A DECADE OF TV AT LINCOLN CENTER IS CELEBRATED
description: Almost a decade ago, when John Goberman produced the live television broadcast from the Metropolitan Opera of ''La Boheme'' with Luciano Pavarotti and Renata Scotto, he got a crash course in tailoring technology to fit art.

title: ECONOMISTS NOW DETECT FALLING TREND IN DEFICIT
description: The Federal budget deficits that have bedeviled the economy since the start of the Reagan Administration have reached a turning point, according to Government and private analysts.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Maryland at North Carolina (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.); Delaware State at Brooklyn, 7:30 P.M.; L.I.U. at Robert Morris (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.); St. Francis (Brooklyn) at St. Francis (Pa.), 7:30 P.M.; Louisiana State at Vanderbilt (Television - USA, 8 P.M.) Golf Los Angeles Open, first round. After Lanny Wadkins equaled the course record with an 8-under-par 63 in the opening round last year, Larry Mize came along in the second round and broke the mark with a 62. However, Wadkins went on to win the $72,000 first prize. (Television - ESPN, 4:30 P.M.) Standard Register/Samaritan Turquoise Classic, Phoenix, Ariz. Opening round. Betsy King is the defending champion. Hockey Rangers vs. St. Louis Blues, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Last season the Rangers did not lose to St. Louis, winning two of the three games and tying the other. But this is their last chance to beat the Blues this season, having tied one game and lost another. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.) Devils vs. Quebec Nordiques, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Although the season is more than half over, this is the first time the Devils and the Nordiques have met. (Radio - WMCA, 570; 7:35 P.M.) Running Empire State Run Up, at 34th Street and Fifth Avenue, 10:30 A.M. Although the Empire State Building is not the world's tallest or even the city's tallest building anymore it is big enough to have its own zip code, 10118, and a race that is in its ninth year.

title: Don't 'Reform' the Joint Chiefs
description: Hidden behind lurid headlines about expensive defense equipment is the story of a first-class, well-organized national military planning structure. It is the unjustly maligned Joint Chiefs of Staff system, the high quality of whose performance is not appreciated by outside critics far removed from present Joint Chiefs' procedures. Instead, there is a misguided movement afoot in Congress to ''reform'' the Joint Chiefs in a way that could undermine a system that has been operating with steadily increasing efficiency.

title: THE MATCHMAKERS WHO WILL PAIR UP CLIENTS AND DECORATORS
description: WHEN Judy Licht and Jerry Della Femina bought a four-bedroom penthouse on Riverside Drive last summer, they knew they wanted the help of an interior decorator.

title: Smoker Cars on N.J. Transit Ending to Reduce Crowding
description: Smoking will be prohibited on N.J. Transit trains starting Monday in an effort to reduce overcrowding and to provide the majority of riders with a ''convenient, comfortable commute,'' the agency announced today.

title: BASEBALL JOB SEEKERS ARRIVING AT CAMPS
description: Spring began today when the first wave of more than 1,000 baseball players and job seekers started to arrive for spring training in 18 camps in Florida and 8 in Arizona.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Tuesday about the New York City Opera's 1986 season misidentified the singer who will perform the role of Charlotte in the new production of Massenet's ''Werther.'' She is Wendy White.

title: Quarter Profit For Harvester
description: The International Harvester Company, the Chicago-based truck manufacturer, said today that it had a profit of $28 million, or 18 cents a share, in its first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 in contrast to a loss of $534 million a year ago.

title: Letter: On Arms Control; Disarm by 90% if Not 100%
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO USE RAWHIDE TO WEAVE CHAIR SEATS
description: When the woven seat of a chair has been removed, it is not difficult to determine from the wear marks along the side rails what type of material was used. Close narrow grooves, plus hand-cut notches on the rails, would indicate rush.

title: CAUTIOUS CONFIDENCE AT I.R.S.
description: Last year at this time a bureaucratic horror story was unfolding inside the long, low building in northeast Philadelphia where the Internal Revenue Service processes Federal income tax returns from 14 million taxpayers in the Middle Atlantic region.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Clerc Retires
description: Calling the international pro tennis circuit ''very egotistic,'' Jose-Luis Clerc said he was retiring from the game. Clerc, 27 years old, a winner of 25 international tournaments during a 10-year career that earned him more than $2 million, said at a news conference in Buenos Aires that he wanted to dedicate more time to his family.

title: POPE EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said that the year-ago periods exclude income from discontinued operations of $501,000.

title: Maryland Bonds Offer Lowest Yield in 6 Years
description: A $124.6 million issue of Maryland general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.40 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 6.35 percent in 1996 and 6.70 percent in 2001, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: MINNETONKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
More Shades of Nixon
description: When the National Fitness Foundation holds a gala March 20 at the New York Marriott Marquis to honor Americans who have made a significant contribution to keeping fit, one of the chief honorees will be former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: WORLCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

U.S.-Soviet Arms Meeting
description: United States and Soviet negotiators on long-range nuclear weapons met today for two and a half hours at the Soviet mission, a United States statement said. Details of the meeting were kept secret under the confidentiality agreement between the two sides.

title: PIECE OF SHUTTLE ROCKET IDENTIFIED ON SEA FLOOR
description: Pieces of debris discovered on the ocean floor near here have been identified as part of the right-side solid-fuel booster rocket suspected of causing the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Canadiens Gain Tie
description: Bobby Smith's second goal of the game, at 4 minutes 59 seconds of the third period, helped the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-4 tie tonight with the Washington Capitals.

title: GIFTS OF INTEREST GROUPS RISE
description: House members seeking re-election received $19 million from political action committees last year, a 54 percent increase from two years earlier, Common Cause reports.

title: LYPHOMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EQUITABLE'S NEW TOWER: A CURIOUS AMBIVALENCE
description: The new Equitable Tower on the east side of Seventh Avenue between 51st and 52d Streets is among the most curious buildings in New York. It is at once adventurous and timid, at once modern and post-modern, at once grandiose and restrained.

title: New Chip From I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had succeeded in developing a single computer chip that incorporates most of the essential functions of its mainframe computers.

title: SAUL, B F REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $83,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $53,000 on the sale of property. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $108,000 and a gain on the sale of property of $1,042,000.

description: b-After a charge reduced income by $245,000, or 30 cents a share.

title: THE THEATER: 'I, SHAW' AT JEWISH REPERTORY
description: A one-act play by Shaw that has not been seen here for 42 years and one by William Kramer drawn from two Shaw short stories are interesting reminders of the strengths and limitations of Shaw's work, including the fiction for which he is best known. The two plays share a program called ''I, Shaw'' at the Jewish Repertory Theater.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Tuesday of the actor and director Howard da Silva cited his film honors incorrectly. He was not nominated for Academy Awards as best supporting actor for ''The Lost Weekend'' and ''Two Years Before the Mast.''

description: International

title: SPENDTHRIFT FARM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: COCA-COLA NET UP 45.1%
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter income from continuing operations rose 19.2 percent. A one-time gain pushed net income for the quarter up 45.1 percent.

description: Does budget-cutting, like charity, begin at home?

title: BATTLE RAGES FOR 10TH DAY NEAR OIL PORT IN SOUTH IRAQ
description: Heavy fighting raged for a 10th day in the strategic Fao peninsula south of here today as Iraq tried to repulse what appears to be Iran's most serious offensive in the five-and-a-half-year-old war.

title: South Korea Detains Dissident a 3d Time
description: The dissident leader Kim Young Sam was again placed under house arrest early today as President Chun Doo Hwan's Government continued efforts to thwart an opposition campaign to change the country's Constitution.

title: PISTONS BEAT SONICS AND EXTEND STREAK
description: Isiah Thomas scored 23 points and the Detroit Pistons won a club-record 10th straight home game as they beat the Seattle SuperSonics, 118-113, in a fight-marred game tonight.

title: 3 SOUTH AFRICAN CLERICS URGE BANKS NOT TO EASE DEBT CRISIS
description: South Africa's three leading anti-Government clerics called on Western creditor banks today to refuse to reschedule the nation's frozen foreign debt until the Government resigns.

title: STATEN ISLAND AND CITY COLLEGE IN FINAL
description: The Staten Island Dolphins were in unexpected difficulty at halftime last night. They trailed York, 38-32, in their City University of New York Conference tournament semifinal. One of their top players had shown up only about 30 minutes before the tipoff and it didn't look as though he would ever get untracked. They were shooting about 40 percent, were being outrebounded and looked sleepy and puzzled.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Fixed Exchange Rates Will Not Work
description: President Reagan's State of the Union Message contained a disturbing warning signal that he is being tempted to compromise his free-market principles as they apply to the largest market in the world: the market in the dollar and other key currencies.

title: RED RUFFING, 81, STAR PITCHER ON 7 YANKEE PENNANT TEAMS
description: Charles (Red) Ruffing, the big right-hander whose pitching and pinch-hitting helped the Yankees win seven pennants and six World Series championships in the 1930's and 1940's, died Monday at Hillcrest Hospital in Mayfield, Ohio. He was 81 years old and had been in poor health since suffering a stroke 13 years ago.

title: ELECTRO-BIOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $59,000 for the quarter and $419,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $116,000 for the quarter and $215,000 for the year.

title: TYLENOL MAKER HOPEFUL ON SOLVING POISONING CASE
description: The chairman of Johnson & Johnson said today that the cyanide poisoning case in Westchester County, N.Y., involving his company's Tylenol capsules should be easier to solve than similar killings in the Chicago area in 1982.

title: Reward Offered For Stolen Zoo Pets
description: One is not likely in any case to ignore a five-foot-long boa constrictor or a yellow-headed parrot that squawks, ''Let's go, Mets.''

title: PANEL FAULTS PLAN TO CUT TRANSPORTATION AID
description: Republicans and Democrats on a Senate subcommittee today criticized a proposal by the Reagan Administration to reduce or eliminate a number of transportation assistance programs in the next fiscal year.

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEXTILE DESIGNS BY ANNI ALBERS AT YALE
description: THE Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven is honoring a local weaver with a worldwide reputation. The current exhibition of more than 100 textiles and graphic works encompasses 60 years of the art of Anni Albers, the widow of Josef Albers, the geometric abstractionist painter.

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $26,495,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and including a gain of $66,013,000 from discontinued operations for the year and after charges from writedowns of certain coal mining assets of $7.6 million for the quarter and year. The quarter and year results are also after a loss of $6.4 million from the writedown of its previously discontinued lead zinc and sulphur mining. The year result also include a gain of $41.8 million from the sale of two subsidiaries. c-After a loss of $9,039,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and including a gain of $4,893,000 from discontinued operations for the year.

title: OLYMPIAN AIMS FOR NEW GOAL
description: Uncle Gordon was the first. Thirty years ago, he went to Cortina, Italy, to play for the United States Olympic hockey team. Four years later, less than a year after Dave Christian was born, his father, William, and his Uncle Roger became important parts of the team that defeated the Soviet Union and went on to win the gold medal at Squaw Valley.

title: Georgia to Seek New Kemp Trial
description: Attorney General Michael Bowers of Georgia said today that the state would seek a new trial of Jan Kemp's lawsuit against two University of Georgia administrators, who were ordered to pay the former English instructor $2.57 million.

title: COST OF TEEN-AGE PREGNANCIES
description: Teen-age childbearing cost the nation $16.6 billion last year, and the 385,000 children who were the firstborn of adolescents in 1985 will receive $6 billion in welfare benefits during the next 20 years, said a study released this week.

title: TS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include those of RTC, a 50 percent owned subsidiary.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago fourth quarter earnings reflect a gain of $265,000, or 5 cents a share, from a change to the FIFO method from the LIFO method of accounting for inventories. Share earnings were adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid in July 1985.

title: Busy March for Tyson
description: Mike Tyson, the hard-hitting, undefeated young heavyweight who has been fighting every other week, will be stepping up his pace next month, according to his co-manager, Bill Cayton.

title: 2 MERGERS LEAVE 8 TEAMS IN U.S.F.L.
description: A change in the ownership of another franchise in the United States Football League may have opened new avenues for Donald Trump's New Jersey Generals and for their quarterback, Doug Flutie.

title: A Pinch-Hitter For Basketball
description: As a big-league outfielder, Ted Savage had an acutely uneventful career, playing with seven teams in nine seasons, batting .233, hitting just 34 home runs. He seems to remember stealing home several times, but there is no apparent record of it.

title: ESI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAFETY ASSESSMENTS HINGED ON WEATHER AND BOOSTER SEALS
description: Documents made public by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and interviews with key participants disclose that the space agency faced two pivotal decisions in assessing the safety of the space shuttle Challenger. These two decisions have become the centerpiece of a growing debate over whether the explosion could have been avoided.

title: BARRY, R G CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After a pretax charge of $1 million related to the disposal of a portion of company business. c-Net income after a pretax charge of $2.7 million related to a plant closing.

title: COLLEGE LEAGUES MAKE MARK ON ICE
description: College hockey, a major sport although a regional one, can be baffling with its overlapping leagues and standings.

title: CHESEBROUGH-POND'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $4,587,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $27,182,000, or 77 cents a share, for the year. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of the Health-Tex division of $4,337,000, or 13 cents a share, and $9,877,000, or 28 cents a share, on its disposal. The company said 1985 sales include the results of Stauffer Chemical Co., acquired in March 1985.

title: Stocks Plunge; Dow Off 20.52 Points
description: The stock market's winning streak came to an abrupt end yesterday, with prices suffering their steepest decline in more than a month. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 20.52 points, to 1,658.26.

title: Concert Will Feature Works by Otto Luening
description: The National Orchestra of New York will give a concert of eight works by the composer Otto Luening, Feb. 28 at 8 P.M. at Columbia University's McMillin Theater, Broadway and 116th Street. On the program is the world premiere of ''Symphonic Fantasia No. 6,'' written last summer.

title: U.S. LINKS SOME FOREIGN AID TO PRIVATIZATION
description: Reagan Administration officials have declared that the extent of United States assistance for some developing countries will depend on their efforts to transfer public assets and programs to private industry.

title: Let's All Help Spend New York's M.A.C. Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: Lefton Gets Sabena
description: Al Paul Lefton Inc., has been named the agency for Sabena Belgian World Airlines, whose previous agency, McDonald & Little, Atlanta, was closed down last fall by its parent company, Ted Bates Worldwide. Billings, according to Lefton, will be over $1 million.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: In fiscal 1986 the company adopted LIFO accounting for domestic inventories which increased net income by $200,000 for the quarter and $5.7 million for the 9 months.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: New-Product Showing For January Is Strong
description: January is typically a slow month for new-product introductions, since few manufacturers attempt sales presentations to retailers during December. However, as Dancer Fitzgerald Sample reports in its latest issue of New Product News, this January produced a strong kick-off to 1986, with 144 new products introduced - an increase of 14.5 percent over the same month last year.

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN POWER CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: MANE'S DEPUTY DENIES KNOWING OF ANY WRONGDOING
description: Claire Shulman told Queens City Council members yesterday that in her five years as deputy to Borough President Donald R. Manes, she was never aware of any corrupt activities on his part.

title: Origins of the Afrikaans Language and Allan Boesak's Church
description: To the Editor:

title: A FILTER CAN HELP WATER QUALITY
description: HOMEOWNERS concerned about the purity of their tap water can choose a water treatment appliance as a convenient alternative to bottled water. Most such devices utilize carbon filtration. The water passes through carbon granules or a compressed carbon block, where contaminants lodge. The filter's effectiveness depends on the amount of carbon: the longer the water is in contact with the carbon, the more particles are trapped.

title: THOMAS NELSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN PROMOTES PRIVATE CLEANUP
description: President Reagan today credited Federal law with prompting the cleanup of major pollution sources, but he asserted that private efforts could best solve specialized environmental problems.

title: FAMILIES' SHELTER SET FOR BROOKLYN
description: The first housing specially built for homeless families in New York State will open in Brooklyn by the end of the year under a program disclosed today by state officials.

title: WIDER PLAN FOR CATASTROPHIC ILLNESS IS URGED
description: Democratic members of Congress said today that President Reagan's proposal to provide health insurance for catastrophic illness did not go far enough in meeting the nation's needs for health care.

title: JWT Board Member
description: Burton J. Manning, 54, chairman of J. Walter Thompson, U.S.A., and vice chairman and creative director of the worldwide J. Walter Thompson Company, has been nominated for election to the board of the parent JWT Group.

title: AFTER 37 YEARS, SENATE ENDORSES A GENOCIDE BAN
description: The Senate approved a United Nations convention against genocide today, nearly 37 years after it was first submitted by President Harry S. Truman.

title: CORRUPTION PANEL QUESTIONS AMERUSO ON BUSINESS DEAL
description: New York City's Transportation Commissioner, Anthony R. Ameruso, appeared for nearly five hours yesterday before a special panel investigating municipal corruption, Mayor Koch had ordered Mr. Ameruso to appear before the panel, headed by John S. Martin, to answer questions about his partnership with William C. Brennan, a State Supreme Court justice who was convicted of bribe-taking, and others in a downtown real estate venture.

title: MAN IS AWARDED SUPPORT PAYMENTS
description: A Canadian judge has awarded $11,350 (Canadian) - about $15,900 (U.S.) - in support payments to a man who cooked, cleaned and cared for three children for 13 years while his wife worked.

title: PICKENS SEEN MAKING FRIENDLY BID FOR PIONEER
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman known for his long string of hostile takeover deals, is on the verge of making his second friendly takeover move in less than two months, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: GORMAN-RUPP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXCEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pfizer Unit President
description: Pfizer Pharmaceutical Products said yesterday that William C. Steere has been named president, succeeding Dr. Sheldon G. Gilgore, who resigned to become president and chief executive of G. D. Searle & Company. Mr. Steere, 49 years old, had been executive vice president of Pfizer Pharmaceutical, a $1 billion unit of Manhattan-based Pfizer Inc.

description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $431,000 for the quarter and 9 months and a tax credit of $415,000 for quarter and 9 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $2,693,000 from repayment of long- term debt.

title: 2 U.S. AGENCIES OFFER PLAN TO EXCHANGE 24 MILLION ACRES OF LAND
description: The Interior Department and the Department of Agriculture announced today that they had completed plans to exchange with each other more than 24 million acres of rangeland and forestland in the West and had submitted the plan to Congress.

title: Gail Wynters, Singer, Performing at Carlos 1
description: Gail Wynters is an uninhibited singer with a rich, throaty voice that can take on a torch singer's woe or exuberant, gospel enthusiasm. At Carlos 1, Avenue of the Americas near Ninth Street, where she is singing through Sunday, she is accompanied by a quartet that gives her unusually responsive support.

title: OFFICIAL OF PAPER AIDING AQUINO SHOT
description: An executive for a leading newspaper in the United States opposed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines was killed at his suburban Los Angeles home today in what some Marcos opponents say was a political assassination.

title: PAYCO AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in September.

title: LEADING SENATE FOE OF INTEGRATION
description: James O. Eastland, for 36 years a conservative United States Senator from Mississippi who served as chairman of the Judiciary Committee for 22 years, died today in Greenwood-LeFlore County Hospital in Greenwood, Miss. He was 81 years old.

title: Nebraska Upsets Oklahoma
description: Brian Carr scored 18 points, including a 10-foot jumper with 4 seconds left, to give Nebraska a Big Eight triumph, 66-64, over nationally ranked Oklahoma tonight.

title: NOTRE DAME WINS BY 102-47
description: No one could have explained Manhattan College's plight any better than did its coach, Tom Sullivan, after Notre Dame overwhelmed his team, 102-47, in the second game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Israel Rejects Ultimatum
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said tonight that Israel rejected an ultimatum by the Islamic Resistance Front to kill one of two captured Israeli soldiers unless Israel called off its search operation.

title: Bridge: When Overcall Is Possible As 'Trap Pass' Alternative
description: If your right-hand opponent opens the bidding in a suit in which you have length and strength, the normal strategy is to pass, without any revealing hesitation. Usually there is no alternative to this ''trap pass,'' but sometimes an overcall is possible in another suit.

title: Congress; The Global Village: A Case in Point
description: Senator Thad Cochran, a Mississippi Republican, was part of the American team that monitored the Philippine elections two weeks ago. When he returned home he was stunned to find how many constituents were aware of those elections and wanted to express concern about the outcome.

title: Why Clothing Sizes Aren't Standardized
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLTZMAN STUDIES LOAN TEACHER GAVE PRINCIPAL
description: The inspector general of the Board of Education is meeting with the Brooklyn District Attorney to determine if there has been any illegality in the case of a principal who solicited $6,000 in loans from a subordinate seeking a promotion, the Schools Chancellor said yesterday.

title: HUSSEIN DECISION: END OF THE LINE IN MIDDLE EAST?
description: King Hussein's break with the political leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization today was viewed here as a setback for the Middle East peace process. Many diplomats said they believed the development could mean the end of the decade-long American-brokered effort to obtain land for the Palestinians in return for recognition and security for Israel.

title: Wells Fargo Debt Is Under Review
description: Ratings on about $3.4 billion of Wells Fargo & Company debt is under review for possible upgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: SAMPLING OF THE LATEST IN FLASHLIGHTS
description: CHOOSING the right household flashlight can be confusing; price, size, shape and bulb type vary. Here is a sampling of some of the new sturdy and versatile flashlights on the market.

title: CINDERELLA TRANSFORMATIONS: SMALL SPACES LOOK LARGER
description: ''IT was a nightmare; I was horrified,'' says Jim Gauer, a New York designer, about the first time he saw the small one-bedroom garden apartment a friend, Mary Mower, bought last year in an Upper West Side brownstone. ''You walked into a dark narrow corridor,'' he said. ''The stand-up kitchen and the bathroom opened directly off the living room, which was dark. The bedroom was 7 by 10 feet and the whole grim thing totaled only 450 square feet.''

title: Land Mine Kills 36 in Sri Lanka
description: A land mine planted by Tamil separatists blew up a truck carrying villagers to a market in northeastern Sri Lanka today, killing at least 36 people and wounding 20, Government officials said.

title: Eastern's Pilots Set Up Pickets in 11 Cities
description: Pilots for Eastern Airlines set up informational picket lines outside airports in 11 cities today while a Federal mediator here held talks aimed at averting a possible strike next week.

title: LIABILITY INSURANCE: A GROWING CRISIS
description: Soaring increases in liability-insurance rates are affecting thousands of residents of New York and other states, forcing cutbacks in the operations of everything from school districts and local governments to bowling alleys and day-care centers.

title: SENATE CONDEMNS PHILIPPINE RESULT AS RIFE WITH FRAUD
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to condemn corruption in the Philippine election, as sentiment mounted on Capitol Hill to restrict American aid to the Manila Government and to try to force President Ferdinand E. Marcos from power.

title: MARCOS WARNS HIS FOES AND ASSAILS INTERVENTION
description: As President Reagan's special envoy continued his consultations here Wednesday on the Philippine political turmoil, President Ferdinand E. Marcos denounced what he called foreign ''intervention in the internal affairs of our people.''

title: Test Pilot Comments On Midwest Air Crash
description: The senior test pilot for the Douglas Aircraft Company, manufacturer of the Midwest Express Airlines DC-9 that crashed on takeoff last fall, told a Federal investigative panel today that there might have been a breakdown of communications in the cockpit.

title: U.S. ACTS TO REVAMP ANTITRUST LAW
description: The Reagan Administration submitted to Congress today proposals for the most sweeping changes in Federal antitrust laws since their passage almost 100 years ago, in what it portrayed as an effort to help American business become more competitive in global markets.

title: CHARLES SEES VICTORY SITE, LOSING OUT IN TESTING TACO
description: The Prince of Wales, on the second day of a four-day visit marking the Republic of Texas's 150th birthday, sampled a taco today and toured an oil refinery and the battlefield where Texas won its independence.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A BASEMENT that cannot be used because it is too damp may be needlessly wasting as much as 50 percent of a home's living and storage space. The problem can usually be solved, sometimes with simple and relatively inexpensive amateur measures. Even if a professional contractor must do the job, the expense, which can be considerable, is usually worthwhile.

title: BACKMAN LOSES CASE TO METS
description: The Mets won one and signed one on the salary arbitration front yesterday. They learned that they won their case against Wally Backman, and they avoided a hearing today with Bob Ojeda by reaching agreement with him on a two-year, $1.2 million contract.

title: Duome & Associates To Handle Japanese
description: Having worked for both Doremus & Company and Albert Frank-Guenther Law, the two bastions of Wall Street advertising and public relations, Joseph J. Duome, at age 60, has decided to go out and do it himself, and will specialize in representing Japanese corporations.

title: Required Reading; 'Home Front'
description: Patti Davis, the 33-year-old actress who is the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan, is co-author, with Maureen Strange Foster, of a newly published book, ''Home Front.'' The work is labeled a novel, but some of the prose evokes familiar images, and the plot line has a somewhat familar ring in that it portrays a staunchly conservative California Governor with a fashion-conscious wife and stubbornly independent children who becomes President. Following are excerpts:

title: MANILA FOES PLAN THEIR NEXT MOVE
description: The talk of compromise and conciliation heard from Washington today seemed distant from realities here.

title: Texas Women Win 25th in Row
description: Fran Harris scored 19 of her game-high 27 points to lead Texas to a 45-16 halftime advantage, and No. 1-ranked Lady Longhorns went on to rout Southern Methodist, 105-48, tonight for their 25th straight victory.

title: It's Not a Board of Strategy
description: Though it is probably extravagant for the Navy to be reactivating battleships like the Iowa, that is no reason for New Yorkers to reject berthing the vessel and her support ships on Staten Island. And while the General Accounting Office may be right to charge that they could be berthed more cheaply elsewhere, that's a question for a budget-minded Congress to answer soon. New York's Board of Estimate can decide only whether or not to accept the facility if the Navy basing plan finally prevails. It should do so forthwith.

title: General Felt Raises Its Offer for Sheller
description: An investor group led by General Felt Industries, a furniture, carpeting and floor products company, said it had sweetened its bid for the Sheller-Globe Corporation to $46.50 a share, from $43 a share.

title: Macy Group Sees Sharp Rise in Debt
description: The management group planning to acquire R. H. Macy & Company in a leveraged buyout said yesterday that the new company's total debt would rise more than tenfold to $3.7 billion, from the company's current $324 million in short- and long-term debt.

title: Lost in the Limbo of State and Local Bonds
description: To the Editor:

description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, succeeded yesterday where other central bankers had recently failed in halting the dollar's steep three-week decline.

description: The Coca-Cola Company is expected to announce within days that it will purchase the Dr Pepper Company, according to Beverage Digest, a soft drink industry newsletter.

title: THE THEATER: A MUSICAL 'MOBY DICK'
description: A MUSICAL ''Moby Dick'' is at least as unlikely a theatrical venture as a musical based on T. S. Eliot's cat poems or one about the game of chess. The other primary candidate for great American novel, ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,'' is a far more suitable subject for musicalization. In that last instance, the Broadway adapters changed the title to ''Big River,'' perhaps to alert theatergoers to the fact that they were seeing a variation rather than the whole ''Huck.'' Were the creators of ''Moby Dick,'' the musical, similarly inclined, they could have entitled their show, ''Small Whale.''

title: Portuguese Group Says It Planted Bomb
description: A radio station said today that an anonymous caller had asserted that a left-wing Portuguese terrorist group planted the bomb that exploded Tuesday in the trunk of an American marine's car inside the gates of the United States Embassy compound.

title: CITY'S NEW INVESTIGATION CHIEF STARTS SHAKE-UP
description: Kenneth Conboy, the city's newly named Investigation Commissioner, has begun a shakeup of the agency, saying it suffers from a ''crisis in confidence'' because of its failure to detect corruption in the Parking Violations Bureau.

description: Jim Dutcher, the former University of Minnesota basketball coach, confirmed today a report that he suspended two members of the team for drug abuse, but refused to identify them.

title: Disney Is Sued
description: Saul P. Steinberg, the New York investor, has filed a suit against the Walt Disney Company seeking to invalidate Disney's buyback of his stock and have his stake in the entertainment and real estate concern returned. A Disney spokesman, Erwin Okun, said that the suit by Mr. Steinberg and his Reliance Group Holdings, which was filed in Superior Court on Tuesday, was ''without merit.''

title: JOHNSON BOUGHT, THEN REJECTED, LOCKING CAPSULES
description: In 1984, two years after seven people died from cyanide-tainted Tylenol capsules in Chicago, Johnson & Johnson purchased a new system that claimed to make capsules tamper resistant. But Johnson & Johnson decided against using the new technique, saying it found the system wanting.

title: Pirates' Bounty
description: The Pirates, whose gate receipts of $5.4 million were the lowest in the National League last season, scratched together $136,455 by staging a 15-hour ticket-selling drive at 30 locations throughout the Pittsburgh area on Tuesday. General Manager Syd Thrift, Manager Jim Leyland and several of their players visited a number of the booths and distributed what a Pirate spokesman described as ''tons of literature.'' That sounds like pretty heavy work for such a relatively meager return, but the buttons that were also handed out by team representatives provided an explanation: ''I'd do anything for a Buc.''

title: Boy, 15, Convicted of Murder In Deaths of AdoptiveParents
description: A jury yesterday convicted a 15-year-old boy of second-degree murder and arson for the deaths of his adoptive parents in Marion, N.Y., near Rochester, in September 1984.

title: CAPTURED ISRAELI IS REPORTED SLAIN
description: An anonymous caller said tonight that an Islamic fundamentalist group had killed one of two Israeli soldiers it captured in southern Lebanon on Monday.

title: A MORMON COLONY THRIVES IN MEXICO
description: A HUNDRED years ago, a group of Mormons loaded their possessions and families onto wagons and moved to Mexico to seek a place to practice polygamy free from interference and to establish a beachhead from which to convert Mexico to Mormonism.

title: GUNMAN TAKES AND FREES 2 HOSTAGES
description: An ex-convict who was dismissed from his job in a midtown tax-preparer's business Tuesday returned to the office with a shotgun yesterday afternoon and took two of his former co-workers hostage, the police said.

title: FORETASTE OF SPRING AT FLOWER SHOWS
description: A FLOWER show may be just what gardeners need to brighten spirits and reassure themselves that spring will soon be here. The following listing includes the schedules and themes of the major flower shows that will be held in the Northeast this year: March 1-9: New Jersey Flower and Garden Show, National Guard Armory, Western Avenue, Morristown.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MARYA: A Life. By Joyce Carol Oates. 310 pages. William Abrahams/Dutton. $16.95. VIEWED from its narrowest perspective, Joyce Carol Oates's latest novel, ''Marya: A Life,'' could be described as a textbook psychological study of a feminist. Marya Knauer is abandoned by her parents early in her life. Because of her father's violent death in a labor dispute and her mother's unwillingness to raise their children alone, Marya and her brothers are dumped with relatives.

description: The Baldwin-United Corporation yesterday named Peter A. Martosella Jr., company president, to the additional post of chief executive, presaging the end of a three-year bankruptcy reorganization.
