title: C.D. YIELDS OFF: SOME FUNDS UP
description: Average yields for six-month certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed in the week ended yesterday.

title: 15.7% JUMP IN BUILDING OF HOUSING
description: Construction of new homes surged 15.7 percent in January, the biggest jump in almost two years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: AETNA LIFE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized capital losses of $14.8 million for the quarter and $58.5 million for the year. The year result also includes an extraordinary gain of $4 million. c- Including realized capital gains of $42.5 million for the quarter an after a realized capital loss of $54.8 million for the year.

title: Treasury Bonds Fall Modestly
description: Treasury bond prices moved erratically yesterday before closing with modest declines as traders digested comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, and concluded that the Fed is not likely to push for lower short-term interest rates in the near future.

title: NAPA VALLEY FLOODS MAY HAVE SPARED VINES
description: More than 6,000 acres of prime vineyards in California's Napa Valley were flooded by record rains in the past week. But as the community mopped up the mess today after the downpour tapered off, the good news from the valley was that the flooding was not expected to result in any lasting damage to the vineyards.

title: Setback Off the Ice
description: With an income of $1 million or so a year, Wayne Gretzky is a wealthy investor, but as a professional hockey player since the age of 17 the Edmonton Oiler star has not had an opportunity to take college courses in business and finance that could teach him how to invest his money wisely. For that he has had to rely on the school of hard knocks.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: A League of Their Own
description: If George Brett and his baseball brothers keep it up, they may have to rename the Class A Northwest League the Brett Brothers League. The brothers have just purchased their second team in the league, the Tri-Cities Triplets in Richland, Wash.

title: DI GIORGIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $7.6 million for the quarter and $11.5 million for the year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1986
description: The Economy

title: WINN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $526,000. c-After a $1,033,000 loss on the extinguishment of long-term debt. d-Net income after tax credits and a special dividend from the Federal Home Loan Bank totaling $481,000.

title: NETS FIZZLE OUT IN STRETCH DRIVE
description: The hard times continue. Tonight, the Nets dragged themselves through another miserable performance, losing to one of the league's lightweights and pushing their losing streak to four games. Worse, they did it just two nights before a game with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Technology; Mining Seeks Modernization
description: AT the Phelps Dodge Corporation's open pit copper mine near Tyrone, N.M., a computer directs drivers in the fleet of 25 huge trucks to whatever shovel is ready to load them.

title: LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the quarter and $1,190,000 for the year, an extraordinary charge of $286,000 for the quarter relating to adjustment of tax credits, and including an extraordinary gain of $13,621,000 for the year from a debt buyout and tax credits. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,379,000 for the quarter and $1,585,000 for the year.

title: WESTERN TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Agnes de Mille Lecture
description: Agnes de Mille will speak tonight at 8 at the Martha Graham School, 316 East 63d Street.

title: MEDAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results include a DISC tax credit of $2.4 million for the quarter and year.

title: Noblesse Oblige
description: The Detroit Pistons' Chuck Nevitt, who, at 7 feet 5 inches, tends to stand out in a crowd: ''Sometimes a person will see me and say, 'Oh, my God!' I tell 'em, 'Just call me Chuck.' ''

title: PAN AM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $3 million for the quarter and year. c-Net losses. The latest quarter and year nets include a $341 million gain from the sale of the Pacific division of Pan American World Airways. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about banking regulation incorrectly described the possibility of an increase in banks' minimum capital-asset ratios, to 9 percent from 6 percent. Regulatory officials have raised the possibility of a gradual increase for all banks, but have not formally proposed it.

title: KOCH WON'T FORCE AMERUSO FROM JOB
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that although he believes Transportation Commissioner Anthony R. Ameruso violated ''the spirit of the law'' by obscuring his involvement in a real-estate deal, he would not be dismissed because he has only a week left on the job.

title: G.O.P. FEUD IN CALIFORNIA COULD BE PARTY BLESSING
description: As Governor of California two decades ago, President Reagan was the leading exponent of what California Republicans still call the 11th Commandment: ''Thou shalt not speak ill of another Republican.''

title: Bank Restates Net Results
description: Louisiana's largest banking company has been directed to restate its fourth-quarter and full-year 1985 results after a ruling by bank examiners of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that the company had not taken big enough charges for bad energy loans.

title: PREMIER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $245,000.

title: BARENBOIM'S BEETHOVEN PIANO SERIES
description: Beethoven, a composer who struggled for architectural completeness, obviously inspires a similar urge in those who perform him. The latest is Daniel Barenboim, who begins his eight-concert survey of the complete piano sonatas Sunday afternoon at 4 o'clock. Avery Fisher Hall, the site of Sunday's concert, and Carnegie Hall, where Mr. Barenboim will continue the series next Friday, are demonstrating their own kind of unity in the project. Often considered rivals, the two houses will share this Beethoven cycle, which stretches well into next season.

title: AQUINO ASKS WEST TO BOYCOTT INAUGURAL
description: Corazon C. Aquino asked 13 Western European countries and Japan today to boycott President Ferdinand E. Marcos's inaugural and withhold recognition.

title: AIRPORT SECURITY TO GET U.S. REVIEW
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole today announced a ''comprehensive review'' of security conditions and procedures at the nation's airports.

title: Grande Bande
description: The Grande Bande of New York will present music by Mozart, Haydn and J. C. Bach on original period instruments at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night at 8. Frederick Renz will conduct. Tickets are $14; information: 362-1911.

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Turning the Corner on School Dropouts
description: Keeping children in school is as important a challenge as any facing the New York City school system, and officials have a right to be jubilant over news that their recent new efforts to fight the dropout rate appears to be having some effect. The danger is that the joy will give way to complacency.

title: U.S. FINDS MEXICO EXPORTS MOST HEROIN AND MARIJUANA
description: The State Department's annual report on worldwide narcotics production says Mexico has once again become the largest exporter of marijuana and heroin to the United States and calls that the ''principal disappointment'' of the last year.

title: C3 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Surgeon Accused Of Raping Patient
description: A plastic surgeon was indicted yesterday on charges that he raped a patient after placing her under sedation.

title: ELECTRO-BIOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $59,000 for the quarter and $419,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $116,000 for the quarter and $215,000for the year.

title: Alien Is in Contempt In U.S. Smuggling Trial
description: A Federal Judge cited a Salvadoran woman for contempt of court today and ordered her held under house arrest after she refused to testify in the trial of 11 people charged with smuggling illegal aliens into the country.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A caption on Jan. 25 under a picture showing the presentation of a bust to Winnie Mandela, the South African anti-apartheid activist, omitted the name of the sculptor. He was Robert Berks.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Why Affluent Elderly Belong in Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: 200 Believed Rounded Up
description: Lebanese arriving here from southern Lebanon reported that Israeli troops rounded up 200 people today during their search operation.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Art Farmer-Benny Golson Jazztet, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South (242-1785). The reunion of the Art Farmer-Benny Golson Jazztet was some of the best jazz news in years. Mr. Farmer is a thoughtfully lyrical soloist with the loveliest of trumpet and fluegelhorn sounds, and Mr. Golson, whose compositions from the 50's and early 60's include an unusually large proportion of enduring standards, is at his best when he writes for a band he knows. This one, with the punch of Curtis Fuller's trombone added to the front line, is the attraction tonight through Sunday. Shows are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. There is a $10 cover charge and a $6 minimum.

title: FEMINIST SAYS SEXUAL EQUALITY IN ISRAEL IS ILLUSORY
description: On paper, women in Israel seem to have gone far in obtaining equal rights, but appearances are deceptive and discrimination is pervasive, Alice Shalvi, a prominent Israeli feminist, told two groups of American women here yesterday.

title: MAXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $300,000 for the quarter and 9 months for settlement of litigation regarding pension withdrawal liability assessment. c-After an extraordinary charge of $390,000 for settlement of litigation.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: REBUILDING OF DESTROYED PHILADELPHIA AREA REMAINS MIRED IN CONTROVERSY
description: Two months after the original deadline for rebuilding the 61 houses destroyed in a fire resulting from a police confrontation with the radical group Move, the reconstruction program is stuck in thick mud and swirling controversy.

title: NEWHALL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: ECONOMY UP AT SLOW 1.2% RATE
description: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 1.2 percent in the final three months of last year, only half as fast as was estimated in January, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A BURST OF MOSLEM FERVOR IN NIGERIA: THE NORTH STIRS AND THE SOUTH FRETS
description: In a room next to the open-air student mosque at Bayero University, Abubakar Imam Ali-Agan nudged his red felt cap up off his forehead. A Koran, the edges of its pages blackened from use, lay on the table before him.

title: Defense Contractor Forms 3 New Units
description: In a move intended to expand its space-related business activities, particularly with the Defense Department, the United Technologies Corporation announced yesterday that it had formed three new business units and named executives to head two of the operations.

title: Marilyn Horne Recital
description: Marilyn Horne will give a recital at the Colden Center of Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and Long Island Expressway, in Flushing, on March 8 at 8:30 P.M. The mezzo-soprano will sing works by Vivaldi, Handel, Mahler, Alvarez, Nin, Monsalvatge, Barber, Donaudy, Copeland, Verdi, Tosti and Arditi.

title: PORT AUTHORITY SEEKS TOLL RISE FOR COMMUTERS
description: The price of commuter discount tickets on the Port Authority bridges and tunnels should be increased, to $1.60 from $1, the agency's chairman said yesterday.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains on the sale of properties of $3,556,699, or 72 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,178,672, or $1.08 a share, for the year. c-Including a gain on the sale of properties of $1,280,929, or 24 cents a share. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in September.

title: A Reading of Shaw
description: A staged reading of the George Bernard Shaw play ''Widower's Houses'' will be presented by the Shaw Project tonight at 7 o'clock at the Friends Meetinghouse, 15 Rutherford Place, between 15th and 16th Streets and Second and Third Avenues.

title: THEATER: 'THE CIRCLE'
description: IN a period of a dozen years, W. Somerset Maugham wrote a streak of popular plays that were consciously influenced by Restoration comedies. From ''Our Betters'' to ''The Constant Wife,'' these were plays that, in the author's words, treated ''with indulgent cynicism the humours, follies and vices of the world of fashion.''

title: DANCE: REED'S 'WITNESS'
description: PETER REED'S ''Witness: (1000 Cranes),'' presented Wednesday night at the Bette Stoler Gallery, takes its title from an old Japanese saying that anyone who folds 1,000 paper cranes will be rewarded with long life. According to Mr. Reed, some victims of the Hiroshima bombing folded cranes as a way of clinging to a hope of recovery.

title: Stressing Academics
description: The way Bill Curry, the Georgia Tech football coach, sees it, a few bad coaching apples are spoiling the college athletic barrel by not stressing the importance of academics to student athletes with little chance of succeeding in the pros. ''We have got a responsibility to young people to show them what the world is really like,'' Curry told a College Board meeting in Atlanta.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Pioneer Confirms Offer From Pickens
description: The Pioneer Corporation said yesterday that it had received a takeover bid from T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, acting as head of his new Mesa Limited Partnership. Both companies have major gas properties.

title: 9 7/8% Bond Issue By Florida Power
description: The Florida Power and Light Company is offering $150 million of 9 7/8 percent first mortgage bonds due 2016 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: FEDERAL HOME LOAN MORTAGE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary net gain of $10 million, or 59 cents a share.

title: SCHISMS AND LANDMARK BATTLES
description: Not since the Battle of Britain has control over air space generated so much conflict. The prospect of developers buying air rights to pile them into ever taller buildings has divided church congregations, most notably St. Bartholomew's, and caused neighborhoods, including the Upper East Side, to seek landmark status.

title: 300 IN SEOUL OPPOSITION DETAINED AS POLICE PREVENT PARTY MEETING
description: The Government deployed thousands of policemen and confined nearly 300 opposition party members to their homes today to prevent a party meeting from being held to discuss expanding a petition drive for a constitutional amendment.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $15,893,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $7,101,000 for the quarter, and including a capital gain of $23.7 million and income from discontinued operations of $5,035,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $6,264,000 for the quarter and $23,137,000 for the year and after capital losses of $27,307,000 for the quarter and $17,460,000 for the year.

title: More Than South Africa Is Involved in Angola
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Leon McLaughlin, a 60-year-old assistant coach who was dropped along with the rest of the St. Louis Cardinal staff when the former coach, Jim Hanifan, was dismissed after the National Football League season, has been rehired by the club as a special scouting assistant to the new coach, Gene Stallings. . . . Mark Breland, the Olympic welterweight champion who is undefeated in nine bouts as a professional, will face another unbeaten pro, Richard Aguirre, (13-0) in Lancaster, Pa., March 2. . . . Xavier McDaniel of the Seattle SuperSonics was fined $3,500 by the National Basketball Association for starting a fight in a game against the Atlanta Hawks Monday night, and two Hawks, Tree Rollins and Kevin Willis, were fined $500 each for their part in the incident. . . . Jack Moran, the race director, says the date of the $300,000 Twin Cities Marathon, scheduled for Sunday Oct. 12 in Minneapolis-St. Paul, had been moved up a week, to Oct. 5 to avoid a conflict with Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year. . . . Coach Matt Guokas of the Philadelphia 76ers says he would not be surprised if his guard Andrew Toney was unable to play again this season. Toney, who has stress fractures of both feet and bone spurs in his left foot, has played only five games this season.

title: POP: SONGS BY JOHN HIATT
description: JOHN HIATT, the Indianapolis-born singer and composer who now resides in Nashville, is a luminous talent with everything in his favor except significant commercial success. The 33-year-old singer, who performed a solo concert at the Bottom Line on Wednesday, has a wonderful, quirky voice that blends echoes of Boz Scaggs, Randy Newman and Elvis Costello into a personal style as soulful as his songs are droll.

title: DR. PEPPER BUILDS COKE'S LEAD
description: The Coca-Cola Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Dallas-based Dr Pepper Company for $470 million in a deal that is important both for the world of finance and the soft drink industry. It represents one of the largest windfalls ever for investors in a leveraged buyout and it is a shrewd strategic move by Coke to keep its No. 1 position.

title: FRED P. POMRANTZ, FOUNDER OF A WOMEN'S WEAR DAILY
description: Fred P. Pomerantz, founder and former chairman of Leslie Fay Inc., a leading New York producer of women's apparel, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: CIRCUIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BankAmerica Rebuffs Weill
description: Sanford I. Weill, the former president of the American Express Company, approached the BankAmerica Corporation about becoming its chief executive, but was rebuffed, a bank spokesman said today.

title: Bridge: When There's Good Reason To Do Something Abnormal
description: In crossing a one-way street few people bother to watch for cars going in the wrong direction, although many New Yorkers look both ways for bicycles.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
REAGAN, IN GRENADA, IS HAILED AS 'OUR OWN HERO'
description: President Reagan flew to this Caribbean nation today and told a crowd of thousands of cheering Grenadians that ''I will never be sorry'' that he ordered an invasion in October 1983.

title: DICOMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: QUININES ASKS BOARD TO REVIEW LOAN SOLICITING
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that he had asked a community school board in Brooklyn to ''reconvene and reconsider'' its decision not to seek disciplinary proceedings in the case of a school principal who solicited $6,000 in loans from a subordinate while she was seeking a promotion.

title: RADIANT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Argentina In I.M.F. Pact
description: Argentina said today that it had reached a deal with the International Monetary Fund that would enable it to draw $865 million in new finance from the fund and from creditor banks.

title: City's Reservoirs Close to Normal
description: The recent rains and snows have brought water levels in New York City's reservoirs - which hit a low of 44 percent during last year's drought - close to normal.

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 5
description: b-Includes a provision of $17.6 million to cover the company's previously announced plans for the disposition or discontinuance of a number of restaurant units.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SECRET C.I.A. RESEARCH ON CAMPUS: HARVARD REWEIGHS GUIDELINES OF 1970'S
description: Three times in recent months Harvard University's undergraduate newspaper, The Crimson, has reported that the Central Intelligence Agency was financing confidential research by Harvard professors.

title: Navy Submarine Examining Underwater Debris for Clues
description: A nuclear-powered Navy research submarine dived 1,200 feet to the ocean floor today to examine sunken debris that investigators believe may hold clues to the explosion that destroyed the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Jersey Chemical Plant Fire
description: A 250-gallon vat of linseed oil spilled and caught fire today, resulting in heavy damage to a building at a chemical plant.

title: YANKS ARE GOING ON CAMERA
description: The Yankees will go to the movies this spring, and they hope that what they see is not X-rated.

title: BAKER, VOLCKER CALL DISCORD MINOR
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, sought today to dispel appearances of a policy split over the dollar and interest rates.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
People
description: * Peter Falcone, president of DDB/ New York, has been elected to the board of Doyle Dane Bernbach Group.

title: FILM: 'FRENCH LESSON'
description: ''FRENCH LESSON,'' which opens today at the Festival, is about Jenny, a pretty, well-brought-up, English teen-ager who's sent to Paris to learn French and, not surprisingly, learns a good deal more.

title: Cuts in Urban Aid Challenged
description: Four Democratic members of Congress filed a suit today against President Reagan's withholding of about $8 billion in Federal aid to cities.

title: WESTERN HEALTH PLANS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ART PEOPLE
description: THEIR names are Ulay and Marina, and their art is to sit at a table opposite each other for seven hours at a stretch, not moving, not talking, rarely blinking. The team, a man and woman whose full names are Uwe Laysiepen and Marina Abramovic, are well-known members of the European avant-garde, and they will perform their work at the New Museum (583 Broadway, between Houston and Prince Streets) tonight, tomorrow and Sunday, from noon to 6 P.M. The artists will begin a half-hour before the museum opens and finish a half-hour after it closes.

title: ENERGY OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BENIHANA NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 5
description: b-Net income.

title: Topics; Small Change Take It or Leave It
description: The great American penny shortage is over. In 1985, after years of hoarding pennies, Americans started turning them in to banks in record numbers, reports The Wall Street Journal.

title: Baretto and Valentin
description: The conga player Ray Baretto will lead his Latin jazz band and the flutist Dave Valentin is leading his quintet in double bills through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Shows begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus 1 A.M. shows tonight and tomorrow; there is a $12 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: G.M. PLANS OPTIONAL AIR BAGS FOR SOME CARS
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would offer a new air-bag system as optional equipment on selected 1988 automobile models. The air bags will be available on the driver's side only and will be designed to work with, not in place of, seat belts.

title: CONTRA RAIDS REPORTED TRAILING OFF
description: Diplomats and military analysts here said in interviews this week that rebel activity has declined sharply in recent months and that the Sandinista Government is in its strongest military position since it took power six and a half years ago.

title: WORKED WITH YOUTH GANGS
description: Hugh K. Johnson, a social worker and authority on juvenile delinquency who worked with New York City street gangs in the 1950's, died of a heart attack Feb. 12 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Washington. He was 65 years old and lived in Washington.

title: ROCKY START FAILS TO KILL SEATTLE CENTER PROJECT
description: Business and government leaders here are going forward with construction of a convention center in the face of the bankruptcy of a real estate company and the failure of a savings and loan association that were major participants.

title: For Tree Fanciers
description: Urban dwellers who want to spruce up their neighborhoods with new trees can learn how to go about it at a free seminar Sunday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue.

title: RUSSELL BURDSALL & WARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $130,000 for the quarter; an extraordinary gain of $1,158,000 and an extraordinary gain of $3,283,000 from a pension reversion program for the year. c-After an extraordinary charge of $518,000 for the quarter; an extraordinary gain of $1,251,000 for the year and an extraordinary gain of $10,902,000 for the quarter and year from the termination of pension plans.

title: Change Urged in Fees For Medicare Doctors
description: Medicare's payment policies have fueled increases in the cost of doctors' services under the Government's health insurance plan for the elderly, a Congressional report said today.

title: PIERRE LAROUCHE IS HOME
description: First they took his job, then they took his number, then they kept him at Hershey, Pa., for nearly four months when the Rangers were having trouble scoring goals. But they didn't take away Pierre Larouche's quick hands, or his feel for the open spot on the ice, and eventually they had to call him back.

title: 3,000 MOURN VAN ARSDALE AT CATHEDRAL
description: More than 3,000 people - from union members in work clothes to politicians in pin-striped suits - gathered yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral to mourn Harry Van Arsdale Jr., for decades one of New York's most powerful labor leaders.

title: Editor of New York Now Publisher Also
description: The honor - and challenge - of being both editor and publisher of a magazine is not common in American publishing circles, although a few outstanding joint holders come to mind.

title: NWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $30.9 million for the quarter and year from a legal settlement.

title: ART: AT THE WHITNEY, 28 ERIC FISCHL PAINTINGS
description: IF the paintings of Eric Fischl get people hot and bothered, it is for a very good reason. He presses down hard upon the exposed nerve of our time. Where others amuse and flatter, he bites. Even those who disdain to feel themselves personally involved recognize that a genuine predator is at work.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $959,000 for the quarter and $86,368,000 for the year. c-Including net income from discontinued operations of $674,000 for the quarter and $7,787,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been reclassified to conform to 1985 classifications.

title: AIFS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings are not available as the company went public on Feb. 5, 1986.

title: COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $314,000 for the quarter and $2,665,000 for the year. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $$1,146,000 for the quarter and $4,442,000 for the year.

title: SANITAS SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,622,000 for the quarter and $1,744,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $123,000. d-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $742,000.

title: High-Tech Babies: a Growth Industry
description: Technological baby-making is increasingly being merchandised just like any other consumer product. State-of-the-art physicians, high-powered lawyers and fast-lane entrepreneurs are all working to make high-tech coupling big business. But the whole enterprise has created a mountain of legal and ethical questions. The nation must pause to address them.

title: Key Executive Shifts For Stone & Webster
description: Stone & Webster Inc., the engineering, design and construction company, announced yesterday that William F. Allen had been named president and would be elected chief executive at the annual meeting in May.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The John Abercrombie Trio, the Gary Burton Group, and Oregon, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue at 17th Street (533-7902). These groups are all premiere acts on the ECM label, which offers the finest in cerebral, European-inflected jazz. Mr. Abercrombie, a jazz-rock fusion guitarist, is leading a trio that includes Marc Johnson on bass and the drummer Peter Erskine. In addition to playing the guitar, he is experimenting with a guitar-synthesizer. Sharing the bill is the vibraharpist Gary Burton and his group, which includes Steve Swallow on electric bass, Makoto Ozone on piano, Martin Richards on drums, and Tommy Smith on saxophone. Performances tonight and tomorrow are at 8, 10 P.M. and midnight and there is a $12.50 cover charge and a $7.50 minimum. Oregon, which is appearing on Sunday, blends American jazz, Indian music and European classicism into a meditative, translucent ''world music.'' The group, which suffered a tragic loss with the death of the percussionist Collin Walcott in 1984, is now a quartet and includes Paul McCandless on reeds, the bassist Glen Moore, Ralph Towner on guitars and keyboards, and the percussionist Trilok Gurtu. Showtimes on Sunday are 8 and 10. There is a $15 cover charge and a $10 minimum.

title: GULFSTREAM: QUICKSAND TO QUICK TRACK
description: The neatest bit of race-track magic this winter was the one performed by the Gulfstream Park track-maintenance workers. They turned one of the fastest tracks in the country into one of the slowest for six weeks, then yesterday suddenly turned it back into one of the fastest.

title: LETTER BY KOCH TO DER SPIEGEL CALLS AN ARTICLE ANTI-SEMITIC
description: Mayor Koch has written to a West German news magazine, calling it anti-Semitic for writing that in his 1977 campaign, ''the beautiful Jewess Bess Myerson appeared before the voters side by side with the ugly Jew Ed Koch.''

title: 3 Arrested in Killing Of U.S. Drug Informer
description: A Government drug informer was shot dead by machine guns in a parking lot here Wednesday night.

title: TORO COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BOUILLABAISSE TO TETE DE VEAU: WHERE TO FIND BISTRO DISHES
description: Ask a Frenchman in New York to define real French food and chances are he will reply without hesitation, ''Bistro food - soups, stews, steak pommes frites, cassoulet, mussels mariniere, country pate.'' And the list of homey fare goes on, with variations reflecting the individual's native region. An Alsatian would add choucroute to the lineup, while a Marseillaise, no doubt, would include bouillabaisse.

title: J. Bonanno, Lobbyist
description: Among lobbyists who have registered for the current session of Congress is Joseph C. Bonanno Jr., of Campbell, Calif., whose most recent official contact with the halls of government involved his discharge from Federal prison last November after serving four months for lying in connection with a San Diego cocaine investigation. His 80-year-old father, now retired in Arizona, recounted his years as a leader of organized crime in a 1983 autobiography, ''A Man of Honor.''

title: Savimbi and Marcos

title: FILM: 'STRAIGHT THROUGH THE HEART'
description: ''Straight Through the Heart'' was shown as part of the New Directors/ New Films Series in 1984. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 1, 1984. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street.

title: ART: PRINT EXHIBITION AT BROOKLYN MUSEUM
description: THE moment of death now being a matter of legal debate, is it any wonder that nobody can say anymore what an artist is, much less come up with a definition for a print? Those exercised by the latter question should not expect an answer from the Brooklyn Museum's 24th National Print Exhibition - the work of Barry Walker, who is associate curator in its prints and drawings department. But in addition to a snappy selection of a hundred wholly or partly printed images, they will find the problem admirably defined and accounted for in Mr. Walker's catalogue essay.

title: 3 YEARS LATER, ILLINOIS IS STILL TRYING TO SOLVE TYLENOL DEATHS
description: The Illinois state police say they are closely following three leads in the continuing investigation into the deaths of seven residents of the Chicago area from cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules more than three years ago.

description: The Polish authorities who threatened to expel Donna Sue Kersey, an American, relented today and granted her a residence permit, allowing her to remain with her Polish husband.

description: Human rights groups seeking action in the capital must often battle to make themselves heard, conducting protests or mail campaigns to draw attention to their cause.

title: Changing the Rules

''If the big-money tennis stars are allowed to play in the Olympics, there is no reason why Nehemiah and Gault should be banned,'' said Primo Nebiolo, the president of the International Amateur Athletics Federation.

title: Soviet Ties With Ivory Coast

Mr. Houphouet-Boigny had contended that the Soviet Ambassador tried to organize an insurrection. A brief statement issued by the Government said the two nations would ''start anew in the shortest time possible the activities of the embassies of each country in the capital of the other.''

title: MUSIC: RUDOLF SERKIN WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
description: SOME good things never change. The sun comes up every day and Rudolf Serkin goes right on playing the piano with his own inimitable mixture of technical brilliance and musical integrity. Mr. Serkin joined the New York Philharmonic last night, exactly half a century from the date of his debut with the orchestra, for a remarkable performance of Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto. This was not playing of the haphazard sort that elder statesmen of the keyboard sometimes offer, knowing we will forgive them and fill in the blanks from fond memory, but Beethoven pianism on Mr. Serkin's own highest level. He is that rarity, a performer who has attained great age and musical understanding while retaining the facility to make his hard-earned insights apparent to the listener.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COME MORNING. By Joe Gores. 218 pages. The Mysterious Press. $15.95. THE STAKED GOAT. By Jeremiah Healy. 232 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95. TAILOR'S DUMMY. By Irving Weinman. 215 pages. Atheneum. $13.95. EIGHT years ago Runyan cracked open a diamond merchant's safe in San Francisco. It was an inside job -an obliging security guard called Cardwell, who owed Runyan a favor from Vietnam, had proposed it to him, and let him into the office. It was also a double-cross - at the last moment Cardwell pulled a gun. Although Runyan was hit, he managed to make his escape; then the law caught up with him, and he drew 15 years to life at San Quentin, but not before he had stashed away the diamonds in a safe place.

description: Oil drilling in the Great Lakes is disapproved by a ''statement of principle'' to be signed Sunday by eight Governors, the office of Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan announced today.

title: It's Now Navistar
description: As expected, the shareholders of International Harvester voted overwhelmingly today to approve changing the company's name to the Navistar International Corporation. The vote, at the company's annual meeting, was 46.7 million shares in favor to 474,000 against, with 498,000 abstentions. The Chicago-based truck manufacturer, had proposed changing its name following the completion of the sale of its agricultural equipment business to J. I. Case, a subsidiary of Tenneco, in January.

title: OHIO BALLET: MODERN AND CLASSICAL MIX
description: Classical ballet companies are turning increasingly to modern dance for additions to their repertories. Ballerinas clamber onto chairs these days and duets are danced to what sounds like the thudding of a jogger's heart. The two kinds of dance don't mix, purists say. But Heinz Poll disagrees. And those who attend performances by his Ohio Ballet this weekend at the Joyce Theater will have an unusual chance to sample both.

SWITCHCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Bankers Trust Company's commercial-paper activities misidentified the government body that chartered Chemical Bank and Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. They are state-chartered.

title: No More Rich Uncle to Rich Allies
description: Before subjecting the nation to another wrenching year-long battle over the deficit, Congress should scrutinize the budget's remaining huge sacred cow - the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: TRADING AIR TO BUILD TOWERS
description: At a site on West 56th Street, Bruce Eichner has assembled enough air to build New York's tallest residential building.

title: Botha Declines Meeting With Churchmen
description: President P. W. Botha, citing a tight schedule and lack of warning, declined to meet today with a delegation of leading anti-Government churchmen, including Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, to discuss South Africa's latest violence.

title: Compaq Adds 3 Computers
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation introduced a series of faster, lighter-weight portable computers today that analysts said were likely to help extend the company's rapid sales growth.

description: b-After a pretax charge of $240,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $2.9 million for the quarter and year.

title: Seabrook Project Issues May Finish Financing
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday announced two bond issues totaling $288 million that are expected to complete the financing needed for the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LEFRAK PROPOSES PLAN TO RELIEVE LACK OF HOUSING
description: The developer Samuel J. Lefrak said yesterday that he was ready to build 2,000 apartments for moderate-income families in response to Mayor Koch's call for help from builders in easing the city's shortage of affordable housing.

title: Prisoner May Go Daily to Lawyer
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a reputed major organized-crime figure could leave a Federal detention center each day to go to his lawyer's office to help prepare his defense if he pays for an armed guard to accompany him, at a cost of $10 to $12 an hour.

title: RANGERS WIN 5TH IN A ROW
description: Beck was back, shoving and grousing, Larouche was darting, passing and scoring, and the Rangers never seemed so menacing and graceful.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
U.S. FILIPINOS FEEL THE STORM AT HOME
description: The tumultuous aftermath of the election in the Philippines has polarized Philippine-American activists.

title: BROADWAY
description: NOTHING has been signed, but there's a good possibility that Kathleen Turner will be returning to the stage soon. Miss Turner, who appeared in several Off Broadway productions before achieving movie stardom in such films as ''Prizzi's Honor'' and ''Romancing the Stone,'' has indicated her interest in ''The Widow's Blind Date,'' by Israel Horovitz.

title: Mr. Ameruso Minces the Law
description: Mayor Koch is right to hold his nose. Anthony Ameruso, New York City's departing Transportation Commissioner, has tentatively satisfied investigators that no crime was involved in a parking lot investment that earned him $120,000. Yet the deal still smells and the Mayor will continue to investigate. Besides a scandal-ridden parking agency, Mr. Ameruso leaves a trail of legal evasions.

title: BAKER, MICHAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Senate Links TV in Chamber To Bill on Procedural Changes
description: The Senate voted today to attach a proposal for televising its proceedings to a set of rule changes, including one governing filibusters.

title: APACHE PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After $137,824,000 for the quarter and year of additional amortization to reflect a reduction in the carrying value of oil and gas properties. c-Net income.

title: New Jersey Bell's 9.45% Debentures
description: The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, a unit of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, is offering $300 million of 9 3/8 percent debentures, due 2026, at 99 1/4 to yield 9.45 percent, through the First Boston Corporation.

title: DARLING LOSES IN ARBITRATION
description: Ron Darling, the No. 2 pitcher on the Mets, lost his arbitration case today and will work this year for $440,000, one-third as much as Dwight Gooden will earn as the No. 1 pitcher.

title: DANCE: THE OHIO BALLET IN POLOBOLUS'S 'UNTITLED'
description: PILOBOLUS has a genius for alluding to all manner of social contracts in dance without a trace of narrative. In Pilobolus's ''Untitled,'' for instance, two women bob, tiff, become pregnant and bear sons, all in the space of a summer picnic. Their long white summer dresses have a hint of the Edwardian to them, as do their gracious manners. But they are giants, standing, it turns out, on the shoulders of the sons they bear, who are hidden under their skirts.

title: ARCHITECTURE: ANTONIO SANT'ELIA
description: ANTONIO SANT'ELIA had the briefest of architectural careers: he was born in 1888, began to work as a draftsman in 1907 and was killed while fighting in World War I in 1916. He left behind almost no completed works of architecture, yet he is one of the most compelling figures modern architecture has ever produced.

title: Economic Scene; Fed-Treasury Crosscurrents
description: WHO is calling the shots on United States monetary policy, interest rates and the dollar - the Treasury or the Federal Reserve Board?

title: BACKERS AND OPPONENTS PACK HEARING ON HOME PORT PLAN
description: Hundreds of people packed a Board of Estimate hearing to overflowing yesterday as the board prepared to act on a plan to base the battleship Iowa and a six-ship support group on Staten Island.

title: Sheller Accepts General Felt Offer
description: The Sheller-Globe Corporation, an automotive parts company based in Toledo, Ohio, said its directors had approved an acquisition offer for about $482 million from a group led by General Felt Industries.

title: Nine Are Indicted In Sales Tax Case
description: Nine employees or former employees of Revillon Inc., a company that sells its furs through a salon at Saks Fifth Avenue, were indicted yesterday on charges of evading state and city sales taxes on nearly $600,000 in sales.

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the prior year include a gain of $230,000, or 2 cents a share, from non-operating fees from a cable television limited partnership sponsored by a unit of Heritage Communications.

title: Guinness Rebid
description: Guinness P.L.C., the brewing giant, raised its bid for the Distillers Company to the equivalent of $3.5 billion, coupling the offer with a revision aimed at meeting antitrust objections to the deal. Its previous $3.2 billion offer was to be the subject of an antitrust investigation by the British Government. The new bid tops the Argyll Group P.L.C.'s offer of $3.3 billion.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Final Round?
description: The Ring magazine, 64 years old and long on the ropes, may soon be down for the count.

title: DISCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in August 1985.

title: DEVILS WINNERS ON OVERTIME GOAL
description: The Devils were finally rewarded for their hard work tonight as they rallied from a two-goal deficit in the third period for a 4-3 victory in overtime over the Quebec Nordiques.

title: SCHOOL STAR MAY LEAVE EARLY
description: Lloyd Daniels, considered the top high school basketball player in the city and possibly the best junior in the country, is thinking about skipping his senior year at Andrew Jackson High School in Queens and entering college next fall, according to his advisers.

title: Article 692686 -- No Title
description: Orel Hershiser, whose 19 victories led Los Angeles pitchers last season, today became the first $1 million winner in salary arbitration this season.

FILING OF CHARGES AGAINST GROSS BY HEALTH DEPARTMENT UPHELD BY PANEL
description: A committee of the Board of Regents voted today that the state's Health Department had the jurisdiction to charge Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, with professional misconduct, according to a member of the committee.

title: But What Controls Control?
description: Mikhail Gorbachev celebrates the first anniversary of his assumption of power at next week's 27th Soviet party congress.

title: ASEA GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results have been calculated according to equity accounting and reflects earning of associated companies and actual taxes. Calculations are based on $1 equals 7.61 Swedish kroner.

description: The Occasional Singers, under the direction of Gil Robbins, will offer music by the contemporary composers Pasquale J. Spino, Nicholas Flagello, Emma Lou Diemer and Arline Diamond at St. Joseph's Church, Avenue of the Americas at Washington Place, tomorrow night at 8. Tickets are $3 to $10; information: 873-8095.

description: For skiers in the East, this has been an almost ideal winter.

description: They were five musicians from Peking who specialized in traditional Chinese music, and it was their first visit here.

title: 6 Miners Dead in Hungary
description: Searchers pulled the bodies of two more miners from a collapsed shaft in the Mecsek coal mine region, bringing the death toll to six in two separate cave-ins this week. The Budapest radio said today that the bodies of a Hungarian and a Pole were found overnight, and that rescuers were digging from two directions in an effort to find six miners still trapped 1,1505 feet underground.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday OPERA AT RANDOM His fascination has always been with random noise, the kind of accidental sounds he could coax from what he once called ''noninstruments.'' At a cocktail party several years ago, John Cage was listening, bored, to a Brahms symphony on the record player. Suddenly, the telephone rang and a door slammed shut, strange notes clawing into the music. ''Now isn't that beautiful?'' he said to a guest. Tonight and Saturday, Mr. Cage, the avant-garde composer who has used everything from computers to cactus plants to create music, is himself a sound to listen for: He is the ''spoken orchestra'' for an opera titled ''The Bus to Stockport and Other Stories.'' The work, based on Mr. Cage's stories, had its premiere last night and is part of the Opera Uptown series, at the Minor Latham Playhouse of Barnard College, 119th Street and Broadway. This weekend the performances are at 8 P.M., with a Saturday matinee at 2 P.M. The score is by Eric Valinsky and Peter Schubert, with additional music by Richard Einhorn and J. S. Bach. The director is Rhonda Rubinson. Don't frown on the idea of going more than once: the point of this work, Mr. Cage characteristically proposes, is that each performance is different and random, a unique blend of music and words, movements and lighting. Tickets are $3; $2 for people over 65 and Columbia University students with identification. Information: 280-2079.

title: Transit Academies
description: To the Editor:

title: GUARANTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $550,000 for the quarter and $1,723,000 for the year and a tax credit of $537,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss including capital gains of $1,137,000.

title: Dr. E. Lovell Becker Is Dead; Known for Kidney Research
description: Dr. E. Lovell Becker, former director of the department of medicine at Beth Israel Hospital and a leading figure in kidney research and treatment, died of complications resulting from diabetes Wednesday at Stony Brook (L.I.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Water Mill, L.I.

title: Market Place; Speculators, B.P. and Sohio
description: WHEN the British Petroleum Company renewed a $6.5 billion line of bank credit last October, speculators jumped to the conclusion that B.P. might use the money to acquire the 45 percent of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) it does not already own. Although this conjecture failed to pan out, it did succeed in driving Sohio's stock to a nearly two-year high of 55 3/4, up from 39 5/8 in January 1985.

title: INJURY STILL PAINFUL
description: Hubie Brown arrived here this morning encouraged by the belief that Patrick Ewing was healthy enough to return to the court after missing the last five games - all losses - because of an ailing right knee. But less than 30 minutes into practice the coach's joy was doused when Ewing left the floor complaining of more ''sharp'' pain.

title: COURSES AND DATA FOR WOMEN
description: New York City's Commission on the Status of Women has issued two booklets that encompass women's interests. One is an updated version of the ''Guide to Women's Studies'' and the other is ''Legislative Achievements for Women in New York State: A 20-Year Retrospective.''

title: CRAMER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SATHIMA BEA BENJAMIN, WITH A CAPE TOWN BEAT
description: SATHIMA BEA BENJAMIN can't go home again. Since she was last in her native South Africa, she has written and recorded music with such titles as ''Liberation Suite'' and performed at anti-apartheid benefits. ''I'm not welcome there, but that's the way it should be,'' she said. ''You have to make a commitment, one way or another, to be at peace with yourself.''

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: When Ed Feldman, the producer of 15 movies from ''Save the Tiger'' to his current co-production ''The Golden Child'' starring Eddie Murphy, watched a television rerun of ''Mission: Impossible'' several months ago, he decided the television adventure series, which ran from 1966 to 1973, ''could make a fun movie.'' So the series about a team of secret agents whose instructions self-destructed each week will be turned into a movie at Paramount. Peter Graves, who headed the television team after the show's first season, will co-star with three unknowns, and Mr. Feldman hopes the team members Greg Morris, Peter Lupus, Martin Landau and Barbara Bain will make cameo appearances. Paramount, which has had major success with three ''Star Trek'' movies, is also making a movie version of ''The Untouchables'' directed by Brian De Palma.

title: SUNLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $13,879 for the quarter and $74,904 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: IRAQI TROOPS PUSH BACK IRANIANS IN KEY GULF AREA
description: Advancing behind what a witness called a ''wall of fire,'' Iraqi troops today pushed back Iranians dug into the strategic Fao Peninsula at the edge of the Persian Gulf.

title: Child Dies and 2 Fall Ill With Rare Infection
description: Three cases of a relatively rare infection, including one case that killed a child, have been reported in Sequatchie County northwest of here, health officials said today.

title: CITY PANEL MEMBER'S ROLE IN S.I. PROJECTS QUESTIONED
description: A member of the City Planning Commission, John P. Gulino, represented two developers in acquiring property for multimillion-dollar projects on Staten Island that are subject to approval by the commission or other city agencies, court and city records show.

title: RICHARDSON SAID TO BE HURT IN SQUABBLE
description: Micheal Ray Richardson's troubled season has taken another strange turn. According to team sources, Richardson suffered a minor cut on the palm of his left hand during an incident early Thursday morning in which the police were called after the Net guard was said to have violated a restraining order and entered the Mahwah, N.J., home occupied by his wife and the couple's daughter.

title: CHINESE DAILIES CHANGE TACTICS AS IMMIGRANTS POUR INTO CITY
description: Some of New York's 10 Chinese-language daily newspapers - once genteel bulletin boards for marriage, business and community announcements -are sending their reporters out to hunt down stories on crime and justice.

title: The High Cost of Protecting Incompetents
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: IT'S an Edward Hopper painting come to life, this World War II coffee shop turned French bistro in the heart of the gritty West Side meat-market area. Formerly the R & L Restaurant, a stainless-steel-and-Formica hash house that catered to butchers and truck drivers in the market's heyday, it was recently taken over by a genial young Frenchmen, Florent Morellet. The new owner changed the name to Restaurant Florent while leaving the period decor largely intact.

title: Faust Tackles A Tough Task
description: Gerry Faust, who arrived on the University of Akron campus in December as the school's new football coach, has been attacking the job with the same unflagging enthusiasm that characterized his tenure at Notre Dame and, before that, at Cincinnati's Moeller High School. He has a big chore ahead of him, and not a lot of time in which to perform it: By 1987, he must have Akron ready to play a Division I-A schedule.

title: Marcos Must Go
description: The Administration and Congress now agree that Ferdinand Marcos is a usurper who needs to be quickly driven from Manila's presidential palace. They properly declare that to be a security interest of the United States, an affirmation of America's commitment to democracy and an obligation to the people of a former colony. The only questions concern tactics.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is essential, at this critical moment in the history of the Philippines, that the United States make it clear that we will not countenance the results of a stolen election.'' - Representative Stephen J. Solarz. [ A1:6. ]

title: BOUCHER, FRENCH ROCOCO, BUT FOR OUR TIME, TOO
description: FRANCOIS BOUCHER is one of those big names in the history of art about which almost everybody knows something, and hardly anyone has wanted to know more. Both during and after his lifetime, he has been seen as the most representative artist of the Rococo age. His paintings of nymphs, goddesses and adolescents in various stages of sexual awakening and provocation embody the taste and tone of the hedonistic French court. Boucher's untroubled paintings could hardly seem further from the brashness and urgency of the art of this century.

title: NEW TREND IN NAIL CARE: KOREAN SALONS
description: It has become well-nigh impossible for a woman to walk down a street in midtown Manhattan without being handed a flier for a manicure shop. They seem to be proliferating the way Korean greengrocers did in the recent past. By what may or may not be a strange coincidence, the nail salons also seem to be staffed mainly by Koreans.

title: Phillips Spending
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said it would spend at least 30 percent less in 1986 than it had originally planned because of falling oil prices. Phillips said it had approved a $1 billion capital spending budget, down $400 million from previous estimates. The move follows similar steps taken by other companies as oil prices have plunged.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2,345,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,364,000 for the quarter and year. Year-ago results for the fourth quarter and year have been restated to reflect the acquisition of First Savings Association of Wisconsin, which was accounted for as a pooling-of-interests.

title: FILM: 'ORNETTE,' PORTRAIT OF MUSICIAN
description: SHIRLEY CLARKE'S ''Ornette: Made in America'' is a hazy but inviting glimpse of the great modern jazz musician and his world. Miss Clarke's methods tend to be as fanciful as Ornette Coleman's are rigorous and abstract, but the collaboration between film maker and subject has its own kind of harmony. Mr. Coleman's complexity remains far out of the film's reach, as does his music; Miss Clarke seems chiefly intent on trailing Mr. Coleman and re-creating something of his aura, rather than detailing his life in any kind of narrative fashion. But the film's vagueness never becomes damaging, perhaps because Mr. Coleman's own presence is so subtly commanding.

title: DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Rising Regional Agencies
description: SITTING in his red brick headquarters building facing a statue of Robert E. Lee, David N. Martin, chairman of the Martin Agency of Richmond, ponders, on occasion, what he considers a developing trend in the advertising agency business.

title: Skating Rink Schedule
description: The ice-skating rink in Brooklyn's Prospect Park will remain open through March 16, the Department of Parks and Recreation has announced.

title: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Students From the Bronx, Actors From the Quaigh
description: Fifty students from high schools in the Bronx went to midtown Manhattan yesterday to see live theater and question the actors on how they did their jobs.

title: EDUCATION CHIEF LAUDS STATE OF SCHOOLS IN U.S.
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett sketched a glowing portrait of American public schools today in his department's annual state-by-state review of public education. As high school drop-out rates decline, he said, college entrance examination scores are climbing.

title: U.S. Trade Outlook
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that falling oil prices coupled with a further drop in the value of the dollar might reduce the nation's trade deficit by $10 billion this year.

title: SCREEN: 'THE HITCHER,' TERROR ON THE HIGHWAYS
description: EXISTENTIAL terror, in the case of Robert Harmon's ''Hitcher,'' means an unmotivated viciousness that's as cryptic at the story's end as it was at the beginning. The film, which owes a thing or two to Steven Spielberg's early ''Duel,'' concerns the mysterious antagonism that springs up between two strangers who meet on the highway. It's very clear what sort of spine-tingling suspense Mr. Harmon is after, and just as clear that neither his direction nor Eric Red's screenplay can generate that kind of intensity. The film's good looks - Mr. Harmon is a former cinematographer and his film was shot by John Seale, who has also done handsome work for Peter Weir - seem largely irrelevant, under the circumstances.

title: DETROIT & NORTHERN SAVINGS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,113,000 for the quarter and $2,013,000 for the year. c-Net loss, including a gain of $515,000 for the quarter and year from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage stock dividend. Share earnings for the year are on a pro forma basis since the company converted to stock ownership in February 1985.

title: VETERAN OF SPACE AND ADMINISTRATION: RICHARD HARRISON TRULY
description: In 1981, when a reporter asked Richard Truly which athletic teams he favored, the astronaut, then orbiting the earth in a space shuttle, answered that he would rather not say because to do so might offend fans of opposing teams.

title: U.S. SAYS MIDEAST NEEDS 'REFLECTION' ON PEACE EFFORTS
description: The United States said today that the breakdown in Middle East peace efforts required that there be an indefinite ''period of reflection'' by all sides on what to do next.

title: Jazztet at Sweet Basil
description: The trumpeter Art Farmer and the saxophonist Benny Golson are leading the Jazztet, a sextet featuring Curtis Fuller on trombone, tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, below West Fourth Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: AFICIONADOS of Japanese food rate their favorite restaurants on a three-part scale: freshness, variety and presentation. The original Hatsuhana, which marks its 10th anniversary this year, continues to rank highly on all three counts, although a few rough spots encountered recently indicate that relentless crowds can take a toll on the kitchen.

title: CALIFORNIA LEVEE YIELDS TO WATER
description: As Governor of California two decades ago, President Reagan was the leading exponent of what California Republicans still call the 11th Commandment: ''Thou shalt not speak ill of another Republican.''

title: 'BLOOD AND ORCHIDS' TO BE SHOWN ON CBS
description: THIS Sunday, the networks are again pulling out their big-production guns as their ratings skirmishes continue. At 8 P.M., NBC is offering a three-hour doomsday scenario called ''The Fifth Missile'' on Channel 4. At 9, ABC begins a glossy Hitler-cum-melodrama mini-series based on the Danielle Steel novel ''Crossings'' on Channel 7. And also at 9, on Channel 2, CBS will broadcast the first half of ''Blood and Orchids,'' a four-hour movie that will be concluded Monday night. For sheer old-fashioned theatrics, spiked with social significance and including Jane Alexander in a role that Joan Crawford would have envied, ''Blood and Orchids'' is by far the juiciest concoction in the lot.

title: Late Rally Pushes Dow Up 14.56
description: After a one-day pause, the stock market resumed its upward march yesterday with the help of late afternoon buying programs that transformed a losing session into a winning one.

title: Diana McIntosh
description: Diana McIntosh, the Canadian composer and pianist, will present a program titled ''In, On and Around the Piano'' at Merkin Concert Hall tomorrow night at 8. Miss McIntosh, who calls her work ''downtown music from Canada,'' will combine electronic tape, slide projections and satiric theater pieces with amplified voice and mouth sounds. Tickets are $8; information: 362-8719.

title: A Mother's Care
description: It's not that Philadelphia doesn't have adequate medical facilities, but when Terry Catledge, the 76ers' rookie forward, came down with chicken pox a couple of weeks ago, he decided the City of Brotherly Love wasn't the place to find the kind of tender loving care he needed. Accordingly, Catledge went home to Mississippi, as he explained later, ''so my mom could take care of me.''

title: CROWN ANDERSEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Orpheus Chamber
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, playing without a conductor, will offer a program of works by Beethoven, Elgar, Prokofiev and Mozart with the pianist Ivan Moravec at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night at 8. Tickets are $8 to $15; information: 247-7800.

FOES SAY MITTERAND PLAYS POLITICS AT HIGH COURT
description: A major political dispute has arisen over a move by President Francois Mitterrand to change the composition of France's highest constitutional court.

title: JOSLYN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOUSE UNIT VOTES TO CURB AID FLOW TO THE PHILIPPINES
description: A House subcommittee voted unanimously today to put all military aid to the Philippines into a trust fund until a ''legitimate government'' has been established in Manila.

title: JOHNSON SEES BANNER SEASON
description: He said it four different ways, and the managers' fraternity may never forgive him. But Dave Johnson of the Mets put it on the line today on the eve of spring training:

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $87.4 million, to $210.07 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: DINING OUT GUIDE: THREE-STAR, PART II, FRENCH
description: Following is a summary of reviews of three-star French restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Dates of original publication are listed. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AURORA, #60 East 49th Street (692-9292) -(Jan. 31, 1986) Joseph Baum's new creation has just joined the ranks of New York's excellent French restaurants. The winsomely plush dining room combines a corporate ambiance with a playful bubble theme. The chef prepares food that stresses flavor over flair. Recommended appetizers are crisp-skinned duck confit in a nest of fresh greens with a lively hazelnut dressing and golden-sauteed sweetbreads paired with sliced potatoes, truffles and a caper-parsley vinaigrette. Entrees included roast pigeon with garlic sauce, veal chop with cabbage pockets filled with rice and wild mushrooms, or salmon steak baked in a mild horseradish crust. Desserts are rarely a disappointment. Entrees, $25 to $32.50. Fridays, noon to 2:30 and 5:30 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. LA COTE BASQUE, #5 East 55th Street (688-6525) - (Dec. 11, 1981) Gorgeous floral arrangements and pleasant lighting, along with fanciful murals of Basque scenes provide a festive atmosphere to this fine restaurant. Excellent starters are the pates and terrines of fish, game or poultry, or you might begin with cassolette of seafood in lobster sauce.

title: KURT BACHRACH-BAKER
description: Kurt Bachrach-Baker, a journalist and former director of B'nai B'rith's foreign affairs department, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital.

title: DR. ERNEST BOREK
description: Dr. Ernest Borek, a former teacher of biochemistry at City College and Columbia University, died Feb. 14 at Porter Memorial Hospital in Denver.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS

title: SENTENCE FOR SKILES
description: An Indiana judge yesterday imposed a 30-day jail sentence on Michigan State's high-scoring star, Scott Skiles, but it won't affect the Spartan basketball team. He gave Skiles the option of serving the sentence at the end of the school year, after the basketball season is over.

title: FINGERS WON'T CONFORM
description: Rollie Fingers lost his chance to play for the Cincinnati Reds when he told the team yesterday that he would not shave off his mustache to conform with the Reds' policy that players not display facial hair, a Reds executive said. The Reds had expressed interest in having Fingers, a veteran reliever known for his mound effectiveness and handlebar mustache, join the team.

title: BOARD REBUFFS A QUINONES BID OVER PRINCIPAL
description: A Brooklyn community school board yesterday rejected a request by Chancellor Nathan Quinones that it reconsider and permit disciplinary action in the case of a school principal who solicited $6,000 in loans from a subordinate seeking a promotion.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. The 1983 invasion of Grenada by United States troops after hard-line Marxists toppled its Government. 2.

title: SCIENCE FICTION EDITOR
description: Judy-Lynn del Rey, a leading publisher of science fiction and fantasy books, died Thursday at Bellevue Hospital. Mrs. del Rey, who had suffered a brain hemorrhage last October, was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Seal on NASA's Fate
description: NASA's role in the shuttle tragedy appears less and less immaculate. The seals between sections of the booster rockets seem to have been imperfectly designed. NASA knew of the problem months ago but failed to resolve it. In deciding to launch Challenger on Jan. 28, responsible NASA officials were apparently unaware that an engineer for the rockets' manufacturer had vigorously advised against the launch that day because of the effect of cold on the seals.

title: HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SPEEDING CREDITING OF CHECKS
description: THREE-QUARTERS of the nation's banks hold checks for six or more business days before depositing the money into accounts and 20 percent of them hold them for more than two weeks, according to a survey by the United States Public Interest Research Group.

title: U.S. CRITICIZES REMARKS BY MAKER OF AIDS DRUG
description: The Food and Drug Administration today challenged a pharmaceutical company's report that it had had some success treating AIDS with a drug.

title: RUSSIAN JAZZ GROUP PLANS GROUND-BREAKING U.S. TOUR
description: A Wyoming-based concert producer has reached a tentative agreement with the Soviet Union to bring a major Russian jazz group to the United States for what is believed to be the first time this summer.

title: FMC STUDIES ANTI-TAKEOVER STEPS
description: Following widespread takeover rumors, the FMC Corporation, a military contractor and manufacturer of chemicals and machinery, said that its board met today to consider a recapitalization plan that would keep the company publicly traded.

title: Brandeis U., Left to Right
description: The List of hosts scheduled for next Wednesday when Sanford D. Greenberg is inducted as a Fellow of Brandeis University at a ceremony in the Dirksen Senate Office Building Auditorium suggests that Brandeis fellows make strange politics. Mr. Greenberg is chief executive of TEI, which finances biomedical research companies. The hosts are Senators Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, a liberal Democrat, and John Heinz of Pennsylvania, a moderate Republican, plus Representatives Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, the conservative Republican, and Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, a liberal Democrat.

description: Mike Bullard scored three goals and Mario Lemieux had two and an assist to lead Pittsburgh. The Penguins are unbeaten in their last six games. The Red Wings lost their sixth straight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1986
description: International

title: TV: THREE NEW BRADBURY EPISODES
description: Last year, ''The Ray Bradbury Theater,'' a collection of half-hour tales on Home Box Office, won a respectable share of plaudits and awards for the pay-television service. Now, evidently, someone at HBO has decided that if one Bradbury episode can be good, three new ones presented back-to-back might be even better. The ploy misfires, as can be discovered tonight at 8 o'clock on HBO.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NETS STUN LAKERS, 121-106
description: The pregame talk was about playing loose, not about playing the Lakers. The message came from Dave Wohl, who had watched the Nets lose four straight games and six of their last seven over the last two weeks.

title: Nicaragua Ready to Talk To U.S. on Security
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua was ready to negotiate security concerns with the United States, but he repeated that the governing Sandinista Front would not discuss domestic policy changes.

description: The porch of the town library is starting to look like Noah's ark, filled with stranded pets rescued from the homes of residents who fled this week's flood.

description: The head of the East German Parliament said today that Erich Honecker, General Secretary of the Communist Party, would like to visit West Germany later this year, after a party congress in April.

description: The Haitian Government will take legal steps try to freeze foreign assets of former President Jean-Claude Duvalier and his family, who fled the country two weeks ago, the new Finance Minister said today.

description: Encouraged by eroding oil prices, Treasury bond prices shot upward yesterday, sending yields to their lowest levels since early 1979.

PATENTS;

description: SYNTHETIC skin that could be used in the treatment of burns and ulcerations has been invented at the Chicago Medical Center of the University of Illinois.

description: The American Museum of Natural History has canceled an evening lecture series called ''Ethnic Communities of New York'' because museum administrators decided that the description of ethnic groups in the course brochure could be construed as offensive.

title: ATLANTIC SOUTHEAST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trident Missile Is Tested
description: A Trident 1 ballistic missile was fired successfully today by the crew of a nuclear submarine cruising under water off Florida, beyond the search zone for wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger. The 34-foot-long missile was launched from the submarine Alaska as part of a ''demonstration and shakedown operation,'' a spokesman at nearby Patrick Air Force Base said. It was the 25th test firing of the missile since January 1977.

description: Shortly after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, a team of military pathologists and forensic experts was flown here to help in the identification of any human remains that might be recovered, the space agency said today.

title: MIDLANTIC TO ADD PHILADELPHIA BANK
description: Midlantic Banks Inc., the second-largest bank in New Jersey, behind Fidelity Union Bank, agreed yesterday to acquire the Continental Bancorp Inc. of Philadelphia in a stock swap valued at about $680 million.

description: Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc., the manufacturer famous for its children's overalls, has a problem that most companies wish they had: It has grown too big for its britches.

description: Staten Island scored the first 9 points in last night's City University of New York tournament championship game against City College at Hunter College, and the Dolphins' star forward, Tony Petosa, was worried.

description: Futures prices for crude oil and gasoline continued on their downward path yesterday, as the primary American crude oil slipped below $14 a barrel and gasoline prices fell below 40 cents a gallon.

description: Since today is traditionally regarded as George Washington's birthday, I want to pay homage to the truth, the telling of which was one of Washington's specialties.

description: Israeli troops and tanks stormed this village in southern Lebanon today on the fifth day of Israel's huge sweep to find two captured soldiers, United Nations officials said.

description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Cairo yesterday on the Egyptian armed forces misstated the total United States military assistance to Egypt last year. It was $1.2 billion, not $1.2 million.

description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had completed the first stage of a $3 billion takeover of a natural-gas pipeline operator, the Midcon Corporation, by buying 21 million shares, or 51 percent, of Midcon's shares for $75 each. Occidental said 35.9 million of Midcon's 41.5 million shares had been tendered under the offer.

title: HELEN HOOVEN SANTMYER, 90, AUTHOR AND EDUCATOR, DIES
description: Helen Hooven Santmyer, an educator and librarian whose novel ''. . . And Ladies of the Club'' made her a celebrity at the age of 88, died yesterday of emphysema in Xenia, Ohio, at Hospitality Home East, a nursing home where she had spent most of the last 10 years.

description: In the topsy-turvy world we live in, the last thing to expect is a fresh and magical ballet about ''Alice in Wonderland'' and its creator.

description: Dr. Leon D. Star, medical director at Kennedy International Airport, received a patent this week for a modified form of the mobile hospital unit that he built and patented two years ago.

title: ON TYLENOL CASE, TRAIL GROWS COLD
description: The detective staff has been pared. There are fewer witnesses left to question, fewer avenues left to explore. Yet the questions remain unanswered.

title: HOLMES-SPINKS DATE
description: Michael Spinks and Larry Holmes have set the date for their rematch. They will meet in Las Vegas, Nev., April 19 in an International Boxing Federation heavyweight title bout. Spinks won the title from Holmes last September.

Salvadorans Protest Economic Policies
description: Several thousand workers marched through downtown San Salvador this morning in the largest such protest to date against the economic policies of President Jose Napoleon Duarte.

description: Since taking over as executive director of baseball operations for the Chicago White Sox late last season, Ken (Hawk) Harrelson has received numerous letters from people looking for work in the organization. One was from Craig Stimac, a catcher who spent his entire career in the minor leagues, save for brief stints with San Diego in 1980 and 1981.

description: A senior adviser to the United States observer team for the Philippine elections made public today a wealth of detail to buttress the group's contention that President Ferdinand E. Marcos was re-elected through ''systematic disenfranchisement'' of millions of supporters of the challenger, Corazon C. Aquino.
