title: BRITISH INFLATION EASES
description: Britain's inflation rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent, in January, the Government said today. It cited lower gasoline prices and post-Christmas department store sales.

title: POLAND CUTS TERMS OF 2 SOLIDARITY PRISONERS
description: The highest Polish appellate court today reduced the prison terms of two leading Solidarity activists, who were sentenced in Gdansk last June for fomenting unrest, but it left unchanged the term given to a third man in the same case.

title:
PATENTS;
RECTANGULAR CONTAINERS
description: Juris M. Mednis received a patent this week for a package of rectangular containers that are offered as substitutes for bottles.

title: EX-AGENT ACQUITTED OF KIDNAPPING IN PUERTO RICO
description: A former police undercover agent linked to a police slaying of two advocates of independence for Puerto Rico was found not guilty of a related kidnapping charge today.

title: DARLING VOICES DISPLEASURE
description: On the first day of spring training, 19 pitchers and 7 catchers went to work for the Mets today past a locker-room sign that reminded them of past indignity and past glory. ''In 1969,'' it read, ''they all laughed when we took the field.''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. President Reagan unveiled this plaque. What does it commemorate? 2. ''The transition phase of democracy is over. The phase of a new real democracy has begun.'' What newly elected President said this? 3. The Reagan Administration wants to send arms to rebels in two countries. He needs Congressional approval for one country but not for the other. What are the countries? 4. The Dodgers' Fernando Valenzuela became the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history when he signed a three-year contract for an average of $1.83 million a season. Who was previously No. 1? 5. Pending the outcome of a lawsuit, United Parcel Service has not paid a parking ticket since March 1985. How much does the city say the company now owes in fines over the past year? 6. The National Book Critics Circle award for the most distinguished work of fiction published in 1985 went to what novelist? 7. The genetic asset that enabled their ancestors to survive famines has been turned into a disability that is killing many American Indians today. What is it? 8. ''We are unable to continue to coordinate politically until such time as their word becomes their bond, characterized by commitment, credibility and constancy.'' Who said this? To whom was he referring? 9. An acquisition agreement this week continued the consolidation of the soft drink industry. What happened? 10. United States intelligence agents say they foiled an attempt by the Soviet Union to gain access to advanced American technology in the 1970's.

title: CASA BLANCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $71,000 for the quarter and $87,000 for the 6 months. Losses from discontinued operations reflect a charge of $5.2 million adverse judgment rendered against the company last year. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect inventory writedowns.

title: LEADING DRAMA FIGURE
description: The Rev. Gilbert V. Hartke, a leading figure in Washington theater for more than 50 years, died of heart failure today at Providence Hospital here. He was 79 years old and lived in Washington.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'SIMON BOCCANEGRA'
description: ''SIMON BOCCANEGRA'' is by most reckonings one of Verdi's half dozen greatest operas, but for understandable reasons the public has never quite taken to it in the rabid way it favors such works as ''Aida'' or ''Rigoletto.'' Though in its revised form, ''Boccanegra'' is Verdi at his most mature level, the scarcity of famous arias and ensemble numbers probably accounts as much as anything for audience indifference. And yet, what a magnificent opera this can be in an inspired, strongly cast performance.

title: OFFICES SECRETLY SERVED AS SHELTER, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Authorities are investigating charges that the city paid thousands of dollars a month to house homeless families in a Bronx shelter that officials did not know existed - a shelter where families lived without complaint in little office cubicles because they thought the city wanted them there.

title: Harlem Architecture Show
description: The architecture of Harlem is the subject of a free slide show and lecture tonight at 6 P.M at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53 Street. Marvin D. Schwartz, an art historian from the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Community Education Department, will speak about the development of Harlem, from the mid-1880's to 1920. Information: 621-0618.

title: What Must Be Done About Infant Mortality

description: A 6-year-old girl died and a 3-year-old boy stopped breathing briefly after a nurse mistakenly gave them morphine rather than Demerol at a health clinic here last month, and a lawyer for the girl's relatives questioned today whether the children needed any painkiller.

title: JOHN BATTLING THE ODDS IN YANKEE TRYOUT
description: On the day Lou Piniella conducted his first spring-training workout as the Yankees' manager, Ed Whitson was here but would have preferred being almost anywhere else, and Tommy John preferred to be here when he would probably have been better off almost anywhere else.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AS THE TWIG IS BENT Four Irish-American women fiddlers who were bowing away by the time they reached the age of 12, continuing a family tradition, will be featured in a concert of Irish-American fiddle styles, today and tomorrow at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. They will be joined by a fifth woman, a specialist in French Canadian fiddle playing.

title: RETAILERS' RENTS ON MONTAGUE ST. TAKING A TOLL
description: Meunier's gift shop - 20 years a fixture in Brooklyn Heights - has closed. So have the Montague meat market, a cleaners, the barbeque takeout shop, the laundry, the Chuan Yuan Chinese restaurant, the Community Book Store. Now, the Jomel stationery store is about to join them.

title: REGENTS RESTORE STATE'S CHARGES AGAINST GROSS
description: The Board of Regents voted unanimously today to let the State Health Department pursue charges of professional misconduct against New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, and one of his deputies.

title: Tax Honeymoon Is Over
description: Tax amnesties have always struck us as too much of a honeymoon for delinquents. Permitting such delinquents, including some outright cheaters, to do interest-free penance penalizes the honest taxpayers who have had to pay more to make up the difference. Still, if well run, a tax amnesty can yield some ultimate relief for the good guys, which is just what has now happened in New York.

title: EUROPEANS LAUNCH 2 SATELLITES
description: The Ariane rocket lifted off from its South American base today and launched two scientific and observation satellites into orbit in a mission seen as an important test of Europe's space program.

title: ROGERS & WELLS SETTLES LEGAL MALPRACTICE SUIT
description: Rogers & Wells has agreed to pay $40 million to 330 investors who lost more than $100 million after J. David Dominelli's San Diego company collapsed in 1984, a legal publication said today.

title: SENATE UNIT WOULD ALTER JOINT CHIEFS
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee has tentatively agreed to a measure that would revamp the organization of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Congressional sources said today.

title: NASA SOON TO GET AN OUTSIDE CHIEF REAGAN AIDES SAY
description: James M. Beggs, who is on leave as Administrator of NASA, will resign soon and is expected to be replaced by someone from outside the agency, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: How Cuomo Makes New York State Government More Efficient
description: To the Editor:

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including $478,000 resulting from utilization of estimated tax credits and operating losses carried forward.

title: BUBKA, AT 19-5 3/4, DEFEATS OLSON
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union soared 19 feet 5 3/4 inches in the pole vault tonight at The Los Angeles Times-GTE meet, setting a world indoor best and beating his American rival, Billy Olson.

title: AQUEDUCT WINNER
description: Big Jim Taylor raced on or near the lead throughout and then asserted his superiority in the final furlong to win by 4 1/2 lengths in the $26,000 Impressive purse at Aqueduct yesterday. Along Came Jones, who challenged for the lead into the stretch, tired but held the second spot.

title: PLEDGE FOR EUREKA
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada pledged about $25 million (Canadian currency) today to encourage domestic concerns to participate in the European Eureka high-technology research program.

title: POLICEMAN RETIRES, 735 TICKETS UNPAID
description: After a decade of what authorities called artful dodging, a veteran New York City police officer - who had amassed 735 parking tickets and $30,140 in unpaid fines - retired yesterday and secured a $24,000 pension hours before the police learned he was one of the city's worst scofflaws.

title: COMPAQ'S EXPLOSIVE GROWTH
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation has secured its place in the annals of corporate America by becoming the first company to eclipse sales of $500 million in its third year of business.

title: IRT TRAIN DERAILS IN BROOKLYN
description: A subway train derailed yesterday evening as it entered the President Street station in Brooklyn, forcing 300 people to evacuate the train and disrupting service to part of the IRT No. 2 line for the rest of the night, the Transit Authority said.

title: EMPI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $2,300 for the quarter, and including an extraordinary gain of $18,700 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $57,500.

title: SON HELD IN DEATH OF A MARCOS FOE
description: The murder of a Philippine-American news executive that gave rise to accusations of political terrorism has turned out to be the result of a family dispute, the police in suburban Glendale said today.

title: Article 836686 -- No Title
description: Bail was set at $500,000 today for Leslie Howard Roberts, the 23-year-old stockbroker accused of falsifying $47 million in stock trading slips.

title: BRITISH STAKE IN MITEL IS SET
description: The Mitel Corporation cleared an important hurdle today when the British Government approved British Telecommunications P.L.C.'s bid to buy controlling interest in the Canadian telephone switching-equipment maker.

title: ISLANDERS ARE TROUNCED, 5-1, BY SABRES
description: John Tucker scored twice and Phil Housley had three assists as the Buffalo Sabres ended a four-game streak without a victory by beating the Islanders, 5-1, tonight.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a Maryland bond offering misidentified the lead underwriter. It was Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: APPLIED DNA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1986
description: Markets

title: WARD IS REAPPOINTED TO FULL 5-YEAR TERM
description: Mayor Koch appointed Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward to a full five-year term yesterday, a technicality required by the City Charter.

title: CONNORS A LOSER BY DEFAULT TO LENDL
description: The countdown continued but Jimmy Connors showed no inclination to leave his chair and resume play. After 16 years on the professional tennis tour, Connors would say later, he thought he had suffered enough indignities at the hands of the officials.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO CONSOLIDATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $307,000 for the quarter and $1,774,000 for the year. c-Including gains of $479,000 from discontinued operations and $2,427,000 from the sale of discontinued operations.

title: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LABELS ON SOUPS: READ WITH CARE
description: The soup aisle will never look the same. There are so many new varieties of soup that it is almost impossible to make intelligent choices. It isn't just the varieties of soup today - most of them still by Campbell's or Lipton - that confuse shoppers. It is also the labels, many of which have one or more of the following: No preservatives. No artificial ingredients. No artificial flavors. No artificial colors. No additives. All natural.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD APPROVES NAVY BASE
description: The Board of Estimate narrowly approved a plan early yesterday to establish a base on Staten Island for the battleship Iowa and six support vessels.

title: DATA TRANSLATION INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NAPCO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest fourth quarter and year include a pretax gain of $5.6 million from an acquisition and a pretax gain of $3.8 million from the sale of a building and are after a pretax writeoff of inventory of $2.6 million.

title: BERLIN'S SCANDAL RECIPE: BOSSES, BRIBES, BROTHELS
description: When Mayor Eberhard Diepgen goes to New York next week, he may want to consult with his more experienced colleague, Edward I. Koch, on the art of damage control in corruption scandals.

title: Penalties and the F.D.A.
description: Amid the latest Tylenol scare, the Food and Drug Administration notes that the maximum fine for violations of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act has been greatly increased. The top penalty was previously $1,000 but can now go as high as $500,000.

title: BRADY, W. H. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
COMDATA NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROSECUTORS, PRESSING LINDENAUER, WARN OF AN INDICTMENT NEXT WEEK
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they would ask a grand jury next week to indict a key figure in the New York City corruption scandal unless he agreed to cooperate in their investigation of Donald R. Manes and other officials.

title: Albany Cannot Divest Easily
description: A bill in the Legislature, actively supported by Governor Cuomo, would require me as sole trustee of the State Common Retirement Fund to sell, over a period of five years, a $6 billion portfolio of securities of American companies doing business in South Africa. The aim of the bill is to fight apartheid. This is something my office already is doing by making sure the companies in the fund's portfolio follow high moral and ethical standards on racial discrimination and other humanitarian issues of concern to New Yorkers.

title: Press Marcos to Bring
description: On Feb. 11, four days after the Philippine election, Evelio Javier, a leading member of the anti-Marcos opposition, was gunned down in gangland fashion in San Jose de Buenavista, the capital of Antique province. Six armed men chased him across the dusty town square at 10:30 A.M., trapped him in a shed behind a store and pumped more than a dozen bullets in him.

title: TERRORIST KILLED
description: Assailants shot and wounded an aide to Prime Minister Bettino Craxi today, and one of the attackers, identified as a member of the Red Brigades, was slain in an exchange of fire.

title: SPRING IN FEBRUARY AS BASEBALL CAMPS OPEN
description: The Duke of Flatbush was wearing a spanking white Dodger uniform and blue windbreaker, both a couple of sizes larger than he wore in the old days. At 59, he looked regal just the same. His face was bright red with a first coat of spring sunshine, and his eyes were squinting under a baseball cap as he watched the game unfold on one of several well-groomed playing fields at Dodgertown.

title: FROM PURGES TO PRIVILEGE: LIVELY DEBATE IN GORBACHEV'S SOVIET
description: An Old Bolshevik declared that he thought it was time to re-establish the practice of regular purges. Another thought party officials should be stripped of their privileges and made to stand in ''those lines we so despise'' with everyone else. That was in Pravda. On television, a Deputy Minister of Light Industry. charged with making clothing and shoes, was invited to answer questions called in live by viewers, and President Reagan went on the air with a New Year's message. The Struggle With Censors

title: BALTIMORE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August.

title: GWYDIR HELPS COLUMBIA DEFEAT HARVARD
description: Columbia shot poorly but forced Harvard to shoot even worse and won, 73-54, last night at Levien Gymnasium.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THOUSANDS CROWD SHELTERS IN FLOOD
description: Thousands of people crowded emergency shelters near here today after a levee holding back the Yuba River ruptured suddenly Thusday night and forced 21,000 residents from their homes.

title: G.E. Aircraft Workers Walk Out in Lynn, Mass.
description: About 3,700 union members walked off the job today at a General Electric Company aircraft engine plant to protest the suspension of a shop steward.

title: Not a Caste Mark
description: To the Editor:

title: PARALYZED WOMAN LOSES BID TO STOP HER FEEDINGS
description: A state judge today ruled that Elizabeth Bouvia, paralyzed from birth by cerebral palsy, must be fed by force because she was secretly trying to commit suicide.

title: IRAN OFFENSIVE WORRIES GULF NATIONS
description: Iran's recent offensive and its continued occupation of a strategic piece of Iraqi territory has stunned many Arab nations and revived fears about the vulnerability of both Iraq and its Persian Gulf neighbors, according to Arab officials meeting here.

title: Sectional Tournament Gives Opportunity to Newcomers
description: Most tournaments provide primarily for the experienced player but offer some action for the novice. The converse is true for the Greater New York Bridge Association's two-day sectional tournament beginning today at the Halloran House, at 525 Lexington Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets.

title: TMBR DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S.-Japan War Games
description: Japan and the United States will begin the first joint war games involving all branches of their armed forces next week. The chairman of Japan's Joint Staff Council, Gen. Shigehiro Mori, said today that about 150 officers from the United States Navy, Army, Air Force and Marine Corps and 250 officers from the Japanese Maritime, Air and Ground Self-Defense Forces would join the five-day exercise. It will prepare for real joint maneuvers in September, the announcement said.

title: FOR PAUL BOCUSE, A PARTY FIT FOR A KING OF CHEFS
description: Paul Bocuse, one of the most influential French chefs of his time, celebrated his 60th birthday here tonight in this Chicago suburb amid a clamor of toasts and the warm embraces of friends and family.

title: Four Rock Bands
description: Four new rock bands will perform today at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052). The music will begin at 10:30 with Yo La Tengo, Antietam will perform at midnight, the Volcano Suns at 1 A.M. and the Scene Is Now at 2 A.M.; tickets are $7.

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $41,217,000 for the quarter, $36,312,000 for the year, and including extraordinary gains of $25,625,000 for the quarter, $29,401,000 for the year. The year result also is after a charge of $6,921,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $45,545,000 for the quarter and $653,510,000 for the year. d-Net loss. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded final net for the latest year.

title: New York Needs Stronger Anti-Corruption Laws
description: In the last month, New York City has been rocked by a still unraveling story of public corruption. The allegations, while disturbing, are not surprising.

title: Harpsichord Recital
description: The harpsichordist Wendy Young will present an all-Bach concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday at 8 P.M. The program will include the French Suite No. 5 in G, the English Suite No. 3 in G minor, and excerpts from the Well Tempered Clavier, all on a William Dowd harpsichord based on an instrument believed to have been played in Berlin by J.S. Bach in 1719.

title: Graph of Market Profile 24.89 GAIN PUTS DOW NEAR 1,700
description: Wall Street wrapped up another impressive week with a big rally that put the Dow Jones industrial average near the 1,700 mark.

title: Britain Charges American With Spying
description: A man identified as a former American naval commander and intelligence worker was charged today with espionage.

title: CELC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: New U.S. Envoy to Austria
description: President Reagan announced today that he was nominating Ronald Lauder, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Europe, to be Ambassador to Austria, succeeding Helene von Damm. Miss von Damm, Mr. Reagan's personal secretary when he was Governor of California, announced her resignation in June amid controversy over her marriage to a Vienna hotelier.

title: SPY FOR CHINA FOUND SUFFOCATED IN PRISON, APPARENTLY A SUICIDE
description: Larry Wu-Tai Chin, the retired analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency convicted of spying for the Chinese for 30 years, was found dead this morning in his jail cell, apparently a suicide, the authorities said.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about regional banking in the Middle West incorrectly enumerated the states affected by an Illinois banking compact, as cited by John Rau, president of the Exchange National Bank of Chicago.

title: GETTING PEOPLE TO STAND IN LINE, AND TO PAY FOR IT
description: It's basic algebra. A Robert Redford traveling at zero miles per hour is set down on a deserted stretch of highway in a sparsely populated state. How big is the crowd after five minutes? Ten minutes? How about after a TV spot announcing his whereabouts?

title: PANEL TO REVIEW BIDS FOR BL UNITS
description: The British Government set up a special committee to review bids for the state-owned BL vehicle company, parts of which are planned to be sold to the General Motors Corporation, officials said. The committee, to be headed by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, was formed after Members of Parliament attacked Government plans to sell BL's truck and Land-Rover divisions to G.M.

title: 2 PALESTINIANS JAILED FOR KILLINGS IN 1978 ARE FREED BY FRANCE
description: The Government has released two members of the Abu Nidal terrorist group after they had served half their prison terms for the assassination of a Palestine Liberation Organization leader in France and another Palestinian in 1978, Interior Ministry sources confirmed today.

title: BUS DRIVER WILL FACE HEARING ON ACCIDENT
description: A Transit Authority bus driver who was charged with leaving the scene of an accident on Thursday after striking a bicyclist told officials yesterday that he was unaware the bus had hit anyone until some of his passengers told him.

title: 4 NEW YORK BUILDINGS LINKED TO MARCOS UP FOR SALE
description: Four New York City properties linked to President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, have been for sale since last year for as much as $300 million, according to documents from real estate and banking companies involved in handling the properties.

title: RICHARD L. TEBERG
description: Richard L. Teberg, a partner in the New York law firm of Reavis & McGrath, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 47 years old.

title: KNICKS WIN TO END LOSING STREAK AT 7
description: It was an occasion for perspective last night at Madison Square Garden. Certainly, the Knicks' 117-104 rout of the Seattle SuperSonics, a victory that ended a seven-game losing streak, was worthy of celebration. Yet what it actually proved was this: In spite of all the problems the team has endured this season, things might have easily been worse. At least the Knicks have excuses.

description: The office of Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat known for his antinuclear views, is investigating a letter sent to members of the Air Force's 501st Security Police Group by the group's headquarters. The group has been policing antinuclear demonstrations at an American base at Greenham Common in Britain.

title: BUILDERS TRANSPORT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Haiti Needs Help
description: Haitians who have known only tyranny for most of their lives are still celebrating the collapse of the House of Duvalier. They are learning to breathe and speak freely; only the dictator's goons now live in fear. Liberation is a blessing indeed, but escape from the disastrous conditions that the Duvaliers leave behind remains a dimly understood challenge.

title: NO NASA PRESSURE ON THIOKOL FOUND
description: Three members of the Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle explosion said today they could find no immediate evidence that the space agency had pressured the manufacturers of the Challenger's solid-fuel booster rockets to approve the Jan. 28 launching.

BEAR STEARNS CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago and the latest 9 months results are pro forma, since the company went public on Oct. 29, 1985. Share earnings results reflect 5 percent stock dividend.

title: Travels With Weinberger
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger plans a swing across the Pacific in late March, and the nations he will not visit are as interesting as those he will. The 13-day trip will take him to Korea, Japan, Thailand, Singapore and Australia.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. proposed changes in pricing for private-line services that it said would mean an average 2.4 percent increase in the monthly bills A.T.&T. business customers receive for their end-to-end services.

description: b-Net income. c-After a nonrecurring net charge of $2.3 million from the discontinuance of the company's physical fitness product line.

Betheil, an associate in the New York law firm of Pryor, Cashman, Sherman & Flynn, were married yesterday. Acting Justice Richard T. Andrias of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the couple's Manhattan home.

description: b-Net income. The latest first quarter figures include results of operations of Excel Energy Corporation acquired Nov. 7, 1985.

A SALES PITCH THAT'S SCHOLARLY
description: In Minneapolis-St. Paul, where the winters are brutal to begin with, University of Minnesota athletics have been battered by particularly severe storms lately, a result of a number of disclosures about the men's basketball program. That's why an effort undertaken some time ago by Merrily Dean Baker comes as an especially refreshing breath of good news.

title: G.E. AND PRATT SPLIT JET ENGINE CONTRACT, 56%-44%
description: The General Electric Company, for the third year running, has won the larger share of the Air Force's jet engine business over archrival Pratt & Whitney, the Air Force said today.

title: Satellite Links Scientists In Boston and Peking
description: Scientists in Boston and Peking chatted with one another today over a satellite hookup to demonstrate the potential of a new $22.9 million center for medical communications.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN A REPLY TO SOVIET ON ARMS PROPOSAL
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan planned to send a letter to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, outlining proposals dealing with strategic arms, medium-range missiles, chemical weapons, troop levels in Europe and other key arms issues.

title: A Playwright's Journal
description: AN UNNATURAL PURSUIT & OTHER PIECES. By Simon Gray. Illustrated. 244 pages. St. Martin's Press. $15.95. No doubt few American readers have seen Simon Gray's play ''The Common Pursuit,'' which had a few weeks' run at London's Lyric Theater, Hammersmith, a year and a half ago, and which has as yet received neither a West End nor a New York production. Inspired in part by the experiences of Mr. Gray's friend Ian Hamilton, who once ran a small but influential literary magazine, the play examines the unraveling lives, ambitions and dreams of five gifted Cambridge students, who leave behind the university, and their high-minded intellectual ideals, for the more pragmatic rewards and frustrations of the London literary world: talk-show appearances, petty journalistic assignments, lucrative book offers, as well as ''the routine stuff of English social comedy'' - ''love affairs, abortions, adulteries, treacheries, compromises, lingering deaths, sudden deaths.''

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,137,000.

title: MARYLAND MOVES IN BABY FOOD CASE
description: Gov. Harry Hughes of Maryland yesterday ordered stores in the state to remove Gerber strained peaches from their shelves because glass shards had been found in two opened jars of the baby food, but the Food and Drug Administration said it had tested 6,000 unopened jars and found no glass.

title: A Capitol Hill Persuader Nonpareil
description: At an age when most people are retiring, 67-year-old Elmer Cerin began a new career as a lobbyist. And, unlike most others in the pin-striped army that invades Capitol Hill each day, he works free of charge.

title: Canada to Boycott Event
description: Canada has decided to boycott the inauguration of President Marcos completely.

AIDS SUFFERER'S RETURN TO CLASSES IS CUT SHORT
description: Ryan White hopped out of his stepfather's pickup truck and walked into school today for the first time since doctors discovered 15 months ago that he has AIDS.

title: ANOTHER ENTRY ON PARKING-TICKET LIST
description: Technically, Victor E. Botnick, one of Mayor Koch's closest aides, is a scofflaw, according to the Parking Violations Bureau. But is he really?

title: THRIFT UNIT BIDS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is seeking bidders for the Washington-based National Permanent Bank Savings and Loan institution, according to John Harding, chief financial officer of National Permanent.

title: LABOR'S CHANGING OUTLOOK: CAN UNIONS ACHIEVE A COMEBACK
description: Change is coming to the union movement.

title: AUTODESK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Ferraro's Son Arrested In Vermont Drug Case
description: The son of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate and a former Congresswoman from Queens, has been arrested on a cocaine charge in Vermont, a county prosecutor said today.

title:
PATENTS;
DEVELOPING VACCINES
description: A method of developing vaccines against infectious diseases has been patented for the Department of Health and Human Services. The process, which involves the combination of human and animal viruses, was developed at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md. Patent 4,571,385, granted this week to Harry B. Greenberg and five co-inventors, covers the production not only of vaccines but also vaccine precursers, which are valuable for research and some immunological techniques.

title: NORCEN ENERGY RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Midwest and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: Toxic Gas Leak Fells 76 In Los Angeles Suburb
description: A cloud of chlorine gas spewed from a ruptured line at a chemical plant today and injured at least 76 people, including three dozen children sickened by vapors that seeped into an elementary school.

title: TAXI CHAIRMAN WAS QUESTIONED BY INVESTIGATORS
description: The chairman of the agency that regulates the city's taxis said yesterday that he appeared before the State Investigation Commission last week to answer questions about two programs his department runs.

title: THE CHANGING WOMEN'S MARRIAGE MARKET
description: Women who defer marriage to go to college and pursue a career are finding that by the time they decide to marry, the marriage market has, in effect, evaporated, according to a new study by two Yale sociologists and a Harvard economist.

title: AILING MEXICO SEEKS NEW TERMS ON ITS DEBT
description: President Miguel de la Madrid called tonight for the international financial community to alter the terms of Mexico's $97 billion foreign debt so that the cost of debt service is based on Mexico's ability to pay.

title: PRESIDENT PLANNING TELEVISION ADDRESS ON MILITARY AFFAIRS
description: President Reagan told House Republicans today that he would make a major television speech about military matters next week, and the Republican Congressmen said later that he would also use the speech to push for new military aid for the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government.

title: RULE CHANGE FAVORED
description: The executive council of track's international governing body voted unanimously yesterday in favor of lifting the ban on Renaldo Nehemiah and Willie Gault, a move that virtually guarantees that the professional football players will be allowed to resume track competition. They had been banned after signing professional contracts, Nehemiah with the San Francisco 49ers and Gault with the Chicago Bears. The final decision on a rules change that would remove the ban will be made at the International Amateur Athletics Federation's congress in August, but following the unanimous executive council vote, that is considered a formality.

title:
PATENTS;
ALARM SYSTEM FEATURES SOUND OF A BARKING DOG
description: A barking dog alarm system intended to frighten burglars was patented this week by Salvatore J. Giordano, a retired insurance agent in the Bronx.

title: The Crisis Is Not in Medical Care, but in Our Legal System
description: To the Editor:

title: BAY SHORE
description: IF Bay Shore is considered the ''heart of the South Shore,'' as its Chamber of Commerce contends, then the ''heart'' of Bay Shore must be considered its waterfront.

title: FROM THE ORIENT, 2 CUISINES IN ONE
description: KOREAN-JAPANESE restaurants such as the New Kalbi House in Flushing, Queens, serve both Korean and Japanese food, not some new composite cuisine.

title: JORDANIANS IRKED BY DELAY IN U.S. ARMS SALE
description: Jordan's military force, which is relatively small but highly trained and technologically advanced, is increasingly irritated by the failure of Congress to go through with President Reagan's proposed $1.9 billion weapons sale, according to senior air force and army officers.

title: AIDS TASK FORCE REPORTS INCREASE IN NUMBER OF CLIENTS
description: IN the year since development of a blood test to determine the presence of the virus antibodies associated with acquired immune deficiency, the number of people seeking help from the Mid-Hudson Valley AIDS Task Force has increased ''quite rapidly,'' according to John Egan, the agency's executive director.

title: An Alternative To Welfare Hotels For the Homeless
description: Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo said last week that, after months of negotiation, they had found a way to build temporary housing for homeless families. The plan, a response to widespread frustration with the overpriced, overcrowded welfare hotels in which homeless families have been placed, will produce housing for 200 families by the end of the year.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TARGET: CANCER. By Edward J. Sylvester. (Scribners, $17.95.) In an editorial three years ago, the science journal Nature raised hopes that the most fundamental causes of some cancers would be known by the end of 1983.

title: 'SEARCH FOR TOMORROW' - RATING ARE DOWN AND FLOOD WATERS ARE IN
description: To finish off the 1985 spring season - and a few characters - ABC's prime-time soap ''Dynasty'' had a bloodbath. To jettison its old format - and a few characters - this Tuesday afternoon at 12:30 NBC's daytime serial ''Search for Tomorrow'' is having, well, a bath.

title: BINGHAMTON IS HOST TO CHINESE BALLET DEBUT
description: When the Central Ballet of China arrived here this week, its members were welcomed by crowds waving posters. Bright red banners with greetings in Chinese hung from buildings and light poles.

title: CONGRESS SPENT $9.28 MILLION ON '84-'85 TRIPS, REPORT SAYS
description: Traveling members of Congress cost taxpayers at least $9.28 million in 1984-85, a watchdog group reported today.

title: Budget Rules Seem to Throw Everyone Off
description: This year, budgeting was supposed to different. Under the new deficit-reduction law, the White House, the Senate and the House of Representatives have had clear instructions for months: Cut the Federal deficit to $144 billion for the 1987 fiscal year.

title: WHEN THEY WERE WRONG THEY WERE RIGHT
description: THE STORIES OF HEINRICH BOLL By Heinrich Boll. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 686 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25. BORN into a liberal Roman Catholic family in Bonn in 1917, and the least military of men, Heinrich Boll was drafted into the German army in 1939 and eventually taken prisoner by the Americans. His first novel was published in 1949, and in 1972 he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature for a body of work that, in its emphasis on life and a positive vision, fulfilled the ideals the prize is meant to honor. Possibly his sense of noblesse oblige induced him to serve as the quasi-official conscience of postwar Germany - who else was anything like as eligible? - and this function, one may surmise, proved a burden to him. How could so private a person, the ironic champion of the outsider and the lone wolf, feel comfortable as a spokesman on public issues and for large and sometimes simple-minded causes?

title: Life-Styles Gap Separates the Generations
description: To the Editor:

title: BUBKA IS NO. 1 AGAIN
description: Sergei Bubka seemed to tone down his earlier remarks about Billy Olson following the Los Angeles Times-G.T.E. Indoor Games.

title: EFFECTS OF COLD EMERGE AS FOCUS OF SHUTTLE PANEL
description: New theories about wind and cold weather have become a major focus of the Presidential commission investigating the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: INVESTORS REJOICE AS PRICES SAIL HIGHER
description: BETWEEN August and October of last year, John F. Murray, a taxidermist in Kerrville, Tex., invested in 51 one-ounce bars of platinum at prices ranging from $259 to $311 an ounce. Today, platinum has sailed to almost $400, and Mr. Murray estimates that he has turned a $10,000 profit.

title: GETTING THE PC TO TAKE SHORTHAND
description: THE personal computer has a well-established reputation in the business world for increasing productivity. Once the hardware and software are up and running, any number of tasks, from managing mailing lists to projecting sales, can be accomplished with considerable savings in time.

title: Other Noble Sufferers
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY LAB MARKS 50 YEARS' MARINE RESEARCH
description: For 50 years, the nautical laboratory at Stevens Institute of Technology has been simulating and studying the hydrodynamics of ship movements.

title: WHAT COLLEGES HAVE LEARNED ABOUT SUICIDE
description: All new students at the University of California, Los Angeles, receive in their registration packet a six-page pamphlet on suicide. Among other things, they are urged to watch for fellow students who exhibit certain warning signs: people who are chronically depressed and hint that they won't be around long, for example, or who give away prized possessions. The booklet lists eight phone numbers for students to call, from the campus counseling center to the university police.

title: A Union Leader Made in New York
description: IN THE 1960's, when Nelson Rockefeller was Governor and Robert F. Wagner Mayor, no one had greater influence in Albany or City Hall than Harry Van Arsdale Jr., the pint-sized president of the million-member New York City Central Labor Council, who died last Sunday at 80.

title: A NIGHTINGALE SANG
description: Melvin Marks was so sensitive to the rude comments that young women make to him today, I couldn't believe his remark about his friend Josephine - ''By now she's surely a fat Dutch housewife.'' Doesn't he see the irony of that within the context of his article? I, for one, hope she is a successful businesswoman. SANDRA MARSHALL Brooklyn

title: TOO DEFENSIVE?
description: Solidity in a defense can be admirable, but it is not intended to be a permanent condition. The solid defense executed perfectly is supposed to wrestle the white initiative to a standstill and eventually produce a completely free, unhindered game for Black.

title: IN SOVIET, A SHIFT TO INCREASING SUPPORT FOR MARCOS
description: The Soviet Union, apparently sensing an opportunity to gain from the turmoil in the Philippines and disrupt American policy, has stepped up its support of President Ferdinand E. Marcos since his disputed election victory.

title: Allan Zelikovic to Wed Carolyn Cohen in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Cohen of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Joy Cohen, to Allan Zelikovic, the son of Esther Zelikovic of Montreal and Miami and the late Herman Zelikovic.A June wedding is planned.

title: MUSIC: THE BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonic continues to present the most engrossing and unusual orchestral programs in town. Although none of the works the group presented Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music were masterpieces (with the possible exception of ''A Mirror on Which to Dwell,'' by Elliott Carter) the concert in toto - constructed around a loose conception of ''American Voices'' -was diverse, imaginative, well-documented and diligently executed. Our musical life would be richer if Lukas Foss, who serves as the Brooklyn Philharmonic's music director, could hire himself out as a sort of ''programmer-at-large.'' He seems incapable of a mechanical idea.

title: TV STATION BATTLES FOR CABLE CHANNEL
description: WLIG-TV wants a channel on the Cablevision system. Newsday is about to vacate a Cablevision channel it has held for almost two years. Some sort of agreement would seem logical. But officials at both WLIG and Cablevision say it is not that simple.

title: THOSE NEW STEREO BROADCASTS ARE WITHIN REACH OF OLDER TV SETS
description: Tuesday evening at 8, CBS will present its first stereo telecast, thus catching up with NBC, ABC and PBS. The occasion is the annual Grammy Awards ceremonies. Thereafter, like the other networks, CBS will send out certain programs - notably ''The Twilight Zone'' series - with stereo sound.

title: John Cole to Marry Charlotte Merriam
description: The engagement of Charlotte Louise Merriam to John Francis Cole has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. George R. Merriam Jr. of Tenafly, N.J., and Wakefield, R.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Cole of Little Silver, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: PORTIA FACES LIFE
description: WHERE THEY ARE NOW The Story of the Women of Harvard Law 1974. By Jill Abramson and Barbara Franklin. 323 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95. IT was not until 1950 that Harvard Law School admitted women as students and not until the class of 1974 that women constituted more than 10 percent of an entering class. ''Where They Are Now'' is a breezy, sometimes affecting but ultimately unsatisfying account of how the 70 women who made up 12 percent of the Harvard Law School class of 1974 spent their first decade as lawyers.

title: INSURERS BALK ON CARRIERS
description: THE liability-insurance emergency confronting New Jersey government and businesses threatens to cripple some short-haul rail carriers and has cast some uncertainty over whether NJ Transit's policy will be renewed when it expires on June 30.

title: A NIGHTINGALE SANG
description: The examples Melvin Marks offers that ''innocence and civility seem to have disappeared'' are all offenses committed by women: a waitress, a pedestrian, a cyclist. Does Mr. Marks find that contemporary men alone practice civility or is it, rather, his observation that men never were civil and women are simply catching up? STEVEN J. SCHEINMAN, M.D. Hamilton, N.Y.

title: Other Noble Sufferers
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE STONE GUEST' MAKES A BELATED DEBUT
description: Alexander Sergeyevich Dargomizhsky's ''Stone Guest'' is a popular work in the Soviet Union; indeed, the composer is considered, along with Glinka, a founder of Russian national opera. Although Dargomizhsky's setting of Pushkin's dramatic poem is now over a century old (''The Stone Guest'' was first performed in 1872) it has apparently only been staged twice outside of Russia -and never in the United States. The Chamber Opera Theater of New York plans to repair this omission with six performances at the Marymount Manhattan Theater beginning Tuesday night.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: MARY V. MOCHARY and Marge S. Roukema have much in common:

title: THE MUSEUMS OF ISRAEL
description: In Israel, a crossroads of ancient civilizations, the countryside itself is like a museum filled with the remains of those who were here before, from Canaanites to Philistines, from Romans to Crusaders. Even the present-day inhabitants -Jews from some 80 lands, Arabs from all over the Middle East, Christians of different denominations - create a living museum.

title: Lottery Repeater Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTY OFFICIALS SPLIT ON REQUESTS FOR ALBANY ACTION
description: WITHIN the last few weeks, Westchester officials have released two separate lists of measures that they want passed by the State Legislature during its current session. Although there is agreement on such key issues as the repeated call for a 3 percent hotel-occupancy tax and the need for reallocation of hydroelectric power in the state, the individual packages - one issued by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, the other by the Board of Legislators - represent a break with recent tradition.

title: Heidi Wood Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Wood of Ridgewood, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Heidi Anne Wood to Eamonn deLisser, a son of Dr. and Mrs. E. A. deLisser of Miami.

title: STOCK VICISSITUDES
description: To the Editor:

title: Staten Island Base Approved
description: It was a close vote, 6 to 5, but the New York City Board of Estimate approved an agreement with the Navy that would establish a home port on Staten Island for the battleship Iowa and six support vessels.

title: Deadline Nears For 9.2% Loans
description: Home buyers have until Friday to submit registration forms for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages offered by the State of New York Mortgage Agency with the lowest rate ever charged under the agency's affordable housing program - 9.2 percent. The mortgages can be for single-family homes, condominiums and - for the first time in the program - co-ops.

title: Countering the Glut of Offices in Fairfield
description: THE new office space that has been flooding the Fairfield County market for more than a year has resulted in lower rents and a myriad of incentives to attract tenants.

title: U.M.D.N.J. HOSPITALS ARE SAID TO LAG
description: An article on Feb. 2 referred to the availability of specialized new technologies and services to University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey hospitals.

title: BLACK FLAG ADDS A SOUPCON OF SOPHISTICATION TO PUNK ROCK
description: Black Flag, formed as a punk rock band in Los Angeles in the late 1970's, has been growing by leaps and bounds lately, with every new record release - growing musically, and that's perhaps the hardest thing for a rock band to do.

title: A Nightingale Sang
description: Melvin L. Marks's article ''A Nightingale Sang'' (About Men, Jan. 19), touched me in a way it might touch anyone living in a large city. I am continually perplexed by the rudeness and, sometimes, the harshness of people encountered on a daily basis.

title: CAMERA PIONEER ALUTED AT ICP
description: Ilse Bing is happy to be recognized finally as one of modern photography's pioneers. She enjoys talking about Paris in the 30's, when she worked alongside such masters as Brassai, Kertesz, Man Ray and Cartier-Bresson. She says she is looking forward to German television's forthcoming documentary on her life, and is excited about the traveling exhibition, ''Ilse Bing: Three Decades of Photography,'' that opened Friday at the International Center of Photography. The show will contain 40 of her photographs.

title: LEAD-SHOT BATTLE IS INTENSIFIED
description: FED up with what it obviously regards as an unjustified reluctance on the part of hunters, legislators and state and Federal agencies to end the silent slaughter of ducks, geese and eagles by lead poisoning, the National Wildlife Federation has gone to court in an effort to force the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to ban the use of lead-loaded shells for all waterfowling in the lower 48 states beginning with the 1987-1988 hunting season.

title: HUSSEIN QUESTIONS WHO SHOULD SPEAK FOR PALESTINIANS
description: King Hussein of Jordan, challenging the leadership of Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, called on the Palestinian people today to decide who should lead them.

title: The Single Life
description: Before she goes down in history as a girl who made a brilliant, if not particularly admirable, career choice, let us consider the teen-age mom. According to President Reagan, she is one lucky youngster. ''Under existing welfare rules,'' he said last week, ''a teen-age girl who becomes pregnant can make herself eligible for welfare benefits that will set her up in an apartment of her own, provide medical care, and feed and clothe her. She has to fulfill only one condition - not marry or identify the father.''

title: SALVADOR REBELS END ACCORD THAT HAD BARRED KIDNAPPING
description: The top commanders of the Salvadoran leftist rebel movement announced today that they would no longer observe an agreement barring the kidnapping of the relatives of Government and military officials.

title: GUILT ON HER FINGERS
description: CURRANNE TRUEHEART by Donald Newlove. 394 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95. DONALD NEWLOVE'S latest novel, ''Curranne

title: MONTEFUSCO'S HOPES ARE HIGH
description: John Montefusco might be one of 17 pitchers with major league experience in the Yankees' spring camp, but he is the only one who has two holes in his hip and an electrobiology machine in his hotel room.

title: CARDIAC CARE: STATE BOARD VS. HOSPITAL
description: HUNDREDS of Connecticut residents travel out of state each year for open-heart surgery, but that may soon change. For the first time in more than a decade, several hospitals around the state are considering offering the surgery.

title: HUNT BY THE HOMELESS FOR APARTMENTS
description: As the five homeless women walked out of the Carter Hotel into the gray winter cold, they were laughing and chatting. It was their big day, their turn to ''ride the van'' and look at city-owned apartments for a permanent home of their own.

title: ANN ILL-TIMED ASSAULT ON MANUFACTURERS
description: UNITED STATES industry is fighting a two-front war. The first front is the tough competition that manufacturers are facing from abroad. Meeting that challenge has often required more careful control of costs, quality improvements and at times painful restructuring of the company. The second front, somewhat surprisingly, is at home.

title: TOOLS AUCTION FOR PUBLIC TV
description: ART, crafts and family heirlooms are the usual stuff of auctions to benefit public broadcasting stations, but this week Connecticut Public Television will break with tradition and offer such items as an 11-ton jig-boring machine.

title: GOOD DIGS IN TIMBUKTU
description: There were no lights on the train, and the cockroaches were stirring, so I stepped off to take a midnight stroll.

title: Grand Vefour
description: To the Editor: Having traveled frequently and happily taking advantage of information gleaned from The New York Times Travel section over a period of many years, I decided during my stay in Paris this past October to treat myself to a gourmet lunch at the Grand Vefour (''Palais Royal: Serene Oasis in Central Paris,'' Feb. 5, 1984 and ''Grand Vefour, Grand Dining, Aug. 11, 1985).

title: DENVER
description: Car-rental companies looking for logos - the Statue of Liberty for New York, a car for Detroit - have no trouble with Denver: It is a skier. Although technically on the high plains, the Mile High City has emerged as the gateway to the largest concentration of ski areas in the country. About 600,000 skiers flew in last season for days on the slopes of the Rockies and nights in the cabarets of the dozen or so resorts within a few hours' drive to the west. But even though Denver is a gateway, it has its own attractions. The oil boom of the 1970's brought enough glass and chrome to satisfy a Houston, and dozens of respectable restaurants and night spots followed, while museums offer important touring shows and are building their own permanent collections.

title:
ART;
THE COMPLEX ART OF CASTING -- GIVING LIFE TO AN ARTIST'S IDEA
description: ''WHEN nothing's going on in your studio, there's the feeling that something's going on here,'' said Mel Kendrick, the New York sculptor, talking about the Johnson Atelier here.'' This is where a lot of us are a couple of days a week when you can't reach us.''

title: WORRY AND WAITING AT FLOOD SHELTERS
description: A tense and somber mood has settled over refugees from Thursday night's break in a levee alongside the Yuba River, which sent 26,000 people fleeing their flooded homes in Linda and Olivehurst near here.

title: Extended and Endangered Families
description: Japanese television broadcast the other night what has become an all-too-familiar scene: white-gloved police officers raiding a suspect investment company, searching through boxes of records to trace the life savings of yet another group of unfortunate investors.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Consolations of Tea There's a literature of small comforts growing up in America, a savoring of the texture of ordinary things. In ''Hill Song: A Country Journal'' (Countryman Press), Lee Pennock Huntington talks of the pleasures of hot tea on cold days in Vermont.

title: HOW ACCESSORY METERS SHED LIGHT ON THE SUBJECT
description: TWO photographers on assignment for national magazines at a news conference carried the latest, automatic-exposure 35-millimeter cameras. Each went up to the podium and began checking the light with hand meters to determine their exposure.

title: Anthony Lieber Engaged To Ellen Donna Grossman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Grossman of East Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Donna Grossman to Anthony R. Lieber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Lieber of New York and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Surge of Aliens Said to Enter U.S.
description: Economic hard times in Latin America have touched off a ''startling'' surge of illegal aliens streaming north across the border,the head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said last week.

title: PATTI LA BELLE: A POP DIVA TAKES OFF
description: In every Patti La Belle show, there comes a point during the ballad, ''Isn't a Shame,'' when the singer abandons all pretenses of control.

title: Carin Sigel to Be Married to Michael Schlesinger
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Sigel of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter Carin Sigel to Michael Alan Schlesinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David N. Schlesinger of Great Neck, L.I. The wedding is planned for June 7. The future bride, an associate in the Washington law firm of Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley & Casey, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and the Boston University Law School, where she was an associate editor of The American Journal of Law and Medicine.

title: JOYCE F. RIEGELHAUPT
description: Joyce F. Riegelhaupt, a professor of anthropology at Sarah Lawrence College, died Friday of cancer at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Puccini's 'Tosca' An Arena di Verona production, featuring Eva Marton, Giacomo Aragall and Ingvar Wixell; Sylvano Bussotti conducting Thorn EMI/HBO Video 118 minutes. $39.95 The most endearing quality of these Arena di Verona performances is their sense of place, their way of evoking - along with the opera itself - a feeling for listeners, the huge outdoor space, the summer sky, even the city itself, all of which are made to surround the music in the most festive of ways.

title: MADLOCK SEES NO HARD-DRUG DISCIPLINE
description: OF the 24 baseball players summoned to meet individually with Commissioner Peter Ueberroth last month following their involvement or implication in the Pittsburgh drug trial, only one has been cleared - Bill Madlock, the 35-year-old third baseman for the Los Angeles Dodgers. While the others hold their breath waiting for a possible suspension or fine, if not both, Bill Madlock has emerged as a candidate for baseball beatification.

title: Verbatim; Pricetag for Wisdom
description: 'I beg this committee to recognize that knowledge is not simply another commodity.

title: SOME POLE VAULTERS ARE ACHIEVING UPWARD MOBILITY
description: Few sports spectacles are more exacting than the pole vault. A young man jams a fiberglass pole into the takeoff box, rides the bending pole into a handstand, wiggles his body limb by limb over a crossbar and then falls 19 feet or so into a foam-rubber landing pit. And this winter, thanks to intense competition - not to mention shrewder physics - the event is more breathtaking than ever.

title: Striving to Nip Graffiti in Bud
description: MAYOR Koch tried yet another tactic last July in New York's long war against graffiti vandals: He moved to cut their supply lines.

title: PHILADELPHIA POLICE UNDERGOING MAJOR SHAKE-UP
description: Two months after taking over this city's embattled Police Department, Commissioner Kevin M. Tucker has begun one of the biggest shake-ups in the department's history.

title: Anita Covington Becomes Bride Of Steven Heller
description: The marriage of Anita Flynt Covington and Steven McArthur Heller, both lawyers in New York, took place yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Enterprise, Miss. The Rev. Walter Hurt performed the ceremony.

title: LEAPING INTO SECURITIES WITHOUT LOOKING
description: THE rise of ''blind pool'' offerings has begun to disturb some analysts, who view such deals as symptoms of speculative fever.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MARDI GRAS TIME What's in a name? Sometimes, not much. For example, while there won't be any wild parading in, through or around Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale today when the Long Island State Park Commission holds its annual ''Mardi Gras Gala,'' there will be plenty of ''family fun,'' its sponsors say. There will be folk and square dancing, musical entertainment, exhibits mounted by the Suffolk County Extension Farm, Oriental cooking demonstrations, 4-H Clubs of Nassau games, and, because this celebration ends the park's annual Winter Arts Festival, a chance to create a poster. It all takes place from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the park's golf clubhouse and is free.

title: TOPICS
description: WHEN I was a small child, going to the library was always an adventure. My local library then was a two- or three-room building on the main street of an Indiana hamlet surrounded by cornfields. I thought of it as a strange, rich house, home of ''The Wizard of Oz'' and other wonder-filled books.

title: London
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading Mary Lee Settle's essay,''Savoring London's Luxury'' (Travel, Jan. 26). Having been born in London and once a frequent ''returner,'' I mentally accompanied her on her lovely journey.

title: August Wedding For Miss Simons, Horse Show Aide
description: The engagement of Hilary Wadsworth Simons to David Blair Miller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William E. Miller of Unionville, Pa., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wadsworth Simons of New York and New Marlborough, Mass. The wedding is planned for Aug. 9.

title: Susan Norsworthy to Be Bride in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Norsworthy of Montreal have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Jane Norsworthy to Marshall Thomas Masko, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Masko of Minneapolis. A June wedding is planned.

title: RECITAL: IVO POGORELICH
description: IVO POGORELICH'S piano recital Friday night at Carnegie Hall was a curious affair. Musically, it was deeply satisfying and occasionally eccentric by turns. But what was really curious was the range of emotion Mr. Pogorelich provoked. For every cheering devotee - and the audience filled both hall and stage - there were grumbling dissenters, their dissent sometimes expressed in unusually violent language.

title: Headliners; Moving Up
description: He has been dropping into stores and riding buses to demonstrate his concern for Moscow residents. He is rumored to have ordered public transport officials to use the buses and subways.

title: BITTER WORDS UNFAIR TO DILIGENT OFFICIALS
description: Mr. Byrne's ire seems to be directed at (1) the conditions that existed during the Millrose pole vault and (2) my comments at the track writers' lunch, as reported in The New York Times on Feb. 18.

title: Wall Street Takes A Funny Bounce
description: Upbeat economic statistics have been appearing almost daily, especially on inflation, and hope has been mounting that the Federal Reserve might be ready to loosen up on interest rates. But in his semiannual report to Congress last week, the Fed's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, took a firm line.

title: PANEL BACKS SHIFT OF MILITARY ROLES
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee is ready to propose sweeping changes in the organization of the nation's military establishment, including the Defense Department, the military services and the role of Congress, according to Senate officials.

title: SMOKING ON TRAINS PROHIBITED
description: RAILROAD passengers who smoke will now have to leave their habit behind when they board NJ Transit trains.

title: Dr. Gross Faces Charges Again
description: The State Board of Regents voted unanimously last week to allow the State Health Department to pursue charges of professional misconduct against Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner. The decision will permit disciplinary hearings against Dr. Gross to resume; the case had been on hold for months as state officials and lawyers for the pathologists debated whether the Health Department, which filed the charges last August, had jurisdiction to do so.

title: IRAQI SAYS ENEMY USES MUSTARD GAS
description: A top-ranking Iraqi general charged today that Iranian troops dug into the city of Fao were using chemical weapons against counterattacking Iraqi troops.

title: A BIG SHOW THAT'S ABOUT SOMETHING LARGER THAN SIZE
description: Anyone wanting a better idea of where photography is headed, and why, should make it a point to see ''The Real Big Picture,'' an exhibition of 50 works by as many artists at the Queens Museum in Flushing Meadows, through March 19.

title: UNEASY POULTRYMEN FEND OFF AVIAN FLU
description: NORMALLY, a meeting of the Connecticut Poultry Association is a sociable gathering of a dozen or so farmers to discuss the latest equipment or techniques in poultry raising.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
EXCELLENCE IN LEARNING
description: An award medal unveiled last week in New York merits special mention because of its strong numismatic connection. It was commissioned by Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc. of Chicago, publisher of the Britannica reference books, to honor recipients of its new Britannica Awards. These awards recognize ''exceptional excellence in the dissemination of learning for the benefit of mankind.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in this section last Sunday on Olympic marketing rights misstated the Xerox Corporation's status in the 1988 Olympic Games. Xerox has not signed to be the official copier for the 1988 Olympics.

title: Seoul Resists A Petition Drive
description: Proposals to do away with an electoral college and hold direct presidential elections are controversial in many countries, the United States not excepted. In South Korea, they can lead to arrest.

title: STRIKING FISHERMEN IN NEW BEDFORD SEE BOAT OWNERS IN RIFT
description: Owners of more than a fifth of New Bedford's fishing boats have broken ranks with their management group and begun signing separate contracts to end a two-month-old walkout by crew members, according to union officials. A management spokesman said he thought the report was exaggerated.

title: 3 BIAS CASES BEFORE SUPREME COURT COULD RESHAPE LAW ON RACIAL GOALS
description: The national debate over the use of racial preferences to redress discrimination against minorities has reached a watershed both in the Supreme Court and in the Reagan Administration.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings * 5.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds * 7.44 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds * 7.37 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts * 6.70 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 11.48 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York * 14.75 Continental Illinois, Chicago * 17.00 Bank of America, San Francisco * 19.50

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: 007 IN PHILADELPHIA Fans of James Bond may be interested in a close-up look at the OO7 Aston Martin driven by Sean Connery in ''Goldfinger.'' The car, which could foil villains in the 1964 film by ejecting oil and/or smoke, will be on view weekends through March 16 at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

title: JENNIFER MULLER: MULTIDIMENSIONAL MEANING TO 'THE WORKS'
description: WHEN she was 3 years old, Jennifer Muller went to what she calls a ''creative school'' in Tuckahoe, where ''you pretended you were a tree or a color.''

title: BOREDOM IN TOYLAND
description: THE toy buyers in their blue pinstripes crowded into Mattel Inc.'s showrooms in New York's Penn Plaza and looked at Popples. The round, brightly colored stuffed toys are Mattel's newest offerings to the world of play, but the buyers looked singularly unplayful; in fact, they looked bored.

title: I.R.A. INVESTMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Reins on Commercial Rents
description: RESPONDING in the midst of last year's mayoral campaign to calls for a new commercial rent control system, Mayor Koch created the Small Rental Business Study Commission in May. Its task was to conduct surveys, analyze the experience of other municipalities, weigh policy options and report back by the end of the year.

title: Chicken Or Egg?
description: Without quite admitting it, the Reagan Administration has turned America's formal policy on nuclear testing on its head.

title: 'FREEZE' SEEKS LOCAL SUPPORT
description: IN 1982 and 1983, a total of 65 New Jersey municipalities - more than in any other state -adopted resolutions supporting a freeze on nuclear-weapons testing. Now the leaders of that drive have announced a new campaign to drum up local support for a nuclear test-ban treaty.

title: TACKLING THE BIG QIESTIONS
description: THE VIEW FROM NOWHERE By Thomas Nagel. 244 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95. MANY people believe that in recent decades philosophy has lost its vocation and abandoned its inquiry into all the interesting and important questions that enthralled the great minds of its history. If you feel that way, you would do well to read this new book by Thomas Nagel, a professor of philosophy at New York University. He is as well versed as anyone in linguistic philosophy and is a fully competent practitioner of contemporary analysis, but no one can pick up his book without realizing that he stands in the mainstream of philosophical tradition and is grappling with the same problems that fascinated Kant and Nietzsche.

title:
GARDENING;
PROPER PRUNING HAS MANY BENEFITS
description: TREES that have been pruned and trained properly will be more attractive, more wind resistant and longer lived than those that have been neglected or improperly treated. It is not all that difficult to do these things properly. It is more a matter of timeliness and persistence.

title: ISRAEL ENDS SEARCH BY ITS FORCES IN LEBANESE ZONE
description: Israeli forces have withdrawn from all areas of Lebanon north of the so-called security zone just above the Lebanese border, the military announced tonight.

title: MUSEUM ON WHEELS IS A HIT
description: FOR 9-year-old Cara Dornton, visiting the Governor's Jersey Pride Mobile Museum proved an unexpected delight.

title: WHEN THE OLD LIVE AMONG THE YOUNG
description: IN exploring viable housing options for senior citizens, I recently came across a study entitled ''A Model of Community Age-Integrated Living for the Elderly: Does It Work?''

title: BETWEEN THE LOVE OF CLIZIA AND MOSCA
description: THE STORM AND OTHER THINGS By Eugenio Montale. Translated by William Arrowsmith. 219 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95. WHEN Eugenio Montale received the Nobel

title: WHITE HOUSE PICKS COUNSEL
description: Peter J. Wallison, former general counsel to the Treasury Department, will replace Fred Fielding as White House counsel, it was announced Friday. Mr. Wallison, 44 years old, has been a partner with a Washington law firm since leaving the Treasury Department in 1985 after four years as general counsel.

title: SING SING PROGRAM OPENS DOOR TO 'SELF'
description: THE buzz of conversation grows louder as 30 men file into the room and take seats among rows of folding chairs. On a blackboard facing the group is printed the message: ''Utilize Your Thinking Skills.'' A young man dressed in green fatigues stands and addresses the group.

title: Senate Condemns Genocide After A 37-Year Delay
description: Decades behind much of the rest of the world, the Senate approved last week, 83 to 11, a United Nations treaty that condemns genocide.

title: TOTTENVILLE WINS TITLE
description: Tottenville of Staten Island, led by four individual winners, captured the team title with 155 points yesterday in the 10th annual Public Schools Athletic League girls indoor track and field championships at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. South Shore of Brooklyn was second at 132 with Truman of the Bronx third at 66.

title: In a 'Castle's' Shadow, Elegant Condos
description: AT the turn of the century, Frederic E. Kip, a wealthy textile manufacturer and inventor, built his family mansion on the rugged ridge of First Mountain at the border of Montclair and Verona. Its turrets, escutcheons and two-foot-thick stone walls reflected the family's European heritage and the building came to be known as Kip's Castle.

title: TAPE DECKS ADAPT TO THE RIGORS OF THE CD ERA
description: Copying records onto cassettes, despite unresolved questions of legality, has long been a major pursuit of audio hobbyists. Now with the advent of digital disks, the dubbing process has become technically more demanding, and cassette decks are being designed with a view toward narrowing the quality gap between the sound of the original CD and the cassette copy.

title: Dance
description: Jennifer Muller once called a dance ''Speeds.'' That title suits much of her choreography in general, for almost everyone agrees that her creations possess pep and zip.

title: HOW TO HANDLE THE PHILIPPINES
description: An old Chinese proverb -''save a man from death and you owe him a living forever'' - may apply to the future relationship between the United States and the Philippines. For the United States, having intruded into domestic Philippine affairs in an effort to keep the presidential election honest, has assumed a new long-term responsibility for its former colonial possession.

title: FUNDING MERGERS AND HIGHER SALARIES
description: AS tax reform heads into the home stretch, the Senate Finance Committee is considering whether to restore business tax ''incentives'' that were rescinded in the House bill. Of course, the cost of restoring these tax breaks would be borne by most Americans, who would lose some or all of the tax cuts provided them in the House bill.

title: Joining Groups For Co-ops
description: THE rapid growth in the number of cooperatives, condominiums and homeowner associations has led to a proliferation of organizations designed to meet the special needs of these forms of property ownership and of their elected leaders.

title: BROADWAY'S 'BRIGADOON' GOES TO THE OPERA
description: Beverly Sills says right away that the New York City Opera's ''Brigadoon'' isn't looking for converts.

title: Q and A
description: Question:Would you please suggest a first-class hotel in Chelsea, London? Not too modern; something like the Basil Street. - R. L. C., Bradenton, Fla. Answer:Admirers of the Basil Street Hotel may argue that its quiet elegance cannot be duplicated in Chelsea. But the borough does have other first-class hotels outside the large, modern category. One is the Cadogan Thistle (75 Sloane Street, London SW1X 9SG; telephone, 235-7141), a red-brick building with 69 rooms. It has an oak-paneled foyer, cocktail bar and 24-hour lounge service. The rate for a double room is about $120. At the 99-room Royal Court (Sloane Square SW1W 8EG; 730-9191) a room for two costs from $100 to $112. Each floor has its own color scheme, the bathrooms are fully tiled and the foyer has crystal chandeliers and antique armchairs.

title: A TASTE OF TERROR IN THREE ACTS
description: IN ''The Shirkers,'' the first of three one-act plays on the Arena Players' ''Terror Times Three'' bill, the playwright C. M. McLellan examines what for many is the ultimate terror - extreme loneliness.

title: Kate Mowlem is Married
description: Kate Vivienne Mowlem, a daughter of Mrs. Salim J. Mowlem and the late Mr. Mowlem of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Ron H. Har-zvi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Har-zvi of Hollis Hills, Queens. Rabbi Melvin Sirner with Cantor Lawrence Avery performed the ceremony at Beth El Synagogue. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is an account executive for the Rockefeller Center Telecommunications Corporation in New York. Dr. Har-zvi is a podiatrist.

title: Shuttle Investigators Wonder Why Engineer's Warnings Went Unheeded
description: What did NASA officials know, when did they know it and why did they not do more about it? Those questions were raised by a disquieting series of revelations last week concerning the launching of the ill-fated space shuttle Challenger.

title: BLOOD DONORS SEEK TO LIMIT RECIPIENTS
description: BLOOD DONORS seeking to designate who receives their donations are challenging the state medical establishment, which is defending its system of pooling donations.

title: Art
description: During his lifetime (1857-1920) the German painter, printmaker and sculptor Max Klinger had moments of apotheosis. When his polychrome marble sculpture of Beethoven was first shown in Vienna, for instance, members of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra were brought into the gallery to pay it a musical tribute.

title: WIDESPREAD RABIES REPORTED DESPITE INDONESIA CAMPAIGN
description: Rabies is present in 21 of Indonesia's 27 provinces, despite a campaign to kill stray dogs to stem the disease, the official press agency reported today.

title: ROME PROSECUTOR SAYS BULGARIAN LIED ON ALIBI
description: A Government prosecutor accused a Bulgarian airline official today of having lied when he told Italian investigators that he was not present when Pope John Paul II was shot.

title: CRIME AND EXTRADITION
description: EXTRADITION treaties are as old as the Pharaohs, but modern courts are still searching for a consistent set of principles to guide their decisions on whether the United States should turn over to other countries persons accused of committing so-called political crimes there. Last week's ruling by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit here, paving the way for the extradition to Britain of an American accused of murdering a police officer, demonstrated that distinguishing between political offenses and mere common crimes can be, as one judge described it, ''excruciatingly difficult.''

title: STARS OF TOMORROW IN CONCERT
description: WHOEVER complained about youth being wasted on the young obviously was not referring to musicians. Ever since the 6-year-old Mozart starting composing and playing rings around his elders, there has been a fascination with prodigies and their accomplishments.

title: GLORY DAYS RETURN FOR FAIRFIELD STAGS
description: THE cover of its media guide shows the Fairfield University Stags basketball team clutching the rails of an open trolley car at a museum in Branford. The slogan accompanying the photograph has become this season's theme: ''Back on Track.''

title: IN VERMONT, RESTORED GLORY
description: The Equinox, newly reopened in Manchester, Vt., after 13 years of shuttered abandonment, was one of the grand hotels of the Victorian era. Well-heeled gentlemen, stylish ladies and privileged children of the powerful and elite fled the summer city heat and, attended by white-gloved servants, boarded the train in Albany or New York and disembarked in Manchester's small train station. They were met by horse-drawn carriages and taken to the historic inn, nestled at the base of Mount Equinox, the tallest peak of the Taconic mountain range.

title: IN SYDNEY'S SUBURBS, AN ENDLESS SUMMER
description: The Barrenjoey Peninsula points like a crooked finger across the mouth of Broken Bay, a large, natural harbor and estuary, north of Sydney. On maps, it is drafted into Sydney's metropolitan sprawl. Twenty-odd miles from the center by road, the Peninsula is technically the northernmost extension of the heavily built-up suburbs that are strewn along the coast on either side of the city's best-known landmark, the Harbor Bridge.

title: Travels With Bush
description: Vice President Bush's White House ambitions may be temporarily set back from time to time by a political gaffe or two, but the organization his supporters are building to win him the 1988 Republican nomination already seems to be taking on formidable outlines.

title: HONORING AN ASSOCIATE JUSTICE
description: The United States Postal Service will issue a 5-cent Great Americans stamp on Thursday to honor Hugo L. Black. The date marks the 100th anniversary of the former Supreme Court Associate Justice. The stamp will be released in Washington, D.C.

title: REBELLION COMES AFTER YEARS OF RESTIVENESS AND FRUSTRATION IN THE MILITARY
description: The troops that stepped from loyalist ranks tonight to resist President Ferdinand E. Marcos demonstrated to the nation and the world the intense pressures that have built up within the military during Mr. Marcos's 20 years in power.

title: The Creative Mind Of Woody Allen
