description: Woody Allen is quoted as admitting that he tends ''to romanticize people and culture heroes and the island of Manhattan,'' which doubtless explains his relative obscurity west of the Hudson, save for several enclaves in Miami, Phoenix and Los Angeles.

title: THE CRATIVE MIND OF WOODY ALLEN
description: I agree with Vincent Canby when he says of Woody Allen that ''there's nobody else in American film who comes anywhere near him in originality and interest.'' However, Woody Allen's desire to get ''more and more serious'' is not only denying the desires of his public, but also his innate ability to be funny - he himself says that ''it was something he could always do.''

title: EASTERN WARNS UNION OF OFFER TO PURCHASE AIRLINE
description: Eastern Airlines, faced with a pilots' strike deadline at 12:01 A.M. Wednesday, told its three unions yesterday that it had received a purchase offer, a union spokesman said yesterday.

title: Cynthia Hill Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Scott Hill of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Conwell Hill to John Michael Dopp, a son of Evelyn F. McKinley of Short Hills, N.J., and Paul S. Dopp of Basking Ridge, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: COMPANY'S OFFER DIVIDES SYNDICATES
description: As far as ideas go for enriching the campaign coffers of America's Cup syndicates, a plan proposed recently by Philip Morris Inc. appeared to be the most lucrative. At stake was more than $4 million, to be divided among the six United States teams -if all would agree to it. But two refused.

title: SOME WHO SURVIVED
description: MOMENTS OF REPRIEVE By Primo Levi. Translated by Ruth Feldman. 172 pp. New York: Summit Books. $14.95. RETURNING 40 years later to the scene of his first classic works about Auschwitz, ''Survival in Auschwitz'' and ''The Reawakening,'' Primo Levi has written a series of sketches and vignettes that vary in quality and focus. Mr. Levi worked as a chemist in a camp laboratory at Monowitz, a private camp near Auschwitz that belonged to I. G. Farben. He writes about the start of a day: ''When reveille sounds (and it's still pitch dark) first of all we put on our shoes, otherwise somebody will steal them and it is an unspeakable tragedy.'' This is Mr. Levi's characteristic tone in ''Moments of Reprieve'' - wry, understated, innocent, mordant and humorous. At its best, the mix makes for an illuminating method of comprehending the abyss of concentration camp experience.

title: Margaret Wenzel Weds
description: Margaret Susan Wenzel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Wenzel of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin Michael O'Callaghan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Anthony O'Callaghan, also of Armonk. The Rev. Jack O'Callaghan, the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony at SS. John and Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: MURDER DEFENDANT'S FEARS REVEALED ON TAPE
description: Robert O. Marshall wept in court this week while listening to a tape recording in which he said a jury would be ''compelled'' to convict him and order him put to death for the murder of his wife.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
DEALING WITH THE MAILSTROM OF EXHORTATORY LITERATURE
description: NO longer is there the tingle of excitement left over from childhood: what will today's mail bring? Will there be a letter from Aunt Sally inviting me to visit? Or a letter from my best friend who's away on a trip? These days I approach the mailbox with irritability: ''With what trash will I be inundated today?'' The postman must have his private thoughts about the needless burden on his aching back as he stuffs my box with what he recognizes as ''junk'' mail.

title: The West Wrings Out and Wonders What to Do Next
description: ON the outskirts of this agricultural community 80 miles south of San Francisco, families were watching television, reading and otherwise spending a quiet evening Monday when a wall of water slammed into their homes.

title: CONCERN FOR WINTER'S IMPACT ON THE NEEDIEST PROMPTS AID
description: The impact of wintry weather on the homeless, ill and despairing is cited by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: QUEEG WOULD FEEL RIGHT AT HOME
description: Yes, ''The Fifth Missile'' is goofy, but it does have its moments. How will the world end? Not with a bang nor a whimper, the three-hour, made-for-television-movie suggests, but possibly, just possibly, with the rancid smell of paint. The paint has been applied to the bulkhead in a Trident submarine (it's literally covering up a particularly nutty military operation by the White House) and when it peels and festers, it drives the crew of the U.S.S. Montana mad. ''The Fifth Missile,'' which seems to be made up of stray pieces of other movies, isn't something to be taken seriously, thank goodness, although toward its latter half it does give off pulsations. How could it not? The end of the world is a sure-fire topic.

title: A DOCTOR'S VIEW OF MODERN MEDICINE
description: PRIVATE MEDICINE is abandoning the poor. As a family doctor practicing in the inner city of Washington, I am embarrassed by my profession's increasing refusal to care for the indigent; I am angry that the poor are shuttled to inferior public clinics and hospitals for their medical care.

title: Vanessa Weber To Wed April 19
description: Dr. John J. Weber of New York and Deep River, Conn., has announced the engagement of his daughter Vanessa N. Weber to Daniel C. Rydholm, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Fred Rydholm of Marquette, Mich. An April 19 wedding is planned.

title: PROSPECTS
description: THE TRADE DOLDRUMS A full year has passed since the dollar peaked against other major currencies. Now it buys about 30 percent fewer Japanese yen, West German marks and British pounds. But the expected improvement in the nation's balance of trade is as elusive as ever. ''It usually takes at least 18 months for trade balances to respond to major realignments in currency values,'' said Edward S. Hyman Jr., senior vice president at Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc. This Friday, says Mr. Hyman, the Government will report another hefty monthly trade deficit. ''We expect the figures to show that imports of foreign merchandise exceeded exports by $17 billion in January, only a shade below the record $17.4 billion trade deficit the Government reported for last December.'' he said.

title: BELAFONTE IS SAID TO BE WEIGHING A CHALLENGE FOR D'AMATO'S SEAT
description: Harry Belafonte, the singer and civil rights activist, is interested in running for the Senate seat held by the Republican Alfonse M. D'Amato, Democratic party leaders said yesterday.

title: A CHILD CARE EXPERT OFFERS ADVICE ON BRINGING UP BABY
description: This week, Dr. T. Berry Brazelton - an associate professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School, founder of the child development unit at the Children's Hospital in Boston and a prolific author - is observing the third birthday of a child of his own - ''What Every Baby Knows.'' The program is a half-hour colloquium on infants and their parents that is carried by Lifetime weekdays at 8:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M.

title: TYLENOL CASE PUTS FOCUS ON O'ROURKE
description: THE television cameras were lined up again, not for the first time since the Tylenol case began unfolding in Westchester, and the press had gathered again to interview County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: THE P.S.C. ROLE'S IN LILCO RATE INCREASES
description: Re: Shoreham, Lilco and the ratepayers. As a showdown of sorts approaches, it is important to realize how far from its original purpose the New York State Public Service Commission, which was established in 1907, has wandered in recent times, and particularly in its flagrant support of Lilco and Shoreham.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: POPCORN and ice cream and pizza aren't junk foods. How can they be? What's popcorn but corn, and what's corn but a vegetable, and how can a vegetable be junk? What's ice cream but the ulimate expression of milk. As for pizza, just mentioning it in the same breath with junk is laughable. Maybe hold the pepperoni, anchovies and the fat part of the crust, but healthy nutrients are literally bursting out of the green peppers, tomatoes and cheese.

title: A MEADOW THAT WON'T BE
description: ROAD WORK 1/2 M. ROAD WORK 1000 FT. ROAD WORK 100 FT. Going north on the Hutch with Mamaroneck Avenue just ahead, I prepare to guide the car along the new route, bracing myself for an environment changed from the familiar road I have traveled since childhood. And, I think, the hardest change is just around the bend.

title: HOPE IN MANILA?
description: The problem now in the Philippines is how to avoid a bloody civil war, and it's just possible that there's still a chance of doing so.

title: TOPICS
description: I WENT to visit friends for the weekend recently, and I am ashamed to admit it's the first time I've ''run away from home'' since my older son was born six years ago.

title: The Creative Mind Of Woody Allen
description: I have been an admirer of Woody Allen for most of my life, and I was delighted to see Caryn James's article ''Auteur! Auteur! - The Creative Mind of Woody Allen,'' (Jan. 19). The man has a wonderful gift of insight into the human condition and the ability to find humor in a situation against all odds. People watching his films are able to identify with the universal emotions of the characters that he so skillfully creates. GRACE ANN V. INYARD Valley Stream, L.I.

title: The Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: ZISKIND, PIANIST, AT J'S
description: GEORGE ZISKIND, a pianist who works in both jazz and cocktail settings, shows the resultant mixture at J's, a restaurant and cabaret on Broadway near 97th Street, where he plays Thursday evenings.

title: Parties With Benefits
description: Awards From the Y Feb. 24 - Young, male and Christian no longer describes the Young Men's Christian Association, the worldwide organization that provides programs ranging from yachting courses to day-care and physical-fitness centers without regard to age, sex or religion. A mainstay of the organization is its volunteers, and the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York, with 24 branches, will honor Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's University basketball coach, and 51 volunteers at a dinner at the Marriott Marquis, beginning with cocktails at 6 P.M. Tickets, $60, from 212-564-1300, extension 221. Party in the Bell Tower Feb. 25 - There will be Champagne and dessert in the bell tower of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street, following a benefit for the Balletfore dance company, which will present six excerpts from its repertory at the church's Riverside Theater at 8:30 P.M. Tickets, $75, from 212-679-0401. Cultural Exchange March 3 - Madre, the Spanish word for mother, is also the name of a group that describes itself as a ''national women's friendship association dedicated to nurturing exchange between people in the United States and those in Central America and the Caribbean.'' At a fund-raising party for the group, there will be an auction of 40 works, including paintings by Willem de Kooning and Roy Lichtenstein and signed first editions by E. L. Doctorow and Grace Paley. The party will begin with cocktails at 8 P.M., followed by the auction, with Joseph Papp and others as hosts, at the Victoria Munroe Gallery, 415 West Broadway (Prince Street).

title: WHITE HOUSE SIGNALS ITS SUPPORT FOR 2 MILITARY MEN IN PHILIPPINES
description: The White House signaled today that it supported two Philippine military leaders who resigned from the Government and who called on President Ferdinand E. Marcos to resign because of fraud in the elections Feb. 7.

title: THE OFF-AND-ON WORLD OF BOXING
description: THE POSSIBILITY of postponement is the one fly in the ointment of a boxing promoter's existence. It occupies all his waking hours before a bout goes off on schedule and hovers around the rim of his consciousness from the moment he signs a fight until the bout takes place.

title: Truman and the Bomb
description: To the Editor:

title: 'LADY JANE' REVIVES HISTORICAL ROMANCE
description: Jane Austen thought she was a prig. Charles Dickens regarded her as a martyr. But, however strong past opinions about her, it is unlikely that the name of Lady Jane Grey - Queen of England for precisely nine days in July 1553 - is all that familiar to moviegoers. Undaunted, Paramount recently released ''Lady Jane,'' a new $8.5 million film about her, at a time when costume historical drama is out of vogue. Even more remarkably, the film represents a triple feature-film debut - for its 18-year-old star, Helena Bonham Carter, its writer, David Edgar, and its director, Trevor Nunn.

title: Coke Enlists Dr Pepper in Soft-Drink War
description: The Coca-Cola Company uncapped last week its latest formula for staying at the pinnacle of the soft-drink industry. In a deal that puts a comfortable distance between it and archrival Pepsico, the company announced that it had agreed to buy Dr Pepper for $470 million.

title: EX-PROSECUTOR RETURNS TO FRAY FOR MANES INQUIRY
description: When Paul W. Pickelle lost the election for Westchester County District Attorney three months ago, he assumed he would not be working as a prosecutor again for quite a while.

title: MAJOR SHOW'S PLUSES AND MINUSES
description: A SHOW honoring the recipients of New Jersey craft fellowships during the 15-year history of the grant-awarding program is on view at the Montclair Art Museum here.

title: Martha Taylor to Wed Joseph D'Ambrosio Jr.
description: The engagement of Martha Wenzel Taylor to Joseph J. D'Ambrosio Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Taylor Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and Lyme, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. D'Ambrosio of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. D'Ambrosio.

title: COMMUNITIES GROW CLOSER TO THEIR 'SISTERS' ABROAD
description: IT is a small world, or so it seems, to the growing number of Connecticut communities that have adopted ''sister cities'' abroad.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: E. B. WHITE, by Scott Elledge. (Norton, $9.95.) This biography traces the literary career of E. B. White from his childhood in Mount Vernon, N.Y., through his many years at The New Yorker, and to the farm on Allen Cove in Maine, where he lived, wrote, gardened and sailed until his death last year. Russell Lynes wrote in The Book Review in 1984 that Scott Elledge ''is fair, respectful, thorough, entertaining, skillful and unpedantic. He has performed a splendid exercise in scholarship and literary analysis, and the result is fun.'' FLAUBERT'S PARROT, by Julian Barnes. (McGraw-Hill, $4.95.) Geoffrey Braithwaite, the narrator of Julian Barnes's novel, is a retired doctor and amateur Flaubert scholar who is obsessed with his literary hero and spends his leisure time tracking down Flaubertian trivia. ''The result is a splendid hybrid of a novel, part biography, part fiction, part literary criticism, the whole carried off with great brio,'' our reviewer, Peter Brooks, wrote last year. '' 'Flaubert's Parrot' is high literary entertainment,'' ''full of insight and wit, rich and even prodigal in its verbal inventiveness.'' THE PROVINCIAL LADY IN RUSSIA: I Visit the Soviets, by E. M. Delafield. (Academy Chicago, $8.95.) The novelist E. M. Delafield spent several months on a collective farm in the Soviet Union in the mid-1930's and recorded her impressions of life there. Michael T. Florinsky wrote in these pages in 1937 that she had created ''a book that is not only informing and brilliantly written but also highly amusing. . . . Some of her pages, with their underlying element of deep tragedy, are tinged with a delicate irony reminiscent of Chekhov.''

title: ONE-MAN BANKS
description: To the Editor:

title: TEST FOR PHYSICIANS RATES CONFIDENCE
description: A PROFESSOR at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington has developed a computer program to test the confidence of medical students in diagnosing and treating patients.

title: RETIREMENT BRINGS UNWANTED ADVICE
description: EVER since I retired, I have been bombarded with helpful advice from all sides: magazines, newspapers, and especially my former employer, a large corporation that has no time for such hand-holding itself but has hired a service to take care of the matter. From them I receive a monthly newsletter headed ''Dear Friend.''

title: Postings; Castle Condos
description: The former Staten Island Hospital, on nine acres at 101 Castleton Avenue in New Brighton, is a walled and fenced cluster of buildings with on-site and nearby parking. When Louis Farkas, his son, Steven, and Geofrey Alexander saw the property they realized it could become a condominium project that would utilize all the companies they have founded and merged.

title: OUSTED PASTOR, IN HOME SERMONS, PRESSES FOR AID TO JOBLESS
description: Every Sunday morning they gather quietly to pray, break bread and sing hymns of praise, these God-fearing people bent on helping the unemployed by wiping out ''corporate evil.''

title: Hungary
description: To the Editor: Dr. Stephen J. Gergatz's letter about Sopron-Odenburg (Travel, Dec. 8), a town in Hungary near the Austrian border, brought back childhood memories that have hounded me for over 60 years; I left Sopron in 1920 (not by choice), but I have never been able to leave it behind.

title: DRIVEN TO DRIVE -- AT LONG LAST
description: FOR a suburban kid, coming of age means getting a driver's license and learning to drive.

title: 'Illusory Tenants' With Sublets
description: MARY M. COLLINS, a young waitress, sublet Apartment 2A at 340 West 88th Street in the fall of 1983. Later that year, she said, the prime tenant agreed to give up his lease if the landlord, Giselle Arenstein, would give her a renewal lease for the rent-stabilized, one-bedroom apartment, which rented for $422.59 a month. ''Face to face, the landlord told me I would get the lease,'' she recalled.

title: September Wedding For Kathleen Mealey
description: Announcement has been made by Carroll J. Mealey of Albany of the engagement of his daughter Kathleen Mary Mealey to Donald Bruce McNaughton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce A. McNaughton of Setauket, L.I.

title: NAVY BEATS ARMY IN OVERTIME, 55-52
description: David Robinson, who had a chance to win the game for Navy in regulation with a free throw with two seconds remaining, scored 7 points in overtime to lead the Midshipmen to a 55-52 victory over Army today.

title: Less Friendly Embassies
description: ''Our object,'' Secretary of State George Shultz recently told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, ''was to be easily accessible - to demonstrate to other peoples the openness of our society and the hand of friendship we extend to all.'' The subject was the design of embassy buildings, and Mr. Shultz was recalling a more innocent era.

title: PLAN ON HANDICAPPED FOUGHT
description: PARENTS of handicapped children are organizing to fight sweeping revisions in the state's system of special education. Some are forming coalitions to block the changes, others are mounting letter-writing campaigns and one group is going to court.

title: KITCHENS FOR TWO-CAREER HOUSEHOLDS
description: KITCHENS, reflecting changes in our culture, are increasingly being remodeled to accommodate two-career households, say Connecticut designers.

title: M. LEO TIERNEY
description: M. Leo Tierney, a photographer at The Boston Herald who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1978, died today at the age of 53, the newspaper said.

title: UNFETTERING MITCHELL-LAMA
description: MELVIN H. MILLER stood before tenants gathered in a synagogue on a snowy night in Queens. As he spoke, murmurs of agreement and disagreement arose from the crowd, which seemed prepared to turn unruly at the slightest provocation.

title: Miss Whitmire Affianced
description: The engagement of Elaine Joan Whitmire, an assistant vice president in the 19th-century works of art department at Sotheby's in New York, to Thomas Finney Dawson, an editor for NBC's News Division in New York, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Bryant Andrew Whitmire of Birmingham, Ala.

title: FATHER GUILTY IN GIRL'S DEATH
description: John Rairdon, 39 years old, was convicted Friday of murder in the death of his daughter Sarah Ann, 13, and District Judge Donald Gray set sentencing for March 17.

title: INQUIRY ON AUTO ACCELERATION EXPANDED BY U.S.
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has expanded its investigation into the sudden acceleration of automobiles to include vehicles made by six manufacturers.

title: Mr. Ameruso's Long Goodbye
description: If Anthony R. Ameruso, the city's Transportation Commissioner, had not already resigned, Mayor Koch said, he would have been fired last week.

title: NO PATTERN IN RULINGS ON PITCHERS' PLAY
description: Even before he walked into his hearing last Friday, Wade Boggs was assured of a salary arbitration record because both he ($1.85 million) and the Boston Red Sox ($1.35 million) submitted figures that surpassed the record $1.2 million salary Tim Raines won last year.

title: Margaret Bailey To Become Bride
description: The engagement of Margaret Buchanan Bailey to Daniel Victor Malloy 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malloy Jr. of Little Silver, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. L. Scott Bailey of Princeton, N.J.

title: WHY HAVEN'T OWNERS ACTED?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A LESSON IN TRAGEDY
description: I FIRST MET ELLISON ONIZUKA IN SAN Francisco in November 1979. He was then a young United States Air Force captain on a public relations tour for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and we had been booked on the same radio show. I watched him struggle to answer what he must have been asked umpteen times: ''Captain Onizuka, how does it feel to be the first Japanese-American astronaut?''

title: 8,500 TONNS OF GARBAGE A DAY -- AND COUNTING
description: DESPITE growing opposition from civic groups and some public officials, towns in Nassau and western Suffolk Counties are steadily moving ahead with multimillion-dollar plans to build sophisticated garbage-burning plants to solve their waste problems.

title: MUSEUM AND CORPORATION - A DELICATE BALANCE
description: The opening 10 days ago of the Equitable Tower - the world headquarters of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States - is an event of major artistic importance. It marks a commitment to art on the part of a prominent American corporation that is as generous and innovative as any before.

title: MAOIST GUERRILLAS BOMB 6 EMBASSIES IN PERU
description: Maoist guerrillas bombed six embassies and 13 other targets on Friday night in assaults in which one woman was seriously wounded, the police said today.

title:
DINING OUT;
SPANISH SPOT MARKS 11TH YEAR
description: THE first restaurant to bring Spanish cuisine to the county, Meson Castellano marks its 11th year. The dining room's pale walls make a natural canvas for festive touches such as a handful of colorful tiles, coats of arms and a wrought-iron window grill revealing a coy, dancing senorita beyond. Recent visits have revealed, however, that many of the Spanish selections upon which most of the menu is based have left something to be desired.

title: TEEN-AGE SUICIDE: EPIDEMIC, NOT TRENDY
description: Dr. Newton points out the potential dangers of ill-conceived prevention efforts in the area of teen-age suicide.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CORONER AT LARGE. By Thomas T. Noguchi with Joseph DiMona. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) A pajama top pocked with ice-pick holes convinces a jury that Jeffrey MacDonald murdered his pregnant wife and two daugh-ters.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Light Shop Illuminates Variety and Discounts Lights On is celebrating its first anniversary with a sale of lighting fixtures and accessories on Central Park Avenue in the Scarsdale Central Shopping Center in the Scarsdale postal district between Fort Hill Road and Mount Joy Avenue. The store policy is to take 20 percent off suggested retail prices, with special promotions lowering prices on domestically produced wares and imports from West Germany, Canada and Italy.

title: JOB PLAN AIDING STUDENTS
description: PROVIDING high-school seniors with part-time jobs after school has helped 170 teen-agers find permanent jobs after graduation, school officials here said.

title: Four Into Seven
description: Lawrence K. H. Chang, the president of Urban Living Inc., bought a four-story walk-up at 250 East 51st Street in Manhattan four years ago, planning to renovate it and add at least one more story. When construction was under way, however, he discovered that the walls were not strong enough to support more weight.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IS THERE a conflict between preservation and development? Does one really interfere with the other? ''Absolutely not,'' said Elizabeth R. Del Tufo, president of the Newark Preservation and Landmarks Committee. ''In fact, they can go hand in hand for the betterment of the city.''

title: Jane A. Kornfeld To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Peter Kornfeld of Tenafly, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Anne Kornfeld, to Robert Steven Bessin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Bessin of Los Angeles. The wedding is planned for May 10.

title: FINDING YOUR MATCH IN A MORTGAGE
description: SHOPPING by computer is becoming increasingly common in the home mortgage market.

title: PASTA AND SEAFOOD GO TOGETHER IN RESTORATIVE HARMONY
description: PASTA makes an excellent foil for seafood cooked in a robust sauce. Percatelli, a thick spaghetti, goes especially well with a spicy tomato sauce made with clams, mussels and shrimp. Fettuccine is superb served in the classic Southern Italian-style, topped with little neck clams in a red sauce flavored with hot crushed peppers and tomatoes. And thin spaghettini is delicious with a traditional green sauce made with mussels, parsley and white wine. All these are fine supper dishes for chilly winter nights. They are substantial and restorative, yet easy on the digestion, because they are high in carbohydrates.

title: MANDELA WANTS A HALT TO RUMORS ON RELEASE
description: Nelson Mandela does not expect to be freed from prison in the coming weeks or months and wants speculation on the matter to cease, his daughter says.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
LABORATORY DETECTIVE
description: Like many people, Joan S. Vogel has been struggling with a lingering cold the last few weeks. Her nose was stuffy for awhile, and she is still trying to shake a post-nasal drip. But the cold did not prevent her from detecting the odor of cyanide earlier this month - something that only about 12 percent of the population can do in full health, Mrs. Vogel said.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: IN THESE PROMISCUOUS PARTS. By Menna Gallie. (Joan Kahn/St. Martin's, $15.95.) Menna Gallie has created a colorful microcosm in her story of a small Welsh mining town where petty crimes and scandals are resolved in a humorous, humane manner.

title: Congress Is Divided Over What to Do About NASA
description: For years, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has enjoyed a privileged place on Capitol Hill. Lawmakers competed to praise its accomplishments and support its programs. And in President Reagan's budget for the next fiscal year, it is one of the few nondefense agencies recommended for more money.

title: THE FRON RUNNER
description: IN THE EVENING DARKNESS, WITH his latest mission for President Reagan behind him, George Bush stares across his private cabin aboard Air Force Two as its four powerful engines roar in the background. The Vice President has the wary look of a marathon runner just before the biggest race of his life. Though the primaries are two years off, Mr. Bush is clearly running for his party's nomination, and the words that tumble out of his mouth, like his expression, reinforce the notion.

title: DON'T MESS WITH US CELLULOID TIGERS
description: ''Come on, kid. There's a world out there that needs saving, and it's waiting just for you.''

title: No Pound Animals for Tests?
description: The Maryland Senate voted overwhelmingly Thursday to stop the City of Baltimore from selling unwanted pound animals to hospitals for research, rejecting assertions of harm to medical experiments beneficial to humans. The bill faces a final vote before going to the House.

title: GETTING RID OF THE POOL
description: ALL late summer, early fall, through Hurricane Gloria and into leaf-dropping time and leafless late fall, I, along with my two sons who live with us in Baldwin, kept saying that pretty soon we'd really have to get around to knocking down the old pool before winter came.

title: BEARS TO RAISE PRICES OF SEATS IN SOME AREAS
description: The price of success is being passed on to the fans as the Super Bowl champion Chicago Bears announced today that they were raising some ticket prices at Soldier Field.

title: FOCUSING ON BRIGHT SPOTS IN OPERAS TO COME
description: The other day I received a seed catalogue in the mail urging me to get moving with my plans to plant ferns that thrive in the shadows. How, I wonder, did these people know that my bedroom window looks out at a blank wall, and that the only unused space now available in my apartment is under the bed? Well, this is the drear season when fantasy is most urgently needed, so why shouldn't I contemplate sleeping amid a bower of ferns? And why not, while this floral fantasy is still in its benign stage, take a moment to browse through the seed catalogues now being distributed by New York's opera companies in hopes of finding something to lift the midwinter pall?

title: Q AND A
description: Roosevelt Island Rentals Question: I have read several reports about plans for new housing on Roosevelt Island. How can I apply for these units? . . . I.J. Manhattan Answer: Starrett Housing Corporation, the developer, has no rental information now, but you can write to its rental agency, Grenadier Realty, 1230 Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11239. When information becomes available, it will be sent to you. Tracking an Abatement Question: How can I find out if the owner of a building is applying for a J-51 tax abatement? I am particularly interested in the building at 307 West 87th Street. . . . C.F.S., Manhattan Answer: According to Larry Finkelstein, director of tax incentive programs in the city's Housing Preservation and Development Department, the building has been receiving J-51 tax abatements since 1977.

title: EAST EUROPE ANXIOUSLY AWAITS SOVIET CONGRESS
description: The Soviet Communist Party congress that begins in Moscow on Tuesday has generated often anxious comparisons among all six Soviet allies in Eastern Europe with the epochal sea change that came when Nikita S. Khrushchev delivered his secret ''sins of Stalin'' speech at his own inaugural party congress exactly 30 years ago.

title: Image, Image, Image
description: No matter how hard it tries, the Republican National Committee has difficulty not making its chairman's annual report look like the stockholders' report of a large, prosperous and image-conscious corporation. The 1985 version now being circulated includes 22 color pictures of the top echelon of party leaders, starting with President Reagan against the flag and the general chairman, Paul Laxalt, in a navy blue blazer.

title: The President's War on Crime
description: In his article ''Declaring War on Organized Crime,'' (Jan. 12), President Reagan urges all Americans to join in the battle against the ''dark, evil enemy.'' I have done battle against political corruption in my city.

title: THE SOUTH KOREAN CRACKDOWN GOES ON
description: The Government put a leading opposition politician under house arrest for the fourth time in 10 days today, confined several others to their homes and sealed off entrances to opposition party offices in a continuing effort to crush a petition drive for a constitutional amendment.

title: PAUL ANDREW QUALBEN
description: WHEN Paul Andrew Qualben was born at a Bronx hospital last weekend, the staff of the Women's Medical Pavilion in Dobbs Ferry cheered.

title: Diana F. Watson Weds J. R. Farrall
description: The marriage of Diana Faith Watson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Watson of Los Altos, Calif., to John Robert Farrall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Arthur Farrall of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. John L. Dodson performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church of Los Altos.

title: Jazz
description: Twenty-five years ago, Carol Sloan burst unexpectedly on the jazz world at the 1961 Newport Jazz Festival. Appearing at the end of an afternoon of ''new talent'' at the festival's outdoor park in Newport, R. I., under such dark and threatening skies that the audience had dwindled to 300 hardy listeners, she scored a success that brought her back for the festival's final night to sing before an appreciative audience of thousands.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S WAR ON CRIME
description: President Reagan informs us that some unions ''when discovered doing business with the mob'' have ''launched a vain attempt to protect their reputation and try to obstruct law-enforcement investigations.''

title: OPERA: AT THE MET 'SIMON BOCCANEGRA'
description: ''SIMON BOCCANEGRA'' is by most reckonings one of Verdi's half dozen greatest operas, but for understandable reasons the public has never quite taken to it in the rabid way it favors such works as ''Aida'' or ''Rigoletto.'' Though in its revised form, ''Boccanegra'' is Verdi at his most mature level, the scarcity of famous arias and ensemble numbers probably accounts as much as anything for audience indifference. And yet, what a magnificent opera this can be in an inspired, strongly cast performance.

title: Article 143286 -- No Title
description: More than $1.5 million worth of paintings and other objects, most of them stolen from the Bennington Museum in Vermont, were recovered in simultaneous raids Friday in Buffalo and in Orlando, Fla., law-enforcement officials in Buffalo said yesterday.

title: Neither Marcos Nor Aquino
description: In a period of about three months, thanks largely to the well-intentioned efforts of Americans of various political persuasions, the situation in the Philippines has deteriorated from a nasty mess to an acute, and potentially disastrous, crisis. Many hold that the only way of resolving this crisis is for President Ferdinand E. Marcos to go - now - and that the United States should press him to do so. They are wrong. The advice they offer is fraught with danger to both the Philippines and American interests.

title: HIGHER STANDARDS PROMOTE EXCELLENCE IN THE CLASSROOMS
description: ''WE are really proud and excited. We strive for excellence and it shows,'' said Jean McNeill, principal of Hurlbutt Elementary School in Weston, after receiving the results from the first state-mandated mastery test given in September to fourth-grade students. Weston fourth graders placed first and second in all areas.

title: LIABILITY INSURANCE: HARD TO GET AND COSTLY
description: WHEN West Orange's auto-liability insurance coverage lapsed, the township's police officers were ordered out of their patrol cars.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Sun City By Artists United Against Apartheid Karl-Lorimar Home Video 60 minutes. $19.95 The most significant gathering of musicians in support of a cause last year was the 54-member group organized by Little Steven (Steve Van Zandt) to create the stirring anti-apartheid anthem ''Sun City'' and its accompanying video, filmed in Washington Square Park.

title: Hilary A. Phelps To Marry a Pilot
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Phelps Jr. of Ridgefield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Hilary Ann Phelps to Lieut. William H. Fisher 3d, U.S.A.F., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Fisher Jr. of Woodbury, Conn.

title: IT'S NEWS FOR METS: WILSON LOBS BALL
description: It's only news when you are favored to win the pennant and your center fielder hasn't thrown well for two years and hasn't thrown at all for four months. So it was news for the Mets today when Mookie Wilson tossed a baseball lightly for 10 or 12 minutes.

title: Iranians Resist An Iraqi Barrage
description: Iraq's failure to dislodge Iranian forces quickly from Fao, its Persian Gulf port, has alarmed nearby Arab countries wary of Iranian expansion. Despite two weeks of pounding by Iraqi helicopter gunships, tanks, artillery and multiple rocket launchers, and charges by each side that the other was using mustard gas, the Iranians held fast last week, cutting Iraq off from the Gulf.

title: SUITS BRIGHTEN WINTER NIGHTS
description: THE idea was set in motion by the New York designer Carolina Herrera, who took a fresh, elegant approach in fashioning a white pants suit for her friend and client Jacqueline Onassis. The suits, made of heavy silk or silk and wool, have wide-shouldered jackets.

title: Restorations
description: To the Editor:

title: PROGRAMS FOR OLDER TRAVELERS
description: Hungry for new business, several major airlines have suddenly focused on older Americans. In recent weeks, people at least 65 years old - and in some cases those as young as 60 - have been the target of new programs offering substantial flight discounts and such fringe bonuses as hotel, car-rental and tour reductions and bonus credits toward frequent-flier awards. Broadening their appeal even further, they are making most of these incentives available to people of any age, regardless of sex or relationship, who accompany the older traveler.

title: THE ORDERLY WORLD OF MARTIN DAVIS
description: THE snow was falling heavily, obscuring the glorious view of Central Park from the 42d floor of the Gulf and Western building. The pristine vista did little to cheer Martin S. Davis, the company's 58-year-old chairman.

title: Pro & Con: Revising Antitrust LawsHow Far Down the Road to Laissez-Faire Should We Go?; John F. Selberling: Multiple Sellers
description: Mergers. Are they good or bad? Should the big ones be stopped? The nation's antitrust laws, embodied in the Clayton Act of 1914, were based on the premise that mergers could be bad and should be curbed. But Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has been arguing that global competition has turned market dynamics upside down, making the Clayton Act, which prohibits mergers that reduce competititon, and other antitrust laws, obsolete. Last week the Administration proposed fundamental changes in them.

title: Is Albany Helping Maintain The Sellers' Market in Milk?
description: When Jimmy Markos opened his grocery store, Willowbrook Farms, on Victory Boulevard on Staten Island eight years ago, dairies bid for his business. They offered him freezers, coolers and no-interest loans, he said, adding that he believes this is a common practice. He said he took the money Queens Farms offered, and until recently sold their milk.

title: JOANNA GLEASON: AT AGE 35, A CHARACTER ACTRESS EMERGES
description: FOR her cinematic debut, Joanna Gleason has a cameo role in what appears to be, by critical consensus, the movie of the moment: ''Hannah and Her Sisters.'' She is rehearsing for a Broadway-bound comedy, ''Social Security,'' which is scheduled for an April opening. Each has a celebrated director: the former, Woody Allen; the latter, Mike Nichols, who also staged Miss Gleason's second film, the coming adaptation of Nora Ephron's ''Heartburn,'' which stars Meryl Streep and Jack Nicholson and is to be released in July. Last season, the actress received a Clarence Derwent Award and received a Tony nomination for her supporting but significant role as the snobbish, insensitive neighbor in the revival of ''Joe Egg.''

title: Dr. Andrea Capalbo to Wed a Lawyer
description: Mrs. John L. Capalbo of Brooklyn and Constableville, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Andrea Jane Capalbo, to John P. Colangelo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Domenick P. Colangelo of Florham Park, N.J., and East Orleans, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: INSTANT WASTE: 1 PAPER, 2 BAGS
description: HAROLD D. BERGER, Long Island regional director of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, often tells a story about the time he went to a Long Island supermarket to buy a newspaper.

title: Anne Upson Has Wedding
description: Anne English Upson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Barnard Upson of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to John Winthrop Marcus, the son of Ruth Alland Marcus of New York and Morey Marcus of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, assisted by the bride's cousin, the Rev. Robert L. Ficks 3d, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Cable TV
description: Though this year's Academy Awards will not be known until March 24, the artistry and craftsmanship that captured a total of 11 of last year's will be displayed on cable for the first time this week, when ''Amadeus'' is shown at 7 on Saturday evening on WHT, followed by ''The Killing Fields'' at 8 on HBO and Showtime.

title: GOOD OL' FREELANCE
description: NONE BUT A BLOCKHEAD On Being a Writer. By Larry L. King. 322 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95. LARRY L. KING'S ''None but a Blockhead'' is an amiable memoir marinated in hard lessons learned and not a little alcohol. In the narrative of his long career as a freelance writer that makes up most of the book, virtually no account of Mr. King's experiences omits booze - or its effects: ''I told Gutwillig let's have a beer or three''; ''after choking down a couple of bloody Marys''; ''it is mid-afternoon and I am mostly sober - only slightly pumped by four or five screwdrivers at lunch.'' The references are compulsive, and for 150 pages one wonders what Mr. King's attitude is toward his own thirst; then, abruptly, mid-paragraph, he finally mentions alcoholism and acknowledges the broader implications of his drinking. Toward the end there is a notebook entry from 1983, a brief ''sermon'' to readers, on the occasion of his newly won sobriety.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Feb. 23, 1986 Fiction

title: PARKING FEE RISING AT NEWARK AIRPORT
description: PARKING rates at Newark International Airport will go up next month as part of a comprehensive plan to reduce vehicle congestion.

title: THE CRATIVE MIND OF WOODY ALLEN
description: Not coincidentally, every film Caryn James cites for its visual virtuosity (''Manhattan,'' ''Zelig,'' ''Purple Rose of Cairo'') had, behind the camera, a master cinematographer, Gordon Willis, renowned within the industry as a perfectionist who demands total control over every image that appears on screen. Recognizing the collaborative nature of film making, Woody Allen would probably be the first to acknowledge the debt he owes to Gordon Willis, as Mr. Willis would to his production and costume designers and his lighting and camera crew (usually the same people from film to film). Mr. Allen should be congratulated for his achievements, which are extraordinary, but not at the cost of overlooking the contributions of an already obscure group of uniquely talented professionals. DOUG LOCK New York City

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: TYLENOL: DESPITE SHARP DISPUTES, MANAGERS COPED
description: Almost from the moment on Feb. 10 when the news broke that a Westchester County woman had died after taking a cyanide-laced Tylenol capsule, Johnson & Johnson found itself racing to stay in control of a rapidly changing situation.

title: ROBUST TUNES OF THE STATE'S PAST
description: IN the 1790's, the Connecticut River Valley fostered a seminal school of singing and instrumental composition known as the Connecticut Valley Tunebook movement.

title: MUSICIANS SEEK IMAGE -- WILL TRADE
description: WHAT's in a name? Suzanne Smithline and Glenn Manion believe a great deal - at least in contemporary pop music circles.

title: Fight to Wipe Out Rubella in U.S.
description: RUBELLA, highly dangerous for pregnant women and their babies, was reported on the ropes in the United States.

title: 1,000 YEARS OF JEWISH HISTORY AT YESHIVA EXHIBIT
description: INSIDE what looks like the walls of a medieval German town, a new exhibition depicts 1,000 years of European Jewish history, culture and survival. On display through June at the Yeshiva University Museum in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan are some 900 items - ranging from illuminated Bibles to military medals to cooking utensils to shrouds.

title: What the Suicide Of a Farmer Means
description: To the Editor:

title: HAWKS TO NETS BY 122-83
description: The emotional impact of Friday night simply vanished. The Nets, who spoke with tempered confidence after a resounding upset of the Los Angeles Lakers, faded quickly and quietly tonight against the Atlanta Hawks. They sensed it was a game of importance, but their effort was a washout: a 112-83 loss at the Omni.

title:
GARDENING;
PROPER PRUNING HAS MANY BENEFITS
description: TREES that have been pruned and trained properly will be more attractive, more wind resistant and longer lived than those that have been neglected or improperly treated. It is not all that difficult to do these things properly. It is more a matter of timeliness and persistence.

title: GOODBYE TO GREEN LINES
description: COMMONPLACE BOOK By E. M. Forster. Edited by Philip Gardner. 372 pp. California: Stanford University Press. $35. IN 1924 E. M. Forster found in the house in Surrey that he had inherited from an aunt, and where he was himself to live for over 20 years, a very large leather-bound notebook. This turned out to be a present from John Jebb, Bishop of Limerick - who had bought it in 1804 - to his chaplain, Forster's grandfather. John Jebb intended to use it as a commonplace book but had only made entries (mostly in Latin and Greek) filling 18 of its 400 pages.

title: TROYANOVSKY GOES TO PEKING
description: Oleg A. Troyanovsky, whose departure as the chief Soviet delegate to the United Nations was announced recently, is to become Ambassador to Peking, Soviet sources said this week. Diplomats said Mr. Troyanovsky's move to Peking reflected the stepping up of Soviet efforts to improve relations with China. He will replace Ilya S. Shcherbakov, 73, who has been Ambassador to China since 1978.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
STRIKE UP THE MUSICAL GOBLETS
description: The illustrations in AMERICAN MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS: In the Metropolitan Museum of Art (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Norton, $39.95) are delectable, but Laurence Libin's book really makes the reader long for an accompanying cassette or record. The lyre-mandolin looks like, well, like a lyre and a mandolin combined, but who could not want to know what it sounds like? Not to mention the sound of a jawbone, a panpipe, a cornstalk fiddle or a two-tongue ratchet. Mr. Libin, curator of musical instruments at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is clearly a scholar of his subject, but he doesn't assume that everyone else is.

title: 2 MILD QUAKES HIT PAKISTAN
description: Two mild earthquakes were recorded today in northwestern Pakistan, and officials said there were no deaths or property damage. The tremors, centered 112 miles northwest of Islamabad, were recorded at 3.8 and 3.9 on the Richter scale, officials said.

title: SKIING AND APRES ITALIAN STYLE IN CORTINA
description: You don't have to be a skier to come to Cortina d'Ampezzo. This Italian ski resort in the Dolomites, some two hours from Venice, does have 100 miles of downhill ski runs and half that in cross-country trails, as well as ski-jumping and bobsledding; indeed Cortina is a candidate for the 1992 Winter Olympics. This is also a place, however, where apres-ski life is in full swing by 11 o'clock in the morning. It is even possible to feel a passing pang for the bruised and blue skiers trudging back from the slopes while you sit, sipping your vin brule, or hot spicy wine, and digging your teeth into one of the doughnuts called Krapfen, as you watch the world go by.

title: REHABILITATION PROGRAM TURNS TO THE PRIVATE SECTOR
description: JUST as President Reagan was suggesting that private interests should take over some functions of government, one of Yonkers's most successful city programs spun off on its own as a private agency with private support.

title: TRAIN VOYAGE IN AUSTRALIA'S VAST INTERIOR
description: Every Thursday, Saturday and Sunday afternoon, the last platform of Sydney's huge, vaulted 19th-century railroad station is the scene of farewells equally worthy of the 19th century. Clusters of people, often families of several generations, chat as the 3:15 departure time of the Indian Pacific approaches; finally, family and friends embrace and passengers board. As the train pulls out, those on the platform wave and linger; there are handkerchiefs, smiles and, occasionally, tears. It is a good, old-time departure for a train ride and a tradition that, despite its renowned status, dates only from the early 1970's.

title: AT MINISTRY, A CALMNESS, AND DEFIANCE
description: Col. Tirgo Gador, assigned to an army unit in the northern province of Cagayan, said he first heard of plans to arrest the Defense Minister several days ago. It was, the colonel decided, a threat not only to the Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, but also to the movement of military officers seeking to change the armed forces.

title: CASHING IN ON 'THE REAL ESTATE SCENARIO' IN JERSEY
description: Somewhere in the suburbs, there may be someone who is not an expert on real estate, but if so, Sol Abrams has never met this particular human being.

title: ROCKEFELLER GIFT TO PRINCETON
description: Laurance S. Rockefeller has pledged $10 million to Princeton University's molecular biology laboratory, which would be the third-largest donation in Princeton's history, the school said today.

title: AN INSPIRED ROMP THROUGH THE LANDSCAPE OF 'LOOT'
description: At first, Joe Orton labeled ''Loot'' a farce. Seeing the play again in John Tillinger's mirthful new production at the Manhattan Theater Club, one fully accepts the author's initial evaluation -as well as such alternate designations as a satire and a comedy of bad manners. If farce, as defined in the Oxford Companion to Theater, is ''an extreme form of comedy in which laughter is raised at the expense of probability, particularly by horseplay and bodily assault,'' then ''Loot'' is a priceless contemporary example of the genre. Horseplay rides high, and bodily assault refers not only to the body English of the actors but also to the attack on the audience's collective funnybone.

title: FORDHAM WOULD SELL PARCEL TO A DEVELOPER
description: Fordham University has asked the city for permission to sell an undeveloped parcel in Manhattan for housing and a possible new location for the Jewish Museum.

title: SCHOOL BOARDS TURN TO SELF-INSURANCE
description: WHEN the New Jersey School Boards Association decided to offer workmen's compensation and liability insurance to local districts, its major goal was to guarantee that the districts, facing rising premiums and often hard-pressed to find coverage, would have an alternative to commercial insurance.

title: AQUINO CALLS FOR 'MORAL SUPPORT'
description: The opposition leader Corazon C. Aquino called on Filipinos today to lend ''moral support'' to the military officials who broke with President Ferdinand E. Marcos, but she said she was ''not calling for rebellion.''

title: One Issue That Seems To Defy a Yes or No
description: The political fight over abortion, which once provoked hopes and fears of a constitutional amendment and a Government more concerned with and involved in the morality of its citizens, has settled into trench warfare. The troops still assemble regularly. Last month, 36,000 foes of abortion marched on the Supreme Court to protest the anniversary of its decision in Roe v. Wade and next month, the decision's supporters hope to gather as many or more of their partisans at the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Brian R. Baine to Wed Lynn Alison Polakoff
description: Lynn Alison Polakoff, an assistant vice president in the taxable fixed income department at the First Boston Corporation in New York, and Brian Richard Baine, an associate in sales and trading at Salomon Brothers in New York, plan to be married next month.

title: A SENSE OF HISTORY
description: FEW DAYS BEFORE I moved my family to Baltimore, my 2-year-old daughter, Kerry, plucked blossoms from the mock orange bush in my parents' yard in Fort Lee, N.J. After reassuring me that the bush would survive yet another generation of childhood assaults, my mother picked up Kerry and told her, ''Your great-grandmother planted that bush.''

title: SCHOOL COUNSELORS JOIN IN JOBS EFFORT
description: IN an effort to improve counseling for teen-agers entering the job market after high school or college, nine school districts in Westchester, together with county businesses, will participate in a new program for school guidance counsellors.

title: WEST VIRGINIA OFFIAL FACES ELECION LAW CHARGES
description: Charlie Brown, West Virginia's Attorney General, who is accused of ''shaking down'' his staff for money to pay off a campaign debt, pleaded not guilty Friday to eight counts of violating state election laws.

title: STUDENTS HOLD RALLY FOR STRIKERS AT HORMEL
description: As the last National Guardsmen pulled out of this strike-torn city Friday, about 200 students left their classrooms to march in support of striking meatpackers at the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant here.

title: OIL COMPANY TOWN, FACING EVICTION, DIGS IN FOR LEGAL BATTLE
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company created the town of Phillips six decades ago to refine oil pumped from the Texas Panhandle. The company built houses for its workers, a park and the swimming pool at the school, fixed the streets and gave college scholarships to students.

title: REFINERS BREATHE A SIGH OF RELIEF
description: THE benefits of plunging oil prices are rippling through the business world. Energy-sensitive industries from airlines to utilities are cheering the almost-daily declines. Wall Street is celebrating with higher stock prices and lower interest rates. Washington economists are eagerly revising their growth estimates upward and their budget deficit projections downward.

title: ANCIENT SCULPTURES TELL OF INDIA'S LIFE AND LEGENDS
description: Happily for us, there seems to be simply no end to the Festival of India that was inaugurated by Prime Minister Gandhi in June 1985 and is scheduled to keep going until well after Labor Day of this year. By that time, and short of living the life of a lighthouse keeper in Alaska or a nomad in the Nevada desert, virtually every interested person in this country will have been exposed to an Indian temptation. And in that context, very few people say ''No.''

title: FROM A NIGERIAN PEN, YORUBA TALES
description: Witch herbalists and strange round shadows, river ghosts and water spirit women swarm in the universe of Amos Tutuola. In one place he finds the crazy removable-headed wild man. In another, the abnormal squatting man of the jungle.

title: THEY WERE WHAT THEY BUILT
description: ARCHITECTURE, MEN, WOMEN AND MONEY In America, 1600-1860. By Roger G. Kennedy. Illustrated. 526 pp. New York: Random House. $35. BEHIND the creation of great houses there are always strong personalities - clients and architects whose self-images and notions of art and sensibility either flourish and thrive or struggle for survival within the cultural, artistic, economic and political contexts of the time. Whether it is in Renaissance Italy, Enlightenment Britain or colonial America, the same very human drama unfolds as a patron decides to build himself a house. Is there enough money? How does its source determine the house's role in the owner's psychology? How and from where do the owner and architect obtain their ideas? Later we wonder, with what sorts of moods and motives was the house conceived and built? Who were the protagonists and antagonists? How does this human drama relate to the larger events and movements of the time or to the past and future? And what can it tell us about the development of values of a particular country - in the case of this book, America?

title: DEEP OCEAN OF MELTED COMETS COVERS URANUS, DATA SUGGEST
description: Analysis of observations made as Voyager 2 sailed past Uranus last month provides strong evidence that the planet is covered by an ocean of superheated water 5,000 miles deep that encloses a rocky but largely molten core roughly the size of Earth.

title: SKIP TRIAL WINS BUY NOSE IN FLORIDA
description: Skip Trial and Proud Truth dueled heads apart for the length of the Gulfstream Park stretch today before Skip Trial held on by a nose to win the $300,000 Gulfstream Park Handicap.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: AQUINO ASSASSINATION IN 1983 CREATED CONDITIONS FOR CRISIS
description: The Philippines have been in turmoil since the day the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. returned to Manila in 1983. Here are key developments since then. Aug. 21, 1983 - Mr. Aquino, who has been in self-imposed exile in the United States for three years, returns to Manila and is shot dead upon arrival at Manila International Airport. Rolando C. Galman, who the Government says is the assassin, is shot dead by guards on the tarmac. Opposition leaders immediately blame the Government for the killing of Mr. Aquino, 50 years old, who was regarded as the strongest rival to President Ferdinand E. Marcos. The first person arrested when the Marcos Government declared martial law in 1972, Mr. Aquino spent eight years in jail before his exile. United States officials also condemn the slaying. In Newton, Mass., Corazon C. Aquino says she is ''fatalistic'' about her husband's death. She and her five children prepare to return to Manila for the funeral. Aug. 31, 1983 - More than a million Filipinos join a 10-hour procession in Manila at the funeral for Mr. Aquino, the largest ever held in Philippines. Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, calls in his eulogy for liberation ''from tyrany and oppression,'' and other prominent groups and individuals call on Mr. Marcos to resign.

title: OCEAN DUMPING DEADLINES COME AND GO
description: WHERE ocean pollution is concerned, good intentions have never been lacking. In the 1970's, official intentions called for:

title: CLERK HELD AS EMBEZZLER
description: Kenneth Eugene Taylor, 21 years old, who was being sought on forgery charges in Florida, was hired as a clerk at First Fidelity Bank here and embezzled thousands of dollars before he was arrested Friday, Michael McDonnell, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.

title: NASA LISTS FUTURE PROJECTS
description: Saying the ''NASA can-do spirit is intact,'' the new shuttle program chief today named a deputy and promised that the problems that caused the Challenger explosion Jan. 28 would be fixed and shuttles would fly again.

title: The View Is Commanding, but the Foundations Are Shaky
description: Whatever their strategic value, this huge American outpost and its companion, Clark Air Base, were the focus of political attention on both sides of the Pacific last week. Questions about their future hovered relentlessly over the debate in Washington about what to do now that Congress and the Reagan Administration seem to agree that President Ferdinand E. Marcos had rigged his re-election.

title: IN PARIS, A VANISHED VALISE IT IS FORMIDABLE, BY EXAMPLE!
description: THE thing that airline travelers dread happened to me: The last pieces of luggage had been snatched off the revolving belt at Orly Airport near Paris - and mine was not among them.

title: OPERA: JUILLIARD PRESENTS GOUNOD'S 'MIREILLE'
description: WE are hearing more from Gounod in this newly Romantic age. Productions of ''Romeo et Juliette'' are popular in our most important opera houses and even ''Faust,'' not long ago an embarrassment of sentimentality, is enjoying well-deserved rehabilitation.

title: Drug Worries In Wilmington
description: FEDERAL agents say it was only an isolated incident, but a Du Pont chemist's plea of guilty to manufacturing $1 million worth of synthetic heroin has other chemical companies checking what is going on in their laboratories.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN PLATINUM
description: PLATINUM has traditionally evoked a glamorous image: The rare metal was introduced to Europe from South America in the 18th century and its silvery luster became much in demand for fine jewelry and art objects.

title: Required Reading; Truman-Nixon Chill
description: The Gridiron Club, an organization of newspaper reporters and editors, embarks on its second 100 years at its annual dinner next month. Following is an excerpt from ''The First 100 Years! A Casual Chronicle of the Gridiron Club,'' a book edited by James Free, concerning Harry S. Truman and Richard M. Nixon and two invitations to Gridiron events:

title: DUNNE SEEKS COURT SHAKE-UP
description: IN his 20 years as a State Senator, John R. Dunne's interests have been diverse.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SIRENS AND SPIES By Janet Taylor Lisle. 169 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $11.95. (Ages 10 and up) IN Janet Taylor Lisle's second book, ''Sirens and Spies,'' two sisters, Elsie Potter, 14 years old, and Mary, who is 15, and a music-loving derelict are the audience that focuses attention on the dramatic Miss Fitch. She is the local violin teacher in their southern Connecticut town and a figure of some flair and mystery.

title: Schuylkill Expressway Work Entering Time of Worst Jams
description: The worst is yet to come for motorists trying to get in and out of the city on the Schuylkill Expressway. At the end of the month, the state Transportation Department will begin the most ambitious phase of the year-old $175 million project to rebuild Pennsylvania's busiest highway.

title: MUSIC: PATTI LABELLE'S SHOW
description: PATTI LABELLE has returned to Broadway with a one-woman show that, compared with the hysterical excesses of the past, is a model of discipline and restraint. The 41-year-old Philadelphia pop-soul singer, who stands on the brink of major stardom after nearly 25 years on the stage, has been known to spend a good portion of her shows lying flat on her back and wailing to the rafters. Though her new show at the Minskoff Theater is by no means a chilly affair, such antics are kept to a minimum.

title: CRIME
description: Carefully assembled and well written, Thomas Boyle's ONLY THE DEAD KNOW BROOKLYN (Godine, $15.95) is a gripping procedural. A psychotic killer is on the loose. To add to the problems of the police, a professor is abducted by an extremist group that announces he will be tried by a ''people's tribunal'' and found guilty unless his university announces a restructuring of its curriculum and its policy toward the underprivileged.

title: A SONG IN THE HEART CAN LEAD TO FAME
description: TED STRANGE, a 26-year-old commercial photographer from Middlefield, kept his eyes focused on a pile of tape cassettes on a table at a restaurant in Newington. As the evening wore on and the pile got smaller, he straightened in his chair.

title: HOUSING NEEDS: ZONING IS JUST ONE FACTOR
description: I am in agreement with Janet Hansen [ ''Zoning, Homes and Human Need,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 12 ] that there is critical need for affordable housing on Long Island. I must disagree, however, with her contention that local zoning is the overwhelming factor affecting ''the amount and kind of housing produced in a community.''

title: RUTGERS HONORING FIRST BLACK ALUMNUS
description: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY'S first black graduate is being honored with an exhibit and minority scholarships program, both commemorating Black History Month.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SEATS IN ALL PARTS: Half a Lifetime at the Movies. By Leslie Halliwell. (Scribners, $15.95.) Leslie Halliwell, best known for the authoritative film guide and filmgoer's companion that bear his name, recalls his early enchantment with movies in this portrait of the critic as a young, Depression-era fan in Lancashire, England.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Old Salem Farm, North Salem, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (914) 669-5610.

title: TEEN-AGE SUICIDE: EPIDEMIC, NOT TRENDY
description: In his Dec. 1 Opinion article, Miller Newton said that teen-age suicide had become a ''trendy item for mental-health types looking for a new key to prominence in their profession.''

title: ELECTRONIC WATCHDOGS FOR THE ACCUSED
description: The cause of justice, alleviation of the overcrowded condition at the Nassau County jail, and the saving of close to one million tax dollars a year may be achieved by the utilization of electronic monitoring of those awaiting trial, without compromising the judicial system or addressing the merit of confinement behind bars of those convicted of crimes.

title:
GARDENING;
PROPER PRUNING HAS MANY BENEFITS
description: TREES that have been pruned and trained properly will be more attractive, more wind resistant and longer lived than those that have been neglected or improperly treated. It is not all that difficult to do these things properly. It is more a matter of timeliness and persistence.

title: TEWELL UP BY ONE AFTER A 66
description: Doug Tewell birdied his first six holes today and went on to card a five-under-par 66 to take the lead after three rounds of the Los Angeles Open.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE. By Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Within the limits of the interesting device she has chosen for her third novel, Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey, whose first novel was the best-selling ''Woman of Independent Means,'' manages a vivid description of a stormy marriage.

title: WESTMINSTER CHOIR IN BRAHMS CONCERT
description: THE Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig will end its four-part Brahms series Friday night with a performance of ''A German Requiem'' with the 150-member Westminster Choir of Princeton's Westminster Choir College.

title: A Sour Mood In the Mideast
description: The prospects for Middle East peace seemed even more remote last week. On the diplomatic front, the process for a negotiated settlement broke down when King Hussein of Jordan declared that he no longer wanted to deal with Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader. In the field, violence erupted as the ambush and capture of two Israeli soldiers provoked an intense Israeli sweep-and-search operation in southern Lebanon.

title: U.S. EMBASSY IN CANADA: LOOKING FOR A HOME
description: The Canadian Government calls Mile Circle a vacant meadow. The neighbors protest that it is suburban parkland. And a brouhaha has broken out because the United States Embassy in Canada may call it home.

title: Marcos Loses Support, and The U.S. Loses Some Options
description: EVEN as the Reagan Administration was cautioning against any precipitous action in the wake of fraudulent Philippine elections, events erupted in Manila yesterday that were beyond Washington's ability to control.

title: A Yankee Anthology
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Noble Sufferers
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a White House statement today on developments in the Philippines:

title: NAVY MOVING TO CATCH UP WITH 4,680 DESERTERS
description: Sailors who have jumped ship should be wary of every knock on the door because the caller could be a military police officer with a one-way ticket to a court-martial.

title: PISTONS WIN SEVENTH STRAIGHT, 113-106
description: Vinnie Johnson came off the bench to score 22 points, including 10 in the final quarter, and Isiah Thomas added 21 tonight to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 113-106 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S WAR ON CRIME
description: As long as there are millions of Americans eager to spend their money on gambling, prostitutes and contraband, there will always be an abundance of opportunists ready to kill one another for the right to supply the goods and services.

title: DRUGS NOT PROMINIENT AT FERRARO SON'S SCHOOL
description: Students and officials at Middlebury College, where John A. Zaccaro Jr. was arrested Thursday on charges of possession of cocaine with intent to sell, say that drugs are present on the campus but not prominent.

title: WARNING ON TRIPS TO MANILA
description: The State Department issued a travel advisory today that urged Americans to postpone nonessential travel to the Philippines ''due to unsettled conditions in Manila.''

title: ROCKET EXPERT BACKS ALTERNATE THEORY
description: A retired executive of Morton Thiokol Inc., the company that builds the booster rockets for the space shuttle, said today he believed that a hydrogen leak from the huge external fuel tank, not a booster failure, was the most likely cause of the Challenger explosion that killed seven astronauts Jan. 28.

title: DANNY PARKER HAD TO DIE
description: DEAD GROUND By Philip Kerrigan. 217 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95. HAVING been an avid consumer - and occasional producer - of thrillers for decades, I recently became convinced, to my great sorrow, that I had wearied of the entire genre. I believed it impossible to find a new work that was both fresh and stirring.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE JAMAICAN
description: THE Reggae music is pulsing through the restaurant, its hypnotic beat insinuating its way into conversations, the melody threading through the soft clatter of dishes and silverware. Outside, the night air is crystalline cold; here at The Jamaican, the lights cast a yellowish glow and the air is redolent of curry and cinnamon-like annotto.

title: GENERAL VOICES ANGER AT ABUSE OF MILITARY AND ELECTION FRAUD
description: In a country where the armed forces have been shaken by widespread allegations of corruption, favoritism and abuses of human rights, Lieut. Gen. Fidel V. Ramos has long seemed a model of old-fashioned rectitude.

title: Never a Captain
description: To the Editor:

title: France Keeps Its Guard Up in Central Africa
description: IN Africa, it has been said, France can make history with 500 men, meaning that Paris can be a stabilizing force in its former colonies without great effort.

title:
ART;
BLACK HERITAGE CELEBRATED IN SHOW
description: IN celebration of Black History Month, the East End Arts and Humanities Council in Riverhead is host to an exhibition of work by members of the Long Island Black Artists Association, a group that holds monthly meetings in Hempstead.

title: Headliners; Vote of Confidence
description: It has been a winter of discontent at Dartmouth College.

title: MIAMI GRAND PRIX THRIVES ON CHANGE
description: The first Miami Grand Prix for sports cars, held three years ago, promised to bring excitement to the streets of that city. Instead the race turned out to be a water-logged disaster, flagged to a halt after less than a quarter of its planned three-hour duration.

title: GANDHI'S POLITICAL TALENTS ARE TESTED
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, who has enjoyed nearly universal praise for his political skills, has run into an unusual storm of criticism over several recent steps and missteps.

title: THE CLOWNS COME TO THE REVOLUTION
description: THE LIGHTNING OF AUGUST By Jorge Ibarguengoitia. Translated by Irene del Corral. 117 pp. New York: Bard/ Avon Books. Paper, $3.95. When it was originally published in 1965 in Mexico, the late Jorge Ibarguengoitia's ''Lightning of August'' caused a considerable literary stir. Until then, the literature dealing with the Mexican revolution had been somber and solemn - its dominant tone set by the monumental saga of the conflict and the gigantic suffering of the community. History, these works implied, was a serious affair. And then suddenly, for the first time, a novel appeared proclaiming that this shattering, traumatic event was, with all due respect, a laughing matter. It had taken the Mexican revolution 55 years to produce its first satire.

title: FLYERS TOP CAPITALS TO INCREASE LEAD
description: The Philadelphia Flyers scored the first three goals today and defeated the Washington Capitals, 3-1.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF MARCOS STATEMENT ON SITUATION
description: MANILA, Feb. 22 (UPI) - Following is a transcript of a nationally televised statement by President Ferdinand E. Marcos today, as recorded by United Press International:

title: 'SEVEN GOTHIC TALES': THE DIVINE SWANK OF ISAK DINESEN
description: WHEN the Book-of-the-Month Club offered ''Seven Gothic Tales,'' by Isak Dinesen, as its selection for April of 1934, its newsletter said simply, ''No clue is available as to the pseudonymic author.'' But even then, with some detective work by the newspapermen of Denmark, this utterly obscure author was emerging into the spotlight as one of the most picturesque and flamboyant literary personalities of the century, a woman who had ''style'' as well as a remarkably grave and luminous prose style, and whose works as they followed her veiled debut seemed successive enlargements of her dramatic persona. She relished what she called ''the sweetness of fame'' and the company of the great and glamorous; she received in her native Denmark and while traveling elsewhere the attention due a celebrity. In her frail last years, on her one trip to the United States, she went out of her way to meet Marilyn Monroe, and recently has herself become a movie heroine, as played by Meryl Streep in the stately adaptation of ''Out of Africa.'' Since her death in 1962 - the cause of death was given as ''emaciation'' - the many-named woman known to the world as Isak Dinesen has been the subject of a number of biographies, including a truly excellent one by Judith Thurman, from which I have drawn most of the following clues.

title: GIRL, 15, IN BASKETBALL SPOTLIGHT
description: SOMETIMES, the snow would be coming down so hard that young Tracy Lis could hardly see the basketball hoop in the driveway of her home in Killingly. But as her father, Wayne, recalled, she would go right on shooting.

title: CREATING NEW SCENTS
description: AT THE START OF THIS DECADE, three perfumers took a look at the American woman and decided who she was and what new scent would best suit her. None of the visions were the same. Calvin Klein's cosmetics group saw a sexy, bewitching woman, one who leaves a trail of men behind her. Chanel saw a sophisticated yet sensual woman, with a sense of humor about herself. Estee Lauder, in turn, saw a romantic, feminine woman, who wanted to return to a more old-fashioned time.

title: PROBLEMS ARE LINKED TO 'MISMANAGEMENT'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RIDGEFIELD STAR COMES TO STAMFORD
description: WHEN we learned that Le Coq Hardi, the stylish French restaurant in Ridgefield, was opening a branch in the Stamford Plaza Hotel, we wondered if this would be yet another example of a business stretching too far and too thin.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN OFFERS MOSCOW A PLAN TO CUT MISSILES
description: President Reagan has sent a proposal to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, seeking the elimination of American and Soviet medium-range missiles in Europe and Asia over the next three years, Administration officials said today.

title: Anne G. Binford Weds Scott Allen
description: Anne Grace Binford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben W. Binford Jr. of Old Tappan, N.J., was married yesterday to Scott Ethan Allen, the son of Mrs. Howard J. Corbin of Centre Island, L.I., New York and Mouans-Sartoux, France, and the late Frank Allen. The Rev. Dr. Barrie T. Smith performed the ceremony at the Hillsdale (N.J.) United Methodist Church.

title: THE TWO SIDES OF PARIS COUTURE
description: NO ONE IS ANY LONGER surprised when a new Yves Saint Laurent couture collection provokes comment. After all, this is the designer who over the years has been so inventive and so forceful in demonstrating his ideas. More than once, he has been at cross purposes with the popular mode and has ended up redirecting it.

title: HIGH CONCENTRATION OF DIOXIN FOUND AT NIAGARA FALLS DUMP
description: The highest concentration of dioxin ever found in New York State has been discovered at a dump site here, authorities said this week.

title: Panist From Marrakesh Plays in Carnegie Hall
description: James H. McKissic The scenario behind James H. McKissic's New York debut might, at first glance, better belong on a theater page than in a music column. There is a dreamy, fictive quality to the story even though it is apparently true. This is what happened:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SENSE OF SIGHT: Writings by John Berger. Edited by Lloyd Spencer. (Pantheon, Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $8.95.) As an art critic, John Berger is notorious for his more or less Marxist treatment of Picasso, published in 1965, and for such equally controversial essays as ''The Moment of Cubism,'' reprinted here from an earlier collection. Mr. Berger is better known in England, principally because, after 10 years of writing art criticism for The New Statesman, he sought to compound his disapproval of capitalism by living and working in a small French peasant community.

title: KEY TOP COURT DECISIONS SHOW VIEWS ARE MIXED
description: The Supreme Court has decided four cases since 1978 on the legality of various preferences for racial minorities designed to redress past discrimination, with mixed and ambiguous results.

title: THE SPIRIT OF LIBERTY ABIDES IN FOLK ART
description: Long before the Statue of Liberty rose in New York Harbor a century ago, female symbols of America were among the most popular themes chosen by folk artists to translate into stitched, carved, cast, painted and engraved works. American artisans have never stopped producing compelling images of Liberty, Columbia and the Indian Queen in weathervanes, scrimshaw, figureheads, trade signs, coverlets, stoves, cookie molds and even a gate post, as can be seen in ''Liberties With Liberty,'' an exhibition opening Tuesday at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street.

title: ISLANDERS SET BACK WINGS
description: When it was finally over, the losing coach in tonight's game between the Islanders and the Detroit Red Wings spoke gently of his club's struggle, while the winning coach, sterner of face and observation, chided his team. The Islanders made a clean three-game sweep of their season series against Detroit with tonight's 5-2 victory at Nassau Coliseum, but it was not an especially pleasing victory, as the Islanders continued their policy of unassertiveness throughout much of the evening.

title: IN THIS CASE, ARM OF THE LAW SEEMS TO SHORE
description: Faced with $1.1 billion in uncollected fines, New York City parking officials say it may be time to give scofflaws the boot.

title: NOT SHORTAGE OF ERRORS ALL AROUND
description: When to point the finger of scorn by naming names and when to allow the guilty to rest thankfully in anonymity is a delicate issue for the bridge reporter. It can be argued that the player who blunders should expect to be named, just as a baseball player who muddles an easy catch would be.

title: COLLEGE IS NOT JUST FOR THE YOUNG, ELDERLY PROVE
