description: FOR Helen Varaljay, a 71-year-old retired secretary, taking college courses at the Fairfield Senior Citizen Center has been a way of keeping up with her family. Since her daughter graduated from college, and her grandchildren are currently enrolled, ''it was time I got into the act, too,'' she said.

title: Linda Low Weds Frank E. Wolcott
description: Linda Herrick Low, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Hine Low of Easton, Md., and Boca Grande, Fla., was married yesterday to Frank Edward Wolcott, a son of Mrs. Charles Cowley of Old Lyme, Conn., and Boca Grande, and the late Mr. Wolcott. The Rev. H. Lawrence Whittemore Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Andrews's Episcopal Church in Boca Grande.

title: BOYS' LIFE MARKS 75 YEARS OF TEACHING SCOUTS
description: When Boys' Life was a baby in 1911, it had 6,100 subscribers and sold for a nickel a copy.

title: OPALS FROM THE OUTBACK
description: Perched in the display case of an elegant jewelery store in Sydney stands a figurine carved from opal, the brilliant green, blue and red colors of the gem sparkling under the artificial light.

title: INTIMATIONS OF MORTALITY: THE BIG SIX-O
description: I AM on my way home after a quick trip to the village art store for some supplies. As I drive along, anxious to get home to work on the paintings that will be in my new show, my attention is drawn to a leaf that blows against my windshield. For some reason I can't explain, I find myself slowing down and thinking about that leaf. It's just an ordinary brown leaf, but for the few moments it clings to my windshield, I become aware of some uncomfortable feelings stirring inside me. Feelings about getting older. Feelings that until now I've tried to ignore. Feelings I suspect are especially troubling to me now because this is the year I've turned 60.

title: THE DINING PULSE RATE
description: EACH YEAR, WE TRAVEL A good deal as judges for cooking contests sponsored around the nation by the March of Dimes. They are known as Gourmet Galas, and the contestants are some of the finest cooks in their communities. We consider this a worthy cause in itself, and the galas give us a fair notion of the sophistication of home cooking in the United States. In this way, we keep a finger on the pulse of how America dines. At a recent contest in Stamford, Conn., I was particularly impressed with the quality of the dishes that confronted us. The winning foods included an exceptional and original Mexican-style quiche, an uncommonly good dish of sauteed chicken breasts with chopped prosciutto, a delectable platter of beef tenderloin with wild mushroom sauce and, finally, clams casino, a fine old American favorite with an especially tasty and well-spiced topping. The quiche and clam dishes make excellent appetizers; the beef and chicken creations would serve as first-class main dishes at anyone's table. (Recipes are on the following page.) DAVE AND JANIS MURRAY'S MEXICAN QUICHE Pastry for a one-crust pie (see recipe) #14 shrimp, about 1/2 pound, shelled and deveined, #1 4-ounce can green chilies, preferably chopped, about 1/2 cup #1 cup grated cheese, preferably half Colby and half Monterey Jack 3/4 cup light cream #3 eggs, beaten Y cup chopped chives Salt to taste, if desired Y cup sour cream #2 tablespoons bottled taco sauce or tomato and Serrano chile sauce. 1.

title: A PLACE TO STAY DURING EXPO 86, PLACES TO DREAM ANYTIME
description: New Rooms In Vancouver Just in time for the opening May 2 of the Expo 86 World's Fair, Vancouver has a new hotel. The 23-story, 505-room Pan Pacific Vancouver Hotel is operated by Tokyu Hotels International, a subsidiary of a Tokyo-based conglomerate.

title: Other Noble Sufferers
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.R.R. ELECTRIFICATION: NEW DELAYS, NEW PLANS
description: THE long-promised electrification of the Port Jefferson branch of the Long Island Rail Road has hit another serious delay that could set it back into the next decade, officials of the line say.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BLACK READING
description: At the White Plains Y.W.C.A., a current exhibition of black contributions to American history and culture features, among other items, outstanding books about black culture. The display is jointly sponsored by the Y.W.C.A. of White Plains and the Westchester Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha, a national sorority of black college graduates committed to community service.

title: Universe Under Glass
description: There's a glass case, an 8-foot cube, in the middle of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan that emits clunks, bongs and bleeps. A small crowd always seems drawn to the sound, then stays for the sight:

title: PAPER CHALLENGES CLOSED COURT FILE
description: A convicted killer who confessed another murder for which two men have already been sentenced has ignited an unusual legal battle between a newspaper and a suburban judge.

title: THEATER SERVING A DUAL PURPOSE
description: WITH the premiere of ''Roads of the Mountaintop,'' the Crossroads Theatre Company, which consistently does the most vital and visceral work in the state, is serving a dual purpose.

title: Michaela McCausland Is Wed in Jersey
description: Michaela M. McCausland and William F. Waddington were married yesterday in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J., by the Rev. Alfred M. Niese.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC OF CHINA Classical and folk music from various regions of China will be heard in an unusual concert at 8 P.M. Monday in Sprague Hall on the Yale University campus. Six young musicians Ensemble of the Beijing Central Conservatory of Music will perform on instruments with such exotic names as ruan, a four-stringed guitar; di, a membraned cross flute; erhu, a two-stringed vertical fiddle; sheng, a mouth organ with 17 bamboo pipes; pipa, a lute, and qin, a seven-stringed zither.

title: ABSTRACTIONISTS INN GALASSO SHOW ARE ''FORTUITOUS MISMATCH''
description: WILLIAM Fares is California born and trained; Robert Yucikas comes from Washington, D.C., and is an alumnus of Eastern New Mexico University in Portales. Abstract painters in their early 40's, both have long since become New Yorkers with several solo exhibitions to their credit, so it is not surprising that their careers have intersected in group shows.

title: HE CALLS ON THEM TO SUBMIT
description: The Minister of Defense and the deputy Chief of Staff of the armed forces quit the Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos Saturday night, took over the defense headquarters and called on the President to resign.

title: THE LEGACY OF A HIT-AND-RUN
description: MARIANO ACCARDI had counted on the justice system to make some sense of his son's death. But now, he says, that system has failed him.

title: FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL CRITICIZED FOR TESTIMONY ON FATAL JERSEY BLAZE
description: Testimony by the nation's top fire-safety official that sprinklers and smoke detectors would not have saved lives in a fire at the Great Adventure amusement park in New Jersey has touched off a dispute among officials.

title: 3 FACES OF BELLEROSE: CHARMS AND DISPUTES
description: ALTHOUGH Bellerose Village, Bellerose Terrace and Bellerose Manor share a common name, they have achieved a remarkable diversity in the 60 or so years since they were founded.

title: Overt Battles Over Two Plans For Covert Aid
description: The Reagan Administration acknowledged its intention to play a ''covert'' military role in Angola and got into a row in Congress as it tried to restart another such operation, against Nicaragua.

title: RESTORING ELLIS ISLAND: BITTER DISPUTE OVER THE FUTURE OF A NATIONAL SHRINE
description: The debate over the future of Ellis Island involves not only what could become one of the country's most resonant shrines, but also the purpose of historic preservation, the proper role of the National Park Service and the best way to pay for maintaining national monuments.

title: VILLANOVA STOPS SETON HALL BY 78-65
description: Harold Jensen scored 19 points as Villanova defeated Seton Hall, 78-65, tonight in a Big East Conference game.

title: LIFE LAY BEYOND THE BRONX
description: A WIDER WORLD Portraits in an Adolescence. By Kate Simon. 186 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Los Angeles Clippers, 7:30 P.M., at Madison Square Garden. The N.B.A. game will be preceded by a special benefit game for the Widows' and Children's Funds of the P.B.A. and U.F.A., featuring the Bravest (the Fire Department) and the Finest (the Police Department), beginning at 5 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) #76ers vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Philadelphia, noon. (Television - Channel 2, noon.) College: North Carolina at North Carolina State. Coach Dean Smith's top-ranked Tar Heels were 90-79 winners over the Wolfpack earlier in the season. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.) Georgetown at Syracuse (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 2 P.M.) Indiana at Purdue (Television - MSG, 4 P.M.) Boxing Marvis Frazier vs. James (Bonecrusher) Smith, 10 rounds, heavyweights, at Richmond, Calif. Frazier's only defeat in 16 professional fights was a first-round knockout by Larry Holmes. Otherwise, he has 7 knockouts in his 15 victories. Smith, 15-4 with 12 knockouts, also lost on a knockout to Holmes in the 12th round of his title challenge. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Tennis Lipton International Players Championships, at Boca West, Fla., men's final, Ivan Lendl vs Mats Wilander. (Television - Channel 7, 1:30 P.M.) Concord Junior Women's Invitational, at the Concord Hotel, Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., singles and doubles finals, 11 A.M. Track and Field Michelob Invitational Indoor, at San Diego. Billy Olson, Joe Dial and Sergei Bubka, the traveling pole-vaulters, are expected to go at it again in this Grand Prix meet.

title: 'WE ENJOY PUSHING RIVERS AROUND'
description: RIVERS OF EMPIRE Water, Aridity, and the Growth of the American West. By Donald Worster. 402 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95. ''SOLITARY, singing in the West,'' chanted Walt Whitman, ''I strike up for a New World.'' From Thomas Jefferson through Whitman and Thoreau, down to Frederick Jackson Turner's famous essay of 1893, ''The Significance of the Frontier in American History,'' and even to the present day, the West has occupied a mythic niche in the American imagination. Jefferson conjured traveling westward as a journey backward in time to ''the infancy of creation.'' He expected that the acquisition of the enormous Louisiana Territory would create an empire of liberty where the American experiment in republicanism could be perpetually refreshened. Thoreau felt jacketed by convention in the settled East, but ''westward,'' he concluded, ''I go free.'' Expanding on Jefferson, Turner argued that the repeated experience of pushing the frontier line westward shaped the culture of American democracy by reinforcing republican virtues, especially ''that dominant individualism . . . that buoyancy and exuberance which come with freedom.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
AN OLD BUT TRUE WAY TO KEEP WARM
description: WHEN winter winds blow and snowdrifts swirl high, it is easy enough for owners of 18th-century houses to keep warm. That is because homes that have been lovingly restored have also had furnaces added and have been insulated. Whatever the weather, the thermostat can be set at a comfortable 70 degrees.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GOVERNING THE HEARTH: Law and the Family in Nineteenth-Century America. By Michael Grossberg. (University of North Carolina Press, $32.) Add Michael Grossberg's analysis to a list of growing volumes on the history of the American family.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THE HERCULES STORY Whether he is called He-Man, Rambo or Superman, ''he'' is essentially an adaptation of the original Hercules, the personification of physical strength and the protector of mankind. ''Hercules in Ancient Art'' is the subject of a slide-talk to be given by Dr. Raymond V. Schoder, a Jesuit priest, at 4:30 P.M. Wednesday in the library lecture hall of the College of New Rochelle.

title: THE RISE OF A YOUNG CONDUCTOR
description: SAMUEL LIPMAN, PIAN-ist, music critic, publisher of The New Criterion and member of the National Council on the Arts, vividly recalls the summer of 1973. He was at Colorado's Aspen

title: ALTERNATIVE TO HOSPITAL IS SOUGHT FOR AIDS
description: ONE-FOURTH of New Jersey's hospitalized AIDS patients could be cared for in less costly settings and those outside hospitals might avoid or postpone repeated admissions if more health and social services were available to them, according to state health officials and others familiar with the disorder.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
LEIDYI'S COMB JELLYFISH
description: (Rainbow Jellyfish) Mnemiopsis leidyi Size: To four inches in length.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: VICTIMS. By Dorothy Uhnak. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Dorothy Uhnak has based her new novel on the case that has become both a paradigm and a cliche of modern soullessness: the 1964 murder of Kitty Genovese, whose indifferent Queens neighbors ignored her screams.

title: Water Tank Foils Retirement Plans
description: LEONARD J. ROSE, a 60-year-old merchant seaman from Maine, has been looking forward to retiring in Harwich, on his native Cape Cod. He bought some land in 1955 and regularly paid taxes on it.

title: Pro & Con: Revising Antitrust LawsHow Far Down the Road to Laissez-Faire Should We Go?; DOUGLAS A. RIGGS: CONSUMER GOODS
description: Mergers. Are they good or bad? Should the big ones be stopped? The nation's antitrust laws, embodied in the Clayton Act of 1914, were based on the premise that mergers could be bad and should be curbed. But Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has been arguing that global competition has turned market dynamics upside down, making the Clayton Act, which prohibits mergers that reduce competititon, and other antitrust laws, obsolete. Last week the Administration proposed fundamental changes in them.

title: INVESTORS, BANKERS: THE NEW BREED IN HORSE RACING
description: FOR many a year America had a love affair with the thoroughbred. During the early 1950's the exploits of Native Dancer, the ''Gray Ghost,'' captured the imagination of millions; a decade later the gallant gelding Kelso had fan clubs all over the country, and in 1973 sports aficionados young and old celebrated the awesome 31-length triumph of Secretariat, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, in New York's Belmont Stakes, the third jewel in racing's Triple Crown.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BURMA: The Longest War 1941-45. By Louis Allen. (St. Martin's, $29.95.) Western accounts of the Burma campaigns of World War II often cast the Japanese as a tireless, faceless human wave, almost desensitized to extremes of hunger and heat.

title: SHEARING CELEBRATING TWO CAREERS IN JAZZ
description: GEORGE SHEARING, the British-born pianist who is playing at the Cafe Carlyle, will celebrate the anniversaries of two careers this week. Tuesday will be the 50th anniversary of his first professional job as a pianist and tomorrow he will reach the first anniversary of his most recent career - as a disk jockey on radio station WNEW on Sunday nights.

title: PROBABLE LOSS OF FEDERAL AID SPURS LOCALITIES TO TURN TO RELUCTANT STATES
description: Cities and counties around the nation, fearing deep cuts in Federal spending for domestic programs, are beginning to put pressure on their states to help make up the loss.

title: Gold Standard Never Stopped Economic Instability
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO HEARS PLEAS FOR BUDGET ITEM
description: In Brooklyn, Roy Lynn wanted to know if Governor Cuomo could give Coney Island a stadium. In Syracuse, Erwin Shultz insisted his city needed an armory. And in New Rochelle, Joan Weber wanted the Governor to stop the construction of new exit ramps along the Saw Mill River Parkway.

title: I SNOOP ON MY CHILDREN -- AND HERE'S WHY
description: I'M a snoop. I look through my daughter's pocketbooks for any revealing notes from her friends. I periodically check my son's school books for unmentioned failing test grades and, yes, I have even resorted to reading diaries.

title: Miss Beresford to Wed
description: Lord and Lady Decies of Waterford, Ireland, have announced that their daughter Clare Antoinette Gabrielle de la Poer Beresford of New York and Jorge Javier Koechlin von Stein of Lima, Peru, are to be married March 8. The future bride is a fashion model with the Zoli Agency. Her fiance, a son of Dora Koechlin von Stein of Lima and the late Jose Edmondo Koechlin, is a racing car driver.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DOUBLEMAN. By C. J. Koch. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) The impulse to control takes on many disguises; those disguises and the ways they clash occupy the Australian C. J. Koch, author of ''The Year of Living Dangerously,'' in his latest novel.

title: PREMIERES A TRIBUTE TO HEROIC BLACKS
description: CALL IT the nonviolent confrontational form of playwrighting. Under any designation, two of the state's theatrical premieres - both timed to coincide with Black History Month -are intended to have far-reaching implications beyond specific time, race or locale. And both, apparently, deal with the One, ''Roads of the Mountaintop,'' now playing in New Brunswick, was written by an oft-produced playwright, Ron Milner. His credits include ''What the Wine Sellers Buy,'' which was presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival in 1974 after an off-off Broadway showing the previous year. (A review of ''Mountaintop'' accompanies this article.) ''Boulder in the Sun,'' by 33-year-old Wayne Slappy, is a work-in-process, having changed directors after a week of previews. It is now being ''redirected'' by Leonara Brazell-Rafua, who taught drama at the University of Nigeria.

title: ONLY THE RETIRED KNOW BROOKLYN
description: A LOVING PLACE By Mark Dintenfass. 287 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95. SEVENTY-FOUR-YEAR-OLD Murray Farber is a retiree whose primary occupation these days is to worry. He frets over his failing health, his sour marriage of 40 years, his withdrawn son and contrary grandson. He anguishes over his decision to leave Brooklyn - where he was considered the unofficial Mayor of Montgomery Street - for the sterility and boredom of a planned community in Florida. But one warm winter night at the Sunset Mall, Murray happens upon an old neighbor from Montgomery Street. This chance meeting draws his thoughts back through time to Brooklyn of the 1930's, back to a place that is not just a geographical location but a nearly mythological neighborhood, ''A Loving Place,'' as Mark Dintenfass's title suggests.

title: PALAU VOTERS APPROVE NEW ACCORD WITH U.S.
description: The residents of this Western Pacific island nation approved a new political and military relationship with the United States on Friday that calls for nearly $1 billion in American aid.

title: CUOMO AIDES TO DISCUSS INQUIRIES
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would send two top aides to New York City this week to discuss what the state can do to further assist in the current municipal corruption investigations.

title: SHE  [ LOVES ]  MAD AVE.
description: ADVENTURES OF AN ADVERTISING WOMAN By Jane Maas. 227 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $15.95. DAVID OGILVY was already a legend on Madison Avenue and the author of the newly published ''Confessions of an Advertising Man'' when Jane Maas took her first advertising job, as a junior copywriter at Ogilvy & Mather in the early 1960's. She had the opportunity to learn from a master, and some of those lessons are evident in this book - not least its title. Mr. Ogilvy has only a walk-on part in ''Adventures of an Advertising Woman'' but is easily its most fascinating character. Unfortunately, both Mr. Ogilvy's creative genius and his flair for language have eluded Mrs. Mass. Without them, the craft of advertising that Mr. Ogilvy exalted is made to seem a trivial business in her book.

title: A TAKEOVER BRAWL LURES A PRIVATE MAN INTO THE PUBLIC RING
description: ON an icy morning about two weeks ago, Joseph A. Frates sat back in an armchair at the Mayfair Regent Hotel in Manhattan and calmly began talking about the heated, bitter takeover battle he is trying to win.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE BIRDS ROBERT F. DARENBERG of Montauk, dockmaster of the Deep Sea Yacht Club on Star Island in Montauk, is not especially fond of sea gulls. It's nothing personal, he said, but sea gulls leave droppings all over the docks of which he has been in charge for the last 27 years.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC
description: THE works of two short-lived geniuses made up the New York Philharmonic's Friday night program at Avery Fisher Hall. Schubert composed his Symphony No. 6 in C at the age of 21, 10 years before his death. Giovanni Battista Pergolesi died only a few days after completing his Stabat Mater at the age of 26. Yet there is nothing immature about their utterance; both are masterpieces, however slight.

title: Beverly J. Bodnar To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Charles Bodnar of Easton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beverly Jean Bodnar, to Walter Gregory Rodiger 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodiger Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: LEONARD OPPOSES BAN
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, who retired as welterweight champion in 1982 after suffering an eye injury in the ring, has told Maryland legislators that, while there is room for improvement in boxing safety, the sport should not be banned. Leonard, a Maryland resident, made his remarks Friday in testimony before a House committee considering a bill to ban boxing and sparring matches in the state.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Tender Mercies Starring Robert Duvall, Tess Harper, Wilford Brimley, Betty Buckley, Ellen Barkin; directed by Bruce Beresford, 1983 (PG) Thorn EMI/HBO Video 93 minutes. $79.95 Like the current ''Trip to Bountiful,'' which also has a screenplay by Horton Foote, ''Tender Mercies'' is a superb showcase for its actors, especially for its star.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CORA SANDEL: Selected Short Stories. Translated by Barbara Wilson. (The Seal Press, Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95.) Born Sara Fabricius in 1880, the Norwegian Cora Sandel started as a painter, not publishing her first story until she was 41, her first novel until she was 45.

title: THINGS LOOK UP FOR CHIPS
description: After a year of bad news, the tide has begun to turn for some semiconductor stocks. The industry's widely watched book-to-bill ratio, which compares dollars of new orders to dollars of shipments, has risen in each month since August.

title: A 'TAILOR' OF PEOPLE'S MONEY
description: AT the age of 46, Merton (Mitch) Mitchell of Lido Beach is a vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers who favors suits made by Huntsman & Sons of Savile Row, shoes by John Lobb of London and cigars from Havana.

title: INDONESIA SINKS BOATS SHUTTLING VIETNAMESE
description: Indonesia has begun to sink boats whose crews are found to be transporting for profit refugees who are fleeing Vietnam, according to diplomats and refugee officials in the region.

title: A NIGHTINGALE SANG
description: Yes, we are getting older and, yes, the world has changed that much. Vulgarity, a decline in civility, preoccupation with self and appearance have become the hallmarks of modernity.

title: A PROPER TEA FLOURISHES IN VICTORIA
description: One of life's most underrated pleasures, ranking right up there with a hot bath and dry socks, is a proper cup of tea. Too often tea gets snubbed as insignificant, and pricy restaurants, which would not think of skimping on their quenelles of pike or duck a l'orange, shrug off a request for tea by delivering a cupful of warm water in which a cheap tea bag appears to have been drowned.

title: Tax Oil to Save Oil
description: As surely as rising oil prices taught Americans to conserve energy, lower prices will lead them to forget. That would be a national tragedy, and a foolish security risk. Prices are falling because we conserved. Now that the price is not incentive enough to save, add a tax.

title: CITY BALLET CHOREOGRAPHERS ARE HINTING AT DRAMA NOW
description: Neither of the New York City Ballet's two premieres in its winter season has been typical of the works we usually see in the company. Predictability, it turns out, is not predictable.

title: Qaddafi Opens a Second Front With the West
description: THE fighting in Chad seems to be flaring up at an awkward moment for the Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, who has been embroiled since January in a war of nerves with the United States. Washington, accusing Libya of a role in the December terrorist killings at the Rome and Vienna airports, has imposed economic sanctions and conducted naval maneuvers north of the Libyan coast.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
DIFFERING SIGNALS OVER THE DOLLAR
description: The dollar has fallen enough, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, told a Congressional panel, a comment that sent ripples through the markets and held broad implications for future monetary policy. It also indicated a split with Administration views, since a day earlier Treasury Secretary James A Baker 3d had said the dollar should fall still further. Although the two men sought to play down their disagreements, it was clear that they are at odds over how to control the economy. Mr. Baker believes the lower the dollar, the more help to the trade deficit and thus the budget deficit. Mr. Volcker believes a dollar that is too low will rekindle inflation. Lower interest rates, within the Fed's realm of control, would tend to force the dollar lower, and Mr. Volcker is not partial to that course.

title: FOR JOB SEEKERS, TRANSIT IS A KEY TO GET OFF WELFARE
description: SHEILA McPHAIL, a former welfare recipient and a single mother of two children, is doing so well as a part-time nurse's aide that Milford Hospital wants her to work full time.

title: FRAZIER URGES LOYALTY
description: Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion, has chided fighters who retire and do nothing for the sport.

title: JERSEY REGULATIONS LIMIT SMOKING IN ORKPLACE AND IN OTHER AREAS
description: Smokers in New Jersey will find a new world waiting for them when the work week begins Monday.

title: SAKHAROV LETTER TELLS OF '85 HUNGER STRIKES
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet human rights activist, wrote in smuggled letters made public today that he was hospitalized against his will and force-fed during two hunger strikes that eventually won his wife the right to travel to the West for medical treatment.

title: GYPPING THE PHARISAIC TRIBE
description: PEOPLE ARE BECOM-ing more sensitive to racial, religious or cultural slurs. Some take umbrage, others take offense, and a few take pen in hand to demand that whoever is in charge of the language take action to change meanings or put a stop to common usage. One example: tribe. Mangosuthu G. Buthelezi is chief minister of the KwaZulu homeland and chairman of the South African Black Alliance. He takes umbrage at anybody who calls the Zulus a ''tribe.'' In a letter to The Washington Post, Mr. Buthelezi writes: ''We Zulus regard it as a gross insult to be described . . . as 'a tribe.' The Zulu people were a sovereign nation with a king until July 4, 1879, when they were crushed in a defeat by the might of the British Army. . . . The fact that as a nation we were conquered does not make us 'a tribe.' '' He compares the seven million Zulus with the half million Swazis, whose Swaziland is a nation represented in the United Nations, and calls on commentators to stop insulting his people by describing them as a mere tribe.

title: DISINCENTIVES URGED FOR CAR COMMUTERS
description: Not only do some employers subsidize car commuters (New Jersey Journal, Feb. 23), but so does the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: DUKE BEATS OKLAHOMA, 93-84
description: What began as a smooth cruise turned into rough sailing for the Duke Blue Devils today. Leading by 23 points 12 minutes into its game with Oklahoma, Duke lost all but 1 point of its lead before pulling away for a 93-84 victory.

title: ST. JOHN'S VICTORY STREAK HALTED BY DEPAUL, 81-72
description: Highly ranked St. John's was pulverized here today by a DePaul team that seemed bent on proving itself to a doubting home crowd, and on using the Redmen as its proving ground.

title: THE MUSIC WORLD IS WATCHING HIM
description: When Herbert von Karajan was asked last year about a possible successor at the Berlin Philharmonic, he mentioned two conductors. One was Carlo Maria Giulini, who is familiar to audiences but who, at 71, is only a few years younger than Mr. Karajan himself. The other was Semyon Bychkov, the 33-year-old Russian-born music director of the Buffalo Philharmonic.

title: GORBACHEV'S PLANS: WESTERNERS SEE A LOT OF ZEAL, BUT LITTLE BASIC CHANGE
description: Since he took power 11 months ago, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has attacked economic problems with a zeal unmatched since Nikita S. Khrushchev disbanded entire layers of bureaucracy 25 years ago.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We are calling on the people of the world to help us.

title:
ANTIQUES;
GEMS OF THE ORIENT IN PLAINFIELD
description: DRAWING on objects from private sources, pieces on loan from the Newark Museum, displays by dealers in fine Orientalia and the extraordinary resources of its own collection of Oriental ceramics and cloisonne, the Friends of the Plainfield Library will present, starting next Sunday, a two-week exhibition and sale of Chinese and Japanese art and antiques.

title: REBELS ARE SHAPED INTO A TEAM
description: AT Georgetown, the jump shot that had made Anthony Jones a high school phenom went on sabbatical. And with it went Jones's confidence.

title: Tragic Attempt To Save a Farm
description: TWENTY minutes before his 700-acre farm in Waynesboro, Ga., was to be sold at auction for unpaid debts, 67-year-old L. D. Hill 3d killed himself to stop the sale.

title: A QUESTION OF WHO CONTROLS PRIMARIES
description: THE Supreme Court of the United States has agreed to hear a very interesting case from Connecticut. Interesting, at least, to election-law enthusiasts like me. Here is what has happened.

title: TENNIS HONORS CHUCK MCKINLEY
description: HE was always a battler. His father was a pipefitter and belonged to no country club, so young Chuck McKinley took a bus to the Y.M.C.A. in downtown St. Louis for his recreation. He swam and played table tennis and dreamed of being another Stan Musial or a football player.

title: Fiction, Reality, Dulleses
description: At 90 years of age, Eleanor Lansing Dulles, a Washington fixture who has written 14 books on economics and international affairs, is turning her hand to fiction.

title: CITY ENDS SUPPORT FOR QUOTAS IN SUIT
description: Mayor Koch has withdrawn the city's support of the use of racial quotas in a longstanding affirmative-action suit to be argued before the Supreme Court of the United States Tuesday.

title: TURNPIKE PROJECT HELD ILL-ADVISED
description: The Feb. 2 article about plans to widen the New Jersey Turnpike was indeed revealing. There will, of course, be public hearings and local officials will have some input, the article reported.

title: FINDING THE RANGE
description: Reggie Isaac, a 6-foot-2-inch guard at Bartram High School in Philadelphia, scored 84 points in a 99-69 victory over Bodine High School Thursday night. Inch for inch, that may have been the best performance ever by a Philadelphia high school player, but it put Isaac only in second on the city's schoolboy scoring list.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Condo Amenities for Mobile-Home Project
description: RISING among the horse ranches and potato farms of Calverton is an unusual, 150-house adult community that may well offer a glimpse of the future, even though it borrows heavily from an old idea.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Feb. 23, 1986 Fiction

title: THE EMERGING DANGERS OF DEREGULATION
description: A favorite saying in Congress is, ''When we economically deregulated the airlines, we did not deregulate safety.'' Technically, this is correct. But the dog-eat-dog competition unleashed by the economic deregulation of any industry forces many if not all companies to cheat and cut corners in ways that are dangerous to their customers, society at large and even themselves. This pattern, visible in any deregulated industry, is becoming increasingly obvious in the trucking and airline industries.

title: 'CASABLANCA'? THEY'LL PLAY IT FOREVER, SAM
description: In 1982 an unemployed writer submitted a screenplay titled ''Everybody Comes to Rick's'' to 217 Hollywood agents as a supposed sample of his work. Most didn't trouble themselves to acknowledge the submission. The 31 agents who did read it rejected it outright with comments to the writer such as ''try something that really grabs you.'' Somehow a script reached the hands of one leading producer who advised the writer that it was not right for films but to try making it into a novel.

title: Loosening the Grip on Corporations
description: THE proposal for change in the antitrust laws that President Reagan sent Congress last week came in five parts. Here are the bills the Administration would like to see passed.

title: NOT-SO-OBVIOUS MAJORCA
description: While packing for a recent, hastily organized vacation, I steeled myself against a sudden fantasy of my destination, the Mediterranean island of Majorca, as a once-succulent Spanish isle turned very rancid. Pervasive rumors had laced this vision, of iridescent oil-slicked water, of air choked with blue fumes, of endless waterfront shops peddling seaside inflatables that flap in the wind.

title: OSWALD AND OTHERS?
description: REASONABLE DOUBT An Investigation into the Assassination of John F. Kennedy. By Henry Hurt. Illustrated. 555 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $19.95. THIS is a compelling yet fundamentally calm analysis of the most important assassination in the United States since that of President Lincoln. More particularly, ''Reasonable Doubt'' examines the processes and findings of the official investigations conducted since Nov. 22, 1963, when John F. Kennedy was killed in Dallas.

title: THE EARLIER THE BETTER FOR GOURMET GREENS
description: Only adventurous oleriphiles need apply here.

title:
SUNDAY OBSERVER;
IT PAYS TO STAY IN THE U.S.A.
description: SINCE EVERYTHING is for sale these days, I wasn't surprised by Julian L. Simon's idea for selling foreigners the right to immigrate to the United States. He wants the Government to fill its immigration quota by selling to the high bidders.

title: FOR LOU PINIELLA, FINALLY THE CHALLENGE IS HIS ALONE
description: WHEN Lou Piniella did not appear at Yankee Stadium one night last season, word spread around the Yankee clubhouse that he had quit as the team's hitting coach. The Yankees had just returned from a disheartening five-game series in Cleveland, and Piniella was said to have been so distraught over his experience as a fill-in manager for the ailing Billy Martin that he had decided to leave baseball. Earlier in the year, he had been designated as the future manager of the Yankees in the line of frequent succession, but suddenly he supposedly wasn't waiting around for the coronation.

title: L.I. OFFICER KILLS MAN HE SAYS TRIED TO HIT HIM WITH AN AUTO
description: A Suffolk County highway patrol officer shot and killed a man he had pulled over for speeding after the man tried to run him over, the police said.

title: FILIPINOS AT HAWAII CONSULATE SAY THEY SUPPORT CHALLENGE
description: The Philippine Consul General and six consulate officers said today that they no longer considered Ferdinand E. Marcos President of the Philippines, and they called for his resignation.

title: IDEOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 TEEN-AGERS DIE IN HIGHWAY CRASH
description: Four Long Island teen-agers returning from a fast-food restaurant were killed Friday night when their car was struck head-on by a speeding car and exploded into flames, the Suffolk County police said. The driver of the other car died later, authorities said.

title: HOW TO HANG WALLPAPER THAT REALLY ISN'T PAPER AT ALL
description: BECAUSE many of today's wallpapers are not really paper, the industry has for some time now been referring to all such materials as wall coverings. Fortunately, hanging most of them, including most vinyl- and plastic-coated or scrubbable wall coverings, is not a difficult job for do-it-yourselfers.

title: FAMILIAR FINGER IS JUST THE KEY FOR OPENING SOME LOCKS
description: AS a college student, Michael Schiller often turned to science-fiction novels as a welcome break from his rigorous electrical-engineering studies.

title: MASSACHUSETTS OFFERS LOANS FOR DAY CARE AT WORK
description: A Massachusetts agency that lends money to help failing industries has set aside a $750,000 loan fund for child-care centers at workplaces.

title: All Dressed Up, Nowhere to Go
description: Other than a fleet of cars, four homes and a yacht, Jean-Claude Duvalier seems to have left little behind except anger. The interim Government nationalized the former President's properties in Haiti last week, warning foreigners and nationals alike to disclose any Duvalier assets they may be holding.

title: Historic Rehab
description: Lyall House at 35 Wooster Street in Manhattan, originally a department store and more recently the site of a rag baler and futon retailer, has been remodeled and is being sold as loft condominiums.

title: Other Noble Sufferers
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMUTERS GET A CHANCE TO SOUND OFF ON SERVICE
description: WHEN NJ Transit was created in 1979, said Anthony L. Grazioso, a spokesman for the agency, ''we inherited some buses held together with baling wire and Band-Aids.''

title: CABARET MARKS 10TH YEAR
description: SOME of Connecticut's top corporations will help Bridgeport's Downtown Cabaret Theater celebrate its 10th anniversary Thursday night, in the first such event since Richard C. Hallinan became the nonprofit theater's executive producer five years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an excerpt in The Week in Review last Sunday from remarks by Anatoly B. Shcharansky after his release from the Soviet Union omitted a passage. The passage, describing Mr. Shcharansky's arrival in East Germany en route to Israel, should have read as follows:

title: POP: HIROSHIMA, A QUINTET
description: HIROSHIMA, the Los Angeles pop quintet led by Dan and June Kuramoto, both third-generation Japanese-Americans, is being marketed as a ''new age'' band. But the term is something of a misnomer when applied to this group, which appeared at the Bottom Line on Thursday night.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bergenfield $148,500 1 Deerfield Street *2*4 bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 37-year-old split level; *2*deck, new roof, fenced yard; taxes $2,903. Hillsdale $295,000 98 Craig Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; pool, sauna, *2*family room with fireplace; taxes $4,326. Pine Brook $155,000 5 Lancaster Avenue *2*3 bedroom, 2 bath, 18-year-old ranch; central air- *2*conditioning, family room, sliders to patio; taxes $2,419. Short Hills $197,500 22 Hobart Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; Palladian windows, *2*den, living room with fireplace; taxes $3,138. Springfield $254,000 5 Tree Top Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; insulated windows, *2*cedar shakes, family room with fireplace; taxes to be assessed. Wayne $186,000 525 Black Oak Ridge Road *2*6-bedroom, 3-bath, 5-year-old bilevel; hardwood *2*floors, aluminum siding, 3-car garage; taxes $3,783. OTHER AREAS North Bellmore, L.I. $152,750 2364 Henry Street *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old ranch; *2*dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. North Haven, Conn. $131,000 75 Upper State Street *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old raised ranch; *2*central air-conditioning, 3.3 acres; taxes $1,881. South Salem, N.Y. $226,000 Laurie Lane *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old frame colonial; *2*deck, porch, stone walls, 2.1 acres; taxes $3,780.

title: LLOYD DEFEATS GRAF IN FINAL
description: Given the cost of court time nowadays, Steffi Graf can always look upon today's experience on the sun-baked concrete at the Lipton International Players Championships as a free tennis lesson. And she could not have asked for a better teacher than Chris Evert Lloyd.

title: GERMAN DANCE FINDS A HOME IN THE LIMON COMPANY
description: It will surely surprise nobody that the Limon Dance Company's two-week season at the Joyce Theater, which opens Tuesday night, includes three works by Jose Limon. When the distinguished choreographer died in 1972, his dancers vowed to keep his company together and his choreography alive. Nevertheless, that company may be developing in surprising ways. And some dancegoers may be startled to discover that its repertory at the Joyce also includes works by Susanne Linke, Jean Cebron, Carlos Orta, Heinz Poll, Lucas Hoving, Anna Sokolow and Meredith Monk.

title: BRADLEY NOW 28-1 AFTER 19TH IN A ROW
description: Hersey Hawkins scored 22 points today as Bradley extended the nation's longest major-college winning streak to 19 games with a 74-64 victory over Wichita State in a Missouri Valley Conference game. Bradley, 15-0 in the conference, also improved the country's best overall record this season for Division I schools to 28-1, and remained undefeated at home after 14 games.

title: AIMING TO BOLSTER FUND RAISING, 2 JEWISH CHARITIES AGREE TO MERGE
description: Two of the world's leading Jewish charities, one with a focus on New York City and the other abroad, have agreed to merge ''to meet Jewish needs wherever they exist.''

title: CLOUD OVER STAR
description: Norris Coleman, Kansas State's 24-year-old basketball star, was scheduled to be playing in the game against Kansas yesterday, but there was a cloud over his head. According to The Kansas City Times, Coleman had been ineligible to play for a Division I school under rules in effect at the start of the season.

title:
Photo of Carved Cherubs on former Lying-In Hospital;
NEW RULES HONE A PRESERVATION TOOL
description: FROM the top of the Terminal Building on Hudson Street in Hoboken, N.J., twin stone faces of Hathor, the Egyptian goddess of joy, will continue to look down at the Hotel Victor Bar and Grill across the street.

title: W,HAT DID THE FOUNDING FATHERS INTEND?
description: THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES WILL BE 200 years old on Sept. 17, 1987, and a Bicentennial commission -headed by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger (whose birthday felicitously falls on that date) - is under way, formulating plans for ''Constitution Day'' festivities. The celebratory air notwithstanding, recent discussions of constitutional values seem to reveal more conflict than shared pride. Some examples:

title: SCARSDALE TRIES AN EXPERIMENT IN IMPROVING TEACHING SKILLS
description: HOW can public-school teachers stay abreast of changing developments in their fields when they spend all their time teaching?

title: CAREFULLY SUSTAIN REFORM
description: Saying, ''We felt we had to do something,'' 29 young workers walked off their jobs with the Philippine Government's Committee on Elections the Sunday after the voting. Later, at possible risk to themselves and their families, they stood before the press at a church altar in Manila and said there had been inconsistencies in the Government's computerized ''quick count'' of the Presidential vote. In so doing, they reflected a widespread spirit of passionate caring for the democratic process and free and fair elections. That spirit was the dominant memory I brought back from my experience as an observer with the American delegation monitoring the election.

title: RELOCATING STATION DEBATED IN FAIRFIELD
description: EARLY each weekday morning in Fairfield, commuters anxiously search for parking spaces on the side streets beyond the railroad station's crowded parking lots. A few hours later, merchants and shoppers circle the downtown area looking for the few spaces still available.

title: Julie F. Herwitz Engaged to Wed V. C. Butkiewicz
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Richard Herwitz of Swampscott, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julie F. Herwitz to Vincent Christopher Butkiewicz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent Butkiewicz of Leominster and Ipswich, Mass. The wedding is planned for June 22.

title:
GARDENING;
PROPER PRUNING HAS MANY BENEFITS
description: TREES that have been pruned and trained properly will be more attractive, more wind resistant and longer lived than those that have been neglected or improperly treated. It is not all that difficult to do these things properly. It is more a matter of timeliness and persistence.

title: HUSSEIN-ARAFAT RIFT SAID TO AID P.L.O. UNITY
description: The breakdown of the peace effort between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat has improved the chances of healing the rift inside the Palestine Liberation Organization and improving the P.L.O.'s relations with Syria, according to Palestinian officials and reports by Arab press organizations.

title: Janet Greenberg Plans To Wed James Razulis
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Mortimer S. Greenberg of Belmont and Mashpee, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Janet Ellen Greenberg to James Casimir Razulis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Casimir Razulis of Randallstown, Md.

title: OUT OF RINGS, INTO HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: THE greatest industrial potential for this most precious metal, which is now more costly than gold, lies with the automotive industry. Catalytic converters made with a mixture of metals from the platinum family have proved highly effective in controlling car exhaust, and have been extensively used here and in Japan since the mid-1970's.

title: 48 FOOD OUTLETS VIOLATE CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 48 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Tylenol Maker Drops Capsules
description: After seven people died from cyanide-tainted Tylenol in 1982, Johnson & Johnson, the drug's manufacturer, put seals on its over-the-counter products, and the Government forced the entire pharmaceutical industry to follow suit.

title: Documenting a War
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STONE 588. By Gerald A. Browne. (Arbor House, $17.95.) The plot of Gerald A. Browne's 1972 novel, ''11 Harrowhouse,'' can serve just as nicely as a description of his latest contribution to the crime-thriller genre: a diamond merchant and his enormously rich jet-set girlfriend, working with two other people, steal a lot of gemstones.

title: Anne E. Corroon and Stephen Grubbs Are Engaged to Be Wed in September
description: The engagement of Anne Eileen Corroon to Stephen Deacon Grubbs has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Francis Corroon of Rye, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Okla Gatehouse Grubbs of Darien, Conn.

title: Miss Pollack Is Engaged To Mark Steven Rosenthal
description: Shoshannah Pollack and Mark Steven Rosenthal, who expect to receive M.D. degrees in June from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, plan to be married in April. Dr. and Mrs. Simeon Pollack of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Rosenthal of Wayne, N.J.

title: A SHOPPERS' PARADISE ON THE PRAIRIE
description: ADECADE ago, Joan Didion, the author, wrote in a magazine article that if she owned a shopping center, ''I would have monkeys and Chinese restaurants and Mylar kites and bands of small girls playing tambourines.'' Let her come to Edmonton. Here on the northern fringe of Canada's flat, frigid prairie is a shopping center calculated to dazzle. There are monkeys, Siberian tiger cubs and 544 different kinds of trees taller than 12 feet. Four submarines prowl a 438-foot-long lake infested by real sharks.There's a roller coaster more than 13 stories high and a $5 million hockey rink where superstar Wayne Gretzky practices with the Edmonton Oilers.

title: COMPUTER CONSULTANTS COME IN MANY MODELS
description: Regarding your Feb. 2 article, ''Computer Consultant Keeps User in Mind,'' computer consultants have become an essential ingredient in implementing microcomputer systems. There is a massive amount of software currently onthe market, and many different variations of hardware available.

title: JAZZ: 'HIGHLIGHTS' SERIES
description: JACK KLEINSINGER'S concert series, ''Highlights in Jazz,'' celebrated its 13th anniversary on Thursday evening at New York University's Loeb Auditorium with a program that differed from those that have usually been presented during the past 13 years.

title: Catharine Stryker to Marry John N. Strawbridge
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Abner Bartlett Stryker Jr. of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Catharine Duane Stryker to John Noble Strawbridge, the son of the late Billie C. Strawbridge and the late John W. Costello, both of Philadelphia. The wedding is planned for June 14.

title: Topics Inventions; Family Mirrors
description: A cheer for Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Jeremiah Denton and Charles Mathias, who have introduced a resolution in the Senate to create a special committee on families and children.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP REACHES ACCORD WITH UNION
description: Agreements signed by the Campbell Soup Company and a farm workers' union will end a labor dispute that dates to 1968, the union's president says.

title: Saving 2,000 Pipes In Pennsylvania
description: PENNSYLVANIA highway engineers have agreed to go 20 feet out of their way to spare a 73-year-old widow's pride and joy: a 2,000-pipe Wurlitzer theater organ that took her and her husband 10 years to install.

title: DEVILS DEFEATED BY KINGS, 5-2
description: The turning point in the Devils' 5-2 loss to the Los Angeles Kings this afternoon at Byrne Meadowlands Arena came 13 minutes into the second period.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's first efforts to define safe levels of chemical contaminants in drinking water have brought at least tentative good news for most New Jerseyans. The Department of Environmental Protection has issued interim guidelines for 14 substances, and 95 percent of the public community water supplies in the state fall within acceptable levels for all 14, according to John W. Gaston, director of the D.E.P.'s Division of Water Resources. A few water supplies have been closed because of high levels, he said.

title: Money, Money, Money
description: Despite the widely held belief that private business provides the only real money in the country, Washington, the heart of government employment, leads the nation in per capita income.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO OFFER PROTECTION TO AQUINO
description: A United States Senator said today that the United States Navy had made available a ship for Corazon C. Aquino should she be forced to flee or need protection in the current Philippine situation.

title: Other Noble Sufferers
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Measures Toxic Waste From New England's Plants
description: Connecticut and Massachusetts produce 90 percent of New England's toxic industrial waste, and more than half of the waste shipped out of the region is stored or disposed of in New York and New Jersey, according to a report by the New England Congressional Institute.

title: A PRESERVE FOR WILDLIFE AND ART
description: Giant crocodiles sit basking in the sun, mouths open, ventilating. A visitor feels the exhilarating chill of meeting the yellow gaze of a crocodile just 20 feet away. All around, the reeds and trees are laden with exuberantly large birds. Even the cockatoos are big and black. In the middle distance, flocks of whistling kites wheel and dive over a bush fire, pillaging the prey flushed out below.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Lucien Rodriguez of France, the three-time European heavyweight champion who once went the distance with Larry Holmes, announced his retirement. The 34-year-old boxer had a 39-12-1 record. . . Dave Hunter, the Edmonton Oiler who began serving a 28-day sentence for impaired driving a week ago, was released from jail Friday after giving notice he would appeal his conviction. . . Jan Kemp, the University of Georgia instructor who won a $2.57 million Federal Court award from the school for dismissing her because she protested preferential academic treatment for athletes, has received a $750,000 settlement offer but will probably turn it down, according to her lawyer.

title: Suddenly, Kohl Is On the Defensive
description: Otto Schily, a lawyer and member of Parliament for the leftist Green Party, does not play by the cozy rules of Bonn politics. Last week, Mr. Schily's legal spadework in West Germany's big political-payoff scandal opened a hole on Chancellor Helmut Kohl's road to re-election.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: IRISH LUCK Gaelic concerts don't come along every day, so fans, alas, will have to choose next Friday between two.

title: GARY PLAYER, A TRUE BELIEVER
description: WHEN Gary Player joined the PGA Tour in 1957, no one could have foreseen what he would go on to accomplish over the course of what has been a remarkable career. No one, that is, except Gary Player -always the truest of true believers.

title: Carla Bradley Is Married To Kevin Sur in Colorado
description: Carla M. Bradley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Havyn Bradley of Fort Collins, Colo., was married there yesterday to Kevin W. Sur, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Sur of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Coyte performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: RISING PHILADELPHIA KOREAN COMMUNITY IS LEAVING GREENGROCERIES BEHIND
description: Yong Lee, 31 years old, gets up at 3:30 every morning to buy the fresh fruit that he will sell until dark at his sidewalk vendor's stand in the heart of Center City. He hopes to save enough to open a permanent store in four or five years.

title: CORNELL WINS AND GAINS LEAD
description: John Bajusz scored 16 points and Len Palmer added 14 as Cornell routed Harvard, 71-35, tonight and took first place in the Ivy League by a game as Brown lost to Penn.

title: HARDSHIPS ASIDE, WINTER OFFERS SOME SPECIAL PLEASURES
description: ''I CAN'T stand the long cold winter, the snow, the ice -all of this,'' a friend said. ''It's too much, too harsh.'' ''Yes,'' I replied, ''the season is a hard one, but there is an appealing side, too.''

title: Yankees by Immersion
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Ryan Is a Bride
description: Karen Ann Ryan, a freelance television producer, and Dan Cordtz, economics editor of ABC News, were married yesterday at the Tavern on the Green in New York by Presiding Justice Milton Mollen of the State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department.

title: 'Hawksmoor' and Wren's Scalpel
description: To the Editor:

title: TOWN SEEKS CONTROL OF WETLANDS FROM BUILDERS AND STATE
description: SINCE 1975, when New York State enacted its Freshwater Wetlands Act, the State Department of Environmental Conservation has had jurisdiction over all wetlands larger than 12.4 acres. Areas smaller than that are not protected by the state unless they are of unique ecological significance.

title: MARYLAND STORES TOLD TO REMOVE A BABY FOOD
description: Gov. Harry Hughes of Maryland Friday ordered stores in the state to remove Gerber strained peaches from their shelves because glass shards had been found in two opened jars of the baby food, but the Food and Drug Administration said it had tested 6,000 unopened jars and found no glass.

title: The Big Winners
description: To the Editor:

title: Violence Closes In on the Other South Africa
description: South Africa's endemic violence came closer last week to the heartland of the nation's wealth in the white northern suburbs of Johannesburg. The manner in which it was contained and finally quashed said something about the tactics the authorities have employed to keep black and white realities apart, as well as about the clamps on black protests, which sometimes turn the violence against itself.

title: I.R.A. INVESTMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
THE DRAWBACKS OF A 'DRY' TOWN
description: REAL-estate agents will often point out that, when buying a house, there are only three really important factors to consider: location, location and location.

title: HOME FOR DISABLED FOUGHT IN DIX HILLS
description: A NUMBER of Dix Hills homeowners are fighting to keep out of their neighborhood the first community residence in Suffolk County for adults with learning disabilities.

title: CHINA TO TRY CO-PILOT OF HIJACKED SOVIET PLANE
description: China said Friday that it would try the co-pilot of a twin-engined airliner belonging to the Soviet airline Aeroflot that was hijacked on an internal flight in the Soviet Far East in December and forced to land in Manchuria.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1986
description: International

title: James C. Cowles and Kathryn Maney, Company Executives, Exchange Vows
description: Kathryn Claire Maney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Maney Jr. of Wilmington, N.C., was married in New York yesterday to James Charles Cowles, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll J. Cowles of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. James Shanley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton.

title: 9 ARRESTED AND 185 POUNDS OF COCAINE SEIZED IN QUEENS
description: City and Federal authorities seized 185 pounds of cocaine and arrested nine people in a raid Friday night in Queens, officials said yesterday.

title: FOR POLICE LIBRARY, REDO AND REFOCUS
description: TUCKED away in the Connecticut Police Academy in Meriden is the sole library in the state devoted to serving the law-enforcement agencies. The library is being renovated, and more people in and out of law enforcement are being encouraged to use it.

title: Headliners; Moving Around
description: No one has more stamina for public appearances than Prince Charles. During a visit to Texas last week to mark the state's 150th birthday, he presented an award to the entrepreneur H. Ross Perot at a ceremony attended by Nancy Reagan and ''Dallas'' stars, ate lunch with oil refinery workers, cut a 90,000-pound cake, admired a British musket at the site where the Texans defeated Mexico, went to a Willie Nelson concert and visited a nursing home named for his uncle, Lord Mountbatten.

title: LOST ROSSINI OPERA PROVES TO BE A MASTERWORK
description: The Rossini revival continues, with new albums of rarely recorded classic Rossini operas and, sometimes, a heretofore completely unheard masterpiece suddenly available in one's record stores.

title: YANK TICKETS GOING ON SALE
description: The Yankees have announced that box and reserved seat tickets for the regular season will go on sale Friday at the Yankee Stadium advance ticket window. Tickets will be available from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. - seven days a week - until the conclusion of the season.

title: THE GRAMMY AWARDS: MAINSTREAM AND SAFE
description: Tuesday night at 8 on CBS, the 28th annual Grammy Awards will be bestowed with great fanfare by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. Performers and record-business executives will buckle on their cummerbunds and smile for the television cameras; an audience of millions will tune in to see just what 1985 meant to the music business.

title: THE LURE OF GOSSIP, THE RULE OF HISTORY
description: TO be a biographer of any merit requires the skills of the historian, the psychologist and the gossip columnist. Without the last two the work will lack those qualities of immediacy and revelation that lie at the heart of any successful biography - ''A shilling life will give you all the facts,'' to borrow Auden's contemptuous phrase. Yet only the disciplines of history can save the biographer from the wastelands of empty and ill-founded speculation and enable him to place his study within the framework of the proper period. As the subject of a biography is set closer and closer to the present day, so the lures of gossip and psychology become more insidious and the rules of history prove ever more difficult to apply.

title: DO METAL SALES SUBSIDIZE APARTHEID?
description: THE political controversy surrounding platinum mirrors the arguments critics raise in protesting American investments in South Africa and domestic sales of the krugerrand.

title: Edward Aldrich Plans To Wed Susan A. Scull
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Penrose Scull Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Anne Scull to Edward Farley Aldrich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hart Aldrich of Rowayton, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Looking for a Fight
description: The way his manager, Stan Tommasello, sees it, Vincent (Choo Choo) Bell is a pretty fair Florida bantamweight. But whenever Tommasello tries to line up a fight for him, promoters and rival boxers look the other way. The problem is that Bell, like the far more celebrated Craig Bodzianowski, has an artificial leg, a result of a birth defect that required amputation below the left knee when he was 4 years old.

title: JOB PROGRAMS AID WELFARE RECIPENTS, STUDY SAYS
description: New state programs under which welfare recipients agree to work at public service jobs in return for their benefits are helping some participants find private employment, according to a national study.

title: Stanley A. Kamen, 60, Dies; Was Hollywood Talent Agent
description: Stanley A. Kamen, one of Hollywood's best-known and most successful talent agents, died Thursday at UCLA Medical Center here. He was 60 years old.

title: J. Walter Thompson To Get a New Chief
description: On March 5 the publicly held JWT Group will announce a new chief executive officer for the J. Walter Thompson Company, its largest component, a worldwide network of advertising agencies and, by itself, the third-largest American agency. The person chosen will not be Burton J. Manning.

title: New York City Housing Authority Could Aid Homeless Families
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1986
description: Companies

title: PURSUIT OF PARKING FINES GOT CHICAGO INTO A MESS
description: The source of trouble for Chicago officials that has led to at least four Federal, state and local investigations into municipal corruption started as an effort to capitalize on a vast, untapped source of revenue.

title: CHARGES AND DENIALS ON PLOT
description: On Saturday, as it became clear that Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile and the deputy Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, were mounting an open challenge to President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the President made a statement on national television about the situation in the country.

title: NASA SEARCH FINDS BIG METAL SHEET
description: A large thin sheet of metal that may have been part of the external fuel tank of the space shuttle Challenger was brought into port today by the research vessel Seward Johnson.

title: Eggs and a Roast
description: On the theory that any Washington journalistic forum that survives for 20 years qualifies as an institution, some reporters and columnists have invited Godfrey Sperling of The Christian Science Monitor to breakfast this morning at the Sheraton Carlton Hotel.

title: ISALNDERS REVERT TO SLUGGISH PLAY
description: It is too early, with 20 games remaining in this season, for the Islanders to panic and assume they will make an early exit from the playoffs. But it is too late in the season, said their uneasy coach, Al Arbour, for the team to be demonstrating its current paralysis of purpose.

title: When Urinalysis Infringes on Employee Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Conspiracy So Immense'
description: One of the ugliest and most dangerous political operations seen in our country in years is now under way in Washington. It is the Reagan Administration's campaign to win a free hand for war on Nicaragua by smearing as pro-Communist all who disagree with the war policy.

title: GUIDRY SEEKS LONGER CAREER
description: When Ron Guidry signed a contract with the Yankees four years ago, he said it would be his last. But, he said today, amending that thought, ''I couldn't really say because I had to see what I would do the next five years. I was 31 then; I'm 35 now, but it's not an old 35. I definitely want to keep playing.''

title: CORRECTION
description: New Jersey lottery numbers in some copies yesterday were reported incorrectly. The Pick-It number drawn Saturday was 774; the Pick 4 number was 2496.

title: CALIFORNIA'S PRIVATE TRIAL SYSTEM SEEMS SETTLED IN
description: A private judicial system that is expeditious and expensive celebrates its 10th anniversary this year, and by all accounts it has become a way of life for retired judges, major law firms and clients who shun publicity.

title: Chief Still Feeding 'Hungry' Midlantic
description: For the last eight years and from a variety of different venues, Robert Van Buren has been telling television audiences in the metropolitan New York area about his ''hungry'' bankers at Midlantic Banks.

title: SADOWSKY IS SEEKING QUEENS POST
description: Edward L. Sadowsky, former chairman of the City Council Finance Committee, said last night that he would seek the Queens Borough Presidency.

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIAN TOWNS HIT WITH SHELLS AND ROCKETS
description: Christian villages in the eastern and northeastern mountains came under artillery and rocket attack today, and a senior Christian leader accused Syrian troops of taking part in the bombardment and asked for their withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: VIENNA CHAMBER CONCERT
description: Phillippe Entremont will lead the Vienna Chamber Orchestra, of which he is music director, in a program that includes Helmut Eder's ''Pice de Concert,'' Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 14 in E flat and Dvorak's Serenade for String Orchestra in E. on March 5 at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Entremont will also be the piano soloist. Tickets, at $15, $12.50, $10 and $8, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: N.H.L.
description: Paul Cyr scored a short-handed goal and added an assist tonight to lead the Buffalo Sabres to a 4-1 victory over the Washington Capitals.

title: MUSIC: ORPHEUS
description: ORPHEUS, the chamber orchestra that performs without a conductor and decides on repertory and interpretation as a cooperative body, played a conservative program in conservative fashion Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: J. Paris de Bollardiere; War Hero and Pacifist
description: Gen. Jacques Paris de Bollardiere, a war hero who became a pacifist, died of cancer Friday at his home in Brittany, family members said today. He was 78 years old.

title: TEWELL CAPTURES LOS ANGELES GOLF
description: Doug Tewell, rediscovering the winning touch for the first time in nearly six years, shot an 8-under-par 63 today for a runaway victory in the Los Angeles Open.

title: Bond Market Receives Boost
description: The bond market, already the beneficiary of lower oil prices and low inflation forecasts, was lifted further recently by a spate of weak economic statistics and hopes for good demand from Japanese investors.

title: HIGGINS SEEKS A ROLE ON NETS
description: He was only half-interested in talking about himself. Rod Higgins's eyes were focused on the television at the other end of the dressing room, his concentration fixed on a videotape of a recent Nets' game. He had to watch and learn quickly, and he knew it, because he is trying to find a place for himself, trying to make some kind of impact in a short time and earn himself a place on a roster. Any roster.

title: Convicted Spy Is Determined To Have Died of Asphyxiation
description: An autopsy has determined that Larry Wu-tai Chin, convicted two weeks ago of spying for China, died of asphyxiation, Roger Ray, the United States marshal for eastern Virginia, said marshal for eastern Virginia, said Saturday.

title: Janet Troy, Publicity Chief, Is Bride of Kevin Tremble
description: Janet Ellen Troy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Troy of Peekskill, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin Tremble, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Tremble of Palisades Park, N.J. The Rev. Paul Zahl, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: PLANNING GROUP SUGGESTS WAYS FOR M.T.A. TO REDUCE COSTS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority could cut operating costs 20 percent by such moves as reducing the number of token-booth clerks at subway stations and replacing elevated subway lines with surface or subsurface lines, an independent research agency said in a report to be made public today.

title: 3 More Suspects Arrested In Slaying of Drug Informer
description: Federal agents have arrested three more suspects in the machine-gun slaying of a drug smuggler turned informer who had refused the protection of a new identity or Federal guards.

title: OPERA: DONIZETTI'S 'UNCONVENTIONAL REHEARSAL'
description: UNDER the title of ''An Unconventional Rehearsal,'' the Opera Ensemble of New York has just produced Donizetti's ''Le Convenienze ed Inconvenienze Teatrali,'' one of the wittier and more palatable specimens of that suspect genre, opera about the foibles of opera. Mozart, Lortzing and many others tried their hand at this somewhat cannibalistic exercise, and all no doubt produced the obvious laughs, but Donizetti also supplied music in his freshest early comic vein and produced a gem.

title: Press Seoul for Democracy, Too?
description: Although world attention now focuses on the Philippines, a similar drama is being played out in South Korea, another East Asian country of comparable strategic importance to the United States. The difference is that while President Ferdinand E. Marcos is trying to steal an election after the votes are in, President Chun Doo Hwan seems determined to prevent a popular election from taking place.

title: Saudis Reject Export Ban
description: Saudi Arabia says it will seek higher oil prices without provoking another energy crisis, in an apparent rebuff to those members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that have called for a halt in OPEC oil exports.

title: Most Boats RetCrn to Sea In New Bedford Dispute
description: Most of the fishing boats that were idled in a labor dispute between fishermen and the Seafood Producers Association here have returned to work, but both sides in the strike say issues remain unresolved, and fishermen vowed today to keep on picketing.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. The Bullets have a 2-1 edge in the season series thus far.

title: Seoul Dissident Released From House Arrest
description: Kim Dae Jung, a key opposition leader, was released from house arrest early this morning, ending 12 consecutive days in which he had been confined to his home with telephone lines cut.

title: COMMUNISTS STAND LARGELY ON SIDELINES IN PHILIPPINE CRISIS
description: With the Philippines caught up in a military and political crisis, the Communist New People's Army in the countryside and their radical allies in the cities have remained largely on the sidelines, putting many of their followers in an uncomfortable position.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Connecticut National Bank, Hartford, has promoted Samuel P. Cooley and Jasper W. Morgan Jr. to executive vice president.

title: Guarding the Guardians
description: Corruption in government is bad enough; but when that corruption mingles with prosecutorial panic and political ambition to breed abuses of power and denial of individual rights, citizens are in more danger than they realize.

title: LENDL TURNS BACK WILANDER IN FINAL
description: The price of being No. 1 is the added scrutiny a tennis player faces during the course of any tournament he plays. So despite the fact that Ivan Lendl continues his domination of the tour that began when he won the United States Open last summer, the questions now revolve around the blemishes that make his victories less than works of art.

title: Carl P. Ray Dies at 71; Ex-Underwood Official
description: Carl P. Ray, a former All-America center on the Dartmouth College football team and for many years an executive of the Underwood Corporation, died Saturday at his home in Pawling, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: JEWS IN LEBANON URGED TO GET OUT
description: Leading French Jews, saying that the Jews of Lebanon are in imminent danger, called on them today to leave for other countries.

title: A JAVELINA SET LOOSE DESPITE ALL
description: There's nothing like a good critter story to stir passions in Texas. So it's not surprising Texans ranging from animal lovers to Gov. Mark White have voiced their concern over the fate of Bubba, the missing javelina of Corpus Christi.

title: Letter: On Corruption; Beyond Graft, the Issue Is Management
description: To the Editor:

title: Bomb Hurts Policeman After Ulster Rebel Dies
description: A remote-controlled bomb exploded today near a police car, wounding an officer hours after an army patrol killed an Irish Republican Army rebel and captured his comrade.

title: CARPENTERS' UNION OFFICIAL CONVICTED OF FRAUD
description: A top official of the 25,000-member New York City District Council of Carpenters was convicted last week of Federal charges that he helped defraud the Government and the union's benefit funds of more than $1 million.

title: Less Dazzle on Broadway
description: They said the neon lights were too bright on Broadway.

title: A Powerful Order
description: Overheard one morning in the Regency Hotel at Park Avenue and 61st Street:

title: 3 ROBBERS FIRE TOKEN BOOTH
description: Three teen-agers set afire a BMT subway token booth at Franklin Avenue and Dean Street in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn early yesterday, and when the clerk fled, they stole $100 from the booth, the police said.

title: Pakistani Hopes Soviet Will Leave Afghanistan
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said today that he hoped talks set for next month in Geneva could lead to the withdrawal of some 115,000 Soviet military personnel from Afghanistan.

title: A Dazzling Dozen
description: Marty Blake, the National Basketball Association's director of scouting, lists the 12 college players who seem to him ''almost certain'' to become regulars in the N.B.A.:

title: WHAT THE TAX WRITERS DON'T HEAR
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield Associations around the country have mounted the most aggressive lobbying campaign since they were formed a half-century ago, spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to hire political consultants and flood Congressional offices with mail.

title: Crowds March in Spain Against NATO Role
description: Hundreds of thousands of protesters marched through Madrid today to express opposition to membership in NATO, an issue scheduled for a referendum next month.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1986 International Marcos troops attacked the garrison in Manila held by two former Government officials, but the assault ended quickly amid evidence that some of the attackers and a growing numbver of military officials had joined the rebels. The attack followed a tense night of threats and counter threats between the two sides. The fast-moving events left the ultimate outcome of three-day standoff unclear. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] A cutoff of Manila's U.S. military aid was threatened by President Reagan unless President Marcos avoided the use of force against those calling for his resignation. The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said Mr. Reagan had sent a message urging Mr. Marcos ''to avoid an attack against other elements of the Philippine armed forces.'' [ A1:4. ] Philippine leftists remain inactive during the military and political crisis, putting many of their followers in an uncomfortable position. Leaders of the left contend that their decision to boycott the election on Feb. 7 has been proved correct, since President Marcos has stayed in office despite widespread indicaitons of fraud and voter intimidation. But a number of political moderates and diplomats believe the boycott cost the Communists a chance to increase their power by linking up to the enormously popular Corazon C. Aquino. [ A1:5. ] The Jews of Lebanon face imminent danger from extremist Islamic groups and should leave the country, leading French Jews said. The appeal at a conference in Paris followed the announced executions of four Jews in Lebanon and the abduction of three Jews by an Islamic group in West Beirut.

title: Pickens Bid May Get Pioneer Leader's Nod
description: C. David Culver, president and chief executive officer of the Pioneer Corporation, has built a reputation as a man who firmly believes in supplying the maximum value to shareholders.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page Feb. 6 about Presidential speechwriters left an incorrect impression concerning the authorship of a line in a speech by President Reagan about the space shuttle disaster. The words ''slipped the surly bonds of earth to touch the face of God,'' are from the sonnet ''High Flight,'' by James Gillespie Magee Jr.

title: GORBACHEV'S FAST START PUTS NEW TEAM IN CHARGE
description: In less than a year in power, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has achieved a shake-up of the top ranks of the Soviet leadership that has been more thorough than any of his predecessors managed in so short a time.

title: METS HAVE PITCHERS TO OFFER IN TRADES
description: The Trade. It hangs there over the Mets' training camp, waiting to happen. Nobody knows when, but everybody expects it will happen during spring training and the players are even speculating on which one of the seven starting pitchers will go.

title: HAITI'S NEW ERA IS UNFOLDING SLOWLY
description: When Haiti's absolute ruler, Jean-Claude Duvalier, boarded a United States Air Force plane two weeks ago and headed for exile, many Haitians hoped that revolutionary changes would somehow follow.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Dazzy Vance once pitched a no-hit, one-run game for Brooklyn. Who was the losing pitcher, and how did the opposing team score?

title: RECITAL: BARENBOIM PLAYS BEETHOVEN SONATAS
description: A GREAT deal of music has flowed under the bridge since 1822, when Beethoven composed the last of his 32 piano sonatas. And yet there is still no more challenging test of a pianist's musicianship and intellectual powers than this journey from the comparative innocence of the Haydnish early works to the spiritually exhaustive and technically exhausting works of Beethoven's final period.

title: REDMEN WEIGH IMPACT OF DEFEAT
description: After a month of staging dramatic comebacks and staving off fierce rallies, the St. John's Redmen saw their streak of good fortune run out Saturday against a DePaul team that played its best game of the season.

title: CAROLINA LOSES TO N.C. STATE
description: From the start of its game with North Carolina State today, it was clear that North Carolina was in for a long afternoon.
