Attempting to rebound from a home-court loss three days earlier, the anxious Tar Heels made their first shot, then missed 10 in a row, never recovered and lost by 76-65 in the Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: REVISED BILL WOULD LIMIT AIDS TEST USE
description: Insurance companies could not require people applying for policies to take a blood test for AIDS under revised legislation proposed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: RUEFUL BELT-TIGHTENING AT TIME INC
description: THESE are days of hardship at Time Inc. Employees at the company once known as ''Parato use dial-a-cab service from the Time & Life Building near Rockefeller Center to go home to Westchester or Greenwich, Conn. Some out-of-town sales conferences have been called off, and People magazine has ended its lunches for senior editors at Le Cygne and Giambelli. Last Christmas, the senior editors' lunch was at Lutece and the office party was at Metropolis on Columbus Avenue. ''We had our last celebration and then tightened the belt,'' said Patricia Ryan, the magazine's managing editor.

title: OTHER SODAS CAUGHT IN COKE-PEPSI WAR
description: The ever-intensifying marketing war between the Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico Inc. offers proof of the old adage that when elephants fight, the ants get stomped on.

title: Reagan and the Rebels
description: White House strategists are urging President Reagan to deliver a major televised speech in support of military and economic aid to the rebels in Nicaragua, one that would be timed to come just before the first Congressional vote on the program, probably late in March. The President is expected to submit a request to the lawmakers this week for $70 million in secret military assistance to the anti-Sandinista forces and $30 million in humanitarian aid.

title: Two Tellers Acquitted
description: A Federal jury found two Bank of New England tellers not guilty Friday of charges that they took part in what the authorities described as a money-laundering operation that moved $728,000 in cash through the bank.

title: DOLLAR DEMONSTRATES VOLATILITY
description: The dollar has dropped almost on cue over the last five months, just as the leading industrial nations had hoped when they agreed in September on a joint effort to weaken the currency. But those who believed that the central bankers were in firm command were disabused of that notion in the past several weeks as the dollar raced downward, threatening to run out of control.

title: General Felt-Sheller Tie Linked to Growth Plans
description: Over the last 14 years, Chester Devenow, chairman and chief executive of the Sheller-Globe Corporation, has built the company into one of the nation's largest suppliers of automotive parts.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Roundup of Quarterly Profits and Sales in Business Day Feb. 17 misstated the percentage change in net income at the Allied Stores Corporation. Net income advanced 30 percent in the fourth quarter from the 1984 quarter.

title: Libya to Cut Output
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said in an interview published today that his country intended to cut its production of crude oil in order to prop up falling prices. Mr. Qaddafi told the Greek newspaper Eleftherotypia that he believed the recent flareup in fighting between Iraq and Iran would also produce a drop in oil production and a corresponding increase in prices.

title: Prince Leaves Desert For a Snowy London
description: Prince Charles left the warm California desert today for snowy London after playing polo and raising funds at a benefit dance.

title: REBELS SEIZE KEY RADIO STATION; U.S. THREATENS TO HALT AID
description: Troops loyal to President Ferdinand E. Marcos today used tear gas against a crowd outside the military camp held by two former Government officials, but the assault ended swiftly amid evidence that some of the attackers and a growing number of other military officials had joined the rebels.

title: HEWLETT TOP PRESENT ITS SPECTRUM SERIES
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company's new Spectrum computers, scheduled to be introduced Tuesday, appear to be somewhat faster than had been expected, and could help the company recover lost momentum in the highly competitive minicomputer market, according to analysts and other sources familiar with the products.

title: SAKHAROV SAID TO ACCEPT EXIT BAN
description: The Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, to win permission for his wife to go to the West for medical treatment, accepted a ban on his own departure, a relative said today.

title: Bear Stearns Net Up 74.8%
description: The Bear Stearns Companies, the holding company for Bear, Stearns & Company, a leading banking and brokerage firm, said Friday that net income in its third fiscal quarter amounted to $47.2 million, or 88 cents a share, a rise of 74.8 percent from $27 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Richard Freeman Wed To Marjorie Sherwood
description: At the Community Synagogue in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Marjorie Ann Sherwood, a senior forecaster for telecommunications products with the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains, was married to Richard Bennett Freeman, program manager for telecommunication strategy at I.B.M. in White Plains. Rabbi Robert Rothman, assisted by Cantor Debra Bard, performed the ceremony.

title: POPE, IN CALL FOR PEACE, ASKS SOLUTION 'WITHOUT BLOODSHED'
description: Pope John Paul II prayed for a solution ''without bloodshed'' in the Philippines in a call for peace today.

title: Judicial Duty in New Jersey
description: For 11 years, New Jersey's Supreme Court has struggled with the constitutional issues implicit in the desire of Mount Laurel, a Burlington County township, to zone out low-income housing. For its labor the court earned its share of criticism for ''judicial activism.'' Last week, it yielded supervision of housing to a new state agency, the Council on Affordable Housing. That was no defeat for judicial activism but a handsome vindication of it.

title: ADAPTING AND REVISING TWAIN'S 'HUCK FINN'
description: ''Persons attempting to find a motive in this narrative will be prosecuted; persons attempting to find a moral in it will be banished; persons attempting to find a plot in it will be shot.'' Clearly that famous prefatory note to ''Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' has neither dissuaded generations of scholars from annotating the text, nor dissauded other persons from adapting, dramatizing, analyzing or, in one editor's words, ''enriching'' Mark Twain's celebrated epic. In the century following its publication, the classic has been issued and reissued (today there are more than 30 editions of the book available), amplified with introductions, bibliographies and criticism, and in one case even rewritten by a professor, who attempted to update it with contemporary slang, graphic sex and a heightened antislavery theme.

title: Catching Up
description: Steve Howe, the relief pitcher whose last three summers have been marked by four drug-related suspensions, spent the winter in Whitefish, Mont., where he worked out, performed various jobs for two radio stations and spoke to high school students about the dangers of addiction. Now, he says, he's ''over the hump'' and ready for baseball again.

title: 'Desert Song' to Be Staged
description: The Light Opera of Manhattan will perform for the first time in its new home, the Cherry Lane Theater, on Wednesday, opening a five-and-a-half-week run of Sigmund Romberg's ''Desert Song.''

title: Fermenta Stock Halt
description: The director of the Stockholm Bourse, Bengt Ryden, said that the management of the biotechnology company Fermenta A.B. had requested that trading in its stock be suspended Friday after the stock exchange began an inquiry into the past month's trading.

title: Drug Foes Aren't High On Civil Liberties
description: In the novel ''Gorky Park,'' the police inspector asks a central character whom she suspects of having stolen her ice skates. She replies, ''Everyone.'' The inspector responds, ''So do I.'' In the same may, people in our society who advocate the indiscriminate use of drug tests and ''lie detectors'' seem to suspect everyone.

title: Border Officers Seeking 3 Men in Agent's Slaying
description: Law officers on both sides of the Mexican border searched today for three suspected drug smugglers who the authorities believe killed a United States Customs official in southern Arizona on Friday.

title: CHALLENGE TO MARCOS: FILIPINOS ABROAD WATCH AND WAIT
description: The Consul at the Philippine Embassy in London today called on President Ferdinand E. Marcos to resign and hand over the Government to Corazon C. Aquino, his challenger in the presidential election Feb. 7.

title: TOP DERBY HORSES WAITING TO EMERGE
description: Almost every February, this litany begins round the race track: These 3-year-olds, they're terrible, the worst in a decade; some $5,000 claiming horse from Idaho could win the Kentucky Derby this year.

title: Machine Tool Orders Rose by 7.8% in January
description: Orders for American-made machine tools increased 7.8 percent in January compared to December's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: That Other Sham Election, the One in Liberia
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAS AIR BID STUDIED BY EASTERN
description: Charles E. Bryan, the president of the largest union at Eastern Airlines, said yesterday that his union would not open its contract to negotiate concessions, as the financially pressed company had requested, and instead was willing to take its chances with a takeover by Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation.

title: How a Parole Board Makes Up Its Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Futures/Options; Industry Clash With C.F.T.C.
description: TO no one's surprise, Chicago's futures exchanges came into the Congressional hearings last week on the reauthorization of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission with their verbal guns blazing.

title: The President's Call on Illegal Aliens
description: Would the Reagan Administration be willing to create jobs for an additional 3 million or 4 million Americans a year? Hardly, not when its new budget proposes cutting job programs. Then why does the Administration blandly acquiesce in creating jobs here for 3 million or 4 million foreigners?

title: The Low Road to Shoreham
description: People who live near Lilco's dormant nuclear plant at Shoreham on Long Island can be safely evacuated in the event of an emergency. That much was proved by the evacuation exercise held this month under Federal supervision. But some of New York's politicians don't want to hear the good news. Some even sued to prevent the drill's being held. Far from welcoming the result, Governor Cuomo, the perfervid champion of nuclear safety, had a spokesman deride it as ''truly meaningless.''

title: CITY SEEKS TO ATTACH PROPERTY OF A SCOFFLAW RETIRED OFFICER
description: City officials plan to search for bank accounts, real estate, cars or other attachable property owned by a former police officer, who retired last Friday and secured a $24,000 annual pension hours before it was learned that he was one of the city's worst scofflaws.

title: No Sit-Out for Inner Circle
description: Months ago, Mayor Koch complained that $250 tickets to the annual Inner Circle show were too expensive for his commissioners.

title: Daimler-Benz Gains
description: Daimler-Benz, maker of the Mercedes-Benz cars and trucks, said Friday that it had increased its worldwide revenues 19 percent last year, to $22.5 billion. Daimler, whose takeover of the electronics group AEG this month made it West Germany's biggest industrial conglomerate, said it was aided by the strong expansion of its car business, 10 percent higher sales in the United States and the dollar's strength last year. The interim report to shareholders gave no specific figure but said worldwide profits topped the record $476 million made in 1984.

title: In Vino Veritas
description: The California wine industry is making its annual Washington pilgrimage this week. The obligatory lobbying in Congress will probably be familiar, but a new public theme is being sounded. Today at the Madison Hotel, the Wine Institute and Winegrowers of California, two industry groups, will sponsor a symposium on wine and health with topics including ''Wine and Longevity,'' ''Wine in Hospital and Geriatric Care'' and ''Wine and Nutrition.''

title: Memorial Service for Dancer
description: A memorial service for Charles Moore, a dancer, teacher and choreographer, will be held tonight at 7 o'clock in the nave of Riverside Church, 120th Street and Claremont Avenue. Leonard de Paur will lead the service, which is open to the public. Mr. Moore died Jan. 23 at his home in Brooklyn after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: Treasury Financings Wind Down
description: Treasury financings this week include a $7.5 billion auction of five-year notes on Wednesday, in addition to today's regular auction of a total of $13.6 billion of new bills due in three and six months.

title: PENTAGON FEARS DELAYS ON FUTURE SPY SATELLITE
description: The destruction of the space shuttle Challenger has left the Pentagon uncertain about its ability to maintain and upgrade military satellites that monitor Soviet military actions and control United States nuclear forces.

title: Boggs to Earn $1.35 Million
description: Wade Boggs lost his bid today for a $1.85 million salary in his fifth year in the major leagues.

title: WOMEN AND GUN OWNERSHIP
description: Lorene Wozniak owns a hair salon in the East Village. She is divorced, and has a 15-year-old daughter. She is one of many women who live on their own, take care of families, run businesses and have chosen to protect themselves by owning a gun.

title: Outdoors: Hunting, Fishing Expo
description: ONCE again, hordes of anglers and hunters will hie to the cavernous Rockland Community College Field House in Suffern, N.Y., for the ninth World Fishing and Outdoor Exposition, which this year will run from Wednesday through Sunday.

title: CRISIS HAS FILIPINOS IN CITY ANXIOUS
description: Filipinos in New York opposed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos expressed their anxiety yesterday about the future of the Philippines and their elation at the strength of the opposition there.

title: Japan, Too, Respects Intellectual Property
description: To the Editor:

title: PHONE DISPUTE OVER MONOPOLY
description: AS deregulation expands, the sanctity of the utility monopoly franchise is increasingly in doubt.

title: MIDDLEBURY HINTS AT EXAMINING ZACCARO CASE BEFORE A TRIAL
description: A police investigation into cocaine use here is continuing, and the dean of Middlebury College suggested today that the school would look into the case of John A. Zaccaro Jr., the son of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice Presidential nominee.

title: Alien Cited in Smuggling Trial
description: A Salvadoran woman has become the fourth witness and the first Central American to be cited for contempt for refusing to testify in the trial of 11 people charged with smuggling Central American nationals into the United States.

title: THE CHANGE IN KOCH
description: Three days ago, Mayor Koch did something he had not done since last September: he held a meeting with the heads of all city agencies.

title: YOUNG FARMER WINS CHANCE TO STRUGGLE ON
description: In the momentary hush that falls over a livestock auction ring when the bidding stops, even the faint barnyard odor hanging in the air seems a little heavier, the bawling of nearby cattle a little louder.

title: SUITS AGAINST MINOLTA SEEN
description: The states of New York and Maryland are expected to file suit today against the Minolta Corporation and several retailers charging a conspiracy to fix prices on cameras.

title: TOP AIDES AT NASA WERE NOT ADVISED OF SHUTTLE CLUES
description: Some middle-level space agency officials and outside engineers apparently suspected within minutes of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger that the cause was faulty seals in a booster rocket, according to interviews with engineers and documents released by the agency.

title: NEWLYWEDS' APARTMENT HUNT: A TRYING START FOR A NEW LIFE
description: It was a marriage of romance and real estate, Aphrodite and apartments. The room was New York City's marriage license bureau, where conversations about wedding rings, caterers and invitations mingled with talk of down payments, finder's fees and 3 Rms. w/EIK.

title: INDONESIAN AIRLINE GETS NEW IMAGE
description: An old bird with a new look is trying to make its presence felt in world aviation. The Indonesian national airline, Garuda, got a new president 14 months ago. Since then almost everything has changed for the once-faltering airline, named for the mythical winged creature that transported the Hindu god-king Arjuna.

title: PANEL SEES WAY FOR AGED TO USE EQUITY IN HOMES
description: A commission set up by Governor Cuomo to study the problems of the aging has recommended legislation to make it easier for the elderly to draw an income from equity in their homes without actually selling them.

title: SAKHAROV'S STATUS: CAN HE BE NEXT?
description: The release of the Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky has moved supporters of another dissident, the physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, to speculate on whether he might also be freed.

title: CROWDS CELEBRATE DEPARTURE OF A LEADER WHO HASN'T LEFT
description: Throughout the capital this morning, people celebrated what they thought was the end of Ferdinand E. Marcos's rule.

title: RANGERS: TREADING WATER ON ICE
description: PIERRE Larouche and Barry Beck appeared in the line of Rangers filing onto the ice, and the Garden throbbed unmistakably for them. When the Garden throbs, it must be that some high voltage is given out because the colors seem brighter, and underneath the yelling and screaming, a hum can be heard, or imagined. It is the fans' way of embracing not just the Rangers but one another, a kind of shared recognition of their still-beating affection for an oft-troubled team.

title: VW Buys 51% Of Car Maker
description: Volkswagen A.G., West Germany's largest auto maker, said Friday that it was acquiring a majority share in the Government-owned SEAT car company of Spain.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REALITY OF MAKE-BELIEVE What is the process that turns an idea into a script that requires staging, costumes, lights and sets? The answer is to be found in ''Collaborations in the Theater,'' a series of six seminars - produced by the Alliance of Resident Theaters/ New York - in which the creative side of theater production is analyzed.

title: 15 on Picnic Drown in India
description: A boat capsized in a river today, drowning 12 schoolgirls and three teachers on a picnic outing, the Press Trust of India reported. The mishap occurred on the Meshva River near a dam in Gujarat State, 400 miles southwest of New Delhi, the news agency said. The cause of the accident was not immediately known.

title: COMRADES OF 60'S MARCHES COMPETE FOR ATLANTA'S CONGRESS SEAT
description: In the 1960's, when the movement for equal rights burned intensely across the South, John Lewis and Julian Bond worked side by side, helping to organize the protests and marches that were to reshape the region.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL HOMAGE TO WORKS OF JOHN CAGE
description: THIS listener once attended an amusement park sideshow devoted to the life and adventures of Elsie the Cow. The gentle beast, by then quite advanced in age, sat placidly upon the stage, eyeing the audience with serene detachment. An announcer's voice described Elsie's past travels throughout the world while papier-mache images of London, Paris and the Far East were assembled and dismantled around her. Except for an occasional twitch of the tail, Elsie never moved.

title: ENVOY REPORTS TO REAGAN ON TRIP
description: President Reagan threatened President Ferdinand E. Marcos today with an immediate cutoff of American military aid unless he avoided the use of force against Filipinos calling for his resignation.

title: DANCE: ELEO POMARE TROUPE ON MANDELA THEME
description: ELEO POMARE has a painter's eye and a gift for evocation in choreography that suggests a narrative, through a delicate blending of pure or abstract movement and the theatrical. His new ''Morning Without Sunrise,'' performed by the Eleo Pomare Dance Company on Saturday night at the Triplex Theater, speaks stirringly to age-old themes and the morning news.

title: MANY CALIFORNIANS GO HOME AS FLOODING SUBSIDES
description: More than half the 24,000 residents near the storm-swollen Yuba River who were forced to flee four days ago returned home today in sunshine to begin the task of cleaning out the mud.

title: 'MOVIEMAKERS,' ON PBS PROFILES DAVID SELZNICK
description: ''DAVID O. SELZNICK, A HOLLYWOOD LEGEND,'' the title of tonight's episode of ''The Moviemakers,'' conveys the gushy spirit of this Canadian series, which has been appearing on Channel 13 at 7 P.M. on Mondays. In the course of the half-hour of interviews and clips from movies such as ''King Kong'' and ''Duel in the Sun,'' the host, Elwy Yost, calls Mr. Selznick ''a giant among giants'' and ''Gone With the Wind'' ''the most beloved movie of all time.''

title: FOR EWING, A LONG SEASON OF PAIN AND FRUSTRATION
description: THIS short exchange between Rory Sparrow and Patrick Ewing was overheard before one of the Knicks' recent practices:

title: Market Place; High Yields And Bond Calls
description: IN the fixed-income market, falling interest rates have been a bonanza for speculators who chose to cash in their profits on bonds purchased last year. Similarly, the sharp drop in bond yields and the rise in bond prices have delighted many local governments and corporations that are now able to refinance outstanding bonds sold when interest rates were much higher. This allows the issuers to reduce interest expenses.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: DEFICIT LAW LACKS PRIORITIES, U.S. GOVERNORS TELL SENATOR
description: Some of the nation's governors meeting here today expressed concern that the Federal deficit reduction act would lead to neglect of critical social needs while allowing some nonessential programs to continue.

title: Brock Comment on World Bank
description: With A. W. Clausen leaving his position as head of the World Bank, some speculation about a possible successor is focusing on Labor Secretary Bill Brock, the Tennessee Republican who has served in both houses of Congress and as the trade representative for President Reagan.

title: STIFFER RULES FOR NURSING HOMES PROPOSED IN U.S.-SPONSORED STUDY
description: A new study by the National Academy of Sciences calls for much stronger Federal regulation of nursing homes and emphatically opposes efforts by the Reagan Administration to reduce such regulation.

title: Pottery Barn's Future
description: Gap Inc. said Friday that it is considering the sale of its Pottery Barn unit. Gap, which bought Pottery Barn in 1984, said the unit had been unprofitable. The company did not disclose the asking price, but a source who declined to be identified said it was between $5 million and $7 million.

title: WHAT TEEN-AGE SILENCE IS SAYING
description: IT'S called the silent treatment, the adolescent cold shoulder, the ''Keep Out - and This Means You, Mom and Dad'' syndrome. Its symptoms are unmistakable: One-word answers to a parent's questions; glares in response to parental comments on dress or decorum; doors barred against prying parental eyes; silence on subjects the adolescent invariably discusses with friends.

title: BRINGING MOVIES TO THE VIDEO SCREEN
description: As the credits unroll at the end of a movie nowadays, there may be a new job title somewhere between chief grip and makeup assistant. It's the ''video adviser,'' whose job is to make sure the film can be transferred to video cassettes.

title: New York City Housing Authority Could Aid Homeless Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Hallmark's I.R.S. Valentine
description: The Internal Revenue Service is trying to collect $11 million from Hallmark Cards Inc. in a new dispute over how the Kansas City-based company accounts for its Valentine's Day business.

title: GRAY SETS 1,000-YARD MARK
description: Johnny Gray's long, graceful strides carried him to a world indoor best of 2 minutes 4.3 seconds in the 1,000-yard run today at the Michelob Invitational track meet.

title: Advertising; N.W. Ayer Realigning Top Levels
description: LOUIS T. HAGOPIAN, chairman and chief executive officer of N. W. Ayer, has restructured some of his top management to free himself to do a bit of acquiring not only of general agencies but also, more important, of specialty communications companies.

title: THE DANCE: YUNI HOFFMAN
description: ODDITY alone is not enough.

title: WHETHER COUNSEL OR COUNSELOR, IT'S A KEY ROLE
description: ''There is no blueprint for the job,'' said Clark Clifford, who served as special counsel to President Truman.

title: HIGHER SIGHTS FOR MUSEUM
description: What's billed as the busiest museum in the world, the National Air and Space Museum, is getting ever busier. And now it seems likely to get a little bigger, too.

title: PLAN FOR SCHOMBURG CENTER DISPLAYED
description: Mayor Koch and New York Public Library officials presented plans yesterday to renovate the original site of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, a landmark Harlem building on 135th Street.

title: CONGRESS LOOKS AT LIABILITY INSURERS
description: In the face of soaring costs and increasing scarcity of liability insurance, Congress is under pressure to impose Federal regulation on the insurance industry for the first time, a move that the industry strongly opposes.

title: 'CROSSINGS,' MINI-SERIES STARRING CHERYL LADD
description: HELLOS and goodbyes -they are the stuff of ''Crossings,'' the six-hour mini-series that reaches the second of its three parts tonight at 9 on ABC. Using World War II as a backdrop, the adaptation of a Danielle Steel novel lurches from departures to reunions with almost giddy abandon. There are enough tears to cheer eyedrop producers everywhere.

title: SYRACUSE BEATS HOYAS BY 64-63
description: For about 35 minutes this afternoon, Syracuse, a unanimous pre-season pick to win the Big East championship, played as if it had indeed blossomed into an undisputed champion. The Orange was giving Georgetown one of its worst thrashings in years, slashing through the vaunted Hoya defense as if it didn't exist and maintaining leads of 10 to 18 points for much of the game.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE. By Alec Guinness. Illustrated. 238 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: EXTRADITION DUE IN WAR CRIME CASE
description: The Justice Department is preparing to extradite a 65-year-old man to Israel to stand trial on charges of murdering thousands of Jews at a death camp in Poland in World War II.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 24, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Committee on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHALLENGE TO MARCOS: A CROWD PROTECTS THE INSURGENTS
description: Before the dawn assault by riot troops, the armies of the night, Philippine-style, squared off against the real soldiers, a brief encounter Sunday that ended without a single shot and barely an angry word.

title: A MEETING OF THE MINDS: YOUNG AND NOT SO YOUNG
description: The old people - Jack Light, Bill McCulloh, Mary Flatley and nine other women and men - sat in a circle. One was in a wheelchair, and several leaned on canes or walkers.

title: Guard Is Shot in Attack At Oklahoma Atom Plant
description: A security guard was wounded by gunfire before dawn today at the Sequoyah Fuels Corporation's uranium processing plant, the site of a toxic leak that killed one worker and sent more than 100 people to hospitals Jan. 4, officials said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch in The Home Section on Thursday from London, Ontario, about a court award of $11,350 (Canadian) in support payments to a man who cooked, cleaned and cared for three children while his wife worked, mistranslated the currency. The figure is about $8,170 (U.S.).

title: Bridge: At New York Tournament, A Deal That Is 'Not Quite'
description: The most social event in the tournament calendar of the Greater New York Bridge Association was played Saturday night at a new site - the Halloran House, at 525 Lexington Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets.

title: Briefcases
description: * Stephen E. Bell, staff director for the Senate Budget Committee for the last five years, is leaving next month to open a Washington office for Salomon Brothers, the New York investment house.

title: LOWLY CLIPPERS DEFEAT KNICKS, 110-99
description: Hubie Brown likes to say that in order for his injury-depleted team to win, it must play the ''perfect game,'' the way he diagrams it on the chalk board in the hours before tipoff every night. But it is a rare night when those circles, lines and arrows become reality.

title: PART OF STATEMENT BY WHITE HOUSE
description: Following is an excerpt from a statement by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The United States provides military assistance to the Philippine armed forces in order to strengthen its ability to protect the security of the Philippines, particularly against a serious threat posed by growing Communist insurgency.

title: ON DESERVING MORE RESPECT
description: RON DARLING took his salary dispute with the Mets to arbitration and lost. Don Baylor's trade-clause dispute never got to arbitration because the Yankees withdrew their grievance, but so far he's losing too.

title: FMC ACTS TO RAISE SHARE PRICE
description: The FMC Corporation, a military contractor and chemical and machinery company, announced today that its board had approved a recapitalization plan that would give public shareholders $70 in cash and one new common share for each share owned.

title: Iraqis Report Retaking An Important Junction
description: Iraqi forces fighting to retake the southern tip of the Fao peninsula from occupying Iranian troops recaptured an important communications junction today, the official Iraqi press agency reported.

title: ISSUES ARISE IN FRAUD CASE
description: The first inkling Mrs. Angelo Gory had that Leslie Roberts, her great-nephew, was ''a conniver, a charming conniver,'' was when she found out that his straight-A's college report card was phony. She said he had actually dropped out of college a semester earlier.

title: Children, Electricity And TV Advertising
description: Outside of pussy cats, puppy dogs and guppies, few things are as heartwarming as young children.

title: Frazier Winner On a Decision
description: Marvis Frazier rebounded from a fifth-round knockdown to record a unanimous 10-round decision over James (Bonecrusher) Smith in a heavyweight bout today.

title: Canadian Inflation Data
description: Federal tax increases and bad weather in the United States were largely responsible for keeping the annual inflation rate in January at the 20-month high of 4.4 percent set in December, the Government's Statistics Canada said Friday. But economists noted that the annual rate of price increases measured over the previous three months, considered a better measure of current inflation, was 6.4 percent, up from 5.3 percent in December.

title: RECORD NUMBER OF CONVICTS ARE ON PROBATION
description: One of every 35 adult men in the United States is on probation, under parole supervision or imprisoned, and offenders under community supervision now outnumber those who are behind bars by a 3-to-1 margin, a Bureau of Justice Statistics study said today.

title: Leaking Barge Drained of Oil
description: A barge leaking oil in the Connecticut River was drained of its remaining cargo Sunday and released from port after workers recovered about 50 of nearly 700 gallons spilled, a Coast Guard official said. The leak was reported about 6:30 P.M. Saturday by the pilot of a private plane who noticed a trail of oil behind the barge as it ended a trip here from Bayonne, N.J. The barge had been carrying about 550,000 gallons of oil in 10 compartments.

title: THE SLEUTH OF BASEBALL
description: ''NO,'' Bill Haber was saying, ''I've never been in a cemetery looking for a missing ball- player. But I deal with cemeteries frequently.''

title: FRANKFURT STOCK RISE IGNORED
description: This city's stock exchange, amid rising corporate profits and overall economic growth in West Germany, was one of the biggest movers among the world's stock markets last year. But such a performance has done little to enhance the status of stock trading among German financiers or the investing public.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP ACCORD ENDS A DECADE OF STRIFE
description: Nearly a decade of unrest in the tomato and cucumber fields of Ohio and Michigan has ended with the signing of a novel labor contract by a migrant farm workers' union, a group of vegetable growers and the Campbell Soup Company.

title: JERSEY EFFORT TO OPEN SUBURBS TO URBAN POOR HAS SETBACKS
description: A landmark State Supreme Court ruling aimed at reducing exclusionary zoning in New Jersey has suffered setbacks through recent political and demographic developments.

title: CHALLENGE TO MARCOS: CHURCH'S VOICE IS ATTACKED
description: The Roman Catholic Church's Radio Veritas fell silent tonight after saboteurs destroyed its major transmitters and station technicians shut down a weaker backup system for repairs.

title: FEW ENTERING LOCAL SCHOOL BOARD RACES
description: With less than a week remaining for the filing of qualifying petitions for school board elections in May, Board of Education officials say they are disturbed by the lack of candidates in several of New York City's 32 local school districts.

title: A.M.C. Lost $6.7 Million
description: The American Motors Corporation said Friday that it lost $6.7 million in the final quarter of 1985, bringing its loss for the year to $125.3 million.

title: STAGE: 'IDIOT'S DELIGHT,' AT THE KENNEDY CENTER
description: No one can accuse the director Peter Sellars of defacing a classic in his outlandish new production of ''Idiot's Delight.'' Robert E. Sherwood's brooding isolationist comedy, a popular vehicle for the Lunts in 1936, was already naive and dated by the time the Nazis invaded Poland in 1939. If there's now to be a ''50th anniversary'' celebration of the play - which is the aspiration of this American National Theater revival at the Kennedy Center - directorial tinkering, if not wholesale rethinking, is an absolute essential. Only an idiot would stage ''Idiot's Delight'' by the book in 1986.

title: A Novel Idea
description: As part of his campaign to be elected House Democratic whip next year, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan has proposed what many lawmakers had believed to be not just unpolitic but unthinkable: a five-day workweek for Congress. In a three-page letter to Democratic colleagues, Mr. Rangel limited the plan, however, to ''those portions of the year when legislation is ready for action.''

title: Farm Credit Unit Has Loss
description: The Farm Credit System's Omaha district, seriously affected by falling land values and troubled loans, lost more than $509 million last year, officials said Friday.

title: ARCHITECTURE: DRAWING BY RUDOLPH ON VIEW
description: OFTEN stereotyped as minimal and cold, modern architecture in fact has a long tradition of complex, expressive buildings rich in historical associations. An architect like Paul Rudolph, for example - former head of the Yale Architecture School and one of the deans of American architecture - has designed buildings and spaces that are baroque in their sweep and drama, and almost sensual for the sheer pleasure of their curved, intricately joined forms and textured materials.

title: ANTI-MARCOS DEMONSTRATORS RALLY AT 2 CONSULATES IN U.S.   By United Press International
description: Demonstrators in San Francisco and Seattle marched on Philippine consulates last night, mutilating pictures of President Ferdinand E. Marcos and calling for an end to his 20-year rule.

title: RENT STRIKE SET ON ROOSEVELT I. AS TRAM PROTEST
description: Roosevelt Island residents voted last night to begin a rent strike as part of their effort to spur the state to restore tram service between the island and Manhattan.

title: Hawaii Volcano Is Active
description: The Kilauea volcano dazzled scientists and spectators today, rocketing lava geysers 1,200 feet into Hawaii Island's skies. The volcano started the 42d major phase of its three-year-long eruption at 3:15 P.M. Saturday after intermittent spurts in the morning, said scientists at the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory. At 2:33 A.M., the lava fountain suddenly shot to double its previous height, flaring from 600 feet to 1,200 feet above the vent for a minute or two, an observatory spokesman said.

title: A Change of Pace
description: There is a world of difference, most horsemen will tell you, between the world of thoroughbred racing and the world of standardbred racing. So much difference, in fact, that the two worlds rarely overlap.

title: Execution for Military Spies
description: Members of the armed forces convicted of espionage in peacetime could be executed under a directive signed Wednesday by President Reagan. The new directive, which formally incorporates the death penalty into military law, takes effect March 1. Congress authorized the change last summer after the arrest of four men involved in a Navy spy case.

title: BANKERS EXPECT MEXICAN DEBT PLEA
description: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico has provided the clearest indication yet that his country will want concessions from its lenders to service its nearly $100 billion in foreign debt, international bankers said yesterday. One banker predicted that Mr. de la Madrid would soon move to limit debt repayments unilaterally to a fraction of Mexico's export earnings, as Peru and Nigeria have done.

title: NEW RULE UNFAIR TO ATHLETES?
description: Colleges with major athletic programs have drawn criticism, often from young athletes who look beyond college to lucrative careers in professional sports, for the decision to require that new student athletes earn minimum scores on college-entrance tests.

title: ROUTE SALE LIKELY IN TEXAS AIR DEAL
description: Antitrust lawyers and Wall Street analysts said today that to win Government approval of its acquisition of Eastern Airlines, the Texas Air Corporation would have to sell either the Eastern or New York Air shuttle routes between New York, Washington and Boston.

title: K-V PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: FOSTER WHEELER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision of $11 million for reduction in the value of two plants.

title: A Namesake of Same Name
description: King County officially designated its namesake to be the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., instead of a slave owner whose name it has borne for 134 years. The King County Council voted 5 to 4 to end its association with William Rufus De Vane King, who was elected in 1852 as Vice President under Franklin Pierce and died before he could take the oath of office. A historian, Sol Barzman, once said of him: ''Of all the inglorious and unknown vice presidents, the 13th must surely lead the list.''

title: NOT BITTER ON PAY, PHIL NIEKRO SAYS
description: Of the 24 pitchers who won 16 games or more in the major leagues last season, one hasn't signed and 22 will earn an average of $880,523 this year. Phil Niekro won 16 games for the Yankees last season, and he will earn $350,000 if he is on the opening-day roster.

title: IN THE VIDEO LAMPLIGHT, A PRESIDENT CARRIES ON
description: Twice in the last two harrowing nights, the rebels thought they had cornered Ferdinand E. Marcos. But twice he nimbly survived, clinging to his gold-tipped executive throne and uttering rambling lawyer's monologues about the orderliness he claimed to see all about him.

title: U.S.-Turkish Defense Talks
description: Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard Perle of the United States met Turkish officials today to discuss defense and industry cooperation and American aid for the modernization of Turkish military equipment. He and Gen. Necip Torumtay, Turkish deputy chief of staff, were head of their respective sides.

title: OPERATING HEAD CHOSEN AT AMC ENTERTAINMENT
description: AMC Entertainment Inc., the nation's third-largest chain of movie houses, yesterday named Ron D. Leslie president and chief operating officer.

title: SUITS AGAINST MINOLTA FILED
description: The Minolta Corporation and 36 Maryland retailers were accused today of conspiring to set unusually high prices on two 35mm cameras that have both automatic focusing and interchangeable lenses.

title: SHUTTLE CRASH: WHERE CLUES HAVE LED SO FAR
description: JUST four weeks after history's worst space disaster, much is already known about the events and circumstances preceding the space shuttle Challenger's explosive end. Suspect components, cold weather and some apparent lapses in human judgment all seem to be implicated.

title: BANKAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $13,629,000, or $1,74 a share, for the quarter and 6 months, and a past-due income of $1,866,000, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including a gain of $896,000, or 12 cents a shares, on sales of investments.

TRANS-INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $43,424 for the quarter, and a loss from discontinued operations of $368,519 for the year. c-Net loss. d-Including a loss from discontinued operations of $114,674 for the quarter and $418,365 for the year.

title: U.S. HAD WARNINGS OF MANILA REVOLT
description: White House officials said today that, based on United States intelligence reports, the Administration had reason to believe as early as last Thursday that a potential revolt by some Philippine military officers was in the works.

title: COURTS CHIEF CHALLENGES SANTUCCI ON CHARGE OF JUDICIAL INTERFERENCE
description: The state's chief administrative judge demanded yesterday that District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens explain his charge last weekend that at least one judge in Queens impeded an investigation of Donald R. Manes two years ago.

title: HEALTH CLUB CHAIN IN MINNESOTA IS FINED $300 A DAY IN BIAS CASE
description: A county judge today ordered a chain of fitness clubs to pay fines of $300 a day until it agreed to change hiring policies that explicitly favor fundamentalist Christians.

title: KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HANSON TRUST SEEKING CARBIDE CONSUMER UNITS
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., a British company with a yearning for brand-name products, yesterday identified itself as one of the bidders for the consumer products businesses put up for sale by the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: WILAND SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax credit of $322,000.

title: BELAFONTE WEIGHS SENATE RUN
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Democratic leader of Manhattan, said today that he expected Harry Belafonte, the actor and singer, to decide within the next two weeks whether to challenge the Republican Alfonse M. D'Amato for his United States Senate seat this year.

title: KOCH CONCEDES HIS TIES TO PARTY WERE TOO CLOSE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had become too close to Democratic party leaders and, in pursuit of political support to resolve the city's fiscal problems more than eight years ago, had allowed them to exercise ''undue influence'' over city government.

title: MASCO OFFERING
description: The Masco Corporation, a producer of building and home improvement products, is offering $200 million of 8 3/4 percent, 10-year notes at 99.344, to yield 8.85 percent, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The notes, rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P., yield 51-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities of similar maturity.

title: BIG EAST'S FOUR SEASONS
description: Once upon a time, the college basketball season flowed into the post-season national tournments the way a river flows into an ocean. Smoothly, easily. But nowhere near as theatrically as now. In looking to tomorrow night's Big East showdown between St. John's and Syracuse at Madison Square Garden, Lou Carnesecca mentioned how teams now must cope with the struggle of four seasons in one, like the locks of a canal.

title: AQUANAUTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $50,928 for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $227,317 for the quarter and $181,088 for the six months.

title: MIDCON UNIT SOLD TO ARKLA
description: The Midcon Corporation, a diversified pipeline and energy company, said that it had agreed to sell its subsidiary, the Mississippi River Transmission Corporation, to Arkla Inc. for about $305 million. The Occidental Petroleum

title: INFOTRON SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOW TV STUDIO FELL TO REBELS, CUTTING OFF MARCOS AND GIVING VOICE TO FOES
description: Just as President Ferdinand E. Marcos went on the Government-run television station this morning to announce ''we are in control of the situation,'' a contingent of 130 soldiers opposed to his rule burst into the television studio.

title: REAGAN OFFERS MARCOS POSSIBLE EXILE IF HE LEAVES THE PHILIPPINES PROMPTLY
description: The Reagan Administration has dangled the possibility of safe haven in the United States before President Ferdinand E. Marcos if he agrees to leave the Philippines promptly, Administration officials said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 'LESS IS MORE'

title: CHANGE OF IMAGE IN 'COLD AND DISTANT OUTPOST'
description: For 136 years there has been a University of Rochester. The university's endowment is among the the 10 largest in the country. It has the largest music literature collection among music schools in the Western Hemisphere. Its optics and laser programs are pioneers in their fields. Its political science department and medical school rank near the top in national academic surveys.

title: 'APARTHEID'S PEOPLE,' 4 REPORTS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: ''APARTHEID'S PEOPLE'' is a rebroadcast, but nonethe less valuable for that. Actually, it works better the second time around. It was originally four separate reports on the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' last fall, but joined together in a one-hour program, there is a cumulative effect. The program, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, says something important about South Africa.

title: LEVI STRAUSS REPORTS LOSS
description: Levi Strauss Associates reported a loss of $114 million for the fourth quarter, primarily because of interest and asset adjustments relating to the leveraged buyout of Levi Strauss & Company last August.

title: Pact to Preserve Area Of Old Forest in Maine
description: The Nature Conservancy, the leading private land conservation group in Maine, announced here Saturday an agreement to acquire several thousand acres of old-growth forest in the northern part of the state.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Bruce Kison, pitcher, announced his retirement.

PRODIGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: LUBRIZOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRICES OF BONDS UP SHARPLY
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, after the Federal Reserve arranged a temporary purchase of securities that some market participants said was an early sign of an easing in monetary policy.

title: ADMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago net income and share earnings results are not available since the company completed its initial public offering in November.

title: COST OF BENEFITS IN ACQUISITIONS
description: EXECUTIVES negotiating megamergers often go down to the wire without looking hard at employee health benefits, an oversight that could cut into the value of a major purchase by tens of millions of dollars.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Saturday about the Board of Estimate's approval of a plan to establish a Navy base at Staten Island incorrectly described the resolution and misidentified a city official who gave details of the proposal. The board voted to support the plan and authorized an appraisal of the property to help determine the sale price; it did not vote to transfer the property to the Navy. The official is John C. Biggins, interim commissioner of the Department of Ports and Terminals.

title: WEST EUROPE COOL TO REMOVAL OF U.S. MEDIUM-RANGE MISSILES
description: Washington's consultations on a response to the Moscow proposal to eliminate nuclear arms by the year 2000 have disclosed a decline in Western European enthusiasm for a reduction of American medium-range missiles, according to officials in several capitals.

title: A MELLOW CONNORS IS STILL THE FIGHTER
description: Jimmy Connors had reached his breaking point and was now striding purposefully to the interview tent, eager to discuss the indignity he felt he had suffered at the hands of the chair umpire. Following in his father's footsteps was 6-year-old Brett Connors, who was assigned the important task of holding daddy's racquets. The interaction between father and son was a brief glimpse of Connors's playing a role other than that of a tennis player. In part, it may explain the popularity he now enjoys with the fans in the latter stages of his career.

title: ICM PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There are no year-ago results because the company completed its initial public offering Jan. 31, 1985. Results for the latest year represent an 11-month period.

title: No Headline
description: Why Not Help Young Women in Time?

title: CITY RESERVOIR LEVELS RISE TO ABOVE NORMAL
description: Water levels in New York City's reservoirs were higher than normal yesterday for the first time since July 1984. During last year's drought, the reservoirs dropped to 44 percent of capacity.

title: SNAPPLE JUICE ACCOUNT TO ROSENFELD, SIROWITZ
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey has become the first agency for the Snapple line of natural fruit juices and soft drinks produced by Unadulterated Food Products of Ridgewood, N.J. The work was previously done in-house.

title: AIDS Can Be Transmitted by Both Sexes
description: To the Editor:

title: WELLS AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writedown of $1,377,967. c-Include a pre-tax writedown of $2,502,133 related to a discontinued product line and equipment in closed facilities for the quarter and 9 months.

title: A FILM MAKER DOCUMENTS THE HUEY LONG ERA
description: Few politicians have so fired the American imagination as Huey Long - the leader of Depression-era Louisiana, the man deemed populist or demagogue, hero or dictator, and rarely anything temperate or in-between.

title: 21 Killed at Festival in China
description: Twenty-one people were trampled to death and 9 others injured at a lantern festival in the eastern province of Jiangsu when a crowd pressed forward to see the lanterns, an official newspaper said. The Sunday edition of the Shanghai Evening News reported that 100,000 people were at the festival Friday night when the accident occurred.

title: Newspaper Editor in Soviet To Head Publishing Industry
description: A Soviet editor whose newspaper has been at the front of an officially inspired campaign for more openness in public life was promoted today to run the publishing industry.

title: DAYS OF DECISION: AS OPTIONS NARROW, U.S. MOVES AGAINST AN 'OLD FRIEND'
description: Administration officials are wondering whether President Reagan's call for President Ferdinand E. Marcos to resign has come too late to forestall a blood bath in the Philippines.

title: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1986
description: International

title: REBELS INAUGURATE AQUINO AS PRESIDENT
description: As far as Corazon C. Aquino was concerned, this was the day she took office and Ferdinand E. Marcos became the rebel.

title: CONCERT: GEWANDHAUS AND MASUR IN BRAHMS
description: KURT MASUR and the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig opened their Brahms cycle at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday evening with broad, severely proportioned and rich-hued performances of the first two symphonies. From the first sounds spoke commitment: the strings surging and full-bodied, the insistent timpani good and strong, the brass a restrained but brooding Gibraltar-like presence.

title: SAVANNAH ELECTRIC & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OIL SLUMP DELAYS 'BAKER PLAN'
description: More than four months ago, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d proposed a new way for the rich countries to help the poor countries cope with their huge debts. It was a program, analysts said then, that offered the least possible pain to all.

title: LOW TURNOUT PREDICTED TODAY IN SCANDAL-WEARY SAN DIEGO
description: The San Diego City Clerk is predicting a voter turnout of only 25 percent to 28 percent for the special mayoral primary here Tuesday, a fact that alone may tell the tale of the race to succeed Roger Hedgecock.

title: GERBER FOODS SUES MARYLAND IN GLASS CONTAMINATION BAN
description: The Gerber Products Company filed a $150 million lawsuit today charging Maryland officials with creating a ''climate of fear and confusion'' by banning the sale of Gerber strained peaches after consumer reports of glass contamination.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Arthur Young, the accounting and consulting firm, has named Sandra K. Johnigan chairman of its National Real Estate Group.

title: HOPI LEADER PURIFIES NEW MEXICO DIG
description: A Hopi religious leader today performed ceremonies to purify a site on the city's west side where some of his ancestors lived about 750 years ago.

title: 'OOPS' IS NORMAL IN VAULTING
description: Indoor track in the United States, Sergei Bubka complained, is a three-ring circus.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 100 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 3.

title: MANY TROUBLESOME YEARS
description: The decision by Eastern Airlines to accept a takeover offer by the Texas Air Corporation was preceded by many troublesome years for the company. These are among some of the important developments that led to the decision:

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT DRAWS FIRE ON E.P.A. INQUIRY
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee and other Democrats say they are growing annoyed that the Justice Department has not begun an independent investigation of three-year-old charges that department officials lied to Congress when they spoke of wrongdoing at the Environmental Protection Agency.

WEST SIDE MAN SEIZED IN KILLING OF AN INFANT GIRL
description: A 19-year-old Upper West Side man has been arrested on a homicide charge and accused of causing the death two weeks ago, by violent shaking, of the infant daughter of a woman with whom he had been living.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Tuba City, Ariz., on Jan. 20 about the translation of the Bible into Navajo mischaracterized the achievement. It was the first translation of the complete Bible into an American Indian language in this century, according to the American Bible Society, which published the new translation. Previously the complete Bible was translated into Algonkian in 1663, Plains Cree in 1861, and Dakota in 1879.

title: U.N. SECURITY COUNCIL ASKS TRUCE IN THE WAR BETWEEN IRAN IRAQ
description: The Security Council unanimously passed a resolution today calling for an immediate cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war and for a troop withdrawal to internationally recognized borders.

title: Chess: Yusupov Takes Series, 6-3, In Semifinal for World Title
description: The Soviet grandmaster Artur Yusupov has won his semifinal world championship candidates match with the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman in Tilburg, the Netherlands. Yusupov piled up a 6-3 score and thus made it unnecessary to play the last game of the series.

description: The Supreme Court left intact today Texas's so-called ''no pass, no play'' law that has sidelined high school athletes and silenced band musicians with failing grades.

description: The Supreme Court today cleared the way for the extradition of John Demjanjuk to Israel, which has accused him of murdering Jews and others as a Nazi death camp guard in World War II. He could face the death penalty if convicted.

title: WINDOWS ARE OPEN AT LAST
description: PROBABLY no category of software has had as difficult a birth as that of operating environments. These software packages, which permit the user to run a number of different programs on one computer at the same time, have suffered tremendously delayed releases.

title: DIGITAL PRODUCTS
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation announced products and services that it said would solidify its lead in enabling computers from different vendors to communicate. title: 3 TUMULTUOUS DAYS: KEY EVENTS SINCE THE SEIZING OF THE DEFENSE MINISTRY
description: The latest turn in the crisis in the Philippines started Saturday night in Manila, which is 13 hours ahead of Eastern standard time. Here are the key events, in Manila time, since the trouble began. Saturday night - Two top Government aides quit their posts and take over the Defense Ministry at Camp Aguinaldo. At a news conference, they demand the resignation of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, accusing him of stealing the election Feb. 7 and abusing his powers for years. The two, Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, and the Deputy Chief of Staff of the armed forces, Lieut. Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, are joined by military units as well as thousands of civilians who surround the Defense Ministry and a nearby constabulary post, Camp Crame. The mass of people forms a shield for the rebels, bringing about a standoff.

title: DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
When the Peace Corps Was Young
description: My record was so bad that I was first rejected by the Peace Corps as a poor risk and possible troublemaker and was accepted as a volunteer only after a great deal of explaining and arguing. The alternative was Vietnam - this was 1963, and President John F. Kennedy was still muddling dangerously along. I was sent to Nyasaland; soon it became Malawi. And then a month before my two-year stint was over, I was ''terminated'' - kicked out -fined arbitrarily for three months' ''unsatisfactory service'' and given hell by the Peace Corps officials in Washington.

title: RAYTHEON AWARD
description: The Raytheon Corporation was awarded a $895.6 million Army contract modification for 770 Patriot missiles, 15 sets of ground support equipment and spares, the Pentagon said. It said work is expected to be completed by February 1992.

title: The Power of an Idea
description: Revolution has many causes, deeply rooted in time, place, passion and economics. When ripe, as in the Philippines, it bursts out with incredible speed and produces the oddest scripts. Suddenly, in Manila, a Harvard-trained lawyer made rich by the embattled dictator and a West Point graduate who only last week hoped to be chief of staff have embraced an avenging widow's claim to the presidency and summoned a human barricade to resist the dictator's cannon.

title: MUSIC: BYCHKOV CONDUCTS BUFFALO PHILHARMONIC
description: ONCE in a very long time, the critic is privileged to attend a musical event tinged with greatness. The Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra's Sunday night concert at Carnegie Hall was one of those occasions, thanks in large part to the contribution of the orchestra's conductor, Semyon Bychkov.

title: WHY RELEASE WAS EARLY
description: President Reagan's statement on President Ferdinand E. Marcos was issued at about 5 A.M. Eastern standard time today because the White House wanted it to influence what it saw was a rapidly deteriorating situation and defuse the violence in the Philippines, which is 13 hours ahead. There were fears that troops supporting Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the chief of staff of the armed services, would move against rebel troops and civilians around Camp Crame, where the anti-Marcos soldiers had established a command headquarters.

title: MERRILL ALTERS WAY BROKERS ARE PAID
description: Merrill Lynch & Company informed its 10,600 retail brokers yesterday of a sweeping new compensation schedule aimed at giving the nation's largest brokerage firm a stronger presence in banklike services.

title: TOY MANUFACTURER POPULARIZED BINGO
description: Edwin S. Lowe, a toy manufacturer who popularized the game bingo, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years and also lived in Quogue, L.I.

title: SHORTER PRESEASON STUDIED BY OFFICIALS
description: Friday night, the Nets surprised the Los Angeles Lakers. The next morning, the Nets left on an 8:35 A.M. flight for Atlanta, where they were beaten by the Hawks by 29 points. After the game, Coach Dave Wohl, who had only 10 healthy players available, said, ''Fatigue set in.'' A game one night and an early flight the next morning is commonplace in the National Basketball Association, and every so often, a coach or a general manager will speak out against the rigors of the schedule.

title: BOEING PRESIDENT GETS CHIEF'S POST
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that Frank A. Shrontz, the company's president, had been named chief executive officer, effective April 28. Mr. Shrontz was named president and chief operating officer a year ago.

title: TOMORROW'S COMPUTER
description: IN 1979 the denizens of the computer science department at Carnegie-Mellon University gathered to gaze in wonder at a new toy, the infant Apple II computer. They felt inspired to make a prediction. By the mid-1980's, they proclaimed, every man will have ''his own powerful machine, far more powerful than today's microprocessors and equipped with such features as high-resolution color graphics.''

title: SAMUELSON HONORED
description: Joan Benoit Samuelson, the 1984 Olympic gold medalist in the marathon and the winner of the America's Marathon in Chicago last October, was named last night as recipient of the Sullivan Award, given to the country's top amateur athlete. Mrs. Samuelson, 28 years old, became only the seventh woman to receive the award in its 56-year history. She finished the Chicago marathon in 2 hours 21 minutes 21 seconds, the second-fastest marathon ever by a woman and 15 seconds slower than the mark set by Ingrid Kristiansen. The award, which was presented in Indianapolis, is given by the Amateur Athletic Union in honor of its founder and former president, James E. Sullivan.

They lost again, this time to the Washington Bullets, and in the aftermath, their dressing room nearly turned into a battle zone. Mike Gminski and Mickey Johnson exchanged angry shouts, and Johnson punched a hole in a blackboard, according to witnesses. Is trouble brewing? Not according to the Nets.

And Mary Lou Retton, who was back on the bars the day after arthroscopic surgery, won a gold medal shortly afterward at the Los Angeles Olympics.

title: ISLANDER MOVES
description: The Islanders, intent on completing player evaluations before the March 11 trading deadline, sent Ari Haanpaa and Mark Hamway to their minor league affiliate in Springfield of the American Hockey League and replaced them by recalling the right wing Alan Kerr and the center-right wing Bob Bassen. Haanpaa, the frequently injured Finnish rookie who recovered from a shoulder separation only to undergo an emergency appendectomy in December, had just 7 points in 18 games while Hamway had 16 points in 43 games. . . . The Devils sent the 19-year-old goaltender Craig Billington to his junior team, the Belleville Bulls of the Ontario Hockey League. The Devils also sent the center Pat Conacher to the Maine Mariners of the A.H.L.

The first was addressed to his political patron, President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who appointed him to the job.

title: Article 526486 -- No Title
description: A. Alfred Taubman, the entrepreneur and real estate developer, has offered $500 million for the Pulitzer Publishing Company, the family-owned communications empire built by the legendary Joseph Pulitzer that includes The St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SIEGE. The Saga of Israel and Zionism. By Conor Cruise O'Brien. Illustrated. 798 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95. THERE is no shortage of books about Israel; there is unlikely to be any shortage of them in years to come. But ''The Siege'' is one of the very few that one would confidently predict is going to prove of enduring interest. It has a combination of qualities that sets it apart from the great mass of writing on the subject; its distinction is of the kind that doesn't get overtaken by events.

title: Greatest Statesman, Greatest Politician or Both?
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBT RATINGS REDUCED FOR PHILLIPS PETROLEUM
description: Declining oil prices claimed another victim yesterday, when the Phillips Petroleum Company's short- and long-term debt ratings were reduced to speculative grade by Moody's Investors Services Inc.

title: DANCE: BENEFIT FEATURES BALLETS BY BALANCHINE
description: FOR the second successive year, the New York City Ballet has closed a season with a specially arranged performance to benefit the company's Dancers' Emergency Fund. Mostly a collection of excerpts, this year's edition on Sunday night at the State Theater nonetheless opened and closed fittingly with two complete ballets by George Balanchine.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Bach's 'St.John Passion' Given at Holy Trinity
description: New York's musical life thrives in more than just its concert halls. In the past few months the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street, has become an important venue for weekend presentations.

title: SMITH GROUNDED
description: Fans of the St. Louis Cardinals, accustomed to Ozzie Smith's backflips at the start and finish of each baseball season, will have to get along without the added entertainment.

title: SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income, including income from discontinued operations of $22,166,000.

title: EARNHARDT FINED
description: Dale Earnhardt was fined $5,000 yesterday and placed on probation for the rest of the 1986 Winston Cup season because of reckless driving at Sunday's Miller 400 in Richmond. Earnhardt was also required to put up a $10,000 bond that will be refunded if he satisfies the terms of his probation.

title: REV. DR. EUGENE SMITH
description: The Rev. Dr. Eugene Smith, a Methodist Church official who was the executive secretary of the United States Conference of the World Conference of Churches from 1964 to 1973, died last Thursday at the Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived in Closter, N.J.

title: Who Likes Whyche?
description: Representative Wyche Fowler Jr. of Georgia, seeking the Democratic nomination to oppose the state's first-term Republican Senator, Mack Mattingly, decided he had a name problem that needed to be corrected early in the campaign. He called in his television consultant, Frank Greer, and told him that Georgians like to call their politicians by their first name and that a lot of folks still weren't sure how to pronounce Wyche.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $101,000 for the quarter and $397,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $247,000.

title: LARGE SOVIET SATELLITE IS FALLING FROM ORBIT
description: A LARGE Soviet satellite, Cosmos 1714, is falling out of orbit and could plunge into the Earth's atmosphere Wednesday afternoon, the North American Aerospace Defense Commmand reported yesterday.

title: LODGE & SHIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT may be winter on the streets, but there are signs of spring in the stores. Warm-weather clothes have been arriving little by little, and people are beginning to buy them. Like birds feathering their nests, these early shoppers are getting ready for the arrival of spring. They're also giving the stores and the designers good indications of what people will really be wearing in the months to come.

title: TWO CHARGED IN U.S. FRAUD
description: A former engineer at the Northrop Corporation and the head of a California company have been charged with fraud in connection with subcontracts for the Air Force's Stealth program.

title: CLOCK-WATCHER
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, in his 17th season in the National Basketball Association, when asked to assess the meaning of his N.B.A. record of 1,304 games played: ''It means I've been out here too long.''

title: GAMMA BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NEWCOMER IS CHOICE FOR BLACK & DECKER JOB
description: Nolan D. Archibald, who joined the Black & Decker Corporation just five months ago, was recommended yesterday to be the company's chief executive officer. Laurence J. Farley, now chairman and chief executive officer of the nation's largest power tool maker, said he would relinquish the c.e.o. title in March and recommended that the company's directors replace him with Mr. Archibald.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b- Net income.

title: PAGE AMERICA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Music/Noted in Brief; Sathima Bea Benjamin Sings at Jazz Center
description: Sathima Bea Benjamin is a singleminded ballad singer. In her two sets Sunday at the Jazz Center of New York, the tempo never rose past a medium swing. Mrs. Benjamin treated the songs as languorous phrases floating above the beat, with carefully turned glides and curves and delicate shifts of timbre - a graceful, somber, pared-down approach.

title: U.S. TROOPS IN PHILIPPINES TOLD TO STAY AT 2 BASES
description: Commanders at two large United States military installations in the Philippines told military men and women today to stay on the bases through the country's political crisis.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock distribution effective last December.

title: ANALYSTS FAVOR CATERPILLAR
description: A YEAR ago, when the Caterpillar Tractor Company's stock was selling only a few points above its 10-year low of 28 3/8 set in December 1984, some Wall Street analysts expressed optimism over the company's prospects, despite the fact that the world's largest producer of earth-moving machinery and equipment had not shown a profit since 1981.

title: SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $2.4 million, or 20 cents a share, reflecting primarily a reduction in the value of certain gas properties owned by one of its subsidiaries.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Chamber Group Offers Haydn and Vivaldi
description: Haydn's Symphony No. 94 in G (''Surprise'') and Vivaldi's musical evocation of spring from his ''Four Seasons'' are not exactly unknown works. But the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered unfamiliar views of these thrice-familiar classics Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Costa Rican Delegation Has Talks in Nicaragua
description: An official Costa Rican delegation met here today with Nicaraguan officials to discuss ways of improving the supervision of their border. Officials said that no agreements were reached but that talks would continue.

title: EX-CITY LABOR OFFICIAL
description: Joseph M. Conlon, an assistant to the New York City Commissioner of Labor during the Wagner administration, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 76 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

ART OF THE IMPROBABLE: AN EAST VILLAGE EXHIBIT
description: Downtown came uptown last night to celebrate itself and its three most important enterprises: making art, dressing up and going out.

title: FATHER'S SLAYING PERPLEXES L.I. TOWN
description: There may have been warnings, but no one heard them. There may have been ways out, but no one saw them. And if there is a sure means to prevent such tragedies from happening again, no one can define it.

title: MORE PHILIPPINE DIPLOMATS QUIT MARCOS SIDE
description: Additional numbers of Philippine diplomats in key foreign and United States posts broke with the Marcos Government yesterday, declaring their support for opposition leaders and Corazon C. Aquino.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,135,000.

ISRAELIS EXPECT EFFORT BY HUSSEIN TO WOO WEST BANK PALESTINIANS
description: Senior Israeli officials said today that they expected King Hussein of Jordan to mount a major effort to mobilize support among the Palestinians of the occupied West Bank for his position on Middle East peace talks.

title: U.P.S. ENTERS TEXAS
description: The nationwide United Parcel Service picked up a package today that it has fought 20 years to deliver: a parcel shipped from one Texas city to another. United Parcel has long made interstate deliveries from other states into Texas. But Texas shipping companies had fought the company's entry into in-state service, basing their opposition on a 1931 state law requiring delivery companies to operate on regular schedules and regular routes.

title: Resharpening Mental Skills
description: A 28-year study of 4,000 people offers further evidence that adults lose mental skills as they they stop using them, but that these skills can be re-aquired.

title: LIBERTY IN MYRIAD FORMS
description: With the promotions surrounding the refurbished Statue of Liberty, one could get the idea that there is only one Liberty.

title: BROOKLYN PROMENADE COMPLEX URGED
description: Eighty-seven acres of largely underused piers and maritime buildings underneath the Brooklyn Heights Promenade should be turned into a sprawling complex of offices and housing centered on an international trade center, a consultant's report to the city and the Port Authority recommends.

title: DRAMA PRIZE GOES TO ANNE DEVLIN
description: The eighth annual Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, given to a woman who has written an outstanding work for the English-speaking theater, has been awarded to Anne Devlin, an Irish playwright. The $3,500 prize was presented to her last night by Janet Suzman, the British actress, at the Garrick Club in London.

title: Kate Simon to Speak At Authors' Series
description: The novelist Kate Simon, whose most recent book, ''A Wider World,'' was published this month, will speak on Feb. 26 at 5:30 P.M. at Marymount Manhattan College, 221 East 71st Street.

title: WEDCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a $500,000 writedown of machine tool inventory due to obsolescence relating to the merger of Wedco and Wadell Equipment Co. in March 1984, and, in the year, foreign currency translation losses of $992,000. c-Net income. d-Including a gain of $648,000 from foreign currency translations.

title: TALKS AIMED AT ZIMBABWE'S UNITY STALL
description: Talks aimed at unifying the political parties of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe and his arch rival, Joshua Nkomo, and ending four years of civil unrest have become stalled amid longstanding suspicions and animosities, according to Western diplomats, and human rights activists.

title: SEOUL EASES STAND AGAINST DISSIDENTS
description: In a sudden and unexplained shift, South Korea's President appeared today to retreat from a crackdown on opposition politicians.

title: UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DATA SHOW BLACKS SLICING INCOME GAP
description: Reciting what it called an ''untold story,'' a prominent research organization reported today that in the last 40 years black men have narrowed the economic gap between themselves and white people.

title: U.S. BACKS CHANGE IN REGIME
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Corazon C. Aquino took separate oaths of office as Philippine President today, underlining the political divisions that have brought the country to the edge of military confrontation.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS ADDS
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy two banks in Chicago's suburbs. Continental, the holding company for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, also said its board had declared dividends on its preferred stock.

title: AIDS Can Be Transmitted by Both Sexes
description: To the Editor:

title: Library of Congress; Leonardo Was a Vegetarian? Read On
description: Leonard Beck refers to himself as ''a librarian.'' He has been with the Library of Congress for 40 years.

title: BORMAN'S TENURE SEEN NEAR AN END
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc.'s decision yesterday to sell itself to the Texas Air Corporation appears to end Frank Borman's rocky 10-year tenure at the helm of the troubled airline.

description: The first Roman Catholic bishop in the United States of American Indian descent was named today for the Diocese of Gallup, N.M.

The debentures, rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P., are offered at a price to yield about seven-tenths of a percentage point more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

title: Gorbachev's Balancing Act
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev will begin the 27th Soviet Communist Party Congress today with a broad report evaluating the last five years and outlining future guidelines for all echelons of Soviet power. What kind of speech should we expect? It will of necessity be a political balancing act.

description: The United States Supreme Court turned down a challenge by a Times Square business to New York's plan for revitalizing the area.

title: PROFILE OF NEW YORK IN THE YEAR 2000: MORE JOBS, BUT A NEEDIER POPULATION
description: New York City in the year 2000, according to a report released yesterday, will enjoy a growing economy but will confront a changing population needing health, education and social services at ''staggering'' costs.

title: PORNOGRAPHY FOES LOSE NEW WEAPON IN SUPREME COURT
description: The Supreme Court today held unconstitutional a widely publicized Indianapolis ordinance that defined and penalized pornography as discrimination against women.
