description: In a fresh surge of violence, 5 people were killed and 30 wounded in a car bomb explosion in Christian East Beirut today, while in the Moslem part of the capital, two political activists were slain after all-night street gun battles between Iranian-backed Shiite fundamentalists and Soviet-oriented Communists.

title: THE AMAZON BY KAYAK, FROM A GLACIER TO THE SEA
description: It all started on last Aug. 29, with Piotr Chmielinski sitting somewhat self-consciously in a kayak on the steep glacier of Mount Mismi in southern Peru.

description: Following is the text of the White House statement today calling on President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines to step down:

description: An 11-year-old believed to be a carrier of AIDS virus returned to class without incident today after a court order lifted a school ban against him.

The company, second in the world in the field after the Caterpillar Tractor Company, previously raised prices by an average of 7 percent effective last Nov. 1.

title: Ann R. KLEIN, 62, DIES; EX-NEW JERSEY OFFICIAL
description: Ann R. Klein, a former New Jersey Human Services Commissioner and the first woman to run for a major party nomination for governor of the state, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Morristown, N.J. She was 62 years old.

title: HAITIAN JUNTA LETS FORMER POLICE CHIEF LEAVE
description: The new ruling junta of Haiti has permitted the former head of the secret police, one of the country's most feared men, to leave for political asylum in Brazil.

title: 'LADY WINDERMERE'S FAN' ON A&E CABLE CHANNEL
description: EARLY on, we hear, ''I can resist everything except temptation.'' Later, ''Wicked women bother one, good women bore one - that's the only difference.'' And near the end, ''A cynic is a man who knows the price of everything and the value of nothing.'' We are very definitely in the sparkling epigrammatic theater world of Oscar Wilde. These particular sallies happen to be from ''Lady Windermere's Fan,'' which can be seen at 9 this evening on cable's Arts and Entertainment network. The intriguing production was produced last year for the BBC by Louis Marks. The director is Tony Smith.

RAYMOND H. REISS
description: Raymond H. Reiss, chairman of the North American Reiss Corporation of Red Bank, N.J., died yesterday at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Monmouth Beach, N.J.

description: Anyone who runs a large business has to confront the problem of delinquent debtors. But the Federal Government, a very large business, seems to have more than its share.

description: Specialized companies hired by landlords to investigate the finances, rent histories and backgrounds of prospective tenants have begun operating in the New York area.

The year result includes also a gain of $56,346 from discontinued operations. Share earnings results reflect 3-for- 2 stock split effective June 15, 1985, and payable on July 10, 1985.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Boston Celtics, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. These teams have not met since Christmas Day, when the Knicks lifted the yoke of Celtic domination by overcoming a 25-point third-quarter deficit and winning, 113-104, in double overtime.

title: A CANADIAN SOCIALIST LEADER
description: T. C. Douglas, who as Premier of Saskatchewan led the first socialist government in a Canadian province, died of cancer today at his home in Ottawa. He was 81 years old.

title: Moslems Are Fearful Of Racial Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. BACKS IDEA OF AID TO MEXICO
description: Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, paid an unannounced call today on James A. Baker 3d, Secretary of the Treasury, and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, as the Reagan Administration signaled it had moved closer to supporting aid for the country because of the oil price slump.

title: EASTERN'S BOARD AGREES TO TAKEOVER BY TEXAS AIR
description: Eastern Airlines, the nation's third-largest carrier, agreed yesterday to be sold to the Texas Air Corporation, which owns low-cost airlines. If carried out, the sale could bring important changes to troubled Eastern and many of its competitors.

title: ST. BART'S AGAIN DENIED ON OFFICE-TOWER PLANS
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission overwhelmingly rejected a proposal early today that would have allowed St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue to construct an office tower on its grounds.

title: PEER REVIEW IS CHALLENGED
description: PEER review, the hallowed system most editors of scientific journals rely on to insure that the articles they publish are accurate, is under fire.

title: POLAR EXPLORERS TO TREK 500 MILES BY DOG SLED
description: In early March, when the dormant winter sun first glimmers on the horizon, 58 hardy travelers will set out from the northernmost point in North America for the North Pole.

title: BID FOR EASTERN JOLTS THE MIAMI AREA
description: The planned sale of Eastern Airlines jangled nerves all over Miami today.

title: PHILIP CROSBY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MISSOURI IS TEST SITE FOR D.D.B. CRUISE ADS
description: Because it is prototypical of the American cruise market, Missouri has been chosen by the Cruise Lines International Association to test a new multimedia ad campaign from Doyle Dane Bernbach/New York that aims to interest people who have never taken a cruise into trying one.

title: DOUBLEDAY SALE OF 3 STATIONS
description: Doubleday & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell three radio stations - including WHN-AM, the New York country music station that is the flagship station of the New York Mets - to the Emmis Broadcasting Company for $53 million.

title: DALLAS'S SWAGGER
description: This city's skyline, which seemed dreary and conventional in the 1970's beside the flamboyant buildings of booming Houston, has now come into its own. Dallas has a new generation of tall buildings, and they represent the full range of architectural possibilities of this decade. And by coincidence, they are coming to completion at just the time the energy-based economy of Houston, this city's traditional rival, has faltered badly.

title: Two Infants in California Are Switched in a Mixup
description: Two new mothers went home from the hospital with the wrong babies in a mistake discovered by accident.

title: CALIFORNIA BACKED ON BANK FEE
description: The Supreme Court today refused to bar California from regulating the service charges national banks impose on customers who write checks for more than they have in their checking accounts.

description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Eckhard H. Hess Dead at 69; Behavioral Science Authority
description: Dr. Eckhard H. Hess, a professor of behavioral science at the University of Chicago who was a leading authority on imprinting, a psychological phenomenon by which an animal's early experience permanently determines its subsequent behavior, died of pnuemonia Friday at Dorchester General Hospital, Cambridge, Md.. He was 69 years old and maintained residences in Cambridge and in Chicago.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Federated to Buy 14 Zodys Stores
description: Federated Department Stores said it had agreed to buy 14 Zodys stores in southern California from the Sterik Company and turn them into Ralphs Supermarkets.

title: Kornhauser & Calene Stretches Its Tentacles
description: Kornhauser & Calene has stretched it tentacles far to the south and west to pick up new accounts.

title: WINE TALK
description: CARNEROS is Spanish for sheep. It is also one of California's newest and most popular wine-producing areas - and one whose new wine designation, given by the Federal Government, is causing confusion in the marketplace.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
GEORGE WATSON
description: George Watson, chief of the Narragansett Indian tribe for 22 years, died Monday at South County Hospital.

title: AN INDEX OF THE GEARS
description: If television cameras ever record the Senate's proceedings, they will find no shortage of speakers or speeches. But which members will fill the screen most often, and what debates are likely to dominate the broadcasts?

title: Rutgers Wins by 52-47
description: Eric Riggins scored 21 points to lead Rutgers to a 52-47 victory over Massachusetts tonight in the first round of the Atlantic-10 tournament.

title: Freedom Savings
description: Freedom Savings and Loan Association of Tampa said Centrust Savings Bank of Miami had made an acquisition offer valued at $22 a share, or a total of about $68 million, for the 3.1 million shares outstanding. Shareholders would receive a combination of cash and preferred Centrust stock, or subordinated debentures and warrants. Freedom said it was considering the proposal.

title: New York Air Ads Continue
description: New York Air's hard-hitting advertising campaign, which attempts to lure travelers from the Eastern Airlines shuttles between New York, Washington and Boston, is continuing to run despite the agreement by New York Air's corporate parent to acquire Eastern, an official of New York Air's advertising agency said yesterday.

title: JUSTICES HEAR QUOTA CASES FROM NEW YORK AND OHIO
description: The Supreme Court heard opposing arguments today in two cases involving affirmative action programs that used racial quotas to rectify past discrimination and provided preferential treatment to minority people who have not been victims of discrimination.

title: Emmis Broadcasting In Biggest Challenge
description: Jeffrey H. Smulyan, the chairman of Emmis Broadcasting Corporation, has taken on his most challenging purchase.

title: Westphal Likes The Small Time
description: The game is still basketball, but the resemblances end there. Paul Westphal's schedule these days takes him not to vast big-city arenas but to dusty gyms where the bleachers are usually empty. The opponents are no longer the Celtics, the Sixers or the Lakers, but Arizona Auto, American Indian Bible College and Sierra Nevada.

title: NAVY JURY GETS CASE OF HEART SURGEON ACCUSED IN 5 DEATHS
description: A naval court-martial today began deliberating the fate of Comdr. Donal M. Billig, former chief of heart surgery at the Bethesda Naval Hospital, who is charged with five counts of involuntary manslaughter.

title: Positive Step
description: More than 45,000 knee operations are performed on football players every year, and Mike Tanel believes that his invention can do something about it.

title: Mexico Needs Special Help
description: Mexico is not merely another developing country with a debt problem. Its economy is closely interwoven with ours. We must address its problems as urgently as we would a financial crisis in an American state. That involves developing new ways of financing its debt, including tax-exempt securities.

title: Christian H. Armbruster Dies; Ex-Legislator From Yonkers
description: Christian H. Armbruster, a former state legislator from Yonkers, died of a respiratory ailment Monday at Doctor's Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: GIANT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $850,000 on a writedown of inventory, special charges of $223,000, both for the quarter and year, and including a gain of $2,787,000 for the quarter and year on the sale of the company's investment in Ply-Gem Industries. c-Net loss.

title: ERLY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains of $22,183,000 on the sale from discontinued operations and a $6,200,000 tax credit, both for the quarter and 9 months. The quarter result also is after a loss of $142,000 from discontinued operations, the year result also includes a gain of $1,073,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $1,217,000 for the quarter and $2,777,000 for the 9 months.

title: SUPPLIES ARE A HOT ITEM AT THIS OFFICE
description: In what prosecutors might call the case of the man who was supposed to mind the store and ended up selling it, a state employee whose job it was to buy furniture and office supplies for his agency was charged yesterday with selling those items from the very office he was supposed to keep stocked.

title: SWORN IN, NEW PRESIDENT HAS A QUIET LUNCH
description: Corazon C. Aquino went home for her inaugural luncheon today. It was a quiet affair.

title: Congress Lifts Ceiling On V.A. Home Loans
description: Congress passed and sent to the White House today a bill to lift the ceiling on the amount of home mortgage loans the Veterans Administration can guarantee this year.

title: NEW REISSUES TRACE ROCK TO ITS ORIGINS
description: THE ''Rock of Ages'' series on Capitol Records - 12 budget-priced albums tracing rock-and-roll from the early 50's through the early 70's - is one of the latest examples of a curious new trend. America's major record labels are beginning to realize that the older music moldering in their vaults is history, and are making it available again in a variety of formats.

title: AN AFFLUENT L.I. VILLAGE RESISTS INTRUSION OF BURGERS AND FRIES
description: The residents of this affluent village 15 miles from Broadway are proud of their highly regarded schools, pocket parks and model housing for the elderly.

title: USLIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized losses on investments of $277,000 for the quarter and $281,000 for the year. c-After realized losses on investments of $15,954,000 for the quarter and $17,031,000 for the year and net from discontinued operations of $570,000 and $4,441,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock split on Sept. 27, 1985.

title: Market Place; Eastern Effect On Competitors
description: THE price of airline stocks has been predictably weak in the short time since the proposed takeover of Eastern Airlines by the Texas Air Corporation was announced. But some experts on Wall Street say that stories of a sudden, drastic cut in fares and stepped-up competition may be overstated.

title: Double Legal Match-Up
description: Two lawyers who have been busy with the growing New York City scandal investigation that began with Donald R. Manes's wounds and charges of bribes in contracts let by the Parking Violations Bureau are to meet opposite each other in a different case tomorrow.

title: Beth Merrill, Stage Actress; Worked With David Belasco
description: Beth Merrill, an actress who played leading roles in several of David Belasco's later productions, died Saturday at a nursing home in Tenafly, N.J. She was 93 years old.

title: Aouita Honored
description: Said Aouita, the Moroccan distance runner, was named the winner yesterday of this year's Jesse Owens award.

title: AFTER MARCOS ABANDONS HIS PALACE, FILIPINOS SHOUT, 'THIS IS OURS NOW!'
description: Up the marble stairs, down the red carpet, past the carved mahogany walls, lies the master bedroom of Malacanang Palace. And there, beside the king-sized bed, sits what appears to be a dialysis machine. It helped keep Ferdinand E. Marcos alive as President of the Philippines, warding off the effects of lupus, a disease characterized by skin lesions.

title: YEARS AGO, A PROPHECY
description: Not long after the end of World War II, a teen-age Filipino girl named Corazon Cojuangco wrote feelingly about returning to her home in Manila from New York, where she had been attending high school.

title: Police Chief Allied to Marcos Is Killed by Filipino Gunmen
description: The local police chief and his driver were shot to death today hours after the chief declared his loyalty to President Ferdinand E. Marcos in a television interview, the police said.

title: Conoco to Develop Three Gas Fields
description: Conoco Ltd. said it would begin a $923 million project to develop three North Sea natural gas fields that will supply 5 percent of Britain's natural gas by the early 1990's, Conoco said.

title: FACT AND FANCY ON THE NEW LOW-FAT CHICKENS
description: SVELTE is unquestionably fashionable in today's chicken world. Two major producers - Perdue and Holly Farms - are clucking about their new, lower-fat birds. For weeks, advertisements in newspapers and on television and radio have heralded the poultry's appearance in local supermarkets.

title: Cyanide Investigated in Death NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 25 (AP) -
description: Traces of cyanide were found in the body of a 32-year-old man and in an Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule found in a bottle under the bed he died in, officials said today.

title: TENACIOUS ENGINEER: ALLAN J. McDONALD
description: Although he is regarded by colleagues as one of the nation's leading rocket engineers, Allan J. McDonald has never been known as the sort of person who seeks the spotlight. But now an apparent combination of haunting prescience and tenacious character has thrust him into the news.

title: Older Women and Men
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: OPTROTECH LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
KYSOR INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $149,000 for the quarter and after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,020,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $163,000 for the quarter and including income from discontinued operations of $248,000 for the year.

title: ST. BART'S PLANS LAWSUIT ON OFFICE TOWER DENIAL
description: Officials of St. Bartholomew's Church said yesterday that they would sue the city to obtain permission for construction of an office tower on the church's Park Avenue grounds.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $40,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and including a gain of $1,504,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net income including a gain of $1,050,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss after a loss of $1,620,000 from discontinued operations and a provision of $20,000,000 for disposal of discontinued operations.

title: IRANIANS LAUNCH A NEW OFFENSIVE
description: Iran said today that it had begun a new offensive against Iraq, capturing heights and villages overlooking a key northeastern Iraqi city.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch Feb. 3 about life in Sydney, Australia, referred incorrectly to New South Wales, the state of which Sydney is the capital. Although it is the most populous of Australia's six states, it is fourth largest in area.

title: IN NEW YORK, A CABBY IS THE KEY TO FINDING FLAVORS OF AFGHANISTAN
description: A NEW YORK without its bagels, dim sum, souvlaki, fettuccine and arroz con pollo would be another place -certainly a lesser one. Happily, from a culinary point of view, there always seems to be another new culture on the verge of making an impression through its cuisine. Finding it can sometimes be as easy as hopping into a cab and striking up a conversation with the driver.

title: KOCH, THE AUTHOR, REBUFFED BY PEN
description: Mayor Koch, the author of two books including one major best seller, has been turned down for membership in the American branch of PEN, the international organization of writers.

title: Reconstruction Is Aftershock of Mexican Quake
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Currier, the Giant strong safety who missed the 1985 season with a back ailment, recently underwent surgery to remove a herniated disk that caused the problem and will miss the team's minicamp in May, according to Coach Bill Parcells, who said he did not know if Currier would be ready for the start of next season. . . . Last week, John Hannah, the New England Patriots' all-pro guard, underwent surgery to repair torn rotator cuffs on both shoulders and is expected to start rehabilitation in four to six weeks. . . . Terence Woods, a University of Minnesota basketball player, was reinstated by the National Collegiate Athletic Association after having been declared ineligible by the school last week over a suspected recruiting violation. The N.C.A.A. found that Woods had not been involved in improprieties.

title: RAMOS'S ORDER TO MILITARY
description: Following is the text of an order to the military today by Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, the new Chief of Staff, to prevent lynchings and the looting of property of associates of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos:

title: Senate Votes Down Bill For Insuring Tramway
description: The Republican-controlled State Senate rejected today, 28 to 26, a measure that would restore tramway service between Manhattan and Roosevelt Island.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said net income in the latest first quarter reflects a 6 cents- a-share gain from a change in accounting for pension funding.

title: DANCE: LIMON TROUPE OPENS WITH PREMIERE
description: THE opening last night by the Limon Dance Company at the Joyce Theater suggests the company is very much in flux. But the direction in which it is headed is anything but clear.

title: Polish Debt Rescheduling
description: A working group of Western creditor banks has agreed in principle to reschedule some of the commercial debt Poland owes this year, banking sources said today.

title: Travels With Babbitt
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona has hired Michael D. McCurry, a former Senate press secretary, as press secretary for his undeclared campaign for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination. The 31-year-old Princeton graduate is moving to Phoenix, which will be the headquarters of the effort that is now taking shape.

title: BABY-FOOD MAKER AND MARYLAND ACCEPT JOINT INQUIRY ON GLASS BITS
description: The Gerber Products Company agreed today to a delay in its $150 million lawsuit against Maryland officials and promised to cooperate with a state administrative inquiry into how bits of glass got into jars of baby food.

title: ROCKET ENGINEERS TELL OF PRESSURE FOR A LAUNCHING
description: Rocket engineers testified today that pressure from the space agency to launch the space shuttle Challenger forced them to reverse their normal role - that instead of having to prove that the shuttle was ready to go, it was up to them to show that a launching would be unsafe.

title: Rebirth in the Philippines
description: The most becoming thing about the Marcos era in the Philippines was its end. Who could have expected nuns to face down the tanks of this wily dictator? Who really expected that a housewife avenging her husband's death could in just 60 days mount a campaign that trounced him at the polls? The tremors of this nonviolent rising will be felt wherever freedom is denied. Whatever the future holds, this moment belongs to the Philippine people and their new President, Corazon Aquino.

title: IN U.S., PHILIPPINE-AMERICANS REJOICE
description: Philippine-Americans from coast to coast exulted yetserday in the end of the Marcos Government.

title: WITNESS IN DRUG TRIAL TELLS OF CASH FOR SWISS ACCOUNTS
description: A witness told the jury in the ''pizza connection'' trial yesterday about delivering millions of dollars in cash from a New Jersey restaurant to secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: Toshiya Eto, Violin
description: The violinist Toshiya Eto will give his first New York concert in 10 years, tonight at 8 in Alice Tully Hall. The program, a tribute to Efrem Zimbalist, will include some of the late violinist's own music, as well as works by Pugnani and Beethoven. Mr. Eto will be accompanied by Vladimir Sokoloff. Tickets are $10 and $12; information: 362-1911.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article Sunday on Johnson & Johnson's handling of the Tylenol crisis misstated the company's sales during 1985. They totaled $6.42 billion.

title: REAGAN ASKS $100 MILLION FOR CONTRAS
description: President Reagan asked Congress today to authorize the use of $100 million in Defense Department funds to provide military as well as nonlethal aid to the rebels seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Gorbachev Disarmament Proposal Emphasizes World Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: The share earnings do not include benefits from tax credits equal to 51 cents for the latest year, compared with 63 cents for 1984. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: DEMOCRATIC GOVERNORS ASSAIL REAGAN ON BUDGET
description: Democratic governors, who hold a 3-to-1 majority over the Republicans in the 50 states, today accused President Reagan of submitting ''a budget of disinvestment,'' one that ''fails to make the critical investment in our nation's future.''

title: RICHARDSON'S ORDEAL IS RECOUNTED
description: June 9, 1978 - The Knicks, picking fourth in the college draft, select Mike Richardson of the University of Montana. The Knick coach, Willis Reed, calls the 6-foot-5-inch guard ''one of the best all-around guards in the nation.''

title: Replays Endorsed
description: Rod Dowhower, the coach of the Indianapolis Colts, thinks it is a shame that television viewers at home get a better view of critical plays than the officials on the field. ''We're living in the electronic age and we should take advantage of it,'' said Dowhower, who called on the National Football League to start using instant video replays to settle disputes on critical calls.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV'S SPEECH TO THE PARTY
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech to the Communist Party congress today, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: Rocket Used in Halley Study
description: The launching and return to earth today of a rocket to study Halley's comet was a success, scientists said. The cameras and film aboard the rocket were returned by parachute after traveling about 300 miles into space, said officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. A second rocket is to be launched Thursday and a third launching to study the comet is scheduled for March 13.

title: Topics; Listening to Voters, and Jurors Undue Process
description: A friend has been serving for almost a week now on a New York supreme court jury and she doesn't understand why. The case involves a driver accused of running traffic lights, possibly while intoxicated.

title: HOPE SEEN FOR REVIVING WEAK FILIPINO ECONOMY
description: Reviving the weak economy of the Philippines will be a formidable challenge for that country's new leadership, but it can be achieved, many analysts said today.

title: In Re Intent
description: When judges are asked to interpret a Federal law, they often turn to the legislative history, the record of statements made by members of Congress while the law was being adopted. This Congressional record is commonly used by the courts to determine ''legislative intent,'' what the lawmakers were really after.

title: Ethics Board Criticizes Philadelphia's Mayor
description: The City Board of Ethics said Monday that Mayor W. Wilson Goode acted improperly by failing to report that he had received 14 suits at discount prices.

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES RISE 11%
description: New-car sales rose 11 percent in mid-February over the 1985 period, the nation's major auto makers reported today. The increase came as some companies closed out low-interest-rate financing programs.

title: Wheels Are Spinning Over the Senate's Rules
description: Capitol Hill is used to rebellions. For more than a decade junior lawmakers have been demanding more power from their elders and often getting it.

title: QUARTZ ENGINEERING & MATERIALS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Topics; Listening to Voters, and Jurors Queens Winners
description: The voters in Queens have given an encouraging sign that the scandals in New York's government may yet revive the city's Republican Party. David Kramer, a Democrat, won the contest to fill a vacant Queens Assembly seat, but by a notably narrow margin over an opponent who ran as a Republican and Conservative.

title: CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for stock splits of 2-for-1 in February 1985, and 3-for-2 in October 1985.

title: CANADA'S BIG BUDGET DEBATE
description: While nobody is comparing the depth of Canada's economic problems to those of Mexico, people earlier this month were referring to the ''Hudson Bay peso,'' as the Canadian dollar plunged to its lowest level ever.

title: Surging Fairfield Set for Tournament
description: Fairfield University reversed its fortunes this year and ran away with the regular-season title in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, but the playoffs, which begin tomorrow with a berth in the national collegiate tournament at stake, may be a different story.

title: FAILURE AT EASTERN: LACK OF TRUST SEEN
description: The failure of union leaders and company executives at Eastern Air Lines to work cooperatively to solve the company's financial troubles seems sure to be a major setback for the concept of workplace participation, experts on labor relations say.

title: Yankelovich Quits For New Venture
description: Dissatisfied with the proposed direction of a new research company that included their concern, the three principals of Yankelovich, Skelly & White have resigned to start their own firm in Manhattan.

title: FOR THE U.S. THE TOUGHEST PHILIPPINE POLICY DECISIONS MAY YET LIE AHEAD
description: The departure of Ferdinand E. Marcos as President of the Philippines is only a first step toward solving the painful economic, social and political problems of the country, politicians and academic specialists said today. All agreed that difficult policy decisions lie ahead for the United States as well as the Philippines.

title: STAMFORD SHOPS FOR A NEW CITY HALL
description: Here in the land of high technology, the corporate pantheons are sheathed in glass and steel.

title: MRS. EARL WILSON
description: Rosemary Wilson, wife of Earl Wilson, the syndicated columnist, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 76 years old.

title: Advertising; Methods To Limit 'Zapping'
description: IN recent years when a panel of speakers was collected for an advertising audience, the odds were that one would be assigned the subject of zapping. It had become a bit of a drag, until yesterday.

title: EXTRA TOUCHES ADD RICHES
Q&A
description: Q.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS USE OF ZONING TO REGULATE SHOWING OF SEX FILMS
description: The Supreme Court held today that local zoning officials have broad powers to restrict the location of movie theaters showing sexually explicit films.

title: CHAD LEADER ASSAILS LIBYA
description: President Hissen Habre today blamed what he said were Libya's ''expansionist aims'' for the strife that has engulfed this African country.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Syracuse vs. St. John's, at Madison Square Garden, 9:30 P.M. The battle for first place in the Big East. A victory for St. John's would give the Redmen a tie for the conference lead.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Allies Bar North Koreans From West Berlin
description: American, British and French authorities in West Berlin barred four North Korean diplomats from the city today, apparently in an effort to halt the flow of combat helicopter parts through East Germany to North Korea.

title: FOR MARCOS, A RESTLESS NIGHT OF CALLS TO U.S.
description: It was about 3 A.M. today in Manila and President Ferdinand E. Marcos was telephoning to find out whether the message he had received from Washington calling for ''a peaceful transition'' to a new government actually meant he should quit.

title: MASTERLY HAND OF GALANOS
description: JAMES GALANOS is a one-man band. ''I do the selling,'' he said. ''I buy the fabrics. I even pick out the lizard skins for the belts. It is part of me. It is my work. I don't have a design staff.''

title: GORBACHEV SAYS U.S. ARMS NOTE IS NOT ADEQUATE
description: Addressing a landmark meeting of the Soviet Communist Party, Mikhail S. Gorbachev today criticized President Reagan's recent response on arms reduction and said the timing of the next summit meeting could hinge on progress in arms control.

title: Daisy Sees Loss
description: The Daisy Systems Corporation, a leading manufacturer of computer-aided engineering systems, said its incoming rate of new orders was less than anticipated and that it expected to report a significant loss for the second quarter, ending March 31.

title: Real Estate; Suburban Offices for CBS Unit
description: CBS Educational and Professional Publishing, a division of the CBS Publishing Group, will move from Manhattan to Mount Pleasant, N.Y., early next year.

title: KACC Acquisition
description: Alan Clore, the British investor, said he had become an equal partner in KACC Acquisition Group, the joint venture seeking control of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Clore and the Oklahoma investor, J. A. Frates, renegotiated the terms of their original Dec. 2 agreement, increasing Mr. Clore's share in the expenses and the possible profits to 50 percent, from 40 percent. Mr. Clore also told the S.E.C. that on Feb. 7 he filed for permission under Federal antitrust laws to increase his holdings in Kaiser. The investment group already controls 8.9 million Kaiser shares, or 20.1 percent of its shares outstanding.

title: EASTERN SALE EXPECTED TO BENEFIT TRAVELERS
description: The planned acquisition of Eastern Airlines by the Texas Air Corporation will ultimately be a boon for travelers, according to analysts, consultants, travel agents and consumer groups.

title: THE DANCE: MARY LUFT, 'IN THE KEY OF WEST, II'
description: MARY LUFT, a choreographer from Florida, brought a terpsichorean travelogue to the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Monday night. ''In the Key of West, II'' was a mixed-media portrait of Key West with choreography by Miss Luft, taped music and video by Bill Seaman and designs by Dina Knapp.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Players Seek Changes
description: Larry Fleisher, the general counsel of the National Basketball Players Association, believes the union-negotiated salary caps have brought prosperity to the league, and now it's time to do something for the players - by abolishing the draft and shifting to a full free-agent system. ''We want the right to be treated like everyone else,'' said Fleisher, who added that the union would press for a free-agent system in negotiations for a contract to replace the one that expires in June 1987. ''We feel there is no reason why we can't operate under a free-agent system, where a player can sign a contract and move wherever he wants to move, and a player can come out of school and sign with whomever he wants to sign,'' he said. Currently, the right of first refusal accorded to N.B.A. teams can limit the movement of free agents. Fleisher, who also serves as an agent for almost 30 N.B.A. players, dismissed the suggestion that without a draft to allocate incoming talent, the rich, big-city teams would have an advantage over smaller franchises. ''If you're going to be the third center on the Los Angeles Lakers, you're not going to get as much as the first one on the Detroit Pistons,'' he said. David Stern, the commissioner of the N.B.A., made no direct reply to the proposal but said he would defend Fleisher's ''right to have as long and as extensive a wish list as he cares to bring'' to the negotiating table.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Broadway column in Weekend Friday incorrectly credited the production of ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' on Broadway. The producers were Elliot Martin, Arnold Bernhard, the Shubert Organization and the Goodman Theater. Frederick Zollo will be a co-producer of the play in London.

title: ORDERS FOR DURABLES GAIN SLIGHTLY
description: Orders to factories for durable goods rose a slight four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department said today. A surge in demand for military hardware counteracted weakness in most other areas.

title: PUBLICITY BRINGS A RUSH TO PAY FINES
description: The scandal in the city's Parking Violations Bureau and notoriety surrounding major ticket scofflaws has telephones ringing and an unexpected $1.9 million in fines pouring into the agency, a transportation official said yesterday.

title: GUAM HAS HAD OTHER EXILES
description: Philippine-Americans from coast to coast exulted yesterday in the end of the Marcos Government.

title: Judge Stays Execution Of Texas Grocer's Killer
description: A Federal district judge today stayed the execution of a killer less than 12 hours before he was to die by injection for the shotgun slaying of a 72-year-old grocer.

title: Alcohol and Babies
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: No Room at the Gallery
description: The National Gallery, which on Sunday will open the largest exhibition of watercolors by Winslow Homer ever presented, is going through a record-breaking period of public attendance, what with the ''Treasure Houses of Britain,'' which runs through April 13, and ''Impres-sionism: the New Painting,'' which runs through April 6.

title: Making It Less Attractive to Be a Dictator
description: To the Editor:

title: CELTICS OVERTAKE KNICKS
description: Patrick Ewing was back last night after missing seven games because of a jammed right knee, and the Knicks' hopes surged. They held the Boston Celtics to their lowest one-half point total of the season in taking a 40-39 lead at halftime, and they were up by 5 points, 50-45, midway through thethird period.

title: Foes of Seoul Leader Question Concessions
description: Opposition party leaders asserted today that President Chun Doo Hwan had not made any real political concessions to them, despite his unexpected move Monday to ease a crackdown on the opposition.

title: No Vacancy in Hungary
description: Ambassador Nicolas M. Salgo, a 1983 political appointee of President Reagan, is apparently going to remain as the United States representative in Hungary, at least for the rest of the year.

title: PYRAMIDS HOTELS RANSACKED
description: More than 2,000 paramilitary policemen, apparently enraged over a rumored extension of their tour of duty, went on a rampage Tuesday through four hotels near the Pyramids and fought gun battles through the night with military units sent in to stop the mutiny.

title: The New TV Diplomacy
description: In the crisis of the Philippines, we have seen the techniques of what is called ''the new public diplomacy,'' and sometimes they work.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., said it had agreed to sell Brookwood Recovery Centers to Parkside Medical Services Corp., an affiliate of the Lutheran General Health Care System. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 67 LOCATIONS COURTING HOLLYWOOD PRODUCERS
description: The film commissions of 67 states, cities and Canadian provinces - from Alabama to Wyoming, from Albuquerque to Alberta - are offering their lakes, mountains and dazzling sunsets this week to the producers of theatrical movies and television series.

title: Memorial for Gilbert Hartke
description: A memorial mass for the Rev. Gilbert V. Hartke will be held on March 3 at 6:30 P.M. at St. Malachy's Church, 239 West 49th Street. Father Hartke founded the drama department of Catholic University in Washington in 1937 and directed productions featuring Helen Hayes, Susan Sarandon, Jon Voight, Philip Bosco and Frances Sternhagen. He died last Friday in Washington at the age of 79.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the first three quarters of 1985 have been restated to reflect a change in accounting which reduced pension expenses for the year by approximately $3.5 million.

title: MARGUERITE YOURCENAR TO BE HONORED
description: Marguerite Yourcenar, the author of ''Memoirs of Hadrian'' and other works, will receive two awards in a special ceremony today at 7:15 P.M. at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South.

title: Great Western's C.M.O. Financing
description: Great Western Mortgage Securities Inc. is offering $250 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole underwriter.

title: HAITIAN JUNTA SPLIT ON EXILE OF DUVALIER AIDE
description: A rift has appeared in Haiti's 18-day-old Government over the departure of the man who served during the Duvalier regime as head of the political police.

title: LOWLY WARRIORS DOWN NETS, 116-109
description: There were no excuses. The Nets simply lost another game tonight.
