description: b-Net income.

title: LOCAL PROGRAM FUNDS SPENT DESPITE CABLE WIRING DELAY
description: Corporations set up by the Borough Presidents of Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx have spent more than $700,000 since 1983 to produce community programming for cable television systems that have either not yet been built or have barely begun operating.

title: A Helping Hand
description: Wade Boggs may have lost in salary arbitration, but a Boston radio station is doing its best to cash in. The station has begun a campaign to help ''poor Wade Boggs make ends meet'' by soliciting redeemable bottles and cans from listeners.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 4
BORMAN PLANS TO STAY FOR NOW
description: Frank Borman, the chairman and chief executive of Eastern Airlines, said today that he would continue to head the company at least until the carrier's acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation was formally approved.

title: 200 STUDENTS AT SMITH SEIZE BUILDING
description: Nearly 200 Smith College students took over the school's administration building today to protest a decision by the board of trustees to retain the college's investments in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Panama Debt Deal Near
description: Panama is close to an accord with the World Bank that will clear the way for rescheduling $579 million in debt due this year, the Finance Minister, Ricaurte Vasquez, said today.

title: SHULTZ PRAISES 'PEACEFUL TRANSITION' IN PHILIPPINES
description: The Reagan Administration moved quickly Tuesday to recognize the new Government of Corazon C. Aquino.

title: REAGAN PLANS SPEECH TONIGHT TO WIN SUPPORT FOR MILITARY SPENDING
description: To combat waning public support for military spending, President Reagan plans to argue in a televised speech that there is a link between a successful arms control agreement and continued increases in military spending, Administration officials said today.

title: Bridge; A Player, 15, Has the Game In His Blood in Many Ways
description: The chance that a child will become a bridge player is greatly increased if he has a close relative who plays the game seriously. And if the whole family plays, the chances increase geometrically.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Savings and Loan Association of Florida, Miami, has elected to its board Marshall S. Cogan and Stephen C. Swid, co-chairmen and co-chief executive officers of General Felt Industries.

title: IT TAKES A COOL HEAD TO DRAW DRAFT BEER
description: CONNOISSEURS say that draft beer has a flavor and freshness unmatched by bottled or canned beer. But good draft beer can be hard to find, many beer drinkers have discovered.

title: Seat-Belt Laws Violate Your Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP ONLY 0.3%
description: The Consumer Price Index rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in January, the smallest increase since September, the Labor Department said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: I WISH I had written this column before I had a recent skiing accident. Having done some research, I can now point to at least five factors that could account for my injury - all of which I could have done something about. In other words, had I known better, I might not have torn a knee ligament.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain from the early retirement of debt of $482,000.

title: BOARD TO GROW
description: The Western Union Corporation said yesterday that its board had again voted to omit the quarterly dividend on preferred shares. This will result in the election of two new directors to the board of the financially troubled communications concern.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1986
description: The Economy

title: KINCAID FURNITURE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
U.S. COMPUTER SECURITY VIEWED AS INADEQUATE
description: Night after night, Tyson Jolliffe, the Federal official in charge of computer security at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, sat at the kitchen table in his home in Leesburg, Va., tapping at his small computer.

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $282,000 for the quarter and $1,876,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $1,456,000. Figures for the latest year and quarter include results of operations from Cotton and Coast To Coast, both acquired in January 1985. Figures for the previous year and quarter include results of operations from Langendorf, which was sold in December 1984.

title: MYERS, L E CO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $25,337,000 from the extinguishment of bank debt for the year. c-Net loss

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1986
description: The Fall of Marcos

title: THE FINAL HOURS OF MARCOS: PLEADING TO SAVE FACE, THEN ESCAPE IN THE DARK
description: The final sadness of Ferdinand E. Marcos was apparent only in the numerous private pleas he made in flailing about for some minimal token of pride.

title: SYRACUSE-ST, JOHN'S: REMATCH FOR FIRST
description: A half hour after his team's 1-point victory over Georgetown at the Carrier Dome last Sunday, Dwayne (Pearl) Washington stood in the midst of a jubilant Syracuse locker room.

title: JERSEY MAN DENIES HE KILLED HIS WIFE
description: A prominent Toms River insurance broker testified today that he had hired a Louisiana man to investigate his wife, not to kill her.

title: Fireman's Fund Sale
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it planned to sell most of its remaining stake in the Fireman's Fund Corporation, the large property-casualty insurer.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the Outdoors column in Sport Pages Friday carried in incorrect byline. The column was written by Janet Nelson.

title: Computerland Franchisees' Deal
description: The Computerland Corporation, a computer retailer based in Hayward, Calif., said its Canadian franchisees and Canada's second-largest computer retailer, Computer Innovations Distribution Inc., had agreed to merge their Canadian sales and service organizations, effective March 29. The new entity would do business under the name Computerland, as a chain of more than 100 stores across Canada.

title: Volvo Cancels Fermenta Link
description: The Swedish car maker Volvo said today that it was canceling a planned $500 million linkup with the biotechnology group Fermenta that both companies had said would transform Sweden's drug industry.

title: FUQUA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $178,000 for the quarter and $1,719,000 for the year. The year result also includes an extraordinary credit of $219,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,238,000 for the quarter, $1,295,000 for the year, and including $1.1 million, or 11 cents a share, relating to termination of DISC in 1984, for the quarter and year. The year result also includes an extraordinary tax credit of $320,000.

title: FRIEDMAN'S LIST ASSETS OF MORE THAN $1 MILLION
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and his wife have holdings worth more than $1 million, including real estate in the Bronx, Queens and the Hamptons, according to a list of their assets that Mrs. Friedman had tried to keep secret.

title: Philip Morris Sells $150 Million Notes
description: Philip Morris Inc. is offering $150 million of 8 3/8 percent notes, maturing in 1990, at a price of 99.617 to yield 8.49 percent.

title: MOSCOW'S STRATEGY IS FOILED
description: The Soviet Union, which unexpectedly came to the defense of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines after his contested election victory this month, noted his flight from the presidential palace without comment today.

title: DANCE: 'MEARES ISLAND,' 4-PART WORK BY GOSHEN
description: MARTITA GOSHEN'S ''Meares Island,'' performed on Sunday afternoon at the Nikolais-Louis Dance Space, was artless in the best and worst senses of the term. Miss Goshen and her three personable dancers simulated nature in the four-part work, set to forest sounds and music by Ralph Towner, Richard Strauss, Charles Gounod and David Darling. They spurted like freshets in little jumps, and swayed and stretched like young branches coaxed by a strong, even wind. Birds and wind currents were suggested when the dancers swooped onto and off the stage in circling runs. And Miss Goshen's Earthworks company danced with a joy and devotion that revealed as much about the natural beauty of Meares Island, in British Columbia, as the pretty slides projected toward the end of the dance.

title: Pregnancy and Health
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: STAGE: MUSICAL PAGEANT
description: FROM the evidence in ''To Feed Their Hopes: An American Cantata,'' the creative life of the author, John Sanford, began with Mrs. Blauvelt, a schoolteacher who apparently inspired him on his book-lined trek through American history. That journey is not effectively dramatized in the new musical pageant at the Quaigh Theater.

title: CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in November and a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: Revue Pays Homage to 60's
description: ''Beehive,'' a musical revue devoted to the 1960's, will begin performances on March 11 at the Top of the Gate, 160 Bleecker Street.

title: Mayoral Voting in San Diego
description: Voters went to the polls today in the fifth mayoral election here since 1983, and in early returns a former City Council member, Maureen O' Connor, was leading.

title: Commodore Credit Accord
description: Commodore International Ltd. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle for $135 million in credit through March 15, 1987.

title: THE MARCOS YEARS: FROM VOW TO 'MAKE COUNTRY GREAT' TO THE PUBLIC REVOLT
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos's departure from the Philippines yesterday put an end to an era - the tumultuous two decades he spent as the nation's President.

title: NEEDIEST CASES DRIVE TO END AT $2.7 MILLION, FUND RECORD
description: The 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will end on Friday with a record amount of contributions to help New York City's homeless, ill and despairing.

title: President's Address To Be Broadcast Live
description: President Reagan's address on military affairs tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOOD NOTES
description: Healthful Cooking Beginning next Wednesday, the New York University Medical Center's Cooperative Care Education Center will sponsor a six-week series of classes on cooking that promotes good health through proper diet and nutrition.

title: Thrift Insider Settles Case
description: For the second time in two days, a former official of the Financial Corporation of America has settled Federal civil charges of selling its shares while possessing inside information. In a suit filed in Los Angeles today, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged John J. Borer Jr. with trading in the stock when he knew the company would report a large loss.

title: Retired ITT Executive Named to Head Scovill
description: Richard E. Bennett, a retired vice chairman of the ITT Corporation, has been named chairman and chief executive of Scovill Inc., the diversified manufacturing company that last year was sold for $530 million to a company controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada.

title: GOODEN TRYING TO OFFSPEED PITCH
description: The bad news for the hitters in the National League this spring is that Dwight Gooden is developing a new pitch, which he needs about as badly as the Army needs a new tank.

title: Amoco to Cut '86 Spending
description: The Amoco Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, said yesterday that it would reduced its planned capital and exploration spending for 1986 to $3.5 billion, from $5 billion.

title: BEGGS RESIGNS AS HEAD OF NASA
description: James M. Beggs, under indictment on fraud charges, resigned today as Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Mr. Beggs, who has been on leave from his post, took the action to let President Reagan name a new chief for the beleaguered space agency.

title: PREFERRED HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Welsh Honor Thomas At the White Horse
description: In the Poets' Corner of Westminster Abbey, a place that memorializes Britain's greatest poets, there is a plaque honoring the fiery Welsh poet Dylan Thomas. His memorial is there among those for Chaucer, Blake, Byron and Shakespeare.

title: WHY UNEMPLOYMENT IS WORSE THAN THEY TELL US
description: To the Editor:

title: San Antonio Sets Refunding
description: A $317.1 million financing by San Antonio to refund previously issued electric and gas system revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday by underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: 'SOLAR SEA' EXPLORES NEW RESEARCH ON SUN
description: ''THE SOLAR SEA'' looks almost as good as its predecessors in the ''Planet Earth'' series, but it really tells us less. Maybe there's less to tell, or maybe the sun is too big a topic. Either way, ''The Solar Sea,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, sometimes seems to be vamping for time.

title: RICHARDSON IS BANNED AS TESTS FIND COCAINE
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, the Nets' playmaking guard whose personal problems have undermined his splendid athletic talent, was banned from the National Basketball Association yesterday after testing positive for cocaine use.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation is offering $200 million of 9 3/8 percent notes, coming due in 1991, at par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: BIG BANKS CONFIDENT ON PHILIPPINE DEBT OUTLOOK
description: Big international banks, spared the economic consequences of a long political crisis, expressed confidence yesterday that the new Philippine Government would continue to make timely payments on the nation's $25 billion in foreign debt, almost one-third of which is held by United States banks.

title: IRISH DEFEAT DEPAUL
description: Donald Royal went 16 for 16 at the foul line as Notre Dame defeated DePaul, 70-59, tonight for its 20th victory of the season.

title: Working Profile: Wendy Lee Gramm; That Other Gramm Of Power and Sway
description: Whom does Ronald Reagan call ''my favorite economist''?

title: ITALY MOVING TO JOIN 'STAR WARS'
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi will ask Parliament to approve Italian participation in the research phase of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, senior Government officials said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SPORTSWRITER. By Richard Ford. 375 pages. Vintage Contemporaries.

title: DANCE: D.J. MCDONALD EXPLORES GROWING OLD
description: CHOREOGRAPHERS do not often concern themselves with growing old. Most dancers are young and many dances are set in a timeless realm. However, two effective works on the interesting program that D. J. McDonald and Dancers offered Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church were about aging.

title: Hammaker's Ordeal
description: Atlee Hammaker, a San Francisco Giant pitcher, is struggling to overcome a mysterious ailment that has sent his weight down 19 pounds, triggered a sharp increase in his body fat, sapped his strength and baffled his doctors. ''I don't know what I had or have,'' Hammaker told The San Jose Mercury News.

title: YANKEES' HOLLAND SEEKS A FRESH START
description: Dale Berra, in street clothes and untied sneakers, sat in front of his locker, visiting with teammates for a few minutes after dropping off his equipment in advance of his first spring workout Wednesday. Rod Scurry and Al Holland were not far away, wearing rubber sweatshirts and riding adjacent exercise bicycles as if they were racing.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For a Tax Amnesty To Cut the Deficit
description: At a time when the Federal Government is hacking away at important programs in order to balance its budget and reduce its deficit, the Reagan Administration and Congress should be looking first at the revenue side - not to raise taxes but to get serious about collecting what is already owed the Treasury. They should adopt what has worked for many states, tax amnesty combined with tougher enforcement.

title: AFTER THE FALL, JOYOUS PANDEMONIUM GRIPS MANILA
description: Guam, the unincorporated United States territory where Ferdinand E. Marcos arrived yesterday, was, like the Philippines, once part of Spain's colonial empire.

title: QUESTION FOR '86 DANES: TO BE OR NOT TO BE IN STEP
description: One tense day last June, Cpl. Robert H. Peterson of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police faced down a drunken gunman.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF TESTIMONY IN INQUIRY ON CHALLENGER EXPLOSION
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, held in Washington yesterday by a Presidential investigative panel, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: LOSING WEIGHT: F.D.A. WARNING
description: Melting off those extra pounds without going hungry is the dream of millions of overweight Americans, and the money they spend trying to accomplish that goal attracts the quacks as well as the conscientious weight-loss promoters.

title: FOX PHOTO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
HEWLETT INTRODUCES SPECTRUM
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced today the first two models of its Spectrum computers, a series of machines that will carry the company well into the 1990's.

title: M.T.A. Bond Offering May Yield Up to 8.568%
description: A $299.6 million issue of Metropolitan Transportation Authority revenue bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a top yield of 8.568 percent for bonds due in 2016. Dillon, Read & Company heads the underwriters.

title: Doyle Dane Creative Teams
description: There are agencies with a single creative director. There are those with two. And, as agencies get bigger and bigger, those with even more.

title: BRADLEY MAKES HIS SECOND BID TO BE GOVERNOR
description: The Mayor of Los Angeles, Tom Bradley, officially declared today that ''this farmer's son and ex-cop is a candidate for Governor of California'' for the second time.

title: CAVENHAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 4
description: b-Net loss.

title: MUSIC: 'EL CIMARRON,' BY HANS WERNER HENZE
description: HANS WERNER HENZE is one of this century's most active, interesting composers, but not all his works seem equally strong; he has a tendency toward rhetorical conventionality. But a piece he composed in 1970, ''El Cimarron,'' counts as one of his major statements: rhetorical - or, better, intensely dramatic - it is, but in no way conventional.

title: BOROS TO MANAGE PADRES
description: Steve Boros, the San Diego Padres' director of minor league instruction, was named their manager today, replacing Dick Williams, who resigned Monday.

title: SOME IN COMGRESS FAVOR MORE AID FOR PHILIPPINES
description: Congressional leaders said today that American aid to the Philippines was likely to be increased because of the departure of Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Economic Scene; The Pressures On Fed to Ease
description: HAS Federal Reserve policy really taken a decisive turn toward greater monetary ease? That is the way the bond market has interpreted the central bank's decision to buy $1.5 billion of securities for a customer account, said to be a foreign central bank. The Fed's action sent bond prices sharply higher.

title: DATA SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Magazine Ad Rise
description: The Publishers Information Bureau, a sister organization of the Magazine Publishers Association, reports that in January its members' magazines showed an increase of 1.3 percent in ad pages, to 9,595 from the same month last year. Gross ad revenues for the month came to $308.9 million, a gain of 7.6 percent.

title: 'WE ARE THE WORLD' TAKES 4 GRAMMY AWARDS
description: ''We Are The World,'' the all-star recording that raised millions of dollars for African famine relief, and Phil Collins, the veteran British rock star, each won three Grammys tonight.

title: FROM A SYMBOL TO A LEADER: THE RISE OF CORAZON AQUINO
description: Corazon C. Aquino began to exercise presidential power even before Ferdinand E. Marcos left the country today, telling some of the country's most powerful men what they would be doing in her Cabinet, and making a key decision about the nation's top financial institution.

title: NETS TEAMMATES SHOW COMPASSION
description: There's a room in the back of the Nets' dressing room where Fritz Massman, the trainer, has created a vivid testimonial to the instability of this franchise by lining the walls with the nameplates of all the players who have been traded or waived or otherwise dropped from the team. The walls are dotted with history - some of it joyful, some of it not.

title: South African Black Killed in Police Raid
description: Policemen armed with riot sticks broke into a meeting in the black township of Kagiso on Monday night and one black student was killed and 30 people were hurt, residents said today.

title: RANGERS 6-GAME STREAK ENDS
description: A Maple Leaf skated around Tom Laidlaw of the Rangers, and Laidlaw looked left, then right, and then realized he was looking to no avail. The Maple Leaf had gone behind him and scored. And that was just one Ranger misadventure.

title: Spying Retrial of an Ex-Agent
description: A prosecutor, beginning a second attempt to convict a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on espionage charges, told jurors today that the agent was part of ''a grimier, more sordid reality'' than movie spy dramas.

title: 'Huey Long' Resumes
description: ''Huey Long,'' Ken Burns's documentary about the Louisiana political leader, has resumed playing at the Bleecker Street Cinema after being briefly suspended because of a scheduling conflict. Today and tomorrow, ''Huey Long'' will be shown at 4:30 P.M. After that, it will play on a schedule of 12:15, 2, 5:15 and 7:30 P.M., Fridays through Sundays, and 4:30 and 7:30 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays.

title: DUVALIER CHARGES HE IS A PRISONER
description: Jean-Claude Duvalier and the owner of the luxury hotel where he is staying both filed lawsuits with identical objectives today: getting the deposed Haitian dictator out of the hotel.

title: AQUINO SPEECH: 'AGONY IS OVER'
description: Following is the nationally televised statement by President Corazon C. Aquino early today after Ferdinand E. Marcos resigned from the presidency:

title: U.S. RECOGNIZES AQUINO AS PRESIDENT
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos fled the Philippines Tuesday, ending 20 years as President. Corazon C. Aquino succeeded him, saying ''a new life'' had begun for her country.

title: Resorts Ends Deal With U.S. Capital
description: Resorts International Inc. said yesterday that it had ended negotiations to sell its hotel and casino in Atlantic City to the U.S. Capital Corporation for more than $300 million. U.S. Capital said that Resorts had rejected its offer of $325 million without giving a reason.

title: CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS: STRENGTH IN NUMBERS
description: ''We're at the cutting edge of a new social movement,'' said Dr. Claudia Black to the crowded convention audience, ''and we're not going to stop until all those children out there are protected.''

title: Postschool Day Care
description: To the Editor:

title: BARRIO MUSEUM WEIGHING FILING FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The director of El Museo del Barrio, one of New York's leading Hispanic cultural institutions, said yesterday that he would recommend that the museum file for bankruptcy if city financing, which has been frozen since last November, was not restored today.

title: DOW DECLINES 5.62 ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Wall Street stock prices fell yesterday as investors, suddenly nervous over oil prices, decided to continue to take profits. Technology stocks, airlines and certain blue-chip issues were the heaviest hit.

title: QUAKER CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sheller Signs Pact On Its Acquisition
description: The Sheller-Globe Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired for about $482 million by an investor group led by General Felt Industries, Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and the senior management of Sheller. Under terms of the agreement, Sheller-Globe shareholders would receive $39 a share in cash and junior subordinated notes having a face value of $17 a share.

title: FORTUNE SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ties to Israel
description: Floyd Abrams can trace his close ties with Israel to an August day 26 years ago.

title: Killer in 1969 Sentenced
description: A man was sentenced today to 20 years in prison for killing his stepson 17 years ago, a death originally ruled an accident. A jury found 52-year-old David Wilson guilty last month of second-degree murder in the 1969 death of 4-year-old Donald Miller. The case was reopened last year after one of the boy's sisters told a reporter that she and other members of the family were suspicious of the death.

title: Seoul's Model: Tokyo or Manila
description: Does South Korea's President, Chun Doo Hwan, want to take his country back to the primitive politics now roiling the Philippines or forward to the economic miracles of Japan?

title: PORCELAIN DISHES: FORM AND FUNCTION
description: ALL-PURPOSE porcelain baking dishes, such as the French-made versions pictured here, are very useful for winter roasts, casseroles and vegetable preparations. These handsome glazed dishes can be brought directly from oven to table, reducing the number of dirty pots and pans.

title: Mayor Culpa
description: After weeks of blaming others for New York City's scandals, Mayor Koch has delivered an extraordinary confession: He heads the government he has been campaigning so loudly against. Speaking at City Hall, Mr. Koch acknowledged at last that his personal integrity, which was never disputed, is not enough to make an honest government.

title: MACHINE VISION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Jan. 28 about the premature birth of a son to the journalists Harold Evans and Tina Brown incorrectly described the status of Mount Sinai Hospital in the city's emergency medical network. The hospital is designated to receive ambulances under the 911 emergency system. B9

title: BRONX TEACHERS COMPLAIN OF CAMPAIGN PRESSURES
description: Teachers and parents in a Bronx school district have complained that teachers and other staff members are being pressured to circulate and sign qualifying petitions for some candidates in the coming community school board elections, school officials said yesterday.

title: And Raise You $788,000
description: The papers had a story the other day about a man getting a $788,000 raise. He is Orel Hershiser, a pitcher employed by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: KOCH SAYS HE'D TAKE PARTY CHIEFS' AID
description: Despite his statement on Monday that he had grown too close to Democratic leaders, Mayor Koch said yesterday that if he had it to do over again, he would accept their support in his political campaigns.

title: FOR POTENTIAL M.B.A.'S, LESSONS IN RELAXATION
description: The 20 students stood perfectly still, with their eyes closed and their arms outstretched before them. A lost soul searching for the right classroom opened the door, took on a rather puzzled look and asked, ''This isn't business administration, is it?''

title: SCREEN: TWIN BILL DOCUMENTARIES
description: ''THE WOMEN OF SUMMER'' (57 minutes) and ''A Day at the Grave of Karl Marx'' (30 minutes) comprise the first-rate documentary bill opening today at the Film Forum.

title: General Foods Recalls Its Plain Brie Cheese
description: The General Foods Corporation is recalling all its one- and two-kilogram wheels of plain, unflavored Brie cheese, saying some lots might contain the same bacteria blamed for the deaths of at least 39 people in California last year.

title: VINES WITHSTOOD FLOOD
description: Officials say the Napa Valley wine country's loss from flooding in last week's fierce storms will probably be about $16 million, but the dormant vines sustained little damage.

title: 0.7% LOCAL RISE IN COSTS TOPS NATIONAL INCREASE
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose in January by seven-tenths of 1 percent, more than double the national increase, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: JOHN A. MACK, an international securities broker, was making a return trip to his dentist for a gold filling. ''What a day I've had - everything's gone wrong,'' the dentist groaned as he inserted the filling in Mr. Mack's mouth. ''Ah!'' the dentist cried happily. ''The filling fits perfectly. The day is saved.''

title: A DIFFERENT NASA: AGENCY ATTITUDES HAD SHIFTED
description: In a day of frequently conflicting, sometimes emotional testimony, the key players in the launching of the space shuttle Challenger managed to agree on one point:

title: JACOR COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $305,800. c-Net loss.

title: MEESE SAYS HE WOULD SHUN SUPREME COURT POST
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he would not accept an appointment to the Supreme Court should a vacancy occur.

title: 2 DEAD AND 4 HURT INCLUDING 3 OFFICERS, IN A BRONX SHOOTOUT
description: Three police officers were shot early yesterday in the Bronx in a shootout with a gunman who killed a holdup victim and wounded another before he himself was killed, the police said.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including a gain of $1,317,000, or $1.4 a share, on the sale of the West Paces Racquet Club.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VOICES OF THE EMPIRE The four-year-old Ubu Repertory Theater brings contemporary French-language plays to English-speaking audiences in the United States. The playwrights come not only from France, but from Quebec and Francophone countries. As part of its program of staged readings and discussions, Ubu is currently offering a festival of plays from French-speaking Africa and the Caribbean.

title: IN THE CAPITALS OF SOUTHEAST ASIA, CAUTIOUS RELIEF
description: The news of the departure of President Ferdinand E. Marcos from the Philippines was received with cautious relief in Southeast Asian capitals. There had been growing concern that the Philippines was headed for civil war.

title: STATES CANNOT MAKE UTILITIES INCLUDE OPPONENTS' LITERATURE IN THEIR BILLS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that under the First Amendment states cannot require utility companies to include in their billing envelopes the messages of groups with which they disagree.

title: NBC News Show Close To Catching CBS Rival
description: NBC's ''Nightly News'' broadcast, in its best performance since 1982, came close to catching ''The CBS Evening News'' in the ratings last week, but the CBS program won, maintaining its 199-week-long hold on first place.

title: SEGOVIA, AT 93, EMBARKS ON TOUR
description: It was Andres Segovia's 93d birthday Friday, and the venerable maestro of the classical guitar was preparing for a tour of the United States.

title: GORBACHEV'S SPEECH: TOUR DE FORCE OF STAMINA
description: Near the end of his daylong speech to the Communist Party's 27th congress today, Mikhail S. Gorbachev faltered momentarily. Inadvertently skipping a page, he lost his train of thought and fumbled with his papers for a moment.

title: NICARAGUA AND COSTA RICA HOPE FOR PACT
description: Costa Rica has agreed to work with Nicaragua to establish ''a permanent force of inspection and vigilance'' charged with keeping peace along their border.

title: Water Gains Enable City to Lift Warning
description: With water levels in New York City's reservoirs above normal for the first time since July 1984, Mayor Koch yesterday lifted a drought warning that had been in effect since last November.

title: HERNANDO COURTRIGHT
description: Hernando Courtright, who made the Beverly Wilshire Hotel a glamorous place for the rich, died Monday after a stroke and a heart attack.

title: Richardson: The Bottom Line
description: The only way to look at the banning of Micheal Ray Richardson from the National Basketball Association is that his permanent disqualification will send a message to other players currently involved in cocaine.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN my youth when I was apprenticing in a Burgundy kitchen, one of the first foods I was allowed to prepare without supervision was what is known as beurre maitre d'hotel or maitre d'hotel butter. This is a dish of softened butter blended with salt and pepper plus a small amount of lemon juice or, on rare occasions, vinegar. It can be made well in advance and applied to a hot, freshly cooked slice of beef just before serving.

title: ARMY TRADITION TO LIVE ON
description: Jack Riley and his son, Rob, were interviewed on television recently about the fact that the son would succeed the father as the Army hockey coach next season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The long agony is over. We are finally free, and we can be truly proud of the unprecedented way we achieved our freedom, with courage, with determination and most important, in peace.''

title: Why Unemployment Is Worse Than They Tell Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Demand for Securities Strong
description: Investor demand was very strong yesterday for more than $2 billion of new corporate and mortgage-backed securities, even though prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed.

title: ONCE FORBIDDEN MALACANANG PALACE LURES PEOPLE OF MANILA TO ITS GROUNDS
description: On Day One after Ferdinand E. Marcos left, his palace was arguably the world's most crowded people's park.

title: 19,000 Miners Stay Home In South Africa Strike
description: A strike by blacks at the Vaal Reefs gold mine grew worse today when 19,000 miners seeking the release of nine jailed co-workers stayed off the job, the miners' union said.

title: China Contract For G.E. Group
description: A General Electric Company consortium signed a contract with China's Huaneng International Power Development Corporation worth $365 million, to provide two Chinese power plants with equipment, including four coal-fired generating units.

title: A COMPUTER MAKER STUMBLES
description: As an Israeli paratroop commander, Aryeh Finegold never lost a man in battle. But as president and chief executive of the Daisy Systems Corporation, he just lost 100.

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUBWAY SURVEY FINDS SOME '85 GOALS MISSED AND OTHERS MET
description: New York City's subway system failed to meet its goals set last year for fixing broken doors, unlighted cars and public-address speakers, but it met goals for maps and signs and reversed a trend toward decay in service, according to a survey released yesterday by a private advocacy group.

title: U.S. Teams Checking For Airline Violations
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration says that Government inspectors are scrutinizing several airlines for possible violations that could warrant penalties.

title: Hagler-Hearns II?
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Thomas Hearns will meet again on June 23 if both fighters win bouts March 10, Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager, said yesterday.

title: BUYING A WASHING MACHINE: START BY BEING YOUNG
description: Suppose a woman in Warsaw decides to buy an iron, or a refrigerator, or a hair dryer, or a vacuum cleaner. How does she do it? A newcomer to Poland might imagine the buyer simply goes to one of the large Government department stores in the center of the city and buys any of the appliances that are on display.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF TESTIMONY AT INQUIRY ON CHALLENGER DISASTER
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, held in Washington yesterday by a Presidential investigative panel, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News:

title: MILITARY SEES PROBLEM IN GROUNDING OF THE SHUTTLE
description: The Under Secretary of the Air Force said today that there would be ''severe'' problems in launching vital military satellites if the three remaining space shuttles remained grounded for more than a year.

title: TRILOGY LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 29
description: b-Includes a charge of $10.5 million to increase the company's reserve for discontinued development activity, and a $5 million provision for the estimated settlement costs of a class action suit against the company. c-Includes a $43 million reserve for discontinued development activity.

title: VULCAN INDUSTRIAL PACKAGNG LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Downhill From the Summit
description: The Reagan-Gorbachev agreement, at their Geneva summit talks, to ''accelerate'' negotiations on nuclear arms reductions is turning sour. The leaders' resolve to meet again in Washington this summer, instead of stimulating the talks as intended, is itself becoming a bone of contention.

title: RYMER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Including a tax loss carryforward of $286,000. c-Including a tax loss carryforward of $1,177,000.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHITES. Stories by Norman Rush. 150 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. ''WHITES.'' The title of

title: PITFALLS AND REWARDS OF READING THE SCORE
description: THE other evening, just as Kurt Masur was about to give the upbeat for Brahms's C minor symphony, I opened my score and was struck by an incongruously humorous association. A version of that first page has been sitting on my desk for months with all the instrumental parts written in the treble clef, along with a cover letter from a man who insists that universal music literacy could be achieved if only the intransigent idiots of the artistic establishment (for whom he has some much more colorful invective than that) would come around to the wisdom of abolishing all the other clefs in which music is written. The idea is that it's easier to learn one clef than three or four.

title: JUDGE DROPS ELECTION CASE AGAINST FIEDLER AND AIDES
description: Charges of violating the state election code against Representative Bobbi Fiedler and an aide involving a Republican primary contest for the United States Senate were dismissed today by a California judge.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $48,000 and an extraordinary loss of $613,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $540,000. d-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $124,000 and an extraordinary loss of $613,000.

title: FAMOUS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After nonrecurring charges of $140,000 and a loss of $219,000 from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards for the quarter, and including a gain of $163,000, or 3 cents a share, from tax loss carryforward for the year. c-After nonrecurring charges of $1,147,000. d-Net loss.

title: She Whose Constituents Are 61 Million Children
description: Ask Marian Wright Edelman about her children, the more than 61 million of them under 18 years of age, and she will tell you they are America's poorest citizens, its least powerful and one of its fastest growing minorities.

title: UP-RIGHT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $139,000 for the latest quarter and $310,000 for the year-earlier period. c-After extraordinary credits of $161,000 for the latest year and $133,000 for the earlier year.

title: Technology; Standardizing Automation
description: THE future of manufacturing is currently undergoing debugging at a General Motors truck assembly in Pontiac, Mich. G.M. Engineers are installing a factory communication system that should allow computers, process controllers, robots and other machines made by competing suppliers to communicate with each other.

title: Aquino's Days at Academy Are Recalled in Pennsylvania
description: Some old friends lent moral support this week as Corazon C. Aquino became president of the Philippines. Mrs. Aquino spent the 1946-47 school year at the Ravenhill Academy, which was operated by Sisters of the Assumption.

title: THE GRAMMY TELECAST
description: THERE was, between yawns, the usual quota of scrapbook moments: Kenny Rogers, the host, opening the ceremonies with an apparently sincere declaration about how the music world has always had a conscience; Julian Lennon appearing in what looked like a long, black 19th-century undertaker's smock; Pat Boone clapping along to a hard-driving Phil Collins performance; Mick Jagger, seen from London via satellite, wearing what seemed to be a replica of Julian Lennon's smock; the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, after asking, ''Isn't this a wonderful show so far?,'' committing the organization to battles against censorship and, with a bow to loftier economics, illegal home taping.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Cablesystems Corp., Beverly, Mass., has elected Barry D. Lemieux president and chief operating officer.

title: U.S. RULES OUT A LINKAGE OF ARMS AND SUMMIT TALKS
description: The United States today rejected a suggestion by Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the timing of his next meeting with President Reagan should depend on progress in the Geneva arms control negotiations.

title: AIDS in Queens and Kokomo
description: Ryan White, a normal Indiana kid except that he has AIDS, is being kept out of school because some adults aren't learning about the disease fast enough. A judge in Kokomo has temporarily barred Ryan from classes on the plea of some parents that he has a communicable disease. But at a recent hearing, all three doctors testified - as would doctors anywhere in the country - that Ryan's affliction is not contagious in his school setting as long as reasonable precautions are observed.

title: FARLEY INDUSTRIES HIRES ECONOMIST-LOBBYIST
description: For the last five years, John M. Albertine has been known as one of Washington's foremost free-market advocates. Now he is getting a chance to put theory into practice.

title: Conde Nast Tackles Business
description: NEXT month the British arm of the international Conde Nast publishing empire will add a new publication, the first in many a year. The subject matter will be quite a departure from anything the company has here or abroad. It will cover business on a monthly frequency and be called just that, Business. The first issue will carry 76 pages of advertising.

title: JERSEY BUS COMMUTERS' DELAYS RISE
description: The Port Authority's express bus lane into Manhattan, which allows 65,000 New Jersey commuters to cut more than a half-hour from their morning trip, has reached the saturation point and is causing delays for many riders.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE CONCORDE IS QUICKER On Aug. 3, 1492, Christopher Columbus, the Genoan sea captain, set out on his ''voyage to the East,'' commanding a fleet of three vessels - the decked, 117-foot Santa Maria and the two 50-foot caravels, the Pinta and Nina. In October he sighted land, an island in the Bahamas now named El Salvador. A year later he sailed to Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and Jamaica. And in 1498 he found the mouth of the Orinoco River in Venezuela.

title: NATIONAL FSI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that because it went public in August 1985, its results for the year-ago fourth quarter and full and for the full year 1985 are pro forma.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The World Bank yesterday offered $200 million of triple-A-rated 8 7/8 percent non-callable 40-year bonds at a price of 99.831 to yield 8.89 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: F.D.A. Expands Recall To 4 More Brie Brands
description: The Food and Drug Administration expanded the nationwide recall of Brie cheese today to four additional brands that may be contaminated with a potentially fatal bacteria.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Per share figures reflect a 50 percent stock dividend to be paid March 31.

title: More Lottery Repeaters Are on the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING MOST OF 10 BY 10 FEET
description: ALTHOUGH her name really is Lois Lane, she doesn't work at The Daily Planet.

title: He Seldom Hits Texas Leaguers
description: He's not quite a Roy Hobbs or a Joe Hardy, but, given the splash he made when he showed up for the opening of the Texas Rangers' Florida camp the other day, the biggest difference may turn out to be that Pete Incaviglia arrived with an impressive set of already-verifiable credentials. Among them: N.C.A.A. Division I record totals of 48 homers and 143 r.b.i.'s in a 75-game season at Oklahoma State last year.

title: HIGH STYLE, LOW PRICES
description: FINDING a well-priced, well-made and stylish piece of furniture that fills a gap at home is bound to be one of the more time-consuming and frustrating tasks facing any homemaker.

title: Piston Streak Reaches Nine
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 30 points and the Detroit Pistons tied a club record with their ninth consecutive victory tonight, a 111-104 triumph over the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Restored Housing For 450 Families
description: Eight abandoned apartment houses in the Bronx and Brooklyn will be renovated by private agencies to house 450 homeless families, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title:
SMART SHOPPING;
DISCOVERING BARGAINS IN DECORATOR FABRICS
description: ANYONE who has ever ventured into a showroom selling decorative fabrics knows that the price of a few yards of goods can soar to hundreds of dollars. There are, however, stores where shoppers can find a wide range of such fabrics from top manufacturers at surprisingly modest prices. For example, a Schumacher cotton-rayon tapestry that sells for $30 to $50 a yard might cost $6 to $15.

title: Court Delays Execution
description: The United States Supreme Court today ordered Florida authorities to postpone the scheduled March 4 execution of Theodore Bundy, convicted killer of two Florida State University sorority members. The Justices, granting an emergency request, said Mr. Bundy's life should be spared until the Court considered a formal appeal filed on his behalf.

title: HOOPER HOLMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUBLISHING: COMPLAINTS DELAY VON BULOW BOOK
description: Alan M. Dershowitz's book on the case of Claus von Bulow, who was acquitted of charges of trying to kill his socialite wife, Martha, had been scheduled for publication next month but has been postponed pending further legal review. The review was prompted by complaints from lawyers for the children of Mr. von Bulow's wife, who has been in a coma since December 1980, and from several other people mentioned in the book. Random House officials say that they have taken those complaints into account and have made some changes, but they deny reports that the book - ''Reversal of Fortune'' -is being either withdrawn or gutted.

title: DANCE: CHOREOGRAPHERS CLUB
description: CHOREOGRAPHERS do not grow on trees, a fact sometimes forgotten in this post-Balanchine era. Showcases of new talent provide a chance for fledgling choreographers to gain valuable professional experience and for the audience to look at new talent.

title: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,594,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the termination of a pension plan; and including in the 9 months a gain of $330,000 from the sale of manufacturing facilities and certain product lines. c-Net income.

title: 4 CONVICTED BY U.S. JURY IN BOSTON RACKETS TRIAL
description: A Federal jury today convicted Gennaro J. Angiulo, two brothers and an associate of racketeering activity including murder, illegal gambling and loansharking. The jury found a fourth brother guilty of illegal gambling but not racketeering.

title: Against Normalizing U.S. Relations With Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Actor Found Dead In Y.M.C.A. Room
description: Brian Englund, an actor and a son of the actress Cloris Leachman was found dead Tuesday in his room at the McBurney Y.M.C.A. on West 23d Street in Manhattan, the police said.

title: A Collection Contract Is Permitted to Expire
description: New York City's contract with Systematic Recovery Service expired yesterday and was not renewed, city officials said.

title: What Harms Women in the Workplace
description: The defeat, last month, of a 12-year-old sex discrimination action against Sears, Roebuck & Company has been widely decried by feminists. In reality, however, the outcome of the suit may lay the foundation for wiser employment policies, helping eventually to advance women in the workplace and society at large.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Tuesday of Louis Silberkleit, co-founder of Archie Comics Inc., misidentified his second wife, who survives him. She is the former Nicole Bernheim.

title: Guy F. Harrison Dies; Symphony Conductor
description: Guy Fraser Harrison, a conductor and organist, died last Thursday at his home in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. He was 91 years old.

title: AMERICAN FILM BAZAAR GOES UPSCALE
description: From the number of working elevators to the kinds of movies being sold, the sixth annual American Film Market has an air of quality that it lacked during its first five years.

title: U.S. UNBLOCKS $26 MILLIION HAITIAN AID
description: The State Department announced today that the United States would provide the new Government in Haiti with $26.6 million in economic and military aid that had been suspended by Washington in the last months of the Duvalier regime.

title: MICHAELS STORES reports earnings for Year to Dec 29
description: b-Net loss, after a charge of $115,000 for an accounting adjustment.

title: SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Utility Financing In San Antonio
description: A $326.6 million financing by San Antonio to refund previously issued electric and gas system revenue bonds was offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 8 percent for bonds due in 2010 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: SYRACUSE SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SHUTTLE DECISION: THE CHAIN OF COMMAND
description: Discussion about the effects of cold on the booster rocket was apparently confined to the rocket manufacturer, Morton Thiokol, and NASA executives from the Marshall Space Flight Center, which manages the shuttle propulsion systems.

title: Indian Protest Disrupts Commerce and Travel
description: Demonstrators protesting price increases hampered commerce in much of the nation today and paralyzed Bombay, a financial and shipping center.

title: Kickbacks Inquiry
description: Up to 50 percent of all employees who make purchases for military contractors routinely solicit and receive thousands of dollars in illegal kickbacks from subcontractors, Senate investigators said today.

title: ANDERSON SAYS HE HAS VOTDS TO PASS TRAM BILL
description: The majority leader of the State Senate said today that he had enough votes to pass a bill on Monday to reopen the Roosevelt Island tramway.

title: SEGOVIA AND 23 ARTISTS HONORED IN LIBRARY GALA
description: It could only happen in New York -one of those glamorous, star-studded evenings in which the talk is of dance, music and Broadway.

title: Belafonte Heartened As He Weighs a Race
description: Harry Belafonte, the singer, ''encouraged'' by a warm reception from senators at a breakfast here, said today that he would decide by Monday whether to run this year against Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.

title: Asian Journalists Ask Guarantees by Aquino
description: A group of Southeast Asian journalists urged President Corazon C. Aquino today to restore press freedom and civil liberties in the Philippines.

title: WHITTAKER'S IS SELLING H.M.O.'s TO TRAVELERS
description: Abandoning its strategy of forging the first comprehensive national chain of health maintenance organizations, the Whittaker Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its H.M.O.'s to the Travelers Corporation.

title: NEW FEARS OF FIGHTING STIRRING IN SRI LANKA
description: An impasse in the negotiations to end the fighting in Sri Lanka is stirring new fears that the Government and its foes may resume their warfare on a larger scale than before the talks began.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a credit agreement reached by Commodore International Ltd. overstated the company's loss and revenues in the year ended last June 30. It lost $113 million on sales of $883 million.

title: CHURCH ACTIVISM RAISES QUESTION OF POPE'S STAND
description: Vatican officials said today that the vocal part played by the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines had raised difficult questions about the church's political role and about Pope John Paul II's campaign to distance priests from political activity.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
In Louisville's Schools, An Integration Success
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. WALTER L. DARDEN
description: Dr. Walter L. Darden, a family physician for 60 years in the Central Ward of Newark, died Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings per share do not reflect the 2-for-1 stock split declared Tuesday and payable on April 7.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOND RALLY IS GAINING MOMENTUM
description: The bond market rally accelerated yesterday, as prices for long-term Treasury issues rose more than 2 points, and yields fell below 8 1/2 percent for the first time since October 1978.

title: What a Gas . . . Station
description: At the opening yesterday of the Westin, which by next summer will be the third new luxury hotel at the intersection of 24th and M Streets, the chain's president, Dwight Call, observed amid flowing champagne that it was ''sort of like a gas station on every corner: You don't have to feel you are out there pioneering all by yourself.''

title: NOBEL INSURANCE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $317,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, said it was buying two Indiana banks for a total of $50.3 million in stock.

title: Article 090686 -- No Title
description: The Pentagon's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1987 contains a request for $8.6 billion in spending for research and procurement for which no public accounting is given, according to an analysis to be published by The National Journal on Friday.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Seabrook Nuclear Plant Stages Mock Emergency
description: A mock alert sounded at the Seabrook nuclear plant today, signaling the start of an emergency response test that could have real consequences on Federal licensing of the reactor.

title: RUNOFF SET FOR TWO LEADERS IN SAN DIEGO ELECTION
description: Two former City Council members, Maureen O'Connor and William Cleator, will face each other in a runoff to determine the successor to Mayor Roger Hedgecock, who resigned after conviction for perjury and conspiracy.

title: GLIEDMAN'S 7 YEARS IN OFFICE SAW NEW HOUSING PRESERVATION EFFORTS
description: For nearly seven years, Anthony B. Gliedman's job has ranged from managing thousands of abandoned apartments buildings to encouraging new construction in a city that has a chronic shortage of decent housing.

title: CURFEW RESUMED AS NEW DISTURBANCES ERUPT IN HAITI
description: New disturbances racked the country today, only hours after Gen. Henri Namphy, president of the five-man interim Government, lifted a monthlong curfew and appealed, in an address to the nation, for unity.

title: MATSUSHITA ELECTRIC INDUSRIAL CO LTD (JAPAN)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 20
description: All results are translated at the rate of U.S. $1.00 equals 203 yen. Each American Depositary Share (share earnings) represents 10 shares of common stock.

title: Mobile Signs Agreement
description: The Mobile Communications Corporation of America said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy 85 percent of the outstanding shares of the American Cellular Telephone Corporation for $135 million, or $7.25 a share.

title: MYSERSON IS AWAITING RULING ON EL MUSEO BEFORE GIVING FUNDS
description: The Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, Bess Myerson, said yesterday that she would not restore city financing to El Museo del Barrio until the Commissioner of Investigation made a recommendation on the matter.

title: Chilean Editor Is Jailed
description: A military court today jailed Fernando Paulsen, news editor of an opposition publication and a freelance correspondent for Time magazine and The Wall Street Journal, pending a trial on charges of slandering the national police.

title: Litton Net Off 36.7%
description: Litton Industries said today that it earned $47 million, or $1.68 a share, in its second fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, down 36.7 percent from $74.2 million, or $1.74 a share, a year earlier. Revenues for the quarter totaled $1.17 billion, up 4.5 percent from $1.12 billion a year ago.

title: More Than Tea and Typing
description: ''We still teach them how to balance a teacup,'' Eleanor P. Vreeland, president of the Katherine Gibbs School, said yesterday over lunch. ''It helps them to develop confidence, to make them feel comfortable in what they are doing.''

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A Hitters' Park
description: Speaking of the long ball: If it's really true that the pitchers are ahead of the hitters in early season, then this should be a fireworks-filled spring at the University of Georgia, once the batters find their best groove. On Tuesday afternoon at Foley Field in Athens, playing their seventh game of the season, the Bulldogs blasted eight out of the park -three by Roger Miller, a freshman catcher - in an 18-12 victory over Georgia College.

title: A.T.&T. Electronic Mail
description: The American Telephone and Telephone Company has begun offering an electronic mail service that will instantly send a short message for 40 cents and more than two typewritten pages for about 80 cents. A.T.&T. has been using the system internally and testing it with 200 other companies.

title: PRESIDENT URGES PUBLIC TO BACK ARMS INCREASES
description: President Reagan declared tonight that any cuts by Congress in his military spending proposal would threaten United States security and endanger any chance of improving relations with the Soviet Union.

title: UNIONIST SAYS EASTERN ACTED TO SHIELD BORMAN
description: Machinists would have been willing to make concessions to keep Eastern Airlines independent, the head of their union says, but company leaders were ''no longer interested in the pursuit of labor cost reductions.''

title: Howard da Silva Memorial
description: A memorial service for Howard da Silva, the actor, director and producer who died Feb. 16, will be held Monday at 1 P.M. at the Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street. It will be open to the public.

title: Nets Can Make a Move
description: The Nets were told yesterday that they could replace Micheal Ray Richardson on their roster immediately, although the club has not yet determined how it will go about filling the spot on a permanent basis.

title: Feeling of Remorse
description: Mark Ingram, Michigan State's top pass receiver, said he knew he had done wrong and felt ''very remorseful.'' His coach, George Perles, said Ingram had been a model citizen recently.

title: Sit-In at Smith College Goes On for Second Day
description: About 200 Smith College students who seized the school's administration building to protest the trustees' decision to retain investments in companies doing business in South Africa kept administrators and secretaries out for a second day today.

title: SEAMAN FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company noted that results are pro forma.

title: Y.M.C.A. CLASS: LOG HOME BUILDING
description: For those interested in building a log house, doing electrical repairs or learning about flower arrangements, classes being offered in March by the Y.W.C.A.'s Craft Students League may be of interest. Registration is under way for three courses of four sessions each: How To Build Your Own Log Home, Electrical Wiring and Flower Arranging I. According to Glenn Overk, the teacher of the first course, log homes have grown in popularity. ''I decided if someone was going to tackle a project that size themselves, they needed more than the information the companies were providing,'' he said. The course will include discussions of choosing the right building site, comparison of different log systems, log-building equipment, solar heating systems and construction. Trips to a log home under construction and to several finished homes are planned.

title: MOSCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MICHIGAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and including an extraordinary gain of $932,000 in the quarter and year; after a loss from discontinued operations of $510,000 in the year, and including net from discontinued operations of $168,000 in the year. c-Restated to give effect to a change in accounting method for valuing certain inventories from a LIFO basis to a FIFO basis: The effect was to decrease previously reported income from continuing operations and net income by $496,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8,074,000.

title: PAYING LESS FOR KITCHEN APPLIANCES
description: THERE are two ways to buy kitchen appliances such as ranges, refrigerators and dishwashers in Manhattan: cheap and cheaper. From the Bowery north to midtown, dealers sell appliances for 20 to 50 percent off list. But the trick to buying any appliance is to compare not just price but also timing of delivery and charges for installation and to include the extra costs if a plumber or electrician is needed.

title: SHIFT TO LONDON MARKS SALOMON'S GLOBAL REACH
description: In a personnel shift meant to take advantage of rapid expansion in its international business, Salomon Brothers Inc. announced yesterday that Peter M. Gottsegen, a managing director in charge of international corporate finance activities in New York, would move to London to oversee global finance activities.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Feb. 17 about a court battle over the estate of J. Seward Johnson, son of a Johnson & Johnson founder, included an erroneous description of a document being used by his widow to discredit family members seeking her husband's fortune.

title: New Pact for Tudor
description: He was the top left-handed pitcher in the National League last season and he won two games in the World Series. Now John Tudor is getting some consolation for the one he lost.

title: DOROTHY N. MARSHALL
description: Dorothy Nepper Marshall, former dean and acting president of Bryn Mawr College, died here Monday after a long fight against cancer. She was 72 years old.

title: Winning Habit
description: What do you give to women who have everything? How about some competition? In its last three games, the undefeated Texas Longhorn women's basketball team has underscored its No. 1 national ranking by a combined 322 points to 135. The first victim was Miami of Florida (112-43), followed by Southern Methodist (105-48) and then Texas Christian (105-44).

title: NASA OFFICIAL ORDERS REVIEW OF 900 SHUTTLE PARTS
description: A top space official has ordered a thorough review of the nearly 900 critical items on the space shuttle whose failure could lead to catastrophe.

title: VOLUNTEERS COMFORT LONELY AIDS CHILDREN
description: It was devastating enough when Nina Shearer learned that her 3-year-old daughter - her only child - had AIDS. But Mrs. Shearer's trauma deepened as she and her daughter, Jackie, were gradually cut off from the world they had known.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Southern California Edison Company is offering $300 million of 9 1/4 percent, 30-year first refunding mortgage bonds at 99.80, to yield 9.27 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: REAGAN'S REQUEST FOR CONTRA AID IS MEETING RESISTANCE IN CONGRESS
description: Congressional opponents of President Reagan's request for $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels began to mobilize today, indicating that the Administration faces an uphill fight to gain passage of the authorization.

title: CONCERT: CHICK COREA AT TOWN HALL
description: THE fusion of jazz and classical music remains an elusive ideal; still, some exceptional artists have been at home in both worlds. Friedrich Gulda recently devoted one side of an album to Beethoven's Sonata in E (Op. 109), the other to a solo improvisation. Over the course of his career, Mel Powell has embraced unfettered jazz stylings and the rigors of serial composition. And, just two years ago, the jazz keyboardist Keith Jarrett played a well-received program of classical piano music in New York.

title: BRIGHT LIGHT FROM THE WEST
description: At first glance, the mask covering Bret Holmdahl's face seemed a perfect way to cope with the bleakest season in the 81-year basketball history of Manhattan College. More than a few of the loyal Jaspers in the stands had been driven to wearing paper bags over their heads, and Holmdahl's face has also been covered for the last month of a lost season.

title: LEBANON CAR BOMB KILLS DRIVER, HURTS 7 AT PALESTINIAN SITE
description: A car bomb exploded today at the entrance of the largest Palestinian refugee district in southern Lebanon, killing the driver and wounding seven people.

title: G.E. Credit Offers $500 Million Notes
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering two issues of extendible notes totaling $500 million through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DSC COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $50 million for the quarter and after a loss of $13,718,000 for the year from cumulative effect of accounting change. c-Net income.

title: A SPLIT DECISION ON BORMAN
description: Frank Borman's 10-year tenure as chairman and chief executive of Eastern Airlines cannot be assessed simply.

title: Merrill Unit Is Realigned
description: Merrill Lynch Futures has decided to fold most of its operations into divisions of its parent company, Merrill Lynch & Company, a senior executive said yesterday.

title: FOE OF NAZIS AND ARMY JUNTA
description: Lady Fleming, the Greek-born widow of the British scientist who discovered penicillin, and a prominent political activist, died in Athens today. She was 73 years old.

title: Venezuela in Debt Accord
description: Venezuela yesterday signed an agreement to stretch out repayments on $21.2 billion of its $26 billion of public-sector debt.

title: BROWN-FORMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
REPUBLIC HEALTH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax benefit of $170,000 in the quarter and $2,645,000 in the year. c-After a charge of $467,000 in connection with early extinguishment of debt. The company said year-ago figures were restated for the acquisition of Health Resources Corp. on a pooling- of-interests basis on Dec. 31, 1984.

title: MARCOS IS NO STRANGER TO HAWAIIANS
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, have been frequent visitors to the Hawaiian islands over the years, where they have many friends, including the Governor.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1986
description: International

title: STRIKE THREATENED AT EASTERN
description: The flight attendants' union renewed its threat yesterday to strike Eastern Airlines on Saturday, further complicating the carrier's attempts to solve its financial and labor problems.

title: Money, Money, Money
description: Just how much can a top lawyer-lobbyist earn in Washington, presumably the town where that particular combination of skills is most in demand? One answer, coming to the surface this week in a flurry of papers disgorged by the firm of Patton, Boggs & Blow, is $1,072,000.

title: Bridge: Boulenger Was a Mainstay Of Many Fine French Teams
description: In world team championship play the third most successful country, after Italy and the United States, is France, with four victories in the past three decades. Among the stars who represented France on many occasions was Jean-Michel Boulenger, who died recently at the age of 51.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & COMPANY-Carroll E. Ebert, vice chairman, bought and exercised option of 22,528 shares giving him directly a balance of 35,078 shares.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net losses.
