Why CBS Scrambled Network Feed to Affiliates
description: To the Editor:

title: MURRAY HIRSCH
description: Murray Hirsch, head of Guild Advertising Inc., a New York advertising and marketing agency, died Monday at Cabrini Hospice.

title: Books: Mehta, Cont'd
description: SOUND-SHADOWS OF THE NEW WORLD. By Ved Mehta. 430 pages.

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CANADA ACTS TO SLASH ITS BUDGET DEFICIT
description: The Canadian Government, faced with a declining dollar and high interest rates, announced today that it was taking steps to reduce its budget deficit significantly for the fiscal year beginning April 1.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a charge from adjustments related to currency transactions of $440,000 in the quarter and $771,000 in the 6 months. c-After a loss from currency adjustments of $8,000 in the quarter and $318,000 in the 6 months.

title: Western Union Loss Widens
description: The Western Union Corporation said today that it lost $335.7 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $62.2 million a year ago. Revenues slipped 10.8 percent, to $257.8 million, from $289.1 million a year ago.

title: All Hail Saudi Arabia
description: The Saudi Arabian Ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, and his wife, Princess Haifa al-Faisal, will play host to a salute to the cultural heritage of their country next Tuesday, and the event promises to be spectacular even by Washington, and perhaps Arabian, standards.

title: Worthen Bank Deficit Widens
description: The Worthen Bank Corporation, the largest banking company in Arkansas, said yesterday that it lost $6.59 million in 1985's fourth quarter, much more than its loss of $452,474 a year earlier.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a pre-tax gain on the sale of property of $2,137,000.

title: USG Agrees To Buy Donn
description: The USG Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the closely held Donn Inc., a producer of ceiling grid and interior access floor systems, for 2.8 million shares.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: 2 BOMBING DEFENDANTS WED
description: The wedding vows were traditional, but the setting for the ceremony Feb. 2 was not.

title: ST. JOHN'S DOWNS SYRACUSE IN BIG EAST SHOWDOWN
description: St. John's turned in one its most inspired performances of the season last night. With all five starters scoring in double figures, crashing the boards and unleashing a relentless inside attack, the Redmen defeated Syracuse, 86-79, before a sellout crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

title: SHUTTLE OFFICIALS DENY PRESSURING ROCKET ENGINEERS
description: Key middle-level space agency managers denied today that they had used ''harsh language'' or undue pressure to force a contractor to reverse a recommendation against launching the shuttle Challenger in cold weather Jan. 28.

title: Deere Optimism
description: The future for Deere & Company and agriculture in general is looking brighter, Robert Hanson, the company's chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting. Although the company lost more than $34 million in the first quarter of this year because of the continuing poor farm economy, he said, fuel costs will be affected by declining oil prices, and the reduced value of the dollar will aid the export of American farm commodities.

title: STEVENS, J P & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $18,757,000, which includes a non-recurring capital gain of $16,400,000, or 94 cents a share, from the sale of Foote & Davies Inc., and income from discontinued operations of $2,357,000, or 13 cents a share. The latest and year-earlier quarter nets exclude sales of the discontinued commercial printing segment. The latest quarter sales exclude those of the Woolen & Worsted Fabrics division for the month of January.

title: SCIENTIFIC COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pacific Telesis Deal Approved by Judge
description: The Pacific Telesis Group won approval from a Federal judge today for its $430 million purchase of Communications Industries. The decision could pave the way for other Bell telephone companies to expand outside of their service areas.

title: REAGAN BUDGET SAID TO MISS CEILING
description: Asserting that the White House has significantly underestimated military spending in its 1987 budget, the Congressional Budget Office said today that President Reagan's spending plan was $15.7 billion over the deficit ceiling of $144 billion.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains on investments of $155,000 for the quarter and $3,016,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $265,000 on investments. d-After gains of $631,000 on investments. All 1984 results are after an after- tax charge of $15.6 million for a discontinued life insurance product and a one-time tax benefit of $24.4 million.

title: Robert B. Brode, a Physicist; Helped Develop Atom Bomb
description: Robert B. Brode, one of the physicists associated with Robert Oppenheimer in the development of the atomic bomb, died Feb. 19 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: Gorbachev's New Old Direction
description: There is a curious point-counterpoint both to Mikhail Gorbachev's urgent demand for an overhaul of the Soviet economy and to the way his Communist Party is reacting.

title: Irish M.P.'s Kill Divorce Bill
description: The Irish Parliament today voted 54 to 33 against a bill to end the country's constitutional ban on divorce introduced by the Labor Party.

title: ACME UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PIONEER IN FIELD OF RADIOLOGY
description: Dr. Russell H. Morgan, a pioneer in radiology and dean emeritus of the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, died Monday at the Stella Maris Hospice in Baltimore after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: HAWAII GREETS THE MARCOSES WITH FLOWERS AND SUN
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos began his exile in the United States today under a warm Pacific sun, a pair of large flowered Hawaiian leis around his neck.

title: OPPONENTS SAY THEY WILL TRY TO STRIP MARCOS OF MILLIONS IN ASSETS IN U.S.
description: Representatives of the new Philippine Government and some members of Congress said today that they would take steps to try to strip former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of millions of dollars of assets in the United States that might have been gained illegally.

title: The 'G' in G.O.P. Is for 'Glitch'
description: The postman handed the letter to me and whispered, ''You must be more important than I thought.'' The letterhead indicated the sender was Senator Paul Laxalt. In part, the letter congratulated me ''on my acceptance for membership in the Republican Inner Circle to help President Reagan fight for Republican control of the U.S. Senate.'' The letter stated that my name had been placed in nomination by Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania, a gentleman unknown to me but certainly a public figure of consequence.

title: ALOHA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses, after losses from discontinued operations of $2,503,000 for the quarter and $4,149,000 for the year.

title: Gov. Janklow of South Dakota Announces Senate Challenge
description: Gov. William J. Janklow, saying changes need to be made in Congress to help Middle Western farmers and small towns survive economic problems, has announced that he will seek the United States Senate seat now held by a longtime Republican ally.

title: Kodak Alters Research Setup
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, continuing a broad reorganization and shift of its product lines, said that its research and development operations would be realigned in an effort to speed product development.

title: Winfield's Camp Absence Explained
description: Dave Winfield and Rickey Henderson were missing when the Yankees held their first full spring workout today. Henderson had a note from his doctor, so his absence was excused. Winfield's, though, was not explained until several hours after the workout ended, and it prompted contrasting reactions from the owner (displeasure) and the manager (unconcern).

title: PEN GRANTS MEMBERSHIP TO KOCH
description: Seven weeks after he was rejected for membership in the American branch of PEN, Mayor Koch has been voted a member of the international organization of writers.

title: REBELS TO FIGHT ON, A COMMUNIST SAYS
description: The New People's Army, the Communist fighting force, will continue its insurgency despite the departure of Ferdinand E. Marcos, a ranking Filipino Communist said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RICHARDSON NOW ADMITS USING COCAINE
description: Perhaps the reality of what he had done did not sink in for several hours. Maybe that was why many hours passed before Micheal Ray Richardson confessed to the truth: He had indeed used cocaine.

title: KOCH TALKS ABOUT CITY
description: ED KOCH is doing all right, according to Ed Koch. That's the short answer to ''How're We Doin'?'', tonight's ''Metroline'' interview with the Mayor on Channel 13, at 10 o'clock, when he comments on such perennials as housing, education, crime, corruption and the city's subways.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IF seepage is making a basement damp - that is, if water is seeping directly through the masonry walls, rather than entering at cracks, holes or open joints -then filling these openings probably will not make the basement completely dry. You will have to try to seal the entire wall surface.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 7
THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Tournaments: Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, quarterfinals at Byrne Meadowlands Arena: LaSalle vs. Holy Cross, 2:30 P.M.; St. Peter's vs. Fordham, 4:30 P.M.; Fairfield vs. Manhattan, 7 P.M. and Iona vs. Army 9 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7 all games. WFAS-FM, 103.9; 9 P.M. only.) Atlantic 10 Conference, quarterfinals. Rutgers at St. Joseph's (Pa.), 7:30 P.M.; Penn State at West Virginia, 8 P.M.; George Washington at Temple, 7 P.M., and Duquesne at St. Bonaventure, 7:30 P.M. Sun Belt Conference, quarterfinals at Birmingham, Ala., Old Dominion vs. North Carolina-Charlotte, 1 P.M.; Jacksonville vs. Virginia Commonwealth, 3 P.M. and Alabama-Birmingham vs. South Alabama, 7 P.M. Western Kentucky vs. South Florida, 9 P.M. (Television - ESPN 1 P.M., 3 P.M. 7 P.M.) North Carolina State at Georgia Tech, (Television - ESPN 9 P.M.) Michigan State at Northwestern, (Television -SportsChannel 8 P.M.) Kentucky at Tennessee, (Television - USA 8 P.M.), Oregon State at Stanford, (Television -ESPN 11 P.M.) Golf Honda Classic, at Coral Springs. Fla., opening round. Curtis Strange won the $90,000 first prize last year with a par on the first extra hole in a playoff with Peter Jacobsen. L.P.G.A. Uniden Invitational, at Costa Mesa, Calif., opening round. Bonnie Lauer will be back to defend her crown in the tournament that features both American and Japanese L.P.G.A. members. Hockey Rangers vs. Pittsburgh Penguins, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Rangers are still trying to catch the Penguins and claim the final playoff spot in the Patrick Division.

title: Of Aides and Ink
description: When Addison Emilia Helmke was asked recently to tell her kindergarten classmates what her father did for a living, she explained with a 6-year-old's economy of words, ''He sees President Reagan, he works for Senator Lugar and his job is to talk on the telephone.'' As press secretary to the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mark C. Helmke, the aforementioned father, has been spending a good deal of time on the telephone in the past few weeks - relaying, explaining and interpreting Senator Richard G. Lugar's opinions on the political crisis in the Philippines. On the record.

title: CECO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROBERT PENN WARREN NAMED NATION'S FIRST POET LAUREATE
description: Robert Penn Warren, the 80-year-old poet, novelist and essayist, was designated today as this country's first official Poet Laureate.

title: Mets Get Corcoran, a Versatile Player
description: The Mets, who have been shopping for a reserve catcher and a left-handed pinch-hitter, solved half their problem today: They signed the free agent Tim Corcoran, a five-year veteran of the big leagues and an accomplished left-handed hitter who can play both the outfield and first base.

title: U.N. AIDE SEEKS TO END IMPASSE IN AFGHAN TALKS
description: A leading United Nations official said today that he would travel to the capitals of Afghanistan, Pakistan and Iran next week to try to break a deadlock in talks on Afghanistan.

title: STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest year shares outstanding results reflect the effect of the repurchase and retirement of 327,762 shares during the year.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TO THE MOUNTIE, FAR NORTH FEELS LIKE HILL STREET
description: One tense day last June, Cpl. Robert H. Peterson of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police faced down a drunken gunman.

title: DAWKINS BETTERS RECORD AS DUKE DOWNS CLEMSON BY 77-69
description: Johnny Dawkins scored 27 points to lead top-ranked Duke to a 77-69 victory over the Clemson Tigers tonight.

title: Baltimore's Markets
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: BOTTLE TAMPERING IN TYLENOL FOUND
description: An F.B.I. official said yesterday that a detailed examination of the bottles in Westchester County that held cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules found there had been tampering with the packaging.

title: AQUINO'S CABINET: OPPOSITION BLEND
description: The 17 Cabinet officials named today by President Corazon C. Aquino seem to be largely a blend of opposition politicians from the years of resistance against the Marcos Government.

title: RARE CATTLE GENES: A SUCCESS STORY
description: A project to preserve rare breeds of cattle from extinction, started a decade ago by employees at historical theme parks such as Old Sturbridge Village in Massachusetts, has blossomed into a national movement to save hundreds of rare and endangered breeds of farm animals from extinction.

title: BankAmerica Corp. To Study Weill Bid
description: The BankAmerica Corporation disclosed last night that its board would consider an offer from Sanford I. Weill, former president of the American Express Company, to become chief executive officer of the financially troubled holding company.

title: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JUSTICES UPHOLD LAWYER'S THREAT TO A CLIENT WHO PLANNED TO LIE
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a criminal defendant's constitutional rights were not violated by his lawyer's threat to expose him if he lied at his murder trial.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $280,000 from the sale of a limestone quarry in Lebanon, Pa. The share earnings reflect a 4 percent stock dividend to be paid Feb. 28.

title: INQUIRY ON CHALLENGER: EVIDENCE OF DESIGN FLAWS
description: For the first time in the heated and sometimes startling inquiry into the Challenger explosion, investigators are beginning to suggest that evidence of critical design flaws in the craft was so strong that the space agency should have stopped the shuttle flights last summer.

title: CHRYSLER 'LEMON' PANEL ASSAILED
description: The Chrysler Corporation is running a ''sham'' customer complaint board that gives buyers of ''lemon'' cars the runaround instead of a new automobile, State Attorney General Robert Abrams charged yesterday.

title: ANGER RISESAFTER WORKERS CUT DOWN PARK'S OLD WISTERIA
description: A couple of weeks ago, Christabel Gough noticed that most of the gnarled, old vines entwined in the wisteria pergola near the Central Park Mall had been chopped down.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN TALK ON ARMS BUDGET, AND DEMOCRATIC RESPONSE
description: Following are excerpts from the speech on military spending by President Reagan last night in Washington and of a response by Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the House majority leader, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: AT JERSEY TRIAL, MURDER SUSPECT ADMITS AFFAIRS
description: A Toms River insurance broker charged with planning his wife's 1984 murder conceded under cross-examination today that despite his expressions of ''undying'' love for his wife, he had pursued other women before and after the killing.

title: AMERICAN AIR SETS SPRING DISCOUNTS
description: American Airlines, in what many say signals the opening of a spring fare war, said yesterday that it would offer discounts of up to 75 percent below its regular coach fare between April 1 and May 22. Two of American's competitors, United and Republic, promptly responded by saying they would slash certain fares.

title: DEMOCRATS SAY ARMS PLAN WOULD REQUIRE A TAX RISE
description: Representative Jim Wright, the House majority leader, said this evening that it would be impossible to continue President Reagan's proposed military buildup and balance the budget unless there was a tax increase.

title: DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $89,000 for the quarter and $187,000 for the year.

title: 15-1 Shot Wins in Florida
description: Midway Circle, one of the few long shots to run for the perpetually heavily backed Woody Stephens stable, scored a dramatic victory as a 15-to-1 outsider in the $59,150 Fort Lauderdale Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: HERS
description: IN the bottom drawer of the changing table, beneath the snowsuits and the hats, is a pink and white striped dress with a white pinafore. It is a size 12 months. The wife of one of my husband's law partners sent it more than two years ago, when my first child's somewhat androgynous name and my stubborn feminist refusal to put a colored ribbon on the birth announcements led her to the conclusion that Quindlen Krovatin was a girl. He was not. I wrote in the thank-you note that I would return the dress for a jogging suit or a pair of overalls, but I never did, and there it lies in the drawer, with the tissue still stuffed inside it, like some limp little body. It has been joined by a pair of white socks with pink birds on the cuffs and a pink cardigan sweater.

title: Taddei Returns to 'Falstaff'
description: Giuseppe Taddei, the 70-year-old Italian baritone who made his Metropolitan Opera debut to critical and audience acclaim earlier this season in the title role in ''Falstaff,'' will return for three unscheduled appearances in the role, the Met announced. He will sing Friday, Monday and on March 8, replacing Louis Quilico. Mr. Quilico will sing the role in the remaining performances, March 11 and 15. Mr. Taddei, whose long career has centered on the Vienna State Opera and the leading Italian houses, had sung in New York only in concert performances before his Met appearances last fall.

title: RCA/Sharp Joint Venture Delayed
description: RCA/Sharp Microelectronics, a joint venture of RCA and Sharp of Japan, is delaying construction of a $250 million electronics plant in southwest Washington while it assesses the impact of the pending merger of RCA and General Electric, a spokesman said. Jon Shroyer, president of RCA/Sharp Microelectronics, said that work on the plant would be held up four to five months.

title: LAP-TOP AWARD BUOYS ZENITH
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation has pulled off a coup by winning the Internal Revenue Service's $27 million lap-top computer contract.

title: MARCOS IN HAWAII
description: Corazon C. Aquino began her first full day as President of the Philippines Wednesday by naming 17 Cabinet members, conferring with defeated rival politicians and holding her first presidential news conference.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STRICT LOCAL RENT CONTROL LAW UPHELD
description: In a ruling likely to make it far more difficult to use antitrust laws to challenge regulatory actions by local governments, the Supreme Court today upheld a strict ordinance on rent control in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Global Steel Output Up
description: Non-Communist countries increased their crude steel production by 4.2 percent between January 1985 and January 1986, according to figures published today. The International Iron and Steel Institute said in its monthly bulletin that output in the 30 countries covered by its statistics was 36.8 million tons in January 1986.

title: A Biederman Toast
description: Biederman & Company, with glasses high, toasts the good judgment of the management of Freixenet, the Spanish-wine marketers, who have seen fit to assign the agency its Castellblanch Brut Zero and Brut Extra wines.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our hearts and hands are with President Aquino and her new Government as they set out to meet the challenges ahead. Today the Filipino people celebrate the triumph of democracy and the world celebrates with them.'' - President Reagan. [ A15:3. ]

title: PAUL HARRIS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Dick Coury, a former United States Football League coach of the year who coached the peripatetic Breakers in Boston, New Orleans and Portland, Ore., has been named quarterback coach of the Los Angeles Rams. . . . The comeback attempt of the defenseman Bob Dailey, who last played for the Philadelphia Flyers in 1981, continues. He has been signed to a new contract and assigned to the Flyers' Hershey Bears American League team. Dailey's career was halted by a serious ankle injury in November 1981.

title: Building a Dream

title: Market Place; Stock Reaction To I.R.A. Flow
description: THE prospect of billions of dollars of fresh cash pouring into the stock market as taxpayers rush to park their money in Individual Retirement Accounts is one reason some market soothsayers are optimistic that the party on Wall Street is far from over.

title: Sebring, Fla., Utility Is Raising $119 Million
description: The Sebring, Fla., Utilities Commission is raising about $119 million through the sale of interest-bearing and non-interest-bearing bonds with a face amount of about $280 million through underwriters led by Wertheim & Company.

description: SMALL inexpensive plants - at under $5 each - flourish all over town. The places to buy them are supermarkets, dime stores and the small plant shops in the wholesale flower district along the Avenue of the Americas between 26th and 30th Streets.

title: REAGAN WELCOMES CHANGE IN MANILA
description: President Reagan sent a congratulatory message to President Corazon C. Aquino today, saying the United States ''welcomed the democratic outcome'' of the Philippine elections, according to White House officials.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Saturday about economic pressures that have driven some merchants from Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights contained an incomplete account of the status of the Dress Rehearsal clothing shop. The shop left Montague Street but has reopened at 104 Atlantic Avenue.

Why We Celebrate
description: It is a long time since Americans of all political views have felt so good about our country's role in a transforming event abroad. From left to right, we are proud that the United States helped the people of the Philippines carry out their Glorious Revolution.

description: For 105 years, Adm. David Glasgow Farragut fixed his gaze over visitors to Madison Square Park. Now, he is looking out over the people of Boston.

title: OPERA: 'STONE GUEST'
description: IT may not be news to most women, but Don Juan lives, both in myth and everyday reality. In the three and a half centuries since Tirso de Molina wrote the first recorded Don Juan drama, ''El Burlador de Sevilla y Convidado de Piedra,'' (''The Seducer of Seville and the Stone Guest''), hundreds of playwrights, poets and composers have taken the legendary libertine as their subject. In opera alone, more than 40 works deal with him, including Alexander Dargomyzhsky's ''Stone Guest.'' The Chamber Opera Theater of New York gave what was claimed as the American stage premiere of the Russian work Tuesday evening at Marymount Mahnattan Theater.

title: JURY HEARS DIFFERING VERSIONS OF EX-AGENT AT 2D SPY TRIAL
description: The jury in the retrial of Richard W. Miller on espionage charges today heard the former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent portrayed by the prosecution as a ''vulnerable, morally weak and corrupt loser.''

description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $138,000 in the quarter and $368,000 for the 9 months. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $180,000 in the quarter and $359,000 for the 9 months.

title: ZENTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $65,000 for the quarter and $127,000 for the year. The year result also includes a gain of $31,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after an extraordinary tax charge of $370,000. c-Net income including an extraordinary tax benefit of $424,000. Previous year results are after nonrecurring expenses of about $1,314,000 for the quarter and about $2,685,000 for the year.

title: The New 'Wonder Five'
description: They form the new St. John's ''Wonder Five'' - Walter Berry, Mark Jackson, Willie Glass, Shelton Jones and Ron Rowan.

title: TRAVELING ANCHORMEN EVERYWHERE BUT MANILA
description: New technology and heated competition for news viewers are increasingly driving network anchormen to take their programs on the road, broadcasting their evening newscasts from distant and highly promotable locales. But that trend caused some awkward moments this week, when anchors found themselves in the wrong places when big news broke in the Philippines.

title: Dow, Up 4.24, Edges Toward 1,700
description: On the strength of just two stocks, Union Carbide and Kodak, the Dow Jones industrial average moved closer to the 1,700 level yesterday while the rest of the market turned in an unremarkable performance.

title: POP: SONGS BY CRAWFORD AT GREGORY'S
description: STEPHANIE CRAWFORD, who is singing at Gregory's, First Avenue at 63d Street, on Sundays and Mondays, has some interesting surface qualities but she has not yet managed to make them add up to a consistent performing style.

title: 8 TO REPAY $7.8 MILLION IN S.E.C. INSIDER CASE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had settled the last of a series of landmark insider trading cases involving the $2.5 billion takeover in 1981 of Santa Fe International, an oil and gas company, by the Kuwaiti Government.

title: MUSIC: BARRY TUCKWELL
description: BARRY TUCKWELL'S skill as a horn player can sometimes make inferior works seem better than they really are, but at his 92d Street Y recital on Tuesday night, performing skill could not dispel the ennui induced by much of the music in the program. It is not that the compositions by Charles Koechlin, Thea Musgrave, John McCabe, Richard Rodney Bennett and Poulenc were of dismal quality, but that not one vibrated with the vitality and sense of discovery characteristic of superior artworks.

title: Giuliani Given Honor By Jay College Paper
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, has been chosen to receive the annual Man of the Year award for 1985 of The Law Enforcement News, a publication of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice of the City University of New York.

title: A Philippine Moment
description: As the Marcos regime fell in the Philippines, the mood at the embassy in Washington sounded a sympathetic chord in a minor key. Pale rectangles marked the walls where Mr. Marcos's image had hung, and shredded documents littered the floor, presumably left when the Ambassador, Benjamin T. Romualdez, departed a week ago.

title: British Trade Surplus
description: Britain's trade balance improved sharply in January, helped by a record oil surplus and a huge budget rebate from the European Common Market, the Department of Trade and Industry said today. Britain had a current account surplus of $1.6 billion in January, the best performance since March 1983 and up $829 million from December, a statement said. Imports fell by $405 million, to $8.56 billion, and exports fell $185 million, to $8.72 billion.

title: Easy Prediction
description: Buddy Ryan, new head coach of the Eagles, when pressed to predict the winner of the 6-4 outcome he foresees in the Philadelphia-Chicago game next season: ''The team with the 6.''

title: The Subway's First Track Record
description: Bits of good news on the subway have recently come from New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority - fewer derailments, fewer delays, some cleaner cars. But the best news is the authority's comprehensive report on new management improvements and disappointments.

title: THREE MORE HIGH CITY OFFICIALS RESIGN AS SHAKE-UP CONTINUES
description: Three high-ranking officials of the Koch administration resigned yesterday, the latest in a shake-up that began with Mayor Koch's re-election and has involved nearly 20 appointees so far.

title: Wheeling Loan
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge said he would approve $60 million in new loans for the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, but a prospective lender said it might change its mind and refuse to lend the money. An attorney for Irving Trust Company of New York said it might revoke its loan offer if the Environmental Protection Agency continues to insist that company assets be reserved in the agency's name to cover the installation of pollution equipment. Wheeling-Pittsburgh, the nation's seventh-largest steel producer, entered Chapter 11 last April in an effort to suspend loan payments while it reorganizes debts of $530 million.

title: Currency-Shift Reports Surge
description: The number of large currency transactions reported to the Government has quadrupled following the Bank of Boston's conviction in a money-laundering scheme, the Internal Revenue Service said today. For more than 10 years, the

title: INEXPENSIVE SHELVES
description: THAT convenient extra shelf for the closet, kitchen or bath does not have to be expensive. A couple of metal or wood brackets combined with a wood or glass shelf can cost under $15.

title: Gulton Accepts Mark IV Offer
description: Gulton Industries said it had accepted a $34-a-share acquisition offer from Mark IV Industries.

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Accounts
description: * Yamaha Motors Corp. to Abert, Newhoff & Burr, Los Angeles.

title: PETER VOGEL, ADVISER TO CUOMO ON AIDS AND RIGHTS POLICIES
description: Peter Vogel, an adviser to Governor Cuomo on AIDS and homosexual rights, died of pneumonia Monday at University Hospital of New York University Medical Center. He had been diagnosed as suffering from AIDS, acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: PROPERTY INVESTORS OF COLORADO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a $2.2 million pre-tax provision for unrealized losses on real estate held for sale and a $3.2 million pre-tax provision for writedowns in the carrying value of the company's 33 percent interest in three real estate partnerships.

title: Heavenly Game
description: Mike Brown of the Pittsburgh Pirates explains why he's glad to be a baseball player: ''I live in California, and when I see those thousands of people on the freeways at 7 A.M., I just say, 'Thank you, Lord, for giving me such a great job.' ''

title: Quotron Deal With A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Quotron Systems Inc. said yesterday they had signed definitive agreements to market a new system for financial services, the Integrated Financial Information System, that is based on Quotron's Q1000 computer and A.T.& T.'s Unix personal computer and local network.

title: Toxic Sewage Problem Cited
description: An estimated 202 million pounds of toxic chemicals flow into America's sewage plants each year, but huge amounts of these hazardous wastes escape untreated into the environment, a Federal study says.

title: CAPITALISM STILL BOGY IN MOSCOW
description: The 5,000 delegates gathered here for the 27th congress of the Communist Party have heard almost as much talk about capitalism as communism.

title: COASTAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EGYPTIAN POLICEMEN FIGHT TROOPS IN REVOLT SET OFF NEAR PYRAMIDS
description: Rebellious paramilitary policemen fought pitched battles with troops in the capital today as the Egyptian Government struggled to put down a revolt that began overnight in the luxury hotel section near the Great Pyramids.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Elagu Vaba Eesti, Indeed
description: Congress is going to some lengths to recognize Estonian National Independence Day.

title: GOLFERS ARE CRITICAL OF STADIUM COURSES
description: The PGA Tour moved East this week and continues Thursday with the opening round of the Honda Classic at Eagle Trace, one of the Tournament Players Club courses.

title: Hanoi Talks on the Missing
description: A United States military team arrived in Hanoi today to resume talks on American servicemen listed as missing in action in Vietnam and to set a date for the return of 14 sets of American remains, military officials said. In Laos, a joint United States-Lao team continued digging for remains in the wreckage of an AC-130 warplane shot down in southern Laos in March 1972.

title: People
description: * John R. Doman has been promoted to executive vice president, management supervisor at TBWA Advertising.

title: PRINCETON THEOLOGIAN WINS TEMPLETON PRIZE OF $250,000
description: Dr. James I. McCord, president of the Princeton Theological Seminary in New Jersey from 1959 to 1982, was named yesterday as the 1986 winner of the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, which carries a cash award of about $250,000.

title: CENCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $15,000 for the quarter and $380,000 for the year.

title: Soccer Stars in Benefit
description: The second FIFA World All-Star Game for the benefit of Unicef will bring 32 of the world's top soccer players to the Rose Bowl July 27, organizers announced yesterday. The first such game, played at Giants Stadium after the 1982 World Cup, drew a sellout crowd and raised $200,000 for Unicef.

title: GORBACHEV ON THE SOVIET ECONOMY: A FLOCK OF INNOVATIVE IDEAS
description: In his marathon keynote speech to the Communist Party congress on Tuesday, Mikhail S. Gorbachev went to great lengths to generate a sense of urgency and excitement over his economic program.

title: CRUISE MISSILE DEBRIS SOUGHT
description: An 11-man team ventured onto the frozen Beaufort Sea today to recover the wreckage of an unarmed American cruise missile that crashed at the start of a test flight.

title: FRIENDSHIP AT NEW HEIGHTS
description: Billy Olson of Dallas and Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union - whose winterlong competition on and off the pole-vault runway has spiced the track and field season - laughed and joked through lunch yesterday.

title: EX-MARCOS CABINET OFFICIAL HOPES TO LEAD OPPOSITION
description: A former Philippine Cabinet minister said today that he was making a bid for leadership of the still powerful remnants of Ferdinand E. Marcos's political party.

title: DOUBLE-MILLIONAIRE ODDS PUT AT ONLY 5.2 MILLION TO 1
description: On second thought, New Jersey lottery officials say, the chances of winning the millionaire drawing a second time are no worse than the 5.2 million to 1 faced by anyone who holds a ticket in the drawing.

title: EXPEDITORS INTERNATIONAL OF WASHINGTON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including pretax gains of about $200,000 for the quarter and year on the disposition of an investment and an office building.

title: VOLCKER SAYS FALLING DOLLAR AFFECTS FED POLICY
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the falling dollar remains a major factor in preventing the central bank from actively seeking lower interest rates.

title: BRIDGMAN'S 2 GOALS LEAD DEVILS' ROUT
description: The Devils did to Billy Smith tonight what the Islanders were expected to do to Glenn (Chico) Resch. They peppered Smith with 39 shots and even scored a short-handed goal for a 7-2 victory over the Islanders.

title: U.S. COAL LEASING TO RESUME
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel announced plans today for resuming the Federal program of leases for coal mining.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earning results are fully diluted. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split distributed Sept. 11, 1985.

title: PERES SAYS HE'LL FOSTER PALESTINIAN SELF-RULE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that he was considering measures to promote self-rule among Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Let's Go Back to the Days of the Police Department Hack Bureau
description: To the Editor:

title: CONVERSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LANGLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics; Numbers, Right and Wrong 411
description: A call to telephone information isn't what it used to be. Directory assistance operators in New York are using a prerecorded voice and by May 1, New York Telephone plans to expand this ''automated response'' statewide.

title: 33 POLITICAL PRISONERS MAY BE FREED
description: The Philippine armed forces Chief of Staff recommended today the immediate release of 33 political prisoners detained under the Marcos regime.

title: Violations at L.S.U.
description: Bob Broadhed, the athletic director at Louisiana State, his assistant, Bill McClure, and two track coaches have admitted violating the state code of ethics by accepting free transportation from companies seeking to install new tracks at the school, but state ethics officials said they would not be disciplined because the violations, which occurred in 1984, were unintentional. Broadhed, who did not make any of the trips - to inspect tracks in Tennessee and West Germany - said he had authorized the others to accept transportation from at a time when the school was contemplating installing a new track, a project that was later dropped.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1986
description: Markets

title: WAYNE-GOSSARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After the provision of inventory reserves for markdowns and LIFO of $347,000; losses incurred in a test- marketing venture and the 1985 closing of outlet stores of $198,000; $46,000 in expenses incurred in plant consolidations, and an adjustment of $154,000 of deferred income taxes provided in prior years.

title: Iran Says Its Troops Killed 1,500 Iraqis
description: Iran said today that its troops advanced farther into mountains in northern Iraq, killing 1,500 Iraqi soldiers and capturing another 25 villages.

title: Financial Corp.
description: The directors of the Financial Corporation of America voted to omit again a common stock dividend for the first quarter of 1986.

title: CUOMO READIES LEGISLATION TO STEM OFFICIAL CORRUPTION
description: Governor Cuomo plans to propose a series of bills Thursday to make it easier to prosecute corrupt public officials and organized-crime members.

title: Yields Off On C.D.'s And Funds
description: Average yields were off slightly for six-month certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday.

title: Four-Figure Question
description: What have you got when Grover Cleveland stares at you from a Federal Reserve note? First, you have $1,000. Second, you have a bill that has not been circulated in 17 years.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: UNION SPECIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net loss and includes a $3 million provision for restructuring for the quarter and year. c-After a tax credit of $1,312,000 and includes a pre-tax gain of $4.6 million from the sale of real estate.

title: DRANETZ TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax benefit of $666,000, or 14 cents a share.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SMUCKER, J M CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid in December.

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATION INTO CYANIDE DEATH OF MAN IN NASHVILLE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today joined the investigation of the death of a Nashville man who had cyanide in his body. A capsule of Extra-Strength Tylenol was found on the floor beneath his bed.

title:
SMART SHOPPING;
A FEW TIPS AND CAVEATS
description: WHEN shopping at off-price fabric stores, go armed with as much information as possible, including swatches or paint chips to be matched, and be prepared to return to the shop several times, because stocks change constantly.

title: CO-OP CITY AIDE CHARGED BY U.S. WITH EXTORTION
description: A former general manager of Co-op City was charged yesterday with extorting more than $350,000 from companies that did work at the giant apartment complex in the Bronx.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $414,000. c-Including a gain of $564,000 for the quarter, a gain of $3,657,000 on disposal of assets and gain of $1,715,000 from discontinued operations, both for the year. The quarter and year results also are after a buyout charge of $2,000,000. Share earnings results reflect a 3 percent stock dividend distributed Jan. 6, 1986.

title: BASIC MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago revenue results have been restated.

title: EDGAR BRONFMAN JR. IN LINE AT SEAGRAM
description: Edgar M. Bronfman Sr., chairman and chief executive officer of the Seagram Company, the giant wine and spirits enterprise controlled by his family, has informally tapped his son Edgar Jr. as his successor.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: QUILTING AND QUILTS
description: Quilts That Tell a Story, 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; 212-427-6000, extension 162.

title: WESTERN UNION CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $196,000. c-After an extraordinary charge of $19,269,000. d-After a gain from the termination of an inactive retirement plan of $4,216,000. e-After a tax credit of about $3.5 million and a net gain from the termination of an inactive retirement plan of about $1.4 million. The results for both latest periods included previously announced special charges of about $300 million, primarily for the writedown of older generation switching and transmission equipment. The 1984 results also reflect an extraordinary charge of $19.3 million from the reversal of the major portion of the $21.8 million tax credit that had been recorded for the first 9 months of 1984. This reversal resulted from the fact that Western Union recorded a pre-tax loss of $63 million in the year- ago fourth quarter.

title: CORRECTION
description: A page 1 Manila dispatch in some copies yesterday included an erroneous report, based on various news agency accounts, that Ferdinand E. Marcos had been taken off a United States Air Force plane in Guam on a stretcher. Mr. Marcos walked from the aircraft without assistance.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $16,157,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The 6 months also includes income of $258,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,693,000 for the quarter and $2,809,000 for the 6 months. The 6 months also includes a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $153,000.

title: Reaching Out
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Topics; Numbers, Right and Wrong The Reagan Effect
description: Have President Reagan's electoral victories turned out to be triumphs of person or of party? Party, ay wishful Republicans, as they talk grandly about ''fundamental political realignment.'' Person, say Democrats, just as wishful.

title: Italian Airman Held In Spying on NATO
description: An Italian airman who worked at the command center of a NATO nuclear missile base has been arrested on espionage charges amid indications that he sold secrets to Libyan agents, senior Italian officials said today.

title: Eat, Eat, Eat
description: The fastest-growing segment of the retail food market, we are told, is that evanescent area in which less is more: Lean This, Low That and Lite The Other. The problem is, no one seems to know just what that is supposed to mean.

title: D'LITES OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 7
description: b-Net income including extraordinary credits of $165,000 for the quarter and $230,000 for the 9 months.

title: Bridge: Odd-Even Tactic Succeeds In a Von Zedtwitz Contest
description: A European signaling method that is now used by many American experts is called odd-even. Odd spot cards - threes, fives, sevens and nines - are used to encourage a continuation of the suit led.

title: U.S. Budget Criticized As Obscuring the Costs
description: Arthur Andersen & Company, an accounting concern, said today that the Federal budget ''obscures the costs of current programs'' by failing to give an accurate picture of the Government's long-term obligations.

title: Stroh's Entering Juice Drink Market
description: The Stroh Brewery Company will enter the juice-based soft-drink market this spring with Sundance Natural Juice Sparkler, the 136-year-old company's first nonalcoholic beverage.

title: The Morning After in Manila
description: Insolvency and insurgency are the predatory vultures that most immediately menace the new democratic regime in the Philippines. President Corazon Aquino's first moves to assemble a cabinet show pragmatism and magnanimity. If her team can begin to mend a shattered economy and spread the benefits fairly it will be worth 10 divisions in combating Communist guerrillas. And at the margins, her task can be made easier by American help.

title: IMPERIAL CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All results are in U.S. currency. Four units of ICI ordinary stock are represented by each ADR.

title: Smith Protest Continues; Hunger Strike at Brown
description: About 200 students at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., continued their occupation of the administration building for a fourth day today to protest their college's holdings in companies doing business in South Africa, and four students at Brown University in Providence, R.I., began a hunger strike in a college chapel for the same reason.

title: Political Rags to Political Riches, Philippine-Style
description: On Monday Heherson Alvarez stood in the snowy chill in Lafayette Park across from the White House, demonstrating against United States support for Ferdinand E. Marcos, who was still the President of the Philippines.

title: RANGERS ROUT PENGUINS
description: Reijo Ruotsalainen skated around his defenders and passed the puck with a soft, almost magical touch. Mike Ridley was his usual hard-working self, scrambling about. Because of one player's splash and the other's diligence, the Rangers soared last night.

title: City Opera's 'Brigadoon'
description: The New York City Opera will inaugurate its first season of musical comedy with Lerner and Loewe's ''Brigadoon.'' There are five performances this weekend: tonight and tomorrow at 8 o'clock; Sunday night at 7 o'clock and matinees tomorrow at 2 P.M. and Sunday at 1 P.M. Tickets are $4 to $37. Information: 870-5570.

title: SPLIT WIDENS ON A BASIC ISSUE: WHAT IS A JEW?
description: America's Jewish religious groups are locked in an impassioned argument over fundamental questions of Jewish identity, with some leaders warning that the dispute could result in deep and enduring divisions in the Jewish community.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Stock Options
description: As a ploy to protect its own shareholders against the ramifications of a hostile takeover, and perhaps even to make takeover artists wary, the board of Foote, Cone & Belding Communiations voted yesterday to give its stockholders an option to buy a new series of preferred stock. For each share of common stock owned by a shareholder, a hundredth of a share of the preferred stock can be purchased for $165.

title: TAMARA BYKOVA IS BACK
description: Two years ago, in what seemed to be an early spring thaw, Tamara Bykova of the Soviet Union captivated a Madison Square Garden audience with a meet record in the high jump as well as with her lithe, intelligent presence.

title: DANCE: LIMON COMPANY IN 'THE MOORE'S PAVANE'
description: ''The Moor's Pavane,'' created in 1949, remains one of the classics of American modern dance and the enduring masterpiece of its choreographer, Jose Limon.

title: NORWESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KNOX LEADING BY 2 ON WINDY COURSE
description: After the PGA Tour eliminated Monday qualifying for 20 to 40 spots in each tournament in 1983, it filled 140 places each week from among the previous year's leading money winners and tournament winners.

title: UKRAINIAN FACING A TRIAL IN ISRAEL
description: A Ukrainian immigrant accused of killing thousands of Jews in the gas chambers of a German death camp in World War II was deported yesterday to Israel for trial. He was flown out of Kennedy International Airport aboard a regular El Al flight.

title: Iranian's Wedding Takes Place in Jail
description: An Iranian who was seized by immigration agents just as his wedding was to get under way finally was married today - in jail, where he must await another deportation hearing.

title: Woman Convicted Again In Death of U.S. Judge
description: The wife of a convicted drug smuggler today was found guilty a second time of conspiring with her husband and his brother to assassinate a Federal district judge.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $1,365,000. c-Including capital gains of $3,026,000. Share earnings results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in November.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a gain of $66 million from the cumulative effect of a change in pension reversion accounting.

title: JURY SUBPOENAS FILE ON BUILDING BY SCHOOL BOARD
description: In what prosecutors described as a major new investigation, a Federal grand jury is examining reports of corruption in the Board of Education's $350 million-a-year school construction, repair and maintenance program, law-enforcement and city officials said yesterday.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $217.4 million from the sale of discontinued operations. Results include the operating results of Chicago Title & Trust Company and its subsidiary, Chicago Title Insurance Company, for the period after June 30, 1985, effective date of their acquisition by Alleghany.

title: BROADWAY
description: SPRING on Broadway isn't marked by crocuses, tulips or daffodils. The Great White Way sprouts something better - a collection of optimists, cockeyed and otherwise, all convinced that their new show is going to be the smash hit of the season.

title: INQUIRY HEAD SAYS NASA ABANDONED SAFETY JUDGMENT
description: The chairman of the Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle explosion charged today that the space agency had abandoned ''good judgment and common sense'' in handling critical safety issues.

title: AUCTIONS
description: SOTHEBY'S annual auction of moderate-priced Old Master and modern prints, in which about half the offerings are odd lots of 2 to 44 items, will be held next Thursday and Friday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. This sale is not for the timid; it is aimed at collectors and dealers who seek offbeat works, some by minor artists, and who are willing to take a chance on engravings and lithographs that may require extensive restoration.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: IN making documentary films, according to Joyce Chopra, who has until now specialized in them, ''You are excited by what you already see, and you accept it as a given.'' In fiction film making, ''you make up an entire world.'' Miss Chopra did the latter in directing ''Smooth Talk'' (review on page C17), her first fiction feature, about the coming-of-age of a 15-year-old girl named Connie (Laura Dern) at the hands of a mysterious and possibly dangerous stranger (Treat Williams). Her biggest worry in making the transition to fiction was not having to work with actors, but the matter of staging. ''With a documentary, you go to the situation and cover the scene, you don't have to decide where to move,'' she said. ''But this time, I had to ask myself, 'How do you break a scene down? Where do you put the camera, and why?' ''

title: Article 420186 -- No Title
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Federal authorities in Hawaii had found 22 crates with new Philippine currency valued at $1,179,000 on a plane carrying private possessions of Ferdinand E. Marcos and the party that fled with him from the Philippines.

title: FILM: HAUNTING WITH A DIFFERENCE IN 'HOUSE'
description: THE title character in ''House'' is big, ominous and Victorian, and naturally enough it has a mind of its own. However, this is not the usual haunted-house movie, if only because the place still manages to look relatively cheery, and because its way of inflicting mayhem is unpredictable. First it abducts a little boy. Then it persuades a nice old lady, the boy's great-aunt, to hang herself. Finally it entraps the lost boy's father, a Stephen King-type author named Roger Cobb, into moving in and trying his luck. Somehow, the house decides to draw upon Roger's experiences in Vietnam to drive him crazy.

title: CONGRESS DEBATES A BILL TO KEEP MILK SUPPORTS
description: Two days before dairy price support payments were scheduled to be cut 4.3 percent under the new budget-balancing law, the House and the Senate today debated legislation to offset the reduction.

title: Greek Workers Strike Over Austerity Policy
description: Tens of thousands of workers went on a one-day strike today to protest the Socialist Government's austerity policies.

title: CATHOLIC PRESS RIGHT TO DISSENT WITHIN CHURCH
description: Many of the same Roman Catholics who placed a 1984 advertisement advocating the right to hold diverse views on abortion have reserved a second full-page advertisement in The New York Times Sunday that criticizes the church hierarchy for its ''reprisals'' against those who dissent.

title: PHILIPPINES FREES 34 HELD BY MARCOS
description: The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino Thursday released 34 prisoners who had been detained on political charges by the Marcos Government. Among them were five prominent civil rights lawyers and a poet.

title: MARCOS WEIGHS HIS CHOICE OF EXILE
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos spent today in seclusion, discussing with members of his family where they will settle permanently as exiles.

title: 2 Notables on 'Dirty' List
description: The Palm, a restaurant renowned for its steaks, and the main kitchen of the Plaza, a hotel famed for its elegance, were cited yesterday for violations of the City Health Code.

title: Misleading the People
description: ''We want agreements that truly diminish the nuclear danger. We want real agreements, agreements that really work, with no cheating.''

title: GETTING BAD NEWS AT THE TOP
description: The discovery that vital information apparently never got to top officials during the ill-fated launching of the space shuttle Challenger is a failure of a sort not unknown in business circles.

title: Navy Corrects a Verdict After Surgeon's Trial
description: The Navy today corrected the announced verdict against Comdr. Donal M. Billig, a Navy surgeon, saying the jury had found him guilty of 18 counts of dereliction of duty instead of 19.

title: Hoyt Seeks Treatment
description: The San Diego Padres have announced that LaMarr Hoyt has voluntarily entered a treatment facility for evaluation of a possible substance-abuse problem and is expected to return before the end of spring training. Hoyt, 31 years old, won the American League Cy Young Award in 1983 with record, then went to the Padres Dec. 6, 1984 as part of a six-player trade. Last season, his first with San Diego, Hoyt was 16-8 with a 3.47 earned-run average.

title: THEATER: LINNEY'S 'SAND MOUNTAIN'
description: When it comes to writing about the ''hot blood and high jinks'' of country people in our border states, no one can touch Romulus Linney. Himself a transplanted Tennessean, Mr. Linney never patronizes his earthy source material. With generosity and humor, he shows his people in their natural plumage, living full lives in the shadow of desperation and poverty.

title: The NU Quintet
description: The NU Quintet, with Don Cherry on trumpet, Carlos Ward on alto saxophone and flute, Mark Helias on bass, Ed Blackwell on drums and Nana Vasconcelos on percussion, is appearing through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $12,000 for the quarter and $26,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $16,724,000 for the quarter, $16,833,000 for the year and extraordinary charges of $288,000 for the quarter and $436,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: Deputy Premier of Malaysia Quits Over a Policy Dispute
description: Deputy Prime Minister Musa Hitam resigned today, officials of the governing party said.

title: EGYPT SAYS POLICE REBELLION IS QUELLED
description: After a third day of fierce street clashes here, the Egyptian Government said today that it had put down a rebellion by paramilitary police. Later, however, there were reports of renewed violence.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Art Baron Jazz Quintet, St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street (935-2200). Art Baron was a member of the trombone section in Duke Ellington's orchestra in the last year of the Duke's life and he continued for three years with the band under the direction of the Duke's son, Mercer. He assimilated the collection of growls, blurts, moans, slides and blats created by the seminal Ellington trombonist Tricky Sam Nanton. Currently, he is leading an Ellington-style ensemble called the Duke's Men. But on Sunday at 7 P.M. he is presenting in his own compositions the entire range of his musical experience from New Orleans parades through Ellington and Stevie Wonder to the avant-garde. His ensemble will include Jaki Byard on piano, Benny Wallace, tenor saxophone, Anthony Cox, bass, and John Vidacovich, drums. The program will include a band setting for what Mr. Baron described as an ''Ethiopian folk song that I heard and even played when I was in Africa with Duke and sat in with some local musicians,'' as well as ''Kate's Memorial Window Dance,'' inspired by both Fats Domino and Charles Mingus. Tickets are $7.50.

title: ALL-STAR GOALTENDER PLAYED 18 SEASONS
description: Jacques Plante, an innovative goaltender and a member of the National Hockey League Hall of Fame, died Wednesday night in a private hospital in Geneva, the league announced yesterday. He was 57 years old.

title: Another Year for Joiner
description: He's 39 years old now, and it has been two seasons since he set the National Football League record for most career receptions, but Charlie Joiner, the San Diego Charger wide receiver, isn't ready to call it a career.

title: DANCE: THE WORKS OFFERS TRIBUTE TO ALCANTARA
description: THERE are composers whose music serves not just as accompaniment for dances but as longterm collaboration that helps to form the choreographer's aesthetic. Such a composer is Burt Alcantara, the former musical director of Jennifer Muller's modern dance company, The Works.

title: PANEL TO DISPLAY FLY FISHING
description: Once again, Theodore Gordon Flyfishers Inc. has assembled an impressive panel of fly fishing experts for the annual Arts of Angling program and dinner.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday REQUIEM FOR A CHOIR With its red robes and majestic sound, the Westminster Choir has been a fixture over the years at musical celebrations of all kinds. It has entertained at the White House and raised its multiple voices in concert halls around the globe. This year the choir has a celebration of its own: its 60th anniversary. Tonight the group, which is made up of students from Westminster Choir College in Princeton, N.J., is back in New York. It can be seen at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center, where it will sing the Brahms German Requiem with the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, East Germany, under the baton of Kurt Masur. The soprano Elisabeth Soederstroem and the bass-baritone Theo Adam are soloists. Tickets are $25 and $17.50 and are available either at the box office or through CenterCharge (874-6770).

title: To America's First Poet Laureate
description: Robert Penn Warren has said he won't commemorate ''the death of someone's kitten.'' So we can forget about that. Neither does he choose to compose paeans to ''the greater glory of Ronald and Nancy Reagan.''

title: ERC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from minority interests in consolidated subsidiaries of $51,705 for the quarter and $41,847 for the year. c-Including gains from minority interests in subsidiaries of $5,997 for the quarter and $127,792 for the year. Results have been adjusted to reflect the acquisition of International Energy Associates Ltd. in June 1985.

title: ART: 'PAESTUM' LOOKS AT 18TH-CENTURY CLASSICISM
description: THE history of European architecture can be generalized as a series of ''returns'' to its Classical beginnings. Alternately, it is viewable as a Classical continuum with ups and downs but only one major interruption - Gothic. And while Gothic, which got its name from its Renaissance critics, lasted four centuries, it was largely confined to northern Europe.

title: BANK BUILDING & EQUIPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PAYING TRIBUTE TO A PATRIARCH OF MODERN DANCE
description: The Jose Limon Dance Company will offer a look into a rich and varied life tonight, when the company pays tribute to Lucas Hoving, a former Limon star, a choreographer in his own right and one of the wittiest and best-loved patriarchs of American modern dance.

title: 17.09 GAIN PUTS DOW AT 1,713.99
description: Sharply lower interest rates and further declines in oil prices caused stocks to rise sharply yesterday on Wall Street and gave the Dow Jones industrial average the push it needed to close above the 1,700 mark for the first time.

title: 10 INJURED IN BLAST AT BREWERS' CAMP
description: A natural gas explosion sent a ball of flame through the Milwaukee Brewers' new spring training clubhouse today, injuring 10 people including Manager George Bamberger and General Manager Harry Dalton.

title: BankAmerica Stock Up $2; Board Meeting Nears
description: Shares of the BankAmerica Corporation surged $2 in heavy trading yesterday, to $17.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, as the holding company for the financially troubled Bank of America prepared for a major board meeting Monday to consider a possible new chief executive.

title: Tango Music for Piano
description: The pianist Yvar Mikhashoff will present programs of 20th-century tango music at the Dance Theater Workshop tonight and tomorrow at 8 o'clock and Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
T.W.A. TO BUY OZARK IN BID FOR MORE TRAFFIC
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it would acquire Ozark Airlines for $19 a share, or about $225 million, under an agreement that would combine two struggling carriers with hubs in St. Louis.

title: BUFFETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
STANDARD OIL'S 2 TOP OFFICERS OUSTED
description: In a move that stunned Wall Street, the Standard Oil Company, which is controlled by the British Petroleum Company, announced yesterday that its two top officers would be replaced April 1. They are Alton W. Whitehouse, chairman and chief executive officer, and John Miller, president and chief operating officer.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PETTIBONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a loss of $7,025,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $32,045,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After a loss of $4,995,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $5,533,000 for the quarter and a loss of $14,035,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $5,533,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOUSE VOTES CONTEMPT CHARGES AGAINST 2 IN MARCOS INVESTIGATION
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to cite two brothers for contempt for not answering questions about their relationships or business dealings with Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda.

title: 7 CHARGED IN THE SALE OF FAKE DALIS
description: The New York State Attorney General arrested five people yesterday on charges of selling fake Salvador Dali lithographs.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $30,667,000 for the quarter and $29,868,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,125,000 for the quarter and $2,789,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: Cuban Jazz at Blue Note
description: There is a Cuban jazz double bill through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). The trumpeter Arturo Sandoval, who lives in Havana, will lead a group and trade sets with the conga player Mongo Santamaria and his group. Shows begin at 9 and 11 P.M. through and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: BERKLEY, W R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net realized gains on investments of $1,027,000 for the quarter and $2,030,000 for the year. c-Including net realized gains on investments of $660,000 for the quarter and $1,220,000 for the year. d-Net loss. Latest year results include those of Carolina Insurance Company which which was acquired on Jan. 30, 1985.

title: MACY, R H & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: The latest quarter was a 13-week period, compared with 14 weeks for year-earlier period.

title: CAROL BRITTO, SOLO PIANO
description: Carol Britto is playing solo piano tonight and tomorrow at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue above 82d Street (787-8300). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $7.50 minimum.

title: President Named At Chesebrough
description: In an announcement that caught analysts by surprise, Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., maker of Vaseline, Q-Tips and Ragu spaghetti sauce, yesterday named Robert M. Phillips to the new positions of president and chief operating officer, effective March 1.

title: MEESE SAYS HIGH COURT SET UP A 'FOURTH BRANCH'
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said tonight that independent Federal regulatory agencies constituted a ''politically unaccountable fourth branch of national government.''

title: MONEY LAUNDERING AT CITY'S OLDEST YESHIVA
description: Since just after the turn of the century, when East Broadway was part of a vibrant Jewish community on the Lower East Side, the Mesivtha Tifereth Jerusalem yeshiva - the city's oldest -has been training scholars and rabbis in the intricate study of the Talmud.

title: Economic Scene; Policy Issues' Tie to Business
description: THE business outlook for the next couple of years depends crucially on the outcome of a set of key policy issues. First comes the battle of the budget. The Gramm-Rudman law faces a constitutional test before the Supreme Court. But many economists believe that, whatever happens to the law, fiscal policy will soon be tighter. But how much tighter is difficult to say.

title: EXHIBITION FROM NAIROBI
description: The emotional impact of the World Conference on Women last year in Nairobi, Kenya, is dramatically reflected in an exhibition on view in a SoHo law office. Entitled ''What Women Want: A Report on the United Nations Decade for Women,'' the show includes five dozen photographs taken at the official United Nations conference as well as at the parallel Forum 85.

title: OUTLOOK ON INFLATION LIFTS STOCKS TO RECORD AS INTEREST RATES DROP
description: Stock prices surged and interest rates tumbled yesterday as investors became increasingly optimistic that inflation has been checked.

title: Carbide Vice Chairman Is Retiring Tomorrow
description: Alec Flamm, who until last summer served as president and chief operating officer at the Union Carbide Corporation, announced yesterday that he will retire tomorrow as vice chairman and a board member.

title: U.N. Says Famine Aid Is Still Needed in Africa
description: About 19 million Africans desperately need food even though there has been ample rain in much of the continent, the United Nations relief coordinator said today.

title: New Music at Roulette
description: The cornetist and composer Butch Morris will bring new music to Roulette, 228 West Broadway at White Street (219-82420 tommorrow at 9 P.M.. Tickets are $5.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $450,000 and a net gain of $145,000 from two sale transactions. c-Net loss after a writedown of $1,750,000.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $54.7 million, to $210.24 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Tobacco Ads Banned
description: President Reagan signed legislation today banning radio and television advertisements for smokeless tobacco and requiring packages to carry on a rotating basis three health warnings about the product.

title: AUTOTROL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,150,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, and an extraordinary charge of $357,000 for the quarter. c-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $145,000 for the quarter and $1,050,000 for the year.

title: STAGE: 'LITTLE FOOTSTEPS,' NEW TED TALLY PLAY
description: FOR better and for worse, there's a little something for nearly everyone in ''Little Footsteps,'' the new Ted Tally play at Playwrights Horizons. A comedy about a Manhattan couple (yes, yuppies) at the frantic juncture of parenthood, ''Little Footsteps'' has jokes for those who have had babies and for those who are childless, Jewish jokes and Wasp jokes, mother-in-law jokes and homosexual jokes, stand-up shtick and physical gags -not to mention a few sermonettes and tears.

title: CONSERVATIVE CHRISTIANS AGAIN TAKE ISSUE OF RELIGION IN SCHOOLS TO COURTS
description: After decades of losing battles, from the local school board to the United States Supreme Court, conservative Christians have returned the issue of religious instruction in the public schools to the Federal courts.

title: ABC FACES SUIT ON TAX CREDITS
description: Leading producers of television shows plan to sue the ABC television network Friday for $1.5 billion in a dispute over who can claim Federal investment tax credits, the Motion Picture Association of America said today.

title: Soviet Satellite Debris Tracked Into Atlantic
description: American military radar today tracked debris from a disintegrating Soviet satellite from Australia over the North Pole and across the northeast corner of the United States into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary expenses of $498,000 associated with litigation. c-Net income.

title: GRAND TOURS: A GUIDE TO GETTING BEHIND THE SCENE
description: ONLY a few feet may separate the front-row seats from the stage, but the magic and mystique of the performing arts often make that distance seem like an ocean.

title: PRETORIA FINDS MOZAMBIQUE NONAGGRESSION PACT 'ALIVE AND WELL'
description: South Africa said today that its nonaggression accord with Mozambique was ''alive and well'' after negotiations between senior figures from the two countries yesterday.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. San Antonio Spurs, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. This is the only visit of the season for the Spurs, who won the first meeting in San Antonio on Nov. 12. (Television -SportsChannel, 12:15 A.M., tape delay. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Mavericks vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Dallas. First meeting of the season between the two playoff contenders. (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.) Colleges: Columbia at Princeton, 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9 and WHWH 1350, 7:30 P.M.). N.C.A.A. Division III Eastern Regional at Potsdam: Alfred vs. Nazareth, 6:30 P.M. Potsdam vs. N.Y.U., 8:30 P.M. St. Francis (Pa.) at Marist, 7:30 P.M.; New York Maritime at Vassar, 7:30 P.M.; Sun Belt Conference tournament, semifinals, at Birmingham, Ala., 7 P.M. (Television -ESPN, 7 P.M. and midnight.) Women: N.C.A.A. Division III Eastern Regionals at N.Y.U. Coles Sports Center, Mercer and Bleecker Streets: Buffalo State vs. N.Y.U., 7 P.M., and Columbia vs. Albany, 9 P.M. E.C.A.C. Division III Metropolitan New York-New Jersey championships, semifinals, at Stony Brook: City College vs. Stony Brook, 6 P.M.; Rutgers-Newark vs. Hunter, 8 P.M. Hockey Islanders vs. Jets, at Winnipeg, Manitoba, 9:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 9 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 9 P.M.) Track and Field USA/Mobil Indoor Championships, at Madison Square Garden. trials, 11 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Opening ceremonies at 7:15 P.M. Sergei Bubka, Billy Olson and Joe Dial meet in the pole vault. Carl Lewis will run in the 60-yard dash and compete in the long jump.

title: From Morocco With Love
description: Back in 1777, when the ink was scarcely dry on the Declaration of Independence, Morocco became the first nation to recognize the United States, and a treaty of peace and friendship between the two countries was signed by Sultan Sidi Mohammed III in 1786 and approved by Congress in 1787. The State Department says this is the longest unbroken treaty relationship in the nation's history.

title: IRAQIS STALLED BY A TENACIOUS ENEMY
description: Despite overwhelming superiority in firepower and equipment and almost complete mastery of the air, the Iraqi Army is being ground down by Iran, its tenacious enemy, because it lacks motivation and the will to fight, Western military analysts and diplomats here say.

title: Paris Bookstore Explosion
description: A bomb exploded today in a Latin Quarter bookstore specializing in anti-Communist works, causing extensive damage but no injuries, the police said.

title: MODULAIRE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FILM: 'SMOOTH TALK,' FROM JOYCE CAROL OATES TALE
description: CONNIE WYATT (Laura Dern), 15 years old, leads two lives. At home, she's the gawky, alternately sarcastic and sullen, younger daughter who refuses to wash a dish or to speak civilly to anyone in the family. Like the Marin County (Calif.) house the Wyatts live in, Connie is unfinished, sort of empty and isolated, surrounded by a weedy landscape. She spends endless hours washing her hair and playing her tapedeck at ear-splitting volume. Says her exasperated, not unfond mother, ''I look into your eyes and all I see are trashy dreams.''

title: 2 RIVERDALE PROJECTS OFFER RIVER VIEWS
description: Where there is a cliff rising from a riverbank in New York City there is usually a striking view. And where there is a view there is the potential for development.

title: CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains of $3,990,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, $5,647,000 for the year and an extraordinary tax credit of $1,675,000 for the quarter and year.

title: AMBULATORY MEDICAL CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL OUSTED IN ARMY DISPUTE
description: A two-star Air Force general has been removed as European command surgeon, a position he was elevated to less than a month ago, the Defense Department said Wednesday.

title: FIRST FAMILY'S FOIBLES: A DRAMA IN TWO ACTS
description: When Patti Davis, elder child of President and Mrs. Reagan, signed a contract to write a semiautobiographical novel about coming of age as the daughter of a Republican with ''hardy good looks and a persuasive voice'' who becomes Governor of California and then President of the United States, she did not mention the fact to her parents.

title: HOLY CROSS GAINS AND WILL FACE IONA
description: St. Peter's, Holy Cross, Fairfield and Iona advanced, and Fordham, LaSalle, Manhattan and Army were eliminated as the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference playoffs opened at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today.

title: HAITI SAYS IT WILL SEEK EXTRADITION OF DUVALIER
description: The interim Government of Haiti announced tonight that it will ask for the extradition of former President Jean-Claude Duvalier who surrendered power and fled to France on Feb. 7.

title: Interlake Spinoff
description: Interlake Inc. said it plans to spin off its steel unit to shareholders.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Think of your countrymen who have already been hurt, who have already suffered so much under your regime.

title: PILOT OF JET DISARMS WOMAN WITH KNIFE ON PLANE IN MIAMI
description: A woman with a history of psychiatric problems who was mumbling to herself about a hijacking while using a steak knife on a flight from Miami yesterday was disarmed by the captain and taken into custody when the plane landed in New York, authorities said.

title: Stenmark Wins 82d Cup Race
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, with a time of 2 minutes 26.04 seconds, today won his 82d World Cup ski race, the 44th giant-slalom triumph in his 13-year World Cup career.

title: PEAK HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $27,723.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend last Friday about French activities in New York gave an incorrect address for St. Vincent de Paul Church. The church is at 123 West 23d Street.

title: Comings and Goings
