description: Eddie Murray, the Baltimore Orioles' first baseman, has been named team captain, the first in the club's history. . . . William Bedford, the 7-foot Memphis State center who had been considered likely to pass up his senior season to turn pro, said he had decided to remain in school because he needs the experience.

title: BUCKEYE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $305,000 from the early repayment of Federal Home Loan Bank Board advances and including a gain of $1,256,000 from Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock dividend, both for the quarter and year. c-Net income. The share earnings reflect 10 percent stock dividend declared in January and to be paid in March.

title: Ruling at Kansas State
description: An National Collegiate Athletic Association committee has ruled that Norris Coleman, Kansas State's high-scoring 22-year-old freshman, had not met minimum high school requirements, and the school immediately declared him ineligible. Kansas State officials said the decision was made by the five-person Administrative Committee, which said Coleman did not have a grade point of 2.00 when he was graduated from Paxson High School in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Swedish Stocks Plunge
description: Stock prices plunged today after Sweden's Government said it would double the tax on stock trading, to 2 percent. The Veckans-Affarer index fell to 618.9 points from 653.4.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1986
description: International

title: Broken Hill Bid
description: A bid by the Australian investor Robert Holmes a Court to buy control of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company was halted by a court injunction. The injunction was issued by the Supreme Court of the state of Victoria on behalf of Broken Hill, a steel, oil and mining concern that is Australia's largest company. Mr. Holmes a Court has offered to buy half of each stockholder's stake in Broken Hill. If successful, the bid would give him 52 percent of Broken Hill's stock. Mr. Holmes a Court valued the bid at about $3.5 billion (Australian), the equivalent of $2.45 billion at current exchange rates.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CHANNELS AT NASA: WARNINGS THAT FADED ALONG THE LINE
description: After hours of testimony this week, the picture emerging from the inquiry into the loss of the space shuttle is one of chronic failure in the space agency and among its contractors to communicate life-and-death problems up the chain of command.

title: DOUBT CAST ON KEY LEDGER IN BONN PAYOFF SCANDAL
description: A key prosecution document in a number of corruption inquiries - a ledger bearing the names of prominent West German politicians - may contain several erroneous entries, the former bookkeeper of the Flick holding company testified today.

title: 2 Ex-Employees of Arrow Air Subpoenaed in Crash Inquiry
description: A House subcommittee today subpoenaed two former employees of Arrow Air in its investigation of the crash of a chartered Arrow jetliner in Canada last year that killed 248 United States servicemen.

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CHRYSLER AND FORD OFFERING INCENTIVES
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, responding to buying incentives introduced last week by the General Motors Corporation, today announced their own plans intended to attract new-car buyers.

title: Thataway, Posse Comitatus
description: If you think the United States border is any barrier to the smuggling of drugs, you're blowing dope.

title: 'JUBILEE,' WHERE 'BEGUINE' BEGAN
description: TWO of Cole Porter's most beguiling standards, ''Begin the Beguine,'' and ''Just One of Those Things,'' can be savored in their original dramatic contexts Sunday and Monday when the New Amsterdam Theater Company presents a concert revival of ''Jubilee.'' A distinguished cast will perform the complete score and most of the libretto of the 1935 musical romp, which has a book by Moss Hart in addition to Porter's music and lyrics.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $11,400,000 for the quarter and year related to the disposition of the company's retail manufacturing operations and including a gain of $4.5 million for the quarter and year from the sale of the stock. c-After a $6 million provision for costs associated with the company's retail manufacturing operations.

title: Sims Plans Return
description: Billy Sims, the Detroit Lion runner who sat out the 1985 season after he aggravated a knee injury while trying to make a quick comeback from surgery, says he will make a new try to resume his career, but this time he will wait until the Lions' training camp in July before putting the knee to the test. Sims, who has not played since October, 1984, spoiled his chances for returning last season when he aggravated the injury during a Lions' minicamp less than six months after surgery.

title: RECORD COMPANIES CURB PROMOTION
description: Two major record companies, Capitol Industries-EMI Inc. and MCA Records, said yesterday they would suspend dealings with independent promoters.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SURROUNDED by television cameras and flashbulb-popping paparazzi, Catherine Deneuve played the Metropolitan Museum of Art this week. The setting was the candlelighted courtyard of the American Wing, where invited guests sipped Champagne, listened to Bach and nibbled on breast of goose and lobster while awaiting the star's arrival. The supporting cast was a team of ''footmen'' dressed in green velvet costumes and tricorn hats of the court of Louis XV, a tie-in to the Met's new Francois Boucher exhibition. The story line concerned the introduction of a fragrance called Deneuve.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 'The Body Politic'
description: Two editors of The Washingtonian magazine with political credentials have created a prose form that they call ''Docu-fiction'' to spin a story about a future Vice President that includes real as well as fictional people. The editors are Vic Gold, a writer and onetime Presidential campaign aide to Senator Barry Goldwater, and Lynne Cheney, an author of two previous novels whose husband, Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming, was White House chief of staff in 1975-76.

title: Plummer Joins Diener/Hauser/Bates
description: Ronald W. Plummer, who in the past has headed the New York offices of two Chicago agencies, has gone to work with Diener/Hauser/Bates, the movie-promotion ad agency, establishing within it Plummer Associates, which will, he said, specialize in hospitality products: hotels, restaurants, resorts, foods and beverages.

title: Ueberroth to Speak
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth has scheduled a news conference at 3 P.M. today in New York for an announcement based on his interviews with those players who either testified or were implicated by testimony at last September's drug trials in Pittsburgh.

title: Letting Sunshine in on M.A.C. Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN TRIES TO AVOID DEFAULT
description: Eastern Airlines struggled yesterday to avert a default today and a strike by its flight attendants this weekend.

title: FILM: HASKELL WEXLER'S 'LATINO,' ABOUT NICARAGUA
description: HASKELL WEXLER, the Oscar-winning cameraman (''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ''Bound for Glory''), is angered and grieved by United States support of guerrilla forces attempting to overthrow Nicaragua's Sandanista Government.

title: AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $88,000 for the quarter, $12,000 for the year; and a gain of $411,000 plus a writeoff of $1,980,000 of Thrust Reverser program, both for the quarter and year. c-Net income including tax credits of $441,000 for the quarter and $2,001,000 for the year.

title: 'Acceptable Risks' On Channel 7
description: The parallels to the tragedy at the American chemical plant in Bhopal, India, practically leap off the screen in ''Acceptable Risks,'' a surprisingly outspoken two-hour drama that will be shown Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 7. This cautionary tale takes place in a fictional American city called Oakbridge. The message, told in human terms through a strong cast of characters, comes across convincingly: It can happen here.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b- Including tax credits of $264,000 for the quarter and $430,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $125,000 for the quarter and $325,000 fro the 6 months.

title: OPTO MECHANIK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Latter-Day Kiosk
description: How do you move a 22,000-pound subway kiosk from Alabama to Astor Place?

title: BATTLE IN COURT STARTS OVER WILL OF JOHNSON HEIR
description: The court battle over the fortune of the late J. Seward Johnson, son of a founder of Johnson & Johnson, opened yesterday in Manhattan with sharply differing characterizations of his widow, who inherited the estate, valued at $400 million to $500 million.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IN SEOUL, CRITICS TOE A LINE
description: The other day, a curious crowd gathered on the avenue near the headquarters of Korea's main opposition party. They gazed at the scene: rows of riot policemen in black helmets that make them so uncannily resemble the ''Star Wars'' character Darth Vader, big black armored cars with sirens and tear gas dispensers and hundreds of plainclothesmen, their youthful faces blank as they stood in the cold with parkas zipped tight.

title: New Zealand Police Stop Royal Convoy Protester
description: A Maori land-rights activist driving a van carrying a vulgar image on one side was arrested today after he tried to join Queen Elizabeth II's motorcade here today.

title: The Farm Issue Personified
description: Dave Johnson has the thick hands and weathered face of a working farmer, not a politician. He looks uncomfortable in a suit, and his tie does not seem to knot right.

title: Dining Out Guide: Pasta
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CENT'ANNI, #50 Carmine Street (989-9494) -

title: LEGISLATORS' REACTION IS CAUTIOUS AS CUOMO OFFERS ANTICRIME BILL
description: Top state legislators reacted cautiously yesterday to Governor Cuomo's presentation of six bills that he said would expand New York's ability to fight organized crime and political corruption.

title: TV's Circus: Conventions
description: Excerpts from a speech at a National Press Foundation dinner in Washington by Don Hewitt, executive producer of the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' and winner of a foundation award for professional excellence, Feb. 25:

title: Boeing Gives Refund
description: The Boeing Company has voluntarily refunded $5.2 million to the Defense Department for what the company considered overcharges for spare parts, the Pentagon said. The Department said Boeing held an internal audit of contracts and decided that some prices charged by a subsidiary - Hydraulic Units Inc, of Duarte, Calif. - were excessive.

title: FLIGHTS OF FANCY: '55 PREDICTIONS ON AIR TRAVEL
description: A man in Bombay, India, foresaw a ''jetomic whizzer'' that could carry 1,000 people and use atomic power to travel at 2,000 miles per hour.

title: LANDFILL GIVING SEATTLE COSTLY METHANE TROUBLE
description: For 1966 it was a great idea, but 20 years later Seattle may have to spend $30 million to $40 million to solve the problems created by filling a gravel pit with garbage.

title: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $9.5 million on oil and gas properties. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $1,069,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: ART: AN EXHIBITION OF SCULPTURE BY HORN
description: RONI HORN was one of 10 younger sculptors interviewed in the November 1985 issue of Art in America. Part of what was important about the article was the language. Mel Kendrick, Donald Lipski, Robert Therrien and others spoke in a way that seemed decades removed from the blunt, hard-nosed prose of Minimalism, of which they were all very much aware. What distinguished the statements of Horn was a thoughtful, literary sensibility with a tendency toward preciosity.

title: UNITIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brazil Economic Plan
description: President Jose Sarney of Brazil will announce an economic package on Friday aimed at cutting the country's 255 percent annual inflation rate, a presidential spokesman said today.

title: Educational Jamming
description: Noontime yesterday was an unusual time for a jam session at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, in Greenwich Village. But as David C. Levy shouted enthusiastically over the hot music, it was a great day.

title: QUINONES OVERRULES A BOARD IN PRINCIPAL'S CONDUCT CASE
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones yesterday superseded a community school board in Brooklyn that voted three times not to prefer charges against a school principal accused of soliciting loans from a subordinate seeking a promotion.

title: Texas-Eastern? Yes, but
description: Deregulation strikes again. The takeover of Eastern Airlines by Texas Air could be the most beneficial of the airline transformations to date. But the potential won't be realized unless labor, management and government do their part.

title: CARNESECCA'S ADVICE PAYS OFF
description: For three days leading up to Wednesday's rematch with Syracuse, Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, drilled into his players' minds that the game would turn not only on how well each of them performed his respective job, but also on how well they worked as a team.

title: AQUINO SETS FORTH: AN AGENDA FOR ACTION IN THE FIRST 100 DAYS
description: When Corazon C. Aquino announced her candidacy for president three months ago, she made it clear she was campaigning on one issue: the ouster of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: BOLD, GROWING COMMUNISTS DRIVE: A SERIOUS CHALLENGE FOR AQUINO
description: Six members of the New People's Army, the Communist fighting force, were waiting for Col. Gilfredo Geolingo, the police chief here, when he drove from his house Tuesday.

title: GEORGIA TECH TOPS N.C. STATE
description: Georgia Tech overcame a second-half offensive lapse tonight to score the last 12 points and defeat North Carolina State, 69-57, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: CLARY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $65,000. c-Including tax credits of $235,000 for the quarter and $170,000 for the year.

title: OIL IMPACT ON POORER NATIONS
description: Most developing nations that import oil will gain more from the impact of falling oil prices on the industrialized world than from direct savings on their own fuel costs, bankers and economists say in assessing the effects of the price slump on the developing countries.

title: REVIVED MET PITCHERS IMPRESS
description: The two leading medical marvels on the Mets' pitching staff passed their first tests today, and remembered what it was like when they had the operations last year.

title: Decision on Bowie
description: When Sam Bowie, the Portland Trail Blazers' ailing center, said last week that he would be having surgery to repair a stress fracture of his left shin and would be out for the season, the Trail Blazers insisted that no such decision had been made and that the question would not even be addressed until Bowie had undergone a further round of examinations. Those examinations have now been completed, according to the Trail Blazers. The team announced that Bowie would undergo the surgery next week.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Appeal Rejected In Raiders Case
description: Oakland's attempt to buy the Raiders football team and move it back from Los Angeles suffered a severe setback today when the California Supreme Court rejected the city's appeal to reinstate its suit.

title: Sergeant Is Suicide After a Shooting
description: An Army sergeant stationed at Fort Drum was shot in the chest by another sergeant, who then committed suicide, authorities said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A corporate earnings table in Business Day on Saturday misstated the reporting periods for the results of the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company. The results were for January and the 12 months ended Jan. 31, not the fiscal quarter and year.

title: 'VALERIE,' NEW SERIES WITH HARPER OPN NBC
description: UNABLE to schedule its two biggest hits, ''The Cosby Show'' and ''Family Ties,'' seven nights a week (although an effort is indeed being made with ''floating'' special editions of the shows), NBC is now turning its attention to the inevitable ploy of producing reasonable facsimiles. The network has a new series called ''Valerie,'' which stars Valerie Harper, but seems equally preoccupied with young Jason Bateman, who seems to have learned everything he knows from watching Michael J. Fox in ''Family Ties.'' The TV machine chugs on, shamelessly.

title: 6% IN POLL SAY THEY SAW HALLEY'S COMET ON ITS CURRENT VISIT
description: About 10 million Americans, or 6 percent of the adult population, say they have seen Halley's comet on its current return to the inner solar system, according to a recent Gallup poll. Two million others ''think they may have seen the comet.''

title: Fed Appeals Paper Ruling
description: The Federal Reserve Board asked a United States Court of Appeals today to allow the Bankers Trust Company to continue selling commercial paper pending appeal of a lower court ruling that such sales violate Federal law.

title: NEW INQUIRY FOR MANES AND HOSPITAL
description: Donald R. Manes, the former Queens Borough President and Democratic county leader, arranged temporary office space at party headquarters for a private psychiatric hospital that employs his wife, an aide to the Queens District Attorney said yesterday.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $195,000 for the quarter and $330,00 for the 6 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $83,296 for the quarter, and including a gain of $136,000 from discontinued operations for the 6 months and also including tax credits of $204,000 for the quarter, $272,000 for the 6 months and a gain of $3,254,090 for the quarter and 6 months on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Nixon Events
description: In addition to several speaking engagements, former President Richard M. Nixon is going to devote himself in the next few months to sketching out his seventh book, which will concern foreign affairs and will ''outline a strategy for using the remaining years of the 20th century to lay the groundwork for an era of peace in the 21st.''

title: Canadian Politician Resigns After 23 Years
description: Jean Chretien, who held key Cabinet posts in a 23-year career that almost made him Canadian Prime Minister, resigned today as a member of Parliament in a feud with John Turner, the Liberal Party leader.

title: WITNESSES TELL OF DIFFICULTIES IN TRADE SCHOOLS
description: After two years of vocational school, studying first to become a beautician and then as a computer programmer, Daisy Moy said, she was $8,000 in debt but without any marketable skills.

title: ALLIED'S PLAN FOR SPINOFF
description: Allied-Signal Inc., giving the details of its spinoff, said yesterday that it would receive $300 million in cash and other proceeds by transferring 35 subsidiaries into a new company, Henley Group Inc.

title: PENNEY, J C CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: Income of unconsolidated subsidiaries for the latest periods totaled $6 million for the quarter and $11 million for the year, compared with $16 million and $28 million for the year- earlier quarter and year, respectively.

title: I.B.M. SEES PRESSURE ON EARNINGS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that recent price cuts would hurt its financial performance in the first quarter of 1986 and that sluggish capital spending could depress results for the entire year.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC PRESENTS BACH 'PASSION'
description: INDELIBLE performances of Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' tend to fall in either of two stylistic categories, even though it is true that so stupendous a work will always overflow categories in all directions. This deeply contemplative but at the same time emotionally gripping score can weave its spell as a piece of devotional mysticism or, at the other end of the scale, as quasioperatic drama. Now and then, in fact, an opera director actually mounts a staged version, which seems to be stretching things but at least testifies to the score's power to stir secular as well as religious imaginations.

title: People
description: * Ian S. F. MacKelden promoted to executive vice president, director of client services, at BBDO Direct, New York.

title: CENTRAL VERMONT PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-POLICEMAN GETS 4 YEARS IN HIT-RUN
description: A former police sergeant was sentenced yesterday to 4 to 12 years in prison as the driver of a hit-and-run police car that struck and killed a 70-year-old pedestrian and seriously injured another elderly man at Park Avenue and 72d Street nearly a year ago.

title: We Can't Afford Delay in Superfund Cleanups
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MARRIAGE AND MORALS AMONG THE VICTORIANS. Essays by Gertrude Himmelfarb. 253 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. THE title of Gertrude Himmelfarb's new collection of essays is a little misleading. It is taken from the title of the opening piece, a dissection of Phyllis Rose's study of Victorian wedlock and deadlock, ''Parallel Lives''; but in the subsequent essays, though marital themes crop up from time to time, they are not a major preoccupation. Morals, on the other hand, are absolutely central to the book's concerns - not in the narrow sense, but in terms of an all-pervading ''moral imagination.''

title: MARCO'S MANSION SUGGESTS LUXURY
description: There were giant Ming-style vases, Persian carpets, a 1763 harpsichord, gold bathroom fixtures, mother-of-pearl geese, laminated orchids and a trove of other treasures in the Manhattan mansion used by Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife for receptions.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $24 million related to the so-called 'fresh start' provision of the Tax Reform Act of 1984.

title: PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Theodora' by Handel
description: The Little Orchestra Society of New York, and the Metropolitan Singers-Greek Choral Society, under the direction of Dino Anagnost, will present one of Handel's late oratorios, ''Theodora,'' tomorrrow at 8 P.M. at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th Street; tickets are $10 to $25. Information: 757-5946.

title: BLAIR, JOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $17,000 for the quarter and nonrecurring charges of $6,365,000 for the quarter, $4,763,000 for the year. The year results also include a net of $1,669,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $25,315,000. c-Net income including gains from discontinued operations of $3,317,000 for the quarter and $9,862,000 for the year. The year result also includes a tax credit of $742,000.

title: Koch's Announcement A Surprise to Gliedman
description: Anthony B. Gliedman was caught by surprise two days ago when Mayor Koch told a roomful of reporters that Mr. Gliedman had decided to resign as Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, Mr. Gliedman said yesterday.

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $210,000, or 5 cents a share, attributable to the restatement of net income for the 12 weeks ended MArch 24, 1984.

title: The New Lions
description: What happened to Wooddale is something that the Columbia women's basketball team just can't relate to. Not anymore, at least.

title: RANGER OIL LTD (CANADA)(N) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,722,000 on sale of debentures and including $37,675,000 of non-extraordinary writedowns of assets in China, the United States, onshore drilling operations and mineral interests. c-Including writedowns of $12,000,000.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After currency losses of $865,000 for the quarter and $1,277,000 for the 6 months and an extraordinary charge of $480,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including currency gains of $85,000 for the quarter and $121,000 for the 6 months.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net income.

title: Market Place; Gains, Losses At Institutions
description: THE market value of oil and gas stocks held by institutional investors dropped sharply in the final quarter of 1985, reversing the pattern of the prior three months, according to the Vickers Stock Research Corporation. This subsidiary of Argus Research Group Inc. collects data on securities holdings of institutions, corporate insiders and other large portfolios.

title: Jane Ira Bloom Trio
description: The saxophonist Jane Ira Bloom will lead a trio - with Ed Blackwell on drums and Fred Hopkins on bass - Sunday at 8 P.M., West 42d Street (695-6909). There is a $5 cover and a $2 minimum.

title: Bucket Dance Theater
description: The Bucket Dance Theater, led by Garth Fagan, will perform tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts, Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing.

title: FISHING STRIKE IS NEARING AN END WITH BOTH SIDES CLAIMING GAINS
description: The two-month-old fishermen's strike is coming to a close with both sides claiming victory.

title: A SOVIET LEADER IN A WIDE-RANGING NEWS SESSION
description: In a performance that would have been unimaginable a few years ago, a member of the Politburo held a wide-ranging news conference today, fielding questions on everything from the black market to the size of his salary.

title: SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writedown of $38 million in the value of year-end crude and wholesale refined product inventories and a tax credit of $6.2 million from over accrual of taxes.

title: No Mercy
description: During the regular season, the girls' basketball team at Wooddale High School in Memphis had been beaten twice by Melrose High, an intracity opponent that won the Tennessee state championship last year and has one of the best schoolgirl squads in the country. The final scores in those two games were 121-20 and 90-23.

title: ART: STARTLING SCULPTURE FROM RICHARD SERRA
description: AT the very beginning of Richard Serra's exhibition of sculptures at the Museum of Modern Art we pass through what is, in effect, a frontier post. The museum's own ''Cutting Device: Base Plate Measure'' of 1969 consists of an assemblage of heterogeneous materials (lead, wood, stone and steel) into which two parallel cuts have been made and the results strewn around in a chance configuration. The doing, as much as the thing done, is the subject of the sculpture, and unmaking is seen to be as interesting as making.

title: Inquiry on Connors
description: Jimmy Connors, who defaulted in the fifth set of his semifinal match against Ivan Lendl at the Lipton International Players Championships tennis tournament last Friday, has been notified by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council that an investigation has begun into his actions. Connors was fined $5,000 by the Pro Council supervisor Ken Farrar for violation of the Code of Conduct provision prohibiting professional players from ''Failure to Complete a Match.''

title: A DAUNTING TASK: CRIPPLED ECONOMY
description: A businessman confided that he probably owed the equivalent of $50,000 in taxes each year, but he was so disenchanted with the Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos that he cheated heavily, paying perhaps 10 percent of what he should have.

title: PACIFIC GAS TRANSMISSION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Include a charge of $5,458,000 for pipeline project construction costs for the quarter and year. c-Includes a gain of $3 million on the sale of gas leasehold rights and a charge of $3.6 million for expenses related to a pipeline project.

title: Vehicle Offices In Malls Urged
description: New Jersey's motor vehicle agency franchises should be run by the state and situated in shopping malls whenever possible, the State Commission of Investigation recommended today.

title: Danes Approve Changes In Common Market
description: Danes solidly approved a disputed package of Common Market revisions in a national referendum today that cleared the way for their enactment by the European Economic Community.

title: FILM: JOHN HUGHES'S 'PRETTY IN PINK'
description: ''PRETTY IN PINK'' pays equal attention to the very old and the ostensibly new. The latest film to be written by John Hughes - author-director of ''Sixteen Candles,'' ''The Breakfast Club'' and ''Weird Science,'' and at the age of 35, one of the world's senior reigning teen-agers - casts a very familiar story in up-to-the-minute terms. It concerns Andie Walsh (Molly Ringwald), a smart girl from the wrong side of the tracks, who is pursued by both a BMW-driving rich kid and a clownish, good-hearted, impoverished boy who really loves her.

title: YANKEES' INFIELD ONLY HALF-SIGNED
description: George Steinbrenner says the key to the Yankees' season is the left side of their infield, but right now the left side of the infield, Mike Pagliarulo and Bobby Meacham, is unsigned and somewhat unhappy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1986
description: Markets

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Nearly $3 billion of corporate debt was priced yesterday, continuing the record pace of the last few days.

title: SENATE DECIDES, 67-21, TO TEST TELEVISED COVERAGE OF PROCEEDINGS
description: In a step that could lead to significant changes in the nation's legislature, the Senate voted tonight to televise its proceedings on a trial basis beginning June 1. Radio coverage would begin as soon as the necessary equipment is installed, perhaps as early as next week.

title: TV GROUPS REACH PACT ON MUST-CARRY RULE
description: Leaders of the major cable and broadcast television industry trade associations said today that they had reached an accord that could end a dispute over whether cable stations should be required to carry the signals of local television stations.

title: RAMOS, OUSTING MARCOS COMMANDERS, BEGINS CHANGES SOUGHT BY THE U.S.
description: In one of his first acts as the new chief of the armed forces, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos has taken a step toward the military changes long sought by Reagan Administration critics of the former Marcos Government.

title: CALLAHAN MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AIR-INDIA REPORT SAID TO BACK BOMB THEORY
description: A judicial investigation into the crash of an Air-India jumbo jet last year was reported today to have concluded that the disaster was caused by a bomb.

title: ROCKWELL CLOSELY TIED TO THE SHUTTLE PROGRAM
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, whose officials testified today about their expressions of concern before the launching of the space shuttle Challenger, has been more intimately involved in the shuttle program than any other contractor.

title: ELIGIBILITY QUESTION HAUNTS C. W. POST
description: When is a 22-3 team not a 22-3 team?

title: No 'Star Wars' Lesson In Challenger Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTAURANTS
description: EVERYTHING at Sparks Steakhouse is oversized - the dining rooms, the steaks, the chops, the lobsters, the wine list, even the customers. This bustling, masculine outpost is, in my view, everything a good steakhouse should be.

title: SHULTZ ASSAILS NICARAGUA IN ASKING AID FOR REBELS
description: Denouncing the Nicaraguan Government as ''a cancer, right here on our land mass,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz faced a skeptical Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as he urged approval of President Reagan's request for $100 million to help the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Brazilian Court Agrees To 'Hail, Mary' Release
description: A Brazilian court judge today ruled that the French film ''Hail, Mary'' by Jean-Luc Godard is to be released for general viewing on a temporary basis.

title: Diner's Journal
description: JEAN-LOUIS PALLADIN, who runs what many consider Washington's best French restaurant, called Jean-Louis at Watergate, is the new consulting chef at Maurice, the opulent restaurant in the Hotel Parker Meridien on West 57th Street. He replaces Alain Senderens, the chef-owner of Lucas-Carton in Paris, who is leaving his consulting job at Maurice to open his own restaurant on West 56th Street.

title: FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $40,000 for the quarter and $27,393,000 for the year. c-Net loss including a gain of $3,879,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income including a gain of $14,148,000 from discontinued operations. There were no share earnings for the previous year because the final net did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: REAGAN SENT MARCOS SECRET MESSAGE 12 HOURS BEFORE WHITE HOUSE'S PLEA
description: Twelve hours before the White House publicly called on President Ferdinand E. Marcos to step down, President Reagan sent a message to the Philippine leader that said that he, his family and close associates would be welcome to live in the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Including gains of $2,285,000 for the quarter and $4,104,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains of $2,422,000 for the quarter and $4,203,000 for the 6 months.

title: SECULAR HUMANISM: MEANING VARIES WITH POLITICAL STANCE
description: Secular humanism, the target of lawsuits in Alabama and Tennessee, shares some traits with humanism in general: It is a philosophical attitude that puts man, his capabilities and lasting values at the center of things.

title: CONTINENTAL DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
COALITION SEEKS WIDER PENALTY IN RIGHTS LAW
description: A national coalition of civil rights groups today urged Congress to restore antidiscrimination enforcement powers that were curbed by a Supreme Court decision two years ago.

title: ROME PROSECUTOR URGES ACQUITTAL OF 3 BULGARIANS
description: An Italian prosecutor called today for the acquittal of three former Bulgarian officials accused of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a pre-tax provision of $15 million for restructuring.

title: SYMBOLS ARE MORTAR FOR BUILDING HAITI
description: Haiti's new Government will need substantial international help quickly as it digs out of the mess left by the Duvalier dictatorship. With or without that aid, the transitional Government would find it enormously useful to harness Haitians' respect for the traditional symbols of their culture.

title: WE CAN'T AFFORD DELAY IN SUPERFUND CLEANUPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Lawrence Festival
description: Sarah Lawrence College will present this weekend a festival of composers who taught or teach there. Tonight at 8 o'clock, there will be a concert devoted to the music of William Schuman featuring the Laurentian String Quartet, the soprano Rosalind Rees, and the Sarah Lawrence Chamber Choir.

title: For Insurance Purposes, Let Roosevelt I. Tramway Be an Airline
description: To the Editor:

title: AZTEC INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Thompson Succession Survivor
description: AND then there was one.

title: O PARIDISO! A BAZAAR AT THE METROPOLITAN OPERA
description: The Metropolitan Opera will have a tag sale on Sunday, and befitting the great opera house, it will be a grandiose event at which mementos of the opera's 103-year history will be sold.

title: CYANIDE IS FOUND IN A TYLENOL PILL
description: A lone capsule in a bottle of Tylenol found near the body of a Nashville man contained cyanide, according to Federal agents investigating the death.

title: GATX Gets Another Offer
description: The GATX Corporation said today that it had received an unsolicited bid of $40 a share, or a total of $514.4 million, from a group led by Adler & Shaykin, a New York-based investment house. GATX, the Chicago-based company that leases rail cars and aircraft, declined to comment in detail.

title: KEY TESTIMONY ON STEPS LEADING TO LAUNCHING OF CHALLENGER
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger held in Washington yesterday by the Presidential panel, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News:

title: CONTINUUM CELEBRATING 20TH YEAR WITH CONCERT
description: For two decades, Joel Sachs and Cheryl Seltzer have been navigating both the mainstreams and the rivulets of 20th-century music, presenting more than 50 retrospective concerts devoted to everybody from Scott Joplin to Milton Babbitt. The titles of the programs reflect their diversity: ''Rice Bowls, Cans, Timpani, Gongs: The Percussion Revolution in America,'' ''Eastward Ho! America's Composers Encounter the Orient'' and ''U.S.S.R.: Unveiling the Avant-Garde.''

title: POOR MAN, POOR LAWYER
description: James Messer, a poor man, was charged with murder. The first lawyer appointed to defend him begged off, citing community outrage at the crime. So did the second. A third lawyer adopted a low-key strategy: He made no opening statement, called no witnesses, did not object to evidence and engaged in only cursory cross-examination. At the sentencing hearing following conviction, he did not ask the jury to spare Mr. Messer's life, did not offer mitigating details inviting mercy and hinted that execution was appropriate. Mr. Messer is now on Georgia's Death Row.

title: EUROPEANS READY TO PUT EXTRA SATELLITES IN ORBIT
description: Arianspace, Europe's commercial satellite launching company, said today that it was ready to put eight extra satellites into orbit in 1987 and 1988 to cope with any shortage of lifting capacity resulting from the explosion of the United States space shuttle Challenger.

title: FARM TOWN RAISES BASKETBALL TALENT
description: Any consideration of basketball's most successful powers would include some obvious names: the Celtics and the Lakers, U.C.L.A. under John Wooden, and North Carolina under Dean Smith.

title: ABC NEWS SAYS IT ERRED IN AIRING RUSSIAN'S VIEW
description: ABC News, responding to a strong White House protest, said tonight that it erred Wednesday night by allowing a Soviet reporter to rebut without challenge President Reagan's nationally televised speech on his plans for increased military spending.

title: DANCE: MULLER TROUPE IN 'DARKNESS AND LIGHT'
description: EVERYTHING had its counterpart or opposite in Jennifer Muller's ''Darkness and Light,'' the production that Miss Muller's company, The Works, presented in its world premiere Tuesday night at City Center.

title: Leichter Ties Marcos To Koch and Goldin
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter charged yesterday that companies affiliated with Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former president of the Philippines, had contributed $25,000 to the campaigns of Mayor Koch and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, and demanded that they return the money.

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $1,020,000 on the sale of a plant.

title: Avondale Gets Unsolicited Bid
description: Dominion Textile Inc. of Montreal said yesterday that its American subsidiary, Dominion Textile America Inc., is offering to buy Avondale Mills for $24 a share, or a total of about $96 million. The unsolicited offer is conditioned on a minimum of 1,350,000 shares being tendered, or about 34 percent of the company's 4 million shares outstanding, and expires March 26.

title: CITY ALTERING TRAFFIC FLOW TOWARD JAVITS CENTER
description: Starting next month, afternoon truck deliveries will be banned from 49th and 50th streets between Third and Eighth Avenues in Manhattan to speed buses through midtown to the new convention center, city officials said yesterday.

title: 2 Sides End Trial Arguments On Recall of X Model Autos
description: The Government's landmark trial seeking the recall of 1980 X Model automobiles ended Wednesday and a Federal district judge now must decide whether the General Motors vehicles have dangerously unsafe brakes.

title: Israelis Attack Villages In Southern Lebanon
description: Israeli forces bombarded several Moslem Shiite villages in southern Lebanon today, hours after the Israeli Army Command announced that one of its soldiers had been killed and four wounded in a clash with Lebanese guerrillas.

title: West Virginia Routs Rutgers
description: Holman Harley scored 18 points and Dale Blaney 16 tonight to lead West Virginia to an 88-60 rout of Rutgers in an Atlantic 10 Conference quarterfinal tournament game.

title: COMET SHOWING WATER LOSS
description: Halley's comet is losing water at wildly fluctuating rates and may have a lumpier surface than anyone expected, according to a scientist who has been following the comet's journey behind the Sun over the past few weeks.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Store Depopulation
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHANCE TO FIND IF ART OF WOMEN IS A SPECIAL ART
description: IS there such a thing as ''women's art''? Is art created by women distinctive by virtue of its style or technique, its size or subject? The best way to explore the issue is by looking at art made by women. And this weekend, at the start of Women's History Month, art lovers and philosophers will have that opportunity, in exhibitions of works by women on view at some 60 galleries and public spaces throughout Manhattan.

title: 2 TELL OF OIL TAX POLICY
description: Reagan Administration officials told Congress today that a tax on imported oil would be unwise energy policy, ''costly to the national economy'' and potentially ''unacceptable to the President.''

title: O'SULLIVAN ZEROS IN ON SPEED
description: When he was growing up in Cork, Marcus O'Sullivan used to wonder what it took to defeat Eamonn Coghlan, an Irish legend and history's fastest indoor miler. O'Sullivan knows now. O'Sullivan, who is studying for his master's degree in business at Villanova, has been undefeated this indoor season. Along the way, he has taken on Coghlan three times. O'Sullivan's victory in Los Angeles on Jan. 17, marked the first indoor loss at a mile for Coghlan since 1981.

title: Productivity Off in Quarter
description: Productivity in the business sector of the economy slumped by 3.1 percent in the fourth quarter, resulting in a sluggish gain of two-tenths of 1 percent for 1985, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Genentech Gets British Patent
description: Genentech Inc., the leading biotechnology company, said the British Patent Office had awarded the company a patent on its tissue plasminogen activator, used in treating heart attack and other blood-clot-related diseases. Genentech also said it would file suit in Britain against Burroughs Welcome for patent infringement.

title: Times Change, But Reds Don't
description: For a team that thinks it has a good shot at a division title, that lacks middle-inning strength in the bullpen and that had a chance to pick up Rollie Fingers for the bargain-basement price of $60,000, the Cincinnati Reds display remarkable tenacity in clinging to a seemingly anachronistic rule.

title: The Mortgage Bank at Battery Park
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch based their 1985 housing initiative on turning New York's Battery Park City Authority into a cheap source of $400 million in mortgages - putting the state's credit at risk. Their revised 1986 proposal deserves approval.

title: 15 DARE TO CHALLENGE SNOW CHIEF IN FLORIDA DERBY
description: ''We got 'em scared in California,'' Mel Stute said this morning, ''but I guess they're not scared of us here.''
